column2: The new trial of James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, and others on the indictment alleging conspiracy with Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer in the policy racket will start in General Sessions on Nov. 14, District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey announced yesterday.

Lumber production increased sharply- last week, countering a seasonal decline, and the adjusted index advanced to 76.7, a new high for the year. This compares with 72.0 for the preceding week and 86.1 for the week ended Sept. 18, 1937..

German Nazi organizations plan to hold celebrations throughout South Jutland Saturday to mark the cession of the Sudetenland to the Peich, according to a German daily in Aabenraa, the Nordschleswigsche Zeitung.

So much of Paragraph 27, Special Orders 154, dated July 5, 1938, relating to 1st Lt. Howard L. Snyder, F.A.-Res., as reads: "Date of rank, June 24, 1938," is amended so as to read: "Date of rank, March 8, 1938."

In the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church yesterday afternoon Miss-Virginia Trotter Hyde, daughter of Mrs. Maxwell Hyde of 935 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Hyde, was married to W. Radford Bascome Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bascome, also of this city, formerly of St. Louis.

Princeton's football squad wound up its second week of work today with nearly two hours of stationary scrimmage on offensive formations, Defensive work of a lighter variety occupied the morning session.

Although bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday failed to equal the total of the comparative period last year, the current volume, as a result of mid-month settlements, was the largest since the week of Dec. 23, 1937.

W. Warren Barbour, who became the Republican nominee for United States Senator in Tuesday's formality Senatorial primary, declared today that the methods used by the "Washington dynasty" in its Democratic party "purges" would be repeated against him.

No action by Britain could have saved Czechoslovakia, Sir Harold Mackintosh, British industrialist and president of the World Sunday School Federation, said here yesterday in an interview at the Hotel Barclay, 111 East Forty-eighth Street.

Mrs. Albert Gollmar, widow of Charles Gollmar, circus owner, was found slaid today in the kitchen of her home. She was 62 years old and had lived here nearly all her life. The body, fully clothed except for shoes, was lying on the floor near the kitchen door.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has called a hearing for Oct. 24 on the joint application of the Aluminum Company of America, the Aluminum Ore Company and the Massena Securities Corporation for an order declaring them not holding companies within the meaning of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935.

William F. Ellis, Bronx civic worker and president of the Ellis Employment Agency, 355 East 149th Street, the Bronx, died Wednesday night at his home, 395 East 151st Street, after a brief illness. He was 44 years old.

The trade association movement is powerless to overcome the disintegrating efforts of recalcitrant minorities during an era of economic stress, inasmuch as the buyer today is in the saddle, according to a book, "Trade Associations in Law and Business,"
New York City faced the possibility of a milk shortage here this afternoon as washouts of railroad lines and highways impaired the facilities for the delivery of milk in the metropolitan area.
The Earl of Perth, British Ambassador to Italy, who returned last Tuesday from a vacation in England, called on Count Galeazzo Ciano, Foreign Minister, late today and they had a long conversation.

Grover A. Whalen, president of the New York World's Fair, will the New York World's Fair, will discuss the drug industry's participation in the fair at the annual convention of the National Wholesale Druggists Association at White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., on Sept. 29. Joseph A. Huisking,

Dr. John W. Pierson of Baltimore was installed as president of the American Roentgen Ray Society today and Dr. Edward L. Jenkinson of Chicago was chosen to succeed him a year hence. The society ended its thirty-ninth annual convention here.

Cash income from marketing of farm production in August was $614,000,000, the Department of Agriculture said today. For the first eight months of this year, farm income was estimated at $4,307,000,000, or 14 per cent less than the $5,004,000,000 reported for the same months last year.

Britain's ancient and historic Westminster Hall adjoining the Houses of Parliament echoed to the sound of German "heils" of greeting this afternoon as 800 German World War veterans assembled under its roof as guests of the British Legion.
Colonel Bill Terry's Giants find themselves confronted by another novel state of affairs today, when they will be asked to invade Boston, lair of Casey Stengel's Bees, from the sea.

Dr. Lotus Delta Coffman, president of the University of Minnesota since 1921, died of a heart ailment in his home here tonight. He was 63 years old. Surviving are his, widow, Mrs. Mary Emma Farrell Coffman, and a son and daughter, William H. Coffman and Mrs. Catherine Farrell Knudtson.

An Associated Press reporter who flew over Cape Cod yesterday said that the scene there was one of mile after mile of devastation. Summer cottages were reduced to kindling wood at Fairhaven, Mattapoisett, Marion, Wareham, Buzzard's Bay and Falmouth, he said.

Auxiliary sandbag dikes were being erected here early this morning as the city sought to avoid possible repetition of the disastrous flood of 1936, when the business center was flooded and damage resulted estimated at $20,000,000.

The War Department issued the following orders today, dated Sept. 21: Bishop, Major Gen. P. P., Fort William McKinley, P. I., to command Seventh Corps Area, Omaha, Neb. Smith, Brig. Gen. F. H., Balboa, Canal Zone, to command Third Coast Artillery District and as commandant of Coast Artillery School, Fort Monroe, Va.

Rhode Island tried hard tonight to shake off the effects of the hurricane that hit this city and surrounding territory late yesterday afternoon causing millions of dollars damage and resulting in the death of more than 250 persons with scores still missing.

Although the Bren gun, invented and originally manufactured in Czechoslovakia, is now the British Army's standard light machine gun, any domination of Czech munition works by Germany will have no effect on British supplies, it was said here today.

Twelve thousand bales of tobacco have been purchased for Generalissimo Francisco Franco's Spanish Insurgent forces through Frederico March, a nephew of Juan March, one of General Franco's staunchest supporters. Shipments will be routed through Germany.

An enrollment of 1,119,220 pupils in the New York City school systern is indicated for the Fall term, Board of Education officials announced yesterday. This is a net loss of 8,665 as compared with last year.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe denied yesterday the request of count sel representing a minority bond holders' committee to invite the See curities and Exchange Commission into the reorganization proceedings of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation under the provisions of the Chandler act.

A 2.3 per cent reduction in employment and a 3.5 per cent drop in payrolls from mid-July to mid-August were announced for New York's retail stores today by State Industrial Commissioner Frieda S. Miller.

Disaster overtook Dwight Long's thirty-two-foot ketch, Idle Hour, when the wind ripped her from moorings off the City Island Yacht Club and wrecked the craft on the Bloomingdale estate at Kings Point, across Long Island Sound.

Ih a review of Australia's trade policy issued yesterday. the National Foreign Trade Council, Inc., expressed the opinion that the Ottawa agreements have proved too rigid and that Australia has found it necessary to join with Canada in obtaining greater flexibility in her trade relations with non-empire countries.

A number of one-family residences in southern Westchester communities were reported yesterday to have been sold by brokers. The ten-room house on the southwest corner of Archer and Oakley Avenues, Mount Vernon, was purchased by a client of S. D. Bolke from the East River Savings Bank for cash. Assessed for $10,000,
The beauty of the Oranges and Maplewood was marred today as a result of yesterday's storm, which felled nearly 250 trees in the five municipalities. The heaviest damage occurred in this city.

The storm damage here as elsewhere along the shore was concentreated on the beach front, where the tidal waves which immediately followed the passage of the storm rolled to a height of more than thirty feet for an hour late yesterday afternoon.

The American Gas Association will hold its twentieth annual convention in Atlantic City from Oct 10, to 13, it was announced yesterday by G. F. Mitchell, President of the Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company and chairman of the convention's program committee.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes, in francs:

Brisk pedaling and almost continuous jamming were in order as the six-day bicycle race went its merry way at Madison Square Garden last night. So consistent was the showing of each of the eleven teams remaining in the grind that not one of them could be disregarded as a possible winner.

Eighteen warships of the British Mediterranean fleet, led by the flagship, the 30,000-ton battleship Warspite, put in at Alexandria today on the annual visit. Comment, however, was aroused b. the fact that they arrived ten days earlier than scheduled.

Folks, it is going to be a little difficult to describe this one. "Hell-zapoppin" is what they call it and ,it was discharged at the Forty-sixth Street last evening. Deciding that it might be a good idea to put on a show, Ole Olsen and Chic Johnson,

Unless it blows up again, today should find the striped-bass addicts taking the big fellows from the surf along the New Jersey coast. The water should be fairly clear and the stripers usually do some heavy inshore feeding after a big blow. Jim Deren,

As had been expected, the transactions in connection with the Treasury's quarterly financing and tax collections brought about a large fall in excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in the week ended on Wednesday. The decline,

Death Announced RETIRED FIREMAN WILLIAM F. McCORMACK, formerly a member of Engine Co. 155, residing at 91-13 78th St., Woodhaven, Queens, died Sept. 17. To Motor and Pump Operators School The following members shall be directed to report at the Motor and Pump Operators' School, 32-02 Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, at 10:30 A. M., on the dates specified above their names:

Canada exported 4,392,214 hundredweight of newsprint valued at $9,621,715 in August, compared with 4,016,732 valued at $8,723,502 in July and 5,662,569 valued at $10,662,990 in August, 1937, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.

A Countess who fled in overalls with her small baby clasped to her breast and a retinue of servants splashing at her heels gave thanks tonight that Providence had seen fit to spare her from last night's hurricane.

In the first semi-annual statement issued by R. H. Macy Co., Inc., Percy S. Straus, president, will report today for the six months ended July 30 a consolidated net toss of $601,039 after expenses, depreciation, interest, provision for Federal income taxes and other charges. In the corresponding half of the preceding fiscal year a consolidated net profit of $787,211 was shown.

Serious shortage of the city's food supply is not expected to result from the devastating storms of the week, agricultural and market, experts said yesterday. While a temporary shortage of some foods, notably fish and highly perishable fruits and vegetables grown in the storm areas, may occur, supplies are expected to return. to normal by the beginning of next week.
One thousand young pheasants were smothered to death during the storm yesterday afternoon when a flock of 4,000 being raised by Fred Yahn was piled up against a poultry-wire fence by the storm.

Four county Democratic executive committees, taking the first formal action on Senatorial primary contests filed by former Governor Eugene Talmadge, unanimously denied today his petitions for recounts.

Neil F. Deighan of Pennsauken was re-elected president of the New Jersey Licensed Beverage Association and was named temporary president of the newly formed National Conference of Beverage Dealers Associations here today.

Exemption of all new industries from virtually all provincial taxes for ten years has been proposed by the Executive of the Province of Buenos Aires to the Provincial Legislature, the Commerce Department said today.

A sharp reaction in copper prices abroad was a feature in the nonferrous metal markets yesterday. Sales of copper were made at 10.31 cents a pound c. i. f. European base ports, compared with 10.525 to 10.55 cents on Wednesday.

The 108-hole golf tournament for a purse of $13,500 is scheduled to get under way today at the Fenway Golf Club, White Plains, N. Y., after having been postponed since Wednesday due to the heavy rain, which made play impossible.

Roy Warner, veteran American -pilot, flying a Curtiss Condor transport plane for the Peruvian Condor Aviation Company on the transandean run from Lima to Iquitos, gave a skillful demonstration of piloting yesterday and saved the lives of his crew and a dozen pas- ha sengers.

Important changes in high army field commands were announced today by the War Department. Major Gen. Percy P. Bishop, now commanding the Philippine Division, was ordered to assume command of the Seventh Corps Area, with headquarters at Omaha. Brig.

A large part of the former plant of the John L. Mott Corporation at Trenton, N. J., has been sold by the Herbert McLean Purdy Management Corporation, brokers, to Stokley Brothers, dealers in food products.

Passengers arriving today on the Hamburg-American liner Hansa, from Hamburg and Channel ports include Mr. and Mrs. Julius P. Meyer, Mr. and Mrs. C. R. Benton, Prof. Eric Seemann, Dr. Manfred Zapp, William Nanz, Mrs. Jane Simrock, Mr. and Mrs. George G. Fleckenstein, Mr. and Mrs. Felix Meyer, Miss Grace B. Phelan, Miss Edna Churchill, Mrs. Olive Stallsmith and Mrs. Lena Womack.

European buyers of Canadian cash wheat came into the market today on the largest scale so far this season. Winnipeg reports placed sales to importing countries and to mills at more than 4,000,000 bushes.

Haggard and sleepless, but uninjured, six passengers and nine members of the crew of the Bridgeport-Port Jefferson steam ferry Park City were towed into Port Jefferson, L. I., at 11 A. M. today after twenty-one hours on Long Island Sound and an all-night buffeting by waves that pounded over the deck and a gale that shook the vessel and whistled through the superstructure.

The steel industry's reduction of prices of rail was praised today by executives of railroads, but they gave no intimation of immediate orders. They said most roads already had purchased trackage for 1938, but that the reduced prices might be a help in figuring budgets for 1939.

Representative Christopher D. Sullivan, leader of Tammany Hall, was refused endorsement for reelection by organized labor as represented by the A. F. of L. in this city last night when the Central Trades and Labor Council, representing unions with a total membership of 650,000, met in Beethoven Hall, 205 East Fifth Street, to consider endorsements of candidates for office.

John Cashmore, Tammany Democrat and Vice Chairman of the Council, tried yesterday to establish his right to sit and vote on the' Board of Estimate as Acting President of the Council during fhe absence of Mayor La Guardia from the city.

Any 13-year-old girl can prepare a tasty meal out of what she is likely to find in her mother's cupboard and serve it within half an hour in generous portions to a family of four if she follows the example set yesterday by a Camp Fire Girl in an experimental kitchen in the Graybar Building.

Dwight F. Faulkner Jr., chairman of the protective committee for Interborough Rapid Transit Company 6 per cent notes, was electedyesterday to the Interborough's board of directors to fill a vacancy caused by the resignation of Grover A. Whalen, who was on the board representing the public.

The judiciary, rather than the army or navy, is the greatest safeguard to democracy, but the courts need to be divorced from politics if they are to survive, in the opinion of Anna Moscowitz Kross, candidate for Justice of the State Supreme Court, First Judicial District.

Eighteen places are set at the long table in the room which Herr Dreesen, mein host at Hitler's favorite inn, embellished for the private conferences frequently held in his modest establishment by the now mighty leader whom he never noticed when he was Corporal Adolf in his company in the German Army.

The big wind and rain came out of the South without any previous ultimatum. It hit us hard, and our neighbors to the east and northeast harder. Some it killed and some it wounded, for we had no air force with which to repel the attack.

Lewis J. Valentine, who on Sunday will begin his fifth year as Police Commissioner of New York and who recently has refused to discuss police affairs with the publie through the press, granted yesterday a mass interview with the reporters who "cover" police headquarters.

Members of the National Hardwood Lumber Association, meeting here for the first session of their two-day convention, were warned by Harry T. Kendall, vice president and general manager of Weyerhaeuser Sales Company, to stop asking the government to help regulate the lumber business.
On his release from Sing Sing Prison this afternoon after serving seven concurrent sentences for larceny and forgery imposed in Rockland County, Leon M. Woodworth, former attorney and a Rockland

Studebaker dealers from the metropolitan area and communities in the Southern half of New York State met yesterday in the Park Central Hotel for a preview of the company's new "State Commander and State President" models for 1939.
King Gustaf presided at a Cabinet council tonight at which it was decided to retain about one-quarter of this year's military class, who would have completed their service around Oct. 1.

Sales of securities in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange in the declining market in the week ended on Sept. 17 exceeded purchases by 125,962 shares, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. The turnover was substantial,

The Yankees reached the end of their last and worst Western trip of the year at Comisky Park today with a triumphant barrage of home runs that was a welcome relief for all concerned. Joseph Lowell Gordon hit his twenty-fourth homer and Red Robert Rolfe his tenth.
After a suspension of six days, play in the national tennis chainpionships will finally be resumed today at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

Representative John J. O'Connor, defeated for renomination in the Democratic primary by James H. Fay, but successful in the Republican primary, gave no indication yesterday of his plans, but made known at his office that he might have something to say today.

James V. Mulholland, director of recreation for the city Parks Deapartment, and nine subordinates have been cited by the National Recreation Association for extended and meritorious services to community recreation, it was announced yesterday.

More than 300 women and a few men crowded yesterday into the office of United States Marshal Kelley to bid for seventy-five articles of clothing,. which had been smuggled from Paris to the New York shop of Marcel Rochas, Inc., and was being auctioned in accordance with the law.

The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended Sept. 21 were announced today: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Hoyle. R. M.. the Icarus, to the Pontchartrain as executive officer. Hilton, C. H.. Fort Trumbull Training Station, to command the Pandora. Perkins, H. C., the Pandora, to the Shoshone as executive officer.
Countess Andre de Limr and Charles de Limur of Burlingame, Calif., are at the St. Regis. Mrs. Park Mason Woolley will return from Europe next week and will be at the Savoy-Plaza.

Conflicting and pessimistic reports of the trend of European events broke over the stock market from the very opening yesterday, forcing prices to retreat still further until closing levels were down 1 to 3 points.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Some twelve years ago Dr. Hollis Godfrey of Yale aroused considerable public interest with a plan for coordinating all preventive and relief agencies to cope with such cataclysms as hurricanes, earthquakes and floods.

Coincident with the decision that polo would get under way again today with a resumption of the Waterbury Cup matches at Meadow Brook, the annual meeting of delegates to the United States Polo Association took place yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

Sylvester Hlavac, retired lieutenant of the New York Police Department who had received a Congressional medal for heroism, died Thursday night at the Post-Graduate Hospital after a brief illness. He was 62 years old.

Townsend Martin's Cravat, who was such a surprise winner of the Jerome Handicap, looms as the favorite today for the long mile and five-eighths of the $7,500 added Lawrence Realization which will feature Belmont Park's three-ply stake program.

Mrs. Frederick S. Coolidge was hostess for a reception at Hotel Wendell tonight for all who have been her guests at the three-day music festival which ended this afternoon. She was assisted by her son and daughter-in-law, Professor Albert Sprague Coolidge. of Harvard and Mrs. Coolidge. Several hundred attended.

Bonds continued to drift lower yesterday in relatively light trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The market, as a whole, again was subject to the influence of disturbing news from Europe as well as to weakness in foreign markets.
With Lou Tomasetti scoring two touchdowns and throwing forward passes for two more, Bucknell opened its football season tonight by routing Furman, 28 to 6, in an intersectional game before 7,500.

Fifty Polish miners paraded through the town of Fresnes today demanding independence for the 200,000 Poles living in Northern France. Police dispersed them and seized swastika flags that they carried.
Following is an additional list of the known dead in Wednesday's storm and those who are still missing. It does not include the names of dead reported Thursday:

Public officials, educators and other prominent persons attended a funeral service for Courtlandt Nicoil, former State Senator -and former president of the Museum of the City of New York, yesterday morning at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration, 1 East Twenty-ninth Street.

Mayor La Guardia expounded his theories of municipal government tonight to 4,500 who greeted him in the Shrine Auditorium as a reform leader who could point the way for this city's newly elected reform government.

Connecticut Light and Power Company-Twelve months to Aug. 31: Net income after expenses, taxes, charges and preferred dividends, $3,596,762, equal to $3.13 a share on outstanding common stock, compared with $3,903,218, or $3.40 a common share, in preceding twelve months.

Member trading in round lots for their own account on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Sept. 3 was 19.66 per cent of the total volume, compared with 22 per cent in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Judge Philip Forman- of the United States District. Court imposed today a fifteen-year penitentiary sentence on "Angelo- B. Oliva,. former, teller in the Columbus branch of the Second Natioial' Bank of Paterson, for embezzling $242,000 from savings accounts at the bank during a seven-year period, about a fourth of the money that passed through his hands.

A telegram received last night from the Fessenden School in Boston reassured parents as to the safety of the twenty-three boys who left New York for the school on the 12:10 P. M. train Wednesday. The train was wrecked at Stornington, Conn., but the boys, in charge of Roderick Hagenbuckle, reached the school in good health Thursday night.

A total of 45,847 persons entered the United States from foreign countries by airplane during the fiscal year 1938, ended June 30 last, the Bureau of Customs of the Treasury Department reported today.

After hours of nerve-racking suspense and anxiety London felt some hope but no certainty early today that a German invasion of Czechoslovakia might be averted. The first impression here after Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's three-hour talk with Chancellor Adolf Hitler on the Rhine was that Mr. Chamberlain had obtained temporary reassurance if nothing more.

Toppled telephone poles and uprooted trees were the main damage here as a result of the gale that struck Burlington on Wednesday. Company K of the Vermont National Guard was called out to clear the streets and prevent injury from live power lines. Three deaths and vast destruction of the apple crop and corn silage have been reported from near-by areas.

The hunts racing season on Long Island reaches its peak today with the annual running of the famed Meadow Brook Cup over the estate of F. Ambrose Clark near Westbury. This is one of the oldest steeplechase events in this country and is cherished on Long Island as a sporting as well as a social event.

In the matter of reorganization of the Utilities Elkhorn Coal Company, a subsidiary of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, the Securities and Exchange Commission issued today an order fixing the maximum allowance of fees, expenses and remuneration which the company shall pay to James B. Culbertson for services as attorney from Feb. 8, through May 31,
The Federal Trade Commission announced today that four New York concerns have entered into stipulations to discontinue certain misleading representations in connection with the sale of their products

Edgar Allen Thompson, president of the A. E. Thompson Company of New York, sales agents for a group of knitting mills, died in his home here last night of pneumonia. Born near Cincinnati, he was the son of John R. and Amanda B. Thompson. His father, a newspaper publisher, had been a leader in Ohio politics and an officer in the Spanish-American War.
Jan Masaryk, Czechoslovak Minister to London, told a radio audience last night that his country had ordered its general mobilization with "the knowledge of France and Great Britain."

Bessie, a frisky brown and white fox terrier owned by 12-year-old Margaret Hughes of 123 Ninth Avenue, was judged the best all-around dog at a Buddy Dog Show held yesterday by the Manhattan Catholic Youth, Organization Center on the Parmelee Taxi Company lot, 416 West Seventeenth Street.
The French Government formally decreed partial mobilization today of its vast reserve army, calling up two groups to the colors as the Czechoslovak-German crisis grew worse over night.

The stock markets here continued cautious but calm today, there being no disposition to make fresh commitments pending the outcome of the AngloGerman talks. Price movements were small and irregular and stocks held up well considering the tension.

Americans in Czechoslovakia are being advised by Wilbur J. Carr, the United States Minister in Prague, to be prepared to leave the country immediately in view of the uncertain conditions, the State Department announced today.

A total of 250,000 lives have been saved since the beginning of the safety movement in industry twenty-five years ago, Dr. C. H. Watson, medical director of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, declared yesterday in a luncheon speech before sixty-one representatives of insurance, industrial and utility companies at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

With Rancocas Creek ten feet above normal, there was two feet of water in this community's business and residential sections today. Twenty families, homeless since yesterday, were spending a second night in the National Guard Armory here. No deaths have been reported. Fifty stores were damaged.

Millard W. Phillips, assistant manager of the Hotel Astor since 1935, has been appointed general manager of a hotel to be erected in Lancaster, Ohio, by. the Community Hotel Company of that city. Jan. 1, when he will leave to direct construction in Lancaster.
A. Otto Birn has resigned as vice president of United Cigars-Whelan Stores Corporation and has opened his own offices at 521 Fifth Avenue, where he will specialize in chain store leasing.

Activity in wholesale markets during the week was cautious, reflecting retailers' attempts to keep stocks complete without committing themselves too far into the future, according to the weekly summary issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The Rev. Dr. Edmund Melville Wylie, associate pastor of the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street, New York City, has been called to the pastorate of the Presbyterian Church here. The edifice was built by the late Mrs. Elliott F. Shepard in memory of her husband.
The Right Rev. William T. Manning, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, issued yesterday the following letter to his clergy:

In the October Atlantic M. Albert Linton, president of the Provident Mutual Life Insurance Company of Philadelphia, whose discussions of the Social Security Act have always been among the most enlightening, returns to a fresh statement of the objections to the reserve principle embodied in the present law and to the system of benefits provided by that law.

As society's Summer capital dug itself out of the debris of Wednesday's hurricane and tidal wave, Newport's year-around residents agreed tonight that the ultra-exclusive Bailey's Beach was no more. Society's Summer gathering place had been cut down by the mountainous surf and only a small part of the main entrance to the beach resort was left standing in the center of Ocean Drive.
Housing properties in widely scattered sections of Manhattan passed to new. control in transactions reported yesterday by brokers.

Twelve more British warships arrived here today from Malta, bringing the total number of units of the Mediterranean Fleet stationed in Alexandria Harbor to thirty-three. This is the largest naval concentration in Egyptian waters since the Italo-Ethiopian War in October, 1935, when there were about seventy British ships here.

The United American Bosch Corporation, Springfield, Mass., has filed a registration under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 417,598 shares of $1 par value capital stock to be offered to stockholders, who will receive purchase warrants, for estimated cash proceeds of $2,505,588.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Sept. 23, unless specified: At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk: Acushnet, Kewaydin. At Guantanamo: Badger, Babbitt, Decatur, Dickerson, Fairfax, Herbert, Leary, Roper, Schenck, J. F. Talbott, Tillman, Tattnail.

Mrs. Marguerite R. Erb, a violinist in the Women's Symphony Orchestra of New York, died yesterday at Montefiore Hospital, the Bronx, after a long illness. Mrs. Erb, who lived at 124 Sherman Avenue, was 49 years old. Born in New York, she was the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Roemaet.

The Great Western Sugar Company, a New Jersey corporation organized in 1905 but having its general offices in Denver, Col., has moved its fiscal office from Plainfield to this place and now has its office at 117 Main Street, law offices of George K. Large, who has been appointed New Jersey agent for the $65,000,000 corporation.

A survey of the storm damage along these shores, where many wealthy New Yorkers have Summer homes, disclosed today that scores of Summer mansions on or near the shore have suffered tremendous damage and in some cases were a total loss.
Eighty players set the stage today for the biggest money tournament in golf, the $13,500 open, which is slated to end next Tuesday at the conclusion of 108 holes.

Gusts of wind of about 173 and 186 miles an hour were recorded at the Harvard Meteorological Observatory on top of Blue Hill during the height of the storm Wednesday, it was reported today by Dr. Charles F. Brooks, director of the station.
Cape Cod, Nantucket and Marthas Vineyard suffered less from the flood and the hurricane than any other coastal areas in this vicinity, according to reports reaching here tonight.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Sept. 21;

One of the major satisfactions of life is waking up from a nightmare. The sun is shining in the window, or is about to do so. From downstairs there drifts the sweet scent of coffee, followed presently by that of sizzling bacon.
There will be a repeat performance in the women's national golf final at the Westmoreland Country Club tomorrow, with the same cast as last year, when the tournament was held at Memphis.

After apparently breaking off negotiations in the afternoon, Prime Minister Chamberlain and Chancellor Hitler again met at Godesberg last night and held a three-hour conference lasting until 1:30 this morning.

A law to prohibit railroad employes from striking would be "salutary," Jacob Aronson, vice president (law) of the New York Central Railroad, said at a luncheon of the New York State unit of the National Conference of Investors in the Hotel Astor yesterday.
The United States decided today to recompense Mrs.. Virginia Venturoli for two gold bricks it. confiscated from her, but it appearedto be no surprise to the Italianborn Bufalo housewife.

Quotation ticker services to points in New England were resumed on a limited scale yesterday, but Boston, points in Western Massachusetts and communities north of Boston were still dependent on fragmentary reports during the day's trading.

Miss Marie Weber of Denver and at Reginald Bryan Owen, son of Mrs. George Rohde of this city and Ly grandson, of the late William Jennings Bryan, obtained a marriage Be license yesterday at the Municipal wil Building here.

Although plans of landlords to renovate rooms for prospective tenants are a strong factor in the renting of apartments this Fall, a good deal of the activity can be attributed to the attractiveness of suites in new buildings.

Joseph P. McCluskey, Fordham's most famous trackman, has arranged an attractive set of three races, the mile, 880 and 440, as a supplement to the varsity-freshman football game, the feature of alumni day at Fordham this afternoon.

Representative John J. O'Connor, who lost renomination in the Democratic primary to James H. Fay, but won the Republican nomination, said yesterday he also would run as an independent Democrat. "I am going all the way through," said Mr. O'Connor, the sole loser in President Roosevelt's "purge."

South Side High School's football team, 1937 city champion, opened its season tonight before more than 3,000 spectators by scoring a 6-to-0 victory over East Side High School in a Newark High Schools League game.
Alvin S. Rosenson, attorney, has been elected president of the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday. He will succeed Nathan S. Jonas, a founder of the institution in 1902.

The hurricane that battered the coast lines of six Northeastern States Wednesday left a toll of death and damage that mounted steadily as estimates trickled through last night from communities cut off by the winds and waves of the worst storm in the region's history.

F. Dudley Wilson, son-in-law, of John Theofel, deposed Democratic leader of Queens County, was arrested yesterday on grand larceny indictments charging that he had misappropriated for his own use $5,254 in rents he collected from residents in Queens apartment houses.

Under clear skies, but on a turf which was still slippery from rain which visited this section in the early hours of the morning, the Bryn Mawr Horse Show continued today with its postponed competitions.

Max Cutler of Elizabeth has purchased from the Rosource Building and Loan Association the three one-family dwellings at 216, 222 and 221 East Tenth 'Street, Roselle, N. J., through George Samuelson, broker.

Miss Adele Ingalls, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Wilson Ingalls of this place, was married to Carl Martin William Jenter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin C. C. Jenter of Pelham, this evening in the Huguenot Memorial Church here.

The latest depression was termed "an unfortunate incident in a trend which is fundamentally up ward" in a speech today by S. Randolph Bruce, assistant general manager of the Royal Bank of Canada, before the convention of the Canadian Purchasing Agents Association convention.

Insurance officials revised yesterday their estimates of claims for damage to vessels. merchandise and property in Wednesday's hurricane and subsequent floods. They said that the claims in New York City and vicinity might amount to $5,000,000, and those for the entire eastern section of the country $50,000.000.
Troops of the First Infantry Brigade, fIrst Division, United States Army, continued to concentrate at tor Camp Dix today in preparation for their annual manoeuvres, which will open here Monday.
More than 100,000 men--possibly 150,000labored today to repair the wreckage of the hurricane and flood regions in New England, under the direction of the Red Cross and many Federal agencies.

Colonel - General Walther von Brauchitsch, 57-year-old commander-in-chief of the Germany Army, was. married here today to Frau Charlotte Schmidt, daughter of a retired judge in Bolkenhain, Silesia. The marriage of Coionel-General Walther von Brauchitsch is the second by a member of the German high command since the early part of the year.

The 155-acre estate of the late Mrs. Mary Strong Shattuck at Lenox, Mass., will be offered at auction today on the premises by Joseph P. Day on order of the executors, T. B. Gilchrist, W. W. Hoffman and the United States Trust Company.

Prayers will be offered tomorrow in every church and today in every synagogue for peace in Europe. Protestant churches will follow the suggestions of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America that fervent prayer rise from every house of worship in the land. Roman Catholic churches will act on the recommendation of Pope Pius

The Treasury Department announced today that Dr. Jacob Viner, who de resigned in April as a special economic adviser, had returned on a temporary basis as a result of the problems growing out of the tense international situation.

Whatever the outcome, and the news is ominous, one extraordinary thing occurred during the past week. Two sides already mobilized for war held everything while they debated, among themselves and across the line, whether they could agree not to fight.

The Cubs bounced back into the thick of the fight for the National League pennant today, taking both ends of a double-header from the Phillies, 3 to 2 and 7 to 6, to climb within two games of' the paceetting Pirates.

A group of Polish-Americans was pledged today to support Poland's demands for Czechoslovak areas dominated by Polish minorities. Encouraged by Germany's success in negotiating concessions for Sudeten Nazis, Poland was reported to have made similar demands on Czechoslovakia.
General Louis Eugene Faucher, until two years ago chief of a French military mission in Czechoslovakia, placed himself today at the disposal of the Czechoslovak defense forces.
Anearnest request that the Supreme Court declare employes of the Port Authority of New York not subject to back income taxes under the Gerhardt decision was made to the court today.

Attention was bo called today to overcrowding in the an House of Detention for Women at 10 Greenwich Avenue, New York City, by Commissioners Sam A. Lewlsohn, Cecilia D. Patten and John L. Schoenfield of the State Commission of Correction.

The State Banking Department announced today it had authorized the Manufacturers Trust Company of New York to open a branch office at Consti- s tuition Mall, Washington Square, s World's Fair Grounds, Flushing.

44th St, 308-20 E; to 17-story hotel, Beaux Arts Apartments, Inc, 111 Broadway, owner: Leon Lionel Levy, architects; cost $7.500. 106th St, 243 E; to 4-story tenement and stores; Estelle Abrahams, 120 W 42d St,

E. W. Scheer, president of the Central Railroad of New Jersey, told stockholders yesterday at their annual meeting in Jersey City that the company had asked bondholders to join in a friendly suit looking toward release from the mortgage securing their bonds of land not required by the company.

Prices of domestic stocks, after having dropped 1 to 2 points in dealings on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, suffered additional losses of about the same amount on the Exchanges of the Pacific Coast as the late news from Europe emphasized the growing danger of war.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Sept. 22: BRIGADIER GENERAL Gulick, J. W., Fort Monroe, Va., to home and await retirement.

The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Sept. 15 showed today that the ratio of the gold reserve to notes in circulation had increased from 122.10 per cent on Aug. 31 to 123.55 per cent.

Fifty-seven promotions in the Fire Department, including the elevation of five captains to the rank of battalion chief, seven lieutenants to the rank of captain, and fortyfive first grade firemen to the rank of lieutenant, were made yesterday at Fire Headquarters by Commissioner John J. McElligott.

The Lincoln Savings Bank has sold 1,213 Beach Twenty-seventh Street, a two-story dwelling adjoining Bayswater Avenue, Far Rockaway, to Martin Solomon for occupancy. The Lewis H. May Company was the broker.

Saddened by increased antiSemitism in Central and Eastern Europe, Jews the world over will begin observance of Rosh haShanah, the Jewish New Year 5699, tomorrow at sundown, with prayers for the amelioration of the dark prospect that confronts their race.

The Rev. Dr. Philip J. Furlong, dean of the faculty of Cathedral College, Madison Avenue and Fiftyfirst Street, has been appointed president of the college. The appointment was one of a number made by Cardinal Hayes just before he died, but the announcement was not made until yesterday at the Chancery office.
Atlantic McElwyn and Dixie Girl took the featured harness races at the Mineola Fair today. Choice Goods and Plateau captured the running events.

" The Great Man Votes," Gordon Malherty Hillman's story of the lone resident of a precinct upon whom an important election depends, has been placed upon RKO's immediate schedule as a vehicle for John Barrymore and Peter Holden, the lad from "On Borrowed Time." Peter is expected at the studio by Oct. 1, with shooting scheduled for Oct. 10.

Breaking with tradition, .a new report card providing for parents a more .detailed' picture of the personality and character traits of their children-has been-adopted by the New -York City school system, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday.

This community was well on the way to reconstructing the terrific damage done by the storm, and all day long Patchogue residents watched truck after truck pass through to the eastward, all loaded down with building materials.

The Censsus Bureau reported to day that cotton of this year's growth ginned prior to Sept. 16 totaled 3,632,153 running bales, counting round as half bales and excluding linters. The Department of Agriculture has reported that the indicated cotton crop this Year is 11,825,000 equivalent 500-pound bales.

French troops kept watch on the Rhine tonight under a "state of alert" proclaimed during a day of foreboding diplomatic activity in Europe's capitals. On the French side sentries paced the river bank and all frontier forces were confined to their combat positions. The German side was dark.

Efforts of twenty residents of the Gramercy Park section to abolish the noise of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company power house at 110 East Nineteenth Street resulted yesterday in the conviction of Harold Jones,

Dr. I. Herbert Odell Jr., chemical engineer, died last night in his home at 10 Lenox Avenue, here, after a short illness. He was 38 years old. Born in New York, he was salutatorian of the class of 1919 of White Plains High School, and received from Columbia University an A. B. degree in 1923, a C. E. degree in 1925 and a Ph. D. degree in 1933.

Fanciful figures have been circulating here concerning the comparative military strengths of France, Germany and other European powers. This is particularly true concerning aviation, in which France, because of a fairly long period of reduced production, finds herself notably inferior.

THERE is a growing danger that a tidal wave of apathy may sweep away all our interest in novels about the South during the Civil War. At least for the time being. Yet I think you should make an exception for Allen Tate's newand, so far as I know, first-novel, "The Fathers."

Because, there are not enough jobs availablee at the cooperative factory and farm to justify the settlement of additional colonists at present, a "limited number" of houses at Jersey Homesteads, the colony ofLhe Federal Farm Security

The Workers Alliance, preparing for a national political drive by home relief recipients and WPA workers to obtain higher relief standards and promote President Roosevelt's recovery program, claimed credit today for the defeat of Representative John J. O'Connor in the Democratic primary election in New York City on Tuesday.

The new British "compromise" plan providing that Czechoslovakia allow Germany to occupy a strip of Sudeten territory ten miles wide along the Czechoslovak frontier, pending arrangements for a transfer of the entire Sudeten area, was presented to Prague last night, according to the Paris correspondent of The London News-Chronicle.
The Continental Oil Company has adopted a retirement and pension plan for any of its 5,000 employes who reach the age of 65 years in the case of men and 60 in the case of women. Dan Moran, president,

While Governor Robert E. Quinn of Rhole Island estimated today that a total damage of $100,000,000 had been done as a result of Wednesday's tropical hurricane, an army of 3,000 relief workers, consisting of National Guard units, the Coast Guard, Red Cross and State and local police, speeded up the work to bring this little State back to normal.

Herman Kraut, 62 years old, a leather goods dealer of 334 West Eighty-sixth Street, was released in $7,500 bail yesterday by Judge Owen W. Bohan in General Sessions after he had pleaded not guilty to first and second degree manslaughter charges.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $22,674,250, to be represented by two States and eighty-two municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $17,308,043 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $23,903,845.

The 5,000-year Time Capsule, containing a condensed record of our present day civilization for the inhabitants of the earth in the year 6939, was deposited yesterday at high noon, the moment of the Autumnal Equinox, at the site of the Westinghouse

President Roosevelt today named Preston Delano, "a very distant relative," to succeed J. F. T. O'Connor as Controller of the Currency The appointment was announced by Stephen T. Early, Presidential secretary, while the Executive was kept in the White House with a head cold.

Union and operator committees on the second day of the four-day truce in the "outlaw" truck drivers' strike continued their attempts yesterday and last night to negotiate a settlement of the labor controversy that almost paralyzed shipping in New York City for seven day and ended with an armistice on Tuesday night.

Automobile traffic throughout Westchester County was back to normal today, the storm debris cleared away. Electric power had been completely restored to all communities and all but a few of the 2,500 telephones put out of service had been repaired.

With the official radio serving up grand opera and waltzes until long after midnight while awaiting broadcast from Godesberg, Berlin residents gave no indication of being overly anxious upon learning that Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain would return to London early today without having reached an agreement with Chancellor Adolf Hitler in Godesberg.

After the costly failure of their attempt few months ago to recover the great electric power plant here, the Republicans [Loyalists] have settled down to strictly artillery warfare on Catalonia's northwestern front, it is stated here.

Sixty patients, men, women and children, were rushed to safety tonight when fire broke out in the old wing of St. Barnabas Hospital; Afoot,- in wheel chairs, on stretchers and beds, they were moved by police and hospital attendants into the new wing.

President Roosevelt was still confined to the White House today with a slight cold in the head. Abandoning his usual Friday press conference, the President authorized Stephen T. Early, one of his secretaries to "pinch hit" for him.

A resolution "reaffirming our support of and loyalty to President Roosevelt and his New Deal legislative program" was rejected today in the closing sessions of the State Federation of Labor convention.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Sept. 17 totaled 660,142 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 91,255 cars, or 16.10 per cent, more than for the preceding week; 162,653 cars, or 19.8 per cent, less than for the corresponding' week last year, and 129,368 cars, or 16.4 per cent, less than during the corresponding week two years ago.

James Cruise, one of three men arrested last Monday as the aftermath of an attempt to smuggle heroin concealed in an ice-cream container into the office of the United States Marshal, was sentenced yesterday to serve eight years in prison.

The Chinese defenders of Tienchiachen, vital mid-China stronghold guarding the Yangtze River approach to Hankow, 100 miles up river, are in a critical condition. Japanese troops from the north and northeast yesterday advanced a mile nearer the river fort, reaching villages only three miles away.

Activity in wholesale markets during the week was cautious, reflecting retailers' attempts to keep stocks complete without committing themselves too far into the future, according to the weekly summary issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Among those in the path of Wednesday's hurricane across New England for whom considerable concern was felt in New York was James Cagney, the motion-picture actor, who is believed to have been at his home on the island of Martha's Vineyard when the storm struck.

An entire floor in the building at 677-9 Fifth Avenue has been taken for Oct. 1 occupancy by the Frank Travel Ser.vice, tourist and steamship ticket agents, through the Cross Brown Company and Clark T. Chambers, Inc.
The number of marriage licenses issued in New Jersey in August, second month of-the State's pre-marital blood-test law, declined 36 per cent compared with the figures for the same month a-year ago.

Marine insurance underwriters handling war risk coverage were in flooded with requests for coverage of transatlantic shipments in both directions as the crisis in Europe took a new turn for the worse yesterday.

A first mortgage of $135,000 has been placed for the Halind Holding Corp on the four-story apartment at 12 Hamilton PI, Garden City, L. I. The loan runs for five years at 5 per cent and was arranged by Butt, Gillliam McVay, Inc.

Argentine cotton exports in amounted to 4,815 metric tons of fibre compared with 4,618 tons in the previous month, with Germany taking practically the entire output, the Department of Commerce reported today.
A renewed wave of selling swept over the foreign exchange market yesterday as the news of the developments in the European crisis aroused fears that war, after all, might not be averted.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,167,000 bales, against 1,164,000 a week ago, 1,157,000 two weeks ago, 1,162,000 three weeks ago and 684,000 a year ago; of which American 610,000, against 623,000 a week ago, 636,000 two weeks ago, 650,000 three weeks ago and 220,000 a year ago.

Hearing of an application for an injunction to restrain the Chief Coroner from proceeding with the inquest into the death of Mrs. Mabelle Orlick Sidley, malted milk heiress, was adjourned two weeks today. Justice Makins granted a Crown request for adjournment.

DODD, MAYNARD (April 10). Gross assets, $84,997: net, $79,327. To Robert Dodd, brother, seven-thirty-seconds residue; Gilbert Dodd, brother, fourteen-thirty-seconds residue; Elizabeth Dodd, sister, seven-thirty-seconds: Mrs. Florence H. Dodd, Maynard Dodd, nephew, twothirty-seconds each. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $45,992. George C. Koch, attorney, 84 William St.
The marriage of Miss Patsy Rathborne, daughter of Mrs. J. Cornelius Rathborne and the late Mr. Rathbore of Powell's Lane, to Henry Augustus Wilmerding Jr.,
The teletype system of the Mount Hope Finishing Company, normally used for business communication between the plant atDighton, Mass., and the concern's agent, Charles E. Hathaway, at 320 Broadway,

Signs of alarm regarding the European political situation were shown today in the world's wheat markets. Prices were on the upgrade from the start, and, while the best figures were not maintained, the close on the Board of Trade here was at net gains of 1 to 1% cents a bushel.

The drafting of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey for the nomination for Governor by the Republican State Convention seemed increasingly certain last night after the executive committee of the Republican State Committee had held a meeting at the Hotel Roosevelt and had received no word that Mr. Dewey would refuse to be a candidate.

James H. MacDonald, founder and for fourteen years president and for twenty years treasurer of the American Road Builders Association, died yesterday at the Hospital of St. Raphael at the age of 87. Mr. MacDonald was said by roadbuilding organizations to be "the father of good roads in America." His efforts led to the establishment of a Highway Commissioner in 1897.
A short circuit which set off air raid sirens in the crowded Bourse district of Paris today sent thousands of office workers scurrying to cellars or rooftops to scan the sky.

Restricted exclusively to tax-exempt offerings, new bond financing this week dwindled to $1,173,479, the smallest weekly total in seven months, or since the period ended Feb. 25, when only $807,000 in new issues were placed on the market.

A net profit of $427,674 for the year ended on June 30 was reported yesterday by the American Shipbuilding Company after deductions for depreciation, Federal income taxes, surtax on undistributed profits and other charges.

New Yorkers may sleep an extra hour tonight, for daylightsaving time ends tomorrow at 2 A. M., when clocks are set back one hour. Of course, many persons will set back their timepieces before retiring tonight.

Ervin J. Smith,who spent a lifetime as a private detective and was head of, the International Secret Service Association, died yesterday afternoon in Bellevue Hospital, at the age of 50, of a bullet wound in the right temple- that: police: said was self-inflicted.

This city seemed tonight to have escaped the worst of the flood which threatened after Wednesday's unprecedented storm. But its security for at least another twenty-four hours depended upon the soggy, man-made dykes along the southwestern rim which saved it last night and early today.

In computing the pension rights of John M. Kelly, whose reinstatement as chief inspector of open-air markets in the Department of Markets was recently ordered, the city was directed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo to credit him with working during the four years he was battling in the courts to regain his job.

With requests for reservations between New York and Boston still far above normal as the result of storm damage to railroads and highways, four of the nation's major domestic airlines continued yesterday to cooperate in maintaining airplane shuttle service between here and the Massachusetts city.

Mrs. Charmian Williams Farson, daughter of. Mr. and Mrs. H. Pushae Williams of the Beekman and widow of Rodney Farson, was married yesterday morning in St. James's Church to George Olin Walbridge 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs.

Delegates to the forty-first annual convention of the National Hardwood Lumber Association denounced today by resolution the present form of the Social Security Act as representing "a loss of public buying power and a reduction in capital available for constructive purposes," and asked for an appropriation of $1,000,000

233d St (17-4954): n w cor of Baychester Ave, 128x154; Rebecca Rubin to Morris Glassberg, 236 E 2d St. Brooklyn Westchester Ave (15-3930); n s. 375 w of Pugsley Ave. 50x100; Anna Coltiletti to Westgrant Realty Corp. 551 5th Ave.
It was still virtually anybody's race as the field in the six-day bicycle race at Madison Square Garden last night turned into the "homestretch."
The Foxcatcher beagles, owned by Mrs. William du Pont Jr. of Newtown Square, took top honors in the final events of the twentysecond annual Bryn Mawr hound show held on the polo field today.
A dispute between the Borough of Seaford and the Eastern Shore Public Service Company, which supplies the town with electric power, headed today toward the United States Supreme Court.

The Seventh International Management Congress concluded its first meeting on American soil today with the election of the first American president of the International Committee on Scientific Management, succeeding Lord Leverhulme of England in that office.

Cooperation between industry and government is the key to better times, Prentiss L. Coonley, Washington economist, told the American Trade Association Executives in convention here today. "There have been administrations pledged to reform in the past," he said.

Sales at the second and lst session of the auction of English and French furniture, Oriental rugs and decorative items from the estates of Adele Kneeland and H. Mabel MacDonald, and the property of Mrs. William H. Hax and other owners drew $14,845 at the ParkeBernet Galleries, Inc., 742 Fifth Avenue, yesterday.

More than 225 freshmen will be welcomed officially by the undergraduate body at the traditional Freshman Day exercises at Barnard College today. Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve will address the students and open the fiftieth academic year of the college at the luncheon in Hewitt Hall on the campus.
Below are given nominal compartive quotations on standard construction of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association Inc.

French imports in August totaled 3,869,024 metric tons, an increase of 326,190 tons over July, the Commerce De partment reports. With the averpartment reports. With the average value of the franc at $0,0273, this made their value 3,709,214,000 francs, or 207,774,000 francs above July.

Football of the professional variety made its seasonal debut last night at Ebbets Field, but aside from the pleasant weather it was all highly disappointing. For Brooklyn fans, rabid as ever, were compelled to sit through the night watching their favorites take a sound thrashing.

Although locally National Furniture Week was completely overshadowed by the general retail sales demonstrations, manufacturers at the American Furniture Mart reported a very sharp increase in reorders, due to the success of August furniture sales in the Middle West.
Review by Deputy Mayor Henry H. Curran, original battle-scarred colors, Seventy-seventh Division, City Hall. noon.

Austin, in 62 Edgemont Rd, Yonkers; Laurence Woodbury, in 55 Old Orchard Lane, Scarsdale; Richard Winslow, in 19 Bronson Ave, Green Knolls; Percy, W. Bidwell, in 34 Chase Rd, Scarsdale; L. R. MacGregor, house Chalford and Inverness Rds, Greenburgh; Louise O. Meuer, Inc, broker.

A directed verdict in favor of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange and certain member firms was entered yesterday in the Supreme Court of New York County in the suit brought against them by the Garcia Sugars Corporation, it was announced by the Exchange.

Diego von Bergen, German Ambassador to the Holy See, called today on Cardinal Pacelli, the Papal Secretary of State. Vatican sources said the Ambassador had come to pay his respects on the eve of Cardinal Pacelli's departure on a vacation in Switzerland.

Mrs. Kate Corbaley, a story editor with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer studio since 1926, died here today at the age of 60. Mrs. Corbaley was associated with many early motion picture dramas, and is credited with scenarios of twenty of the pioneer pictures.

Former Attorney General Charles J. Margiotti, continuing his testimony before the House Investigating Committee, today told of an alleged deal whereby Democratic leaders gave truck companies large orders from the State government in return for a $50,000 political contribution.

The Prague wireless station broadcast a proclamation by President Eduard Benes last night ordering general mobilization of the Czechoslovak Army. The decree was read first in Czech, then in German, Hungarian, Ruthenian and Slovak in that order. It ordered all persons liable for military service to proceed immediately to their appointed stations.

A program looking toward consolidation of certain utility properties of the North American Company system in Wisconsin and issuance of $69,500,000 in bonds and notes of the new company to be created was announced yesterday by James F. Fogarty, president of North American.

Pearl St, 166; Charles M. Joseph, referee. to Anna J. Cohen. 80 Ave P. Brooklyn; mtg $30.000. foreclosure ($3.50). Stanton St, 191; Marjo Holding Corp to Partman Associates, Inc. 2 Ave A: mtg $19.500 and purchase money mtg $3.800 ($4).

Stocks closed from fractions to 3 points lower in slightly more active trading; turnover, 721,300 shares. Bonds generally lower in heavier dealings; railroad, United States Government and foreign issues weak; transactions, $4,547,350.

Throngs waiting to try on their government provided gas masks overflowed from the Regent Street center into Piccadilly Circus this evening as the' Westminster area air-raid precautions program got under way. Each applicant, after trying on his mask for size, received a card specifying whether he was to receive a large, medium or small type when masks were issued.

John Theodore Scheepers, importer of flower bulbs and a director of the Horticultural Society of New York for twenty years, died early yesterday in the Le Roy Sanitarium rr at the age of 60. He had been a C patient there for three weeks, suffering from heart disease.
Daniel Doody, head of the Detroit office of Gilman, Nicoll Ruthman, publishers' representatives, has been transferred to the Chicago office. Detroit operations will be supervised by E. F. Mossner.

Miss Jean Corbett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Wiley Corbett of 443 West Twenty-first Street, will be married to Denis Ralph Peck of London on Oct. 22 in St. Clement Danes Church on the Strand, London.

In view of the widespread success of Townsend Plan candidates in Maine, New Hampshire, California and elsewhere, it is interesting and encouraging to note what happened in this State in Tuesday's primaries.

Not the southern coast of the country but Long Island and New England felt the brunt of the tropical hurricane. The story is told in 15,000 families in distress, at least 500 deaths, property damaged to the value of hundreds of millions.

The hurricane which swept into New England on Wednesday caused almost complete disruption of merchandise shipments from important industrial cities and brought renewed havoc to New York concerns already harried by local shipping difficulties caused earlier in the week by the truckmen's strike.

The S. R. Dresser Manufacturing Company yesterday notified the New York Stock Exchange of a proposed change in name to the Dresser Manufacturing Company and a change in the authorized capital stock from 100,000 shares of Class A stock and 100,000 shares

Mr. and Mrs. James Riley Bartholomew of 35 Clark Street, Brooklyn, gave a dinner last night at the Bossert, at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Adele Bartholomew, to William Redfield Drury,

The forty-eight-family apartment house on a plot 100 by 115 feet at 2,786-8 Bainbridge Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by -the Halbridge Building Corporation to the Levier Realty Corporation for cash over a first mortgage of $145,000.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "There has been comparatively little business done in the American wool markets this week. Here and there, evidence of minor interest is shown and a fair weight of medium bright fleeces has been moved, largely in one channel.

Peter Van Steeden Jr., orchestra leader, has leased from the F. S. R. Realty Company an estate of more than ten acres on Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, Westchester, with a Colonial farmhouse-type main dwelling of ten rooms and three baths, a guest house of six rooms and two baths, and other outbuildings.

Howard C. Davis, an executive of the Queensboro Chamber of Commerce, died this morning at the Meadowbrook Hospital in, East Hempstead after a brief illness. Mr. Davis, who lived at 120 Linden Street here, was 70 years old.
Josephus Daniels, United States Ambassador, was attacked here today as the person "who ordered the bombardment of Vera Cruz in 1914 and one who should be persona non grata" in Mexico.

A plan for reorganization of the Munson Steamship Line ,whereby it will start business with a cash balance of $1,300,000 and other assets was confirmed yesterday afternoon by Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe. An agreement between trustees of the company and the United States Maritime Commission which was approved on Thursday led to the reorganization.

While the world's attention has been focused on the critical state of affairs in Central Europe, the League of Nations has been debating the problem of collective security. The phase of the question which has been uppermost is the future of Article XVI.

Several hundred members of the Printers Union protested tonight before the office of The Times of London against that paper's now-celebrated editorial of two weeks ago advocating cession of the Sudetenland to Germany. Here is the way The Times will describe it in tomorrow's issue:

The League of Nations today gave out a request from the Spanish Government for help in solving "the grave and urgent problem of assuring a supply of food during the coming Winter for approximately 3,000,000 refugees who have come from territories in the hands of the Rebel authorities."

The task of restoring communication lines with the thousands of telephones and telegraph offices isolated in the New York area, Long Island and New England continued unabated yesterday, handicapped by floods, power failures, lack of transportation and poor road conditions.

Miss Joan Brentano Bersbach, daughter of Mrs. Frank J. Bersbach of Winnetka, Ill., was married this afternoon to Archibald McGhee Foster, son of Mr. and Mrs. Volney Foster of Lake Forest, Ill., in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church here. The Rev. Dr. Arthur Ketchum,

Vladimir Potemkin, Acting Commissar of Foreign Affairs, in the absence of Maxim Litvinoff at Geneva, handed a note to the Polish charge d'affaires at 4 o'clock this morning warning Poland that the Soviet Union would denounce its non-aggression treaty with Poland if Poland invaded Czechoslovakian territory.

The United States District Court here lifted today its supervision over the affairs of the Baldwin Locomotive Works and released the company from further responsibility for "the debts and other liabilities" that existed when it petitioned to reorganize three years ago.

Formulation of a seven-point "rehabilitation program" directed toward maintaining production andemployment in the popular-price dress industry was announced yesterday by Louis Rubin, executive chairman of the Popular Priced Dress Manufacturers Group, Inc.
A civic celebration and street parade were in store today for Mr. and Mrs. George C. Green, who chugged across the country and back in their 34-year-old runabout automobile.
Mrs. Nora Borden Baldwin of Rumson, daughter of Alfred Borden of Gladstone, was married here this afternoon to Buel F. Weare of Williamsport, Pa., at Fernanagh Farm, the home

Paying only the slightest attention to those sports whose seasons have been pushed back days by tempests and cloudbursts, football steps toward the center of the stage today, the first Saturday of the year on which the schedule contains many games that can call for more than local interest.

Harry H. Wallace, secretary, a director and sales manager of J. H. Thorp Co., Inc., 250 Park Avenue, jobbers and importers of draperies and upholstery fabrics, died yesterday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after a twomonth illness.

A large part of Long Island was still without light and power yesterday, and the lack of current for refrigeration was making the food situation acute in some communities. At the lower end of the island fresh meat was difficult to obtain.

Edward F. McGrady, vice president and for a year director of the labor relations of the Radio Corporation of America, was elected yesterday to the board of directors of the corporation to fill the vacancy created by the recent death of James R. Sheffield, it was announced by David Sarnoff president.

J. A. Perkins, Assistant Minister of Customs, in answering an allegation that a representative of the government was discriminating in favor of English magazines in banning undesirable publications, said today that of seventy-two publications adjudged prohibitable, practically all were American.

The European crisis was reflected today in an announcement by dockyard officials that movement of British naval vessels no longer would be published. The dockyard is the base for the British Navy's American and West Indies Fleet. At present there are no ships in these waters.

The Rev. Dr. Samuel Colcord, publicist and pacifist, who made a fortune in the real estate business and devoted it to the furtherance of peace, died in his sleep early yesterday morning at St. John's Inn, a private home for aged ministers in St. Johnland, L. I. He was 88 years old.

More than 15,000 school children from districts in Nassau and Suffolk Counties were admitted to the Minea Fair Grounds, free, today, to See the ninety-sixth annual Blue Ribbon Exhibition of the QueensNassau Agricultural Society.

Department store sales in the week ended Sept. 17 were 12- per cent lower than in the corresponding week a year ago and for the four weeks ended Sept. 17 were 9 per cent lower than for the corresponding period in 1937, the Federal Re-serve Board reported today.

Discussing Princeton's football prospects is a delicate task this season. The Tiger is bearing a burden he would prefer to forget. But it is inescapable. Princeton still is in the shadow caused by the tragic death of Bill Lynch.
St. Joseph's College of Philadelphia opened its football- seasontonight by beating West Chester Teachers, 17 to 0, before a crowd of 9,000.

The Public Service Commission has new forms ready for use of motor truck operators in filing applications for certificates. Only those who file before Oct. 29 can reserve their rights under the "grandfather clause" of the Motor Carrier Act.

Three Hupmobile models for 1939 were shown to newspaper automobile editors and special writers at a preview at the Grosse Pointe Yacht Club today. They are the senior eightcylinder car on a 125-inch wheelbase; the senior six on a 122-inch wheelbase, and the new low-priced six.

A plucky Albright College football team held Temple to a 6-to-0 victory tonight as the Owls opened their season before a crowd of 18,000. Temple's lone touchdown came early in the first period after a drive of 55 yards.

The Public Utility Commission directed the National Broadcasting Company today to show cause at Newark on Oct. 18 why it should not be enjoined from constructing and operating the transmitting station W2XDS at Bound Brook. NBC, although holding a Federal permit to operate the station, "has neglected and refused to comply" with a State requirement that it obtain a certificate of necessity and convenience," the commission said.
Telephone conversation between New York and Prague, Czechoslovakia, was severed without explanation late yesterday afternoon, with no immediate prospect of resumption of service.

Most of the salt-water fishing is confined to the surf and the bays these days, for those who still have boats after the gale are taking no chances on being caught in the blow that so often follows a hurricane.

The Memphis Power and Light Company offered today to sell its electrio distribution system to the City of Memphis for $16,401,418. The city at once turned the offer down as "unacceptable" and indicated that it would make a counter-offer, probably tomorrow.

Eighty years old today, Dr. Thomas Darlington, grand sachem of Tammany Hall and former Health Commissioner of New York City, will celebrate his birthday with a quiet "at home," so he will not be too greatly disturbed with his work. Of all the pleasures open to man, the pleasure of work is the greatest, in his opinion.
The City Council went back to school yesterday, thus aligning itself with the seasonal trend. In its previous sessions it accomplished little beyond three emergency tax measures.
The Holland-America liner Nieuw Amsterdam arrives today from Rotterdam and way ports. Among her passengers are Thomas Mann, the author, accompanied by Mrs. Mann: the Rev. Dr. Frederic S.

With few exceptions, travelers on railroads in the metropolitan area were enjoying normal service yesterday, but those who sought to journey to New England points beyond Hartford and New Haven in Connecticut were less fortunate. The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad was unable to provide train service beyond those two points owing to the damage to roadbeds and bridges caused by the hurricane and floods.

George McCall, president of the Catawissa Railroad and former vice president of the Westmoreland Coal Company, died yesterday in his apartment at the Wellington. He was 80 years old. Mr. McCall was chairman of the board of the Philadelphia Contributionship, a director of the Real Estate Trust Company and the Philadelphia Savings Fund Society, and a member of the Rittenhouse Club.

Allotment of $2,000,000 of PWA funds for National Park Service construction work 'in twenty-four States was announced today by Secretary Icks. Among the projects 'was the Statue of Liberty National Monument, for which $45000-will be expended

Many men and women of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York will make the annual pilgrimage tomorrow to the Shrine of Our Lady of Martyrs at Auriesville, N. Y., the birthplace of Kateri Tekakwitha, the Lily of the Mohawks. A special New York Central train will leave the Grand Central Terminal at 7:15 A. M. tomorrow, making stops at 125th Street,

Brazil, which produces little wheat but is now engaged in experimental planting, is reported considering a decree to make mandatory the use of native wheat as far as it will go. Ministry of Agriculture officials say Brazil is able to produce wheat cheaper than she can import it.

Jesse William Phoebus, former newspaper editor, died here last night at 7:45 o'clock after an illness of four months. Mr. Phoebus, who for more than forty years until his retirement from newspaper work thirteen years ago was identified with newspapers in Ohio, Philadelphia and New York, succumbed to a kidney ailment. His age was 73.

A strike of elevator operators and other service employes against what their union leaders called "subnormal wages" spread along the upper West Side from the Seventies to Washington Heights yesterday and apartment house residents, caught unaware, were compelled to climb stairs.

Mrs. Joan Kaufman Biddle received a divorce today from George Drexel Biddle of Philadelphia. She alleged desertion. The custody of children and a financial settlement, the terms of which were not disclosed, were agreed upon July 14

The Rev. Dr. Frederick C. Grant, for the last eleven years dean of the Seabury-Western Episcopal Theological Seminary, Evanston, Ill., will be installed as Edward Robinson Professor of Biblical Theology in Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street, Wednesday, at 4 P. M.

Cincinnati's rascally Reds pushed across a run in the twelfth inning today to nip the Pirates, 5 to 4, and chop Pittsburgh's National League lead to two games over the climbing Cubs. The victory placed the Reds in a third -place tie with the Giants.

The rising tide of WPA employment reached. on Sept. 10, a new "high" for the fourth consecutive week, with 3,102,000 relief workers reported on the rolls. This total, announced by WPA officials today, represented an crease -of 16,300 over the previous

A unanimous plea for greater cooperation between the legitimate theatre and motion picture industries was voiced yesterday by 685 stage actors at a quarterly meeting of the Actors Equity Association in the Hotel Astor.

Although well over $500,000,000 of its $800,000,000 fund for slum clearance and low-cost housing already has been earmarked or advanced by the United States Housing Authority, fifteen States still have failed to act on enabling legislation which would put their cities in a position to receive loans and grants from this source.

Trading in fresh pork cuts active, veal and calf slow; other classes only fair in local markets yesterday. Prices of traefer meats mostly unchanged. The kosher markets opened fairly active, with most classes strong to higher. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

The first twelve railroads to report for August showed a drop of 13.4 per cent in net operating income, compared with a decline of 25.2 per cent in July. The gross revenues and net operating income of these companies in August compared as follows, percentage of declines being shown and the last three figures being omitted from the following table:

The Free Corps, which Konrad Henlein organized to help put Sudetenland under the German swastika, appears to be unworkable. Generally along the border, therefore, it has withdrawn to the German side, evacuating the towns it had taken.

The choppy waters of the Potomac proved just right today for James W. Mullen Jr., an amateur from Richmond, Va., and he outscored the professionals in outboard motor boat races of the twelfth annual President's Cup regatta.

Despite Hank Greenberg's fifty-fifth. and fifty-sixth home runs of the season, the Detroit Tigers dropped. a double-header to the Cleveland Indians today, bowing by 8 to 1 in the opener and. by 6 to 5 in the nightcap, halted at the end of the seventh inning by darkness.

Edward F. Barrett, president of the Long Island Lighting Company, announced yesterday the resignation of John W. Little as assistant treasurer of Long Island Lighting and treasurer of its affiliated companies, the Kings County Lighting Company and the Queens Borough Gas and Electric Company, and as a director of the Queens company. The resignation will be effective on Sept. 30.
