Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt momentarily stunned a group of architects and laymen yesterday when she described dining rooms as "oldfashioned" and of little use in the modern small house. Such space, she asserted, might better be turned into a den or study

The American Federation of Labor Nonpartisan Committee opened its campaign to "reward its friends" by urging working men and women to support for re-election State Senator John J. Dunnigan, Bronx Democrat, and Assemblyman Robert J. Crews, Brooklyn Republican. Of Senator Dunnigan, the committee statement said:

The Newark Bears completed a "Frank Merriwell" drive tonight by whipping the Rochester Red Wings, 9 to 0, to win their semi-final International League play-off series and qualify for the loop's Governor's Cup final against the Buffalo Bisons.
The Union Pacific Railroad Company is expecting its business in the remainder of this year to run above the 1937 level, according to a statement made in Chicago by W. M. Jeffers, president.
Gene Tunney makes his debut in the new edition of "Who's Who in America." There he is described as former heavy-weight prize ring champion and now head of a big liquor corporation.
Ida F. Pomeroy has sold to the Kenwood Investing Corporation the three-story building at 2,450 Delamere Place, Brooklyn, on a plot 26.8 by 100 feet, through Proops Management, Inc., brokers.

The first of three auction sales at which about 20,000 parcels of Nas- Co sau County real estate, with an aggregate valuation of approximately $3,500,000, will go on the blocks begins at 2 P. M. today in the Nassau County Police Auditorium, in Mineola, L. I.

Express representatives from all sections of the country will gather in Chicago on Oct. 4, two weeks in advance of the date previously announced, for a three-day "More Business Conference" of the sales organization of the Railway Express Agency.

A recapitulation of scores in the fifth annual open pistol matchres, sponsored by the Maryland State Police, gave the team trophy today to sharpshooters of the New York City Police Department, on a score of 1,491 out of a possible 1,500 points.

Cotton traders found yesterday's reports from Europe sufficiently disturbing to cause increased selling on the Cotton Exchange and prices turned down, to close 7 to 8 points lower on the day. Despite the holding movement among Southern growers, cotton was moving into sight at a more rapid rate than forwardings of the staple to mills of the world.

Stanley A. Knisely of Cleveland, advertising manager of the Republic Steel Corporation, was elected presidents of the National Industrial Advertisers Association as the organization closed its sixteenth annual convention today.

A marine disaster due to Wednesday's hurricane was reported here today when survivors told of the foundering of the Ocean View, a fishing vessel, off Fishers Island, with the loss of six members of the crew.

An emergency meeting of the Canadian Cabinet was held this afternoon to consider the European situation. The Cabinet was presided over for the first time in three weeks by Premier Mackenzie King, who had been confined to his home by illness.

While New York hotels are faced with the problem of coping with the large number of visitors due here next year, numerous out-oftown hotels will shortly launch extensive campaigns to attract patronage -from those people who intend to visit the World's Fair. Many Manhattan hotels, such as those in the merchandise districts

Fired by the large promises made by foreign statesmen and by their champion, Adolf Hitler, the Sudeten German inhabitants of a number of places in Northwestern Czechoslovakia revolted during the last thirty-six hours and raised swastika flags.

Celebration of the twentieth annilversary- of the battle of the Argonne and the rescue of the "Lost Battalion" of' the Seventyseventh Division, will start today with services at noon on City Hall steps. Deputy Mayor Henry H.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: There is a lot of foolish argument being circulated with regard to the foot-fault rule in tennis, and the letter of Elisha Flagg, carried in THE TIMES last Saturday, seems to add to the foolishness.

ADAMS-Emily Josephine, the wife of Dr. Warren Sanford Adams, daughter of the late John Henry Adam and Sarah Sampson Adam, after long illness, at Little Boar's Head, N. H., on Thursday, Sept. 22. Funeral service at Christ Church, Oyster Bay, N. Y., Sunday, Sept. 25, at 3 o'clock. Interment at Cold Spring Harbor, N. Y.

Eugene P. Connolly, American Labor party candidate for Representative in the Thirteenth Congressional District, will open his campaign against Representative Christopher D. Sullivan, leader of Tammany and Democratic candidate for re-election in that district, at a street rally tonight at Forsyth and Grand Streets in front of Mr. Sullivan's campaign headquarters. Connolly headquarters have been opened at 64 Rivington Street.
Manhattan's football team, employing a new system, will open the 1938 metropolitan collegiate season this afternoon when it meets a Di doughty St. Bonaventure eleven.

Sir Andrew Macphail, noted pathologist and lecturer, died in a hospital here this evening. He was brought to the hospital a month ago after becoming ill at his Summer home on Prince Edward Island. Sir Edward would have been 74 years old this November.

America's newest man-of-war, the $15,000,000 Philadelphia, a 10,000ton battle cruiser, was made ready to take her place with the recently formed Atlantic squadron today at the League Island navy yard.

FerrisHighSchool's eleven launched the 1938 Hudson County scholastic football season at Roosevelt Stadium tonight by conquering the Henry Snyder School, 26-6. The victors scored against their lighter rivals in every period.

Battered remnants of a Black Army that had attempted to invade the United States were dragging themselves today over a single, narrow bridge at Munfordville, sixty-one miles south of Louisville, while a pursuing Blue Army pounded them from three sides.

In any age group of children, girls have more teeth decayed or missing than boys, although there is no difference in the health of -teeth due sex, according to findings published today by the United States should c Public Health Service.

Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins ruled yesterday. that the Municipal Civil Service Commission lacked authority to fix a maximum age limit of 50 years for candidates S for appointment as porters in city buildings and departments.
Mrs. Warren Cleveland Foote of Martha's Vineyard, Mass., and Cocoanut Grove, Fla., has apnounced here the marriage of her daughter, Miss Gladys Foote, to Henry Taft Eaton Jr., son of Mr.

Poland urged the new Czechoslovak Government today to send a prompt answer to its note of Sept. 21 demanding cession or Teschen to Poland; The Polish envoy to Prague called on the Premier, General Jan Syrovy, and in final form "with all gravity," according to a Polish communique, drew his attention to the necessity of answering the note without delay.

New York City facilities crippled by the storm Wednesday night were gradually being returned to normal yesterday. By evening much of the damage caused by the hurricane which swept across the city had been repaired.

Holing a fifteen-foot putt on the final green for a birdie 3, William A. Ryan of Detroit today matched the thirtysix-hole gross of 158 scored by Raleigh W. Lee of Columbus, Ohio, and thus necessitated a play-off tomorrow morning for the United

About 150 bankers and bond dealers attended yesterday the annual field day of the Bond Club of New Jersey, which was held at the Essex County Country Club, West Orange, N. J. The principal event was the competition for the club's golf trophy to be awarded

A plea of not guilty was entered in General Sessions yesterday by Charles De Groot, an auditor of the State insurance fund for employes, on the indictment alleging he accepted an unlawful fee from a contractor to understate the number of persons on his payroll.

The Greenwich Police Department tonight set up short-wave radio communication with the New York City Police Department as the result of a breakdown in the interstate police teletype system between New York and Connecticut.

The San Carlo Opera Company made its sole excursion into the German repertoire of its current season at the Center Theatre with a performance last night of Wagner's "Lohengrin." The opera sung in its original tongue, received a presentation serious in its intentions and creditable especially as regarded the efforts of most of the principals of the cast.

Professor Raemer Rex Renshaw of New York University and his wife. plunged nineteen stories to their deaths late last night from their Tudor City apartment at 45 Prospect Place. Their bodies landed in a small grass-covered plot just south of the entrance to the building.

A team representing the firm of Hemphill, Noyes Co. won yesterday the sixteenth annual Charles Hayden Trophy golf tournament at the Oakland Golf Club, Bayside, L. I. Thirty-four Wall Street firms represented by about 150 golfers participated.

Stephen L. Johnston of New Paltz, Ulster County utility man, who died on 'Tuesday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was buried today in New Paltz Cemetery. He was graduated from State Normal School in New Paltz and from Eastman Business College.

Colleges and universities along the Eastern seaboard suffered considerable damage in Wednesday's storm, according to reports received nere yesterday. Institutions in New York City largely escaped serious injury, but in New England there were three dead, and almost every campus had lost old trees or reported dormitories or recitation halls without light.

Thomas G. Scheider, 21 years old, of 725 Riverside Drive, an insurance company employee, whose automobile struck and killed Grace Sornberger, 40, of 200 West 108th Street, a nurse at Woman's Hospital, as she was crossing Amsterdam Avenue near 105th Street on Wednesday night,

The Disaster Loan Corporation, an RFC agency, stands ready to cooperate with communities that have suffered damage in the hurricane and floods, it was announced today by Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Dr. Alfred W. F. Blunt, Bishop of Bradford, who was the first to raise his voice publicly against King Edward VIII, now the Duke of Windsor, today condemned the "wickedly foolish treatment" of Germany after the World War.

The entire estate of Representative Robert Low Bacon of Old Westbury, who died suddenly at Lake Success, L. I., on Sept. 12, was left to his wife, Virginia Murray Bacon, according to his will, dated Dec. 30, 1936, which was filed with Surrogate Leone D. Howell today.

Captain Evans F. Carlson of the United States Marines, who is a military observer in China, has resigned his commission in the Marine Corps, it is understood, as a result of Navy Department objections to statements made to the press following a trip to Communist-dominated provinces. in North China and Northwest China.

Premier Benito Mussolini returned this morning from a tour of the northeastern provinces to attend the various ceremonies connected with the closing of the Augustean celebrations. He made only a flying trip here, however, for he will leave tonight for Padua and Belluno, where he will deliver speeches tomorrow, in which he is expected to refer again to the latest developments in the Czechoslovak crisis.

The most prominent of the Indian princes who offered their services today to the King Emperor in the event of war are the Maharajas of Travancore, Udaipur, Alwar, Rewa and Sirour and Maharawal Jaisalmer.
The game scheduled between Amherst and Hobart Colleges here tomorrow was cancelled by Amherst today when officials reported to Hobart that it would be impossible to transport their team to Geneva.

New Jersey conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, at its 102d annual session here, called on Governor A. Harry Moore today "to use the influence of his office and of the State" to guarantee the right of free speech.

The Federal Court of Appeals today denied a petition of the National Labor Relations Board for enforcement of an order against Union Pacific Stages, Inc., and criticized the board for the manner in which its conclusions were reached.

Damage estimated by Mayor William Bennett at "a conservative two million dollars" and by insurance men at "nearer five million" was caused by the hurricane here. One man, blown through a factory window, lost his life in the city itself. In suburban cities and towns seven others died by falling trees, collapsing barns, flying debris, or skidding into highway washes.

Van Wyck Mason, the author, set out from Nantucket at noon last Wednesday to deliver a new manuscript to his publisher, but before he finally reached New York yesterday morning he witnessed the drowning of two women, went through a near-wreck of a steamboat and dodged live wires, falling trees and flying debris.

Eight five-story tenements, forming the southeast corner of Washington and Gansevoort Streets, known as 809-13 Washington Street and 60-74 Gansevoort Street, were bought in yesterday by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank as plaintiff in foreclosure proceedings for a nominal bid of $1,000.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Nine prominent members of the New York Electrical Contractors Association, which has been under scrutiny by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey since he became a special prosecutor a little more than two years ago, were indicted yesterday on misdemeanor conspiracy charges.

Miss Marjorie Jeanne Putnam, a descendant of General Israel Put-' nam, and daughter of Mr. and' Mrs. Hobart Hayes Putnam of this place, was married here this afternoon in the Cathedral of the Incarnation, to James Lawrence Maxwell, son of. Mr. and Mrs. Howard W. Maxwell of Maxwelton, Red Spring:Colony, Glen Cove.

The way comedies have been crackling into town the days a body scarcely knows where one laugh leaves off and the next begins. Latest of the merry-makers is "Hold That Co-Ed," which is altogether too wishy-washy a title for the Roxy's impious satire of two great American institutions-football and politics.

Slowness featured the trade on all classes of cattle today, with prices generally steady at the low point of the week, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Hogs and lambs also sold steady.

Local officials of the American Red Cross issued a call yesterday for funds to meet the emergency flood conditions in New York and New England. All contributions from Manhattan and the Bronx should be forwarded to the New York chapter's headquarters, 315 Lexington Avenue.

Heads of the nineteen standard railway unions will meet in Chicago Monday to canvass the strike ballots among railway employes. Announcement of the result will be made soon afterward, it was reported today.

Jacob Brown, police captain, who retired in 1923 after thirty-nine years of service, died yesterday at the home of his daughter-in-law, Mrs. Florence Brown, at 85-02 169th Street, Jamaica, at the age of 79. He was born in Germany.

Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in the Federal court, Brooklyn, yesterday signed an order directing all creditors of Prudence Company, Inc., to show cause why the plan of reorganization of the company shall not be referred to the Securities and Exchange Commission for analysis and report.

B. Charney Vladeck, leader of the coalition group in the -City Council, disclaimed: yesterday the- title of Majority Leader and shifted full responisibility: for local legislation to the Democratic majority. He stated. his position: at the first meeting of the Coulicil'since the Summer recess.

Dwight Long, who went around the world in his thirty-two-foot ketch, Idle Hour, and returned to New York this week after traveling the seven seas for 35,003 miles in the last five years, tells the story of his voyage in a book which will be published by Harper next Spring.

While cheerIng reports of receding flood waters in all of Northern New England were being received here today, plans were being laid for the immense task of reconstruction that confronts the section of the country hit by Wednesday's hurricane and Thursday's floods.

The State of South Carolina will enter the market on Oct. 11 with a new issue of $2,900,000 of State highway certificates of indebtedness. The issue will be dated Oct. 1, 1938, and will mature serially on April 1, 1940 to 1945. Bidders are to name the rate of interest.

BOSTON College.vs. Canisius-What, already? Furthermore, Gil.Dobie hasn't sent word about this. When the Yankees celebrate the clinching of their third consecutive pennant by losing six games in a row, anything fan happen here. (Or in Europe.)

The settlement of the dispute between the Waterfront Employers Association and the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union over terms of a new contract effective Oct. 1 is regarded here as pointing the way -to a new, more realistic and more harmonious period in labor relations on the Pacific Coast.

Cligng to the ground throughout, Rhode Island State opened the season by defeating the University of Maine, 14 to 6, before 3,000 fans today. The. Rams did not attempt a pass. Their two touchdowns were scored by Albruzzi around right end .n the first and third periods.- Ksaney converted both times.

Thomas E. Colleton, New Jersey FHA Director, and J. H. Thayer Martin, New Jersey Tax Commissioner, will be among the tenants in the new MacAvoy Court apartment house when It is opened for occupancy next Saturday.

For the third successive day, four of the nation's major domestio air lines continued yesterday to shuttle back and forth between New York and Boston with passengers in an effort to supplement storm-crippled rail and highway communications.

Justice Willis Van Devanter, retired associate justice of the United States Supreme Court, returned yesterday on the Holland-America liner Nieuw Amsterdam from a tour with his two sisters of Great Britain, Ireland and several countries of the continent.

" The Thread of Ariadne" (II Filo d'Arianna), an opera in three acts, with music by Pasquale Rubino, Italian-American composer, and text by Achille Geremicca, professor of literature at the University of Naples, received what was announced as its world premiere last night at Town Hall.

Clifton (N. J.) Woman's ClubMeeting of civic and legislative departments, 2:30 P. M. Speaker, D. A. Saunders, on the international outlook. D. A. R. (Anne Cary Chapter)Opening. meeting, 2:30 P. M., home of Mrs. Matthew L. Kuckens. East Rockaway.

Covering all fields of literature for adults and juveniles, the Autumn list of 100 books approved by the Cardinal's Literature Committee of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York was made public yesterday. Outstanding titles include "The Horse and Buggy Doctor," by Arthur Hertzler; "St. Catherine of Sienna," by Joannes Jorgensen; "Communism and Man," by F. J. Sheed, and "I Follow St. Patrick," by Oliver Gogarty.

CHILDREN nowadays, with their knowledge of political and social questions that astonishes their elders, seem to be having very little childhood. One wonders whether these precocious younglings have time for such light literature as "Peck's Bad Boy," "Little Lord Fauntleroy," "Master Skylark," "Little Women," "Hans Brinker." '"Tanglewood Tales." the romantic fiction of Kirk Munroe or the college heroics of Ralph Henry Barbour.

Don A. Campbell, president of the National Lumber Dealers Association, reports that, following a careful analysis of building material costs throughout the country during the month of August by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, United States Department of Labor, the average cost of materials was shown to be at the lowest level since the Fall of 1936.
Miss Helen Ferguson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Ferguson of Middlebury, became the bride of Austin Lockwood Adams of Middlebury this afternoon in the chapel of Westover School. The Rev. Dr.

A new approach to the problem of labor relations will be initiated here on Saturday when the newly organized New York Association'of Foremen's Clubs, Inc., will hold an allday conference of industrial executives, supervisors and foremen at the Hotel Astor.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey tomorrow will reduce the price of gasoline one-half cent gallon throughout New Jersey with the exception of the Trenton area and Cumberland County, where prices already have been lowered because of competitive conditions.

Flood and storm sufferers in the eastern end of Long Island, where Wednesday's storm struck with great fury, are assured of food, Commissioner David C. Adie of the Department of Social Welfare announced today.

AT the end of the war William A Stephen Grooch, naval aviator, realized that he did not want to give up flying and go back to the automobile business. But when he talked with his friends about commercial air work they thought he was crazy. "Snap out of it," they said.

" Kelly's Comet," a streamlined, chromium rocket-ship from which helium-filled balloons will be dispensed at 10 cents each, will make its debut at the Central Park Zoo today, according to an announcement yesterday, by the Department of Parks.
What is believed to be a record in the number of patents granted to an individual at one time was established here this week when 111 design patents were granted to Gustave F. Erhard of Scranton, Pa.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va.--The oyster season in this area will have its official opening on Saturday, Oct. 1, as ruled by the Virginia Commission of Fisheries in a recent special session, despite petitions of many oyster men to advance the opening date to Sept. 15.

THE title has nothing to do with astrology. It means the asterisks on the menu, which had about a hundred dishes of which a few were starred each day. The two English maiden ladies, in their forties, and their cook, Gladys, were trying to make a living by renting floors in the family inheritance, a tall old house in a seaside town.
Clemson College defeated Tulane University, 13 to 10, today in a football upset that stunned more than 12,000 spectators who had expected victory for the Green Wave.

Brunhilde Cross, the 18-months-old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Cross of Washington, D. C., was drowned this afternoon in a fish pool in rear of the home of Alfred Inglis at 106 Haddon Place, Montclair. The water was about sixteen inches deep.

Bloomfield High School's Bengals, State football champions in Group 4, were held to a scoreless tie today by a courageous Nutley high school eleven in the opening game of the season for both, played before more than 10,000 spectators.

THE twenty-third volume of the American Year Book surveys the events of the year 1937 in twenty-seven major fields of activity. Although this edition follows the same general plan as its predecessors, the year's happenings and developments have caused some changes in emphasis.

IT is nowadays fashionable to speak of Zola's "Therese Raquin" as an out-of-date piece for the theatre and to perform it, when it is performed at all, as a spectacular exercise or test-piece for one, or perhaps for two, leading actresses.

Business leaders were urged to take the public into their confidence by John W. Hill, in charge of public relations for the American Iron and Steel Institute, in addressing today the closing meeting of the American Trade Association executives.

Final decision on the constitutionality of one of the most far-reachin pieces of legislation enacted under the New Deal-the Tennessee Valley Authority Act-is expected to be rendered by the Supreme Court of the United States in its Fall term.
Thomas H. Raynor, president of the Greenwich Real Estate Board, predicts a building boom In Greenwich as soon as business and stock market conditions show evidence of improvement.

A steady expansion of the shopping facilities in the Jackson Heights, L. I., store center around Eighty-second Street, is taking place, reports the Queensboro Corporation in announcing several store changes recently in the English Gables Building, owned by the Hibest Realty Company.
THREE new productions will be presented during the final week of the San Carlo opera season.
Nearly 2,500 students, ranging in age from 18 to 70, are going to school daily in shirtsleeves and overalls as the Fall term in the Ford Apprentice School gets under way.
Mrs. James R. Arneill Jr., of Denver, today was chosen first president of the new National Federation of Women's Clubs of America.
Called to the reception room of his engraving plant here today, William Paravano, 54, owner of the Girard Bank Note Company, was shot to death while taking with a visitor.

UNREST in Europe once again turns travelers' eyes to South America and lands on this side of the Atlantic. Already comprehensive plans are nearing completion for tours touching great ports and picturesque small harbors.

ELECTRIC train service-wireelectric and Diesel-electricbetween New York and Florida will become a reality in December, when the Seaboard Air Line Railway puts into service nine streamlined 1,800-horsepower Dieselelectric locomotives now under construction by the Electro-Motive Corporation.
Handkerchief manufacturers, favored with lower prices for gray goods, are planning to use higher count fabrics and to put more decoration on their Spring lines, it was reported yesterday.

Almost all important European exchanges plunged yesterday to the lowest records of recent years as the mounting tension of the European crisis expelled capital from Europe in an increasing flight to this country.

At the League of Nations Assembly in Geneva last Wednesday, Premier Juan Negrin of the Spanish Government dramatically announced the end of a colorful but controversial chapter in the history of modern war.
AFTER scanning most of the advance publicity in circulaAltion there is something soothing about the admirably modest manner in which Musicraft quietlyy goes on its independent way.

Held in his tracks for more than three scoreless periods, big Ed Clary, University of South Carolina triplethreat star, broke through for 15 yards and a touchdown in the final minutes today for a 6-to-0 victory over Xavier University.
A temporary injunction, believed to be the first applied under the State price-fixing law to a product sold in bulk,

Union Church, a little old-fashioned meeting house, situated on a hill here, was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Anne Spring Denny Alsop and Richard Watson Gilder. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Philip Adams Job.
The Cubs continued their furious stretch pursuit of Pittsburg's National League leaders today by routing the Cardinals 9 to 3.

THE District of Columbia Department of the American Legion has announced its endorsement of the resolution, recently adopted by the Maryland department, which proposes to create in the Baltimore-Washington Highway a "national model of traffic safety."

A survey of persons living in higher priced homes reveals that Colonial-style houses are still first choice in the $30,000 to $50,000 price class, and that air-conditioning is growing in favor, the Rye Ridge Realty Corporation, owners of Sterling Ridge, Harrison, Westchester County, reported yesterday.

LONDON. DIRECT rail-and-sea services taking seven days between England and India are promised in a new $17,500,000 scheme advanced by Sir John Ward, director general of the- Iraqi State Railways and port director of Basra.

Donald W. Campbell, treasurer of the State Mutual Life Assurance Company of Worcester, Mass., told the delegates at the recent New England regional realty conference in that city that the life insurance companies regard their real estate holdings as among their most valuable assets.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Chadwick of Maple Hill, Newburgh, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Chadwick of this city, to Mahion Richard Boyer of New Brunswick, N. J., son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Boyer of Pine Grove, Pa.

Arkansas University recovered from its first-half jitters to score 27 points in the final half and defeat Oklahoma A. and M. by 27 to 7 today before 4,000 fans. A pass over the goal line from Cowling to Hancock produced the Aggie touchdown in the second period. Arkansas sophomores appeared nervous and dropped pass after pass.

Opening its 1938 football season today, the Navy won from William and Mary by 26 to 0 before 20,000 spectators, a record-breaking crowd for an initial contest. Last year the Middies defeated the Indians, their inaugural opponents for ten seasons, by 45-0, but today's game was not without features of encouragement for the Navy coaches.
The army and navy high commands, concerned over Europe's war. crisis, intend to ask Congress for funds and legislation to quicken the pace of American military preparedness.

Builders in Queens and adjacent sections of Long Island report a steady continuance in demand for medium-priced homes-and many developers, instead of curtailing their operations, are enlarging their Fall construction programs.

A meeting of the Litchfield County clubs of the Connecticut Federation has been called for Tuesday at Woodbury. Several round tables will be held for club presidents, committee members and club secretaries, and Mrs. Laura Hale Gorton, State president, will be a speaker.

Lord Marks, one of the leading engineers in England and one of the first peers created by the Socialist government, died today at Bournemouth at the age of 80. As George Croydon Marks he sat in Parliament as a Liberal for fifteen years, but became a Socialist in 1929, and was soon after made a noble.

William H. Demler of 1,148 Stillford Avenue, Plainfield, treasurer of the Mid-City Trust Company for many years, was reported missing today. A statement issued by John A. Gaffney, executive vice president, said that Mr. Demler had been missing since Tuesday night and added:

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Sept. 22: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Gorton, 1. W., Newport, R. I., to Naval Training Station, Newport, R. I. Vollbrecht, R. A., Coco Solo, C. Z., in December, to Naval Training, Station, San Diego, Calif.

Scoring in the first and third quarters, the Samuel J. Tilden High School team opened its football season yesterday by downing an alumni outfit, 14 to 0, at Tilden Field. The game was the first ever played bn the new Tilden gridiron, which was formally dedicated last Spring.
The chartering market for oil tankers in the Gulf Coast-North Atlantic route is extremely dull and rates are at the lowest level in many years.
Renewed efforts to restore communication lines severed by Wednesday's storm were made yesterday by telephone companies in the metropolitan area, Long Island and New -England.

With the November Congressional elections only six weeks away, a new nation-wide survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion, of which Dr. George Gallup is Director, indicates Republican gains of at least sixty seats if the election were held today.

A number of colored slides portraying the World's Fair as it will stand in 1939 will be shown for the first time by executives of the fair at a luncheon meeting of the New York Building Congress on Wednesday at the Hotel Commodore.

The National Horse Show, which inaugurates formal entertaining in town, opens Nov. 5, the Saturday before instead of the day after election as in former years. There is always much entertaining in connection with this fixture in society luncheons and dinners between sessions and supper parties following the night performances.

Despite the fact that the National Retail Demonstration Week was marred by almost continuous rain in the East, climaxed by a hurricane which wrought millions of dollars in damage, every retailer should "feel complete gratification over the demonstration and the way it took hold," Saul Cohn, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, declared in a statement issued yesterday.

As an aerial survey showed that Vermont's damage from the hurricane and rainstorm of Wednesday amounts to millions and the State' death toll mounted to five with several other persons missing, Federal, State and privately employed work- were ers labored overtime today to clear watt up debris, re-establishing communications and power lines and repair damage to railroads and highways.

In all American history there is hardly a name blacker than that of the Revolutionary soldier Benedict Arnold. For a few thousand pounds he sold valuable military information to the British, planned to surrender West Point, fought against his countrymen and was responsible for the. burning of New London in his native Connecticut.

The net outcome of the conversations here between Chancellor Adolf Hitler and Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain has become clear today. It is that a little more time has been gained in which Czechoslovakia must comply with the more extreme, demands of a German ultimatum--nothing more.

Beaten and befuddled for three periods, the University of California's Pacific Coast Conference and Rose Bowl champions of a year ago opened their 1938 football campaign today with a smashing 12-to-7 victory over the St. Mary's Gaels.

The value of Argentina's imports for the first eight months of this year was 981,770,000 pesos, against 962,725,000 in the corresponding period of last year, according to the Argentine Information Bureau. The increase was ascribed principally to higher price levels.

Pivotal issues partly recovered opening losses of 1 to 3 points and closed steady; turnover, 797,370 shares. Foreign loans weakened 1 to 4 points; United States Government and other bonds lower; transactions, $3,882,000.

A furnished model home will be opened today in the Wilmot Woods residential community in the Scarsdale-Heathcote section of New Rochelle by the developers, the Haring Blumenthal Corporation. The house is in the New England colonial style with a slate roof.

Accountants and assistants of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey examined yesterday the books and records of several electrical concerns said to have been implicated with nine contractors who were indicted Friday on charges of conspiring to defraud and cheat the city as well as private concerns through collusive bidding in the last five years.

When alarm over the international situation was at its highest last night the army's regular Fall manoeuvres which had been going on since Monday, were suddenly called off at midnight and the troops returned to barracks.

Federal Judge Patrick T. Stone, an order qn file in District Court today disclosed, has amended the procedure whereby eleven defendants, although convicted by a jury, were acquitted of charges of violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Act by fixing gasoline prices.

Miss Sylvia White, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner W. White of Oyster Bay, has organized a committee of debutantes to assist with plans for the benefit performance of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo on Oct. 26 at-the Metropolitan. Opera House.
Boston at New York (2)-McKain (5-4) and Ostermueller (12-5) vs. Gomez (17-12) and Hadley (9-6). Washington at Philadelphia (2)Leonard (12-14) and Chase (8-9) vs. Reninger (0-1) and Nelson (10-10).

THE convention hall will be decorated with bunting and banners. A women's drum and bugle corps will be on hand, perhaps more than one. A band will blare at designated times. There will be a keynote speech, praising or denouncing the policies of the party in power.

Personal bequests of more than $250,000 and funds which will go eventually to religious and philanthropic institutions were left by-the late Harry Kraus, stock broker in this city, whose will was filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court.
Little Patty Berg's fourth attempt to lift the women's national golf crown was successful today.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow:

Leaking badly and with her masts gone and rudder disabled as the result of being battered by the hurricane last Wednesday, the British schooner Fieldwood, bound from Turks Island to Providence, R. I., with a crew of seven under Captain A. C. Ker, was towed into Quarantine yesterday.

Two American women will be decorated with the Order of the Red Cross by the Estonian Government this week in recognition of their services in fostering understanding between the two countries and in developing the Y. W. C. A. in Estonia.

The marriage of Miss Jane Gamble, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Samuel Gamble of this city, to Heckscher Tweed, son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Tweed, also of New Haven, took place here at noon today in St. Joseph's Church.
More than 500,000 more men were called to the colors today in France. Just how many were called is difficult to say, as they were not summoned by classes but by categories in different classes.

The Distributors Division, Smoked Fish Workers Union, Local 20,377, was permanently enjoined yesterday by Justice Ferdinand Pecora of the Supreme Court from picketing and intimidating smoked fish dealers who did not buy supplies from it.

With the launching tomorrow of a new three-month course, the WPA Household Training program lifts the restriction on enrollment to recipients of home relief, and general aptitude and personality become the qualifications for admission.

A St. Bonaventure forward pass bounding from a cluster of clawing hands into the arms of Johnny Ertle provided the deciding blow as the scrappy up Staters shaded Manhattan College, 7 to 6, at Randalls Island Stadium yesterday in New York City's initial intercollegiate football game of the new campaign.

DURING early Fall, when the automotive indus try brings out its products for a new year, the industry also remakes its plants, William O'Neil, general manager of the Dodge division of Chrysler Corporation, said last week in describing the magnitude of "changeover" operations for new models.
Color Show. Decorators Club, 745 Fifth Avenue, Sept. 27 to Oct. 11. Ensembles by leading decorators featurinq painted walls. Also an exhibition of children's rooms.

Mexican bullfighters announced today that they were delivering a twenty-day ultimatum to the "bullring trust" demanding that only Mexican and no Spanish bullfighters be allowed to appear in the ring during the Winter season.
Ninety-four members of the freshmen class at Rutgers University have been pledged by eighteen fraternities and clubs in the preseason rushing period, Dr. Fraser Metzger, dean of men, announced today.

APPLICATIONS to build television stations in Albany, N. Y., Schenectady, N. Y., and Bridgeport, Conn., filed by the General Electric Company with the Federal Communications Commission, have met with the approval of Examiner R. H. Hyde.

A fascist coup d'etat in any part of South America was held to be impossible by the Rev. Dr. Joseph F. Thorning, Professor of Social History at Mount St. Mary's College, Emmitsburg, Md., in an interview yesterday at the Hotel Roosevelt after his return from a visit to Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay.
Dr. Thomas Mann, the noted author who is an exile from his native Germany, arrived here yesterday on the Holland-America liner Nieuw Amsterdam to make America his permanent home.

The economic obsolescence of what would otherwise be usable property which has been such a common condition in many large cities of this country in former years is practically non-existent in any other land, declares Leonard C. Smith, realty broker and appraiser of East Chicago, Ind.

In his Trieste speech on Sunday Premier Mussolini used Italy's Ethiopian conquest as justification not only for the general racial policy now being pursued by the Fascist government but also for measures Italy is taking against the Jews.

DETROIT. PRODUCTION swung up sharply in the automotive industry this week as more plants got into volume rate on 1939 models. With the exception of Ford, which is still in the process of model changeover, the industry as a whole is moving forward at a pace well above the previous week and above the same week a year ago.

ON JULY 1, 1769, Spalish priests and soldiers who had come up from Mexico stood on a slight eminence and looked down on San Diego Bay. It was, says Mrs. Fremont Older at the beginning of her book, "California's natal day."

With the prestige of his infant National Progressive party very much at stake, Governor La Follette embarks next week on the most crucial, certainly the most strenuous campaign of his career in a bid for an unprecedented fourth term as Wisconsin's Chief Executive.

PARIS. TO observe the fortieth anniversary of the first radio message received in France from England and to mark the exact spot of its reception, a commemorative monument will be dedicated in the Spring of 1939.

More than 300 cities participated this year in the annual celebration of National Furniture Week which closed yesterday, according to reports from the local offices of the National Retail Furniture Association.

Randolph-Macon and Drexel battled to a 6-6 tie today. A last-minute goal line stand in the fourth period saved the Jackets from defeat, when the Dragons moved to the one-yard line with a series of passes and line plunges.

While wars and rumors of wars agitate the world the United States is carefully tending defensive forces which put it on a stronger footing than at any time in past history. The policy of the whole Administration and of Congressional leaders is one of peace, but there is agreement that American peace is best preserved by creating the power to protect it.

A new gain by Germany, this time at Czechoslovakia's expense, would affect vitally her position in the world. Such questions as these become pertinent: How does the Third Reich of Adolf Hitler compare in size, population and economic importance with the Second Reich of Wilhelm II, before the World War?
Stewart McDonald announced yesterday that the Federal Housing Administration has brought to completion a nation-wide system of minimum standards for small home construction.

The French liner Champlain, arriving today from Havre and Plymouth, has among her passengers George R. Van Namee, Mr. and Mrs. Walter Lippmann, Klaus Mann, Marcel Aubert, Mr. and Mrs. Victor Nef and Professor Paul Hazard.
Jack Knott held his erstwhile teammates to five scattered hits to gain a 3-to-2 victory for the White Sox, after the Browns won the opener of a double-header, 8 to 7.

The hurricane which swept over a large part of the Long Island coast and up through New England on Wednesday left in its wake quite a few realty problems. Thus far; of course, relief workers and emergency crews have been concentrating on the pressing tasks of rescue and of restoring transportation and communication lines.

Universities have never been more important for mankind than they are today as havens of peace, Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve declared in her welcoming address to more than 225 Barnard College freshmen at the annual Freshman Day luncheon yesterday afternoon at Hewitt Hall on the campus.

IN opening what it termed the "first modern motor clinic" in New York, the Gulf Oil Corporation announced yesterday the installation-of a machine that records the road performance ratings of stationary automobiles in its service station at 110th Street and Central Park West. Developed by Dr.

The report of the President's Commission on Industrial Relations in Sweden, with an accompanying letter from President Roosevelt, reads as follows: [The subheads written into the report by the commission appear in light-face type here. The subheads in bold-face type were written by the editor.]

Magistrate Matthew J. Troy in Felony Court, Brooklyn; refused yesterday the request of Assistant District Attorney Alexander Baldwin for further delay in a hearing in the case of Isadore Juffe, 48 years old, of 332 East Fourteenth Street, Manhattan, charged with grand larceny, and dismissed the defendant from custody.
German competition in Latin America will be intensified if Germany succeeds in getting Czechoslovakia's Sudeten area without resorting to war, foreign traders predicted here yesterday.

What, if any, interest has the United States in the world distribution of power? In 1823 Canning suggested the Monroe Doctrine to bring the new world in "to redress the balance of the old." In 1904 Theodore Roosevelt protected Japan when France and Germany seemed on the point of helping Russia.

A survey of the distribution of the savings associations holding membership in the Federal Home Loan Bank System discloses the fact that they are located in 1,963 towns and cities representing 85 per cent of the urban population in the country.

Fresh Chinese troops, hurled in repeated counter-attacks without regard for heavy casualties, are balking Japanese attempts to capture Tienchiachen, vital Chinese fortified position 100 miles down the Yangtze from Hankow.
A portion of the New Canaan, Conn., estate owned by Edgar Rickard, known as Woodsedge, has been purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Alanson C. Eberhart. Mrs. Eberhart is the authoress Mignon G. Eberhart.
The advance guard of the persons Who will be identified with both native and foreign exhibits at the World's Fair is manifesting a preference for living quarters in mid-Manhattan.

Competely outclassing a light Marietta .eleven, the Rutgers football team opened its seventieth year of gridiron warfare with a 20-to-0 victory on Neilson Field today before 7,000 persons. The game was the first for Rutgers under its new coach, Harvey Harman.

Miss Ernestine Bunnell, daughter of Mrs. Walter Lyman Bunnell of this place, was married to Albert L. Birdsall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira D. Birdsall of Grand Rapids, Mich., in the Presbyterian Church today by the Rev. Dr. William K. McKinney.

Efforts will be made at a special meeting of the directors of the National Automobile Dealers Association tomorrow to bring back into the fold the dealers of Wisconsin about 1,000 strong, who recently, withdrew on the ground that proposed changes in the constitution and by-laws had not been offered within 120 days for vote of the membership, as was agreed in the convention held here last April.

Because the schedule requires it, the Phillies and Dodgers, neither of whom can be dislodged from their respective eighth and seventh positions in the standing, played the first of a three-game series at Ebbets Field yesterday.

An Italian nobleman, Count Theo Rossi, had a jaunty, single-handed pleasure cruise this sunny afternoon on the Potomac instead of the intended speed-boat race, and yet probably won the President's Cup for 1938.

New England's hurricane-flood disaster entered the clean-up stage today with authorities centering attention on rehabilitation of property and feeding, housing and safeguarding the health of the victims in the Merrimac and Connecticut River Valley.

Massachusetts will wake up tomorrow morning not knowing just what time it is as a result of a request this afternoon by Governor Hurley that the State continue on daylight saving time for another week in order that flood and hurricane-stricken communities might have better opportunity for rehabilitation.

EUROPEAN events of the past week have strengthened the demand for isolation in this country as have no other circumstances since the "war to end war." For weeks, with the crisis abroad gathering momentum, the nation has been engrossed--as it has not been engrossed for two decades--with the question: if war comes, can we stay out?

A new stake for all retriever breeds and for Irish water spaniels is to be established this Autumn in memory of the noted sportsman the late Jay F. Carlisle of East Islip, L. I. It will be contested over the estate of Gerald F. Livingston in Huntington, L. I., Sunday, Nov. 6, and will be the featured event of a two-day meeting.

COMES now the season of melancholy and, appropriately, cheering news from three of of the town's less garish bright-spots where the gentler folk may find relief from Autumn nostalgia. Among the first to introduce the festive note will be El Morocco, all set to embark upon its seventh season this Wednesday night.
SPORTS-MINDED camera fans need no reminder that the football season has already been ushered in with its usual fanfare of colorful bands and cheering collegians.

SOUILLAC, France. TWO American motor cars, with the conspicuous red licerise plates of the American tourist's temporary importation, have just followed one after the other with a brief interval down the main street of this little town.

The possibility that Russia, if war breaks out, will play a more important military role than had been expected was seen by many foreign diplomats here in the Soviet's threat of yesterday to denounce its non-aggression pact with Poland if the latter attacks Czechoslovakia.

As the Czechoslovakia crisis focuses attention on the threat of another European war, American peace organizations have mobilized for an active "keep out of war" campaign. Four peace groups called on the President this week to adhere to the .stay-out-of-war policy and warned him not to repeat the history of the World War Democratic Administration.
Mel Harder's index finger became numb after he held the Tigers in check for six innings today, and Detroit hammered his successors for six runs and a 7-to-6 victory over the Indians.

A course in real estate mapagement will be given during the Fall evening session at City College, Twenty-third Street branch. The course will present the fundamentals and current practices in various types of buildings in the metrnnopolitan area,

Mr. and Mrs. Gaines McMillan have come from Baltimore to the Weylin, where they have joined Miss Mary G. Rice of Morristown, N. J. Mrs. William Orr Barclay will return to the Plaza today from Great Barrington, Mass.
THIS able study of the problems of the Mediterranean basin, that ominously developing hotbed of deadly international rivalries, should be enthusiastically welcomed by the ordinary reader.

The Interstate Commerce Commission has postponed to Oct. 15 the date for filing exceptions to the plan of reorganization for the Chicago, Indianapolis Louisville Railway proposed by the commission's examiner.

To further the program of personal guidance at Colby Junior College this year, Miss Elizabeth Hagedorn of Trenton, N. J., and Miss Thelma Shreiner of Hanover, Pa., have been appointed to the faculty to serve as dormitory counselors.

Two concerts devoted to works performed at the Berkshire Festival of Chamber Music, sponsored by Mrs. Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge, last week in Pittsfield, Mass., will be given tomorrow and Tuesday at 8:30 P. M. in the Lenox Gallery of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

Former Mayor James Simpson and a companion were killed today in an automobile accident in downtown Toronto. Mr. Simpson, who was Mayor in 1935, and a man identified tentatively as R. T. Barton of Winnecoune, Wis., were in a coupe that was in collision with a southbound street car at Bay and Harbor Streets during the noon-hour rush. The car was wrecked.

The government has been forced to close police stations, district offices and even postoffices in many Arab towns because of almost daily arson, robbery and plunder by rebels on government institutions.

A highlight of the early Autumn season here was the marriage this afternoon in St. James Church of Miss Virginia Winmill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Campbell Winmill, to Robert Henry Radsch of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Radsch of Appleton, Wis.

Twenty-two hundred students of Massachusetts State and Amherst Colleges have been mobilized here to work with highway crews and volunteers in clearing up storm damage estimated to exceed $1,000,??000.

A course of fifteen lectures on Thursday nights dealing primarily with New Deal legislation, its current problems and future tendencies, will be offered this Fall 'by the Practicing Law Institute, 150 Broadway, it was announced yesterday.
The Czechoslovak Legation tonight said that there was not the slightest chance the Prague government would accept Germany's latest demands for settlement of the Sudeten German dispute.

Ceremonies to commemorate the twentieth anniversary of the Battle of the Argonne and the subsequent rescue of the famed Lost Battalion began yesterday on the steps of City Hall, when the original flags. of the Seventy-seventh Division were reviewed by army officers and city officials.
Carl Heyser Jr., reported yesterday that he participated in an unusual sale of a house in Old Field South, Stone Brook, L. I., on Wednesday at the height of the hurricane.

In one of the best contests for the erased famous trophy seen in several years, Three Coq Bruyere, owned by John Straw- from bridge of Philadelphia today won the Meadow Brook Cup Steeplechase over the estate of F. Ambrose Clark.

In mourning for the late Cardinal Hayes, the College of Mount St. Vincent opened last week without the usual ceremonies and receptions. Besides his other duties, the Cardinal was president of the college.

Major Gen. J. W. Stewart, who served with the Canadian Expeditionary Forces during the World War and was one of Canada's leading railway construction engineers, died today in his home after a lengthy illness. He was 76 years old.

The decline in sales volume for 132 industrial companies for the first half of this year averaged 30.3 per cent below the corresponding period of 1937, according to the annual survey of advertising budgets by the National Industrial Advertisers Association, released for publication yesterday.

NEW YORK'S busy and everchanging waterfront, whose development has been in separable from the history and growth of the city, will undergo many further changes within the next six years if the $30,000,000 program of fourteen new projects presented to the City Planning Commission recently by Dock Commissioner John McKenzie is approved.

LOS ANGELES. THE end of the Santa Fe Trail has been found. It is a poker parlor. California is adopting gambling as a diversion for its visitors and residents alike, thereby joining other States in providing such a pastime more or less openly.
NEWS has been so overflowing at the microphones in Europe that the broadcasters have been forced to allot more time to bulletins and commentaries.
Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney were hosts tonight at a dinner with dancing at their home near the estate of Mr. Whitney's mother, Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney.

THIS study, according to the publishers, is "an attempt in handbook form to put actual working tools into the hands of the American student and present the basic factual material of lives and works of the chief major and minor painters of the Italian Renaissance."
Modern floor paints really are enamels, points out The Painter and Decorator, which explains their use on new wood floors calls for no more care than properly painting any surface.

IT is no accident that Professor Hogben links science with the citizen in the title of his book. Despite his quips at the expense of politicians, dinersout, golfers, Gifford lecturers and mathematical physicists who dabble too much in metaphysical speculation, he is worried about "the large and growing number of adolescents who realize that they will be the first victims of the destructive power of science misapplied."
FRAULEIN HUSTON waddled in Dachshund splendor to Seat 18 in Row L. Her happy barks en route caused tenants of the pit to slight their instruments for a momentary gaze on the patronless stalls.

Country homes on the North Shore will house many guests, during the four days of the Piping Rock Horse Show, which will open on Wednesday for the thirty-sixth time. The show is dedicated this year to the memory of Pickles, a hunter that was ridden to the Meadow Brook hounds by Thomas Allison from 1910 until 1935.

With Quirke pitching well all the way and Kelly hitting hard for extra bases, the New York Department of Education baseball team defeated the New York Department of Purchase, 13-5, for the championship of the civilian city employes at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

Miss Eloise Morgan Shaw, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. William E. Shaw of 706 Riverside Drive, was married to .the Rev. George Herbert Orser, son of the Rev. and Mrs. William A. Orser of Olney, Va., yesterday afternoon in Christ Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

Industrial relations in Sweden have reached their present state of development largely because "the settlement of differences by methods of persuasion rather than by force has become the order of the day,"

Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor" was yesterday's matinee offering of the San Carlo Opera Company at the Center Theatre. The opera received a routine performance, agreeable enough on the whole to elicit hearty applause from an audience of good size for a Saturday afternoon presentation.

The building trades strike, which has partly paralyzed construction in the Paris district since Monday, has been called off by the workers "on account of the international situation." Work will be resumed Monday.

The United states dollar resumed its sharp rise against the pound sterling in the foreign exchange market today. The rate at one time touched $4.78, out at this point intervention of the official control turned it back to $4.78%.

ADLER--Mr. and Mrs. Milton. 500-Ocean Ave., Brooklyn. announce the arrival of a baby girl, on Sept. 19, at the Park West Hospital. ADLER-Mr. and Mrs. Milton J. (nee Lillian Bonat), joyfully announce the arrival of Deanne, Park West Hospital. BARSKY-Mr. and Mrs. Albert Barsky announce the birth of a son at Hunts Point Hospital.

DAME NATURE--Tomorrow evening at the Booth Theatre. The Theatre Guild is opening its twenty-first season with this. adaptation, by Patricia Collinge, of a play by Andre Birabeau. Concerned with the love affair of two 15-year-old children, its cast includes these names: Jessie Royce Landis, Onslow Stevens, Montgomery Clift, Lois Hall, Forrest Orr, Morgan James, Milton Graff, Thomas Coffin Cooke and Harry Irvine.
The Bostonian, regular Shore Line express, which left Grand Central Station, New York, at noon (E. D. T.) Wednesday, was a major victim of the hurricane, it came known today.
Steamship passenger agents revealed yesterday that their offices are being besieged by prosspective travelers who, frightened by events in Europe, wanted to cancel their reservations.
Jeffrey Dell will have the distinction of two successive first nights next week with his plays, "The Judge" and "Official Secret."

A NEW low in tactical strength has been reached by the Twentieth Pursuit Group of the Third Wing of the GHQ Air Force, based at Barksdale Field here. The three squadrons which comprise the group have a total of fifty-three pilots, but there is only one tactical plane on hand.

Mrs. Patrick Henry Adams, president of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs, has announced plans for the formation of two choruses of 200 members each for participation in music festivals during the season.

Raleighl W. Lee of the Columbus (Ohio) Country Club became the third member in the thirty-four-year championship tournament history of the United States Seniors' Golf Association to record more than two national triumphs when he successfully defended his crown by defeating William A. Ryan of Detroit in the eighteen-hole play-off at the Apawamis Club today.

With production in each of the last four months higher than the previous one, a new high record for production of gold was established in August by Bidgood-Kirkland Gold Mines, Ltd., Kirkland Lake area, with an output of $57,492, representing an average recovery of $12.97 a ton.
Negotiations between the unions and the employers involved in the truck drivers' strike that had been interrupted by a four-day armistice ended at 1:30 A. M. today without an agreement.

Speaking in tones that sounded like a bugie call to war, 'Premier Benito Mussolini, after announcing that the memorandum for CzechoFlovakia Chancellor Adolf Hitler handed to Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain yesterday has the character of an ultimatum expiring on Oct. 1,

ABRAMS--DELIGDISH--Mrs. Minnie J. Deligdish of 25 West 68th St., wife of the late Joachim L. Deligdish, is happy to announce the engagement of her daughter, Sylvia Rena, to Theodore Abrams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry H. Abrams of Woodhaven.

AS the first automotive offering for the new car year, the new Plymouths for 1939 were placed last week in showroom windows of dealers throughout the United States. Public announcement of the cars, which are the largest yet produced by the company, began this week-end with newspaper advertisements.

WASHINGTON.--Engravings for the new official map of the United States, ordinarily revised every two years, have just gone to the printers. Congress at its last session appropriated $15,000 for the revision. The General Land Office has the job of keeping the map up to date.
THE acclaim which greeted " Paradise"--Esther Forbes's brilliantly realistic novel of the Massachusetts Bay Colony--doubtless will be repeated in welcoming "The

At the height of the Czechoslovak crisis this week, when the League of Nations sat futilely talking while great powers that created the League were countenancing aggression such as the League was specifically intended to prevent, foreign diplomats here immediately began asking themselves: "Will Russia withdraw from the League?"
Present conditions indicate continued activity in home building during the Autumn and early Winter, according to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.
The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today the following additional applications from New York for registration as brokers or dealers in the over-thecounter market:

The Merrick Park Gardens Corporation, of which Lewis S. Franklin is president, will hold ceremonies today to mark the formal opening of a new development of medium-priced homes for Negroes in the Merrick Park section of Jamaica. L. I.

THIS book by a veteran crime reporter is not so much a study of "styles in crime" as a collection of picturesque events and personalities from the history of crime in New York City. Changing styles there are, to be sure:

William J. Morey, 33 years old, of 352 Seventeenth Street, Brooklyn, a patrolman attached to the Atlantic Avenue Station, was dismissed yesterday from the Police Department for intoxication and failure to safeguard his revolver.

MONTREAL.--The annual in flux of sportsmen from the United States seeking hunting trophies in the heavily wooded, hilly and lake-studded terrain of the Province of Quebec will formally start this week with the full opening of the shooting season.

With almost every feeder industry in the automobile field having suffered declines of 50 per cent or more this year, the early introduction of the new models and the brighter business prospects led them last week to look for a moderate upturn for the coming year, according to a survey of trade associations and manufacturers.

APT-SALZMAN-Mr. Geo L. Salzman announces the marriage of his daughter. Vera. to Mr. G. Lee Apt on Sept. 19 and the taking up of their residence at 1.288 Westervelt Place, Hewlett, L. I. BOTTHOF-GRAY-Mrs. A. B. Gray announces the marriage of her daughter, Lucy Gray, to Mr. Frank Botthof Jr., to take place Sunday. Sept. 25, at 3 o'clock, at St. George's Chapel, 16th St., east of 3d Ave.

The settlement in Palestine of 6,500 oppressed Jews from Central and. Eastern Europe in the last six months, despite Arab disturbances and economio difficulties, should inspire Jews beginning observance of Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year 5699, this sundown, Harold Jacobi, New York chairman of the campaign of the United Palestine Appeal, said in a New Year's message yesterday.

Miss Vera Larkin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Andrew Larkin of 1,040 Park Avenue, was married yesterday afternoon to Edward Henry Beck, son of Mrs. Edward Henry Beck of 64 East Eightysixth Street and the late Mr. Beck. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Francis X. Quinnan in a setting of all yellow blossoms at the home of the bride's parents.
Alarm developed in parts of Belgium, which was overrun by Germany in the last war, as the government took precautionary defense steps today.

Lou Little brought his Columbia football squad to Camp Wyomissing for a practice scrimmage with the Lafayette eleven today and after two hours each team had scored one touchdown. No effort was made for the extra point.

William P. Hahn, builder in Belknap Street near the Merrick Road in Springfield Gardens, Queens, reports that eleven new dwellings in the $4,790 price class have been sold since the opening of the model home two weeks ago.

Lowell Textile easily defeated the University of New Hampshire, 20-0, today. Textile scored early in the first quarter when Meuser went off tackle to tally from the 5-yard line. A pass, Madden to Meuser, and another, Madden to Haas were good for two more touchdowns in the last period.
A wooden letter-opener carved by Boy Scouts was presented yesterday morning to Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. in appreciation for his efforts in behalf of fundraising camrpains of the Scouts.
THE tragic death of Major Gen. Oscar Westover, chief of the Army Air Corps, in a plane crash at Burbank, Calif., last Wednesday was a great loss for civil as well as military aviation.

With losses incurred under the mutual mortgage system of the Federal Housing Administration remaining almost negligible, the administration expects its income to rise sufficiently in the coming months to produce a surplus for the mutual mortgage insurance fund in the fiscal year ending June 30, 1940, administrator Stewart McDonald declared yesterday.
Yugoslavia and Rumania were reported in reliable quarters today to have told Hungary that they would go to the aid of Czechoslovakia, their Little Entente ally, if she were attacked by Hungary.

THE curriculum for the Fall classes at the American Artists School, 131 West Fourteenth Street, has been revised and enlarged for the Fall term. A related course in painting and sculpture, tried out during the Summer session, will be offered during the new term.

Three compliance inspections of all new residential construction on which commitments have been issued for an insured mortgage are made by the Federal Housing Administration. These inspections include examinations of construction, repairs or alterations made by staff inspectors to determine if the work has been done according to the plans and specifications approved by the FHA.
WASHINGTON.--Of the more than 4,000,000 men mobilized for our wartime armies two decades ago, only a small number remain under compulsion to answer another mobilization order.

The Vatican commission that came to the United States several weeks ago for formal identification of the body of Mother Francis Xavier Cabrini, prior to her canonization on Nov. 13, sailed for home yesterday on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia.

THE personal attention of a single individual with taste and intensity often achieves a degree of perfection not easily attained in large organizations where responsibilities are diffused and divided. No better example of this can be found than "Early American Stencils on Walls and Furniture" (William R. Scott, $15).
UNDER the baton of John Barbirolli, as permanent conductor, the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra will return to the air on Oct. 23 for twenty-eight Sunday afternoon concerts.

THROUGHOUT the hectic diplomatic manceuvres and menacing events of recent weeks, the British Government has striven for peace while preparing for war. By varying devices, with varying misgivings, with varying approaches to Cabinet unity, it has sought to isolate small wars and postpone a conflict of major powers even for a few months-even sometimes for a few days.

OVER large and important areas last week, trade contended with the most adverse conditions. Sponsors of National Retail Demonstration Week expressed gratification with results; but, except for the Middle West, there appeared to be further setback due to the hurricane, floods, heat and other unfavorable circumstances.
LITERARY competitions often provide useful indications of the trend of popular taste, and some significance may be attached to the results of a recent prize offer by The Observer.

COMEDY is a matter of taste. It is also a matter of clothing. Charlie Chaplin's first picture caused no uproar at all; it was not until he found the baggy pants, cane, derby hat and oversize shoes that he became a successful funny man.
The first issue of "Who's Who in America" in the year 1899 contained 8,600 biographical sketches. The new issue tomorrow will show 31,545

With Colorado voters scheduled to pass upon the State's chain store tax in a referendum to be held on Nov. 8, keen interest is being shown in chain store circles on whether that State will follow the lead of California in turning thumbs down on the chain levy.

The Board of Education asked the State Civil Service Commission at a public hearing in the State Office Building last week to classify two positions of school superintendent, which were created last Spring by the La Guardia administration, as appointive jobs, exempt from the civil service regulations.
James S. Whitty, who for twentyeight years had been a clerk in the Building Department of Queens, died Friday at the age of 43 in St. John's Hospital, Long Island City.
Part two of the late Sumner Healey's collection of antiquities and objects of art brought $5,296 at auction yesterday afternoon at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 742 Fifth Avenue.

With few scattering exceptions, the storm-crippled facilities of New York City were restored to normal yesterday. Throughout the day the full field forces of the Departments of Sanitation, Parks, Highways and Sewers worked at top speed cleaning up the last remains of storm debris from the streets and parks.

Preliminary construction operations are now in progress for the erection of seventy-two-family six-story apartment house on the Joseph Christiano property, adjoining the Greenwich High School parking space on West Elm Street. Title to the property has been taken and a building permit issued to Jack Chutick.

TWENTY years ago tonight began America's greatest battle--the Argonne-Meuse--which lasted until Armistice Day. The anniversary is being celebrated by veterans of the Seventy-seventh Division, which was made up largely of drafted men from New York City.

THIS book appears at a timely moment, now that reports of shakiness in Germany's economic structure are getting into the headlines. But it is emphatically not for the layman. Its author tackles his formidable subject with Teutonic thoroughness; he fires compact chunks of economic theory at his readers with merciless perseverance.

National Chairman Farley today coupled an endorsement of Senator George McGill, Kansas Democrat up for re-election in November, with an invitation to- Senator Capper a Republican, to "come over with us formally."

Counsel for Howard C. Hopson notified the Securities and Exchange Commission today that Mr. Hopson would appear as a witness in its hearing to determine whether the Uilities Employes Securities Company is a special investment company for selling securities of the Associated Gas and Electric Company to employes.

Champion Royal Kid Regards, owned and handled by Mrs. E. P. Anders of Linden, N. J., gained the honor of best in show at the eighth annual specialty fixture of the Brooklyn Boston Terrier Club, held at Forest Hills yesterday.

Fred C. Trump, Brooklyn builder at East Forty-third Street and Clarendon Road, in the Flatbush section, reports that the third unit of thirty-three homes in that development is rapidly nearing completion and twenty-one homes have been purchased from the plans, bringing the total of dwellings sold in that community to 225.

American history knows two Benedict Arnolds: the one who led the heroic march against Quebec, was wounded in the desperate assault upon that city, held the shattered American forces together in their tragic retreat from Canada, was wounded again as he charged into the thick of the fighting at Saratoga, and for this was snubbed and neglected by the American Congress;

THE Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, under Fritz Reiner, its new permanent conductor, will give sixteen pairs of concerts this season on Friday nights and Saturday afternoons, beginning Nov. 18, in Pittsburgh, Pa.

A completely feminine ticket for State officers, both elective and appointive, will be selected this week on a mock ballot being circulated by the New York League of Business and Professional Women, as a part of its campaign for more women in public office.

A new name to describe "chain stores" in popular language is badly needed at the present time, according to a prominent retail executive. The connotation of the word "chain" is not all that could be desired, he said, pointing out that it is used in such descriptions as "chain gang," "chain letters" and also implies a sense of being bound or restricted.

Several sales of plots at the Candlewood Lake Club, New Milford, Conn., were reported yesterday by Martin H. Sherwin, vice-president of the developing concern. Dr. Warren Weaver, Raymond W. Rouse and Curtice L. Mathews bought plots on Candlewood Road.

The nation's bill for highway construction, maintenance and bond expenses was $1,166,706,000 last year, the Bureau of Public Roads stated today. This-figure represented the amount spent by the States and included Federal aid benefits for construction.
A powerful offensive on the ground and through the air overshadowed a weak pass defense today and Boston College steam-rollered Canisius, 63-12, before 12,000 fans:

The Northeastern States swept by Wednesday's hurricane dug out from under the debris yesterday and came to grips with problems presented by wholesale looting and the neeessity for immediate relief and long-range rehabilitation.

A thousand persons attended the opening session this afternoon of an auc'tion sale of properties in Nassau County, at an estimated value of $3,500,000 and comprising roughly 10,000 parcels, all of which are to be disposed of in the course of the sale which is expected to last about three weeks, with many night sessions.

Seymour Worrall Hyde, a sportsman and World War intelligence officer, was thrown from his horse and injured fatally today while riding with the Radnor Hunt at Whitehorse. He died in Bryn Mawr Hospital at 5:30 P. M. from a brain injury.
The half-Wild hogs that range the South Georgia swamplands were ranked today by J. O. Stewart, United States Revenue officer, as tops among moonshine still detectives.
Mayor La Guardia will be a speaker before the American Labor party at its State Convention in the Manhattan Opera House Oct. 3 and 4, Alex Rose, State executive seeretary, announced yesterday.

The headline on a news dispatch from Washington, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 21, reported that the American Chemical Society was fighting suppressed patents and favored the McFarlane bill, which would limit to five years the patent control now granted for seventeen years.

Twelve names have just been added to the membership lists of the Real Estate Board of New York. They are Louis Hoffman, W. R. MacInnis, Joseph G. Dubraska, Fabyan R. Saxe, Lester P. Slade, F. Bevill Champion,

IN your Sunday article Sept. 11 I noticed that you devoted most of your space to a discussion of what part of 1938 art would be instructive and interesting to the citizens of 6939. This seems to be a highly worth-while discussion.

The South American countries, which profited greatly from the last European war, are in an even better position today to meet and take advantage of the changes In world trade which would result if a new European conflict broke out, according to a study of the subject which has been prepared by Daniel A. del Rio, assistant vice president of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company.
Virginia's eleven fought Virginia Military Institute's team to a standstill today, 12 to 12, at Scott Stadium. Among the spectators was Senator Carter Glass.

Princeton University will formally opens its 192d academic year on Tuesday with what is expected to be the largest enrollment in its history. A total of 2,705 undergraduate and graduate students are expected to register. Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president, will deliver the annual opening address.

Prices of wheat in the world's leading markets advanced sensationally today ?? response to the warlike character of the news from Europe. In Liverpool futures gained 7% to 8 1/4 cents ?? bushel and in Rotterdam they ?? 3 8/3 to 7 cents. Both markets were closed before trading started North America.

Bonds called last week for redemption prior to maturity were in fairly large volume as three large issues of public utility securities were announced for payment. Except in this group, however, there was little activity, and this consisted mainly of. calls of small amounts of foreign and domestic municipal bonds.

October first, traditional moving day, will bring some changes for the women's organizations which maintain permanent headquarters in the city. The New York League of Business and Professional Women, formerly located in the Hotel Biltmore, has arranged with the Women's City Club for the use of its assembly room in International Building on Rockefeller Plaza for the two evening meetings held every month.
Local chapters of the American Red Cross began campaigns yesterday to meet quotas set for them by the National organization in the $500,000 relief fund for rehabilitation of storm and flood victims.
An extra dividend of 71 cents a share was voted yesterday on the $1.25 participating preferred shares of the Greenwich Gas Company. A dividend of 24 cents a share on the common stock also was voted.

" Death from the air" means one thing to war-threatened Europe. It means something different now to the Northeastern United States, where it was demonstrated last week that Nature's own fury of wind and rain can be as destructive as man's metallic showers from the skies.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Sept. 23: COLONEL Sparks, L. C., F.A., General Staff Corps, one day leave, Sept. 26. LIEUTENANT COLONELS Jones, R. E., Inf., and Watts, W. H., Chaplain, promoted to Colonel.
Events have moved with such rapidity this week that no responsible observer would dare predict with certainty what their effects upon British foreign policy will be.
Mrs. Robert F. Lenington, a missionary of the Presbyterian Church in the United States, died in Brazil on Monday, according to word received here yesterday. She was 63 years old.
Prime Minister J. B. M. Hertzog told the House of Assembly today that he was confident there would be no war. No country, he added, had a right to drag in South Africa should there be hostilities.
WITH that flair for titles which she showed when she called her book on Rossetti and his circle "Poor Splendid Wings," Frances Winwar, by drawing on Othello's lament,

Mr. and Mrs. Howard Sherwood Tierney of Greens Farms and Mr. and Mrs. Henry Beale Spelman of Fairfield gave a supper dance tonight at the Fairfield Country Club for their debutante daughters, Miss Gene E. Tierney and Miss Dorothy N. Spelman.
