Giovanni Martinelli of the Metropolitan Opera Company and Mile. Colette d'Arville, soprano of the Paris Opera Comique, will give a joint concert at the College of New Rochelle on Sunday evening, Oct. 16.

As the first step in a program of "information and education" on homes, home planning and housing, Life magazine in its current issue carries a portfolio of plans and statistics on financing various types of dwellings.

Many of New Hampshire's communities were gradually returning to normal today while every available agency was pressed into service in a rehabilitation program after floods and Wednesday's hurricane left the State in its most crippled condition in history.

In residential Hampstead today, air wardens walked along the quiet tree-lined streets, knocking on doors, and carrying three sizes of gas masks. Each warden fitted a mask to about 300 people and noted the measure required for each, preparatory to distribution.

The most immediate question left over from President Roosevelt's net failure at purging less than 100 per cent followers from the Democratic party--a failure mitigated only by the defeat of John J. O'Connor for the Democratic Congressional nomination in New York's Sixteenth district--is, of course: what will be do next?

When the Chiefs of the nation's railway unions meet in Chicago next Monday it is expected that they will announce an overwhelming vote of their members favoring a strike to resist a 15 per. cent wager reduction planned by the railroads for about 1,000,000 employes. It is believed they will set the strike date as Oct. 1.

Invitations will be sent out soon for the annual Autumn Ball, which will be held at the Tuxedo Club on Oct. 22. Final plans have been completed for the event, which is expected to be the largest Autumn Ball held here in many years.

AT first glance it doesn't promise to be the greatest musical comedy, or farce, or drama you ever saw. It promises, if anything, never to open at all. A "work light" suspended from above glows forlornly on a stage bare of "props"; in the dusky shadows actors not in costume recite in lines that mean nothing and, under the circum.

Overcome by the excitement preceding the wedding of her son, Mrs. Yetta Kaufman, 56 years old, of 8,814 Bay Parkway, Brooklyn, died of a heart attack at 11:30 o'clock last night during the pre-nuptial celebration in Gluckstern's Restaurant at 135 Delancey Street.

Thousands of Americans who had never before seen Mayor La Guardia became acquainted with his personality and objectives during the threeweek tour of the South and West which the Mayor will complete on Saturday, when he leaves this city for New York.

THE twenty-fifth annual exhibition by the- Allied Artists of America will be held from Oct. 16 to Oct. 31 at the American Fine Arts Building. A departure from the traditional limits of previous exhibitions to oil paintings and sculpture will be the inclusion of water-colors and mural sketches.

The latest consignment of gifts from American children to the children of Spain goes out this week, as part of the work which the Committee on World Friendship Among Children has been carrying on quietly for eleven years.

The Alexander Summer Company opened its new office building last week at the corner of Queen Anne Road and Cedar Lane, Teaneck, N. J. Alexander Summer is president of the firm. The structure will house more than fifty persons connecteq with the concern.

THE god of war who two decades ago rushed the development of radio by urgent de mands that shook research experts out of their peacetime, painstaking routine, now finds in his hands a device through which verbal bombasts and the rumble of war machines are heard round the earth.

Miss Florine Glenn, daughter of Mrs. James A. Glenn of South Boston, Va., and the late Mr. Glenn, was married to Nieland Burstall van Arsdale of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry P. van Arsdale of Omaha, yesterday afternoon at 32 Washington Square, the New York home of her aunt, Mrs. R. M. C. Glenn of Montclair, N. J., by the Rev. Gordon Wadhams.
Eight hundred visiting German war veterans were guests today at the West End residence of Sir Ian Hamilton, British Legion leader.

Registration to capacity is reported by many of the colleges and universities in New York and near-by States which have just begun their academic year or will open this week. In several instances notable increases in enrollment over last year have been recorded.

THE discovery of a human body in the ruins of a tumble-down cottage that has burned to the ground makes the beginning of as neat a baffler as we have encountered in some time. Positive identification of the body is impossible, but there is reason to believe that it is that of James Fenchurch, who occupied a confidential position in the British Defense Ministry and who is missing.

Temporary Assignments SERGEANT--James A. Giattini, from 110th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. office, Queens, for 1 day, from 4 P. M. Sept. 21. PATROLMEN--William T. Little, from 77th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. office, Kings, for 1 day, from 4 P. M. Sept. 16.
WHEN Peter Lorre, cherubic little badman of the movies, heard that the Nazis had seized power, he exclaimed, "There is no room in Germany for two such villains as Adolf Hitler and me."
The Tennessee football team rolled up 26 points against Sewanee in the first half today and then coasted to a 26-to-3 victory before more than 15,000 fans.

Prices for Manhattan real estate, as measured by recorded transfers, apparently stiffened during August, although there was a moderate seasonal decline in the number of transfers compared with the previous month.
The announcement of the appointment of several new executive officers and directors of Douglas L. Elliman Co. last week marked the promotion of several persons long associated with that firm.

Officials in charge of the Sugar Act called today for a sharp reduction in acreage and tonnage of cane sugar production for 1939 from the mainland cane sugar area, consisting of Florida and Louisiana.

Declaring that "bread and progress are of greater concern to us and to the American people as a whole than so-called traditions," the Workers Alliance pledged its full support to day to President. Roosevelt if he sought a third term.
EIGHT new exhibitions opened last week, emphasizing the approach of renewed activities in the New York art world after the lull of the Summer months.

THE stamp collector's major interest centers today on Czechoslovakia. It is history that political, military and geographical developments profoundly affect his hobby, and the current Czech situation holds out so many possibilities of varying character that numerous intriguing questions logically arise as to the immediate postal future of this land of Sokol and Falcon.

IF he isn't knee deep in associate producers, agents, scenarists, directors, musical arrangers, press agents and people wanting him to endorse something, John Payne at the moment is undoubtedly somewhere on the California seacoast concentrating on a sun tan.

The high hopes long entertained by President Roosevelt that he might be able at a propitious moment to offer the world his leadership for peace have been dashed, temporarily at least, by the European events of this week, if competent political and diplomatic opinion here can be accepted at its face value.

The proposal of Representative Bruce Barton, Republican, to reddce the, size of Congress by half was attacked yesterday by Walter H. Liebman, his Democratic opponent, as a plan of reactionaries to "scuttle our representative system of government and to subvert the Constitution."

The Nash-Kelvinator Corporation announced today that due to labor difficulties all of its Nash automobile plants in Wisconsin would close down the night of Sept. 26. The corporation operates Nash plants at Kensosha and Racine and the Seaman body Corporation, which makes bodies for its cars, in Milwaukee. for its cars, in Milwaukee.

NOT thunders over Europe or adventures along trails far flung about the globe are the concern of Colonel Powell in this latest book of his among so many. He writes here about his own home town. And that town is Syracuse, in New York State, founded on salt and named Salina until the rage for names from cl assical antiquity swept the country.

Sonny Jones, Edmonton, Alberta, negro boxer, scored a technical nockout over Mike (Kid) Frattini ?? Italy in 1:47 of the sixth session ?? the scheduled ten-round feature out at the opening of the ?? in Rockland Palace last night.
Harold Kaplan, Queens builder, has just completed a group of medium-priced homes in his Ridgedale community at Sixtieth Avenue and Fresh Pond Road in the Ridgewood section of Queens Borough.

BROADCASTERS have been notified that the Federal Communications Commission will open hearings on Oct. 24 in its investigation of network broadcasting, monopoly in the broadcasting industry and related matters.

Due to the interest shown in the "house of color" put on exhibition last week in Strathmore-at-Great Neck, L. I., it will be kept open to the public for an "indefinite period," William J. Levitt, president of Devitt Sons, builders, anonunced yesterday.
Dr. Theo Morell, physician to Field Marshal Hermann Goering, issued a communique today announcing that his patient, who became ill during the Nuremberg Party Congress two weeks ago, was well again.

There is, to be sure, an atoll in the Pacific, in the Low or Dangerous Archipelago, about 20 degrees south of the Equator and 150 degrees west of Greenwich. Sometimes the ocean is a murmur and sometimes it is a thunder. Sometimes the inhabitants run up the palm tree trunks and cling there while wind and spray whip past their ears and the tide drives clear over into the inner harbor.

Panzer College upset East Stroudsburg, 7-0, at Nutley High School Field as the two teams opened their football season today. Forced back to its 20-yard line at the start of the final period, East Stroudsburg sent Eddie Praislier back to punt.
Society on the North Shore has turned its interest to fox-hunting, following the drag hounds and attending horse shows and race meetings.

WEEK-END hiking has strongly blossomed out in Paris this Fall, and the presence of thousands of young Jewish refugees, boys and girls, is playing a large part in making the notoriously unathletic Parisians hike-conscious.

The Georgia School of Technology this month celebrates a most important anniversary. On Oct. 8 exactly fifty years will have elapsed since this famous institution first opened its doors at Atlanta, and on that date its golden jubilee will be celebrated with an elaborate program of exercises, lasting throughout the day.
The Rev. Dr. Wyllys Rede of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Maryland died at the Duke University Hospital, Durham, N. C., in his eightv-fifth year.

The Chandler act, amending the Federal Bankruptcy Act, became effective last Thursday, and credit men and bankruptcy lawyers were concerned over the confusion attendant upon the transition from one law to another.
Robert V. White, Philadelphia, asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for an order authorizing him to hold the position of president of the Lehigh New England Railway Company.

A bee bested a homing pigeon in a half-mile race staged here today by two young apiarists and a pigeon fancier. The bee, an Italian drone, buzzed across the finish line four seconds ahead of its adversary, a blue checker white-flight hen. The winner's time was 4 minutes 56 seconds.

A NNOUNCEMENTS continue to arrive of activities planned for a season which promises to be not only a full but an interesting one. There are still many dancers who usually do not allow a season to go by without some local appearances, yet to be accounted for, but here is a further list to supplement those that have gone before.

For the first time in many years it is likely that both major parties will have to use the "draft" to get a candidate for Governor of New York State. It is altogether probable that it will be a case of the

The W. R. Smith property, consisting of eighty-seven acres with more than 3,000 feet of frontage on Long Island Sound and South Cove, at Saybrook, Conn., will be offered at auction by Major William Kennelly on Oct. 4 in the Real Estate Exchange on Vesey Street, Manhattan.
With Mexico fearful that European developments may eliminate the German market for expropriated American and British oil, two tankers started to load here at dawn today for a dash to Hamburg.

IN the Modern Gallery at Prague may be seen a figure by Jan IStursa (reproduced) that--as the writer remarked in these columns some years ago, at the time of a visit to Czechoslovakia-exemplifles a plastic achievement as gratifying as it is exceptional.

WHILE Broadway and its devotees are, or should be, standing tiptoe and atingle on the threshold of a new season, theatregoers of Rio de Janeiro, who steer their course stageward by the Southern Cross instead of the North Star, find satisfaction in contemplating a season which has brought many delights but is now drawing rapidly to its close.
A flickering hope that the peace of Europe might after all be preserved turned back yesterday a stock market that at the opening assumed all the proportions of runaway liquidation.

All carrier pigeons in this frontier region must be destroyed immediately under military orders. This notice, posted with mobilization and requisition orders, called upon owners of carrier pigeons to kill the birds and present the bodies to the local Town Hall as proof.

Richard L. Strobridge, chairman of the forthcoming annual campaign of the Welfare Federation of Yonkers, announced yesterday the appointment of division leaders. The drive, to aid thirteen social welfare agencies, will be held Nov. 9 to 23. The goal is as yet unannounced.
A stubborn cadet football team from Penn Military College was defeated by Lehigh University Engineer's before a crowd of 7,000 in Taylor Stadium this afternoon. The score was 16 to 13.

Another step in the latest attempt by the Government to set up minimum prices for bituminous coal will be taken with the hearings announced by the National Bituminous Coal Commission for Oct. 10 at Washington. From the earliest days of NRA the Government has struggled to bring some sort of order out of an industry which has experienced demoralizing price-cutting and cutthroat competition.

THE final round of the national singles tennis championship at Forest Hills yesterday brought a couple of roommates together in the open air. Mako vs. Budge. That's the same-as Damon vs. Pythias, or almost like Castor vs. Pollux.
USUALLY we have to wait two or three weeks before a new season yields a mature piece of work.

Youth, as typified by two checker b champions of the Park Depart- b ment's playgrounds, won over age yesterday in a special tournament to determine "the open champion" in this sport, held in the recreation building of Heckscher Playground near the Fifty-ninth Street entrance of Central Park.

Various party candidates, speaking at the annual pre-campaign cocktail party of the New York Young Democratic Club at the Commodore Hotel yesterday, warned Democrats against allowing the Republicans to "befog" the "true issues" by making the election a contest of "personalities."

IT is not news that invention has had much to do with the development on this continent of a civilization different in many respects from any that exists or has existed elsewhere. The difficulty is in explaining why. Why are we so unlike England, France, Germany, Italy? Why does capitalistic America possess such a fascination for communistic Russia?

Thomas J. Grahame of 277 Park Avenue, first vice president of the Globe Indemnity Company, died yesterday in the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital. Mr. Grahame, who was 52 years old, had been in poor health for more than a year.

A plan which provides fire insurance on buildings in course of construction for the life of a job by a single policy taken out by the owner at the beginning of the work has been developed and made available by the American Institute of Architects and the Associated General Contractors of America, according to a circular issued jointly by these organizations yesterday.

VERYBODY lives more lives than one, says Claude Bragdon; and several lives at the same time, what is more. But not many people live lives so distinct, so interesting, each in. own way so solid; as his have been. Not many people live so many lives as Claude Bragdon, for the matter of that.

The University of Texas Longhorns spotted the University of Kansas Jayhowks 19 points in a torrid -football game today, then were robbed of a tie by a placekick that zoomed outside the uprights in the final 45 seconds of play. The score was Kansas 19, Texas 18.

Led by Dick Metz of Lake Forest, Ill., the second half of the field, numbering 181 and containing the nation's best, swung into action in the longest tournament of the year, the 108 hole open, over the Fenway Golf Club course today

In its recent population report, the National Resources Committee, which estimated a population peak within the next fifty years of approximately 158,000,000, then to be followed by a gradual decline, pointed out that this impending cessation in population need give no cause for alarm.

DANGERS of after-dark automobile driving are being lessened as progress continues in safety lighting of highways throughout the country. "Indirect" lighting, provided by a series of new-type reflectors along the roadside, has been installed on eighty-five miles of highway between Detroit and Lansing, Mich.

Captain Larry Durrell and the veteran Timmy King led Williams to a 13-to-0 victory over the highly touted Middlebury Panthers on Weston Field today to inaugurate the Williams 1938 season before a crowd of 2,500.

IT is James Farrell's crude, slow, massive and undeniably forceful accumulation of the sensory impressions of a few central observers such as Studs Lonigan and Danny O'Neill that has led critics to call him a photographic realist.
Picked teams from the Negro American and Negro National Leagues will meet in an all-star game this afternoon at the Polo Grounds.
HENRY PURCELL'S opera "Dido and Aeneas" will be presented by the Peninsula Philharmonic Society of Newport News, Va., nightly at 8:30 o'clock, Oct. 3-8, at the Parish House in Williamsburg, Va.
Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Pope Vason of this city have announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Julia Beall Todd of Atlanta and New York, to Leopold Seyffert Jr. of Philadelphia and New York.

The American Labor party has just opened the Labor Club at 63 West Forty-fourth Street, adjoining the Hotel Algonquin, to establish a central meeting place and 'to increase interest and membership in the party among persons inside and outside the trades union movement.

Charles Muller, newly elected Republican leader of the Seventh Brooklyn Assembly District, declared last night for the drafting of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey for the Republican nomination for Governor.
THE. hills are brown in Summer in Southern California, where Judy Van der Veer has her ranch. So this book is a record of Summer days--"here where hill shadows pattern a
The nation's newest first line destroyer, the U. S. S. Jouett, was launched today from the yards of the Bath Iron Works Corporation.

An owner who occupies a portion of a foreclosed property for his business is not required to pay rent to the mortgagee, according to a recent opinion rendered by Justice Cuff in denying a motion brought by the State Mortgage Commission.

About $200,000 in back wages was ordered paid by the Carlisle Lumber Company in a United States Circuit Court ruling today. The court, upholding the National Labor Relations Board, found the Onalaska (Wash.) company guilt of unfair labor practices.

John B. Long, general manager of the California Newspaper Publishers Association, told the State Bar Association last night that newspapers consider the contempt case against The Los Angeles Times and activities of the American Newspaper Guild "threats to the freedom of the press."

Henry Schloo, retired meat market owner, died early yesterday at his home, 141-26 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, Queens, at the age of 70. Mr. Schloo's father was a pioneer storekeeper of Corona, where the son was born.

The 500 Regular Army, NatiOnal Guard and Reserve officers who staffed the Second Army here in the theo'retical war between the Blues and the Blacks lack the thorough team-Work essential for. success in battie, Major Gen, Hugh A.Drum declared today, although 'he conceded their "individual expertness.
The staff of the Association of American Colleges is engaged at present in completing details for the programs of the annual meeting and the regional conferences to be held this Fall.
The Alleghany Corporation issued yesterday its first financial report to be prepared in accord with what the management believes to be the requirements of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

It is frequently said that while other nations may properly concern themselves with a nation's foreign policy, whatever form of government the people of that nation choose is purely their own affair. But recent events make clear that this is true only within certain limits.
All white blossoms and candles provided a decorative background today in St. Luke's Church here where Miss Camilla Morgan was married to Remsen Ditmars Donald by the rector, the Rev. Dr. John Harper.

ONE of the most thrilling expeditions in the world is a hunt among the high Andes for the shy and elusive vicufla and the still swifter and even more elusive Andean deer, known by its Quechua Indian name, taruca.

The Red Sox made one more hit than the Yankees yesterday at the Stadium, but that hit happened to be Jimmy Foxx's forty-eighth home run of the campaign, a majestic drive into the upper left-field tier.

Two fast-stepping, groundgaining backs, Arthur Jones and Lefty Lawless, sparked a fine University of Richmond attack today for a 19-to-6 victory over the University of Maryland in the Southern Conference season opener.

In a finish so close and thrilling that it caused 11,000 fans to cheer wildly, without restraint, for a full hour, the hardy German team of Gustav Kilian and Heinz Vopel rode through to triumph in the six-day bicycle race which came to an end at Madison Square Garden last night.

A new mile record of 4:14 for the Fordham University outdoor track was set yesterday by Archie San, Romani, New York Curb Exchange star, and furnished the high spot of a program of sports that featured Alumni Day on Rose Hill.

Mountaineer hopes of opening the 1938 football season with a staggering upset collapsed on this sunny afternoon as the rebuilt forces of Jock Sutherland's Pittsburgh Panthers crushed West Virginia, 19 to 0, before 35,000 spectators.
Slamming two pitchers for six hits and four runs in the tenth inning, the Senators beat the Athletics today, 7 to 3. Until the tenth George Caster had yielded only six hits.

The marriage of Miss Muriel Beyea, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Beyea, to William B. Hutchinson 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hutchinson Jr. of Leonia, took place here this afternoon at the home of her parents. The Rev. J. A. Ingham of Leonia Performed the ceremony.

Newell-Daniel announce that in celebration of the first anniversary tomorrow of their purchase of thirty-five acres in the Manhasset section of Long Island for their Flower Hill residential development, ground will be broken for the sixtieth dwelling in that community.

Fall classes in horticulture and ornamental gardening at Columbia University, under the direction of Professor Hugh Findlay, begin on Oct. 4. Besides lectures on the culture of various plants and soil preparation, students will have greenhouse practice and take garden field trips.

The regular meeting of the Board of Education will be held Wednesday at 4 P. M. at 500 Park Avenue. Action on assignment of new teachers to junior and senior high schools will be considered. Election of an associate superintendent to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Dr. John S. Roberts last Spring is also scheduled.
OF late John Steinbeck has had some pretty high adjectives hoisted above his name. But he will not have to strike his colors with this collectin of short stories.
EXILE: Students at Georgetown University will have an opportunity this Winter to learn about international affairs from an old hand. Last week it was announced that
Entrance to Czechoslovakia from Austria is now possible only through Bratislava, about forty miles from Vienna. All other roads are closed to private traffic and being reserved for troop movements.

Under ideal conditions, Nibble Hanover, owned by the Aiken (S.C.) Stable, won the forty-sixth renewal of the Kentucky Futurity for 2year-old trotters that featured to day's opening Grand Circuit card. He was driven by Harry Whitney.

J. Donald Budge defeated Gene Mako, 6-3, 6-8, 6-2, 6-1, to retain the United States championship. Having previously won the British, French and Australian titles, Budge became the first player in history to take all four of the world's major tennis crowns in the same year. Miss Alice Marble routed Miss Nancye Wynne, 6-0, 6-3, in the women's final.

The Chicago City Council is studyIng plans whereby private capital and private initiative may cooperate toward reclaiming the slum areas of the city. The City Council has requested the housing committee of that body to make recommendations as to whether the Council should request State legislation to permit the chartering of public service building corporations or devise other methods.

Hopeful of retaining their position at the top in the Eastern Division of the National Football League and fully aware of the power of the strengthened Eagles, the New York Football Giants will swing into action at Philadelphia this afternoon.

To the Art Editor: Your correspondent, Miss Benjamin, who wrote inquiring about the pictures of William Page in last Sunday's NEW YORK TIMES, will be interested to know that the Detroit Institute of Arts has two of Page's most important works, a self-portrait and the portrait of his wife.
The Pirate preserved their blender twogame advantage in the National League pennant proceedings today by whipping the Reds, 4 to 1, behind Russ Bauers's sparkling sixhit pitching.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor R. Callahan, daughter of Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Callahan of the Appellate Division, First Department, and the late Mrs. Callahan, to James C. Healey, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Healey of the Bronx, took place yesterday morning in the Church of the Sacred Heart, High Bridge.

Riverdale House, the new gardentype apartment house at 474 West 238th Street, in the Riverdale section, has been completed and opened, Armino and Michael Campagna, builders, reported yesterday. Some of the apartments already have been rented.

Sharp increases for every major line of business in New York City, as a result of the World's Fair here next year, were predicted yesterday in a detailed study of possibilities by S. A. Rauch, business consultant.
The hurricane which last week swept up the Atlantic Coast, ripped through Long Island and New England and vanished in the Arctic regions of Canada was no freak.
For many years the writer, in common with many garden lovers, has cherished rather mixed feelings about hyacinths.
Nathan Straus, housing administrator, said today that the Federal Authority was preparing to earmark $10,000,000 next week for slum clearance and low-cost housing projects in Puerto Rico.

A PPROXIMATELY four cen turies after the founding of the first permanent settle ment in Paraguay, but not in the precise anniversary year, the South American inland republic has issued two stamps, 5-pesos olivegreen and lip chocolate-brown, commemorating the establishment of Asuncion, the capital city.

With fifteen different builders preparing to erect a total of 1,592 private homes at a cost aggregating $8,750,000 in the vicinity of Juniper Valley Park at Elmhurst, L. I., that section is one of the leading centers of private home building in the New York area, points out Stewart Willey, builder of the Juniper Park Homes in that section.

Some helpful suggestions are presented by a housing expert to the home owner planning to brighten up his rooms by some repainting. The first thing essential after deciding to paint a room or some interior or exterior woodwork is to approximate the surface to be covered and the color desired.

The Phoenix Securities Corporation issued yesterday a statement regarding the "derivative action" started against Loft, Inc., and itself by a stockholder of Loft complaining of the action of that company in granting to Phoenix Securities options on 400,000 shares of Loft stock and the exercising of 2 such options.
A new palm better adapted to household use than any previously available has been added to the rather limited selection of plants which are well adapted for growing In apartments and dwelling houses.

John F. Sweeney, former New York police inspector, who became the first Chief of Police of Long Beach in January, 1926, a post he held for four years, died at his home here today after a brief illness, at the age of 77. Flags throughout the city were lowered to half staff in his honor.

The Rev. Theodore A. Fisener, pastor of the Church of the Messiah for thirty-two years, died last night in New Haven Hospital following a minor operation at the age of 65. He was president of the Connecticut Universalist Convention.

Miss Blanche Adele Evans, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Evans of Westfield, was married to the Rev. Harold B. Wright Jr. of Sparrowbush, N. Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold B. Wright of Westfield, in the chapel of Drew University, Madison, this afternoon.

Senator Carter Glass of Virginia, whom President Roosevelt has called "the unreconstructed rebel," gave his definitions today, of a "liberal" and a "conservative." "A liberal is a man who is willing to spend somebody else's money," said Mr. Glass.

Production and distribution will show slow but steady gains through the Fall months, members of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents predicted yesterday in their monthly report on current business activity.
Senator William H. King of Utah declared today that only determined joint action by the democratic nations could block the "predatory course" of Germany, Italy and Japan.

As a means of curtailing the deterioration of many of the higher grade older communities in various parts of the country, F. W. Norris, Boston home builder, suggests the desirability of a diversion of the present residential building activity toward the reconstruction of such neighborhood areas.

TO develop artists, not specialists in one phase of the theatre, is the avowed aim of the recently founded American Conservatory of Music, Drama and Dance, which opens Oct. 17. With this end in view the curriculum will embrace general teaching in all three fields to which the school is dedicated before instruction is offered along particular lines.

MANHATTAN CLARK. SARAH AGNES (Sept. 18). Estate, more than $10,000. To Charles Carr, Jersey City, real estate; Agnes McLaughlin. 288 St. Nicholas Ave., $2.000 and residue; two minor bequests. Thomas L. J. Curran, 18 E. 41st St., executor.

Miss Dorothy Day, the daughter of Mrs. Frederick A. Day of this city, was married this afternoon to Arthur P. Funk, son of Mrs. George Funk of Bristol. The ceremony was performed in the Prospect Methodist Church by the Rev. Dr. L. H. Dorchester of Groton Long Point and the Rev. Paul DuBois, pastor of the church.

Double personality seems to be spreading. As majority leader of the Senate Mr. Barkley hews to the line drawn by the Administration. As a loyal party man he offers to succor his Democratic brethren, be they goats or sheep. "If Senator Tydings felt he needed my help, I would go there the same as for any one else." If Mr.
The reduction in bread prices has stimulated sales of the higher-price loaves substantially in the last two weeks, according to reports yesterday from both bakers and retailers.

Brig. Gen. Walter C. Short, commander of the First Brigade and First Division, United States Army, will arrive in Camp Dix tomorrow with his staff to direct the annual brigade manoeuvress that will begin here Monday. Units of the brigade have been massing here since Wednesday.

Upsala College of East Orange, N. J., upset Muhlenberg on the gridiron today by a score of 14 to 13. The victors scored touchdowns in the first and third quarters, with Knox converting both extra points. Muhlenberg scored its two touchdowns in the first period.
At a total estimated cost of $90,000, the New York Military Academy is erecting a group of eleven dwellings on its campus here for occupancy by faculty ' members and their families.

Newell Daniel, developers, have added to their holdings in the Flower Hill section of Manhasset, L. I., by purchasing fourteen acres adjoining their present operations on the east, just north of the Munsey Park section.

A small gathering of society attended the fortieth running of the Meadow Brook Cup this morning on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark and after the onehour program of racing dispersed to attend informal luncheons in the neighborhood and hurry on to the tennis matches, polo and the Belmont Park races.
Landon Phelps, 20 years old, of Mount Kisco, N. Y., a student air pilot, escaped with minor bruises today when a two-place biplane he

A strong demand for properties in Orange County, N. Y., is reported by Harry Vail, Warwick broker. Among the parcels he re gently sold was the 450-acre De Kay estate, which was purchased by H. C. Coster.

Minnesota's Golden Gophers hurled another sharp challenge to the football world today, defeating the Washington Huskies, 15 to 0, before 50,000 persons in a game closely fought for the first half only.

The St. John's Prep football team inaugurated its 1938 campaign by dropping a 6-0 decision to the Brooklyn College junior varsity at Boys High Field yesterday morning. The game was also the first of the season for the winners.
The gold-and-black Commodores of Vanderbilt University took advantage of three breaks to defeat Washington University, 20 to 0, in an intersectional football game today before a crowd of 5,000.

Defeated for United States Senator by young Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. in 1936 and prevented from returning to his old job as Mayor of Boston by young Maurice J. Tobin in 1937, 64-year-old James Michael Curley dumfounded the wiseacres and probably slightly surprised himself by running away with the Democratio nomination for Governor in Tuesday's primary.
The Dartmouth Indians, as impressive as they were last seasonwhen they escaped defeat, opened their football campaign today by swamping a courageous but nexperienced Bates team, 46-0.

An injury to Bill Stack, firststring center, forced Head Coach Ducky Pond to shift Captain Bill Platt to the pivot post today and experiment with several tackle candidates to fill the Yale football leader's former job.

THE casual visitor to Washington may not guess it, but one of the most active Federal agencies in the national capital during these intersession months is housed in a tomblike structure on Pennsylvania Avenue, and is devoted to the preservation of documents which have long since ceased to be of practical importance to the departments of government

NORRIS DAM, Tenn. EVEN in this cooler weather the Tennessee Valley Authority policeman perspires freely as he directs streams of vehicular and pedestrian traffic across the top of Norris Dam, on the Clinch River, twenty-four miles north of Knoxville.

Sir Philip Dawson, Conservative Member of Parliament for West Lewisham since 1921, died in a Berlin hospital today, according to word received here, at the age of 71. He was returning from a conference in Warsaw.
Propagandist activities among the German inhabitants of Danish Slesvig are increasing as a result of the crisis over Czezchoslovakia.

Praise of the United States as a nation in which racial and class hatreds have not been allowed to produce the strife that threatens Europe was voiced last night by Governor Lehman in an address at a dinner of the United Italian Associations in the Hotel Commodore.

The prospect of failure in Columbia College is greatest for the bright student who was quickwitted enough to "float" through high school, doing a minimum of work, Dean Herbert E. Hawkes warned 550 freshmen yesterday in the McMillin Academic Theatre, Broadway at 116th Street.
Construction work will begin Tuesday in Buffalo on a 668-family lowrental housing project which will have a unit cost of less than $1,000 a room, the United States Housing Authority announced today.

A total of $23,174,278 was expended from State and local funds for general relief in 105 selected urban areas in August, an increase of per cent over the amount spent in July, the Social Security Board announced today on the basis of voluntary reports from State and local agencies.

The surrender of the Sudeten German areas of Czechoslovakia to Germany would mean-strategically--that the last "bastion" of Europe had fallen before Chancellor Hitler, in the opinion of military men here.
" I SHOULD like the benefit of editing, with omissions, the book of my acts and thoughts,"
Columbia High School's eleven, undefeated last season, continued its winning streak in the opening game of the season today by disposing of Lincoln High School of Jersey City,. 47 to 0.
James Thompson (Doc) Prothro announced tonight his resignation as manager of the Little Rock Travelers of the Southern Association.

On Oct. 24 in the State Education Building at' Albany, the seventyfourth convention of the University of the State of New York will commemorate the 300th anniversary of the founding of the first common school in New York State.

THREE exhibitions of the work of photographers are now on display at various points. In the lobby of the Western Union Building at 60 Hudson Street, the Western Union Camera Club is exhibiting a series of eight portraits made at a recent meeting and fifty candid pictures.

One of the first municipalities to take advantage of the law recently adopted in New Jersey empowering private sale by municipal authorities of any land and buildings it owns, but does not need is Mountain'Lakes, residential community in Morris County.

Rents for both single-family dwellings and apartments showed a "definite" increase during August, according to the index compiled by Real Estate Analysts, Inc., for the National Association of Real Estate Boards on the basis of reports from metropolitan centers in all parts of the country.

Charles J. Margiotti, former State Attorney General, today accused David L. Lawrence, Democratic State Chairman, and Edward Prendergast, secretary to Governor Earle, of demanding that two deputy attorneys general be dismissed for not paying "political assessments" to the Democratio organization.

Two new records were set and two 1937 champions were beaten when the first half of the Metropolitan Association A. A. U. senior women's outdoor track and field championship program was completed yesterday at Macombs Park.

One of the important actions of the recent meeting in Zurich, Switzerland, of the International Congress of Building Societies was the formation of the International Union of Building Societies and Savings and Loan Associations.

THE thing about being an author, or an adaptor, or at any rate not having to get up on the stage and do it myself, is that I can be completely detached," I said happily to my husband some time last June.
No matter how big a household one runs, for a family or for living alone; the chores can be made lighter with some of the new things in the shops.

With Jack O'Donnell accounting for both touchdowns, Coach Jack Lavelle's All Hallows Institute football team began its campaign by halting St. Agnes of Sparkhill, N. Y., 12-0, at the Castle Hill Athletic Field yesterday.

LONDON.--After centuries of more or less haphazard protection against fire, Britain's fire brigades are now to be organized on a national basis. Heretofore, local authorities could provide a firefighting service or not as it suited them. But now, under the terms of a bill passed by Parliament, such protection is made compulsory.
Displaying a powerful ground attack, Holy Cross scored in every quarter today and trounced Provi dence College, 28 to 0, before 12,000 football fans.

THE year A. D. 1789 was significant on both sides of the Atlantic, and while America is celebrating the 150th anniversary of the United States Constitution France will be observing the sesquicentennial of another epoch-making event in world history, namely, the French Revolution.

Racing craft still in commission after the ravages of the hurricane competed today in the final championship regatta of the Yacht Racing AssociaLion of-Long Island Sound, held at the American Yacht Club.

All visitors to the special preview yesterday of the American Hobby Show found their way sooner or later to a wall where brightly colored, sharply worded posters were prominently displayed. They looked odd, these posters, among the plaster models of prizefighters' fists and crocheted houses.

More than 500 controllers from all parts of the country are expected to attend the seventh annual meeting of the Controllers Institute of America, which will open tomorrow morning at the Hotel WaldorfAstoria and continue through Tuesday.
Martial law continues in this city tonight, but the three-day emergency created by fire, water and wind is rapidly passing.
WHEN you have finished reading "Dialogo dei Massimi Sistemi" you feel either that you know everything about its author, Tommaso Landolfi, or that you know nothing at all.

This critical week-end finds the Czechs battered but undaunted. This week has seen the republic run through the whole gamut of emotions. First it was national confidence and pride as a necessary preparation for a self-defensive war in which the Czechoslovak Army had a very definite role to fulfill.

Remodeling of the house once occupied by Mark Twain at 14 West Tenth Street to provide ten threeroom apartments will be completed to pertnit occupancy by Oct. 1, according to Wm. A. White Sons, agentRs.

THE first anniversary of the American Contract Bridge League passed very quietly last week, while a small group in the Midwest who are planning the establishment of an opposition "national bridge league" were being even more quiet about their plans.

The recent State Constitutional Convention, as its president saw it, and his impressions of the new Constitution drafted for the voters this November, will be the opening presentation at THE NEW YORK TIMES Review-of-the-News Conference to be held at Cathedral House in Garden City, L. I.,next-Wednesday.

Governor Lehman laid the cor nerstone of the New York State Marine Amphitheatre and Exhibit Building at the World's Fair grounds yesterday and in a radio address accompanying the ceremony hailed the coming exposition as an opportunity for peoples from all parts of the world to gather and engage in "a freehand broad interchange of ideas and views."
Mrs. C. Y. Bennett's Pylon II, by Pharos from Puramid, today won the Newbury Autmumn Cup over two and an eighteenth miles, defeating Sir Harold Gray's Snake Lighting by two lengths.

" THE town is German, the countryside is German, the people are German! And at last Salzburg has experienced with indescribable joy together with all Austria, the greatest day of her history--her homecoming to the 'Reich'!

A furious Tide of Crimson from Alabama swept through vast Memorial Coliseum today, carrying before it the hopes of the Southern -California football team. The defeat by 19 to 7 once again postponed the Trojans' return to gridiron greatness. A gathering of 65,000 saw the game.

Morgan (Mugs) Gingrass, Northern Michigan Teachers College quarterback, bid for a spot in the record books today by making a 102-yard touchdown dash with an intercepted forward pass as his team defeated Oshkosh, Wis., Normal, 13 to 0.

Owners of apartment buildings in which strikes were called on Friday, notably. on the upper West Side, by the. Building. Service Employes International Union, were urged yesterday by the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations to sign agreements with the union, as union spokesmen announced that eight of thirteen buildings "struck" had accepted contracts.

Wee Davey O'Brien, Texas Christian's 150-pound thunderbolt, pitched a couple of poisonous passes-one for a gain of 65 yards, the other for 47--that buried Centenary's Gents, 13--0, in the Southwest's top curtain-raiser today.
MR. COOKE should be a happy writer because he can accept people as they are. So he has all the world to write about and need never fear sterility.
SAN FRANCISCO will see a new approach to the staging of Mozart's "Don Giovanni" in the course of Its opera season which begins next month.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I voted for Roosevelt in 1932 because I knew the country was in a hell of a mess. I thought that with this Man on Horseback coming in things would soon be straightened out. That Democratic platform sounded pretty good to me and appealed to my common sense.
ELY CULBERTSON, who could probably be described as one not apt to overlook a trick, has not only written a mystery novel but has dramatized it, which brings him into the ken of this column.

With Fall moving days at hand, New York housewives are busier than ever with homemaking problems. Packing and crating are among their immediate tasks, to be carried out in the midst of planning for the new apartment.

Setting a new record of 1:44 for the race, H. P. Headley's Menow showed a return to form today by winning the twentieth running of the Potomac Handicap, a $10,000 added test of a mile and a sixteenth.
Presldent Roosevelt remained in the Executive Mansion again today but Dr. Ross T. McIntire, the White House physician,

FROM the moment that Sifan loosens his girdle, opens his sheepskin garment, and is ready for the day, this story takes the young reader right into the heart of Tibet to follow with aroused interest in that country of curious customs the adventures of this native-boy.

Army found the University of Wichita easy prey in its opening football game today, burying the Kansas eleven under a 32-to-0 count. Ten thousand spectators viewed the contest, played in Michie Stadium in a beautiful autumnal setting.
Executing a dazzling flank attack from the sea, Skipper Bill Terry safely brought his Giants to port today and the feat utterly confounded Professor Casey Stengel.

Although office buildings are continuing to lag behind dwellings and apartment houses in whatever gains real estate may be experiencing, changing conditions may bring improvement to the office building field sooner than expected, in the opinion of Robert L. Stearne, a director of the Philadelphia Real Estate Board.

Recovering from its brief setback, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has overcome its last decline and moved to a new high for the year. For the week ended Sept. 17 it stands at 85.9, which compares with 84.5 for the previous week and 104.9 for the corresponding week last year.

The succession of four weekly declines in business loans that has been shown by the reporting member banks, of the Federal Reserve System in this city has raised new doubts about the prospects of genuine business recovery this Autumn.

Harold Sloan, head of the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, is erecting a studio guest house adjoining his Summer home at Lake Mohawk, Sussex County, N. J. It will contain a large living room, bedroom, electrically equipped kitchen and bath.

Scoring with a rush after a desultory start, Sonny Whitney's national open championship Old Westbury team today defeated Johnny Schiff's Roslyn four to reach the semi-final round of the Monty Waterbury Cup polo tourney which determines the United States handicap title.

Pasquale Pilla, 43 years old, of 2,342 Haviland Avenue, the Bronx, shot himself to death early-yesterday morning in his home because, the police believe, he thought he had killed a neighbor, Mrs. Elizabeth Oberman, 35, who rents the first floor of the same house.
WHOEVER is master of Bohemia is master of Europe," Bismarck said long ago; his words have found an echo in the driving policy of Adolf Hitler.
SIXTEEN Sunday evening chamber music concerts at Town Hall under the auspices of the New Friends of Music will be broadcast between Oct.- 23 and Feb. 19, from 6 to 7 o'clock, through WJZ's network.
Miss Patricia Ford Schlotman and William Moore Joy were married this afternoon in the Grosse Pointe Memorial Church by the Rev. Frank Fitt.

While Europe has been seething this week, what has the League of Nations been doing? It has gathered here for its Assembly all the Foreign Ministers of the European member States, with the significant exception of Great Britain and Frances--both absent for the first time in a dozen years--Poland, Yugoslavia and Portugal. They have been looking on with horror and fear--or panic.
The Erskine Hewitt collection of early American art will be sold at a five-session sale beginning Oct. 18 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, it was announced yesterday.

Old-age-pension hopes are being exploited in Nebraska in a manner somewhat different from the California $30every-Thursday scheme, but-in one quite as disturbing to the economically sober folk of the State.

THOSE who read as they run probably did not notice it, but the newspapers of the metropolitan area last week carried a dramatic--and perhaps unintentional--commentary on the recent progress of commercial airline flying.

With August setting a new monthly high record of $4,000,000, a total of $16,240,000 in loans for repair and modernization work on buildings in the New York City area has been insured by the Federal Housing Administration since February, when the government again assumed. the insurance of such advances, State FHA Director Thomas G. Grace announced yesterday.
The Official Gazette today printed an expropriation decree nationalizing 5,000 acres in Cayuco, in the State of Oaxaca, belonging to United States citizens.

Proof that outboard drivers during the 1938 season were giving their all in a mad scramble for honors and acclaim is seen in the tabulations of James W. Mulroy of Chicago, now that the racing year is over except for the last gasp.
Members of the United States Army equestrian team that will compete this Fall in the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden w re appointed today. The captain of the team is Major John T. Cole.

Some interesting facts regarding farmhouse conveniences and living standards in different sections of the country were revealed in a survey recently conducted jointly by the Departments of Commerce and Agriculture.

The Bears pushed over a run in the ninth inning today to nose out Buffalo, 6 to 5, in the first game of their four-out-of-seven play-off series for the International League Governors' Cup and the right to meet the American Association winner in the little world series.

Only a short time after Representative O'Connor of New York, the tenth Democrat blacklisted for renomination to Congress by the President's "elimination committee," had, unlike the nine others, lost his party primary, National Chairman Farley made a speech in Ohio.

For the second day of its leadership training course, the New York City League of Women Voters will hear on Thursday a symposium on "The Leader as Administrator." Heads of local units will take part in the discussion of problems submitted before the afternoon session.

FIRST MILITARY AREA Major Percy C. Fleming, Field Artillery, will proceed, on or about Sept. 29, from Utica. N. Y., to Gloversville, N. Y., on temporary duty in connection with the training of Organized Reserves, and upon completion of this duty will return to Utica, N. Y.

A Bronx division office of the three-cents-a-day plan of the Associated Hospital Service of New York will be opened tomorrow at 226 Fordham Road, according to an announcement yesterday by Frank Van Dyk, executive director of the service.

THE big French couturiers have been exceptionally kind to women this Winter, especially when it comes to evening styles. They have made it possible for them to say which type they wish to follow: the old-fashioned hoop-skirt beauty or the slim modern sylph.
Mrs. John C. Dempsey of 153-32 Forty-first Avenue, Flushing, Queens, former well known charity worker, died on Thursday at the age of 84.

Sister Catharine, Superior of the Community of St. John the Evangelist, died yesterday morning in the Sister House, 492 Herkimer Street, Brooklyn, adjoining St. John's Hospital which she served for nearly sixty years. Her ninetieth birthday was observed on Wednesday.

Repre sentatives of railroad employes in fourteen States were on record today as opposed to extension or enlargement of Federally operated barge lines through the medium of the Inland Waterways Corporation.

Dorothy Schaffter, Associate Professor of Political Science at Vassar College, from which she is on a sabbatical leave to pursue housing studies on a grant from the Carnegie Corporation, has assumed the chairmanship of the New York Women's Committee of the National Public Housing Conference.

MR. SALT writes clearly and cleanly, with a certainty of style that is never complacent and never arrogant. He has done most of his work in the very short poem. It is a difficult medium unless one turns it into facile imagism or witty epigram.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Addison Rennolds of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beulah Branch Rennolds, to Bowles Armistead Burke, son of Dr. and Mrs. M. O. Burke, also of Richmond.

Dr. Roy L. Black- men mon scored a 39 to take low gross honors in the nine-hole qualifying round of the New York Athletic Club's annual Fall week-end golf tournament on the Buckwood Inn course today. William J. Waite and S. R. Milburn shared the low net prize, each carding 42-8-34.

Retail trade made scattered gains last week, but losses were substantial where they occurred. The sharp reductions in New England were not computed, but were tremendous in such cities as Providence, Springfield, Hartford and New Haven, and heavy in Boston, Worcester and the smaller cities of Southeastern Massachusetts.

Frank Gannett, publisher of the Gannett newspapers, said today that "only a free press" stands be tween the American citizenship and 'one-man rule." Mr. Gannett replied, in a radio speech to attacks by Senator Minton in what he termed Mr. Minton's "efforts to gag the press."

With hunters and saddle horses predominating, the Pocantico Hills Horse Show will be held today at the Sleepy Hollow Farms, North Tarrytown, N. Y. Saddle horses in the open and championship division will be pitted against Marvin Y. Bell's chestnut mare Promenade, winner of six championships, one grand championship and twenty-seven blues to date.

Out of a total of 1,021,587 loans made by the Home Owners Loan Corporation, 36,825 accounts aggregating $84,005,975 had been repaid by Aug. 1, according to Charles A. Jones, general manager of the corporation.

With the end of daylight saving time at 2 A. M. today, millions of persons in New York City and elsewhere were expected to have set back their timepieces one hour before retiring last night. Many of them were also expected to avail themselves of the extra hour for sleep.

The new Central Nurses Residence on Welfare Island has just been opened for service. It is the first major building to be completed In the long-range program of the Department of Hospitals to reclaim the island as a place of healing for the city's sick, and it reflects the increasing emphasis on better living conditions for the city's nursing staff in the five boroughs.

The superior manpower of Georgia's Bulldogs was extended to the limit today in overcoming The Citadel, 20 to 12, before 7,000 spectators. The contest marked the debut of Georgia's new coach, Joel Hunt.

Gold promises to become acutely embarrassing. The United States now holds more than $13,500,000,000 of it, about 56 per cent of the world's stock. The figure and the percentage are rising steadily, even in peacetime. If there were a war, experts figure, another $5,000,000,000 would come flooding in.

The National Hockey League, recently reduced to seven clubs when the Montreal Maroons' franchise was suspended, decided today to operate as a single unit during the 1938-39 season instead of following the old twogroup plan.

The Connecticut River was receding early this morning at slightly better than two inches an hour, and what probably will be known here from now on as the 'Battle of Colt's Dike" appeared to have been won for good.

Mr. Chamberlain took along William Strang, a Foreign Office official knowing German, and Herr Hitler had Dr. Paul Schmidt of the German Foreign Office.

Britain laid Germany's peace terms before the Czechoslovak Minister yesterday with no attempt 'to dictate acceptance. They set Oct. 1 as the final date for transfer of Sudetenland to the Reich and refused guarantee of the remaining frontiers unless Poland and Hungary agreed.
Ernest C. Jarvis, head of a stamp a, collection firm, said today that he had been authorized to offer for the first time in the open market what he said was the world's rarest stamp.

Mrs. Edmund H. Cahill, president of the State Federation of Music Clubs, and Mrs. Edgar Stillman-Kelley will be guests of honor at a reception to be given on Friday at the Hotel Astor by the Dramatic and Musical Assembly. Mrs. Marine Springer is president of the hostess group.

Paul R. Gelling told today how he fought and vanquished a hawk that attacked him without provocation. Colling said that he was getting the cows in his pasture when the big bird swooped at him, grasped his thumb in a talon, beat him with its wings and attacked him with its beak.

Three series of lectures on landscape architecture, gardening arrangement and kindred subjects will be given during the coming Winter and Spring under the auspices of Columbia University on the old estate of the Alexander Hamilton family, known as Nevis, at Irvington, overlooking the Hudson River.

American manufacturers have a definite opportunity to increase their sales volume in Argentina, as well as other Latin-American countries, Thomas L. Barratt, managing director of N. W. Ayer Son, S. A., said yesterday as he left for Buenos Aires.

SIX years ago a slim blond girl who earned her living in the beauty salon of a Fifth Avenue department store presented herself at Roosevelt Field. L. I., and announced: "I'm starting on a six-week vacation and I want to spend it learning to fly. Do you think I can learn enough in that time to get my pilot's license?"

Magic Hour and Dinner Date captured the Lawrence Realization and Matron Stakes, respectively, before 20,000 persons at Belmont Park yesterday to give both the East and West a share in the main prizes.
Duke University opened its season tonight by scoring an 18-0 victory over Virginia Polytechnic Institute in a Southern Conference game.

Last week the New York City school system officially added a new $2,500,000 unit-the Brooklyn High School of Automotive Trades--to its educational plant. The doors closed with 2,500 boys-all bent on learning the various aspects of the automotive trade-enrolled for the four-year course.
Cardinal Pacelli, the Papal Secretary of State, was in a slight automobile accident today while returning to the Vatican- from Pope Pius's Summer residence here.

The government short-wave radio station at Prague, Czechoslovakia, whose call letters are OLR4A, stayed on the air without interruption again yesterday, repeating its performance of Friday when news bulletins were announced at regular intervals and occasional messages of importance were broadcast in the midst of musical numbers.

It used to be a sort of generally accepted practice-without any one's giving the matter much real thought--to carry out any needed remaking of the garden in the Spring. In recent years, however, there has been marked change in the attitude of both professional plantsmen and amateurs toward such remodeling.

The modernize for Winter" movement is expected to gain impetus from the downward trend of building material prices, as shown by the Federal Government reports from all sections of the country, in the opinion of the National Retail Lumber Dealers Association.

Main floor accessory sections and sportswear departments showed the most successful sales results in retail stores last week, according to a special summary prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.

During the first six months of the present year plans for the renovation of 230 tenement buildings on the lower East Side were filed with the Building Department, points out Joseph Platzker, secretary of the East Side Chamber of Commerce.
A warem sun shone down on hurricane-battered Long Island today, making the search for the bodies of Wednesday's disaster victims easier for the searchers and aiding rehabilitation of utility systems.

The Bronx Board of Trade hat written the members of the City Planning Commission urging that they take favorable action on the plans submitted to the commission by the Department of Public Works calling fop the improvement of two bridges which "form an important part of the Eastern Bbulevard development" in the Bronx.
The Rev. Dr. John Barr Dunlap, a retired missionary from the Siam Mission of the Presbyterian Church in the United States, died Thursday in Los Gatos, Calif. He was 78 years old.

Miss Charlotte-Marie Fenselau, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. John Fenselau of this place, was married to Charles Oliver Hall Jr. of East Orange, N. J., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hall, also of East Orange, this evening in the Huguenot Memorial Church here.
THE first retrospective exhibition of the work of Maurice J. and Charles Prendergast to be held in New England is now in progress at the Addison Gallery, Phillips Academy.

Defining the constitutional position of France regarding a declaration of war, Le Temps published the following: "It must be remembered that while in 1914 Germany declared war on France the situation is today entirely different, as it would be for France to declare war on Germany.

Residential accommodations in apartment houses as well as dwell ings for rent are becoming scarce in the Queens and Nassau sections of Long Island and in Brooklyn, Arthur J. Horton, vice president of the Bulkley Horton Company, reported yesterday.

An Institute of Leadership as a part of the program arranged for the New York World's Fair of 1939 by the National Council of Women will be discussed at the annual board meeting to be held on Thursday morning and afternoon at the Women's City Club in the International Building of Radio City. Mrs.

The street lights blinked here tonight for the first time since Wednesday's hurricane came upon the city. The State, which is trying hard to return to its normal existence, awaited a blank check from the Federal Government to cover the cost of rehabilitation. The death toll tonight was estimated at more than 300 persons for the entire State; 251 have been identified and 73 are still missing.

After a Spring and Summer that had been most erratic in their weather behavior, the stage appears to be all set for a perfect Fall planting season. The soil is well saturated with moisture and several weeks of sunny days and cool nights are reasonably to be anticipated. Thus there may prove to be at least a streak of silver lining to a garden year that has been a big black cloud.

Mayor La Guardia started for home at 4:30 this afternoon on the flagship New York of American Airlines from the Grand Central Airport in Glendale and is scheduled to arrive tomorrow forenoon at 11:28 o'clock.

A real estate course beginning Sept. 28 will be given by the school of business of Fordham University In cooperation with the Brooklyn Real Estate Board. The course, which will consist of fourteen lectures, will be given in the rooms of the business school in the Woolworth Building, Broadway and Barclay Street, on Wednesday evenings at 7 o'clock from Sept. 28 to Jan.

John E. Parker Jr. of Essex County, former metropolitan amateur champion, and Paul Williams of the home club assumed a two-stroke lead today in the first round of the Glen Ridge Country Club's third annual member-guest invitation golf tournament for the Allison Dodd Trophy.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange were highly sensitive yesterday to European news dispatches. Early losses of 11 to 13 points under nervous selling from Liverpool and the Far East reflected pessimism as the result of over-night reports, but as later advices indicated renewed hopefulness of a peaceful settlement of the Czech problem, Wall Street covering developed.

BODIES, it appears. are often improved by cutting. One may take that on the authority of the surgeon. The same is frequently the case with books as a good many editors will agree. This book is a case in point A healing blue pencil would have been good for it.

LOOKING back upon the things he has seen and the tales he has heard, the author of this book has made a collection of stories which he describes as "mostly actual facts told in a free and. rambling way."
An attractive house containing some unusual features is being built for Mrs. J. P. Brinton on Bobolink Lane in the Percy A. Rockefeller development at Greenwich, Conn.
North Carolina matched experience against Wake Forest's determination before 14,000 fans today and won its opening Southern Conference football game, 14 to 6.
Wesleyan defeated the Coast Guard Academy at football today, 27 to 0. Captain Daddario carried the ball over for the first touchdown on a run, around the end from the 6yard line.
Widespread dissatisfaction with operations of the Agricultural Adjustment Act may be a factor in returning Kansas to the Republican fold in November, visitors to the State Fair said here this week.

Greater unification of Hunter College's 7,000 students, now scattered in four college buildings, will be realized in September, 1940, by the completion of the sixteen-story building at Park Avenue and Sixtyeighth Street, now under construction, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Eugene A. Colligan, president of the college.

A method of instruction which seeks to apply various individual talents and capacities to academic subjects and to permit students to exhibit their special aptitudes by producing long-range projects has been developed in the civics classes of the High School of Music and Art.

Reshuffling of courses in Teachers College, Columbia University, to keep pace with the growing universality of high school education in the United States was announced yesterday by Dean William F. Russell for the new academic year opening Thursday.

The predictions made by the Federal Housing Administration early in the year that there would be a decided upturn in new residential construction are proving correct, points out William D. Flanders, president of the Lawyers Title Corporation of New York and formerly an official of the FHA.
VILLAINY as a fine art has been cultivated since time immemorial. Some of the very best people in history have been villains--certainly some of the most memorable.
Alleged favoritism shown to a C. I. O. stockyards union by the National Labor Relations Board was attacked in a petition filed today in the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.

Fear is being expressed today among members of the Bucks County artists' colony at New Hope for the safety of William Langson Lathrop; 79, dean of the colony, believed to be lost aboard his sailboat, Widgie, which was reported to be anchored off Montauk Point, L. I., before Wednesday's storm.
An alert University of Mississippi football team rose to take a place among the South's leading gridiron contenders tonight with a 20-to-7 surprise victory over Louisiana State before 20,000 fans.

OVER half a century has been spent collecting evidence in support of the existence of psychic phenomenon. The quality and bulk of this evidence has convinced many; still, a very large portion of the world of science remains skeptical and probably will continue to remain so even though the present quantity of documents cramming the archives of societies for psychic research be doubled or tripled.

The tenth Boston Conference on Distribution, a national forum for discussion of distribution, will be held- here on Monday and Tuesday. Speakers prominent in business, retailing, government and education will discuss a variety of subjects in connection with marketing and trade.
Mrs. Phillips Allen Clark, active in society and in the New York Women's League for Animals, died yesterday in her home, 40 East Sixty-second Street, after a long illness. She was 72 years old.
An airplane brought Moir McKenzie, head of the empire section of the Federation of British Industries, from Ottawa today in time to board the liner Empress of Britain for England.

The Treasury, it became known today, has decided to release part of the gold that has been held idle in its general fund to meet current expenditures, and on last Wednesday and Thursday it put $114,500,000 to such purposes.

The Nationalists [Rebels] reported today the occupation of more Republican [Loyalist] lines, trenches and fortified positions in the Ebro sector, while on the Teruel front three of their army corps proceeded with the work of burying fallen Republican militiamen, dispatching prisoners to the rear and classifying war material captured in the Sierra de Javalambre, southwest of Manzanera and Sarrion.

Responsibility for the decline in employment in manufacturing industries since 1929 is attributable in about equal degree to rising productivity and to the persistence of reduced industrial activity, according to a bulletin, "Employment Opportunities in Manufacturing Industries," by Frederick C. Mills, published yesterday by the National Bureau of Economic Research.
Crispin Oglebay's Holystone, with Miss Muriel Cleland of Bedminster, N. J., up, won two of the imporant events today at the Bryn Mawr ??orse show.

Despite the fact that the sumac is beginning to show a hint of coming scarlet, and the leaves are beginning to thin off in the covers, there is still an opportunity to do some fresh water fishing. This is the season when the bass and pickerel are really hungry, and there is no point in putting the rod away for the Winter.

ELIZABETH LINKLATER--she was Elizabeth Young then-first went to sea at the age of 4, in the 345-ton barque Parejero, of which her father was captain. They sailed from a port in Essex for Boston, with a cargo of chalk, and the voyage across the Atlantic took twenty-eight days.
TO his first novel a beautifully written and profoundly searching story of the Old South, Allen Tate brings the stern discipline of the long practice of poetry and much experience as a biographer.

Philip Lieber, president of the First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Shreveport, La., and a former president of the United States Building and Loan League, who "conscientiously opposed" the original National Housing Act, has reversed his former stand and now is urging all classes of business to align themselves behind the amended measure.

Unless otherwise stated, the resuits of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges.. Figures in many cases are subject to-final adjustments.
INTERIOR decoration has become more flexible. Manufacturers are offering new types of well-designed furniture and a great variety of patterns and weaves in textiles.
Harry Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, announced as he left here last night by airliner for storm damaged New England that he had discharged Fred Healy, WPA Administrator in New Mexico.
The Federal Housing Administration completed its plans yesterday to help the owners of property in the storm-stricken zones to rebuild or repair their homes and business structures.
Immigration officials at Ellis Island announced yesterday that a transcontinental contingent of seventy aliens ordered deported by the Department of Labor would arrive in Jersey City tomorrow.

Two new Catholic institutions in the Archdiocese of New York-the Frances Schervier Hospital and Home for the Aged, the Bronx, and Good Samaritan Hospital, at Suffern, N. Y.-will be dedicated next month, it was announced yesterday by the New York Catholic Charities at its headquarters, 477 Madison Avenue.

Significant readjustments in engineering education have been made necessary by problems created by governmental expansion, Dean Thorndike Saville of theNew York University College of Engineering declared in his annual report to Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase, made public yesterday.
A 36-yard runback by Cohen of a quick kick in the third period gave Massachusetts State a touchdown and victory by 12--6 in its initial gridiron contest today against American International.

Observers of Hitlerism pronounce the world's natural impatience to learn against whom the Third Reich will move next to be premature. This question will become immediate only when the fate of the Czechoslovak republic and the Slavonic provinces has been decided.

Miss Josephine K. Newton of this city and New York, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Fort Newton of Philadelphia, was married here this afternoon at the home of her parents to Clement Warren Hooven, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Clement Warren Hooven of Anderson, Ind., and New York.

Two of this city's largest trade shows are looking for new quarters for their 1939 Summer expositions here because the influx of World's Fair visitors next Summer will make it impossible to hold the exhibitions in the Hotel Pennsylvania, where they have been housed in other years.
ON Cape Cod the cranberry plants on 14,000 acres of low-lying bogs are complementing the purple asters and the gold of goldenrod with a deepening brownish red.
A one-time pupil taught the old mats ter at Memorial Stadium today when a smartly coached Ohio University eleven upset the favored University of Illinois, 6 to 0, before 20,000 spectators.

New York: Henry Holt Co. $3. The final volume in this series of diaries describing a journey through England and Wales in 1781-94. Edited by C. Bruyn Andrews.

The Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, meeting last -week in an executive session attended by fifty representatives of twenty-three cooperating national denominations, appealed to all Christians to pray for peace and for all those suffering from religious and racial oppression.

A DAPTING from philately the "souvenir" sheet idea which is so popular in many countries, the National Tuberculosis Association will this Fall distribute, in addition to the customary single-item gummed and perforated seal in a new design, a special souvenir pane which includes the seal itself, centered, and four other "stamps" illustrated with heads of men who have in various ways been identified with civilization's battle against the disease.

Marked improvement in highway communications in those parts of New England swept by the storm was reported yesterday by the Automobile Club of New York. Several roads that had been blocked have been reopened to motor traffic, while others arteries, according to the survey, are being made temporarily passable.

Dollar bonds of foreign countries led yesterday a general decline in values of bonds in active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Renewed tension over the turn of affairs in Europe resulted not only in a withdrawal of bids from pivotal issues in all groups but also considerable liquidation, with the result that prices crumbled 1 to 5 points throughout the list.

The angle a roof makes with the horizontal is called its "pitch." Roofers speak of it in terms of inches. An eight-inch pitch, for example, means that the slope of the roof rises eight inches vertically for every horizontal foot. An eight-inch pitch is a steep roof.
