Professor Harry D. Gideonse, former chairman of social science courses and Associate Professor of Economics at the University of Chicago, has been appointed Professor of Economics at Barnard College, Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve announced yesterday.

Its wings and tail afire, an amphibian plane made a forced landing in the harbor here about 6 o'clock this evening. The two occupants escaped injury by jumping into the water and swimming until they for were picked up by a fishing boat a few minutes later. All the fabric was burned off, but the craft remained afloat.
Marking its third move since the firm was founded sixty-three years ago, Marcus Co., jewelers, will open new quarters at 681 Fifth Avenue on Oct. 3.
It was officially reported today that there were 17,000 Sudeten German refugees from Czechoslovakia in Germany. It was estimated that 40,000 arrived across the border today.

Prague's capitulation has caused the balance between the two ends of the RomeBerlin axis to swing heavily in favor of Berlin. Since the axis was formed, in the now famous meeting of Chancellor Hitler and Count Ciano at Berchtesgaden on Oct. 24, 1936, Germany has scored two very notable and very tangible victories.

A. W. Warley, president of the Maritime Association, said yesterday that the failure of the Federal Government to allot funds for the construction of the proposed tunnel between the Battery and the Brooklyn waterfront threatened the future value of Brooklyn as a terminal of ship lines serving the port.

Purdue's Boilermakers suddenly came to life in the last half of their football inaugural with the University of Detroit in Midsummer heat today and rushed across three touchdowns to win, 19 to 6, before 21,000 sepctators.
The book was closed yesterday oil the greatest record of success eves compiled by a lawn tennis player ti one season of national and internal. tional championship competition.

Walter L. Jonas of 122 East Twenty-seventh Street, a prominent member of the Ethical Culture Society, of which his father, the late Sigismund Jonas, was a founder, died yesterday in Mt. Sinai Hospital, after a long illness, at the age of 56.
Konrad Henlein, the Sudeten Nazi leader, and 150 of his uniformed, steel-helmeted Free Corps fighters crossed the border from Germany early today.

While definite action has not been taken as yet, the executive board of the American Gas Association is expected to approve for another three years the cooperative advertising campaign which it set under way on Oct. 17, 1935, according to reports in the industry.

Christians and Jews throughout the country will be urged to observe a special day of prayer for the victims of racial and religious oppression in Europe, the executive committee of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America announced yesterday. Sunday, Nov. 20, has been suggested as the date for this national observance.

An attempt to get the Republican and Democratic State conventions to incorporate liberal education planks in the respective party platforms will be made by the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations it was announced yesterday.
Burgess Meredith, whose cinema career has been limited to "Winterset" and "Don't Forget to Remember" at RKO, is to report at Metro on Tuesday for one of the leading roles in "Spring Dance."

Describing the $30-a-week pension plan, which is to be submitted to California voters in the November election, as "absolutely impossible of operation," the State Relief Commission has put itself on record as opposing the plan's adoption.
A group of forty-four American citizens, fearful of crossing the frontier at Eger into Germany, returned to Prague today. They had heard reports they would be placed in German concentration camps.

The Bache Collection, which has been closed during the Summer, will be reopened at 11 A. M. tomorrow. As heretofore, admission will be by card obtained on application at the home of the collection, 814 Fifth Avenue.

Employment and payrolls of the steel industry in the first half of this year were substantially higher than in the corresponding periods of 1934, and 1935, when operations also were less than 50 per cent ef capacity, according to a compilation by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

Buffalo squared the four-out-ofseven International League final play-off series today by whipping Newark, 5 to 3, in the second game. Although held to four hits, the Bisons took advantage of three errors to do all their scoring In the seventh inning.

An experiment that may have farreaching effects on intercollegiate football is under way at the University of Pennsylvania this season, where George Munger, who celebrated his twenty-ninth birthday yesterday, is handling a varsity coaching job for the first time.

The forty-fourth annual Credit Congress of the National Association of Credit Men will be held in Grand Rapids, Mich., June 12 to 15, it was announced for publication today by Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the association.

The text of the "final" memorandum of Chancellor Adolf Hitler of Germany given to Prims Minister Neville Chamberlain of Britain Friday for presentation to Czechoslovakia, as disclosed by authoritative sources in London, follows: Reports increasing in number from hour to hour regarding incidents in the Sudetenland show that the situation has become completely intolerable for the Sudeten German people and, in consequence- dangerous to the peace of Europe.

Miss Quick, a 5-year-old gray mare owned by Jack Spratt of Westbury and exhibited by Billy Dobbs of Syosset, captured the hunter championship rosette at the Brookville charity horse show today on Rigan. McKinney's estate.

Laurence A. Steinhardt, United States Ambassador to Peru, and Mrs. Steinhardt are expected to arrive Thursday from Europe. They will be at the Savoy-Plaza. Mrs. George M. Newell, who had een at the Pierre, left yesterday for Santa Barbara, Calif.

While the United States Bureau of Agricultural Engineering at Washington was planning to ask for a $75;000 appropriation for a preliminary study to work out plans for a mechanical sugar cane harvester aLouisiana planter in a $500 machine shop on his .own plantation went ahead and built one which he had invented.
More than 2,500 Lutherans from New York City, Westchester and Connecticut attended the celebration of the 421st anniversary of the birth of the Lutheran religion at Concordia Seminary here today.

Fifty-nine men and women, including two officers of the United States Army, have been added to the instructional or administrative staffs of New York University for the current academic year, it was announced yesterday by Harold O. Voorhis, university secretary.

Another championship rosett? was added to his mounting collection today by the chestnut gelding Lord Britain, as the wellknown thoroughbred from the May Top Stables of Mrs. Edgar Mayer of Port Chester captured the hunter title at the second annual Pocantico Hills Fall Horse Show.
W. Percival Snyder of Bound Brook, N. J., who was jury foreman in the second Hall-Mills murder trial at Somerville, died at Union Memorial Hospital last .night after a long illness. His age was 61.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 48 per cent of capacity, up 2 points from the week preceding, and the highest rate since the end of last October. Tonnage output

The North German Lloyd liner Bremen will arrive today from Bremen and channel ports, bringing a large list of passengers, including Dr. Hans H. Dieckhoff, German Ambassador, and Dr. Hans Borchers, Consul General of Germany in New York.

The unfair methods used by Jewbaiters to attack the Jews are out of harmony with any of the teachings of Jesus Christ, the Rev. Howard D. McGrath said yesterday in Grace Methodist Episcopal Church, 133 West 104th Street.
Apprehension felt throughout Egypt because of the highest Nile flood in more than a decade has now abated, following three days of coni tinua decline in the river's level.

The first comprehensive exposition of New York City's intricate police machinery by the police experts who operate the gears will be made available to civilian employes of the department beginning this afternoon at 5:30 o'clock.

O. N. Lindahl, controller of the Universal. Atlas Cement Company, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, who also is a member of the Chicago Control and national director of the Controllers Institute of America, will be nominated today as vice president of the institute.

Captain Walter Willis of the Long Island Fishing Information Bureau called us to explain that, like Mark Twain's, the report of his death had been "grossly exaggerated," and that the Long Island Fishermen's Specials would be discontinued indefinitely.
Arthur Herman Adams, a consulting engineer with offices at 420 Lexington Avenue, New York, died this morning at his home here at the age of 59. He had been in poor health for two years.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Reinhard of Maplewood have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Charlotte Herben Reinhard, to Carlos Earle Burnett, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. E. Burnett of Dallas, Texas.

Messages of greeting from President Roosevelt, Secretary of State Hull and Senator Robert F. Wagner were made public yesterday in observance of Rosh Hashanah, the beginning of the year 5699 in the Jewish calendar, which opened at sundown last evening.
Supply contracts valued at $4,059,262 were awarded during the week ended Sept. 22 by eleven Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Labor Department announced today.

Johnny Parker of Essex County and Paul Williams of the home club captured the Glen Ridge Country Club's third annual member-guest invitation golf tournament today with a 36-hole best-ball total of 144, even par.
History doesn't recognize ultimatums. Nothing is ever final, no word is ever the last word, in a world where men and nations remain unknown quantities, even to themselves.
Stocks nervous on European crisis; prices reacted after recovering the preceding week's losses, and closed around levels of previous Saturday; turnover, 5,034,900 shares.

Business conditions in August improved materially over those in July and the favorable trend continued into September, according to the Federal Reserve Board's monthly statement of business conditions, made public today.

The fourth national convention of the Workers Alliance drafted today a six-year program for relief and economic recovery, called on President Roosevelt to "speak out" against the partition of Czechoslovakia and cheered a plea that WPA workers and home relief recipients become "Paul Reveres of 1938" on the national political front.

With thousands of New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad workers rebuilding the line, Howard S. Palmer, president of the company, was able this evening to announce the re-opening of four important sections, from Hartford to Springfield, Saybrook to New London, Waterbury to Winsted and from Danbury to Canaan.

Awards for safety plans and essays to teachers and high school and college students were announced yesterday by the C. I. T. Safety Foundation. The foundation was established in 1936 by the Commercial Investment Trust Comporation, a national automobile sales finance company, to promote safety on highways.

The B. M. T. has arranged for a loan of $8,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to pay for new cars and general rehabilitation of rolling stock and equipment on its street car lines in Brooklyn, it was disclosed yesterday.

The end of a momentous week finds a nerve-racked Europe still facing a grave crisis. Just seven days have passed since Mr. Chamberlain, returning from Berchtesgaden, agreed with his French colleague, Premier Daladier, to bring pressure to bear on Czechoslovakia in behalf of the only settlement which then seemed capable of preventing an immediate outbreak of war in Central Europe.

The environs of a Harlem elementary school will become a laboratory this week for a cooperative project of Teachers College and the Board of Superintendents of the New York school system to attack a problem of modern educationhow a school can be more closely attuned to the community it serves.

Violent fluctuations last week in the stock market reflected the influence of and reaction to changes in the Czechoslovak situation. Stocks were firm generally and, at times, active until after Thursday. Daily rises of up to 5 points

The British Government is giving consideration to comprehensive plans for the development of the Turner Valley oil field in Southern Alberta, which include the construction of a pipeline to Vancouver, it was learned tonight.

Stabilization of world currencies and cooperative action are steps essential to end the present confusion in international economic relations, the Guaranty Trust Company of New York says in its monthly review of business and financial coneditions, published today.

Further gestures of futility were made in Ebbets Field yesterday before 8,124 spectators when the Phils and Dodgers played to a stand-off in a double-header.
Typical newspaper headlines on articles on the international situation follow: Tageblatt: "II Duce always ready for battle-new speech by Mussolini in Belluno."

The beautification of a church would be in vain if there were not a similar rededication of the worshipers, the Rev. Arthur R. Kleps said in a sermon yesterday at the Immanuel Luthern Church, Lexington Avenue and Eighty-eighth Street.

" What you learn or do not learn of the conditions and interrelatedness of the world will play a pare in the decisions you will have to make, and is on the conscience of every one of you," President Neilson of Smith College told an audience of 2,300 at the opening vespers of the academic year tonight.

The German wholesale price index on Sept. 14 was 105.6, unchanged from the week before. In the first eight months of this year the highest point reached by the German wholesale price index was 106.1, in the weeks ended on Aug. 3, 10 and 17.

A par round of 70 put Bill Burke of Cleveland, a former national open champion, at the top of the field with a card of 139 after 36 holes of the 108-hole, $13,500 open tournament at the Fenway Golf Club today.

Niagara University opened its 1938 football season today by running roughshod over La Salle College of Philadelphia, 40 to 0. The Purple Eagles tallied in every quarter except the second, when La Sale momentarily threatened to score with an aerial attack.

Mr. Rome and Mr. Friedman have made the transmigration from Labor Stage to the Music Box without loss of life or property. Something less than a year ago they upset the even tenor of the town by writing and staging "Pins and Needles" for the histrionic garment workers.

Prices of corn fluctuated in an erratic manner last week on the Board of Trade, mainly in sympathy with wheat. There was considerable hedging pressure at times as a result of a material increase in sales of old crop grain in the country, especially Iowa.
Brooklyn Day was celebrated yesterday at the Fort Hamilton military reservation where more than 8,000 persons watched a polo match, guard mount and retreat parade.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,973,509,350. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills.

Although diplomats and politicians may be pessimistic, military circles, while refusing to express any opinion on the actual situation, nevertheless state certain general principles in which some comfort may be found.

Before leaving for London this afternoon Premier Edouard Daladier called the French Cabinet together and obtained unanimous approval of the attitude that he and Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet proposed to take in discussions with British Cabinet Ministers of the Hitler memorandum and the Czech reply.

The financial markets here are passing through a period of the greatest anxiety and tension with what must be regarded generally as highly commendable calm. At the same time it is undeniable that the tense situation is producing its effect in many ways.

" In times of crisis, when the resources of men shrivel, the resources of God unfold," declared the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo yesterday morning in his first Fall sermon at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

THE war spirit has spread to this usually quiet corner and the Red Badge of Rebellion is herewith nailed to the mast. It isn't a matter of hauling up the paving stones and building barricades in the streets in the old French style. But there should be a swirling rush of indignant citizens with ropes for the public hanging of the outrageous scoundrels who draw up these Fall football schedules.
The Stock Exchange here has been rather inactive, transactions being limited to professional operators, while the moneyed class still is out of the market. The market still is expecting
President Roosevelt relaxed his watch over the European situation today long enough to witness the concluding races of the President's Cup Regatta from the Yacht Potomac.
The Spanish Government reported today its troops had captured two fortified hills west of Manzanara, imperiling an Insurgent force in Teruel Province.

At the National Association of Postmasters Convention in St. Paul the figure that takes the eye is Mrs. Mary Stewart. She was appointed postmaster at Oxford, Md., by President Hayes in 1877. She is the oldest in service of all Mr. Farley's helpers.

Democratic voters of the Six-five teenth Congressional District fied papers Saturday incorporating the Andrew Jackson party, upon which Representative John J. O'Connor will run as an independent Democrat at the November election as well as on the Republican ticket.

Mrs. Joseph R. Truesdale has joined Pease Elliman as a specialist in private houses and apartments. The John H. Eisele Company, with a bid of $248,500, was the lowest bidder on the new school building for the Board of Education of Manhasset, L. I., according to Brown's Letters, Inc. Tooker Marsh are the architects.

As a feature of the celebration of the twelfth anniversary of Religious Education Week, which began yesterday, a conference of the Protestant church workers of the city will take place on Thursday from 10 A. M. to 10 P. M. in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street.

Dressed in their native costume, fifty Indians representing a dozen tribes -assembled yesterday afternoon at Inwood Hill Park, Dyckman Street overlooking the Hudson River, and performed the dances of their fathers as a celebration of Indian Day.

The Theatre Guild opens its twenty-first season this evening at the Booth Theatre with a production of "Dame Nature," which-as you may already know-is Patricia Collinge's adaptation from the French play by Andre Birabeau.

The report of the President's commission on labor relations in Sweden, like that previously published on labor relations in Great Britian, is a model in compactness, clarity and impartiality of what such a report should be.

Financially, the idea of moving up today's scheduled game between the Yankees and Red Sox at the Stadium was a highly satisfactory one. The double-header, which marked the champions' last Sunday appearance of the regular season in the Bronx, yesterday drew 22,783 fans.

The National Committee for Religion and Welfare Recovery has made public a letter from President Roosevelt endorsing its annual Loyalty Days, which will be observed next Saturday and Sunday, and its National Stewardship Convention to be held in Chicago Nov. 1 to 3.

Authorities here on the grain trade assert that prices of wheat probably will fluctuate until the European crisis abates. Even within Germany, where markets are tied and prices are fixed, each new threat of war induces farmers to withhold deliveries.
Freed from, the limestone reef that held her captive for four days, the 1,100-ton British naval sloop Dundee tonight was tied up at a dock in Ellis Bay, Anticosti Island.

Only by the resurgence of the true Christian spirit of grace and kindness in the conduct of men and women can this generation hope to avert a complete collapse of our present social system, the Right Rev. Dr. Robert N. Spencer, Bishop of West Missouri, declared yesterday morning at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

For the twenty-third consecutive month exports of iron and steel products, excluding scrap, in August exceeded 100,000 tons, according to preliminary statistics made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Mrs. Jeanette McCabe, 45 years old, of 275 West 238th Street, the Bronx, was found shot dead yesterday morning in-her apartment after tenants of the building reported having heard five shots fired. Police are seeking her husband, Edward McCabe, 57; for questioning.
The Cubs defeated the Cardinals, 7 to 2, before 30,014 fans today to remain two gaines behind the first-place Pirates as the National League race entered the final week.

Miss Priscilla Proudfoot, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Smith Proudfoot of Kew Gardens, Queens, has completed plans for her marriage on Oct. 7 to Maxwell Sheridan Palmer of Forest Hills, Queens, son of Sheridan B. Palmer of Greenville, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Palmer. The ceremony will
The Rev. Dr. Charles Trexler was installed yesterday afternoon as pastor of Grace Lutheran Church, Forest Hills, Queens. Lutheran clergymen from all the boroughs of the city were present.

More than 4,000 corporations in the United States have profit-sharing, bonus or pension plans for their rankand-file workers. This is the finding of a Special Senate Committee which is making a national survey of profit-sharing systems. The committee has headquarters here.

A reception and dance will be given by Mr. and Mrs. Richard Stockton 3d of Princeton, N. J., for their debutante daughter, Miss Roberta Thorburn Stockton, on Oct. 14 at the Present Day Club in Princeton.

Members of North Shore society and their children arrived early for the morning session of the Brookville Charity Horse Show, which closed tonight on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Rigan McKinney, an exhibition given in behalf of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children in Nassau County.

A freak airplane accident in which two planes collided in the air twelve feet above the ground while both were trying to land at an airport here today caused serious injury to two passengers in one craft, while the pilot of the other escaped with minor injuries.
Twenty-seven years' ministering to the congregation of the Brick Presbyterian Church brought the title of "Pastor Emeritus" yesterday to the Rev. Dr. William P. Merrill, who will retire Oct. 1.

We feel that we may be nearer a European war than at any time before. The result of the French Cabinet council today and of the FrancoBritish conference which followed immediately in London has been to make a clear issue of the tangled Czechoslovak problem.

" War is being forced upon the world by the actions of a madman," the Right Rev. William T. Manning, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, declared yesterday to a crowd of 9,000 at a Gold Star Mothers' Day ceremony on the Mall in Central Park.

Charles Weaingarten, drug buyer at Whelan Drug Company, will be in charge of buying and merchandising for Madison Drug Stores, Inc., a new Florida drug chain, with New York headquarters at 354 Fourth Avenue.

Michael Bell of Peekskill won the horseshoe-pitching championship of the metropolitan area yesterday when he outscored thirty-eight other entrants in an A. A. U. tournament held at Willow Brook Park at Travis, S. I. Bell was runner-up in the national tournament held on Labor Day.

Although communism and nazism are to be condemned because of their common principle of exaltation of the state above all else, communism is "one of the prophetic and creative movements of modern times," John Haynes Holmes dedared yesterday at the Community Church, Town Hall, 123 West Fortythird Street.
That acute football disease of fumbilitis brought the Giants down into a defeat that was as unexpected as it was undeserved before 23,877 in the Municipal Stadium today.

Europe's war alarms dominated the world's wheat markets last week and all other factors were as good as ignored. It was not until late in the week, however, that importing countries in the Old World gave unmistakable signs of realistic concern and started to purchase grain to cover possible future requirements. The demand, however,
A joint Anglo-French declaration is expected to be sent to Chancellor Adolf Hitler of Germany today in an eleventh-hour attempt by the two western democracies to avert war over Czechoslovakia.
Albert Sarraut, Interior Minister, outlined tonight measures taken by his Ministry in cooperation with the Seine and Seine-et-Oise Prefects for the defense of Paris.

Czechoslovakia's capital tonight was the. darkest in Europe, blacked out against any foreign air.raid. Street cars crawled along with a faint blue glimmer replacing the usual headlight. Within dozens of the capital's old houses there were no lights at all.

Fred (Rosebud) Lucas, 36 years old, beat the Reds, 5 to 3, today for the fourteenth straight victory he has scored over his former team-mates since he left their roster to Join the Pirates five years ago.

The Rev. Edward V. Higgins, founder and national chaplain of the Catholic War Veterans, at a ceremony attended by nearly 5,000 persons yesterday afternoon dedicated Catholic War Veterans Square at Rockaway Boulevard and 117th Avenue, South Ozone Park.

The swiftness with which European events seem to be moving toward war was emphasized this afternoon by Premier Benito Mussolini who, in speaking at Vicenza to another huge crowd of acclaiming Fascists, announced that Italy would be obliged to adopt military measures if other nations continue to recall reservists and concentrate their fleets.

Miss Anna Laurens Dawes, author, daughter of the late United States Senator Henry L. Dawes and the late Electa Sanderson Dawes, died today at White Tree Inn, her home here for the last three years, at the age of 87.
The staccato of high-pressure pumps broke the Sunday quiet here today as the last of the flood water in dow forced to the streets.

An apartment of twelve rooms in 950 Park Avenue has been leased by the Carpenter Realty Corporation to Edwin Wolf of the Wolf Housing Corporation. The lease was announced by Byrne Bowman, Inc., brokers, who arranged it, and was one of many reported in scattered sections of the city over the week-end.
Two measures for old-age pensions proposed by initiative petition are on the ballot to be submitted to the and voters of Oregon for approval or rejection at the general election on Nov.

Showing an overwhelming desire for un interrupted work during the coming year, the San Pedro local of the International Longshoremen and Warehousemen's Union ratified today the employer-employe coastwise agreement to run for a year from Oct. 1.

Mayor La Guardia completed his three-week tour of the South and West yesterday when he arrived at Newark Airport aboard the New York of the American Airlines after a fast flight from Los Angeles to plunge into negotiations for a settlement of the truck drivers' strike.

Bizet's "Carmen," given by the San Carlo Opera Company last night at the Center Theatre, was heard by a large and responsive gathering. The personnel remained the same as that of the earlier presentation this season except that Mario Valle was the Escamillo and Mildred Ippolito the Frasquita.

There is dire need for a sweeping revival throughout the world, as national sins bring on national calamity, the Rev. Dr. Paul W. Rood, president of the World's Christian Fundamentals Association, said in his sermon yesterday at the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street.

The thirteenth annual World's Championship Rodeo will open at Madison Square Garden Oct. 7 and continue to Oct. 30, it was announced yesterday. This will mark the fiftieth year of rodeo contests in the United States.

Union Square became the Forest Hills of paddle tennis yesterday and the usual speechmakers were forced to the background as mere onlookers. The occasion was the beginning of the city-wide championships of the Police Athletic League in paddle tennis and shuffleboard.

Mr. and Mrs. John J. Holland of the Bronx have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Elenore Holland, to Emmett Francis McNamara of this city, son of Mrs. Robert Atkins and the late Richard McNamara.

Special prayers for a peace of justice and for the relief of sufferers from last week's hurricane were offered yesterday in every Protestant Episcopal Church in the Diocese of New York at the request of Bishop William T. Manning.

William Bogart Spencer, a civil engineer ahd construction expert who had been occupied for the last two years on construction projects in Central America, died suddenly of a heart attack at his home here last night at the age of 61.

William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Iivestigation, announced yesterday that he had begun an inquiry into the so-called fur racket to find what possible connection police and other public officials had with the gang, alleged to have included three patrolmen, that swindled Brooklyn merchants out of more than $25,000.
The Rev. Myron N. Wescott, pastor of the Half Moon Baptist Church since July, 1937, died yesterday at an Albany, N. Y., hospital at the age of 63.

Governors of- at least five New England 'States will confer in Boston today with officials of the American Red Cross, the Works Progress Administration, the Public Works Administration and other Federal and State relief and rehabilitation agencies to map a longrange program to restore areas swept by Wednesday's hurricane, which took nearly 500 lives in seven Northeastern States.
Japanese columns north and south of the Yangtze River are fighting in rain and mud in their efforts to cut key railways serving Hankow, Chinese. military capital.

Dr. Francis Wayland Adams, oldest living graduate of Amherst College, died in his home here last night at the age of 98. He was a member of the New England family of Adamses which gave the nation two Presidents.
Expressions of nearly 1,000,000 railroad, employes Who voted to decide whether to call a nation-wide strike or accept a 15 per cent wage reduction are in the hands of the railroad brotherhoods.

A group of more than forty clergymen and educators will visit colleges and universities in this country during the next few months and will conduct "missions" among the students, it was announced yesterday by the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.
A hopeless cause galloped with startling swiftness to its inevitable conclusion today as the Giants lost both ends of their double-header with the Bees today.

ANOTHER installment of Jules Romains's socalled contemporary prose -epic is on sale under the title "Death of a World."* This is Volume VII in the American edition and carries the narrative of "Men of Good Will" through 1913 and up to Aug. 1, 1914, the date of the French mobilization.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission has under preparation a promotion system for every city department which will in time give virtually every employee an opportunity to advance through promotional examinations, the commission announced. yesterday in the first issue of its Civil Service Bulletin. The bulletin will be published each month as a source of information on municipal civil service.

The American Transit Association and its subsidiaries will open their convention at Toronto on Oct. 2. It is expected that more than 200 leading companies operating street cars and buses, trolley coaches, subway, elevated and interurban lines and 134 manufacturers of public transportation equipment in the United States and Canada will be represented. The convention wil be

Representative Samuel Dickstein, investigator of Nazi activities In this country, and Fritz Kuhn, leader of the German-American Bund, met yesterday afternoon for the first time on a lecture platform to discuss whether the Bund was "American" or not.

There was a large attendance of members of society today at the annual Westbury Kennel Show, held ofthe polo field of the estate of Mr. tnd Mrs. John S. Phipps. Many B4 the exhibitors came from the Provkille Charity Horse Show, a few miles away, where they were showing also their hunters and jumpers or their children' pomes..

Telephone reports received today from workers in the New York and New England storm-swept areas show that the task of rehabilitating families and rebuilding their homes has doubled over earlier estimates, Norman H. Davis, chairman of the Red Cross. announced this afternoon.

Four more meet marks were eclipsed and another champion was dethroned in the second and final session of the women's metropolitan A. A. T. track and field championships at Macombs Dam Park in the Bronx yesterday. The Mercury A. C. of Harlem, led by Miss Ivy Wilson, made 41 points to take the team title in the two-day carnival, in which six records fell altogether.

For two days the Pittsfield police, using boats and grappling irons, have searched unsuccessfully in the Housatonic River'for Aurelio Glorni. aged 43, pianist and composer, who is believed to have been drowned. Whether, if dead, he was drowned accidentally or otherwise is not known to the police.

The report of the Electric Power and Light Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on July 31, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income after operating expenses, taxes and charges, of $6,626,639, compared with a net of $9,458,267 in the twelve months to July 31, 1937.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Siegman of 965 Fifth Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Roselle Siegman, to Edward Schoen Jr., son of Mrs. Schoen of East Orange, N. J., and the late Judge Schoen.

The Memphis Power and Light Company, a subsidiary of the National Power and Light Company, rejected yesterday an offer of $13,000,000 from the city of Memphis for its electrical properties with a broad intimation that negotiations will be ended unless the city increases its price. The negotiations are expected to be resumed tomorrow.

Terming the arrest of eleven "reputable business men" on charges of disorderly conduct and "unlawful invasion of personal liberties," Magistrate Charles Solomon in Bridge Plaza Court, Brooklyn, dismissed yesterday complaints against the defendants, arrested early yesterday while playing cards in the Greenpoint Business Men's Club, 677 Manhattan Avenue, Brooklyn.
The Belgian Government Committee on Wartime Food Supplies was called today to meet under General George Theunis because of the tense international situation.

Columbia University will mark the e: opening of its 185th year Wednesday afternoon with exercises in the McMillin Academic Theatre, Broadway at 116th Street. Classes and laboratory work: will begin in virtually all branches of the university the following day.

Trailing, 4 to 0, going into the eighth inning, the All-Stars from the Negro National Baseball League rallied to tie the score in that frame and went on to defeat a selected team from the Negro American League, 5 to 4, in ten inn- t ings before 12,000 at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 80.8, which compared with 80.7 the week before, 80.6 two weeks before, 80.6 three weeks before and 80.4 four weeks before.

It is increasingly clear from a study of recent army exercises-particularly the Third Army field manoeuvress of August-that the military service, despite its virtual rearmament and reequipment, now proceeding apace, despite the advanced thinking of many of its officers, has not yet rid itself of the great incubus of the past, of the dead hand of history, of obsolete methods of procedure and organization.

Resolutions by the International Federation of Business and Professional Women and the National Lawyers Guild were added last week to those adopted by other organizations urging the two major parties to nominate at least one woman candidate for one of the two Supreme Court vacancies in the First Judicial District.

After a recovery of 31 to 34 points early last week, the cotton market turned easier and lost most of its gains. At the close of trading on Saturday active futures deliveries on the New York Cotton Exchange showed for the week net advances of only 8 to 11 points.

The Tigers batted out a 7-to-5 victory today to end at two-all their final series with the Indians. Hank Greenberg, seeking to break Babe Ruth's home-run record, was up four times and got one hit, a double. The only homer of the day

What has been happening in this little frontier town of Graslitz during the last few days is likely to be only a dress' rehearsal of what will happen if the hundreds of thousands of anti-NazL Germans and Czechs in Sudeten German territory are handed over to the Reich without guarantees of protection.

Walter H. Liebman, Democratic candidate for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District, a director of Beth Israel Hospital, which has a union contract, has urged Mayor La Guardia to approve the City Council resolution for withholding public money from private or voluntary hospitals which fail to bargain collectively with employes, it was announced yesterday by Local 129, State, County and Municipal Workers of America. the union affected.

Although rebounding occasionally, the pressure on the pound sterling remains heavy and resistance by Great Britain's Exchange Stabilization Fund is called for constantly. The recent panicky relapses were repeated yesterday. If the European
The Athletics split a double-header with the Senators today, taking the first game, 6 to 5, in ten innings and losing the second, 5 to 4, in a seven-inning contest called because of darkness.
Henry Marshall, a former Republican State Senator and Assemblyman from Brooklyn, died last night in Mary McClellan Hospital here, where he had been ill since July. His age was 91.

A caravan of seven armored trucks carrying $31,000,000 in bills and coins was conveyed by a huge police detail tonight as the money was secretly transferred from Providence, R. I., to the Federal Reserve Bank at Boston.

Patrolman Harry Rogers, 35 years old, of the West Twentieth Street station, captured, his man after shooting him in the hip early yesterday morning, but his right hand was badly cut a moment later as he struck a blow at the still struggling prisoner just as the latter opened his mouth.

Dr. and Mrs. Albert C. White of Glenargie Park, Palenville, N. Y., and Stanmore, Pembroke, Bermuda, have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Adrienne White, to John Calvert Lightbourn of Roxdene, Pembroke, Bermuda.

A popular emissary from European sportsdom today captured the enthusiasm of 100,000 speed boat spectators ashore and afloat, including a smiling, cheering President of the United States, by performing the impossible and making it look easy.

The estimated dollar value of retail financing of new passenger automobiles in August was 58 per cent under August, 1937, the Commerce Department has announced. As compared with July, the decrease was 4 per cent.

George D. Brooke, president of the New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad, sent telegrams last night to holders of the company's $14,800,000 of 6 per cent notes due next Saturday who had not deposited them in assent to a plan for extending the maturity of the notes for three years.
Developments here indicate that with the critical situation in Europe Mexico has placed the United States Government in a difficult position.

Expressing disappointment at the results of the constitutional convention, the Women's City Club, through Mrs. Samuel Sloan Duryee, its president, announced yesterday its recommendations on the various constitutional amendments to be voted upon Nov. 7.

A study of budget standards for families in the lowest income brackets, which may have considerable effect on future relief grants from both public and private agencies, was made public yesterday by the New York Budget Council.

It is believed the British Broadcasting Corporation has completed its plans for the organization of war broadcasting. Musical and other entertainment programs would' continue on the air because suspension might demoralize the public.

John T. Cushing, former publisher of The Boston Daily Record, Boston Evening American and Boston Sunday Advertiser, died yesterday in Chicago, according to word received here. His age was 50. Mr. Cushing, who

The annual memorial services for the dead of the Police Department were held yesterday afternoon by the Police Square Club in the Riverside Church. About 2,000 relatives' and friends, including 300 uniformed members of the department, were present.

The truck drivers in three locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters voted 4,071 to 365 yesterday afternoon at a meeting sanctioned by their union at Meca Temple, 133 West Fifty-fifth Street, to resume their strike immediately.

The giant forty-two-passenger Douglas DC4 airliner has exceeded in forty-six test flights the predictions of its designers, Arthur E. Raymond, vice president and chief engineer of the Douglas Aircraft Corporation said today.

Two special trains carrying 1,500 pilgrims from New York City arrived at Auriesville this morning and many other pilgrims came from the Hudson and Mohawk Valleys to witness ceremonies in connection with the blessing of the inscription stone of the new Jesuit Tertianship building at the Shrine of North American Martyrs.

In the belief that democracy should be advertised to the Canadian people to combat ideas of totalitarianism, Canadian leaders will cooperate in a nononpartisan radio B addresses in the next four months.

A special meeting of the holders of common and preferred shares of the American European Securties Company has been called for Nov. 2 in Newark, N. J., to vote on a proposed reduction in the stated value of the issued and outstanding co mon stock to $354.500, or $1 a shar The common stock now has a stated value of $10,139,510.

The Pennsylvania Railroad, a leader in the movement that resulted in the recent 25 per cent increase in coach fares, has reported a decrease of 14 per cent in passenger revenues in August, the first full month in which the higher fares were in effect.

The autographed, limited edition of Carl Van Doren's "Benjamin Franklin," issued by Viking Press in three volumes, will go on sale Sept. 30. The regular one-volume edition, which is the Book-of-theMonth Club selection for October, is released Oct. 7.

The seven-story apartment house for fourteen families at 117 West Seventy-ninth Street has been sold by Philip. J. Rudden to Sun Estates, Inc., Barnett Horowitz, president. It is assessed at $170,000 and was sold for cash over a first mortgage through Slawson Hobbs, Inc., brokers.
All steamship companies in Paris received hundreds of telephone calls today and will be besieged when their offices open tomorrow by those seeking passage to the United States.

President Roosevelt made a personal appeal early today to Chancellor Hitler and President Benes to settle the GermanCzech controversy by negotiation. He pointed to their countries' obligations under the Kellogg-Briand pact. [The text of the message is on Page 4.]

The Yamashita Line, which has just entered seven new eighteen-knot motorships in the Japan-Los AngelesNew York-Buenos Aires service, has slashed the Brazil-California coffee rate from $1 to 50 cents a bag.

Poland expects to be able peacefully to occupy the Czech Teschen district by the end of this week, following the Czech Government's favorable reply to a Polish note in which it was asked if Prague would keep its promise to accord to the Polish minority the same treatment as that accorded to others.

The Bartlett Frazier Company announced tonight that its commission business in commodity futures and its security brokerage business here will be transferred on Friday to Shields Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange and other security and commodity exchanges. C. D.

Whatever views are held regarding the future of Czechoslovakia, it is certain that her economic position will be so weakened in the event of partition as seriously to impair her ability to maintain foreign-debt payments,. and default or partial default is held likely.

Scores of persons living in this Morris County farming area and a sprinkling of mining engineers inspected Paul Speling's "oil well" today, the former with visions of finding "black gold" on their property and the latter with exceedingly puzzled expressions.
A crowd of 65,000 gathered in and near the Chicago Stadium this afternoon and cheered predictions, made by several speakers, that Czechoslovakia would be saved from dismemberment.

The fabric of peace on the Continent of Europe, if not throughout the rest of the world, is in immediate danger. The consequences of its rupture are incalculable. Should hostilities break out the lives of millions of men, women and children in every country involved will most certainly be lost under circumstances of unspeakable horror.

Government provision for the care of the aged, including hospitalization, has released Community Chest funds to some degree so that they may be used for the care of children and for recreation, according to a statement issued yesterday by Dr. George E. Vincent,

J. Donald Budge of California now stands as the first player in history to win in the same year all four of the world's major tennis titles-the Australian, French, British and American. It is his ironic destiny to be playing so well that he makes the tournaments in which he participates uninteresting.

Conferences will be held tomorrow between officials of the Racine and Kenosha locals of the United Automobile Workers and S. Norman Moe, Milwaukee attorney, representing Governor La Follette, in efforts to settle the trouble at the Nash-Kelvinator automobile plants in Wisconsin.

A seasonal improvement has developed in the last two weeks in the foreign demand for American lard. Cash interests, however, say it is not because of war talk, but because lard sold to continental Europe must be distributed to interior points by canal before the canals freeze.

Plans of leaders of the Democratic State organization were thrown into confusion yesterday when Senator Robert F. Wagner announced he would not accept the nomination for Governor but would run for reelection to his present office.
Mary Anderson, director of the Women's Bureau, reports that an eight-State industrial survey shows that women suffered more than men from unemployment between 1928 and 1936.

The Most Rev. Stephen J.Donahue, who succeeded the late Cardinal Hayes-as Administrator; of the Archdiocese of New York, made his first public appearance yesterday at the- dedication of an annex to the parochial school of St. Catherine-of Genoa, 503 West 153d Street.

Although American shoe imports by Canada in July declined to 14,787 pairs, valued at $32,026, as against 27,025 pairs, valued at $42,097, in the previous month, Toronto shoe interests say that low-priced American shoes, particularly women's novelty shoes, are becoming increasingly competitive, the Commerce Department reports.

Hyman Cohen, 26 years old, of 720 Alabama Avenue; Harry Cohen, 28, 682 Wyona Street, and Leo Felschmann, 36, of 283 Liberty Avenue, all of'Brooklyn, were locked up at the Astoria, Queens, Police Station last night on charges of felonious assault.

Had it not been for Fritz Haber's synthetic ammonia process, which made it possible to obtain from gases the nitrogen compounds so necessary in high explosives, blockaded Germany would have capitulated six months after the first shot in the World War was fired.

Patrolman Alfred V. Rock of the West 152d Street station suffered cuts of the left hand early yesterday morning in arresting Eugene Sheehan, 28 years old, of 48-26 Forty-seventh Street, Woodside, Queens, after a scuffle.
Charles S. Hirsch, head of the stock exchange firm of Hirsch, Lilienthal Co., died yesterday of a heart ailment at his home, 300 Park Avenue, after six weeks' illness. His age was 75.
A mother's anxiety for her 2-year-old daughter sent a Coast Guard cutter steaming 150 miles out from its base and halted briefly on the high seas the voyages of two cruise liners.

Brazil's cotton exports for the first half of the year were greater in volume than correspondingly in 1937 but the value was lower. Official figures for 1938 to June 30 put exports at 114,367 metric tons (about 481,000 bales), against 105,589 tons to June 30, 1937.

The delicate situation in Europe has caused the Rhodes trustees to suggest that the scholars-elect postpone sailing for England until peace becomes more certain, it was announced here today by Dr. Frank Aydelotte, president ' of Swarthmore College and American secretary to the Rhodes trustees.

The British Pavilion at the New York World's Fair, according to the plans announced yesterday by Grover .A. Whalen, fair president, and Sir Louis Beale, commissioner general, will constitute one of the outstanding exhibits in the foreign zone of, the fair.

A black cocker spaniel serenely surveying a ringside that tensely watched the developments in the ring for the final judging came through today. He went the rounds of the ring and with unconcern watched his five rivals. Responding to the intonation of his handler he posed and moved.

The Rev. Walter G. Summers, head of the Department of Psychology at Fordham University, and the inventor of the electrified "lie detector," died Saturday night of a coronary thrombosis at his residence at the university. He was 49 years old.

When the freshmen class of about 845 'meets tomorrow for organization at Yale University, about half, because of high entrance records, will be allowed to undertake work in subjects more advanced than the usual first-year courses.

There is a tendency to dehumanize man and belittle religion in every generation, and it is now at work in ours, the Rev. John Walter Houck, pastor of Pilgrim Congregational Church, Grand Concourse at 175th Street, the Bronx, said there yesterday morning.
Moscow's recently adopted bellicose tone on the Czech question was directed yesterday and today chiefly against Poland.

With 1,000 freshmen on hand, Harvard College preppered for the arrival tomorrow of upperclassmen and graduate students to register for the institution's 303d year. Enrollment in the college and the eleven graduate schools of the university is expected to be about 8,300, about the same as last year.
Germany's new giant dirigible, the LZ-130, made her fourth test flight today with Captain Hans von- Schiller in command.

Dr. James Thompson (Doc) Prothro, who resigned recently as manager of the Little Rock Travelers of the Southern Association, said tonight he will manage a major league baseball club in 1939. Prothro, who lives in Memphis, refused to divulge the name of the team.

Brig. Gen. Walter C. Short, commander of the First Division, regular 'army, with his aide de camp, Major Walter C. Phillips, arrived in Camp Dix today to conduct annualbrigade manoeuvres which open here tomorrow. During part of the manoeuvress he will act as Commander of the First Brigade.

Brotherly love is not confined by national boundaries, and when the nations of the world realize this, the lines between countries will become "frontiers of brotherly cooperation," Senator Robert F. Wagner declared yesterday.

A Young British lawyer, who is generally no churchgoer, got up long before his usual hour yesterday morning to go to church to pray for peace. When he left the church there was a huge truck outside the door with a loudspeaker blaring over and over again:

Carr V. Van Anda of New York City bought for $25,600 at public auction yesterday afternoon the 153-acre property with a twenty-nine-room mansion, known as The Mount, on the north shore of Laurel Lake.

Vito Marcantonio, Republican and American Labor party nominee for Representative in the Twentieth Congressional District, appealed yesterday for the support of Prbogressives of all parties, including New Dealers, against James J. Lanzetta, Democratic candidate for reelection, whom he charged with having the support of anti-New Deal forces.

With remarkable absence of excitement, with little out-ward show of sentiment this region, literally under the muzzles of German guns on the other side of the Rhine, goes about its business of being prepared for whatever the morrow may bring in the matter of peace or-war.
The new German proposals, handed to the Prague Government this morning were said to impose conditions upon Czechoslovakia that could not be considered by any government.

Frederick C. Bellinger, campaign manager for Frederic R. Coudert Jr., Republican nominee for State Senator in the Seventeenth Senatrial District, announced yesterday the selection of Walter S. Mack Jr. as chairman of the Coudert Campaign Committee and of William Ziegler Jr. as treasurer.

A new regional New York State radio chain was established yesterday when the newly organized Empire State Network got under way. Comprised of six up-State stations, it is headed by Harold E. Smith, who is organizing a complete sales organization.

With a northwest breeze that was easy and not puffy and troublesome and in water as playful as a midsummer ripple, the annual regatta of the Handicap Yacht Racing Class was held out on Long Island Sound today.

The New York State Federation of Labor, representing 1,000,000 trade unionists affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, called yesterday upon the people of the State to reject, at the coming constitutional referendum,
Unleashing a powerful ground attack that reached its height in the It third period, the Washington Red- that skins defeated the Cleveland Rams, 37-13, in a National Football League game today.

A purported vagabond poet, discouraged by inability to find work or get relief because of his prison record, was arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Brill in Bay Ridge court, Brooklyn, on a charge of vagrancy and held for a hearing on Sept. 30.

Ebby Gerry's Aknusti team had its best polo of the season ready today and galloped over Greentree to the final of the Monty Waterbury Memorial Cup tournament. most importanthandicap event and the last big competition of the year.

Front page news in Soviet Russia today was the non-stop flight of three women from Moscow to the Far East. Pravda, the Communist Party newspaper, also published news of the Czechoslovak crisis but its editorial was devoted to the problem of increasing consumers' goods.

The "proud" nations of today's world, whose policies are dictated by lust for power and ambition for dominion over other countries, should be warned by the adage, "Pride goeth before the fall," the Rev. Robert E. Woods declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Eli Newmark of Lakewood, known for years as the "slot machine king" of Ocean County, who disappeared two years ago on the day he was to have appeared for sentence in Newark Federal court on a charge of operating an unregistered still in Ocean County, was arrested this afternoon in Island Park, L. I., as a fugitive and brought here for detention.
Kenneth Fedeer, 26 years old, of Westmont, N. J., was burned to death this afternoon when a car he was driving ignited after it had overturned on Browning Lane, Bellmawr, near here.

Because of the inability of the Kolisch Quartet to appear, the concert scheduled for tonight at the New York Public Library has been cancelled at which new works were to have been performed that were presented last week at the Berkshire Festival of Chamber Music, under the auspices of Mrs. Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge, in Pittsfield, Mass. The concert tomorrow night, however, will be given as announced.

The general wholesale price index on Sept. 17 was 645, against 644 and 641 one and two weeks before. The commodities gold index was 40.6, against 40.2 and 40.3 one and two weeks previously, respectively.

Germany's preparations for war had little effect last week on the money market. Banks reported moderate cash withdrawals by foreigners. The day loan rate yesterday was 21/4 to 21/2 per cent, but against this the Reichsbank's reports continued to indicate a state of inflation due to emergency official credits.

On markets, the history of last week is one of complete bewilderment, of alternations of expectation for and against peaceful solution of the Czechoslovak problem. Stock market averages fairly tell this part of the story.

The British cruisers Ajax and Exeter spent today in the outer roads hurriedly taking on supplies for several weeks following the receipt of Admiralty orders to reprovision and stand by for further orders. They were en route to make

Doubt that the Christian church could survive another world war was expressed by the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of the Christ Methodist Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, in his sermon yesterday morning on "Where Is Thy God Now?"

Out of castor oil and coal the late Dr. Wallace H. Carrothers of the du Pont laboratories succeeded in making a new kind of rayon---one which has the elasticity that rayon lacked. He had surmounted the last technical obstacle that confronted makers and users of rayon. Yet it may take

Last week's tendency in the foreign exchange market was less favorable, with sterling advancing from 178.30 to 178.55 and the United States dollar from 37.12 to 37.20, after receding on Tuesday to 36.93.

A WPA worker on the North Beach Airport project was arrested yesterday charged with stealing several hundred dollars from persons eager to become members of the International Union of Operating Engineers by promising to get them into the union for a fee.

More than 20,000 persons, many of them obviously of Central European origin, overflowed Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon in a "Save Czechoslovakia" mass meeting to protest against the proposed dismemberment of the twenty-year-old democracy.

Eight outstanding events of the new musical season will aid the cultural, medical and recreational work conducted by the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association, it has just been announced by a committee representing the beneficiary.
The Federal Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Eugene Plotnikoff, gave last night at the Federal Music Theatre an all-Russian concert which attracted a capacity audience. Vladimir Brenner, pianist,

Gerald F. Kane, formerly a partner in Abell, Kane Co., has joined the trading department of W. F. Thompson Co. The Asuncion Port Concession Corporation has notified holders of its 8 per cent gold debentures, due on April 1, 1946, that coupons due on Oct. 1, 1933, will be paid on Oct. 1, next, at their face amount with interest at the Chase National Bank.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler has ordered a "historic manifestation" to the nation on the subject of Czechoslovakia in Berlin's biggest auditorium tomorrow night. He will speak and the whole German people has been ordered to listen to a broadcast of his address.

In the rustic setting of Schmidt Farm here, the fifth annual Cosmo Villa party will be given on the night of Oct. 7 to raise funds for the care of needy children afflicted with cardiac ailments at Irvington House, a non-sectarian sanatorium at Irvington-on-Hudson.

The Rev. Robert I. Gannon, S. J., president of Fordham University, will preach the sermon at the annual "Red Mass" of the guild of Catholic lawyers at 10 o'clock tomorrow morning at St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church, Cardinal Place and Duane Street.
Jesus's precept to love one's neighbor should be applied to international relations, the Rev. Dr. John S. Bonnell declared yesterday he in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

Five hundred members of New York Lodge 15 of the Loyal Order of Moose and of the Ladies' Auxil lary of that organization were present yesterday afternoon at ceremo-nies dedicating the lodge's new club tre Building at 254 West Fifty fourth Street.

Early this morning a group of Britons, some carrying babies, walked in darkness over the Czechoslovak frontier from Czech Teschen to Poland after a journey from Prague on the last train before the frontier was closed.
Earl Russell (Bertrand Russell), English author and philosopher, said on his arrival from Europe yesterday that after the next great war the entire world will be as "mad" as part of it is today.

Any lingering doubts on who will hold the Bermuda Trophy in the International Class for the next year were dispelled today in the last special Sunday regatta of the season, conducted by the Echo Bay Yacht Club.

There are only two official copies of the map delineating the new frontiers that Chancellor Adolf Hitler demands be cut into Czechoslovakia. One is in Berlin. The other copy is in Prague, flown there by the British military attache in Berlin.

The Federal Government this week-end began its first national survey of trade associations when the Department of Commerce, as part of its contribution to the monopoly investigation, sent questionnaires to about 2,300 national and interstate associations.

Three thousand delegates to the State convention of the Townsend movement were told today that they would have to bear down and support their organization and get bust at the polls if they expected to receive their promised pensions.

Among the ways by which Britain's financial anxiety finds expression is the continued demand for gold. But it must be recorded that this is less marked than in the previous week, although there is renewed hoarding of currency notes, both by the British public and by Continental Europeans; and a steady conversion of sterling balances into United States dollars.

It required only the hour or so that a football game takes to find giants sprawling in the dust of defeat in the new season of 1938. They fell n the Far West, Middle West, South and in the East, with perhaps the biggest disappointment here the defeat of Manhattan by St. Bonaventure by the margin of the point after touchdown.
Mrs. Rodney S. Jarvis entertained with a luncheon today at Wheelbarrow Hill Farm, Great Barrington, for Mr. and Mrs. Pompelio Maresi of New York, who are the guests of Mr. and Mrs. H. Gray Treadwell.

Reorders for ready-to-wear and accessories arrived steadily in the market last week from sections of the country unaffected by storms. The better and medium-price dress markets were quite busy, but demand dropped off in the lower end. Wool dresses of all types were particularly popular.
Gabby Street was notified today that he would not be signed to manage the Browns next season. The unexpected news came suddenly shortly after the Browns' double victory over the White Sox.

Fifteen thousand workers marched to the Presidential Palace this morning in a demonstration of support for President Federico Laredo Bru's administration, but presented a petition asking for the passage of many items of legislation.

An analysis of direct and indirect attacks upon the trade agreements program, as they have taken form in measures proposed to Congress, was issued today by the National League of Women Voters for the use of its membership in opposing future legislative moves against the trade treaties negotiated by the United States.

Harry L. Hopkins, Federal WPA Administrator, left here tonight for Boston after promising Rhode Island residents every resource of the Federal Government in carrying out the work of repairing the damage caused by Wednesday's hurricane and tidal wave.

The third French Line employee involved in the defrauding of the line of $62,500 by means of "washed" United States internal revenue stamps was arrested yesterday when he arrived here on the-French liner Champlain.

A stream of Sudeten German refugees from Czechoslovakia has been pouring across the border here. German officials estimated that 170,000 had come to Germany. Great numbers of German inhabitants of this border region have been fleeing to the interior.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The editorial in THE TIMES concerning the Brooklyn-Battery tunnel states that the public is more interested in "whether or not we need such a tunnel in the near future than in any dispute over its effects on traffic."

The Bourse here was dominated completely this week by the political developments in Europe, and the gloomy contents of the Dutch budget presented late on Tuesday and the announcement of a material increase in taxation contributed to the depressed tone that characterized the latter half of this week. Fears of a retardation

Charles Houston, 25 years old, who attempted an assault on the downtown 28,500-foot peak of K-2 in the Himalaya Mountains, last Summer, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen accompanied by R. H. Bates of Philadelphia, who was one of his companions on the climb.
More than 150 homing pigeons were released from the roof of the RCA Building in Radio City yesterday morning on the first leg of the nation-wide Seagram pigeon derby.

War-risk rates were doubled here yesterday, sending quotations on some cargoes to levels 200 times those in effect prior to the Czechoslovak crisis. At the same time underwriters notified shippers that all war-risk insurance issued henceforth would exclude coverage on shipments ultimately destined for Germany, without regard to where they may be shipped originally.

The new $160,000 red brick postoffice in this Republican village, which local officials never sought and now find not in complete architectural harmony with buildings of old English type in the business district, was placed in service today without ceremony.
With apartment renting for Oct. 1 occupancy in its final week, brokers and landlords continued to report long lists of new tenants for houses in all parts of the city. Those reported yesterday were:

Mrs. Alice Neilson Strohmeier of Englewood, N. J., daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Hans Jacob Neilson, was married to John C. Turrell of this city last night in Christ Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, by the associate pastor, the Rev. Benjamin F. Saxon.

After a chase through State House corridors and on State Street in front of the State Capitol buildings today Alfredo Besnocchi, 419 Common-wealth Avenue, this city, wanted by Federal authorities for an alleged liquor law violation, was captured by members of the State House police force and United States deputy marshals.

The Most Reverend John G. F. Day, Archbishop of Armagh and Protestant Primate of all Ireland, died today in a private hospital at the age of 65. He was elected Archbishop on April 27, and had been Bishop of Ossory, Ferns and Leighlin since 1920.

Victorious Ann, the Fanfare Farm's consistent black mare, gained her sixth victory of the season, leading Pordina by two and a half lengths in the six-furlong Portsmouth Purse at Rockingham Park today.

Paced by home runs hit by Buddy Rosar and Charlie Keller, the Newark Bears trounced the Buffalo Bisons by 10-2 tonight to take a 2-1 lead in the International League's final play-off series. Atley Donald, Newark hurler, allowed eight hits.

Charles Cook Paulding, president of the Union League Club of New York and a retired vice president of the New York Central Lines, died suddenly this evening presumably of a heart attack, in his room at the Gideon Putnam Hotel, where he had spent most of the Summer. He wouldd have been 70 years old on Dec. 10.

The body of a man tentatively identified as John Monks, 65 years old, a handyman, was found here late today in a house on Perkins Avenue. Dr. Amos O. Squire, Westchester medical examiner, said the man had been dead about two years and had probably died of natural causes or had frozen to death.
The European situation has moved Chilean naval officials to speed up negotiations for the purchase of two 8,000-ton cruisers, plans for which are being studied.

Though required to conform to the academy routine which kept them from the field until 5 o'clock, the Navy football men started work today for the game here Saturday sta with Virginia Military Institute.

Business, faced with "a hostile Federal Government and a hostile public," must build good-will for it- sale self, Henry C. Perry, president of the Controllers Institute of America, told some 500 delegates to the Institute's seventh annual meeting wer yesterday in the Hotel Waldorf- cove Astoria.

I see that new school report cards, purporting to rate personality and traits of character, are to be issued, and this leads me to wonder if it is possible for one person scientifically and correctly to evaluate another in those terms, even if the subject is a child.
AMERICAN JEWISH YEARBOOK. (Jewish Publication Society of America, $3.) The fortieth volume, covering the period from Sept. 26, 1938, to Sept. 13, 1939.

GUNNAR GUNNARSSON'S autobiographical narrative of a red-headed farm boy in Iceland, begun for us so happily with the appearance of "Ships in the Sky" last January, now continues with a sequel called "The Night and the Dream."* This covers some ten years more in Uggi Greipsson's life-from the time he is 8 until he is about 18.

Premier Benito Mussolini delivered yet another speech today--at Verona this time--and once again appealed urgently to the London and Paris governments to abandon Czechoslovakia before it was too late and war became inevitable.
The European crisis was a major theme of sermons yesterday as Jews throughout the nation thronged places of worship for the observance of Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year's Day.

J. A. Herlihy, former director of engineering of United Air Lines, has been appointed vice president in charge of operations, it was announced yesterday by the company. He succeeds H. W. Schroeder, who becomes vice president in charge of safety and conformance with Civil Aeronauties Authority regulations.

Practically all classes of cattle old steady today, but it was a slow and draggy trade on everything except strictly choice and prime mediumweights and weighty steers, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Hogs sold generally 10 to 25 cents lower. Lambs were strong.

Four units of members of the Advertising Club have been formed in a drive by the club for 500 new members set to begin next week. Lowell Thomas, president of the club, is "commander-in-chief," G. Lynn Sumner is "field marshal" and Edward J. Hegarty Is "chief of staff."
With two weeks remaining before Army's game with Columbia, Coach Bill Wood excused only two of his varsity players today as the Cadets started preparation for their first major contest.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 21: Decreases of $16,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans; $65,000,000

An investigation was begun by authorities to learn the origin of a fire that destroyed the Stockton Villa Hotel today, causing $15,000 damage. The blaze broke out on the fifth floor of the five-story 100-room wooden structure near a chimney and spread quickly to the rooms.

The Very Rev. Joseph M. Noonan, president of Niagara University, told enrolling students today that he was prepared to dismiss summarily any professor defending theories of comparative racial qualities. The university is a Catholio institution..
The war threat from the Czechoslovak crisis has rendered this the tensest moment the German people have experienced since the world conflict.

With $13,500 at stake in the 108-hole open golf tournament still raging here over the Fenway course, there were plenty of blue chips in evidence today. A blue chip in golf is a short shot that leaves the player very blue, sometimes verging on the purple or apoplectic tinge.

Four teams in the National Football League are waging a keen fight for passing honors, having completed 50 per cent of their aerials, and the New York Giants have ousted the Washington Redskins for the aerial leadership in the third week of play, according to statistics announced yesterday.

The Governments of France, Britain and Czechoslovakia replied promptly to President Roosevelt's dramatic appeal, voiced in the name of 130,000,000 people, for a peaceful solution of the crisis in Central Europe.
The Department of Commerce said today that a better demand for raw materials caused an increase of 17 per cent in imports of merchandise in the United States in August, compared with July.
After two weeks at Hershey, the Pennsylvania varsity football squad worked on Franklin Field today, Coach George Munger directing morning and afternoon sessions.
Brother combinations continued to hold the spotlight as the Long Island Golf Association held another of its amateur-pro tournaments at the Brookville Country Club today.
A total of 181 awards in four Spring sports at Columbia was announced yesterday by Reynolds Benson, athletics manager. Varsity and freshman athletes and managers were rewarded.

Lang don- Post of New York, who has been president of the American Federation of Housing Authorities, gave up the post today to John Carroll, chairman of the Massachusetts State Board of Housing, and was elected to the new post of chairman of the board of directors of the organization at the opening session today of its three-day meeting.

With the conclusion of transfer agreements with Holland and Norway, the problem of transfers for the service of German loans-a situation brought about by the Austrian anschlusshas been set up on a new basis.

Britain rushed her preparations for an immediate war today. An order was issued calling out all anti-aircraft units of the Territorial Army, which corresponds to the National Guard in the United States and which will be the British people's chief reliance against bombing raids.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Sept. 21, aggregated $8,573,000,000, or 11 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 7 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.
Automobile production increased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index rose to 30.6 from 25.5. The figure for the week ended ept. 25, 1937, was 133.6.
Four marines were killed and two others injured tonight when their Lockheed plane crashed into shallow water of the Potomac River immediately after a takeoff from the marine base here.

Britain announced last night that she and Russia "will certainly stand by France" if that nation should go to the defense of Czechoslovakia. This information was not delivered to Herr Hitler before his speech but a personal note from Prime Minister Chamberlain was given to him urging further negotiations.

Dr. Harvey N. Davis, president of Stevens Institute of Technology, Hoboken, N. J., advised students yesterday in an address at the beginning of the college's sixty-eighth year that if they wanted to avoid sub-professional occupations later they should concentrate on one of the two basic branches of engineering.

Retail advertising display linage in seventy-nine major cities in the week ended Sept, 17 declined 12.3 per cent from the corresponding week of 1937, according to Advertising Age. Volume for the week was 21,028,335 lines, as compared with 23,969,568 lines a year ago.

Dr. Maurice Lautman, who specialized on rheumatic diseases, died Friday at his home in Hot Springs, Ark., according to word received here yesterday by friends. Dr. Lautman, who was 49 years old, succumbed to a heart attack.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Worth of Jackson Heights, Queens, have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Marie Worth, to Joseph Wheeler Pepper Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Wheeler Pepper of Tallahassee, Fla.

Because the fleet-footed Ben Chapman was nabbed trying to execute his second bit of larceny on the bases and because Pinky Higgins followed a juggling act with an overthrow, the Yankees sneaked through to victory over the Red Sox yesterday in the final appearance of Joe Cronin's band at the stadium.

The Queen Elizabeth, to be launched today, is a little larger in tonnage than the Queen Mary, a little longer. Probably she will be a little faster. Yet she will not stand apart--the biggest, swiftest, most luxurious liner ever built.
The War Department disclosed today that the Second Division of the army would be reorganized into a highly mobile unit as a probable model for other infantry forces.

A sharp decrease in the number of strikes, workers involved and mandays idle during the first seven months of this year, as compared with the first seven months of 1937, was reported today by Secretary Perkins.

The Brooklyn Edison Company yesterday filed with the Public Service Commission of New York a petition seeking approval of issuance of $4,240,000 of its consolidating mortgage bonds to refund a similar amount of first consolidated 4 per cent gold bonds of the Edison Electric Illuminating Company and which mature on Jan. 1, 1939.

Reports of a possible clash between the liberal and Old Guard elements in the Republican party over the nomination of candidates other than for Governor reached here tonight as the first of the delegates arrived for the opening of the State convention Wednesday.

Chicago's onrushing Cubs cut Pittsburgh's National League lead to a game and a half today by defeating the St. Louis Cardinals, 6 to 3, and tomorrow will face the Pirates in the first of their all important threegame series.

GOLDIN--Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Golding and son convey their wishes to their friends and relatives for a happy and prosperous New Year. KRASSAY-Mr. and Mrs. Julius Krassay and family. 315 East 80th St., extend New Year's greetings to their friends and relatives.

Assurances of the willingness of his government to solve its dispute with Germany by. pacific processes were contained in a reply by President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia to President Franklin D. Roosevelt's appeal to European nations to continue negotiations for a peacefulsettlement.

It is not necessary to review the history of the present controversy with the trucking industry. Buffice it to say that the interruption of service last week and today has not only caused great losses to business and industry but undue hardship to untold numbers of innocent persons within the city and in the hurricane-stricken areas of Long Island and in New England.

The Rev. James J. McGuone, 31 years old, formerly connected with St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church, 1,183 Franklin Avenue, the Bronx, was killed here tonight when the automobile he was driving struck a traffic island and overturned on the Bronx River Parkway Extension near the Croton Lake Bridge.

A personal message from President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia to President Ignaz Moscicki of Poland, was brought from Prague by plane this . afternoon by a special messenger and given to the Czechoslovak Minister here for immediate transmission.
