Despite gathering war clouds abroad, fifty spokesmen from ten foreign countries joined American business executives today in urging a path to peace through revitalized international trade at the opening sessions here of the tenth annual Boston Conference on Distribution.

A strike of drivers and matrons operating the 160 vehicles of the Children's Bus System which, under a contract with the Board of Education, hauls 20,000 children to school daily-among them many cripples and detectives and onefourth of them students in parochial schools-was called suddenly yesterday.

John F. Montgomery, United States Minister to Hungary, and Mrs. Montgomery are at the Sherry-Netherland. President Justice and Mrs. Pelham St. George Bissell have left Wayside, their country home in Freeport, L. I., and are at 270 Park Avenue for the season.

Despite a rise in traffic accidents for the past week-end, figures covering deaths and injuries for the week declined sharply last week in the city, the safety bureau of the Police Department announced yesterday. The most noteworthy drop was in the number of fatalities.

Tom Shaw, labor leader, who held office under Ramsay MacDonald in both Labor Cabinets, died today at the age of 66. Mr. Shaw, who had been secretary of the International Federation of Textile Workers since 1911, except for an intermission of two years, became ill a few days ago while visiting in Belgium.

Winners of regional competitive scholarship awards to incoming students at Mount Holyoke College were announced Thursday by President Ham, as well as Regents scholarship awards and prize winners for high academic standing.

Following are the texts of the authoritative statement issued yesterday on Britain's decision to join in defending Czechoslovakia in case of attack and of Prime Minister Chamberlain's statement early this morning replying to Chancellor Hitler's speech:

The final club tournament of the season, the Autumn Plates, for sixteen-goal teams, was concluded at Meadow Brook today when the Long Island team won the trophies, defeating Cleveland, 11 to 5. After the match the prizes were presented to the winners by Mrs. Gerald Dempsey.

The idea of granting homestead tax exemptions to encourage home ownership continues to gain ground. Several States have been added this year to the list of those giving preferential tax treatment to dwellings.

New York City will publish a book describing the operation of its departments and agencies for distribution prior to the opening of the World's Fair on April 30, it was disclosed yesterday. Mayor La Guardia has instructed each department to prepare a review of its work in 1938 for inclusion in the new volume.

Assurances that the United States is ready for any financial emergency that might result from war in Europe were given this afternoon by Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr., at his press conference.
Fletcher Bowron, former Superior Court judge, celebrated his inauguration as Mayor today getting "bawled out" by a traffic cop. The Mayor didn't like it.

Clean Out, a 6-year-old daughter of Pompey who appears to have regained her best form, carried the colors of Mrs. Vera S. Bragg to an easy victory in the Firearm Class D Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday to register her third straight triumph. She had won at Saratoga and in her previous outing at Belmont.
Regular army troops of the 1st Brigade, 1st Division, commanded by General Walter C. Short, succeeded today in driving out enemy "Red" forces which threatened the military reservation- here.

The Rev. Grafton Burke, M. D., Alaskan missionary and medical officer of the Protestant Episcopal Church of America, died Sunday in Seattle where he arrived from Fort Yukon last Summer suffering from a nervous breakdown.
J. Fletcher Farrell, executive of Sinclair oil companies since 1916 and a banker for many years in Chicago, died here last night at his home at the age of 60 following an illness of several years.

Continuing the adventures of the eccentric and socially minded millionaire, Frank Capra will make "Mr. Deeds Goes to Washington" as his final picture for Columbia. The cast, as in the original, will be headed by Gary Cooper and Jean Arthur with many of the supporting players from "Mr. Deeds Goes to Town."

The Village Board of Southampton voted today to decline an offer of WPA aid in cleaning up after Wednesday's hurricane. Many trees were blown over and considerable damage was done to the waterfront of this exclusive Summer resort.

The Guild of the Catholic Chapel of the Most Holy Trinity at the United States Military Academy, West Point, is now making plans for the third annual military ball in aid of the chapel. The event will take place in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor here on the night of Oct. 29, following the ArmyNotre Dame football game.

Business in the stock market here was virtually at a standstill today as developments in the European political situation were awaited. Most sections of the market reflected calm, however, and prices in general were steady after being marked down sharply all along the line.
The Democrats, their campaign program snarled by the refusal of Senator Robert F. Wagner to run for Governor, were laying plans yesterday to draft Governor Lehman.
Baron Charles Kruchina, Hungarian commissioner general to the World's Fair, signed a final contract yesterday afternoon for his country's participation in the exposition.

Willie Hoppe and Joe Chamaco divided the first two blocks of a twelve-block three-cushion exhibition match at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy yesterday. Chamaco, champion of Mexico, won in the afternoon, 50 to 45, in fortyfive innings.
Placed beside the news from Europe these days, an announcement by Senator Wagner that he will run for his present office and no other does not seem very important.
Governors of nine States agreed at a conference here today that States should not erect trade barriers at their boundary lines or enact laws interfering with free trade.

It is Katharine Cornell's wish to play in "Herod and Mariamne" for a limited engagement only, say from eight to twelve weeks at the most, regardless of how favorably it might be received by the Drama Critics Circle.

Burney Blackwell Skiles, an instructor in the history department of Long Island University, Brooklyn, died of a heart attack on Sunday night at his home, 50 West Ninth Street, Manhattan. His age keep was 44.

The New York Dock Company has notified the New York Stock Exchange of the extension to Dec. 31 of the time within which 5 per cent serial gold bonds due on April 1, 1938, may be deposited under the recapitalization plan.
Whether they finish second, third or fourth in the National League race, the Giants have voted thirtyone full shares of the world series money, Manager Bill Terry announced yesterday.

Truck drivers of New Jersey, who have been negotiating for six weeks for a new contract, yesterday voted a concurrent strike with the New York truckmen to obtain the same benefits as to hours and wages as those sought in New York City.
Warren Lee Pierson, president of the Export-Import Bank at Washington, conferred with Chilean authorities today.

The full story of last week's hurricane will never be told. We can never get the whole picture of people in thousands of homes in the exposed areas, listening to the howl of a wind such as most of them had never heard before, hearing the crash of falling trees, perhaps watching with horrified eyes while water crept across the floor.

The Princeton football squad's offensive weapons were put to a searching test on University Field today. Coach Tad Wieman sent the squad through an hour and a quarter's stationary scrimmage to wind up the session. He also picked forty-four for his varsity squad.

With numerous wholesale houses in the apparel field closed yesterday because of the religious holiday, activity was curtailed sharply. Resident offices reported a steady flow of orders for ready-to-wear, but said that individual commitments were small.

Columbia's football squad worked at top speed yesterday at Baker Field for the opening game Saturday against Yale in the Bowl at New Haven. Starting the third week of practice, Coach Lou Little eliminated the morning session, but the players more than made up for the cut in hours by the intensity of their drill in the afternoon.

The Securities and Exchange Commission, in entering today upon its first reorganization duties under the Chandler amendments to the Federal Bankruptcy Act, issued a statement of policy under the new law in which the SEC emphasized that its new functions in corporate reorganizations would be "purely advisory."

Business was almost at a stand still today with the Jewish New Year and a truck drivers' strike influencing factors. Some jobbing houses were closed in deference to the Jewish holiday. With reference to slaughter of cattle, calves and lambs, some houses closed tight, a light lamb kill at others.

Authorities sought the body of a Aver reported second victim of a modern Bluebeard today after finding the dismembered body f a woman in a shallow grave on a ranch near here. Inquiries also were being made into the whereabouts of five other women.

" Weather reports: "Paris, rain all over France; forecast, more rain with southwesterly winds. London: rain, general throughout the British Isles; forecast, more rain with morning fogs. Berlin: fair with barometer rising."

For an hour tonight, facing directly an audience of 15,000 in the Sportspalast, Chancellor Hitler addressed the German people listening in by order at loudspeakers over all the land and his speech was far from being the expected defiance of British and French public opinion steadily rising against his Czechoslovak ultimatum.

The marriage of Miss Carol Whitney Van Etten, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Rutan Van Etten of 375 Park Avenue, to Dr. Albert D'Errico of Dallas, Texas, will take place on the afternoon of Oct. 18 in the Central Presbyterian Church. The ceremony will be performed by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Theodore Cuyler Speers.

Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, after a full day in the New England hurricane and flood area, announced tonight there would be unlimited government funds to carry out the rehabilitation of the six New England States and part of New York.
History is the favorite subject with applicants for a teacher's license in the New York City schools.

Miss Elizabeth Constantine Lane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Henry Lane of Tokeneke, this place, has chosen the afternoon of Oct. 8 for her marriage to Chester E. Ingraham Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ingraham of Bristol, Conn.

The Canadian Club of New York will honor Sir Gerald Campbell, the newly appointed High Commissioner to Canada, and Lady Campbell, with a dinner and presentation Friday evening in the club's quarters in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, on the eye of their departure to Ottawa.

A verdict of guilty of first-degree murder was brought today against Tomas Lopez de Victoria at Ponce in the killing of Colonel Luis Irizarry, National Guard officer, on July 25, when an attempt was made to assassinate Governor Blanton Winship during the celebration of the fortieth anniversary of the landing of the Americans on this island.

An engraver and two printers today confessed that they counterfeited nearly $400,000 in New York Central Railroad bonds and American Express Travelers' checks which were offered for sale throughout the country last Spring. They were seized Saturday by State's attorney's police.
Torrential rains and flood waters accompanying last week's hurricane have taken a heavy toll of rich farming land throughout the storm-swept area of the Northeastern States.

Two students at the Portsmouth (R. I.) Priory School have been missing since the hurricane last Wednesday, according to a teletype alarm sent out today by the New Rochelle police to all New England States.

Dr. Frank R. Smith Sr., member of the original Johns Hopkins Hospital staff under Dr. William Osler, died today at his home here. His age was 82. He had been ill since Sept. 2 and death resulted from a heart ailment.

The marriage on Sunday afternoon in Litchfield, Conn., of Mrs. Eleanor Munroe Green of that place, daughter of the late Henry Smith Munroe, Dean of the Columbia University School of Mines, to James Freeman Curtis, New York attorney and Assistant Secretary of the Treasury under President Taft, was revealed yesterday.

For the second time within two months, District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn proceeded yesterday to conduct a personal investigation into rumors of "official corruption" involving, a member of his office and this time centering about a fur swindle in which five policemen and four other persons have been indicted.

As the Connecticut River receded rapidly today and. Hartford and other stricken towns in Connecticut mobilized local armies of WPA and similar agencies for the tedious work of cleaning and rehabilitating inundated areas, attention turned back to the human problem and the job being done by the Red Cross.

John L. Lewis, head of the Committee for Industrial Organization, arrived yesterday on the Panama Pacific liner City of Norfolk from Mexico City, here he attended the congress of trade unions of LatinAmerican countries.
Week-end developments, Chancellor Adolf Hitler's speech and varying interpretations of both ruled world markets yesterday.

America guilt must go forward to the "good new days" of improved city life rather than return to the "good old days" of rural life, said E. L. Mosley of Colorado Springs, president of the International City Managers' AssociatiO, in a speech today at the opening of the organization's silver anniverersary conference.

The hurricane that blew substantial areas of New England into the water is now history and Yankee pluck and enterprise have the situation well in hand, but warning is herewith given Lou Little and his Columbia Lions that they are venturing into dangerous territory In invading the Yale Bowl on Sat??.
The Charles Francis Press of 461 Eighth Avenue received a contract yesterday from the Board of Elections to print 1,200,000 copies of the proposed new State Constitution on a bid of $23,750.

St. Anns Ave, 127, (9-22961); Eustacchio Coretti to Gluseppe Miloscia, 127 St. Anne Ave, extends mtg to March 5, 1942, 5 1/2 per cent; $10,000. Hering Ave, (15-4275), w s, 161 ft n of Rhinelander Ave, 31x100; William Flintrop to Knickerbocker Federal Savings and Loan Assn. 640 Madison Ave, due as per bond; $7,200.

The Insurgents' fourth counterattack in the Ebro sector, after being pressed for seven days with greater intensity than any of their previous efforts, has come to a sudden halt. For two days there has been no activity on this front.

Louis George Haas of White Plains and Scarsdale, secretary for the last fifteen years to General Cornelius Vanderbilt and former office executive of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad and the Seaboard Airlines, died here yesterday in the United Hospital at the age of 73. He suffered a heart attack in July and another one early this month.
Replacement costs of losses on Federal and State property in the Long Island storm area last Wednesday were estimated today at $1,500,000.

Dartmouth's football forces began work today with new enthusiasm for next Saturday's game against St. Lawrence. Coach Earl Blaik supervised an afternoon session featured by passing and strategy against five, six and seven man lines, and finished with a signal drill for the first eleven.

New proposals for a wage contract between the International Longshoremen's Association and the ship lines operating from Atlantic Coast ports were submitted yesterday by Joseph P. Ryan, president of the association, at a five-hour conference with the ship owners.

No outward sign of anxiety or excitement can be noticed in The Netherlands and no conspicuous military measures have been taken. Although the development of the European situation is followed with the keenest interest, The Netherlands do not seem as much impressed as their neighbors.

Here some highlights of Chancellor Hitler's speech today on the Gzechoslovak crisis: The time has come to talk business. I have made an offer to Herr Benes (President of Czechoslovakia). It is nothing else than realization of what he himself has already conceded.

The Federal Farm Security Administration is turning over its facilities in storm-stricken areas for the immediate relief and rehabilitation of farm families, it was announced yesterday by Philip H. Henderson, regional supervisor of rural rehabilitation, at the Farm Security Administration offices, 45 Broadway.

Meeting for the first time since the World War, 400 officers of the Seventy-seventh Division of the A. E. F. held a reunion dinner last night at the University Club. The occasion was the twentieth anniversary of the start of the division's participation in the Battle of the Argonne in September, 1918.

The text of Chancellor Hitler's address today on the international situation follows: On February 22 I made before the Reichstag deputies a fundamental demand concerning which there could be no bargaining.

Count Robert van der StratenPonthoz, Belgian Ambassador to the United States, arrived last night on the French liner Normandie, having cut short his vacation at home because of the international crisis.

Institutions were principals in a number of the city realty deals announced yesterday, when several properties uptown passed into new ownership. The Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank sold to a client of Frederick Zittell Sons, Inc., the six-story new-law tenement at 205 East 103d Street.

Reports issued yesterday continued to show how passenger revenues in the East accelerated their decline after the increase of 25 per cent in coach rates made last July. The New York Central reported a drop of 17 per cent in these revenues in August, the first full month in which the increased rate was in effect, while the Baltimore Ohio reported a decrease of 19.5 per cent.

President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia is scheduled to broadcast from 5 to 5:10 o'clock this afternoon over the Columbia, the National, and the Mutual systems. He is to speak from Prague and is to tell Czechoslovakia's attitude toward the German demands.
The battleship Texas and the cruisers Philadelphia and Savannah went down the Delaware River from the Philadelphia Navy Yard today.
Officials of truckmn's unions in Camden and Philadelphia will meet

A stoporder suspending effectiveness of a registration statement covering securities to be issued for the financing of an apartment-hotel building in Dallas, Texas, under an arrangement known as the "Clyde Plan," after its author, Walt Clyde of New York, was issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The body of a woman picked up in the ocean off Coney Island Sunday morning by a fishing smack was identified early this morning at the Kings County Morgue as that of Mrs. Georgia Peiker, wife of Harry C. Peiker, assistant to the general manager of the Home Owners Loan Corporation at Washingtion.
A decision of the Federal Court of Appeals at Portland, Ore., is instructive for the light it throws on two aspects of the Wagner Labor Relations Act and its administration.

The San Carlo Opera Company presented Verdi's "La Traviata" at the Center Theatre last night before a capacity audience. James Melton, radio and movie tenor, made his second appearance as a guest artist with the company, singing the role of Alfredo.

Introducing its two "luxury liners" for 1939, the "Special" and the Deluxe," to dealers in the New York region,. Dodge division of Chrysler Corporation yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania held an advance announcement meeting for 330 dealers and 800 salesmen from Northern New Jersey, South Central and Northeastern New York and Eastern Pennsylvania.

Hering Ave (15-4275); w s, 161 ft n of Rhinelander Ave. 31x100; Tuscan Building Construction Corp to William Flintrop, 1,917 Hering Ave. Allerton Ave (16-4440); s w cor of Boston Rd, 163x234; Leo Weil to Le-mil Realty Co, Inc; mtg $53,800.
American radio amateurs in thirty States have enabled Harvard scientists to learn new facts about the behavior of the electrified "E" layer some seventy-four miles above the earth.
This state was working hard today to shake off the 'effects of last' Wednesday's hurricane, while 15,000 rescue workers continued to search the ruins of the waterfront districts for bodies.

Running contrary to the seasonal trend, new business booked by furniture manufacturers last month ran ahead of the July volume for the first time in six years, according to the monthly summary of furniture business issued yesterday by Seidman Seidman, public accountants. During the last five years August bookings have averaged about 11 per cent less than in July, whereas business last month was 2 per cent better.

Uncertainty over the debt and fiscal policy of the nation was blamed by General Hugh S. Johnson as one of the reasons for lack of progress in an address before the National Wholesale Druggists Association here today.

Admiral Sir Heathcoat Grant, who served with the British Navy, for fortythree years, died here yesterday at the age of 74. Admiral Grant was attached to the British Embassy in. 1912 and 1914. During the early part of the World War, he was stationed in South American waters and later became senior officer at Gibraltar.
Mr. and Mrs. Archer P. Fahnestock gave a luncheon in the Persian Room of the Plaza yesterday for Prince and Princess Boris Scherbatow, who returned recently from Biarritz, France.
After weeks of bombing activity in Kwangsi, Japanese planes today appeared again over Canton and four machines dropped bombs on the waterfront and near Lingnan University.

George Gershwin, composer who. died in Beverly Hills, Calif., July 11, 1937, left a net estate of $341,089, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. Mr. Gershwin died- without leaving a will and the entire estate passes to his mother, Mrs. Rose Gershwin of 25 Central Park West.

The Workers Alliance probably speaks only for a small minority of the persons on Government work relief. Otherwise there would be real reason for concern in the undisguised political activity and pressure of the Alliance.
Jan Masaryk, Czech Minister to London and son of the founder of the 20-year-old Czechoslovak republic, said tonight after Adolf Hitler's speech:

Eli Newmark, former Ocean County slot machine and liquor still operator, who was a fugitive from justice from Sept. 8, 1936, until yesterday, was sentenced here today to eight years in a Federal penitentiary and fined $25,000 by Federal Judge Guy L. Fake.

John Henry Lewis, light-heavyweight champion of the world, signed yesterday to defend his title on Oct. 14 against Al Gainer of New Haven in the New Haven Arena The bout, scheduled for fifteen rounds, will be promoted by Andy Neiderreiter and Lou Raymond of New York.

The German Ambassador to the United States declared last night that it was "too late" to meet the Czechoslovak problem with solutions that might have been acceptable a few years ago, and intimated that the only alternative to a forceful untangling of the question was Czech capitulation to Hitler's demands.

A solemn requiem high mass in honor of the late Cardinal Hayes and the late Mgr. Patrick N. Breslin, former Dean of the Bronx and former honorary president of the College of Our Lady of Good er a Counsel here, who died on June 28, will be celebrated tomorrow morning in the college chapel. Mgr. Breslin is interred in the chapel crypt.

The first decline in five weeks was registered last week by the Wholesale Commodity Price Index compiled by the National Fertilizer Association, which dropped to 73.2 from 73.8 in the week preceding. A month ago the index stood at 73.1 and a year ago at 87.1, based on the 19261928 average as 100.

Atlanta won the right tonight to represent the Southern Association in the Dixie series with Beaumont of the Texas League by defeating Nashville, 8 to 3. The Crackers took the Southern's Shaughnessy final play-off series, four games to one.

Sixteen private utilities, which are fighting the Tennessee Valley Authority, today asked the Supreme Court to enjoin the government agency from generating electricity, selling power or building plants in competition with the private interests, or establishing regulation in the territory affected.

John P. Frey, chief of the A. F. of L. Metal Trades Department, attacked Federal regulation of wages and industrial relations today in his annual report to the metal trades conference, and called for greater cooperation between labor and industry.

Holystone, 7-year-old chestnut gelding from the Stables of Crispin Oglebay of Gates Mills, Ohio, today was named champion hunter of the forty-second annual Bryn Mawr horse show after splendid performances with Miss Muriel Cleland of Bedminster, N. J., up. Holystone took seven ribbons during the past four days of the exhibition.

A member of a rare branch of the whitefish family is included among about twenty specimens of Arctic fish recently received by the American Museum of Natural History from Manitoba, Canada, the museum announced yesterday.
President Roosevelt was requested today by the Philadelphia Federation of Churches to set aside

Negotiations looking to sale of the electrical division of the Memphis Power and Light Company to the city of Memphis were suspended today with the announcement of Paul B. Sawyer, president of the National Power and Light Company, top holding corporation, that he would not recommend acceptance to his stockholders of the offer made by the city.

The Workers Alliance convention, at its final session tonight, pledged its political support today to all candidates of the American Labor party, Labor's Nonpartisan League, the Minnesota Farmer-Labor party and the Commonwealth Federation of Washington and Oregon.

A 4-year-old boy playing with matches in the second-floor hallway of a six-family tenement house at 219 Franklin Street, in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, caused a fire yesterday, according to the police, which resulted in injuries to four persons.

The foreign exchange market broke further yesterday to levels of cheapness not previously seen in several years as the developments in the European crisis again speeded the flight of capital to this country.

Steel operations this week are scheduled at 46.7 per cent of capacity, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This represents a decline of 0.6 point, or 1.3 per cent, from the rate of 47.3 per cent last week.

DAME NATURE, a comedy in three actS, by Andre Birabeau, derived from the French by Patricia Collinge. Staged by Worthington Miner; settings by Norris Houghton; production under supervision of Theresa Helburn, Lawrence Langner and Mr. Miner;

Allan B. Salinger, secretary of the protective committee for stockholders of Loft, Inc., in a statement issued yesterday said that there were "two outstanding facts" which the Phoenix Securities Corporation in its explanation of the circumstances surrounding the granting and exercising of Loft options "fails fully to cover."
All England would endorse a vote for war in aid of Czechoslovakia, if such action were taken after the resumption of Parliament on Wednesday, one of its members dedared here yesterday.

The Department of Labor had labor troubles of its own tonight. Seventy-two employes of the Bureau of Immigration and Naturalization declared that Secretary Perkins had "disregarded" their 7-to-1 vote against an order moving them from the air-conditioned Labor Department Building to "an unventilated loft building."

Convinced that further negotiations between union and operator representatives would produce no settlement of the truck drivers' strike that has paralyzed shipping in New York City for more than a week, Mayor La Guardia submitted a compromise proposal to the negotiators whom he locked in City Hall last night and demanded an end of the strike by noon today.
Continued anxiety over the situation in Europe brought in further liquidation on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and prices eased into new low ground for the current movement for some positions.

Former Assemblyman Oscar B. Smith of this town died today at the Presbyterian Hospital in Newark after an illness of several weeks. His age was--71. Mr. Smith, who had conducted an undertaking business here for the last thirty-eight years, served on the Morris County Board of Freeholders, 1903-05, and was Republican Assemblyman from Morris County, in' 1909-10.

The Art Adventure Fair will be opened with a preview tonight at the New York Museum of Science and Industry, Rockefeller Center. Designed to indicate to amateurs the opportunities inherent in the arts for leisure-time activity, the Fair will continue until Oct. 23.

The Gordon Baking Company reported yesterday for the first six months of 1938 a consolidated net income of $558,029, after charges. After dividend requirements on the 6 per cent preferred stock, the income was equal to $18.35 each on the 30,000 shares of common stock outstanding.

Having returned from Philadelphia without any serious injuries, the New York Football Giants will start practice today at Innisfail Park for their second National League contest with the Pittsburgh Pirates at the Polo Grounds next Monday night.

Canada virtually has exhausted its quota of. the United States trade in red cedar shingles, according to information received today by the Department of Trade and Commerce from its trade commissioner in New York.

Running on a platform calling for a $100-a-month pension for an persons over 50 and a job for all young people, George C. Surrock, a former employee of Bloomingdale Brothers, last night announced that he would be a candidate on an independent ticket for Congress in the Sixteenth District.

Walter Peirson, a leather goods manufacturer, died today at his home in Radnor at the age of 82. He entered the leather business early, joining his father, Christopher C. Peirson, first Burgess of West Philadelphia.

William D. Flanders, president of the Lawyers Title Corporations of New York, which succeeded by merger last August the New York Title Insurance Company and the Lawyers Title Corporation, announced yesterday that the following have been elected directors of the corporation:

The Civil Aeronautics Authority will begin next week a survey of the airports of the country as a basis for recommendations to Congress concerning Federal participation in construction, operation and maintenance of a national system of airports and the extent of such participation.

Renewing an appeal for a $500,000 relief fund, Norman H. Davis of the American Red Cross reported to President Roosevelt today that 63,000 men, women and children suffered losses in last week's hurricane that swept New York and New England, causing greater devastation than the hurricanes that occur more frequently in the South.

The City Movers Association, an organization of the smaller housing moving firms in Manhattan, has approved a schedule calling for a rate of $7.50 an hour for a truck and three men and $9 an hour for a truck and three men. This is a slight increase over the rate of last Fall.
General John J. Pershing, Commander-inChief of the American Expeditionary. Forces in the World War, returned to Paris today. He had been resting at Aix-en-Provence for two weeks.

The Delco-Frigidaire Conditioning Division of General Motors Sales Corporation, Dayton, Ohio, has introduced a new heating device, called a "quik-action" oil furnace, which is claimed to be revolutionary in design.

Fines totaling $5 were paid yesterday by Lester Callazo, 26 years old, a deaf-mute automobile driver, after he was arraigned before Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio in Traffic Court on charges of passing a red light and driving without a license.
Harold A. Rosenberg has been appointed buyer of linens and domestics, draperies, blankets and comforters for C. Ludwig Baumann Co., Brooklyn, Jamaica and the Bronx.

Attorney General Herbert R. O'Conor was virtually assured tonight, two weeks after the State primary, of receiving the Democratic nomination for Governor of Maryland in the party convention on Wednesday.
The Federal Government should clear up promptly the questions of tax exemption on governmental obligations and of intergovernmental immunity from taxation of salaries of State and Federal

The Society for. the Publication of American Music will publish this season Edward Burlingame Hill's sextet, Op. 39, for flute, oboe, clarinet, bassoon, horn and piano, it was announced yesterday. Previously announced for publication is Douglas Moore's quartet for strings.

Recurrent waves of selling and buying in response to each fresh turn of events in the European crisis swept over the stock market yesterday and at the close prices in the pivotal issues were down 1 to 3 points on the day.

The personal columns of The Times of London carried many advertisements today for places in the country away from air raids. A contractor offered to build a concrete underground shelter for eight persons "ready for use, [pound]30."

Myron C. Taylor, former chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation, who was chairman of the conference at Evian, France, for the relief of refugees, returned yesterday on the Normandie of the French Line.

John Cowper: Powys's new book, "Enjoyment of Literature," will be published on Oct. 17 by Simon Schuster. It is a survey of world literature from the time of Homer and the Old Testament down to the writing of Thomas Hardy and Marcel Proust.

Prices of foreign loans crashed yesterday in their widest collapse since the current war alarms became acute. Trading in these issues on the New York Stock Exchange was unusually active and quotations fell 2 to 13 points.

The average interest rate on the Treasury's weekly bill offering of approximately $100,000,000 increased from 0.106 last week to 0.142 on the issue sold today, according to an announcement by Secretary Morgenthau.

Herman Fakler of the Millers National Federation, Washington, was elected president of the American Trade Association Executives, succeeding North Storms, at the Pittsburgh convention of the group, it was announced here yesterday.
Vito Marcantonio, Republican-American Labor party Congressional candidate in the Twentieth District, Manhattan, formally opened his campaign yesterday with a plea for liberal and progressive support.
Lafayette College students were urged not to became academic hitchhikers by President Lewis at the opening convocation today. The entire student body and the faculty were present.

Harold Silverman pleaded not guilty yesterday' before Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora to an indictment by the extraordinary grand jury charging him with felonious participation in a bakery racket.

Dr. Graham Taylor, pioneer social service worker and founder of the Chicago Commons, died today at his home in Ravinia, Ill., at the age of 87. For almost fifty years Dr. Taylor had been a Chicago institution, helping through his settlement work to solve the problems of the foreign-born and the needy in the densely populated districts.

An informal "Buy it in Brooklyn" campaign was started yesterday by twelve of Brooklyn's business leaders with the double purpose of stimulating local retail purchasing and awakening a greater civic interest in the borough on the part of its people.

American exporters have been doing so little advertising in Central European countries that the current war scare has had a negligible effect on their plans, H. N. Elterich head of the export advertising agency of that name, said yesterday.

Vojta Benes, elder brother of President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia, arriving in the United States yesterday morning as an unofficial ambassador of good-will to the American people, declared that the Czechs "are behind their guns, ready to fight to the last breath and to the last man" for the preservation of their war-born republic.

The waterfront lost its trucking service yesterday as the strike of truck drivers was resumed, but officials of ship lines withheld action in the hope that settlement would be reached before their piers became clogged.

Not guilty pleas were entered in General Sessions yesterday by three more of the nine members of the New York Electrical Contractors Association who were indicted last Friday by the New York County grand jury on misdemeanor conspiracy charges in the alleged "rigging" of bids on public and private work totaling $25,000,000.
Two youths assaulted and robbed a man yesterday morning on the downtown platform of the Ninth Avenue elevated station at Fortysecond Street, but were captured by policemen after a two-block chase.

Elliot R. Brown, foreman of the jury in the recent Supreme Court trial of James J. Hines, the Tammany district leader, yesterday issued a statement on behalf of eleven other jurors and himself, ineluding the two alternates, protesting against "unjust criticism" by another juror of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey after the close of the case in a mistrial.

Stockholders of the International Silver Company will meet on Oct. 27 to vote on a voluntary plan of reorganization, the main feature of which would be to give in exchange for each share of present preferred stock one share of new 5 per cent

Arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Vincent Sweeney in Felony Court, Ridgewood, Queens, on felonious assault charges, Hyman Cohen, 26 years old, of 720 Alabama Avenue; his brother, Harry Cohen, 28, of 682 Wyona Street, and Leo Fleischmann, 36, of 283 Liberty Avenue; all of Brooklyn, were held for hearing Oct. 3.

Intervention of President Roosevelt in the railroad wage dispute was made certain today when nineteen railroad unions, authorized by an overwhelming vote of their members, set zero hours for striking against the proposed 15 per cent pay cut.

A 20 per cent increase in men's shirt production in August over July brought the industry's operating .capacity to 83 per cent as against 69 per cent in the preceding month and 64 per cent in August, 1937, the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers reported yesterday. The production rate was 30 per cent greater than in August of last year.

The freakish behavior of the tropical hurricane that ravaged Long Island and the New England coast last week made the task of charting its progress and issuing warnings of its approach one of the most difficult the Weather Bureau has faced, Dr. James H. Kimball, the meteorologist in charge, said yesterday.

Supporting President Roosevelt's appeal for peace, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, co-winner of the Nobel Peace Prize in 1931 and president of the Carnegie Foundation for International Peace, declared in a statement yesterday that the United States could not stand aloof from the European crisis.
Declaring the oil tanker Mercury was classified as a "hot ship" by the National Maritime Union, members of the International Oil Workers Union refused to put a cargo of gasoline aboard her today.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Mary Gracia Neville, daughter of Mrs. George Wilder Neville of London, England, formerly of this city, to Henry Millar Fitzwilliam Rawlings, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry E. Rawlings of Montreal.

The 10,250 officers and 105,000 enlisted men of the navy for the first time in history are almost 100 per cent American born, it was disclosed today in nativity tables just completed by the Bureau of Navigation.

Mary Pickford announced today that she favored an international sitdown strike by women to prevent war. "The women of the world,. somehow should stage an immediate sitdown strike directed to prevent this threatening war," the former movie star told a group of women at luncheon.
The wheels of destiny are moving fast. The announcement that Great Britain and Russia will join France in a triple front if Germany invades Czechoslovakia is a clear and momentous answer to Hitler.

The six-family house at 3,609 Fifteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, was sold by J. Tabachnikoff to a client of William Liss, broker. Sale was for $10,500 and was subject to a mortgage of $6,500. The property has a reported annual rent roll of $2,424.

Dr. Henry Stoesser, an examining physician for the Prudential Insurance Company of America and president of the board of trustees of the Queesnboro Public Library, died yesterday at his home, 91-43 Eightieth Street, Woodhaven, Queens. He was 76 years old.

Among firms reported yeseterda as having signed contracts for commercial space was the Diversey Corporation of Chicago, chemical manufacturers,. which leased quarters for executive and sales offices in the Time and Life Building, Rockefeller Center. A. Sheldon Jaffe was the broker in the transaction.
United States Ambassador William C. Bullitt today issued a statement advising Americans, in view of the European situation, to return to the United States.

A veteran test pilot voiced the opinion today that Major Gen. Oscar Westover, chief of the Army Air Corps, crashed to his death in a military plane Wednesday because he violated a canon of flying by attempting to recover too quickly from a stall.
Working feverishly behind large straw-matting screens, men of the German Labor Front could be seen today constructing fortifications along the Rhine bank.
Signal practice, a light dummy scrimmage and a long session of calisthenics under Trainer Frank Kavanagh oc- by cupied Cornell today in the season's last daily double workout.
Three fight clubs in widely scattered parts of the city will conduct shows tonight, with the New York Coliseum in the Bronx promising to attract the largest crowd.

Josef Hofmann has resigned as director of the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia, it was announced last night. The distinguished pianist, who has occupied this post for twelve years, said that he regretted resigning, "but as the directorial duties absorbed a great deal of time, they interfered with other of my musical interests."

Memphis, Tenn., will be in the market, on Oct. 18, with an issue of $1,000,000 revenue bonds, for which bidders are to name the rate of interest. The issue, dated Oct. 1, 1938, will mature on Oct. 1, 1942 to 1956.

T. D. Taggart's Yale O'Nine, highly regarded as 1939 Kentucky Derby timber, scored with ease in the fastest six-furlong time of the meeting today. The Peter Hastings gelding reached the wire five lengths ahead of D. J. Sullivan's Good Odds, who took second money in a photo finish with W. J. Hirsch's Soldierette. Three others competed in this event, the Pinehurst Purse.

Wall Street was about as much at sea over the effect on world peace of Chancellor Hitler's speech yesterday as were the various capitals. That part of the German leader's text which became available before the close of the market first forced prices up from the low levels of the day and then in the last fifteen minutes of trading brought a reaction that eliminated the fractional gains made a few minutes earlier.
Chancellor Adolf Hitler's speech tonight left opinion in League of Nations Assembly quarters divided over whether he had made the war danger less or greater than his ultimatum published this morning.
September, a month from which one seldom knows by experience what to look for, and which this year has presented an extremely varied picture of weather conditions, is after all going out gently.

The National Iron Bank of Morristown sold to the Labuc Corporation of Newark the plot 50 by 200 feet at 33-35 South Street, Morristown, N. J., through Louis Schlesinger, Inc., brokers. The latter has arranged a lease of a building to be erected on the site to Sears, Roebuck Co. David J. Lehman is the architect for the proposed structure.

The Mohawk Trail, completely blocked in two sections by landslides, trees and washed-out bridges and culverts, may be closed all Winter, according to reports received today by the Boston Automobile Club.
Knoweldge that Chancellor Adolf Hitler would speak tonight hung like a thundercloud over the political atmosphere of this capital all day.

Tech High of Atlanta, Ga., scored its third straight football victory of the season, defeating Pompton Lakes High, 7-0, today. Frank Heinold hit the center of the New Jersey team's line for 2 yards early in the second period to culminate a 55-yard march by the fast Southern team.

At the convocation opening the seventy-fourth year of Vassar College this morning, Professor Amy L. Reed of the Department of English urged the 1,240 assembled students to think of the four years of college not merely as preparation for the future but as living for its own sake.

Manning Doherty, Minister of Agriculture in Ontario's United Farmers government from 1919 to 1923, died today. He was 62 years old. He was head of the brokerage firm of Doherty, Roadhouse Co. since 1930. His son, Brian Doherty, wrote the play "Father Malachy's Miracle" which ran successfully in New York last year.
Official displeasure over the attitude of the United States press toward the Sudeten problem 'was frankly expressed tonight by the Diplomatische Korrespondenz.

A Presidential call for a special meeting of the Cabinet tomorrow afternoon, "because of the existing situation," coupled with feverish activity at the State Department on behalf of Americans stranded in European danger zones, combined today to make official Washington keenly aware of the fast-developing war crisis in the wake of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's Berlin address.
The Canadian Cabinet will meet at 11 o'clock tomorrow morning to consider what steps this country should take in view of today's darkening of the war clouds.

Eight outstanding high school graduates of the metropolitan area have received Schweinburg scholarships of $300 each from Cooper Union for 1938-39, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Edwin S. Burdell, director of the union.

From their London conference Premier Edouard Daladier and Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet returned this afternoon by air to find there was no necessity even for calling a Cabinet meeting before tomorrow morning. Events had spoken for themselves.
Annual meeting, Controllers Institute of America. Sessions 10 A. M. and 2:15 P. M. Dinner 7 P. M. "Cost Accounting in Public Business," Dr. Arthur E. Morgan. Henry C. Perry, toastmaser.

Industrial production advanced sharply in August, according to the monthly survey of business issued yesterday by the statistical division of the National Industrial Conference Board. The survey reported that business prospects have shown material improvements.

Substantial gains in restoring telephone and telegraph links with the areas isolated by Wednesday's storm were reported yesterday by New York representatives of the communications companies, who said that service in several sections was "almost normal."

The impression of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's speech here is that he has not "banged the door on negotiations" and might be prepared to make some minor concessions if President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia capitulates on the main points.

The Mohawk Trail, completely blocked in two sections by landslides, trees and washed-out bridges and culverts, may be closed all Winter, according to reports received today by the Boston Automobile Club.
Knoweldge that Chancellor Adolf Hitler would speak tonight hung like a thundercloud over the political atmosphere of this capital all day.

Tech High of Atlanta, Ga., scored its third straight football victory of the season, defeating Pompton Lakes High, 7-0, today. Frank Heinold hit the center of the New Jersey team's line for 2 yards early in the second period to culminate a 55-yard march by the fast Southern team.

At the convocation opening the seventy-fourth year of Vassar College this morning, Professor Amy L. Reed of the Department of English urged the 1,240 assembled students to think of the four years of college not merely as preparation for the future but as living for its own sake.

Manning Doherty, Minister of Agriculture in Ontario's United Farmers government from 1919 to 1923, died today. He was 62 years old. He was head of the brokerage firm of Doherty, Roadhouse Co. since 1930. His son, Brian Doherty, wrote the play "Father Malachy's Miracle" which ran successfully in New York last year.
Official displeasure over the attitude of the United States press toward the Sudeten problem 'was frankly expressed tonight by the Diplomatische Korrespondenz.

Permits for residential construction fell 31.4 per cent from July to August, primarily due to a marked decrease in New York permits, aocording to the Department of Labor. There was an increase of 55.9 per cent over August, 1937, however.

Commercial failures in the United States in the week ended Sept. 22 rose to 193, as compared with 159 for the same week a year ago and 232 a week ago, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. This was the lowest figure for any full week this year. The totals for the weeks ended Sept. 8 and July 7 were lower, but in each case only five working days were included.
Seventy-four of the 298 churches in the New Jersey Conference of the Methodist Church had new pastors assigned to them at the close of the 102d annual session here today.

In the ivy-clad University Chapel 1,400 undergraduates and teachers of Fordham College gathered yesterday morning for the traditional red mass of the Holy Ghost, which formally opened Fordham's ninety-eighth academic year.

Creation of a great lake in the mountainous country lying north of Hoover Dam has resulted in the opening up of part of a large gold area where mining used to be virtually impossible because of its ruggedness.
Going into the stretch of the 108-hole open tournament at the Fenway Golf Club, Bill Burke of Cleveland was leading the field with a seventy-two-hole score of 286 tonight.
Pivotal issues rebounded on early part of Hitler's speech, after weakening 2 to 5 points, but reacted and closed lower with leaders off 1 -to 3 points; turnover, 1,226,090 shares.

Isolation of the United States from the thoughts and movements in other countries is no longer possible, Paul Swain Havens, president of Wilson College, told members of the Presbytery of Carlisle here tonight.

How the news of the safety of two women at Woods Hole, Mass., was obtained during the storm last Wednesday by a sevenhour process involving cabling Paris was revealed here yesterday. No other means of communication was available.
Miss Virginia Guard of Pelham won the qualifying medal in the fourth annual women's invitation tournament of the Briar Hills Golf Club with a fine score of 42, 44--86 today.

President Roosevelt's appeal for peace to the four European powers directly concerned brought a chorus of approval from Senators and Representatives in Washington today tempered only by demands that the United States maintain strict neutrality in the crisis.
A fifty-nine-family apartment house has just been completed by Samuel Barkin Sons, builders, at 8 Gramercy Park from plans by J. M. Felson, architect.

Among the arrivals yesterday on the Gdynia America motor liner Batory was 81-year-old Charles William Jacobsen of Copenhagen, who made his first Atlantic crossing to visit three of his sons living in the United States.

Premier William Aberhart of Alberta said last night that in the present European crisis the British, French and Russian people are being stirred by a "foolish concept of contractual obligation which demands its fulfillment no matter what the conditions are."

Wheat prices fluctuated in a most erratic manner today, the character of the political news from Europe being the dominating influence. Small buying or selling orders frequently caused rapid price changes.

Newspaper captions in Germany tell this story: The Hamburger Fremdenblatt: "Germany's Last Word--Text of the German Memorandum." The 12-Uhr Blatt: "The Fuehrer Commands! We Follow -- Mussolini: 'If Other Countries Take Military Measures We Will Do the Same.'"

The American Hobby Federation opened its first hobby show yesterday at the Spear Auditorium, 22 West Thirty-fourth Street. On exhibition, besides the results of such standard hobbies as collecting coins, stamps and autographs, are many unusual items, such as crocheted houses, carved peach-stones, novelty wishbones plaster casts of boxers' fists and three-dimensional postcards.
The Nieuw Amsterdam of the Holland-America Line will sail today for Plymouth, Boulogne and Rotterdam. Among passengers listed are Commander John Gade, U. S. N.;

Inflation of German currency is being accelerated alarmingly by military preparations. Contrary to the general rule for the third week in September the Reichsbank return for Sept. 23 shows a large increase in loans and a substantial rise in banknote and total circulation.
Precautionary measures taken by the [British] Gibraltar authorities include the fixing of a boom at the entrance to the admiralty harbor.

The Latonia Jockey Club gave over its program to benefit racing for eleemosynary institutions of greater Cincinnati today. As is customary at racing benefits, the featured attraction was a Gentlemen's Cup race.
Much relief has been caused in Belgium by an announcement in the evening press that German troops have been withdrawn from the German side of the frontier in the vicinity of Eupen and St. Vith.
McLin and Driver Henry Thomas, the winning Hambletonian combination, captured the forty-sixth trotting of the Kentucky Futurity on the Grand Circuit today.

Favorable and unfavorable factors in the week's world trade developments were reported today by the Department of Commerce on the basis of cablegrams and radiograms from its foreign trade attaches as follows:...

The sixth set of plans for units of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's housing development in the Bronx was filed yesterday. They cover two eight-story houses on land bounded by the south side of Metropolitan Avenue, east. of Unionport Road, the west side of Purdy Street, the west side of Odell Street, the west side of Olmstead Avenue and the west side of St. Raymond's Street.

The Federal Power Commission heard testimony today that the operations of the Jersey Central Power and Light Corporation, through connections with other utilities, extended into New York and Pennsylvania.
An unidentified youth about 17 years old plunged five stories to his death last night when, the police said, he was dicovered ransacking an apartment at 23 East 109th Street.

Representatives of the Port Raritan District Commission at Perth Amboy asked the Rivers and Harbors Board today to approve proposed improvements of the Raritan River. The commission and other interests asked that the river be dredged to a fifteen-foot depth from Perth Amboy to New Brunswick.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed--By MYRON E. BENSON, farm laborer, Dover Plains.-Liabillities, $1,147; no assets. EVAN V. QUINN, salesman, 70 E. 96th St.-Liabilities, $564,578, mainly contingent; no assets. The Olean Trust Co. of Olean, N. Y., where he was formerly in business, is listed as a judgment creditor for $522,294. CHARLES SCHNEIR, unemployed furrier, 615 Fort Washington Ave.-Liabilities, $3,094; no assets.
A $500,000 television transmitter is being installed by the Columbia Broadcasting System atop the Chrysler Building at an additional cost of $150,000, it was announced yesterday.

The neutrality legislation that remains on the statute books, although it was not applied in the case of China and Japan after having been imposed against both sides in the Spanish civil war, will figure in the deliberations of the Administration at the outset in the event of a European war.
Long lines of motorized units of Germany's new army in full field equipment paraded along Berlin's main streets for three hours last evening and then disappeared as mysteriously as they had appeared.
Two boys from the Portsmouth Priory School in Portsmouth, R. I., who started last Wednesday for Southampton, L. I., by way of Canada, were taken home today by their parents.
Reappointment of Casey Stengel as manager of the Bees for 1939 was announced by General Manager Bob Quinn tonight to "forestall any rumors to the contrary."

Between the excited voice that was raised in scorn and anger in the Sportspalast on Monday and the quiet, patient, almost tragic voice that spoke from London yesterday there lies the measure of all that is dear to the civilized peoples of the world.

With the movement of most other types of goods virtually at a standstill in New York because of the trucking strike, great vans loaded with household goods rumbled through the streets steadily yesterday and far into the night as the peak of activity was reached for the Fall moving season in the residential field.

The eight-room house on more than a quarter of an acre of land at 114 Brite Avenue, Scarsdale, Westchester County, was sold by the Home Savings Bank of White Plains to Mills Ripley. Louise O. Meuer, Inc., broker, negotiated the transaction.
Shippers and distributors of merchandise may apply for emergency truck service through the Department of Sanitation offices at 125 Worth Street, Manhattan, where the telephone number is WOrth 2-3221.

The Republican State Convention, which will open here tomorrow, will nominate District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey of New York County for Governor Thursday, and Mr. Dewey will accept the nomination. That acceptance is certain was learned tonight as delegates and party leaders arrived from the metropolitan district;

The situation on the Franco-German border remained unchanged today, save that German farmers owning land on the French side and French farmers owning land on the German side were not permitted to cross the frontier. In most frontier villages there are a number of such owners.
A benefit entertainment, under the patronage of several women of prominence, was given last night in La Maisonette Russe of the St. Regis to inaugurate the fourth season of that restaurant.
Sam Snead made a sensational rush in the last two rounds and slammed his way to another golfing triumph today, winning the 108-hole open over the Fenway Golf Club course with a score of 430.

Billy Beauhuld, 139 1/4, Jersey City, knocked out Enrico Venturi, 140 1/2, Italy, in 2:20 of the sixth session of the main bout, carded for eight rounds, at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. A crowd of 1,500 saw the fight.

Because her fiance has been called to the colors by his native France, Miss Edith Roberts Groome, daughter of Captain and Mrs. John C. Groome of this city, was married this afternoon to Lieutenant Jean Albert Collin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Albert Collin of Paris.

Continuing his personal investigation into rumors of "official corruption" involving a member of his office and centering about a fur swindle in which three policemen and four other persons have been indicted, District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn, interrogated four witnesses yesterday before a Kings County grand jury.
The possibility of a last-minute appeal to Premier Benito Mussolini to use a moderating influence with Chancellor Adolf Hitler is reported under discussion by London and Paris.

Two sophomore linemen, Bob Hunt and Len Warner, continued to make a favorable impression with the Pennsylvania coaches today and may start in the opening game against Lafayette here Saturday. Frank Reagan, another newcomer, is slated to call the signals.

Concluding their season's business with each other in a gathering darkness that made them scarcely visible to the 12,585 paying patrons, the Giants and Dodgers split a double-header at Ebbets Field yesterday.

Lefty Vernon Gomez may not win twenty ball games this. year, but he has his eighteenth triumph safely stowed away in the Yankee bat bag, thanks to his victory yesterday over the Senators at the Stadium before a gathering of 2,773.

The Bank of France today raised its rediscount rate from 2 1/2 to 3 per cent. The advance in the rediscount rate of the Bank of France yesterday was the first official central bank response in Europe to the effects upon the money markets there of the growing political crisis.

President Roosevelt's second message to Chancellor Adolf Hitler of Germany, urging that negotiations for a solution of the European crisis continue, was broadcast to the world by short-wave radio in six languages last night.

Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein, who recently announced that he would fight any effort to have North Beach Airport designated as an Eastern airmail base, was assured here today by representatives of four major airlines that although they were considering North Beach Airport as an Eastern terminal, nevertheless complete abandonment of Newark Airport as a passenger terminal was not contemplated.

A verdict of suicide by gas asphyxiation was filed today by Dr. Amos O. Squire, Medical Examiner of Westchester County, in the death of Robert Bissell, 45 years old, Curb Exchange representative of Gude. Winmill Co.

The Long Island Golf Association held another of its one-day amateur tournaments at the Plandome Golf Club today, with Ralph Strafaci of Shore View taking the low gross honors with a score of 37, 37-74, two strokes above the regulation figures for the 6,309-yard layout.

The stock market here seemed to be more optimistic today despite the harrowing uncertainties of the European political situation. Business continued small, but a number of small price gains were registered.
A string quartet by Frank Bridge and a piano quintet by Ernest roch, with the composer as pianist, were played last night in the Lenox Gallery of the New York Public Library,

After two days of quiet there was a renewal of violent attacks in the Ebro sector today. The Rebels, pressing forward with their usual artillery fire and aerial bombings succeeded in taking three elevations in the Coll de Coso area. Tonight the Loyalists were counterattacking.

Clanking and snorting like the famed taxicabs that took the Second Army of the Marne to the front, 800 outmoded Sanitation Department trucks converted City Hall Park into a huge outdoor garage yesterday as Mayor La Guardia mobilized his mechanized forces
Otto Baumgarten, twenty-five years a restaurateur, was honored last night at a dinner meeting of the Society of Restaurateurs at his own place, the Restaurant Crillon, 277 Park Avenue.

The Vatican newspaper, L'Osservatore Romano, asked in an editorial today whether a European war, if it should come, would not be "to maintain a date--the first of October" rather than "as has been contended, to maintain a feudal lordship of one State over people not its own."

The European crisis was imputed to man's revolt against the laws of God and to his abuse of the gift of free will, in sermons by rabbis here yesterday, the second day of Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year. Other sermon topics were Jewish education, Zionism and Jewish rituals.

Queen Victoria, bay filly by Peter Volo and out of Margaret Arion, was sold tonight for the top price of $7,600 at the first night of the Walnut Hall Farm yearling sales in near-by Donerail. Queen Victoria was purchased by W. H. Strang of Brooklyn.
Yugoslavia's attitude in the present European crisis was the chief matter of conversations today between King Boris of Bulgaria and Prince Paul, Regent of Yugoslavia, at Castle Bran, in Slovenia.

Dr. Charles P. Emerson, dean of the University of Indiana Medical School from 1911 to 1932 and past president of the Association of American Medical Colleges and of the National Committee for Mental Hygiene, died last night at the age of 66.

Columbus Ave, 725, 25.2x85.6 irreg; Louis J. Miccio to Central Savings Bank; p m mtg, 10 yrs, int per bond, $25,000. 2d Ave, 2,286, 25.8x100; Herbert Braasch to Tessa F. Wilks, 325 Riverside Drive; due Aug. 1, 1939, int per bond (half int), $5,161. 53d St, 3-5 E; Leasehold Stork Restaurant, Inc, to Hazel Billingsley, 983 Park Ave; due Sept. 21, 1938, 6 per cent; $20,000.
The new herb garden at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, containing about 100 herbs used in medicine and about sixty culinary herbs, was opened to the public yesterday.

About 6,000 army enlisted men are going to have their pay raised before Summer. War Department statisticians figured today that funds Congress provided this year for advanced grades and specialist ratings would result in the largest number of promotions since the World War.
Following is the text of the Czechoslovak Government's note rejecting Chancellor Adolf Hitler's Sudetenland demands, which was handed to the British Foreign Secretary, Viscount Halifax,

The San Carlo Opera Company will give two benefit performances today at the Center Theatre: the "Barber of Seville," this afternoon for the Municipal Art Committee; "Samson et Dalila," tonight in aid of the Jamaica Jewish Center.

That negotiations for the sale of the electrical properties of the Memphis Power and Light Company to the City of Memphis had not been broken off was indicated today when Paul B. Sawyer, president of the National Power and Light Company, parent corporation, denied that he had said that he would not even submit to his directors the $13,000,000 offer of the city.

A delegation of the Save Czechoslovakia Committee applied at Police Headquarters yesterday afternoon for a permit to hold a parade on Saturday, the last day set by Germany for the return of the Sudeten part of Czechoslovakia.

Because of the Jewish New Year holidays, the slaughter of those classes generally dressed kosher was suspended in most slaughter houses in the New York area yesterday. There was a light lamb kill at a few points, however. The truck drivers' strike Is still in force and is interfering with out-of-town shipments and receipts.
The special train bearing the 400 delegates and alternates from New York and Westchester counties to the Republican State Convention arrived at 8 o'clock tonight, one hour behind the schedule.
Alfred J. Ferry, former baseball pitcher and scout, died today at St. Luke's Hospital after an illness of two days. He was 60 years old.

Although war threatens in Europe, with the Soviet Union pledged to participate actively, War Commissar Klementy Voroshiloff is now in the Far East, it was learned today. He is attending a Communist party conference of the Far Eastern "front."
The list of storm dead was increased yesterday with the finding of an unidentified body on Long Island and the identification of the following:

Stocks declined following Prime Minister Chamberlain's speech and closed heavy with price changes mixed; turnover, 771,210 shares. Italian and Australian loans rallied, United States Government and other bonds irregular; transactions, $4,775,800.

Al Reid, 127, Bronx, outpointed Vince Dell'Orto, 126, Italian featherweight, in the star attraction of eight rounds at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of 7,000 saw Reid gain the decision on the strength of his aggressiveness and infighting.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Sept. 27, unless specified: Hong Kong to Manila: Alden, Barker, Paul Jones, Whipple. Guantanamo to Canal Zone: Bagaduce, YT129. Brooklyn, at Boston. Chaumont, San Francisco to Honolulu. Cuttlefish, Newport to New York. Cachalot, New London to Boston.

The following officers of the regular army, on duty with the National Guard and the Organized Reserves, Second Corps Area. are detailed as members of Central Marking Committees, for the purpose of conducting instructions in Command and General. Staff Extension Courses during the school year 1938-39:
John J. Hennessey, credited with building the Olympian and other trains while master car builder for the Milwaukee road, died here today in his home at the age of 91.
Miss Susan Dannat Griffith of 21 West Fifty-sixth Street, New York, died here early today after a brief illness. She was for many years a leading benefactor in Saratoga Springs.

Joseph Buerckel, Commissioner forAustria, spoke in Heroes Square here this evening to 100,000 persons. The general tenor of his speech-mostly shouted, this being the style of oratory the Viennese appreciatewas not unfriendly to a peaceful settlement by Germany with France and Britain.
Joseph V. Little, technical adviser for the Firth Sterling Steel Company, died at his home in Bala today at the age of 70.
James Cagney, motion - picture actor, motored to New York yesterday from his Marthas Vineyard home, which was struck by the recent storm.

As a test of the validity of an injunction restraining striking employes of the Busch Jewelry Company from picketing its stores the two C. I. O. unions involved will station pickets at each of the twelve stores in the metropolitan district, Harry M. Sacher, attorney for the unions, announced yesterday in Supreme Court.

Acting Governor Charles E. Loizeaux made public today a letter from President Roosevelt to Governor Moore assuring him that the establishment of five hosiery mills on homestead projects in the South is not intended to lower wage standards or reduce employment in private plants.

Stocks of crude oil and its products held by the principal marketing companies in California, except those at sales and service stations, amounted at the end of August to 150,467,639 barrels, a decrease of 13,063 from the 150,480,702 at the close of July, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.
New York City has received PWA grants totaling $12,581,310 for four of the sixty-nine non-Federal projects approved by President Roosevelt and announced by Secretary Ickes today.

Opposing the scrubs in a short scrimmage in preparation for the Columbia invasion Saturday, the Yale varsity today specialized in forward passing, Bud Humphsey doing most of the throwing to End Art Dyess and to Halfback Al Wilson.
Offensive and defensive aspects of punting were emphasized at Columbia yesterday in a rigorous fourhour workout at Baker Field in preparation for the opening game with Yale Saturday.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today reopened its proceedings for the determination of maximum hours of service for bus and truck drivers after labor organizations and trucking companies had asked for further consideration of the rules prescribed by the commission on July 12.

Eastern division players stole the spotlight during the third week of action in the National Football League. Stellar performances by three men from the West kept the Easterners from a clean sweep on the nineteen top-ranking places, according to statistics announced yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia was asked by the American Student Union yesterday to declare Friday, the day before the expiration of the German ultimatum to Czechoslovakia, "Peace Mobilization Day" to demonstrate feeling here in relation to the crisis.
Joseph Miller, veteran builder in Queens, died yesterday at his home, 104-15 118th Street, Richmond Hill, after an illness of seven months. He was 65 years old.
Walter Heber Wheeler, former New York commission merchant, died this morning in his Summer home in Colliers, N. Y., of a heart attack. He was 72 years old.

Governor Earle and other highranking Pennsylvania Democrats were accused tonight by Charles J. Margiotti, former State Attorney General, of preventing him from investigating the so-called "Erie gravel scandal" for six months after State police had made a report on it.

President Roosevelt said after a Cabinet discussion of the New England flood situation today that no special Federal machinery was contemplated for handling the relief problem involved and that funds already available to government-lending agencies probably would suffice to do the job.
The French Consul said today four French warships paying a good-will visit to Manila had been suddenly ordered to sail at noon today for an unannounced destination, possibly Saigon, French IndoChina.

Captain Bill Wood, Army's new head football coach, was introduced to New York newspaper men at the Army-Columbia dinner held at Jack Dempsey's Restaurant, Eighth Avenue and Fiftieth Street, last night.

Universal adoption of mediation, conciliation and voluntary arbitration as a substitute for force in the settlement of industrial disputes was urged as the only practical and desirable method of regulating the relations between capital and labor in an address last night by Edward F. McGrady, vice president of the Radio Corporation of America and former Assistant Secretary of Labor.
Tonight is the opening, under Brock Pemberton's banner, of "Kiss the Boys Goodbye," by Clare Boothe, whose topic is Hollywood's pursuit of the woman of the lost year or two, Scarlett O'Hara.

Mott St, 293, 76x64.4 irreg; Joseph M. Hart-field, referee, to East River Savings Bank; foreclosure ($26.50). 13th St, 524 E, 25x103.3: Antonio Genovese to Genzag Realty Corp. 116th St, 362 W, 18.9x100.11; Union Dime Savings Bank to Reldar Realty Co, 230 Park Ave; mtg $9,750 ($1.50).
Thomas Quigley McGoodwin, for the last ten years secretary and member of the board of the Standard Oil Company of Kentucky, died here tonight from bronchial pneumonia at the age of 69.
Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's statement in his speech today that he intends to persevere in his efforts to avert war has caused a wave of hope to sweep over Italy.

Trade in hogs and lambs was active today, but the former averaged a little lower, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. The demand for finished weighty steers and best light yearlings, as well as heifers of all kinds,

John P. Nicholas, manager of the livestock department of the Insurance Company of North America, 99 John Street, died yesterday at his home, 168 East Seventy-fourth Street, after a long illness. He was born in Baltimore County, Md., seventy-one years ago, a son of Wilson Cary Nicholas and Augusta Moale Nicholas.

Walter H. Wiley Jr., 18 years old, of 43-15 Forty-fifth Street, Long Island City, who was questioned in connection with the murder of a young couple in Queens, the socalled red circle murders, was named in three indictments handed up yesterday by the Queens grand jury.
Percy A. Miller, Town Commissioner of Irvington, was elected chairman of the Essex County Republican Committee here early this morning in a closely contested vote at the Essex House.

The thirty-sixth annual Piping Rock Horse Show, which will start today and continue until Saturday at Locust Valley, L. I., promises to surpass all the past shows in both the quality and quantity of the entries.
Miss Betty Jameson, 19-year-old golfer from San Antonio, Texas, today won medalist honors in the qualifying rounds of the annual Berthellyn Cup invitation tourney.
Albert M. Freeman, dean and teacher at Blair Academy here for fortyfour years, died this morning in the General Hospital, Easton, Pa., after an operation. He was 72 years old.

James E. Murray of 1,406 Hancock Street, Brooklyn, attached to the City Clerk's office in Manhattan and former property clerk in the New York Police Department, died on Monday in St. Vincent's Hospital.

After the first two rounds had been played in' the fourth annual invitation golf tournament over the Briar Hills course today all the favorites were still in the running, Miss Virginia Guard of Pelham, who yesterday won the qualifying medal, breezing through with an 8 and 6 victory over Mrs. W. B. Farrington of the home club and a 4-and-2 triumph over Mrs. Harry G. Cotter of Jackson Heights.

C. V. (Sonny) Whitney's handsome bay gelding, Estilista, a Monoculu horse from the Argentine that has contributed its full share to the success of its owner's Old Westbury team this year, won championship honors today in the nineteenth annual show of the National Polo Pony Society, held on the grounds of the Meadow Brook Club.

World-wide experiments in economics have created the need for adequate laboratories in which social scientists may test their theories and apply their analyses to actual conditions, Dean A. Wellington Taylor of the New York University Graduate School of Business Administration declared in his annual report to Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase, made public yesterday.

The "League to Amend the National Labor Relations Act," an organization seeking to "lessen the hardships" of the Wagner law, asked the State Board of Standards and Appeals yesterday to certify its application for incorporation.

The most illustrious team De Ormond (Tuss) McLaughry has developed at Brown was his "Iron-man eleven" of 1926, which went through the season unbeaten to win national acclaim for the durability of its individual members.

After a seven-hour session of the Canadian Cabinet, Prime Minister Mackenzie King announced tonight that his government was "in complete accord" with the statement made by Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain to the world today.
The Maritime Commision has approved the adjustment plan signed last month whereby the Dollar Steamship Line, Inc., will be able to resume extensive steamship services.

A $1,000,000 lawsuit over the Dionne quintuplets opened today before Federal Judge John P. Barnes, with the $1,000,000 value put on the right to sell pictures and books about them and possibly to take them on a tour of the country.

American and British interests in Shanghai enjoy the rights of unrestricted trade only in theory and actually are continually harassed by Japanese who are now working energetically to supplant all competitors, Walter Kelly,
Full mobilization of the British fleet will be ordered tomorrow as a "precautionary measure," the Admiralty announced late tonight.

President Roosevelt made a final plea for peace in a telegram tonight to Chancellor Adolf Hitler of Germany. He urged in the name of humanity and in behalf of the American people that negotiations be kept open for an adjustment of the Central European crisis.

QUEENS BUTTINE. MARY (June 10). Assets $38,056 gross; $28,989 net. To husband Anthony J. Buttine. Outstanding holdings in jointly owned property $28,751. Frederick S. Rauber, attorney, 39-15 Main St., Flushing.
Wheat prices fluctuated today in accord with the rapid changes in the character of the reports regarding the European political situation. Traders regarded the overnight developments

Kenneth F. Simpson, announced yesterday his resignation as Republican leader of the silk-stocking Fifteenth Assembly District. The resignation affects his chairmanship of the county committee of the district, as well as membership on the executive committee of the county committee for Manhattan.

Unconfirmed rumors of improvement in the European situation swept financial London today. As a result the, stock market, though still jittery and still war-minded, at the close did not need the agreement by dealers in government securities to stabilize prices near yesterday's close.

Seven German liners in the North Atlantic passenger trade, including the Bremen and Europa, will be far from their home ports on Saturday, the deadline set by Chancellor Hitler in his ultimatum to Czechoslovakia.
The text of President Roosevelt's appeal tonight to Chancellor Adolf Hitler of Germany to keep open the negotiations for settlement of the Sudeten dispute follows:
Learning how to be at ease, how to accomplish many things and live a peaceful life was stressed by President McAfee in her address at the opening chapel at Wellesley College today.
Edwin Richard Lawrence of 425 West 160th Street, former treasurer of the Times Square Trust Company, died Sunday in St. Elizabeth's Hospital after a short illness. He was 69 years old.
