Whether the intended meaning of the word "monopoly," as it is used in Section 2 of the Sherman AntiTrust Law, is broad enough to apply to corporations which operate industries without competition, was the subject of briefs submitted yesterday to Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey in the government's suit to restrain the Aluminum Company of America and its subsidiaries from alleged violation of that law.
A member of a labor union cannot sue an unincorporated brotherhood for damages because of his dismissal, but he can sue individual members of the union, the Georgia Supreme Court ruled Tuesday.

The monopoly investigation undertaken by the Temporary National Economic Committee is neither an attack upon nor a defense of business, but is an earnest search for facts upon which to build a national policy, a group of 300 trade association executives were told yesterday by three of the officials engaged in the investigation.
Hasty Star barely managed today to withstand the desperate stretch drive of J. H. Carr's Prospectus and win the feature race at Rockingham Park. He paid $4.84 for $2.

Mayor La Guardia, in a direct appeal to striking truckmen yesterday morning, succeeded at a stormy meeting in getting a majority of the strikers to accept his proposal for them to settle for a forty-four-hour work week on a pay basis of a forty-seven-hour week.
Dr. and Mrs. Roscoe R. Hyde of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Irene Hyde, to Dr. William Earl Moore of Newark, N. J., and New York.

The State of Maryland will offer for sale on Friday a new issue of $5,108,000 of road bonds, the issue being submitted for competitive bidding by the State Roads Commission. The bonds will be dated Nov. 1, 1938, and will mature serially on Nov. 1, 1940 to 1951. Bidders are to name a rate of interest not exceeding 3 per cent.

The badly battered defenders of Tienchiachen, "gateway" to Hankow on the north bank of the Yangtze River, are still holding out against Japanese forces that have been hammering the mountain fort for ten days.
The official German News Agency reported today that if Czechoslovakia should turn over the Sudetenland to Germany amicably by Saturday, German troops entering would find a "dead land."

A luncheon was given yesterday by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph T. Ryerson in the outdoor Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton for Mr. and Mrs. C. Perry Beadleston and the Misses Margaret MeG. and Edith A. Bead?? and Mary Ryerson.

A provision of the State Welfare law authorizing the Commissioner of Public Welfare to furnish food, clothing and "other necessaries" to children to enable them to attend school was cited yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Charles E. McLaughlin as justification for the recent action of the Board of Estimate in appropriating $200,000 to the Welfare Department for transporting children to parochial and other sectarian schools.

George Dunglinson Jr. was appointed today vice president in charge of traffic of the Norfolk Western Railway Company, effective on Oct. 1. He is assistant vice president. He succeeds the late G. F. Butler.

The London Stock Exchange became yesterday the first major securities market to take official cognizance of the possibilities of a European war. Rigid restrictions were placed on gilt-edge securities at the opening of trading and the market was orderly throughout the day. While the regulations were entirely those of officials of the Exchange,

Johnstown more definitely confirmed his place as the favorite for Saturday's $80,000 Futurity when he sped down the Widener chute yesterday to win the six-furlong dash as he pleased under scale weight of 122 pounds and in the remarkably fast time of 1:10 3-5.

Properties in Brooklyn reported yesterday as having been sold by the Colonial Realty Company, Inc., broker, included the three-family house containing fifteen rooms at 1,520 Forty-ninth Street, which was purchased by S. Gartner from the Lawyers County Trust Company. The structure is on a plot 40 by 100 feet.
Willie Hoppe and Joe Chamaco split the third and fourth blocks of their exhibition three-cushion match at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy yesterday.

Harry A. Redmond, member of the law firm of Jeffery, Redmond, Escher Murray, 1 Wall Street, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital after an illness of several months. Mr. Redmond, who lived in Plandome, L. I., was 53 years old.

Major Gen. Oscar Westover, chief of the Army Air Corps, who was killed in an airplane crash at Burbank. Calif., last Tuesday, was buried in Arlington National Cemetery this afternoon after services conducted by Chaplain Ora J. Cohee, U. S. A., in the chapel at Fort Myer. Interment was with full military honors in which the air corps paid an impressive tribute to its dead chief.

A warning to private-business as well as government in business to set their houses in order, particularly with respect to public policy and to a more accurate accounting of costs- and values, was sounded yesterday by Dr. Arthur E. Morsin, former chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, and Richard C. Patterson Jr., Assistant Secretary of Commerce.

Bernie Friedkin, Brownsville lightweight, defeated Jose Santos of Portugal in the feature bout of eight rounds at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, last night. A crowd of 3,500 persons saw the battle. Santos, a substitute for Jerry Mazza, scaled 130 pounds, as against 136 for Friedkin.
AMERICAN PHOTOGRAPHS, by Walker Evans. Museum of Modern Art, ($2.50.) A photographic record of contemporary civilization in Eastern America.

More than 200 aspirants for Princeton's minor and freshman Fall sports teams turned out for the first time today. Two of the groups, freshman football and varsity soccer, were greeted by new, coaching line-ups.

With 400 exhibits on view, ranging from a golf "caddie" on wheels to safety devices for making bathing less dangerous, the annual convention of the National Inventors Congress opened here yesterday. The gathering will continue through Friday at the Hotel Edison.
An analysis of the situation in Europe is presented here by a noted journalist, who was for several years head of the press department of the British Foreign Office.
Washington voters will pass Nov. 8 on an amendment to the State constitution, proposed by the Legislature, to permit a graduated State income tax, hitherto held unconstitutional.

The Royal and Ancient Golf Club, ruling body of the game in Great Britain, decided tonight to follow the lead of the United States in limiting to fourteen the number of clubs a. player may carry in competition.

Among the properties in New Jersey reported yesterday as having been sold was the seventy-five-car garage at 896-902 Communipaw Avenue, northeast corner of Mallory Avenue, Jersey City. The CocaCola Bottling Company was the purchaser. Mary A. Somers was the seller.

Dizzy Dean Ditched his great heart out and the tubs smack into the thick of the National League pennant battle today. With little on the ball besides its cover, Dean hurled a thrill-packed 2-to-I victory over the league-leading Pirates that left the Cubs trailing the Bucs by only half a game, with two more games between the clubs scheduled for tomorrow and Thursday.
Clay Ave (11-2782), w s, 984 f n of 169th St, 50x74; J. Rhodes O'Reilly to Sophie Saltzman, 2,146 Grand Ave. Washington Ave, 2,124 (11-3047); Antonio Scalone to Charles A. Wolgast, 304 Echo Pl.

Irvin Gleason's Nate Hanover, driven by Vic Fleming, won the Reynolds Pacing Stake today in straight heats, establishing a new world's record of 1:59 for 4-year-old pacers in the first mile. Lone Ace, owned by Thomas Thomas, Cleveland, was second to Nate Hanover, with Her Ladyship in third place.

Wilfred Garretson, 66-year-old golfer from Raritan Valley, who won the metropolitan senior championship recently at Siwanoy, took a lead of three strokes today in the annual New Jersey seniors' championship when he scored a 79 over the Essex Fells Country Club course.
Horatio Walker, Canadian painter, died today in his home on the Island of Orleans, near here. He was 80 years old and had suffered a paralytic stroke a month ago.

A committee for the Erie Railroad's $100,000,000 of 5 per cent refunding bonds headed by' Wilfred Kurth, .chairman of the Home Insurance Company, plans to file next week with the Interstate Commerce Commission a plan of reorganization for the line which would guarantee that its control by the Chesapeake Ohio would remain in escrow for five years, it developed yesterday.
The most ominous words in Hitler's speech are not the ones in which he declares that his patience is exhausted,

In view of the evolution of the international crisis and military measures taken in neighboring countries, The Netherlands Government has announced its decision to increase the frontier guard from 10,000 to 40,000 by calling up men living in frontier districts.

The Bomar Stable's Grand Slam, making his first start of the Fall season in this State, scored an easy victory in the Hillen Road Purse, outstanding race on today's program. The veteran son of Chance Play packed top weight of 118 pounds and closed a length in front of E. D. Shaffer's Evening Shadow.
The loss of life and devastation suffered in last week's storm mark that disaster as one of the outstanding tragedies of this region. The dead can only be mourned;

MARQUIS CHILDS has come back from Scandinavia with another interesting report, not a deep-reaching one but earnest and well-informed. He calls it "This Is Democracy: Collective Bargaining in Scandinavia,"* the implication being that American capital and labor have a good deal to learn from the experience of Norway, Sweden and Denmark.
Cows still come home along the evening path. Shame on this heart for doubting memory, And scorning dreams as some dim aftermath Of childhood which assails us treacherously.
In the chapel of Christ Church here this afternoon Miss Mary Hope Fedden was married to Arthur Davies Wingebach, son of Mr. and Mrs. August Wingebach of this place.

Distributors of foodstuffs are entitled to special consideration when asked to handle "free deals," one-cent sales and other special merchandising efforts for manufacturers, Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., told the thirty-ninth annual convention of the California Retail Grocers and Merchants Association tonight. Mr.
Covering by spot houses yesterday in the October delivery on the Cotton Exchange lent firmness to cotton values and momentarily competed with the European news as the chief market factor.

The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to reopen the New Haven's reorganization case for submission before Dec. 31 of a new reorganization plan which the road expects to present.

Navy football has been hard hit by the loss, for a time at least, of Johnson Wilson, head backfield coach, who was operated upon for appendicitis last night. His return to the field is expected in about two weeks.
President Roosevelt appealed to Chancellor Hitler anew last night to keep peace negotiations open, terming a resort to force "unjustifiable."

The Vingtieme Siecle's Luxembourg correspondent reported today that the Grand Duchy would remain neutral in case of war. Its railroads will not be used for the transportation of war materials and no war materials will be supplied to belligerents, even if this means closing iron and steel mills, it is said.

New orders for fabricated structural steel booked during August amounted to 102,539 tons, as compared with 87,154 tons in the preceding month and 124,879 tons in August, 1937, according to the American Institute of Steel Construction, Inc. This was approximately 20 per cent better than the monthly average so far this year.

George Preston Hotaling of 640 Park Avenue, estate and corporation lawyer, died on Monday at Doctors Hospital after being ill for six months. He was the last surviving member of the law firm of Forster, Hotaling Klenke, 76 William Street. His age was 81.
More than 100 persons attended the annual dinner of the Westchester County Golf Association at the Winged Foot Golf Club tonight.
President Roosevelt's plea for peace found an echo here. It was prominently displayed by the press alongside President Getulio Vargas's congratulatory message to Mr. Roosevelt.
As Oct. 1 with its dread portents approaches, there remains a fully precedented step which the President could take and which may probably have already been discussed in the Cabinet.

The Museum of Modern Art, in its temporary quarters at 14 West Forty-ninth Street, will open to the public today three exhibitions: Prints in color and black-and-white by the French artist Georges Rouault; American photographs by Walker Evans, and a group of approximately one hundred "useful objects" which sell in retail stores at prices under $5.
Former Mayor Claude A. Hill of Hackensack died late today of a heart attack in his home here. He was 57 years old.

President Leon Cortes Castro condemns war as a means of solving international conflicts and praises President Roosevelt's appeal to Chancellor Adolf Hitler and President Eduard Benes in a statement in the Prensa today.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the registrations of two over-the-counter brokerage houses in New York City had been canceled for the reason that the firms had discontinued business.
The Reds squelched Paul Dean's attempt for a third comeback victory today, driving him from the mound with ten hits in five innings and beating the Cardinals, 3 to 1.

Ignatz Meduski, 56 years old; Herman Oberg, 67, and Mrs. Alexandria Kulbacki, 52, all of 163 Chauncey Street, Perth Amboy, were killed tonight when the car in which they were riding was struck by a train of the Central Railroad of New Jersey at the Maurer Lane crossing here.
About 70 employee of the Plymouth automobile assembly plant here went on Strike today after what union officials said was a breakdown of negotiations with the company management.

After a wrangle between the Council and the Assembly of the League of Nations, in which the Council reversed its stand, Rafael Waldemar Erich of Finland held office today as a judge of the Permanent Court of International Justice at The Hague.

3d Ave, 616, 4-story tenement, 23.11x80; Central Hanover Bank Trust Co against Roberta A: Allen; due, $47,020; to plaintiff for $19,000. By EDWIN J. McDONALD 9th Ave, 701, 5-story tenement, 25.1x100; Peter Doelger, Inc. against Arbos Corp; due, $99,046; taxes, etc, $908; to plaintiff for $10,000.

Mike Jacobs announced yesterday that he was considering matching the winner of the Lou NovaGunnar Barlund battle with Joe Louis for the latter's heavyweight championship of the world Jan. 6 in Madison Sauare Garden.
Inflation of the German currency, apparently as a result of military preparations, is beginning to accelerate at a rate that must be causing misgivings within the country.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's address last night left a confused impression here. The immediate feeling was that the British Prime Minister had once again quailed at the thought that it might be necessary for the democratic States to stand up to Nazi threats and was thinking to prepare the ground for still another surrender by Britain and a renewed demand for the mutilation of Czechoslovakia.

While the political crisis in Europe still teetered on the brink of war, the crisis in the foreign exchange market plunged ahead yesterday to new complications. For the first time since the fall in the European exchanges began last July, a sharp cleavage appeared between the currencies of the potential belligerents and those of the neutral countries.
Charles T. Judge, retired superintendent of the Massachusetts Reformatory at West Concord, died tonight in his home at West Concord. He was 70 years old.
Alex MacLean, manager of Jack Johnson before the Negro won the heavyweight boxing championship of the world, died today of pneumonia contracted after an operation. He was about 65 years old.
A good-sized house attended the twin bill of "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" last night at the Center Theatre, given for the second time this season by the San Carlo Opera Company.

Gold production in California in 1937 amounted to 1,174,578 fine ounces with a value of $41,110,230, according to compilation of final--returns from mineral producers by the statistical section of the California Division of Mines.

Multi-family dwellings on the upper West Side figured in several of the realty deals in the city reported yesterday. After an ownership of about ten days, the two five-story apartment houses at 557 and 561 West 174th Street were resold, through Nehring Brothers, Inc., brokers, for a client of Kadel, Sheils Weiss to a buyer represented by J. Lemle Son.

Columbia University will enter its 185th year with exercises today at 3:30 P. M. in the McMillin Academic Theatre, Broadway at 116th Street. Addresses will be delivered by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, and Dr. Harry J. Carman, Professor of History, Classes will begin tomorrow in virtually all departments.
Magistrate Anna M. Kross opened Harlem headquarters at 2,260 Seventh Avenue, at 123d Street, last night in her campaign for the State Supreme Court. Her main headquarters are at the Commodore Hotel.

Charles Joseph Thale of this city, heating and air-conditioning engineer and vice president and a director of Almirall Co., New York, died yesterday in Mount Vernon Hospital after a brief illness. He was 54 years old.

A plea by Wisconsin officials for aid from the Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation in the moving of. this State's large surplus of canned peas will be made in Washington Thursday, it was announced here tonight.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,251,150 barrels, compared with 3,239,050 in the preceding week, an increase of 12,100, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 193,150 barrels less than the calculation of 3,444,300 daily by the Bureau of Mines for September.

Governors Island military authorities reported yesterday to the Missing Persons Bureau at police headquarters that Second Lieutenant William Robert Chamberlain of the United States Army Medical Administrative Corps had disappeared after leaving his home in Belchertown. Mass., on Sept. 14.

A group of public service commissions in the South today petitioned the Interstate Commerce Commission to consider as part of the record in the reorganizations of the Chicago, Indianapolis Louisville Railroad Company, known as the Monon, the portions of the record in the commission's proceeding in 1932 on the consolidation of railroads which contested a proposal to merge the Monon with the Baltimore Ohio.
" WPA was created only to do handmaiden service to industry and to the labor market," Nels Anderson, WPA director of labor relations told a Bennington College audience last night.

For the first time in a decade, the Democratic organization of the State approached the eve of a State convention uncertain of the identity of its ticket, and of its prospects of success in the November elections.

Scattered recoveries, particularly in foreign loans, featured slower trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The general trend, however, was toward lower levels, and all the major averages showed moderate declines on the day.

The Red Sox bunched fourteen hits off two Athletic pitchers today to defeat the last-place Mackmen, 11 to 1. Ross started for the Athletics and lasted five and a third innings, the Sox getting nine hits and four runs off him.

Creditor classes especially will be helped by the Chandler act, revision of the National Bankruptcy Law, which went. into effect Sept. 22, Brace Bennitt, membership and promotion director of the National Association of Credit Men, asserted tonight.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Miller of Los Angeles of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Wray Miller, to William T. J. Middleton of this city, son of Mrs. William T. Middleton and the late Mr. Middleton.

Protesting against the German stand in the Czechoslovak crisis, 1,500 persons took part last night during the after-theatre rush in the Times Square area in a demonstration organized under the auspices of the New York County committee of the Communist party.

The Mexican Army jumping team arrived in New York yesterday from Havana, Cuba, to begin preparations for the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden Nov. 5 to 12. The team will compete in nightly international military contests at the National.

Police Commissioner Valentine will promote three of his officers to inspectors, four to deputy inspectors, five to captains, fifteen to lieutenants and twenty to sergeants tonight at the opening of the departmental show, "Around the Clock With New York's Finest," at Madison Square Garden. The show will begin at 8:15.
The Interstate Commerce Commission was asked in a brief filed today by the Postmaster General to deny an application by Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc.,

A decision to close the Gloversville tannery of the Surpass Leather Company permanently was announced today by Harold Connett, president. In revealing that the closing order would be effective Oct. 5, Mr. Connett said the company would transfer its operations to its Philadelphia plant because it could "no longer afford to divide its production between two tanneries."

Speed as well as caution in the execution of the government's $800,000,000 slum clearance and low rent housing program was urged today by Nathan Straus, Administrator of the United States Housing Authority, upon the 200 local housing agencies enlisted in the effort.

President Roosevelt halted for sixty days any possibility of a nationwide railroad strike when he named a neutral fact-finding board today. The board is comprised of Chief Justice Walter P. Stacy of the North Carolina Supreme Court, Professor Harry A. Millis. until his recent retirement head of the Department of Economics of the University of Chicago, and Dean James M. Landis of the Harvard Law School.

The Chanin Building had a gross income for the year ended July 31 of $1,597,000 and an operating income of almost $1,000,000 after payment of ground rent, taxes and the setting up of the required reserves, according to Amott, Baker Co., Inc. The $6,093,500 first mortgage bonds outstanding earned at the rate of 6.8 per cent and holders of such bonds were paid interest of 5 per cent.

This historic community has already "struck up the band," so far as the women of the Republican party are concerned. Their observance of the second decade of their enfranchisement is evolving into an invasion, quiet but significant, of the sessions of the party convention opening here tomorrow.

Katherine Marjory, the Duchess of Atholl, first Scotswoman to win a seat in the House of Commons and wife of the Premier Earl of Scotland, declared yesterday that Adolf Hitler's reply to President Roosevelt's appeal for European peace contained "astonishing" statements.

The need for the nations of America to create new ties to protect them from war among themselves and to avoid the spread of other conflicts to them was stressed today by Dr. Carlos Concha, Peruvian Minister of Foreign Affairs, in a note to Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

Hank Greenberg, distance-clouting first baseman of the Tigers, poled two tremendous drives to center for his fifty-seventh and fifty-eighth home runs of the season today as Detroit swept a double-header with the Browns, 5 to 4 and 10 to 2.
With shortages beginning to develop in bulk items as a result of the truck tie-up, department stores were compelled in some instances yesterday to revise merchandising and advertising plans.

Courtlandt Nicoll, former New York State Senator, who died at Water Mill, L. I., on Sept. 20, in his fifty-eighth year, bequeathed legacies to two religious, one charitable and one public institution and his residuary estate to his widow, Mrs. Ione Page Nicoll, of 149 East Seventy-eighth Street.
Responsible sources reported today that three light cruisers here were being provisioned hurriedly. Navy officials refused to comment. The cruisers are the Cincinnati, Trenton and Concord.

Miss Ellen Sayles Webster, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ora Sears Webster of this city, was married this evening to Henry Erben Gaillard of Cleveland, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. B. G. Gaillard of Sutton Manor, New Rochelle, in the North Avenue Presbyterian Church here.

Moving swiftly in an undoubted dress rehearsal for Europe the League of Nations Council is understood to have agreed unanimously in a secret session this afternoon to execute the rest of Article XVI and declare that Article XVI's sanctions now become applicable to Japan because of her refusal to settle her dispute with China through the League Covenant.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges. Figures in many cases are subject to final adjustments.

The totalitarian theory of "racism," which arrays race against race, was assailed by the Very Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, in a sermon yesterday at the annual Red Mass of the Catholic Lawyers Guild. The mass was celebrated at the crypt of St. Andrew's Church, Cardinal Place and Duane Street.

At the annual meeting of group V, Savings Bank Association of the State of New York, held yesterday, Richard J. Wulff, president of the Fulton Savings Bank, was elected chairman of the association for the ensuing year, succeeding George C. Johnson, treasurer of the Dime Savings Bank.
The city's death rate rose for the week ended last Saturday, it was reported yesterday to Dr. John L. Rice, City Health Commissioner, by Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Records.

The subcommittee on priority of the Mayor's Citizens Committee supervising emergency truck transportation during the strike of drivers met yesterday under the chairmanship of William H. Chandler, manager of the Traffic Bureau of the Merchants Association, and later announced its specific duties.

The report of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Aug. 31, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income, after expenses and charges, of $1,294,363.
Cornell's scrubs were Colgate Red Raiders on the practice field today, but their aerial bombs failed to click with any great degree of accuracy against the varsity defensemen.

The large plot of land on the south side of Forty-third Avenue, 125 feet east of Kingsland Avenue, Elmhurst, L. I., was sold by the Guaranty Trust Company to Christian Zahn. The plot is 160 by 70 feet and will be improved with a commercial garage.

Mayor Frank Hague, on his return to City Hall today after arriving from Europe on the Normandie last night, predicted there would not be any war in Europe at this time. He declined, however, to state the basis of his opinion.

Clarence Hodson Co., Inc., will offer today 500,000 shares of Class A common stock of the American Business Credit Corporation at $6.75 a share. The corporation will employ the funds in the specialized forms of commercial financing in which it engages.

" The brutalized world in which you will have to spend your maturity will be more serious even than your personal losses and the shattering of your dreams, for it is your generation which will be most affected if war comes," President Ada L. Comstock told a thousand students gathered today for the formal opening of the college year at Radcliffe.
Jack Doyle, Irish heavyweight, neatly knocked himself out tonight in the second round of his fight with Eddie Phillips.
At a meeting of the directors of the Philadelphia Electric Company yesterday, John E. Zimmerman resigned as chairman of the board and was succeeded by William H. Taylor, president of the company.

The parts of the military machine continued being assembled today with perfect smoothness. Compared with 1914, the work of assembly is easier. Twenty-four years ago it was done somewhat covertly in order to avoid accusations that France was an aggressor.
Steel ingot production increased less than seasonally last week and the adjusted index eased to 67.4 from 67.7. The figure was 111.3 for the week ended Sept. 25, 1937.
The season of formal entertaining in the Persian Room of the Plaza was inaugurated last night, when many members of society were hosts at dinners and suppers.

MANHATTAN CLARK, GRETA POMEROY (Sept. 24). Estate, undetermined. To Elizabeth Osborn, employee, 40 E. 62d St., $5,000; Emily L. Tuckerman, cousin, 1,029 Park Ave., diamond ornament and pearl necklace; Emma Stone, Belleview Ave., Newport, R. I., Margaret S. Norris, Ridgefield, Conn., Ethel B., Clark 1,616 Bellmont St., Washington, D. C., Margaret G. Phelps, 12 E. 79th St.. Harold Burnet.

In one of the day's upsets, unseeded Owen Anderson of Los Angeles eliminated Frankie Parker, seeded No. 4, in the second round of men's singles in the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament today. The scores were 6-3, 6--1.

It was authoritatively said today that the recent Foreign Office pledge to aid Germany and Italy under the anti-Communist pact did not imply that Japan would rush into war against Russia if the Soviet supported Czechoslovakia in a war against Germany.

A committee of the New York Towboat Exchange, speaking for the towboat operators of the port district and Connecticut River ports, rejected yesterday a demand of the union representing their em ployes for a wage increase of $1 a day.
THANKS FOR TOMORROW, a melodrama in three acts, by Le Roy Bailey. Incldental music by Jewel Bennet, Beatrice Roderick and Raymond Cutis. Staged and produced by Walter Brooks. At the Bayes Theatre.

Broadcasting stations WBBC and WVFW of Brooklyn and the Federal Communications Commission joined today in asking the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia to remand for further hearing before the F. C. C. a case involving a ruling made more than a year ago by the commission barring stations WLTH and WARD from the air.
Following is the text of Chancellor Hitler's reply to President Roosevelt's appeal for peace: His Excellency, the President of the United States of America, Mr. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Washington.
Newark's champions took a 3-to-1 lead in games in the final International League play-off series tonight by defeating the Bisons, 9 to 7. The Bears need only one more victory to clinch the series.

With the State grain elevators at the port of Oswego filled and the Barge Canal temporarily blocked near Amsterdam, shippers have turned to railroad outlets and in the last three days have moved more than 100 carloads of grain to seaboard cities.

Eamon de Valera, Irish Premier, after listening to Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's speech, sent him the following telegram tonight as a personal message and not as one from the President of the League of Nations Assembly:

Herbert S. Carter Jr., since 1925 headmaster of the Harvey School in Hawthorne, N. Y., died yesterday at his Summer home in West Chop, Martha's Vineyard, Mass., after an illness of several months. He was born in this city on Sept. 30, 1900, a son of the late Dr. Herbert S. Carter.

The State-wide New Jersey truck drivers' strike appeared to be near a settlement last night as scores of individual employers either signed contracts or signified their intention of signing on the basis of the proposal made Monday night by Mayor La Guardia.

The New Jersey campaign for the election of a United States Senator this Fall will be fought on the issue of the New Deal. The lines were drawn in the keynote speeches of former Senator W. Warren Barbour, Republican candidate, and William H. J. Ely, Democratic candidate, in their respective party conventions, which opened here today.

Of all "events" at the Monadnock Region Fair in Swanzey, N. H., we should most have liked to see the oxenpulling contest. The prize-winners in the under 3,300-pound class pulled 7,165 pounds fifteen inches.
President Roosevelt's first peace appeal to Chancellor Hitler and the latter's reply dominate the front pages of the morning's newspapers.

Mr. and Mrs. Richard Donkersloot of this city will observe their fiftieth wedding anniversary tomorrow. They were married at Oude Tonge, The Netherlands, and have been residents here for forty-eight years.

A continued in crease in savings accounts and an increase in deposits with the Bank of Canada featured the report for Aug. 31 of Canadian chartered banks to the Dominion's Finance Department, made public today. Savings deposits increased $12.000,000 in the month, and $57,000,000 in the year.
Owner Bill Scully and Manager George Kenneally of the Boston Shamrocks, independent professional football club, tonight announced their retirement.

The basic law of this State is too important in the life of every citizen to be changed by guess or hearsay. No voter should consider himself qualified to pass on the proposed constitutional amendments which will be adopted or rejected next November until he has read and digested them.
The Hon. Sir Herbert Marler, the Canadian Minister, and Lady Marler have come to the Ritz-Carlton from Washington.
Tomorrow Parliament is going to meet and I shall be making a full statement of the events which have led up to the present anxious and critical situation.

A resolution expressing "gratitude and commendation" to President Roosevelt for his "splendid endeavor" to settle the European dispute "by reason rather than force" was adopted last night by 500 persons of various faiths commemorating the Jewish New Year at special services in the Plymouth Congregational Church of the Pilgrims, Orange and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn.
Recurrence of a charley-horse today put Stanley Johnson,promising Syracuse fullback, on the sidelines. The big- sophomore probably will miss the opening game with Clarkson here Friday night.
A fifteen-round bout between Mike Belloise and Joey Archibald for the featherweight championship of the world was ratified yesterday by the New York State Athletic Commission at its regular meeting.

A settlement of the school bus strike that began Sunday in the five boroughs was announced at 11:30 o'clock last night by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, after nearly eight hours of conferences in which he sought to bring the two sides of the dispute together.

Charles Williams, a 72-year-old expoliceman, was overcome by two policemen after holding the police at bay for nearly half an hour yesterday by threatening to. leap from the roof of a four-story frame house at 3,465 Bronx Boulevard, the Bronx.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's first step in placing James J. Hines, the West Harlem Tammany leader, on trial again on the policy racket indictment will be taken this morning before General Sessions Judge Owen B. Bohan
Six Belgian classes were called-to the colors today after a Cabinet council. A communique states that this measure has been taken solely for "reasons of security and a desire for peace."
The catastrophes facing other nations may leave America in the position of geographical "conservator of the culture attainments of the human race," Dr. Harold W. Dodds,

The State Department warned Americans today to forego travel to Europe except in cases of absolute necessity and authorized consular officers in Europe to allow American liners to carry additional passengers beyond regulatory limitations back to this country.

The New York World's Fair will have the only wheat field within the city's limits, it was announced yesterday. The wheat field was planted yesterday afternoon after the ground had been plowed by M. Lee Marshall, president of the Continental Baking Company and once a farm boy at Marshall, Mo.

Earnings of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad this month were more than sufficient to wipe out the net loss of $458,423 incurred in the first eight months of the year, Ralph Budd, president, reported yesterday.
Mrs. Fred A. Neuberg of the home club took low gross honors in a one-day event of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Hackensack Golf Club today.
Bob Feller won his seventeenth game of the season today, striking out ten White Sox batters and allowing only five hits as the Indians took the first of a three-game series, 6 to 1.
Due to the religious holiday the number of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was considerably below the preceding week and the corresponding week a year
The executive committee of the Chicago Stock Exchange approved today the following listing applications:

After almost a month of work, the September grand jury in Brooklyn, with an output thus far of about 250 indictments, may see this labor come to nothing, if questions of law raised yesterday and today in a two-part editorial of The New York Law Journal are upheld.

Tire shipments during August were estimated at 4,045,540 units, an increase of 2.5 per cent over shipments of $3,947,431 in July, according to the Rubber Manufacturers Association, Inc. Last month's shipments, however, were 17.3 per cent below those of August, 1937, when shipments totaled 4,889,290. Shipments for the first eight months of this year aggregated 26,487,795.

Under the terms of the Railway Labor Act the President has appointed a fact-finding commission of three members to investigate the 15 per cent wage reduction proposed by the railroads and to make recommendations.

In another dramatic appeal, timed for the early hours of a fateful day in Europe, President Roosevelt has sought again to bring the influence of the United States to bear in behalf of a peaceful solution of the present crisis.
About $1,650,000 worth of surplus agricultural commodities were bought by the Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation in the two weeks ended Sept. 21, the Agriculture Department announced today.
There are to be no political announcements or introductions of politicians from the boxing or wrestling rings of New Jersey, Abe J. Greene, State Athletic Commissioner, ruled today.

Max Wald of 1,016 Garden Street, Hoboken, a former aviator in the German Army, who was shot down during the World War, committed suicide early today in Orange Memorial Hospital by hanging himself with a knotted sheet tied to a radiator over his bed.

Broader powers to enforce trade laws were urged for the Federal Trade Commission by Garland S. Ferguson, chairman of the commission, in an address today at the annual meeting of the National Wholesale Druggists Association.

Miss Adele Marie Wichmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. William Wichmann, was married here this evening at the home of her parents to Duncan W. Barton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Barton of Maplewood.

Although the proposed $10,000,000 institutional advertising campaign for the life insurance field did not come up at the annual convention of the National Association of Life Underwriters last week at Houston, Texas, the organization inferentially endorsed the plan by electing two men who have publicly. advocated such a campaign.

The war Department released the following orders today, dated Sept. 26: MAJOR GENERAL Herr, J. K., Chief of Cavalry, five days' leave, Sept. 29. COLONELS Lynn, C., Adjutant General's Dept., one month and twenty-nine days' extension of leave, with permission to visit foreign countries.

A five-meet schedule has been arranged for the Manhattan crosscountry squad, it was announced yesterday by Herbert M. Kopf, director of athletics. The Jaspers will appear in dual meets with Alfred and Penn State and in the metropolitan intercollegiate event, the I. C. A. A. A. A. competition and the national A. A. U. championships.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora declined yesterday "because of my previous association with it" to pass upon an application made by Julius (Red) Williams, Negro witness in the recent James J. Hines

The exchange of diplomatic notes continues between Prague and Warsaw. A special courier left by plane this afternoon with the Polish reply to the Czechoslovak note in which Prague agreed in principle to a frontier change in the Teschen area.

Mayor La Guardia declared a public emergency yesterday in the strike of 15,000 truck drivers, which has hampered the shipping of the port for more than a week. He began moving needed supplies with obsolete trucks of the Sanitation Department manned by strikers who were accompanied by city drivers.

A first mortgage of $245,000 has been arranged by Lawrence, Blake Jewell, Inc, for the Algy Building Corp on the six-story apartment on the south side of 167th St, between Sherman and Grant Aves, the Bronx.

Phyllis Bottome, author of the current best seller "The Mortal Storm," a novel about dictatorship, will arrive in this country on Oct. 5 from England. Her publishers, Little, Brown, announced this week the eleventh printing of her novel, which now totals 45,000 copies.
Oldham Athletic took over leadership of the northern section of the English football league today by defeating Accrington Stanley 3-1 on the latter's ground.

A plan to have the government buy all old and unsalable merchandise stocks from retailers at the end of each season at prices covering wholesale cost and necessary store operation expense, and to distribute these goods to the needy through the WPA,

Miss Lorraine Cooper, daughter of Mrs. William Henry Blauvelt Cooper of 361 Carlton Avenue, Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Cooper, will be married the afternoon of Oct. 21 in the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixtyfourth Street, to Warren Allen King, son of Mrs. Warren Charles Strugnell of Bloomfield, N. J., and the late George Garrett Hallock King.

Citing possible danger of Jersey City's water supply being polluted, the State Water Policy Commission denied today the application of the Oak Ridge Lake Park Realty Company for a permit to dam the Rockaway River twenty-three miles above the municipality's Boonton reservoir for four years.

In anticipation of early purchases of additional sites for slum clearance and low-rent apartments the New York City Housing Authority yesterday appointed Herbert Jacques Morris to direct its future acquisitions of land. Mr. Morris has resigned from his partnership in the realty firm of Leonard S. Gans, Zeckendorf, Morris Company to give his full time to the new work.
The engagement of Miss Lois Hamilton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emmett S. Hamilton of Queens Village, to Donald Leask Fuller of Stamford, Conn., has been announced by her parents.
J. F. McKeown; who supervised the laying of hundreds of miles of railroad track in the United States and Canada, died today in his horne here at the age of 89.

The United States will have to change its attitude toward Mexico and wait until that country is able to pay for the expropriated lands and equipment of American oil companies if it is to obtain compensation without force -and without losing the friendship of Mexico and the permanent market there, Dr. Samuel Guy Inman, executive secretary of the Committee on Cooperation in Latin America, said here yesterday.

It seems that the big blues and stripers have definitely made their appearance in the Montauk surf, but the angler is now confronted by the problem of lodging and food once he gets there. Although the roads are now passable to most points, the storm has left considerable confusion in its wake.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed, as of the dates respectively indicated, upon the eligible list of holders of licenses for service in day secondary schools other than junior high schools, the names of the following applicants, who have been granted licenses, as indicated:

A war picture was announced today when Edward Small, revealed plans for making "The Maginot Line," which will feature Louis Hayward. Material was gathered for the story of the French defenses by George Bruce during his trip abroad last Spring.

John Charles Thomas, the singer, in protest against additional assessments on his income for 1933 to 1935, inclusive, testified yesterday before the United States Board of Tax Appeals in the Federal Building.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Sept. 24: COMMANDERS Pollard, W. A. Jr., Civil Engineer Corps, detached from Bureau of Yard and Docks, Navy Dept., Washington, D. C., in December, ordered to 15th Naval Dist., Balboa, C. Z.. as Public Works Officer.

Miss Ruth Rouse of London, who was elected president of the World's Council of the Young Women's Christian Association at its recent meeting near Toronto, arrived yesterday at national headquarters, 600 Lexington Avenue. She will remain here for a week before returning to England, where she also is secretary of the Missionary Council of the Church of England.
The war scare hit shipping its sharpest blow yesterday, as scores of potential passengers suddenly decided that it would be safer to remain in the United States.

Latecomers in search of apartments are keeping the staffs of brokers and management concerns moving at top speed. Yesterday's long report of rentals would indicate that the customary last-minute rush is in full swing. A number of notables appeared In the lists.

THE Annapolis alumnus said somewhat grumpily that everybody in this area paid attention to the Army football team and few could spare time or space for the Navy team. Well, for one thing, West Point is just up the river and the Cadets, in a manner of speaking, are "locals" like the neighbors' children.

For the second afternoon Dartmouth "bore down" in practice on Memorial Field today, a marked departure from the languid sessions that have marked the training in the mud and rain that have dogged the Indians almost from the first day of Fall practice. t day of Fall practice.

Major Gen. Alan Geoffrey Charles Dawnay, who as director of Public Relations at the War Office since October had been in charge of efforts to explain the significance of changes introduced by Secretary Hore-Belisha, died today at the age of 50. He took particular interest in the use of films and posters to publicize the new model army.
The chimney sweep profession is due for a comeback, according to L. Logan Lewis, New York industrial engineer.

The Cuban Nazi party today demanded the status of a legal political organization, in an appeal to the Governor of Havana Province. Juan Prohias, a former newspaper man who several months ago conducted an anti-Semitic campaign over the radio, is the party leader.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick allotted yesterday to the twenty-six banks and trust companies that usually buy the city's securities an issue of $30,000,000 of New York City revenue bills at an interest rate of one-half of 1 per cent.

Plans for the resumption of round-the-world service by the Dollar Line were started yesterday, after the Maritime Commission announced that Senator William G. McAdoo and Joseph R. Sheehan had been appointed chairman of the board and president, respectively.

Mrs. Amelia May Connett Plerson of 12 Mount Prospect Place, Newark, wife of William H. Plerson, former vice president of the Fidelity Trust Company of Newark, died at her Summer home here today after a week's illness at the age of 68.

The marriage of Miss Regina Marie Therry, daughter of Mrs. Margaret Hughes of 340 East Fifty-seventh Street, to Theodore Stanton Friedberger, son of Mrs. Theodore A. Friedberger of 325 East Seventy-ninth Street and the late Mr. Friedberger, took place yesterday morning in the Church of St. John the Evangelist, Fifty-fifth Street and First Avenue.

MANHATTAN BERGHORN, MARGARET (Sept. 13). Estate, more than $10,000. To Elsa Berghorn, daughter, household, personal effects and life estate in one-fourth residue; George Berghorn, Louis Berghorn, executor, 2,314 1st Ave., and William Berghorn, executor, 485 Central Park West, sons, one-fourth residue each.

A client of P. C. D'Onofrio, broker, bought from Frank and James Di Bitetto for $10,000 cash the four-family dwelling at 2,124 Chatterton Avenue, the Bronx. The house occupies a plot 25 by 105 feet, and has an annual rent roll of about $1.900.

Peter Hatzis, 18 years old, f 1,614 Fortieth Street; Albert Rispoli, 17, of 1,958 Sixty-seventh Street, and Thomas Marcello, 21, of 112 Avenue I, all Brooklyn, pleaded guilty yesterday before Kings County Judge Peter J. Brancato to first-degree robbery in the hold-up of a candy store at 1,701 McDonald Avenue, Brooklyn, on Sept. 22.

The truck drivers strike in New Jersey was rapidly approaching an end yesterday as individual -truck owners in most parts of the State signed contracts with the drivers' locals on terms based on. Mayor La Guardia's compromise proposal.

Westfield Acres, the Federal Government's low-rent housing project costing $3,116,000 in Camden, N. J., will be turned over to the Camden Housing Authority for operation and management on Saturday under a lease agreement signed today by Nathan Straus, USHA Administrator.

Miss Marie Louise Weber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene H. Weber of Denver, was married here last night to Reginald Bryan Owen, son of Mrs. Borge Rohde, former United States Minister to Denmark, and grandson of the late William Jennings Bryan.

Senator Pittman proposed today that the a government, to dispose of the enormous cotton carryover, trade ten pounds of cotton for one ounce of silver in foreign markets and with the expected 670,000,000 ounces thus acquired pay the farmer for his I product at the rate of 12.9 cents a pound boy issuance of certificates against the silver.

" If the Germans want to choose peace, all right, but if they want to pick a fight we'll give them one they will never forget." That is the spirit tonight among French forces camped along the Rhine as the final decision on peace or war rapidly approaches.

The Republican State Convention opened with a snag developing over completing the Dewey slate. Bruce Barton and Oswald D. Heck condemned the New Deal on "vote buying" and as failing to solve the unemployment problem. [Page 1.]
Following is the text of Herbert Hoover's address tonight before joint Republican groups: My fellow-citizens: I deeply appreciate the graciousness and the cordiality of your reception.
A duplex apartment with double height studio and living room with a balcony has been leased by Gifford A. Cochran in the cooperative building at 322 East Fifty-seventh Street.

The action of the Village Board of Southampton in declining WPA aid in clearing away the wreckage left by last week's hurricane might well be pondered as an example of self-reliance. Southampton, of course, is a well-to-do community, judged. by average standards.

The Rev. Dr. Leon A. Davison, president of the board of trustees of Blair Academy here, will conduct a funeral service at 3 P. M. on Friday for Albert M. Freeman, dean of the academy, at his home here.

Total revenue of the electric power and light industry in the United States during July aggregated $176,009,300, according to statistics based on Federal Power Commission classification of accounts, released yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute. In July,

Nellie Direct, owned by W. B. Eckert of Reading, Pa., won the $400 George A. Hamid Free-For-All Handicap in the New Jersey State Fair harness race competition today, but it took the bay mare four heats to turn the trick.
The Tribune de Geneve says that the Swiss Government is fully prepared for any emergency in the next few days and does not exclude the possibility of a general mobilization.

John Charles Thomas, radio and opera singer, paid $1,613 in tips in 1935 when he lived in the Ritz Towers, he testified yesterday before J. Edgar Murdock of the United States Board of Tax Appeals at a hearing in the Federal Building on his appeal from additional income tax assessments of $60,000 for the years 1933, 1934 and 1935.

A luncheon was given yesterday by Captain and Mrs. John C. Groome of Philadelphia on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Their guests included Mrs. George Dallas Dixon Jr., Mrs. Leland Thompson, the Misses Emily Henrieque, Doris Foote and Alice Hutchins, and Peter Schuyler Thompson.
The most fantastic golf story ever told or dreamed-ended at 10:30 o'clock tonight when J. Smith Ferebee tapped in a short putt on the eighteenth hole of Salisbury's No. 4

The confused diplomatic picture of the past week was made clearer at a number of vital points today by Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's speech in the House of Commons and by the publication of a British White Paper containing the texts of ten important documents dealing with the Czech-German crisis.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Sept. 26: COMMANDER Crutchfield. J. A., granted sick leave three months, to await orders San Diego, Calif.

Accused of breaking into forty Summer homes in Cortlandt and Yorktown, eleven Peekskill youths pleaded guilty today before County Judge Frank H. Coyne to charges of unlawful entry. They had been indicted for third-degree burglary. Judge Coyne remanded them pending sentence.

A revised and codified set of rules of the Municipal Civil Service Commission was published yesterday in The City Record. A public hearing on the rules will be held on Oct. 3 at 2 P. M. at the commission's offices on the fourteenth floor of the Municipal Building.

The family, the school and the church have weakened during the last fifty years in their constructive influences upon youth and have left it the butt of criticism that should be leveled at its elders, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared yesterday at exercises in the McMillin Academic Theatre opening the institution's 185th year.

Accused of killing a motion picture operator by striking him on the head with a fire extinguisher in the projection room of a Queens theatre, Solomon Schulman, 35 years old, of 649 Marcy Avenue, Brooklyn, another --motion-- picture operator was held without bail yesterday for the grand jury by Magistrate Vincent Sweeney in Felony Court, Ridgewood, Queens.
Stanley M. Isaaacs, Borough President of Manhattan, and Franklin P. Adams, newspaper columnist, joined yesterday in the official opening of Tag Day Week for the American relief ship to Spain.

Proposals to establish a "medical cooperative" in New York, where by medical and surgical care would be offered to families under two plans, for $16 and $24 a year, respectively, are not viewed with favor by The New York Medical Week in an editorial headed "Where's the Bargain?"

The thirty-sixth annual Piping Rock Horse Show opened this afternoon, and society from many parts of Long Island, New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania arrived to see the large class of jumpers that opened the four-day program.
Art Morison appeared likely today to see service at fullback for the first time when Syracuse University opens against Clarkson here Friday night.
The only visible military precautions being taken in Russia are local blackouts, air raid and gas drills and field exercises by young factory and farm workers.

A three-hour workout was devoted chiefly to passing offense and defense by the New York University football squad at Ohio Field yesterday. With Coach Mal Stevens out of uniform and confined to the sidelines because of a cold, the varsity drilled against Maine formations employed by the reserves under the supervision of Assistant Coaches Charlie Comerford and Stewart Scott, who scouted the New England outfit last week.

Certain specialty shops here continue to enjoy sales increases despite declines in other establishments. One Fifth Avenue shop, for example, has had a 25 per cent increase thus far this week over the same period a year ago, which follows an unusually good showing for the earlier part of September.

Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin ruled yesterday that stockholders of the Globe Financial Corporation may be sued personally for assessments levied against the stock of the defunct Globe Bank and Trust Company that is held by the corporation. About $788,400 is involved.

J. J. Downing Honored at Dinner About 250 persons honored John Downing, Park Department supervisor of recreation in Brooklyn, a dinner given last night at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, in observance of his twenty-fifth anniversary as a member of the department.

Orville Wright, who with his brother, the late Wilbur Wright, was the first to build and fly a man-carrying airplane, has told the Association of Men With Wings that he is eager and willing to bring back to America the famous first heavier-than-air machine.

Fifteen thousand New Yorkers thrilled last night to the daring of the city's police force, whose stalwarts put on "Around the Clock With New York's Finest" at Madison Square Garden. But there were additional thrills that were not on the program. Two mounted patrolmen were hurt in falls, one having to be taken to a hospital.

More than 1,000 Pontiac dealers and salesmen attending an advance announcement meeting for three 1939 models in the Hotel Astor were Informed yesterday by H. J. Klingler, president and general manager of the Pontiac division of General

GOOD Beebe is hard to beat, and "Zaca Venture" * is certainly good Beebe, popular yet perfectly sober natural history. It isn't so much exciting as interesting reading; it is hard to see how it could be more so, even though the subject is merely fish, birds, seaweed, benthos, nekton and plankton.

The Navy eleven worked this afternoon against a special squad drilled by Frank Foster in the running and passing plays of Virginia Military Institute, its opponent for Saturday. Later, there was some kicking practice which brought several new booters to the front. ew booters to the front.

Minor injuries created a shortage of wingbacks today- during Army's football practice when Moon Mullin followed Lauterback to the sidelines, both with cuts on their legs received from shoe cleats. However, Coach Bill Wood spent an hour with a varied combination of backfields as he worked them against J. V. teams armed with Columbia plays.
Canada's mineral production in the first six months of 1938 was valued at $209,654,610, com-: pared with $215,382,814 in the same six months in 1937, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.

The Fletcher Joint Stock Land Bank of Indianapolis, Ind., has called for redemption on Nov. 1, next, bonds totaling $521,000, according to an announcement yesterday by William B. Schiltges, president of the bank. The specific issues called are: $495,000 of 3s, dated May 1, 1935, optional May 1, 1938, and due May 1, 1939, and $26,200 of 4 1/2s, dated Nov. 1, 1928. optional Nov. 1, 1938, and due Nov. 1, 1968.

Gay Song, brown trotting colt, by Volomite and out of Evensong, was sold tonight for $10,200, the highest price thus far of the three-day yearling sales which started yesterday at the Walnut Hill Farm of Donerail.

Mrs. George Emick's Unselfish scored his second victory in three days today by charging from fourth place at the head of the stretch to beat Shining Heels by a neck in the Hyde Park Handicap at Hawthorne.
German, English and French will be the languages used across the conference table tomorrow when Adolf Hitler, Benito Mussolini, Edouard Daladier and Neville Chamberlain confer in Munich.
In connection with the other problems now confronting Europe, a report circulated in Rome today that, although still lacking confirmation and indeed officially denied, nevertheless is worth noticing.
Electric power production declined last week, countering the normal seasonal and long-term trends, and the adjusted index dropped to 94.1.

Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons made a long statement to both branches of Parliament tonight, reviewing the events leading to the European crisis and reiterating the backing of the Australian Government for Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain at London. Mr. Lyons's remarks were supported by John Curtin, leader of the Labor party.

A 1905 record set by Dan Patch fell today as Billy Direct, 4-year-old pacer owned by McConville and Downey of Ogdensburg, N. Y., was proclaimed the world's fastest harness horse for one mile with a mark officially announced as 1:55.
Moving Day figures from the gas and electric company do not bear out the familiar statement that New Yorkers are a nomad race.

Hysterical buying and selling featured the world's wheat markets today. Overnight war talk was responsible for a sharp upturn in the leading markets at the opening, but later there was an avalanche of selling based on the prospect of settlement of the difficulties abroad and prices faded faster than they had advanced.

Announcement today of the four-power conference in Munich tomorrow followed a day of high-pressure diplomatic exchanges and long-distance telephone calls between Berlin, London, Paris and Rome. It burst in upon the stagnant political atmosphere like a freshening breeze. eeze.

Mayflower Ave (15-4332), e s, 175 ft s of Evelyn Pl, 125x100; August C. Reps to Edward P. Stachnik, 2,119 Vyse Ave. Findlay Ave. 999 (9-2432); Guaranty Trust Co of N Y, trustee, to the New India Assuarance Co, Ltd, 150 William St. Belmont Ave, 1,992 (11-3079); Josephine Silvestrelli to Nicola De Crescenzo., 790 E 181st St.

Miss Priscilla Alden Allen, daughter of Mrs. Frederick Hobbes Allen of Pelham Manor, N. Y., and Newport, R. I., and the late Colonel Allen, and Francis Jackson Hallowell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Hallowell of Dedham, Mlass., will be married next Monday noon in St. George's Church, Paris.

Bruce Barton's keynote speech at the New York State Republican Convention was a very good performance as keynote speeches go. It was full of neat phrases and telling points, and as definite as the present confused state of Republican opinion would permit it to be.
Testimony that the German-American Bund is an un-American organization entirely dominated by the Nazi government was offered today to the special House committee investigating un-American activities.

It is regrettable if accuracy is to be sacrificed to zeal on the part of the opposition to the so-called court review provision contained in Section 27 of Article 'VI, constituting the Judiciary Article of the revised Constitution submitted by the recent Constitutional Convention to the voters of the State of New York for their approval or rejection.

The report of the National Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Aug. 31, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income, after all operating expenses and charges, of $8,588,233.

Loring PI, 2,264, 2-story dwelling, 35x110.4; Broadway Savings Bank against Rosalinde S. Spies; due, $13,673; to plaintiff for $2,000. 165th St, 872 E, 3-story tenement, 20x76.8; HOLC against Ella K. Kulikofskys; due, S31.070: to plaintiff for $500.

Ira Hutchinson pitched Boston to a 3-to-1 victory over the Phillies today in the Bees' final home contest, recording his ninth victory and giving his club a sweep of the three-game series. Completed in 1 hour 23 minutes, the encounter not only was the fastest here this year but was witnessed by the smallest crowd, 952. y the smallest crowd, 952.

Selection of about 5,000 young men between 17 and 23 years of age for enrollment in New York State Civilian Conservation Corps camps will start Saturday, David C. Adie, State Commissioner of Social Welfare, said today.

A major European war would not affect seriously the international character of the World's Fair, in the opinion of fair officials, it was indicated yesterday. Great Britain, France, Italy and Russia, it is believed, would continue to participate in the fair, although a few of the smaller nations, if they become embroiled, might decide to withdraw.

An old woman knelt today before the relies of Saint Wenceslas in the Prague Cathedral. Her face was expressionless and her body swayed slightly as she prayed. Over her head she wore a white kerchief, folded in the manner of a Bohemian peasant woman.

Application is being made to the SEC to strike the following securities from listing and registration on the Exchange because of the small amounts outstanding and available for trading: Milwaukee Northern Railroad Company consolidated mortgage 41/2i per cent bonds, due on June 1. 1934;

The Italian liner Rex, arriving today from Mediterranean ports, has among her passengers Beniamino Gigli, Mme. Elisabeth Rethberg and Ezio Pinza, operatic and concert singers; and Dr. Jaroslav Novak, Czechoslovak Minister to Venezuela and former consul general in New York.

Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Sept. 17 totaled 280,945,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines. This represented a drop of 1,512,000 barrels in the week, comprising a decrease of 1,734,000 barrels in domestic crude but an increase of 222,000 in foreign crude. .

Miss Betty Jameson, San Antonio (Texas) golfer, won her first-round match from Mrs. Max Berg of Philadelphia today in the Berthellyn Cup invitation tournament at the Huntingdon Valley Country Club, 7 and 6.

A nation that had been sadly and calmly but undramatically preparing for war received today the news of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's new conference with Chancellor Adolf Hitler tomorrow as a twelfth-hour reprieve.

Invitations have been sent out by Mr. and Mrs. James A. Plumstead of this place, for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Natalie Plumstead, to Hilyard Stokes Simpkins; son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Simpkins of Burlington, in the Hillside Presbyterian Church on Oct. 14. erian Church on Oct.- 14.
Ross Lusk, 62 years old, a WPA worker, who said he was a veteran of the Spanish-American War, shot himself in the abdomen yesterday in his apartment at 307 West Seventy-ninth Street.

The war threat in Europe provided an overtone to a discussion of foreign affairs and domestic problems before 1,500 Long Island club women here today. The women applauded the reading from the platform of each bulletin that made war seem more remote; speakers framed their talks in the background of the European situation, even those whose topics might ordinarily be remotely concerned with Europe.

Resident offices in the men's wear field expressed the opinion yesterday that in some cases they may have to seek extended dating on bills because of delivery delays resulting from the trucking tie-up. Half-hose from Southern mills, for instance, has been waiting as much as ten days to two weeks in New Jersey, whereas shipments are usually received in a few days.
Edward Epstean, pioneer photoengraver, was honored at a dinner last night in the Hotel Astor by the artists, designers and collaborators of PM Magazine in celebration of his seventieth birthday.

A declaration that all Americans should support President Roosevelt in his efforts to prevent war in Europe was coupled by former President Herbert Hoover tonight with an attack upon the Roosevelt administration as "politically immoral."

To adolescence was given the screen's attention today. At R.-K.-O., Roger Daniel, 14-year-old orphan, whose stage experience has been limited to high school theatricals, was placed under contract and assigned the lead in P. J. Wolfson's "The Pure in Mind."

Kansas City used eighteen men, including coven pitchers, to beat St. Paul, 12 to 11, and square the final American Association play-off sealed at three games each before 2,999 fans tonight. re 2,999 fans tonight.

New Jersey's team of women golfers today retained the J. J. Thomson Trophy in the annual competition against a squad of fifteen Westchester-Fairfield representatives by the one-sided score of 12 to 3. The matches were played over the Essex County Country Club course.

William E. Marvin, who as Mayor of New Hampshire's only coastal city welcomed Japanese and Russian delegates to the Russo-Japanese Peace Conference in 1905, died today after a short illness. He was 66 years old.

The world must turn to the Western Hemisphere to find any foundation for the belief that might does not make right and any justification for faith in the efficacy of democracy, James S. Carson of New York said in an a address here today.

Immediate convocation of the signatories of the Briand-Kellogg pact together and a declaration that the moral, political and economic resources of the United States will be denied the aggressor was urged upon President Roosevelt yesterday as a means to save the peace of the world. The American League for Peace and Democracy offered the plan.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Sept. 27: MAJOR GENERALS Mosely, G. V. H., two days' leave, Sept. 28. Bishop P. P., one month and ten days' leave, Nov. 21.

Launching her campaign for nomination to the New York Supreme Court, Magistrate Anna Moscowitz Kross, in an address before the Business Woman's Round-Table Luncheon Club, Hotel Iroquois, declared yesterday that the judiciary should be taken out of politics.
Former Kaiser Wilhelm of Germany declined today to discuss anything that has occurred since 62 B. C. 2 B. C.

The directors of the Kansas City Southern Railway announced yesterday terms for a merger of that line with the Louisiana Arkansas Railway. The merger is to be through an exchange of stock, in conformity with recommendations in other years by members of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

The American Tobacco Company announced yesterday that it had obtained reductions of the interest rate on $18,532,000 of its debentures. The reductions apply to the $16,740,000 of 3 1/2 per cent and the $1,792,000 of 3 1/4 per cent debentures. The rate on each was cut to 2.45 per cent, effective on Nov. 15.
A large store and basement unit in the midtown district has been leased by the Crown Paper Company, dealers in paper boxes, through Spear Co., Inc., brokers.

Conferences of more than a year resulted yesterday in a statement of professional principles, embodying fundamental distinctions between lawyers and life underwriters in the handling of wills and insurance estates.

James J. Hines and Albert Marinelli, Tammany leaders, both of whom have felt the impact of District Attorney Dewey's aggressiveness, were among the 400 New York City delegates to the Democratic State Convention who left for Rochester yesterday.

Manufacturers of nationally advertised products were warned today to prepare themselves to oppose any bills introduced in States to make registration of trade-marks mandatory, by G. S. McMillan, secretary of the Association of National Advertisers, at the opening of the organization's three-day annual convention at the Homestead here.

FELLOW REPUBLICANS: You have given me a high honor. I deeply appreciate it. There are about 235,000 young men and women in New York State who will vote this Fall for the first time. I have received a number of questions from these first voters which I propose now ton answer.

Judge Owen W. Bohan of General Sessions granted yesterday the motion of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey for a blue-ribbon panel of 500 talesmen from which to select the jury for the new trial of James J. Hines, the Tammany district leader, on the policy racket indictment.

Running back to her good form which she displayed in New England last Spring, D. B. Midkiff's Flying Bonny accounted for today's feature, an allowance race for 2-year-olds. Backed into heavy favoritism, the son of Flying Heels and Bonny Dear led throughout-to beat W. U. Ridenour's Morcarine by a length under a steadying pull.

Klaus Mann has returned to this country after several months in Europe, bringing with him the first fourteen chapters of "Escape to Life," a story of the German emigration upon which he and his sister, Erika, have been working for a year. The book is scheduled for publication by Houghton Mifflin early in 1939.
Seven new musicians, replacing those who died or were pensioned last year, have been admitted in the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society, it was announced yesterday.

Three projects for building veterans' hospitals including a 450-bed addition to facilities in the Bronx, were reinstated today by Secretary Ickes following protests to the White House, accompanied by assurances that all is in readiness to begin construction according to approved plans.

The Tufts College Medical School has awarded the Commonwealth Fund Scholarships for the class of 1942 to Willard H. Boynton of Grove-land, Massachusetts State College and Yale School of Public Health;
Some cautious Britons, it was indicated tonight, are "crashing" the gasmask lines to get "spares."

A shake-up, resulting directly from Maryland's upset 'defeat by Richmond last Saturday, sent the Terrapins' two varsity ends back to the second-string today, with two sophomores and a junior elevated to the first team to fight for their jobs. Maryland meets Penn State Saturday. ay.

Leaders of the American Labor party, headed by Luigi Antonini, State chairman, Alex Rose, State executive director, and David Dubinsky, demanded last night that the party receive proper recognition on the State and other tickets of the Democrats and Republicans, threatening as an alternative to help defeat such tickets.

Secretary Roper said today that he had "every reason to believe" the present upward trend in business would continue. He cited Department of Commerce statistics to show that individual incomes advanced from an index figure of 80.4 for May to 82.5 for August. to 82.5 for August.
New York League of Women Voters, Spear Auditorium, 22 West Thirty-fourth Street, 10:30 A. M. "Treating Personnel Problems Objectively," Dr. Frank J. O'Brien.

New York University's varsity cross-country team will engage in five dual meets this Fall in addition to competing in the metropolitan intercollegiate championships and the I. C. A. A. A. A. title run, it Was announced yesterday by Albert B. Nixon, graduate manager of athletics.

The recent reductions in the prices of rails and track fastenings have not resulted in inquiries for these supplies from the railroads, except for the New York Central, according to Iron Age. The review pointed out that the railroad's requirements had been known.

The high hopes of one of the best physically equipped football squads of the East last Fall were wrecked by the worst epidemic of injuries that has afflicted a team of Gilmour Dobie's in his long career as a coach. This year, an even more arresting array of avoirdupois is assembled on the heights of Boston College, but this time no one is counting his Eagles before they are hatched.

My Dear Prime Minister: When I undertook the task of mediation in the controversy between the Czechoslovak Government and the Sudeten German party I was, of course, left perfectly free to obtain my own information and draw my own conclusions.
If Germany's' industrial strength in 1914 had been what it is today, says the Voelkischer Beobachter, "the World War would definitely not have lasted four years."
Uncorking a great stretch bid, Phil Schwartz's Napper Tandy wore down the favored Be Blue in the final seventy yards today to win the six-furlong feature at Rockingham Park and return $9.64 for $2.
Clifford B. Harmon, American founder and president of the Ligue International des Aviateurs, suffered a stroke of paralysis yesterday.

President Lazaro Cardenas tonight appealed to Chancellor Hitler of Germany and President Benes of Czechoslovakia to avoid a "conflagration." In identical messages to the two Executives. Senior Cardenas said:
Thirty German submarines have been sighted in the past two days passing The Skaw, on the northern coast of Jutland, en route from the Baltic Sea to the North Sea.

Striking employes of the Busch Jewelry Company deferred action yesterday on their threat to resume picketing of the twelve Busch stores as a test of the validity of an anti-picketing injunction issued last June by Supreme Court Salvatore A. Cotillo.

The State Superior Court today restrained the Delaware River Tunnel Corporation from starting work on a proposed $17,000,000 tube- under the river until the Dauphin County Court has ruled on Mayor S. Davis Wilson's injunction seeking to halt the project.

A "liberal" Republican party and a "radical" Democratic party will meet in battle in the national campaign of 1940, Representative Bruce Barton of New York City predicted this afternoon in a keynote address at the opening session of the Republican State Convention. eDublican State Convention.

Wilfred Garretson, 66-year-old Raritan Valley golfer, virtually clinched his second senior links championship of the year when he added an 82 today at the Essex Fells Country Club to the 79 scored yesterday for a 161 total in the annual New Jersey State seniors' championship.
Settlement of a strike at the Chrysler Motor Corporation factory here was announced tonight.

William J. Reilly, former chief usher of the Roxy and an employee of other moving-picture theatres, now an attendant at the Veterans Hospital in the Bronx, and Mrs. Rosalie Spatcher Knishern of 161 West Sixteenth Street, ballet dancer at the Radio City Music Hall,
Insurance companies are cooperating with the Securities and Exchange Commission in its inquiry as part of the so-called monopoly investigation.
Delegates to the thirty-third annual convention of the National Stationers Association re-elected Harold J. Hampton of the Indianapolis Office Supply Company, Indianapolis, Ind., as president today.

Seldom has there been seen a more sudden and complete reversal of form in financial markets than that which took place yesterday morning. The time of the turnabout was set at 10:28 o'clock, soon after Wall Street learned of the arrangements for a four-power conference to be held today in Munich.

WAITING for news from the West was irk some. The Cubs won a flag a few years go by staging an astounding winning streak down the stretch. They seemed to be at it again. Still, the Pirates had been playing good baseball. Chicago is an hour behind New York on the time schedule and the batteries for the day's game hadn't been posted, so the waiting group filled in by discussing other matters.

Dr. Jasper A. Hennigar has purchased the estate of Frederick C. Manvel, at 54 Lafayette Place here, through the real estate agency of Thirza Hennigar. The property, which is 75-foot front and 300 feet deep, has a ten-room residence.

The Atlantic Coast steamship lines accepted a compromise offer of wage contract terms yesterday from the International Longshoremen's Association, indicating final settlement before the present contract expires tomorrow at midnight.
In response to pleas by shippers and trucking companies, the Interstate Commerce Commission today modified its order for minimum motor-carrier rates for the New England region issued on Aug. 3.

The Nizam of Hyderabad, who besides being one of the richest men in the world is the premier Moslem ruler of India and enjoys the title of "Faithful Ally of the British Government," today offered his services to the Viceroy in the event of war.
Canadian newsprint producers are far more interested in retaining the profitable North American market than in the South American field.

Preliminary to the general convention of the American Federation of Labor, which opens here Monday for a two-week session, the building and construction department, with 1,500,000 workers affiliated, began a three-day meeting today.
