The Lunenburg schooner Bluenose will sail for Boston tomorrow to defend the International Fishermen's Racing Trophy in a series with the Gertrude L. Thebaud of Gloucester.

A decided easing of tension here was apparent with announcement of tomorrow's four-power meeting in Munich. As a direct result, the Cabinet meeting planned for today was canceled by Premier Mackenzie King.

Imports of iron and steel products during August, exclusive of scrap, were 18,404 tons, valued at $1,182,741, against 14,094 tons, valued at $955,215, in July, and 38,379 tons, valued at $2,543,241, in August, 1937, the Commerce Department reported today.
Increase of the National Guard to 435,000 men was asked today by guard officers in convention here.

Shooting the most sensational golf of her career, Miss Ada Mackenzie of Toronto shattered par by three strokes today and led the Ontario team to a first-round victory in the interprovincial team match for the Canadian women's golf championship. ship.
The Greenwich Orchestra, Edgar Schenkman conducting, will be heard in concert this evening at the Federal Music Theatre, with Rosamond Chapin, soprano, and Samuel Antek, violinist, as soloists.
Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's speech tonight and the forthcoming conference in Munich had a mixed reception here. In official circles a reserved attitude was maintained.
A merger of Post Flagg and Gray Wilmerding, Stock Exchange firms, is under discussion, it was said yesterday. Members of the firms said the step had not gone beyond the discussion stage.

Herman A. Elsberg, a dealer in silks and antique fabrics at 51 East Fifty-seventh Street, died yesterday of heart disease at his residence, 112 Central Park South, in his sixty-ninth year. He was an authority on textiles, had supplied exhibits to museums and had written articles on various phases of textile art.

An hour of full-speed offensive scrimmage, marking the last contact work of the week, was called for the Harvard varsity football squad by Head Coach Dick Harlow today. The Crimson team now will taper off the next two days for the Brown game in the stadium Saturday, which is worrying Harlow no little.
Expanded industrial operations which will call about 1,000 men back to their jobs were announced today by the Tennessee Coal, Iron Railroad Company.

Fire Island Inlet jetty, a 5,000-foot breakwater reaching into the Atlantio Ocean from Point Democrat at the westerly end of the island, will be built during the next eight months by the Federal Government at a cost of $759,000, it was announced here today by Robert Moses, president of the Long Island State Park Commission.
Secretary Ickes announced today a new broadcast series, "Immigrants All--Americans All," designed to dramatize the contribution of racial minorities to the greatness of the United States.

The Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service will start a drive for $250,000 this afternoon after a meeting Was in the Empire State Club, in the State Building, at which 300 workers will receive instructions.

Charles Ellis, 51 years old, of 410 Fifty-first Street, Brooklyn, accused of crying out, "We need a Hitler over here," and urging several persons to "raise hell" in a home relief station at 5,318 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, last Friday after he had failed to get a food voucher for which he applied in behalf of a friend.

Before the eyes of 3,000 spectators a 16-year-old boy was killed last night by a racing automobile as he attempted to dart from the infield to the grandstand at the Cross Bay International Speedway in Ozone Park, Queens. The boy was Joseph Neumeyer, who lived at Ninety-second Street and 157th Avenue, Howard Beach, Queens. According to the police,
William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, appeared yesterday as a witness before a Kings County grand jury in an investigation being conducted by District Attorney William F. X.

Reed W. Chambers has purchased for occupancy from the certificate owners of Issue 118 guaranteed by J. Lehrenkrauss Sons the former estate of J. Lester Lehrenkrauus, in Huntington. L. I., for $31,000.

The organization of State-supervised privately owned lending agencies to be called "Mortgage Debenture Companies" with powers to lend on realty any where in New York State is proposed by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, in a booklet issued for distribution to the public.

For over a year farm products exports from the United States have been rising and imports have been falling. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics reports that in the twelve months ended June 30, the value of farm products exports from the United States increased $158,00,000

The annual meeting of shareholders of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company was adjourned yesterday until Dec. 28 because of a lack of a quorum. Only 103,935 out of the 175,001 voting shares necessary to constitute a quorum were represented.
The four-story building at 872 Broadway. southeast corner of Eighteenth Street. has been. sold for cash by the estate of Katherine Brophy to Samuel Landow.

The Railway Audit and Inspection Company of 75 East Forty-fifth Street, an organization accused before the LaFollette Civil Liberties Commiittee of professional strike-breaking, withdrew yesterday its application for a renewal of its private detective agency license.
The Cleveland Rams today dropped Hugo L. Bezdek as head football coach and announced that Assistant Mentor Art Lewis, former Ohio U. tackle,

The National Automobile Dealers Association, meeting here today, elected the following officers: J. W. Roby, Shreveport, La., president; L. C. Cargile, Texarkana, Ark., first vice president; Frank H. Applegate, Racine, Wis., second vice president: J.

The marriage of Miss Hilda Lucille Daum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. George Daum of Pittsburgh and this city, to Frederick Darley Ogilby Jr., which had been planned for yesterday in Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street, has been postponed indefinitely, owing to an accident- suffered a week ago by the prospective bride.
The government announced today its intention of maintaining the strictest neutrality in case of a European conflagration.
The National Labor Relations Board today ordered the Eastern Footwear Corporation to cease all alleged unfair labor practices at its Dolgeville (N. Y.) plant.

Isolationists and pacifists in Congress and out who have feared or suspected a close policy relationship between New Deal Washington and London should be comforted by the news of the meeting at Munich today when Chancellor Hitler will receive the heads of the States of Great Britain, France and Italy and discuss possibilities of peace.
After dipping to new low levels in initial transactions, foreign dollar obligations led a spectacular recovery in bonds yesterday in active trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

The new Holland America Line ship Noordam sailed yesterday from Rotterdam on her maiden transatlantic voyage to New York, according to word received at the New York office of the line, 29 Broadway. She is due in this port Oct. 7.

Dr. Edgar Alden Bedford, for many years head of the Department of Biology and General Science at De Witt Clinton High School recently holding a similar position at Andrew Jackson High School, died Tuesday at St. Clairsville, Ohio; after a long illness, according to word received here yesterday. He was 65 years old. .
Charles E. Duryea, sometimes called the "father of the automobile," died in his home here at 9 A. M. today after an illness of about a year and a half. He was in his seventy-fifth year.

Beginning in October, Armour Co. will launch a nationwide advertising campaign, using newspapers and magazines, to promote a "meal of the month" sales drive for Armour products in cooperation with dealer outlets.

In "Bot" Smith's hilltop field up here in the northeastern corner of the United States, this afternoon 4,000 persons stood in the rain and watched Governor Lewis 0. Barrows paw his way to the Gubernatorial potato-picking championship of the western hemisphere.
The Technicolor Motion Pictures Corporation, a subsidiary of Technicolor, Inc., showed for the eight months ended on Aug. 31 net earnings of $862,612 after estimated adjustments,
It was as near invisible As night in early dusk. So slight it was, It was as unbelievable As day in early dawn.

Two old Bermuda families were united today in the marriage of Miss Lucy Campbell Mercer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Campbell Mercer of Kinnoull Fairylands, to John Bluck Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bluck, at St. Mark's Church, Smith's Parish.
Plans were filed yesterday in Queens for two apartment developments, the estimated cost of construction of each of which is over a million dollars.

With the basic preparation of Columbia's football squad for the opening contest against Yale on Saturday virtually completed, after two and a half weeks of intensive training, Coach Lou Little began to ease off the work of the Lions yesterday at Baker Field.

Abe Feldman, mast side heavyweight, will join the staff of sparring partners working with Lou Nova, San Francisco battler, when the latter resumes workouts today at Pompton Lakes, N. J. Nova is rounding into shape for his fifteen-round bout with Gunnar Barlund at Madison Square Garden Monday night.

Saint-Saens's "Samson et Dalila" was presented by the San Carlo Opera Company last night at the Center Theatre for the benefit of the Jamaica Jewish Center. The performance was enthusiastically received by an audience of good size.

The church's function in the world at the present time is "religious rather than secular," the Rev. Dr. Frederick Clifton Grant, newly appointed professor of Biblical Theology at the Union Theological Seminary, declared yesterday at the opening of the 103d academic year of that institution.
Eight of a team of eleven players representing the Province of Quebec Golf Association were named today to defend the Lesley Cup Sept. 30 and Oct. 1 at the Merion Cricket Club, Philadelphia.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation sold to the l60 First Street Corporation, Salvatore Urso, president, the four-story flat at 160 First Street, Hoboken, which it acquired under foreclosure last month.
John C. Davis of Denver was elected president of the National Wholesale Druggists Association at the organization's annual convention here today.
Funeral services for- Charles H. Grefe, formerly a grower and packer of fruit, who died Monday, were held today at his home here. The Rev. Claude McIntosh of First Presbyterian Church officiated.
Patrick J. Conway, 36 years old, of 48-53 Forty-fifth Street, Wood-side, Queens, a business agent for the Highway, Road and Street Construction Laborers Union of the A. F. of L.,
Stocks rebounded 2 to 6 points from a lower opening on announcement of four-power conference in Munich today, and closed sharply higher; turnover, 1,572,310 shares.

Although "Kiss the Boys Goodbye" is a new comedy by the author of "The Women," it is not, strictly speaking, a sequel. Clare Boothe, la belle dame sans merci, is investigating the manners of a group of poisonous people assembled at a Westport house party, and she is impartially opposed to both sexes.

GOVERNORS ISLAND 2d Lt. Renato J. Barone, CW.-Res., 102 East 124th St, New York, N. Y., Corps Area Service Command, Fort Totten, N. Y., is ordered to active duty with the CCC for six months, effective Sept. 29, at headquarters Trenton district, CCC, North Olden and Breunig Aves., Trenton, N. J., for assignment and duty in connection with CCC activities. Date of rank: Aug. 31, 1938.
Bill Miller replaced Mike Burke at right half in Pennsylvania's scrimmage today. An open attack that is expected to be used in the inaugural game against Lafayette was emphasized.

Concentrating on polishing its offense, the Manhattan football team scrimmaged for an hour against the d first freshman eleven as preparations for tomorrow night's game P with Niagara at the Polo Grounds e: continued. Coach Herb Kopf, anxious to make the work of the o backfield more efficient, checked a and rechecked the timing of the secondaries as he sent them through t, their repertoire of plays. rtoire of plays.

A petition was on file in Federal Court today in which Dr. A. E. Morgan, ousted TVA chairman, seeks to enjoin Directors David E. Lilienthal and H. A. Morgan from "hindering" him' as a "member and chairman" of the Tennessee Valley Authority board.
Class I railroads of the United States in August had a net railway operating income of $45,376,622, or 1.67 per cent on investment, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Governed by the changing developments in the European crisis, the foreign-exchange market yesterday first collapsed and then rallied wildly in a day of disordered price swings unparalleled since the worst days of the currency debacle five years and more ago.

The Order of the Red Cross of the Estonian Government was conferred yesterday upon Mrs. John H. Finley, chairman of the foreign division of the Young Women's Christian Association, and Miss Lois Diehl of St. Louis. former American secretary in Estonia for that organization.

America's wage-earners should look to expansion of the non-profit hospital service plans for security against illness, Louis S. Reed, assistant chief of the health studies division of the Social Security Board, told the American Hospital Association convention this afternoon.

Stocks here soared after Prime Minister Chamberlain's dramatic announcement of the four-power conference in Parliament this afternoon and experienced their greatest burst of activity in several months.

Roscoe Toles, Detroit Negro heavyweight, scored a technical knockout victory over Jimmy Adamick, young Midland (Mich.) battler, in the second round of their scheduled ten-round engagement at Olympia Stadium tonight.
The body of Louis E. Eno, 41 years old, of 133 West Eightieth Street, New York City, was found beside that of his pet dog in the woods on the western slope of the Palisades here this afternoon.

Having failed in their demands that contractors stop removing top soil from Westchester County for use on the New York World's Fair grounds, towns and cities in the county moved today to outlaw the practice. The town of Harrison applied in the Supreme Court here for injunction relief and a dozen communities prepared to adopt prohibitory local laws.

Three Federal officers engaged in the investigation of German espionage activities in the United States are believed to be among the passengers on the North German Lloyd liner Europa, which was ordered back to Bremen yesterday while en route to New York.

Ireland today installed anti-aircraft guns to protect Foynes, the transatlantic flying base. Huge new guns were also being installed in the forts of Cork Harbor, recently taken over from the British, and anti-aircraft guns were placed near principal electric plants throughout the country. nts throughout the country.

Germany withdrew the far-flung tentacles of her mercantile marine yesterday in a drastic move that threw shipping on the Atlantic into unprecedented confusion, turned liners around at sea and sent two vessels out from New York Harbor empty, before all their prospective passengers could be warned.

The $80,000 Futurity, richest race in the world for juveniles, assumed a new complexion yesterday as the result of a sensationally fast race down Belmont Park's Widener chute by E. R. Bradley's Benefactor, a bay son of Blue Larkspur. Clocked in 1:10 flat for six furlongs, the youngster bettered Johnstown's time of Tuesday by three-fifths of a second and advanced himself in the estimation of many.
Johnny Mize, Cardinal first baseman, belted three hits today to move into first position in National League batting and help St. Louis beat Cincinnati, 8 to 7.
J. Donald Budge of California made his appearance in the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament today and promptly disposed of youthful Bobby Carruthers of San Diego, 6-4, 6-3, in the men's singles.

Financial markets here went through one of the most dramatic and exciting days in years yesterday as news of the four-power conference in Munich today to seek a means of averting war turned sentiment in Wall Street from heavy foreboding to exuberant relief.

Less than a week after the craft unions of Pennsylvania had taken similar action, the executive board of the State Industrial Union Council, representing C. I. O. unions claiming a membership of 400,000, today endorsed the Pennsylvania Democratic ticket in the Fall campaign.

The Assembly's general commission, including all the main members of the League of Nations, agreed this evening that the Assembly would adopt tomorrow morning a resolution associating it with President Roosevelt's peace messages and expressing the "earnest hope" "that no government will attempt to impose a settlement by force."

Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein of Newark was "a little bit hysterical" when he criticized the safety provisions of the North Beach Airport, which the WPA is building in Queens, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, declared yesterday.

A select committee of Parliament today branded as an unfortunate mistake the "Sandys affair," which started a historic fight between the army and Parliament over threatened revelation of military secrets. The committee in a lengthy report cleared most of the participants entirely, including Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain, and rebuked others mildly.

Miss Patricia Bolling of Greenwich, Conn., scored an outstanding victory today during the first session of the thirty-sixth annual Piping Rock horse show, riding the winner of the Frank Melville Jr. Memorial Challenge Trophy for hunters over the outside course.

The magic touch Which has enabled the Yankees to romp off with three straight pennants and which shortly is expected to give them their third successive world series title was still eluding Marse Joe McCarthy's Yankees at the Stadium yesterday as they concluded their season's affairs with the Senators by losing, 4 to 1.

The twenty-story office building at 42 Broadway was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms. It was bought in by Alvin Untermyer, trustee, as plaintiff, on a bid of $3,945,251, subject to a mortgage of $2,550,000.

The toe of Paul (Tiny) Engebretsen, 240-pound guard from Northwestern, brought the Green Bay Packers a last-period field goal and a 24-to-22 National Football League victory over the Chicago Cardinals before a crowd of 12,500 tonight. d of 12,500 tonight.

Favorable action on a proposal that a permanent staff representative be stationed in Buenos Aires to promote American standards and other standards now in use by American industry was taken yesterday by the board of directors of the American Standards Association.

Fred Anderson, 25 years old, of 338 Forty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, who escaped a mandatory sentence of thirty to sixty years' imprisonment when a Kings County jury decided last week he was a first offender despite his record, was sentenced yesterday by Kings County Judge William O'Dwyer to four to ten years in Sing Sing Prison.

Mr. and Mrs. W. Ward-Stephens of 132 East Nineteenth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Pierpont Stephens, to John Martin Lyden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin F. Lyden of Youngstown, Ohio.
The Mohawk Valley Towns Association has asked the State to appropriate $350,000 for an appeal to tourists to travel up-State New York highways to the 1939 New York World's Fair.

Taking issue with the Board of Examiners, Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, chairman of the Board of Education's instructional affairs committee, proposed yesterday the adoption of recording machines to test the speech of candidates applying for teaching licenses in the New York school system.

The text of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's address in the House of Commons today follows: Shortly before the House adjourned at the end of July, some questions were addressed to me as to the possibility of summoning the House before the time arranged and during the recess in certain eventualities.

A suggestion that Denmark, Sweden, Norway and Finland send troops to take over police duties in the Sudeten areas and in Czech plebiscite districts was made tonight by one of Denmark's minor political parties. Messages were telegraphed to the Premiers of the four neutral countries urging them to make the offer.
The Navy Department announced today the retirement under the age limit, of Rear Admiral Frank H. Brumby, commandant of the Fifth Naval District and of the Naval Operating base at Norfolk, Va.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. William Willis of this city and Wainscott, L. I., of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Margaret Willis, to Benjamin Prince Fowler, son of Dr. Edmund Prince Fowler of Spuyten Duyvil and the late Mrs. Mabel Denman Fowler.

Jimmy Dykes's White Sox took a five-run lead and stayed ahead in one of the season's biggest slugging matches today to down the Indians, 14 to 11, and virtually eliminate Cleveland from second-place consideration in the American League.
Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain took off for the Munich four-power conference at 8:35 o'clock this morning (2:35 A. M. in New York).
Captain Joseph W. Rink, U. S. A., retired, serving his fourth consecutive term as Mayor of Hammonton, died this afternoon in his sixtieth year of a heart attack.

Premier Hendryk Colijn, addressing the country in a broadcast tonight, announced that unless the tension of the European situation decreased in the next twenty-four hours the government would introduce a bill proclaiming a state of emergency throughout the country and would proceed to take measures for mobilization.
Senator Vandenberg praised the political "yes-but-man" and his role in nonpartisan politics, in a speech here tonight at the annual dinner of the Michigan League of Women Voters.

Official scorers of National Football League games this Fall are cooperating with George Halas, chairman of the rules committee, by reporting the number of time outs called, the actual elapsed time of all league games,
Paralysis of the coffee market and suspension by the Bank of Brazil of trade in German compensation marks brought the possibility of disruption of trade sharply to the attention of exporters today.

The constitution for the proposed World Council of Churches has been approved generally by twelve church groups in this country it was reported yesterday at a joint meeting of the American sections of the World Conference on Faith and Order and the Universal Christian Council for Life and Work in the Hotel George Washington.
Two residents of this Manitoulin Island port on Georgian Bay, Wesley Ryder and Albert Bateman, will receive $750 each for their part in the finding Sept. 7 of the body of Daniel C.

A committee of the State Federation of Labor characterized as "a vicious proposal" today, a proposed amendment to the State Constitution providing for judicial review of all decisions of administrative agencies.

Mr. and Mrs. Hugh D. Auchin-closs have come from Merrywood, their home in McLean, Va., to the Gotham. Mr. and Mrs. Marion Eppley are at the Waldorf-Astoria before returning to their place, Beacon Rock, in Newport.

Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens said yesterday that endorsement of his plan to run for Governor as a Conservative party candidate had come to him in telegrams and telephone calls from-all parts of the State.

The owners of homes and other buildings on Long Island that were destroyed by last week's hurricane nevertheless will have to pay real estate taxes for the fiscal year 1938-1939 on the demolished properties, it was disclosed yesterday by Alfred Snyder, clerk of the Brookhaven town board of assessors.

In the thickening gloom, with the score tied and two out in the ninth inning today, red-faced Gabby Hartnett blasted a home run before 34,465 cheering fans to give his Cubs a dramatic 6-to-5 victory over the Pirates and a half-game lead in the furious National League pennant battle.

In view of the present European crisis, the board of managers of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange voted yesterday to keep the Exchange open on Saturdays t during October for trading in sugar futures.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized the Southeastern Greyhound Lines to issue 18,120 shares of 6 per cent convertible preferred stock of $20 par value and 94,480 shares of common stock of $5 par value with which to pay notes.

Unless there is a direct turnabout in the traffic safety trend of the last eight months, there will be a substantial reduction this year in automobile fatalities, the National Safety Council predicted today.

The Works Progress Administration's Federal Theatre Project has abandoned its plan for touring shows on a nation-wide scale and will not form a partnership with Lee Shubert, producer, for the presentation of Prologue to Glory," E. P. Conkle's play about Abraham Lincoln, on the road, it was disclosed yesterday.
Establishment of a reportorial prize of $25 by Theodore Joslin of The News-Journal Company of Wilmington, Del., was announced by Boyd Edwards, head master of the Mercersburg Academy, today.

Stipulations filed with the Board of Tax Appeals today ended eleven years of litigation between the government and the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company of Youngstown, Ohio, over an income-tax claim of $1,168,878.

Prices of cotton jumped more than $1 a bale from early low levels yesterday on the Cotton Exchange when it was announced that a four-power conference had been called for Munich today in an effort to avert the Czechoslovak crisis.

Mr. Chairman, Ladies and Gentlemen of the Convention: You have done me a great honor in elevating me to the chairmanship of the Republican State Convention of 1938. It is an honor that comes to very few men and it carries with it great responsibilities and serious obligations.

The Department of Justice will ask the Federal grand jury at Newark to decide whether Norman Thomas, national Socialist leader, was actually kidnapped from Jersey City on the night of April 30, Attorney General Cummings announced this afternoon.
Robert K. Cassatt was elected a director at a meeting yesterday of the board of directors of the United Gas Improvement Company, to fill the place of the late Clarence H. Geist.

The Republican-Democratic "deal" during the Constitutional. Convention, by which a ban on the proportional representation method of voting was put in a proposed amendment to the State Constitution, was repudiated early this morning by the committee on resolutions of the Republican State Convention.

A group of Southern organizations has been permitted by the Interstate Commerce Commission to intervene in the proceeding for reorganization of the Chicago, Indianapolis Louisville (Monon) Railway, the commission announced today.

Three women, including Mrs. Fred Perry, wife of the tennis star and known on the motion-picture screen as Helen Vinson, were injured slightly at Sixth Avenue and Fifty-third Street yesterday when three automobiles collided there.
James William Sullivan, editor, printer and called the "Father of the Initiative and Referendum Movement in America," died early today in his home here. He was 91 years old.

Thirteen new members of the Hunter College teaching staff will be guests at a tea to be given tomorrow by the staff of the dean's office at the 2 Park Avenue building of the college. Members of the administrative committee of Hunter College and all members of the staff also have been invited to attend.
The Department of Commerce reported today that average daily sales of chain drug stores in August were 4.2 per cent lower than August, 1937. Sales in August were up 1.2 per cent over July.
Whatever contingencies arise tomorrow so far as party candidates are concerned, the distaff half of the Republican convention will leave for home well satisfied.
Hank Greenberg, needing two more home runs to tie Babe Ruth's major league record of 60, went hitless today as his Tiger teammates batted out 12-to-0 victory over the Browns.

20th St. 252 W, 25x86; Amelia M. Majewski to Lillian M. Nuhn, 212 Linden Rd, Mineola, L. I.; mtg $10,000; quitclaim. Stanton St, 126, 22.6x98.2; David Finkel to Max Schneider, 750 Empire Ave. Far Rockaway, L. I.; mtg $14,000 (50 cents). Beekman St, 20, 23.6x85.3; Joyce Bushel, referee, to Mutual Life Insurance Co; foreclosure ($5).

Manhattan's freshman football team will play three games this season, it was announced yesterday by Herbert M. Kopf, director of athletics. Thirty-four men have been working out daily under the guidance of Coaches Pete Battle and, Biff Glassford since the opening of the school year, Sent. 12.

Upon receiving official confirmation through diplomatic channels of the summoning of the four-power conference at Munich tomorrow, the White House, through Stephen T. Early, secretary to the President, said today that the meeting "offers great hope and encouragement."
Thornton Wilder left the leading part in his play, "Our Town," last night, Frank Craven resuming his role after a two-week leave of absence passed in Hollywood.

As Prime Minister Chamberlain was delivering a grave speech to the House of Commons yesterday two slips of paper were handed to him that bore tidings which instantly dispelled the war clouds hanging over Europe.

Edward Knowlton Woodworth, one of New Hampshire's leading bankers and lawyers, died this morning at Wyman House, Cambridge, Mass., of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 63 years old. e. He was 63 years old.

Pilsner beer, it appears, is safe. The indications are that the famous Bohemian brewing district is not likely to go the way of Vienna, into the Nazi domain. Spokesmen for two importing firms declared yesterday that the rich hops-growing land around the Czech city of Pilzen, or Pilsen, is so clearly Czech country that Hitler has not included it in the territory and assets he has demanded of Czechoslovakia.

Miss Virginia Guard of Pelham, playing the best golf seen in the tournament, won the fourth annual Briar Hills women's invitation competition, by defeating Mrs. Alfred King of Apawamis, 4 and 3, today.
The Red Sox defeated the Athletics, 2 to 1, today for a sweep of the two-game series. Joe Heving allowed only six hits and won from Lynn Nelson in a pitching duel.

Mrs. Sylva Annenberg Leichner of Fresh Meadow tallied an 83 to take the low gross honors in the women's Long Island one-day handicap tourney at the Oakland Golf Club today. The former New York State champion played the first nine in 43 and covered the inward route in 40.

Amid the turbulence of politics Mr. Farley has set apart the week of Oct. 2-8 as National Letter Writing Week. In that period all postmasters and postal employes are to mass their energies "to encourage greater use of postal facilities, with particular emphasis on the writing of letters."

Sixty men stormed the rectory of St. Barbara's Catholic Church today and evicted the Rev. Simon Borkowski, whom pickets had kept a virtual prisoner for seven weeks to keep him from fulfilling a transfer order.

" Moving day" no longer is the nightmare it used to be for landlords, van men and tenants alike. It appears that the old hectic days and night of congestion and delays during the Fall reason will not return to plague the city dweller.
A four-day extension of one-year drivers' licenses, which expire Sept. 30, has been arranged by the State Motor Vehicle Bureau, it was disclosed yesterday by Deputy Commissioner I. J. Brody.

Dr. Robert M. Hopkins, general secretary of the World's Sunday School Association, and Mrs. Hopkins, will sail on Saturday for Cape Town, South Africa, on the City of New York, it was announced yesterday. Later,

The board of governors of the New York Curb Exchange has approved the original application of the Salt Dome Oil Corporation to list 584,682 shares of $1 par common capital stock, with authority to add 535 additional shares upon official notice of issuance.
Newark marched roughshod over Buffalo today for its second consecutive International Baseball League play-off championship and set its cap for a second consecutive little world series title.
The second half of the 1938 real estate tax will be due Saturday, Oct. 1, City Treasurer Almerindo Portfolio announced yesterday. Payment will be accepted during October without penalty.
ADLER--Charles, beloved husband of Clara. devoted father of Howard S. and Stanley L. Services Friday. Sept. 30, 1:30 P. M., 70 Grove Ave., Cedarhurst, L. I.

An end of the two weeks' strike of 15,000 truck drivers today was expected last night when the Merchant Truckmen's Bureau, representing local operators, voted to accept the compromise terms of Mayor La Guardia.

Headlines on the international situation in this morning's newspapers follow: Deutsche Allgemelne Zeitung--"The Czech Bloody Terror Continues in Undiminished Intensity" Mussolini, Chamberlain and Daladier in unich Today."

Addressing the Swarthmore student body at the opening of the academic year President frank Aydelotte urged the undergraduate body at swarthmore College to keep their heads in this trying situation, and discuss the important decision now being taken by the heads of all the States of Europe.

A brass plaque marking the site of the old Koster Bial Music Hall, where the first showing of motion pictures in a theatre took place forty-three years ago, will be unveiled on Tuesday at the Thirty-fourth Street side of Macy's department store under the auspices of Motion Pictures' Greatest Year campaign.

The Atlanta Crackers, champions of the Southern Association, defeated the Beaumont Exporters of the Texas League, 7 to 3, tonight in the opening game of the Dixie Series with a five-run splurge in the third inning. e in the third inning.

Frederick Egner, organist of the First German Presbyterian Church here for fifty-nine years and formerly secretary of the Half-Dime Savings Bank of this city, died last night in his home at the age of 75.

The Steel Construction Company, Birmingham, Ala., submitted to the navy today a $121,671 low bid for construction of an extension to the structural machine shop at the Charleston (S. C.) Navy Yard. Hughes Foulkrod Company, Philadelphia, bid $122,200 and the Virginia Bridge Company, Roanoke, Va., $125,800.

It would be impossible for the imagination to conceive a more dramatic scene than the House of Commons witnessed yesterday when, in the closing moments of an address which held no apparent hope that an immediate outbreak of war could be avoided, Mr.
Fred Perry, English professional tennis star, won his first-round match in the national professional tennis tournament in the Chicago arena tonight, defeating Bill Crokers of Chicago, 6-0, 6-3, 6-4.
Assurances are being given that the monopoly investigation now getting under way at Washington will seek to maintain an open-minded and impartial attitude.
The Munich conference call has considerably lessened tension here. It is believed the four participating powers will succeed in settling the present grave crisis.
Philip E. Barnard, Babylon attorney, died , this morning of a heart attack at the age of 44. He formerly was president of the Republican Club.
Max Weloff, prominent real estate operator, who came here from Philadelphia forty years ago, died at home today of a heart attack. He was 55 years old.

The definite prediction that Governor Lehman will be drafted by the Democratic State Convention to run again, and for a four-year term, against Thomas E. Dewey, was made soon after midnight by the Democratic State and National Chairman, James A. Farley.

Salient passages from Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's speech in the House of Commons today were broadcast in German and Italian tonight in a new effort to present this country's case directly to the people of the totalitarian States. alitarian States.

While bottled beer outsells canned beer in New York almost two to one, there is a wide variation among the sales volumes of different brewers, according to a study of canned and bottled beer sales in stores here just completed by the research department of THE NEW YORK TIMES. Some 260 stores with beer licenses had weekly sales of 157,256 bottles of beer as against 84,094 cans.

Mayor La Guardia asked all New Yorkers yesterday to spend five minutes praying for world peace at 12:30 P. M. today, while the European situation is being discussed at Munich. Churches and synagogues will be open for prayer at noon. The Mayor's proclamation said:

More than sixty entries have been received for the Adjacent Hunts Racing Association meeting to be held Saturday on the grounds of the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club of Port Chester, N. Y., it was announced yesterday. Leading contenders of the hunt circuit are included in the field.
Officers and directors of the National Automobile Dealers Association, at a special meeting today, decided to recommend a new constitution and by-laws to the membership.

Acting on the theory that even a peaceful solution of the Sudeten problem will mean that the region will become German and its exports largely unsalable in this market, domestic manufacturers have started active solicitation of business which normally would go to Czechoslovakia.

Playland, the $11,000,000 Westchester Amusement Park here which was under four feet of water during the flood last week, suffered $30,000 damage by fire today when the Japanese Tea Garden, photo studio and several game and refreshment stands were destroyed.

Prime Minister Mackenzie King has agreed to the appointing of a Canadian commission to cooperate as a fact-finding body with a similar United States commission on the proposed United States highway through British Columbia and Yukon Territory to Alaska. aska.

The Chamber of Deputies in Argentina has approved a bill empowering the government to fix minimum prices on grains or to subsidize farmers whenever it is deemed necessary "for defense of national production," it was stated yesterday in a report of the Argentine Information Bureau.

The removal of stained glass from the windows of Chartres Cathedral was started today by technicians aided by a corps of volunteers. Twenty-eight steel scaffoldings were erected for the purpose, and small pieces of glass were placed carefully in special backing cases. backing cases.

More active movement of merchandise than at any time since the trucking difficulties began was reported yesterday by department store executives here. Fast freight trucking was resumed as smaller operators signed the new contracts
The tension in Hankow is mounting because of reports of the steady weakening of Chinese Army resistance in the face of the relentless pounding by Japanese forces.
Repudiation of the measure to prohibit proportional representation, which was adopted by the Constitutional Convention, was sought tonight by Democratic leaders at the State Convention.

The National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday that 10,590,000 workers were unemployed in August, a drop of 369,000 from the July total. This estimate included as unemployed 3,475,000 workers in the WPA, Civilian Conservation Corps and other government works agencies.
Thirty times a runaway in less than a year, Ruth Wheeler, aged 4, became a major problem today to this city. Three weeks ago she stowed away on a bus and wound up in Niagara Falls.

When the New York Football Giants face the Pittsburgh Pirates next Monday evening at the Polo Grounds it is probable that Hugh Wolfe, former Texas University back, will be in the local eleven's array. This was indicated by Coach Steve Owen during yesterday's practice session at Innisfail Park.

Harry Dixon, junior quarterback, capped his recent phenomenal improvement by marshaling his Black Princeton eleven to a 41-0 victory over the Whites in a forty-five minute scrimmage on University Field today.

Death Announced Retired Fireman Little Rutherford, formerly a member of Engine Co. 250, residing at 1959 Hendricksen St., Brooklyn, died Sept. 26. Funeral will take place from his late residence at 9:30 A. M., Friday, Sept. 30. Interment at Holy Cross Cemetery. The Deputy Chief of the 12th Division shall detail one Captain, one Lieutenant and twelve Firemen, as funeral escort.

Miss Irma Louise Endel, daughter of Mrs. Albert M. Endel of Montgomery, Ala., and the late Mr. Endel, was married to M. James Spitzer of this city yesterday noon in a private suite at the Sherry-Netherland.

The final step in the reorganization of the New York Stock Exchange, as recommended by the Conway committee, was taken yesterday when three representatives of the public were elected to serve on the board of governors.
Certain passages in Chamberlain's speech yesterday dealing with Hungary elicited corrections from Hungarian official circles tonight.
By tradition, the great financial markets indicate by their course the real probabilities in such matters of supreme economic importance as the outbreak or the averting of a general European war.
The Waldorf-Astoria Hotel opened yesterday, its third annual exhibition of arts and crafts by its employes. There are 126 exhibitors and they range from bellboys to Oscar, the hotel's famous host.

The nineteenth annual exhibition of art, handicraft and fancy work, sponsored by the Lenox Library Association, of which Grenville Lindall Winthrop is president, was opened here today at Sedgwick Hall.

United States Ambassador Joseph C. Grew appealed to Japan yesterday to send a peace proposal to Germany and Czechoslovakia similar to that made by President Roosevelt. The Foreign Office spokesman last night issued the following statement on the appeal:

President Roosevelt's: telegram to Chancellor Hitler last night is acknowledged editorially by The Muenchner Neueste Nachrichten, Nazi party organ, as contributing an understanding opinion on the present situation, which, the paper comments, would have scarcely been expected from the President's speeches in recent months.
Demanding postponement of the date on which they are scheduled to vacate their homes so that the building can be torn down to make a highway approach to the Triborough Bridge and the World's Fair,
The British Government has under consideration a plan for compensation for wartime damage to property, it was announced in the House of Commons today by Sir John Simon, Chancellor of the Exchequer.

Hunters seem to be getting almost as ambitious as the anglers these days, for the man who formerly spent his days hunting rabbits and pheasants is now interested in bigger game. Many want to know where they can go to be reasonably certain of getting a deer and bear, and others want caribou. Most of them want to go before it gets too cold, and they don't care how far they have to travel.

Fluctuating foreign exchange quotations, attributed to the European crisis, caused Detroit merchants today to begin discounting Canadian money. The rate varied from 4 to 8 per cent as the quotations changed.

MANHATTAN LANGFORD, GEORGE PHILIP (April 20, 1938). Gross assets, $25,376: net, $16,532. To Philip K. Langford, son, temporary estate in residue with right to invade principal for maintenance and education, also interest in trust for Amy Amelia Churchill, decedent's half-sister, who receives an annuity of $500; four others receive remainder bequests. Chief assets,

The government's weekly report of crop conditions was issued yesterday as follows: The weather during the week was extremely favorable for outside operations throughout the Cotton Belt and picking and ginning made uniformly good to excellent advance.

Greta Garbo, notion picture actress, today was aboard the liner Kungsholm en route to New York after having been in Europe since December, 1937. She left Gothenburg yesterday and is due at Aberdeen, Scotland, tomorrow.

How will they line up, two and two or three and one? Is Premier Eduard Daladier of France strong enough to carry this immense argument? In which camp will Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy be? Will Chancellor Adolf Hitler scream, as he did at Berchtesgaden? Will it bring real peace?

The Securities and Exchange Commission has called for Oct. 13 a hearing on applications and declarations under the Holding Company Act by the Milwaukee Electric Railway and Light Company and the North American Edison Company,
Con Conrad, song writer, died today at near-by Van Nuys, where he had been staying for his health. His age was 49.

The Barber Steamship Lines, Inc., of Brooklyn was fined $200 yesterday by Judge Grover M. Moscowitz, in Federal Court, Brooklyn, after a representative of the company pleaded guilty to an information charging it with failure to deliver an alien stowaway on the motor ship Tai Ping to immigration officials.

Hog prices were 15 to 25 cents higher today. Sharply reduced supplies furnished the principal strengthening factor, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Lambs were also strong and in instances 10 to 15 cents higher. Outside demand for finished steers and yearlings pepped up the trade on such kinds today, but the balance of the steer and yearling list sold slowly at barely steady prices.

Showing the same liberality as they have in all their previous years of world series spoils distribution, the Yankee players yesterday voted to divide their portion of the 1938 series receipts into twenty-eight full shares, as well as making generous allotments to others.

Two armed thugs entered the ground-floor apartment of Bernard Rogers, 50 years old, and his son, Michael, 25, at 531 West Forty-ninth Street yesterday and after a fifteen-minute scuffle with both occupants escaped with $500 and a wrist watch.

Pensioned On his own application, to take effect 12 midnight, Sept. 27: INSPECTOR--George F. Ferre, 9th Division, at $2,950 per annum. Appointed Dec. 30, 1902. Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M.. Oct. 1:...
The first buyers of the Outlet Company, Providence, to arrive in this market since the hurricane of last week will be here this morning to replenish stocks destroyed or damaged during the storm.
If current news accounts of our national game were included in the Time Capsule, buried in the Flushing meadows, the scholars of 6939 are going to have some difficulty deciphering them.
Mrs. John G. Sargent, whose husband was Attorney General during the Coolidge administration, died at her home here yesterday at the age of 73 after an illness of nearly three years.
The Appellate Division, Second Department, convened yesterday for the first time in its new $1,500,000 court building at Pierrepont Street and Monroe Place, Brooklyn.
Prince Paul, the Regent, returned to Belgrade today from Brdo Castle in Slovenia, where he had been spending the Summer.
President Roosevelt has decided definitely against coming into Pennsylvania this Fall to campaign on behalf of the Democratic ticket, Senator Guffey, the campaign manager, said today.
A movement to nominate a Statewide independent ticket was announced tonight by J. Harvey Williams, chairman of the Republican Committee for John J. O'Connor.

Albert M. Greenfield, Philadelphia real estate broker, told the Pennsylvania House's Investigating Committee today that he never was connected with an alleged "sale" of movie legislation and that he never had entered into any financial transaction with Governor Earle.
Calling of the Munich conference caused. such a wave of optimism here today that a Foreign Office spokesman warned against letting hopes run too high.

Eugene Ormandy has been appointed music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra under a new three-year contract, it was announced yesterday by the board of directors of the Philadelphia Orchestra Association.

The war balance favored the Loyalists today in the Ebro fighting. In two counter-attacks in different parts of that front, hills previously lost were recaptured. One of these had been particularly vigorously fought for in previous actions, since it overlooks a main highway.
Marshall Field 3d, grandson and namesake of the Chicago merchant, inherited a $100,000,000 fortune today on his forty-fifth birthday anniversary.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that a hearing to determine whether the Allegheny Corporation had made misleading statements in its financial reports filed from 1934 to 1937 in connection with the listing of securities on the New York Stock Exchange had been postponed until Oct. 10.

Coach Carl Snavely indicated in today's light practice that Cornell's starting backfield Saturday against Colgate is very much of a mystery. Only Vince Eichler, 205-pound Utica boy, is a sure thing. He will go at fullback. e will go at fullback.
President Roosevelt asked the people of the United States today to join with him and his family on Sunday in prayer for the continued peace of the world.

Miss Rosette Arklay King, daughter of Mrs. Ford King of Morristown and East Seventy-second Street, New York, and of Arklay King of New York, will be introduced to society in December at a tea dance at the Colony Club in New York.
Officials of the railroads and of unions representing 1,000,000 workers converged on Washington today for hearings before a special mediation- board on a five-month-old wage dispute.
William Harrison Moreland, retired Indian civil servant and generally acknowledged as the world's leading authority on the Mogul emperors, died yesterday at the age of 70.

The National Conservation Bureau of the Association of Casualty and Surety Executives, which cooperates with schools, public agencies and trade groups in a nationwide program for "creating safer communities," convened in its quarterly meeting yesterday in its headquarters at 60 John Street.

A solemn mass of requiem will be celebrated today at 10 A. M. in St. Augustine's Church, 1,183 Franklin Avenue, the Bronx, for the Rev. James J. McGuone, who was fatally injured on Monday night in an automobile accident on the Bronx River' Parkway Extension.

A drop of $2,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, the fifth successive weekly decline, was reported by member banks of the Federal Reserve in this city in their statement of condition as of Wednesday, and issued yesterday.
Pending the definitive fixing of Czechoslovakia's new frontiers it is impossible to assess precisely Germany's gain in raw materials and manufacturing resources.

THE reviewer stepped over the gray and white slopes of the newspapers strewn on the floor around his chair. He went across the room to the bookcase. There, between Talleyrand's memoirs and Terry's "Mexico," the lighted dial of the radio still glowed angrily.

Hurled against the curb after losing their grip on the tail-board of a truck behind which they were "hitching" a ride on their roller skates, one boy was killed and his playmate was painfully injured at about 10 o'clock last night when the truck made a sudden turn from Bedford Avenue into Clymer Street, Brooklyn.

Spring lambs advanced 15 to 25 cents today In an active market. Swine prices weakened in a slow, draggy trade. Choice and prime steers and yearlings sold readily, others dragged at barely steady prices, the United States Department of Agriculture reports.
Great Britain drew tremendous sighs of relief this morning when it was finally announced from Munich that an agreement had been reached there.
The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has obtained an order by the Colonial Department of the Netherlands East Indies for twelve transport airplanes, Robert E. Gross president, announced yesterday.

Johnny Vander Meer got into some tight spots today but held the Cardinals to seven hits and won his fourteenth victory, 7 to 4, for the Reeds. He walked six men, forced in one run and struck out only one batter, Johnny Mize.

In a speech championing the New Deal, Senator Robert F. Wagner, keynoter at the Democratic State Convention here today, assailed Republicans as "last-minute hitch-hikers seeking a free ride on the progressive bandwagon."

In support of its contention that "under-the-counter" chiseling on liquor prices is much less prevalent than had been charged, the New York Joint Liquor Conference, organization composed of wholesale and retail liquor dealers of the city, yesterday made public a report showing that only 88 out of a total of 1,199 stores canvassed in a shopping survey of the metropolitan district were guilty of Drice-cutting.
Governor Herbert H. Lehman, faced all day today with a relentless draft movement from the leaders of the Democratic party, failed at a conference tonight to announce his willingness to run again.

The Pennsylvania Railroad announced yesterday the retiremet today of J. E. Weller, traffic manager at Chicago. Effective tomorrow, R. J. Wood, now general freight agent, will become Western freight traffic manager at Chicago, C. B. Sudborough is appointed Southwestern freight traffic manager at St. Louis and I. T. Marine, general Western freight agent at Chicago.

BRODERICK, GEORGE F. (Oct. 1, 1937). Estate, less than $1.000. To Jane Broderick, daughter, 1.101 North Ave., New Rochelle. N. Y., entire estate. Rena C. Collins, same address, executrix, sister. EASTON, LOUISA (May 29). Estate, less than $5,000. To Harriet Wheeler, executrix, 488 Beacon St., Boston, Mass.

Twenty-eight hundred members of Local 132 of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, employed in the manufacture of plastic buttons, compacts, buckles and dress accessories, went on strike yesterday morning for higher wages and shorter hours.

Princeton University's undergraduate enrollment has topped all previous records this Fall with a total of 2,403 students, according to figures announced today by Wilbur F. Kerr, registrar. Twenty arrivals more are expected before the books close.

The Alton Railroad Company, controlled and managed by the Baltimore Ohio Railroad pany, has suggested to some of the leading holders of its refunding 3 per cent bonds, due on Oct. 1, 1949, that interest be placed on a contingent basis for eight years.

Army's football practice today consisted of a long passing drill, followed by a review of its running plays. Putting the varsity against a B team which had been detailed to learn Columbia plays, Coach Bill Wood carefully went over the defense assignments.

Soccer games in England on Saturday will be held as scheduled, it was announced today. The football authorities, however, will be guided by the War Office in their attitude while the present international situation lasts.

" When I was a little boy," said Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain today as he stepped into the plane that took him to the Munich conference, "I used to repeat 'if at first you don't succeed, try, try again.' That is what I am doing.

Miss Gwyn Grant, niece of Mr. and Mrs. Coulter D. Huyler of Greenwich, will be married on Nov. 5 to Roland Ruutz-Rees, adopted son of Miss Caroline Ruutz-Rees, former headmistress of the Rosemary Hall School here.
William H. Menn of Los Angeles was elected president of the National Association of Insurance Agents in the closing session of its annual convention here today.

Thousands of men, women and children poured into Ireland from England today despite widespread hopes that the Munich conference would avert a European war. Extra steamers were pressed into service on the Irish Sea to accommodate them.

Thurman W. Arnold, Assistant Attorney General, has opened a series of conferences with motion-picture company executives to discuss the Justice Department's anti-trust suit against the picture industry.

Dr. Melchmore Mauro-Cottone, organist and composer of choral and organ music, died yesterday in Parkway Hospital at the age of 55. He lived at 222 West Eighty-third Street. Dr. Mauro-Cottone was graduated from a conservatory of music in Salerno.

A proposal that the church cooperate with the home in fostering Christian character was made yesterday by Professor Samuel L. Hamilton of New York University at a one-day conference for church workers and parents held under the auspices of the Greater New York Federation of Churches as part of religious education week.

The domestic wheat markets staged a good rally today following an opening decline, and the close was about at the top. Scattered selling developed early in sympathy with a break of 2 3/4 to 3 7/8 cents a bushel in Liverpool, but there was no material pressure here.

Former Senator David Baird Jr., whose "regular Republican" candidates for nomination for Camden County and State Assembly offices were defeated in the recent primary election by the ticket of the Republican League for Clean Government, announced today his retirement from political activity.
Dr. Ernest Coleman Levy, public health authority, died Today in his apartment in the Hotel William Byrd. He was 70 years old and had been in failing health for several years.

The Pennsylvania Railroad Company in August had a net income of $1,727,131, compared with $2,762,209 in August, last year, according to a statement made yesterday by M. W. Clement, president, in Washington, D. .C. The surplus was $1,002.215 after all charges and appropriations, compared with $2,083,504 in August, 1937.

New York City consumers may be comforted by the fact, apparent after latest check-ups on the amount of damage done to food crops by the hurricane of last week, that even such a catastrophe does not affect the city's food supply seriously.

The Pennsylvania Railroad Company tomorrow will pay the annual instalment of $1,050,000 on its Series "C" 4 1/2 per cent general equipment trust certificates, issued Oct. 1, 1924. The carrier announced that no new financing would be required to meet the maturity.

Margit Elizabeth Mary Tempke, just 3 years old, pert, with light blue eyes and blonde hair, arrived yesterday all by herself on the Gripsholm of the Swedish-American Line, after a year's stay with her grandparents in. Finland.

A declaration by the United Light and Power Engineering and Construetion Company covering its organization and operation as a subsidiary service company for the United Light and Power System has been approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission under certain conditions.

Two tornadoes dipped down into this city at about 8:05 o'clock this morning and brought death to at least twenty-six persons, injuries to hundreds and damage to property estimated at between $2,000,000 and $5,000,000.
James Madison Barrett, former treasurer of the old New York Tribune, died on Tuesday at his home, 335 East Nineteenth Street, Brooklyn, at the age of 78.

Long before Charles E. Duryea was born inventors had been experimenting with steam-driven "road locomotives." Indeed, the steam coaches of Sir Goldsworthy Gurney were so successful that they plied regularly on British roads over a century ago until driven off by restraining acts of Parliament.

Public school athletic teams were informed today by the State Education Department that it would not approve contests with private or parochial schools which fail to observe basic departmental athletic regulations.
Two sophomores and nine lettermen appear slated for starting roles as Syracuse opens its football season against Clarkson tomorrow night in Archbold Stadium.

The Mexican Supreme Court decided today to delay its decision on the oil companies' principal petition forw an injunction against expropriation until next Thursday in order to give the justices more time to study the case.
By a quirk in the Immigration Law, Clifford Bye of Tampa found himself a citizen of two countries today. He confronted William A. Reilly, Chief United States Immigration Inspecor with his problem,

The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today an application by the Lima Cord Sole and Heel Corporation for permission to withdraw its $1 par value common stock from listing and registration on the Cleveland Stock Exchange, effective at the close of trading on Oct. 9.
The Hamburg-American liner Deutschland, arriving from Hamburg and channel ports today, has as passengers Brig. Gen. George B. Pillsbury, retired, and Mrs. Pillsbury;
Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve welcomed more than 100 transfer students to Barnard College at a dinner given in their honor last night in Hewitt Hall on the campus.

Petitions nominating Charles W. Bryan, three times Governor and Democratic nominee for Vice President in 1924, as an independent candidate for Governor were filed today in the Secretary of State's offlce.
The Duchess of Atholl was guest of honor at a dinner give last night by Dr. and Mrs. Nicholas Murray Butler at their home, 60 Morningside Drive.

Coach Earl Blaik continued to hustle his Dartmouth eleven along today, and in addition the big Green mentor made the second promotion of the week when he raised Senior Lou Highmark to the starting eleven.

A rainstorm accompanied by fresh to strong winds, possibly reaching gale force, will strike New York some time today but there is virtually no possibility of tornado conditions similar to those which yesterday damaged Charleston, S. C., it was said at the Weather Bureau here last night.
The Seaman Body Corporation, a subsidiary of the Nash Motors Company, was dissolved today

The following Marine Corps changes for the week ended. Sept. 28 were announced today: Williams, Capt. W. R., Quantico. Va., to office paymaster, Marine Corps, Naval Operating Base. Norfolk. Va.Swinnerton, Capt. J. M., Mare Island. Calif. to Marine Corps Base, San Diego, Calif.

A thief crept up behind a New York diamond dealer sitting in the Union Station here today, snatched a brief case containing $30,000 worth of set and unset diamonds and escaped in an automobile driven by an accomplice.

The list of ten players who will form the metropolitan district team to compete in the Lesley Cup competition was announced yesterday by the Metropolitan Golf Association. The tests will be held today and tomorrow at the Merion Cricket Club in Ardmore, Pa.

Celebrating her fourth anniversary as a president of Bonwit Teller Co., Mrs. Hortense M. Odlum will cut a huge birthday cake tonight at ceremonies at the Fifth Avenue store. The cake is a replica of the store, with its new twelye-story addition to be opened soon, outlined in gold.

George E. Kennedy, examiner for the National Labor Relations Board, today recommended that the board require The Hollywood Citizens-News to re-employ five members of the American Newspaper Guild it had discharged and others who struck in sympathy last May.
The American Locomotive Company yesterday announced that it had terminated its arrangement with Gyro Process Company whereby it acted as exclusive agent for licensing the Gyro cracking process.

Allan T. Preyer of the Vick Chemical Company, and for the last year treasurer of the Association of National Advertisers, was yesterday elected chairman of the board of the A. N. A. at its annual convention in Hot Springs, Va.

Nathan Straus, United States Housing Administrator, said today if the New York City Housing Authority effected any great saving in the construction of current projects it might be possible to divert the unused portion of USHA loans to other projects in the city.

Two Americans, captured by the Rebels earlier this month while fighting with the International Brigade on the Ebro front, have just arrived at the concentration camp of San Pedro de Cardena, three miles south of Burgos.

The annual drive for funds to continue the Samaritan services of the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service has begun. The appeal this year is again for $250,000, a supplementary fund which is being raised in the spirit of those who "gave what they could" in payment for the help and comfort and courage brought to them all last year by the visiting nurse.

William Boedigheimer, 24 years old, of 247 Harman Street, Brooklyn, pleaded guilty last Sept. 22 to an indictment charging him with stealing and forging three WPA checks totaling $56.88. The bill contained nine counts.

Stanley MacRea, 28 years old, a stenographer, was sentenced to an indeterminate penitentiary term up to three years yesterday by General Sessions Judge Owen W. Bohan for a $307 theft perpetrated more than seven years ago.

The Southern Pacific Railroad's application for authority to issue $7,251, 000 of first refunding mortgage gold bonds, to be sold to the Southern Pacific Company at par and accrued interest, was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
A feature of the early Autumn hunting and racing season in Westchester will be the Adjacent Hunts Race meeting on Saturday afternoon at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club course near here.

" No administrative body will ever influence me in construing what I believe to be the law," Federal Judge William Bondy said yesterday, in rejecting a suggestion made by counsel for a stockholder of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation that the Securities and Exchange Commission be invited to take part in the reorganization of the corporation.

Politicians began talking about young Thomas E. Dewey as a Gubernatorial candidate even before he was elected District Attorney of New York County in 1937. It was suggested afterward that the 36year-old scourge of the racketeer might even be the Republican nominee for President of the United States in 1940.

Special prayers were offered up yesterday in many of the city's churches and synagogues for the cause of peace in response to a suggestion made Wednesday by Mayor La Guardia, who had received requests from members of religious groups that a special time for prayer for world peace be set aside.

Charles S. Tuttle, trust officer of the City National Bank and Trust Company, died today at his home in Oak Park, Ill. He was 72 years old. Mr. Tuttle had been in the real estate and banking business here for more than forty years.

The case of Norman Marcus, 19year-old delivery boy, and his flaming red auto scooter provided such a tricky legal problem yesterday in Brooklyn Traffic Court that even a Solomon had difficulty in solving it. A little doubtful as to young Marcus's guilt, Magistrate Charles Solomon fined him $1 and let it go at that.
Savings banks continued yesterday to find a ready market for their realty holdings in Manhattan. The New York Savings Bank sold three buildings and leased one.

Supreme Court Justice William Harman Black, who is retiring from the bench this year, has endorsed Magistrate Anna M. Kross for one of the two approaching vacancies on the Supreme Court bench in the First Judicial District, according to a statement sent out yesterday from Magistrate Kross's headquarters in, the Hotel Commodore.

A collection of books, periodicals, pamphlets and cartoons which escaped the burnings of the Nazi regime were exhibited yesterday afternoon at the New School for Social Research by Dr. Kurt Pinthus, a former drama and film critic of Berlin, Germany, who is now a lecturer on European literature at that institute.

Henry H. Egly, a vice president of the investment banking firm of Dillon, Read Co. of New York, has been named by the Securities and Exchange Commission as head of a new unit in its Trading and Exchange Division, of which Ganson Purcell is director.

President Roosevelt named seven new Brigadier Generals today and promoted three to Major General. In line with the policy followed by General Craig, Chief of Staff, to keep the age level of general officers as low as possible, consistent with other considerations, the nominations comprised one of the lowest age groups promoted in recent years.
Al fresco luncheons marked the intermission today of the thirty-sixth annual Piping Rock Horse Show being held for four days on the show ring of Piping Rock Club.

With force the only rule recognized today among nations it would be suicidal for the United States to adopt the proposed constitutional amendment for a referendum by the people before war could be declared, Major Gen. John J. O'Ryan told former members of his World War command at the 107th Regiment reunion dinner at the Hotel Astor last night.

The Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahue, Auxiliary Bishop and Administrator of the Archdiocese of New York, announced yesterday the appointment of six administrators of churches and the transfer of fortyfive assistants.
William S. Murray of Utica was re-elected chairman of the Republican State Committee at a meeting of the members here in the convention hall after the convention adjourned early this morning.

Registration of 8,133 students in Harvard University for the current academic year was announced today, with enrollment officially closed in all but one or two graduate departments, although late registrants are expected in nearly all the schools.

The will of Mrs. Victoria Morris, who died at Ann Arbor, Mich., on Sept. 18 last, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday, names the Seamen's Church Institute of 25 South Street residuary legatee. The petition for probate formally valued the. estate at "more than $20,000."

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, addressing members of the Rotary Club at their weekly luncheon in the Hotel Commodore yesterday, asked business men to aid in curbing the activities of the National Labor Relations Board for the benefit of labor and industry.

Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Blair Mitchell will give a reception tomorrow afternoon at Pennbrook House, their place in. Far Hills, N. J., for their debutante granddaughter, Miss Sylvia Mitchell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Van S. Mitchell.

American Agricultural Chemical Company capital stock, no-par value, will be suspended from dealings on the New York Stock Exchange on Monday, when common stock, no-par value, of the same company will be admitted to the list.

Following is the text of Thomas E. Dewey's acceptance address at the Republican State Convention: Ladies and gentlemen, I accept your nomination. The State of New York has a proud history of sound, progressive government.
Two buildings that were residential landmarks in the Murray Hill section before the turn of the century will make way for a modern apartment house, it was learned yesterday.

Isaac L. Bloodgood, a member of one of Greene County's oldest families, died yesterday at his home in Hensonville, at the age of 83. He was last surviving member of a family of eight children. Educated in public schools and Stamford Seminary, he later taught in Windham School.

Physicians attending Jimmy Adamick, 23-year-old Midland (Mich.) heavyweight boxer, predicted tonight that "barring complications" he would recover from a cerebral concussion suffered when he lost on a technical knockout to Roscoe Toles, Detroit Negro.

Bobby Stap, the 3-year-old Queens boy who during the past year has stowed away on four different vessels because of his desire to "go to sea," was released yesterday from the Children's Shelter in Jamaica.
George Lott Jr. of Chicago and Fred Perry of Great Britain advanced to the quarter-finals of the national professional tennis tournament tonight with straight-set victories.

Tearing into an already wellbeaten enemy with perhaps more vehemence than exigencies demanded, the Giants opened their final two-game series of the year with the Phillies at the Polo Grounds yesterday by thrashing Jimmy Wilson's tail-enders, 9 to 2.

Bucknell University broke ground today for two new wings to its Engineering Building at a special ceremony which included a radio address by Dr. Edward Albert Wiggam, writer on scientific topics, and a tribute by Arnaud C. Marts, Bucknell president, to the men who pioneered in engineering at the university.

The New York Advance, a weekly newspaper. circulating in Yorkville, suspended publication yesterday after an arbitrator had ordered two employes, allegedly discharged for union activities, reinstated with full back pay.

W. Wallace Alexander, Inc., Philadelphia, an investment trust, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering two series of $500,000 each of Alexander Fund participation units designated respectively as NNN and OOO,

Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, former national champion, and Miss Betty Jameson of San Antonio, Texas, will meet tomorrow in the semifinal round of the Berthellyn Cup invitation golf tournament at the Huntinadon Valley Country Club.

Both halfback positions and right guard are unfilled on the Cornell varsity eleven as the day draws near for the Colgate opener. Carl Snavely has three speedy halfbacks, but doesn't know which two to start. The three are Whit Baker, Hal McCullough and George Peck.

Greyhound, E. J. Baker's 6-year-old flier, lowered his own world- trotting record for the mile to 1:551/4 in a race against time today. The best previous time for a trotted mile was 1:56, which the Grey Ghost from Baker's St. Charles, Ill., stables set here in 1937 and equaled last Friday as the Grand Circuit meeting opened.
Men and women of Munich stood cheerfully for hours today for a glimpse of the 69-year-old man who started this business of man-to-man talks for peace.

Fishing is grand sport, but tomorrow the season opens on woodcock. Tonight will see hundreds, perhaps thousands, of devotees of the "timberdoodle" moving from southern to northern counties, at least for the week-end.

Informed sources said today they understood Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain. had obtained from Chancellor Adolf Hitler and Premier Benito Mussolini an agreement to negotiate a fourpower non-aggression pact as soon as the Czechoslovak problem was solved.
Marine insurance underwriters here cut in half yesterday their quotation on war risk for gold shipments, making the rate for shipments from European ports to the United States 25 cents per $100.

In addition to the election of Morris S. Tremaine as chairman of the board and William D. Flanders as president, directors of the Lawyers Title Corporation of New York, at a meeting yesterday, also elected the following officers:

Movements of vessels follow. All dates are Sept. 29 unless specified: At Manila: Alden Barker, J. D. Edwards, Paul Jones, Whipple. At New York: Babbitt, Decatur, Tillman. At Whitestone: Dickerson, Schenck. At New Haven: Badger, Herbert, Leary. Acushnet, at Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, Sept. 28.

Dollar sales of wholesalers during August were greater than for any month since last November, and sales of manufacturers made the most favorable comparison with the corresponding month of 1937 to be recorded thus far this year, according to the monthly joint study of the National Association of Credit Men and the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, issued today.

Hollywood Ave, 258, 25x137.7xirreg; Treasurer of the City of New York against Frank Slavek, due, $9,003; taxes, $1,400; to plaintiff for $1,000. Whitlock Ave, 750, 1-story laundry, 100x70; Bethbert Realties, Inc, against 430 E 59th St Corp, due, $36,500; to plaintiff for $1.000.

After an eleven-month strike seventy-five drivers of the BergenPassaic division of the Garden State Bus Lines returned to work at 5 o'clock this morning under a contract providing for the payment of a total of $10,000 in back wages in ten installments.

The growth of Cluett, Peabody Co., Inc., National Carbon Company, Inc., and the Westclox Division of General Time Instruments Corporation are traced in Volume 5 of the current series of case studies on "Organization and Operation of the Advertising Department," made by the Association of National Advertisers and released yesterday.

The Republican convention completed the party's State ticket and adjourned early today. In opening the final session at 10:30 o'clock last night, Chairman Oswald D. Heck announced that the order of nominations would be changed to begin with those for Representative at Large.

Paris has begun to breathe easily again after a week of tense anxiety. Restaurants, bars and night clubs have again filled up. Last night big crowds were about, celebrating the improved peace prospects.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith declared that New York City "cannot afford to lose the benefits of private philanthropy" yesterday in addressing the opening meeting of the campaign in behalf of the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service-for a supplementary fund of $250,000 for the maintenance of this service. The meeting was held in the Empire State Club in that building.

The Frieda Horn, German steamer that was chased yesterday by the United States Coast Guard cutter Unalga for having arrived and departed in violation of customs regulations, is returning to port on instructions of her Hamburg home office, it was anannounced this afternoon by the steamers' agents.

Posting a best-ball of 63, eight under par, Frank Kringle and Anton Folinus of Sunnyfield led a field of thirty-seven pro-amateur teams today in the annual eighteenhole prelude to the New Jersey State P. G. A. championship.

Jimmy Ritchie, trainer of Sgt. Byrne, has within a fortnight, gained and lost another exceptionally keen horse, for yesterday at Belmont Park he saddled River Pirate to win the first race of the local season at a mile for juveniles.
A E. Webber's Oddesa Frank won the Haverhill Claiming Purse today, one-mile feature at Rockingham Park, and paid $8.68 for $2. In second place was Jack Whyte's Lady Infinite, with Affirmation third.

With the announcement that "we are getting awfully near the end of our rope," Nathan Straus, United States Housing Administrator, revealed today that not $800,000,000, but only $650,000,000 was actually available for earmarking to local housing authorities for low-rent and slumclearance housing projects.

The largest really transaction to be made in the old Constable Hook section of Bayonne, N. J., in recent months took place yesterday when the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey sold to the Trebor Realty Corporation two parcels of land containing 135 acres.

The Republic of Poland will announce today details of its offer of definitive settlement to holders of its twenty-year 6 per cent dollar bonds due on April 1, 1940, whereby American holders will receive payments of principal and interest in American funds.

As reported a few days ago in these columns, Sidney Lee, treasurer of the Royal Academy, has taken up with Homer Saint-Gaudens, director of the Fine Arts Department at Carnegie Institute, the matter of a proposed large-scale exhibition of American art to be held in London under the auspices of the Royal Academy.
The Czech Government contributed its share today toward the success of the Munich conference. A communique issued this afternoon reads:

Trading was fair to slow in local markets yesterday. Fresh pork business was improved. Lamb sold strong to slightly higher, fresh pork cuts uneven, cow scarce and stronger: other classes about steady. Trading in kosher lamb was slow and about steady on the early market, and business in other classes was largely in cold meat, at weak prices.

Two men were arrested by New York Central police today after several New York City delegates to the Democratic State Convention said they had been swindled by card sharps. When the train arrived here at 2 A. M. the railroad police seized two well-dressed strangers.
Thomas E. Dewey as the Republican nominee for Governor of New York became first today in the speculation of politicians as to the Republican nominee for President in 1940.

The Medical Funding Corporation, recently organized to provide medical and hospital service subscription plan, has leased an entire floor in 21 East Fortieth Street for its New York headquarters. The lease was arranged by the Cross Brown Company, brokers.
