An urgent plea against the dismemberment of Czechoslovakia was made last night by speakers at a mass meeting of more than 800 members of the Hunter College faculty and student body in the college building at 2 Park Avenue.
Soon after District Attorney Dewey finished his acceptance speech tonight he was bombarded with hundreds of telegrams predicting his success in the Fall campaign.

The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended Sept. 28 were announced today: Hogan, Lt. W. C., Fort Trumbull Training Station, temporarily assigned to the American Whaling Factory vessel Ulysses, as inspector, at Curacao, Dutch West Indies, about Oct. 23.

Residential properties again provided the bulk of the activity in Bronx realty reported yesterday. An investor bought from Stanley E. Glauger, operator, the six-story elevator building at 3,036 Bailey Avenue, on the northeast corner of Albany Crescent Terrace, for cash above a first mortgage of $118,000.

An examination of eyes, ears nose, throat and teeth took place yesterday as 1,200,000 pupils in the New York City school system participated in the annual Health Day program. In more than 1,000 buildings boys and girls heard lectures on the proper care of the body, the value of milk in the diet, arid the dangers of malnutrition.

Leading local merchants honored John C. Watson, president of the New York State Council of Retail Merchants and an official of the John G. Myers Company, Albany, at a luncheon yesterday in the RitzCarlton Hotel. The gathering was "in recognition and appreciation of his services for retail distribution in this State."
Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman was present but not voting today. She was not talking, either, except to a few intimates. Quietest and remotest

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Sept. 27: COMMANDERS Groesbeck, B., Jr., Med. Corps., the Yorktown, to Naval Air' Station, Norfolk, Va., in November or December. Perry, W. H., Med. Corps, Great Lakes, Ill., to the Yorktown, in November.

An unprecedented action which may invalidate more than 200 indictments returned by the September Kings County grand jury, on the ground that a woman was illegally a member of the grand jury, was instituted yesterday with the obtaining of a show cause order from County Judge Peter J. Brancato in Brooklyn.

Albert Patrich, Chancellor Adolf Hitler's wartime sergeant, is at work gathering in the harvest from his Morrison County farm. He does not think Hitler wants to fight--he simply could not after going through the carnage of the World War.

Special committees of the Investment Bankers Association of America and the Investment Bankers Conference, Inc., appointed some time ago to work on the organization of the industry under the Maloney act, will hold their first joint meeting on next Tuesday morning at the Bankers Club.

Jumping in faultless fashion, without the semblance of a mistake, the veteran chestnut mare Goldamsel, owned by Mrs. Tilli Kaufmann of Great Neck, took first monev today in the $1,000 Guaranteed Jumper Sweepstakes, the richest event of the second day's program of the thirty-sixth annual Piping Rock Horse Show.

Miss Alma Isabel Guy, a leader in training and recreation work for the blind and for the last twentyfive years women's recreational director of the Lighthouse, operated at 111 East Fifty-ninth Street by the New York Association for the Blind, died yesterday morning at the home of her aunt, Mrs. Charles L. Guy, 145 East Seventy-fourth Street, after a year's illness. She was 68 years old.
After an ownership by the Preston family of over fifty years, seven dwelling properties in the Bushwick and neighboring sections of Brooklyn have been sold by Elon Preston to Saul Sussman.
The following table snows tne Iiiteen most active stocks traded in on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows fram- -h~ 1. ~hree days:

Wilfred Garretson, 66 years old, of Raritan Valley, today added the New Jersey seniors' golf title to the metropolitan Brown he won recently at Siwanoy. Garretson actually won his Jersey title yesterday when he added an 82 to a score of 79 made on Tuesday, but the entire field did not complete the thirty-six-hole competition until today.

On the strong right arm of Bill (Iron Man) Lee the fighting Cubs were carried to a crushing 10-to-1 victory over the Pirates today, a sweep of the three-game series and a game and a half lead in the National League pennant battle.
Police Commissioner Valentine issued a special order yesterday covering police details for Oct. 10 to 15, inclusive, to preserve order and to safeguard voters' rights during the registration period.
The news that an agreement had been reached in Munich caused an explosion of joy in Rome and everywhere in Italy.

Eustace Seligman of the law firm of Sullivan Cromwell, counsel for the Lehman protective committee for the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation's 5 per cent bonds and debenture stock, and B. A. Javits of Javits Javits,
The engagement of Miss Cecile Goldstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max Goldstein of 320 Central Park West, to Julian D. Mainzer of 755 West End Avenue, has been announced by her parents.

A banking group composed of the Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company, Eldredge Co., Inc.; Washburn Co., Inc., and Adams, McEntee Co., Inc., submitted yesterday the successful bid for a new issue of $3,000,000 of Buffalo refunding and relief bonds. The group won the award on its bid of 100.359 for 3.40s.

If information in the files of the Navy Department is accurate, and there is every reason to believe it is substantially correct, Germany would be able to send into action in the event of war a fleet of about fortyfive small submarines,

For the eleventh consecutive week awards in the current sevenday period show an improvement over the corresponding period of last year. The figures reported by the Engineering News-Record show a total of $49,229,000, a rise of 16 per cent over the 1937 volume of $42,494,000.

Prices of bonds on the New York Stock Exchange had yesterday their greatest advance in many months as cable advices reported dissipation of Europe's war clouds. Opening on a strong note, all classes of issues continued a spirited advance, which, together with Wednesday's sharp upturn, went a long way toward retracing losses of the last few weeks.

A Westchester County grand jury investigation of the primary petition of David S. Murden of Peekskill, who tried to run on Sept. 20 for the Republican nomination for County Executive, was completed today and at least one indictment was voted.
Resentment against New York City domination of the Republican State Convention was expressed today by leaders of nineteen up-State counties.

Miss Marian B. Cunningham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Cunningham of 73 West 105th Street, and John J. Dennehy, son of Mrs. Michael J., Dennehy of 101 West Eighty-seventh Street, and the late Mr. Dennehy, were married yesterday at the Church of the Ascension.

Following three weeks' suspension resulting from her refusal to play the feminine lead in "Law West of Tombstone," Anne Shirley goes back on the RKO payroll next week to do the romantic lead in "The Pure in Mind," which starts Tuesday with P. J. Wolfson directing.

During the week ended Sept. 28 member bank reserve balances increased $183,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases of $53,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks, $17,000,000 in Treasury cash and $5,000,000 in non-member deposits

The Football Giants were sent through an intensive drill yesterday at Innisfail Park in preparation for their encounter with the Pirates Monday night at the Polo Grounds. A new backfield combination was tried. Dale Burnett was the wingback, Tillie Manton, No. 2, with Kink Richards and Len Barnum the tailbacks.
General. Alfred Krauss, one of the Austrian strategists of the World War, died of a paralytic stroke today in near-by Geisern. He was 76 ears old.

Mrs. Sarah Hamilton Mellor, secretary of the Board of Trustees of West Chester State Teachers College, died last night while presiding at a meeting of the Parent Teacher Association of West Bradford Township. She was 65 years old. The wife of Dr. Howard Mellor, eye specialist, she lived at Sconnelltown, near here.

Proposals offering to the Hungarian minorities in Czechoslovakia the application of the nationality statute worked out by former Premier Milan Hodza were described as utterly unacceptable this morning in Hungarian official circles.

District Attorney Dewey took advantage of a faulty amplifier system in the convention hall tonight to deliver his first blow at Democratic opponents. As the prosecutor began to speak, static suddenly developed in the loudspeakers, drowning out his voice.

In an editorial this morning The Times of London urges Britain, regardless of the outcome of the present crisis, to prepare a plan for a system of "national service" to mobilize her war strength. It says in part:

The Rev. John James Burggraaff, pastor of First Reformed Church, died today at Hackensack Hospital after a short illness. He was 72 years old. Mr. Burggraaff headed the local church for nine years, succeeding his brother, the late Rev. N. J. Burggraaff.

Manhattan's football team, eager to atone for last week's defeat by St. Bonaventure, will clash with a powerful Niagara University eleven tonight at the Polo Grounds. A crowd of 10,000 is expected to witness the only all-college contest to be played under are lights this season in New York.

The Phillips family, self-styled Bronx "hillbillies," nosed out more classical ensembles to win first place in a city-wide contest for musical families, sponsored last night by the Department of Parks on the Central Park Mall.

FIRST RACE-Purse $800; maiden 2-yearolds; six furlongs. Love Day, 113 ....(Porter) 30.90 6.84 3.70 Elliptical, 108..(Yarberry) .... 2.68 2.34 Housework, 113 .....(Fels) ........ 2.82 Time--1:15 2-5. Cult King, Branch Water, West Acre and Flying Jack also ran.

Marked improvement in the trucking situation was reported here yesterday by local retail executives. While some congestion was noted at the docks, the movement of merchandise to the stores was active and Edward J. Murphy,

Tentative assessed valuations on all real estate in the city for tax purposes in the first half of 1939 will be ready for publication tomorrow, it was announced yesterday by William Stanley Miller, president the Tax Commission.

Despite all it has done for mankind generally, "steel has been able to do very little for the people whose savings make its very existence possible," Tom M. Girdler, chairman of the board of the Republic Steel Corportion, said tonight at a dinner of the Association of Iron and Steel Engineers, which has been in convention here since Tuesday.

The Dodgers were a winning team when they shook the dust of Ebbets Field from their spikes yesterday in their final home appearance until 1939, for they won the second game of the double-header from the Bees, 8-6, after dropping the opener, 2-1, before 2,822 paying patrons.

William Colquhoun of 182 North Broadway, Yonkers, former Public Works Commissioner and wellknown Yonkers business man, died yesterday at the Presbyterian Medi?al Center, Manhattan, after a short illness at the age of 53.

We knew they'd get around to it sooner or later--Myrna Loy and Clark Gable, we mean, to the newsreel business. Metro was just biding its time until its literary researchers had collected catastrophes enough to fill out a patchwork plot.

A plea for selfish-' enlightenment" among liquor retailers to avoid threatened extremes of a more rigid State control or a recurrence of the "chaos" of pre-prohibition days, when whisky of bad quality sold for 5 cents and "tied" saloons were the custom, was made yesterday by James J. (Gene) Tunney before the United Restaurant Liquor Dealers of Manhattan.

A pontifical month's mind mass of requiem for Cardinal Hayes will be celebrated in St. Patrick's Cathedral Tuesday morning at 10:30 o'clock. All the priests of the Archdiocese of New York have receiVed an announcement.

Jack Little, president Of Local No. 156, United Automobile Workers of America (C. I. O.), said today that employes of the General Motors Corporation Buick division would take a strike vote Saturday, protesting "the refusal of the management to bargain collectively" with a U. A. W. A. committee on seniority problems.

The recently organized Park Association of Westchester County announced today that it would hold a dinner at the Westchester Country Club in Harrison on Oct. 20 and ask outstanding State and local officials to discuss the park problems of the county.

Mrs. Katrina Van Wyck of this city, daughter of Mrs. Philip Van Rensselaer Van Wyck of Butler, N. J., and the late Mr. Van Wyck, was married at noon yesterday to Alexander Ogilvie Cushny, also of this city, in the bride's home at 31 East Seventy-ninth Street.

Purchases of securities in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Sept. 24 exceeded sales by 29,531 shares, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. The aggregate value of the securities purchased exceeded those sold by $1.506.932.

Stocks continued to advance and closed with gains of 1 to 4 points; turnover, 1,228,710 shares. All groups of bonds strong, for-, eign loans up 2 to 17 points, Czech issues leading; transactions, $7,282,600.

Philadelphia at New York-Mulcahy (10-19) vs. Schumacher (13-8). Pittsburgh at Cincinnati (2)--Lucas (6-3) and Tobin (14-10) vs. Derringer (20-14) and Moore (6-3). Chicago at St. Louis-Page (5-3) or Root (7-7) vs. Warneke (13-8). Other clubs not scheduled.
The Rev. Malcolm .E. Peabody of i Chestnut Hill, Pa., was consecrated 1 today as Bishop-Coadjutor of the Episcopal Diocese of Central New 1 York. Eighteen Episcopal Bishops took part.

Princeton, Tulane and Virginia Military Institute are newcomers to Columbia's football schedule for 1939, which was announced yesterday by Pierre Kolisch, undergraduate football manager. Yale again will oppose the Lions in their opening game in the Bowl on Oct 7.

The two weeks' strike of more than 15,000 truck drivers moved toward complete settlement yesterday as 10,000 men returned to work under agreements with individual employers based upon the compromise proposal of Mayor La Guardia of a forty-four hour week at the rate of forty-seven hours' pay.

In gloom caused by an approaching storm and on a sea of mud created when the storm finally struck, the Yankees took their farewell of the hapless Athletics for the 1938 season today at Shibe Park, winning one game and tying another in a twin bill before a ladies' day gathering of about 8,000.

Joe Chamaco and Willie Hoppe continued on even terms in their twelve-block three-cushion match as they split the seventh and eighth games yesterday at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy. Chamaco won in the afternoon, 50--45, in fifty-seven frames.
Charles Woram is with Jackson Brothers, Boesel Co. A special meeting of stockholders of the Symington-Gould Corporation scheduled for yesterday was postponed to Oct. 11, because of lack of a quorum.

Reviewing a behind-the-scenes controversy in the last Presbyterian General Assembly over faculty appointments at Princeton Theological Seminary, the Presbyterian Conservative Magazine, Christianity Today, in its current issue, out tomorrow, deplores occupancy of faculty chairs at the seminary by Dr. E. G. Homrighausen and Dr. Emil Brunner.

The body of Jacob Shulman, business agent of a Newark furriers' union, who disappeared Sept. 14 after a meeting at the Newark Labor Lyceum, was found in the underbrush off Plainfield Avenue in Berkeley Heights, near here, this afternoon.

The report of the American Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Aug. 31, issued yesterday, showed a net income of $11,826,814 after all operating expenses and charges. The net was equal after preferred dividend requirements to $2.16 each on 4,482,737

Senator Edward R. Burke, Democrat of Nebraska, returned on the United States liner Manhattan last night from a seven-week vacation devoted mainly to a study of employer-labor relations in European countries.

The National Labor Relations Board has certified the Leather Workers Union, No. 21,687, Essex and Hudson Counties, New Jersey, as the exclusive bargaining agency for employes of Blanchard Brothers and Lane, Inc., of Newark.
Henry A. Roemer, president of the Pittsburgh Steel Company, told stockholders today that steel wages "cannot be maintained unless there be compensating advances in the price of steel products."

Hopes of a favorable outcome of the talks in Munich caused today further sharp rises in the stock markets. The advances, however, were halted when optimism became tempered by a disposition to await events before opening fresh commitments.
George Kasmire Wendell of Scarsdale, former manager of the Fifty-seventh Street branch of the Chase National Bank of New York, died here yesterday in the Northern Westchester Hospital.

The Title Guarantee and Trust Company has sold the following properties in Brooklyn and Queens: to Benjamin Buchlater the dwelling and store at 88 Grafton Street, Brooklyn, on a plot 20 by 76.7, and to Domenico Macaluso and Louis J. Butta the vacant plot 40 by 85 known as 242 Lake Street.

John P. Frey, chief of the A. F. of L. metal trades department, disclosed tonight he had notified the Dies committee in Washington and four San Francisco newspapers that he had mistakenly charged William T. Bonsor of San Francisco with being a "Trotskyite Communist."

Old Westbury moved one step nearer a successful defense of its Waterbury Cup polo title today and did it impressively with a clear-cut 19-to-11 defeat of the Ramblers in the season's last high goal tournament.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Elizabeth Bergen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Edgar Bergen of 66 DeKoven Court, Brooklyn, to Harold Frederick Relyea, also of Brooklyn, son of Mrs. Frederick Harold Relyea of Rome, N. Y., and the late Mr. Relyea, took place here last night in St. James's Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street.

The spectacular recovery by the pound sterling in the foreign exchange market, which began on Wednesday with the announcement of the four-power conference in Munich, was pushed vigorously yesterday as financial markets here and abroad felt increased confidence that war would be averted. The pound got up to $4.78 1/2, or 18 1/2 cents above its low of the previous day, and finished near its top price at $4.78 1/8, up 4 1/2 cents net.

Asserting that the time turbans had come to remove the influence of the "corrupt" Tammany machine from the State government, District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey of New York County last night accepted the Republican nomination for Governor.

Samuel Kahn, president of the Market Street Railway Company, announced yesterday that the company's sinking fund payment of $75,000, due on June 30, and on which ninety days of grace were allowed, would not be paid today. The Sept. 30 payment of the same amount will also be passed, he said.

The determining factor in deflecting the current of events in the direction of peace in the present European crisis was the intervention of President Roosevelt at the last moment, Sir Willmott H. Lewis, Washington correspondent of The London Times, told members of the Bond Club of New York yesterday at a luncheon at the Bankers Club.

Scoring a 75 over the difficult upper course of the Baltusrol Golf Club, Miss Gail Wild of Baltusrol and Miss Josephine Merrill of Montclair today took a six-stroke lead in the first round of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association thirtysix-hole best-ball tournament. Miss Wild scored a 79, Miss Merrill an 86.

Only four of the amendments prep pared by the recent Constitutional Convention merit approval by the voters in November, and even these fall short of what should have been submitted, the City Affairs Committee declared in a statement made public yesterday.

From-the sun deck of the Italian liner Rex as it moved in bright sunlight up the bay toward the Statue of Liberty yesterday, the vibrant voice of Beniamino Gigli, voluble Italian tenor, broke out jubilantly in the strains of "Where Do You Work John, On the Delaware Lackawan," with an accompaniment of comic gestures.

Elmer F. Andrews, administrator of the wage-hour law, announced today the appointment of George A. McNulty of St. Louis as associate general counsel. Mr. McNulty is now assistant general counsel of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
A crowd gathered tonight in front of 10 Downing Street and shouted praise at the door behind which "Good Old Nev" hangs his hat and umbrella when he is home.

Mrs. Anna Tucker, one of the first graduates of the old Newark Normal School,. a former Newark teacher and a great-granddaughter of Captain John Clawson of Revolutionary War fame, died at her home here today. She was born in Newark ninety-six years ago.

Coach Lou Little applied the finishing touches to Columbia's football squad yesterday at Baker Field, culminating almost three weeks of rigorous training, and at 11:20 o'clock this morning he will lead his band of thirty-five players aboard a train for New Haven and the Yale Bowl.

At a special meeting of the Stouffer Corporation the stockholders amended articles of incorporation and the code of regulations and authorized a bank loan not to exceed, $250,000 to be used for expansion purposes.
After a long workout which wound up in the rain, Coach George Munger announced that three sophomores will start in Pennsylvania's opener Saturday against Lafayette.

The tentative 1938 platform as agreed to by the Committee on Rules and Regulations for submission to the Republican Convention follows: We, the Republican party, in convention assembled, pledge our support to this platform.

Fordham held its last hard workout on Fordham Field yesterday for the season's opener with Upsala at Randalls Island Stadium tomorrow After a long drill on the blocking and tackling dummies, the tentative first two teams staged a dummy scrimmage. A brisk signal drill concluded the intensive three-hour session.

Announcement was made yesterday by the New York Southern Society of the first award of a recently established one-year scholarship available to any young man or woman between 18 and 25 years old, who is a blood relative of a member or former member of the society.

Roy Weatherly drove over the wall the first ball pitched to him in the tenth inning today to give the Indians a 9-to-8 victory over the White Sox. Chicago made five hits for five runs in the eighth, but the Indians came back to score three times in their half of the eighth and one in the ninth to tie the score.
Mrs. Rodney Procter was hostess this afternoon at Orleton Farm, Stockbridge, for the annual meeting of the Lenox Garden Club. Mrs. Owen Johnson and Mrs. James Graham Parson assisted.

Mrs. Russell Holman of Innis Arden led a great turnout of 72 players to win low gross honors with 42, 42-84 in the Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association one-day tourney over the Apawamis Country Club course today.

Miss Katherine Cushman Fiske, daughter of Mrs. Haley Fiske of Scarsdale, N. Y., and the late Mr Fiske, former president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, was married to the Rev. Emmons Parkman Burrill of Pleasantville, N. Y., at -noon yesterday in St. Boniface Chapel of the Cathedral or St. John the Divine.

William Sittenham, New York real state man and art connoisseur, died here yesterday after a short illness at the age of 76. A native of Germany, Mr. Sittenham came to the United States when he was 17. He devoted considerable time to the restoration of old masters.

Trade between the United States and Brazil has increased sharply in the last month as a result of agreements on financial restrictions negotiated by Warren Lee Pierson, president of the United States Export-Import Bank, on his recent visit to South and Central America, it was disclosed yesterday.

Kansas City tonight won the final game of the post-season American Association play-off from St. Paul, 2 to 0, for the right to play the Bears in the little world series, starting in Newark, N. J.. Saturday afternoon.

Supreme Court Justice Thomas F. Noonan yesterday directed the State. Athletic Commission to submit its proceedings relating to the dethronement of John Henry Lewis as world light-heavyweight champion for a judicial review, declaring that the commission's action was reviewable in the courts.

Two young men charged with an ingenious scheme for obtaining money by forging checks were arraigned before Magistrate Sweeney in Queens Felony Court yesterday. One of them, Arthur Traumiller, 21 years old, of 78-29 Sixty-first Street, Glendale, Queens, was held in $7,000 bail on a forgery charge.
A damage suit for $1,000,000 against Dr. Allen R. Dafoe, physician for the Dionne quintuplets, and three other defendants, was dismissed today by Judge John P. Barnes in Federal District Court.

A year ago football scouts assigned to Soldiers Field were reporting back to their chiefs that the way for the boys to stop Harvard was to get Struck before they got fooled by the most befuddling legerdemain unveiled on an Eastern gridiron since Bert Bell's hiddenball hocus pocus was palmed off at Franklin Field.
Brig. Gen. Edward M. Markham announced yesterday that he would leave his $10,000 post as Commissioner of Public Works after serving seven months to take a position for a private firm in Chicago.

While the four statesmen talked in private at Munich today of Czechoslovakia, and perhaps Spain, Maxim M. Litvinoff of Russia. representing Europe's great outsider, talked in public to the League Assembly's political commission about the Spanish and Czechoslovak situations.

THE ANATOMY OF REVOLUTION, by Crane Brinton. (Norton, $3.) A comparative and sociological study of revolutions. CAUCUS-RACE, by Henrietta Sands Merrick. (Putnam, $3.) Observations on conditions in the Near and Far East.

The Manati Sugar Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday in a statement covering the period from Nov. 1, 1937, to June 30, 1938, a net profit of $95,607 after interest, depreciation, Cuban profits tax and man other deductions.

After forty-two years of service in the New York Public Library, of which thirty-eight years were spent in examining tens of thousands of documents, manuscripts, letters, pamphlets and books sent to the library from all over the world, Miss Maria V. Leavitt, head of the gift department, will retire today.
The Treasury deposited with the Federal Reserve Banks in the week ended on Wednesday $143,481,000 of gold certificates, on top of a similar deposit of $90,008,000 last week.

The Supreme Court is soon to try the issue whether three German medical practitioners should have their medical licenses endorsed in this State. This is the effect of a ruling of Justice-Sydney F. Foster. on an appeal from the regulation of the Board of Regents requiring an examination.

Twelve men and women tenants of the building at 1,291 Metcalf Avenue, in the East Bronx, picketed the State Building, 80 Center Street, yesterday afternoon, where Robert Moses, chairman of the Triborough Bridge Authority, has his offices.

The Ohio Power Company, a subsidiary of the American Gas and Electric Company, has filed an application under the Public Utility Holding Company Act for exemption from the requirement of filing a declaration in connection with the issue and sale of $55,000,000

As a result of large filings by gas and electric utility companies, registration statements becoming effective under the Securities Act of 1933 in August rose to $394,433;000, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

CERUTTI, ERNEST (Jan. 20, 1937). Gross assets. $412,302: net. $383.149. To Alfredo Cerutti, brother. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $280,471. Joseph A. Cox, attorney, 51 Chambers St. CHAPMAN, WILLIAM B. (Dec. 16. 1931). Gross assets. $41,928; net, $35,625. To Bruce W. Chapman, son, specific stock and residue. Chief assets. stocks and bonds, $39,402. Conboy. Hewitt, O'Brien Boardman, 39 Broadway, and Alex T. Wells. 41 E. 42d St.. attorneys.

Drubbing the Senators, 13 to 5, the Red Sox mathematically clinched second place in the American League today. This is the highest the club has finished since 1917 and 1918, when Ed Barrow, now business manager of the Yankees, piloted them home second and first respectively.
Headliner, bay colt sired by Peter Volo out of Lady Lux, was purchased tonight for $6,100 in the concluding session of the three-day yearling sale at the Walnut Hall farm of Donerail, near here.

Mr. and Mrs. Elliott Averett of Dixiedale Farm, this place, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janie Miller Averett, to Sherman Vail Allen, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Vail Allen of Fair Haven, Vt.

War is hideous, and peace is beautiful, and there are no two ways about that. Responsible statesmen who make any contribution to the preservation of peace are deserving of grateful thanks from their fellow-men, and that cannot be argued.

The board of directors of Hotel Barbizon, Inc., have voted an extra dividend of $4 per share on the common stock to holders of record on Sept. 27, 1938, according to Seligman, Lubetkin Co., Inc. This brings the dividends paid on the stock during the current fiscal year to $12 per share.
Horace Wilson, former Mayor of Wilmington and for many years president of the Wilson Line, died in Roosevelt Hospital here yesterday after an abdominal operation. He was 76 years old.

Bank clearings of the principal cities throughout the country dedined 11.8 per cent in the week ended on Wednesday to $4,606,664,000 from $5,222,371,000 in the corresponding period last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. In a similar comparison a week earlier the loss was only 7.9 per cent.
President Roosevelt has approved today a -definite plan for the naming of the types of naval ships, continuing some past usages and confirming some current and new practices.

A lighted cigarette tossed into the gutter on the west side of Eighth Avenue where gasoline had trickled from a damaged automobile caused a sheet of flame to shoot up suddenly along the entire block between Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets at about 1 o'clock this morning, seriously burning a woman who was walking near the curb.

Dr. Frank R. Oastler, surgeon and nationally known naturalist who died Aug. 2, 1936, left a net estate of $1,547,054 practically all of which eventually will go to Yale University's Forestry Department to be used for the conservation of wild life, both birds and mammals," according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday.

Denouncing the Democratic Administrations in Albany and Washington, the Republican State convention here today adopted a platform praising the work of the Republican-controlled State Constitutional Convention and pledging a vigorous battle for the gubernatorial candidate, District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, on the political underworld issue.

Tommy Bridges won his thirteenth game of the season when the Tigers defeated the Browns, 6 to 2, today in their final home appearance. Detroit raked Buck Newsom, who went the route for St. Louis, for eleven hits, but Hank Greenberg, aiming for Babe Ruth's record of 60 home runs, failed to add to his total of 58.
Princeton began tapering off today in preparation for the Williams game, the squad running through a series of light but spirited offense and defense drills on running, passing and kicking.

The war for which Europe had been feverishly preparing was averted early this morning when the leading statesmen of Britain, France, Germany and Italy, meeting in Munich, reached an agreement to allow Reich troops to occupy predominantly German portions of Czechoslovakia's Sudetanland progressively over a ten-day period beginning tomorrow.

The resignation of I. A. Hirschmann as vice president of SaksFifth Avenue, to take effect Oct. 15, was announced here yesterday. Mr. Hirschmann joined the Fifth Avenue store in March, 1934, with his duties comprising all sales promotion and the merchandising of a part of the store.
One passage in President Butler's speech at the Columbia University opening exercises must have made some of his own progressive Teachers College professors look straight ahead of them.

After three postponements, the seventy members' of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo embarked yesterday for this country from London on the Georgic, according to an announcement by S. Hurok, general manager.

Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Alfred Wye of Asbury Park, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Inskip Wye of this city, to Henry Andrew McCashin, also of New York, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Henry McCashin of Boston.

With reports of clearing skies in Europe, shipping on the North Atlantic started on the way back to normalcy late last night, although another large transatlantic liner had been withdrawn from service for what may be war duty.

Newspapers and radio advertising will be used extensively to promote National Retail Grocers Week, which starts on Oct. 10, according to the National Association of Retail Grocers, which is sponsoring the event.

Hit on the left temple by a pitched ball while playing baseball last Sunday near his home in Yorktown Heights, Nicholas Mongero, 21 years old, died here today in the Northern 'Westchester Hospital of a brain embolism.
Battles between opposing counsel consumed most of the time yesterday at a hearing by the Securities and Exchange Commission on the affairs of the Interstate Hosiery Mills, Inc.

As a precautionary measure, all leave outside India for members of the armed forces has been temporarily stopped and a forty-eight-hour recall warning has been issued to men who are on leave in India.
Pleas for peace were offered and programs for collective action against Nazi Germany were suggested by speakers yesterday at a "Save Czechoslovakia" rally in the Great Hall of the City College.

Invitations have been sent out for the marriage of Miss Clara Gertrude Koch, daughter of Mrs. Henry John Koch of New York and the late Mr. Koch, to John Sherrerd Welles, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Bessal Welles of Plainfield, N. J., on Oct. 15 in Fordham Lutheran Church. The Rev. Frederick H.

Following are some of the newspaper headlines on the European situation appearing in German papers today: 12-Uhr Blatt: "Amok-running Terror of Praguers Shrieks to Heaven-Is That Benes's Answer to the Meeting of Four Statesmen in Munich?"
The Oxford University Press will publish in October a group of four maps in full color, size 17 by 22 inches, three of Czechoslovakia, and one of Europe.
An official statement on the Polish position, in respect to the Teschen area in Czechoslovakia, was issued on Tuesday by the Polish Information Service in Washington, D. C. It said, in part:
The text of the Czechoslovak concessions and willingness to submit the Sudeten issue to arbitration submitted before the decision at Munich, as made public here, follows:

Away from the stage for eight years, Alison Skipworth makes her return tonight in "30 Days Hath September" at the Hudson Theatre. A farce about the legacy brokerage business, the play is by Irving Gaumont and Jack Sobell and comes to town under the auspices of Kirby Grant, Inc.
Various methods of achieving some more orderly and more uniform system of realty taxation in this country are being studied by several national trade organizations and governmental agencies.

Hanson Edward Ely Jr., son of Major Gen. Hanson E. Ely of Washington, World War figure and former commandant of the Army War College and the Second Corps Area, died today in Orange Memorial Hospital after a five-week illness. Mr. Ely, who was 42 years old, lived in Orange.

Every one of the more than 1,000,000 Catholics in the Archdiocese of New York was called upon yesterday by the Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahue, Auxiliary Bishop and Administrator of the Archdiocese, to receive holy communion Monday and pray for peace.

Inventories of the wholesale dry goods group were down 7.9 per cent at the end of June, as compared with the previous six-month period, according to the mid-year inventory survey figures released yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

For one important reason it is a matter of regret that Thomas E. Dewey has accepted the nomination for Governor which the State convention of his party so enthusiastically offered him. He was elected only last November to a four-year term as District Attorney of New York County.

The City Bank Farmers Trust Company, as trustee, today will notify holders of the Mead Corporation first mortgage 6 per cent bonds, Series A. due May 1, 1945, that $235,000 of the bonds have been drawn for redemption on Nov. 1 at 102.

Miss Frances Bland Tucker, daughter of Mrs. William Payton Tucker of St. Joseph, Mo., and the late Dr. Tucker, was married to Robert Selby Armitage of London, England, yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration by the Rev, B. A. E. MacLaughlin.

The long-drawn-out Farrier case, involving diamonds unofficially valued at $50,000 and said to have been a part of the Russian crown jewels, came to an end in Chancery Court here today when Vice Chancellor Maja Leon Berry handed down a final decree in the action and directed Mrs. Josephine M. Farrier to return the gems

John C. Metcalfe, investigator for the special House committee inquiring into un-American activities, testified at the committee's hearing today that in 1937 Fritz Kuhn, leader of the German-American Bund, informed him that he had power over the German consular set-up in this country.

More than 500 persons attended a meeting in the New York University School of Education at Washington Square last night to pay tribute to the memory of Dr. James Weldon Johnson, Negro poet and educator, who was killed in an automobile accident last June.

The revised status of transactions between husband and wife, the evaluation of partnership assets for tax purposes, writing off of worthless securities and other methods of minimizing taxes under the 1938 Revenue Act were discussed last night by Mark' Eisner, former United States Collector of Internal Revenue, before the current law section of the Practicing Law Institute, meeting in the Engineering Societies Building.

Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., brokers, announce that they have arranged for the New York Trust St Company, as trustee, a 3 per cent first mortgage loan on the fifteen, fourteen and eight story apartment buildings at 381 and 383 Park Avenue and 105 East Fifty-third Street.

Thomas H. Hunt of Mount Vernon, manager of the new business department of the Chemical National Bank of New York, died of a heart attack on Wednesday after crossing the street near his office. He was 63 years old and had been with the bank for the last twenty years....

Three hundred and forty-four members of the three upper classes at Smith College who achieved averages of at least B for the year 1937-38 were announced by Dean Marjorie Hope Nicolson at the full college assembly this morning.

Bids for approximately $100,000,000 of Treasury bills were invited tonight by Secretary Morgenthau. The weekly offering of ninety-one-day bills will be made on the usual discount basis and in the customary denominations.

Harry. T. Headley, who had been in his lifetime a farmer, carpenter, seaman, lifeguard and for eight years Atlantic City's Street Commissioner - ""Mayor of the Boardwalk"-died in his home today after suffering from a heart ailment since last May. He was 68 years old.

A central clearing house at 85 the John Street for handling loss claims resulting from last week's hurricane and floods was set up yesterday by the National Board of Fire Underwriters and the Eastern Loss Executives Conference.

John J. Bergen, investment banker, has leased a furnished apartment of thirteen rooms and six baths in 770 Park Avenue through Douglas L. Elliman Co. The lease was one of many reported yesterday by brokers and renting agents.

The New York Curb Exchange will remove from unlisted trading on Oct. 14 certificates of deposit for Imperial Russian Government 6 1/2 per cent three-year credit bonds due on June 18, 1919, and five-year 5 1/2 per cent bonds due on Dec. 1, 1921.
Ernest Schelling, pianist, composer and conductor of the Young People's Concerts of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society has been engaged for four appearances in the Netherlands next month.
Following are the texts of the addresses of Senator Wagner and Postmaster General Farley before the Democratic State Convention:
The Munich conference is viewed here with complete disapproval as certain to result in the sacrifice of Czechoslovakia and serious impairment of France's strength.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES'S editorial "More Flexibility Needed" expresses conviction that the military service has not yet rid itself of obsolete methods of procedure and organization.
William H. Vanderbilt, 36, former State Senator and son of Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, was named candidate for Governor today by the. Republican State Convention.

A 21-year-old Negro, identified by two public school teachers and a parochial school pupil as the perpetrator of three daylight robberies in Brooklyn school rooms, was arrested last night on a robbery charge.

Mayor La Guardia announced. yesterday his intention to support Senator Wagner for re-election. In a telegram to City Treasurer Almerindo Portfolio, who is a delegate to the Republican convention at Saratoga Springs, the Mayor said:
After an absence of nearly three months, pickets representing two striking C. I. O. unions reappeared yesterday before twelve stores of the Busch Jewelry Company and two affiliated companies.
The general level of wholesale prices continued upward in the week ended on Sept. 24, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

Albert Santo, 37 years old, owner of the Cross Bay Speedway at Cross Bay Boulevard and Sunrise Highway, Queens, where a boy was killed during the races Wednesday night, pleaded not guilty to a charge of criminal negligence in Queens Felony Court yesterday
As a revelation of the inside story of the events of the past two weeks, Mr. Chamberlain's speech in the House of Commons must be rated one of the most important documents in modern history.

In denying today an application by three Western railroads to acquire a trucking company as the first step in the development of a $6,000,000 rail-truck transportation 'system, the Interstate Commerce Commission expressed hostility to joint railroad-trucking activities that might be destructive of competition.

An Ontario foursome won the Canadian women's interprovincial team match and the Royal Canadian Golf Association shield today with an aggregate gross score of 668, two strokes better than Quebec, the defending champions.

A move to bar "unwholesome and illegal" amusements at the New York World's Fair was made yesterday by the National Council of Women at the annual meeting of the council's board in the Women's City Club, International Building, Radio City.
Chicago packers withdrew offerings of calfskins yesterday after selling moderate amounts of September take-off at 18 1/2 cents, an advance of 1/2 cent from last selling prices.

Great Britain entered the World War in 1914 because she feared German commercial expansion on world markets and hoped to destroy it for all time, but neither she nor any other nation need fear German competition in the future, says an article entitled "Rivalry in World Trade Is no Longer Ground for War"
Millions of Germans early today hailed the joyful words "there will be no war." They held their breath as news from Munich was broadcast long past midnight.

A shortage of magistrates Is causing hardship to lawyers, litigants and policemen, it was asserted yesterday by former Magistrate Leo Healy, who now is president of the Criminal Bar Association of Kings County.
Domestic and foreign buying developed yesterday on the Cotton Exchange here as Munich advices pointed to progress toward an agreement on the Czechoslovak Problem.
Let no man say that too high a price has been paid for peace in Europe until he has searched his soul and found himself willing to risk in war the lives of those who are nearest and dearest to him.

Henry J. Burke, former chief of the Peekskill Police Department and Chief of Police at'Indian Point Park in recent years, died at his home here today after an illness of several months. His age was 67. He was appointed a patrolman in 1901 and was made chief in 1918; He retired on a pension in 1931.

Ostensibly because of a disagreement over a compromise plan for the creation of a Central China Organ China Affairs Board], Foreign Minister General Kazushige Ugaki today tendered his resignation. Thereafter he departed to his country villa complaining of stomach trouble.

Characterized as a man of courage and integrity, known to the people of the State not by his promises but by his performances, District Attorney Dewey was nominated today by the Republican State Convention as the candidate for Governor.

Stocks of merchandise on hand in department stores in this district, at retail valuation, were 13 per cent lower at the end of August than at the same time a year ago, and apparel store stocks declined 10 per cent, according to the monthly review of business and credit conditions issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Three major tax reforms are advisable in this country, Roswell Magill, for mer Under-Secretary of the Treasury, said today to delegates of the American Institute of Accounting at their meeting here.

In a moving appeal for peace, in the course of which he repeatedly broke down and sobbed Pope Pius XI begged God to take his life if by this means the world could be spared the slaughter and ruin of war.
Activity on national securities exchanges fell sharply in August, the vacation period, although the dollar volume was $1,105,364,617, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

An amended plan for reorganization of the Van Sweringen Company, real estate division of the financial structure of the late Van Sweringen brothers, under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Law has been filed with and is being considered by William B. Woods, special master, it became known today.

The Civilian Conservation Corps announced today that State directors had been ordered to select 49,497 men between Oct. 1 and Oct. 20 to fill vacancies. Robert Fechner, director, said that this number was about 75 per cent of the total required to bring the CCC to its maximum strength of 300,000.

Benjamin V. Cohen, one of the two young lawyers said to wield more influence with President Roosevelt than any other Americans, returned from. Europe on the liner Manhattan last night surrounded by a system of secrecy and protection more elaborate than any remembered in the port by customs men and others who have met ships for the last generation.

Josef Cristea, Rumanian tenor, and Fernando Guarneri, Italian baritone, gave a joint recital last night at Town Hall. Dorothy Barton, a youthful new soprano from Waco, Texas, assisted. Mr. Cristea, who made his American debut

The people of Charleston, digging out of the wreckage of a windstorm which took twenty-nine lives and injured more than 200 other persons, were cheered tonight by the announcement that the Federal Government would help with $500,000 to restore damaged public buildings in this historic city.

The wedding of Miss Elizabeth Gamwell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Holland Gamwell of Pittsfield, to Dr. Theodore Winslow Jones of this city, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. William Northey Jones of Newtown, Conn., took place this noon in St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, with the Rev. Dr. Jones officiating.

With long-distance trucking in and out of this city still tied up yesterday by the teamsters' strike, intracity trucking returned to normal under the compromise plan suggested by Mayor La Guardia. Nearly 13,000 of the 15,000 strikers were reported back at work.
Aggressive Nationalist members of Northern Ireland's Parliament in a statement today demanded reunion between Ireland [Eire, the former Free State] and Northern Ireland.

A permit was granted yesterday by the New York City police for the "Save Czechoslovakia Zero Hour Parade," scheduled for noon today. Some 1,200 policemen have been assigned to stations along the route, with the starting point at Twenty-fourth Street and Madison Square Park.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain had a hero's welcome on this reniy Autumn evening when 'he came back to London, bringing the four-power agreement and the Anglo-German declaration reaffirming "the desire of our two peoples never to go -to war with one another again."

Plans for reorganization of the New York Curb Exchange will come under review of the Securities and Exchange Commission for the first time today, when a group from the Exchange headed by Fred C. Moffatt, president, will consult with William 0. Douglas,

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The old adage, "An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure," applies not only to the field of medicine but also to the international political and economic set-up. Unfortunately, the present National Administration, and perhaps a majority of the past ones, have failed to realize this.
The White Sox pounded out a 7-to-5 victory, then were held to a 3-3 tie by the Browns today as darkness halted the second game in the eighth inning.

Mr. and Mrs. Leroy A. Van Bomel gave a dinner in the Persian Room of the Plaza last night for Miss Marie-Louise Fox and Howard F. Van Bomel, who will be married here on Tuesday in the Church of the Heavenly Rest.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull voiced the "universal sense of relief" today over the peace settlement in Europe while calling for redoubled efforts to maintain "principles of order under law, resting on a sound economic foundation."
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construction of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association,. Inc.:

The marriage of Miss Margaret Chambliss Cooley, daughter of Mrs. George Edwin Hodge and the late Gifford W. Cooley, to John L. Dupree of Bridgeport, Conn., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John L. Dupree of Brownsville, Tenn., took place here this evening at the home of the bride's mother.

The report of the Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore for the first eight months of this year, issued yesterday, shows a net income, after all expenses and charges, of $3,728,277. This was equal, after

It is interesting that the conversations today on reorganization of the New York Curb Exchange are the first that officials of the Securities and Exchange Commission have held with leaders of the Curb. There were hints, of course.

The stock markets were swamped today with buying orders following the Munich agreement. Prices soared rapidly in one of the most exciting days in years. After a pause for profittaking, the rise was resumed and the markets closed at the day's best levels.

Good wishes for her continued success in retailing were expressed by more than 500 guests at the party held by Mrs. Hortense M. Odlum last evening to mark her fourth anniversary as president of Bonwit Teller Co. The guests included store executives and representatives of the publishing field.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Oatman, daughter of Mrs. Alva Oatman of 103 East Seventy-fifth Street and the late Mr. Oatman, to K. Randolph Dunnell of Brooklyn, took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church. The ceremony was

Prime Minister Chamberlain and Chancellor Hitler, at a final conference at Munich yesterday, agreed that: "We regard the agreement signed last night and the Anglo-German naval agreement as symbolic of the desire of our two peoples never to go to war with, one another again." Terms imposed
The best selling piece of literature, fiction or non-fiction, in California today' is a snappy little pocket-size booklet entitled "Ham and Eggs for Californians."

With an investigator of the special House committee on un-American activities continuing his testimony today on what he described as links between the German-American Bund and the Nazi government, Dr. Hans Heinrich Dieckhoff, the German Ambassador, called at the State Department to deny such connections.
The Standard Dredging Company of New York today prepared to start extensive harbor improvements costing $870,000, with the arrival of the dredge New Orleans.

The trucking strike and the religious holiday served to hold down retail sales figures this week and a decline of about 8 per cent under 1937 was estimated for local department stores. While a loss of about

Three world's harness race records were broken today in the closing program of the Grand Circuit meeting here. Rosalind established a new mark of 1:57 for trotting mares; Her Ladyship set up a new standard of 1:56 3/4 for pacing mares and Chief Counsel cracked the 3-year-old pacing record with a 1:57 3/4 performance. All marks were made in tests against time.

Mrs. Virginia Odor Rickey, wife of Harry Norris Rickey, former editor of The Cleveland Press and of The Washington Daily News, and former editor in chief of the Scripps newspapers, died last night at the Washington Sanitarium after a long illness. She was 66 years old.

Despite the continued delay in the appearance of any corporate financing, the volume of new bond offerings this week rose to a total of $12,009,680 due to the increased activity in the tax-exempt field. This compares with only $1,173,479 in new issues placed last week, all of which were tax-exempt loans, and with a total of $17,287,000 in new bonds offered during this week last year.

Bondholders of the Central Railroad of New Jersey will receive within a month or so a plan for reducing the company's fixed interest charges, it was disclosed today. Edward W. Scheer, president, revealed that such a proposal was under consideration when he was questioned about interest payments on the 4 per cent and 5 per cent general mortgage bonds on Jan. 1 next. He said, however, that he
Miss Rae Emile Parish and Philip Bondy, whose engagement was announced in July, were married here at noon today in St. Matthew's Church by the Rev. Arthur Ketchum.
Mrs. Sarah Truslow Dickinson, an initiator of the Young Women's Christian Association in Brooklyn, died yesterday in her home at 438 West 116th Street after a short illness. She was 75 years old.

Cables have been received here announcing the marria? yesterday in Ancon, Canal Zone, of the marriage of Miss Dorothy Anne Laist, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Laist of 1,125 Fifth Avenue, this city, and of Georgetown Lake, Mont., to Keith Ferguson Finlay of Chuquicamata, Chile.

Football today finds the stream of the new season filled from bank to bank, with the joining in of every college of note that plays the game. When the last whistle is blown this evening all hands will have had a taste of gunfire.

Trading was mostly fair to good in local markets yesterday. Grasser steer hinds and ribs lower, others steady. The lamb market was strong to slightly higher, bull lower; other classes traefer meat mostly unchanged. Kosher veal and calf opening higher, lamb barely steady to lower, beef steady with Thursday's late decline. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

A six-year-old female elephant, the gift of Abraham Straus, arrived from Europe yesterday and was placed in the Prospect Park elephant house during the afternoon to take the place of Hilda, who was destroyed last month after her mate, Bill, had butted her into a twenty-five-foot dry moat.

Donald Budge advanced in the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament today, but his rival, Gene Mako, was beaten in an upset. Budget defeated Ronald Lubin of Los Angeles, 6-3, 1-6, 6-3, to enter the semi-finals, and will meet Adrian Quist of Australia, who eliminated Owen Anderson, University of California at Los Angeles player, 6-3, 7-5. -5.

" This is glorious news," was how one Cabinet Minister summed up public reaction in South Africa today to the peace news from Munich. It is generally believed that there will now be a sharp stimulus in the Union's defense program.

New securities offered to the public here in September were in cornparatively small volume. Bond flostations were the smallest for any period since last May, but larger than September last year, while stock flotations, although the largest in four months, were the smallest for any September since 1935.

Following is the ticket nominated by the Democratic State Convention today: For Governor-Herbert H. Lehman of New York. For Senator, Long Term-Robert F. Wagner of New York. For Senator, Short Term-James M. Mead of Erie.

The Bushwick Cooperative Building and Loan Association, 612 Grand Street, Brooklyn, received permission from the State Banking Department today to change its name to the Bushwick Savings and Loan Association.
The term 'existing installations" in Article II of the four-power Munich accord when taken in the sense of its German translation shows how completely Sudetenland is to be handed over to Germany.

Any new court building to house the City Court and parts of the Municipal Courts should be situated on the west side of Foley Square rather than on the sites of the Tombs and Criminal Courts, the City Hall Park Association declared in a statement yesterday.

Forty-nine conventions and shows, with an attendance of about 35,000 persons from out-oftown, will be held in the city this month, C. N. Nichols, executive director of the convention and visitors' bureau of the Merchants Association of New York, announced yesterday. In number.

A long-time study of "the forces that have produced normal young men," a new type of medical research, was started today at Harvard University under the direction of Dr. Arlie V. Bock, head of the Hygiene Department.

Edmund Morton Smedberg, a descendant of General Jacob Morton. commander of the New York City militiamen during the War of 1812, died here yesterday in the Doctors Sanitarium of a heart ailment at the age of 78.
Like the good soldiers they are and were at West Point, Earl Blaik and Harry Ellinger know how to fight back in the face of adversity.

" The Human Needs of New York" will be the subject of the address to be delivered by Mayor La Guardia at a Protestant Church Women's Conference on the topic "The City" on Tuesday in the Christ Methodist Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

Metal furniture gradually is creeping up on wood and absorbing a larger portion of the furniture buyer's dollar, Frank E. Seidman of Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants, told the tenth annual convention of the National Association of Furniture Manufacturers here today.
Brig. Gen. William Ennis, U. S. A. retired, who was the oldest living graduate of the United States Military Academy at West Point, died at his home here this afternoon in his ninety-eighth year.

Loadings of revenue freight' for the week ended on Sept. 24 totaled 675,553 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 15,411 cars, or 2.3 per cent, more than for the preceding week; 161,332 cars, or 19.3 per cent less than for the corresponding week last year, and 131,517 cars, or 16.3 per cent, less than during the corresponding week two years ago.

In what is regarded as one of the most importance technique changes ever made by the agency, N. W. Ayer Son, Inc., Philadelphia, has rearranged its space-buying practices so that one man will have charge of each medium, it was learned here yesterday. Previously,
William J. Latta, a Former general agent for the Pennsylvania Railroad, died last night at his home in Chestnut Hill at the age of 86.

AMHERST VS. SPRINGFIELD-On advice from Cincinnati, the world series is going to Chicago. It's better to stay out of Pittsburgh, anyway. That's the town where they invite a stranger to drop around for a friendly chatter on football and he finds himself in a pitched battle over Modern Art! One slight aquamarine vote for Amherst.

Ronald Colman, English screen actor, and Benita Hume, also English and of the movies, were married at San Ysidro Ranch near here tonight by a judge. Their attendants were Heather Thatcher, actress, and Colonel Tim McCoy, Western picture actor.

T. R. Crumley, president of the Jersey Central Power and Light Company, told a Federal Power Commission examiner today the concern was not under commission jurisdiction in so far as transmission of power was concerned.

To combat rising shipping rates on wheat, the Canadian Board of Grain Commissioners placed today a maximum rate of 7 cents a bushel on wheat shipped from Fort William or Port Arthur to ports on the St. Lawrence.

Mrs. Mary Schermerhorn Oliver, widow of Dr. Charles A. Oliver of Philadelphia, died yesterday at the home of relatives here. She was a member of the Daughters of the American Revolution, Margaret Yardley Club of New Jersey, Garden Club of East Orange, Woman's Club of Orange and the Nantucket Yacht Club. Surviving are
All seats for the Berkshire Symphonic Festival next Summer at Tanglewood. Mass., will be reserved with no increase in price, it was announced yesterday.

The Cubs and the Cardinals further complicated the National League's flag race by battling to a 7-7 tie at Sportsman's Park today and leaving themselves a double-header to play tomorrow, next to the last day of the season.

Miss Virginia Carolyn Koons, daughter of Mrs. John Van Nostrand Dorr of 1,040 Park Avenue and Westport, Conn., and of Thomas A. Koons of this city, was married to William O'Brien Ashe Jr. of Hartford, Conn., last evening in the rectory of St. George's Church at 209 East Sixteenth Street.

In every church tomorrow sermons will be preached on the European crisis and prayers of thanksgiving will be said that as an outcome of the four-power conference in Munich, Germany, the war danger has waned.

Mrs. May Neff Fitzgerald Major, who with her first husband, Thomas M. Fitzgerald, founded the FitzgeraldMercy Hospital in Darby, a suburb, died last night at- her home in Lansdowne. Her age was 78. Mr.

For three years Governor Lehman has been recommending the establishment of mortgage banks in his annual message. A measure to authorize them passed the State Senate early this year by a vote of 33 to 4, but was lost in the Assembly. Last year a similar

Secretary Morgenthau, commenting on the fall in sterling exchange during the recent acute stage of the war crisis, remarks that the machinery of the tripartite agreement had worked extremely well. By this he undoubtedly meant that the agreement by England, France and the United States

Russ Bauers, lumberjack from North Wisconsin, rescued his Pirate mates from elimination in the National League pennant race today with a four-hit pitching performance that gave Pittsburgh a split in a doubleheader with the Reds.

Henri Charpentier, internationally famous French chef, closed his restaurant, The Original Henri's, on Scranton Avenue here, on Wednesday, and departed for Chicago seeking another business connection, according to his son, Pierre, who lives here.

A client of Walter C. Burbank, the vice president of a New York trust company, has purchased from the East River Savings Bank the two-story colonial residence at 98 Morris Lane South, New Rochelle, Westchester, for occupancy.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks , 1,157,000bales, against 1,167,000 a week ago, 1,164,000 two weeks ago, 1,157,000 three weeks ago and 684,000 a year ago, of which American 599,000, against 610,000 a week ago, 623,000 two weeks ago, 636,000 three weeks ago and 216,000 a year ago.

The international executive board of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, yesterday directed the officers and executive board of New York Local 100 to begin, not later than Nov. 1, negotiations for renewal of all existing agreements with rapid transit, street railway and bus lines.

Dividends declared by companies in September were the smallest for that month in four years. Payments of $216,290,830 were authorized by 1,167 corporations, compared with $244,641,824 by 765 concerns in the preceding month; $363,170,461 by 1,311 in September, 1937, and $194,434,623 by 1,008 companies in September, 1934.
Building plans submitted yesterday included several housing projects for sites in Queens. Architects also filed for a few homes in Brooklyn.

A slender 72-year-old jewel dealer battled a heavy-set armed thug yesterday morning and frustrated a hold-up aimed at several thousands of dollars' worth of jewels in the vault of the firm of H. Herman Son, 562 Fifth Avenue, which is on the fourth floor of a twelve-story building at the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-sixth Street.

Nassau County will offer today the properties in the second session of the last auction sales by the Board of Supervisors to dispose of realty acquired by the county through foreclosure of tax liens. The sale will be held at 2 P. M. in the Nassau County Police Auditorium in Mineola. L. I.

Department store sales during the week ended Sept. 24 were 6 per cent lower than for the same week last year and for the four weeks ended Sept. 24 were 7 per cent lower than for the same period in 1937, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. today.
Because of the need for roadway repairs the upper deck of the Queensboro Bridge will be closed to traffic from Monday until some time in December, the Department of Public Works announced yesterday.
W. Vincent, a civil servant of Winnipeg who is in London on holiday with his wife, was probably the most thrilled person among the huge crowd that cheered Mrs. Neville Chamberlain to the echo today.

The WPA Federal Theatre is setting up the storm signals at Maxine Elliott's Theatre, where the much postponed "Big Blow," dramatized by Theodore Pratt from his own novel, arrives tonight with wind and sound effects. The play,

Speculators who bought wheat futures recently on war talk liquidated their holdings today and sent the market into new low ground for the current reaction. The selling, however, was well absorbed, persistent buying developing under 64 cents a bushel for the December and 65 cents for the May future.

Member banks of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York were notified yesterday by Owen D. Young, chairman of the board of the Reserve Bank, that an election would be held next month to choose successors to two directors whose terms will expire on Dec. 31.
Acting Captain Maurice Gould ran back a punt 43 yards for a firstperiod touchdown today as Andover opened its season with a 13-0 victory over the Bowdoin jayvees.

A special meeting of shareholders of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation has been called for Nov. 22 to approve an agreement between the I. T. T. and the bondholders' committees of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation. The agreement provides

Jules Ascheim founder, president, treasurer and a director of the Colt-Cromwell Company, Inc., manufacturers of riding boots and military leather goods, died on Thursday in his apartment in the Hotel Warwick, 65 West Fiftyfourth Street, after a short illness. Company headquarters are at 1,239 Broadway and its plant is in Stoughton, Mass. Mr. Ascheim was 70 years old.
The National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers yesterday recommended to its members that they include a protective clause on wages and hours on all orders and contracts.

Miss Dorothy Most, daughter of Mr. -and Mrs. Fred H. Most of Houston, Texas, was married in the First Presbyterian Church here today to Harry F. Schroeder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chris Schroeder of this place. The ceremony was
Today drafting by the Democratic State Convention of Governor Herbert H. Lehman for renomination was a developrment in a situation which from the beginning had been charged with drama.

Appealing to business men to lay aside all preconceived notions and prejudices regarding the program of the Temporary National Economic Committee, Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney of Wyoming, chairman of the committee, today issued a vigorous denial that his group intends to engage in a "trustbusting" escapade or to seek out victims for punitive action.

With the woodcock season opening today in Northern New York and the waterfowl season opening in Maine, New Hampshire, Vermont, Michigan, Minnesota, South Dakota, North Dakota and Wisconsin, the shooting season definitely is under way.

Senators from farm States, unsuccessful today in their efforts to see the President about higher government loans on wheat and cotton, scheduled a- conference tomorrow with Department of Agriculture officials.

With good fields assured for all of the five events on the program, the Adjacent Hunts Racing Association is set for one of its best meetings today at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club at Rye, N. Y. Some of the outstanding jumpers in the East have been named for the events and a crowd of 10,000 is expected to see the racing.

Back at his desk yesterday morning, after his trip to Saratoga Springs to accept the Republican nomination for Governor, District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey saw in the Democratic renomination of Governor Lehman evidence of desperation on the part of that party's "bosses."

Imports of gold received at the Port of New York in September totaled $303,451,000, the largest for any month since February, 1934. These figures are based on the daily reports of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York covering shipments entering directly into the gold stocks and do not include official stabilization fund shipments.

To mark the tenth year of scheduled commercial air transportation, the nation's twenty-one airlines today will begin the celebration of National Air Travel Week, lasting until Oct. 9. Special educational and display flights will be made from major airports throughout the United States.

The auction of the estate of William Gillette at Hadlyme, which was to have been held tomorrow, has been postponed until Oct. 15. This was learned here from Carlos S. Holcomb, of the First National Bank of Hartford, executors of the will of the actor, who died April 29, 1937. Mr. Holcomb has received

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

The Baylor Bears, featuring the brilliant passing of Billy Patterson, defeated Oklahoma A. and M., 20 to 6, before a crowd of 4,000 tonight. Three times, once in the second and twice in the final period, passes of 20 yards or more from Patterson put Baylor in scoring positions.

The French liner Paris, arriving today from Havre, Southampton and Cobh, has among her passengers Serge Lifar, Miss Mildred Dilling, Andre Marchal, George Bonesco, Francois Chiarsini, Mr. and Mrs. Jules V. Behar, Samuel Bloch, Auguste Mopper, G. Jackson, Burton Holmes, Miss Lucy Littel and Charles Loridans.

Loadings of freight on the railroads in the last three months of this year will be about 3.6 percent below the total for the same period last year, according to estimates by the thirteen Shippers Advisory Boards.

A Democratic pledge of "steadfast loyalty and devotion" to President Roosevelt, Republican denunciation of his administration and of Mayor Frank Hague's alleged suppression of civil liberties in Jersey City, and an expression by both parties of opposition to new State taxes are the outstanding planks in tentative platforms of both parties made public here today.

Premier Benito Mussolini was hailed today throughout Italy as the man who gave to the world the gift of peace. He was received with triumphal honors on his return to his native land from the Munich conference.
London has a new Lord Mayor, elected the other day in a picturesque ceremony at the Guildhall. It was the

Lacking El Chico, the champion, the world's richest juvenile race will be run today at Belmont Park with a field of twelve, any one of half a dozen of those named having a good chance for the main share of the $77,855 which will be the gross value if a dozen start.

In their general features the Democratic and the Republican State platforms seem almost like twins. Subtracting national policies and a few partisan digs, both are naturally and necessarily kind to agriculture, producer and consumer. As to business,

Stocks opened strong on news of European peace agreement and closed with gains of 1 to 4 points; combined averages recovered all losses of month and closed with slight gain; turnover, 1,897,860 shares.

Miss Jean Bauer of Providence, R. I., former New York women's champion, and Chris Brinke of Detroit, quarter-finalist in the recent national amateur tournament, today set the pace for the field in the fourth annual mixed foursomes golf tournament at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club.

Reginald Owen has replaced Lionel Barrymore as Scrooge in Dickens's "Christmas Carol," and the Metro cameras will turn next week. Barrymore asked to be relieved of the assignment because of ill health, and Owen, who had been cast as the Ghost of Jacob Marley, was switched to the leading role. Terry Kilburn, a youth from "Lord Jeff," will appear as Tiny Tim, and Lynne Carver has the leading feminine role. Edwin L. Marin will direct.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals only $8,087,750, to be represented by eighty-three municipalities, compared with the revised total of $33,418,779 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $24,147,818.

George Washington University's heavily favored football team, its running attack muffled by a game Furman eleven, struck via the air for a second-quarter touchdown and a 7-to-0 victory in the capital's

A large audience attended the production of "Carmen" given last night at the Center Theatre by the San Carlo Opera Company. Lyuba Senderowna and Pasquale Ferrara in the roles of Carmen and Don Jose, respectively, replaced Coe Glade and Dimitri Onofrei,

Advances of 50 cents a ton on anthracite coal have been made, effective Oct. 10, by various New York dealers, it was announced yesterday by Roderick Stephens, co-ordinator of the retail solid fuel industry. He said this was the first
President Roosevelt today gave his unqualified endorsement to the New' York State Democratic ticket. He let it be known that he had had nothing to do with its selection.
About 18,000 liquor licenses have been issued in this State for the annual period beginning Oct, 1, Henry E. Bruckman, chairman of the State Liquor Authority anounced yesterday.

James Harold Crowley, the Old Horseman of Notre Dame, begins his tenth season as a head coach and his sixth at Fordham as the Maroon opens its golden anniversary football year against Upsala College at Randalls Island Stadium this afternoon. Play will begin at 2 o'clock.

Rain that interrupted the program at the show grounds this afternoon and drove several hundred members of society to their homes and country clubs to entertain their out-of-town guests failed to put a damper on the annual dinner dance of the thirty-sixth annual Piping Rock Horse Show, which is being held for four days at the Piping Rock Club. The dance,
Tang Shao-yi, former Chinese revolutionary leader and first Premier of the Chinese Republic, died today after an operation to remove a hatchet buried in his skull.
Yale and Columbia are ready for the nineteenth meeting in their football series tomorrow in the Bowl. The New Yorkers are favored to win.

Mrs. James Roosevelt, who left recently for the West, arrived yesterday in Seattle for a visit with her granddaughter, Mrs. John Boettiger, and Mr. Boettiger. Mrs. Frederic Foster de Rham of Tuxedo Park and her debutante daughter, Miss Madeleine Butt, will be at Carlton House for the Winter.

Assurance of peace in Europe brought general buying into the Cotton Exchange early yesterday, but after prices had risen $2 a bale above the low levels of several days ago reactions developed under profit-taking.

Announcement has been made of the engagement and approaching marriage of Mrs. Beatrice Ladin Block, widow of Louis Block of this city, to Morris Weinfeld of New York and Washington. The marriage will take place on the afternoon of Oct. 9 at the home of Mrs. Block, 955 Fifth Avenue. Dr.

Announcement was made here yesterday of the marriage of Miss Ann Cairns of this city, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John S. Cairns of Boston, to John Schley Behr, also of New York, which took place secretly on Thursday afternoon in Elkton, Md.
With both teams fielding a flock of 1937 hold-overs, Harvard and Brown will launch their 1938 gridiron campaigns in the Harvard Stadium tomorrow.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "There is a better tone in the wool market and more business being done this week, some houses reporting a fair volume of business since the announcement of the settlement of the Czechoslovakia problem, apparently reflecting a slightly better tone in the piece goods markets.

Arthur Lowell Sherer, manager of the Eighty-sixth Street branch of the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company of New York and former Republican Assemblyman from Harlem, died suddenly of a heart attack here last night at his home.
Leopold Stokowski will conduct the Philadelphia Orchestra in eleven, and possibly fourteen, concerts in Philadelphia and elsewhere during the period from March 13, 1939,

Boston College tonight defeated a hard-fighting Northeastern University football team, 13-0, before a crowd of 7,500. Slated to trample over the opposition, Boston College had a difficult time. Vito Ananis tallied the first touchdown midway through the first quarter.. Ira Jivelekian place-kicked

Howard Ellington Lum, former credit manager and director of Browning, King Co., New York clothiers, died here yesterday at his home, 64 Greene Avenue, of a heart ailment. He was 76 years old and was one of the oldest residents of this community.
Promotion of coney coats in connection with other merchandise forming the "Essential Wardrobe," a trade-marked name, has been started by the National Coney Fur Institute. The wardrode will be

A motorist gave a summons to a policeman today. On Monday morning Patrolman Michael Reagan of the Third Precinct will stand trial in City Court for indulging in the old, wellknown custom of stopping an automobile to sell the driver a ticket for a policemen's ball.

The Tennessee Valley Authority filed a motion in the Federal district court here today seeking dismissal of Dr. Arthur E. Morgan's suit challenging the power of President Roosevelt in removing him March 22 as chairman-director of TVA.
Mrs. James J. Sexton Jr. of Granville, Ohio, gained a second leg on the Sinbad Memorial Trophy, as the thirteenth annual Montclair Horse Show opened today in the ring of the Montclair Riding Club.

Miss Maria V. Leavitt, who is retiring after forty-two years of service in the New York Public Library, was honored at a reception given by her fellow-workers in the trustees' room at the main building at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, yesterday afternoon. A testimonial set by hand
