Bruno Walter, conductor, who is returning to this country this season to conduct various orchestras, has just received his French citizenship papers, according to announcement by the Columbia Concerts Corporation. Mr. Walter,

In a little more than an hour yesterday the names of 500 talesmen were drawn in the County Clerk's office, in the Hall of Records Building, as the blue-ribbon panel from which the jury is to be chosen in General Sessions on Nov. 14 at the new trial of James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, in the policy racket indictment.

East Side locations were selected for many varieties of retail enterprises by a number of the concerns listed in brokers' reports of commercial leasing yesterday. The store and basement on the corner of Fifth Avenue and Fiftyninth Street, in the Hotel SavoyPlaza was taken by Maison Simone.

J. J. and Nevin Moser have purchased, through J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker, from John Hilkman, the two-family house at 16 Sixth Street, in the Highwood Park section of Weehawken, N. J., and will occupy both apartments.
Production and export of petroleum in Venezuela declined slightly in July, the Department of Commerce said today. Production in July was put

At the funeral the mourners review their memories of the deceased. It seems a long time ago since that late September day when this writer stood for the first time on the banks of the Moldau and looked across at the walls and towers of the castle and the cathedral of the Bohemian kings.

Niagara caught Manhattan on the rebound from the unexpected St. Bonaventure defeat and paid heavily for it at the Polo Grounds last night. The Purple reputedly was "loaded for bear," but, the Jaspers unloaded the Eagles in a hurry as they slashed through to a 19-0 victory before the delighted gaze of a gathering of 6,122.

The greatest number and total value of new cooperative bank mortgage loans in six years were granted by the member banks of the Massachusetts Cooperative Bank League in the twelve months which ended the league's fiftieth year this month. Total new home

That stiff smile with which Governor Lehman this afternoon acknowledged' the ovation at his renomination to an office he had not wanted was eloquent of his attitude toward the draft movement to which he capitulated. But no echoing

Charles Poletti, Justice of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District, who has been nominated as Lieutenant Governor on the Democratic ticket, was one of the youngest lawyers ever to serve as legal counsel to a New York State Governor. He was Governor
Nine hundred men and about seventy-two officers of the Naval Reserve were debarked yesterday from twelve destroyers after a two weeks' training cruise to, Guantanamo Bay. Cuba.

President Roosevelt is personally more popular now than he was immediately before his record victory at the polls in 1936, despite the failure of his efforts to purge the Democratic party of opponents of his program, according to a survey reported in the October issue of Fortune. The survey hereafter
One word, "Peace," completely summarizes expressions on yesterday's events in the French press, and the same word fell from the lips of every one in the streets, in army camps and in homes.

Assailing the Republican leaders at the Constitutional Convention as having resorted to party politics and as having refused to cooperate with the Democratic minority in the drafting of a liberal document, the

The Public Service Gas Company of Montana has filed a petition with the Federal Power Commission asking approval for the construction of a 1,500-mile pipe line from Montana to the Messaba iron region in Minnesota. The project would cost $49,402,000.

In response to inquiries concerning reports that Senator Vojta Benes, brother of the Czechoslovak President, had collapsed as a result of his speech at a meeting here last night, the Czechoslovak Legation here said today that the Senator.

Mrs. Mary F. Taber, librarian of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for twenty-one years, retired yesterday. The appellate court library had only 500 volumes when she began work as its head. Today it has 14,000 volumes.

A new by-law, passed by the Board of Higher Education last June, designed to reorganize the faculties and structure of the administrations of the municipal institutions will become effective today in the four city colleges-Hunter, Brooklyn, City and Queens Colleges.

The statement of the Bank of Canada for the week ended on Wednesday, issued today, shows that notes in circulation increased $1,552,000 and that the ratio of net reserve to notes and deposit liabilities was 52.77 per cent on Wednesday, against 53.32 per cent a week before.

Opposing views as to the reasonableness of the present wage level in the railroad industry were presented by counsel for the railroads and labor at the opening hearings today before the emergency board named by President Roosevelt on Tuesday to study the five-month-old dispute.

Miss Liselotte Kaufmann, daughter of Mrs. Paula Kaufmann of Vienna and the late Josef Kaufmann, was married to Alfred Jaretzki Jr. of New York here this afternoon in the First English Lutheran Church by the Rev. Martin Luther Enders.

The Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan will resume preaching tomorrow at the 11 A. M. service in St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, of which he is rector, after eight months of illness with neuritis. He has completely recovered.
Eight years have trudged by since Alison Skipworth last barged through a play in this town. That is a long time to be deprived of her querulous and aggressive comedy.

A wave of heartfelt relief swept over Australia today as news of the Munich agreement became known. Special editions of newspapers sold as fast as they appeared on the streets and the public generally acclaimed Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain for saving the world from threatening disaster.

There is no way of knowing what ,argument finally prevailed upon Herbert Lehman to accept the nomination for Governor which his party was so desperately eager to offer him, but it must have been a strong one.
The Bears won't take a chance on their famous recuperative powers in their little world series baseball engagement with Kansas City of the American Association, opening tomorrow.

This is in reference to a phrase occasionally used by observers of objects in flight and recently applied by James P. Dawson in describing Jimmy Foxx's home run into the upper left-field stand at the Yankee Stadium last Saturday.

Robert E. Sherwood has delivered his new play, "Abe Lincoln in Illinois," to Scribners, who are planning immediate publication. The play, which recreates the early part of Lincoln's life before he took office as President, will be produced by the Playrights Producing Company and is expected to open in New York on Oct. 15.

Before a hundred members of the West Virginia Utilities Association in convention here, Basil Manly of the Federal Power Commission discussed the commission's ideas, policies and plans. He talked of the survey of power, made to provide an ample supply in time of military or other emergency; of the integration of activities and of methods of accounting.
Dr. Joseph E. Goodbar, president of the Society for Stability in Money and Banking, attacked yesterday the Federal Government's policy of administering the Social Security Act.

In sharp contrast to the recent recordbreaking inward movement of capital to the United States from warscared Europe, capital moved out of this country at a decreasing rate from the first recession fright of last Fall through the second quarter of the current year, the Treasury's quarterly statement of foreign capital movements disclosed today.
The New York State Merchant Marine Academy, oldest State marine school in the United States, held its seventy-ninth annual gradnation exercises yesterday afternoon at Fort Schuyler, the Bronx.
Texas Tech converted an intercepted pass into a victory tonight when it came from behind with a touchdown for a 7-to-6 decision over Duquesne's football team.

The Missing Persons Bureau at Police Headquarters received an alarm early today asking it to search for Colonel William J. Wilgus, former head of the Works Division of the Emergency Relief Bureau and one of the country's most prominent engineers.

Visibly relieved by the favorable turn of events abroad, President Roosevelt said today that he would leave late tomorrow night for his Hyde Park home to resume the rest, interrupted several weeks ago when he went to Rochester, Minn., for a visit with his son, James, who was about to be operated on.
Edwin E. Soyer has been admitted as a general partner in Goodbody Co. Luke C. Doyle and H. Sellers Mckee are with Pyne, kendall Hollister.

The League of Nations Assembly adopted a report today separating the covenant from the Versailles Treaties, inviting suggestions from non-members of the League on how to develop non-technical cooperation with the League and giving various declarations by members on sanctions as being optional in character, thus weakening the League.
Effective yesterday, the old partnership of Ely Son was dissolved. Ely Co: is being formed by Valentine A. Ely, William T. Kirk 3d and A. Pam Blumenthal.

The New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad will default in the payment of $14,807,000 of 6 per cent notes due today, it was announced yesterday. Holders of the notes had been asked to consent to another three-year extension.

Dahlias and lilies in profusion, against a background of growing birch trees, decorated the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Janet Harrison Kneale to James Alexander Hetherington 2d. The Rev. Dr. Cordie J. Culp performed the ceremony.
An investing client of S. Goldwater Co. bought from the West Seventy-second Street Realty Corporation the four-story apartment building at 1,438 Morris Avenue, the Bronx, on a plot 35 by 92.6 feet.
It is with a deep sense of the honor you confer upon me that I accept the responsibility of presiding over the deliberations of this convention.

A storm that formed in the Gulf of Mexico Wednesday and swept rapidly across Florida and up the Atlantic seaboard, bringing winds of tornado force to Charleston, S. C., and causing torrential rains elsewhere in the South, moved past hurricane-stricken Long Island yesterday and last night and on up the New England coast, apparently doing little damage.
Charles Edward Rugh, professor emeritus of education at the University of California, died here yesterday at the age of 71. He was a native of Lamartine, Pa.

A jubilant and confident Democratic State Convention today renominated Herbert H. Lehman for Governor after he had finally decided to yield to a draft movement of an intensity surpassing all recent movements of the kind.

A brief has been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Providence Gas Company urging the granting of its application for termination of unlisted trading in its common stock on the New York Curb Exchange. The stock is not traded on any other Exchange and the company is anxious to restrict dealings to the over-the-counter market.

Whatever happens, Senator Pittman's first thought seems to be, how can I take advantage of this situation to help silver? Undismayed by the failure of all his predictions regarding what his previous silver schemeadopted, alas, by Congress-would do,
Definitive New York Dock Company convertible 5 per cent notes due on April 1, 1947, are ready for delivery in exchange for temporary notes, the Manufacturers Trust Company announced yesterday.
A banking syndicate headed by Smith, Barney Co. received yesterday the award of a new issue of $5,108,000 Maryland State Roads Commission 3 per cent bonds on a bid of 100.6099. The bonds,

Continuing her streak of great golf in spite of rain and a high wind, Miss Gail Wild of the home club scored an 82 on her own and, teamed with Miss Josephine Merrill of Montclair, outclassed the field and won low-gross honors in the women's New Jersey best-ball tournament.

May women serve as special jurors in the counties of Bronx, Kings, New York, Queens and Westchester? Only these five counties are entitled to special juries. May women serve as grand jurors in the counties of Bronx, Kings and New York, in which special statutes regulate the selection and qualifications of grand jurors?

All Berlin awaited in anxious expectancy early this morning to hear the results of the Munich conference. The Berlin office of THE NEW YORK TIMES all night received telephone calls from Germans asking in broken English whether some agreement had already been reached or whether the correspondents believed some agreement was likely.

Harriette Totten Thompson, represented by Bennett E. Siegelstein, attorney, has purchased from Henry A. Uterhart, receiver of the South Shore Thrift Corporation, the Grasser industrial property in the village of Island Park, Long Beach, L. I.

THERE are probably more Irishmen in New York than there are around O'Connell Street, and a good many of them-as well as every one else who has no constitutional objection to reading a very good biography-should be interested in Sean O'Faolain's life of Dan O'Connell, "King of the Beggars."*
Poland's "last warning" was given tonight to the Czechoslovak Government in a new note sent by special plane to Prague, the Polish Foreign Office spokesman declared.
Delegates and visitors began arriving today for the opening tomorrow of the fourth National Catechetical Congress of the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine.

Although the Chinese loss of the important Yangtze fortification of Tienchiachen is now announced officially, the Chinese say that Japanese warships have not yet crossed the boom and mine field across the Yangtze at that point.
The branch bank of the United States Federal Reserve System, a subsidiary of Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank, which was opened in Cuba in 1923, ceased operations today.

Twelve striking employes of the Busch Jewelry Company and the attorney for their unions were ordered yesterday to show cause why they should not be adjudged in contempt of an injunction restraining picketing outside the company's stores.

Mayor Watkins Overton announced tonight that the city of Memphis, in cooperation. with the. Tennessee Valley Authority, had agreed with the Memphis Power and Light Company to buy the latter's electric properties for $13,500,000.

As hourly bulletins dramatized the events of what one speaker called "a tremendously fateful day in history," 2,300 New Jersey club women heard the future of democracy linked here today to the permanence of Europe's peace agreement on one hand, and on the other to reform in the system of local government and other developments at home.

The New York Towboat Exchange appealed yesterday to the Army engineers to conduct a survey of the navigation problems along the South Shore of Long Island and the shore of the mainland before carrying out their proposal to construct the Fire Island jetty.
The executive board of the State
The general joy over the Munich agreement is overshadowed by the fear that Hungarian and Bulgarian revisionism will receive fresh impetus and sooner or later turn against Rumania.

A contra-seasonal decline in cotton-mill activity last week caused the adjusted index to slump to 110.8 from 116.7, the revised figure for the previous week. The figure was 127.1 for the week ended Sept. 25, 1937.
Appointments of more than 700 men and women to the New York City teaching staff was approved yesterday at the regular Board of Education meeting at 500 Park Avenue. Of this number, 632 were

A cost study in a number of New York State trust institutions shows that for every dollar of income received in 1936 the cost of rendering the trust service involved was $1.13 and in 1937 the cost was $1.15, Henry A. Theis, vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York said here today in an address before the Mid-Continent Trust Conference of the American Bankers Assodiation being held in the Stevens Hotel.

Buoyancy ruled in all sections of the bond market yesterday in more active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The European agreement stimulated a broad demand that sent prices up in spectacular fashion. Transactions on the Exchange broadened out to $9,963,000, compared with $7,282,600 on Thursday.

Declaring that Latin America will show an even greater growth during the next forty years than since the turn of the century, Joseph D. Bohan, sales manager of the Centaur Company, yesterday urged T members of the Export Advertising Association to increase their promotional work in South America and to discover at first hand the needs of the markets down there.

Miss Jane Snyder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward R. Snyder of this place, became the bride tonight of William H. Areson Jr.. son of Dr. and Mrs. Areson of Upper Montclair. The ceremony was performed at the Women's Club of Upper Montclair by the Rev. Dr. Morgan Phelps Noyes, pastor of Central Presbyterian Church here.
Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange last month was slightly more active than in August, but was still the smallest of any September since 1934.

William J. Graham, chairman of the executive committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, has announced that the following candidates have been approved by the committee for membership in the chamber: James R. Hobbins, vice president, Anaconda Copper Mining Company; Harry M. Hooker, president,

With most tenants settled in their apartments today, the traditional Fall moving day, the rush for rooms has passed its peak. Renting is not yet at normal, however, as brokers and managing agents continued yesterday to report additional leases by late-comers.
A PWA grant of $157,000, representing 45 per cent of the cost of a proposed school building, was rejected by the voters today. The count was 798 opposed and 700 in favor of the measure.

In this cheering Europe none cheered today from fuller hearts than the French people when at Le Bourget airfield and all along the road past the Opera to the Ministry of War they welcomed Premier Edouard Daladier. There were many who wept as they cheered.

President Lazaro Cardenas today decreed the expropriation of 3,200 acres of land belonging to his political enemy, General Fortunato Zuazua, who is openly opposed to the present regime and who has attacked its policies In public statements. The land nationalized is El

Great relief was felt throughout India as a result of the Munich conference although the Indian public generally deplores the territorial concessions to Germany. The Times of India points out that one encouraging factor in the situation was the unity of the empire In the face of the German threat.

The first contingent of German troops crossed the Czechoslovak frontier near Aigen, in the former Upper Austria, early today, starting Chancellor Adolf Hitler's occupation of territory granted him by the fourpower Munich accord.

Though Mayor La Guardia declined to discuss the Governorship race between Governor Herbert H. Lehman and District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey yesterday, his close associates at City Hall said that the Mayor would not take sides in the campaign for the present.
" Under protest to the world"so run the headlines in nearly all newspapers tonight-the Czechoslovak Government bowed today to the dictated terms from Munich.

Following is the text of Governor Lehman's acceptance speech to the Democratic State Convention: Mayor Thacher, Postmaster General Farley, fellow-candidates on the State ticket, fellow-Democrats and friends:
The British Government has decided to contribute about 5,000 seasoned British troops to the "international bodies" that will keep order during the plebiscites in Czechoslovakia.

Flashing the form that carried him to the top rank of American golf a few years ago, Craig Wood of Rumson today took a two-stroke lead in the annual New Jersey Professional Golfers Association championship when he scored 66 and 72 for a total of 138 at the half way point over the Suburban Golf Club course.

Marine insurance underwriters here made sharp reductions in their quotations on war risk yesterday, but the rates were still substantially higher than those which were in effect prior to the German-Czechoslovak crisis.

Spurred by news that the Spanish Loyalist Government plans to discharge all foreign volunteers from its army, spokesmen for the Friends of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade announced yesterday the immediate launching of a new campaign to raise $150,000 with which to charter a ship and bring back all Americans now serving in Spain.

Negotiations for the merger of the Beekman Street Hospital with the Broad Street Hospital, with a view to consolidating hospital facilities in lower Manhattan, were disclosed yesterday at a luncheon of banking and business officials in the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

Immediate rezoning of the Jamaica Bay area for recreational and residential purposes was recommended yesterday by a special committee of the Citizens Union. The plan adopted in 1922 to develop the area into a huge port should be definitely repealed, the committee said.

The comparatively new problem of management of public housing projects, now being advanced on a broad scale in this country through the United States Housing Authority and cooperating local and State agencies, is attracting the

Member trading in round lots for their own account on the New York Stock Exchange for the week ended on Sept. 10 was 20.74 per cent ol the total volume, compared with 19.66 per cent in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Four Czechoslovak soldiers and two Sudeten Germans were killed today in crossfire outside Eger in the farthest western tip of territory being ceded to Germany. Otherwise all fighting stopped in this Sudeten region as the Free Corps prepared to march back into Czechoslovakia behind the German Army of Occupation.

France has lost her greatness." This statement, broadcast by the Comintern radio station today about Russia's ally, summarized the disfavor with which Soviet circles viewed the four-power accord reached in Munich.

A net profit of $499,060 was reported yesterday by Bloomingdale Bros., Inc., in an unaudited statement covering the year ended on July 31. In the preceding twelve months a net profit of $738,640 was shown.
Paced by Harold (Babe) Ruth, 155pound halfback from Binghamton, Syracuse University's football team trounced Clarkson Tech, 27-0, tonight before 15,000 fans under the lights in Archbold Stadium.
New York jumped into the lead tonight at the halfway mark in the annual Lesley Cup golf championship, piling up a total of 28 points.

The communique issued today by General Ludwig Jan Krejci, Inspector General of the Czechoslovak Army, to his men follows: Soldiers! The Government of the Czechoslovak Republic has been forced under the pressure of world events to accept the transfer of certain regions of our nation to the neighboring Reich.

Testimony by Theodore Phillips Jr., a partner in the accounting firm of Homes Davis, at the Securities and Exchange Commission's hearing into the affairs of the Interstate Hosiery Mills, Inc., yesterday dealt principally with his contention that Homes Davis had not been remiss in its handling of the company's reports.

A so-called washed-stamp racket, by means of which the government is said to have been defrauded of $1,000,000 a year in taxes on cigarettes, was revealed yesterday when a Federal grand jury indicted three manufacturers, a retail dealer and a corporation.

Princeton and Williams held light workouts on drizzly University Field today in preparation for their meeting in the Tiger's opener in Palmer Stadium tomorrow before an estimated crowd of 20,000. Princeton holds an upper hand in the seven-game series, having won six contests and tied one.

A sharply firmer tendency in the rates on the weekly offerings of Treasury discount bills constituted the only quotable change in the money market in September. As A had been the case for two and one- bro half years call and time money Cot rates were unchanged.

In the face of a downpour and threatened gale, today's matinee program of the thirty-sixth annual Piping Rock Horse Show was postponed until tomorrow, much to the relief of owners and riders, who had gone through a morning of competition under the most dispiriting conditions.

The Union League Club of New York receives a bequest of $50,000 under the will of its late president, Charles Cook Paulding, lawyer and retired vice president of the New York Central Lines, which was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

It was reported today that Cyril B. Upham, an assistant to Secretary Morgenthau of the Treasury, would be appointed to succeed Marshall R. Diggs as Deputy Controller of the Currency, it being understood that Mr. Diggs had offered his resignation. No formal announcements were made, however.

The Ritz brothers' "Straight, Place and Show," which ran at the Roxy yesterday, seems to have been one of those pictures produced by the trial and error method--a trial to its audience and an error on the part of its producer. Damon Runyon

Miss Jessie Thomson Cleverdon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter S. L. Cleverdon of this place, was married this afternoon to Eugene Alfred Mintkeski of Brooklyn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Mintkeski of Kingston, Pa., at the home of her parents here. The Rev.

Leonard J. Cushing, recently assistant to the senior partner of Redmond Co., today becomes a member of the firm of Burnham Co., 61 Broadway. Mr. Cushing graduated from Princeton with the class of '22. From 1922 to 1935

It was emphasized in Securities and Exchange Commission circles today that the commission had not sought to enter into the reorganization proceedings before Federal Judge William Bondy in New York in the reorganization of the

The foreign exchange market, under the leadership of the pound sterling, continued yesterday to rally strongly in response to the dramatic lifting of the menace of war in Europe. Sterling advanced to $4.84 3/8, more than 24 cents above its low point of last Wednesday and closed at $4.83 3/8, up 5 1/4 cents net.

Fred Perry, English tennis star who has not lost a set in two rounds of singles play in the national professional tournament, continued his record into the doubles division today. He teamed with Vincent

The first advance this year was named. yesterday on kraft liner board, when producers named a quotation of $45 per ton for the last quarter. The board was sold in the last quarter of 1937 at $52.50 a ton and was cut $5 in the first quarter of this year and $2.50 in each of the next two quarters, bringing the quotation for the third quarter to $42.50.

The aid of State and civic agencies toward the organization on a national scale of a field corps of safety inspectors was sought yesterday by H. H. Kelly, chief of the Bureau of Motor Carriers of the Interstate Commerce Commission. Mr. Kelly addressed a forum

The committee appointed by the directors of the Gulf, Mobile Northern Railroad to negotiate a merger with the Mobile Ohio Railroad expects to present its recommendations to the board at an early date, I. B. Tigrett, president of the former road, said yesterday.

As we meet, the rays of peace have pierced the clouds of war that hovered over nations across the sea. We stand solidly behind the policy of The Good Neighbor, both within our own borders and in our relations with other nations.
Investors were active yesterday in the purchase of housing properties in scattered sections of Manhattan. Savings banks figured as the sellers in some of the transactions.

The Standard Investing Corporation has adopted a plan offering to its debenture holders the alternative of exchanging their present debentures either for a like principal amount of new three-year debentures or cash equal to 25 per cent of the old debentures, plus interest at 51/2 per cent to Aug. 15, 1939, when the bonds come due, on that 25 per cent, and new debentures in the amount of 75 per cent of th old.
Reports of troop-laden Japanese transports of Shanghai and Tsingtao tonight revived speculation that Japan would launch a South China campaign centering on Canton.

A hard charging Texas A. M. football team took the wind out of the Tulsa Golden Hurricane today to defeat the Oklahomans, 20-0. The Aggies struck in the, first, third and fourth periods for their touchdowns before a crowd of 14,000.

Tallying both of its touchdowns In the final half, the Thomas Jefferson High School football team turned in a surprise 13-to-7 triumph over Boys High before 8,000 persons at Boys High Stadium in Brooklyn yesterday.
The United States'and Colombia will raise their legations to the status of embassies, it was stated today. The change will be made as soon as arrangements can be completed.
While Germany's army marched forward in "peaceful conquest" of the Sudetenland Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's servants searched his 10 Downing Street residence today for his umbrella.

On the East River some distance south of the Queensborough Bridge two miniature geysers gradually moving toward each other across the water can be seen daily. They mark the progress in construction of the Queens Midtown Tunnel, beguh two years ago today.

At the World's Fair of 1939 an overwhelming masculine majority has plied paint brush and chisel as the great exposition's brilliantly tinted structures take shape against the Flushing sky, yet a feminine minority is not submerged in the resultant ensemble.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the discussion of permanent business recovery, and the resumption of sound economic development in the United States, it seems a hopeful sign that merely abstract debate is giving way to practical considerations.

This week the 10-year-old girls of Public School 17, Manhattan, are starting on a three-month bus trip to California. The children, many of whom have never left their block, are eager to see Washington, New Orleans, the Mississippi River and the West.
The Giants will finish no lower than third in this year's scrambled National League flag race. Either they will have undisputed possession of the berth or will share it with the Cincinnati Reds.
Germany last week became the strongest nation in Europe, and Adolf Hitler a more powerful and absolute ruler than Kaiser Wilhelm II ever was.

Notre Dame's fifty-first football team, sparked by a classy sophomore and powered by almost a score of hard-running ball carriers, rolled over Kansas today, 52 to 0. A crowd of 45.000 witnessed the contest.

WASHINGTON.-With the Congressional campaign heading into the final stretch, these are busy days in the House of Representatives folding room. Here speeches of Congressmen, previously printed in the Congressional Record, are mailed out to constituents and others. Distribution of speeches plays

The impetus given to the study of foreign and domestic affairs last week by the first "Review of the News" conferences sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES will find expression among club women of Westchester.

One thing the Poles believe they have learned this week: In present-day Europe treaties, alliances, pacts and all other international agreements have lost all value for small nations. That belief explains their course in their dispute with Czechoslovakia.

The University of Delaware came from behind to defeat its old rival, Ursinus, 12-9, in the opening game of the season for both teams today. Delaware outplayed Ursinus except in the third quarter, when Armstrong blocked a kick and ran 20 yards to score.
Women outguessed men in a contest offered by the New York State College of Forestry at the State Fair. The question was the length of the paper in two rolls of newsprint.
Dr. Pedro Groppo, Argentine Minister of Finance, in his budget message to the Congress estimated revenues for 1939 at 855,900,000 pesos, according to the Argentine Information Bureau.

Plans will be pressed immediately for the resumption of the service operated around the world by the Dollar Steamship Lines, it was announced by Joseph R. Sheehan, newly elected president of the company, on a visit last week to the New York offices.
Mayor Wilson today directed Yellow Cab Company officials and striking cab drivers to "get together by Thursday."
Mr. Allan Ramsey Wurtele seems to have worked so successfully in the dark that not even the United States Bureau of Agricultural Engineering knows anything about his sugar-cane harvesting machine.

Albright stopped Geneva's eleven today, handing the Covenanters a 19-to-0 setback. Inaugurating the home season the Lions gained seventeen first downs to twelve for the Beaver Falls squad. Coach Dietz's warriors counted in three periods. Aszman scored a touchdown late in the first quarter after a 28-yard drive.

Mrs. C. De Wolf Gibson and several of her friends, as well as younger members of society, will take an active part in the thirtysixth anniversary celebration of the Saks-Thirty-fourth Street store on Thursday.
EVERY historical narrative worth the paper it is printed on, whether it is cast as fiction or as fact, depends on source material which has usually cost the author much anxious thought.

WITH forty-six test flights under varying load conditions and flying requirements safely behind it, the 42-passenger Douglas DC-4 last week rated at 65,000 pounds and quieted conclusively all earlier fears that America's airports are too small for such mighty equipment.

The Diesel-powered flying boat, Nordstern, one of the three Deutsche Lufthansa planes making survey flights over the North Atlantic between here and the Azores, is scheduled to land near City Island about 9 o'clock this morning, according to officials of the German company. Her sister ship,

PITTSFILD. JUST before the concluding number in the last concert of the Berkshire Festival of chamber music, held on South Mountain here Sept. 21, 22 and 23, Mrs. Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge, who founded the famous colony in 1918, stepped to the front of the stage to greet the audience which had been her guests for five programs.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold A. Breen of Caldwell, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Scott Breen, to Caryle Edgar Miller, son of Mrs. Henry E. Miller of Caldwell and the late Mr. Miller.

Mr. and Mrs. Philip A. Doherty Jr. gave a dinner last night in the Garden of the Ambassador for Miss Janie Elizabeth Igoe and Dr. Henry George Wehmann, who will be married on Oct. 20 in the Church of the Holy Innocents.

The Leftist morning paper L'Oeuvre in today's issue calls on its women readers to join in a French national gift to Mrs. Neville Chamberlain. Beneath a conspicuous appeal there is a cut showing the British Prime Minister's cheery attitude as his wife bids him goodbye for the Munich trip. The caption reads:

To all intents and purposes, the Democratic convention held here this week might just as well have been held in a telephone booth. From start to finish, the make-up of the Democratic State ticket depended on Herbert H. Lehman, and on no one else.

Mail orders and reorders were numerous in all divisions of the New York wholesale market last week, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers. "Deliveries on wanted merchandise were still difficult to obtain," the summary states.

New orders for steel office furniture during August totaled $1,537,675, compared with $1,773,361 in the same month last year, according to the report issued for publication today by the Bureau of the Census of the Department of Commerce. Shipments in August aggregated $1,677,205, while unfilled orders at the end of the month totaled $1,062,922.

The marriage of Miss Louise DeWolf, daughter of Mrs. Edward Arthur DeWolf of this place and the late Mr. DeWolf, to Emil Arthur Kratovil of New York and Glenwood Landing, L. I., son of Mr. and Mrs. Emil Stephen Kratovil of Springfield and Southwick, Mass., took place here this afternoon in the South Dartmouth Congregational Church.

The Lehigh Valley Railroad Company has announced that the interest due yesterday on the Pennsylvania and New York Canal and Dock issues and the Lehigh Valley Terminal Railway first 5s is being met. These payments, amounting to $443,750, would be extended under the road's plan for adjusting interest payments.
Floral murals have been chosen as the decorative feature of the new Schrafft's restaurant at 61 Fifth Avenue, corner of Thirteenth Street, nearing completion for opening early in November.

LONDON. THE publication of the fourth volume of Winston Churchill's "Marlborough" (Har rap) marks the completion of a monumental work which one reviewer describes as not only a great biography but also a splendid historical panorama.

The Reich today announced a new 1,500,000,000-mark government loan-the third major loan in the current year and the fourteenth since 1935. The new loan brings the borrowing in the public capital market up to 11,130,000,000 marks.

HAVING threatened us with it for some time, Columbia now releases the complete Milan "Lucia di Lammermoor" from which last month's single of the sextet was extracted (Operatic Set No. 20, in two volumes). On records, at least,

Approximately one hundred debutantes of the new season have accepted invitations to participate in the cotillion which will be the principal feature of the annual Velvet Ball and Debutante Cotillion on the night of Oct. 28 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
Held scoreless for the first half, Muhlenberg shoved over three touchdowns in the last two periods today to beat Dickinson, 19 to 7, before 4,500. Dickinson was undefeated last year.

Dr. George Gallup, director of the American Institute of Public Opinion, will deliver the principal address Monday at the seventeenth annual institute of the New Jersey Press Association at Rutgers University. About 150 newspapers will be represented.

Miss Jane Hubbard, whose parents, Mr. and Mrs. Giles Munro Hubbard of Pelham Manor, N. Y., have a Summer home here, was married this afternoon in the Norfolk Congregational Church to Arthur Knox Jr., son of Arthur Knox of Norfolk and New York and the late Mrs. May Barnard Knox.

The news that the Cubs had won the pennant hit the Pirates between the eyes tonight. Outside of President William E. Benswanger, no one on the team, once considered a sure shot for the National League flag, had anything to say.

Methods by which older urban neighborhoods threatened with blight may be improved or protected so that general rehabilitation may be encouraged will be one of the chief topics to be discussed at the annual convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, to be held in Milwaukee, Wis., Nov. 9 to 12.
Trin ity triumphed over a fighting Union team today by 19-13. Bri1liant broken field running by Morris speedy dashes by Sophomore Rya and passes by Rihl to Kelly furtured the victory.
THIS book is the result of six lectures -delivered at the University of Cambridge in the Spring term of this year. Sir Maurice Amos. lawyer and professor of law.

Parading along almost at will, as virtually every one had expected, Fordhams football machine got the habit of crossing enemy goal lines yesterday as the fiftieth Ram gridiron season was opened with a 47to-O victory over Upsala at the Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island.
On the twentieth anniversary of the downfall of the Hungarian Kingdom and the beginning of the dismemberment of its territory Budapest is triumphant.

A demonstration designed to bring about a change in the foreclosure policies of the Home Owners Loan Corporation was staged in front of the HOLC offices at 270 Broadway yesterday morning under the sponsorship of the Brooklyn Home Owners Association.

Cyril B. Upham, an assistant to Secretary Morgenthau of the Treasury, was appointed First Deputy Controller of the Currency by Mr. Morgenthau today after the resignation of Marshall R. Diggs, who has been Acting Controller since J. F. T. O'Connor resigned in April, had been requested and obtained.

Poland's annexation of the Teschen district of Czechoslovakia will be keenly resented here as another Hitlerinspired move toward German aggrandizement. No official statement was available tonight on the Soviet's attitude toward the new turn of events.

Miss Alice Marie Livesey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Samuel Livesey of Montclair, wasmarried this afternoon in the home of her parents to Curtis Campaigne Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Campaign, also of Montclair. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Vincent E. Donavan of St. Vincent Ferrer Church, New York.

IF you are browsing in the bookstores do not allow the cryptic title of this first novel to turn you away from it. Since Hecht's "Erik Dorn," or perhaps since Dreiser's "The Genius," there has hardly been a more direct and moving account of a sensitive young man running counter to a provincial American environment.

The Board of Examiners recommends that license as teacher-intraining in day second dary schools other than junior high schools in the subjects as indicated, be issued, as of Sept. 29, 1938, to the following applicants:

Among the attractive suburban sections in New Jersey where a steady demand has been witnessed this season for homes of a moderately expensive type is. Short Hills, and the sale of two additional dwellings recently completed there was reported yesterday.
LITTLE more than a hundred years ago any one who spoke of ancient civilization was understood as a matter of course to be referring to Greece and Rome: today, both

There is reason to believe, despite all present appearances to the contrary, that one effect of the Munich accord and the events preceding it has been to make certain British Conservative quarters begin to consider favorably "a British alliance with Russia."

Two divergent systems of shaping undergraduate affairs are to be in force in Yale College the coming year. A student conference group appointed last year by Dean George H. Nettleton has been such a practical success that its continuance

From the rafters of London's Science Museum hangs the original Wright biplane of 1903, the machine that first carried a man through the air with engine power. It is only a loan exhibit which Orville Wright may withdraw at any time. He declines to bring it back

Haverford opened its football season today with a 7-6 victory over Susquehanna University. Beeler, Haverford's speedy quarterback, broke through Susequehanna's line for nine yards and his team's only touchdown on the first play of the second quarter.
Vermont is confronted by several problems as Federal, State and town agencies unite in the work of rehabilitation. Vermont storm deaths numbered eight.

The Presidents' Council and Luncheon, an annual event of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, will be held on Oct. 17 at the Hotel Roosevelt, with Mrs. William Crocker, president of the Federation, presiding. The council will meet at 10:30 in the morning and luncheon will be served at 1, with Richardson Wright as the guest speaker.

Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Milbank of New York exhibited their Labrador retriever, Champion Earlsmoor Moor of Arden, at the Devon Dog Show Association's annual all-breed event today and the nice moving black specimen was named best among close to 800.
A sharp increase in railroad freight haulage was reported yesterday as the strike of long-distance truck drivers continued for the seventeenth day.
The strained atmosphere along the French-German frontier that accompanied the recent war threat gave way today to a spirit of international camaraderie.

James A. Lunn, brother-in-law of George U. Harvey, Queens Borough President, will lose his $5,000 job as special supervisor of construction on the Queens County Court House in Jamaica on Oct. 15, by action of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, it was learned yesterday.

THE Hupp Motor Car Corporation yesterday announced three new lines of six and eight cylinder Hupmobiles for 1939. At the same time the company said that a new four-cylinder line to be brought out later will have the unusual body style of the smaller new six.

The French liner Paris brought 658 passengers from Europe yesterday including thirteen veterans of the Spanish civil war, American volunteers who served with the Spanish Government forces. Among them were James Benet, son of the poet William Rose Benet, and David Thompson, a nephew of Kathleen Norris, the novelist.

Operation of the New Jersey Unemployment Compensation Commission, which will begin payment of benefits in January, was described this week by former Governor Harold G. Hoffman at a meeting in Atlantic City of the New Jersey Funeral Directors Association. Mr. Hoffman is executive director of the commission. He said:

The frontier guard reinforcement and other extraordinar precautionary measures were canceled today. The gratification of The Netherlands over the peaceful solution of the Czechoslovak crisis is manifesting itself in newspaper editorials and in the formation of numerous committees to send to British Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain congratulatory messages and flowers.

In the day period from the day after the hurricane through Friday, 10,162 passengers were flown between Boston and New York, a world's air record for air traffic between two' cities, American Airlines, Inc., announced today.

The report of the Royal Typewriter Company, Inc., and its domestic subsidiaries for the year ended on July 31, issued yesterday, shows a net profit of $1,526,172 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and the surtax on undistributed profits. This is equivalent to $4.70 each on 268,618 common shares after dividend requirements on the 7 per cent preferred stock.

Unemployment increased in eleven of twenty-three major countries during the third quarter of 1938, as compared to that period in 1937, according to the International Labor Office quarterly report on world unemployment published today.

Changes in financing conditions during the last few years have been reflected in the management requirements for savings and loan associations, declares John W. Ballard, chief examiner of the Federal Home Loan Bank System.
Events of the last few days indicate that operation of the Maloney act for self-regulation of the overthe-counter security business is soon to become an actuality.

Holy Cross marched steadily along the football victory trail today by trouncing Rhode Island State, 46 to 13, before 7,500 fans. It was the second 1938 conquest for the Crusaders, who were undefeated last year.

IF there has been any doubt that Leopold Stokowski was dissociating himself from the Philadelphia Orchestra, a bit of news last week should have been sufficient to dispel it. Eugene Or mandy has been made music di rector of the organization and has been given a new three-year eontract extending from 1938 to 1941.

Still half-dazed by the machine-gun like rapidity of the week's events, half exhausted by the nervous strain of preparing for a sudden, unexpected threat to the nation's life, the British people now are recovering their breath again.

Virginia's eleven registered two touchdowns in the first quarter to defeat Washington and Lee today, 13 to 0. A long pass, Cardoza to Gillette, produced the first score, and Sargeant booted the extra point. Cardoza raced 35 yards through tackle for the second touchdown.

Unable longer to watch the agony of his wife, dying of a stomach cancer, Harry C. Johnson, retired gasoline distributor, asphyxiated her with illuminating gas this morning in their home. Authorities termed the case a "mercy killing."
Terrors or the darkened streets of Paris disappeared in a blaze of light in the principal boulevards tonight as airraid preparations were removed by official orders.

With thirty-three States and Puerto Rico committed to participate in the World's Fair on the Flushing Meadows next year and $2,500,000 appropriated for their exhibits, Grover Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation, estimated yesterday a minimum expenditure of $4,000,000 in the Court of States, where the exhibits will be situated.

Flashing American, chestnut gelding owned by Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Schiffer's Kilkare Farm of Elberon and Sheldon M. Stewart's chestnut mare Cedar Brook Kate Havlin captured the three and five-gaited saddie championships, respectively, of the thirteenth annual Montclair t Horse Show, which came to a close

A fighting Lehigh team made a thrilling last-period drive today to deadlock the Boston University eleven, 6-6. Seeking revenge for the setback of a year ago, the Engineers fought desperately all the way.
To the Art Editor: MAY I add to your argument another reason why I do not think European critics may be final judges of whether or not we have a native art? Most Europeans have

Maintaining the fast pace he set in the early rounds, Craig Wood of Rumson blasted his way to his fourth New Jersey P. G. A. championship today with a record-breaking seventy-twohole total of 279 at the Suburban Golf Club.

The Cubs, crippled but courageous, clinched their third. National League pennant in seven years by routing the Cards, 10 to 3, in the second game of a torrid double-header today while their only rivals, the Pirates, were losing in Cincinnati.
Mrs. Abbie L. McCune, widow of William G. McCune, former vice president and treasurer of the Otis Elevator Company, died Friday night at her home in Greens Farms, Conn. The daughter of Charles

The marriage of Miss Mary Briganti, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Domenico Briganti of this city, to Dr. Erhard Fernholz of Princeton, N. J., son of Rektor and Mrs. Gustav Fernholz of Hiddenhausen, Westphalia, Germany, took place yesterday afternoon at the University heights PresbYterian Church.
Villanova, undefeated in ten games last year, opened its 1938 season today with a 59-0 victory over American International College of Springfield, Mass.
The behavior of the audience at this week's new Palladium vaudeville show, "These Foolish Things," threw a revealing light on the British public's attitude to approaching danger.

WHEN pigeons were first used in races or as quick bearers of messages history does not make clear. Solomon is said to have raced pigeons for sport. Cyrus, King of the Medes and Persians, used them in war.

Pausing to take stock after ten years of experimental drama, the Laboratory Theatre at Mount Holyoke College, under the leadership of Professor Jeannette Marks, finds its influence penetrating far into the homes and work of its graduates.

Problems facing the industrial executives and foremen of business plants, viewed in the light of changing labor conditions, were analyzed yesterday by leaders in industrial relations and plant management at an all-day conference-under sponsorship of the New York Association of Foremen's Clubs at the Hotel Astor.

With the National League completing its whirlwind, last-minute shift in standard bearers, the decks were cleared yesterday for action in the 1938 world series, which moves swiftly on the stage this week as baseball's farewell contribution of the year.

Promotion of a nation-wide bowling contest in 1937 and 1938 by the Brunswick-Balke-Collender Company of Chicago was undertaken "to create in the respondent company a monopoly in the manufacture and sale of bowling equipment," the Federal Trade Commission alleged in a complaint filed against the firm today.

The City Council has been asked by the State Board of Housing to grant partial tax exemption to worthy limited-dividend housing projects, particularly to-a proposed project in Brooklyn on a site owned by the Polytechnic Institute, it was revealed yesterday by Louis H. Pink, chairman of the board.

The third-quarter statements of the big Wall Street banks will begin to appear with a rush tomorrow. It is not hard to guess what they will show-enormous amounts of idle cash, large investments in government securities, which stand next to cash in liquidity and only just above it in earning power, and a pitifully small volume of the loans and discounts which are traditionally supposed to constitute the backbone of a bank's earning assets.

ACCORDING to Mr. Tisdall and other authorities. the House of Hanover has been human as well as royal. Not only were the princes masculine. Queen Victoria. at any rate, was "feminine." Elizabeth Tudor herself was not more mildly and modestly man-conscious.

The fine arts lectures and entertainments at Clark University, established and conducted by Professor Loring H. Dodd of the Deapartment of English and Art, will be held this year in the new theatre now nearing completion.

The engagement of Miss Marcia Elizabeth Ellis has been announced by her mother, Mrs. Dorothy R. Ellis of this place and Haddam, Conn., to Ensign Lewis Olcott Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank T. Davis of Middletown, Conn.

SINCE the recent announcement that about 17,000 of New York's high-school students would take a trip around Manhattan Island in pursuance of a regular course of the Department of Education's school curriculum, an increasing number of New Yorkers who have never seen the waterfront from the vantage of a boat have taken up the idea themselves.

To eliminate the trouble of bothering with screens when opening and closing casement windows, special attachments that permit quick and complete operation of the outward swinging casements without interference from any source have been developed, points out the Metal Window Institute.

Desplie tne tact that production of refrigerators this year has been cut about 50 per cent, retail sales volume since the start of 1937 has been reduced only about 30 per cent, according to distributors here yesterday.

The Haring Blumenthal firm announced yesterday that two offers to purchase the furnished model house opened last Sunday in the Wilmot Woods home community in the Scarsdale-Heathcote section of New Rochelle, Westchester County, had been made a few hours after the dwelling had been formally opened for public inspection. More than 1,000 visitors

There was no aggressive selling of wheat today in North American markets and brokers expressed the belief that holdings of futures accumulated during the war scare had been well liquidated. Prices held within narrow limits. The market averaged lower

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Cecil Elizabeth Pendleton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Culpeper Pendleton of this city, to Dr. John Edward Fissel Jr., also of Newport News, son of Mrs. John E. Fissel of Baltimore and the late Mr. Fissel.

The desirability and income of many apartment houses, pointed out a management expert, may be enhanced by the addition of a garage compound of sufficient capacity to house the automobiles of tenants. Such an improvement is not difficult to make where there is ample unused lot space at the rear of the plot.
A belated "Save Czechoslovakia From the Zero Hour" parade was held here yesterday with 12,000 to 15,000 persons, according to a police estimate, in the line of march.
George C. Rice, investment broker and former sports writer, died yesterday at his home, 5,555 Sheridan Road. He was 67 years old and a native of Waukesha, Wis.
A combination built-in window seat and bookshelf adds attractiveness and utility to the living rooms of many small houses. It is particularly adapted for recessed windows.

Dr. and Mrs. Curran Bertram Earle of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Curran Earle, to Claiborn McDowell Carr Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Carr of Hewlett, L. I. Miss Earle attended Furman University here and was graduated in 1937 from Sarah Lawrence College in Bronxville. N. Y.

MUCH that Mr. Cane has written has been in the tradition of the Imagist school The scene is brief and laconic, the color sense acute, the pattern and rhythm often that of the Japanese "haikai," and the short poem has "no comment" on its cosmic meaning.
A large proportion of the leases in the new fourteen-story Goodhue apartment house on the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, in the Murray Hill section, are being made to
Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said today that it had authorized loans to eleven public agencies in cooperation with grants by PWA.

Scoring in every period, the Baldwin High School football team opened its season by turning back Hicksville, 25-7, today. Bobby Munn, halfback, led the Golden wave attack wih two touchdowns. The line-un:

Raphael Boudreau, who never has missed a try-for-point in three years of college play, delivered the goods again today and Oklahoma's Sooners upset vaunted Rice Institute, 7-6, before 18,000 stunned, perspiring fans. Just before half-time he

A cruise on the Hudson's Bay Company relief ship Nascopie through 12,000 miles of ice-laden waters of the North has been completed by a 75-year-old woman, who was greeted at Fort Ross as the oldest white person to set foot on that lonely outpost in the Northwest Passage.

Laying of cornerstone, new hospital of Haym Salomon Home for the Aged, 43 St. Marks Place, noon. Speakers: Mayor La Guardia, Commissioner Paul Moss B. Charney Vladeck, Dr. William Sirovich, Rabbi M. Kaplan.

Nathan S. Jonas, founder of the Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities and retiring president of the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn, was the guest of honor last night at a dinner and ball of the Jewish Hospital at the Waldorf-Astoria,

Complete confidence in the ability of the Democratic State ticket, headed by Governor Herbert H. Lehman, to defeat Thomas E. Dewey and his running-mates is being expressed privately as well as publicly by Democratic leaders in the State.

Robert K. Henry, coalition candidate who won the Democratic nomination for Governor, withdrew from the race tonight to leave Julius P. Heil, Republican, alone in the field against Governor Philip F. La Follette.

The City Fusion party announced yesterday a Bronx slate headed by Howard C. Kelly and George Galvatore, both Independents, as candidates for the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District. Municipal Court Justice Matthew M. Levy, American Labor party incumbent, was named as a candidate for re-election.

WHEN the German troops marched into Vienna, it seemed at first as though the existence was threatened of those Dutch and Swiss publishing houses in which the German emigre authors had their books published in German.

With an awesome display of that power for which it is famous, Pittsburgh ran roughshod over Temple before the startled gaze of 41,728 spectators in the Temple Stadium today and crushed the Owls, 28 to 6. There was just nothing to it.

Emerging as an innovation in the traditional details of registration on the Cornell University campus is the organization of a Bureau of Recreational Interests under the guidance or the board of managers of Willard Straight Hall, the student union.

Theodore Roosevelt intervened to make peace in the Russo-Japanese War despite his own profound conviction that to do so was a mistake and that it would be better for the future peace of the world to allow the two nations to fight to the point of utter exhaustion, it was asserted yesterday.

Members of the floor committee for the annual Tuxedo Autumn ball to be held Oct. 22 at the Tuxedo Club were announced today by Mrs. S. Sloan Colt, chairman of the ball committee. Angler Biddle Duke is chairman of the floor committee.
The University of Pennsylvania's "New Deal" in football under the youthful head coach, George Munger, made a brilliant start today when the Quakers swamped Lafayette, 34 to 6.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were in somewhat smaller volume than in the preceding period, individual announcements being almost wholly for small sums of outstanding issues. Notices were principally for municipal bonds, although the largest single retirements were in the foreign and industrial fields. Several of the calls were for October payment, but most were for payment in later months.

Not in half a century had a Pacific Coast colt come over the mountains to take the Futurity, but it happened yesterday when W. E. Boeing's Porter's Mite, the world record holder for six and a half furlongs, sped down the Widener chute to score by a nose before 25,000 in the world's richest juvenile race. Basil (Rocky Mountain)

Already 5,000 crippled children, or one-quarter of the estimated total in New York City, have been registered with the city Commission for the Study of Crippled Children, which began work several weeks ago, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Philip D. Wilson, chairman of the commission.

Now that the first moment of exultation over the Munich conference has passed, the Italian press shows a very decided tendency to throw cold water on the hopes of those who believe that Munich will be made the starting point for other agreements between the four Western European powers.

Amherst and Springfield opened their football seasons today on Pratt Field in a hard-fought game that resulted in a 6-6 tie. Capitalizing on an intercepted pass by their ace fullback, Al Furman, the Jeffs made short work of converting it into a touchdown and taking a first period 6-0 lead.

A $500,000 television transmitter is being installed by the Columbia Broadcasting System atop the Chrysler Building at an additional ccst of $150,000. Completion is scheduled for the early part of 1939, but no date has been set to begin operations.

Three large homesite tracts on Remington Road in the new residential section of Munsey Park at Manhasset, Nassau County, L. I., have been purchased by James D. Tullin, builder, for early improvement with fine homes.

In remodeling the basement to install a recreation or play room careful consideration is advised to the lighting and ventilation. A play room with insufficient natural light and poor ventilation will probably not only be unhealthful but will lack the appeal of a sunlighted room.

Montclair State Teachers College was held to a scoreless tie today in its opening game of the football season by Arnold College of New Haven, Conn. The Montclair eleven drove to the 5-yard line in the closing minutes, but a fumble ended the threat.

Lowell Textile scored in every period today and overwhelmed Panzer College, 39 to 0, in a brilliant exhibition of aerial football. The local Millmen, surprise conquerers of New Hampshire a week 5. ago, started flinging passes early and completed four of the first six tosses for two touchdowns before the first period was half done. They were never pressed.

A group representing the New York Curb Exchange, headed by Fred C. Moffatt, its president, met today with William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and Ganson Purcell, director of the commission's trading and exchange division, concerning plans for reorganization of the Exchange. After the conference neither side would comment on the deliberations.

The system of housing construction recently developed by Eugene Mopin, French civil engineer, which is said to result in marked reductions in the cost of housing projects and better organization of construction, is described in a report prepared by the Works Progress Administration in New York City.
A proclamation issued by Mayor La Guardia yesterday set aside Oct. 1 to Oct. 9, inclusive, as National Air Travel Week to commemorate ten years of successful passenger transportation by air.

Illinois, stopped last week by Ohio University, came back today with a powerful running attack which netted 347 yards from scrimmage, sixteen first downs and a 44-to-7 victory over De Paul University of Chicago.
Supply contracts valued at $9,999,083 were awarded during the week ended Sept. 29 by eleven Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contract Act, the Labor Department announced today.

Judge McDevitt today imposed maximum sentences totaling 363 years on eleven members of two hold-up gangs. Nine of the prisoners, ranging in ages between 21 and 38, were members of a band that had plotted to hold up the office of the receiver of taxes.

The National Association of Housing Officials with headquarters at Chicago, will hold its sixth annual convention at the Wardman Park Hotel, Washington, D. C., Oct. 11 to 14, inclusive, it was announced yesterday by Coleman Woodbury, director.

Carnegie: Tech unfolded a devastating offensive in its 1938 gridiron debut today to crush Davis and Elkins, 49 to 0, while a small crowd of about 8,000 looked on from the vast reaches of Pitt Stadium.
Johnny Daggett and Clyde Hatch paced Colby to a surprising 23-0 victory over Tufts today. Both got away for several long runs and each was either on the throwing or receiving end of touchdown passes.
Army defeated Virginia Polytechnic Institute, 39 to 0, on the gridiron today. The teams had met only once before, in 1905, when the Southerners came here and won from the Cadets, 16 to 6.

LONDON. IN the center of Berry's Wine Shop, historic St James's Street rendezvous, Stand scales which have recorded the weight of famous men and women of the past and present and have stood the test of time for four centuries.

Georgetown University opened its sixty-third football season today with a 51-to-0 victory over Hampden Sydney College. The first score came as a result of successive line plunges by Castiglia. He also rammed the ball over for the extra point.
ON an elevation commanding a view of the surrounding coun tryside, a new residence was completed recently at Reldyes and Hazlett Avenues, Leonia, N. J., for Edward Cupaioli.

The estate of George W. Crawford, late head of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, amounted to about $25,000,000, according to an accounting filed with the Register of Wills today. He died in 1935, leaving most of his fortune to his widow, Annie Laurie Crawford, and his daughter, Martha Sharp Crawford.

Increased consumer demand for covered-shoulder and true dinner types of formal apparel is the outstanding point revealed in an analysis of September apparel sales prepared by Lord Taylor.

With very little fanfare and fewer than 6,000 fans present, the little world series opened today with a 3-0 triumph for the Kansas City Blues over the Newark Bears, Kemp Wicker southpawing his way through the neat shut-out.

ACCUSTOMED as we are to the roundabout machinations of that most persistent of human scourges, the pass seeker, we are compelled to acknowledge the originality of the gentleman who telephoned a local movie house last week, using what we can only describe as the pigeon approach.
The sportsmen of this area could not have asked for a finer day for the opening of the woodcock season, and the light rain which fell last night made perfect working conditions for the dogs.

William A. Morris, 52 years old, of 50 Welton Street, here, the brother of Prosecutor Charles M. Morris and prominent for thirty years in Republican circles, was killed accidentally in his home today when a double-barreled shotgun he was cleaning was discharged and

The proposal last week of Senator Key Pittman of Nevada, leader of the silver bloc in this country, that the huge cotton surplus be disposed of in foreign markets by the government offering to exchange ten pounds of the staple for one ounce of silver opens a new phase of the silver question.

Dr. Charles T. Haines, a practicing physician here for forty-two years and a vice president of the Associated Anesthetists of the United States and Canada, died last night of heart disease. His age was 75.

BESET by the anxiety arising from the European crisis, storms and their aftermath and crippling strikes, trade struggled along last week but doubtless suffered a setback. Now that the threat of war abroad seems removed, merchants count on much freer buying as a natural response to the general feeling of relief.

SAN REMO. MILAN'S Summer outdoor op era bill at the Sforza Castle consisted, this year, of "Aida," "Boheme," "Lucia," Latuada's "Don Giovanni," "Cavalleria" bracketed with Vittadini's ballet "Vecchia Milano," "Tosca," Pietri's "Maristella,' "Chrnier," "Gioconda," "Rigolet. to" and "Traviata."

Conway Tearle, aged 60, stage and screen actor, died of a heart ailment in a hospital tonight. He had been ill for two weeks. After appearances on London and New York stages, Mr. Tearle entered motion pictures in 1914 and achieved stardom.

CABO VERDE, Changchow-fu, Schleswig-Holstein, Zuffenhausen, Adrianopolis, Popo catepetl and British Somaliland may be just vague tonguetwisting gazetteer names to the average copy-desk writer, but to the newsreel editor, who orders the cranking of the world's events as they transpire, they are spots that require no atlas consultation when anything important happens.

Announcement has been made by Captain and Mrs. Eugene Tuttle Scudder of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Scudder, to DeForest Barkley Voorhees, son of Mr. and Mrs. George E. Voorhees of Montclair.

Polo activity on Long Island today centered around two practice games on the Phipps estate, which included many high-goal stars. Two are members of the open championship Old Westbury quartet, which will defend its Monty Waterbury title on International Field tomorrow against the Aknusti four at 3 o'clock.

A well-dressed man, about 60 years old, in whose pockets the police subsequently found $1,860.50, was killed at about 6:55 o'clock last night by a northbound train of the Second Avenue elevated line, on the tracks of the station at First Street and First Avenue.

THE initials "H. M." are by now so well known to mystery connoisseurs that it is scarcely necessary to state that their owner is known as Sir Henry Merrivale on formal occasions. if any such there be in his tumultuous life. for H. M.
