Miss Ruth May Barron, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Barron of Branford, Conn., was married to Henry F. McHenry of this city yesterday afternoon in the Church of Our Lady of the Scapular of Mount Carmel here by the Rev. Stephen McGleenen.

Examinations for teaching licenses in applied science, applied electricity and industrial processes have been scheduled by the Board of Examiners, it was announced yesterday. Fifty positions are open in the fields of automotive trades, building trades, cosmetology, electrical trades, food trades, graphic arts, metal trades and needle trades. Applications must be filed at 500 Park Avenue by Oct. 17.

The foreign-exchange market weakened yesterday after its spectacular recovery of the previous two days. Profit taking and the normal tendency of the market to close out commitments at the week-end were responsible for the declines, but they were small in comparison with the rally that had preceded.

FOR most of us Icarus-the effort of Icarus-represents something cleanwinged, shining in failure, imperious in aspiration. Mr. Morris has dramatized that tradition and endowed it with a casual. homely grace that gives his modest novel an unusual quality.
A ninth Zephyr light-weight, streamlined train is to be added to the equipment of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad, Ralph Budd, president, announced yesterday.
INTERSTATE: The friendly rivalry between Maine and Idaho as potatogrowing States was given official recognition last weekk in the form of a potato-picking

Living theatre, professionally produced, and featuring Shakespeare, Ibsen and Goldsmith, will be presented before New York's high school students during the current school year. The program of classical plays has been developed jointly by the Board of Education and the WPA Federal Theatre, it was announced yesterday by George Kondolf, local project director.
Sunshine after The blackest of storms had threatZened. Peace after nights of bad dreams. There is the European situation as this week closes. Will the Sunshine last?

The four-acre estate at Croton, N. Y., of Harold Gray, cartoonist and creator of "Little Orphan Annie," will be offered at auction on the premises on Oct. 12 by William Kennelly, auctioneer. It overlooks the Hudson River and is two miles from the New York Central Railroad station at Harmon.

The German War Ministry was inclined to be first indignant and then a little contemptuous today on learning that American morning newspapers had asserted on information sent out by two news agencies under a Berlin date line that the German advance into Czechoslovakia had crossed the border soon after midnight.
Miss Grace Keator will relate the experiences of her sight-seeing trip to England this Summer at meeting tomorrow night of the Blind Woman's Club, of which she is honorary president.

Wallpaper, which for a time was threatened to be relegated to more or less oblivion, is making an astonishing comeback and many dealers are finding a strong demand for it, points out Albert Mayer, architect and member of the advisory committee of the City Planning Commission.

Delegates from eleven locals formerly affiliated with the Workers Alliance and from four independent groups of WPA workers and home relief recipients met yesterday at 79 East Tenth Street and formed a new city-wide organization.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete version of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES receive a great

The extension of the church into new and untried fields will be the major consideration at the biennial convention of the United Lutheran Church in America, which will meet in Baltimore from Oct. 5 to Oct. 12.

A total of $24,691,800 damage was done to private and public property in Suffolk County by the hurricane of Sept. 21, County Superintendent of Highways Hermon F. Bishop estimated today in the first comprehensive survey of the effects of Long Island's worst storm.
The age-old saying that "women talk the most but men talk the best" has the endorsement of Clyde W. Dow, specialist in speech at Massachusetts State College.

Several, of the units in the Linden Gardens apartment house development under construction at the corner of St. Georges Avenue and Stiles Street, Linden, N. J., will be completed about Nov. 1, it was announced yesterday.

Vera Hruba, 18-year-old champion exhibition skater of Czechoslovakia, who arrived yesterday on the French liner Paris with her mother, said that her father and her brother had been called to the colors and that she would rather have had war than have her country yield to the demands of Hitler.
Jimmy Wilson resigned today as manager of the Philadelphia National League club, declaring his action was for the "best interests of all concerned."

THOUGH audiences have developed a habit of walking into the street during intervals to discover whether the bombs have begun to drop and whether our Prime Minister is at the moment in Downing Street or Berchtesgaden, the theatre is extremely active. "Serena Blandish"
The University of Rochester, after having lost ten games, opened its 1938 football season today with a 6-6 tie against Oberlin College today.

The twenty-third National Recreation Congress will open in the William Penn Hotel, Pittsburgh, tomorrow and will continue through Friday. Held under the auspices of the National Recreation Association, the congress provides a clearing house for persons interested in community recreation.

Miss Lois Catherine Swartman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Swartman of this city, was married here this morning in Trinity Episcopal Church to Richard A. Wright Jr., son of Mrs. Richard A. Wright of Flushing, L. I., and the late Mr. Wright.

Money, the most nimble-footed of all refugees, has been in full flight before the threat of war in Europe. Since midsummer a torrent of gold has been pouring in upon us from abroad and in the past few weeks, as the tension over the Czechoslovak crisis increased, the inrush of foreign capital, according to the Secretary of the Treasury, Henry Morgenthau Jr., reached recordbreaking proportions.
Work has been started on the new home of the Church of the Epiphany at the northwest corner of York Avenue and Seventy-fourth Street, and the cornerstone exercises have been set for Oct. 16.
The Munich conference, by removing one great cause of European strife, rendered, in the Italian view, a signal service to the cause of peace.

Prizes will be awarded for the best diaries kept of experiences on their first jobs on Tuesday evening, when seventeen young women graduates of last June hold their first reunion dinner at University House, 106 East Fiftysecond Street.

Auctioneershave disposed of the Duke of Windsor's fine herd of Shorthorn cattle, realizing $10,000 on seventy head for the royal owner of the EP branch in the foothills of Alberta'a southern rangeland.

A number of Westchester woman's clubs open their season this week with meetings whose topics range from literature to current affairs. "Eccentricities of Genius" is the title of a talk James B. Pond will give to the Dobbs Ferry Woman's Club tomorrow afternoon at the Ardsley Country Club.

Gerhard von Koschembahr, a former German State Railway official who left Germany four years ago to live in Switzerland, arrived yesterday on the French liner Paris with his wife, ten children and a governess and eighty-seven pieces of baggage to take up a permanent residence in the United States.
The Worcester Evening Post, in its final edition today, announced suspension of publication of the paper, effective with today's issue. The paper has been in existence forty-seven years.
Beckie Dale, 2-year-old pacing filly from the Newbrook Stables, and Danny Return, trotting gelding owned by Willow Brook Farms, won the feature events of the weekly matinee at Weequahic Park today.
THE New Jersey masters' pair tournament, usually well attended and often won by New York players, will be held at the Essex House in Newark on Friday and Saturday.

WITH this lively, if somewhat loquacious, yarn the saga of Red Clark o' Tulluco has run through its fifth volume, and he is still the same likable, though wild, light-hearted, devil-maycare, fast-shooting cowboy about whose venturing into dangerous situations Western fans like to read. Red rides over to Nelplaid.

An appropriation of $9,469,000 for home-relief during October has been voted by the Board of Estimate as the result of a special meeting called by Mayor La Guardia in City Hall. The amount is $300,000 less than the appropriation for September, with the difference attributed to recent increases in transfers from home-relief to WPA.

Leaf tobacco exports from the United States for the first eight months of this year were substantially greater than for the corresponding periods of 1937 and 1936, the Department of Commerce reported today.
Polish troops tomorrow will march into the Teschen area following Poland's determination tO enter the "land beyond the Olza" simultaneously with the entry of the German Army into the Sudetenland.

At the Midwest agricultural clinic at Hutchinson on Thursday, Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, discovered that the wheat pulse is high, especially when the grower is advised that he may have another year of 40-cent wheat unless the acreage is curtailed.

Heroines of the struggle for the enfranchisement of women will be hailed as a legion of honor by the National Woman's party, whose biennial convention opens at the Book-Cadillac Hotel in Detroit on Friday evening.

A net loss of $252,579 in the fiscal year ended on June 30, in contrast to a net profit of $53,589 in the preceding year, was reported today to stockholders of the APW Paper Company here by Dwight G. W. Hollister, president. Mr. Hollister attributed the loss to a severe decline in general business activity, coupled with increased costs of raw material and labor. Gross sales for the year were given as $3,019,464.

THE young Irish intellectuals who fought in the AngloIrish War got to know, understand and love the Irish people. They wandered in and out of the houses of the people in both country and city, they ate, slept and hid with them.

ALL young children respond, as all children should, to nonsense, and if boys and girls make the acquaintance of genuine nonsense early, they acquire a taste which they will keep all their lives to their infinite enjoyment.
The fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 898 West End Avenue, southeast corner of 104th Street, is now fully rented, according to Gordon S. Braislin, Inc., agents.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-The recent tropical storm, which played havoc with many of the coastal cities, overlooked Atlantic City, and this resort, enjoying warm Autumn sunshine, is entertaining many early Fall visitors.

A perfect day for football, sunny but cool. The Columbia squad was first on the field. Lou Little, Cliff Battles, Sam Cordovano and A-nthony the Red Matal walked around the field, testing the footing of the turf and watching the practice exercises of the Lions. The Yale squad rushed out and did limbering-up stunts before tossing and kicking the football around.

LONG before Columbus made his great voyage a "Stone Age people had crossed the Pacific from continent to continent across its widest part, and had colonized every habitable island within its vast interior."

FOR the first time in the history of the growth of Oriental collections in American museums -- and the growth of such collections has been astonishing the last ten years-a portfolio illustrating outstanding museum examples has been published.
AMERICAN democracy, as Professor Counts sees it, is in a pretty bad way. Where, a generation ago, it seemed triumphant it is today on the defensive or in retreat.
Final arrangements are now being made for the thirteenth annual Monmouth County Hunt race meet, which will be held in the afternoon of Oct. 15 on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Amory L. Haskell here.

Miss Maridel Saunders, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Paul Hill Saunders of this place and New Orleans, was married tonight to Philip Hack, son of Mrs. Bessie F. Hack of Memphis and New Orleans, in Christ's Episcopal Church here.
Mark the free-riding Carabineros of the towns and open country of Chile as ever dangerous contenders in any military event in which they may appear on this continent.

AN ultra-short-wave broadcasting station is being built by the Board of Education of Cleveland, Ohio, as a result of the FCC opening up twenty-five such channels for educational purposes. The 500-watt station will operate on 41.5 megacycles.

Northwestern, with designs on the Western Conference football championship, opened its season today by smothering Kansas State, 21 to 0, before 35,000 spectators. Northwestern, with superior power and speed, combined a bruising running game and tricky forward passes to achieve its victory.

A 107-lot tract of land adjacent to Congress Park, Port Chester, Westchester County, will be improved with a group of homes by Colonial Park, Inc., developers of the Mayfair Acres and Chappaqua Farms developments in Greenburgh and Chappaqua respectively, it was announced yesterday.
Connecticut's monetary loss in the recent hurricane, which was accompanied by tidal waves along the shore and major floods in the river valleys, is now being estimated at $100,000,000.

Should the American people have the right to vote on sending American troops abroad? That question, embodied in the Ludlow amendment, precipitated one of the most heated debates of the last session of Congress, and it is likely to be heard again when the new Congress comes to Washington this Winter.

Paced by Jack Nix. junior halfback, the Mississippi State College football team rolled over Florida, 22-0, today. The Maroons were never in danger. Nix took a 35-yard pass from Sonny Bruce on the 3 and stepped over for a first-period score.

The engagement of Miss Grace Frances Minty, daughter of Mrs. Mary Minty of Lake Arrowhead and the late Dr. Arthur W. Minty, to Charles Fern Hopkins Fisher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin A. Fisher of Boonton, has been announced.
Miss Abigail Rozelle Bolger of Cleveland and Albert Lee Hawes of New York were married here this afternoon in St. Paul's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Dr. Walter R. Breed.

Industry, labor and trade associations are being canvassed by the Republican National Committee for their reactions to the Administration's reciprocal trade program in a "confidential" survey intended to supply the party with the basis for suggestions covering the trade treaties in the 1940 Presidential campaign, it was learned here last week.

THE seventy ninth Worcester Music Festival will be held Oct. 3-8, at Worcester, Mass. Six programs are announced, at each of which the Worcester Festival Orchestra, conducted by Albert Stoessel, the festival's directoro, will appear. Choral works to be given with

In comparison with other years surprisingly few important New Deal matters face the Supreme Court, meeting on Monday for the annual eight-months term. Yet upon the calendar is a subject of tremendous significance to the Administration.

NOW that Vienna has learned to think with its blood, as the Nazis say, another wave of refugees has washed up on the shores of the democracies. Among them is Professor Sigmund Freud, founder of psychoanalysis and one of the most original of contemporarv thinkers. A life-long Viennese and

The threat of war in Europe failed to stem the mounting tide of economic recovery in this country, the Chamber of Commerce of the United States reported in the leading article of its Washington Review, published today. The gradual, sustained rise in business activity, first apparent in July, held to the end of September, and the slump was viewed as having terminated its downward movement last June.
HEINRICH HAUSER is a young man who neither links with the German novelists of pre-war days nor with the Nazi Germany of today. The publisher states that
MORE illustrators want to work on "The Tempest" than on any other of Shakespeare's plays, the Limited Editions Club has decided.
Bill McCann led the Iona Prep School to victory over the Ossining High School eleven today by a 20-6 score. Al Incognito scored the first touchdown, sending the visitors into a 6-0 lead.

How the German military mind assessed its chances in the event of war was disclosed yesterday by Colonel William J. Donovan, who returned recently from a trip to Europe during which he watched a display of the Reich's land and air strength in the manoeuvres at Nuremberg and then saw them tested under fire in Spain.
DAVID SACKSON, violinist, and Julius Chajes, pianist, will begin a series of three sonata programs this afternoon, thus more or less officially opening the new recital season at Town Hall.

Miss Charlotte Eugenia Conway, daughter of Mrs. Lysander B. Conway and the late Mr. Conway, was martried here this evening at Laurel Cliff, the home of her mother, to Dr. Francis JosephCurran of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Curran of Minneapolis. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas Walsh of St. Mary's Church, Norfolk.
Mr. and Mrs. Herbert A. Ehrmann gave a tea at their home here today, at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Louise Ehrmann, to Jay (Moody Worsfold.

Miss Natalie Fuller, daughter of Mrs. Seymour Keyes Fuller of this place and the late Mr. Fuller, was married here this afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church to Richard Moulton Howland, son of Professor George Carter Howland of the University of Chicago and Mrs. Howland.

President Roosevelt closed his desk today and took a special train for an overnight run to Hyde Park, where he will rest a few days. He may extend his stay to a week or more before returning to the capital, if conditions warrant.
Rensselaer Tech's football team defeated Hamilton College, 14 to 6, in the season's opener for both colleges today. It was a hard-fought game all the way.
THE biggest ocean liner in the world so far, the Queen Elizabeth, launched at Clydebank last Tuesday, will soon be in the hands of decorators.

The Yankees' hopes of winning 100 games this season vanished at Fenway Park today when they were decisively defeated by the second-place Red Sox, 9 to 2. The world champions gathered only four widely scattered hits off young Jim Bagby.

Seventy-five Union College freshmen visited Skidmore College today for the first of the series of Skidmore-Union freshmen parties which for the last three years have been a feature of the freshman programs at these neighboring colleges.

Miss Helen De Witt Arbuckle, daughter of Mrs. De Witt Arbuckle of Bloomfield, was married this evening to Joseph George Richards of Washington, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Van Slyke Richards of New York.

Academia honors for the Spring semester at Manhattan College have been awarded to 194 members of the student body, it was announced yesterday. Fifty-two students were cited for first honors, while 142 received second-honor ranking. The School of Liberal Arts topped the list with twenty-two honor men.
Senator Burke of Nebraska predicted today that Congress would be called upon to modify the Wages and Hours Law before the 40-hour workweek provision went into effect.

Creation of adequate national reserves of basic ores, including strategic minerals, foodstuffs and fiber crops of domestic origin will be discussed at the National Congress of Industry and Raw Materials at Sioux City, Iowa, Nov. 14, 15 and 16.

DURING the hurricane that lashed New York and New England recently, four of the major domestic air lines operating out of the metropolitan area pooled equipment to set what is believed to be a record for the handling of air passengers. With railroad, bus

Miss Helen Margaret wood, aaugnter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Owens Wood of East Orange, was married this evening in Munn Avenue Presbyterian Church here, to George Beard Walker of Oshkosh, Wis. The pastor, the Rev. Robert Brewster Beattie, officiated.

The Navy, scoring two touchdowns on passes from Lem Cooke to Captain Pete Powell and Lou Burke, the ends, within six minutes of the start of the game, and single touchdowns in the third and final quarters, won from Virginia Military Institute today,' 26 to 0.

CHEROKEE, N. C.-The reenactment of ancient rites and traditional ceremonies of the eastern band of Chero kee Indians will take place on their original hunting grounds in the shadow of the Great Smoky Mountains when the annual Cherokee fair will be staged Oct. 4-7 on the reservation.

St. Joseph's Church was decorate with ferns and white Autumn flowers for the marriage here this morning of Miss Gladys Adelaide Durand, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Celestin A. Durand of this city, ?? George A. Corroon, New York broker and son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Corroon of Massapequa.

Mr. and Mrs. William A. P. MacKnight of Germantown have announced the engagement' of their daughter, Miss Bettie Frances MacKnight, to Reed Knox Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Knox of Deland, Fla., formerly of Pittsburgh and.Valley Forge.

The Department of Agriculture announced today a series of liberalized wheat loan regulations designed to allow farmers to obtain benefits of market premiums on the high protein wheat and high quality durum wheat.

President Roosevelt exerted the moral influence of the United States for peace between Poland and Czechosiovakia, as he did between the other European powers earlier in the week, it was disclosed today by Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

THE tropical hurricane which recently struck the Northeast took that region by surprise, but Florida, during the Fall, is always ready for storms. Houses are built low and strong; storm-proof shutters and doors are quickly available.

The Citizens Savings Bank has leased for a branch office the large corner store in the General Electric Building at 570 Lexington Avenue, southwest corner of Fifty-first Street, through the brokerage firm of Cushman Wakefield.

The threat of a European war has seriously affected the Junior Year Abroad plan, under which several New Jersey College for Women students since 1927 have spent their third undergraduate year in France, Germany and Spain.

A new residence for all-year occupancy at Packanack Lake in the Boonton section of New Jersey has been purchased by George W. Herrington, formerly of North Bergen, reports Ira C. Jones, sales manager. The house is on Beechwood Drive in the lake community's colonial residential section. It was designed by the architectural firm of McMurray Schmidlin of Union.

Mayor La Guardia and a group of city officials will give course No. 1 on the program of the New School for Social Research, an institution of adult learning at 66 West Twelfth Street, which enters its twentieth year with the opening of the Fall semester tomorrow.
Mrs. Lena Clough of Peoria, Ill., is the first woman to graft a pig's tail to an apple tree, she announced tonight at the third annual Illinois liars' contest.
Thomas E. Dewey's debut on a stage considerably larger than New York County brings to mind a favorite subject of public

California rolled over Washinngton State, 27-3, today, with brilliant Vic Bottari the star performer. The Bear halfback was responsible for three touchdowns in the first half. He tossed the pass Morley Mathewson gathered in on the 55 for a touchdown. He threw a lateral to

Prince Johann Nepomuk of Schwartzenberg head of a famous Austrian family, which before the World War was among the largest landowners in Europe, died today in his Vienna palace after a long illness. He Was 78 years old.
On a footing of musicianship, the Committee for the Recognition of Women in the Musical Profession has formulated definite plans to level the barriers against "mixed" symphony orchestras, opening the
Modern education is conceived in terms of life today. Broadly speaking, the activities of this life fall under two headings, work and recreation, both essential to a satisfying existence.

In the shoot at the Jamaica Bay traps of the Bergen Beach Gun Club yesterday R. H. Helsel, L. Hunt and G. C. Schwalb finished with 49 out of 50 each. Helsel won the extra string with a run of 25. Hunt and Schwalb each had 24.

Connecticut State defeated Wesleyan, by 13-5, today for its first football triumph over the Middletown forces in seven years. Daddario, injured Cardinal captain, paced his team through the first half, but after running for three consecutive first downs He was forced out.

Jack Sharkey Jr., 134 3/4 pounds, Union City, N. J., was declared the winner over Phil Baker, 136, Stamford, Conn., in their scheduled main bout of eight rounds at the Ridgewood Grove in Brooklyn last night. Referee Joe Vaccarelli halted the bout in 1:40 of the fourth, disqualifying Baker for not trying.

Columbia High School's eleven gained a 7-to-6 victory today over Plainfield High School. Hoyt's drop-kick for a point after touchdown was the deciding factor after Weismiller took a lateral in the final period on the Plainfield 26-yard line and raced for a touchdown.
Rough Time returned to his home territory today and gave a six-furlong horse laugh at the old saying: "They never come back."
Two Lafayette juniors have been enrolled in Occidental College and two from the California college are here in an exchange student idea evolved by the heads of both educational institutions.
FOR ten years the thirty-six-mile Circumferential Parkway circling the eastern shores of Brooklyn and the outer edges of Queens County was a road on paper only, its cost, estimated at $28,000,000.

Under a headline "Toscanini Disappears," The Sunday Referee reported today that nothing had been heard of Arturo Toscanini, the famous conductor, since he bought a ticket for the United States aboard the Ile de France sailing on Sept. 15. The story aided that he did not make the voyage, although he did not cancel his passage.

A record number of high school seniors have entered this year's Good Citizenship Pilgrimage contest, according to reports received by Mrs. Henry M. Robert Jr., president general of the D. A. R. Thousands of high schools

FAR out in the Atlantic, twenty years ago this day, tragedy was in the making. Twelve camouflaged transports-eleven British, one Frenchwere following a submarine-dodging zigzag course, jammed with Americans bent on fighting in Europe but just now sickened and dying by the score.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain of Great Britain was attacked by speakers and twice booed by the audience at a meeting last night at Carnegie Hall under the auspices of the Youth Committee of the United Czechoslovak Societies.

THIS is a season when fashion reporting is a veritable joy. At every turn one is met with something that excites and stimulates the eye and the mind. There's not a moment's monotony in searching through the field and in writing about finds. This relates in a very special way to daytime separate dresses.

THE program originally scheduled for this hour has been canceled. .... Ladies and gentlemen, we now take you to Europe," and American listeners eavesdropping for the past three weeks on mobilization overseas sat back to listen, thankful that radio takes them to Europe only figuratively speaking on invisible waves.

IMMEDIATE financial success recorded by the new Thousand Is lands International Bridge in the first month of its existence will spur into activity the building of many similar projects, now held in abeyance, and will afford motorists convenient short cuts at various other points throughout the country, according to municipal planners and bridge builders.

The marriage of Miss Margery L. Andrew, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth E. Andrew of Hillside, to Lester Stevens Gibbs, son of Mrs. Grace H. Gibbs of West Lafayette, Ind., and the late Edwin C. Gibbs, took place this evening in the Westminster Presbyterian Church, Elizabeth. The pastor, the Rev. Dr. 0. W. Buschgen, performed the ceremony.

The four power Munich accord was branded "a peace without honor" by a number of rabbis in sermons here yesterday on the Sabbath of Repentance, preceding the Day of Atonement on Wednesday. Some rabbis, however, said that the price paid was not too great for peace.

The WPA purchase 'of clothing for distribution among those on relief has aroused national controversy. In the following article the Assistant Administrator of WPA gives his views of the transaction and its results.

Thirtynine National Youth Administration supervisors from as many States will attend two-week institute at Quoddy Village, Me., beginning Monday, and will receive training in supervising shopwork and resident centers.
The Social Science Research Council publishes today a study' of oldage pensions indicating that President Roosevelt's advisers have underestimated the cost of the New Deal's pension program.

More than 6,000 persons have been escorted on daily free art trips in New York City last year, it was announced yesterday in a report by the WPA Adult Education program of the New York Board of Education.

A meeting of the Adjacent Hunt Racing Association was held here this afternoon on the grounds of the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club. Mrs. James C. Clark, M. F. H., headed the race committee. The boxholders included Mr. and Mrs. A. T. Baldwin,

Led by Mitchell, Horne and Parker, and showing a smart air attack plus plenty of power along the ground, New Hampshire rolled over Bates, 22-6, today, chalking up sixteen first downs to seven for the home team.

Adrian Quist of Australia defeated Donald Budge, holder of all the world's leading tennis prizes, here today in the semi-finals of the annual Pacific Southwest- championships. The score was 7-5, 6-2, 5-7, 6-3.

Gilbert G. Thorne, who retired in 1926 as a director and senior vice president of the National Park Bank of New York, died last night at his home, The Orchards, in Lakeville, Conn., after a gradual decline incident to his age, 82 years.

Miss Margaret Cupitt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irvin M. Cupitt of this place, was married 'to Louis P. Struble Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis P. Struble of Bellevue, Pa., in the First Methodist Church today. The ceremony, performed by the Rev. John Wesley Lord, was followed by a reception at the Cupitt home.

DRAMA fugitives from the frown of London's Lord Chamberlain, British play censor, find sanctuary at the Gate Theatre, intimate odeon in Villiers Street seating a bare two hundred amusement prospectors. Admission fees range from $1.00 to $1.50, and engagements there are limited to six weeks, though there are records indicating that some of its exhibits have not weathered that gamut. It is to the Gate that

Alfred Duff Cooper, First Lord of the Admiralty, resigned from the British Cabinet today in protest against the "peace for our time" settlement that Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain reached with Chancellor Adolf Hitler at Munich.

Spanish Government spokesmen said today that machinery for the evacuation of foreign volunteers from Barcelona's army probably would start running next week, when a League of Nations' supervisory committee is expected to arrive.

A hard charging line, led by Captain Jerry Stein at center, combined with a driving backfield to give City College a 15-to-2 victory over the University of Buffalo in the opening football game at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday.
PLATINUM PRINTING is dead in this country, driven to the wall by the greater economy and dependability of other methods of making photographic prints. Now comes a new product

Though clearly superior, Cornell's Big Red football team, of which so much is expected, found itself pitted against a stubborn Colgate eleven today and in the end had to find contentment in a 15-6 victory. Both squads launched the 1938 gridiron campaign before 12,000 persons at Schoellkopf Field.
SERGE KOUSSEVITZKY begins his fifteenth season as conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra next Friday and Saturday, when that organization opens its fifty-eighth season in Boston, Mass.
SYDNEY, Australia. ONE of the least-known sports in the world and one of the most exciting is the bull racing, which takes place at Madura in the Netherlands East Indies.

On the gridiron where Clinton Frank won lasting fame among the great backs of football Sidney Luckman turned in one of the most remarkable performances of his career today to lead Columbia to a conclusive 27-14 victory over a disappointing Yale team in the Bowl.
In its most decisive victory in six years, East Orange High defeated Morristown High, 28 to 0, today. Nate Johnson scored three touchdowns.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., Oct. 3. SERGEANT-Nicholas J. Nagle, from 100th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in Bureau of Criminal Identification. PATROLMEN-Joseph Krajewskl, from 3d Precinct to 123d Precinct. Charles R. Morton, from 68th Precinct to 18th Division, assigned to duty as chauf feur.

Arab rebels suffered heavy casualties at the hands of British forces in Palestine today. In an engagement between a police patrol and Arab rebels at Ramallah, about ten miles north of Jerusalem, a British police officer was killed.
WITHOUT television, the radio audience of America during the past three weeks has watched the game of Old World diplomacy played in the air over the map of Europe.

IN these critical weeks, the world has been waiting as anxiously for the voice of Great Britain as it has for the pronouncements of Adolf Hitler. And once more, as often in the past, it has wondered about the British temperament and the British method.

Entering the second year of deferred rushing, with freshmen prevented from joining fraternities until the Spring, Colgate University is making an attempt this Fall to give the first year men some of the social and cultural advantages which they miss by not being in a fraternity.
A "long-range" development program for Battery Park and the lower tip of Manhattan was submitted to the City Planning Commission yesterday by the West Side Association of Commerce, which

Mr. and Mrs. Olin Derr of Daytona Beach, Fla., and Keeseville, N. Y., formerly of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Mary Derr, to Dean Hill Jr., son of Mrs. Louise F. Hill of Bronxville, N. Y., and Dean Hill of this city.

New York State farmers who wish to learn new methods of carrying on their work will be able to attend courses at the New York State College of Agriculture at Ithaca for a Winter term beginning Nov. 2 and lasting until Feb. 10, 1939. Tuition is free to those who have been residents of the State for one year previous to registration. For non-residents there is a fee of $25.

Concerned with latest methods of imparting religious instruction to Roman Catholics, the fourth National Catechetical Congress of the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine opened here today with more than 8,000 delegates from all parts of the United States and several foreign countries in attendance.

A herd of ten purebred brown Swiss cattle has been presented to Father Flanagan Boys Home by Mr. and Mrs. Dan V. Stephens of Fremont. The herd, all fine show stock, including a bull. is valued at $5,000.

The presence of several national officers, and the first report of a newly formed committee on the advancement of American music will feature the forty-third annualState conference of the D. A. R. opening Tuesday at Jamestown.

Willie Turnesa, the national amateur champion, and his up-State partner, Miss Virginia Guilfoil, Syracuse University sophomore, today had no particular trouble advancing into the semi-final round of the fourth annual mixed foursomes tournament at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club.

AMERICAN sculpture by members .of the Sculpture Guild will be shown at the Brooklyn Museum from Oct. 22 through Nov. 27. This will be the second exhibition by this new society of sculptors and first sponsored by a museum.

Among the many Fall planting problems confronting the homeowner the setting out of a hedge or boundary planting-because of the comparative number and expense of plants it involves-is often one of the most perplexing. If not rightly solved before the plants are set out, it may be an endless source of trouble in the future.

Mr. and Mrs. Caleb Clarke Moore of Darien, Conn., and Camden, S. C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Camilla Moore Gay, to Ogden King Myers, son of Mrs. T. Halsted Myers of the Savoy-Plaza and the late Dr. Myers.

The Republican State ticket, headed by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, was extolled yesterday in a statement issued by the Union League Club of Brooklyn. The statement praised Mr. Dewey's record as a public prosecutor and declared that he would bring to the Governor's office the promise that his achievements in disclosing alliances between crime and politics in New York County would be broadened to include the entire State.

Steamship men report a slight but steady revival in travel interest, and several lines rebooked passengers who had canceled their plans during the week because they hesitated to enter a politically disturbed Europe. Most companies were

DICTATORSHIPS are among the oldest human institutions. When certain things have to be done for the safety of a tribe or a nation there are obvious advantages in one-man leadership or control. One man, if he be a born leader with his head well screwed on can act more swiftly and at times more shrewdly than a committee or a council or a parliament.
The alertness of two detectives, Frank Crimmons and Charles McGowen of the East Fifty-first Street station, yesterday resulted in the arrest of an alleged jewelry thief.

AT about thirty suburban railway stations round London where no bus or tram service passes the station, the commuter who comes home to find himself in an unexpected local shower need no longer take a taxi.
A NEW crop of exhibitions to fill idle hours for the members of the photographic fraternity have opened in the city. At the Museum of Modern

TORONTO.-In the northward trek to hunting grounds this Autumn more sportsmen will use airplanes. In Canada the use of the airplane has opened up hur ing areas which formerly were too remote, regions where only Indians and trappers live.

Charles H. Sullivan was re-elected chairman of the Suffolk County Democratic Committee tonight at an organization meeting that may be challenged in court, according to supporters of Robert N. Gilmore of Babylon, who also sought the chairmanship.
To the cheers of 13,000 fans, Tennessee's Volunteers came from behind today to defeat Clemson College, 20 to 7, in a game replete with thrills.

Taxes on industrial corporations in 1937 were equivalent to 53 per cent of corporate net income after deduction of taxes, according to figures issued yesterday by the National Association of Cost Ac countants. The report,

New york today won 1938 Lesley Cup golf honors with a team score of 60 points to 47 1/2 for Massachusetts in the two-day tournament on the suburban Merion course. Canada, last year's winner, scored 28 1/2 points and finished last. The Pennsylvania team was third with 44 points.

With a disappearance at sea of the coastal blow, the New Rochelle Yacht Club held its annual Fall cruising race today, and Henry Sears's Actaea appeared to be the winner, but the ratings of the two contestants were not registered with their entries to figure their handicaps.

LONDON. ENGLAND is making a brave effort to keep its last 200 windmills still working. The Society for the Preservation of Ancient Buildings is helping owners with technical advice and, where necessary, with public or private subscriptions.
Fred Perry of England reached the final of the national professional singles championship at the Chicago Arena tonight by defeating Berkeley Bell of New York in straight sets, 6-2, 7-5, 6-3.
Business, financial, labor and civic organizations in a number of cities and other communities throughout the country are uniting for a "Ready for Winter" campaign this Fall and Winter.

The University of Michigan hit the football comeback trail today by vanquishing Michigan State, 14 to 0, in a fiercely contested struggle before 82,500 fans. Michigan partisans hailed the victory, achieved through touchdown marches in the second and fourth periods, as the end of four years of groping in the gridiron wilderness.

A solemn mass for the repose of the soul of Cardinal Hayes will be celebrated tomorrow morning in the Chapel of St. De La Salle on the campus of Manhattan College. The Cardinal was graduated from Manhattan in 1888.

General endorsement of the operations of the Federal Surplus Commodity Corporation's activities in food lines was voiced by grocery manufacturers here last week in commenting on the increased buying of surplus foodstuffs being cartried on by the government organization. Crop surpluses acquired by
The Teachers College of Connecticut, taking to the air on decisive plays, defeated the Trenton (N. J.) Teachers eleven today, 13 to 6.

Miss Audrey Caroline Garrison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Guy D. Garrison of Colchester, Ill., and Riverside, Greenwich, was married to Charles P. Mason of Greenwich Towers in the First Presbyterian Church here this morning by the Rev. Dr. Minot C. Morgan, the pastor.

In a world dominated by pacific sentiments and free trade, changes in political frontiers might have only a minor economic significance. Trade relationships would continue largely in their accustomed channels, subject to those adjustments made necessary only by changes in currency, in legal codes,

Lauding President Roosevelt's peace appeals, Leon Jouhaux, French Labor Federation chief, just returned from the United States, said in his account of his American trip before the Union Council that when he was received at the White House he had implored the President to intervene and had been gratified subsequently to learn of the President's two messages to Europe on behalf of peace.

The marriage of Miss Rosemary Strong, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Strong of this city, to William Charles Guenther, son of Mrs. Charles Guenther of Newark, N. J., and the late Mr. Guenther, took place here yesterday in St. Joseph's Church.

Rumors that blind persons could obtain Seeing-Eye dogs by saving empty paper match holders were branded as false by Mayor La Guardia yesterday. The Mayor was informed of the rumors by Mrs. Dorothy Harrison Eustis, president of the Seeing-Eye. In her letter to the Mayor, Mrs. Eustis said:

Young matrons and debutantes of this season and former years who are members of committees for the Carnival on Wheels to be held next month will meet at tea Tuesday afternoon at the Stork Club to advance preparations for the benefit entertainment. The carnival,
AS background for the National Automobile Show, decorations on the walls of Grand Central Palace from Nov. 11 through 18 will carry facts and figures illustrated by large mural paintings.

Exeter opened its football 'season today by winning from Tilton, 6 to 0. A touchdown was scored in the first period by Charles Cowan, who stepped over from the one-yard mark after Ralph Ward and Joe Kane had reeled off long runs.
The Cooperative Wild-Life Research Unit at the Pennsylvania State College is beginning this Fall its first full year's work on improvement of conditions for game birds and ani mals.
Captain Sammy Roeder, Franklin and Marshall fullback, scored three touchdowns today to lead his team to a 27-12 victory over Lebanon Valley before a crowd of 8,000.

The University of Chicago's Maroons twice came within two yards of touchdowns today then found the Bradley line turned to granite and were forced to accept a scoreless tie in their opening game of the season.

The northern districts of Sudetenland-the industrial cities of Bruex, Dux, Teplitz and Aussig-form the backbone of the industrial and mining production of the whole of Bohemia. Today, prior to the German occupation, this correspondent witnessed there the despair and anxiety prevailing even in many Sudeten German circles.

The Curtis first and second teams and John Adams High School won top honors in their respective divisions as the Publio Schools Athletic League group cross-country runs began at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.
A NEW role in modern warfare is played by the radio operator who controls the "nozzle" of a powerful short-wave station to spray and obliterate the broadcasting from another country.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Peter F. Osborne of Leaksville, N. C., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Annette May Osborne, to George Harrison Fullerton of this city, New London, Conn., and Hendersonville, N. C.
Mr. and Mrs. Aubrey H. Straus of Richmond, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Augusta Wilma Straus, to Robert Campe Goodman of Norfolk, Va., and Washington, D. C.

Miss Burnley Welsh, a descendant of Thomas Jefferson and of Colonel John Burnley of the British Army in the Revolutionary. War era, was married here yesterday afternoon to Edward Libby Dame, son of Mrs. Frank L. Dame of Garden City, L. I., and the late Mr. Dame.
THE profound influence which the films have upon social customs and habits is over powering, when you come to think about it. Danielle Darrieux

The Tax Commission announced yesterday that the supplemental assessment roll for the first six months of 1939 showed a net increase of $140,333,419 over the final 1938 total assessed valuation on all taxable real estate and special franchises in New York City. The increase brings the tentative total for the six months' period to $16,790,631,213.

More than 7,000 persons attended the performance of "Madama Butterfly" and "Aida" yesterday afternoon and evening, respectively, which closed the seventeen-day season of the San Carlo Opera Company at the Center Theatre.

Superb passing by David O'Brien and superior line play gave the Texas Christian University Horned Frogs a 21-to-14 victory over the University of Arkansas in the Southwest conference's opening game of the season today.

Alabama's Crimson Tide smashed Howard, 34 to 0, today in a display of power and versatility before 8,000 fans. The Alabama line dominated the play from the start and the Tide was never in serious trouble.

A powerhouse Minnesota outfit thundered over Nebraska's Cornhuskers today, winning by 16 to 7, mainly through a blasting first-half drive that netted two touchdowns. Forty-seven thousand-persons saw the Golden Gophers spoil Coach Biff Jones's record of not having lost a season's opener.

Brown hurled a stunning surprise at Harvard today by humbling the Crimson football forces in the team's opening game of the season. The eleven from Providence, much given by tradition to dealing unlooked-for setbacks to more highly rated rivals, showed a wealth of speed and a fine knowledge of fundamentals to win by 20 to 13.
A Democratic State Convention dominated by James M. Curley, nominee for Governor, adopted today an election campaign platform restricted almost exclusively to his views on current issues.

DURING these critical days in Europe the youth of the dictatorruled nations have been roaring approval of the commands of their leaders. The men and women who lived through the World War have been less military-minded than the younger people.

William H. Donner, retired steel manufacturer and philanthropist and former father-in-law of Elliot Roosevelt, has bought a villa on Lake Geneva and established a perma nent residence in Switzerland. His wife, who will join him this month, refused to discuss a report that he would become a Swiss citizen.

An eventual German understanding with France, colonies from whatever nations can be persuaded to cede them, a commercial treaty with the United States, economic penetration of the Balkans-all these are the next objectives of German foreign policy unless all signs mislead.

The leaders in the nation-wide campaign to obtain better care for American mothers and babies met here today to formulate a new year's program. Representatives from forty of the fifty-eight national organizations cooperating registered for the conference.

Ralph De Pasquale and James R. Bowen have announced a partnership to engage in general investment business under the name Income Investors. Mr. De Pasquale was formerly in charge of the trading department of Clark, Kohl Eyman and Mr. Bowen occupied a similar position with H. M. Geraghty Co.

Washington and Jefferson opened its forty-ninth football campaign today by filling the October air with passes and subduing Marietta of Ohio, 27-0. Three times the Presidents scored by the overhead route.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Ruth Elaine Newman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Newman of Brooklyn, to Elliott Arthur Caplin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto P. Caplin of New Haven, Conn.

A poll of Princeton University's graduating class of 1938 has shown 86.8 per cent of the members reporting that they are satisfactorily occupied, it was announced today by Richard W. Warfield, director of the Bureau of Appointments and Student Employment.

Applications for projects involying a total expenditure of $35,000,000 cascaded into the regional offices of the Public Works Administration Friday as communities in the eleven Northeastern States rushed to get needed public improvements in before the legal deadline for new applications, which passed at midnight.

" Racketeering" trade associations, those whose control is in the hands of small cliques, and those whose operations are not in the public interest will come quickly to light in the investigation undertaken by the Department of Commerce as part of the monopoly study by the Temporary National Economic Committee, in the view of association
The threatened bankruptcy of the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad is a repetition of the experiences of other railroads dating from the consolidation contests of the 1929 era.

HOLLYWOOD. THE faces of the cinema's comedians have lost their mournful look in recent days because the purveyors of laughter see in the association of Eddie Cantor with RKO and Metro a probable upturn in the
By the margin of a safety, the James Madison High School football team topped Manual Training High, a borough rival, 2-4, in the inaugural of the season for both teams at Ebbets Field yesterday.

George Washington's eleven got off to a good start this season by routing Theodore Roosevelt High School, 14-0, yesterday at the Washington Stadium. The victors came through for both of their touchdowns in the second quarter.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company is expected to file next week with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $50,000,000 debentures to mature in ten years. Although the interest rate has not been determined, it is expected to be 3 1/4 or 3 1/2 per cent.

Stewart Browne, for many years president of the United Real Estate Owners Association, left no-real estate when he died in French Hospetal on Aug. 4 at the age of 84. This was revealed yesterday when his will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court, listing personal assets valued at approximately $6.500.

Miss Mary Louise Perfect, daughter of Mrs. William Grant Perfect of Forest Hills Gardens, and the late Mr. Perfect, and Thomas Tyson Cook Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cook, also of Forest Hills Gardens, were married yesterday morning in the Church of Our Lady Queen of Martyrs, Forest Hills. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Jerome Holland.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity reacted to 84.2 for the week ended Sept. 24. This compares with 86.0 (revised) for the preceding week and 104.6 for the corresponding week last year.
Soccer matches throughout England and Wales today drew big crowds who celebrated the dramatic turn in the European situation by tributes to Prime Minister Chamberlain.

Two leading supporters of the government, The Sunday Times and The Observer, led the chorus of praise for Prime Minister Chamberlain. They argued that he had obtained much better terms for Czechoslovakia than were laid down in Chancellor Hitler's Godesberg demands.

LIKE father, like son, they were saying the other day when John Craven bounded into the 'office of John Golden and wondered whether he wouldn't do for the leading role of that proposed revival of "The First Year."
Duke routed Davidson, 27 to 0, today. A crowd of 6,000 persons-one of the smallest ever to witness a Southern Conference battle heresaw the Blue Devils score four touchdowns.

Surging up and down Mountaineer Field in their mightiest fashion, West Virginia University's football hosts crushed their neighbors from West Virginia Wesleyan, 38 to 6, today before a crowd of 5,000.
Mrs. Richard Percy Limburg, designated as "America's No. 1 fund-raiser" by Mrs. Sidney C. Borg, chairman of the Women's Division of the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish

The State Department called attention today to the fact that the law of June 8, 1938, for the registration of agents of foreign principals, required registrations by Oct. 6 and that if registrations were not filed by that time, penalties were provided. These may be a fine of $1,000 or imprisonment for two years, or both .

Tom Davis, counsel for the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, today accused the railroads of insincerity in their wage-cut efforts. At the hearing before the emergency factfinding board, named by President Roosevelt to study the wage dispute, he contended that the railroads in reality were attempting to destroy the basic wage structure, established through years of negotiations.

While the date of transfer of title to the electrical distribution properties of the Memphis Power and Light Company to the city of Memphis could not be determined definitely today, city officials said they expected it to be about the middle of December.

The new British trade-mark law, An which recently became effective, Stan has several features of particular interest to manufacturers here who do business in Great Britain or have plans for doing so, according to an analysis issued yesterday by Hugo Mock, counsel for Toilet Goods Association.
The annual card party to aid the maintenance of Anthonian Hall, residence for blind women at 105107 Greene Avenue Brooklyn, will be held this year on Nov. 19 at the Columbus Club in Brooklyn.

Wise Prince, Felix Spatola's little black horse, today won his tenth start of the year when he scored a smashing victory in the $3,500 added White Mountain Handicap at Rockingham Park before a crowd of 20,000.

THE fiery red of frost-bitten gum trees and the bright yellow of sassafras are beginning to splash these Southern Appalachians of the Asheville region with Autumn glory. The seasons, at least, follow their ancient routines in a land where everything else is changing.
Worcester Tech, with a touchdown and a safety, opened its football season today by defeating the United States Coast Guard Academy,9 to 0.

The climax of the season at the Innis Arden Golf Club, Old Greenwich, was a novelty dance held at the clubhouse tonight. Entertainment consisted of novel and modern dance numbers and an accordionist. Several dinner parties preceded the dance.
Santa Clara, champion of the Sugar Bowl the last two years, opened its 1938 bid for national football recognition today with a stunning 22-to-0 victory over Stanford University.

COLLEGE boys and girls trooping back to the campus this Autumn will be taught more generally than ever before in academic history how to become good husbands and wives. In the East and West, and even shyly and anonymously in the South,-the preparation-for-marriage course is picking its arduous and uncertain way into ivied halls.

With the appointment this week of a "coordinator of student activities" and the formation of a social-planning committee, the demands of students and faculty for a planned social program at Brothers College of Drew University are rapidly being recognized by the administration.

When Duke University lights 100 candles on her birthday cake this month, alumni will send greetings from nearly every State in the Union and from thirty-one foreign countries. "One Hundred Years of Southern Education in the Service of the Nation" will be the central theme.

The marriage of Miss Catherine Dodd Col4, daughter of Mrs. Katherine D. Cole of New York and the late Frederick A. Cole, to William Pate Church of Chicago, son of the late Mrs. Alice Pate Church and the late John R. Church of Brooklyn Heights, N. Y., took place here this afternoon at the home of the bride's uncle, Frank C. Dodd.

A job, and one job only, for every student on the Hamilton College campus who needs employment is the aim of the new system of student agencies which is being established this Fall by the college administration.
Spanish Loyalist purchases in the United States are averaging slightly less than $2,000,000 a month at the present time, Miles M. Sherover, head of the Hanover Sales Corporation, American
Miss Mariette Bertram Dimon, daughter of Charles A. Dimon of Germantown, was married this afternoon to George Lear, also of Germantown, son of the late Mr. and Mrs Tenrv Lear.

A study of trade statistics covering exports to agreement and nonagreement countries does not bear out a contention that sales to countries with which the United States has concluded reciprocal trade agreements have increased more rapidly than to others, the American Tariff League contended yesterday in a bulletin prepared for its membership.
One last glorious fling at the 1938 racing season is being provided this afternoon for speed boat pilots and especially outboard drivers on the Hackensack River at Kearny, N. J.

The fourth of a series of public auction sales of real estate bought in by the County of Nassau prior to 1930 was held tonight at the Police Auditorium where buyers paid $57,255 for property placed on the auction block. This brings the gross sales to more than $142,000.

Speculation regarding the economic angles which may have been discussed in the peace meeting at Munich was general among foreign traders here last week. Fear that Germany, aided by the raw materials and manufacturing advantages of the Sudeten areas of Czechoslovakia, will intensify her

Chicago's baseball fans suddenly went delirious tonight after the Cubs, in a drive led by Manager Gabby Hartnett, had won the National League championship in the most turbulent finish in thirty years.

Harry W. Finnell, a vice president of the Phelps Dodge Copper Products Corporation, 40 Wall Street, died yesterday morning in the Lenox Hill -Hospital after an illness of a few days. He was born fifty-seven years ago in Morgantown, W. Va., and attended the University of West Virginia.

Automobiles heated by steam are disclosed in patent No. 2,131,635 just granted to Raymond F. Mullen of Rochester, N. Y. The heating system is sealed in so that no water to generate the steam need be added.

Dr. Alfred E. Van Horn, practicing physician and specialist here for forty years, died last night in his home. He was born at Summit Hill, Pa., seventy-seven years ago, and was graduated from the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine in 1884.

The Justice Department agreed today to confer with officials of the National Retail Credit Association on the advisibility of modifying a decree regulating certain activities of the association. The conferences will begin next week.

The only incident reported at German Army Headquarters during today's occupation of Zone No. 1 occurred at Neuhef, a small village, where a Czech lieutenant and ten men barricaded themselves in a house and covered the road with machine guns.

About all the pennant-winning Cubs left intact in their dressing room at Sportman's Park today were the walls and steel lockers-and they wouldn't be there tonight if the celebrants could have budged them.

Bergen College triumphed over the New York Aggies on the gridiron today, 19-0, scoring a touchdown in the first period and two more in the second. The victors' first tally resulted from a pass, Derensis to Cappaccio. Walsh kicked the extra point.
The White Sox beat the Browns, 6 to 3, in the first game of a double-header today, then lost the nightcap, 4 to 0, when darkness halted the contest after five innings.

THE progressive role of the airplane in the pursuits of peace is the theme of National Air Travel Week, which opened yesterday to mark the first decade of regular air transport service in the United States. All over the nation
A statement approving Prime Min sister Neville Chamberlain's policy was given The Sunday Dispatch last night on behalf of Duke of Windsor. The message,

A large store front and facade of structural glass resulting from the renovation of six buildings at the southeast corner of Fulton Street and Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, into a modern two-story business unit has been completed by the Neponsit Building Corporation.

When the Blue. Mountain Eagle Climbing Club of this and near-by cities makes its Fall pilgrimage to Bake Oven Knob in the Blue Mountains on Sunday, Oct. 9, it will not have to hear stories of the "haunt" which frightens visitors to the old Hawk Mountain Bird Sanctuary Harm house, several miles from the Knob.

Westchester will hear the National Labor Relations Act discussed by its chief administrator, Joseph Warren Madden, chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, at THE NEW YORK TIMES Review-of-the-News Conference to be held tomorrow at the Mamaroneck Junior High School on the Boston Post Road.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Fleming Stafford of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Phyllis Knapp Stafford, to Edmund Lockwood Decker Jr. of Pittsburgh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Lockwood Decker of Montclair, N. J.

Even though the Dartmouth varsity football team played only a few minutes at the start of the game, little St. Lawrence was bewildered by the Indian reserves, and the Green gained a 51-0 victory today.

Hank Greenberg went hitless in four attempts today as Denny Galehouse of the Indians shut out the Tigers, 5-0, on five hits. Galehouse pitched his best game of the season for Cleveland, striking out five.

The indictment of Fred A. Male of 27 Spruce Street, Yonkers, an insurance and real estate broker, charges of perjury and forgery was announced today by the Westchester County District Attorney's office. The offenses allegedly were

A contract providing for arbitration of all disputes was signed yesterday by the Inter-City Gasoline Dealers Association and the Gasoline Station Attendants Union, Local 20,408, an A. F. of L. affiliate.

Gerhard Jentsch, representative of the Geneva College for Women, has urged Miss Mildred Burges, its head, to reconsider her decision to close the college. This decision was transmitted to Geneva from New York by cable during the worst of the European crisis. The reopening of the

Last week's hurricane laid low about $400,000 worth of old-growth and second-growth timber in the University of New Hampshire's College Woods, according to a rough estimate by the Department of Forestry.

When the Yankees and the National League pennant winners meet in the world series next week an interested spectator will be Uncle Sam. The old gentleman will have one eye on the box score and the other on the gate, hoping that the series will go the route.

Rejection of proposed Constitutional Amendment 1 was urged upon voters yesterday by the New York State Communist Party, which declared that the amendment contained "dangerous tax proposals" that would make it more difficult to tax the rich and easier to levy heavier taxes upon the poor.

By forcing a safety in the last period. when it trailed, 14 to 13, Rutgers triumphed today over a fighting University of Vermont eleven, 15 to 14, in the most exciting game seen on Neilson Field in years. Eight thousand fans saw the
The Reds crushed Pittsburgh's flag hopes today by swamping five pitchers with a seventeen-hit attack and a wild 9-to-6 victory before a ladies' day crowd of 13,396 fans.
Three thousand members of New York's famous Twenty-seventh Division, which smashed the Hindenburg line in France. twenty years ago, marched today in a parade dedicated to peace.

As the University of Pennsylvania opens a new academic year the educational program of its Institute of Local and State Government, established a year ago, is being expanded with the appointment, for the first time, of graduate "apprentices."

Automobile accident in New York State during August decreased 37 per cent, as contrasted with those of August, 1937, it was announced yesterday by Charles Harnett, State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.

During the European crisis Mrs. Roosevelt adhered scrupulously to her policy, announced at her first White House press conference, of refraining from comment on matters of international negotiation or pending legislation.
Hunter girls spend more than half as much time in their "underground campus"--the subways-as they do In classes, lectures and laboratories, it was found in a recent survey at the college.

To help the men in the street understand something about the weather, how to recognize storm signals and how to read the heavenly signs, the WPA Adult Education program of the New York City Board of Education has started three free meteorogical' classes, Gustav A. Stumpf, project administrator, announced yesterday.
More than 1,200 civilian volunteers in eastern North Carolina will aid the army during the next two weeks in America's first spectacular test of an elaborate air raid warning network.

The hurricane of Sept. 21 exacted a heavy toll from shade trees. New York City and vicinity were lucky to escape with losses no greater than they were. In Connecticut the whole character of such beautiful towns as Old -Lyme, Middletown and Hartford has been changed.

THE Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo will present eighteen ballets during the twenty three performances scheduled to begin at the Metropolitan Opera House on Oct. 12 and to run through Oct. 30. Of these, seven will be works never before presented here and two others will be revivals of nineteenth century works which were not in the repertory of the DeBasil Ballet Russe to which the present company is the successor hereabouts.

Peter Dings, retired oil operator and banker and former member of the Federal Reserve Board, died today in the Henrotin Hospital of injuries suffered on Sept. 21, when he was struck by an automobile. His age was 69.

The marriage of Miss Beatrice M. Bussey to William Holland Ives took place tonight at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Edgar Bussey. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Morgan A. Downey, S. J., of St. Ignatius Catholic Church.

The marriage of Miss Marjorie Alice Marson, daughter of the Rev. Dr. John William Marson and Mrs. Marson of this city, to Robert Henry Williams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh S. Williams of Newark, took place this evening in the Mount Pleasant Baptist Church here, of which the bride's father is pastor.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John R. Lambert of 440 Riverside Drive, this city, and Milford, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Valerie Marie Lambert, to Philip S. Hemphill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick R. Hemphill of Jamestown, N. Y.
All Hallows conquered Xavier High, 18-7, at the Castle Hill Athletic Field in the Bronx yesterday for its second football victory of the season. It was the first game of the campaign for the losers.

The widely discussed subject of copy testing basked in the advertising spotlight again this week when thet Association of National Advertisers devoted a full session to various aspects of the problem during its in three-day convention here.

Dahlia enthusiasts are reporting an unusual amount of damage this season by the European Corn Borer. Due to his method of working, this obnoxious pest is likely to go unnotice by the amateur until he has done great injury.
IN the present state of the world Bertrand Russell could hardly have chosen a more timely social theme than that of Power.

Committees are now being organized for the December Ball, an entertainment that has been a feature of the Winter season for several years. The event will take place on Dec. 1 at the Ritz-Carlton and, as in the past, its beneficiary will be the Grosvenor Neighborhood House. Net proceeds from the ball

Substantial increases in employment and payrolls in the clothing industry which are not related to ordinary seasonal trends were pointed to today by Harry L. Hopkins, WPA administrator, as being "conclusive evidence" of the wisdom of the $15,000,000 clothing purchase plan started by the WPA late in June for the benefit of relief clients.

W. V. Thompson of Chicago, for the last fortysix years associated with Brunswick-Balke-Collender Company in executive promotional capacities, died yesterday at Billings Memorial Hospital following a relapse from an abdominal operation.

Aurena Coccia of Fort Lee, retired ballet master, died yesterday in Englewood Hospital after a long illness. He was 70 years old. Born in Rome, Mr. Coccia came to the United States as a dancer with the Barnum Bailey Circus.

Governor Lehman will head the State ticket to be named by the American Labor party at its convention which opens in the Manhattan Opera House tomorrow morning. The party will endorse all of Governor Lehman's running mates on the Democratic slate with the exception of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. and Controller Morris S. Tremaine.

The Peddle School varsity football team was victorious over St. John's Prep of Brooklyn, 6-0, in its first game of the season today. In the middle of the third quarter, Bill Dolt, Peddle end, snared a pass from Al Hanover to score the only touchdown of the game.

Although they are confident of a sales upturn this Fall, organized distributors of refrigerators in this area have decided to defer until next Spring resumption of the large scale campaign which they launched earlier in the year to spur sales, it was learned here yesterday.

The five-story business building at 154-6 East Forty-sixth Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues, will be sold at auction under foreclosure on Tuesday in the Vesey Street rooms by Henry Brady. The plot has a frontage of thirty-two feet.

Miss Jane Buckley Welch of this place was married today to Francis Edgar Clifford of Arlington, N. J., son of Mrs. Irene M. Clifford of Fairport, N. Y., and the late John R. Clifford, at the home of her parents by the Rev. James J. Owens.

One of the large farm deals of the season in the Bernardsville section of New Jersey has just been closed in the purchase by Morton 0. Davis of Manhasset, L. I., an executive of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, of the farm containing 174 acres and a Grade A dairy in the Chester area.

A little less than twenty years ago the Big Four of 1919-Woodrow Wilson, President of the United States; Lloyd George, Prime Minister of Great Britain; Georges Clemenceau, Premier of France, and Vittorio Orlando, Premier of Italy--held secret meetings
Connecticut clubs are devoting this week to a variety of activities, although a number of events have been canceled as a result of the recent hurricane.

METHOD: At a press conference last week Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt spoke of her lecture engagements for the Autumn and her method of preparing speeches. It seems that she never speaks from a completed manuscript. "I found," she said, "that if I did not have to think about what I was saying I became bored with my own conversation."

Cocoa Kid, 148, New Haven, carried off the decision over Eddie Cerda, 143 1/4, Mexico City, in a tenround bout last night at the Rockland Palace. Danny Peal, 168 1/2, Tulsa, Okla., defeated Curtis Sheppard, 177 1/2, Harlem, in the eightround semi-final.

THE rural highway is coming into its own. For years it was the Cinderella of our road system, suffering neglect while builders concentrated their ingenuity and funds on superhighways to break up the bottlenecks in and around' big cities.

The Rev. Owen Francis Dudley of London, Superior General of the Catholic Missionary Society of England, will give an address this afternoon at 4 o'clock at the Catholic Young Women's Club, 641 Lexington Avenue, at Fifty-fourth Street.

Bloomfield's chances of retaining the State group 4 high school foot ball championship were shattered today as Belleville held the Bengals to a scoreless tie. Nutley accomplished the same feat against Bloomfield in the opening game last week.

There are the days when farsighted gardeners are taking advantage of every hour of sunshine and daylight to complete garden making and re-making before rapidly shortening afternoons and the approach of freezing weather will call a complete shut-down on outside activities.

Fraternity groups at Union College established the highest scholarship average in eleven years last year, according to Dean Garis. The nonfraternity students, which have traditionally led the- fraternity members, were ahead by only 007 of a point, the average for the "neutrals" being 2.490 and the

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Olszewski of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Regina Olszewski, to Monroe Williams Blake, United States Vice Consul to Warsaw, Poland.

A conference on health insurance and medical care, -which included one of the largest gatherings of labor union representatives to discuss the problem in this country, heard attacks on organized medicine yesterday for failing to evolve a system which would provide adequately for the low-income group and endorsed the principle of compulsory health insurance for persons of low income.

The marriage of Miss Grace Carolan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Carolan of 511 East Eighty-eighth Street, to Frederic Carl Saacke, son of Mrs. Rudolph Saacke of this city and the late Mr. Saacke, took place yesterday noon in the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixtyfourth Street.
A college library is being planned for the centralization of library facilities at Hunter College in the new unit now under construction at Sixty-eighth Street and Park Avenue.

Ontario's production of gold in August fell just $65,000 short of the record established in July, due to treatment of lower-grade ore by mines in the Porcupine Camp, the bulletin issued by the Ontario Department of Mines reveals.
MEMO to the Drama Critics Circle: John Sigvard Olsen of Peru, Ind., and Harold Ogden Johnson of Chicago, Ill., can take it.

IN the desperation of the depression of the early Thirties the New Deal suspended the anti-trust laws through NRA to permit stabilization of prices by industry, which is a mild way of saying that the Administration permitted price-fixing.

The police here took extraordinary precautions today to avert a threatened clash tomorrow night between Nazi and anti-Nazi adherents when Fritz Kuhn, national leader of the German-American Bund, is scheduled to address a local bund meeting.

The National Grandmothers' Club in its first annual convention today selected the first Sunday in October, that's tomorrow, as "Grandmother's Day." Mrs. John Wesley Gray of Chicago, grandmother of two, "grandma secretary" of the club, in explaining the objective said:

IF Zoltan Korda ever decides to give up directing films for his producer-brother, Alexander, he should find several careers open to him, but one for which he might easily qualify would undoubtedly be "Special Adviser to His Majesty's Empire on Native Diplomacy."
The Republican State Convention at Saratoga Springs, which reached its climax on Thursday night in a speech of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey accepting the nomination for Governor was unique.

Miss Katharyn June Manusos, daughter of James J. Manusos of Chicago and Mason City, Iowa, and niece of Mr. and Mrs. George De Benneville Keim of Gable Hall, Edgewater Park, N. J., was married this afternoon to Douglas Beck Tyler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Beck Tyler of Riverton. The Rev.

Miss Esther Winnifred Pelton, daughter of Mrs. Archibald L. Pelton of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Pelton of Kentville, Nova Scotia, was married to Albert William Haas of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore J. Haas of Dickson, Tenn., last night in St. Paul's
Keeper Joseph Birdsall, who when he guarded the front entrance to Sing Sing prison for years was known to thousands of prisoners and visitors, died of a heart attack in Ossining last night.

Foreign traders returning from Washington late last week predicted that the Anglo-American trade treaty would be announced within the next few weeks. Settlement of all major questions involved in the treaty has been reached, they said, and the State
Chancellor Adolf Hitler has issued a decree appointing Konrad Henlein Reich Commissioner for the occupied Sudeten territory, directly responsible to the Chancellor.
Dr. Milton Newman, former resident physician on eye service at Metropolitan Hospital, died yesterday at his home, 241 Central Park West, after a long illness. He was 29 years old.

Another attempt to break the deadlock gripping the household employment situation got under way last week as a new and ambitious committee set out to wrestle with some of the difficulties besetting domestic work and workers.

FOR those who listen to learn, the roads from the loudspeaker lead in several directions but the main path is to the library, Jennie M. Flexner, readers' adviser of the New York Public Library, pointed out in a recent WEVD broadcast.

A platform condemning the "amazing and complicated series of power-politics deals" of the American Labor party was adopted yesterday by the State convention of the Socialist party, which nominated Norman Thomas for Governor. About eighty delegates

When large apartments are altered into smaller units it is usually necessary to add to the storage facilities of the new suites. Adequate storage space has definite appeal to renters and is to be had in most modern competitive buildings.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas. THE army's advanced flying school at Kelly Field next Wednesday will graduate the largest class of airplane pilots to complete the course here since the school was organized sixteen years ago.
After five years of experimenting, Syracuse University, at the request of the student body, is offering for the first time this year a credit course on marriage problems.
A football kicked into the air carries in its flight all the power of the foot that did the kicking. Its usefulness is in proportion to that Power.

Miss Yvonne Aimee Conord, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Theodore Conord of Bloomfield, was married to Richard Southard Merrick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert John Merrick of Kennett Square, Pa., this evening in the Watchung Presbyterian Church. The Rev. John A. Reed, pastor of the church, performed the ceremony.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has issued an order permitting the general protective committee for security holders of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation to be heard in the reorganization and integration proceedings but without intervenor rights.

THE football season is under way. Back from training camps in the mountains and by sea and lake shores, squads of superbly conditioned young athletes, their bodies hardened by months of manual toil during Summer vacation, are rehearsing their assignments and polishing up their plays in hundreds of colleges throughout the country Already they have rid
