This almost forgotten village in Dufferin County near Orangeville was sold at auction today to pay the back wages of a telephone operator. Old-timers said that the sale caused the most excitement here in thirty years.

While the Government of Great Britain was practically paying its way in the face of heavy commitments, the Government of the United States was running further into debt, the Chamber of Commerce of the United Stafes declared today in a pamphlet it has just published called "Facts About Taxes and Public Spending."
WITH war greatly limiting the more conventional tours of the Orient, especial attention is directed to the heretofore less traveled areas in this part of the world.

The Haverford School eleven triumphed over Poly Prep of Brooklyn, 7 to 6, today. Captain Nicholson of Haverford ended a 50-yard drive in the first period by plunging a yard through tackle for a touchdown. He kicked the extra point from placement.
IULIA DE BEAUSOBRE is entering upon a three-month period of solitary confinement in a Moscow prison when the record of her book begins The time is February, 1932, and
WHEN Hugh Legare Wysor moved out of the Virginia homestead where he had lived for sixty years a great quantity of letters and family papers.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Kathryn Magovern, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Magovern of South Orange, to Harry F. Murphy of Maplewood, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Murphy, took place this morning in Our Lady of Sorrows Church.

The marriage of Miss Elinor Mary McCarthy, daughter of Mrs. Daniel paul McCarthy of this city and the late Mr. McCarthy, to Joseph Gavin, son of Surrogate and Mrs. John H. Gavin, also of Jersey City, took place here this morning in St. Michael's Church.
TWO new coins of British East Africa have recently appeared on the local market. These are the 1-shilling and 5Q-cent pieces in silver. On both coins the obverse

A mak naval intelligence officer and a Federal Bureau of Investigation man In questioned today a 41-year-old man who detectives said had been loitering for four weeks in the vicinity of two Akron factories working on navy contracts.

With theatres and night spots opening one after the other these coolish evenings the social season, calling for evening finery, is getting under way. The little things that make for a dramatic outfit, the hair ornaments, jewelry, evening shoes and bags, are as glittering and colorful as they can be.

Eastern railroads have been authorized by the Interstate Commerce Commission to file proposed reduced rates on export grain from Chicago to New York on twenty days' notice, instead of the usual thirty-day notice.
A scoreless tie for the third straight year was the story of the annual football duel between the Auburn Plainsmen and Tulane Green Wave today.
Mrs. Carrie Hope Coxhead, prominent in New York State and Washington, D. C., church circles, died here today after a brief illness at the age of 73.

When a wholly unprecedented hurricane swept from the Atlantic last week to destroy hundreds of lives and millions of dollars in property in Long Island and New England one of the first questions to arise in many minds was:
An ambition of years to reach the age her great-grandfather did will be realized tomorrow by Mrs. Angeline Briggs Gardner, Westchester County's oldest citizen, when she observes her 104th birthday.

Polish troops will march today into the Teschen district, Czechoslovakia having surrendered to the ultimatum sent from Warsaw Friday. Further areas will be subjected to plebiscites. A Polish army 200,000 strong had been gathered at the frontier ready to strike if necessary.

Once again yesterday Adolf Hitler extended the boundaries of the Third Reich. His advance came at the end of a week more tense than any Europe had known since Kaiser Wilhelm II ruled in Berlin. since the days of Poincard, Sir Edward Grey, Czar Nicholas and the rest.

An amendment to the Fair Labor IStandards Act, which would serve to plug the loophole revealed by a recent United States Circuit Court decision, was suggested here by Mortimer Fischel, general counsel of the National Work Shirt Manufacturers Association.

Miss Rosalind Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis H. Brown, was married here today to Edward Townsend, son of Myron T. Townsend of Pelham, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Gertrude Barnard Townsend. The ceremony was performed in Christ Church by the Rev. Albert J. M. Wilson.

Under the auspices of a patroness committee comprised of many women of prominence in society, a dinner dance for the benefit of the Musicians Emnergency Fund will be given Wednesday night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis to mark the formal opening of that rendezvous for the season.

THE Studebaker Corporation last week introduced its two new automobiles for 1939. Continuing the model names used last year, the company designates its 110horsepower eight as the "State President" and its 90-horsepower six as the "State Commander."

The Railroad Retirement Board announced today the appointment of James G. Robinson as director of railroad unemployment insurance It said the selection had been made by a competitive civil service examination. The office pays $10,000 a year.

Death Announced Fireman First Grade Daniel Lelner of Engine Co. 234 died Sept. 30. Funeral will take place from his late residence. 78-04 Seventy-eighth Street, Glendale, Queens, at 1:45 P. M., Monday, Oct. 3. Interment at St. John's Cemetery.

KANSAS CITY, Mo.-Shawnee Indian children long since have passed from the old Shawnee Mission, but the mission, now a State park but a few miles from the heart of this city's business district, quietly is observing its centennial this year.

The history of mesmerism from Ma its adoption by the elite of London in the Eighteen Forties to its use by Sigmund Freud in the study of hysteria is told by Arno L. Bader of the English department of the University of Michigan in the leading article of the current issue of The Colophon.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler came back this morning to Berlin, where Dr. Joseph Goebbels, his Minister of Propaganda, had arranged a popular triumph for him. The resulting demonstration was more frenzied and more vociferous than that which followed the absorption of Austria.
Plans are under way to preserve as a shrine the site of the station near the South Wellfleet shore from which Marconi sent the first wireless message across the Atlantic. T Funds are being sought.

With 15,000 spectators, including reunioning members of the Princeton class of 1928, sitting in Palmer Stadium, the Tigers opened another chapter in their ancient football history under a new head coach, Tad Wieman, today.

A statement that Professor Felix Frankfurter was opposed to President Roosevelt's proposal to change the Supreme Court was made today by one of the leading participants in the fight on the court bill last year.

A FRESH restatement of the case for the most unjustly abused and misunderstood of the men who made the American Revolution, such as is to be found in Mr. Smith's study of Thomas Paine, is a welcome step in the rehabilitation of a tarnished reputation.

The trials of four persons accused as German spies will be postponed on Tuesday when their cases are called before Federal Judge John C. Knox. It was said yesterday in the office of United States Attorney Lamar Hardy that adjournments of one to two weeks will be sought pending the return of investigators who went to Germany to take a deposition from Dr. Ignatz T. Griebl fugitive spy suspect.

Contending Teams-New York Yankees, champions of the American League, and Chicago Cubs, champions of the National League. Managers--Joseph V. McCarthy, Yankees, and Charles Leo (Gabby) Rartnett, Cubs. How Series Is Decided-Best four out of seven games.

A sophomore back, Paul Christman, led Missouri to a 14-to-7 victory over the University of Colorado today. The visitors scored first on a 42yard-pass play, Rex Tomlinson to Art Unger, in the second period, but with Christman throwing accurately the Tiger offense clicked in the third.

Placements in remunerative positions for 1937-38 have shown a decrease compared with 1936-37 at Barnard College, according to the annual report presented to Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve yesterday by Miss Katherine S. Doty, assistant to the dean and head of the occupational bureau at the college.

Home owners and prospective home owners are advised to give careful attention to the sheet-metal work on the houses they occupy or contemplate buying. Sheet-metal work includes the gutters and leaders, or downspouts, the flashing around chimneys, windows and doors, and in valleys and on ridges, and the ducts for healing and ventilating.
The Grand Duke Cyril, pretender to the throne of the Russian Czars since the assassination of Nicholas II, is dangerously ill in the American Hospital here.
Miss B. Delphine Roberts and C. Kenneth Lange, both of this city, were married here yesterday afternoon in the University Heights Presbyterian Church by the pastor; the Rev. Norman H. Sibley.

Dr. Joseph N. B. Rawle, for forty-seven years until three years ago, a stenographer in the Municipal Court system, died on Friday at his home, 90 Prospect Park Southwest, Brooklyn, at the age of 72, after a month's illness.
WHILE this may or may not prove to be "motion pictures' greatest year," there doesn't seem to be any doubt about last month having been motion pictures' greatest September. At first I was inclined

Further price advances were registered by almost all classes of bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Trading continued at a lively pace, the turnover of $4,959,000 being the largest for a Saturday since last Nov. 27.
Scoring on five quick plays after the kick-off, Bucknell drove to a convincing 27-14 victory over Gettysburg College today in Memorial Stadium before 5,000 fans.
Felix Arnold, treasurer of the Staats-Herold Corporation, died yesterday in his home at 317 West Eighty-ninth Street after a long illness. He was 69 years old.
A superior University of Georgia eleven had the fight of its life today to eke out a 7-6 victory over South Carolina's Gamecocks before 13,000 spectators.

Taking advantage of its only two first downs of the game, the Westbury High School eleven, outweighed forty pounds per player, scored a touchdown in the first period to gain a 7-6 decision over Freeport today.

The marriage of Miss Irene Margaret Hamilton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Ferguson Hamilton of Glen Ridge, to H. Stanley Heeb Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Stanley Heeb of Bloomfield, took place this morning at the Hamilton home.
Concordia Collegiate Institute of Bronxville scored a 25-to-7 victory over the Hastings High School on the gridiron today as Henry Reiter staged a one-man show.
YEARS ago, when short-wave stations were experimenting with low power, listening on the high frequencies was carried on primarily by experimental observers. Today the picture is different.

To meet reports that rayon cord tires are superior to those made of a cotton fabric, the Bibb Manufacturing Company of Macon, Ga., largest independent producer of tire cords in this country, last week began an extensive campaign to promote its new heat-resistant cotton cord.
Jeannette Stafford Fuqua, daughter of Colonel Stephen Ogden Fuqua, United States military attache in Spain, was married here today to Rupert Belleville, son of Mrs. Gordon Leith of London.

WITH fourteen plants back in production this week, the real upturn in the automotive Industry is now on. Most plants are operating at close to capacity in an effort to stock dealers with 1939 cars at the earliest possible moment.
A sum approximating $107,000 daily is being spent by the Home Owners Loan Corporation in improving the properties it has acquired, announced Charles A. Jones, general manager, yesterday.
The State committee of the National Municipal League ended a two days' session this afternoon, called to discuss the proposed constitutional amendments.
SIGHT-SEERS have found something new in Wall Street. Almost every morning between Spring and November they wander down to the East River just below Brooklyn.
Science holds for society possibilities both for good and evil. While it is able to create a new and more agreeable world, its advances are often diverted toward the service of war.

IT is hard to believe that Tom Wolfe is dead, very hard to think that his living voice will not be heard again. A sort of splendid eloquence came from him an absolute faith in the power of words to re-create reality, a determination and, as

In much quieter trading, fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday were held within a 6 point range in a trendless market. Week-end liquidation and hedge selling was about balanced by foreign and trade buying, with, final prices ranging from 4 points higher to 1 point lower than Friday's closing quotations.

The 315 young women who passed the written test for policewomen include lawyers, psychologists, psychiattists, nurses, former Wellesley, Barnard and Hunter College students, a dancer from the Music Hall Rockettes, Arthur Murray's dancing school and the Minsky burlesque, the daughters of policemen, school teachers, a boxer and a writer of "true" detective- stories, the Municipal Civil Service Commission disclosed yesterday.

The official text of last night's broadcast by President Arturo Alessandri was published today. He said he did not expect a repetition of the Nazi uprising of Sept. 5, but that if an attempt vas made it would be crushed by loyal army forces.
To the Music Editor: Though an ardent lover of symphonic music, I do not anticipate much pleasure from the new season about to open throughout the country. Even the Toscanini radio

The Right Hon. Alfred Duff Cooper, P. C., D. S. O., First Lord of the Admiralty since June, 1937; a Conservative with very strong views on the importance of national defense, frequently attempted to lead the British people into preparedness during the years when he was Secretary of State for War (1935-37).

Because of the first shock of the blow delivered against Czechoslovakia through the decisions of the Munich conference no one in this country feels able to say today whether from an economic standpoint the remnant of Czechoslovak will or will not be able to survive.

THERE is no greater luxury than a reference shelf at home intelligently filled so that answers to innumerable questions that rise to plague one can be easily found. In the field of English letters there is no better "first aid" than "A Survey-History of English Literature" (Barnes Noble, Inc., $2.75) by Professor William Bradley Otis and Mr. Morriss H. Needleman.
Although penalties offset the full effect of N. Y. U.'s football machine in the season's debut against Maine yesterday at Ohio Field, the violet triumphed by 19 to 0.

Ohio State's gridders, hardly the Scarlet Scourge of former years, took a long step toward the Western Conference title today by defeating Indiana, 6 to 0, before 67,397 fans, a record opening-day throng.

THIS is pickle-making time. The ingredients are here in quantity -- green cucumbers, scarlet tomatoes, peppers, white and yellow onions, celery and firm round cabbages, white and red. These vegetables,

TORONTO. PASSENGERS, mail and express will be carried on scheduled runs before the end of the year on Canada's publicly owned transcontinental airway, according to an announcement of Philip G. Johnson, vice president and general manager in charge of operations of Trans-Canada Airlines.

The policy of the administration in the current agitation over modification of the Agricultural Adjustment Act in the coming Congress was made clear this week in two speeches delivered in the Southwest by Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture.

What is said to be the first utilization of super-market methods in a new drug store will be opened in Tampa, Fla., on Nov. 15 by Madison Drug Company, which plans to develop a chain throughout Florida.
The Munich settlement is regarded here as worse than the Berchtesgaden program, as embodied in the Franco-British proposals of Sept. 19. It closely approximates the so-called Godesberg ultimatum.

Disputes over the rulership of the 320 square mile territory of Teschen, in the southeast corner of Silesia, have raged since the ninth century when the kings of Poland and Bohemia strove to control it.

DROPS representing blood and tears falling from a wagon yoke will be part of the framework design of a oneand-a-half penny plus l 1/2p stamp in a semi-postal series which the Union of South Africa will issue in December to commemorate Dingsan's Day.

A large increase in orders for toys for holiday delivery was reported in the market here this week, with department stores placing many commitments for merchandise that were deferred earlier in the season.

A report of comparative attendance at the annual field day encampments of the New York National Guard, prepared for Major General William N. Haskell, commander, and made public today, shows the 212th Coast Artillery Regiment of Manhattan leads in the twenty-six units. It is the only organization with no absentees,- having 751 men, or 100 per cent of its roll-calls.
Four persons were injured, two seriously, yesterday morning when a Knickerbocker Hospital ambulance was in collision with a truck and an automobile on Fiftieth Street and First Avenue.

IF a program which now is being furthered by the Collectors Club of New York matures successfully, New York will possess the most comprehensive and scientific philatelic research laboratory in the world.

The Munich decision aroused considerable excitement here. Throughout the city tumultuous pro-Czech demonstrations were organized. Before the Czech legation large crowds of students cheered Czechoslovakia and demanded that she be not abandoned.

The police broke up last night a mass demonstration of more than 5,000 boys and girls of high school age, members of the Young Communist League, who had mobilized their forces on the East Side and, marching two and three abreast, invaded Times Square about 9 o'clock in a protest against Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and Chancellor Adolf Hitler.

Continued large holdings of cash and government securities were shown in the condition statements as of Sept. 30 that were issued yesterday by a number of local banks and trust companies. Changes from June 30 shown in the reports that became available were too mixed to indicate exactly what the trend of the last quarter has been.

A steady decline in each of the three decades since 1910 in the earnings on capital invested in the steel industry is revealed in a study by the American Iron and Steel Institute of published financial reports of companies in the industry.

Miss Sibyl Baldwin Coates, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Osborne Coates of Longacres, Wayne, was married to William F. Sanford of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard C. Sanford of New Haven, Conn., this afternoon in the Church of the Good Shepherd at Rosemont.

AS an example of the extraordinary times in which we are living, consider this: three musical shows were produced in one week not long ago. It was even more sensational than that: three musical shows were produced within four days; "You, Never Know" opened on Wednesday, "Hellzapoppin" on Thursday and "Sing Out the News" on Saturday.

A new house, constructed last Summer near the 4-H Home on the campus of the University of Georgia, is expected to help twenty additional members of the club save about $4,000 this year. By doing the homework themselves, the students believe that the cost of room and board will average $8.60 a month, which was the charge for each student during the Spring quarter last year in the cooperative house.
King Boris today issued an amnesty on the twentieth anniversary of his rule. It was said that Damyan Velgheff, former head of the Bulgarian Military Academy, might be among those receiving amnesty.
In war, the United States would be more nearly self-sustaining than any other nation, yet it lacks in whole or part twenty-one materials essential to national defense.

Nearly 4,000 soldiers participating in annual manoeuvres of the First Brigade, First Division, both of which are commanded by Brig. Gen. Walter C. Short, will end the regimental phase of tactical problems on Monday and will begin brigade tactics Tuesday.

The American Art AssociationAnderson Galleries will hold its first sale of the season next Friday and Saturday afternoons. The sale will consist of heirlooms, early American furniture, paintings and decorations belonging to Mrs. H. L. Palmer Powers.
Japan's War Minister, Lieut. Gen. Seishiro Itagaki, tonight telegraphed Chancellor Hitler "profound felicitations on the brilliant success achieved by Germany in the Czechoslovak issue."

As Rhode Island struggled to Its feet from its greatest disaster surveys under way the latter part of this week Indicated the hurricane and tidal wave of ten days ago had taken a property toll even greater than the $100,000,000 estimated by Governor Robert E. Quinn soon after the storm.

A strike called by the American Newspaper Guild when negotiations for a new contract collapsed failed to halt publication today of WilkesBarre's two afternoon dailies, The Evening News and Times Leader. The Sunday Independent, also included in the strike call, announced that it would be on the street tomorrow. The Record, a morning paper having no Sunday edition, was not affected today, but picketing of its plant was expected to start tomorrow afternoon.

Miss Maylah Grace Hallock, daughter of Judge and Mrs. Charles Albert Hallock of this city, was married here this afternoon in the First Congregational Church to Richard Bartlett Park of West Hartford, son of Mrs. Nathan Rogers Park of Cincinnati and the late Mr. Park.
Since European war clouds are now dispelled, Brazil has ceased her stock-taking of resources and raw material that might have supplied warring nations and improved the foreign exchange outlook.

Senator Smith of South Carolina, who was one of those marked in President Roosevelt's "purge," warned Secretary Wallace tonight that the administration's farm program would be "seriously jeopardized" unless the government met the demands for more cotton aid.

The United States supplied 76 per cent of the supplies of fresh apples imported into Egypt during the first six months of this year, according to a report of the American Commercial Attache at Cairo, the content of which was made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Blair Mitchell gave a tea this afternoon at Pennbrook, their estate in Bernardsville, to introduce to society their granddaughter.- Miss Sylvia Mitchell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Van Schaick Mitchell of Far Hills and New York. Autumn foliage and flowers decorated the home. Mrs. Mitchell received with her granddaughter.

Widespread interest was shown in retail circles last week in the. suggestions for revised department store organization voiced at the Boston Conference on Distribution. by Fred Lazarus Jr., vice president and treasurer of F. R. Lazarus Co., Columbus, Ohio, and N. Baloit
Oregon University lined up with the true contenders for the Pacific Coast Conference football championship today by defeating the University of California at Los Angeles, 14 to 12.

The first of a series of twelve lectures on contemporary housing and rehousing will be given at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, Wednesday evening by Charles Abrams, counsel to the American Federation of Housing Authorities, sponsor of the lectures.

Enrollment of students in State institutions of higher education will soon exceed that in both the colleges and the universities under private control, if the rate of increase in the growth of the State institutions continues as it has since 1928. This conclusion is drawn in a paper published yesterday by the General Education Board.

Slight prospect is seen in California today that the plan to pay $30 every Thursday to everybody over 50 will be passed when it appears on the State ballot on Nov. 8. Most bankers, editors and responsible politicians believe the scheme is already beaten and are now convinced that the scare about the "ham-and-egg paradise" was unjustified even at its height.

Marking the first public presentation of several hundred innovations among the 1,500. Items of business equipment to be displayed, the thirty-fifth annual National Business Show will open tomorrow in Commerce Hall of the Port Authority Building, Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street. The show will continue all week.

DALLAS, Texas.-As features of its Golden Jubilee celebrabration the State Fair of Texas will include in its exhibits both its first annual hobby show and its first annual flower exhibit. The fair was organized in 1886, but skipped 1936 and 1937, when the Texas Centennial and the PanAmerican Exposition occupied the grounds. The opening day,

In Moscow's view, the month now ending with the enforced capitulation of Czechoslovakia has been one of the most disastrous diplomatically in history. Not only, it is felt here, has it witnessed international integrity fall to its lowest point in modern times but it has exacted futile sacrifices from Czechoslovakia.

It is difficult to see how any one, whether he favors or opposes government ownership or operation of public utilities, can fail to agree with Dr. Arthur E. Morgan's insistence that the real costs of such operation should be honestly, accurately and openly determined:
WASHINGTON - Established to provide party workers and speakers with facts related to current issues, the Republican Reporter now has a circulation of about 19,000 copies.

A surprisingly strong Norwich University eleven defeated Hobart College, 20 to 0, in the season's opener for both teams today. The Norwich attack featured beautiful open-field running by Stone and the plunging of J. Hughes, with effective blocking throughout. Stone was taken from the game in the final period with a slight concussion but recovered quickly.

Everett Bowman of Fort Thomas, Ariz., and Paul Carney of Galeton, Col., will battle for the Rodeo Association of America's title of world's champion all-around cowboy for 1938 at the thirteenth annual world's championship rodeo at Madison Square Garden, which will open next Wednesday and continue until Oct. 30.

Seven proposals to redevelop the West Side from the Battery to Rector Street were submitted to the City Planning Commission yesterday by the West Side Association of Commerce, Inc., of 330 West Fortysecond Street, for inclusion in the master plan of the city which the commission is authorized to prepare under the new charter.

Retail trade made some further gains last week, but for the country as a whole sales were off from a year ago. Seasonal merchandise was in active demand in most districts. Reconstruction in New England was proceeding slowly and, with transportation still difficult, store volume was cut.

An eightState police search for Colonel William J. Wilgus, 72, famous engineer, ended today when the man who directed construction of Grand Central Terminal in New York City was located in a hotel here.

With the beginning of the Fall semester at the University of Oklahoma, all Methodist young people of college age are attending the same church for the first time in the history of the university town of Norman.

Manhattan College received yesterday a set of religious texts written in the language of the Indian tribes populating the Northwestern portion of the Untied States from the Marquette League for Indian Missions. Brother Albert Paul,
Purdue ripped through the Butler University line for three touchdowns and a 21-to-6 triumph before 18,000 spectators in Butler Bowl this sunny afternoon.
Penn State's Nittany Lions uncovered surprisingly sharp claws today as they conquered the University of Maryland by 33-0 in their season's opener before a fathers' day crowd of 12,000.
The German press has already begun to mention Germany's demand for colonies. The Hamburger Fremdenblatt, for instance savs that "if to a strong

The Ohio Power Company, Canton, Ohio, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 to cover issue and sale of $55,000,000 of first mortgage bonds. The interest rate and price to the public are to be furnished later.

Santi Quaranti, owned by the Groton Stable of Mrs. Robert Winthrop, today won the Connecticut Plate, feature of the annual meeting of the Adjacent Hunts Racing Association at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club.

Practically all of the second floor in the twelve-story business building at 140 Chambers Street, southwest corner of West Broadway, is now being occupied by William S. Sussman, Inc., which moved there last week, S. Earl Honig, president of the firm. reported yesterday.

While conditions once more approached normal in New Hampshire after last week's gale and floods, State disaster relief subcommittees completing their organization and surveying the damage, today had estimated the total losses at $24,000,000.

With an occupancy ratio of 95 per cent, the El Dorado apartment house, a General Realty building at 300 Central Park West, is completing its most successful renting season since it was opened in 1930, according to the West of Central Park Association.

A specially appointed principal took charge today of the Vaux Junior High School, where 300 pupils have refused to attend classes because, their parents charged, they were robbed and beaten by a group of older boys essaying the role of big time gangsters.
WHEN an author writes a book-excellent, original and thoroughly delightful-such as "National Velvet," his charmed readers look forward blissfully to the appearance of his next volume. Naturally, they

THE Brockhaus Verlag of Leipzig has published an imposing volume. rich in numerous illustrations, colored maps and detailed explanations, which will be of the greatest value to all who have more than a tourist's interest in Germany. The title is "Das Buch
A powerful University of North Carolina football team pushed over three touchdowns, all by George Radman, today to turn back North Carolina State College, 21 to 0.
Estimate in dollars of the damage done by last week's hurricane in Maine is impossible, since each day brings to light additional wreckage in remote places. It can be stated,

Reports of the work of Boy Scouts during the hurricane in New England add another stirring chapter to the history of the movement in the United States, it was declared yesterday at the national office of Dr. James E. West, chief Scout executive.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today denied the application of Roy Greene for permission to construct a railroad from Pittsburgh to Harrisburg, Pa. Mr. Greene sought permission to build the 203-mile line on a rightof-way of the old South Penn Railroad Company.
With about half of the 664 students in its membership, the St. Lawrence University Outing Club has planned an enlarged program of outdoor activities for the Fall, Winter and Spring.
CAPE TOWN'S oldest and most famous fishing schooner, the Titania, is the latest victim of the Namib Desert in South West Africa, known to seamen as the "Coast of Dead Ships." The Titania's crew were

HISTORIC old Fort Clinch, on Amelia Island near Fernandina, Fla., is being saved from the destructive currents of Cumberland Sound by CCC enrollees working under the supervision of the National Park Service.
A University of Texas eleven which amazed 17,000 spectators today by outplaying Louisiana State in the first half collapsed to let the powerful Tigers dash to a 20-0 victory.

New York State is the king-pin in any national political structure. If it drops aways, the entire machine begins to fall apart. Presidents have been elected without the support of New YorkHayes in 1876 and Wilson in 1916-but managing politicians of the major parties are more disturbed if prospects seem poor in New York than they are about any other campaign portent.

The engagement of Miss Emeline Lewis Thorne, daughter of Samuel Thorne of this place and the late Mrs. Thorne, to Robert Vance Brawley of Salisbury, N. C., son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Robert Vance Brawley of Salisbury, has been announced by her father. The announcement was made this afternoon at a tea given by Mr. Thorne at his home here.
Armour Co. rejected today the request of the Packing House Workers' organizing committee to negotiate blanket wage agreement for employes in all Armour plants.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The gains from the Munich settlement for the forces of law and order are substantial and far, outweigh the sacrifices. The greatest gain of all is that the democracies set out to enforce peace and succeeded.

What was done in Munich on Thursday night and Friday morning is thought here to have gone further in its probable consequences than merely the cession to Germany of territory that has belonged to Czechoslovakia for twenty years.
TWO New York artists who have been absent from the exhibition field for several years returned to the galleries last week with shows of recent work. Strongly contracted in intent

The Cambridge School of Architecture and Landscape Architecture, founded in 1915, and since 1933 an affiliated graduate professional school of Smith College, has this month been incorporated as an integral part of Smith College.

Citing the fact that institutional owners of real estate are optimistic about the future of the realty business, Robert L. MacGregor, supervisor for the Prudential Insurance Company of America, advises all real estate men to adopt the same attitude.

THE brilliant blue and green waters that surround Bermuda are the haunt of some of the gamest fish that swim. Any angler who allows himself to be carried off to Bermuda by his family need not fear that he will have no use there for his fishing tackle.

Scholarships and other tuition awards amounting to about $500,000 will be presented to undergraduate and graduate students at New York University in the current academic year, it was announced yesterday by Harold O. Voorhis, university secretary.

Formidable reserve strength helped Wisconsin's football squad score a 27-to-O victory over Marquette University before a crowd of 27,876 in the season's opener for both teams. The Golden Avalanche put up a surprisingly strong defense early in the battle, but gradually weakened against superior replacements.

All South America lined up solidly with the United States this week in an informal but nevertheess forceful alliance in favor of peace as a result of President Roosevelt's appeal to Chancellor Adolf Hitler of Germany and President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia not to plunge the world into war.

IN photography, quite as well as in any other art form, individual or group vision can be made articulate. And when this does happen a photograph that is really creative can, like a creative painting, seem in a legitimate sense suffused with signature.

The Piping Rock Horse Show at Locust Valley, L. I., continues today, although it was scheduled to end yesterday. Due to the-inclement weather of Friday, that day's events were postponed until today, much to the disappointment of the children, for the last two days are riven over largely to them.

Followers of field trial sport and spaniel breeders in particular will gather in Albany this week-end for the seventh annual field-trial meeting of the Albany Spaniel Field Trial Club, which will be run over the varied terrain of the Gallogly Farm in Feura Bush, a few miles west of the capital, Saturday and Sunday.

In addition to exerting a widespread influence on land planning procedure for home sites, the land planning section of the Federal Housing Administration has made it possible for builders and developers to make material savings in their operations, Seward H. Mott, chief of the section, declared yesterday.

BACKGROUNDS for shop interiors are coming to depend for effectiveness on the interior designer. Store managements recognize that past methods of display can be vastly improved by creating a hospitable air and a flattering setting for their wares.

Jack Welsh's 49-yard run in the third quarter gave the Mercersburg Academy eleven a 7-0 victory over the George Washington University freshmen today. Robinson of the visitors was forced to kick from his own 10-yard stripe, and Welsh, receiving, darted down the side for the touchdown.

Reports from the Midwest wheat farmers of growing dissatisfaction with the results of the Soil Conservation Act, which succeeded the original Agricultural Adjustment Act, suggest the possibility of a change in our farm policy in the near future.
Two games that will have an important bearing on the eastern division championship race of the National Football League are scheduled for today and tomorrow.
A series of Monday "debutante days," to be continued through the Autumn and Winter, will be inaugurated tomorrow at the Opportunity Shop, 46 West Forty-seventh Street. On these occasions a group

Out of what seemed the blackest certainty of war, peace has been snatched at the last minute, thanks, it is admitted here, to the persistence of Prime Minister Chamberlain more than to any other single cause, and the relief in France is momentarily enormous.

Mrs. Charles Maitland Connfelt will return Monday on the Queen Mary, and will go to her home in Brookville, L. I. Mrs. Nina L. Duryea has closed The Mill, her home in Stockbridge, Mass., and is visiting Mrs. Philip A. S. Franklin at Locust Valley, L. I.
Using a makeshift line-up to give some of their regulars a rest, the champion Cubs dropped their closing game of the season to the Cardinals today, 7 to 5, before a surprising turnout of 12,000 fans.
The heavy Catholic University eleven gained a 13-to-0 victory over St. Bonaventure College today before 6,000, the largest crowd ever to witness a game here.

Teschen reports that at 2 o'clock this afternoon Polish troops with unfurled flags, bayonets and machine guns and carrying flowers crossed the Olza bridge, which hitherto had separated the Polish and Czech parts of Teschen.

Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic candidate for reelection, will start today a 4,000-mile campaign tour that will last thirty days and carry him into at least 300 communities. The campaign party will leave Albany at 9 o'clock this morning.

The new hospital for the sick and infirm inmates of the Warschauer Haym Salomon Home for the Aged, 136 Second Avenue, adjacent to the home at 43 St. Mark's Place, was dedicated yesterday with the laying of the cornerstone of the new building.

The army gave a preliminary test today of its first far-flung civilianmanned air raid warning net and officers announced it worked mechanically with scarcely a hitch. In from two to five minutes some 2,000 volunteer observers flashed warnings from points as distant as 200 miles that hostile aircraft were sighted.

W. Ward-Stephens has accepted the post of organist of St. James Episcopal Church, Jerome Avenue and 190th Street, in the Fordham section of the Bronx, of which the Rev. Arthur V. Litchfield is the rector. He succeeds Benjamin Norton Scudder, who served twentytwo years.

Donald Hallman, Theodore A. Dunst, Matthew Green, Harold D. Grossman and Stanley Zeitlin were the winners in the first round of the preliminaries in the annual tournament for the championship of the Marshall Chess Club yesterday.

The Daily Express said today that worry over the international crisis was the principal cause of the illness of Queen Mary, who has been confined to Marlborough House for several days suffering from a sore throat.
Mr. Samuel Campner of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter. Miss Janet Ruth Campner, to Siegfried Weis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sigmund Weis of Sunbury. Pa.

Dr. Arnaud Denjoy, Professor of Mathematics at the University of Paris, will come to Harvard University as exchange professor from France, and Dr. Leigh Hoadley, Professor of Zoology at Harvard, will go to the Sourbonne as exchange professor to France, it was announced here tonight.

The Financial News's index of thirty industrial shares based on July 1, 1935, as 100, dropped on Wednesday to a low record of 73.7. By Thursday, it had recovered to 79.9, and on Friday was 83.5. Last week the index stood at 75.3; last month it registered 82, and a year ago, 107.6.

Nicholas Power, one-time Chief of Police of Halifax, who broke a conspiracy to assassinate the Prince who later became King George V, died today. He was 96 years old and had retired in 1907 after serving on the force forfortythree years.

The problem of world peace has not been solved by the Munich peace pact, and unless the people of all nations prepare spiritually as well as in other ways they may suffer a great disillusionment before the onslaught of an "ambitious conqueror," the Rev. Dr. Minot Simons said yesterday in his ser mon at All Souls Unitarian Church, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue.

The executive council of the American Federation of Labor, in its annual report made public today, bitterly condemned the "unholy alliance" between the National Labor Relations Board and the Committee for Industrial Organization and announced that amendments to the National Labor Relations Act would be necessary to curtail the board's "unlawful assumption of broad powers."

Colonel Jacob Ruppert and Farm Director George Weiss of the Yankees tonight were in the happy position of being able to pat the backs of both their International League and American Association hired hands, but tomorrow night they'll be on the horns of another dilemma.
The Jersey City Giants opened their American Football Association campaign at Roosevelt Stadium today and defeated the Newark Tornadoes, defending titleholders, 23 to 0, before 10,000.

Those who waited until the second day to open the woodcock season found the covers rather thinned out, although many put out this morning in the hope that the frost had brought in some '"flight" birds. A few more frosts and a full moon will find the flights well under way, and we'd like nothing better than the opportunity to try these covers at that time.

With only three unbeaten teams left in the fifteen-member loop, Southern Conference football squads will risk further dents in their recwords this week by opposing some of the nation's leading elevens.

Another chapter in the history of the 171-year-old Brick Presbyterian Church, now at Park Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street, ended yesterday when the Rev. Dr. William P. Merrill, retiring after twenty-seven years as pastor, introduced his successor, the Rev. Dr. Paul Austin Wolfe, to the congregation at the morning service.

The truckmen's strike, begun two weeks ago-with the walkout of 15,000 men in New York, was settled finally last night when the Highway Transport Association, representing 123 companies engaged in interstate business, signed an agreement with Local 807 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters on the basis of the com promise proposed by Mayor La Guardia last week.
John A. Lynch, retired Chicago banker, died tonight in CoralGables, Fla., at the age of 85. He recently went to Florida for the Winter.

The launching of an organization composed of nearly a hundred distinguished scientists and educators from various parts of the country to make a "thorough, unbiased and strictly scientific investigation of the problems related to the control of alcoholic beverages and to seek solutions through a program of unprejudiced research and education"
Ten are named for the Belgrade Stakes, opening-day feature today at the Jamaica meeting, which will mark the last 1938 racing on Long Island of the Jockey Club season.

Invitations have been sent out for the marriage of Miss Virginia Adele Jennings, daughter of Mrs. Emmett Judson Jennings of this city and the late Mr. Jennings, to Robert Minter Ferguson Jr. of Newark, which will take place here on the evening of Oct. 21 in the Weequahic Presbyterian Church.

After the police twice had repulsed the efforts of flying squadrons of World War veterans to invade the hall where he was to have spoken, Fritz Kuhn, leader of the GermanAmerican Bund, Nazi organization, cancelled his speech tonight and left under police escort.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 47 per cent of capacity, down 1 point from the preceding week. The last two weeks, however, brought the highest rate since the first week in November, when production was contracting rapidly, having held up better, comparatively, than business in general.

Germany's wholesale price index on Sept. 21 was 105.6, unchanged from Sept. 14. In the first eight months of this year the highest point reached by the German wholesale price index was 106.1, in the weeks ended on Aug. 3, 10 and 17. The lowest was 105.3, in the first two weeks of June.
Among passengers who disembarked yesterday from the Anchor liner Caledonia from Scotland and Ireland were three veteran transatlantic tourists who have spent much of their time at sea.

The story of a rescue at sea in which tragedy was averted when the United States liner American Banker took off the crew from a burning and sinking schooner 150 miles east of Halifax, was told in a brief message intercepted by the radio marine station at Chatham today.

At few colleges in the East has the Notre Dame system of football been so successfully installed as at Holy Cross. In 1933 Dr. Edward N. Anderson, captain at South Bend in 1921 and rated by the late Knute Rockne as one of the best ends he ever coached, came to Mount St. James to introduce the hop shift behind the balanced line.

Commenting on the Czechoslovak situation, Universal, in an editorial headed "Czechoslovak Peace," today says that Czechoslovakia for twenty years pursued a policy of faithfulness to her international obligations and to the sanctity of her signatures on treaties, up to the point of suicide.

Attorney General Cummings is keeping the promise that he made on Sept. 12. A special session of the Federal grand jury will be called on Oct. 17 at Newark to hear the evidence collected by Department of Justice investigators in the case of Mr. Norman Thomas, who in early May made charges of kidnapping against two of Mayor Hague's police officers.

After three days of heavy rain on the Ebro front the weather cleared this morning and the Insurgents were able to resume operations. These are still being conducted principally by artillerY and aviation.
The Philadelphia Germans defeated the Baltimore Germans in an American Soccer League fixture today by 4--0. Philadelphia took the lead nine minutes after the start, Nemchek scoring.
The customary Summer stagnation in industry was less acute than usual this year in Germany. In August the number of hours worked in industry was 16.3 per cent larger than that of a year before.

Now that the peril of war has disappeared, general attention will turn again to the domestic situation and particularly the state of France's finances. Apart from the ordinary budget, which is not balanced, the Treasury must resort to borrowing to cover the exceptionally heavy expenditures, especially for armaments, to which now will be added the expense of recent partial mobilization.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,973,440,350. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills.
The French wholesale price index for the week ended on Sept. 24 was 648, compared with 645 and 644 one and two weeks before.
Mrs. Richard Cobden Jr. of Larchmont, N. Y., and her daughter, Mrs. Isaac Lincoln Merrill Jr., gave a luncheon for eighteen today at Olde Egremont Tavern, South Egremont.

Walter H. Liebmann, Democratic opponent of Representative Bruce Barton in the Seventeenth Congressional District of Manhattan, charged last night in an address before the Roosevelt Society at the Hotel Capitol that Mr. Barton's advertising firm has as clients many of the most "reactionary" forces in the nation.

Dr. Arthur Stanley Mackenzie, first Dalhousie alumnus to become its president and under whose guidance it arose from a provincial college to a widely known university, died today in a hospital here at the age of 73.
Dr. Thomas Bassett Keyes, nationally known for his work in the prevention of tuberculosis, died today at the age of 63 in his home at Lake Bluff.

From London. "Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain had a hero's welcome on this rainy Autumn evening when he came back bringing the four-Power agreement and the Anglo-German man declaration reaffirming 'the desire of our two peoples never to go to war with one another again.'

Philadelphia's wandering tug, the John Wanamaker, was back at its dock today and Mayor S. Davis Wilson announced he had suspended Superintendent of Docks Michael J. Sullivan for taking it out of the harbor without authority on "a fishing expedition."

The holy communion service, origfinally a symbol of unity, has become the symbol of schism in the Christian church, declared the Rev. Dr. Zenan M. Corbe, executive secretary of the Board of American Missions of the United Lutheran Church, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Lutheran Church of the Advent, Broadway and Ninety-third Street.

Declaring that 75 per cent of the buildings In Manhattan are valued at near or less than their site assessment because of obsolescence, the Graded Tax Committee announced yesterday plans for a drive to revise the tax system on real estate.

Despite the generally alarming news from abroad and the warlike preparations in France and Great Britain and the lesser nations and in face of the unsatisfactory development in the early conciliatory efforts, Italian public opinion went through the week's events with unshakable calm.
Wally Berger hit a home run in the eighth inning to give the Reds a 5-to-4 victory over the heartbroken Pirates today, their third triumph in the important four-game series.

BIG BLOW, a dramatization in five scenes by Theodore Pratt from his novel of the same name. Staged by Anton Bundsmann; settings by Samuel Leve;-music by Hans Bruno Meyer; lighting by A. H. Feder; costumes by Mary Merrill; produced by Morris Ankrum and George Brewer Jr. for the WPA Federal Theatre Project. At Maxine Elliott's Theatre.

Professor Harry A. Millis, who has been named by President Roosevelt as a member of the fact-finding board to investigate the railroad labor dispute, is co-author of a three-volume study of "The Economics of Labor," being published by McGraw-Hill.

Dismissed from a hospital after treatment of head wounds suffered in a drug store political fight, Jesse Hilton Stuart, 31 years old, a Kentucky farm youth turned poet and teacher, vowed today that he was leaving his native State "for good."

The condensed statement of condition of J. P. Morgan Co., including Drexel Co., the Philadelphia branch of the firm, showed as of Sept. 30 total deposits of $436,317,117 and total assets of $500,267,342, compared, respectively, with $415,070,629 and $479,869,888 on June 30 last.

The seventh annual report of the United States Sugar Corporation, mailed to stockholders yesterday, shows a net income of .$621,687 after operating expenses, taxes and charges for the year ended on June 30, 1938. This was equal, after preferred dividend charges, to 39 cents a share on the outstanding common stock, compared with $871,082 and 55 cents respectively in the preceding fiscal year.
That there is a continuance of the demand for apartments throughout the city was indicated in lists of new tenancies announced over the week-end by brokers and renting agents.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed-Against CLAROLITE CORPORATIOON, lamp shades, 30 W. 26th St.-By E. I. duPont de -Nemours Co., Inc., on a claim for $1,317. Petitions Filed-By JOSEPH GREEN, cutter, 6,655 BroadwayLiabilities $1,026, no assets.
Jimmy Foxx, the Red Sox slugger, and Ernie Lombardi, husky Cincinnati catcher, are the 1938 batting champions of the big leagues, according to The Associated Press.

More than 6,000 Italian Roman Catholics paraded through the upper East Side yesterday afternoon to attend a Holy Name rally at the Church of the Holy Rosary, 442 East 119th Street. The parade was held by the Archdiocesan Union of the Italian Holy Name Societies, and was the union's first.

The Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street, gave a farewell dinner last night for one of its members, Sir Gerald Campbell, who has been British Consul General in New York for eight years and who will leave next week for Ottawa, to become High Commissioner of the United Kingdom in Canada.

Bleecker St. 190: Samuel Lax, referee, to 926 President St Corp. 1,450 B'way; mtg $20,000, foreclosure (50 cents). Mulberry St. 141: Concetta L. Blue, executrix of Antonio Cagliostro, to Citizens Savings Bank (50 cents).

The champion Washington Redskins loafed to an 18-0 exhibition game victory over the Louisville Tanks of the American Pro Football League today but their star passer, Sammy Baugh, made only two brief appearances.

Recent political events in Europe have been as devastating to man's civilization as the recent hurricane was to New Englad, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, dedared in a sermon yesterday at the seminary's chapel, Claremont Avenue at 121st Street.

All that by any one in California, man or woman, will have to do to qualify for the receipt of $30 a week (in State scrip) without having to work for it, if the constitutional amendment providing for a retirement life payments act is carried at the November 8 election and is not held unconstitutional by the courts, is to sign an affidavit and have it sworn to before a notary public.
Three similar fires within a short time, though in different sections of Queens, convinced detectives of the Astoria and Newtown police stations last night that a firebug was active in the borough.

Mining unions here report that the American Smelting and Refining Company, one of the two largest American mining companies in Mexico, has refused to sign three new collective work contracts and that as a result the Federal Labor Board will take up the cases thief week.

Five hundred officers and men of the Fire Department made a pilgrimage yesterday to the grave of Honorary Deputy Fire Chief M. F. Loughman in Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Mount Pleasant, N. Y., where a circular screen monument of granite was unveiled by Fireman Vincent J. Kane, president of the Uniformed Firemen's Association, which erected it.

William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, has been ordered by Mayor La Guardia to make an intensive inquiry into all law-enforcement units in Brooklyn as a result of conditions that led the Citizens Committee on the Control of Crime in New York to report the need for public scrutiny of "every agency for the enforcement of the criminal law in Brooklyn."
Scoring in every period, the Vleittown four defeated Burnt Mills at Schley Field today by 8-5. Sheldon Prentice set the pace with four goals.
Swiss military planes searched today for a German airliner reported missing with ten passengers and a crew of three on a run from Frankfort on the Main, Germany, to Milan. Italy.
Field trial enthusiasts gathered along the shores of Great South Bay today for the final water tests of the Autumn season's opening stakes of the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club.

Five passengers were slightly injured and 250 others were shaken yesterday afternoon when the municipal ferryboat Mary Murray crashed into the piling on her starboard side as she glided into her slip at St. George. S. I.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, trustee, has drawn for redemption on Nov. 1, through the sinking fund, $39,000 of Rochester and Pittsburgh Coal and Iron Company purchase money mortgage bonds upon the Helvetia Property. The bonds will be paid at 110 and accrued interest.

An indication of an attitude in Panama that is reassuring for the safeguarding of the Panama Canal appears in the first editorial by former President Harmodio Arias since he gained control of The Panama American.

A delightful little news item from Yonkers reveals the astonished Patrolman Michael Reagan receiving a summons from the stern hand of plain Mr. Martin Klein, manager of the Westchester Division of the Automobile Club.
With Joe DiMaggio displaying evidence that he has recaptured his home-run hitting form, the Yankees concluded the American League season here today with a 6-to-1 victory over the Red Sox.

The celebration of German Day in Madison Square Garden last night became the occasion for an open break between Nazi disciples and those who consider themselves more Americanized Germans in this country.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity- prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 80.4, which compared with 80.8 the week before, 80.7 two weeks before, 80.6 three weeks before and 80.6 four weeks before.

The German seaplane Nordstern, one of the fleet of planes making transatlantic survey flights for the last fifteen months, landed at the Pan American Airways base here this morning. It was the first German transport ship to arrive since the emergency sailing orders during the recent crisis.

There seems to be no stopping young Frankie Strafaci in the mixed foursomes tourney which the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club stages each Fall, for today the little Brooklyn atom scored his third consecutive victory in the event, with Mrs. Harry McNaughton as his partner.

A local boy made good today at the final session of the thirty-sixth annual Piping Rock Horse Show. It was a notable victory that was scored by James W. Maloney of this town, jumping his veteran bay mare Cherokee in the final round of the $1,500 open jumping tournament in which the civilians contested against the military.
The markets for corn developed independent weakness last week, as compared with wheat.
Stocks recovered all the losses for September and registered widest gains since the week ended June 25; turnover, 7,642,670 shares.

A Western Union messenger, off duty, and two blind girls had their first airplane ride yesterday at Floyd Bennett Field. They were among the 150 airplane riders on demonstration flights given jointly by the four major airlines in observance of National Air Travel Week.

Liquidation developed in lard futures last week and closing prices yesterday were 27 1/2 to 37 1/2 cents under final quotations of a week ago, with the nearby futures around the low point of the season. A fair run of buying orders developed during the war scare period, but most of these holdings were sold out later, thus tending to depress the market.

George D. Ellis Sons, Inc., Philadelphia, makers of tin cans and other metal containers for the oil industry, has acquired the Myers Manufacturing Company, Camden, N. J., producers of Labelstick metal boxes.

A nearly lyrical defense of cockroaches is the latest move by Deputy Mayor Henry H. Curran in the pleasant controversy arising from his- flinty attitude toward a plea for playgrounds for the city's dogs.

The Japanese stated tonight that they had taken the important town of Paishih, located on the Fu River south of the Yangtze. This move, they said, endangers a forty-mile front where the Chinese forces are said to number at least thirty divisions.

Miss Julia Niles Gavit, only surviving sister of Mrs. Pauline Gavit Gates, wife of Dean Milo Hudson Gates of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, New York, died at her home here tonight at the age of 83. In her earlier life she lived for many years at Stockbridge, Mass.

Marcus Gordon will give a piano recital at Town Hall this evening. The Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia, of which Mrs. Mary Louise Curtis Bok is founder and president, opens its fifteenth season today.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Norman Collyer of Forest Hills, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Norman Collyer, to Dr. E. William Cook, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Ira Cook of Texarkana, Ark.

After a moderate recession at the beginning of last week, cotton prices turned upward on the improvement of the European situation. At the close of the market on Saturday, active future delivseries on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances for the week of 11 to 22 points, compared with gains of 8 to 11 points in the preceding week.

Midnight on Saturday .was the deadline for filing certiorari suits in Mount Vernon, White Plains, Yonkers and other cities of Westchester County. .So many taxpayees have brought actions in Supreme Court seeking reductions of 1939 assessments that the total of reductions asked ismore than $2,500,000.

From Chequers today Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain announced that he had sent Premier Edouard Daladier of France a message, not only thanking him for his cooperation through the Czech-German crisis, but also giving him to understand that France had nothing to fear from the Anglo-German agreement reached at Munich last Friday.
Belgium's promptness in mining her strategic routes and in mobilizing to defend her neutrality was a leading factor in the peaceful result of last week's war crisis, according to many sources here.

A crowd of 15,000, the largest in the polo history of the post, saw Fort Hamilton's team subdue the Governors Island Blues, 8--7, in a benefit game yesterday at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation in Brooklyn. A number of prominent army officials and Mary Pickford, screen star, witnessed the match, the proceeds of which went to the Army Relief Society.

Reports from California indicate that "Ham and Eggs" is not the steaminghot political dish it was a month ago. When Sheridan Downey defeated Senator McAdoo in the primaries on a Townsend-built platform to give everybody over 50 "$30 every Thursday," the California State Treasury trembled. So did many liberals who are not quite so liberal as Mr. Downey.

The United Mine Workers of America, over 40,000 of whose members are idle in the hard-coal region, today actively entered the strike which members of the Newspaper Guild called yesterday morning against the four newspaper plants in Wilkes-Barre.

Professor George Elwood Nichols of Yale University and Mrs. Nichols announced today the engagement of their. daughter, Miss Grace Evelyn Nichols, to Arnold Densmore Rhodes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger W. Rhodes of Lancaster, N. H.

The 20,000,000 Catholics in the United States were called upon to take the lead in fighting communist, fascist and other irreligious forces attempting to destroy American democracy by speakers at a general meeting today of the fourth National Catechetical Congress of the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine, now in ?? here.

The Dodgers closed the National League season at Shibe Park today by defeating the Phillies twice, 7 to 3 and 7 to 2. Two rookie hurlers, John Gaddy and Sam Nahem, subdued the Quakers with little trouble.

Transit unification in the city will be delayed for several years if Constitutional Amendment 9. providing for exclusion of $315,000,000 from the city debt limit for unification, is not approved by the voters at the election, according to a report that will come up Thursday before the State Chamber of Commerce.

Sacramento's Solons won the Coast ,League Shaughnessy play-off by defeating San Francisco, 3 to 1 and 4 to 1, in a double-header today. Today's victories gave Sacramento, a St. Louis Cardinal farm, a 4-to-1 margin in the 4-out-of-7 series.

THE business we have just seen in Europe gives us an excuse to speculate once again, whether we enjoy the process or not, on the nature of modern Germany. There is no longer any doubt that at present Nazism is a positive force, the most powerful of this decade.

The 1938 big league baseball season was one of the most successful financially in years, The Associated Press reported. Attendance was more than 10,000,000, eclipsing by some 600,000 the 1937 mark and perhaps setting a new all-time "high" when all the returns are counted.

The fifth anniversary of the reinterment of the body of the ?? erable Mother Francis Xavier Cabrini in a tomb in the chapel of the Cabrini High School, 701 Fort Washington Avenue, will be observed at the school this evening at 8 o'clock.
Wilfred Draycott, veteran actor who frequently toured the United States with Marie Tempest, died here yesterday at the age of 90. His real name was Frederick William Drayson.
The Young People's Socialist League staged a protest demonstration in Times Square yesterday afternoon against the annexation of parts of Czechoslovakia by Germany.

United States airplane manufacturers have found in the settlement of the German-Czech problem renewed hope that they would be able to deliver 500 military planes ordered by Britain and France. A declared European war would have required President Roosevelt to prohibit such shipments to belligerents under terms of the Neutrality Act.

Both in the type of scores and in the results, the first Saturday of October produced some thoroughgoing upsets in the football world and left things pretty well confused. It is still very uncertain where the real strength lies and it will take one or two more weeks of play before the parade straightens itself out in any pattern.

The German advance into the Czech salient projecting into Germany from Warnsdorf and Rumburg began at 9 o'clock this morning. By 4 o'clock this afternoon the German troops, advancing in war formation and headed
CANOR COUNTRY, by Florence Pages Jaques. (University of Minnesota Press, $2.50.) The diary of a trip through the Minnesota lake country.

Fred Perry, former English amateur star who entered the national professional tennis tournament last week, carried off the singles championship tonight by defeating Bruce Barnes of White Plains, N. Y., 6-3, 6-2, 6-4, at the Chicago Arena.

President Roosevelt returned to his family home here today to resume the rest he had interrupted amid gathering European war clouds a fortnight ago and to lead the nation in a prayer for peace and of thanksgiving for its preservation. In these prayers he had asked all Americans to join.

Mrs. Ferdinand L Mayer, wife of the United States Minister to Haiti, is expected at the Madison tomorrow from Under Wood, her home at Old Bennington, Vt. Mrs. E. Hope Slater of Washington is returning on the Queen Mary, and will be at the SavoyPlaza.

The prayers of the people rather than the acts of any particular statesman were responsible for averting war in Europe, declared the Rev. Erwin Umbach in a sermon for young people at-St. Paul's Lutheran Church, Knickerbocker Avenue and Palmetto Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning.
A rugged line that helped Sid White and Irv Roth glitter in the backfield gave Brooklyn College a 32-0 triumph over Fort Hamilton in the opener for both elevens at Fort Hamilton yesterday.

This Berkshire "border" town of 1,138 population celebrated today the centennial of the arrival of the first railroad train in the county. A locomotive and two cars reached here from Hudson, N. Y., Sept. 2, 1838. Passengers were carried by stage coach to Pittsfield, 12 miles away.

An appeal to a higher court may relieve a husband from an erroneous lower court order to support his wife, but he cannot recover what he has paid her meanwhile, according to a decision of Justice Jacob Panken of the Domestic Relations Court, made public yesterday.
Thirtyone lives have been lost in two recent shipwrecks in Arctic waters, it was learned tonight. Nothing has been heard of a fishing expedition led by a Norwegian captain, Hallvard Devold,
Announcement was made yesterday of an agreement between the government and Bowater-Lloyd (Newfoundland)- Ltd., for timber and tariff concessions. Approval by the Dominion's office is required.
Five children of Mr. and Mrs. Willis Beckwith perished in a fire which destroyed their home today and fatally burned the father, who died several hours later.

Gunner Barlund of Finland and Lou Nova, a California heavyweight, will meet in the feature bout of fifteen rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. The bout is the first in Promoter Mike Jacobs's series of eliminations to determine the outstanding challenger for Joe Louis's title.

The twenty-fifth anniversary of the first service held in the present edifice of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue at Fifty-third Street, was observed the morning service yesterday.

Max Metzger, for more than fifty years a pharmacist in Brooklyn and Queens and for the last twenty years the owner of a drug store at Forest Parkway and Jamaica Avenue, Woodhayen, died yesterday at his home, 85-50 Forest Parkway, Woodhaven. His age was 72.

One great heave by Barney McCosky from right field kept the Beaumont Exporters in the Dixie Series today. His twelfth-inning toss choked off a possible winning Atlanta tally and left the game tied, 3-3, after thirteen innings, called on account of darkness.
Czechoslovakia agreed to negotiate the territorial demands of Hungary today while the armies of two other neighbors poured across her dismantled frontiers.

The forces of evil that are momentarily triumphant in Europe soon will be torn and destroyed by the very motives that have brought them together, the Rev. Charles A. W. Brocklebank, rector of St. Marks in the Bouwerie, said yesterday in his sermon as guest preacher at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Chancellor Hitler will have his triumph in Sudetenland today when he will accompany the German Army to Asch, where Konrad Henlein is awaiting him. German troops began crossing the border in the Asch region early today.
St. Joseph's College of Philadelphia scored in every period against a plucky, but outclassed, Mount St. Mary's eleven of Emmitsburg, Md., today. The score was 29-7.

Weather conditions and anxiety concerning international relations exerted a depressing influence on wholesale and retail trade last week.- The market,' however, received a fair volume of mail orders for apparel of all types.

Anticipating the requests of the thousands of visiting motorists who will seek road and travel information during the World's Fair, the Automobile Club of New York will open in the Hotel Pennsylvania tomorrow what is said to be one of the largest and most modern travel bureaus in the city and State.

Leaders of the American Labor party were busy on a platform draft and trying to decide on party candidates for State Controller and Attorney General last night on the eve of the opening today in the Manhattan Opera House of the party's first formal State convention.

Buck Newsom scored his twentieth victory today as the Browns defeated the White Sox, 4 to 3, in the first game of a double-header, but St. Louis lost the nightcap, 3 to 0. The second contest was called in the sixth because of darkness.

As France would have been the most vulnerable country had war broken out, the behavior of the Paris market during the acute crisis last week showed how remarkably calm and self-possessed was the nation.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 70.2 on Sept. 28, compared with 69.5 a fortnight before, 70.4 a month ago and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

Striking twice within a five-minute span, the Brooklyn Dodgers vanquished the Chicago Cardinals before 17,129 spectators at Ebbets Field yesterday, 13 to 0, and thereby vaulted into a three-way tie with New York and Philadelphia for second place in the Eastern Division of the National Football League.

Conflicting reports have been received here concerning Arturo Toscanini, who yesterday was reported to have "disappeared" in Italy. The Reuters correspondent in Milan reported this morning that Signor Toscanini,

Last week's settlement of the European crisis came with such dramatic suddenness in Munich that no one here will yet hazard a conjecture as to its permanent effect on the world's money markets and on the economic situation as a whole.

Shipments of gold to the United States, which at first assumed importance again in August, increased to record proportions in September, when they aggregated approximately [Pound]71,000,000. Exports of the metal to Switzerland, The Netherlands and other countries offering safety or an assumed guarantee that in the event of war holdings would not be impounded, also have been heavy.

After Munich, What? This is the question to which Europe wakes up this morning after the nightmare of the past three weeks. The wild delirium of relief at the hair'sbreadth escape from war calms down.

Man in his efforts to find peace and security in this terror-stricken, world has tried every solution but the one offered by Jesus Christ, the Rev. Francis K. Shepherd declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the North Baptist Church, 232 West Eleventh Street.

Lieut. Col. Sir Reginald Seymour, for twenty years Equerry in Ordinary to King George V and subsequently Equerry to Queen Mary, died today at the age of sixty. Severely wounded both in the South African and World Wars, he became King George's Equerry in 1916 after being incapacitated for further active service.
The Scots-Americans gained a 3-to-2 verdict over the- Brookhattan F. C. in their American Soccer League fixture today.
Dr. James Rowland Angell, former president of Yale, and Mrs. Angell will introduce Mrs. Angell's daughter, Miss Caroline Woodman, to society on the afternoon of Oct. 21 at the new home of the hosts.

Highgoal polo came to the close of its season with the best game of the year today. With 10,000 in the big stands of International Field wrapped in overcoats and blankets, Aknusti fought its way through to the Waterbury Cup by defeating Old Westbury.

Evacuation of the important town of Bodenbach, which was Czechoslovakia's largest harbor on the Elbe River, was completed this morning, but as late as 4 P. M. no German troops had occupied the town. Order was maintained by the municipal police, all Sudeten Germans.

Harry Hopman, captain of the Australian Davis Cup team, contributed a sensational upset in the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament today by eliminating John Bromwich, ranking Australian, 6-3. 6-3, 10-8.

The 1938 outboard racing season came to an end today as the Passaic Yacht Club staged a regatta for boats in Classes A, B, C and F on the Hackensack River. Each race consisted of two laps of one mile each.

William Rabenort, a district superintendent of schools in the Bronx, who had been prominent in the New York public school system for twenty-three years, died suddenly Saturday night of a fractured skull when he fell in the bathtub in his Summer home at Beacon Beach, N. J.

Mrs. Wilfred B. Langmore of Garden City, L. I., formerly of 235 East Fifty-seventh Street, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Muriel Langmore, to George Hugh Bainbridge, only son of Mrs. J. H. Bainbridge of Halford, Warwickshire, England, and the late Commander Bainbridge, R. N.

With a docket already numbering nearly 400 cases, the Supreme Court will meet tomorrow for its 1938 term. Tomorrow's session will be formal, and real work will not begin until Oct. 10, when the calendar will be adjusted through rejection or retention of hundreds of petitions for review of lower court rulings.
Isidore D. Morrison, retired lawyer and Zionist, died yesterday morning from coronary thrombosis at his home, 575 Park Avenue. He was 66 years old.

Commodity prices were irregularly lower last week, according to The Annalist. Its index dropped 0.3 point to 80 on Saturday, the lowest level since mid-August and 14 points below the index of a year ago.
French tax receipts for August amounted to 3,894,000,000 francs of which 1,151,000,000 francs, is in direct taxes.

In the short space of one week, Great Britain's financial markets have experienced all emotions, from blank despair to abounding hope. Securities prices moved with a velocity not witnessed in any previous crisis except on the eve of the Great War of 1914.

A $15,000 oratorical contest open to all young men and women between the ages of 16 and 24 will be conducted throughout the nation this month by the Young Republican National Federation, it was announced yesterday.

Accused of operating an illegal alcohol still in a private house in a select neighborhood at 25 Chatfield Road, Yonkers, William Feldsman, 38 years old, of 841 East 176th Street, the Bronx, and two companions were held by the Yonkers police today for appearance tomorrow in Federal court in New York.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary is due today from Southampton via Cherbourg with 2,118 passengers, a record number, officials of the line said yesterday. The list includes Count George Polocki, Polish Ambassador to the United States, and Dr. Hu Shih, Chinese Ambassador.

General Rudolf Medek, one of the best known leaders of the Czeqhoslovak Legion in the World War, has addressed letters to King George VI and the French President, returning his decorations. To King George he wrote:

More than 1,000 men and women representing veterans' organizations in Queens marched in a parade yesterday to dedicate a square at Forty-second Avenue, National Avenue and 102d Street, Corona, to the veterans of all wars. Miss Delia Esposito, county president of the Ladies Auxiliary of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, unveiled a boulder at the square.

A pledge of local autonomy and of freedom from political assessment was incorporated yesterday in the constitution of the new city-wide organization of WPA workers and home relief recipients, which was formed as the result of a split in the ranks of the Workers Alliance of Greater New York.

Joseph T. Cosby, with a service record of more than thirty-six years, retired on Saturday as vice president of the National City Bank. His banking career was prefaced by one year in the consular service.

The Department of Hospitals of the City of New York will receive bids, which will be opened Oct. 13, for the construction of a new tenstory administration building at Bellevue Hospital, according to Brown's Letters, Inc.

Mickey Haslin, recruit infielder, returned to the Polo Grounds too late to get part of the Giants' share of the world series pool but just in time to insure third place money for the National League champions of last year, who finished one game ahead of the Reds.

The possibility of a new playground near the Borden Avenue approach to the Queens-Midtown Tunnel was disclosed yesterday by the Queensboro Council for Social Welfare, which made public a letter from Park Commissioner Moses to Pierce H. Power, president of the council. The letter said:

The New York Central Railroad announced yesterday that workmen had completed repairs on the last of its affiliated lines that were disrupted by the hurricane and floods in New England and that service on these lines would be resumed today.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Perry D. Bogue of Round Hill, this place, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Bogue, to William K. Townsend, son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Townsend, also of Greenwich.

Life insurance companies were disturbed less by the depression than any other major type of private credit institution, the Twentieth Century Fund's committee on debt adjustment reported in a statement made public yesterday.
