The first wave of exhibitions for the 1938-39 season in New York's art galleries neatly coincides this year with the opening of October, nearly a score of shows being scheduled for the first week of the month.

With military occupation of the ceded Sudeten areas proceeding according to schedule, attempts were made here today to study more closely the implications of the four-power agreement signed in Munich. Early appraisals accept it as a long step toward general European solidarity.

Vincent Astor, who owns the Waldorf Building at 2 to 16 West Thirty-third Street and 15 West Thirty-second Street, has purchased the adjoining twelve-story loft building at 5-7 West Thirty-second Street.

Between $600 and $700 was taken from a safe in the book room in Newark University, 40 Rector Street, this afternoon. The safe combination was not forced. Entrance to the building was gained through a rear door.

The engagement of Miss Ruth Adler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Adler of 211 Central Park West, to Herman N. Liberman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Liberman of 1,010 Fifth Avenue, has been announced by her parents.
The Federal Government's newly appointed civil aeronautics officials will lunch with Mayor La Guardia while flying over New York tomorrow as part of their observance of National Air Travel Week.

The onset of the Sudeten crisis perceptibly-accelerated the pace of German currency inflation, the Reichsbank's report for Sept. 23 disclosing a heavy increase in loans and a substantial rise in bank notes outstanding and in total circulation.

Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for Governor, yesterday branded the leaders of the American Labor party as "bureaucrats" who have confronted members of their own party with a ticket which is "an amazing mixture of Democrats, Republicans, Communists or Communist fellow-travelers and plain members of the Labor party."
Dr. Henry Hanson, representative of the Pan-American Sanitary Bureau, was decorated with the official Order of Merit by the Ecuadorean Government before he sailed for New York yesterday.
From a report made public today by the Citizens Union it appears that Park Commissioner Moses and Sanitation Commissioner Carey will not go to war over Jamaica Bay.
St. Mary's Celtics defeated the Bethlehem F. C., 5 to 3, in an American Soccer League match at Celtic Park in South Brooklyn yesterday. At half-time the Celtics led, 3--0.

New York State's fish hatcheries produced a total of 474,662,665 fish of various sizes in sixteen different species in 1937, the Conservation Department announced today. The fish were planted in suitable lakes, ponds and streams throughout the State.

Mrs. Jennie Johnson, 66-year-old cancer sufferer, whose husband turned on the gas yesterday in their home in Hewlett to save her from further agony, died of gas poisoning and not of cancer, it was indicated today by Dr. Theodore J. Curphey, Nassau County Medical Examiner, after an autopsy.

John Ward, 31 years old, of 273 Cypress Avenue, the Bronx, was found dead in a bedroom of his apartment early today after a twoalarm fire that swept the two upper floors of the five-story building at that address, driving twentyfive families to the street.

Asserting that the countries that are threatening world peace are those whose people have been trained to ignore God, the Rev. Joseph A. Tytheridge, preaching yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, warned that the present system of American education was producing a future generation which will be a similar "powerful force for destruction."

Twelve employes of the Republic Steel Corporation have charged, in affidavits placed in the records of the Senate Civil Liberties Committee, that they received violent treatment at the hands of striking pickets during a strike at the company's plant in Canton, Ohio, in May, 1935.

With the war scare out of the way, no substantial barrier remains to a continued upsurge in advertising linage, according to agency executives. In the early days of last week considerable uneasiness had been engendered by the nearness of a world conflict, and some advertisers had begun to talk about moving cautiously, but the peace settlement ended all uncertainty.

Miss Dorothy Alexander, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Alexander of this place, has completed plans for her marriage on Oct. 22 to William A. Caldwell of Ridgewood. The ceremony will take place in the evening in the First Reformed Church and will be performed by the pastor, the Rev. James E. Hoffman.
Miss Isabel Kearny Day, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Osborne Atwater Day of this city, was married to Thomas Hooker, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Hooker, in Christ Episcopal Church yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: That man is petty, indeed, who will allow his prejudices to stand in the way of a full and a frank recognition of the notable part played by the President of the United States and his- Secretary of State, Cordell Hull, in the late negotiations for peace at Munich.

The New York Americans bowed to the Kearny Irish-Americans by 2--0 in a thrilling soccer game at Starlight Park yesterday. A crowd of 3,000 saw the New Yorkers put up a stirring battle until the final whistle.

Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, whose aplomb is generally equal to any emergency, became considerably ruffled yesterday morning when she arrived at Grand Central Station at 11:40 o'clock to be met by an escort of a detective and a uniformed detail of fifteen patrolmen and a sergeant.
Mrs. Caroline Peddle Ball, sculptress, of Harwinton, widow of Bertrand E. Ball, died here yesterday in the Charlotte Hungerford Hospital after several months of failing health.
The official gazette today published the names of 321 Soviet Russian citizens who had been disfranchised. The names were mostly Jewish.

Recent arrests by postoffice inspectors have smashed two gangs which committed a series of postoffice burglaries throughout Pennsylvania and the Middle West, Postmaster General Farley announced today.

Miss Mollie Todd Jenks, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Daker Jenks of this place, will have her sister, Miss Ida Daker Jenks, for her maid of honor at her marriage to Edward Victor Donaldson Jr., on Oct. 15.

A comprehensive plan to restore, protect and improve the Fire Island barrier beach at an estimated cost of $15,500,000 was submitted tonight to town and county officials of Suffolk County by Robert Moses, president of the Long Island State Park Commission.

The moving pictures, radio and pictorial newspapers are making us Intellectually lazy, said the Rev. Dr. Karl Reiland, rector emeritus of St. George's Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Place and East Sixteenth Street, in a sermon there yesterday morning.
Arthur White Tedcastle, pioneer in the development of the New England foreign shoe trade and a friend of Woodrow Wilson, died today at his home in Milton at the age of 82.

The New York Football Giants will make their first home appearance of their fourteenth National League campaign at the Polo Grounds tonight, when they face the Pittsburgh Pirates, who are headed by Whizzer White. The kick-off for the arc-light contest has been set for 8:30 o'clock.
The British Embassy protested today to Soviet authorities against the alleged seizure of three British trawlers by Russian warships in the Arctic Ocean north of Murmansk.
World series interest flamed to fever pitch tonight with the return of Chicago's conquering Cubs and the National League championship.
Perhaps not in many years has a comparison of contending world series teams offered so many perplexing aspects as does one of the Yankees and the Cubs. In this coming meeting we have on the one side

Winding up the yacht racing season on Long Island Sound today, the International Class held two contests and Corny Shields won both of them with his Aileen. Bill Cox, sailing Caryl Sayre's Feather, was second in the morning event, 30 seconds astern of Aileen at the end of six miles.
Helen Hayes returns in "Victoria Regina" tonight at the Martin Beck Theatre. This will be the third Broadway engagement for the Laurence Housman play, the first having opened on Dec. 26, 1935.

Edward P. V. Ritter, who was president of the Grand Central Palace and the Merchant and Manufacturers Exchange from 1912 until his retirement in 1920, died yesterday in his apartment in the Hotel Astor after an illness of several months. His age was 80.

Miss Susanne Lee Cooper, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Ira Cooper of this city, has chosen Oct. 21 for her marriage to G. Burgess Fisher 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Burgess Fisher of Hartford, Conn. The ceremony will be performed in the First Congregational Church by the Rev. George Ogden Kirk, the pastor.

More than 15,000 men and women attended a polo game at the Fort Hamilton Army reservation in Brooklyn yesterday for the benefit of the Army Relief Fund which gives aid to the widows and orphans of soldiers.
It's off again, on again, for the steamer San Angelo. The 5,605-ton steamer left Baltimore last night for Cristobal but ran aground a few hundred feet from Fort McHenry, in the harbor.

Questionnaires have been sent to every candidate in the House of Representatives and the United States Senate asking their stand on the national foreign policy with respect to Spain, it was announced yesterday by the Lawyers Committee on American Relations with Spain, of which Paul Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, is chairman. It reads:
Bob Feller, young Cleveland marvel, enhanced his fame today, but the Indians bowed twice to the Tigers, 4 to 1 and 10 to 8.
Word was received here today of the death yesterday at Bolton Landing, N. Y., of Frank H. Abbott, dean of New England and Florida hotel men. His age was 88.

The Chicago Bears, packing superior weight and power, downed the Philadelphia Eagles, 28 to 6, today in a National Football League game. The Bears remained undefeated and on top in the Western Division of the loop. It was the second setback for the Eagles.
David Sackson, second violinist of the Gordon String Quartet, and Julius Chajes, Polish pianist, gave the first of three sonata recitals late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall.

Mr. and Mrs. Flavel Shurtleff of Montclair, N. J., gave a tea at their home yesterday afternoon at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Brown Shurtleff, to Robert Leland Crowell, son of T. Irving Crowell of Upper Montclair and the late Mrs. Crowell.

The rapidly changing political scene completely dominated the Boerse from Monday to Friday. Anticipation of the Fuehrer's speech on Monday sent most of the principal issues down as much as 4 1/2 points, but buying by the banks later limited losses on the day to 2 points.

A new mark for church membership in this country has again been attained, according to The Christian Herald's annual report of church statistics, prepared by Dr. Herman Carl Weber, the publication's statistician.

Although the European crisis shocked business in this country, further gains in business, particularly in retail trade, were made last month, it is brought out in the current monthly letter of the National City Bank.

Solidifying the studio's schedule, Selznick International has announced its program for the 1938-39 season. According to John Hay Whitney, seven films will be released, including the completed "The Young in Heart" and "Made For Each Other," which has just gone before the cameras.

The "Little Mother" of thousands of men in American: prisons, General Maud Ballington Booth of New York, cocommander of the Volunteers of America, told a mass meeting of social workers, penologists, the lay public and members of the American Prison Association tonight that "society has fallen down on the job of befriending the paroled prisoner."

Miss Lucille E. Melchior, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Melchior of this city, became the bride of Edward Hoffman, son of Harry C. Hoffman, in St. Mary's Catholic Church here yesterday. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. M. J. Boylan, the rector.

THEY say that once upon a time Illinois was playing Penn on Franklin Field and a fellow named Red Grange turned it into a one-man show. This observer missed that but saw Sid Luckman in the Yale Bowl on Saturday. He did everything for Columbia except lead the band between the halves.
Frederick Ryan, 55 years old, of 53 Great Kills Road, Great Kills, S. I., a deckhand, was swept from the deck of a Manhattan-bound Staten Island ferry boat about 2:30 o'clock yesterday morning.

Present and future possibilities for credit extension will be discussed at a Tri-State Conference of District 2 of the National Association of Credit Men at the Bellevue-Stratford Hotel, Philadelphia, Oct. 21 and 22. About 500 credit executives from New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania are expected to attend.

Reconciliation of man and God and of dictatorship and democracy are a requisite for the building of bridges to span the chasm of hate, Indifference and intolerance between nations and between man and God, the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo declared yesterday morning in a sermon to the congregation of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Fortyeighth Street.
Ray Schalk, manager of the Indianapolis club of the American Association, may succeed Gabby Street as manager of the St. Louis Browns in 1939.

The big four in Munich saved peace. Why? Can they preserve it in the future? And how? These are the most important questions of the day. As I see it, they succeeded first of all, because of the balance of opposing forces.

The Irish Free State again will be represented in the nightly international military jumping contests at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden from Nov. 5 to 12, it was announced by Whitney Stone, vice president and secretary of the National Horse Show Association, yesterday.

St. Mary's Gaels, relying mainly on ground plays, overpowered Gonzaga's Bulldogs, 20 to 0, before a crowd of 12,000 today. It was a St. Mary's show almost from the opening kick-off, with the Gaels superior on land, in the air and almost every other department.

Mr. and Mrs. Archiebald J. Dando of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy A. Dando, to Lewis B. Fiori, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard B. Fiori of San-Vito-Cadore, Italy.

Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Book Shops, Gimbels, Macy's, Scribner's, Wanamaker's and Womrath's: FICTION My Son, My Son! by Howard Spring (Viking). The Yearling, by Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings (Scribner's).
State Convention, American Labor party, Manhattan Opera House, 10 A. M. Speakers: Mayor La Guardia, Arthur Huggins, Leland Olds, Alex Rose. Continues tomorrow.

Details of the plans for the Canadian pavilion at the World's Fair were made public yesterday by Douglas S. Cole, Canadian Trade Commissioner, after he had received them from Major J. C. Parmelee, deputy minister of the Department of Trade and Commerce, Ottawa.

Marshal Alexandru Averescu, Rumania's World War generalissimo, died tonight at his Bucharest palace at the age of 75. He was Premier of Rumania three times and commander of the Rumanian Army in 1913 in the successful war against Bulgaria. He also was commander of the army in the World War.

At the moment Fla that Premier Edouard Daladier was preparing to go before a special sitting of Parliament on Tuesday for the approval of the Munich accords, Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain today sent to his French colleague a message of thanks which should-strengthen the French Premier's hand.

After an interruption of eleven days, due to hurricane and flood damage, normal train service will be resumed tomorrow by the Boston Maine Railroad on most of the important lines which were affected by the storm, railroad officials said tonight.

An 11-year-old girl in pink pantaloons and a 17-year-old boy with the precision of a professional prestidigitator won first prizes at the finals of the city-wide magic contest on the Central Park Mall yesterday afternoon, but it was a youngster in the audience, who, by his unswerving determination to be a volunteer assistant, almost stole the show.

The schooner General A. W. Greely, bearing the MacGregor Arctic Expedition homeward, is 150 miles off Cape Cod tonight after having encountered a tropical storm of gale force during the past twenty-four hours.

Colgate's Red Raiders lost to Cornell yesterday, 15--6, but today Coach Andy Kerr, who knows his football players, went so far as to say that "Colgate will have a very good football team before the season ends."
Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, celebrated his sixty-seventh birthday anniversary this morning by spending about two hours in his office. Otherwise, his day was uneventful.

George V. Denny Jr., president of Town Hall, announced yesterday a new series of late afternoon lectures and round-table discussions "designed for the tired business man and woman." They will be directed by Chester D. Snell, former dean of the extension division of the University of Wisconsin.

Carrying word to Washington that New England's emergency situation is over and that rebuilding in the wake of the hurricane and flood is well under way, Robert E. Bondy, American Red Cross disaster relief director, left Providence tonight to nfer with Norman H. Davis, Red Cross chairman.
The movements of the pound sterling in the last few days were matched in violence by the wild fluctuations in the stock market here.

The National Labor Relations Board handled 16,770 cases between the Fall of 1935 and Sept. 1, it reported today, and has closed 12,950 of them, leaving 3,820 pending as of Sept. 1. The board claimed that its action had averted 612 strikes, involving 162,738 workers.

The government announced today it would begin on Oct. 10 to release troops called up for service during the Czechoslovak crisis. The communique said "Commencing Oct. 10 classes of 1910 and 1912 which recently-were called up will be gradually returned on leave."
A novel experiment in newspaper training begins at Harvard this Fall as the Nieman Fellows leave their editorial desks from many centers and go back to college.
The World Series schedule for the Cubs and Yankees: Games 1 and 2 at Wrigley Field, Chicago, Wednesday and Thursday, Oct. 5 and 6, both starting at 2:30 P. M. New York time.
The last concert of the Federal Music Project's Russian symphony series, given last night at the Federal Music Theatre, attracted an audience that occupied every seat and standing space.
One of the pleasantest yet most unexpected exhibits at the World's Fair will be a quarter-of-an-acre wheat field planted by a baking company.
Congress was urged today by the National Association of Manufacturers to investigate fully charges that certain "high industrialists" were aiding Fascists and Nazis in the United States.

For more than two weeks the world's wheat market has been wholly dominated by European war alarms. Prices advanced sensationally but without any broadening of public interest in the market, and it took relatively little selling to start the prices downward when the corner was turned to peace.

Raymond M. Schwartz, who was secretary of the committee that filed removal charges against former County Clerk Albert Marinelli and who later served with a committee that urged Thomas E. Dewey to run for District Attorney, "rebuked" the prosecutor yesterday for his insinuation that Governor Lehman was "window-dressing for a corrupt machine."
The Westchester sessions of the third annual series of THE NEW YORK TIMES News Conferences will be held today at the Mamaroneck Junior High School on the Boston Post Road, opening at 10:30 A. M.
Morris M. Goldman, who owned and operated the Goldman Hotel here for the last twenty years, died today at his home after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

Philadelphia and Washington split a double-header today, the Senators annexing the first game, 5 to 2, as Joe Krakauskas gave only six hits. Big George Caster pitched five-hit ball for the Athletics' 4-to-2 victory in the second contest.
Back to the gridiron wars marched thousands of schoolboy players during the past week-end as King Football firmly established his grip in virtually every section of the East.

Financial markets which, from the moment when the Czechoslovak crisis became acute, had reflected closely the public's alternations of hope and despair, presented last week a picture which is not often to be seen on the exchanges.

Problems of legal and constitutional development in the United States and the relation of the country to the present international situation were outlined before 1,100 Westchester County clubwomen here today at the annual NEW YORK TIMES Review-of-the-News Conference, held in the Mamaroneck Junior High School on Boston Post Road.

Voting under the new Board of Higher Education by-law ."democratizing" the city colleges Brooklyn College faculty members in the English, Romance Languages, Chemistry and Art Departments se-. lected yesterday new-chairmen for their departments.
A travel and personal service bureau, available to the 36,000 members of the Automobile Club of New York, was opened yesterday by the organization on the ground floor of the Hotel Pennsylvania.
Following are excerpts from speeches of various leaders in the debate in the House of Commons today on foreign affairs, and of Foreign Secretary Halifax in, the House of Lords.

From a speculative standpoint today's wheat market furnished one of the dullest sessions in a long time. All futures on the Board of Trade here held within a range of 3/8 cent a bushel, one of the smallest average fluctuations in a number of years.

Important changes are being made in the text and presentation of the Baltimore Catechism, the standard of religious instruction for Roman Catholics in America since 1885, it was learned tonight at the National Catechetical Congress of the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine.

To help promote the efficient operation of municipalities, Mayor La Guardia urged yesterday at the opening of the annual conference of the American Public Works Association that public works officials be exchanged among cities so that they could share the advantages of their various experiences.

The Italian Government, in Informazione Diplomatica, the Foreign Ministry organ, strongly urges Czechoslovakia today to reach an understanding with Hungary as soon as possible regarding the Hungarian minorities.

As in last week's practice, timing promises to be the keynote of the New York University football squad's workouts this week in preparation for the contest with Rutgers on Saturday at New Brunswick, N. J. Coach Mal Stevens expressed his dissatisfaction with the execution of plays in the Maine game and a good part of yesterday's drill at Ohio Field was devoted to improving this aspect.

The Federal Government incurred a deficit of $700,983,353 in the first quarter of the current fiscal year, which ended on Friday, compared with a deficit of $287,075,674 in the corresponding period last year, the Treasury Department's daily statement showed today.

With a feeling of quiet confidence which is not the least of their valuable assets, the Yankees entrained for Chicago yesterday for their world series meeting with the Cubs which opens tomorrow at Wrigley Field.

Dr. Joseph Anthony Vaeth, Associate Professor of Romance Languages at the New York University College of Arts and Pure Science, died of pneumonia here today at Lawrence Hospital after a brief illness.

Three vessels on the Atlantic giving positions widely apart, were reported in danger last night. One asked all vessels in the vicinity to stand by, one was being towed by the Coast Guard and the third was awaiting assistance at a late hour.

Fusion party, made public yesterday a list of the candidates endorsed by that party for offices in the city. Mr. Howe said that the party, being purely a civic organization and not interested in State or national politics, was selecting no candidates for other than local office or legislative posts representing local districts.

The National Football League contest between the Brooklyn Dodgers and the Pittsburgh Pirates will be played Sunday at Forbes Field as originally scheduled, it was announced yesterday by Coach Potsy Clark.
The Dramatic Society of the College of Mount St. Vincent, Riverdale, announced yesterday the election of May Reynolds, a senior, as president, and Alice Kearney, a junior, as secretary-treasurer.

Henry A. Hunt, Negro principal of the Fort Valley, Ga., Normal and Industrial School and an assistant to the governor of the Federal Farm Credit Administration, died of a heart attack on Saturday in Washington, D. C., according to word received here yesterday. Mr.
Chancellor Adolf Hitler's speech today in the main public square of Eger, just after this town had been annexed by German forces, follows: Men and women of Eger!
In the Customs and Patent Appeals Court of the United States today, John M. Leach of New YorK was admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:

Mrs. Margaret Holt Lowry, formerly of New York and Philadelphia and descended from prominent Virginia and North Carolina families, died yesterday in the home of her sister, Mrs. Holt Clark, with whom she resided at Palos Verdes Estates in California, it has been learned here. Her age was 58.

Whizzer White gave Owner Art Rooney his first dividend on a $15,000 investment last night when he paced the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 13-to-10 upset victory over the New York Giants before the dumbfounded gazes of 18,805 spectators who attended the first National Football League game of the season at the Polo Grounds.
Sales of country property in theI Huntington section of Long Island have been picking up recently, according to William J. McNiff, broker.
The twenty-four-hour period beginning at sundown this evening will be for Jews throughout the nation the most solemn day of the year-Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement.

ARNOLD--Felix, on Oct. 1, 1938, beloved husband of Dora E. Arnold (nee Halk), at his residence, 317 West 89th St. Funeral services at the Lutheran Church of the Advent, 93d St. and Broadway, on Tuesday, Oct. 4, at 2 P. M. Interment private.
Walter A. Smith, 78 years old, will retire on Thursday as paying teller at the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, 165 Broadway, after more than fifty-eight years of service.

179th St (11-3106), a w cor of Mapes Ave, 100x35; Sarah J. Schaefer to 530 East 173d St, Inc. 530 E 173d St; mtg $28,000. Park Ave (11-3039), e s, 25 ft a of 185th St, 50x100: John Pieper to Sophie Freenick, 521 E 147th St; mtg $9,000. Albany Post Rd, 5,114 (13-3415H); Anlovil Contracting Corp to Theresa Merola, 5,114 Albany Post Rd: mtg C1 4.400.
Steel production is scheduled at 47.9 per cent of capacity this week, compared with 46.7 per cent last week, a gain of 1.2 points, or 2.6 per cent, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.
It seems that New Brunswick has no monopoly on the bear population this season, for the plentiful supply of beechnuts has brought numbers of big blacks to the ridges of the northern area of Maine.

The store and apartment property at 1,317 Avenue Z, Brooklyn, was sold by George E. Chatillon and Emma W. Schaefer, trustees, to Salvatore Burrafato and Domenico A. Galotti. N. Edward Veron was the attorney for the purchasers. Wingate Cullen, attorneys, represented the sellers. Walter Samuels, Inc., were the brokers.
Thousands of Roman Catholics visited churches in the Archdiocese of New York yesterday to pray for peace in response to a call from the Bishop Donahue, Administrator of the Archdiocese.

A technical loan of 11,000,000 pesos contracted by the National Bank of Mexico has been called by the government through the Bank of Mexico, causing new disquietude in banking circles. The step was taken to reduce the government's overdraft of 174,000,00C pesos at the Bank of Mexico.
Otis A. Thompson, president of the National Bank and Trust Company of Norwich, N. Y., was renominated yesterday for Class A director of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Walter C.

Miss Margaret Schieffelin Pardee, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Irving H. Pardee of 133 East Eightieth Street, will be married to Dr. Talcott Bates, son of Mrs. J. Willard Travell of 12 East Sixty-fourth Street and the late Rev. H. Roswell Bates, on the afternoon of Oct. 13 in St. Bartholomew's Church.

Spanish Insurgents said today they "bombed" Madrid with 178,000 loaves of bread. Loaves one-quarter. of a pound each were cast on the former Spanish capital, Insurgent dispatches said, while Government aircraft batteries blazed away at the "bombers."

The use of persuasion, without resorting either to censorship or the establishment of fixed standards, has been found effective enough to become the sole method of the copy control committee recently organized by a group of women's magazines.
Dr. Fong Foo Sec, educator and for many years an editor of the Commercial Press, the Far East's greatest publishing organization, died today at the age of 68.

The Board of Transportation has held the income and the operating expenses of the Independent Rapid Transit Railroad at approximately the same level while providing 3.8 miles of new railroad covered by eight new subway stations, the annual report of the Independent lines indicated yesterday.

In line with a previous announcement that he was determined to bring the WPA to the highest possible level of efficiency, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell sent out yesterday the first of a series of letters to project supervisors designed to improve management and operation.

Progressive American business welcomes a broad and impartial governmental investigation of monopoly as a step toward correcting possible errors in price structure, Clarence Francis, president of General Foods Corporation, told about 400 editors and executives today at the seventeenth annual New Jersey Newspaper Institute at Rutgers University.

The marriage of Miss Helen Marie Sierra, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis R. Sierra of Flushing, Queens, to Cuthbert Cook Snowden, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ralph C. Snowden of Niagara Falls, N. Y., took place yesterday afternoon in the rectory of St. Andrew's Catholic Church, Flushing. The Rev. T. J. O'Brien performed the ceremony.
The text of the speech of Alfred Duff Cooper, former First Lord of -the Admiralty, in the House of Commons today follows:

Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank of New York, and Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, sounded warnings here today against that type of government which exercises too rigid control.
Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr., Crestmont star, won the gold qualifying medal in the annual New Jersey State women's golf championship with a score of 41, 43-84 over the hilly Plainfield course today.

Transfers involving some of the most important commands in the army were announced today by the War Department. The commands are those of the Pacific sector of the Panama Canal Zone, three coast artillery districts and the First Army Corps Area.

An entertainment program delineating the viewpoint of the "social theatre" and consisting of dance, song and sketches will be presented this evening at Mecca Temple under the auspices of the New Theatre League.

Estate, more than $10,000. To Annie Miller Averbeck, widow, 390 West End Ave., household, personal effects and life estate in residue; Maximilian J. Averbeck Jr., son, executor, Ashley Rd., Llewellyn Park, West Orange, N. J., and Carolyn A. Tyler, daughter, Circle Rd., Dongan Hills, Staten Island, succeeding estates in residue. Central Hanover Bank and Trust Co., 70 Broadway, executor.

To provide funds for students on its waiting list, the Hattie Bondy Scholarship Fund, which has supplied carfare and lunch money to needy college students, will hold a bridge and bingo party at the Hotel Delmonico Sunday at 8 P. M. Paul Asch and Harry Engel will act as masters of ceremony.
For lo these many months the word has been abroad that the two football teams of the year in the Ivy group are Dartmouth and Cornell.

Declarations made from the platform of the German Day celebration in Madison Square Garden as reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES' yesterday were incorrectly attributed to Hans E. Wirsing, president of the United German Societies, instead of to H. O. Spier, secretary of that organization.

The pound sterling and the currencies linked to it turned weak again yesterday in the foreign exchange market under the combined influence of a renewed movement of European funds here to participate in the rising securities markets and the news from London

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, which last Wednesday left a Europe feverishly preparing for war, arrived in New York yesterday with 2,112 passengers, the largest number ever carried by the ship.

Colonel John Reed Kilpatrick, president of Madison Square Garden and one-time end on the Yale football team, startled the members of the Football Writers Association at their first weekly meeting at Jack Dempsey's Restaurant yesterday by blasting Yale's policy of curtailed Fall practice.

With more than 80 per cent of the outstanding underlying bonds of the Los Angeles Railway Corporation deposited in accordance with a refunding plan, the directors have extended to Oct. 31 the time for

The National Industrial Conference Board yesterday reported an increase of 338,000 manufacturing employes in August, compared with July, lifting the total of employed persons to 43,453,000, a gain of 422,000 or about 1 per cent.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn reserved decision yesterday after hearing arguments in an appeal from the conviction by a jury in Suffolk County Court on July 12 of six members of the GermanAmerican Settlement League, Inc., operatorss of Camp Siegfried, at Yaphank, L. I., for failing to file documents and statements with the Secretary of State, as required by law of all oath-bound organizations.

Once more the American Federation of Labor, this time in the annual report of its executive council, has bitterly attacked the administration of the National Labor Relations Act. The council declares that the Labor Board has "brazenly and by official acts declared itself as a proponent of the C. I. O., fostering its interests and by the effect of its decrees recruited membership for the C. I. O."

Prosecutor Howard Eastwood announced today that the September grand jury had not returned an indictment against Magistrate William P. Young, 46, on charges of "assessing excessive costs" in his small-cause court here.

With a genuine show of enthusiasm, the delegates to the first legal State convention of the American Labor party, in the Manhattan Opera House, last night renominated Governor Herbert H. Lehman and United States Senator Robert F. Wagner and nominated Supreme Court Justice Charles Poletti for Lieutenant Governor.

Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Elliott Huger of this city and Flatrock, N. C., have announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Margaret Louisa Watkins, to Reuben B. Robertson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robertson of Asheville, N. C.

The Rev. Dr. Charles S. Kemble, for many years a Methodist Episcopal minister in New York and New Jersey towns died yesterday afternoon in the hospital of Lord Taylor, department store at Thirtyeighth Street and Fifth Avenue.

Foreign Secretaries-or, as we would call them, Secretaries of State-were eclipsed by the heads of governments as the Czech crisis came to the boiling point. The names of Chamberlain, not Halifax; of Daladier, not Bonnet; of Hitler, not Ribbentrop; of Mussolini, not Ciano, and of Roosevelt, not Hull, were first on the lips of men when the Munich agreement was projected and ratified.

Mrs. Arthur Hudson Reddall of 173 Riverside Drive and Hampton Bays, L. I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Sampson Horton, to John Murray Black, son of Mrs. Roger Derby Black of Washington, D. C., and the late Colonel Black.
Retired Captain Joseph A. Kelly (1), Tormerly a member of Engine Co. 289, residing at 60-27 Woodbine St., Ridgewood, Queens, died Sept. 23.
A roaring reception by thousands of Chicagoans keyed Manager Gabby Hartnett and his Cubs today for their world series with the Yankees opening Wednesday.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 28:

In the despair and bitterness into which this country has been plunged as a result of the Munich decisions reconstruction of the Czechoslovak Cabinet is under consideration, with a view to coming to terms with Germany, now that the country has been deserted by allies and friends.

A plea for substantial and immediate American aid for the refugees pouring out of the Sudeten German areas of Czechoslovakia was made to Secretary of State Cordell Hull today by Vladimir Hurban, the Minister of Czechoslovakia.

Following is the text of the platform adopted by the State convention of the American Labor party: The American Labor party enters its third political campaign with a confidence born of the knowledge that during the brief period of its existence it has become deeply rooted throughout the Empire State and has gained nation-wide adherence to, and respect for, its basic principles and political faith.
The text of the speech made by Prime Minister Chamberlain in the House of Commons today follows:

California-Oregon Power Company--Twelve months to Aug. 31: Net income after operating expenses and charges, $887,861, compared with $1,105,148 in the twelve months to Aug. 31, 1937; gross revenues for the period were $4,627,600, against $4,670,273 in the preceding comparable period.

Shoe retailers had average net profits ranging from 1.6 to 4.4 per cent by groups in 1937, despite sharp recession in the last quarter, according to an analysis of operating and merchandising experience issued yesterday by the National Shoe Retailers Association, from figures compiled by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

An old Chelsea holding and dwellings in various sections of Manhattan figured in the realty transactions reported yesterday. The five-story double flat at 225 West Fifteenth Street, held for more than a quarter of a century by the Clark estate, was sold to a client of Jacob Kessler, broker.

THE football coaches, scouts, officials and innocent bystanders went into their first formal huddle of the Fall in this vicinity yesterday. Lou Little showed up in the pink of condition. He came through the Columbia-Yale crisis without a scratch.

The State Supreme Court, sitting today at Pittsburgh, declared unconstitutional legislation of the. Earle Administration which would have blocked a grand jury investigation of graft and corruption charges against Governor Earle and thirteen associates until a legislative inquiry, now under way, had been completed.
The international stock market indices for Oct. 1, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:

Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo dismissed yesterday contempt of court proceedings against twelve striking employes of the Busch jewelry stores and Harry Sacher, their attorney, after Mr. Sacher had agreed there would be no more picketing by members of the two unions he represents pending further litigation on an antipicketing injunction issued by Justice Cotillo last June.

Windows in a number of buildings in the vicinity of Borden Avenue and Vernon Boulevard, Long Island City, Queens, were broken yesterday forenoon by a blast from work being done at the Long Island City end of the Queens-Midtown vehicular tunnel.

Jack Blrnbaum, 29 years old,. whey for more than a year, since his arrest, had been a thorn in the side of Tombs officials because of his simulation of insanity, was sentenced to a five-year Sing Sing term yesterday by General Sessions Judge Freschi on his conviction of the theft of $800 in April. 1937.

With full knowledge that it is facing a complete change of national and foreign policy, the Chamber of Deputies will meet tomorrow to discuss the four-power Munich agreement and all that led up to it.

Because of their long association with John Theofel, former Democratic leader of Queens, County Judges Charles S. Colden and Thomas Downs are disqualifying themselves from hearing the trial of the politician's son-in-law, F. Dudley Wilson, charged in two indictments with grand larceny.
Japan finds it difficult to continue cooperation with the League of Nations since the report authorizing sanctions against Japan, a Foreign Office spokesman states today.
The Chilean Legation announced that Jose Luis Tejada Sorzano, former President of Bolivia, died today at Arica, Chile, at the age of 56.

Leo Moon, a pitcher for seventeen years, won the Dixie series for Atlanta today with a three-hit, 7-0 decision over Beaumont of the Texas League. The Crackers, Southern Association champions didn't drop a game in the series, winning four and tying yesterday's thriller in thirteen Innings.
Class I railroads in July had 929,886 employes, a decrease of 244,548 or 20.82 per cent correspondingly last year, the Interstate Commerce Commission reported today.

James H. Fay's margin over John J. O'Connor in the primary fight for Congress in the Sixteenth Manhattan District was 553 votes, according to the official canvass made public yesterday by S. Howard Cohen, president of the Board of Elections. The vote was Fay 8.352, O'Connor 7.709.
Joe Migdal, 185-pound junior back, moved into Manhattan's first-string eleven yesterday afternoon as preparations for Saturday's battle with Holy Cross at Worcester got under way.

A thousand members of the British Legion, a patriotic and charitable organization of those who fought in the World War, will be sent to Czechoslovakia to supervise the plebiscites to be held there, it was announced today.

An Eighth Avenue bus was stopped between 126th and 127th Streets yesterday afternoon and the passengers were forced to dismount one at a time while a patrolman, with drawn revolver, hunted for two Negro hold-up men who a few minutes before had robbed Albert Harris, a renting agent on the second floor of 370 Manhattan Avenue, of $168.

A tentative 1939 budget for White Plains which would increase the tax rate by $2.50 for each $1,000 of assessed valuation, was presented here tonight for consideration by the City Council at a public meeting held in the Eastview Junior High School.
The Bureau of Navigtlion released the following orders today, dated Sept. 30:

Miss Tolly English, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. English of this city, was married to William F. Clarke, son of Lieut. Col. and Mrs. Frank W. Clarke of Quebec City, Que., yesterday in the rectory of St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Joseph Tytheridge.
The death of Giulio Setti, former chorus master of the Metropolitan Opera, was reported by cable yesterday, according to an announcement made by the Metropolitan Opera Company.

VICTORIA REGINA, a play in three acts and ten scenes, by Laurence Housman. Settings designed by Rex Whistler; staged and presented for the third time on Broadway by Gilbert Miller. At the Martin Beck Theatre.
The first quarantine against yellow fever at the Panama Canal in twenty years was established today by the Chief Health Officer, Colonel H. C. Pillsbury, against Caribbean ports.

Fatalities in traffic accidents took another sharp drop last week and week-end as compared with the corresponding periods of last year, it was announced yesterday by the Safety Bureau of the Police Department.

Four thousand troops of the First Infantry Brigade, First Division, completed today the preliminary stage of training manoeuvres here during which battalion and regimental problems were solved in the field.

Governors of the New York Curb Exchange will be called in special session this afternoon after the close of the market to discuss reorganization plans which were submitted on Saturday to the Securities and Exchange Commission.
One of the most comprehensive sports programs ever undertaken was announced yesterday as a feature of the World's Fair by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation.

A refugee from the Spanish war who sought asylum in the United States after seeing his cousin and nephew executed by the Spanish Rebels, won his freedom yesterday in Federal Court here, although he admitted he had stowed away on an American vessel in 1937 in violation of our immigration laws.

Mary Pickford of the films hurried here from New York by plane today to be at the hospital beside of her husband, Charles (Buddy) Rogers, who suffered a torn right shoulder ligament in an automobile accident near Delaware, Ohio.
Automobile production last week increased more than seasonally and the adjusted index advanced to 36.3 from 30.6. The figure for the week ended Oct. 2, 1937, was 139.1.
Robert M. Lockwood, export manager of the Ford Motor Company during the first seven years of its existence, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital at the age of 75.
Bruno Mussolini, 21-year-old son of the Premier, is to marry Gina Ruberti, daughter of Professor Guide Ruberti. A brief published announcement did not set a date.
Chicago packers, who withdrew all offerings of hides last week, re-entered the market yesterday with quotations 1/2 cent higher on all grades, and some sales were made at the advance.

Representative Dies informed the National Association of Manufacturers today that an agent of the House Committee on Un-American Activities would look further into charges that certain unidentified industrialists were aiding Nazi and Fascist movements in this country.

Britain authorized a loan of ??10,000,000 to Czechoslovakia yesterday to aid her reconstruction. There was a heated debate in the House of Commons after Prime Minister Chamberlain defended the Munich agreement.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Appleton, who are at the Madison after returning from East Hampton, L. I., have gone to Palm Beach. Dr. Hu Shih, the newly appointed Chinese Ambassador, who arrived on the Queen Mary, is at the Ambassador before going to Washington.
The Real Property Council of New York, Inc., has set up a bureau of research, legislation and bill drafting for the purpose of giving advice on proposed legislation, reports Robert Daru. president.

The address of Governor Lehman at the State convention of the American Labor party follows: I am sincerely grateful to you for the honor which you have paid me in nominating me as your candidate for the office of Governor of the State of New York.

Princeton held a short review session on University Field today brushing up on the fundamentals and studying the passes that failed to click against Williams Saturday. Practice started and ended late, with floodlights used for the first time this year.

Commercial and industrial failures in the United States in the week ended Sept. 29 totaled 203, as compared with a 163 in the same week a year ago and 193 a week ago, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

Corporal Sellier, who was tne first to blow the "cease-firing" command on his bugle when the armistice went into effect Nov. 11, 1918, blew that happy message again last week when news of the Munich settlement was announced, says a dispatch from Belfort to the Petit Parisien.

Price reductions were announced for 1939 models yesterday by Studebaker and Pontiac. The Studebaker cuts included one of $95 on the State President model. Pontiac cuts were typified by a reduction of $70 on the lowest priced two-door sixcylinder sedan.

Frankie Cavanna, 146 1/4 pounds, East Side, scored a technical knockout over Milt Aron, 146, Chicago, in the feature bout at the Broadway Arena last night before a crowd of 2,500. The fight, scheduled for eight rounds, was stopped at 1:50 of the seventh.

Pedro Dreyfuss, a French engineer in whose favor Minister of Trade Ricardo Bascunan signed last week without previous announcement a concession authorizing a search for oil in Chilean territory, declared today that he had already located sites in the Cordillera region of the Central Provinces where the existence of oil was beyond question.

The official Town and Country Planning Advisory Committee, in its report on the preservation of the countryside which was issued here this week, unanimously recommended "a single and effective code" for the control of outdoor advertising.

Captain Richmond A. Ware, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Ware of Bronxville, N. Y., have announced from Ware Crest, their Summer place near Hot Springs, Va., the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Mary Ware, to Byrne Bauer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Hudson Bauer of 215 East Seventysecond Street, this city.

The development of intellectually competent persons who can work creatively with hands as well as with brain is the great need of America today, Dr. William Mather Lewis, president of Lafayette College, told 1,800 students and faculty members of Pratt Institute yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia's prompt order to Commissioner of Investigation Herlands to begin a general inquiry into law enforcement in Brooklyn will be widely approved. The Citizens Committee on the Control of Crime in New York, led by its president, Harry F. Guggenheim, has been watching the work of criminal courts, prosecutors and the police in this city for fifteen months. On Sept.

The Schooner A. W. Greely, carrying the members of the MacGregor Arctic Expedition, will arrive at Port Newark, N. J., tomorrow afternoon. The expedition departed from Reindeer Point, Greenland, the base camp of .the party, July 7.
Carding a sub-par 32, 3365, Henry Dobbs and Henry Ciuci of Fresh Meadow captured the Long Island P. G. A. amateur-pro tournament at the Rockville Country Club today.

Suffolk St, 165, 25x100; mtg $12,250; also Broome St, 53, 25x100; mtg $12,000; Rose Margulis ano to Margod Realty Corp, 401 Braodway; ($1). 79th St, 6 E, 25x102.2; Wm. C. Dickerman to Crosstown Realty Corp, 521 5th Ave; mtg $75,000 ($5).

Uncertainty caused by the war scare in Europe last week lingered among manufacturers and foreign traders here yesterday despite the temporary settlement resulting from the Munich conference on the Sudeten problem.
Denmark's foreign exchange reserves have improved steadily in the last fifteen months, according to a report to the Department of Commerce from the United States commercial attache in Copenhagen.
On his own application: To take effect 12 midnight, Oct. 1: PATROLMAN - Andrew Kerrigan, 70th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed July 3, 1913.

Lou Nova of San Francisco nominated himself as a heavyweight worthy of consideration when he defeated the rugged Gunnar Barlund of Finland last night in the feature bout at Madison Square Garden. Nova scored a technical knockout in the seventh round of the fray, which was listed for fifteen rounds.

Five hundred women volunteers who will help the Women's Division of the Federation for Support of Jewish Philanthropies to raise $1,000,000 heard yesterday how the money will be used to aid 300,000 persons.

Jewelry valued at $40,000 to $50,000 was stolen from Mrs. Lawrence Tibbett, wife of the singer, as the liner Monterey approached Los Angeles harbor, she reported today. Mrs. Tibbett was accompanied by her husband.
Arrangements were made yesterday for the transfer of a New York Stock Exchange membership at $68,000, a decrease of $12,000 from the last previous transaction.
The National Federation of Private Traders was formed at a meeting at Birmingham this week to oppose the "cooperative society menace."

The University of Maryland's injury-riddled eleven suffered its greatest blow today-Jim Meade is out with a broken ankle. Meade, sparkplug of the team's attack, big figure in its defense and all-Southern back last year, injured the ankle Saturday against Penn State.

11th St, 119-25 E, 93x123.9 irreg; Webster Enterprises, Inc, to Sally Ellis, 31 Harrison Ave, Brooklyn; pr mtg, $100,000; 3 yrs, 5%; $20,000. Suffolk St, 165, 25x100; pr mtg, $12,250; also Clinton St, 228, 25x93.6; pr mtg. $15,000; Margod Realty Corp to David Cohen. 147 E 3d St; 5 yrs, 5%; $5,000.

Al Simmons turned in his Washington uniform today and said with some heat that he hoped he never would have to wear it again. "So far as I am concerned," the veteran outfielder told reporters, "the Washington baseball team and I are through."
Nominations for New Zealand's general election closed today with 176 candidates named to contest the eighty seats of the House of Representatives. Election day is Oct. 15.

The American Republics liner Brazil, which will sail Saturday on the first voyage of the new passenger and freight service to the east coast of South America, was taken on a trial run yesterday to Fire Island and Barnegat Light.

Harry Chapman Jones, founder of the H. C. Jones Engraving Company and a former president of the Litho-Printex Corporation, died yesterday at his home in Great Neck, L. I., after a six months' illness of heart disease.

An old Chinese and Japanese legend about orangutans was applied today to the war in China. A Japanese correspondent reported he had it from a reliable Japanese source that the Chinese had 5,000 orangutans trained to throw hand grenades.

Expressing approval of the policies of President Roosevelt, Leland Olds, temporary chairman of the State Convention of the American Labor party, urged the progressives of the State in his "keynote" speech yesterday, to support the Labor party candidates at the polls.
Once again the banks outside New York City and Chicago have made a better showing in the matter of business loans than the big city banks.

Manhattan Alterations Norfolk St, 58; to 5-story tenement and stores; Chesterfield Building Co, Inc, 9 E 40th St, owner; D. Kaufman, engineer; cost, $12,000. I 93d St, 313-5 E; to two 5-story tenements; Dry Dock Savings Institution, 59th St and Lexington Ave, owners; A. J. Simnberg, architect; cost, $8,000. Monroe St. 1,371; to 5-story tenement and stores; Mary Littman, 7 E 42d St, owner; _B. H. Whinston,_ architect; cost, _$3,000.

Strictly choice and prime fed steers and yearlings sold actively and fully steady, top remaining at $13.35. Hog prices opened 10 to 15 cents lower, but further weakness developed and the close was 25 cents down, the United States Department of Agriculture reports.

Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente refused yesterday to reduce the $10,000 bail fixed for Julius (Red) Williams, held as a material witness in the James J. Hines trial, after he had been informed by Assistant District Attorney Charles P. Grimes that the witness "obviously had been reached" between the time he testified before the grand jury and the time he took the witness stand at the trial of the Tammany district leader.

The text of Mayor La Guardia's address at the State Convention of the American Labor party was as follows: Mr. Chairman, Delegates: It is customary for all parties to invite the Mayor of the city in which a State convention is held.

Representative James M. Mead, Democratic candidate in New York for the short term for Senator in New York, urged today the establishment of a permanent Federal work-giving agency for all workers over 45 years of age.
Pennsylvania came out of its easy victory over Lafayette without an injury and started intensive work for Yale's football visit Saturday by tuning up its offense today.
The advance was resumed on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday as prices reached new high levels for the current movement and about 1/2 cent a pound above the recent low point.

Twentyone Jews, including three women and ten children, ranging in age from 1 to 12 years, were killed and three persons wounded last night on the shores of Lake Galilee, in the old Jewish quarter of Tiberias, in a massacre by stabbing, shooting and burning perpetrated by Arabs.

At least two of three women fliers, who started a non-stop flight from Moscow to the Far East Sept. 24 and had since been missing, were reported found alive today near Komsomolsk, on the Amur River along the Manchukuoan border.

Expressing confidence. in a sharp upturn in the demand for business equipment and launching a variety of new machines designed to cut costs and increase efficiency, seventy exhibitors participated yesterday in the opening of the thirtyfifth annual National Business Show in the Commerce Hall of the Port Authority Building.

Adrian Quist of Australia won the men's singles championship of the annual Pacific Southwest tennis tournament today, defeating his fellow-countryman and non-playing captain of the Australian Davis Cup team, Harry Hopman, after a stubborn contest, 6-3, 0-6, 6-4, 6-4.
AT MIDNIGHT ON THE THIRTY-FIRST OF MARCH, by Josephine Young Case. (Houghton Mifflin, $2.) A narrative poem in blank verse.
Miss Ruth Newell Maverick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Maverick of this city, will be married on Oct. 15 to Hugh Kenneth Haller of Buffalo, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Haller of Frederick, Md.

Eight striking A. F. of L. machinists returned to their jobs at the Hoyer Engineering Company today after Mrs. Elizabeth Wallner, president of the firm and mother of nine children, promised them a 32 per cent share of the profits for the next fifteen months.
Jack Altman, city chairman of the Socialist party, announced yesterday that the party would open its State campaign this week with a series of rallies in this city.

An exhibition of oils, water-colors, gouaches and drawings by the late Robert B. Harshe, who died last January, opened yesterday at the Rehn Gallery, 683 Fifth Avenue, and will continue until Oct. 22.

John Kissel, former Republican Representative and State Senator from Brooklyn, and one-time owner of a brewery and a chain of saloons, died yesterday at his home, 821 East Forty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, after a brief illness.
" Abe Lincoln in Illinois," first production of the new Playwrights Company, was presented here tonight prior to its New York opening.
The wholesale commodity price level was slightly lower last week according to the National Fertilizer Association's index. This index for the week ended Oct. 1 stood at 73.1,

The realty auction lists in the Bronx yesterday were made up entirely of houses foreclosed by the Home Owners Loan Corporation. There were seven properties in the day's sales record, and in each case the house was bid in by the HOLC. The list follows:

In the Supreme Court of the United States today Henry Silverman, Walter M. Andrew, Carl E. Ring and Irving F. Goodfriend of New York City were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:

Trading in cotton futures on three organized cotton exchanges, New York, New Orleans and Chicago, totaled 4,991,000 bales during September compared with 2,816,100 bales in August, the Commodity Exchange Administration announced today.

Robert V. White, president of the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company, said yesterday that he knew of no negotiations for a reduction of the rent paid by the Central Railroad of New Jersey to his company for the use of the Lehigh Susquehanna Railroad.

Accusing John L. Lewis of having failed to say a single word against communism in his recent Mexico City "bull ring" address, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, today asserted that the Committee for Industrial Organization's chairman was leading a movement to wipe out the present structure of the federation and attain, by setting up "one big union," the "very objective of the Communists."

Development of a new sanitary milk-bottle lip intended to correct what long has been the weakest link in bringing healthful milk to the consumer is announced by Dr. Lloyd Arnold of the University of Illinois College of Medicine in Chicago.

A eulogy of Associate Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo, who died in July, was delivered by Chief Justice Hughes as the Supreme Court opened its 1938-39 term today. After a fifteen-minute session the court adjourned until next Monday.

Paso, Texas, Will consider tenders for $491,000 of school, drainage and library bonds. for which bidders are to name the rate of interest. The issue, to be dated Nov. 1, 1938, will mature on Nov. 1, 1939 to 1958.
Turpentine firm, 20 3/4c bid: no sales; receipts. 276 barrels; shipments, 205 barrels; stock, 51,772 barrels.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Color Schemes: Red and Orange," Grace Cornell, 11 A. M.; American Wing (general tour), noon; motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.; "Interior Design: Italian Furniture," Grace Cornell, 3 P. M.

The present will to peace of the world offers the opportunity and basis for a more permanent solution of international ills through armament reduction, freer flow of trade and an agreement against air bombing and gas attacks on civilians, Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, declared tonight in a radio address.
The Germany Army began today to take possession of the third and most important of the four sectors of the Sudetenland assigned by the Munich four-power conference for immediate occupation.

Mrs. Hattie McKinna, 32 years old, a chambermaid in the Palace Hotel here, died in the Perth Amboy General Hospital today one hour after she had been shot by her estranged husband during an argument in the corridor outside her room in the hotel, according to Police Chief John F. Murray.

Alphonse Ovide Pessou, an insurance broker with offices at 225 Broadway, died in Beekman Street Hospital yesterday afternoon, a short time after he had collapsed, apparently of a heart attack, in front of 175 Franklin Street.

A solemn high mass of requiem for the late Cardinal Hayes was celebrated yesterday morning in the St. John Baptist De la Salle Chapel on the Manhattan College campus by Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, of the Class of '73. Students and faculty members attended.

A. F. Cleveland, railroad witness, told the President's fact-finding board today that government activities had contributed directly to the loss in revenues which, the carriers contend, make necessary a 15 per cent pay cut for their employes.
Samuel Perlman of 1,419 St. Mark's Avenue, Brooklyn, a retired cap manufacturer, died yesterday in the Madison Park Hospital, Brooklyn, of complications following an operation.

Reports reached here through Paris today that Marshal Vassily Bluecher, Commander in Chief of the Soviet Army in the Far East, had been arrested. Agence Radio declared from Paris that there was a general conviction in Moscow that Marshal Bluecher had been imprisoned.

Speculative interest in the bond market turned to railroad issues yesterday with these obligations advancing fractions to 8 points to lift the price index a full point on the day. Buoyancy ruled in other sections of the market but the trading price fell off from last week's levels.
Although the apartment renting season has officially passed, such activity continues at a brisk pace, reports received yesterday from brokers in scattered sections of the city indicated.

A chance discovery by President Roosevelt on his Dutchess Hill forestation project today may mean that the all but extinct chestnut tree, devastated by a mysterious blight several years ago, may be coming back.
The Rev. Michael J. Dwyer, who was successful in five varied professions before becoming a Catholic priest, died here tonight after a short illness. His age was 77.

Extra details of police were required last night to unravel the worst traffic snarl the city has. had in recent months, caused when the'upper roadway of the Queensboro Brilge was closed for repairs. From 4 to 7 P. M. some automobiles required forty-five minutes to cross the bridge.

With Mayor La Guardia, city officials and members of the Civil Aeronautics Authority in the leading plane, seventeen transport aircraft and one smaller chartered plane flew over the city yesterday afternoon, carrying about 300 invited guests.
Holders of outstanding stock-purchase warrants of the United Aircraft Transport Corporation, predecessor company to the United Aircraft Corporation, United Air Lines Transport Corporation and

Robert A. Magowan has been elected a vice president and director of Merrill Lynch Co., Inc. Vincent M. Gowen and William Cooke Faulkner have joined the New York Stock Exchange firm of E. W. Clucas Co. as co-managers of the trading department.

The Treasury's weekly offering of approximately $100,000,000 in ninetyone-day bills was sold today at an average interest rate of 0.032 per cent, compared with 0.142 per cent last week, Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight. There was at least one bid of 100.

Argument before the Supreme Court on the constitutionality of the Tennessee Valley Authority was postponed today for a month to allow the government's special counsel, John Lord O'Brian, a Republican, to campaign in New York for the United States Senate against Robert F. Wagner, ardent New Dealer.

Judge Leonard J. Hackney, former Indiana Supreme Court Justice, patron of Rollins College and former general counsel for the Cleveland, Cincinnati, Chicago St. Louis Railroad, died here yesterday at the age of 83.

George M. Harrison, chairman of the Railway Labor Executives Association, served notice today that his group would oppose the proposed merger of the Gulf, Mobile Northern and the Mobile Ohio Railroads.

Fred A. Male, Yonkers insurance and real estate broker, pleaded not guilty today before County Judge Frank H. Coyne to indictments alleging that he committed forgery and perjury in obtaining signatures on the primary election petition of David S. Murden.
Trucking service, local and interstate, resumed normal aspects yesterday with the return to work of 2,500 drivers employed by members of the Highway Transport Association.

Patrick J. Kelly of the Montana Field Club last night was named president of the Metropolitan Association of the A. A. U. at the Capitol Hotel. Kelly, former chairman of the boxing committee, succeeds Major Patrick J. Walsh, in office since 1934.

Patricia Morison, who was seen on Broadway in the role of Laura Rivers in Mare Connelly's "The Two Bouquets." has arrived at Paramount for the feminine lead in "Persons in Hiding," by J. Edgar Hoover.

Yesterday the Supreme Court began a new term in which a number of cases of national moment will come up for review. The court stands adjourned till next Monday to go over the calendar. We shall have to wait to know what petitions have been granted and what refused; but the right to review was accorded to some last Spring.
The Treasury announced today that the Philadelphia Mint manufactured last month 2,600,000 1peso coins for Cuba and 1,080,000 12 1/2-centimo and 6,000,000 5-centimo coins for Venezuela.

More than 3,000 delegates to the/ twentieth anniversary convention and exposition of the National Restaurant Association met at the National Restaurant Mart today to hear Henry I. Dunnock, president, warn that restaurant men must exercise greater ingenuity than ever to hold their patronage.
Germany's revenue from taxes and duties should total 17,200,000,000 marks for 1938, Fritz Reinhardt, Secretary of State for Finance, told newspaper men here today.
When Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx enrolled last semester in Deputy Mayor Henry H. Curran's class he professed a desire to learn something about etymology.
Miss Eileen Balfe, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Balfe of 1,120 Park Avenue, who will be introduced to society at a dinner dance to be given by her

A funeral service was held yesterday afternoon in All Angels Protestant Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-first Street, for Aurelio Giorni, pianist, composer and member of the faculties of the Springfield (Mass.) Conservatory of Music and Smith College.

The twenty-third annual exhibition of the Society of American Etchers will be held at the National Arts Club from Nov. 30 to Dec. 27. It is the wish of the society (formerly the Brooklyn Society of Etchers) to make this exhibition comprehensive.

Five Japanese import and export specialists, commissioned temporarily by the Nippon Government in the service of the Bureau of Foreign Trade, arrived here on the NYK liner Asama Maru this week end, bound for a protracted 'survey of Mexico and Central American countries as far south as Panama.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Toward the end of Frederick T. Birchall's dispatch from Munich, Sept. 30, appear two paragraphs which set out thoughts of great significance for the future of European peace, and even for a more soundly conceived and more strongly grounded concept of collective security.

The Spanish Insurgent command, relieved by the end of the war scare in Central Europe, pushed forward anew today against government lines on the Ebro River front. Heavy rain, which contributed to blocking the northern campaign, ended.
Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal FederaZ income taxes and other charges.
Among the properties in New Jersey reported yesterday as having been sold were the two fourstory store and apartment buildings at 701-05 Palisade Avenue and 406 Eighteenth Street, West New York.

The University of Pennsylvania, as a balancing factor in event of failure of income to meet budget expenses this fiscal year, is withholding 3 per cent of the basic salaries of its staff with the understanding that a return will be made if the financial situation warrants.
Four dual meets and the Metropolitan intercollegiate and I. C. A. A. A. A. championships comprise the City College varsity cross-country schedule for the Fall.
Sales of copper abroad were made yesterday within a range of 10.35 to 10.425 cents a pound, c.i.f. European base ports, compared with 10.44 to 10.51 cents on Saturday.

Republicans regained control today of Stamford, largest' of the 100 or more communities which balloted for municipal offices. Stamford, after eight years of Democratic rule, gave the Mayoralty to Charles E. Moore, Republican, by 8,583 votes to 6,443 for Edward Gonnoud, Democratic incumbent.
Aviation Captain Julio F. Sosa and Belisario Salazar, a chief mechanic in the Salvadorean Army, have returned by way of Canal after studying in Italy, bringing with them six Caproni fighting planes.

A client of A. Katz, attorney, bought from the New York Savings Bank the two four-story apartment houses at 276-8 West 115th Street, on a plot 50 by 100.11 feet. The properties have an assessed valuation of $32,000. Cushman Wakefield, Inc., were the brokers.

Landmarks in old Murray Hill, the former private home colony south of the Grand Central district which still clings to some of its mellowed restrictions against the invasion of trade, continue to fall prey to wrecking crews.
Two United States Army pursuit planes collided in midair today, but without loss of life. One ship crashed. The other, damaged, returned to the army base at Nichols Field.

Federal Judge William Bondy reserved decision yesterday after hearing argument on a motion by Hamilton C. Rickaby, attorney, for approval of a report by George W. Alger, special master, who recommended acceptance of a plan for reorganization of the Radio-KeithOrpheum Corporation under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.
Governors of the Bankers Club of America were re-elected to threeyear terms at the annual meeting yesterday. New officers will be chosen later this month.
Publishers of Wilkes-Barre's four newspapers, against which members of the Ainerican Newspaper Guild went on strike Saturday morning, decided late today to suspend publication "indefiniitely."
Edward Payson Stoughton of 51 Fifth Avenue, who celebrated his ninety-second birthday last week in London, dropped dead yesterday morning on board the Queen Mary as the ship approached the dock.

The appointment of Leo C. Levin as treasurer and controller of Franklin Simon Co. was announced here yesterday by J. Howard Denny, president of the Fifth Avenue store. Mr. Levin succeeds W. B. Gorman who has become controller of L. Bamberger Co., Newarli.
September, with a rainfall of 10.38 inches, was the wettest month ever experienced by Albany with one exception, the Weather Bureau reported today.

Mrs. Edward Mathews Latham entertained with a luncheon yester day in the Garden of the Ambassa dor for Mrs. John Jennings Par sons, who recently returned from Bucharest, Rumania, where she had passed the last four years. Mrs.

William Alexander Hoy of 180 Waverly Place, a lawyer who had practiced here for many years in the Surrogates' Courts, died yesterday in the Lenox Hill Hospital after a short illness. He would have been 77 years old on Saturday.

Elisha Hanson, general counsel for the American Newspaper Publishers' Association, said today that he would advise publishers to "get rid of" newsboys under 14 years of age, and to obtain proof of age for all minor employes.

The great "ham-and-eggs" drive for weekly pensions of $30, payable in scrip every Thursday morning for everybody over 50 years of age, man or woman, in California, who quits work or has no job, caught the conservative interests of the State napping.

A bitter clash between two investigating authorities of almost equal authority in Brooklyn developed yesterday when District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn challenged William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, to tell a Kings County grand jury all he knows concerning possible "corruption" in Mr. Geoghan's office.

In the nine years from 1929 to 1937, total income of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company aggregated $1,261,313,000, and of this amount nearly half, or $589,091,000, was paid to employes in the form of wages and salaries.
The bucking broncos, saddle horses and wild cattle that will be used in the rodeo were brought to town last night and unloaded at the New York Stock Yards, Eleventh Avenue and Fortieth Street.

Belmont Ave, 2,170 (11-3083); Margherita Galotta to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, extends mtgs. to July 1, 1943, at 4'6 to 5 per cent: $22,500. 142d St, 506 E (9-2286), 506 E 142d St Corp to Troy Savings Bank, extends mtgs to Oct. 1. 1943 at 41 pner cent:, 50.000.

Sir Gerald and Lady Campbell were guests of honor at a dinner given last night in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton. Among those present were Mr. and Mrs. Ogden H. Hammond, Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Mrs. Henry Martyn Alexander, Mrs. Sidney C. Borg,
The expected expansion failed to materialize on the stock market here today and more sober judgment on the Munich settlement was reflected in a general easing of prices after early firmness.

Fearon was at center in place of Russell, and Starusky at right guard instead of Glueck, as the Harvard varsity worked out today. None of the eighteen Cambridge men who played against Brown was injured, although Glueck received some hard bumps and will rest for a day or two.

Coach Andy Kerr gave the varsity players who were in the Cornell game only a light workout today, but he concentrated on developing new halfbacks as he drilled Colgate for the intersectional battle with Duke in Buffalo this Saturday.

Away flying and leading from start to finish, the 5-year-old High Time horse, Postage Due, was first by two lengths at 10 to 1 as Jamaica began its Fall meeting yesterday. The result was a surprise to many because the W. C. Winfrey color-bearer had not done well at Belmont Park in his previous start.

Mr. and Mrs. Andrew W. Johnson of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Alva Johnson, to John H. Heminway, son of Mrs. Jay O'Brien of New York and the late Louis Marshall Heminway.

Followers of all religious faiths, as well as those whose faith may not conform to any one confessional, will find profound significance in the pastoral letter drawn up by the German Catholic Bishops at Fulda on Aug. 19 and published yesterday in THE TIMES.

The dwindling market for bituminous coal in the last decade and a half has been due not to competing fuels but rather to increased efficiency in the use of bituminous coal by both industrial and residential consumers, according to the report of the Committee on Prices in the Bituminous Coal Industry, which has just been distributed to its members by the National Bureau of Economic Research.
Two men closely associated with Mayor La Guardia were nominated for the Supreme Court yesterday by the Republican organizations in the city.

Many will read with some astonishment the news that the American Association for the Advancement of Science has decided to make a "thorough, unbiased and strictly scientific investigation of the physiological and social effects of alcohol," and to give us at last "the right solution for the time and place in which we live."

Works of Raymond Marien on the books of the Interstate Hosiery Mills, Inc., never was given preferred treatment, according to Theodore Phillips Jr., partner of Holmes Davis, accountants for the company, at a Securities and Exchange Commission hearing at 120 Broadway yesterday.

Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroJeum at the close of the week ended on Sept. 24 totaled 280,278,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines. Compared with the figures of the previous week, this total represents a decrease of 667,000 barrels, comprising decreases of 525,000 and 142,000

Members of the National Poultry, Butter and Egg Association were reported today sharply divided as to the best method of compliance with the Federal Fair Labor Standards Act at the close of the first day of their convention here.
The magicians' contest in Central Park day before yesterday had a junior division for wonder workers under the age of 12.

Arturo Toscanini, the symphony orchestra conductor, was reported by associates to have left Milan today. They believed he was going to Cherbourg, France, where he expected to sail for the United States.
The final battle of the little world series on the Eastern front was waged under floodlights tonight with Bill Meyer's Kansas City Blues being routed by the Newark Bears, 7 to 1.
New naval aides at the White House were named today as follows: Lieut. Commander Walter R. Jones, commanding the Presidential yacht Potomac; Lieutenant John F. Newman Jr. of the staff of the Potomac,

There can be no doubt that the debate which began in the House of Commons yesterday will end in an overwhelming vote of confidence for Mr. Chamberlain. A large majority of British opinion is clearly behind the Government in the course which it has followed.

Warning against political interferences with universities in this country, the Rev. Dr. Ralph Cooper Hutchison, president of Washington and Jefferson, predicted yesterday that if the present trend continued the independent colleges would be eliminated and communism or fascism would be the final result of State control.

A $950,000 mortgage loan at 4 1/2 per cent on the eight apartment buildings being erected on the n w cor of St. George Ave and Stiles St, Linden, N. J., has been arranged by Hubbard, Westervelt Mottelay, Inc, brokers.
This is the month of anniversaries for the Supreme Court. Tomorrow will mark the anniversary of Justice Black's entrance to the court.

Kenesaw M. Landis, commissioner of baseball, said today that Mark Irving Vaughan, president of the Baseball Writers Association of America, would be chief scorer for the world series opening Wednesday between the Chicago Cubs and New York Yankees.
