Mrs. Julia Willets Comly of Philadelphia obtained a divorce here today from Robert Rowland Comly on grounds of cruelty.

Slaughter moderate to light in local markets yesterday on all classes of generally dressed kosher in anticipation of Jewish holiday "Yom Kippur." The lamb market was higher, other classes traefer meats steady. All kosher markets opening very slow at weak prices.

Gross assets, $13,844; net, $12,797. To son, Philip J. O'Connell, $300; son, Walter O'Connell, $400; daughter, Florence O. Fallon, Los Angeles, Calif., $300; grandson, Joseph Montreuil, watch; son-in-law, Conrad Miller, violin; daughter, Edith Miller, one-third residue; daughter, Marion Montreal, two-thirds residue.

The mail orders received in the markets here yesterday were larger than a week ago, reflecting easing of the war scare and better retail turnover in many areas, resident buying executives reported. Practically all departments shared in the volume of orders, with apparel, piece goods and accessories outstanding.
At sundown tomorrow, the end of the traditional Yom Kippur fast period, Yiddish playhouses throughout the country will emerge from their lethargy to greet the arrival of a new theatrical season.
Large increases in deposits and in holdings of cash were the principal features of the third quarter bank statements issued yesterday by local banks and trust companies.

The air is still. The sky is a cornflower blue, washed clear of that fiery violet which tints the Summer zenith. Pale smoke from the chimney of the house on the slope beyond the orchard lifts an admonitory finger. They have evidently lighted the fires too soon.
Mrs. Edith Greenough Wendell of this city, widow of Professor Barrett Wendell, Professor of English at Harvard, died tonight of puenmonia, in her home at the age of 79.
The leading article in the current issue of The Colophon, the quarterly for book-lovers published by Pynson Printers, has been written by Arno L. Bader and is entitled "Those Mesmeric Victorians."
Jubilant over the decisive opening victory, Columbia's football squad began its preparations for the game with Army Saturday by going through a spirited three-hour workout at Baker Field yesterday.

Saying that he would handle the question "without gloves," Arthur Huggins, permanent chairman of the State convention of the American Labor party, called yesterday for an end of the warfare between the two branches of organized labor and challenged the effort of George Meany, president of the State Federation of Labor, to prevent federation unionists from voting the Labor party ticket through the A. F. of L. Non-Partisan Committee.

A movement to standardize the insurance policies of the nation's 4,000 mutual surety companies was started here today in what was described by L. G. Purmort of Van Wert, Ohio, president of the Federation of Mutual Insurance Companies, as an attempt to avert "threatened investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission."
Stocks advanced irregularly and closed higher for the fifth consecutive day. Chemical, building and rubber shares were the feature; turnover, 1,462,030 shares.
The average price of 200 realty bonds comprising the Amott-Baker Price Average showed a loss of 1.3 per cent in the month of September, according to Ameott, Baker Co., Inc.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded in on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:

Six public or charitable institutions were among the legatees named in the will of William Purcell Bickett, certified public accountant and member of the firm of Haskins Sells, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday.
Republican leaders indicated yesterday that they expect Mayor La Guardia to come out for Thomas E. Dewey for Governor. Mr. Dewey himself is understood to be of that belief, it was said.
Group Securities, Inc., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement for 1,000,000 shares of a new class of stock designated as fully administered shares.
Richard Crane, 56, former Minister to Czechoslovakia, was accidentally killed today with his own gun while hunting sora on his estate, Westover, near here.

A long blackboard session at Rutgers today, in which mistakes against Vermont were discussed, was followed by a brief dummy scrimmage. Motion pictures of the Vermont game were shown with Coach Harvey Harman stressing the good and bad points of the Scarlet's 15-to-14 victory over the Catamounts.
Atlantic County's application for a $1,203,000 Public Works Administration project, to build a permanent new bridge to neighboring Brigantine Island, has been completed and forwarded.

More than 128,000 young people have been "placed" in private industry, and special employment services for young people have been established in 101 cities in thirty-six States, by the National Youth Administration, Aubrey Williams, executive director stated today.

The business outlook has shown a material imrprovement as a result of a sharp advance in industrial production during August, according to the monthly survey of business issued yesterday by the statistical division of the National Industrial Conference Board.

The Metropolitan Opera Association will undertake five major revivals in the sixteen-week season beginning Monday evening, Nov. 21, Edward Johnson, general manager, announced at his annual Fall press conference yesterday.
The Reichsbank's statement as of Oct. 1 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

The Transit Commission approved yesterday the city's application to remove the Sixth Avenue elevated line, which wends its noisy way across real estate that city experts contend will be more' valuable by $275,000,000 ten years after the ancient structure is removed.

Secretary Hull today announced the appointment of Breckinridge Long, former Ambassador to Italy, as head of the commission which will join with other American countries in starting a new steamship line to the East coast of South America, to take the place of the former Munson Line.

The Frederick E. Bellows High School eleven of Rye Neck today went down to a 20-0 defeat after holding Eastchester High scoreless for the first half of their game marking the start of the 1938 campaign for both teams.

Estimating the wealth of refugees from Germany at from $2,000,000,000 to $6,000,000,000, Myron C. Taylor, vice chairman of the Intergovernmental Committee on Political Refugees, expressed confidence yesterday that "a considerable portion" of these funds could be saved for the rehabilitation of the emigrants in other countries.

The world series between the Yankees and Cubs, scheduled to open tomorrow at Chicago, will be broadcast by the coast-to-coast networks by permission of Kenesaw Mountain Landis, commissioner of baseball. The local outlets will be WEAF, WOR, WJZ, WABC and WHN.
The Official Gazette today carries President Lazaro Cardenas' final decree expropriating 17,980 acres of land belonging to William Randolph Hearst in the State of Chihuahua.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Sept. 28, aggregated $6,747,000,000, or 22 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 17 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.
With the new ticket code now a month old, Broadwayites note that the new restrictions on speculators have yet to prove their effectiveness.
The leasing of space for another unit in a chain of men's clothing stores and larger quarters for a textile concern marked the commercial rentals announced yesterday.

THIS may sound like fiction, but it is all, or very nearly all, sober fact. About thirty-five years ago, when they were digging the Lexington Avenue subway, one of the minor employes working underground was a gaunt and somber man from Gardiner, Me. His name was Robinson.
The season is new; performers are new; only the programs do not change. Marcus Gordon, as the first solo pianist of the youthful season at the Town Hall last night, relied on traditional fare.

Six varsity and four lightweight boats took to Lake Carnegie and 130 freshmen manned the rowing machines today as 215 oarsmen, the largest Princeton rowing turnout on record, answered Coach Fred Spuhn's summons for Fall practice.
The stock market here continued quiet today and there were declines in most sections as a result of some' misgivings in the aftermath of the Munich settlement.
It seems that the man who is torn between two desires, fishing or hunting, might as well let the hunting win these days, for the saltwater fishing has been disappointing for almost a week.

The importance of rededication to religion by nations as well as by individuals to obtain peace in this troubled world was stressed by rabbis in sermons here last night at the traditional Kol Nidre services, opening the observance of Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, the most holy day in the Hebrew religious calendar.

The War Department approved today applications of the Board of Supervisors of Suffolk County, L. I., for the construction of three bridges, one across Shelter Island Sound (Gardiners Bay), another across Shelter Island Sound and the third over Great South Bay.

Columbia University has awarded twenty-five fellowships and scholarships for graduate study this year to men and women from eleven States and from England, New Zealand, Italy, Canada and China, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, the president, announced yesterday.
Marie Luisa Arcelay, a member of the Legislature and the first LatinAmerican woman to win an elective legislative seat, today sent to President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia the following message:

A plan for the extension for three years of $14,807,000 of 6 per cent notes of the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad, which were defaulted on their maturity on last Saturday, was declared operative last night.
Wheat futures resumed their downward trend today and at no time did the markets show a disposition to rally. Much of the day's business was done in the first thirty minutes of the session.

Strong opposition to passage of four bills prepared by Governor Earle's committee, which has been studying problems of the anthracite industry, was voiced here today at the third of a series of hearings before the House mines subcommittee. Earlier hearings were devoted to backers of the measures.
Stocks fluctuated narrowly and closed steady and mixed in less active trading; turnover, 947,780 shares.

The Penn Western Gas and Electric Company, Wilmington, Del., has filed under the Public Utility Holding Company Act an application to the Securities and Exchange Commissibn to approve the declaration of dividends completely liquidating and dissolving the corporation, the commission announced today.
Mrs. Sarah Oliver Hulswit brought to New York City last night the movement she launched last Spring in Suffern, N. Y., under the title of "The Women's Rebellion."

The American public in general considers the newspapers fair to the Roosevelt Administration, according to the results of a survey announced yesterday by Dr. George Gallup, director of the American Institute of Public Opinion.

Holders of common stock of the Chicago Great Western Railroad, whose equity was held to be worthless in a reorganization plan approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission on Aug. 4, today petitioned the commission to reconsider the case.
A family problem-an overpowering lady and her unhappy son-is Chester Erskin's topic in "The Good," opening at the Windsor Theatre at 8:30 tonight.
The Department of Housing and Buildings has issued a permit for the demolition of the fifteen fivestory tenement houses at 400-432 West 134th Street, owned by John D. Rockefeller.

Confirming the predictions of many advertising executives that newspapers would be the first to feel the upturn in linage resulting from general business improvement, advertising in New York newspapers was only 11.5 per cent below a year ago for September, compared with a 20.3 per cent decline for August.
An inning-by-inning account of every game in both the National and American Leagues during the 1939 season will be shown daily on two electrically operated score boards at the exhibit building of

The slowness of the Czech military evacuation produced a near incident near here today. Advancing Germans a few miles beyond the town came in sight of retreating Czechs. Shots were fired and both sides began digging in.

With her canvas filling in the afternoon breeze, the square-rigger Joseph Conrad sailed out of port yesterday under the flag of the United States Maritime Commission for a week's training cruise at sea. The vessel carried twenty-two seamen-students, representing the second class of the commission's new merchant marine training school.

Mayor La Guardia told a group of church women yesterday that the best way to eliminate disease and crime was to remove the sources of these evils in unsafe and insanitary tenements. He defended the principle of Federal subsidies for housing projects to replace slums.

The export trade of the United States with Europe held up well during August compared with the same month in 1937, the Department of Commerce reported today in an analysis of figures for that month by countries.

The French Clubs of Hunter College will give as their annual production for the benefit of the Henry Bargy Scholarship Fund "Les Femmes Savantes," a comedy by Moliere. The play, under the direction of Miss Kathryn D. Hymes, will be presented at the High

Dr. Adolph Frey, former faculty member of Syracuse University's College of Fine Arts and founder of the Frey College of Musical Art of Watertown, died today in a hospital here of pneumonia, which set in after an appendectomy on Saturday. His age was 73.

Steel ingot production last week held -to the previous week's level, although the normal seasonal trend was upward, and the adjusted index eased to 66.5 from 67.4. For the week ended Oct. 2, 1937, the figure was 106.8.
After Germany took over the Saar Basin with its mines, her coal began to make inroads on the British export trade in that article, although, strange to say, Italian import trade was not shifted.
The 1938 Community Services Campaign of the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities was opened yesterday at a luncheon held in the Hotel Bossert in -Brooklyn.

Edward Lenz, 57 years old, an unemployed electrical worker, was arrested last night in front of the Municipal Lodging House in East Twenty-fifth Street, charged with killing his common-law wife on Sept. 25.

FOXES have always been a lot closer to this local seeker than he has ever been to foxes. About the first long story he ever read, the innocent start of a fatal practice, was a book called "Red Fox," by Charles G. D. Roberts,
Contending Teams and Managers-New York Yankees, champions of American League; Joseph V. McCarthy, manager. Chicago Cubs, champions of National League; Charles Leo (Gabby) Hartnett, manager.

The largest offering of public utility bonds to go on the market since early in August will be made today by a syndicate headed by Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc., in the form of $37,500,000 of Virginia Electric and Power Company first and refunding mortgage series B 31/2 per cent bonds due in 1968 at 103% and interest from Sept. 1.

The first of the new major league managerial portfolios for 1939 was handed down today when Jerry Nugent, president of the Phillies, announced that James Thompson (Doc) Prothro will succeed Jimmy Wilson, who resigned his post a few days ago.

Increased appropriations for the Federal establishment or enactment of his government reorganization plan were suggested by President Roosevelt today as the only remedies for the excessive overtime and arrearages in work in the government agencies in Washington.

Prices of cotton failed ot advange yesterday beyond Monday' s levels for the current movement the Cotton Exchange. Buyers adopt ed a cautious attitude pending more definite reaction by Souther holders to prices slightly above cotton loan basis.
" Americans at Home" Mrs. Halpert appropriately calls the exhibition that opened yesterday at the Downtown Gallery, 113 West Thirteenth Street.

Elmer F. Andrews, Administrator of the Wage-Hour law, announced today the tentative selection of twelve regional areas which will mark the administration of the Fair Labor Standards Act. Second on the list is the State of New York, with headquarters in New York City.

The British Government regards its guarantee to Czechoslovakia as already in effect, Sir Thomas Inskip, Minister for the Coordination of Defense, told the House of Commons tonight at the end of the second day's debate in both houses of Parliament on the crisis and its consequences.

The Transit Commission served notice on the B. M. T. yesterday that the city intended to recapture the company's Culver Line to Coney Island, effective Dec. 31, 1939. The Board of Transportation is drawing plans for incorporation of the line into the city's Independent Subway System to serve as a connecting link between the Coney Island area and the Church Avenue
Mr. and Mrs. John Bachman Hyde of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rose Foster Hyde, to Herbert Peck Fales of Pasadena, Calif.

The forgotten man in the city's army of 155,486 employes will have his chance to win a medal under a new plan approved by Mayor La Guardia. Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, announced yesterday that Samuel H. Ordway Jr., Federal Civil Service Commissioner, had started a medal fund for civilian employes with a donation of $1,000.
Tom Smith, trainer for Seabiscuit, said today that Charles S. Howard, the racing star's owner, had posted $5,000 for a match race with Samuel D. Riddle's War Admiral at Pimlico next month.
American Management Association's 1938 conference will open at the Hotel Pennsylvania at 10 A. M. and continue tomorrow.
The world series spirit took violent hold here tonight on the eve of the opening game between the Yankees and Cubs tomorrow in Wrigley Field.
The combination of Mrs. Louise Viau's Conquer, trainer J. P. Jones and Jockey Johnny Gilbert accounted for its fourth straight victory today in the Annapolis Purse.
Normal business in several countries was hampered in recent weeks by the European crisis, the Department of Commerce said today in an analysis of conditions abroad. The analysis follows in part:
The first State convention of the American Labor party completed its work yesterday afternoon by nominating candidates for the lesser places on its State ticket.

Declaring that the airplane can be "the most marvelous agent for peace man ever created or the deadliest weapon God ever let man create," Captain E. V. (Eddie) Rickenbacker, president of Eastern Air Lines and World War flying ace,

The Federal Trade Commission has joined with the Biddle Purchasing Com pany of New York in asking the Supreme Court to review a decision of the Circuit Court of Apppeale for the Second Circuit on May 2, which held the Biddle concern had violated the controversial "broker. age clause" of the Robinson-Patman act, it was learned today.

Supreme Court Justice Poletti resigned yesterday his $25,000 a year post on the bench because of his nomination for the Lieutenant Governorship on the Democratic ticket. The vacancy will be filled by Governor Lehman until a successor can be elected a year from this November.
The Yankees will trot on Wrigley Field tomorrow overwhelming favorites to win the world series from the Cubs. Betting in this metropolis of the Middle West is brisk, too.
Arturo Toscanini, symphony conductor, has received his passport and has already left Milan to sail aboard the Normandie tomorrow for New York, it was said today in well-informed circles here.

An investing syndicate has acquired the property at 47 to 71 East Main Street, Bay Shore, L. I., consisting of thirteen two-story taxpayer buildings in the block front between Bay Shore and Third Avenues. The sale was reported by David S. Meister, former owner.

The text of the speech by Earl Baldwin of Bewdley in the House of Lords today follows: In addressing your Lordships for the first time I make my first political speech for many years not as the leader of a party and with no responsibility as a member of a government,
It is expected that Louis Rothschild, the banker, will soon be released from prison, but perhaps not allowed to leave Germany.

Miss Mary Lewis has been named executive vice president in charge of sales promotion and advertising of Saks-Fifth Avenue, it was announced yesterday by Adam Long Gimbel, president of the store. Miss Lewis will take up her new duties immediately.

Since the great crash of 1929 and the departure in 1935 of Giulio GattiCasazza as General Director of the Metropolitan Opera Association that organization has followed a steep uphill road in its climb back to a position of security and restoration of its artistic tradition.

The Federal spending program is regarded as the most positive basis for confidence in the immediate business outlook, according to the monthly Industries Service prepared by Fenner Beane, Stock Exchange members. However,

Deaths Announced Retired Battalion Chief Francis J. Gray, formerly assigned to the 20th Battalion, residing at 2,751 University Ave., Bronx, lied Oct. 2. Funeral will take place from the Walter B. Cooke, Inc., Funeral Home, ?? West 190th St., Manhattan, at 10 A. M., Wednesday, Oct. 5. Interment at Calvary Cemetery.

With four regulars resting on the sidelines, Harvard held a strenuous scrimmage today in preparation for the coming of Cornell Saturday. Coach Harlow increased his first squad to thirty players by bringing up Al Maguire, an end; Frank Curtis, a blocking back, and Joe Cardella, who has made great strides as a bucker.
Eleven workmen were killed and many were seriously injured today when a freight train crashed into a motor bus at a crossing at Wiesloch, near here.

A field of forty-seven has been listed to start in the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship, which will get under way today at the Oceanside Golf Club. Oceanside. L. I.

Park Terrace West, 67, 25x100: John C. Myers, referee, to Lina P. Kreuder. 336 Fort Washington Ave. foreclosure (S10). 75th St. 337 E. 25x101.3; Manderman Realty Corp to Continental Baking Co, 630 5th Ave. mtg $20.250 (50 cents).

Merrill May, Newark third baseman and prize player on the list, was selected by the Phillies tonight in the major league draft meeting. The Phillies, as the last-place team of both leagues, had the right to make the first selection. They also took Legrant Scott, outfielder and left-hand hitter, from Indianapolis.

As the first step in what may be the most sweeping investigation ever, undertaken into the public agencies of Brooklyn, William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, called on 1,402 financial institutions yesterday to produce all
Women's millinery at both wholesale and retail is making a much better showing than most other lines of merchandise in the Chicago area.

Mrs. Leonora Kolb Troutman, active for the last eleven years in charity work here, died last night in the Lawrence Hospital at the age of 58. She was the wife of George M. Troutman, a regional executive in New York for Swift Co.

Ten-year-old Frances Puccio won yesterday the Helen Stotesbury silver medal with her essay on the topic "For the Outstanding Rescue of a Dog Made During the Last Year." The contest, in which 500 were entered, was held under the auspices of the Humane Society of New York in recognition of "National Dog Week."
The factional dispute within the United Automobile Workers of America was settled today, with the reinstatement of four officers who were expelled. This was done by the executive board on the terms

Miss Rose Clare Duffy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Joseph Duffy of Hoboken and this place, was married in St. Catherine's Church here this afternoon to Denis Gallagher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas gher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas G. Gallagher of Jersey City.
For the first time department chairmen in Hunter College have been elected by members of their own departments in accordance with the newly adopted by-laws of the Board of Higher Education.
Winthrop Smith, a retired broker and bank director, died at his home in Glenside on Sunday at the age of 93.
Julius Bauer, a Jewish merchant, 45 years old, has been sentenced to six months' imprisonment for violating the Nuremberg racial laws by living with a German Aryan woman.

The board of managers of the New York Cocoa Exchange, Inc., said yesterday in an annual report that the volume of business done in the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 was 90,624 contracts. compared with 145,136 in the preceding twelve months.
Coach Andy Kerr and his Colgate Red Raiders got down to real serious work today for the Duke battle in Buffalo Saturday.

Miss Helen T. Findlay of New York, arts department secretary of the Association of Junior Leagues of America, was the guest of honor at a luncheon given today by the Pittsfield Junior League at the Pittsfield Country Club.
Running in improved form J. D. Norris's Strolling By lasted long enough to win the Kew Gardens Class B Handicap at Jamaica yesterday and provide a mild upset for a good-sized crowd.

A suggestion that newspapers charge department stores minimum rates for advertising and then take a percentage of the sales which those advertisements produce, was made to the eighth annual Institute for Retail Problems at the Pennsylvania State College this afternoon. The proposal,
Spanish Insurgent artillery, aviation and infantry smashed at government lines anew tonight, intensifying the Insurgent offensive against government Positions on the Ebro front.

The liquor industry, State and Federal regulatory officials, advertising men and representatives of leading advertising mediums will hold a conference here beginning Oct. 25 to discuss liquor advertising problems.
" So far as Canada and the United States are concerned, we have practically reached a new trade agreement," said Prime Minister Mackenzie King after a Cabinet meeting today;
Benjamin A. Cheney, who since 1902 had represented many manufacturers in Mexico, Cuba, San Domingo and Puerto Rico, died of a heart attack this morning at the age of 67.
Excerpts from speeches made in the House of Commons and the House of Lords in today's debates on the Czechoslovak settlement follows:

The number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was considerably more than in the preceding week but was slightly below the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

Girolamo Valenti of New York, chairman of the Italian Anti-Fascist Committee, told the House Committee Investigating Un-American Activities today that the Fascist government of Italy, through Italian consular officers and other agents in this country, had built up a strong Fascist movement among Italian-Americans.

In the Church of the Heavenly Rest here yesterday afternoon, Miss Marie-Louise Fox, daughter of Mrs. John H. Grace of White Plains and the late David Fox, was married to Howard Frederick Van Bomel of Rye.
Domestic production of lead in August was 23,723 tons, compared with 27,976 in July, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics. World production was 147,409 tons, against 153,254.

The increasing efficacy of the boycott of German goods in this country was proclaimed yesterday by the Joint Boycott Council of the American Jewish Congress and Jewish Labor Committee in a report asserting that German imports into

Today the heart of America beats on Wrigley Field. To explain to a foreigner why this is so would be impossible. He could never comprehend the supreme importance of some games between two baseball teams called the Yankees and the Cubs or why they should be described as a World Series.
The War Department approved today an allotment of an additional $347,000 for dredging and rock removal in lower New York Bay, Raritan Bay and Staten Island Sound.

A report urging cooperation with the Federal Monopoly Committee so long as the investigation is "conducted on a non-political and non-partisan basis" will come today before the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York at its first Fall meeting.
It is the hope of the Roosevelt administration that American industry will learn from the recent settlement of the European war crisis that it will profit more by cooperating with government

Alfred Duff Cooper's allegations in the British House of Commons yesterday that mobilization of the British fleet played a part in Chancellor Adolf Hitler's calling the Munich conference were branded in German political circles as "simply childish," according to a semi-official news agency report.
Miss Dorothy Bundy, another member of the famous tennis family of Santa Monica, Calif., won the Pacific Southwest women's net title today by defeating Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Fabyan of Boston, 6-4, 6-4.

The subpoenas served on 1,402 banks, brokerage houses and other financial institutions by William B.. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, called on them to produce by next Tuesday all records and evidence of any description involving the following persons attached or formerly attached to the office of District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn:
A 39-year-old housewife, Frau Katherina Kneup of Kleinbittersdorf in Saarpfalz, was guillotined here today for attempted espionage.

Harry Douglas, biographer and former newspaper man, a descendant of Sir Joshua Hempstead, who founded Hempstead, L. I., died yesterday in Tampa, Fla., according to word received here yesterday, He was 81 years old.

The Spanish Republican Government and its supporters turn a decidedly deaf ear to reports from London that Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and Premiers Edouard Daladier and Benito Mussolini, having settled the matter of Czechoslovakia, are now turning their attention to arranging a peace for Spain.

The Bell System lines added 83,500 telephones in September, compared with a gain of 99,400 in the same month last year, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday. For the first nine months of 1938 there was a net gain of 247,050 stations, against an increase of 705,800 in the same period of last year.
Charles Head Smith, a member of the Chicago Board of Trade for nearly fifty years, died today in a Montclair, N. J., hospital, at the age of 80.

The French language newspaper Journal de Moscou, which habitually reflects the views of the Soviet Foreign Office, gave expression today to what was regarded in diplomatic quarters as Russia's farewell to her ally, France.
The British pound and the French franc resumed yesterday their recovery in the foreign exchange market, but the volume of business was reduced greatly.
Mrs. Agnes Welch of 25 De Koven Court, Brooklyn, wife of Jeremiah Welch, assistant secretary-treasurer of the Chicago, Milwaukee St. Paul Railroad Company, died Monday of pneumonia.

The 545-family low-rent housing development of the Yonkers Municipal Housing Authority, which provides for a group of apartment houses on St. Joseph's Avenue, Yonkers, at a cost of $3,306,000, moved a step nearer to realization today with the signing of the Federal loan agreement.
Mrs. Mary Isabel Malmar, widow of John Jay Malmar, former executive of the Corn Exchange Bank, died yesterday in her home, 411 West Twenty-second Street. Her age was 73.
A ten-room house on two-thirds of an acre of land in the Beechmont section of New Rochelle, Westchester County, has been sold by the Notlin Holding Corporation to H. R. Owen of New York.

Telephone calls originating at Boston and other Massachusetts points for New Hampshire above Keene are being sent part way by short-wave radio, Fred G. Kegler, manager of the Athol-Gardner exchange, said today.

A coalition of Townsend plan advocates and Republicans was effected here today as the Republican State convention placed in its platform a plank pledging the State's Republicans in Congress to use their influence to

A sharp curtailment of shipments by United States manufacturers selling supplies and equipment to China has occurred in the last several weeks as a result of Japanese interference with transportation routes between Hong Kong, Britishowned port, and interior points of China, exporters said here yesterday.
Captain Jose Bezerra of the Alagoas State police, who slew Lampeao, Brazil's most notorious bandit, arrived here by plane today on a furlough.

Walter Dreicer of 4 East Seventyeighth Street, a jeweler with an establishment at 580 Fifth Avenue, died on Monday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a short illness, at the age of 43. He was a grandson of Jacob Dreicer, who came to New York from Russia in 1866 and founded the Dreicer jewel business here.

With the compact of Munich the foreign policy of the present administration became obsolete, and presumably the President, Secretary Hull and Under-Secretary Welles are searching for a new one. Perhaps its outlines emerged in Mr. Welles's radio speech Monday night in which,

A syndicate represented by Charles M. Hiesiger, lawyer, has purchased the 4-story apartment house at 260 Stockton Street, Brooklyn. Purchase was for cash. The property will be renovated to remove all violations.

MANHATTAN BATTIN, EVALYN I. (June 17). Estate, less than $1.000. To Curry Lea, executor, 300 Hayward Ave., Mount Vernon, N. Y. BAYLIS, ADELAIDE E. (Sept. 28). Estate, more than $10,000. To Charloftte F. Sands, St. Luke's Home for Aged Women, $1,000; Adelaide Brooks Baylis, daughter, Bedford, N. Y., and William Bayllis, son, executor, Bedford Village, N. Y., residue equally.

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 3,231,800 barrels, compared with 3,251,150 in the preceding week, a drop of 19,350, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.
Dr. J. Norman Henry, physician, explorer and sportsman, died at his home in Gladwyne today a few minutes after being stricken with a heart attack. He was 65 years old.
Several dinner and supper parties were given last night at the formal opening for this season of Restaurant Larue.

Vice Consul Frank Walker, for several years attached to the British Consulate here, has been transferred to Zurich, Switzerland, because the German authorities objected to his returning -with his wife after a London vacation.

Modern selling methods apply as vitally to the transit industry as to the sale of soup, automobiles or drugs, Charles Gordon of New York, managing director of the American Transit Association, said today at the fifty-seventh annual convention of the association.

Production and distribution of goods are linked together as a single job and more of the cost of the combined process may rest on production in the future, Lew Hahn, general manager of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, asserted yesterday before the midwinter fashion merchandising clinic of the Millinery Merchandising Executives Association, Inc., meeting in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
Theft of the crown jewels which once adorned the Empress Carlotta when Emperor Maximilian ruled Mexico was solved today by Federal officers.

The Navy's first-string backfield was divided between the hospital and the playing field today as the passing attack was brushed up for the game with Virginia Saturday, which will close the home season.

Moving out of the pack at the sixteenth pole and wearing down Mrs. L. N. Nimkoff's Chauvin, the Medway Stable's Breezing Along today won the Colburn claiming purse to reward his backers with $7.82 for a $2 ticket at Rockingham Park.
THE BACK DOOR, by Julian R. Meade. (Longmans, Green, $2.50.) A novel by the author of "I Live in Virginia."
The second Session of an auction sale by Joseph P. Day of varied properties in all parts of the city will be held tomorrow afternoon in the Hotel Pennsylvania on order of executors and trustees.

Glorious Autumn weather prevailed today for the first round of match play in the sixteenth annual women's New Jersey State golf championship over the Plainfield Country Club course. All of the favorites came through in fine style.

The judicial conference, composed of senior judges of the Federal Circuit Courts and Justice Department representatives, recommended today that provision be made for thirteen additional judges to relieve congestion of Federal dockets.

On their march into the Teschen area Polish troops this morning reached Karvina, the center of the Silesian coal mining industry, the annual output of which is 4,000,000 tons, mostly first-class coke coal. The entire Polish coal production is 36,.000,000 tons.

The expected reconstruction of the Czechoslovak Cabinet was carried out tonight. The most important features are the dropping of Kamil Krofta as Foreign Minister and the inclusion of two more generals, as well as an offer by Premier Jan Syrovy to a Slovak politician, M Sokol, to accept a portfolio for Slovakia.

So closely contested is the race for individual laurels in the National Football League that the conclusion of the fourth week of competition shows a two-way tie for the scoring lead, a four-way deadlock for field-goal kicking,
Lou Nova, the San Francisco heavyweight who turned in a surprise knockout triumph over Gunnar Barlund on Monday night, conferred with Promoter Mike Jacobs yesterday regarding his next ring start.

John H. Hanson, in charge of the Los Angeles Federal Bureau of Identification, said today that a confession had been obtained from Meyer Sopher, 23, a mess attendant on the steamship Monterey, in connection with the theft of $50,000 worth of jewels from Mrs. Lawrence Tibbett.
American soldiers may soon be wearing uniforms made from specially treated wool which will not shrink even when washed in hot water.

After an absence of two seasons from competitive golf, Mrs. G. E. Hackney of Oakland captured low gross honors in a Women's Metropolitan Golf Association oneday tournament at the Rockville Country Club today.

Prominent clergy and laymen of the Archdiocese of New York marched in solemn procession in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday and participated in a high mass of requiem to mark the passage of one month since the death of Cardinal Hayes.

Huntover Lodge, the home of Colonel Lloyd C. Griscom, Ambassador to Italy under President Theodore Roosevelt, was destroyed by fire this afternoon, although volunteers of three fire departments fought the flames.

President Roosevelt authorized today an immediate start on flood control projects in the New England storm-stricken area involving an ultimate cost of $28,630,000, with $11,000,000 of the amount to be made available during the current fiscal year.
Mrs. Tuckerman Draper gave a dinner last night at Hampshire House for Sir Henry Getty Chilton, British Ambassador to Spain, and Lady Chilton.

Vacant apartments within a specified rental range may now be listed free of charge with the Vacancy and Re-housing Bureau, a WPA project sponsored by the New York City Housing Authority, it was announced yesterday.

A plaque marking the site where motion pictures were first commercially projected forty-two years ago was unveiled yesterday on the Thirty-fourth Street side of Macy's Department Store. The location was that formerly occupied by Koster Bial's MusicHall.

A decrease in mortality from influenza and pneumonia among the millions of industrial policyholders of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company this year was reported yesterday by Donald B. Armstrong, third vice president of the company.

Aiming to halt Army's customary victory marches against Columbia when his Lions invade West Point Saturday, Coach Lou Little sent his charges through a brisk offensive and defensive drill at Baker Field yesterday.

For the second time in the Sino-Japanese war Japanese planes yesterday morning bombed Chungking, loosing explosives from above the blanket of mist that hangs over the new capital almost all year into vacant lots in the western residential section,

The 14,000 employes of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company who belong to the Transport Workers Union, a C. I. 0. affiliate, have been asked by Thomas E. Murray Jr., Federal receiver for the company,...

An orphan of 18, introduced as a product of "the slums of New York," addressed the opening meeting tonight of the State conference of the National Society of the Daughters of the American Revolution and was applauded by nearly 300

46th St, 156 E, 5-story office building, 32x 100.5; James G. Rogers against Van Real Estate Co; due $144,323; taxes, etc, $2,043: to plaintiff for $146,000 By EDWIN J. McDONALD 27th St, 132-142 W, 6-story loft and store building, 120x98.9;

The New York Central Railroad announced yesterday the distribution of a $2,000,000 order for rail among the Bethlehem Steel Company, Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, Inland Steel Company and Algoma Steel Corporation.

John W. Barwell, industrialist and philanthropist, died Monday at the age of 84 in his home in Waukegan, Ill. A graduate of Oxford University, Mr. Barwell came to this country in 1899 and established the Blatchford Calf Meal Company in Waukegan.

A "peace tree" was dedicated in Central Park yesterday afternoon on Maple Lawn, East Drive and Sixty-sixth Street, in the interests of international amity, by the Lions International and the Lions Club of New York.
Investors and operators were principals in a number of the Manhattan realty deals announced yesterday, when the bulk of the activity centered in the West Side.

The Madison Square Garden Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries reduced their loss in the quarter ended on Aug. 31 to $137,007 from a net loss of $176,090 reported for the corresponding quarter of last year.

Thomas Hibbard, treasurer of the George Lawley Shipbuilding Company of Dorchester for twenty-eight years and its former president, died today at his home in Milton at the age of 84. He retired in 1918.

ABRAHAM--Jennie, on Oct. 5, beloved sister of the late Albert Abraham and Sarah Phillips. Services at the chapel of Temple Emanu-El, 65th St. at 5th Ave., on Thursday at 11 A. M. Cincinnati papers please copy. ADAMS--Robert C., Oct. 4, at his home, Newtown, Conn. Notice of funeral later.

The controversy between the Securities and Exchange Commission and Associated Gas and Electric interests was continued today when, at a hearing for oral argument, Archibald R. Graustein, as counsel, urged the SEC to reconsider its earlier memorandum opinion, in which it held that the general protective committee for security holders of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, which is in reorganization, was an instrument of the Associated Gas interests.

Several persons were injured-one was shot in the leg-during a clash here last night at an anti-Fascist meeting held under auspices of the Trotskyist Fourth International and the Confederacion General de Trabajadores, the C. G. T. unions.

The New York Curb Exchange has admitted to unlisted trading Standard Gas and Electric Company 6 per cent gold debentures due in 1957, which were issued to holders of Standard Power and Light Corporation 6 per cent gold debentures due in 1957.

After almost a week of rapidly rising prices the bond market yesterday settled down to consolidate its gains. Although some profit taking was in evidence, a firm underlying demand for pivotal issues prevented any severe reaction in prices.
Joseph R. Sheehan, presidentdesignate of the Dollar Steamship Line, said today that the company's services would be re-established under a new name and full operation would be resumed in four months.

Judge Henry J. Kimball of Watertown; Surrogate D. Page Morehouse of Oswego and Supreme Court Justice Francis D. McCurn of Syracuse were nominated for justices of the Supreme Court today by both the Republican and Democratic parties.

Governors of the New York Curb Exchange voted yesterday approval of a reorganization plan which provides for a paid president, public representation on the board of governors, creation of four administrative departments, each under the direction of a secretary, and the setting up of new machinery for arbitration. The decision is now to . .. .
Seemingly unconcerned about the possible prison term that confronted her, Mary Reed, 27 years old, slender and rather short, who said she was a waitress, pleaded guilty yesterday before General

Over the opposition of Senators Clifford R. Powell of Burlington County, Arthur F. Foran of Hunterdon, Thomas D. Taggart of Atlantic and I. Grant Scott of Cape May, the Republican State Convention adopted today a platform closing the door to new taxes or bond issues in 1939 to finance relief and the Mort plan of education.
A first mortgage loan of $122,000 with interest at 5 per cent for five years on the fifty-four-family apartment house at 2,021-3 Davidson Ave., Bronx, has been arranged by the Herman A. Acker Corp.

APPARENTLY there isn't going to be any secret about this world series. For that matter, there rarely is, and these world series have been going on since 1905 under modern rules. The only real secret uncovered at the last moment was Connie Mack's unveiling of "Empty" Ehmke as the starting pitcher for the Athletics against the Cubs in the series of 1929.
The Holy Cross football team, which gets its first big test against Manhattan here Saturday, worked on the defense against Jasper plays in a long dummy scrimmage today.
Mayor Kelly is all set to bet somebody's hog on the Cubs to whip the Yanks in the world series. He had word today that Mayor La Guardia of New York, en route here for the games,

John Williams Davis, nationally known chemist, who was credited with the invention of the process for separating helium from natural gas, died here today of a heart attack at the age of 51. He became ill Saturday.
Properties in the Bronx reported yesterday as having changed hands included a large waterfront site and multi-family dwellings.
Princeton practiced behind locked gates for the first time today, devoting most of a ninety-minute session to its initial scrimmage with Coach Johnny Gorman's promising freshman squad.

Precisely how much value the endorsement of the American Labor party has for a candidate of one of the two major parties in New York State must remain a moot question until the election-and perhaps after.

Use of the State's free public camp sites this season increased 10 per cent as compared with last year, Lithgow Osborne, Conservation Commissioner, reported today. A total of 676,432 persons used picnic grounds, bathing facilities and camp sites from May 28 to Sept. 15.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 3: COLONELS Davis. J. R. (F.A.), relieved from detail In the National Guard Bureau, Washington, D. C., and detailed with the Organized Reserves. Presidio of San Francisco, Calif., to sail from New York about Feb. 7.
Stocks traded on the New York Curb Exchange lost $135,707,288 in aggregate market value in September, according to a tabulation released yesterday.
Statements of condition of the leading banks in this city, as of Sept. 30, which were issued yesterday, continued to indicate large increases in total deposits, compared with those on June 30.

It was all one family but not an entirely happy one that rolled 'along today toward the American Association acres of the Yankee farm lands and a resumption of the fratricidal strife that broke out in Newark last Saturday afternoon.
Mrs. Mary Ellen Moran Fallon, member of the Catholic Woman's Club here and founder of the Ladies of Charity of St. Gabriel's Church, died today in her home at the age of 84.

Surely, begot of permanence, That ingrained word of lesser faith, Love is no wisdom that can sense The blood's earthquake and storm of wrath. Yet I'd sooner see my veins pour up Their tumult to the winds, and earth Shake them as dry as doom, than sup Religion of a greater worth.

Public works construction has entered a new era in which the needs of the worker must be considered as they never were before, Perry A. Fellows, Assistant Chief Engineer of the Works progress Administration, told the annual congress of the American Public Works Association yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Mrs. Philenia Donnelly, widow of the late Thomas F. Donnelly, leader of the "Save the Palisades" movement, died yesterday in the home of her daughter, Mrs. Allie D. Radigan of Jersey City, at the age of 56.
A year ago Ossie Solem came to Syracuse from Iowa to install a new football offense, patterned after the Minnesota system in which he was brought up by the late Dr. Harry Williams.

A strange flag with seven red-andwhite stripes, a shield bearing three lions and a golden cow's head fluttered over Twenty-third Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues yesterday. It symbolized an achievement rarely noted, with or without fanfare, in New York City. A cow had gone "over the moon" in world's record time.

Raoul de Roussy de Sales, correspondent for the Paris-Soir, was reelected unanimously president of the Association of Foreign Press Correspondents at a general meeting of the foreign newspaper men held Monday night at the Hotel Lombardy.

The Cameo motion-picture theatre, a one and two-story building at 225-237 Ocean Avenue, Jersey City, on a plot 172 by 127 feet, was sold by the Saooky Realty Corporation to the Broadlawn Realty Company. The sale was subject to four mortgages totaling $212,000.

2d Lt. Ronald T. Onffroy, Sig-Res., 832 Ostrom Ave., Syracuse, N. Y., is relieved from his present assignment to the 1,226th S.U., C.A.S.C. So much of paragraph 1, Special Orders No. 119, this headquarters, dated Sept. 16, 1938, as pertains to 2d Lt. Richard S. Cowen. FA-Res. is revoked.
Harry E. Ward, president of the Irving Trust Company, was elected yesterday chairman of the clearing house committee at the annual meeting of the New York Clearing House Association.
Wickliffe Smith Buckley, president and treasurer of the Mechanics Savings Bank, died today of coronary thrombosis in his home here. He was 71 years old.

One of the chief defects noted in the New York University football team during its game with Maine last Saturday was the absence of a good kicker. The Violet tallied three touchdowns, but only one extra point.
The Mexican air force's supply of airplane gasoline is low because of Mexico's inability to produce enough high test fuel. Flying time has been cut to conserve stocks of gasoline.
A number of leases for large quarters in buildings located in the midtown section marked the contracts for commercial space reported by brokers yesterday.
Funeral services for Isidore D. Morrison, retired lawyer and Zionist leader who died Sunday morning, were held yesterday at the B'nai Jeshurun synagogue, 270 West Eighty-eighth Street.

Originally written for his children and now published for a wider audience, David Mannes's autobiography, "Music Is My Faith," relates the musician's early days as a poor boy in New York's.Tenderloin and his experiences playing

A sumnary of transactions in August by officers, directors and principal Stockholders of equity securities, nade public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, showed hat the United States Rubber Company had acquired 28,716 shares of commonn and 81,947 shares of 6 per lent preferred stock of the Samson Corporation, bringing the former's holdings, respectively, to 37,743 and 41,255 shares.
The German occupation of Zone No. 3 in the Sudetenland gathered in today both Karlsbad and Marienbad, which have been Czechoslovakia's most famous cure resorts.

To show France's appreciation of Premier Benito Mussolini's intervention at Munich, the French Cabinet decided today to send without further delay an Ambassador to Rome to fill the post now vacant for two years.
L. N. Renault Sons, Inc., distributor of Renault champagne and wine, expects to have sold 1,750,000 bottles of champagne since repeal by Christmas, according to Murray Radler, Eastern sales manager.

Frank V. Kelly was re-elected chairman of the Kings County Democratic Executive Committee yesterday. The position, which he has held since September, 1934, carries with it the duties of county leader.

Miss Alice Dunning daughter of Mrs. Henry W. Lowe of 435 East Fifty-second Street, has chosen Oct. 14 for her marriage to H. Ashton Crosby 3d, son of Mrs. Atwood Violett of New York and the late H. Ashton Crosby Jr. The ceremony

The United States Trust Company of New York has brought suit in Supreme Court to foreclose a $110,000 mortgage it holds on the town house of Richard Whitney, former stock broker, at 115 East Seventythird Street.

Directors of the Commonwealth Edison Company voted today to increase the dividend rate of the capital stock from 31/4 to 40 cents a quarter. The first 40-cent dividend will be paid on Nov. 1 to stockholders of record of Oct. 14.

The business parcel on Route 6, Grand Army Highway, in South East, Brewster, N. Y., which recently was sold by the estate of W. J. Dykeman to Frances Elizabeth Simpson, has been resold through Herbert J. Gebing to Elizabeth Douglass of New York, who owns an adjoining estate.
The Rumanian press expresses hope that after the Teschen settlement Czechoslovakia's relations with Poland will become normal and possibly friendly.

Illness and injuries took toll of the Rutgers football squad as serious work for the N. Y. U. game got under way today. Len Cooke, veteran left tackle, is confined to the college infirmary with a high fever and tonsillitis, and John Mullen, regular right half-back, sprained his back in the Vermont game, and is not expected to be ready by Saturday.

Slaughter moderate on all classes in local markets yesterday in anticipation of Jewish holiday Yom Kippur. The veal and calf market was steady to $1 higher on hindsaddles, other classes mostly steady. Trading generally slow. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Mrs. John Henry Clews of the Plaza will return tomorrow from Europe. Sir Henry Getty Chilton, British Ambassador to Spain, and Lady Chilton have returned from Grand Rapids-and are at the Ambassador before sailing for Europe.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Oct. 1: REAR ADMIRAL Townsend, J. C., detached as member of General Board, Washington, D. C., in November, and ordered to duty as Commandant, Fourth Naval District and Commandant, Navy Yard, Philadelphia, Pa.

President Roosevelt declined today either to sponsor or discourage a suggestion by Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, in a radio address yesterday that the time was ripe for an international conference at which a more permanent basis for world peace might be achieved.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey indicated yesterday that he would wage an unorthodox campaign in the race for Governor, at least so far as the campaign tours are concerned. Instead of the county-by-county canvass that has
Hungary, eager to regain territories of which she was stripped by World War treaties, pressed the Czechoslovak Government tonight for immediate occupation of some Hungarian zones of Czechoslovakia.
H. V. Thorby, Minister of Defense, announced today that the volunteer militia would be immediately increased from 35,000 to 42,000 and that the permanent forces would be substantially augmented.
Thomas Blagden, an early Adirondack Mountains camp operator and owner of considerable property in Washington, D. C., died here last night at Camp Omega, his Summer home, at the age of 85.

Ivan Simpson, 64, film character actor, was found suffering from carbon monoxide poisoning in his automobile at the Rivera Country Club early today. Physicians said later that he was improved and would recover.

Post-season apartment renting continue at a good pace, judging by the volume of reports from brokers and. agents received yesterday. East Side buildings drew a large proportion of the new tenants listed.

President Roosevelt said today that he planned to see Governor Lehman before the November election, but that he had no definite appointment to confer with the Democratic Gubernatorial candidate at this time.

A conservative reaction against the excesses of certain labor leaders in the violent jurisdictional war between the A. F. of L. and the C. I. O. all along the Pacific Coast has brought a strong chance, according to many political observers, for the passage of a State-wide initiative measure to regulate strikes and picketing.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., Oct. 5: LIEUTENANTS-Irving M. Davies. Emerency Service Division. Assignment changed from desk duty to supervisor. Assignment to desk duty continued: George F. McGann, from command 9th divisionn to command 122d Precinct.
A new schedule of fees has been adopted for 1939 for the ten eighteen-hole municipal courses operated by the Department of Parks, it was announced yesterday.

A few additional details were revealed today by the State Department concerning the manner in which President Roosevelt's personal message reached Premier Benito Mussolini, urging intervention of the Italian Chief of State for peace in Europe.

A banking group headed by the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation will offer publicly today at prices to yield from 4.25 to 4.50 per cent,..according to maturity, two new issues, aggregating $1,000,000, of municipal light and power revenue 41/4 per cent bonds of Seattle, Wash.
A marriage today of interest here and in England is that of Miss Jean Howle, daughter of Mrs. Clifford Howle of White Court, Torquay, England, and the late Captain Howle, R. N.,
Rix Nelson Yard, sophomore tackle from Toms River, N. J., took the place of the veteran Dominic Polilli in Penn's first scrimmage against Yale plays today.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel Hofstadter ruled yesterday that the custodial staffs of the public schools are subject to the State Labor Relations Act and upheld a ruling of the State Labor Relations Board directing Martin Nolan, custodian of the Washington Irving High School, to reinstate an ousted foreman with back pay.

A request by shippers of grain on the Great Lakes that a temporary maximum rate of 71/2 cents a bushel be set for the shipment of wheat from the head of the lakes to ports on the St. Lawrence River was refused today by the Board of Grain Commissioners, which on Friday fixed a rate of 7 cents.
Lord Shaughnessy, son of the first Baron Shaughnessy, late chairman of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company, died in a hospital today of pneumonia. He was 55 years old.

Fourteen merchant ships operating under the American and Italian flags participated yesterday in an experiment in the charting of weather conditions on the Atlantic Ocean designed to prove that airplanes may be informed of conditions all the way across the ocean.

Belief that the Arctic Crockerland, named by the late Rear Admiral Robert E. Peary, discoverer of the North Pole,- does not exist was expressed by Commander Isaac Schlossbach, navigator and pilot of the MacGregor Arctic Expedition, which returned to Port Newark this afternoon after a fifteen-and-onehalf months' trip to the Far North.
A bench warrant was issued today for Sally Rand, fan and bubble dancer, because she did not appear for trial on charges of biting, scratching and generally assaulting Miss Hazel

A program of meetings in which young men will have a special opportunity to take part will be a feature of the convention of the National Association of Tobacco Distributors, Inc., which will be held Jan. 18 to 21 at the Palmer House, Chicago.

Premier Daladier won the French Chamber's endorsement of the Munich accord yesterday by a vote of 535 to 75 and then, after an all-night debate, obtained financial decree powers with which to meet the dislocation resulting from the war scare. [Page 1.]

The Investment Bankers Conference, Inc., a nation-wide organization of dealers and brokers, was chosen yesterday as the vehicle through which the over-the-counter security industry will form a national association of security dealers to register with the Securities Exchange Commission under the Maloney act for self-regulation of that business.

Business needs no defense "because history is a series of business adventures," Dr. James Shelby Thomas, president of the Chrysler Institute of Engineering and of the Clarkson College of Technology, said yesterday at a luncheon of the members' council of the Merchants Association of New York at the Hotel Astor. Louis K. Comstock, president of the association, presided.

Joan Crawford, at her request, today was assigned to the starring role in "Ice Follies" at Metro. The skating ballet scenes are being photographed, but no casting had been made. Miss Crawford visited the set to see the ice troupe and became intrigued.

C. Benjamin Mitchell Jr. is with Amott, Baker Co., Inc., in their office here. Edward Harling is in charge of the municipal bond department of Pelz Co. The Lawyers Trust Company has been appointed registrar of the capital stock of the American Safety Razor Corporation.

The Supreme Court is expected to hear argument by counsel here tomorrow on the application of Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, for a writ of mandamus compelling Daniel Casey, Jersey City's Director of Public Safety, to give him a permit to hold an outdoor meeting. Both sides filed briefs today.

The banking firm of Simon Hirschland, founded in 1841, has been "Aryanized" and taken over by Burkhardt Co. The Hirschland firm was known in New York banking circles because of its connections with the iron industry in the Ruhr district.
When Mr. Chamberlain got home from Munich he was in a more embarrassing position than Signor Mussolini or Herr Hitler. The latter two gentlemen did not have to answer questions. Mr. Chamberlain did.

The impanelling of a special grand jury on Oct. 17 to hear charges against the American Medical Association of the District of Columbia, brought by the Department of Justice, was ordered today by Chief Justice Wheat of the Federal District Court. The association is an affiliate of the American Medical Association.

Indications of the striking changes which are being made by Catholic theologians in the Douai-Rheims version of the New Testament, are given in passages in a revised text of the Gospel of St. John, obtained here tonight at the close of the National Catechetical Congress of the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Oct. 4, unless specified: Brooklyn, at Navy Yard, New York, Sept. 30. Cachalot, Newport to Navy Yard, New York, via New London.

A "streamlined" program for the 1938 Investment Bankers Association convention that will condense five days' work into a four-day meeting, was announced yesterday to members of the association. This year's meeting, to be held Oct. 26 to 29, -at White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., saves a day without loss to the program through a selection of subjects and speakers that concentrates attention on "vital issues authoritatively handled," the announcement stated.

Choice and prime fed steers and yearlings sold actively today, under a broad demand from outsiders at strong to higher prices, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. The advance moved the top to a new high for the season at $13.40. Fat lambs were strong but the hog market continued to decline.

Sir Harold Beauchamp, father of the late Katherine Mansfield, the author, is dead here. Sir Harold, who was born in Ararat, Victoria, on Nov. 15, 1858, was a sone of Arthur Beauchamp, former member of the Provincial Council of Victoria.

Arthur H. Jones, Mayor of this town since 1929, having been elected five times, died today in his home of bronchial pneumonia. He had been ill since June 29, when he suffered a brain hemorrhage. He was 65 years old.
Still a trifle bewildered by it all and not at all certain that there may not yet prove to be a catch in it, this merry metropolis tonight finds itself swept into another world series fever.
After dragging six of her children from her blazing home, Mrs. Leo Levesque, 27, was burned to death today with an 8-year-old daughter, Lea.

The State Board of Housing will sponsor a two-day meeting of members of housing authorities from all parts of the State at the Hotel Astor, Oct. 21 and 22, Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance and chairman of the Housing Board, announced yesterday.
The Philharmonic - Symphony League will hold a luncheon in the ballroom of the Hotel Plaza on Oct. 19 for members and others. Mrs. Vincent Astor and George E. Sokolsky will be speakers.

The Carrier Corporation, Syracuse, N. Y., maker of air-conditioning and other equipment, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a statement covering $2,500,000 of 41/2 per cent ten-year convertible sinking-fund debentures due in 1948.

Hearings by the Securities and Exchange Commission into the affairs of Interstate Hosiery Mills, Inc., came virtually to an end yesterday. A pro forma adjournment was taken this morning to permit the introduction of various exhibits and correction of records, if necessary.

Efforts to settle the century-old boundary dispute between Peru and Ecuador have broken down so far as the special delegations that have been negotiating here for more than two years are concerned, it was learned today.
Judicial conventions were held by the American Labor party yesterday in both the First and Second Judicial Districts after the close of the party's State convention.

A twentieth century cave man sat in a cement and steel alcove under the Wrigley Field bleachers tonight and watched the shadows lengthen. He's been there seven nights and six days, without light or heat or hot water, waiting to buy the first $1.10 ticket to the opening game of the world series at 9 A. M. tomorrow.

The hope for a new low record for-diphtheria deaths in 1938 is threatened by increased prevalence of this disease, as compared with 1936, Dr. John L. Rice, city Health Commissioner, warned yesterday. The lowest diphtheria death rate was set in 1936.
Country life long ago disappeared in Manhattan, but a study of the old records often brings up a fascinating picture of Manhattan farms in days long past.

The Allied Chemical and Dye Company, in a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and made public yesterday at the New York Stock Exchange, has revealed for the first time the nature of its miscellaneous investments, including, among other securities, 10.4 per cent of the voting strength in the American Light and Traction Company.

The New York Community Trust, 120 Broadway, receives a legacy in excess of $350,000, in the will of Daniell Ernest Martell of 100 Central Park South, which was offered for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

As the panic and excitement culminating at Munich die down, and the deep misgivings underlying the relief in Great Britain and France rise to the surface, we find that all the old crises, overshadowed for a time by the dread of general war, are still with us.
The steamship Manhattan of the United States Lines sails today for Hamburg via Cobh, Plymouth and Havre. Passengers are John F. Montgomery,

The number of commercial and industrial failures for the week end ed Sept. 29 was smaller in three out of five trade groups as compared with the same week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The American Bridge Company has obtained a contract for 15,500 tons of steel shapes for Bonneville Dam transmission line towers. A total of 11,480 tons for the Delaware Aqueduct project was divided among several steel makers.
The text of the declaration read to the Chamber of Deputies by Premier Daladier and to the Senate by former Premier Camille Chautemps follows:

Problems facing the school children of Harlem will be studied by New York City teachers in a special course arranged by the Board of Education, it was announced yesterday. An attempt will be made to develop a better understanding between the schools and the various agencies in the community.

Heads bared, a hundred thousand Alsatians spontaneously sang the "Marseillaise" when the French Chief of Staff, General Marie Gustave Gamelin, this morning reviewed the Maginot line troops in the most impressive military parade seen in this city since the end of the World War.
The Bank of Brazil commenced today allotting exchange to cover foreign imports after a nine day's suspension which resulted in the accumulation of about $35,000,000 which now awaits cover.

President Roosevelt, in a message today to the annual convention of the American Federation of Labor, called upon the leaders of organized labor to make peace between its factions for the sake of increasing labor's prestige and preventing "the

Twenty years after the Battle of the Meuse-Argonne in the World War, Benjamin Pagliano, 44 years old, formerly private first class, 308th Infantry of the Seventy-seventh Division, A. E. F., is to receive decorations from the French Government as one of the 250 survivors of the more than 500 who made up the famous "Lost Battalion."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is but natural that the decision by Great Britain and France to abandon to its fate the only democratic republic east of the Rhine and thus to avoid war should be greeted with relief by all who fear war-and all peoples do fear war.
Mayor La Guardia reminded the conference of public works officials in his speech last Monday that "there is no Democratic or Republican way to dig a foundation or build a bridge."

The work of liquidating boundary and other technical details of the Sudeten settlement is making satisfactory progress, it was said at the German Foreign Office today. It was expected that the line of demarcation of the fifth zone would be announced tomorrow.

The total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $200,597 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. The average price a share of all listed stocks on Sept. 30 was $30.54, compared with $30.55 at the end of August.

Dr. Eduard Benes was the disciple of and collaborator with the late Thomas G. Masaryk, who has been called the "Father of Czechoslovakia." It was to Dr. Benes that Masaryk turned to carry on his policies when he retired in December, 1935.

Miss Vermont, with Uttori driving, captured all three heats of the 2:12 Class trot at the Danbury Fair track today. The bay mare, from the Barton (Vt.) stables of E. P. Cray, outclassed a large field.

Claire Trevor, who left Fox to free lance, has been engaged by Walter Anger for the starring feminine role in "Stagecoach," adapted from the Ernest Haycox short story, "Stage to Lordsburg." John Ford, who will direct, expects to get the picture started next week. The screen play is by Dudley Nichols.
It is an understandable mood which speaks of night settling down on Versailles, or the Treaty of Versailles

The first shipment of cotton into North Carolina wrapped in cotton cloth Land bound with cotton rope has been received by Green River Mills, near Hendersonville. The all-cotton wrapping weighs four and a half pounds against thirteen pounds for jute and iron bands.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Pettinos of the Savoy-Plaza, who have been passing several months in Europe, will return tomorrow on the Washington. Rear Admiral and Mrs. Richard E. Byrd have come from Boston to the Biltmore.

Many dinners will precede the performance of "Kiss the Boys Goodbye" tonight at the Henry Miller Theatre, which has been taken over by the Stepney Fresh Air Committee to raise funds for the Stepney Fresh Air Camp in Botsford, Conn.
The Central Railroad of New Jersey incurred a net loss of $328,000 last month, against a net loss of $123,467 in September, 1937, Edward W. Scheer, president, said yesterday.

After a controversy lasting more than a year, Mayor S. Davis Wilson today suddenly signed a new agreement leasing the city-owned gas plant to the Philadelphia Gas Works Company, a subsidiary of the United Gas Improvement Company.

Mrs. Nicholas Longworth, daughter of the late Theodore Roosevelt, former President, addressed more than 350 members of the Greenwich Woman's Club at its opening meeting of the season held in the Masonic Temple Auditorium this afternoon.

Supreme Court Justice Edward Riegelmann granted in Brooklyn yesterday an order requiring John McGlade, sexton of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis Xavier, Sixth Avenue and Carroll Street, Brooklyn, to submit to examination before trial of a $25,000 damage suit brought against the church by Mrs. Thelma A. Wilson and her husband, Robert A. Wilson, of 90 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn. The plaintiffs charge that

Walter Douglas Jr., airline president, married Miss Annabelle Spriggs Wager, University of Arizona student, here today. Mr. Douglas is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Douglas of New York and Guadalajara, Mexico.

The annual card party for the benefit of Willoughby House Settlement has been arranged by a group of members of the senior and junior board of directors of the organization for the afternoon of Nov. 2 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Stanley K.

Net income of the Woodward Iron Company for the first nine months of this year amounted to $303,696 after depreciation, depletion, interest, Federal and State taxes and other charges, according to the financial statement issued yesterday.

By an act of Congress approved May 31, 1938, the President was authorized to appoint four additional circuit judges, one additional associate justice of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, twelve additional district judges and three additional associate justices of the District Court of the United States for the District of Columbia.

The success of Premier Edouard Daladier of France in obtaining from Parliament virtually dictatorial powers up to Nov. 15 "for immediate economic and financial restoration" gave another boost yesterday to the foreign exchange market.

The Republicans of the Fifteenth Assembly District, home of most of the prominent party members in the city, will pick a new leader tomorrow night to succeed Kenneth F. Simpson. Mr. Simpson resigned his district leadership a week ago, and refused, at a long conference last night, to reconsider his decision.

Deals involving the payment of cash featured the Manhattan realty transactions announced yesterday, when several business properties in midtown and residential parcels in scattered sections changed hands. A number of the purchasers revealed plans for modernization and reconstruction of their newly acquired holdings.

With his service pistol lying on the floor near him, Patrolman John J. Meehan Jr., 36 years old, a member of the Police Department for thirteen years, was found fatally wounded at 3:15 A. M. yesterday with a bullet in the right temple in his bedroom at 39-25 Fiftieth Street, Astoria, Queens, where he lived with is father, John J., Sr., and a sister, Alice. He was taken to St.

Spokesmen for communities in West Tennessee served by the Kentucky-Tennessee Light and Power Company announced today that they had reached an agreement with the utility for purchase of all its properties west of the Tennessee River.

On their own applications--To take effect 12 midnight, Oct. 4: PATROLMEN William D. Thompson, 103d Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Oct. 2, 1913. Christian H. Lammrich, Traffic Precinct E, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Oct. 2, 1913.

Additional bank statements as of Sept. 30 which were made public yesterday continued to show a rising trend for total assets and deposits in the last quarter. Contrary to what had been shown by most other bank statements those which became available yesterday all showed a reduction in cash for the quarter. Government security holdings were higher in all cases.

The Harvard A and B teams had another scrimmage today, each putting in an hour on offense and defense. Cornell plays were used against both combinations and each ran its own plays against the C eleven. The varsity was intact except for Glueck, guard, and Cohen, fullback, who were excused for the day.
A Japanese naval landing party reported today that it had captured the Maanshan fort on the south bank of the Yangtze River west of Panpaishan yesterday after a bayonet charge.
President Federico Laredo Bru tonight appointed Dr. Oscar Garcia Montes Secretary of the Treasury to fill the vacancy left by the recent resignation of Amadeo Lopez Castro. Dr. Garcia

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today the basis for determination of proportionate shares for farms in the mainland sugar cane area for the 1939 crop, using the estimate made Sept. 24 that the 1939 requirements would be 540,000 tons of sugar, which was comparable with the 1938 requirements.
After standing among the leaders of Eastern football for eight successive years, Colgate last Fall experienced the most disastrous season any team coached by Andy Kerr has known.
Arthur King Wood, treasurer and a director of the Welsbach Street Illuminating Company, died last night at the age of 63 in his apartment here after an illness of two days.

Several important changes in the Standard Gas and Electric Company system, as a result of the recent emergence of that utility group from reorganization proceedings, were announced yesterday by Bernard W. Lynch, president of Standard Gas and Electric.

An exhibition of paintings by leading artists of Brazil is being shown on the ninth floor of the International Telephone Building, 67 Broad Street. This work has not been displayed before in North America.

Mr. and Mrs. Bartram North Stuart of, this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Elizabeth Stuart, to William R. Jewett, son of Mr. and Mrs. William P. N. Jewett, also of Passaic.

Doubt that the present trend of government will make for a happier society, as its sponsors believe, was expressed yesterday by Representative Bruce Barton in a luncheon address at the Dartmouth College Club, 30 East Thirty-seventh Street.

The California Railroad Commission authorized yesterday the Pacific Gas and Electric Company to acquire the preferred stocks of the San Joaquin Light and Power Company. Oct. 14 has been set as the final date for acceptance of the offer of exchange.

THE GOOD, a play in three acts, by Chester Erskin. Staged by the author; scenery by Donald Oenslager; produced by Norman and Irvin Pincus. At the Windsor Theatre.

The second round of the New Jersey women's State golf championship, which is being played over the Plainfield Country Club course, saw, one of the favorites, 19-yearold Miss. Laddie Irwin of Glen Ridge, succumb to the fine golf of Miss Gall Wild of Baltusrol, who won 2 up.

Before its largest and most enthusiastic crowd the little world series was unveiled in Ruppert Stadium tonight in a soul-satisfying ninthinning victory for Bill Meyer's Blues over Newark by a 9-8 score.

Dr. Ralip E. Diffendorfer of New York, corresponding secretary of the.Methodist Episcopal Church's Board of Foreign Missions, announced today he had just received word that a, "state of emergency" had been declared in the church's work in Japan and Korea.
