An owner from New Orleans, Joe W. Brown, captured the Hazelwood Handicap yesterday at Jamaica, where one of the biggest midweek crowds in years saw Spillway score by a head at the end of a speedy six furlongs over a fast track. The son of Cohort received a powerful ride from Leon (Buddy) Haas and just got up in 1:114-5.

Foundation Plan, Incorporated, formerly known as United Endowment Foundation, Inc., 52 Vanderbilt Avenue, and six officers and employes were ordered yesterday to show cause why they should not be enjoined from violations of the Securities Act in marketing a "thrift plan."
Chances are about even that George McDaniel, light but fiery back from Lynchburg, Va., will start against his fellow-Virginians Saturday, rather than Lem Cooke, the triple ace of the Navy backfield.
Appointment of twenty-one Fellows in the Bureau of Street Traffic Research was announced today by the committee on transportation of Yale University.

Broadening of the advertising programs of individual manufacturers and dealers in automatic stokers and by Anthracite Industries, Inc., was predicted yesterday in trade circles where it was reported that heavy campaigns this season had brought unusually sharp sales increases.

American embassies and legations in Europe are now informing American residents that there is no longer reason for their returning to the United States, Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State said today.

Underwriting groups headed by Dillon, Read Co. and the Mellon Securities Corporation will offer publicly today by neans of a prospectus $42,000,000 of bonds and notes of the Michigan Consolidated Gas Company.

The twelfth Brooklyn outdoor art exhibition, presented by independent painters who tack their work to the unpainted fence around the Central Library Building, under construction, at Eastern Parkway Flatbush Avenue and Grand Army Plaza, got under way yesterday.

Pressing resolutely forward with an assurance that seemed to defy any challenge to their reign of supremacy, the Yankees today attained the first objective toward what they confidently expect will be their third straight world championship.

John W. De Kay, capitalist and author, died yesterday in Takoma Park, Md. Burial services will be held Friday at Falls Church, Va. He came from his home in mington, Calif., in June to visit his brother, Henry E. De Kay of Ashburn, Va., and decided to stay in this vicinity to finish writing a book. Friends attributed his death to overwork.

Potentially, one of the most interesting contests in the current campaign is that of John Lord O'Brian of Buffalo for the seat of Senator Wagner. It could, if the New York Republicans and Mr. O'Brian have the stomach for a hard fight, present a foremost national issue over the extremes of the New Deal. Perhaps it will so develop,
This city has received a check for $82,244 from the Great Western Sugar Company of Denver in settlement of an action brought against it to collect personal property taxes for 1937-38.

George W. Gale 3d, grandson of the founder of Galesburg and Knox College, died yesterday at the home of a daughter in Saratoga, Calif., according to word received by relatives here. He was 90 vears.old.
The resignation of President Eduard Benes means Czechoslovakia will swing quickly into the economic and diplomatic orbit of Germany, in the opinion of many well-informed observers in London tonight.
Charles Hare, England's No. 2 Davis Cup player,. was eliminated from the Pacific Coast tennis championships today by an unseeded public courts player.

Czechoslovkia will go ahead with its preparations to participate in the World's Fair of 1989, the Consulate General of that country has notified Admiral William H. Standley, fair director of foreign participation.

Prospects for sales of tire accesseries and repair materials during the next six months are exceptionally bright, according to H. W. Brown, sundry sales manager of the Fisk Tire Corporation. Bicycle tire
The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday a net gain of 6,999 telephones in service during September, compared with a gain of 9,740 instruments in September, 1937.

During a four-hour meeting of the Crown Council today 'King Carol discussed the country's foreign policy with his Ministers. It is learned that the Czech problem and its ramifications with CarpathoRussia were considered carefully.

Eddie Collins Jr. today replaced John Miller as Yale right halfback in the most extensive scrimmage practice of the week for the Pennsylvania game. Aside from struggling through forty-five minutes' defensive and thirty minutes' offensive play he was given half an hour's punting drill by Assistant Coach Bill Renner.

Mrs. Adelaide Spencer Meredith, wife of Dr. Albert B. Meredith, head of the department of educational administration at New York University, died at her home here today after a long illness. Mrs. Meredith was graduated from Wellesley in 1897.

Mrs. William Warren Tracy entertained the Williamstown Garden Club at Ormeland, Williamstown, today at its annual meeting. Mrs. Andrew Lester of Springfield, Ill., the hostess's sister, assisted, as did Mrs. William Howard Doughty and Miss Florence B. Minton.

Eight families fled from the Holland House apartments at 73-37 Austin Street, Forest Hills, Queens, at 5 A. M. yesterday after a gas explosion caused by a woman suicide exploded and shook the structure. Damage to the building was slight and was confined to the apartment in which the gas was turned on.

Norman Thomas; Socialist candidate for Governor, opened his campaign last night with a series of outdoor speeches in Queens. In his first address, at Jamaica Avenue and Steinway Street, Astoria, Mr. Thomas said his campaign would be based on such issues as milk supply, housing and pensions.

December is the time that the Krimskys, John and Jerrold, would like to see the local arrival of their second project, the musical version of Robert Nathan's short story, "The Orchid." The Dutchess County Republican Executive Committee late today designated Allan A. Ryan Jr. of Rhinebeck as its choice to succeed Senator Frederic H. Bontecou as candidate for Senator in the DutchessColumbia-Putnam district.

John Karcis, veteran fullback, was signed yesterday by the New York Football Giants and was among the twenty-eight members of the squad who left for Washington to conclude preparations for the clash there on Sunday with the Redskins in Griffith Stadium.

After having been in its present quarters at 46-50 White Street for thirty-five years, Henry Glass Co., manufacturers of rayon, cotton and linen fabrics, have taken a lease on large quarters in the building at 86-88 Worth Street and will move there shortly after Jan. 1, it was announced yesterday.

The average American college student is not duped by the "alluring pictures" of dictators' promises for an abundant life through regimentation, Dean John T. Madden of the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance declared in his annual report to Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase, made public yesterday.

Harold Riner, 27 years old, was charged with attempted burglary and violation of the Penal Code sections dealing with the drugging of race horses in indictments handed up yesterday by the Queens grand jury.

Mrs. John Allen Dillon entertained with a luncheon yesterday at Sherry's for Miss Mollie Todd Jenks, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Daker Jenks of Pelham Manor, N. Y., whose marriage to Edward Victor Donaldson Jr. will take place Oct. 15 in the Huguenot Memorial Church, Pelham Manor.

The right of women to serve on grand juries in Brooklyn and validity of more than 200 indictments returned by the September Kings County grand jury, which included a woman member, were upheld yesterday by Kings County Judge Peter J. Brancato on the ground of "sound public policy."

Walter Gunthard Stamm, prominent athlete at Pingry School here more than twenty years ago, died last night at Bay Pines Hospital in Florida after a brief illness. He was a son of Alexander and Elise Gunthard Stamm of this city.
The five-story apartment house on a plot 65 by 85 feet at 1,523 Taylor Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by the Geo-Tay Realty Corporation to Henry Hastedt.

A $295,000 mortgage loan at 4 1/2 per cent has been arranged for the Hammerdinger Estate Corporation on the industrial buildings at Dry Harbor Road and Cooper Avenue, Glendale, L. I., by Lawrence, Blake Jewell, Inc., broker.
Paul Osborn's "On Borrowed Time," adapted for the English stage by Ian Hay, was more witheringly criticized on its opening at the Haymarket last night than any play for a long time.
A call for a constitutional convention for the Committee for Industrial Organization to meet in Pittsburgh on Nov. 14 was issued today by John L. Lewis, chairman.

The investigation into official corruption in Brooklyn took a new and surprising turn last night when Governor Lehman announced that he had directed District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn, William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, and Police Commissioner Valentine to confer with him at his home this afternoon.
Charles Percy Fullerton, jurist and railway executive of the Dominion, died in the home of his daughter, Mrs. A. C. McMillan, here today. lie was 68 years old.

Business can take a lesson from the army in planning for continuous retraining of its personnel, the first session of a two-day conference on office management of the American Management Association was told yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
Excavation work will start today for a new type of commercial building, combining garage facilities and office space, as the thirteenth unit in Rockefeller Center.

The five-power International Commission in Berlin held a meeting today-it is in fact in almost continual session-and decided the further territory in the Sudetenland to be occupied by German troops between Friday, when the occupation of the last of the four zones fixed by the Munich agreement will be complete, and next Monday. This concerns socalled preponderantly German areas.

Mrs. Mary Ruth Meredith Leslie, daughter of Mrs. Abbot Geer of 520 East Eighty-sixth Street, will be married Saturday morning in Westerly, R. I., to H. Marshall Oliver of this city.

Mr. and Mrs. E. Magawly Banon of 81 Riverside Drive and Newport, R. I., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Banon's cousin and adopted daughter, Miss Mary O'Leary, to Dr. William P. Whalen, son of William E. Whalen of this city and the late Mrs. Whalen.

The final quarter of 1938 has started with bright prospects for the engineering construction industry. "Heavy" building contracts awarded during September reached $289,725,000, the highest figure for any September since 1929, due largely to a sharp rise in public work, a study of figures gathered by Engineering News-Record shows.

The two four-story garden-type apartment houses at 14 and 16 Forest Street, Montclair, N. J., known as Forest View and Mountain View respectively, were sold by the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company to B. A. Lipman.

DAGGETT, GRACE L. (May 17). Estate, less than $10,000. To Sarah D. Chamber, Bloomerside, Peach lake, Brewster, N. Y., and Grace D. Rader, Manasquan, N. J., daughters, executrices, equally. FERRELL, HORACE A. (Sept. 21). Estate, about $6,000. To George W. Ferren, son, 117 Beech St., Bellville.

Governor Bibb Graves today advocated a football game between the Universities of Alabama and Minnesota "within a month" in New York or Chicago, "to raise $1,000,000" for Red Cross relief work in storm-wrecked Northeastern States.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, threatened today to break off fraternal relations with the Canadian labor movement if the latter failed to oust all affiliates of the Committee for Industrial Organization.

One hundred and seventy-one awards to City College athletes were announced yesterday by Professor Walter Williamson, college manager of athletics, for participation in varsity and junior varsity baseball, varsity lacrosse, varsity tennis and varsity and junior varsity track.

Reorganization plans of the Connecticut Company, the trolley and bus lines of the New Haven Railroad system, have been approved by the Connecticut Public Utilities Commission and have been filed with the United States District Court here for approval by Judge Carroll C. Hincks.
George A. L. Field, who was dis--ntly related to President Abraham Lincoln and wrs a founder of the Philadelphia Mummers Association, died in Camden yesterday of a heart ailment at the age of 64.

Henri Grechen, who operated the barber shop in the Hotel Brevoort, Eighth Street and Fifth Avenue, for thirty-seven years until illness com pelled his retirement last Spring, died yesterday in the Rosary Hill Home at Hawthorne, N. Y. Born in France seventy-three years ago, he had lived in tne United States since young manhood.

Among the passengers who sailed for Europe yesterday on the steamship Manhattan of the United States Lines was John Flournoy Montgomery, United States Minister to Hungary, who is returning to Budapest.

Dr. Henry N. MacCracken, president of Vassar College, speaker this afternoon, at Wesleyan University at the convocation in recognition of scholarships, said his remarks would resemble a study in academic entomology, since he "was in search of an insect known as a liberal."
This steel city's Department of Public Works was practically closed down today and nearly 400 employes were out of jobs.

The anonymous spokesman for the Administration who hopes that American industry will learn from the recent settlement of the European war crisis that it will profit more by cooperating with Government than by namecalling and "economic saber-rattling" has a genius for irony.

John C. Metcalfe, investigator for the Special House Committee on Un-American Activities, told the committee today that the German-American Bund was seeking to consolidate all fascist elements in America into one movement which the "Hitlerinspired Bund" was to lead.

Applications for permits covering new structures and the rehabilitation of existing buildings in Queens, filed with the Department of Housing and Building last month, were almost double the value of the projects submitted in the same month of last year.
QUEENS Assets $33,244 gross, $30,688 net. To widow, Rose M. Forrest. Outstanding holdings in jointly owned property, $26,325. Duncan E. Longworth, attorney, 75 Lee Ave., Rockville Center. L. I.

L. Boyd Hatch, vice president of the Atlas Corporation, has leased for occupancy from LeGrand Bouton Cannon the five-story private residence at 131 East Seventy-first Street, through Mrs. Edward Stout, Inc., broker.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Ralph W. Collins of Dongan Hills, S. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caroline Barbara Collins, to Richard Hand Wadhams, son of Albion J. Wadhams, also of Dongan Hills, and the late Mrs. Wadhams.

The unusually rapid decline in sterling exchange, and the very large gold shipments to the United States, have been properly ascribed to the agitated transfer of foreign capital to the United States, when war seemed imminent.

Herman E. Siefert, formerly assistant general manager of the State stores division of the Schenley Distillers Corporation, has been placed in charge of the distribution and sales in monopoly States for Gibson Distilling Company.

Designating petitions bearing the label of the "Independent Progressive party" were circulated here today in support of Thomas E. Dewey, Republican Gubernatorial candidate, and his running mates on the ticket.

Out of the Munich conference and settlement has come this indirect result, that the Popular Front of Radical Socialists, Socialists and Communists that has governed French policy for two years has been completely shattered.

Pitman Ave (17-5030), s s, 47 ft w of Monticello Ave, 35x100; Ambrose J. Delehanty, referee, to Eastchester Savings Bank, Mt. Vernon. Newbold Ave, 2,246 (14-3822), Central Savings Bank to Ann Markowitz, 2,246 Newbold Ave.

Bertram L. Marks, retired lawyer, died on Tuesday at his home, 208 West Eighty-sixth Street, after an illness of more than two years. Mr. Marks's last office was at 8 West Fortieth Street. His age was 54.
President Roosevelt was urged today by four peace organizations to exert "the full influence of this government" to bring about a world economic and disarmament conference soon.
Governor Moore said today he had been advised of his selection as a Thirtythird Degree Mason, highest honor in Masonic fraternal circles. In accordance with the rites of the
Miss LeBrun Cruger Rhinelander and William G. McKnight Jr. will have twenty-two attendants at their marriage on Oct. 14, which will take place in St. James Church.
Mr. and Mrs. Davis Sachs of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy I. Sachs, to Dr. Robert Isenman of Malden, Mass.

Bronx Ely Ave, n w cor Pitman Ave to 55 ft n of Pitman Ave, 4 2-story dwellings, 19x36; John Baroncelli, 2,517 Radcliff Ave, owner; L. M. Rothman, architect; cost, $22,000. Starling Ave, n w cor Castle Hill Ave, 75x 104; 1-story stores, Max-Gor Realty, Inc, 50 E 42d St, owner; T. Dunn, architect; cost, $10,000.

Investigation of alleged communistic tendencies at New York University and Hunter College in ,New York City was proposed by Mrs. F. Kiersted Pidgeon, delegate from the Washington Heights chapter, during a round-table discussion at the State conference of the Daughters of the American Revolution this morning.

The Port of New York Authority vill produce a net revenue of about $3,810,000 for the current year and expects an income of not less than $3,000,000 annually until 1946, Frank C. Ferguson, the chairman, said yesterday in an address to the Savings Bank Bond Men of New York

Trial Decisions The following members of the Department having been tried before Francis X. Giaccone, Deputy Fire Commissioner, on date specified, for violation of Rules and Regulations, 1937, the following decisions are rendered by the Fire Chief and Commissioner:

Any modification of the Johnson law, which closes the money markets of the United States to foreign governments in default on payments due the United States Treasury, must be undertaken in the spirit of the greatest precaution, Senator Borah said tonight.

Arthur G. McKeever, managing director of the Merchant Truckmen's Bureau, announced yesterday that a final understanding had been reached by truck owners with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters with reference to interpretations of the agreement that ended the recent truckmen's strike.

No kosher slaughter in local markets yesterday, due to Jewish holiday, "Yom Kippur." Trading generally slow on all classes. Tuesday's kosher chucks and plates market mostly 50c higher on choice and prime, other grades mostly steady to 50c higher; all other classes mostly steady. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow;
Despite the most glorious golfing weather of the whole year, only nine of the scheduled thirty-two matches were played in the annual Metropolitan P. G. A. championship at the Oceanside links today.

The New England Council's index of general business activity rose during August 6.5 per cent, to stand at 91.8 per cent of estimated normal, as compared with 86.2 for July. This is the best monthly rate recorded since September, 1937, when the index stood at 96.2 per cent.

The advance in cotton futures was resumed yesterday, with prices up to new high levels for the current movement. Tightness of Southern spot cotton offerings, and statements by the Administration citing cotton as an example of a commodity that should go higher because present prices do not reflect the cost of production, contributed to the rally.
Federal Housing Administrator Stewart McDonald said today the high level of home financing activities during September indicated a substantial amount of new home building during the rest of the year.

Prices of wheat declined fractionally in the early trading today to the lowest level since Sept. 21, but there was no material pressure on the market. Short covering developed later In sympathy with the strength in securities and with corn and a rally of 1 1/2 to 1 3/4 cents a bushel followed, with the close at net gains of 11 1/8 to 1 1/4 cents.

Charles M. Hambright, former commander of the Wisconsin department of the G. A. R., died last night in the Soldiers Home Hospital. He was 93 years old. He was elected State commander of the G. A. R. in 1935 while he also was acting commander of the E. B. Wolcott Post, of which he had been quartermaster for twenty years.
Jim Ferrier, Australian open golf champion, defeated Bobby Locke, Irish and South African open champion, at Manly today.

Two hundred representatives of the nation's leading dairy producers met today to consider a national advertising program to stimulate sales of their products and relieve a surplus almost 100 per cent greater than it was a year ago.

The report of the General American Investors Company, Inc., for Sept. 30 shows net assets of $28,012,843 applicable to the debentures and capital stock. This compares with $24,882,688 on Dec. 31, 1937. The increase for the nine

J. B. S. Haldane, distinguished scientist and author of "Possible Worlds" and "Science and Human Life," has written his first juvenile book, "My Friend Mr. Leakey," the story of a magician. It was published yesterday by Harper.
ALL THAT MATTERS, by Peter Mendelssohn. (Holt; $2.50.) A novel laid in Nazi Germany. ARCTIC JOURNEYS, by Edward Shackleton. (Farrar Rinehart, $3.50.) The story of the

Hoge McCartney of 36 Plaza Street, Brooklyn, a teacher of English at James Madison High School, who had been connected with the school system since 1911, died on Monday at the age of 66 in Adelphi Hospital of a heart malady.

Fifteen years ago, 10,000 miles from the University of Missouri, two children enrolled in kindergarten in Peking, China. They met again recently at the city desk of the Missouri University School of Journalism for the first time in six years, the university reports.

The proceedings for the reorganization of the Missouri Pacific Railroad was reopened today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to receive certain stipulations and an amend ment to the modified plan filed by the committee for holders of 'Missouri Pacific first and refunding mortgage bonds.

Strong endorsement of the New York Curb Exchange's reorganization plan was voted yesterday by the New York Curb Exchange Partners Association. In a declaration signed by Herbert G. Einstein, chairman, the association asserted that the plan fulfills all requisites "toward producing a modern,

With Cliff Battles, the former Washington Redskin running ace, playing in the threat position for an "Army" team of scrubs that put on a varied running, passing and quick-kicking attack, Columbia's varsity received a thorough defensive drill at Baker Field yesterday.

ABRAHAM-Jennie, on Oct. 3, beloved sister of the late Albert Abraham and Sarah Phillips. Services at the chapel of Temple Emanu-ElI 65th St. at 5th Ave., on Thursday at 11 A. M. Cincinnati papers please copy.

It was chiefly due to the European outlook and the political skill of Eduard Benes, second and last President of the Czechoslovakia we have known, that the young republic attained a maturity beyond its years and an influence beyond its size and power.

In connection with the launching of the government's new "Good Neighbor" steamship service to South America, the Maritime Commission has approved an agreement among three steamship companies serving West and East Coast ports of the southern continent, covering a round-trip cruise service for passengers who wish to travel down one coast and return along the other.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange kept close pace with stocks yesterday, and in the heavlest trading since mid-September prices advanced sharply. Railroad issues moved ahead 1 to 9 points, with even wider advances in some obligations. The turnover was $10,
A luncheon and a fashion show entitled "Fall Tonic Session" will be held on Monday in the Great Hall of the Junior League clubhouse at 221 East Seventy-first Street. The various fashion
In her first bid for the women's United States senior golf crown, Mrs. Dorothy Campbell Howe of Merion led the field of 75 players with a score of 79 at the Westchester Country Club today.

David S. Murden of Peekskill, who tried unsuccessfully to run in the primary for the Republican nomination for County Executive of Westchester, started circulating petitions today for his nomination on the Progressive party ticket, using the Bull Moose emblem of Theodore Roosevelt.

Germany is preparing to bill Czechoslovakia for "reparations" dating back to the birth of the republic. Neutral observers regard the demand as a powerful lever to force Czechoslovakia into Germany's Danubian economic system.

A $1,000,000,000 increase in trade will accrue to Greater New York from its World's Fair next year, Grover A. Whalen, president of the exhibition, told members of the Chicago Association today in a luncheon address.

After unanimously endorsing Governor Lehman for re-election, the legislative committee of the State Brotherhood of Locomotive Enginemen and Firemen went on record today as "absolutely opposing any and all wage cuts" for railroad employes.

Mrs. Grace Danzig Clark, wife of Herbert W. Clark of Old Greenwich, died in the Stamford Hospital today of a cerebral hemorrhage. Born in New York sixty years ago, the daughter of the late Abraham and Jennie Danzig, she was graduated from Hunter College in 1898 and taught school for a year before her marriage.

A warning that the Chicago, New York St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad was faced with bankruptey, despite the backing of the Alleghany Corporation, top company in the Van Sweringen railroad-holding system, was issued yesterday by George D. Brooke, president of the underlying company. Mr. Brooke's statement

John Nino Malnati, maitre d'hotel who had catered to Presidents and Kings and had been restaurant and banquet manager of the Biltmore Hotel since its opening, died yesterday in his home in Pelham Manor, N. Y., of a heart ailment.

Electric power production declined last week, countering the normal seasonal and long-term trends, and the adjusted index dropped to 93.4. The figure was 94.1 for the preceding week and 104.4 for the week ended Oct. 2, 1937.

The Brooklyn Eagles tallied in every period and wound up with an impressive 34-0 victory over the Union City Rams in an American Professional Football Association encounter under the lights at Ebbets Field last night. About 3,000 persons saw the Eagles make their home debut.
Beginning today the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company will put the case of the chain store industry before the public in daily newspapers in every town in which the company has stores.

When the first period ended yesterday morning at Haaren Cooperative School Annex, 120 West Forty-sixth Street, forty boys emerged into the street and started shouting: "Come on out-you don't have to go to school today!"

The directors of the Dardelet Threadlock Corporation have elected C. Russell Feldman, president of the Simplex Radio Company, a member of the board and chairman of the executive committee. T. A. Hellwig Jr. was made a director and a member of the executive committee.
Wilhelm Sommerfeld, 27 years old, died on the guillotine today for espionage. Two convicted spies, one of them a woman, were executed yesterday.

Sir Willmott Lewis, Washington correspondent for The London Times, in the convocation address formally opening the 115th session of the University of Virginia today, questioned whether the democratic nations had made the same progress in the field of social justice that they had in the sphere of material growth.

Two tenement house properties in Manhattan and six in the Bronx have been sold by the Central Savings Bank to 30-25 Steinway Realty, Inc., Quentin F. O'Connell president, through Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., broker.

The report of the Engineers Public Service Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Aug. 31. issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $3,709,336 after all operating expenses, taxes and charges, compared with a net income of $3,379,662 in the preceding twelve months. Gross revenues of the system rose to $52,708;045 from $51,081,532.

Gleason Ave, 2,047, 24.6x106.1; Home Owners Loan Corp against Faustina Stramiello; due, $12,703; taxes, etc, $153; to plaintiff for $10,150. 169th St, 815 E, 2-story dwelling, 21.1x58.2 irreg; Newburgh Savings Bank Against Salcia Brandon; due, $4.902; taxes, etc. $94; to plaintiff for $4.000.

Miss Anne M. Murray, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Murray of Pelham Manor, N. Y., will be married to Edward Allen Scofield of Stamford, at the home of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Breese, in Cos Cob, Greenwich, on Saturday afternoon. The Rev. Dr. George A.

Bids for the construction of the destroyer tender Prairie and the seaplane tender Albemarle were opened at the Navy Department today. The New York Shipbuilding Corporation of Camden was the low bidder for both ships.

Recurring deficits and the prospect of competing with musical events at the World's Fair caused the Westchester Music Festival Association to announce today that the festival scheduled for next May in the County Center had been postponed a year.

Officials of Milwaukee County, Wis., will offer on Oct. 24 an issue of $2,600,000 of corporate notes at an interest rate not exceeding 21/2 per cent. The notes, dated Nov. 1, 1938. will be due on July 1, 1939.

Raising the issue of State's rights on the question of Federal Government flood control work in New England, Governor George Aiken stated today that Vermont was ready to cooperate with the Federal Government on any plan that did not require "the surrender of the ownership and jurisdiction over natural resources."
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 4: COLONELS Miles H. (F.A.), 18th F.A., Fort Sill, Okla., to headquarters, 4th F. A. Brigade, same station.

Charles Mannarano's book learning has not done him much good. Back in 1926 it resulted in his arrest on a counterfeiting charge, which was later dismissed, and yesterday, if he is to be believed, it caused him to be sentenced to prison.
Robert C. Adams, New York banker and president of the BancamericaBlair Corporation,- died in his home in Newtown Tuesday evening from a heart ailment. He was 65 years old.
At the annual Founder's Day exercises at Lehigh University today, Dr. C. C. Williams, president, conferred three honorary degrees on men of science as follows:

Sir Henry Wood, who is still at the height of an exceptional career, celebrated his fifty years as an orchestra conductor in Albert Hall tonight with a concert before a thronged house, arranged for musical charities by his brother and sister, both musicians.

The crowd that saw today's opening game of the world series may not have been the largest ever assembled in Wrigley Field-they have discontinued the practice of putting the overflow on the field here-but it was the largest gathering housed in the remodeled ball park and taxed accommodations absolutely to the limit.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey reduced yesterday the price of gas and fuel oil 1/3 cent a gallon in tank cars here. The new price for the medium grade of fuel oil, distillatee fuel oil, gas oil. and Diesel fuel oil is 4.125 cents, while the heavy grade fuel oil is 3.875 cents.

Princeton hit a midweek letdown today and for two hours prepared listlessly to meet Saturday's Dartmouth invasion. Yesterday the Tigers scrimmaged against the freshmen, but today they returned to fundamentals and practice was reopened to visitors.

Fed steers, especially strictly choice and prime kinds, sold actively again today at fully steady prices. Prime offerings uncovered a new top at $13.50, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Hog prices showed a little reaction following recent sharp declines. Lambs weakened, with the day's top at $8.35.

Chicago and Joliet plants of United Wall Paper Factories, Inc., will go on a double shift tomorrow night, due in part to improvement in sales of the two big Chicago mail-order houses and in part to a broadening general demand for wallpaper.

Eduard Benes, who helped found the Czechoslovak Republic after the World War and had held public office ever since, resigned as President yesterday. In a farewell address he termed the Munich settlement unjust, but blamed no one, saying, "History will be our judge." [Page 1.]
A number of leases for quarters in buildings on Park Avenue marked the contracts for residential space reported by brokers yesterday.

The common cause of Jews, Catholics and Protestants to sustain the spiritual and moral forces of democracy against advancing tyranny, and pleas for recognition of the rights of racial and religious groups were themes that marked the sermons delivered yesterday to the thousands who attended the Yom Kippur services in the city's temples and synagogues.
Chancellor Adolf Hitler delivered tonight the keynote address opening the sixth annual Winter relief campaign, "the world's greatest social work," in the Sportspalast.

New steel business in September is estimated by The Iron Age at 15 to 20 per cent greater than that in August. The trade journal states, however, that after a settlement of the European crisis had been reached some signs of a further improvement immediately developed and that two or three sales offices of steel companies in New York had the largest volume of orders for any week this year.
With the scheduled arrival of more buyers here next week, a sharp increase in reorders on Fall apparel and accessories is anticipated, reports here yesterday indicated. The religious holiday this

The marriage of Miss Marjorie Knight, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Clinton Knight of Clinton Corners, Dutchess County, N. Y., to Elliott Beach Macrae, son of John Macrae of this city and the late Mrs. Macrae, took place here yesterday morning in the rectory of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Following the suspension of the gold standard in France in the Autumn of 1936, the gold reserves of the Bank of France were revalued provisionally by a law of Oct. 1 of that year. The gold was revalued at a rate of 49 milligrams gold 0.900 fine, which corresponded to a value of 4.96 cents for the franc.

The official documents in last week's British White Paper were supplemented today by the disclosure of the instructions sent to-Basil Cochrane Newton, British Minister to Prague, just before the presentation of the Anglo-French "ultimatum" on Sept. 21.

In an uncontested suit before Vice Chancellor W. Frank Sooy, a jury in Chancery Court here today adjudged Miss Addie Steelman, 52 years old, of Linwood, N. J., incompetent to administer an estate of $125,000 to which she will soon fall heir. The woman's mother,

Mrs. William S. Gould gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Miss Audrey W. Pearl of London. A luncheon was given by Miss Catharine Gamble, debutante daughter of Mrs. Paul Abbott, at the Stork Club for Miss Elizabeth Howe, also a debutante, to celebrate the latter's birthday.

Barnard College freshmen will attend a party to be given in their honor by the Folk Dance Club of the college tonight in Barnard Hall on the campus, at which Don Chambers, authority on American country dancing, and his group will entertain.

A violent wind delayed for an hour the sailing of the liner Normandie, which had been scheduled to leave at 2 P. M. today. The force of the wind, coming from the south, on the great superstructure of the

Representatives of foreign business houses whose activities include publicity work or advertising on behalf of their principals must register with the State Department today or be liable to heavy penalties, the Merchants Association was advised by the government yesterday.
One week from Saturday will find the New York deer hunters taking to the tall timber in the northern counties, but the hunters in the Catskill area will have to wait until Dec. 1 this year.

Turning in a score of 39, 41-80, Mrs. Marion Turpie McNaughton of Sound View took the low-gross prize in the Women's Long Island Golf Association one-day tournament at the Pomonok Country Club in Flushing yesterday.

Martin Klein, Westchester branch manager for the Automobile Club of New York, who last week served a summons on a policeman selling tickets to a benefit, issued a statement yesterday to rally Car owners in that county against what he termed excessive and discriminatory charges.

Coach Mal Stevens sent his New York University football squad through an intensive dummy scrimmage against Rutgers formations yesterday afternoon at Ohio Field. Most of the coaching staff's attention was devoted to the back-field men, who spent almost two hours in familiarizing themselves with new plays and in improving the timing of old ones.

Mrs. Jeannie Ogden Miller Cornell, widow of Dr. William Paterson Cornell of Columbia, S. C., died Tuesday in Buffalo at the home of a daughter, Mrs. William A. Mayhew, after a prolonged illness. From 1924, the year of her husband's death, until her resignation last month, she had been executive secretary of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Florida.

John Paul Caswell, a retired captain of the United States Army who saw service in the Spanish-American War and in the Philippines, died off Tuesday in the United States Naval Hospital, Brooklyn, after a long illness. He was 62 years old and lived at 3,914 Avenue P, Brooklyn.

fine retirement of Fred T. Dickerson of this city as secretary and treasurer of the Central Railroad of New Jersey after continuous service of more than fifty-four years with the company was announced today by E. W. Scheer. president of the company.

The Shepard Steamship Line announced yesterday plans for the transfer of its terminal operations from Pier 64 to Pier 52, North River, effective with the sailing of the freighter Sagebrush on Oct. 15.

Premier Theodor Stauning, at the reopening of Parliament yesterday, expressed the Danish people's relief that the war danger had been averted and stressed the importance of Denmark's remaining strictly impartial in any future conflict.

Representatives of the A. F. of L.'s mechanical unions joined today in efforts to bring about a truce in the dispute between publishers of the four Wilkes-Barre newspapers and the C. I. O.'s Newspaper Guild, a fight which left this city without local papers for the second successive day. The mediators
One hundred old shade trees here were so weakened by the recent hurricane that they may fall and injure pedestrians, Commissioner of Public Works Charles F. Twidy informed the Mayor's office today.

A gift of $100 from Governor Leh- R man to the Red Cross hurricane relief fund was announced yesterday by General Robert C. Davis, executive director of the New York Red Cross Chapter. New gifts yesterday P brought to $112,919 the amount thus far contributed in Manhattan and the Bronx.
The Board of Trustees of this village has found a new way of economizing. Seventeen fire hydrants will be removed if the National Board of Fire Underwriters consents. The water company charges
Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Classic Myths: Introduction to the Gods," Stuart M. Shaw, 11 A. M.; Collection of Greek Art (general tour), 2 P. M.

Price reductions were revealed yesterday by the Hudson Motor Car Company in announcing its three lines for tests could be used with 1939 to distributors gathered here. The Country Club eight series carries reductions up to $112 in the moderate price field. Prices on the

Characterizing recent events in Europe as "monstrous," Foreign Minister Alvarez del Vayo of the Spanish Republic, speaking by radiophone from Barcelona to an audience in Madison Square Garden here, warned last night that the Spanish people faced one of the most perilous moments of the war.
An overwhelming victory for Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain is expected when the House of Commons finally takes a vote tomorrow after four days of debate on the Munich agreement.
Administrator Stewart McDonald of the Federal Housing Administration today appointed Raymond T. Cahill of New York City deputy administrator in charge of mutual mortgage insurance.

Appeals for unity among Lutherans and among the churches of the world to meet problems of this "critical time," and for a greater effort to minister to the "underprivileged" of this country, marked the opening here today of the biennial convention of the United Lutheran Church in America.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is clear from the reports your correspondents have furnished on the reaction to the Munich agreement that the vast majority of people in all the countries interested are immensely relieved by the lifting of the threat of war.

Grounds and buildings of Arnold College for Hygiene and Physical Education have been sold to the Hospital of St. Raphael here for $110,000. The hospital expects to erect within a year a 100-room wing on the site to alleviate overcrowded conditions.

Public offering will be made today of 1,000,000 -shares of $1 par value common stock of the International Television Radio Corporation by Mayhew Reily. The stock will be offered as a speculation, by means of a prospectus, at $1.60 a share. It has been registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Film programs to be -shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as suitable for children 14 years and under by the Schools Motion-Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed

The people of the United States paid more to their Federal Government in taxes during the fiscal year of 1938, which-ended on June 30, than during any previous year in the history of the country, it was reported officially today to Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau by Guy T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary will sail this afternoon for Southampton via Cherbourg. Among her passengers will be Sir Henry Chilton, British Ambassador to Spain, and Lady Chilton; Sir Louis and Lady Beale, Captain G. E. T. Eyston, automobile racer;

Assets of Grand National Films, Inc., which has for several months been operating under Section 77-B of the National Bankruptcy Act, have been sold to a New York corporation of a similar name in which

The death in Sendai, Japan, of the Rev. Dr. David B. Schneder, missionary educator in the Orient for fifty years, was announced today by the board of foreign missions of the Evangelical and Reformed Church. His age was 81.
Miss Helen Post of Port Washington, L. I., and Miss Edith Bray of Philadelphia returned yesterday on the steamship Western World from a hunting trip up the River Amazon in Brazil.

Agreements were signed yesterday by the owners of War Admiral and Seabiscuit for a special race at Pimlico in Baltimore on Tuesday, Nov. 1, each horse to carry 120 pounds a mile and three-sixteenths. This was made known yesterday following an extended luncheon meeting at Belmont Park between Samuel D. Riddle, owner of. War Admiral, and Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, vice president of the Maryland Jockey Club, that operates Pimlico.

Formation of a new investment banking organization patterned closely after the larger British investment trusts was announced yesterday by the Tri-Continental Corporation and Selected Industries, Inc. The new Company, known

Increasing prosperity and the efforts of President Roosevelt to preserve peace in Europe are factors that will greatly aid the Democratic party in the November election, James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today.

With the tension over the Czech crisis relaxed, the British Government-or at least the part of it concerned-turned today to the consideration of the robberies, murders and brigandage in Palestine, where, as Colonial Secretary Malcolm MacDonald told the House of Commons today, the situation has shown "serious deterioration. "

The Institute of Musical Art of the Juilliard School of Music begins its thirty-fourth season today. George A. Wedge, the director, announces the addition to the faculty of Emanuel Zetlin, who will conduct classes in ensemble, and William van Giesen, who will teach voice.
In the United States Court of Claims today the following proceedings were had: TUESDAY, OCT. 4 Cases submitted without argument: 43,553-William C. Porter. 43,659--Maurice Rothberg.

The Pennsylvania Supreme Court at Pittsburgh today refused to waive a ten-day rule and help Carl B. Shelley, District Attorney of Dauphin County, speed up the grand jury investigation of graft and corruption charges against Governor Earle and thirteen associates.

War is changing Japan into a grimly fatalistic nation, scarcely recognizable as that of two years ago. Everywhere there is evidence of stringent economies. Business buildings, homes, shops and streets are not being repaired. A general air of pinching
Eddie Oliver, golf pro from Wilmington, Del., tied the Chevy Chase competitive course record with a 67 today as he paired vith Dr. L. B. T. Johnson to win the club's annual pro-senior tournament.
Miss Annie Burr Jennings of Fairfield opened her home this afternoon for a tea, marking the tenth anniversary of the Robert E. Lee Memorial Foundation.
Three high officials of the Federal Land Bank were arrested at Cuernavaca today charged with stealing 100,000 pesos from the bank which provides government aid to community

A lion, escaping from a cage in a Boardwalk concession, clawed a man to death this evening as it dragged him for more than a block under the piling of the Boardwalk. Police armed with pistols and shotguns searched the maze of piling two hours before they found the mangled body. At about the same ...
Charles R. Hook, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, made this statement yesterday in commenting on a statement made at Hyde Park by a White House spokesman: ...
That ennui may lead to surprising events on a fine Autumn morning was demonstrated yesterday in the case of Mike, gentlemanly gray horse owned by the Sheffield Farms Company.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Jasper of Wykagyl Park, this city, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Juliet Earl Jasper, to Walter T. Absolon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Absolon of Bronxville.

John J. Dorman, former New York City Fire Commissioner, was re-elected chairman of the Kings County Democratic Committee last night at a meeting in the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Mr. Dorman has been chairman of the county committee for more than ten years.

President Roosevelt turned his attention today to the Pennsylvania political situation and prepared to welcome to Hyde Park House tomorrow Democratic leaders of that State headed by Governor Earle and Senator Guffey.

Dr. Francisco Castillo Najera, Mexican Ambassador to the United States, left by airplane for Mexico City this afternoon to report to President Lazaro Cardenas on the conversations he has been conducting over the past ten days with Secretary of State Cordell Hull and Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, looking to an adjustment of the controversy over Mexico's expropriation of American-owned agrarian lands.

Negotiations with Czechoslovakia over Hungary's demand for the cession of former Hungarian border regions have been postponed for at least two days, it was announced here today to allow the new Czech Foreign Minister to study the situation.

So much of Paragraph 16, Special Orders 80, dated April 6, 1938, as orders 2d Lt. John L. Ward, Inf.-Res., to active duty with the CCC, effective April 6, 1938, and relieving him therefrom, effective Oct. 5, 1938, is amended so as to order Lt. Ward to active duty with the CCC. effective

Members of the National Restaurant Association were urged today by George R. LeSauvage of Frenk G. Shattuck Company, New York City, to fight for equitable labor legislation before the laws are passed, instead of the laws are passed, instead of after. Mr. LeSauvage is chairman
Stocks closed strong and active, with gains of 1 to 5 points; industrial and combined averages at highest levels since last October; turnover, 2,235,910 shares.
The season just ended was a poor one for skippers who defended Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound championships in Saturday and holiday regattas.

Hirosi Saito, Ambassador to the United States, is being recalled and placed on the diplomatic reserve list. He will be succeeded in Washington by Kensuke Horinouchi, now Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs.
Rutgers University's football team went through a two-hour session today under the lights of Neilson Field. Intensive work on N. Y. U. plays and formations featured the practice.

THIS is curious but apparently true: the man who founded the first practical international organization in the world, the Red Cross, remains generally unknown, although there is hardly a country on the globe where the symbol of his work is not as familiar as the sunrise.
Mrs. Margaretta Cameron MacVeagh Farrar Smith, granddaughter of Simon Cameron, Secretary of War in Lincoln's first administration, died today at her home.

An addition was made to the Cornell football coaching personnel today with the signing of Ray Van Orman, former all-America Big Red end and head coach at Johns Hopkins, to serve the remainder of the season.

A three-day conference for members of the Actuarial Society of America and the American Institute of Actuaries was opened yesterday morning in the Waldorf-Astoria. About 300 men attended the sessions, including twenty-five actuaries from Great Britain.
Belated recognition for "participation in the three great offensives of the World War" was bestowed yesterday oil Benjamin Pagliaro by Major Albert B. Cudebec, United States Army Engineers, retired.

Orders directing the Interborough Rapid Transit Company to speed up the installation of signal and safety equipment on the local tracks of its elevated and subway lines will be issued by the Transit Commission before the end -of this week, it was disclosed yesterday.

The rival managers weren't fooling. It was big Bill Lee against bigger Charley Ruffing. Sun and shadow were chasing one another across Wrigley yield as the pitchers warmed up. A stiff wind was coming in off Lake Michigan. In batting practice, hitting into the teeth of a brisk breeze, the players of both teams agreed that it might take two men to hit one homer today.
The stock market here continued quiet today pending clarification of the international situation, but the tendency was brighter in most sections, aided by Wall Street's firmness.

A fight over State old-age pensions is overshadowing the Gubernatorial and Congressional campaigns in Colorado. This State has a pension system, written into the Constitution by an amendment adopted by initiative and referendum in 1936, under which a minimum of $45 a month is guaranteed to every resident of the State, 60 years old or over, under terms which make it easy to qualify.

Representative John J. Boylan, who had been sent to Congress from the Fifteenth New York District in Manhattan for the last sixteen years, died early yesterday in the French Hospital here after an illness of several weeks. He was 70 years old.
Records of the Treasury showed today that the government had paid $96,298,011 in benefits under the Railroad Retirement Act up to Aug. 31. Officials said these

The Firestone Tire and Rubbez Company filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement for an issue of $50,000,000 ten-year 3A per cent debentures due on Oct. 1, 1948.. Brown Harriman Co., Inc., and Otis ,Co. are named as the nrincinnpal underwriters.

Important proposals for eliminating the Spanish war as a factor in international politics are understood to have been submitted to the Italian Government today by the British Ambassador, the Earl of Perth, who had another hour's conversation with Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Foreign Minister.
With 400 dogs 'on the benches the Danbury Agricultural Society today opened - its fifty-fifth annual all. breed dog show, in connection with the historic Danbury Fair.

The Supreme Court reserved decision today after hearing argument on an application filed by Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, for a writ of mandamus requiring Daniel Casey, Jersey City's Director of Public Safety, to issue a permit to him for an outdoor meeting.
Three members of the British Curtis Cup team won their second round matches and entered the quarter-finals of the women's Canadian open golf championship today.
A preliminary survey made public today by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics said crop damage in the New England flood and hurricane would run into millions of dollars.

With addresses by Louis H. Pink, New York State Superintendent of Insurance, and V. N. Valgren of the Federal Farm Credit Administration, and election of officers, the forty-third annual convention of the National Association of Mutual Insurance Companies was ended today in the Syracuse Hotel.
Pig iron production in September, according to The Iron Age, gained 16.2 per cent over that of August, the daily rate last month having been the highest since November, 1937. The September total was

M. W. Clement, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, told President Roosevelt's Fact-Finding Board at the railway wage hearings today that survival of the railroads depended on acceptance by labor of the principle that wage reductions were essential in times of depression. He said that wage cuts were in the best interest of the men themselves.

Important proposals for eliminating the Spanish war as a factor in international politics are understood to have been submitted to the Italian Government today by the British Ambassador, the Earl of Perth, who had another hour's conversation with Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Foreign Minister.
With 400 dogs 'on the benches the Danbury Agricultural Society today opened - its fifty-fifth annual all. breed dog show, in connection with the historic Danbury Fair.

The Supreme Court reserved decision today after hearing argument on an application filed by Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, for a writ of mandamus requiring Daniel Casey, Jersey City's Director of Public Safety, to issue a permit to him for an outdoor meeting.
Three members of the British Curtis Cup team won their second round matches and entered the quarter-finals of the women's Canadian open golf championship today.
A preliminary survey made public today by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics said crop damage in the New England flood and hurricane would run into millions of dollars.

With addresses by Louis H. Pink, New York State Superintendent of Insurance, and V. N. Valgren of the Federal Farm Credit Administration, and election of officers, the forty-third annual convention of the National Association of Mutual Insurance Companies was ended today in the Syracuse Hotel.
The number of families receiving relief in this city rose 10 per cent in the year ended Aug. 31, according to statistics published yesterday by the Welfare Council.

William Y. Preyer, formerly vice president, has been elected president of the Vick Chemical Company to succeed Lunsford Richardson, who will become chairman of the board, it was announced yesterday. H. Smith Richardson,

Instead of textbooks, small model trains, home-made maps, motion pictures, songs and poems, museum trips and classroom experiments were employed to trace the history of land transportation in this country by the bright 10-year-old pupils of Public School 500, 126th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Bonds with face value of $10,000, and forty shares of stock, part of what was reputed to be the missing $50,000 estate of the late Harry Thomas, South Hackensack tax collector, turned up by accident in an auction house here today.

The statement of the Bank of Canada for the week ended yesterday, issued today, shows that notes in circulation increased by $5,275,000 in the week and that the ratio of net reserve to notes and deposit liabilities declined to 51.09 per cent from 52.77.
The Bank of France's balance sheet today gave the first authentic evidence of the heavy strain which the recent war preparations placed on the Treasury and the institution itself.

The Treasury today invited bids on $100,000,000 of ninety-day bills to be sold on a discount basis to the highest bidders. Bids will be received by Federal Reserve Banks or their branches up to 2 P. M., Eastern Standard time, on Monday.

World series enthusiasm continued to run high today as the Yankees and Cubs locked horns in their second postseason battle. But the attendance did not quite reach the level of yesterday's opening day gathering, and the receipts declined in proportion.

Major changes in the organization of the Department of Agriculture, designed to expedite the services of the department to the public and to unify lines of work which have assumed paramount importance as a result of New Deal legislation, were announced today by Secretary Wallace.
An unusually low level of air pollution during the last four months was reported yesterday by David R. Morris, meteorologist in charge of the New York Meteorological Observatory in Central Park.

After a heated debate in which conservatives objected that the name smacked of "socialism," the biennial convention of the United Lutheran Church in America, opening here today, approved a constitution for a new Board of Social Missions to unite three existing agencies of the church.

" The Devil Takes a Bride," the latter being a selfish spinster who detests her father, opens tonight at the Cort Theatre under the sponsorship of Montgomery Ford, who gave it a try-out this Summer at Locust Valley, L. I.
A man does not spend the greater part of his maturity in the same work without acquiring a philosophical detachment to knit the raveled sleeve of daily care.

The government of India has leased quarters on the fifth floor of the International Building East, Rockefeller Center, to house the India Trade Commission. The lease, for immediate occupancy, was negotiated by Cushman Wakefield, Inc., brokers.

Although every box seat has been sold for the world series games at the Yankee Stadium, where the classic will be resumed tomorrow, General Manager Edward G. Barrow announced yesterday there were plenty of good reserved seats available.

James Stewart will be teamed with Robert Talyor in "Hands Across the Border," Metro announced today. The story, which is the tale of hockey rivalry between West Point and the Royal Military College of Canada, will go into production following Taylor's "Stand Up and Fight" and Stewart's "Ice Follies."
Mrs. Rosa Offenbach Redlich, a niece of Jacques Offenbach, composer of "The Tales of Hoffmann," died yesterday in her apartment in the Hotel Salisbury after a short illness. She was 81 years old.

The advance on the Cotton Exchange came to a halt yesterday when December contracts touched 8.30 cents a pound, the price at which farmers may obtain loans from the government under this year's cotton-loan program. Prices moved irregularly over a narrow range with the volume of trading restricted in anticipation of the official crop estimate tomorrow and closed 1 to 6 points higher.

Obviously under great emotional stress, Vojta Benes, brother of Dr. Eduard Benes, who resigned Wednesday as President of Czechoslovakia, told about 200 members of the Rotary Club of New York yesterday that "We were not beaten, we were sold."

Monroe St. 291-7, 100x95; Edwe Realty, Inc, to City of N Y, $28,000. Jackson St, 18-20, 39.3x100; Central Savings Bank to City of N Y, $8,000. 18th St, 108-10 W, 50x95; Cecile Tonnelle to Herman G Hinse, 373 Claremont Ave, Montclair, N J (50 cents).

Now that the world has witnessed the complete breakdown of what there was in the previously existing system of collective security, those nations that still hold to democratic ideals face a dilemma. War has for the moment been averted.

Miss Ruth Ellen Stewart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. E. Stewart of Newtown, Mo., was married to William Sorey Hazelton, son of. Mrs. Marion T. Hazelton of Avoca Farm, Navesink, N. J., here today in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Dr. Joseph B. Bernardin.

The Senate Committee on Campaign Expenditures will report to the Senate the action of Secretary Morgenthau in approving the alleged political activity of M. Hampton Magruder, Collector of Internal Revenue at Baltimore, during the recent primary elections.

A cheerful atmosphere pervaded the stock markets today, expansion of business being reported because of Wall Street's firmness and Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's declaration that no early general election was contemplated.

Joe Beggs, the former javelin thrower from Geneva College, turned in another top-flight job of hurling a baseball in Ruppert Stadium tonight, with the result that Newark took the fifth game of the little world series by a 6-1 count and now leads Kansas City in the minor classic, three games to two.

The Transit Commission, by unanimous action of its three members, handed down an order yesterday directing the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, the Manhattan Railway Company and the Federal receivers for both companies to install a Continuous system of automatic block signals and train-stopping devices on the local tracks of the Second, Third and Ninth Avenue lines.

MANHATTAN ARNOLD, FELIX (Oct. 1). Estate, mon than $20,000. To Richard A. Holch, 17' Hjortekaervey, Per Klampenborg, Den mark, $1,000; two specific bequests; Dor E. Arnold, widow, executrix, 317 W. 89th St.. residue.

LeRoy Anspach, pianist, who gave a recital last night at Town Hall, had selected as his chief offerings the Mendelssohn "Variations Serieuses," Beethoven's "Appassionata" sonata and a Chopin group in which figured the "Fantasie" and the scherzo in C sharp minor.
Establishment of a food-testing kitchen for cooperatives was announced yesterday by the Eastern Cooperative Wholesale, supplying retail cooperative stores in this part of the country.

Assembling of the site for the city's first exclusively municipal slum-clearance housing project is now under way, it was revealed yesterday by Alfred Rheinstein, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority.
Mercer St, 128-30 and Broadway, 557-9; 50x 200; for 2-story light manufacturing and stores; Simon Blechman, 502 Broadway, owner; Harry Hurwit, architect; cost, $65,000.

Delegates to the annual convention of the American Federation of Labor today voted to continue a special tax to raise a "war chest" to combat the Committee for Industrial Organization and to carry on organization work in many fields.
At a recent meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute, T. M. Girdler, chairman of the Republic Steel Corporation, expressed concern over the earnings of the industry.

Calling on President Roosevelt here today, Heywood Broun, president of the American Newspaper Guild, pledged that organization's full support to the New Deal recovery program, and proposed to the President the creation of some sort of fact-finding board which would lay a basis for settlement of the C. I. 0.A. F. of L. feud.
The possibility of Czechoslovakia asking a reconstruction loan through the League of Nations was admitted in Czech quarters here, but they stress that no decision has yet been taken in Prague.
K. D. Parmentier, chief pilot of the Royal Dutch Air Lines, left today for Southampton, England, to embark on the liner Bremen tomorrow for three weeks in the United States.

Norma Shearer and several executives of the motion-picture industry were named defendants yesterday in a suit which charged they received "excessive" compensation from Loew's Incorporated to the detriment of stockholders.
A dozen leading industrialists debated here today about how best to comply with the suggestion-attributed to President Roosevelt-that business, labor and the government stop "name-calling."

The Internal Revenue Bureau's formal report shows that the amount collected from internal taxes by the Federal Government during the fiscal year ending with last June not only surpassed the similar collections of any previous fiscal year (running $1,005,570,000 beyond the fiscal year 1937) but exceeded by as much as a quarter of a billion the collections of the fiscal year 1920, which hitherto had held the record.

Owing chiefly to'a lull in retail buying, business in the Pittsburgh district declined slightly last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburgh. There was a further increase in the volume of industrial production and in originating freight shipments.

Residents of the Fieldston section of the Bronx made their final appeal yesterday to the City Planning Commission for establishment of a new' "G" zone there which would restrict the area to one-family residences.
John J. O'Connor, secretary and research clerk to Senator John J. Dunnigan, died today at the home of a sister in Boston, according to information received here. He was 51 years old.
The Owls of Temple and the Horned Frogs of Texas Christian clash in a night game at Philadelphia this evening. ... Which makes Coach Dutch Meyer sound like a naturalist when he declares:

With new contributions received yesterday, the Manhattan-Bronx total for the hurricane relief fund rose to $115,550, General Robert C. Davis, executive director of the New York Chapter, American Red Cross, announced.
Palestine Government military forces, including airplanes, killed sixty Arab rebels today and wounded many more without suffering any casualties themselves.

Frederick E. Williamson, president of the New York Central system, asserted at the railroad wage hearings today that the system he headed was not over-capitalized. Under cross-examination by counsel for the railroad brotherhoods before the President's fact-finding board, he also denied that its securities contained any "watered" stocks.

In a meeting dedicated very largely to racist and Jewish problems the Fascist Grand Council after more than five hours of discussion decided early this morning to throw "some zones of Ethiopia" open to Jewish immigration from all countries of Europe.

Two changes were made yesterday in the City College football team as it practiced indoors for its encounter with St. Joseph's at Philadelphia tomorrow. Richard Turenschine, 190-pounder, gained the right tackle assignment in place of George Alivezon, who is suffering from a knee injury, and Bert Rudoy replaces William Mayhew at fullback.

Count Csaky, Secretary General of the Hungarian Foreign Office, arrived here by air from Budapest this morning and immediately saw Foreign Minister Josef Beck. The Hungarian envoy to Warsaw, Andrew Hory, was also present during the conversation, after which Colonel Beck saw President Ignaz Moscicki.

An appeal that Mayor La Guardia intercede to require cooperation by William B. Herlands, City Commissioiner of Investigation, with Abraham S. Wechsler, State Director of Licenses, in checking up on "inimical" activities of some night patrol agencies was sent the Mayor yesterday in a telegram from Mr. Wechsler.
The probable line-up and batting order for the third game of the world series, which will be played in New York on Saturday, follow:

The State Supreme Court today warned The Philadelphia Inquirer it was in contempt of court for the publi-cation of a story forecasting the court's decision on laws affecting a proposed grand jury investigation of campaign charges against Governor George H. Earle and thirteen others.
A minimum wage of 40 cents an hour, or $16 a week, was fixed today by Secretary Perkins for employed of companies in the wool carpet and rug industry which supply the government.

Charles C. Michener, who was for twelve years secretary of the International Committee of the Young Men's Christian Association, died yesterday in Los Angeles of a heart ailment, according to word received here last night.
Adoption by each State of substantially the same regulations for liquor advertising as are now ,enforced by the Federal Alcohol Administration will be proposed at a conference beginning Oct. 25
Arrangements were made yesterday for the sale of a New York Stock Exchange seat at $70,000, or $2,000 more than the preceding transaction.

Erno Balogh, pianist, will appear in recital at the Town Hall tonight. Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, will speak at the season's first meeting of the Metropolitan Opera Guild at the Hotel Pierre next Tuesday afternoon.

Slaughter of all classes fully normal in local markets yesterday. Lamb carcasses were lower, hindsaddles and cuts mostly steady; other classes steady. Demand was generally fair. No kosher market Wednesday. Early trading indicated all classes steady. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:
As a result of heavy banking transactions usually incident to the first-of-the-month period, bank clearings showed a substantial improvement in the week ended on Wednesday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On Sept. 21 the Securities and Exchange Commission submitted to Congress the third part of the results of its studies of investment trusts, and although the report itself was careful to indicate the essential differences in the nature of investment companies, your recent editorial on this report failed to call attention to these differences.
Walt Willis, who just returned from a Montauk check-up, reports that they are taking stripers from the surf with exciting regularity and occasionally manage to bring in a good-sized blue.

YANKEES--A great cheer went up as Dean strode to the mound and his mates raced to their positions, and when Dizzy started warming up, the cheer was renewed. Another cheer came when the Great One blazed the first pitch over for a called strike. But there was a moment of suspense when Crosetti chased Reynolds back to the leftfield wall for his fly on the second pitch.
Traffic through the Panama Canal declined last month, according to a report issued by the War Department today.

The more fish New Yorkers eat the cheaper fish will be, according to William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, who joined yesterday the chorus of home economists and fish men in urging city consumers. to eat more fish. Because of National Fish Week, ending tomorrow, housewives this week have been the object of a barrage of fish propaganda. This final sales talk,
Senator George W. Norris told a small audience in his home town last night that he was serving his last term.

Having obtained from Parliament full powers for forty days with which to put back some order into the disorganization of French finances caused by the alarm and necessary expenditure of the past few weeks, Premier Edouard Daladier and his colleagues are taking a few days in which to consider what should be done.
One excellent way of combining health, pleasure and civic duty in the next few weeks is for the citizen to alter the route of his
The General Baking Company in its statement for the thirteen weeks ended on Sept. 24 reported yesterday a net profit of $731,142 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other deductions.

George S. Messersmith, Assistant Secretary of State, hailed last night the opening of the American Republics Line's new service to the east coast of South America as indicative of a new appreciation of the interdependence of the American republics.

For use as a floral nursery, the 112-acre farm, formerly owned y Walter W. Hockenbury in Wantage, Sussex County, N. J., has been purchased by Robert Wayman of Bayside, L. I. Charles M. F. Meisel was the attorney for the purchaser.

Trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was the heaviest since July 20, last. Transactions amounted to $11,530,200, compared with $10,894,975 on Wednesday. After recording substantial gains in early trading, the market encountered considerable profit-taking in later dealings but, on the whole, was able to absorb the selling, and the close was irregularly higher on the day.
Dr. Henry M. Wriston, president of Brown University, said tonight he had offered a visiting professorship to Dr. Eduard Benes, who resigned Wednesday as President of Czechoslovakia.

Although the rain kept Fordham's football team in the gymnasium yesterday, Coach Jimmy Crowley made use of the afternoon to begin preparations for the Ram's first major encounter with Purdue at the Polo Grounds a week from tomorrow.
Provision for the operation of fifty-four CCC camps in the State of New York is included in the corps program for the twelfth enrollment period, Oct. 1, 1938, to March 31, 1939, announced here today.

Mr. and Mrs. Gustav Johnson of this city have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Sigrid Isabel Johnson, to Charles F. Bonilla of Baltimore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rodrigo Bonilla of New York. The wedding will take place here on Oct. 29.

Britain's Ambassador, the Earl of Perth, had his fifth meeting since Saturday with Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano today and submitted what British circles termed "concrete proposals" for the withdrawal of foreign combatants from Spain and for the early coming into force of the Anglo-Italian agreements.

Conditions governing the King' Cup, foremost prize for yachts o this country, were changed yesterday at the Fall meeting of the New York Yacht Club. The limitation of single-masted vessels was re duced from fifty to forty-five feel waterline, and that of vessels with more than one mast from sixty to fifty feet.

Miss Susan Dannat Griffith, Skidmore College trustee and benefactor, who died on Sept. 26 at Saratoga Springs, N. Y., named the Presbyterian Hospital, 620 West 168th Street, prirncipal legatee in her will, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

AKRON-M. O'Neil Co.; E. C. Olsen, basement, boys' clothing: 1,440 Bway. ATLANTA-Rich's, Inc.; A. S. Leak, men's clothing; men's, boys' furnishings; F. Brandes, coats, furs, raincoats; W. Fritz, mdse. mgr.; ready to wear; 128 W. 31st (Kirby, Block Co.).

The illness of Captain Bill Platt and the discovery that Bill Stack, First-string center, cannot play against Pennsylvania today cast a damper on the final practice here of the Yale eleven. The team will depart for Philadelphia tomorrow morning,

The American Revolution cannot be compared with "other revolutions about which we hear much today," said Mrs. Henry M. Robert Jr., president-general of the national society, Daughters of the American Revolution, in an address tonight before more than 400 delegates and visitors to the annual State conference.

Tentative valuation of property of the Magnolia Pipe Line Company owned and used for common carrier purposes as of Dec. 31, 1934, was set today by the Interstate Commerce Commission at $41,200,000. Additional property owned by Magnolia but not used by it was valued at $1,307,000.

Although the bleacher fans who keep the nightlong vigil at the world series were not so numerous around Wrigley Field last night and early this morning as they had been on the watch for the opening game of yesterday, commercialism again reared its head.

Turpentine firm, 203/4c bid; no sales; receipts, 142 barrels; shipments, 2,801 barrels; stock, 50,377 barrels. Rosin firm; sales. 202; receipts, 1,896; shipments, 1,o15; stock, 261,859. Quote: B, $3.70; D, $4.00; E, $4.25: F, $5.25; G, H, I, K, M, $5.30; N, $5.70; WG, $5.80; WW, X, $6.25.
The study in contrasts between victor and vanquished was more pronounced today than yesterday in the clubhouses of the world series combatants.
Manhattan's football team, after a ninety-minute dummy scrimmage in yesterday's rain, was pronounced ready for action tomorrow against unbeaten Holy Cross by Coach Herb Kopf. The Jasper squad,

Sales of electrical wholesalers for the second quarter of this year incresed 14.7 per cent over the first quater, but dropped 37.9 per cent from the second quarter of 1937, according to figures isued by the Department of Commerce as part of its current Census Survey of Business.
Will Geer, a leading player in "Sing Out the News," and Herta Ware, actress. who has appeared with the Actors Repertory Company,

Rates to be charged during the World's Fair next year have been adopted by about fifty hotels located principally in the Times Square district, as members of the Independent Hotel Association of New York, it was announced yesterday. The scale fixed is said to be less than 20 per cent above the present tariff.

Roman Totenberg has been named concertmaster of the Orchestra of the New Friends of Music, it was announced yesterday. Erich Simon has been engaged for the post of assistant conductor. The conductor is Fritz Stiedry.

The reopening of Thrift House for the season was marked yesterday by a tea at Harmonie Club, 4 East Sixtieth Street, attended by 150 volunteer workers. Mrs. Herbert Pollack, president of the rummage shop, at 7 East Fifty-seventh Street, announced that in the last six years the management had turned over $150,000 to the New York and Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities.
Mrs. Paul M. Warburg has sold her eighty-acre estate on Inwood Avenue, Hartsdale, to the Hartsdale Park Corporation of 341 Madison Avenue.

Louis E. Felix, 55 years old, of 24 West Sixty-ninth Street, a lawyer with offices at 545 Fifth Avenue, collapsed in his office at about 10 o'clock last night while talking to Isador Rabinow of 74 West Thirtyeighth Street, a friend.

New Fall fashions in clothing will be shown soon by the 2,800 men and women domiciled in the city's two homes for the aged, for the Hospitals Department decreed yesterday an end to the century-old clothing styles and ordered new and up-to-date clothing instead.

Money in circulation on Sept. 30 was $6,621,973,228, or $50.82 per capita, which was $79,569,341 more than at the same time last year, the Treasury announced today. At the end of August money in circulation amounted to $6,504,145,135. The following table shows the classifications of currency and comparisons with earlier periods:...

At the eleventh hour Slovakia seems to have been saved from partition. It was officially announced tonight that the Slovaks' autonomy demands had been granted in entirety. The executive committee of the Slovak Catholic Peoples' Party issued a communique on the negotiations it had been conducting in Zilina with representatives of other parties in Slovakia.

The Panama Pacific liner City of Baltimore will sail tonight for California by way of the Panama Canal. Her passengers include Mr. and Mrs. Harold Hackett, Oscar Goertner, M. C. Boyd, Miss Henrietta A. Huns, Mrs. L. L. Mabry, Mrs. Margaret Berry, Frederick Lorraine, H. A. Ingles, W. H. Beals, Mrs. J. W. De Maine and Charles Pausner.
A three-hour drill, with emphasis on defensive formations, yesterday closed New York University's preparations for the meeting with Rutgers tomorrow.

Apparently the victim of a gangland "ride," a man later identified as a drug peddler long known to the Brooklyn police was found slain shortly before last midnight on Water Street, near Jefferson Street. The body bore bullet wounds in the neck and chest.
