Former Representative Stanley Hubert Dent, chairman of the House Military Affairs Committee throughout the World War, died at his home here today at the age of 69. Physicians attributed death to a heart ailment. He was ill only an hour.

Repeating its action of the last two years, the Eastern Conference of the Methodist Protestant Church voted today at its twenty-eighth session here not to send delegates to the conference on unification of all Methodist denominations at Kansas City in April.

Percival E. Jackson, appearing as counsel for a group of minority bondholders of the Manati Sugar Company, appealed yesterday to the United States Circuit Court to set aside fees of $71,500 granted by Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe to members of a bondholders' committee and their counsel in proceedings to reorganize the company.

The committee on floor procedure of the New York Stock Exchange has ruled that beginning today New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad refunding 41/2 per cent bonds shall be traded ex-interest of 21/4 per cent and that they continue to be dealt in "flat." To be a delivery they must carry March 1, 1939, and subseauent coupons.
KINGS WHELLER, ADELAIDE A. (April 14, 1932). Non-resident. Gross assets, $700; net, $700. To daughter, Margaret I. Lloyd. Chief assets, real estate, $700. William A. Ryan. attorney, 66 Court St.

District Attorney Edward J. Neary of Nassau County announced today that the psychiatric examination of Mrs. Helen Novinski, wife of an Old Westbury chauffeur, who killed her two young children on Sept. 8, inindicated that she was insane at the time of the tragedy and was still insane.

Despite obstacles raised by the recent war scare, the Congress of the Association for Scientific Research Through Photography and Motion Pictures was able to open on schedule at Discovery Palace here today with the cooperation of many of the nations that might have been involved in a war.
President and Mrs. Harold W. Dodds will :e hosts to 670 Princeton University freshmen and their friends at the annual freshman reception tomorrow afternoon at Prospect, the President's residence.

Immediate action for permanent rehabilitation of farm lands in the Northern Great Plains area was recommended to President Roosevelt today by the Northern Great Plains Committee, which reported that seven years of drought had disrupted the economy of the region.

Freshmen of the New York University College of Arts and Pure Science and College of Engineering must wear the traditional orange ties and caps for the duration of the academic year because they were defeated by the sophomores yesterday in the annual "Bloodless Thursday" competition at University Heights, the Bronx.

Julian May Wright, judge advocate of the International Court at Cairo, Egypt, died in Cairo yesterday, according to a cablegram received here today. His mother, Mrs. C. K. Wright of Washington, D. C., and Bar Harbor, was with him at his death.
Five golfers were tied at 76 for the medal in the qualifying round of the twentieth annual Arcola invitation tournament at the Arcola Country Club today.

Thousands of spectators in various cities have been witnessing demonstrations for Air Travel Week. In Europe crowds in the streets cannot glimpse a group of planes in the sky without instinctively shrinking toward the park trenches dug for shelter against bombs. Aviation is primarily an arm of war.

The general level of wholesale prices dedined during the week ended on Oct. 1, according to figures issued today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average as 100, stood at 78.0 compared with 78.4 on Sept. 24 and 86.9 on Oct. 2, 1937.

Leaving its line of Spring suitings about unchanged from the Fall line, American Woolen Company announced yesterday the establishment of a new department to produce and market paintings in cottonand-worsted mixtures.

The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today an order terminating the registration and listing of the no par value Class A and Class B common stock of Rainbow Luminous Products, Inc., on the New York Curb Exchange, effective on Nov. 5.

The pickaback seaplane Mercury took off from the mother ship Maia yesterday in an attempt to establish a long-distance flight record. Captain D. C. T. Bennett, who piloted the Mercury on the flight to New York, was again at the controls when Cptain A. S. Wilcockson, in the parent aircraft Maia, launched him at 1:19 P. M. with sufficient fuel for the forty-hour flight to Cape Town, 6,370 miles away.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. McCarty of 262 Central Park West and Hewlett, L. I., gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eileen Marie McCarty, to Francis Richard Curry, son of John F. Curry, former leader of Tammany Hall, and Mrs. Curry of 101 Central Park West.
Charles Hale, retired Professor of English at Rutgers University, where he had served for twenty-five years, died today of a heart attack while working in his garden.

Among the many curious superstitions of politics is the holding of a grand, final party rally on the Saturday night before election. By that time everybody must know how he is going to vote. Almost everybody has had enough speeches.

A committee representing Luzerne County locals of the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization, aided by international representatives of three printing trades unions, was empowered today to seek a settlement of the dispute between the C. I. O.'s American Newspaper Guild and the publishers of WilkesBarre's four newspapers.

166th St, 463 W, 25x100; 463 W 166th St Corp to the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States; p m mtg to extent of $13,000 and bldg loan to extent of $22,000, due Oct. 1, 1948, Int per bond; $35,000.

Colgate's Red Raiders went through their last workout on their home field today for the Duke battle. Refraining from any contact work as he tapered his squad off, Coach Andy Kerr ordered a long kicking drill and then spent the rest of the time running his first-string eleven on defensive and offensive formations.
Authorization of the first lease of hangar space in the North Beach Airport, Queens, was voted by the Board of Estimate yesterday with American Airlines, Inc., as the lessee.
Prime Minister Chamberlain was upheld in his peace policy by the House of Commons yesterday, 366 to 144. Parliament adjourned until Nov. 1, while Mr. Chamberlain started on a fishing trip.
The German Army today began the occupation of Zone No. 4 in the Sudetenland, adjoining the German province of Silesia. The advance began at 8 A. M. in bad weather and will continue tomorrow.

Prime Minister Eamon de Valera of Ireland the former Irish Free State] has indicated to Great Britain that he considers the time now is opportune for a plebiscite in certain areas of the six counties of Northern Ireland, it was learned here tonight.

The Court of Appeals listened today to arguments on both sides of the question of who is vice chairman of the New York City Council. The court is to determine whether John Cashmore was elected vice chairman or whether the office went to James A. Burke, member of the Council from Queens.

Currents o public opinion which during the last two years have swept numeri cal and strategic strength to the National Woman's Party may be also, its members feel, that "flood tide of fortune" on which the equa rights amendment may be forced through Congress.
Dr. Margaret Ethel Lacey, the only woman ever to hold a regular appointment on the Board of Examiners, will retire on Nov. 1 after thirty-seven years of service in the New York City school system.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings, the reserve note circulation and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

Elmer F. Andrews, National Wage and Hour Law Administrator, declared at the opening session of the National Association of Cotton Manufacturers' annual meeting here today that the industry need have no fear of widespread wage differentials favoring the South and at the same time praised the industry as the leader both in setting up an NRA code and later a Wage-Hour Board of its own.

Irving H. Taylor of Detroit, widely known in automotive and aeronautic circles in this country and abroad, today was named chief of the automotiveaeronautics trade division of the Commerce Department.
Sir Henry Gray, physician and surgeon, died in a hospital today of a heart disease. His age was 69.
Lumber production declined more than seasonally last week and the adjusted index receded to 72.4 from 77.7. The figure was 77.8 for the week ended Oct. 2, 1937.

Fourteen were killed today when a large tank of sulphur dioxide on a freight car exploded when a freight train collided with a passenger train at a junction near here. The gas spread over a large area, seriously hindering rescue work.

The New Jersey Magistrates Association voted today to protest the practice on the part of some State troopers and agents of the Motor Vehicle Bureau of taking persons arrested for motor-traffic violations before "favored magistrates," friends or those who have done favors for the officers.

Trial Decisions The following members having been the before Francis X. Giaccone, Deputy I Commissioner, on date specified, for vle tion of Rules and Regulations, 1937, following decisions are rendered by the Chief and Commissioner:

Nornay Saddler, smooth foxterrier from the Wissaboo Kennels of James M. Austin of Westbury, L. I., today won best in show honors at the conclusion of the fifty-fifth annual dog show of the Danbury Agricultural Society, held in connection with the Danbury Fair.
Donald Budge, world tennis singles champion, returned to his home courts today and easily won his first match, a second-round affair, from William Pedlar of Vancouver, B. C., 6-2, 6-1.
Dizzy Dean vs. Goofy Gomez. When the rival world series managers set that one up, they could have called on the Four Marx Brothers to umpire the game.
Edsel Ford, president of the Ford Motor Company, announced today a new automobile in the lower medium-price range, to be known as the Mercury 8.

Captain John Mulhaley, skipper of the schooner Saugatuck, which was lost on Long Island Sound for two days in sub-freezing temperature with fourteen persons aboard in February, 1933, died early today in Norwalk Hospital. He was 47 and had been ill five months.

A man identified by his Social Security card as John Larsen, 40-yearold barge captain, of 141 Sixtyeighth Street, Brooklyn, was killed by an eastbound train at the Wellwood Avenue crossing of the Long Island Railroad here tonight.

The volume of engineering construction awards in the current week is 39 per cent greater than in the corresponding period of 1937, making the thirteenth week in succession that an improvement has been shown over last year's figures, it was announced yesterday by The Engineering News-Record.

Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont, the medalist and a former holder of the title, was the victim of an upset in the semi-final round of the women's New Jersey State golf championship on the Plainfield Country Club course today.
Dr. C. Nelson Raymond, dean of the medical profession here, died of heart disease early today at his home. His age was 74.

Commenting on the ineffectiveness -of the League of Nations, particularly in the face of recent developments in Europe, the newspaper Imparcial says that the South American countries must be placed on guard against any revival of the idea of creating a Pan-American group of nations, as suggested on many occasions in these republics.

A mighty tussle between Jimmy Hines of Lakeville, holder of the district open title, and 54-year-old Charley Mayo Sr. of the Lido Club featured the third round of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship at the Oceanside links today.

Mr. and Mrs. Albert Guggenheim, of 20 East Seventy-sixth Street, New York City, died this morning at the City Hospital from injuries sustained yesterday in the wrecking of their automobile on the coastal highway, 27 miles south of Brunswick.
Mrs. A. S. Hardart, wife of an executive of Horn and Hardart, Inc., and her 17-year-old son, Robert, of 150 Monterey Avenue, Pelham, have registered at Fordham University.

To aid the work of the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association, twenty-seven debutantes acted as executives, sales girls and models at Saks-Thirty-fourth Street yesterday on the occasion of the store's thirty-sixth anniversary celebration.

An application of the New York Stock Exchange to strike from listing and registration the $100 par value capital stock of the New Orleans, Texas Mexico Railway Company has been granted by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the commission stating that delisting was sought, among other things, because the shares were included in the proposed reorganization plans for the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company.

At the second and final session yesterday of the auction sale of varied properties throughout Greater New York conducted at the Hotel Al Pennsylvania by Joseph P. Day, new high bids aggregating $97,600 for the nineteen parcels were received.

A $200,000 mortgage at 5 per cent for ten years on the 6-story apartment house at 30 Clinton Pl, New Rochelle, Westchester County, has been arranged for Charles Mayone, owner, by Henry Waltemade, Inc, broker.

A warm endorsement was given yesterday by the American Federaation of Labor to Attorney General John J: Bennett Jr., candidate for re-election on the Democratic ticket. Mr. Bennett and Controller Morris S. Tremaine are the only two Democratic State-wide candidates who did not receive the endorsement of the American Labor party.

Several old-age pensioners of Colorado have sued the State recently to compel it to pay them the full $45 monthly pension promised to persons over 60 by the constitutional amendment adopted at the 1936 election.

Alfred J. Lundberg, head of the East Bay Transit Company of Oaaland, Calif., was elected today president of the American Transit Association. He succeeds Charles W. Chase, president of the Indianapolis Railways.

Lester G. Ott, vice president and general operating manager, and Robert H. Hadley, vice president in charge of sales and merchandising, of the United Cigar-Whelan Stores Corporation, were elected yesterday directors of the company, it was announced by Walter G. Baumhogger, chairman of the executive committee.

John W. Davis, former Ambassador to Great Britain, speaking in his capacity as honorary vice president of the Legal Aid Society, appealed last night for public support for the society in a talk over radio Station WEAF.

Secretary Ickes announced today PWA loans of $630,500 and grants totaling $3,412,659 for forty-four additional ron-Federal projects, including a garage and incinerator for Peekskill, N. Y. This project,

Employes must be convinced 'that greater efficiency means better service and that the more costs can be cut, the more business will be attracted, which in turn will require more instead of fewer employes, John T. Sinkey, assistant treasurer of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, told the concluding session of a two-day office management- conference of the American Management Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

Two distinct heavy waves of profittaking on the Stock Exchange yesterday turned what promised to be a repetition of Wednesday's stock market into an irregular session, and closing prices were deprived in most instances of the wide gains registered early in the day.

George Z. Medalie, who has been political mentor to Thomas E. Dewey for the last few years, is acting as campaign manager for Mr. Dewey's Gubernatorial candidacy, it was indicated yesterday, until a campaign manager is selected.
Three members of the British Curtis Cup team and Mrs. F. J. Mulqueen of Toronto entered the semi-final round of the Canadian women's open golf championship today.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, In pounds sterling:
Mrs. Harold Minott of Lawrence Farms scored a 92 today to take the low gross honors in the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association one-day handicap tourney at the Knollwood Country Club.

One of our city's most useful civic agencies is the Citizens Union, formed "without regard to party, for the purpose of securing the honest and efficient government of the City of New York." The union is not, of course, infallible, but it has a good record, of being on the constructive side with regard to issues and candidates.

The Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation has been authorized by the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Holding Company Act to pay $1,627,175 in dividends on Nov. 15 as the regular quarterly payment on its cumulative 6 per cent preferred stock, Series A;

After five successive weekly declines, the commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City rose $1,000,000 in the week ended on last Wednesday, according to the condition statement of the banks issued yesterday.
The battle cruiser Hood, which was reported injured while escorting the liner Aquitania, has been at Gibraltar since Oct. 1. She did not convoy the Aquitania, nor has she been damaged in any way.
Count and Countess Giuseppe Cippico, who passed the Summer at their villa in Italy, will arrive today on the Roma and will be at the Waldorf-Astoria for the season.

In the third quarter of this year the General Electric Company received orders of $60,533,135, compared with $88,010,937 in the corresponding period last year, a decrease of 31 per cent, according to an announcement made yesterday by Gerard Swope, president.
Frederick C. Schraub, a former State Dairy Commissioner, died today of a heart attack at Brigham Hall Sanitarium, Canandaigua, where he had been a patient since 1928. He was 82 years old.
New York's Free Forum, 119 West Fifty-seventh Street, 7:45 P. M. "Czechoslovakia and the Present World Crisis," Dr. Sherwood Eddy.

Another chapter was added to the brilliant golfing career of Mrs. Dorothy Campbell Howe of Merion today as she won the women's United States senior title with a record score of 159 over the south course of the Westchester Country Club.
Determined to capture their third successive world title in the shortest possible time, the Yankees today scored their second straight triumph over the Cubs, 6 to 3. Joe McCarthy's horde,

Following is the text of the speech of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain in the House of Commons today closing the debate on foreign policy: The leader of the Opposition remarked a few minutes ago that in his view the four days which have been occupied with this discussion have been fully justified.

Francis X. Shields, former Davis Cup team member, and Miss Mary Cootes of Washington defeated Miss Ruth Sowers and Louis J. Carruthers of Brooklyn, 6-3, 6-3, today in a mixed doubles match in the Hot Springs invitation tennis tournament.

With large stocks of tobacco on hand and with acreage cut from 42,000 to 30,000 acres for Federal benefit payments, planters have agreed on more drastic reductions in the hope of raising the prices of the next crops.

The Holland-America liner Noordam will end her maiden crossing of the Atlantic in New York Harbor early this morning and dock at the company's terminal in Hoboken after an eight-and-a-half-day voyage from Rotterdam.

John H. Attas of J. S. Bache Co. splashed his way over the North Hills Country Club course in Douglaston, L. I., yesterday to capture the President's Cup for the second successive time in the Wall Street Golf Association tournament.

When the smoke of uncertainty clears away, "business management will come into its own and it will have a public utility concept as its guide," Saul Cohn, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said yesterday. Re spoke at the annual Fall luncheon of the National Notion Association at the Hotel McAlpin.

Several dozen Cleveland members of the Czechoslovak Legionnaire Association turned into national headquarters here today medals awarded them by France and Great Britain for distinguished World War service.
President Lazaro Cardenas conferred at length at Chapultepec Palace today with Ambassador Francisco Castillo Najera, immediately after the latter's arrival by airplane from Washington.

Stocks eased on profit-taking and closed irregular after advancing to highest levels in year; turnover, 2,451,060 shares. All groups of bonds closed irregularly higher in largest turnover since July 20; transactions, $11.530.200.
A BLUNT INSTRUMENT, by Georgette Heyer. (Crime Club, $2.) A mystery novel. THE CHRISTMAS TREE MURDERS, by Joel Y. Dane. (Crime Club, $2.) A mystery novel.

The three-story building at 16-18 South Fourth Avenue, Mount Vernon, Westchester County, now oocupied by the Schindel Department Store, was sold by V. N. Bailey, Isaac M. Carpenter Jr. and Charles J. F. Decker, trustees, to a client of John J. Reynolds, broker.
Dr. Charles Noble, Professor of English at Grinnell College from 1893 to 1919, died yesterday at the age of 90. He had been ill a year.

To take effect 8 A. M., Oct. 7: PATROLMEN--Francis H. Hunt, from 4th Precinct to 18th Division, designated third grade detective. John T. Flood, from 46th Precinet 18th Division, assigned as chauffeur.

After the capture of Hankow the Japanese Army plans to push southward along the Canton-Hankow Railway at least as far as Changsha and Hengyang, in Hunan Province, thereby imperiling Kwangtung's northern border.
Joseph A. Larkin, city editor of The New York City News Association for the last eleven years, died at his home, 107-16 Ninety-third Street, Woodhaven, Queens, yesterday after a long illness.

The complaint of coal-mining interests in West Virginia and Eastern Kentucky, known as the Property Owners Committee, that rates charged by the Pocahontas Lines for shipment and handling of bituminous coal for transshipment at Hampton Roads were unreasonable,

Gardner B. Perry, Paul S. Blair, C. Shelby Carter, Fred I. Collins, N. S. Hall and W. H. R. Unger were authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to serve as a protective committee for holders of the Erie Railroad's refunding and improvement mortgage 5 per cent bonds under certain conditions.

The Pepsi-Cola Company is to be managed by a group representing both sides of the present dispute for control between Loft, Inc., and Charles G. Guth, under an order approved by the Chancellor's Court in Wilmington yesterday, it was stated last night by A. B. Hoppe, executive vice president of Loft, Inc.

Leonard D. Mahon, through L. W. Robertson, at 148 Locust Ave, Scarsdale, Westchester County, for HOLC; Raymond R. Beatty Organization, brokers. W. R. Spindler, residence on Sage Terrace in Greenacres section, Scarsdale, for estate of Jessie M. Haldane; Prince Ripley, Inc, brokers.
Mrs. Theodor Thomasson of Lund, Sweden, has announced to friends here the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elisabeth Thomasson, to Harold Benson Thorne Jr. of New York and Montclair, N. J.
Cooperation with the monopoly investigation now being prepared by a Congressional committee, was voted yesterday without dissent by a full meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

Odds on the world series outcome tonight went to 1 to 10, favoring the Yankees to win the post-season struggle against the Cubs. There was little inclination shown by admirers of Gabby Hartnett and his National League champions to support the team's chances.

Relatives in Halifax today received word of the death in Nice, France, of Dr. J. Aubrey Lippincott, Dalhousie University's second oldest graduate and at one time physician attached to General George Custer's famed 7th United States Cavalry. Dr. Lippincott, who was 91 years old and had been living in retirement since 1935, died Sept. 23.
Walther Funk, the German Minister of Economics, who arrived here today as the guest of the Turkish Government, is receiving special State honors.
The Russian Embassy formally denied tonight, on authority of Moscow, reports that the Soviet Government had been consulted by Britain and France on the decisions of the Munich conference.
Joseph D. Baker, a leading citizen here by virtue of his many philanthropies and civic leadership, died today. He was 84 years old.
The Fall tree-planting program of the Department of Parks, acting in cooperation with the owners of property in blocks needing beautification and restful shade, is now in full swing.
A fully staffed and equipped Ministry of Information, which has existed in "shadow" form for some time, was ready if war had broken out last week, it has been learned.

Why the President-for patently it was he-rever?ed to the ancient and obvious disguise of "White House spokesman" in reading his latest lecture to American industry is explained by the Hyde Park reporters thus:

Production of steel in the United States in September totaled 2,657,748 gross tons, -the highest figure since October, 1937, and a rise of 4.5 per cent over the 2,546,988 tons produced in August. The output was 38 per cent under the 4,289,507 tons produced in September, 1937, the American Iron and Steel Institute reports.
With the east and west sides of the midtown section sharing equally in the bulk of activity, a number of prominent persons were reported yesterday as having signed contracts for residential space.

The lowest estimate for constructing extensions and remodeling the post office and court house building at San Juan, Puerto Rico, has been submitted to the United' States Treasury Department by the Viking Construction Corporation of New York, which bid $495,955, according to Brown's Letters, Ine.
The island of Minorca was bombed again yesterday by Insurgent planes, according to word received here tonight.
Syracuse finished its heavy preparations today for the Maryland football game here Saturday. Only a light signal drill is scheduled for tomorrow.
The Navy squad worked in the rain this afternoon, cheered by the news that Lem Cooke, its ace passing and ball-carrying back, was in shape to play against Virginia Saturday if needed.

A sealed indictment charging four former Federal Alcohol Tax Unit agents and two former deputy internal revenue collectors with acting in collusion with a number of bootleggers to extort large sums of money from druggists and other business men and to defraud the government of taxes on bootleg liquor was ordered opened yesterday by Judge Marcus B. Campbell in Federal court. Brooklyn.
Immediate reductions ranging from 5 to 12 per cent in the list prices of its Farmall, all-purpose tractor line for 1939, were announced today by the International Harvester Company.

More than 200 Barnard College students and members of the faculty, including Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve and Miss Agnes Wayman, head of the physical education department, danced the "Shoo Fly" and square dances led by Don Chambers, authority on American country dancing, at the party in honor of the freshman class given by the Folk Dance Club in Barnard Hall on the campus last night.

The National Labor Relations Board today certified the American Federation of Newspaper Writers, Reporters and Editorial Workers, an American Federation of Labor affiliate, as the sole collective bargaining agent for employes of the editorial departments of The Boston Daily Record, The Boston Evening American and The Boston Sunday Advertiser.
Many reservations have been made for the annual Cosmo Villa barn dinner dance tonight at Schmidt Farm, Scarsdale, N. Y., in behalf of Irvington House.

Arnold Gingrich, editor of the magazines Ken, Esquire and Coronet, told the Special House Committee Investigating Un-American Activities today that the Gestapo (German secret police) had set up within the last year a special section for espionage and Nazi propaganda in the United States.

Walter A. Smith, 78 years old, was the guest of honor at a luncheon yesterday on his retirement as paying teller at the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, 165 Broadway, after more than fifty-eight years of service.

Choice and prime fed steers and yearlings were very scarce today and sold well at fully steady prices, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. Unevenness featured the trade on all steers and yearlings; hogs held steady in a slow trade and lambs were strong to 15 cents higher.

Joseph Dobish, owner of the lion that escaped from its cage last evening and killed a man before it was shot by a policeman, was released in $3,000 bail this afternoon to await action of the grand jury on a charge of manslaughter.

Governor Lehman announced last night that he had taken under advisement the question of superseding District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn and appointing a special grand jury in the inquiry into official corruption in that borough.

The foreign exchange market softened again yesterday after its gains of the preceding days. News dispatches from Europe indicating that all misgivings over the peace settlement had not been overcome; that Germany seemed disposed to demand more of the Sudeten area than provided for in the Munich agreement, as originally understood, and that the French still faced a critical financial strain, all served to dampen any enthusiasm for a further rise in the exchanges.

The Democratic County Committee of Queens took exception to the State convention's stand on reapportionment in endorsing the Democratic State platform last night and endorsed the reapportionment amendment to be submitted to the voters at the election.

The first open competition for decoration of one of the Rockefeller Center Buildings-a competition calling for the designing of a bronze panel depicting the theme of "News" for the main entrance of The Associated Press Buildingcloses today. Three prizes of $1,000, $500 and $250, respectively, are to be awarded by the jury which will pass on the Works submitted. Decision will be announced early next week.

Deposits of gold certificates with the Federal Reserve Banks by the Treasury, which were resumed two weeks ago after a lapse of about six months, continued in the week ended on Wednesday covered by yesterday's Reserve reports.
Some idea was given today as' to how London's civilian defense against air raids would have functioned if last week's crisis had boiled over.

Mrs. Roland Douglas gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. C. Berwind Hayes, who arrived from Rio de Janeiro. Among the other guests were Mrs. Bruce F. E. Harvey, Mrs. Spencer Eddy Jr., Mrs. Charles W. Nichols Jr., Mrs. James Randall Creel, Mrs. Carl B. Schuster, Mrs. Rushmore Patterson and Mrs. Wolcott E. Andrews.
Continuing contact work unusually late this week in preparation for the Dartmouth game, Princeton ran through a hard, spirited session on the mud of University Field today.

Miss Betty Ward and Whitney Trowbridge Kelsey, whose engagement was announced in August, will be married on Nov. 5 at the home -of the prospective bride's step-father and mother, Mr. and Mrs. W. Lysle Alderson, 31 East Seventy-ninth Street.

Despite the fact that Governor Aiken of Vermont and Governor Murphy of New Hampshire have indicated that they will take issue with the Federal Government over the power rights involved in flood control work, army engineers at Holyoke indicated today that they would begin flood control work within a week.

Laird, Bissell Meeds and Munds, Winslow Potter, will be merged on Nov. 1, it was announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. The new firm will be known as Laird, Bissell Meeds. It will nave offices in New York, Wilmington, Del., and Philadelphia.
An application by the Illinois Greyhound Lines, Inc., to purchase certain operating rights and property of the
Turkey, the youngest of republics, will construct a pavilion at the World's Fair to show its products and choicest treasures and to demonstrate that the principles of democracy are still flourishing.

Because one of their number had been "arbitrarily dismissed," 2,100 workers of the Salmson aviation factory at BouIogne-sur-Seine began a sit-down strike today, but the police stormed the place in the evening and cleared out the sit-downers in less than twenty minutes.

Despite the rain yesterday, attendance continued good at the National Business Show being held in Commerce Hall of the Port Authority Building. While exhibitors of the business machines reported many prospects, actual placing of orders was reported heavy at the booths featuring stationery and allied supplies.

Cooperation of the foreign trade interests here in promoting the use of South African wines and brandies was pledged yesterday by guests attending a luncheon tendered general exporters and liquor dealers by the Cooperative Wine Growers of South Africa, in the Hotel Plaza.

Reflecting a further increase in the price of copper abroad, leading producers yesterday advanced the price of the refined metal in the domestic market from 10.50 cents a pound to 10.625 cents. On Wednesday the price was advanced from 10.375 to 10.50 cents a pound.

A court order signed by Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church, vacating an injunction temporarily restraining Reinhardt Co. from further dealing in securities in New York, was filed yesterday in the County Clerk's office.

A net asset value of $31.28 a share was reported yesterday for the 2,081,580 shares of stock of the Lehman Corporation as of Sept. 30, compared to $30.72 a share on June 30, according to Robert Lehman, president of the company.

173d St (11-2914), s e cor of Washington Ave, 30x100; 480 E 173d St Corp to Jessie Friedman, 1,804 Harrison Ave; mtg $34,000. Carroll P1 (9-2456), s e cor of 168th St, 170x75; Herbert Associates, Inc, to Repeal Building Corp, 1,742 Popham Ave; mtg $272,800.
The State Tax Commission filed yesterday with the County Clerk a tax warrant for $4,019.33 against Mae West, actress. The warrant is the equivalent of a judgment for allegedly unpaid income taxes.

Contending that many legitimate business men here may have made themselves liable to prosecution through failure to register yesterday under the Federal law requiring the registration with the State Department of representatives of foreign principals, the Merchants Association telegraphed to Washington last night asking the State Department to refrain from reporting any delinquents to the Departmen,t of Justice for ten days to two weeks.

At the close of business on Sept. 30 there were 1,380 bond issues of $50,330,816,368 par value listed on the New York Stock Exchange. The total market value of these securities was $44,836,709,443. The figures compared with 1,371 issues of $49,423,890,528 par value, and $44,182,833,403 market value on Aug. 31. The average end of August price was $89.40.

Charles R. Butts, a banker, died last night at the age of 84 after an illness of more than a month. Since 1923 he had been president of the Norwich Savings Society, where he began as a clerk in 1871, and since 1931 he was president of the Thames Bank and Trust Company of this city.
The Brotherhood of Locomotive Enginemen and Firemen's legislative board today endorsed the candidacy of Justice Charles Poletti for Lieutenant Governor on the Democratic ticket.
The Brooklyn College football team finished this week's practice sessions yesterday with a short signal drill and a half hour of pass defense work for the backs.

Since President Roosevelt would not go to Pennsylvania to speak on behalf of the State Democratic ticket there, the ticket came to Hyde Park today to report to the Chief Executive that the party would sweep the State by a majority of at least 200,000 in November without his personal intervention.

Miss Ruth Rowe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Rowe of the Bronx, was married to Jack Davis of this city and Washington, D. C., son of Mrs. George Davis of the Bronx and the late Mr. Davis, last evening in the Colonnades of Essex House by the Rev. Dr. Herbert S. Goldstein of New York.

Attorney General R. G. Menzies, in a debate on foreign affairs in the House of Representatives today, answered a demand by John Curtin, the Labor leader, to know what commitments Australia had undertaken in the event of war by declaring emphatically "None!"

The Interstate Commerce Commission today denied a petition by officials of four New Jersey municipalities for reconsideration of the case in which the commission recently granted a two-cent-fare increase to the Hudson Manhattan Railroad on its downtown branch.
Money market was featureless Business was small and quotations unchanged for all classifications.
The mechanics of selecting football officials was explained to members of the Touchdown Club at the Dartmouth Club yesterday by Asa Bushnell,
Columbia's football squad drove through a heavy workout in a steady rain yesterday at Baker Field, stressing defense again.
Modern Age Books has announced the addition to its Fall list of H. J. Timperley's "Japanese Terror in China," published in England by Victor Gollancz, Ltd., under the title "What War Means."

The two-family dwelling containing eleven rooms at 25-35 Fourteenth Street, Long Island City, L. I., was sold to Marco Campione by the Home Owners Loan Corporation. William A. Krahe Son, Inc., were the brokers.
Several properties in the Darien and Noroton sections of Connecticut were reported yesterday as having been sold through Leon A. Fish, broker.

Edward H. Williams is with Dougherty, Corkran Co. of Philadelphia as manager of their office here at 111 Broadway. Frederic W. Naumburg is in the office of Fuller, Rodney Redmond here. H. G. Carpenter and Walter A. DeLamater are with Karl D. Pettit Co.
Ernst Pollak, president of the Ernst Pollak Corporation, 110 West Forty-second Street, commission and export merchants, died in Paris on Tuesday, it was learned here yesterday.
Adpotion of the slogan "Use the Wholesaler and Save" was voted at a luncheon meeting of the Council of National Wholesale Associations at the Pennsylvania Hotel yesterday.

The veteran Walter Carter, who has had the utmost patience with the 4-year-old bay Clodion, was rewarded at Jamaica yesterday when his son of Pharamond II came from behind to capture the Warwick Handicap in gallant fashion.

Harvard today closed its major preparations for the Cornell game with a session of defensive work against the Ithacans' plays. There also was a thorough rehearsal of all phases of the Crimson's attack, with emphasis on forward passing.

By JAMES R. MURPHY Strange Ave, 1,905, 50x100; HOLC against Antonio Perri; -due, $10,827; to plantiff for $5,500. Giles PI, 3,451, 5-story apartment, 105.2x 91.7 irreg; Felix A. Muldoon, trustee, against Charles Gleger; due, $307,744: taxes, etc $4,300; sub to sales agreements for $14,000, $70,000, $44,000, $5,376 and $9,912; to plaintiff for $1,000.

Irving Eldridge, 1341/2, Bronx, defeated Johnny Morro, 1351/2, Fordham, in the feature eight-round bout at the New York Coliseum last night before 5,000 persons. Aggressiveness throughout the contest enabled Eldridge to score.

Sales of securities in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Oct. 1 exceeded purchases by 54,831 shares, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. Sales were 1,199,542 shares and purchases 1,144,711.
The leasing of several East Side residences and the sale of small multi-family tenements formed the bulk of the realty trading reported in Manhattan yesterday.
The Standard Oil Company tanker E. J. Bullock sank in the Gulf of Mexico near the Dry Tortugas late today less than two hours after an explosion set the 435-foot vessel afire.

Six employers who pleaded guilty in the last month to defrauding the State Insurance Fund were sentenced to prison terms yesterday by Justices Flood, Hofmann and Finegan in Special Sessions, while a seventh defendant escaped with payment of a fine.
Westchester County's bid for the 1939 conference was accepted as the State conference of the Daughters of the American Revolution, in session for four days, adjourned today.

The Most Rev. John Andrew Richardson, Anglican Archbishop of Fredericton and Metropolitan of the Ecclesiasical Province of Canada, died late today at the end of thirty-eight years in the priesthood. He was 6I years old.

Hub Vacuum Stores, chain vacuum cleaner dealers, store and basement; Durante Construction Co, Koenig Advertising Service, Dr. Herman Schron, dentist, Dr. Mortimer S. Friedner, chiropodist, in Hub Center Building, 148th St, 3d and Willis Aves, the Bronx; Hugh A. McGorry Jr. Inc. managing agents.

Declaring that "boys will be boys," Presiding Justice Edward Lazansky and Justice Frank F. Adel, of the Appellate Division in Brooklyn, dissented yesterday in a 3-to-2 decision upholding a $5,000 judgment for injuries suffered by a girl student in a Staten Island public school when she was pushed down a stairway by a group of boys.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construction of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

P. G. WODEHOUSE and Westbrook Pegler, two of our foremost living moralists, have just published their newest studies in contemporary manners.* Mr. Wodehouse's report takes the form of a novel. It is called "The Code of the Woosters," and it is scarcely hampered at all by its weirdly wandering plot.

Operations of the Aviation Corporation and its subsidiaries in the nine months ended on Aug. 31 resulted in a net profit of $402,062 after deductions for depreciation, experimental expense and estimated normal Federal income taxes, according to a statement issued yesterday.

Commissioner K. M. Landis, who arrived in New York yesterday, emphatically denied that any "hidden significance" attended the taking up of a working press ticket held by Rogers Hornsby when the former major league star and manager tried to enter Wrigley Field through the press gate for the second world series game in Chicago Thursday.

Miss Barbara Nichols Johnston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Earl Johnston of West Hartford, was married here this afternoon in the Asylum Hill Congregational Church to Nathaniel Demorest Rogers of Hartford, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cephas Brainerd Rogers of Danbury.
Mr. and Mrs. Archibald Gourlay Thacher have announced the engagement and - approaching marriage of Mr. Thacher's daughter, Mrs. Isabel Davies Thacher, to John' Paul Barringer of Philadelphia.
The annual convention of the New York State Council of PolishAmerican Democratic Clubs will open today at 1 P. M. at the Polish National Home, 19-23 St. Mark's Place. for a two-day session.

The following Reserve officers recently released to the First Military Area for assignment, are assigned to units as indicated: 389th Infantry-2d Lt. Donald D. Fowler, F.A.-Res., 290 State St., Albany, N. Y. 2d Lt. John S. Shibe. Inf.-Res., Co. D, 26th Inf.. Plattsburg Bks.. N. Y.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag dismissed yesterday a minority stockholders' suit which sought to hold officers and directors of the National City. Bank of New York personally liable for $725,000,
Eric L. Pedley, international polo player, will become a partner in the proposed New York Stock Exchange firm of Pedley, Martin Co. of Los Angeles on Oct. 21. Until Aug.

Katharine Burton, author of "Sorrow Built a Bridge," now in its seventh printing, has handed in her new manuscript to her publishers, Longmans, Green. It is entitled "Paradise Planters, the Story of Brook Farm," and deals with the transcendental period in New England and leaders of the Brook Farm experiment. Publication is planned for early Spring.

New York and New Jersey schools are among the winners of the annual Massachusetts Institute of Technology awards, established to give recognition to schools -whose students excel in one of the five principal first-year subjects.

The Virginia Electric and Powe Company has called for redemption on Nov. 7, at 105, all its first and refunding mortgage, Series A, 4 per cent bonds due on Nov. 1, 1955, outstanding in the amount of $37,488,000.
Two stately schooners, relics of an age that has passed, arrived at Boston Harbor today to dispute the sailing championship of the North Atlantic fishing fleets.

All Italy is awaiting with intense interest Pope Pius's reaction to the new matrimonial principles the Fascist Grand Council adopted last night, since this is a matter in which the Catholic Church has a voice.

On July 23 Governor Earle of Pennsylvania called a special session of the GeneralAssembly. He called it to "repel an unprecedented judicial invasion." He called it to anticipate a Dauphin County investigation of charges of criminal conduct filed by District Attorney Shelley against the Governor himself and thirteen other persons.
Clark H. Minor, president of International General Electric, told the American Club yesterday that the success of the Munich decisions will depend upon how they are applied to trade.

It was officially announced tonight that Germany has extended to Turkey a trade credit of 150,000,000 marks for the purchase of "industrial and miliary equipment and materials for public works and other purposes."

The Associated Clinic conducted from October to June at Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Clinton and Montague Streets, Brooklyn, under the auspices of the Brooklyn Church and Mission Federation, began its ninth year yesterday.
General Franco's planes have been staging "bread raids" on cities in Loyalist Spain. Instead of the conventional high explosives,

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 6: MAJOR GENERAL Arnold, H. H., Chief of the Air Corps,three days' leave, Oct. 6.

The current football season has been unprecedented in the feast of big-game attractions offered from the very start. Today again finds the public at a loss to know in which direction to turn, so tempting is the gridiron banquet spread before it on all fronts save the Southwestern, four of whose leading entries left home for intersectional engagements.

One whisky highball or one gin cocktail or one and a half quarts of beer may be taken on an empty stomach without the concentration of alcohol in the blood exceeding 0.5 milligram a centimeter, the limit of strict sobriety, according to three Yale physs-, iologists.
A 6-year-old boy, John E. Rogers, is the plaintiff in a suit on file in the Second Judicial District Court here against a Newark ice cream company and one of its drivers.

The Grand Council of Fascism signed today the death warrant of the last survivor of Italy's democratic institutions when it decreed the abolition of the Chamber of Deputies and its replacement by what is to be called the "Chamber of the Fasces and Corporations."

Judge George L. Donnellan in General Sessions Court yesterday freed Mrs. Mary Peraski, captured in 1936 with the "arsenal gang," on a suspended sentence after she had pleaded guilty to an indictment charging her with part ownership of a number of gun silencers.

Ernest W. Borkland Jr. has been appointed manager of the municipal bond department and Hoyt Peck was made assistant manager of Tucker, Anthony Co. The firm also announced that William S. Welch and Eric Etherington have joined their sales organization.

Revenues of the Northern Pacific Railroad in the first three weeks of September were about 11 per cent less than the total for the same period last year, according to Washington advices quoting Charles E. Donnelly, president, yesterday.

Mrs. Manaaretta B. Nichols Crosbie-Roles, widow of Francis CrosbieRoles of London, England, died in London on Wednesday, according to word received here last night. She was the only daughter of the late John A. Nichols of Brooklyn.

The State Department announced today that President Roosevelt had proclaimed Wednesday the Treaty of Friendship, Commerce and Navigation concluded between the United States and Siam Nov. 13 and that it was effective as of Oct. 1, the day on which ratifications were exchanged in Bangkok. It replaces a treaty signed here on Dec. 16, 1920.
Mrs. Peggy Moffett Carlisle and George Atwell Jr., both of New York, were married today at the Drake Hotel. The bride is the daughter of James A, Moffett, former Federal Housing Administrator.

Mrs. James Graeme Lidgerwood of 168 East Seventy-fourth Street and Kennebunkport, Me., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jean Graeme Lidgerwood, to Henry Boas Gilbert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henderson Gilbert of Harrisburg, Pa.

Exchange of checks at the principal clearing houses of the country in September totaled $24,086,655,274, an increase of 9.4 per cent over the preceding month, but a loss of 10 per cent compared with September last year.

New Jersey will pay William Le Hardy of London $2,500 to cross the Atlantic, look at a signature and tell what he thinks of it. His word may determine the ownership rights to the eastern half of the Delaware River, with fishing, pier and wharfage privileges on the New Jersey shore, for a twenty-four-mile strip between New Jersey and Delaware.

Clergymen will preach tomorrow on the week's developments in the Czechoslovak crisis, and in churches of all faiths tomorrow and in synagogues today prayers that peace may be permanent will be offered. By order of the.

BROWN vs. LAFAYETTE--Old Gunga Dean almost got away with that game against the Yankees. If he had won it-with not even an arm up hissleeve!-Dean would have been hailed as another Houdini. After a brown study, one vote for Brown.

Eposa, conqueror of Seabiscuit and considered the leading handicap star of her sex, heads the field for the Continental Handicap, richest race of the Jamaica meeting, to be run today at the Metropolitan Jockey Club's course. Assigned the top impost of 126 pounds, Esposa will face ten others over the mile and a sixteenth route for a prize that is expected to gross more than $12,000.
The wheat market developed a much stronger undertone today and after a small decline in the early trading prices started upward after midday on aggressive commission house buying.

Tony Shucco of Boston, after having scored what looked like a knockout over Adolf Heuser, German and European light-heavyweight champion, in their twelve-round bout at Deutschland Hall tonight, was disqualified in the fifth round for what the referee termed "unfair fighting."
The probable line-up and batting order for the third game of the world series at the Yankee Stadium this afternoon follow:

In a rapid exchange of messages among all concerned yesterday, Governor Lehman. asked for a sworn petition and "all the facts" to support the request for a special prosecutor to supersede District Attorney Geoghan of Brooklyn, and Mr.
Richard Halliburton, American author, who arrived in Yokohama this afternoon, plans to sail a Chinese junk across the Pacific on a course along the equator.

Retail prices of food rose in the month ended on Sept. 13, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1923-25 average as 100, was 78.7, compared with 78.4 on Aug. 16, and 85.8 on Sept. 14, 1937.

Miss Carolyn A. Coon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Coon of this place, was married tonight at the home of her parents to Donald C. Creasy, son of George H. Creasy of New York and the late Mrs. Creasy.
The law firm of DeWitt, Lockman DeWitt moved its office yesterday from 88 Nassau Street to 270 Broadway, terminating what is said to be the oldest continuous tenancy of this kind in New York City.
One pilot was killed and another parachuted to safety today when two French combat planes collided in midair near Dijon during a practice flight.
Scarsdale High today defeated Pelham High, 9 to 0, marking the first triumph for Scarsdale over its traditional rival since 1928.

Greta Garbo, the Swedish film actress, returned yesterday on the liner Kungsholm from Europe, where she spent the Summer. She said she did not know what plans Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer had but she understood her next film would have a Russian theme and that

Federal Judge Phillip Forman today fined Maurice Winniman, who gave his address as 259 Schley Street, Newark, $300 on a charge of sending lottery slips from Keansburg to Kingston, N. Y. He pleaded guilty, the first of nine defendants to answer an indictment charging them with participation in the Keansburg lottery.
SECRETS OF AN ACTRESS, screen play by Milton Krims, Rowland Leigh and Julius J. Epstein; directed by William Keighley; a Warner Brothers production. At the Strand.
The Italian Government has been asked by the United States not to discriminate against American Jews and not to subject them to provisions of decrees issued by Premier Benito Mussolini.

There are two ways of regarding the latest efforts of the industrial leaders composing the Administration's business advisory council to formulate a statement of the lines along which they believe cooperation between the Government and business should proceed. One is to say, cynically,

The National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers reported today that men's apparel merchants were not discouraged by the fact that sales luring September were substan:ially lower than for the same month a year ago.

The marriage of Miss Alexandra Margheti6, daughter of Mrs. Clement Fessenden Merrill of Warwick, N. Y., to Rawson Lloyd, son of Mrs. John Lloyd of 28 East Seventieth Street, formerly of Philadelphia, took place here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. James's Episcopal Church.
Business remained restricted in the stock markets today, but the undertone was firm and the most eventful account since the World War ended on a confident note.

134th st, 514-16 E, 1-story factory, 49.10x 100; Veteran Assn of 71st Regiment, National Guard of N Y. against Manhat. tan Swiss Embroidery Co; due, $9,498; taxes, etc, $1,400; to plaintiff for $1,000. Merry Ave. 1,369, dwelling, 25x87.10x irreg; Home Owners Loan Corp against Mary Damiani; due, $6,872; to plaintiff for $2,050.
Charles Teale Rue, secretary of the Perkins Goodwin Company, New York paper concern, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home here at the age of 47.

Betting on the world series yesterday was described as "moderate" by Jack Doyle, Broadway commissioner. Big operators are handling normal business, Doyle declared, but the small "books" are doing little or nothing.

W. Warren Barbour and William H. J. Ely, respectively the Republican and Democratic candidates for United States Senator, made counter appeals today to the Sheppard Senate committee for a New Jersey inquiry, each asking that the other's campaign be investigated.

In the last few days, or since the easing of the Czechoslovak crisis, prices of both securities and commodities have moved up sharply. Even cotton, which is in a most unfavorable statistical position, has recovered approximately $2.50 a bale. Prices of grains,
Hunters were ordered out of woods in five southern counties of New Hampshire today as the State closed the area because of the danger that fire might sweep the timber.

Despite the loss in sales occasioned by the religious holiday in the week, retail trade here showed improvement over the slow pace of last week. Cooler weather was reflected in heavier volume in the apparel departments, while main floor and home wares sections likewise had a more active turnover.

W. Earle Andrews, former architectural engineer of the Long Island State Park Commission; was retained today by the Suffolk Board of Supervisors to make a survey of Fire Island Beach from Southampton to Fire Island Inlet for the board's guidance in meeting the emergency resulting from the devastation caused by the hurricane of Sept. 21.
Horace R. McCoy of Rockport, Ill., has been made chief of the specialties division of the Commerce Department's Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, it was announced today.

Herman Matson, 28-year-old critic of the local political administration, who was arrested after he had been beaten Sept. 15 during a vain effort to address a crowd in a park here on relief conditions, was found guilty today of being a disorderly person, but sentence was suspended.
Ward's Automotive Reports today estimated the current week's output of motor vehicles at 37,665 units, against 25,405 last week and 71,958 this week a year ago.

A $500 fellowship for a year's study is being offered by the Menorah Society of Hunter College in commemoration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of its founding, it was announced yesterday. The fellowship may be applied to study at the Hebrew University or at the American School of Oriental Research in Jerusalem, Palestine, or for combined study at both institutions.

The mythical Ivy League championship will be the goal when Dartmouth and Princeton meet on the Palmer Stadium gridiron tomorrow at 2 P. M. Princeton enters as a decided underdog against the undefeated Indians, but the Tigers are hopeful of an upset.

" Dark Rapture," a pictorial record of the 42,000-mile trek made through the Belgian Congo by Armand Denis and his wife, Leila Roosevelt, will have its first local showing today at the Globe. The Denis-Roosevelt African expedition set out from Antwerp in 1925 and shot about 125,000 feet of film, from which the present picture was culled.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: It was indeed refreshing to read the letter in your column last Saturday relative to "Iron Man" Gehrig. I believe that it echoes the sentiments of many baseball fans.
Gold to the value of $204,844,905 came into the United States in the week ended on Sept. 30, the Department of Commerce said.
Dandel J. Tobin, president of the. International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which is the largest union in the American Federation of Labor, started a movement today to bring about resumption of peace

Samuel Kronsky Co. has placed for the Acorn Holding Corporation a new first mortgage of $800,000 for ten years at 41/2 per cent on the sixstory business building on the northwest corner of Jamaica Avenue and 166th Street, Jamaica, Queens. The building is occupied by Ludwig Baumann.

Ralph M. Easley, chairman of the executive council of the National Civic Federation, announced yesterday the formation by the federation of a committee of one hundred on American civil and property rights.

Pennsylvania's high-geared football team meets Yale in their annual game on Franklin Field tomorrow. This will be the eighteenth meeting in the series that started in 1879, and only once has the Red and Blue been victorious.
Details of the new De Soto for 1939 were announced yesterday by L. G. Peed, vice president of the De Soto division of the Chrysler Corporation. Complete details will be announced to the public soon.

Officials of the Department of Agriculture said today that no official cognizance had been taken of a proposal by Senator Pittman of Nevada that the government trade its holdings of cotton for silver in the foreign markets to dispose of the huge cotton carry-over.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Prints German Masters of the Fifteenth Century," Edith R. Abbot, 11 A. M.; Persian and Indian Miniatures: A Contrast (Survey of Collections). Mabel Harrison Duncan, 2 P. M.; motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.

The New South Wales coal strike has been settled on the terms proposed by the State Minister of Labor, calling for immediate resumption of work and investigation of the miners' claims by a judge of the Commonwealth Arbitration Court.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals today refused to interfere with an investigation of the relationship of the Associated Gas and Electric Company and the Utilities Employes Securities Company, an investing association of employes.

A New Hampshire farmer complained today to District Attorney Walter A. Ferris that, when he drove into Mount Vernon yesterday afternoon on a vacation trip he was accused by two patrolmen of passing a red light and was told that it would cost him $25 in court unless he "settled it right now for $10."

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Oct. 7 unless specified: Augusta, at Chinwangtao. California, Navy Yard, Puget Sound to San Pedro, via San Francisco, Oct. 6. Cachalot, at Navy Yard, New York, Oct. 6. Gold Star, at Hong Kong. Leary, at Annapolis.

Mrs. Ethel Anderson, 41 years old, of 128 West Leaming Avenue here, gave birth today to her nineteenth child, a 7 1/2-pound girl. Married at 16, Mrs. Anderson has sixteen living children, seven boys and nine girls.

Sixty-four fellowships for study at the Juilliard Graduate School for the forthcoming season have been awarded by the school through competitive examinations held during the last fortnight, it was announced yesterday by Ernest Hutcheson, president.

Fourteen Americans, captured by the Spanish Insurgents while fighting as volunteers in the Loyalist army, are expected to enter France tomorrow at Hendaye. From that point, it is planned, they will take the first train to Paris and after that they will be returned to their homes as quickly as possible.
The text of District Attorney Geoghan's letter to Governor Lehman yesterday follows: Oct. 7, 1938. Hon. Herbert H. Lehman, Governor of New York State, 820 Park Avenue, New York, N. Y.

Miss Marjorie Starkweather Sheldon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Rhodes Sheldon Jr. of this city and Spindrift, Saunderstown, R. I., was introduced to society here at two parties today. She is the first of the debutantes of this city to "come out" this season.

That banks here invested some $73,000,000 in government bonds during the last three months because of the lack of normal commercial demand for credit was disclosed in the quarterly statements released today showing the condition of the institutions as of Sept. 28.

The youthful executive committee, given complete merchandising authority and responsibility at Arnold Constable Co. during September, turned in gross sales of more than $1,000,000 in the month, Isaac Liberman, president of the store, announced yesterday.
Foreign travelers arriving today from Northern Korea reported the Soviet flag was flying atop Changkufeng Hill, where Russian and Japanese forces battled during the Summer over the disputed

Two hundred cowboys and cowgirls, besides a large number of tamed and untamed horses and steers, tossed themselves into the ring at Madison Square Garden last night to give this frontier town its annual demonstration of what things are like in the Old West.

The firs Pingry School eleven defeated Carteret Academy of Orange today, 7-0. In the last minute of play Scotty Cunningham took a Carteret fumble 35 yards for the only touchdown of the game. Mac Bristol place-kicked the extra point. Pingry threatened often in the early periods.

Mrs. F. J. Mulqueen of Toronto shot five pars and a birdie on the last six holes today to beat Mrs. J. B. Walker of Ayrshire, Scotland, 1 up, and advance to the final round of the Canadian women's open golf championship. She will oppose Miss Clarrie Tiernan of Dublin for the title tomorrow.

A conference of representatives of the towboat industry and the union representing their employes broke up after five minutes of discussion yesterday with the announcement of union leaders that a meeting would be held tomorrow night to consider strike action.
Alarmed by the mounting casualties in Palestine the British Government is rushing ahead with a plan for an immediate Arab-Jewish armistice.

Two weeks of unremitting efforts by the highway departments of the New England States, using large forces of workers. have cleared most of the main traffic lines in that area, which were seriously damaged by the hurricane of Spent. 21.

Gene Smith, Oakland High School teacher, who eliminated Adrian Quist, Australian star, from the Pacific Coast tennis tournament, joined Bobbie Harmon of Berkeley today and defeated Don Budge. Oakland, and Franjo Kukuljevic of Yugoslavia in the doubles. The score was 6-4, 3-6, 6-0.

Applications for certificates of convenience and necessity covering eighteen existing and nineteen new airline routes have been filed with the Civil Aeronautics Authority. The proposed new lines would add more than 9,000 miles to the existing air transportation system of 32,000 miles.

Colonel Jake Ruppert, quoted from New York today as "pulling for my Kansas City Blues," can go right ahead rooting for them tomorrow, for in the sixth game tonight before 6,304 fans, the Blues backed up Marvin Breuer's fine pitching with a 4-2 triumph over the Bears to. tie the little world series at three games each.
The Presidents of Washington and Jefferson knocked Muskingum College's Muskies off the undefeated list with a 21-to-7 victory tonight.

The sun is just passing its greatest maximum of spot activity in recent times. Records at the Carnegie In'stitution's Mount Wilson Observatory showed today that there had been more spots on the sun in the last two years than for any similar period since 1870.

Loudest and longest applause at the opening session today of the biennial convention of the National Woman's Party went to the symbol of the campaign just opening for adoption of the equal rights amendment to the Constitution.
Favorites found the going exceptionally rough in the first two rounds of the twentieth annual Arcola invitation golf tournament today.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $22,480,300, to be represented by three States and ninety municipalities. This compares with the revised total of only $8,835,750 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $23.765.016.

Passing of the European war crisis was reflected in the capital market this week by the appearance of two large corporate-loans, lifting the total of new bond offerings to $83,034,000, the largest for any period since the week ended Aug. 12, last, when $83,707,000 in new issues were marketed.
THE DEVIL TAKES A BRIDE, a play in two acts. by Joe Bates Smith. Staged by John Hayden; settings by Lawrence L. Goldwasser; produced by Montgomery Ford. At the Cort Theater.

A Jewish family of fourteen, fleeing from what they believe is certain domination of -the Free City of Danzig by Nazi Germany, arrived yesterday on the HollandAmerica liner Noordam to find homes in the United States.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Oct. 5: COMMANDER Herlihy, J. E., Dental Corps, to the Dobbin, instead the Holland. LIEUTENIANT COMMANDERS Herbst, H. H.; the Maryland, to continue treatment Naval Hospital, San Diego, Calif.

Gross assets, $24,284; net, $20,760. To the Silver Cross Day Nursery. $100: Frederick L. Evkel Jr.. $1,000; three specific bequests; William G. Austin, son, residue. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $21,758. Mitchell, Taylor, Capron March, attorneys, 17 East 42d St.

Thoroughly competent piano playing that had style, a pervading sanity and compelling sincerity of purpose to commend it was heard from Erno Balogh at his recital last night in Town Hall.

A shrinkage to $8,240 in the estate of Anthony Comstock, vice crusader, who died in 1915, is shown in an intermediate accounting of his estate submitted to Judge Lloyd Thompson in Orphan's Court here today. The accounting was submitted by the Summit Trust Company, trustees of the estate.

The Clearing Machine Corporation, Chip cago, has filed a registration state ment under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 75,000 shares of $1 par-value common stock, of which 41,667 shares will be sold for the account of the company.

Surviving wartime officers of the 165th (Old Sixty-ninth) Regiment will hold a reunion dinner at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel tonight, the eve of the twentieth anniversary of the day on which they led their men

Lou Nova, San Francisco heavyweight, was signed yesterday by Mike Jacobs to meet Tommy Farr, British Empire champion, in a fifteen-round bout at Madison Square Garden on Dec. 16. Nova, who recently registered a knockout triumph over Gunnar Barlund. departed for his home last night.

Miss Annabel Gait, a missionary of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, who retired in 1934, died on Monday in Orlando, Fla., of a stroke, it was learned here yesterday. Her age was 70.

Two of the six Federal agents named in an indictment charging extortion of money from business men and defrauding the government of taxes that should have been collected on. illegally manufactured liquor appeared yesterday in Federal court, Brooklyn,
The last vestige of control over the $1,000,000,000 Standard Gas and Electric Company system by H. M. Byllesby Co. interests has been severed.
The Mexican Government has shipped 575,000 barrels of Poza Rica crude oil into Texas since Aug. 20, putting it well ahead of its schedule of 10,000 barrels -a day to the Eastern States Oil Company.

BENNAT IRON WORKS, INC., 1,361 Seneca Ave., by Winter Wolff Co., for $206; Concord Steel Corp., $133; Fisher Bros. Steel Corp., $404. Franl W. MEYERS STATIONERY PRINTING CO., INC., 315 Broadway, by United Service Printing Corp., for $183: Falcon Engraving Co., Inc., $153: Palographia Co., $139; Commercial Engraving Co., Inc., $104.
Alfred E. Smith, former Hammonton contractor and builder, collapsed and died of apoplexy today while sawing down a tree at his home here.
The Controller of the Currency and the Federal Reserve Board issued today calls for the condition statements of banks under their jurisdiction as of Sept. 28.
The Northern States Power Company of Delaware, a subsidiary of the Standard Gas and Electric Company, has filed with the Securities

Lilies against a background of cybotium ferns provided the floral setting yesterday afternoon in St. Thomas ChurchXfor the marriage of Miss Marjorie Morriss MacCollorn, daughter of Mrs. R. M. Morriss Betts of 16 East Eightieth Street, this city, and of Donald Hoyt MacCollom of Roanoke, Va., to Benjamin T. Fairchild 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. B. Tappen Fairchild of Ships Timbers, Cold Spring Harbor, L. I.

Cotton-mill activity increased more than seasonally last week and the adjusted index advanced to 115.3 from 112.8, the revised figure for the previous week. The index was 121.2 for the week ended Oct. 2, 1937.

The Business Advisory Council of the Department of Commerce, composed of business and industrial leaders, endorsed today the recent appeal of a "White House spokesman" for cooperation as a basis for lasting industrial recovery.

The city yesterday overflowed with baseball fans. From all directions the world series followers converged on New York by train, airplane, bus and auto and crowded midtown hotels on the East as well as the West Side.

Besides Anne Roselle, already announced, Leonora Corona will be among the leading sopranos of the New York Grand Opera Company during its forthcoming season at the Manhattan Center. Miss Corona, former member of the Metropolitan, will make her initial appearance with the troupe as Leon?ra in "Il Trovatore."

Earle Welborn of 192 East End Avenue, a sales executive for the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., died Thursday in St. Louis, where he had gone on a business trip, after a short illness. He was 54 years old.

The marriage of Miss Virginia Baker Felter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Washington Felter of 9 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, to Russell Bernay Harding, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Hight Harding, also of Brooklyn, took place yesterday afternoon in St. Bartholomew's Church, Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Frank M. Townley.

Robert Myerle, 19-year-old son of an insurance executive of Bedford Village, N. Y., was sentenced yesterday to an indefinite term at Elmira Reformatory after he had violated parole on three occasions. He was arrested in January on a charge of brandishing a pistol in front of a night club on East Fifty-eighth Street.

The reconciliation of government, capital and labor to promote social peace in America was urged last night by Father Ignatius W. Cox, Professor of Ethics at Fordham University, speaking at the opening of the Xavier Labor School, 30 West Sixteenth Street.

The Marine Trust Company of Buffalo and R. D. White Co. won yesterday the award of $287,000 of school bonds of Union Free School District No. 2 of the towns of Cortlandt and Yorktown, N. Y., on their bid of 102.559 for 3s.

J. Gilbert Hall, New York, defending champion, and Percy Kynaston, Brooklyn, 1936 titleholder, will meet tomorrow in the final of the Hot Springs Fall invitation tennis tournament. Hall advanced today by defeating Horace Orser, 6--1, 6-3.

Retired fireman Bradford C. Campbell, formerly a member of H. L. Co. 118, residing at Cania, N. H., died Oct. 4. Funeral will take place from 31 1st St., Brooklyn, at 2 P. M. Saturday, Oct. 8. Interment at Evergreen Cemetery. The Deputy Chief of the 10th Division shall detail one captain, lieutenant and twelve firemen, as funeral escort.

One of the season's more ambitious offerings, "The Fabulous Invalid," opens tonight at the Broadhurst Theatre. This is the Moss Hart-George S. Kaufman panoramic account of the shifting fortunes of a-New York theatre from the turn of the century until 1930, in which will be presented brief moments from more than sixty plays and musical shows produced during that period. The play has been directed by Mr. Kaufman.

In its last tune-up before engaging powerful Purdue at the Polo Grounds next Saturday, Fordham's football forces will play Waynesburg at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, this afternoon. The kick-off is set for 2 o'clock.

Shipments of oil burners during August totaled 15,373 units, compared with 10,689 in July and 22,413 in August, 1937, according to figures just issued by the Department of Commerce. Shipments for the first eight months of this year totaled 71,405, against 116,159 in the same period last year.

Two large automobile plants were shut down today and 15,000 workers were thrown out of work when the C. I. O. United Automobile Workers started a strike demonstration to enforce a demand for a thirty-two-hour week.
Paul Shannon of The Boston Post was elected president of the Baseball Writers Association of America at the annual meeting last night at the Hotel Commodore.

This year 10 per cent more persons than last year visited New York's free public camp sites. The Conservation Commissioner reports that from May 28 to Sept. 15 the State picnic grounds, bathing facilities and camp sites resounded to the whoops of 676,432 who were getting away from it all.
Two teams carded 77s to tie for medal honors in the Scotch foursome invitation golf tournament staged for the first time by the Sands Point Club today.

A celebration of the 150th anniversary of the first formal conference of Methodist preachers will be held tomorrow afternoon at 3:30 o'clock in John Street Methodist Church, 44 John Street, near Nassau Street.

Japanese official quarters reported last night that the encirclement of Teian, thirty-one miles south of Kiukiang, had been completed and that their forces were moving eastward from Loki, instead of westward toward Wuning as the Chinese had expected.

The Rev. Dr. Philip J. Furlong has taken up his duties as the new president of Cathedral College, Madison Avenue and Fifty-first Street, where for the last eighteen years he has been a member of the faculty.
Texas Christian University's famed aerial circus, with little Davey O'Brien replacing Sammy Baugh in the passing role, swamped Temple, 28 to 6, in an intersectional game tonight before 25,000.

Irked by the failure of some communities in the eleven Northeastern States to get projects started on schedule,' Colonel Maurice E. Gilmore, regional director of the Public Works Administration, announced yesterday that his office had taken 100 grants away from laggard communities and that it would not temporize with further, delays.

An old downtown building which had been held by one owner for more than seventy years, and another on the upper West Side held for about forty-one years, figured in the Manhattan realty transactions reported yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Sonya Kowal of New York, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Kowal, to Robert Franklin Colwell, also of this city and Wilmington, N. C., son of Mrs. Robert Franklin Colwell and the late Mr. Colwell, took place here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Church of the Heavenly Rest. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, the rector.

Army faces Columbia in Michie Stadium tomorrow for the first major contest of the Cadets' season. The team had its last real workout for the game yesterday and today took only light exercise. In this series with the Lions, five games have been played, each team winning two, the other contest being a tie. Tomorrow Army hopes to gain the rubber game.

Violette and Helene Coffer-Chantal will give a two-piano recital today at 3 P. M. in Town Hall. In the same auditorium at 8:30 P. M. Bernard Kundell, violinist, will be presented in a recital under the auspices of the Society for Advancement of Young Musicians.

Lawrence High's eleven remained unbeaten in seventeen games, four of which were deadlocks, since early in 1936 by routing Woodmere High, 20-7, in its season's opener tonight at Horn Stadium. Pete Ruggieri, with a pair of touchdowns and a conversion, paced the home forces' offense. The line-up:

The 1939 convention of the National Restaurant Association will also be held in Chicago, Roy W. Cooley, president, announced as the twentieth annual convention ended today. The date set is Oct. 2 to 6.

Ambassador Josephus Daniels called for the erection of "prohibitive tariff walls against the entrance of subversive doctrines" in Latin America in a speech today before the International Feminine Convention.
Miss Marie M. Winthrop will become advertising manager of Oppenheim, Collins Co., Brooklyn, on Monday, succeeding Miss Elvira Vingiprova who resigned recently.

Miss Elizabeth Phillips, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick R. Phillips of this place, was married today to Deane W. Krueger of Brooklyn and Ossining, N. Y., son of Mrs. Charles H. Krueger and the late Mr. Krueger, in the Irvington Presbyterian Church here.

Chancellor Josiah O. Wolcott today ordered Charles G. Guth and the Grace Company, of which he is owner, to surrender 237,000 shares of Pepsi-Cola Company stock to be sequestered until final settlement of a suit brought by Loft, Inc., of which Mr. Guth was president.

Current rayon stocks are low in all branches of the industry except among weavers, according to the results of a survey announced yesterday by The Rayon Organon, published by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc. The high rayon shipments of the last three months.
A relaxing of caution was apparent in the wholesale market this week, according to the weekly summary prepared by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Complete panic prevails among the refugees from the German-occupied areas tonight concerning the news that Germany has officially demanded the return of all German emigres, including Socialists and Communists, on the grounds that the Third Reich is "unwilling to part with a single German."
