The Confidential Personal Loan Company of New York has applied for licenses to do business at 273 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn; 57 Bay Street, St. George, S. I., and 562 Broadway, Albany, the State Banking Department anunced today.
The bulk of the Brooklyn trading which brokers reported yesterday involved residential parcels in scattered sections of the borough.
After announcing that the city's garbage, rubbish and ash collectors who went on strike Thursday morning had been discharged, Mayor Wilson today went ahead with plans to resume the service tomorrow.

John J. Duffy, for twenty-eight years an accountant in the office of the City Controller and prominent in the Knights of Columbus, died on Thursday in his home, 493 First Street, Brooklyn. He would have been 66 years old today.

The administrator of Southwest Africa was urged by a political meeting today to take action looking toward a plebiscite to determine whether this former German colony should be restored to Germany or remain under British rule.

The biennial convention of the United Lutheran Church in America adopted without dissent today a judgment of its "supreme court" permitting the admission of women to deliberative and administrative bodies of the church.

A revamped Rutgers football team will engage New York University on Neilson Field tomorrow in the thirty-fifth meeting between the two institutions. The kick-off is listed for 2 P. M. Dorn, sophomore left tackle, replaces Len Cooke, out with tonsillitis.
Railroad witnessess contended at the wageeale hearings today that a 15 per ant reduction would not materially effect general business.

Robert E. Dowling will head an independent citizens committee for the re-election of Senator Robert F. Wagner, it was announced yesterday. Senator Wagner's headquarters will be in the Chanin Building, where the headquarters of the citizens committee for the re-election of Governor Lehman already have been opened.

Frederic R. Coudert Jr., Republican candidate in the Seventeenth Senatorial District, was elected unanimously last night as leader of the Fifteenth Assembly District to succeed Kenneth F. Simpson, Re publican County Chairman and National Committeeman who resigned as district leader because of the press of his other duties.

Estate, about $2.200. To Society for the Propagation of the Faith, St. Joseph's Home for Aged, 209 W. 15th St., and Rev. George J. Willman. 51 E. 83d St.. $500 each; Church of St. Francis Xavier. 30 W. 16th St., $1.000 and residue. John T. Magan. 102 South 11th Ave., Mount Vernon, executor.
On the authority of Mrs. Gertrude Binney Kay, a Boston educator who lectures to students of the drama, it is permissible to dunk doughnuts at informal parties.

As messengers of good business in the Northwest, F. E. Murphy, publisher of The Minneapolis Tribune, and Charles F. Collison, farm editor of that newspaper, reported to some 300 business and advertising executives at a luncheon at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, on "the steady up-swing of business" in their region, including Minnesota, Wisconsin, the Dakotas and Montana.
With the addition of May Robson, John Halliday and Roland Young to the cast, Warners will place Mark Reed's "Yes, My Darling Daughter" before the cameras next week, with William Keighley directing.

Five well-dressed young men, four of whom showed pistols, escaped with $4,500 from the one-story brick warehouse of Lever Brothers Company, Inc., soap and glycerine manufacturers, at 4,604 Second Avenue at Forty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, shortly after 8 o'clock last night.
Memoranda filed with the New York Stock Exchange committee on floor procedure by three big odd-lot houses demand that "sniping" in their field be brought to an end, it was learned yesterday.

129th St, 225 W. 16.8x99.11; Wm. De Brier to Ida Moss, 225 W 129th St; due and int per bond: $1,250. 162d St. 429 W. 18.6x112; Martha Buddress to Delos Holding Corp, 270 Madison Ave; p m 5 yrs, 4 per cent; $5,000.

Residential leasing, as reflected in brokers' reports received yesterday, continues in good volume despite the fact that the seasonal peak is more than a week past. Rentals in buildings in many parts of the city were listed.

The four-Power agreement signed at Munich on Sept. 30 placed the evacuation of the territory to be ceded immediately to Germany by Czechoslovakia, the determination of additional territory "of preponderantly German character" and the delimitation of still further areas, in which plebiscites were to be held, under the supervision of "an international commission composed of representatives of Germany, the United Kingdom, France, Italy and Czechoslovakia."

The right of the Board of Education to ignore a recommendation for the reinstatement of a teacher made by the medical board of the Teachers Retirement Board was affirmed unanimously yesterday by the Appellate Division. The teacher had contended that the Board of Education had no discretion in the matter.

Boynton Ave (14-3652), s w cor of Eastern Blvd. 100x100; also Elder Ave, s e cor of Eastern Blvd, 100x100; Verwood Realty Corp to J. M. Lipset, Inc, 371 E 149th St. Edson Ave, 4,331 (17-5055); Bronx Housing Corp to Samuel. De Refler, 313 S 9th Ave. Mount Vernon.
Purging of collective farm personnel is under way in Siberia as a result of widespread difficulties in garnering excellent grain crops in the eastern part of the Soviet Union.

The interruption of advertising schedules for steamship lines selling passenger service to Europe which resulted from the threat of war will not bring any loss of revenue to the media used, agency men said yesterday.
John A. Bell, since 1930 chief clerk in the office of the New York County District Attorney, died yesterday at St. Eliabeth's Hospital after a week's illness. His age was 68.

Wilkes-Barre went without local newspapers for the fourth successive day today while efforts to settle the dispute between striking members. of the American Newspaper Guild and the publishers of the city's four newspapers bogged down in uncertainties.

The Transit Commission approved to yesterday, by a two-to-oone vote, the "enlarged plan" 'for-the removal of twenty grade crossings-of the Long Island Railroad on Atlantic Avenue in the four mile stretch between East New York, Brooklyn and Jamaica, Queens.
Any one who travels through the countryside these days knows that among the victims hardest hit by last month's hurricane were our friends the trees.

Slaughter liberal on most classes in local markets yesterday. Traefer meats mostly unchanged. Kosher lamb opening about steady; other classes higher. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Club elections at Manhattan College yesterday under the supervision of the Student Council resulted in the elections of Joseph V. Dooley Jr., Harold F. Roma and George J. Trefcer as presidents of the Pen and Sword Society, the Mendelian Society and the Manhattan branch of the American Chemical Society,

Louis E. Felix, 53-year-old lawyer and president of the Tammany Club of the Ninth Assembly District, died of poisoning, it was reported last evening by Dr. Alexander 0. Gettler, city toxicologist. Mr. Felix,

More than 2,200 Chevrolet dealers, retail salesmen and other organization members from New York, Connecticut, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Massachusetts yesterday had their first look at the new models for 1939 and learned of advertising

Thirty-three survivors of an explosion that wrecked the tanker E. J. Bullock at sea arrived here today. The seamen had been picked up in lifeboats by the tanker 0. M. Bernuth, which turned them over to a Coast Guard cutter off the base here.
The Holland-America liner Noordam, a 10,000-ton combination freight and passenger vessel of a type hitherto unknown in this port, arrived yesterday from Rotterdam on her maiden voyage.
Major J. Madison Hare, World War chaplain and retired Baptist clergyman, died in his cottage here yesterday after a protracted illness from a stroke. He was 78 ears old.

A man identified tentatively by cards in his clothing as Richard Henry Winsatt, 63 years old, of 511 Eleventh Street, N. W., Washington, drove his car off a string piece under the Triborough Bridge near 125th Street last night' and was drowned in the East River.

The Argentine Republic has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering an issue of $25,000,000 of ten-year sinking fund 41/2 per cent external bonds

Raymond J. Garrick, 18th Division, 8th Detective District, designated as Third Grade Detective. Assignment to duty as chauffeur discontinued. To take effect 8 A. M., Oct, 8: From precincts indicated to 18th Division, designated as Third Grade Detectives: John A. Allen, 20th Pct.; John G. Mullane, 114th Pct.
A map showing the sections of Sudeten Czechoslovakia authorized by the international commission sitting here for immediate occupation by German troops was made public tonight.

The will of Cardinal Hayes, Archbishop of New York, who died Sept. 4 in his sleep at his Summer home at St. Joseph's, N. Y., filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday disclosed that he bequeathed his estate to three Bishops of the Roman Catholic Church in accordance with the canon laws. The value of the estate was not declared.

A corps of more than 2,000 Boy Scouts trained in safety and traffic work will serve as safety monitors at the World's Fair, Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation, announced yesterday. Members of the corps also will form guards of honor for the reception of distinguished guests at the fair and on other special occasions.

Prince and Princess Alexandre de Caraman-Chimay have come to the Pierre from Tranquillity Farm, their place in Allamuchy, N. J. Mrs. Walter Eyre Lambert will be at 157 East Seventy-second Street for the Winter. Dr. and Mrs. Albertus Adair Moore have returned to 277 Park Avenue from Five Oaks Farm, their countryy home in Winchester, Va.

An alert and fast-charging Marquette eleven broke up Southern Methodist's famed aerial attack tonight at Soldier Field, then converted a blocked punt into a surprise 7-to-0 triumph before a crowd of 25,000.

More than 1,000,000 jobless New Workers received $73,517,057 in State unemployment insurance checks in the first nine months of this year, according to figures made public yesterday at the regional: offices of the Federal Social Security Board. About 60 per cent of the money went to persons in this city.
Thomas L. Lyon, Professor Emeritus of Agronomy at Cornell University, died today after a short illness. He was 69 years old.

The cotton trade evened up accounts yesterday in preparation for the government's crop forecast, which will be issued at 11 o'clock this morning. Fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange here were irregular and in a narrow range.

Magistrate Anna Moskowitz Kross, who has served notice of her intention of running independently for the Supreme Court in the first judicial district, which includes Manhattan and the Bronx, announced yesterday that Mayor La Guardia would be the guest speaker at a campaign luncheon for her next Friday at 1 P. M. in the Hotel Commodore.

Those planning to hunt in New Hampshire or Massachusetts had better communicate with the fish and game departments of these States before completing plans, as the hunting season has been closed in sections of both Commonwealths due to fire hazards.

Scenes of religious enthusiasm such as had not been witnessed here since March, when Germany annexed Austria, occurred tonight inside St. Stephan's Cathedral, where Theodor Cardinal Innitzer, Archbishop of Vienna, who supported the annexation, preached to a crowded congregation on the occasion of the "Rose Wreath" festival of youth.

Dr. Edna Zinn Juchhoff, a surgeon and health lecturer, died today in the Jefferson Park Hospital at the age of 58. Dr. Juchhoff was the first woman to be graduated from William and Mary College and studied medicine at several universities.

Henry Goldman, retired senior partner of Goldman, Sachs Co., bankers, left a net estate of $5,425,485 when he died April 4, 1937, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. His widow and three children are the principal beneficiaries.

William Proctor Van Heusen of New Rochelle, former partner in the stock brokerage firm of Braasch, Van Heusen Co., at 120 Broadway, New York, died today in the New Rochelle Hospital after an illness of seven months. He was 40 years old.
Realty men and builders have been speculating on the possible effect the East River Drive will have on the development of the adjacent land.

Substantial salary and wage cuts for its employes were announced today by the Canadian pacificc Railway as an inevitable result of failure of gencial traffic volume, and particuiarly of grain traffic to improve to the extent expected earlier in the year.

President Roosevelt indicated today that he would propose to the next session of Congress that Federal counter-espionage activities be intensified and coordinated to protect the nation's military and naval defense plans from the prying eyes of foreign agents.

Maxwell Low, operator, has purchased from the 625 West 113th Street Corporation, through Armstrong Brothers, brokers, the onestory taxpayer on the southeast corner of 183d Street and Jerome Avenue, the Bronx.

Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in the Federal Court, Brooklyn, denied yesterday an application by counsel for the Brooklyn Trust Company for an order directing that the plan of reorganization for the Prudence Company, Inc.,
Franchises for the distribution of National Distillers Old Taylor and Old Grand Dad brands of bottledin-bond Kentucky bourbon whiskies have been granted to a selected number of distributors in States

Bruiser Kinard, recovered from his ankle injury, was back at tackle in the Brooklyn Dodgers' line-up today as the team took part in its final drill in preparation for the encounter with the Pittsburgh Pirates Sunday in Pittsburgh.

Swept aside by a brilliant University of Detroit passing attack in the opening period, Catholic University never recovered and went down to defeat, 27 to 0, tonight in an intersectional football encounter witnessed by a crowd of 20,000.

The Minister of Justice refused today to review a 62-year-old case in which the late Jean Richepin, French author, was sentenced to a month in prison for lines allegedly offensive to public morals in his famous poem "Song of the Beggars."
Dr. Joaquin Ochotorena, magistrate of the Supreme Court, tonight was appointed Secretary of the Interior by President Federico Laredo Bru.
Caleb J. Milne 4th has leased from Mrs. Edwin C. Hoyt for occupany the private residence at 166 East Eighty-first Street, through Beatrice Renwick and Pease Ellinan, Inc., co-brokers.

Anis Fuleihan's second piano concerto will be one of the new works to be presented this season by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under the baton of John Barbirolli, who returns to New York from Europe tomorrow on the S. S. Normandie.
Bonds crept moderately higher in subdued trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

Collection ratios on open credit accounts of department stores showed a 1.2 per cent increase for August, 1938, as against the same month last year, and a decrease of about 2.5 per cent from July this year, the Commerce Department reports.

Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for Governor, in his opening radio speech of the campaign attacked the O'Connell machine in Albany, yesterday, accusing it of registration frauds. Mr. Dewey served notice that in later speeches...

The Apparel and Accessories Associates, Inc., is completing arrangements with the New York World's Fair, 1939, Inc., for the purchase of the building planned for the textile industry, which is now nearing completion, Joseph Love, president of the Associates,

At the request of the San Francisco Stock Exchange the Securities and Exchange Commission has postponed further from Oct. 11 to Nov. 15 the effective date of on order granting an application of the Market Street Railway Company to delist its $100 par value 6 per cent cumulative preference stock from that Exchange.
Mrs. DeWitt Untermeyer of Hollywood captured the New Jersey State golf championship today when she defeated Miss Gail Wild of Baltusrol, 7 and 5, in the 36-hole final at the Plainfield Country Club.

Charles F. Clarkson, 49 years old, of Freehold, president of the Charles Hellmuth Printing Ink Corporation of 154 West Eighteenth Street, New York City, was injured fatally and Edward F. Lynch, 48, of 2,395 Valentine Avenue, the Bronx, a salesman for the concern, was injured critically when the automobile in which they were riding crashed into a stanchion of the Elizabeth Avenue Viaduct, in State Highway Route 25 here, early today.

The indications are for partly cloudy and warmer weather today and for partly cloudy weather with little change in temperature tomorrow, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock last night.
The British pick-a-back plane Mercury was trying early today to establish her position, in a series, of radio messages, after a long distance record attempt from Dundee, Scotland.
Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein of Newark will open the two-day conference of the Committee for Industrial Organization at Krueger Auditorium here at 10:30 o'clock tomorrow morning.

The Federal Government came to the support today of Kansas and Kentucky officials who are insisting to the Supreme Court that ratifications of the Child Labor Amendment by the Legislatures of those two States last year are valid.

Pedestrians on Park Avenue were caught in a flurry of excitement yesterday morning when two police emergency trucks and several radio and detective cars converged on "The Little Shop of T. Azeez" a few minutes after two armed men

Reports of the great European State banks, covering their operations of the last few weeks, give some idea of the commotion in the credit market when war over Czechoslovakia was still thought imminent.

William C. Sniffen, 37 years old, former bookkeeper and cashier of the Irvington Buick Company of Irvington, N. J., who was sought for nine months on an indictment charging embezzlement of $2,300 from the concern, was committed here today
Members trading in round lots for their own account on the New York Stock Exchange in the week 19.92 pre ended on Sept. 17 represented 19.92 per cent of total volume,
A high official of the Treasury said today that much of the more than $600,000,000 of foreign money which fled here from the European crisis was flowing into investments in this country.
The Erie Railroad's executive board decided today to ask for a second three-month extension of the deadline for filing a plan of reorganization.

Harvard University announced tonight that it was "Investigating with a view to taking disciplinary action" the "riot" of last evening when a group of Harvard freshmen attempted to break up a parade by the band of the Cambridge Post Juniors, American Legion.

TO THE EDITOR OF THF NEW YORK TIMES The news in THE TIMES of Oct. 4 that Mr. Roosevelt has found chestnut saplings on his estate at Hyde Park is especially interesting to those of us who remember regretfully the days when "chestnutting" was a major Autumn sport in the country and when the trees added much to the glory of the woods.

In a letter to Secretary Morgenthau answering his questions, Chairman Sheppard of the Senate Committee on Campaign Expenditures declared today that it was a violation of the law for any officeholder to make a contribution to an individual candidate.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Oct. 1 totaled 697,938 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 22,385 cars, or 3.3 per cent, more than for the preceding week; 145,923 cars, or 17.3 per cent, less than for the corresponding week last year, and 121,188 cars, or 14.8 per cent, less than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Funeral services for Arthur H. Jones, Mayor of Kearny, who died here on Tuesday, were held tonight in the John B. Crane Son Funeral Home here. State Senator Lester H. Clee, pastor of the Second Presbyterian Church at Newark, conducted the services.

Harold Riner, 27 years old, of 5,407 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, who was arrested at the Jamaica race track and charged with tampering with race horses and attempted burglary, pleaded not guilty yesterday before Queens County Judge Thomas Downs and was remanded for trial Oct. 24.

Compulsory swimming courses in the New York City high schools were proposed yesterday by Ellsworth B. Buck, vice president of the Board of Education. A formal recommendation to this effect will be given to the board's instructional affairs committee soon.

ARMY TRANSPORT SERVICE, NEW YORK, N. Y.--Carpenter, $1,272 a year, including $192 subsistence and $60 quarters; deck engineer, $1,590 a year, including $270 subsistence and $60 quarters; lineman, $1,272 a year, including $192 subsistence and $60 quarters: third steward. $1,392 a year including $192 subsistence and $60

Mike Turnesa, brother of Willie, national amateur champion, and Al Brosch, pro at the elaborate Bethpage Park public links at Farmingdale, will clash in tomorrow's thirty-six-hole final round of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship.

The three three-story flats with stores at 112-118 Tonnele Avenue, Jersey City, N. J., on a plot 105 by 99 feet, assessed at $86,100, were sold by the Provident Institution for Savings of Jersey City to the JenFay Realty Corporation for $55,000. The bank took back a purchase money mortgage for $49,500.
Stockholders of the United Electric Coal Company approved yesterday proposed loans aggregating $2,100,000 with which to pay creditors and increase funds for mining development.
A new superliner similar to the Normandie, but with greater passenger and cargo capacity and increased power which may make it the speed queen of the North Atlantic, will be built by the French Line,

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Mary Louise Keane, daughter of Mrs. Timothy A. Keane of this city and the late Mr. Keane of Albany, to Henry Reginald Newsholme, son of Mr. and Mrs. David H. Newsholme of New York.

Irving Goodman, 43 years old, of 2,150 Creston Avenue, the Bronx, known to the police as "Sol the Mock," pleaded not guilty yesterday when arraigned before Kings County Judge William O'Dwyer on a charge of extortion. He was remanded in $5,000 bail for trial.

Carter Kyle ran back a punt 65 yards for a touchdown in the closing seconds of the first period to enable Patchogue to beat Huntington High, 7--0, tonight. Captain Bob Mazzotti converted the extra point on a placement.

As its first production. the recently organized Yiddish Dramatic Players presented last night at the Irving Place Theatre a domestic drama, "'Round the Family Table," which might be called What Every Jewish Family (and some others) Knows.

Mrs. Alice Moore of 2,028 Diamond Street, Philadelphia, was found dead-today of a bullet wound in the head on the grave of her husband, Raymond Moore, in Ewing Church Cemetery, Ewing Township, near here.

The principal foreign exchanges continued to weaken yesterday. Primarily the movement involved a renewed wave of distrust of the franc, but the transfer of funds away from francs and into dollars was, as usual, carried out through the London market with consequent pressure upon sterling.
Miss Caroline Deming Camp, for many years active in social work in Brooklyn, died yesterday at her home, 257 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, after an illness of several months. She was 75 years old.
The sixteen-story loft and store building at 15-17 West Thirty-sixth Street was bid in by the Greenwich Savings Bank at auction yesterday for $325,000.

Loosing a powerful running attack underneath an effective aerial barrage, the University of Georgia Bulldogs crushed the Purple Hurricanes of Furman University, 38 to 7, today to remain undefeated in the 1938 campaign.

The Swiss Federal Government, according to an apparently inspired Swiss press report, decided today to suspend for three months the publication, sale and distribution of the Journal des Nations, which ban will apply also to any newspaper that may be substituted for it.

Department store sales for the week ended Oct. 1 were 15 per cent lower than for the same week one year ago, and for the four weeks ended Oct. 1 they were 10 per cent lower than for the corresponding period in 1937, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

With their battered foe securely in tow, Marse Joe McCarthy's Yankees move into the Stadium today for the third clash of the world series struggle with the Cubs and for what points unmistakably to a swift, decisive dash to their coveted third straight title.
The sixty-family apartment building at 500 West 140th Street is now 100 per cent rented, according to Blumstein Management Company, managing agents.

The thirteenth in the series of Ivy League football clashes between F Harvard and Cornell since 1890 tomorrow is expected to be just as unlucky for the Crimson as was the twelfth, which was played twenty-three years ago, when the allAmerica star, the late Charley Barrett, led the last Big Red team from Ithaca into the stadium. The game is likely to draw a crowd of 25,000.

Plans for several apartment buildings and new groups of singlefamily dwellings were filed in the city yesterday. In the list were two apartment houses for Manhattan and one for Brooklyn. The borough lists follow:

The marriage of Miss Marie Adeline Gerhardt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Herman Gerhardt of Brooklyn, to Dr. William Robert Griffin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Griffin of Sayville, took place here this afternoon in the rectory of St. Patrick's Church. The Rev. Jerome H. Ludder officiated.

Whether the Federal Government is to become the chief support and guide of pure scientific research was a question brought up today at a gathering of scientists for the fiftieth anniversary of the Abbott Laboratories in North Chicago.
Eugene Miles Prentice, vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, died of a heart attack last night in his home here. He was 53 years old.
THE Metropolitan Opera Satururday matinees will be broadcast for the eighth consecutive season through WEAF's coast-tocoast hook-up beginning Nov. 26.

While the world's attention has been distracted during recent weeks by the danger of a titanic war in Europe, the sanguinary struggles in Spain and China have been dragging along through new and bloodier scenes toward their yet doubtful climaxes.

Although some commentators in Ohio have compared the debates to be held between Senator Robert J. Bulkley, Democratic candidate for re-election, and Robert A. Taft, his Republican rival, to the historic ones between Abraham Lincoln and Stephen A. Douglas eighty years ago, the people of Ohio do not seem to be convinced as yet that they are in that class.

Miss Barbara Ruth Gillion, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas V. Gillion of Flushing, Queens, was married to Douglas Howard Miller, son of Mrs. C. M. Hinman and Donlald H. Miller of New York, yesterday afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church of Flushing.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

Seton Hall prep and Manhattan College freshmen played to a 7-7 tie today. The youthful Jaspers scored in the third period when Castiglin shot a pass to Smoleski, who lateraled to Baron, who in turn tossed to Allen and the latter ran 20 yards down the side lines to score.

A renewal of the demand for United States dollars, particularly from French sources, sent the rate today to $4.785-16 in terms of the pound sterling. Francs, rigidly controlled, closed unchanged at 17829-32. The pound yesterday was $4.79.

T. S. ELIOT insists the first duty of fiction is to provide a durable and peculiar pleasure, but it must serve certain subsidiary purposes as well, chief among which is providing a sort of national portrait gallery.

Humiliated beyond even their worst fears, the Cubs reached what seemed to be the lowest point in despair yesterday as they swallowed their third straight setback by the rampaging Yankees. And today the Chicagoans face what may well be their fourth defeat in a row in the world series.

Miss Laura Creighton Palmer, daughter of Leigh C. Palmer, former Rear Admiral of the United States Navy, and Mrs. Palmer of Darien, Conn., was married here yesterday afternoon to Wilfred Ernest Shaw, son of Mrs. Henry W. Shaw of Cape Cod, Mass., and the late Mr. Shaw.

THERE is an old Creole adage which says in effect: "A man with a proper philosophy enjoys a proper digestion." The ever-increasing number of Autumn tourists now being attracted to the Evangeline country of Louisiana, which Huey Long's network of modern roads has made easily accessible, are discovering that the gastronomical satisfactions derived from Creole cookery may be, in themselves, sufficiently stimulating to give man a proper philosophy.

A bit of old Williamsburg, Va., has been brought to Brooklyn by the Mothers Club of the Flatbush Young Men's Christian Association. By introducing the artistic perfection of more than a century ago into the setting of a clubhouse for young people, the members of this organization see a symbolic reconciliation of the differences between the generations represented.

To a question every one is asking abroad-How is Czechoslovakia settling down within her new restricted frontiers?-it is not yet possible to give an answer for the good reason that on one yet knows what these frontiers are going to be.

By a strange quip of irony, the abbreviated Czechoslovak State about to emerge from the reshuffle ordered by the Munich four-power conference may soon find itself-the willing political and economic vassal of the Reich.
TODAY Chamber Music, by Samuel Gardner, violinist; Charles Krane, 'cellist, and Coenraad V. Bos, pianist, in the first of a weekly series: WNYC, 11-11:45 A. M.
With only seconds of play remainIng, Substitute Tony De Beneditto took a deflected forward pass and ran 20 yards to give Staten Island Academy a 6-6 tie with Brooklyn Friends yesterday.

William Tyler Page, who has watched national political fireworks from an office under the Capitol dome for more than fifty years, is certain that Congress is about to tighten up Federal campaign expenditure laws.

Kenny Powell, elusive Negro halfback, staged a one-man show before 4,000 onlookers at Ryan Stadium today to lead New Rochelle High School to a 33-6 football victory over Port Chester High in a W. I. A. A. game.

The annual Columbus Day parade under the auspices- of the New York Chapter, Knights of Columbus, will be held Wednesday at 2 P. M., from the chapter headquarters, Eighth Avenue and Fifty-first Street, to Columbus Circle.

To the Drama Editor: Permit two complaints as to Thornton Wilder's incomparably good play "Our Town." First, I resent Mr. Wilder's having left us, although he says we have so little understanding, alone in the cemetery with the impenetrable stars.. especially bleak seen through the unresponsive eyes of his catatonic dead.
GLOUCESWTER, Mass. ANOTHER ten years and Cap'n Ben Pine could not get a crew of ablebodied Gloucestermen to man a Gloucester schooner. Maybe five years.

The big Brahma steers continued to give some of the greatest thrills at the rodeo in Madison Square Garden yesterday, but it was in the wild cow milking contest that the most momentous event occurred, from a statistical point of view.

Mayor Wilson S. Brower died today at his home at 561 Valley Road after an illness of several weeks. He was 49 years old. Mr. Brower underwent an operation at Mt. Sinai Hospital in Manhattan on Aug. 29. He returned to his home two weeks ago.

IT is odd how ideas change A little more than fifteen years ago most of us were complacently snickering over the stuffy dullness of Queen Victoria as Lytton Strachey caught it on the nibs of his sardonic pen. Those were days when we were pretty sure of ourselves. and willing to laugh at any one.
President Roosevelt spent a quiet Saturday at his home today in the company of his old friends, Professor and Mrs. Felix Frankfurter.

Students and faculty have formed a photography Club at Keuka College to further their knowledge in their hobby. Using an abandoned room off the physics laboratory, students have built a darkroom with an enlarger and other equipment.
A comely 22-year-old co-ed is supreme leader of 6,000,000 farm women who are assisting their husbands and sons in the guerrilla armies of North China.

A communique by the Foreign Office this morning denies the accusation of the Ecuadorian Foreign Minister that in suspending the boundary conference at Washington Peru is guilty of an "anti-juridic and surprising act."

Frozen in by ice seven feet thick, the three-masted schooner General A. W. Greely spent last Winter off Reindeer Point in Northern Greenland while in a camp on shore the members of the MacGregor Arctic expedition conducted research into the origin and movements of Far Northern "air masses" and their influence on weather conditions throughout the North American continent.

The largest number of independent retail grocers ever to participate in a single promotional event will take part in the "National Retail Grocers Week" campaign opening tomorrow, according to the National Association of Retail Grocers, sponsors of the event.

The department of education of Manhattan College announced yesterday the organization of a Student-Teachers League under the sponsorship of Brother Amian, F. S. C., head of the faculty of the education course.

A petition accusing the publishers of Wilkes-Barre's four newspapers of negotiating in "bad faith" with representatives of the American Newspaper Guild and of "locking out" the striking guild members was filed with the National Labor Relations Board in Philadelphia today.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Elizabeth Eder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Eder of this place, to Ernest Hughes Wyche took place at noon today in St. John's Episcopal Church here. The Rev. Donald MacAdie, rector of the church, officiated.

ASTOR--Sadie, suddenly, on Oct. 7, 1938, widow, of Max Astor, leaving surviving three sons, Samuel, Louis, Isidor. Deceased, Sadie Astor, a member of Socho. chower Lodge, I. O. B. A., No. 384. Funeral from Park West Memorial Chapel, 115 West 79th St., Manhattan, Sunday, 11 A. M. Interment at Mount Judah Cemetery.

EXHIBITIONS of antiques were once held mainly for the delight of the collector. Now they have become events of interest to interior decorators and less professional home decorators, who find in them many suggestions for decorative accessories with individuality.

The resignation of James T. Gerould as librarian of Princeton University and the appointment of Lawrence Heyl as acting librarian were announced here this week. Mr. Gerould, who has held the position since 1920, is suffering from ill health.
Presidential approval of 112 PWA sewerage projects, including thirty-nine in New York State and four each in New Jersey and Connecticut, was announced today by Secretary Ickes, PWA Administrator.

Justice Gustave W. M. Wieboldt of New York Court of Special Sessions and a former State chairman of the Steuben Society of America, tonight urged that the society members pledge themselves to fight to its extinction the German-American Bund.

A championship match with neither gate nor purse will open off this port Tomorrow morning when two fishing schooners and their crews go out to make sport of their hazardous calling in what probably will be the last contest for the International Fishermen's Trophy.

Leasing of Adirondack land holdings of big lumber and pulp companies for private hunting preserves continues. This week the Oval Wood Dish Corporation of Tupper Lake leased nearly all of its 50,000 acres to several hunting and fishing clubs.

THE development of a new vibration study technique that has brought about revolutionary improvement in the design not only of aircraft propellers but also of engines and other parts was announced last week by the Hamilton Standard Propellers division of United Aircraft Corporation.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., Oct. 10: PATROLMEN--Alfred Barbuto, from 60th Precinct to 64th Precinct; Aristide U. E. Giordano, from 64th Precinct to 60th Precinct. Temporary Assignments PATROLMAN--James J. Brady, from 18th Precinct to Quartermaster's Department, assigned to clerical duty for 16 days, from 8 A. M., Oct. 16.
Joseph Stalin sent congratulations today to three ace Soviet women fliers for establishing an international distance record for women.
ERNEST HEMINGWAY in the preface to his "The Fifth Column and the First Forty-Nine," published this month by Scribner's, tells of his work on the play in Madrid during a bombardment.

The Navy football team completed the first phase of its season, three home games with elevens from the Old Dominion, by defeating the University of Virginia today, 33 to 0. The excellence of the Annapolis running attack stood out and made it unnecessary to resort to the air often.

Credit men will henceforth require greater caution on the part of certified public accountants against the possibility of defalcations or falsifications by their employes, it was suggested last week, when concern over this problem was given more than usual attention because of discussion at an SEC examination into the case of Interstate Hosiery Mills.

Birth control and reduced immigration are more to blame for lower citrus prices than overproduction of crops, 150 citrus ranchers and packers agreed today after a talk by John B. Schneider, agricultural economics specialist of the University of California.

Menasha Skulnik, producer and star in the Yiddish Theatre, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in Federal court, alleging that he had no assets and that his liabilities total $21,026. He gave as his address the Public Theatre, 66 Second Avenue.
Wake Forest scored a spectacular victory over South Carolina, 2019: in the final minutes of a Southern Conference battle that kept the 6,500 spectators in a frenzy.

Persons interested in the East Side House Settlement and its auxiliary, the Winifred Wheeler Day Nursery, have taken over for the benefit of the organizations the lower tier boxes at the Metropolitan Opera House for a series of artistic events to be held there during the season.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were in substantially larger volume than during the preceding period. The announcements were well diversified as to type of loan involved, including one of the largest single public utility retirements in many weeks.

One of the most interesting old Dutch landmarks in Bergen County, N. J., has just changed hands. The rambling red sandstone house in Tenafly which belonged to the Westervelt family for 179 years was sold last week by Richard M. Sulzer of New Canaan, Conn., to George Price, artist, who will occupy it as his studio and home. Swift Kerr, Inc., of Tenafly were brokers in the deal.

Mr. and Mrs. Pierpont V. Davis of this place gave a tea this afternoon at their home here to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Gabriella Davis, and Miss Mary Pophan Stevenson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Stevenson of New York, formerly of Ossining.

HOLLYWOOD. THERE have been several instances in which studios, confronted with a meritorious picture that failed to fit into the usual formulas employed to exploit films, have been confounded to such an extent that the publicity departments have thrown up their hands and allowed the offerings to go out into the cold world and shift for themselves without the benefit of press agentry genius.

A system of providing medical aid for the less fortunate on a basis of fees arranged according to ability to pay will be put into effect in Pinellas County Jan. 1 under a program ratified today by the County Medical Association.

George U. Harvey, Queens Borough President, declared last night that former Supreme Court Justice Charles Poletti was an "out and out Communist and a spokesman for the American Labor party." He added that if the Democratic ticket is successful in November and Governor Lehman decides later to run for the Senate "we will have a Red for Governor."
Tradition and an alert Southern California team wrecked Ohio State's hopes of football glory today before a crowd of 62,578, the Trojans winning, 14 to 7, although outgained in every department.

Peddie School scored in the first and third periods to defeat Newman School, 13--6, on the latter's field today. Al Hanover, Peddie backfield star, tallied both touchdowns on short runs. Newman's lone tally was son.
Mrs. F. J. Mulqueen of Toronto won the Canadian women's open golf championship today, defeating Miss Clarrie Tiernan of Dublin on the thirtysixth hole, 1 up.

The Curtis High School crosscountry team, a winner last week, added to its prestige when it scored an easy victory in the third division of the Public Schools Athletic League group runs at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

Pushing over three touchdowns after Lewis of Susquehanna had booted a field goal to take the lead, Drexel came from behind today to win, 19 to 3. Walt Ehmling went over from the 2-yard line for Drexel's score, climaxing a 69-yard drive.

Gardens on Parade, the horticultural section of the New York World's Fair, will bring together in one well-planned planting, carefully arranged to provide the visitor with a maximum of information at a minimum expenditure of time, new, rare and interesting plants from all over the world.

The annual memorial service for members of the Fire Department who died last year will be held at 3:15 P. M. today at the Firemen's Monument, Riverside Drive and 100th Street. Seven members of the uniformed force were killed in the discharge of duty and thirty-seven died from natural causes.

LONDON. A NEW attempt is being made to solve the country-house problem in Great Britain, and negotiations under the scheme are being carried on between the National Trust and a number of country-house owners. All over England the countryside changes rapidly.

Held to 3 points in a blazing opening half by a fast, scrappy Princeton team that came within a foot of scoring a touchdown, Dartmouth struck with lightning rapidity in the third and fourth quarters today to win its first major test of the season, 22-0.

AN average cross-section of America is to be found in the small towns. Everybody knows that, of course, but many things that "everybody knows" have been shown to be wrong. Now that fact is confirmed by the National Resources Committee report on consumer incomes.
IF your dentist pulls the wrong tooth or your physician sends you smaller bills than you owe, don't be alarmed-they might have been thinking of Mozart and Mendelssohn.
The appeal from students, faculty and parents of students that the Union College Phychology Department begin formal "vocational guidance" for undergraduates has been realized this year.

Four creditors of Marguerite Basil Miles, a former wife of the late Colonel Henry M. Rogers, railroad man who inherited a vast Standard Oil fortune from his father, filed an involuntary petition in bankruptcy against her yesterday in Federal court for debts totaling $2,882.

MANHATTAN ASCHEIM, JULES (Sept. 29). Estate, more than $1,000. To Hilda Ascheim, widow, executrix, 65 W. 54th St., $5,000 and life estate in residue; Joseph J. Ascheim. son, same address: Joan A. Biel, daughter, Brookline, Mass.; Mildred A. Masback, daughter, 125 W. 76th St., remainder interest; seven minor bequests.

There are ten foreign scholars at Barnard College this year. Six of them, Agnes Adamy, Amalia da Costa, Tordis Hugo, Gaby Tartoue, Glafyra Rangel and Ana del Valle, are new students in residence at the college.

Sukkoth, the Feast of the Tabernacles, the Jewish festival of thanksgiving for the fruits of the harvest and for the bounty of God, will be ushered in this sundown with special services in temples and synagogues. The observance lasts nine days.

Stocks closed strong, near highest levels in a year, with trading the largest for a Saturday since July 2: turnover, 1,113,130 shares. Corporation bonds higher, United States Government issues easier, foreign bonds steady; transactions. $4,839,500.

The recent visit of Secretary Wallace of the Department of Agriculture to the Southwest to whip up support for the Agricultural Adjustment Act has created reactions both favorable and unfavorable to governmental farm programs.

Miss Evelyn Treat Voorhees, daughter of Mrs. John Brownlee Voorhees of this city and the late Rev. Dr. Voorhees, one-time pastor of the Asylum Hill Congregational Church of Hartford, was married to Arthur Brewster Emmons 3d of Dover, Mass., at noon today at the home of the bride's mother here.

One of the largest galleries in up-State spaniel field trial history saw Robert McLean's Flight of Falcon Hill win the all-age springer stake in the seventh annual meeting of the Albany Spaniel Field Trial Club at Feurabush today.

Expressing strong approval of the proposed revision of store organization which would switch emphasis from the buying to the selling function, Ira A. Hirschmann said yesterday that this set-up is vital to the progress of department stores, "whose markets are now being carved up like Czechoslovakia by intense specialty shop and chain store competition."

EISEN--Mr. and Mrs. Leo, announce the bar mltzvah of their son, David, Oct. 15, 10:30, Free Synagogue 40 West 68th St. At home, 118 West 79th St., 4-7. GOLDSTEIN--Mr. and Mrs. George Goldstein, 144 Hastings St., Manhattan Beach, announce the confirmation of their son, Sander, at the Manhattan Beach Jewish Center, on Saturday, Oct. 15, at 9 A. M.

Cap and Gown Day, known at many other colleges as Moving-Up Day, was observed at Elmira College yesterday. The address was delivered by Carl Carmer, author of "Listen for a Lonesome Drum," "Stars Fell on Alabama," and other books, who spoke on the subject "American Mythology."

A dinner dance for the benefit of Five Points House will be held Oct. 18 at the formal opening of the Trianon Room of the Ambassador. More than 300 Children of destitute families are cared for' by the organizatioh at Pomona, in Rockland County, and in boarding homes in the suburbs of New York.

With Irving (Shine) Hall accounting for two touchdowns and a try for point, Brown University today conquered Lafayette, 20 to 0, before about 13,000 football fans. Lafayette won the toss and chose to defend the north goal, with a strong favoring wind at its back.
Every three minutes on the average, during 1937, a forest fire started in the United States, but the year's total of losses was considerably under that of 1936.

Two fountain-pen dealers, two dealers in medical preparations and a vendor of a disinfectant have entered into stipulations with the Federal Trade Commission to discontinue certain misleading representations in the advertising and sale of their products, the commission announced today.

IT seems, these days, that the easiest way to become a screen actor--or, at any rate, to be listed in the cast--is to become a columnist first. Walter Winchell, Jimmie Fidler, Louella O. Parsons, Paul Gallico, Sidney Skolsky and Ed Sullivan are only a few of the syndicated scriveners who have found their way to the screen via commenting on Hollywood.

Public opinion continues to manifest concern regarding the aftermath of the Czechoslovak partition and there are demands for a coordinated program of measures assuring Rumanian independence, especially in view of Hungarian revisionist demands.
Reliable sources reported today that Karl Ritter, the German Ambassador, had been declared "persona non grata" by the Government of Brazil.
Mr. and Mrs. Samuel F. B. Morse of Pebble Beach, Calif., have come to the Ritz-Carlton. Mrs. John Davis Schoonmaker'is in Albany, where she will pass the Winter.

Overcoming a weight advantage of twenty-one pounds by clever infighting, Otis Thomas of St. Louis gained the decision over Yustin Sirutis of Jamaica in the feature tenround boxing contest at the Rockland Palace in Harlem last night. A crowd of 2,000 attended.

The Arnold College Terriers trounced Wagner College's football team, 25 to 0, today. Paced by Bill Pudvah, who tallied twice; Sam Izzo and Ed Sylvia, the victors tallied three times in the third quarter and once in the final chapter.
Felix Spatella's Wise Prince today scored his third consecutive victory at Rockingham Park in the General Greene Purse.

Initial meetings in three news seminars conducted for women's clubs in the metropolitan district will be held this week. At the Woman's Club of Garden City, Mrs. Alfred G. Mohrman will act as chairman for a meeting tomorrow on the subject of the Far East. Speakers will be Mrs. Austin Scott, Mrs. A. H. Boardman and Mrs. Budd K. Strader.

A fouryear cause in hotel administration has been started this Fall at the University of New Hampshire, to "train selected young men and women on a semi-vocational plan and to contribute to the further development of recreational opportunities in New Hampshire."

The first sections of the areas comprised in Zone No. 5 of the Sudetenland, the zone assigned to Germany by the International Commission sitting in Berlin, were occupied by Cerman troops today and the high command announced that the remainder would be taken up after noon tomorrow, thus completing the entire occupation by Monday (Oct. 10), as prescribed, in the Munich agreement.

A stand against strikes by WPA workers was taken today by Aubrey Williams, Acting Works Progress Administrator, in the face of a situation in Cleveland and Akron, where organized truck operators on WPA projects are threatening to strike.

THE annual Westchester Music Festival will not be held this Spring. This was decided at the recent Fall meeting of the board of directors of the Westchester Music Festival Association, Mrs. Valentine E. Macy, president, at which plans for 1938-39 were discussed and results of the last three years' activities reviewed. It was unanimously voted that the festival be postponed until a year from this coming May.

What is described as the largest single order for radiators ever placed for a privately-financed housing project has just been closed by the American Radiator Company for installation in the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's garden apartment colony under construction on the old Catholic Protectory property in the Bronx.
City College, after twice being repulsed inside the 5-yard line in the opening period, could not hold off the allaround power of St. Joseph's College, and lost today, 27--7.

Now that Europe has a peace-at-any-price respite of a few months or a few years, as the case may be, the armchair historians and self-appointed experts face a really tough job. Especially is this true of those who wish to tell a story of how simple it all was and how the outcome could have been foreseen from the very start if one had looked at it from a really skillful point of view.
SAN REMO. IN the Casino opera season here keen interest was aroused by Gian-Carlo Menotti's comic opera, "Amelia Goes to the Ball," presented in the Italian version, styled "Amelia al Ballo."

THOSE who look to Mr. Beals, that seasoned traveler through the length and breadth of Latin America, merely for warnings of sinister machinations of Nazi, Fascist, Japanese, Communist and what-not propaganda in the countries to the south of us, will be disappointed.

With the deadline only a few hours away, the Cambridge Committee for Plan E won its battle tonight to have the referendum for a City Manager and proportional representation appear on the November ballot.

The "red caps" who carry baggage for passengers at railroad stations, whether they receive salaries or depend for their remuneration solely on tips, were classified as railway employes by the Interstate Commerce Commission today and therefore come within the provisions of the Railway Labor Act.

The marriage of Miss Kathryn E. Herren, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Herren of this city, to Otto W. Chadbourne of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Chadbourne of Fairhaven, Mass., took place here at noon today in the Cathedral of the Incarnation.
Maurice Chevalier, internationally known music hall and cinema actor, has been made Chevalier of the Legion of Honor by the French Government.

There was a decided improvement in investment sentiment here last week. The passing, at least temporarily, of the European war clouds not only stimulated renewed activity on the part of investment bankers and prospective borrowers but also tended to break the spell that had virtually closed the outlet for new securities.

Amherst College routed Tufts today, 34 to 7, in the first Lord Jeff football victory over Tufts since 1911. The teams battled on even terms in the first period, but Amherst with a burst of power in the second completely outclassed the home team.

Williams College freshmen faced two innovations this Fall. The library arranged for them a three-day orientation program which included displays, lectures, explanations of equipment and a final examination.

A question involving a knotty problem in patriotic behavior has been posed by a Queens housewife and considered inconclusively by Mayor La Guardia, according to correspondence made public yesterday by the municipal radio station WNYC.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.--The Clarence H. Geist memorial tournament at the Seaview Golf Club next Friday, Saturday and Sunday is the sports feature here during the coming week.

Miss Katherine Morse, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond P. Morse of this plate, was married here this evening in the Church of St. James the Less to Frank Bartlett Harrington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred P. Harrington, also of Scarsdale, by the rector, the Rev. Allan Chalmers.

The 1,000,000 women eligible to vote in New York State who did not participate in the 1936 election are being courted by six women's organizations united in a nonpartisan movement to bring out the vote in November.

LONDON. WHO was the original Nosey Parker? Not long ago in the House of Commons a bill was proposed which, if passed into law, would have involved a good deal of bureaucratic prying into private lives.
Out of all the fears and hopes, the suspense, resignation, despair and the final unexpected joy which filled last week there has come this change in France:

President Lazaro Cardenas today ordered the Attorney General of Mexico to investigate public charges that his brother, Damaso Cardenas, was get ting rich from government contracts, including, specifically, one on the Mexico City-Guadalajara road.

Contending that the award of $434,561 which Supre meCourt Justice Charles B. McLaughlin recently approved as compensation to the Manhattan Railway Company for removal of the East Thirty-fourth Street elevated spur between Third Avenue and the East River was "excessive," the First Avenue Association appealed yesterday to the Board of Estimate to spread this assessment over the entire city instead of levgng it against owners in the Thirty-fourth Street district.
Gas pumped into the hold of a London freighter to exterminate rats ended the flight of two German Jews who were trying to reach the United States.
Fifty years after his invention of the system of shorthand that bears his name, Dr. John Robert Gregg was honored last night by nearly 1,000 persons at a golden jubilee dinner at the Hotel Commodore.

Minnesota opened its 1938 Big Ten title bid by defeating Purdue, 7 to 0. before 52,000 persons today, but the gallant Boilermakers fought so stubbornly that the Golden Gophers' famed power attack needed almost three complete periods to produce the winning score.

Coming back after intermission with a deadly passing game and a battling hidden-ball play, Vanderbilt University's Commodores wiped out an early lead and inflicted a 14-7 defeat on the University of Kentucky's less experienced sophomores.
J. Gilbert Hall of New York retained his title today in the annual Hot Springs invitation tennis tournament with a 6--2, 6--1, 6--1 victory over Percy L. Kynaston of Brooklyn.

The University of Rochester team defeated Rensselaer Poly by two touchdowns on the River Campus gridiron today and recorded its first football triumph in two years. The Yellow Jackets scored In the second and fourth quarters and made both conversions for a 14-0 count.
An exhibition of water-colors and gouaches by living Connecticut artists will be held in the Avery Memorial Print Rooms of the Wadsworth Atheneum from Nov. 12 through Dec. 4.

Right in the Council chamber in City Hall where he has seen his coalition majority crumble and his own authority dwindle to the mere possession of a gavel, Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, yesterday warmly praised the Democratically controlled Council as the "least dignified and the most disorderly, but the most vital legislative body in the country, not excepting Congress."

TWO of the season's cycles will be launched this week. Efrem Zimbalist, assisted by his accompanist Vladimin Sokoloff, will begin a series of sonata programs tomorrow night, and the Musical Art Quartet will give the first of six chamber music programs Tuesday evening.

THE Metropolitan championships, largest sectional tournament held in New York City, will begin tomorrow night at the Park Central Hotel. There will be five contests: "Amateur" pairs on Monday and Tuesday nights;

Valley Stream Central High School's football team maintained its lead in the South Shore Athletic League by defeating Westbury, 27--0, today. Captain Bill Orr scored two touchdowns, Bill Ward and Billy Bothman accounting for the other tallies.

BOSTON. AUTUMNAL holidays, interrupt ed in New England by the hurricane, are being observed by mournful motorists and chastened inn-keepers. Many of the larger hotels are open this week, and several will remain open through October. "Business as usual" is the slogan of resort and recreational interests.
The big Wall Street banks now have less than one-quarter of all their assets employed in the form of loans and discounts, an analysis of their statements of conditions on Sent. 30 shows.
Speakers for the Second Elementary Judging Course, sponsored by the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, have been announced by the chairman, Mrs. Bryce Disque. On Tuesday morning, Oct.

Miss Virginia Kimball Farrar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Dana Farrar of Glen Ridge, and Kenneth Irving Dadson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Irving Dadson, also of this place, were married tonight in Christ Episcopal Church of Bloomfield and Glen Ridge.
The fact that the future campus of Colby College on Mayflower Hill was once the floor of a prehistoric sea was disclosed by evidence unearthed in recent excavations for new buildings.

A varied program of festivities has been arranged in connection with the thirteenth annual race meet of the Monmouth County Hunt Racing Association, which will be held here next Saturday afternoon on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Amory L. Haskell.

Voters here will decide in a referendum to be held in connection with the November general election whether or not an application for erection of an apartment house building in East Broad Street shall be granted.

THE "Present Discontents" series in The Times Literary Supplement of which I wrote three weeks ago has had some interesting sequels. The three original articles, contributed by an anonymous author and critic contained no reference whatever to the machinery of book distribution.
Women wearing tailleurs with mixed tweed skirts and colored leather jackets have been seen walking in the Bois in the morning.
Bill Meyer's Kansas City Blues made a barbecue of the Newark Bears tonight and 15,054 fans who sat in on the feast at Colonel Jacob Ruppert's Western stadium went into a state bordering on delirium.

Demonstrating the rare versatility of their attack, the Yankees swung into high gear from practically a standing start as they brought the current world series to the Stadium yesterday and then moved so swiftly that a gathering of 55,236 scarcely had time to appreciate all that had happened.

A field goal by Joe Cody from the 5-yard line in the third period gave Montclair State Teachers a 3-0 upset victory over Hofstra College today. Hofstra four times was inside the rival 10-yard line, but lacked the ??unch necessary to score.
Those of you who are taking vacations in November this year will do well to bear in mind that the Pisg. ?? deer hunt will run from Nov. 7 to Dec. 3, and should provide plenty of sport and excitement.
Scoring with consummate ease throughout, the powerful Flushing High Red Raiders smothered Seward Park under an avalanche of touchdowns to score by 38--0 yesterday at Flushing Memorial Field.
REPORTS of debates at Westminster have as a rule the same interest in later years as The Congressional Record.
The Consolidated Oil Company, Wichita Falls, Texas, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 100,000 shares of $10 par value common stock to be

PARIS.--Nothing has escaped the Americanizing process in France, not even the venerable institutions of courtship and marriage. Undoubtedly it is difficult to change century-old customs in basic institutions, particularly in a country like France, which is intrinsically conservative.
What may be considered a semiofficial declaration on the subject of Portugal appeared yesterday in the official government organ, the Vanguardia.

The final all-breed dog show of 1938 in the United States will be that of the Bronx County Kennel Club. The annual exhibition of the veteran organization will be given on Dec. 11 and announcement was made yesterday of the list of judges just approved by the A. K. C.
Displaying a powerful ground attack, Mount St. Michael High vanquished Brooklyn Prep's football team, 12-0, yesterday on the winners' gridiron.

PURSUIT OF HAPPINESS. By Herbert Agar. 12mo. Boston, Mass: Houghton Miffflin Company. $3. The story of American democracy. GEORGE GERSHWIN. Edited by Merle Armitage. 4to. New York: Longmans. Creen Co. $5.

It does not often happen that the courts deny to the government's representatives the right to examine the books and records of a taxpayer, particularly where the examination is sought in connection with pending litigation.

Another benefit is now being arranged for the Musicians Emergency Fund, which shared in the proceeds from the opening of the St. Regis Iridium Room last Wednesday night. The beneficiary, of which Mrs. Vincent Astor is acting president, will sponsor the first performance of the 1939 Ice Follies on. the night of Nov. 29 at Madison Square Garden.

EUROPE'S war crisis having ended and the American wave lengths again swinging with music instead of "flashes," the broadcasters are now thinking it all over, figuring out who scooped who on the air and what might have happened to broadcasting had the Old World exploded.
With nomination by the American Labor party at its first State convention last week of all the Democratio candidates except two, the battle lines for the State campaign were firmly drawn.

Miss Marion E. Martin, assistant chairman of the Republican National Committee, said tonight that the women of the nation could not be "fooled" by propaganda about the New Deal protecting the consumer.
Intensification of espionage activities is expected in most quarters of Europe now that the war scare that grew out of the Czech-German crisis has subsided.
The Belair Stud's Johnstown, speedy son of the speedy Jamestown, set a new record for the $5,000 added Richard Johnson Stakes today to beat six select juvenile sprinters before a crowd of 15,000.

Favored Allegheny College lost to Haverford today, 28-0. Haverford made its first touchdown when Derr loafed along 34 yards for a score while the Allegheny team stood around waiting the verdict of an official's horn, sounded for a penalty--against Allegheny.
A faculty committee on creative arts has been established at Swarthmore College to formulate a program of creative work for undergraduates.

Boys and girls who are unhappy in the classroom, find difficulty in adjusting themselves, or are bewildered by secret family problems now get special attention from trained counselors in the guidance bureau conducted at Samuel J. Tilden High School Brooklyn.
Paul Christman of Missouri pitched a great game today, but his support was weak and the Tigers bowed, 21 to 13, to a more rugged Kansas State team in a Big Six conference football game.

A State-wide survey indicated today that about 2,000,000,000 board feet of timber, about 80 per cent of it pine, was blown down in New Hampshire by the hurricane of Sept. 21, and that salvaging it would cost $10,000,000 to $15,000,000.

To bring religion to the college Campus without violating the principle that church and State must be kept separate, is the purpose of a campaign for $10,000,000 started by the Board of Christian Education of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.
A field goal with only seconds left to play gave Louisiana State University a thrilling 3-0 victory over Rice Institute tonight in a game that left more than 40,000 fans gasping.

Working in cooperation with the College of the City of New York and Hunter College, the Museum of the City of New York is offering a course of practical training for teachers, prospective teachers and other people interested in museum work.

Older machinists who lose their jobs have more difficulty in obtaining re-employment than younger men, even if the age of the former does not militate against holding their original jobs, the Works Progress Administration reported in a study, "Ten Years of Work Experience of Philadelphia Machinists," made public today. The report covered the period from 1926 to 1936.

LITERARY criticism often neglects to grant due attention to style. One of our able critics, Yves Gandon, undertakes to fill the gap in "Le Demon du Style" (Plon, 224 pp., 18 fr.) by devoting his mature sense of form and stanch knowledge of the French language to the study of our great contemporary prose writers from the standpoint of the manner.

Anenlarged Department of Drama at Holy Cross college is to be under the direction of Professor Irving T. McDonald, who will combine his. new duties with the office of librarian, which he has filed since 1930.

The Holy Cross powerhouse shocked Manhattan with a lightninglike first-period touchdown today, and before the green-clad warriors from New York were able to recover the Crusaders followed with two more scores to build up a comfortable advantage which no amount of trying on the part of the visitors could overcome.

Wisconsin today issued a warning to future Western Conference foes that it must be counted in on the championship race. The Badgers crushed Iowa. 31 to 13, before 35,000 spectators. Iowa rooters haven't seen an Iowa team win a Big Ten game at home since 1933.
Mr. and Mrs. Lee Wingate Carroll of Montclair entertained with a costume barn dance tonight at Merry Brook Farm, their place here.

The Cunard White Star motorship Georgic is due today from England, France and Ireland. Among her passengers are Captain J. A. Holland, Professor Frank H. Constant, Mrs. V. A. L. Mallet, John Gammie, Dr. and Mrs. Joseph W. P. Murphy, Lieut. Comdr. A. V. S. Yates, Mrs. S. Perry Sturges, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Bateman and Mrs. Dorothy Ananieff.

Prospective candidates for presidency of the State League of Women Voters are being groomed for the position which Mrs. Charles Poletti resigned last week. Nominees will be presented at the annual convention opening Wednesday at Utica, for a three-day session.

What is claimed to be the first successful commercial method of making Roquefort cheese in this country has been developed at Iowa State College, according to a patent (No. 2,132,077) granted to Dr. Clarence B. Lane and Bernard W. Hammer of Ames, Iowa.
The Cheshire Academy eleven today defeated Kent School, 13 to 0. In the third period Stotzer scored from the 40. Six plays later Marx tallied on another long run. Wells starred for the losers.

IN 1928 Louise Thaden made a new endurance record by staying twenty-two hours in the air. It was only a little more than a year since, at the age of 21, she had left home for California to learn to fly.
OUR interest in Franklin is autobiographical; he is the most complete and the most characteristic of Americans. Alone of his great contemporaries he seems familiar and accommodates himself

The Gettysburg Bullets scored an upset today when they outfought the strong Albright Lions to pound out a surprise 7-to-0 victory. Albright obtained an advantage early in the conflict by intercepting a Gettysburg pass on the Bullet 30-yard line.
Dr. Bradford William Giveans, formerly a practicing physician in East Orange, died yesterday at the Marcus L. Ward home here at the age of 70.
King George and Queen Elizabeth announced here unexpectedly tonight that they had accepted the invitation of the Canadian Government to visit the Dominion for three weeks early next Summer.
New Jersey Agricultural College One of the questions most frequently asked our experiment stations at this season of the year is, "How late can the seeding of lawn grass be done?"
Mussolini's new and Jewish laws do not exact square with his ambition to revive the old Roman Empire.

Homer Eaton Keyes of 30 Sutton Place, editor of the magazine Antiques since 1921, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was born In Brooklyn sixty-two years ago His wife, the former Caroline Abbott, died in May.

Several properties in New Canaan, Conn., have been sold through Baldwin Co., brokers. Among the parcels was Mrs. Frederic Ewing's estate on Greenley Road, containing a large stone dwelling and ten acres of land, which was purchased by John E. Lancaster of Hewlett, L. I., who will make it his permanent residence.
Brokers in many parts of New Jersey last week reported many evidences of renewed interest in home ownership, indicating an active Fall buying season in all of the popular suburban sections.

The Bureau of Agricultural Economics announced today that 29 per cent of this year's cotton crop ginned before Oct. 1, was 29 per cent strict middling white or better in grade; 36 per cent was middling white;
THERE are novels which are correctly so called because they establish a definite and fully rounded microcosm which is an authentic replica of a definite and complete segment of actual life.

The four greatest potential fire hazards in private homes, declares P. A. Andrews, vice president of the Johns-Manville Company, are found on the roof, in the wiring system, in the heating and cooking systems and in the sidewalls.

Four college presidents will endeavor to interpret "Physics as an Essential Part of a Modern Education" in a symposium during the annual meeting of the Pennsylvania Conference of College Physics Teachers at the Pennsylvania State College Friday and Saturday.

Alex Rose, State executive secretary of the American Labor party, announced last night that Magistrate Anna Moskowitz Kross had been picked by a group of party leaders from Manhattan and the Bronx as a candidate of the party for justice of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District.
Harold Smead, chief pilot of the Eastern Division of the Transcontinental and Western Air Lines, today was found dead in his room at the Newark Athletic Club, here. He was 40 years old.
WITH the lengthening of Arctic shadows, European short-wave transmitters now begin the long Winter trek down the megacycle line.

A crowded week opens with "Behind the Blinds," by Vivian Tidmarsh, at the Winter Garden on Monday. Seven plots are linked by housing sixteen characters in a block of London apartments. J. B. Priestley's "When We Are Married" reaches the St.

Miss Dorothy Ellis Wanzer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Hunter Wanzer, was married here this afternoon at the home of her parents to Thomas Russell McKay of Charlotte, N. C., son of Mr. and Mrs. George B. McKay of Hempstead.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick G. Frost of Beechmont, this place, gave a tea at their home today at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Frost, to Henry Clay Moses Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Moses, also of New Rochelle.
This is a story of the Federal Theatre's attempt to satirize itself. It is about 178 WPA thespians in search of a theatre, years after Luigi Pirandello's characters went in search of an author.

The palace of Theodor Cardinal Innitzer, Archbishop of Vienna, which fronts on St. Stephan's Cathedral, was attacked at 9 o'clock tonight by a mob that stoned its windows, smashing all those on the first floor.
A spectacular fire which caused damage estimated at more than $50,000 destroyed two large storage buildings on the estate of Lloyd W.
Continuing their survey flights over the North Atlantic between New York and the Azores, two Deutsche Lufthansa Diesel-powered seaplanes. will arrive and take off here today.

Credit for the discovery of America should go to the Irish, who made the first crossing of the Atlantic some time before the year 795 A. D., 700 years before Columbus and 200 years before Leif Eriksson, it was asserted here yesterday by Thor Thors, Icelandic Commissioner to the New York World's Fair, who arrived in the United States last week to make preparations for his country's exhibit.

Elizabeth's fourteenth annual Own Your Home Exposition will be opened at the Elizabeth Armory on Monday evening, with a variety of educational exhibits by seventeen city department, civic, welfare groups and character-building organizations. The show will continue through Saturday.

Oklahoma defeated Texas University, 31-0, in the thirty-ninth meeting of the schools before 20,000 fans in broiling heat today. Only the breaks enabled the Texans to carry their deepest march to the Oklahoma 12. Their net gain on ground plays amounted to eleven yards.
The probable line-up and batting order for the fourth game of the world series today in the Yankee Stadium follow:

Swarthmore opened its 1938 football season today with a 18-15 triumph over the Union College eleven. The Little Quakers, led by the brilliant open field running of Larry Wolfe and splendid passing by Captain Ed Jakle, scored in the first, second and last periods.
Federal statisticians charted a Spring peak today for the business stimulation efforts of the current spending program.
A valiant last-minute goal-line stand gave Lehigh a 0-0 tie with Case today. Digging in on the 4-yard line, the Engineers from Bethlehem, Pa., repulsed three Case thrusts, then kicked out of danger.

Road tests to determine the ultimate possibilities of the steam passenger locomotive will start tomorrow at Fort Wayne, Ind., as a joint project of the Association of American Railroads and various manufacturers.

The' locust, one of our loveliest trees, is of recent years becoming noticeably defaced by dead limbs toward the top of the tree. This is principally due to the work of an insect known as the Locust Borer.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Mildred Ruth Bookholtz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Isidor Bookholtz of this city, to Stanley Rosenbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Rosenbaum of Florence, Ala.
Mrs Patrick Henry Adams, president of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs, will preside at the Fall conference Thursday at the War Memorial Building in Trenton.

Champion Nornay Saddier, striking smooth foxterrier from the Wissaboo Kennels of Westbury, L. I., was named best today at the fourth annual exhibition of the Kennel Club of Wilmington and established a record of thirty-three best-inshow prizes.

Retail business responded to the seasonal impetus and results generally were much better throughout the country last week, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buying office.

Can President Roosevelt successfully mediate the fratricidal conflict between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization? That is the question that was being asked throughout the country this week.

Mayor La Guardia and Senator Robert F. Wagner were among political figures of city, State and nation who attended a high mass of requiem yesterday at St. John's Roman Catholic Church, 230th Street and Kingsbridge Avenue, the Bronx, for John J. Boylan, Representative from the Fifteenth New York District in Manhattan. Mr. Boylan died Wednesday in French Hospital after an illness of several weeks.

Aniinouncement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Paul H. Elsdon of Glen Rock, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Elsdon, to Charles H. Thurber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Thurber of West Harford, Conn.
Mr. and Mrs. Frank E. Knowles of this city have announced the engagements of their daughters, Miss Elizabeth Sweetsir Knowles to Wilber V. Hunt, and Miss Dorothy Whiting Knowles to Herman J. Chilton.

Miss Gigiotta Conquest Bertelli, daughter of Commendatore Riccardo Bertelli of this city and the late Mrs. Bertelli, was' married here yesterday to Captain Ugo Venier d'Annunzio di Montenevose, also of New York.
Evansville College's team tasted sweet victory today and lost a national football title as it scored its first points since 1936 to upset Wabash College, 27 to 0.

FRONT ROYAL, VA. EACH cool night is bringing new bits of color to the green hills which overlook this former headquarters of Belle Boyd, the Confederate spy, and when Fall color comes the cars come too in greater numbers than at any other season.

Three new laboratories for physical chemistry, psychology and chemical engineering, which are nearing completion on the Genesee River campus of the University of Rochester are tangible signs of the expansion of the science departments of the institution.

Miss Paulina Moxley, daughter of Mrs. Richard Hayes Davis of this city and of Sampson Buchanan Moxley 3d of Shelbyville, was married to Marshall Morris Bassick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Webb Bassick of The Oaks, Brooklawn Park, Bridgeport, Conn., here this afternoon in the Harbison Memorial Chapel.
Ivan C. Harden, former vice president of the Bartlett Frazier Company, grain brokers here, has been appointed special representative in charge of corn delivery by the Commodity Credit Corporation.

Amityville High's eleven furnished an upset by conquering Bay Shore, 7--0, in a battle between Suffolk County rivals today. With three minutes of play remaining, the home eleven went on to break what appeared to be an imminent scoreless tie when it recovered a fumble that enabled Tom Sarno to score seconds later on a 2-yard plunge. Bob Fallott drop-kicked the extra point.

MAURICE EVANS will present the entirety version of "Hamlet" for the first time in New York next Wednesday evening at the St. James Theatre. We believe that the play as Shakespeare originally wrote it is incomparably better balanced in its development of action;

Word reached here today of the sudden death at Worthing, England, of the Right Rev. R. J. Lucas, former Anglican Bishop of Mackenzie River and honorary warden of the church army in Canada. Bishop Lucas was 71 and a native of Brighton.
