Never in the history of modern times have responsibilities been more clearly defined; never has Europe known since the days of Louis XIV or those of Napoleon such an example of avid desire for self-expansion, such brutal hunger for conquest as is today being displayed by Chancellor Adolf Hitler.
News from Salamanca today said that General Francisco Franco was about to send home all Italians who had fought on his side continuously for eighteen months.
LONDON. IT may have been remarked by visitors to England that our plays are nearly always over dressed. The fault is sometimes in the actresses but not always.

A strike vote among United Automobile Workers of America in the Buick division of the General Motors Corporation at Flint was deferred today pending a conference with high officials of the concern in Detroit Tuesday.

President Roosevelt declared today that women might well "strive for greater preparedness for meeting their service responsibilities" by "specialized training" and "cultivation of an understanding of social problems."

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Persian and Indian Miniatures: A Contrast" (Survey of Collections), Mabel Harrison Duncan, 2 P. M.; "Frandisco Goya," Edith R. Abbot, 2:30 P. M.; motion pictures, 2:80 P. M.; "Design in Tall Buildings" (Gillender Lecture), Harvey Wiley Corbett, 3 P. M.

Stocks and bonds advanced sharply for the second consecutive week as investors and traders, relieved of immediate worries over the European political situation, turned hopefully to consideration of the domestic business scene.

Showing definite superiority in all departments of the game, Scotland defeated Ireland, 2--0, at Windsor Park today in the opening match of the international football tournament. Before a crowd of 30,000, including a good sprinkling of Scotsmen, the Irish put up a plucky fight on a heavy ground.
Youth and age, experience and inexperience faced each other yesterday at the Yankee Stadium in a drama that was not lost on veteran baseball followers or the players themselves.

Miss Margaret Williams, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Mallory Williams of this place, was married here today in Calvary Episcopal Church to Billings Burch Fairbrother, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lorenzo D. Fairbrother, also of Stonington.

The culminating phase of a month of highly important manoeuvres will start at Fort Bragg, N. C., this week when planes of the army's General Headquarters Air Force will attempt to penetrate, without detection, the most extensive warning net and the most formidable anti-aircraft defenses ever concentrated in this country.

THE body is discovered on page one, which is unusual in the mystery novel nowadays. And the reader learns next that a well-to-do gentleman named Ernest Fletcher has been killed with a blunt instrument.

The Washington Gas Light Company, Washington, D. C., has filed an application under the Public Utility Holding Company Act for exemption from the requirement of filing a declaration covering the issue and sale of $8,500,000 of 4 per cent refunding mortgage bonds due in 1963.

M. Antoine of Paris,.the international hairdresser, who says he started the current vogue of the upsweptt hair-do, arrived in New York on the Ile de France yesterday morning, full of disgust about the war scare but ready to take up the task of showing "the delightful, energetic American woman" something new in coiffures.

OF the nine novelties promised by the newly organized (or reorganized) Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, which opens on Wednesday evening at the Metropolitan Opera House, five will be presented this week, although it is a short week.

Frightened by the recent war scare in Europe, American exporters with warehouses in free-port cities and in other parts of Europe's trouble zone are considering moving them to Sweden and Norway, executives said yesterday.

The sale of eighteenth century furniture, tapestries, silver and other decorations collected by the late Mrs. Charles B. Alexander and others realized $32,911 yesterday and Friday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries.

Announcement has been made to friends here by Colonel Ralph H. Goldthwaite, U. S. A. M. C., and Mrs. Goldthwaite of Fort Sill, Okla., of the engagement of Mrs. Goldthwaite's daughter, Miss HelenLouise Butler, to Dr. Carl Norman Giere of Minneapolis.

PARIS.--In the rivalry of European powers to establish hegemony over Central European and the Balkan States, France today is forced to play a secondary role. This situation has been emphasized by the repercussions in the Balkans of Germany's victory in Czechoslovakia.
Captain Don Bowersox of Exeter, standing on the Harvard freshmen's 20-yard line, lifted the ball between the goal posts for the only score of the game and a 3-to-0 football victory today.
A program of pier replacement proposed nearly two years ago by Dock Commissioner John McKenzie was undertaken last week when work was started on the demolition of Pier 64, North River.

Considerable interest has been aroused in commercial and financial circles in South America by the round-thecontinent tour now being made by Warren Lee Pierson, president of the United States Government's Export-Import Bank, which was created in 1934 to assist in the development of American trade.

Teachers colleges must take a more aggressive leadership in combating public ignorance and misunderstanding that obstruct educational progress in many communities, three faculty members of Teachers College, Columbia University, declared in a book issued yesterday by the institution's bureau of publications.

With Columbus Day approaching and today once designated by President Roosevelt as Lelv Eriksson Day, Italians, Norwegians, Icelanders and Irish will again patriotically assert the claim that one of their compatriots was the original discoverer of America.
Displaying plenty of power when necessary, the Wildcats of Villanova College halted Muhlenberg's Mules, 25--7, before 10,000 in Jack Coffield Stadium today.

The superior line play of the Middlebury eleven brought a hard-earned 7-0 victory over a fighting Coast Guard Academy team today. Jack Johnson, playing his first varsity game, led the Middlebury attack while Goerecki and Thompson starred for the visitors.
Playing a see-saw battle on Price Field, the Ursinus Bears, coached by Don Kellett of U. of P. fame, battled the Red Devils from Dickinson to a 7-7 deadlock today.

SOME quickening in trade was reported last week, as war fears were relieved, but various centers also told of particular difficulties that held down sales. Thus, the weather. in the Middle West was unfavorable to Fall buying. Low prices have held back farm products from market and reduced cash purchasing power.

A Red and White Ball will be given here next Friday night at the Bedford Hills Community House for the benefit of that institution's community program. Subscribers to the event are asked to wear red, white or black attire in keeping with the ballroom decor.

A divorce suit by Mrs. Barbara Guggenheim Wettach against Fred E. Wettach, international polo player, was on file here today. She charged her husband with drunkenness and a violent temper, and asked custody of their 7-year-old son, Michael.

ON the expedition reported here-officially the twenty-fourth expedition of the Department of Tropical Research of the New York Zoological Society--Dr. Beebe voyaged on Templeton Crocker's two-masted Diesel schooner Zaca through the teeming waters of Lower California and to Clarion Island.

A national council on medical education, licensing and hospitals to serve as a "central clearing house" for existing groups concerned with the educational needs of American medicine was proposed yesterday by Dean Willard C. Rappleye of Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons.

The marriage of Dr. Jean Captain, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Captain of Montclair, to Dr. George Burr Sabiae, son of Professor and Mrs. George H. Sabine of Ithaca, N. Y. took place this afternoon in the home of the bride's parents.

Representatives of consumer cooperative associations in thirty-two States are scheduled to attend the eleventh biennial congress of the Cooperative League of the United States of America in Kansas City next Wednesday, Thursday and Friday.
The Czech Socialist party is considering secession from the Second International in consequence of the failure of French and British
MR. FORD'S magnificent story of literature may have been a year's writing, but it is a lifetime's work and I can think of no. other person who could have conceived and carried it out.
Reports that Oldsmobile would make a bid for business in the low-price field were confirmed today when it was announced that the advertised delivered prices on 1939 cars would start at $777.

Unawed by Alamaba's prestige, North Carolina State came to town today with a defense the Crimson Tide could crack only twice in sixty minutes and forced the Big Reds to he satisfied with a 14-0 homecoming victory.

Trading in shell egg futures on the Mercantile Exchange last month set a new high record for a September, Lloyd S. Tenny, the market's business manager, said today. The turnover was 6,826 contracts for 81,912,000 dozens of refrigerated eggs.

Miss Barbara Louise Bourne, granddaughter of the late Frederick Gilbert Bourne, one-time commodore of the New York Yacht Club and president of the Singer Sewing Machine Company, was married here today in St. John's Episcopal Church to Horton Smith, prominent golfer.
Denying France had broken her word to Czechoslovakia, Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet today was wildly cheered when he returned here to receive homage from his constituency.

The Works Progress Administration sewing rooms added 227,837 garments in September to the store they manufactured in August for distribution to needy school children, according to Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local WPA Administrator.
History was written on. the sundrenched Franklin Field gridiron today by a young sophomore named Francis Reagan, who plays quarterback for George Munger's Pennsylvania eleven.

Cornell's big and powerful football team defeated Harvard today by 20--0. That had been expected, but the way in which it happened was entirely unexpected, for despite the size of the score, Harvard was in the game until the third period was almost over, having a fighting chance to tie the count.
Secretary Perkins reported today that 4,800,000 employes of manufacturing establishments have benefited by application of the Walsh-Healey act since it became effective two years ago.
Mark S. Matthews of New York was elected president of the State Junior Chamber of Commerce today as the convention ended. Robert Noonan of Batavia and Frederic Rogers of this city withdrew.

A tract comprising 550 lots on both sides of Utopia Parkway between Sixty-ninth and Seventy-third Avenues, adjoining the Fresh Meadow County Club, has been purchased by Moss Brothers from Morris Wolzer and M. Weinstock for immediate development with medium priced homes.
Roguish Girl, the "rheumatism horse" claimed for $3,500 at Saratoga, reached her highest plane so far in the Continental Handicap, witnessed by 12,000 persons at Jamaica yesterday.
Lester A. De Groot, a Queens attorney, died Friday at the Jamaica Hospital of anemia at the age of 32. He had offices at 161-19 Jamaica Avenue, Jamaica.

The first of three planned shipments of flour and soap to Spanish families made destitute by the civil war, a project in which the American Red Cross, government agencies and private organizations are cooperating and the distribution of which will be made impartially to

THE discoverers of "Nine Chains to the Moon" describe it as possibly one of those books which, published once or twice in a century, "dominate an entire generation and revolutionize a whole era of thinking."

Overcoming unexpectedly stubborn resistance, Notre Dame unloosed two offensive thrusts today to conquer inspired Georgia Tech, 14 to 6, in renewing an intersectional football rivalry. The game featured the Engineers' fiftieth anniversary celebration.

This herd of fawns has the U. S. Forest Service to thank for the bran and vegetable dinner on Which they are feasting in the Pisgah National Forest Game Preserve in North Carolina. Since 1934 the Federal Government has conducted a deer nursery there, from which the fawns are shipped to forests throughout the country when they are old enough to take care of themselves.

The approach of the Fall campaigns is giving a political flavor to current events talks slated for the Westchester women's clubs this week. National affairs will be discussed tomorrow at the first lecture of the season sponsored by the Bronxville Women's Club.

With William Oliverie leading the attack, Scarborough School scored twice in the first half to defeat Albany Academy today, 13 to 0. Oliverie tossed one 30-yard pass to Kresge in the first period to set the stage for the initial touchdown.
A commuter extraordinary is Arthur Castle, who has been traveling every week-end for fifty-two Summers between his Rochester office and his Thousand Islands home.
District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, opened his headquarters at 11 East Forty-fourth Street yesterday and received optimistic reports from party leaders up-State.
Northeastern marched to the Bates 25-yard line five times today, but scored only one touchdown to win a hard-fought football game, 6 to 0, before 3,000 fans.

Santa Clara, football toast of the Pacific Coast, turned a one yardgaining thrust of 52 yards into a touchdown today to defeat the formidable Texas A. M. eleven, 7 to 0, and make another bid for national recognition.
A frantic search today for missing Leslie Warren Jr., aged 3, ended when a State Trooper found him about a mile away from his home testing out the Merritt Parkway as a tricycle course.

The Federal Home Loan Bank of New York announced yesterday that it has distributed to many of the leading savings and loan associations in the metropolitan area home mortgages approximating in value $2,500,000 and other mortgage blocks ranging from $100,000 to $1,000,000 are being assembled for distribution as rapidly as possible.

Henry W. Merritt, former president of the National Association of Retail Druggists, postmaster of Wilkes-Barre under President Hoover, and Potentate of Irem Temple for two terms, died at his home here last night. He was 65 years old.

The personnel bureau at Wellesley College, under the direction of Dr. Alice I. Perry Wood, is concerning itself in many ways with the adjustment of students to the campus and with proper direction of their vocational interests.

A Home-Coming Day crowd of 2,500 today saw the Green Terrors of Western Maryland College score two easy touchdowns against Washington College of Chestertown, Md., then hang on grimly for a 13-to-0 victory.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today modified previous orders establishing minimum rates on a wide variety of products transported by motor carriers between Southeastern New York and Northeastern New Jersey and points in Connecticut, Massachusetts and Rhode Island so that motor carriers may on one day's notice file tariffs not in excess of the minimums for the products covered.
ResignIng as administrator upon completion of the unemployment census, John D. Biggers reported to President Roosevelt today that the influx of women workers was a central factor in the problem.

A fifty-second anniversary sale "flier" catalogue just issued by Sears, Roebuck Co. offers new evidence of the increasingly keen competition between Chicago's two big mail-order houses that at times amounts almost to a price war.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Members of the Research Council on Problems of Alcohol, and doubtless numerous members of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, have read with much interest your statement on the plans of the council and the editorial which appeared in THE TIMES.

A strike vote affecting 2,000 men and about 300 tugboats will be taken tonight at a meeting of the United Marine Division .of the International Longshoremen's Association, it was announced yesterday by Captain William V. Bradley, head of the union.

Mr. and Mrs. William B. Courtney of this city have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Jerome Courtney, to Charles Lyman Case, son of Charles E. Case of Summit and the late Mrs. Case, which took place here Sept. 30 in Christ Church. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Edgar L. Cook.

Trained nurses gathering for an exchange of ideas on nursing services at three up-State institutes beginning this week, have expanded their program to include representatives of lay women as consumers of nursing, and practical nurses, recently brought under State control.

Georgetown University defeated Roanoke College of Salem, Va., at Griffith Stadium today, 33--6. The courageous little team of Virginians came full of fight, and the superior weight and man-power of the Hoyas could tally only 13 points in the first half.
A week in which organized business and professional women will make graphic the story of their advance as well as their contributions to the business world opens today.

With sterling and the franc unchanged in price from the previous day, the foreign exchange market yesterday ended the week on a dull note. A shipment of $1,051,000 gold reached this port from England, but no new engagements of the metal abroad were reported.

Democrats of Pennsylvania have set a goal of $200,000 for these $100-a-plate dinner at which Chairman Farley will speak here Oct. 20. Matthew H. McCloskey Jr., former State Finance Chairman of the party, originated the idea of the dinners and succeeded last year in raising $195,000 from this source.
After the shake-up of the last two weeks, Europe's greatest problem-Germany--occupies the minds of Poles in no less a degree than those of other peoples on this troubled Continent.

THE sequel to Gunnar Gunnarsson's magnificent autobiographical novel, "Ships in the Sky," takes us ten years deeper into the quietly rugged life of Uggi Greipsson, the carrothaired farm boy of Iceland who stole our hearts away last year.
THERE is something of profound appropriateness in the fact that exhibitions of graphic work by Honore Daumier, Georges Rouault and Kaethe Kollwitz are being held concurrently in New York.*

Although Great Britain has won reprieve from the immediate threat of a major war, British soldiers, including the famous Black Watch Regiment, are fighting a little war in Palestine, where scores of casualties have been reported recently in skirmishes between the English troops and Arabs.

The first tangible result of the Munich conference, apart from the obvious one of the limitation of the Czechoslovak problem's threat to European peace, has come to hand with the French Government's decision to recognize the conquest of Ethiopia and appoint an Ambassador to Rome.
Tulane University flashed a powerful, versatile attack on North Carolina today and marked up its first victory of the season with a 17-to14 upset.

AIR MAIL, having performed successfully in seven-league boots, is about to don magic slippers to do a smaller but no less spectacular job along the by-ways of America. The problem of feeder air-mail service is on the way to solution.
The Supreme Court completed today its examination of about 300 cases filed during the Summer. It will announce Monday which ones will be reviewed.

ROYAL JEWELS; In the National Museum at Mexico City have been on exhibition for many years jewels that belonged to the ill-fated and unhappy Carlotta, Empress of Mexico for a brief period in the Eighteen Sixties.
Robert Fechner, CCC director, approved the re-establishment today of six camps in New England to end fire hazards in areas swept by the recent hurricane.

A group of debutantes of this season, including the Misses Emily Hunt, Josephine Adrian and Innes K. Drury, compose a flower committee for the annual Autumn luncheon for the benefit of the Children's Village to be held Oct. 18 and 19 at the Versailles.

The prospect that bids will be invited this month for construction of the muchdebated memorial to Thomas Jefferson in the District of Columbia is seen here as a result of final approval of modified plans within the last week by the National Capital Park and' Planning and the Fine Arts Commissions.

Mountaineering, which is the most popular year-round sport at Middlebury College, had a hearty endorsement this week when more than 400 men and women students joined the Mountain Club, largest organization on the campus.

Former Supreme Court Justice Charles Poletti, making his initial campaign appearance in the Bronx, at Morris High School, addressed yesterday the first county convention of the American Labor party to be held in that area. After paying tribute to Governor Lehman, Mr. Poletti remarked that he had had "some ribbing" for relinquishing a $25,000 job to be candidate for Lieutenant-Governor.

Stanford University's Indians scored an unimpressive 8-to-0 victory over Washington State today before 15,000 spectators. It was Stanford's first Pacific Coast Conference game, but the third league defeat for the luckless Cougars from Pullman, Wash.

Bowdoin came from behind with four touchdowns in the last half to defeat a hard fighting Wesleyan eleven, 27-13, today. A passing attack, Hussong to Peterson and Cagney, brought the ball deep into Bowdoin territory arly in the first quarter.

Washington and Lee employed an inspired attack today to tie West Virginia, 6-6, in an upset witnessed by 8,000 fans. The Virginians rocked the Mountaineers back on their heels from the start and completely outplayed them until the waning minutes.
HOT SPRINGS, Va.--The social and sports calendar next week is crowded and the "high season" at the Homestead is in full swing.
Dudley S. Blossom, honorary life chairman of the Cleveland Community Fund, died last night of a heart ailment at the age of 59.
The Bailey brothers of New Brunswick, N. J., Frank and Mike, cleaned up today in the dirt track automobile races that marked the closing of the Danbury Fair.

Expressing the hope that Chelsea School can "show others and spread to other schools a method of integrating school work as a childhood experience," Ruth Gillette Hardy, principal of Public School 33, says in the annual report of the second school year and the first Summer play school, "Our dream is a school where 'subjects' have disappeared into purposeful, responsible activity, Simultaneously mental. physical and emotional."
September brought new quarterly production records to several Canadian gold mines, as well as new monthly highs for recovery of the metal.

An overtone, sounded softly at first but growing in volume as the Administration political orchestra gets under way, is beginning to rise above the cacophony of the Congressional campaign. It is a blend of several notes which ordinarily do not harmonize. But the score-writers of the New Deal symphony believe they can effect the concord they are after, and that votes will be charmed from the populace thereby.
Don Budge, the world's No. 1 net ace, moved into quarter-finals of the Pacific Coast tennis championships today by eliminating Ronald Shayes of England, 6--4, 6--0.
A swift running attack led by sophomores, particularly by Red Hahnenstein of Aurora, Ill., carried Northwestern to a 33-to-0 football triumph over Drake University today before a crowd of 25,000.
Alvin C. York, who twenty years ago today annihilated an entire German machine- gun battalion "practically unassisted," spent today working as usual on his 395acre farm.
Americans captured while fighting in the Barcelona Government's International Brigade crossed to Hendaye from Insurgent Spain today on their way to the United States.

Unable to cope with an attack which moved with splendid coordination throughout, a plucky Baldwin High eleven bowed to Petersburg (Va.) High, 14--0, in the third intersectional meeting between the schools since 1934 at the Municipal Stadium today.

Joseph Szigeti, violinist, and Benny Goodman, swing leader and clarinetist, will introduce a concerto for violin, clarinet and orchestra by Bela Bartok at Mr. Szigeti's recital in Carnegie Hall on Jan. 9, it was announced yesterday.

Under the 1938 program of the Public Works Administration, funds have been allotted, as of Sept. 15, for 2,275 educational building projects. These will cost, including local contributions, about $350.000,000. This is the largest educational allotment which PWA has made in any single year since it began operations in the Summer of 1933.

A five-under-par 67 enabled Johnny Burke, 21-year-old national intercollegiate champion, and Thomas Breslin of the home club to take a four-stroke lead at the halfway mark in the Crestmont Golf Club's second annual member-guest invitation tournament today.

Rolland Lundberg's pitching arm and Perry Stenson's kicking toe squeezed out a 7-to-6 decision for the University of Montana in a gridiron struggle with DePaul today. Tom O'Brien snagged a pass in the first period on the goal line for a DePaul touchdown.

Sore beset, there is something still indomitable about the Czechs and the Chinese, the two underdogs in this present bull-pit of nations we call the world. No news could be more sympathetically received in this city than he announcement that both are to Participate in our World's Fair.

Franklin and Marshall triumphed over Penn M. C. today, 27-0. Captain Sammy Roeder and Rabbit Asplin, veteran backs, were the stars, the former scoring three times. Asplin made a 38-yard touchdown run in the first period.

Residential structures aggregating 21,126 were erected during the month of August in cities of 10,000 population or more as compared with 12,601 home units built in that month of 1937, according to a survey just completed by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.
In one of the greatest comebacks in its history, Boston University rallied to beat St. Lawrence University, 19 to 14, before 5,000 fans at Fenway Park today.
Staging long marches in every period, Fordham overwhelmed the visiting Waynesburg eleven at the Randalis Island Stadium by 53 to 0 before 8,000 yesterday.
Rutgers will start its fourth annual series of classes in job placement on Oct. 24, Ralph N. Campbell, director of the Bureau of Personnel and Placement, announced this week.

Israel Amster, Communist candidate for Governor, who has predicted the re-election of Democratic Governor Lehman, described his Republican opponent, Thomas E. Dewey. tonight as a "mask for reactionaries."
The shattering events of the past fortnight do not appear to have shaken Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's hold over his people or weakened his grip upon the Conservative party.

A fighting Illinois football team, with a line that outcharged opposing forwards throughout the battle, smashed its way into the Big Ten title picture today by a 12-to-2 upset victory over Indiana's stubborn Hoosiers before 15,000 spectators.

The play-by-play description of the third game of the world series at the Yankee Stadium yesterday follows: FIRST INNING CUBS--Pearson's first pitch to Hack was called a ball, and in five pitches the count went to three and two without Hack taking his bat off his shoulder.

The mar riage of Miss Lydia vanDyke Mellick, daughter of Mrs. C. Cassius Mellick of Plainfield and the late Mr. Mellick, to J. Ainslie Palmer Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Ainslee D. Smith of this city, took place this afternoon in the Summit Methodist Episcopal Church.

WASHINGTON. THE Postoffice Department's first "philatelic truck" nearing completion and is expected to start a tour of the Atlantic States sometime this month, carrying a $100,000 display of stamps and equipment, according to Roy M. North, Acting Third Assistant Postmaster General.
TOMORROW Hawaii celerates Double Ten Day, an oriental fete staged by the Chinese community in commemoration of the founding of the Chinese Republic.

Neither a European crisis nor the bitterness of an election year has dampened the enthusiasm of farm folk for fairs and stock shows the universal outdoor Fall attraction of the Middle West. In many cases such events in 1938 have set all-time attendance records.

A $9,930 profit for the first fourteen and a half months of operation of Stanley S. Holmes Village, $1,500,000 Federal housing project for Negroes on the Northside here, is shown in a financial statement issued by the United States Housing Authority in Washington.

Spirituality, beauty and manners have not kept pace with the physical comforts achieved in the last twenty years, declared Dean E. Raymond Bossange of the New York University School of Architectecture and Allied Arts in his annual report to Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase, made public yesterday.
Today--At Yankee Stadium, New York. Tomorrow-At Yankee Stadium (if necessary). Tuesday-No game, teams traveling.

The marriage of Miss F. Margery Woolsey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Valette Woolsey of Glen Rock, N. J., to Richard Frank Hardy, son of S. Frank Hardy of Trenton, N. J., and the late Mrs. Hardy, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration.
Troops of the First Brigade, First Division, concluded annual manoeuvres here today by surrounding a Red enemy force during a tactical problem in attack.

Mrs. Arthur W. Bingham Jr. will give a tea tomorrow at the headquarters of the Smith College Club of New York, 34 East Fiftieth Street, at which she will discuss with her aides plans for a special benefit matinee performance on Feb. 10 of "La Boheme" with Grace Moore and Jan Kiepura.

A controversy over Chicago's financial condition engaged public attention this week following distribution by the City Hall of a report which pictured the municipal government as "the best in its history" and which was attributed to the Committee on Public Information.

The Board of Examiners recommends that license as teacher-in-training in economics and economic geography In day secondary schools other than junior high schools, be Issued, as of Oct. 7, 1938, to the following applicants:

The Chicago Corporation has reported a net asset value of $54.78 a share for the preference stock and 70 cents a share for the common stock as of Sept. 30, compared to $55.30 and 84 cents respectively on June 30.

Miss Edith Adele Kruse, daughter of Mrs. Frederick H. Kruse of Maplewood and the late Mr. Kruse, was married this evening to Clemens Frederick Hathaway, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Hathaway of River Edge, N. J.

Time Inc., of New York City, publishers of Life, was sued in the Federal District Court here today for $250,000 damages as the result of the publication of an X-ray photograph of a woman's abdomen and pelvis illustrating how a pair of surgical scissors was left in her body after an operation for appendicitis.

The New York World's Fair of 1939 has sold or assigned all but 600,000 of its 3,000,000 square feet of building space available for exhibits, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation.
FURS are as eloquent of styles as silks and woolens. They follow the new silhouette. It is amazing to find that a Persian or caracul can more than suggest the spool curve.
AS we drove South last Summer we passed countless shrines. Here Washington was born, here he spent his boyhood, here he farmed, here and here and everywhere he slept.
Enrollment figures for a crosssection of private schools throughout the United States indicate an increase of just over 1 per cent from 1937.

Those who have no great fortune to draw upon in furnishing apartments might like to look at some brand new unpainted furniture designed to the queen's taste (literally) by a Swedish architect. Some of the unpretentious, but highly effective pieces are already seeing service in the homes of the Swedish royal family.
(All time is P. M., Eastern standard, unless otherwise indicated; dial locations are in megacycless.
Duke's undefeated Blue Devils pushed over a touchdown in the third period today and then, with a little help from Lady Luck, staved off Colgate's aerial magic to win, 7 to 0.

John P. Pullman, president of the Wisconsin Public Service Corporation, received last night a leatherbound volume containing a message signed by the 1,500 employes of the corporation in honor of his fiftieth anniversary in business.
The University of California at Los Angeles rose to one of its greatest gridiron triumphs today when it defeated highly favored Washington, 13 to 0, in a Pacific Coast Conference battle.

Londoners today saw their balloon Barrage against raiding aircraft flown over the rooftops for the first time. The balloons, each tethered by a thin steel cable that could cut through the wing of a raiding bomber, were sent up from about forty selected spots that form the "inner ring" of London's defenses.

The Interstate Commerce Commission said today that Class I railroads employed 961,868 persons during September, an increase of 2.41 per cent over August but a decrease of 15.1 per cent, compared with September, 1937.

ADELMAN--LUSTIG--Mr. and Mrs. William Lustig, 1,573A East 18th St., Brooklyn, announce the engagement of their daugnter, Dorothy, to Stuart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Adelman, 1,859 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, N. Y.

PRINCETON, N. J. THIRTY - SEVEN annoyances that cause radio listeners to tune off have been uncovered in a survey by Gilbert Fraunhar of Harvard University. A report on his analysis is revealed in the October issue of The Public Opinion Quarterly of Princeton University's School of Public and International Affairs.

Work has been started on the covering of artificial stone and steel for the World's Fair trylon and perisphere on the fair grounds in Flushing, and these "theme" structures will be completed by the end of the year, Hegeman-Harris Company, Inc., New York builders, announced yesterday.
The third annual Carnival on Wheels for the benefit of the Vocational Service for Juniors will be held on the night of Nov. 11 at the Mecca Temple Casino, in West Fifty-fifth Street.
The New York State Osteopathic Society adopted a resolution today to cooperate in the national health program as recommended by the recent government health conference at Washinton.
THE European war scare seriously impaired operations of leading stamp dealers in Paris and London and for that reason relatively few new foreign adhesives arrived in New York last week.

Opportunity for individual work with the materials of history and the literature of the field will be offered as graduate study in two new courses at the evening and extension division of Hunter College this Fall, according to an announcement by the director, Broderick Cohen.

DURHAM, N. H.--A powerful University of Maine team set back the University of New Hampshire Wildcats, 21--0, today before a capacity crowd gathered for the annual Dads' Day. Maine also won the varsity cross-country meet, 26--29.
Four Connecticut College undergraduates, the first daughters of alumnae ever enrolled at the college, will be presented at the alumnae week-end celebration at the college Oct. 14, 15 and 16.
Scoring both touchdowns by the air route, Manhasset High's football team upset Stony Brook School, 13 to 0, today. The line-up:
Louis Ramhod Jr., 11 years old, of 985 Third Avenue, swallowed a five-inch hatpin yesterday when he stumbled while walking along East Fifty-seventh Street.

Miss Louise Janet Mangin, daugnter of Mr. and Mrs. James Mangin of New Brunswick, N. J., was married here yesterday afternoon in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral to Richard Andrew Roe, son of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Roe of Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Joseph A. Tytheridge.

When the Radcliffe Choral Society for the first time in its history gave a special entertainment to welcome the freshmen, the latter's enthusiastic response to recordings of programs in which choral has sung, indicated that membership in what has been for some years the most popular extra-curricular organization at Radcliffe would be greater than ever this year.
Michigan's football revival struck a new high today as the Wolverines romped to a 45-to-7 victory over a courageous but sadly undermanned University of Chicago eleven.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Oct. 6: COMMANDER Rault. C. V., Dental.Corps, the Medusa, to the Maryland, Dec. 1. LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS

A NEW type of concrete roadway with non-skid surface and quick-drying body was laid recently on the Lakes-to-Sea Highway, when Pennsylvania used the Vacuum Concrete process to resurface a three-quarter-mile stretch somewhere between DuBois and Clearfield, in the West Central part of the State.

The Institute of Musical Art of the Juilliard School of Music has awarded sixteen scholarships for study at the school this season, it was announced yesterday by Oscar Wagner, dean of the Juilliard School of Music. The awards were made after competitions held during the last week.

ASHINY black limousine, equipped with "one-way" glass which permits the occupant to see out without being seen by spectators on the outside, swings out through the gates of the high stone walls surrounding the gardens of the beautiful Villa Torlonia. near Rome.

A new Europe began to emerge last week from the ruins of the old. Boundaries drawn at Versailles were being redrawn. Alliances that for two decades had been part of the European system were being shunted aside as new alignments appeared over the horizon.
Representative Doughton gave assurance today that a wide variety of pension plans, including one for $200-a-month payments, would get Congressional attention next session.
LONDON. LONDON'S City Fathers have decided that the flocks of pigeons in Trafalgar Square and St. Paul's have become a nuisance.

Having proved by the Czechoslovak settlement that they have increased their influence in Europe, Mussolini and Hitler evidently intend to speed up their propaganda campaigns in other parts of the world. Hardly had the Duce left the four-power conference at Munich than his Minister of Popular Culture, Dino Alfieri, gave the press a glowing account of Fascist cultural activities in the countries of South America.

The following Foreign Service changes since Oct. 1 were announced today by the State Department: Orsen N. Nielson of Beloit, Wis., Department of State. assigned Consul General at Munich, Germany. George F. Scherer of New Yor, Vice Consul at Havana, assigned Vice Consul at Mexico City.

Secretary Woodring asserted tonight that "the cool mind and skilled, sure fingers of one man," President Roosevelt, devised measures that resolved the economic crisis of 1933 and the war crisis of 1938.

Mr. and Mrs. Louis J. Adrian of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathleen Louise Adrian, to Charles Brotherston Bryson, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Bryson of Woodside, Queens, and Glasgow, Scotland.

An exposition of building, industry and services will be opened in Chicago on Tuesday with exhibits of thirty-two nationally knows companies and associations, designed to show private investors some of the latest developments in building equipment and construction.

One of the most severe criticisms of the peace-training of the army ever published in an American military magazine appears in' the current 'number of the semi-official Infantry Journal, published last week.
ON a June day in 1859 a young banker from Geneva went to seek an emperor's aid for a land improvement project and found himself caught, not in an official anteroom, but on a battlefield.

FISH "hunting" has been curbed by the French Ministry of Health, which has jurisdiction over sports. Henceforth the diver who goes below the surface with an undersea rifle to shoot fish must do so without the diving helmet or oxygen tank which enables him to stay below the surface for some time.
Makers of equipment for railroads received in September orders for five locomotives, 1,079 freight cars and eleven passenger cars, according to Railway Age.

Greenfield defeated the Cosmopolitan Cubs, 2 to 1, the Bears vanquished the Bluebirds, 2 to 1, the Carrolls routed the Knickerbockers, 10 to 0, the Cosmopolitans blanked the Clansmen, 6 to 0, and the Orioles shut out the Waltons, 4 to 0, in the New York Field Hockey Association's second series of interclub matches in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday.

Worcester Tech defeated Trinity in their annual game today, 12 to 6. The Engineers pushed over their pair of touchdowns in the opening period. Fritch tallied from the 5yard marker after a Trinity punt had been blocked.

De Witt Clinton's eleven gained its second victory by conquering Theo dore Roosevelt, a Bronx rival, 6-3, yesterday at Castle Hill Stadium in a game marked by the superb defensive playing of both squads.
Harry Hopkins, answering criticism of the Works Progress Administration, declared today that continuance of the work program represented the democratic will of the American people.

Jack Buchanan, the medalist and former Philadelphia district amateur champion, shot a 72, two over par, to defeat Norman Hermann, Coatesville, by 2 up today to gain the semi-final round of the sixteenth annual Fall tournament for the Silver Bunker Trophy at the Wildwood Golf Club.

Stuart Scheftel and T. D. Boardman of the home club and T. F. Scholl of Huntington and his partner, Ray Torgerson of Queens ValLey, advanced to the final round of the Sands Point Club's first invitation Scotch foursome golf tournament by registering two victories a piece today.

Striking drivers of municipal ash collection wagons and their sympathizers, who threw bricks at police escorts, today caused temporary abandonment of Mayor S. Davis Wilson's plan to have ashes and garage collected by substitutes hired to replace the 3,000 strikers.

THE German armies that marched into the Sudeten area last week signified that the Third Reich of Adolf Hitler had become the colossus of the Continent. Hob-nailed boots ringing down upon the steep mountain roads of what was once Czechoslovakia echoed in every corner of the world, and the shadow of the swastika loomed across the Balkans darkened the route to the East.

THE New Friends of Music have just announced the programs for its sixteen Bach-Beethoven-Haydn concerts to be given on Sunday afternoons at 5:30 o'clock, Oct. 23-Feb. 19, in Town Hall. Schedules for the Carnegie Hall series will be made known later.

Production of "bantam" model cars in France, Belgium, Germany and other nations on the Continent will be switched in favor of larger types capable of carrying at least four persons, according to word brought back here last week by exporters of automobile accessories.

Miss Virginia Gebert McDouall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Gates McDouall of East Orange, was married this afternoon to Paul Alban Ward of Chicago, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Bowles Ward of Newark. The ceremony, which took place in St. Barnabas Episcopal Church, Newark, was performed by the rector, the Rev.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 7: COLONELS Barry. J. A., Adjutant General's Dep't.. Presidio of San Francisco, Calif., to retirement.

In St. John's Episcopal Church here this afternoon Miss Elizabeth Constantine Lane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Henry Lane of Tokeneke, Darien, was married to Chester E. Ingraham Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ingraham of Bristol.

A smooth-running Hill School football team overwhelmed Poly Prep of Brooklyn, 42--6, today. Opening the game with a touchdown pass from Hutt to Drumheller, Hill held sway over the visiting eleven in every quarter.

Sales and merchandising problems of machine tool dealers will be discussed tomorrow and Tuesday at the annual convention of the Associated Machine Tool Dealers of America in the Hotel Alms, Cincinnati.

We have had gloomy prophets deploring the decline of religion in the United States and predicting dire consequences among the younger generation. Apparently their premises and conclusions are both completely wrong.
The United States liner American Banker radioed today that it had rescued five members of the crew of the American motor schooner Pioneer last Sunday. The American Banker is due at Plymouth tomorrow.

Mrs. Mary Ruth Meredith Lesale, daughter of Mrs. Abbot Geer of 520 East Eighty-sixth Street, and H. Marshall Oliver of this city flew in a chartered plane to Westerly, R. I., yesterday morning and were married there by a justice of the peace.

PAINTINGS and water-colors by Annot, Rudolph Jacobi and Ethel Katz, instructors at the Master Institute of United Arts, 310 Riverside Drive, are on view in the galleries of the institute from 1 to 3 daily, including Sunday.

The extent to which forms of transportation are subsidized by Federal or local governments is the subject of a series of studies started a few years ago by Interstate Commerce Commissioner Joseph B. Eastman when he was deral Coordinator of Transportation, it was learned today.

FOR the new model-year Buick offers four eight-cylinder cars redesigned as to styling and with mechanical and handling improvements. The four models are the Series 40 Special, with 120-inch wheelbase; Series 60 Century, with wheelbase 126 inches;

Miss Hilda Lucille Daum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. George Daum of 200 West Fifty-fourth Street and Pittsburgh, was married to Frederick Darley Ogilby Jr. of Philadelphia yesterday morning at the residence here of her parents. The Rev. George F. Daum, brother of the bride, officiated.

After engaging in scoreless ties with Nutley and Belleville, Bloomfield High School's Bengals, State group four champions last year, finally broke through today in a 36-to-0 victory over South Side of Newark.
Captain A. A. Frierson's invasion of Eastern horse shows gained him three blues and as many reds during the first day of the eighteenth annual Orange fixture at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today.
Buist Warren, third-string sophomore halfback, led Tennessee to a 7-to-0 victory over Auburn on the gridiron today.
The Baldwin School at Bryn Mawr, Pa., expects to welcome 1,000 alumnae, educators and friends next week-end at a celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the institution.

THE little Hotel des Trois Couronnes at Brigue is a pleasant inn, where motorists pause gratefully as they drive down from the rigorous heights of the Simplon Pass; as an oldestablished country hotel at the foot of the Simplon it has a certain celebrity, but it possesses a sharply different claim to fame as well.

THE NEW WORK TIMES business index made a slight gain in the week ended Oct. 1, rising to 84.4 from 84.3 (revised) for the preceding week, but has failed to regain fully its losses since the 1938 high of 86.0 achieved in the week ended Sept. 17, just before the European crisis.

Robert Nelson, 210-pound sophomore center, booted a perfect placement from an angle on the 19yard line in the last 30 seconds to give Baylor University a 9-to-6 victory over the University of Arkansas today.
Reorganization of companies affiliated with the New York stock Exchange has been concluded with a change in the officers and directors of the New York Quotation Company, it was announced yesterday.

Business is turning more and more to its working personnel to discover defects in the relationship between management and labor and to find guidance in increasing mutual efficiency, Alvin E. Dodd, president of the American Management Association, said yesterday in discussing the trends of business direction brought out at the twoday Office Management Conference of the association held at the Hotel Pennsylvania last week.

Governor Lehman obtained yesterday a copy of some of the minutes of the July Kings County grand jury and began studying the details of the "fur racket" investigation conducted by District Attorney Geoghan of Brooklyn during which charges 'of bribery in the racket were reported to have been made.
Giving, an admirable demonstration of deception, power and coordination, Bronxville High School's football machine administered a 17-0 setback to Fordham Prep yesterday morning at Fordham Field.
The annual National.Horse Show, to be held in Madison Square Garden from Nov. 5 to 12, again will have its complement of attendant social activities throughout show week.

Captain Hermann Koehl, who made the first east-west transatlantic flight with Colonel James Fitzmaurice, Irish flier, and Baron Gunther von Huenefeld, died yesterday in a Munich hospital. He was 50 years old.
The varied problems of homemaking and decorating are occupying the thoughts of thousands of women now that moving days are about over.

A RIDE on the Independent subway may not be as glamorous as a spin down SunsetBoulevard in a snappy, open roadster, and the roofs of Long Island City may not be as alluring as the minarets of Hollywood, but, for all that, the Independent subway and Long Island City are assuming their unbewitching place in the cinema world once more.
Now that the European war crisis has subsided, Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, is expected to resume his trade-agreements program with renewed vigor.

Captain George E. T. Eyston, who set the land speed record of 357.5 miles an hour in his seven-ton automobile, Thunderbolt, last month, told some 200 members of the Downtown Athletic Club last week about traveling faster than the shell of a field howitzer.

The marriage of Miss Daphne Joan Dunn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pierce John Dunn of Randall Manor, S. I., to Richard E. Deems, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter A. Deems of New York and Deemston, Pa., took place here yesterday morning in the Perroquet Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Inspired by Frank Funair's sparkling 94-yard run three minutes after the kick-off, a keenly drilled Bucknell team upset Penn State, 14 to 0, today before an alumni day throng of 12,000. It marked the first time in two years that the Lions were held scoreless.

Property from the collection formed by the late Ormond G. Smith, removed from his country residence, Stepping Stones, Wheatley Hills, L. I., will be sold at auction at the Parke-Bernet Galleries on Friday afternoon and Saturday morning and afternoon.
Because of Brazil's unfavorable trade balance the Bank of Brazil last week did not liquidate commercial import drafts. This week practically the same thing happened.
This week ends with the prospect of general European peace-until the next crisis. As to when that will develop, one man's guess is as good as another's.

AT the moment that George Jefferson Smiley and his sister, Princess Lula Belle Ada Corinne step off the Prairie Express and start on foot on the final lap of the journey to Persimmon Creek they walk straight into the affections of the reader, be he little or big.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art opened to the public yesterday a special exhibition of photographs of domestic architecture in New England and New York in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. The show, which will continue through Dec. 4, is a sort of pictorial tour of Colonial dwellings, of the northern States of the Atlantic seaboard.

Confusion concerning the cities and industrial centers of Czechoslovakia which will go to the Germans as a result of concessions agreed upon at Munich was still general here yesterday, a week after occupation of the Sudeten area had formally started.
Royal Arch Masons of tne metropolitan area have set for next Sunday their second annual Royal Arch Sunday observance under the auspices of the Grand Chapter,

Registration of voters for the election Nov. 8 will start tomorrow and continue through Saturday. The polls will be open from 5 to 10:30 P. M. through Friday and on Saturday from 7 A. M. to 10:30 P. M.
Pittsburgh's record-breaking enrollment of voters climbed to 331,683 in a tabulation issued today by the Registration Commission, covering yesterday's figures.

Ever since wool was woven into cloth, textile manufacturers have been trying to prevent it from shrinking, so that a shirt will come out of the wash as big as it was when it went into water and not three sizes too small.

In the eyes of the Japanese public the drive on Hankow has become the entire Chinese-Japanese conflict at the moment. General disappointment is apparent over the fact that China's provisional capital still is uncaptured.

RESHAPING of De Soto's safetysteel bodies for 1939 models to make them four and one-half inches wider across the front compartment was announced last week by this division of Chrysler Corporation. Already dealers have seen advance units of the car in Detroit.
The pickaback seaplane Mercury ended her flight from Dundee, Scotland, to Cape Town today after an emergency landing that did not prevent her breaking one record.

THE vital place of the automobile industry in American economics is to be the underlying theme of decoration to be used this year for the National Automobile Show, which opens in Grand Central Palace on Nov. 11 for an eightday run.

Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. wrote today to Ben Martin, his 27-year-old Democratic opponent for the Congressional district seat, that he was withholding "all the secrets of how to run for Congress" until after election day.

THE Philadelphia Orchestra opens its t enty-first New York season of ten concerts Oct. 18, in Carnegie Hall, with Eugene Ormandy conducting. On the initial program are Beethoven's overture "Leonore" No. 3 and the Second symphonies of Schumann and Sibelius.

Miss Florence Josephine Pratt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Pratt of Highland, N. Y., was married to James L. Lumb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry T. Lumb of Poughkeepsie, today in the Reformed Church of New Paltz.

Mrs. Elizabeth Cole Amory of Boston was married to Dr. Hugh Cabot, advocate of socialized medicine and one of the consulting surgeons of the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., here today at a ceremony attended only by the immediate families.
FASCIST ROMANCE: The 21-yearold aviator son of Italy's dictator is soon to be a bridegroom, according to a last-week announcement linking the names of Bruno.

Pitt's Golden Panthers licked an old wound today and smashed out a 27-to-0 triumph over a gallant Duquesne University eleven-the team which rocked the football world with an upset victory over Pitt in 1936.

The plight of women refugees of Central Europe-a topic that is receiving more and more attention at club meetings-has enlisted the sympathies of many groups, although not all of them have agreed on what action would be wisest to follow at this time.

Dave Grimaldi, fullback, paced Springfield College to a 13-7 victory over Clarkson Tech on Pratt Field today. Grimaldi scored touchdowns in the second and third quarters, being practically the only Maroon back who could gain ground consistently against the visitors.
Profit-taking and week-end evening-up operations on the Board of Trade brought about today a recession of about 1 cent a bushel in wheat futures following a fractional upturn early.

President Harmon W. Caldwell of the University of Georgia has announced that beginning this Fall a State-wide survey of the archeological resources of Georgia will be made by Robert Wauchope, Assistant Professor of Archaeology at the university. Headquarters for the survey will be the university.
Technical circles learned today of an important modification introduced by the government yesterday in a decree issued last week in favor of a French engineer, Pierre Dreyfuss.

THE West Side Y. W. C. A. Camera Club will hold its first meeting on Tuesday evening. The club, under the leadership of Sherman Rutter, will hold formal meetings once a month. Members will be entitled to the use of the dark room and enlarger on laboratory nights each week.

A father and his two sons comprise the professorial staff of the Department of History at Franklin and Marshall College. Dr. H. M. J. Klein, the father, is head of the department and Audenried Professor of History.

Home runs by Joe Gordon and Bill Dickey helped the Yankees defeat the Cubs, 5--2, at the Stadium for their third successive victory. The New workers now need only to bag today's fourth game to set a record of three world championships in a row. Monte Pearson pitched yesterday for the Yanks, limiting the Chicagoans to five hits and striking 'out nine.
The emergency created in most of New England by the hurricane of Sept. 21 has now, with the exception of one dangerous circumstance, passed.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As you have recently mentioned editorially, the railroads are drifting toward government ownership and operation. Nevertheless our press and the public appear to be apathetic.

WEATHER clear, track fast. The Cubs opened with a whirlwind attack: two bases on balls and an infield hit. But nothing came of it. With the bases filled and only one out, the gallant attack stalled. Monte Pearson struck out Carl Reynolds and Gabby Hartnett "in concussion."
Representative Dies proposed today that President Roosevelt order an investigation to determine whether government officials and employes have been members of Communist or Fascist organizations.

Work Is beginning now on a color film of campus life and will continue throughout the year for release in June, in an effort to acquaint alumni and prospective students of the University of Michigan with university activities.

The National Youth Administration asked 1,000 young relief workers in this city what they thought of the NYA program and found that 90.1 per cent believed their jobs helpful as employment experience, Mrs. Mary Rodgers Lindsay, assistant director of the NYA in charge of research, announced yesterday.

NO Punch and Judy entrepreneur is Clifford C. Fischer, who last week installed in the International Casino two revues which in color and opulence and size rival anything that Broadway has seen since Mr. Fischer's last venture farther uptown.

In the Federal effort toward the rehabilitation of the areas in New England devastated by hurricane and floods, the Disaster Loan Corporation is playing an important part. In the Northeast, up to now, it has been one of the government's least known agencies.

The eight-day 26,000-mile air tour of the United States and Cuba undertaken by Alice Rogers Hager as part of the celebration of National Air Travel Week will end at 6:55 o'clock this evening at Newark Airport. She will arrive there at that time from California, the last leg of her trip.

Federal contributions to relief and recovery in this State totaled $3,075,231,570 in the period from President Roosevelt's inauguration on March 4, 1933, to June 30, 1938, according to statistics made public yesterday by H. Ferris White, regional director of the National Emergency Council.

BOONVILLE, Mo. -- Tourists traveling through Central Missouri on U. S. 40 will find the historic significance of this region called to their attention by the bronze plaque and huge red granite boulder recently placed on a wayside turnout four miles east of this old Missouri River town.

New York's treasury was $75 richer today, thanks to two consciences. Controller Tremaine revealed he had received by mail from New York City $25 from "an anonymous and presumably conscience-stricken" contributor.

The six-story building at 1,920 Broadway, corner of Sixty-fourth Street, has been leased for a long term to Midtown Chevrolet, Inc., from the Unum Real Estate Corporation through the Cross Brown Company, brokers.

The marriage of Miss Kathleen Cuthbert Vines, niece of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Graves of Flushing, Queens, to Francis H. Pfaff took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bridegroom's mother, Mrs. Edward Franz Pfaff of Spuyten Duyvil.
Led by Jim Schwartzinger, the La Salle M. A. eleven subdued Chaminade by 20-0 today. The line-up:

A record-breaking performance by Jerry Levin, 16-year-old swimming ace of Abraham Lincoln High School, marked the opening of the annual series of dual aquatic meets for the senior high school borough team championships of the Public School Athletic League in the 25-yard pool of Brooklyn Technical High School yesterday.

A number of leading educators at Eastern colleges will attend a luncheon on Thursday in honor of Miss Grace Hadow, principal of the Society of Home-Students of Oxford University, who is arriving in this country from Australia to speak at women's colleges.

A tax rate of 18.9 mills was recommended today by the budget committee of the Board of Estimate and Taxation, Greenwich, composed of Roger S. Baldwin and William Rowe, as its budget for the coming year, advocating total appropriations of $3,615,637.73.

Final tabulation of votes cast for student government leaders at Georgian Court College today assured a majority of offices to New Jersey residents, but two important positions were won by students from New York.

CYPRUS has recently issued its first King George VI coin. This is a 9 piastres silver piece showing on the obverse the crowned head of King George VI facing left and the inscription "Georgivs VI Dei Gra. Rex et Ind. Imp.," and on the reverse the two walking lions (also called Norman lions) and the inscription "Cyprus, 1938, Nine Piastres."

NEWSPAPER accounts and broadcasts of current world affairs should be homework for students, John W. Studebaker, United States Commissioner of Education, suggested during the past week, and classroom time should be devoted to discussion of the significance of it all.

The marriage of Mrs. Viola E. McMurray and Rene M. La Montagne of New York took place here shortly after noon today at Woodhull House, the Summer home of the bride in First Neck Lane, in the presence of relatives and a few close friends.

Rural medicine, in the opinion of Owen D. Young, must take a chance on "centralized dictation" in the hope of escaping "centralized authority." Mr. Young, chairman of the board of the General Electric Company, acted as chairman today of a conference on rural medicine at Mary Imogene Bassett Hospital. Summarizing earlier discussions, he said:

A proposal that the Federal Government set up a "Baby RFC" to lend money to small business men for long terms at low rates of interest on no more security than "an impartial investigation into the character and business record of the applicant" was made last night by Walter H. Liebman, Democratic candidate for Representative from the Seventeenth Congressional District in Manhattan.

Charges by Republican candidates in New Jersey that WPA workers in that State had been subjected to political coercion during the Congressional campaign led Aubrey Williams, Acting Works Progress Administrator, today to send Francis H. Dryden, field representative of the WPA in charge of the Middle Atlantic States, into New Jersey to conduct a personal investigation.

Religion and Christian thinking are at the "big moment" when humanity can be served on an unprecedented scale, in the opinion of Dr. John R. Mott, chairman of the International Missionary- Council and president of the World Alliance of the Y. M. C. A. Dr. Mott sailed Thursday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary to attend the World Missionary Congress in Madras, India.

Hunting with beagles is attracting more attention in this colony than any other sport introduced in years. Angier Biddle Duke, master of the Duckhollow Foot Beagles here, introduced the sport in this section. Interest is not confined to any age.

EXCEPTIONALLY varied fare is available to the chronic gallery visitor in a dozen recently opened exhibitions. Alf J. Stromsted, a Norwegian-American artist, whose paintings have appeared in group exhibitions, is making his solo debut at Contemporary Arts.

ALOVL--RSTERNBERGER--Mrs. Rose B. Sternberger announces the marriage of her daughter, Evelyn Starr, to Edward G. Alovis, Sunday, Oct. 2, 1938. BAYER--ROSEN--Mr. and Mrs. Norman Rosen of New York City announce the marriage of their daughter, Marjorie, to H. Stanley Bayer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Bayerof this city, Oct. 7, 1938.
Sales of General Motors automobiles to American and Canadian dealers, together with overseas shipments, totaled 36,335 last month, compared with 82,317 in September last year.

Occasional displays of strong line work and the sturdy play of Shaun Meehan enabled the Williams football team to top Norwich, 13-6, today. Williams opened the scoring, Captain Larry Durrell going across in the first period after Meehan had put the ball into position with two long runs.

NEXT Thursday marks the twenty-fifth anniversary of THE NEW YORK TIMES American Aerial Derby, a dash around the island of Manhattan by five airmen that startled and thrilled thousands of persons in New York and throughout the world.

Some of the most important spade work conducted in Washington in many a day is now in process here for the forthcoming joint CongressionalDepartmental investigation of monopoly and the concentration of economic power.

Boat owners had better change their minds and plot courses in other directions if they were intending to spend some October and November days on the Great South Bay waterways from Patchogue to the Shinnecock Canal.

Garden clubs in the larger cities have of late been stressing the desirability of planting window boxes for Winter decoration. Some suburban garden club members, quick to take the hint, are pointing out the advantages of this plan for their own localities.

Mortimer L. Nathanson, chairman of the legislative committee of the Brooklyn Insurance Brokers Association, Inc., has been elected to the board of directors and made a member of the executive committee of the Insurance Federation of the State of New York.

A TYPICAL high-geared hard-working New Yorker is Gramercy Knickerbocker Jones of Manhattan. A chap with a fine, keen, trained mind, he attracts and carries heavy responsibilities. Being that sort, too, he is as sensitive to pressure as a. barometer.

Four conferences in Princeton University's School of Public and International Affairs for the coming academic year were announced today by Professor De Witt Clinton Poole, director of the school. The school started its ninth year this Fall with an enrollment of ninetyfour students.

A proposal for what is generally believed to be the largest naval appropriation in peace time is being studied by the Bureau of the Budget. No details have been made public and none will be until the Budget Bureau completes its work and the recommended appropriation goes to the President for his approval.

A superior St. Anselm College football team easily defeated Brooklyn College, 39 to 0, before 1,500 spectators at Athletic Field today. Ray McLean, flashy pilot for the Hawks, scored four touchdowns in three periods.

Miss Evelina Fuguet McClure, daughter of Mrs. Yvonne Fuguet McClure of En La Sombra, Bala-Cynwyd, and of Major Linwood Dunham McClure of Norristown, was married this evening to John Shaw Lafean, son of Mrs. Wilbur Leroy Lafean of Wynnewood and of the late Mr. Lafean.

The greatest enemy of Christianity today is the "godless professor" in secular education, the biennial convention of the United Lutheran Church in America was told here today during a discussion of Lutheran higher education. Greater support was urged for Lutheran institutions in a world "hostile to the church."
A mysterious explosion early today damaged the Eastwood Mills, a large factory building that houses several textile concerns.
A panel discussion on "Federal Aid to Education" will feature the Connecticut State meeting of the American Association of University Women, convening Saturday at Edgewood School, Greenwich.

MEXICO CITY. THE celebration early in September of the tenth anniversary of the founding of the Symphony Orchestra of Mexico marked the conclusion of a historic decade in Mexican music. During this period Mexico was brought abreast of the modern musical world in a development which encompassed cultured society, illiterate day laborers and thousands of school children.

MAN'S boundless courage in the face of disaster could hardly be expressed in more convincing terms than by the speed with which reconstruction progresses in those sections of eight Eastern States crushed by the three-hour hurricane of Sept. 21 and subsequent floods.

Dr. Sigismund S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals of this city, and Mrs. Goldwater of 320 Central Park West and Huntington, L. I., have announced the marriage, on Sept. 12, in Paris, France, of their son, Robert J. Goldwater, and Miss Louise Bourgeois, daughter of Louis Bourgeois of Paris, and the late Mrs. Bourgeois.

The restored birthplace of John Morton, whose vote in the Continental Congress was credited with putting Pennsylvania on the side of independence, was dedicated today at Prospect Park, ten miles southwest of this city.

THE New York auction houses are about to resume normal operations minus the presence of Mitchell Kennerley. That he will be missed there can be no question, particularly in the light of his brilliant record at the American Art Anderson Galleries last season.

The United States liner Washingon arrived yesterday from Havre, Southampton and Cobh with 816 Passengers after having omitted her visual call at Hamburg because of he war crisis and the rush of american tourists to get home.
SCARCELY had the Bruno Walter set of Brahms's First symphony been considered for mention here last week when there arrived a fresh recording of the Fourth.

LONDON. NOT since the Great Fire of 1666 has London been the subject of a town planning scheme so comprehensive as the thirty-year plan Sir Charles Bressey recently completed for the Ministry of Transport.

Bryn Mawr College is pointing with pride to its new James E. Rhoads Residence Hall, the planning and furnishing of which represent composite views of members of the administration, faculty, alumnae and undergraduates.
Carnegie tech ran roughshod over Wittenberg College today, trimming the Lutherans, 32 to 13, in an intersectional football game. The visitors lost no time in scoring.

When President Roosevelt signed the Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1938 on Feb. 16 he defined the basic farm policy of the nation as "to assure agriculture a fair share of an increasing national income, to provide consumers with abundant supplies of food and fiber, to stop waste of soil and to reduce the gap between huge surpluses and disastrous shortages."

The marriage of Miss Frances Patricia Murray, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Charles Murray 'of East Orange, to Robert Claude Remley, son of Ernest Remley, also of East Orange, took place this morning in the rectory of Our Lady Help of Christians Church here.

The Yankees will take the field at the Stadium today for the fourth contest of the world series favorites to win the game. If they triumph they will deal a blow to the books that laid 5 and 6 to 1 against them to win in four straight.

LIFE among the playwrights, life among their works: Somewhere knocking around Broadway is a new script by A. E. Thomas, last represented on The Street by last season's "Merely Murder." The new one: simply "Palace."

To the Art Editor: MANY solitary workers in unsuspected places must have been heartened by your analyses of the problems that bemuse painters and other creative artists who are honestly struggling to relate their work and their surroundings.

The marriage of Miss Mary Fisher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. Fisher of Pottsville, Pa., to Donald C. Plumb, son of Mrs. Charles Plumb of Terryville, Conn., and the late Mr. Plumb, took place yesterday morning in the Church of the transfiguration.

Secretary Wallace reiterated tonight, in a letter made public after the Federal Crop Reporting Board had forecast a large increase in this year's cotton crop, that new processing taxes should be enacted to finance subsidy payments to cotton growers.

Generalities about Wall Street are almost always wrong. The "average" Stock Exchange house, if it ever existed, probably went out of business in 1929. But it is probably true that a large proportion of the brokerage firms in the Street are one-person organizations.

The course of financial markets, home and foreign, even before the dispute over Czechoslovakia's Sudeten territory became acute, indicated pretty clearly that misgiving over the chance of a European conflict was then a potent influence.

Bernard Kundell, gifted young New York violinist, made his initial bow as recitalist last night at Town Hall under the auspices of the Society for the Advancement of Young Musicians. In a difficult program, well chosen to display technical prowess and comprehension of style in sharply contrasted types of composition, Mr. Kundell made an easy conquest of a large audience by the many laudable characteristics of his performances.
The railroad brotherhoods opened their case before the President's Fact-Finding Board today with an attack on the importance of the cost-of-living factor in wage-rate determination.

THE main item of news this morning concerns the Group Theatre-concerns specifically some dates and names of those who will be involved in "Rocket to the Moon" and "Gentle People," or the Group's first and second offerings of this new season.
Play in the Meadow Brook Club's annual Fall invitation best-ball handicap golf tournament got under way today, with twenty-eight combinations seeing action in the four flights.

Charles E. Wissner, formerly secretary of the Brooklyn piano firm of Wissner Sons, Inc., died Friday at his home, 868 Sterling Place, Brooklyn, at the age of 59. A native of Brooklyn, he was a nephew of the late Otto Wissner, founder of the piano company, and had been associated with the firm for thirty years, retiring last February.
Garner (Slim) Enterline, aged 29, a racing automobile driver of Philadelphia, died in a hospital today soon after his car had crashed through a fence at the fair grounds here.

Hamilton College tied a heavier Hobart eleven today, 13--13. Trailing as the fourth quarter opened, Hamilton scored twice on plunges by Erickson. Ferris's first and fourthquarter touchdowns accounted for Hobart's scores. Hamilton outgained and outrushed Hobart, scoring 17 first downs tot Hobart's 9.

With the removal of the cooperative housekeeping group at Vassar Colin honor of Jean Culbert Palmer, House this project, started as a depression emergency measure in 1933, becomes an established unit in the social economy of the college.

Miss Georgia Straub, daughter of Mrs. Herman L. Hoering of 36 Riverside Drive and of the late Frederick E. Straub, was married here yesterday morning to George J. Hossenlopp, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. J. A. Hossenlopp of Rutherford, N. J.
A conference looking to the stimulation of all types of private construction was announced today by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States to be held here Oct. 20 and 21.

The Woman's College of the University of North Carolina is starting this Fall one of the largest building programs in its history. By Nov. 15 work will have begun on a $300,000 Science Building, the first structure in its $800,000 project.

A last-quarter uprising today gave Vermont a 9-6 victory over Colby before 2,000 football fans. His team trailing by six points late in the game, Bill Pye, Vermont end, grabbed a fumble by Daggett of Colby and dashed 20 yards to tie the score. Frank Taylor booted the point.

Donald C. L. Murray, general secretary of the International Federation of Housing and Town Planning, died last night in the Garfield Hospital at the age of 48. He was a son of Sir Hugh Murray, Hampshire, England.

Miss Jean Adrienne Kefauver, daughter of Colonel Lloyd A. Kefauver, Medical Corps, U. S. A., now stationed in Boston, and Mrs. Kefauver, was married yesterday afternoon to Lieutenant Glenn Cole, U. S. A., son of Colonel Otis R. Cole, U. S. A., and Mrs. Cole of Fort McDowell, Calif.

The mortgage insurance business on residential properties in the New York City area completed by the FHA during the first nine months of this year was 95 per cent greater than during the same period of 1937, Thomas G. Grace, State FHA director, announced yesterday.

Formal consideration of the- plan for establishing a cooperative organization of liquor importers and distillers for the enforcement of fair trade laws in the sale of their products, will be given by the National Association of Alcholic Beverage Importers, Inc., at their annual convention in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow.
Hendrik Willem Van Loon, author and historian, returning from Europe Friday on the Swedish liner Kungsholm after completing his first visit to Europe in six years, said it would probably be his last.

A record crowd of 10,000, spread out over the rolling green acres of the Rolling Rock Hunt Club, gathered today under sunny skies to witness the fourth annual running of the International Gold Cup Steeplechase at three and one-half miles over brush.
Japanese cavalry, which Cut tne Peiping-Hankow Railway, eightyeight miles north of Hankow and twelve miles south of Sinyang on Friday, was driven away yesterday and railway traffic was resumed.

The marriage of Miss Catherine Eleanor Witherspoon, daughter ,of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Garrison Witherspoon of Riverdale-on-Hudson, to Jerome Kidder, son of Mrs. Hugh Kidder, also of Riverdale, and the late Dr. Kidder, took place yesterday morning ir the. Church of St. Margaret's.

The Purchase horse show held here today at the Purchase Stables benefited the Orthopedic Dispensary and Hospital in White Plains. Miss Jeanette Eastman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lee J. Eastman of New Rochelle, and Mrs. Owen H. Clarke of New Rochelle and Van Nuys, Calif., were co-chairmen of the event.

The report of Roan Antelope Copper Mines, Ltd., for the fiscal year ended on June 30, which was made public yesterday, shows a profit of $1,575,068 after expenses, debenture interest, reserve for replacement and obsolescence and other charges, but before taxation.

The second annual theatre benefit sponsored by the Westchester County Children's Association will be held on the evening of Oct. 18 at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre, New York, under the chairmanship of Mrs. Mason B. Starring Jr., of Irvington-on-Hudson .

Two former winners will meet in the final round of the twentieth annual Arcola invitation golf tournament tomorrow. Charles Whitehead of Plainfield, N. J., State amateur champion, and Charles Clare of Racebrook, the Connecticut champion, came through after brilliant performances.

OSCAR WILDE-Tomorrow evening at the Fulton Theatre. A biographical play by Leslie and Sewell Stokes, with Robert Morley, who played the role at London's Gate Theatre, in the part of Wilde; with Mark Dignam, John Buckmaster, Edward Trevor, Harold Young, John Carol, J. W. Austin and Oswald Yorke in the cast.

Pressure on the part of business for some form of institution to meet the needs of small enterprises seeking capital loans will compel the creation of intermediate banks before the end of the coming year, industrialists, business executives and bankers agreed here yesterday.
New York State's government is "better managed than any business in the world," Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, said today in an address here before the New York State Insurance Federation.

Dezso D'Antalffy has been engaged by the Philharmonic-Symphony Society to succeed the late Melchoir Mauro-Cottone as organist of the orchestra, it was announced yesterday. Mr. D'Antalffy is at present the organist at Radio City Music Hall.
