The German menace to Britain, which a fortnight ago took the form in most persons' minds here of bombing aircraft, has been converted by' the activities of German Economics Minister Walther Funk in Turkey and elsewhere into a commercial juggernaut of alarming dimensions.

Washington is poised for the 1938-39 social season the moment the White House gives the expected signal. Within the next ten days, if other important matters don't intervene, that signal will come when the First Lady of the Land announces thE dates for the state events of the Winter.

Overpowering a helpless University of Maryland team with a fine display of running and passing, Syracuse University scored a 53-to-0 football victory today before a crowd of 8,500 fans in Archbold Stadium. Marty Glickman tallied three times, once on an 80-yard dash and again on one of 40.

The increase of 387,000 bales in a month in the government's estimate of the cotton crop to a total of 12,212,000 bales as of Oct. 1 was not expected yesterday by the trade, but prices on the Cotton Exchange eased only 45 to 70 cents a bale as a result of the announcement.
A RECORD of journeyings in the Near and Far East, Mrs. Merrick's "Caucus Race" is more than an ordinary travel book. The adventures and humors of the road are delightfully related;
A regular meeting of the Board of Education will be held on Wednesday at 4 P. M. at 500 Park Avenue. Election of an associate superintendent of schools is scheduled.

THESE are the recollections of a man who has for many years been one of New York's most successful trial lawyers. The bulk of the book concerns celebrated cases wherein Mr. Wellman acted either as prosecutor or counsel.

Dr. Walter T. Marvin, dean of the College of Arts and Sciences at Rutgers University, has announced the names of ninety-nine sophomores, juniors and seniors who achieved honor school ranking during the 1937-38 college year.

Virginia Polytechnic Institute ran away with the William and Mary eleven today before 4,500 fans with a score of 27 to 0. It was the worst defeat Virginia Tech had handed the Indians since their gridiron series was resumed in 1929.

Professor Bernhard Geiger, who for many years held the Chair for Indian and Iranian Philology in the University of Vienna, arrived yesterday on the United States liner Washington with his wife and daughter, Ruth, to take up his residence in this country. He said his parents and two sisters- and two brothers came to America in 1902.
THE motion picture as a medium of visual education has been "just around the corner" for so many years that many have come to regard it as a fairly well established supplement to the textbook.
John J. Rammacher, president of the Eastern Grain Elevator Corporation, died here late yesterday at the age of 58. He was severely injured a week ago when a saddle horse he was riding fell on him.

NOW is the time when the landscape is swathed in a multicolored cloak of Fall foliage, and the amateur photographer wandering afield cannot overlook, if he is at all sensitive to beauty, the scene that nature has spread before him.
THE Federal Project's performances of Flotow's "Martha" in the Music Theatre this week will employ an esthetic born of necessity.

New York's old age relief rolls have increased only 8 per cent in a year that has seen some Western States brought to the rim of bankruptcy by pressure from Townsend plan advocates and their political allies, State and Federal welfare officials reported yesterday.

Columbia and Army staged another thriller in picturesque Michie Stadium today before a gathering of 25,000 which was limp and emotionally exhausted at the finish. A Cadet eleven that looked supremely invincible as it rode a 12-0 lead in the first quarter bowed in the end to the passing wizardry of Sid Luckman.

Now, when gardeners are busily engaged in planning and planting for next Spring's bulb gardens, the chance to provide for beautiful flowers from bulbs indoors during the Winter is too often overlooked. Tulips, hyacinths, daffodils, crocuses and many of the smaller-but equally lovely-Spring flowering bulbs can be grown for an indoor display.

Alert for every opportunity and clicking with precision on its drives, New York University's football eleven handed Rutgers a 25-to-6 setback on Neilson Field today in the thiry-fifth gridiron meeting between the rivals.
Army officers in the Panama Canal Department now have a rare alibi in case any one questions their visits to Panama hot spots. They can say the general sent them.

A. A. U. W. (Nassau County chapter)--Meeting, 6 P. M., home of Miss Florence McDermott, Hempstead. Athena Club of Freeport--Music department meetings, 2:30 P. M. Carroll Club--Tea. John Brunini, speaker, 5 P. M.
Michael Babyak, 14 months old, fell six floors from the tenementhome of his parents at 610 East Ninth Street yesterday afternoon and escaped virtually unhurt.

After a week's conferences with Chilian leaders, Dr. Rudolf Grossman, president of the SpanishAmerican Institute of Berlin, visited President Arturo Alessandri today to stress the importance of cultural relations between Germany and Chile.

A crop of 12,212,000 bales of cotton this year was forecast today by the Department of Agriculture, as of Oct. 1, which is 5,361,000 bales under the forecast of Oct. 1, last year, when the United States produced its record crop.

Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for Governor, speaking at several campaign rallies in Manhattan, attacked the Democratic party yesterday as "the party of Frank Hague," and charged it with responsibility for the suppression of civil rights.

Russia n is making paper from dogbane, weed of wide-spread growth in the United States, and similar production here was possible, Dr. Robert E. Woodson, assistant curator of the herbarium at Shaw's Gaden, declared today.
The Juniata Indians galloped to a 66-to0 victory over the New York Aggies eleven before a capacity Parents Day crowd today. Every man on the Juniata squad saw action.

George W. Lederer, theatrical manager and producer often referred to as the Ziegfield of his day, died early yesterday in the Physicians Hospital, Seventy-third Street and Thirty-fourth Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens. He was 76 years old.
Connecticut State's superior offensive play subdued the Massachusetts State eleven, 19--0, today. The game was marred by many fumbles on both sides.

Departmental elections at the city College which were held during the past two days under the provisions of the new Board of Higher Education by-law resulted in the election of eight new department chairmen and the re-election of seventeen other heads, according to the results announced by Dr. Nelson P.

FROM the beginning of his incumbency as general director of the Metropolitan Opera Association, Edward Johnson was confronted with two major problems. They related both to the artistic and the financial recovery of the organization from the disasters consequent upon the financial panic of 1929.
New Zealand's Socialist Government will face its first election test Oct. 15, and the most bitter electoral fight in memory is now under way.
The fourteenth annual convention of the New York State Council of Polish-American Democratic Clubs opened yesterday at the Polish National Home, 19-23 St. Marks Place.

Daniel J. Tobin, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, was defeated today when he sought to have the executive council of the A. F. of L. make an additional peace move toward the C. I. O.

Al Brosch, professional at Bethpage State Park, today won the Metropolitan P. G. A. championship over the Oceanside Golf Club course by defeating Mike Turnesa of Fairview, 3 and 2. The match ended when Turnesa, already 2 down, was stymied fifteen feet from the cup.

The investigation launched last week by William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, into alleged corruption in the courts and law enforcement agencies of Brooklyn, which led to Governor Lehman's intervention, had been expected ever since Mayor La Guardia, in his last campaign, promised to send "another Dewey into Brooklyn."

Marking the second consecutive monthly gain this year, toy sales in September showed a rise of 28 per cent over the same month last year, according to the preliminary report for last month announced yesterday by James L. Fri, executive director of the Toy Manufacturers of the U. S. A. The cumulative totals for the nine months are incomplete as yet, Mr. Fri said.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Louise Palmer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Grant Palmer of this place, to John Knipe Herrmann, son of Mrs. Charles Edward Herrmann oY Scarsdale and the late Mr. Herrmann, took place here at noon today in St. Luke's Church.

DETROIT. AUTOMOTIVE production and employment continued strong here last week with the return of the Ford Motor Company to new model output on a partial basis. The company is expected to get under way in much greater volume next week.

The future of peace in Europe depends largely upon whether the Slavic nations will strengthen themselves and unite to create a counter-force to prevent further German expansion, aided by British and French efforts to neutralize Czechoslovakia, Raymond Leslie Buell, president of the Foreign Policy Association, declared yesterday at the organization's first luncheon meeting of the year.
Prior to the opening here tomorrow of the National Conference of Catholic Charities, diocesan directors of that organization considered today methods of improving public relations.

WILLIAM L. LATHROP, N. A., of New Hope, who was lost from his sailboat at Montauk, L. I., during the recent hurricane, had expected to spend another week aboard his boat painting before returning home for the Winter.

Miss Elizabeth Brooks Lewis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Lewis of Sunnydale Farm, Paoli, was married this afternoon to Thomas Willoughby Pope, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Richard D. Pope of Westbury, L. I. Dr. Pope performed the ceremony,

Residential construction gives every evidence of continuing through the balance of the year at a high degree of activity, declared Stewart McDonald, FHA Administrator, yesterday in announcing that the financing work of the organization for September showed that small home mortgages selected for appraisal had an aggregate volume of $98,431,975, being an inerease of 117 per cent over September, 1937.

Twenty-six scholarships in Columbia College have been awarded on nomination of alumni organizations to freshmen who come from public and private schools in eleven States, L Dean Herbert E. Hawkes announced yesterday.

Umpire Charley Moran, veteran of the. diamond and gridiron and former coach of Centre College's "Praying Coloneis" was painfully though not seriously injured yesterday in the fifth inning of the third world series game at the Yankee Stadium.
Massachusetts State College will grant the Bachelor of Arts degree for the first time in June as a result of recent trustee action.

The gardener who attempts to get along without a cold-frame of some sort is handicapping himself severely-and unnecessarily. For it can scarcely be successfully argued that a frame cannot be afforded.

Miss Elizabeth Chase Aery, daughter -of William Anthony Aery, director of education at Hampton Institute, and of the late Mrs. Clara Thompson Chase Aery, was married this afternoon in her father's home to Roland Ebeltoft Olson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lauritz M. Olson of Lake Park, Minn.

If the press were "to fail in its trust, if it and all other agencies of discussion abuse their freedom, the consequences to democracy will be fatal," Premier Angus L. Macdonald of Nova Scotia told the Nova Scotia Weekly Newspapers Association last night.

Miss Charlotte Metcalfe Stone, daughter of Mrs. William M. Stone of Flushing, Queens, and the late Dr. Stone, was married to Robert Maynard Holberton of this city, formerly of Bowling Green, Va., yesterday afternoon in St. George's Episcopal Church, Flushing. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Hubert S. Wood.

Eighteen classifications of store expense by functions will be surveyed in the study of store operation costs now under way under the auspices of the Metropolitan Controllers Association, it was stated yesterday by Leo C. Levin, chairman of the organization. Graphs are being prepared and will be ready next month.
Teschen, claimed by Poland on the ground that the population is overwhelmingly Polish, has about 50 per cent Czechoslovak inhabitants, according to the last census, it is pointed out here.

With the lifting of the European crisis, business and financial leaders were able last week to make a reappraisal of the economic outlook. For many weeks all efforts to forecast the probable course of business and the financial markets have had to be qualified by the possibility of a general European war.

While the existence of this State continues to be endangered, the realistic character of the Czechoslovaks is manifesting itself in the government's unceasing efforts to save as much as possible from the wreck by opening immediate commercial and financial relations with Germany.

THE radio audience is divided into two general classifications--set owners who use their radios more or less as a utility and those who follow the programs from day to day. The former are casual listeners; the latter earnest listeners.
While "open-market" sales of property in Manhattan have been tending upward in recent months, the trend in foreclosures has been notably downward.

The Iowa State Cyclone swept a dark cloud over Nebraska's hopes for a fourth consecutive Big Six Conference football championship by conquering the Cornhuskers, 8 to 7, today. It was the first time Iowa State defeated Nebraska since 1919.

Although the Arabs may be ready to accept the plan of the Iraq Foreign Minister, Tewfik Bey Sweily, for granting equal rights and the gradual establishment of a national representative government in Palestine, the Jews here rejected it on the ground that it would leave them in the status of a permanent minority.

The passports of all German Jews, regardless of the date of issue, will be invalid as from Oct. 7 for travel into a foreign country unless countersigned by the Ministry of the Interior, according to a decree published in the Official Gazette today.
The fall in world prices for foodstuffs and raw materials is presending to Australia a new problem in Federal and State relations in the field of finance.

John Borican of the Shore A. C., Asbury Park, set a new American record today when he won the National A. A. U. pentathlon with 3,304 points, breaking the former record of 3,030, held by Eulace Peacock, who did not defend his title.

Dedication exercises for the new Squibb Institute for Medical Research, occupying a $750,000 laboratory building at New Brunswick, N. J., will be held at 2 P. M. Tuesday in the gymnasium of Rutgers UniVersity.

The 4,000--foot concrete and steel loop roadway approach to the Lincoln Tunnel in New Jersey, between Weehawken and Pleasant Avenue, Union City, will be opened to traffic on Saturday at noon, according to an announcement yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.

JOHN HAY. the centennial of whose birth occurs this week, was poet, novelist, historian, journalist, politician and diplomat, and in each of these careers attained some measure of success. But it is as the Secretary of State who sponsored the policy known as the Open Door that he is chiefly remembered today.

Brown University alumni will have a greater opportunity this year than in the past to share in interests and activities related to the work and welfare of their alma mater, under plans which are being mapped by the Associated Alumni in cooperation with the university.

Two dispatches touching on the Dust Bowl area offer a study in contrasts. The first is from Washington. The Northern Great Plains Committee. reporting to President Roosevelt, finds that the people in parts of the Dakotas, Wyoming, Nebraska and Montana "would be little better equipped on the whole to cope with a serious drought next year than they were in 1930."
Adelhi Academy of Brooklyn defeated Hopkins School, 14 to 7. in a stirring football battle today. Herzog and Guidet scored for the visitors, Falsey for Hopkins.

Mixed price movements ruled in trading in bonds yesterday throughout the two-hour session on the New York Stock Exchange. Secondary railroad issues were the focus of speculative interest in the domestic section, while dealings in other major groups, including United States Government and foreign loans, were dull and fluctuations were restricted to a narrow range.
HISTORIES of American government designed to show that it is an unrelieved black record of corruption are not wholly new Mr. Loth's, however, differs in certain notable respects from any predecessor.

A carrier pigeon sired by a German pigeon which alighted on an American warship off the English coast during the World War has been presented to the former owner of the German pigeon by the United States Army.

Three thousand persons, including fifty of the men who served as officers in the old Sixty-ninth Infantry during the World War, watched a review of the 165th Infantry last night in the regimental armory at Twenty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue.

OF all great figures in history, Christopher Columbus has probably suffered the most in reputation by the writings of historians. His biographers during the last fifty years have run the gamut between the sentimental idealization of Roselly de Lorgues and the excessive disparagement of Cecil Jane, Henry Vignaud and a host of lesser imitators.

IN no other part of the world has history been written at a rate so rapid as in the territory of the former Austro-Hungarian Empire. Twenty years ago this month the mighty structure of the House of Habsburg collapsed and the lands over which it had ruled were distributed among seven nations.

Two Republican Senators predicted today that their party would muster a force in the next Congress which would be able, with some Democratic help, to prevent the passage of "objectionable" New Deal legislation.

The American Republics liner Brazil, first vessel of the "Good Neighbor Fleet" to the east coast of South America sailed yesterday from Pier 59, foot of West Eighteenth Street, with 155 passengers. The list included a good-will mission from the United States to the South American countries where the ship will call.

A plan to start a court action to compel the Board of Elections to replace its present staff of eighty appointed administrative employes through competitive examinations will be considered Tuesday by the executive committee of the Civil Service Reform Association, it was announced yesterday by H. Eliot Kaplan, executive secretary.

Credit sales promotion, scientific cost finding in credit operations and the development of better community credit control were cited as "new worlds to conquer" in consumer credit research by J. Anton Hagios, manager of the credit management division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, in an address here today before the Ohio State University Institute of Credit.

R. H. Helsel smashed fifty straight at the traps of the Bergen Beach Gun Club on Gravesend Bay yesterday to carry off the high gun prize in a field of twenty-one. The handicap honors were taken in a shootoff by R. Annunzetto, with a run of twenty-five.
IN quest of new voices. "the Metropolitan Opera Auditions of the Air" today begins the 1938-39 "search," which will end in the Spring with two singers awarded contracts with the "Met."

IN 1929 James Branch Cabell sent to friends and acquaintances a Christmas card bearing a sketch of himself sweeping books and writing material from his desk, and captioned: "Now That I Am Come to Be Fifty." He further announced that he had completed "The Biography of Manuel" and was through with writing forever.
President Leon Cortes withdrew the Costa Rica-Panama boundary treaty from Congress this afternoon on the recommendation of twentyfour members of Congress.

Starting its second year of shortwave broadcasting of lectures to an international audience, Harvard University announced today a reorganization of its program whereby departments or schools will take turns each month in the 1938-39 series.

One of seven men who allegedly raided a pigeon loft on the roof at 82 East 113th Street and stole twenty-one homing pigeons, valued at $25 apiece, was held in $1,000 bail for hearing on Tuesday when arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Rothenberg in Felony Court.
Allan Haywood, New York regional director of the C. I. O., tonight assailed William Green, president of the A. F. of L., for not striving toward peace between the two labor organizations.

Retail sales turned downward last week in several districts, and weather was usually blamed. Unseasonably warm temperatures in the West and Southwest nipped a budding improvement in Fall apparel sales.

Stressing the importance of providing adequate care for the historic relics of the United States Navy where they might be a source of inspiration to all youths who are being trained as officers in the service, Rear Admiral David Foote Sellers, U. S. N., retired, today laid the cornerstone of the Naval Academy Museum and delivered the address at the ceremonies.

A REPORT, as yet unconfirmed, has drifted in that Germany is issuing a stamp to celebrate Hitler's acquisition of Sudetenland. If the rumor is based on fact, this will be no surprise to collectors in the light of precedent, as Germany released postal paper of that character after recovering the Saar region in 1935 and after seizing Austria in 1938.

AMONG the opening exhibitions of the season, that at Kraushaar's (till Oct. 22) is espe cially noteworthy, consisting as it does of paintings by French and American artists, the works having been selected with an eye to contrasts.

Two detectives of the East Fiftyfirst Street station yesterday halted the planned career of crime of 17-year-old Joseph J. Orosz of 2,082 Hughes Avenue, the Bronx, when they arrested him for violation of the Sullivan Law and took charge of his loaded .32 calibre automatic pistol and thirty-four spare bullets in his pockets.

A municipal reception committee greeted officers of the New HollandAmerica motorship Noordam as it docked here today on its maiden voyage, inaugurating a new steamship service between Philadelphia and The Netherlands.
One immediate result of last week's conferences on the Palestine question was seen tonight when the Colonial office announced that four battalions of infantry--with the necessary auxiliaries,

American and foreign wheat markets parted company last week, the latter sinking to lower levels than before the recent war scare. The decline in prices abroad is considered here a reflection of the bearish construction placed on the world's supply-anddemand situation and pressure from exporting countries.
The Lalor Foundation announced today the program for its third series of fellowship awards, authorizing grants to the total amount of $25,000 for the academic year 1939-40.
Premier Benito Mussolini's withdrawal of 10,000 men from Spain and Chancellor Adolf Hitler's speech at Saarbruecken today,

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 48 per cent of capacity, up 1 point and restoring the rate of two weeks ago. This rate is considered high, seeing that there is almost no railroad demand and little support by the automobile and building industries.
It seems that the men who seek sport with the long bow and the broadhead arrow are coming into their own at long last, for a number of States are now permitting hunters to use this weapon.
The fourth annual specialty event of the Newark Boston Terrier Club today saw Champion Rockefeller's Ace, owned by W. C. Ely of Zionville, Pa., take best-in-show honors.

Peter Paul Peebles, associate professor of jurisprudence at William and Mary College, died of a heart attack last night at the age of 52. A member of the William and Mary faculty since 1924, he had previously been in business in Norfolk.

Pilgrim Ave (15-4193): e s, 263 ft s of Liberty St. 50x100; Kathryn C. Papineau to Philip Russo, 2,214 Eastern Blvd. Needham Ave, 1.426 (16-4719); Christopher Sapienga to Carlo De Luca, 1,413 Needham Ave.

The world wide mission of the Christian church was stressed by the Rev. H. M. Shuman, president of the Christian and Missionary Alliance, in his annual missionary sermon yesterday at the Gospel Tabernacle, Eighth Avenue near Forty-third Street.

Dr. Forde Morgan, since 1908 medical director of the Sterling Products Company and its predecessor, the Charles H. Phillips Company, died Saturday night at his home, 1,328 University Avenue, Bronx, after a six weeks illness of heart disease.
Andrew H. Manson, who won the Southern amateur golf championship in 1905 and 1908, died here today of a heart ailment. His age was 60.
Figures of France's foreign trade in September have just been issued. They show imports amounting to 3,534,000,000 francs, against 3,709,000,000 in August and 3,498,000,000 in September, 1937.
Harvey G. Rockwell of the insurance and real estate firm of his name at 182 East 122d Street died Friday of a heart attack in a drug store on Forty-second Street near the Grand Central Terminal.

Combined net earnings of the Marine Midland Corporation and its constituent banks, trust companies and other affiliates for the quarter ended on Sept. 30, after taxes and adjustments to minority interest, were $905,478, according to the corporation's report to the New York Stock Exchange.
The discovery of a desert crime involving the deaths of seven persons was reported today in a newspaper published in the holy Moslem city of Nejaf.

John Haynes Holmes in a sermon yesterday at Town Hall where a Community Church service was held defended the actions of Prime Minister Chamberlain and Premier Daladier, who yielded to Hitler's demands.

Christ is the true friend of the laborer, the poor and the unemployed today just as He was while a carpenter of Nazareth, the Rev. William J. Smith said in a sermon yesterday at the Church of St. Francis Xavier, 30 West Sixteenth Street.

A well-balanced ground and air attack gave the Niagara University Eagles a 20-to-7 victory today over Providence College. The Eagles scored their first touchdown shortly after the opening kick-off when they recovered a fumble and crossed the goal line in eight plays.

" It's the Best Team in the Land," the Yankee theme song, figuratively crashed through the walls of the Yankee clubhouse yesterday as the American League champions came rushing into their quarters, bubbling over with joy at their fourth straight victory over the Cubs in the world series.

St. Andrew's Protestant Episcopal Church on Arthur Kill Road, Richmond, S. I., began yesterday a week's celebration of its 230th anniversary. Three hundred parishioners and guests attended services led by the Rev. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of Trinity Church in Manhattan.
Despite a personal appeal by Governor Lehman, delegates to the State convention of the New York State Council of Polish Democratic Clubs, which claims to represent 500,000 voters,
Applications are now open for the following positions. Details are available at the office of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, Municipal Building, or in the City Record:

Donald Hallman, victor in the first two sessions, lost to Dr. P. Schlesinger in the third round of the preliminaries in the annual tournament for the championship of the Marshall Chess Club yesterday. Dr. Schlesinger, with the black pieces, scored in thirty moves.

Residential properties on the West Side of Manhattan were involved in many of the realty sales reported by brokers over the week-end. Several of the houses had been held by the seller for a long time.

Detective Herman Rave of the West 123d Street station is looking for the owner of a diamond ring valued at $1,000 which a porter said he found in Rockefeller Center about two week ago, it was tevealed yesterday.
Although still unsettled, the pound sterling is showing greater stability within its present narrower range of fluctuation.

More than 3,000 members of the Third Order of St. Francis made a pilgrimage yesterday to the statue of St. Francis in St. Patrick's Cathedral. They were greeted by Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of the Cathedral, who expressed the hope that the occasion would increase the love of St. Francis in their hearts.

The report of the Electric Power and Light Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Aug. 31, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $5,620,369 after all operating expenses, taxes and charges, against $9,596,885 in the twelve months to Aug. 31, 1937.

One of the first large philanthropic entertainments of the season will take place Thursday night, when the performance of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Metropolitan Opera House will be given as a benefit for the Seamen's Church Institute of New York.
A milling throng tonight packed St. Stephen's Square, where Nazis rioted last night and stoned the palace of Theodor Cardinal Innitzer, 62-yearold Archbishop of Vienna, injuring him and a canon.

Norfolk St. 138, e s. 25x100; Metropolitan Life Ins Co to David Geller, 2,035 Creston Ave: mtg $18,480, and p m mtg $3,020 ($7); same property; David Geller to Rose Rotherosen, 250 W 88th St; mtg $21,500.
The Newark Tornadoes gained their first American Professional Football Association victory in three starts tonight when they downed the Clifton Wessingtons, 7 to 0.

Miss Florence Dodd Sullivan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Sullivan of this place, will be married on Nov. 4 to Edmund Ambrose Lynch, son of Mrs. Edmund A. Lynch, also of Cedarhurst, and the late Mr. Lynch. The ceremony will be performed in Trinity Church, Hewlett, by the rector, the Rev. J. Reginald Moody.
For the first time since the hurricane and floods nearly three weeks ago, normal train service was resumed by the Pennsylvania Railroad yesterday between Boston and Southern and Western points.

A series of conferences between publishers of Wilkes-Barre's four newspapers and Eugene MacKinnon, negotiator for the American Newspaper Publishers Association, followed by talks between Mr. MacKinnon and other negotiators, led to reports tonight that a significant step soon would be taken in the local newspaper dispute involving the publishers and the American Newspaper Guild.

Brooklyn Dodgers led with their Ace Parker to the dismay of the Pittsburgh Pirates today for a 17-to7 triumph, which boosted the visitors into a tie with the Washington Redskins for first place in the Eastern division of the National Football League as the Pirates dropped to last.
The Racine and Kenosha plants of the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation, closed by a labor dispute that tied up 7,000 jobs, will reopen tomorrow, it was announced by Richard Frankenstein, U. A. W. A.

" Oscar Wilde," by Leslie and Sewall Stokes, opens tonight at the Fulton Theatre, the first of this week's five premieres. It is presented by Norman Marshall, keeper of the Gate Theatre, London, where the play was produced in 1936. Mr.

A total of $259,100,000 was spent in August by Federal, State and local governments in aid to the needy, including relief clients on works projects, the Social Security Board announced today. This preliminary figure, it was stated, was about 2.5 per cent above the revised total for July.

The four-power Munich pact has tremendously weakened the position of European democracies without achieving any more than a postponement of war, Rabbi Stephen S. Wise said yesterday in his sermon at the Free Synagogue in Carnegie Hall.

Reporters of the future take long chances. Certainly their previews of events to come are made easier by Hitler's handy guidebook; but, even with the aid of this map of the future, the prophets who have been surrendering the rest of Europe to Germany since the Munich conference ceded the Sudetenland seem to be taking more for granted than did the framers of the treaty of Versailles, now broken by all the signatories.

The Fire Department's annual memorial services for members who died during the last year were held yesterday afternoon at the Firemen's Monument, Riverside Drive and 100th Street, with 1,500 uniformed men and officers from all parts of the city present.
The Yankees and Cubs sliced the largest financial melon ever received by players in a world series of four games when the returns were all in from the box office yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia returns a wise answer to Mrs. Elizabeth Faff of Glendale, L. I., who wrote to inquire whether it is necessary to get out of bed and stand when our national anthem is played over the radio. The answer, of course, is yes and no.

A flaming airplane from Roosevelt Field swooped down on the Meadow Brook Club's golf course here this afternoon, taxied to a gentle 'stop near the fifth hole where a threesome was playing and was consumed by the fire just after the

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Louise Blackmar -Hart of this city and Washington, D. C., daughter of Mrs. William T. Hart of Columbus and the late Mr. Hart, to Henry Goodfellow Hunt of Washington and Arlington, Va., son of Mrs. Gaillard Hunt and the late Mr. Hunt.
New York State will sell tomorrow a $100,000,000 issue of its short term notes to meet obligations soon coming due.

Miss Frances Ruth Davidson, a blind student at Carthage College, Carthage, Ill., has won the Captain Charles W. Brown Memorial Medal of the American Foundation for the Blind, it was announced yesterday.

Bishop William T. Manning urged Christians throughout the world "to pray and labor for peace so that we may yet be saved from the unmeasured horrors and unknown consequences of war," in his first sermon of the Fall season yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street.
The Times of London says tonight "on good authority" that Princesses Elizabeth and Margaret Rose will not accompany King George and Queen Elizabeth on their Canadian visit next Summer.
The effects of the recent European crisis are being seen daily here. Clearing bank deposits dropped [Pound]29,250,000 in September, mainly because of the withdrawal of foreign balances.

New ballroom dances of the sporadic type which holds a popular appeal for at least a season were demonstrated yesterday at the October meeting of the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., in the Hotel Astor.

Almost forty years after "Casey" Jones drove the crack Cannon Ball train through three freight cars at Vaughn, Miss., a monument to the storied engineer was dedicated today at this town from which Casey got his nickname.

Billy Nichols proved too formidable for the First Division polo team yesterday and as a result Governors Island won, 12-5, at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation field to keep the Colyer Trophy for another year.

The importance of scholarships and the lack of sufficient funds for many students who merit a college education, including a consideration of the abuses arising from the competition for students and the necessity and dangers of extensive publicity for colleges,

Europe's recent fright will be an upheaval long to remember and the reflux of scared capital is likely to be slow, especially if the United States lives up to its current promise of business recovery.

Miss Harriet Arthur Dyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Dyer, was married here to Sverre Sorenson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abram Sorenson of Atlantic Highlands, yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents.

The occupation of the fifth and last zone of the Sudetenland, taking German troops to what is likely to be the permanent frontier between Germany and what is left of Czechoslovakia, was continued today and will be completed tomorrow.

The French liner Normandie is due this afternoon from Havre via Southampton. Passengers are William C. Bullitt, United States Ambassador to France; Miss Anne Morgan, Gurnee Munn, Earl Beauchamp, Count and Countess Rene de Chambrun, Marquis and Marquise de Talleyrand, Princes de Cantacuzene,

Mrs. Howard G. Law died at her home here today at the age of 47. A graduate of Northwestern University, she was a music instructor at Grand Prairie Seminary, Onaga, Ill., and had been Girl Scout Commissioner ago. here for ten years.

James Roosevelt, the President's eldest son, arrived here today at the Oakland Mole Railroad Terminal aboard his father's private car to spend two months recuperating from his recent operation for a stomach ailment.

Clarence (Spike) Fisher of the home club defeated John Robinson of the Pennsylvania Golf Club, 3 and 2, in the final of the Wildwood Golf Club's sixteenth annual tournament today to win the Silver Bunker Trophy.
Seventy members and five carloads of scenery and costumes of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo arrived yesterday from London on the Cunard White Star motor ship Georgic.

Making public the architect's plans for the proposed Public School 31 to be erected on Fortysixth Road, between 211th Street and Bell Boulevard, Bayside, Queens, Mayor La Guardia yesterday praised the work of the reorganized Bureau of Construction of the Board of Education.

Members of Local 333, United Marine Division, affiliated with the International Longshoremen's Association, met last night at the Manhattan Plaza, 66 East Fourth Street, and authorized the officers of the union to call a strike of all men employed on towboats in the harbor of
Canadian Women's Club, in 106 E 52d St: Dr. Samuel Blumgarten, dental offices, in 2 E 54th St; Edward J. Howard, advertising artist, in 441 Lexington Ave; Cushman Wakefield: Inc. brokers.

Miss Gwyn Grant, niece of Mr. and Mrs. Coulter D. Huyler, has completed plans for her marriage to Roland Ruutz-Rees, on Nov. 5. The ceremony will take place at the Round Hill Community Church here with the Rev. Harold E. Wilson, pastor, officiating.

A renewal of faith in democracy was urged by Dr. Henry Neumann in an address yesterday morning at the weekly meeting of the Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture, at the St. Felix Street Theatre, near Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn.

Operators of more than 150,000 farms in the Northeast area, including New England, New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, cooperated in the 1937 AAA farm program, that agency announced today in a preliminary report.
St. Bonaventure's eleven, rebounding from a defeat last week by Catho-lic University, smashed its-way to a 20-to-0 victory over Mount St. Mary's today.

Although both democracy and religion are losing battles on every side today, they are really winning wars, declared the Rev. Dr. John L. Davis in his sermon yesterday morning at the Washington Square Methodist Episcopal Church, 133 West Fourth Street.

Captain Evan W. Scott, senior member of the Chaplains Corps, U. S. N., and Mrs. Scott of San Diego, Calif., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betty Jane Scott, to Dr. Daniel Bailey Hardenbergh, son of Mrs. D. B. Hardenbergh of Middletown, N. Y., and the late Dr. Hardenbergh.

The marriage of Mrs. Beatrice Ladin Block, widow of Louis Block of New York, to Morris Weinfeld of this city and Washington took place here yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride, 955 Park Avenue. The Rev. Dr. Stephen S. Wise performed the ceremony.
The Southern Conference football championship has about narrowed down now to North Carolina's defending titleholders and Duke's Blue Devils.

Columbia University received a total of $403,792 in eighty-four gifts during the last four months, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the institution, announced yesterday. The sum will be applied largely to the support of research in medicine and other sciences.

Miss Mary Cootes of Alexandria paired with Frank X. Shields today to win the mixed doubles in the Hot Springs invitation tennis tournament. They defeated Miss Margot Lee of Washington and J. Gilbert Hall, singles winner of South Orange, N. J., 6-3, 3-6, 6-4.

John S. Regan, 38 years old, of 130-24 129th Street, South Ozone Park, Queens, was held without bail for a hearing tomorrow after arraignment yesterday before Magistrate Frank Giorgio in Felony Court, Ridgewood, Queens, on a charge of homicide.
Following the violent fluctuations during the crisis, the Boerse was comparatively quiet this week and ended virtually unchanged from last Saturday.

Drastic curtailment of the powers of the National Labor Relations Board and proposals to remedy defects alleged to exist in the National Labor Relations Act will be proposed in a nine-point program to be presented to. the annual convention of the American Federation of Labor when it opens its second week's sessions tomorrow.

The Informazione Diplomatica, official organ of the Italian Foreign Office, in a note issued early this morning expressed the hope that the withdrawal of a strong contingent of Italian "volunteers" from Spain might give Britain an opportunity to put into force the Anglo-Italian agreements of last Easter.
Mr. and Mrs. Wililam Earl Dodge Stokes, who have been at the Lenox Club for several weeks, gave a dinner tonight. They will return to New York tomorrow, and will leave later in the week for Idaho.
An increase in the anti-prohibitionist vote was recorded yesterday when the authorized poll was taken in Victoria on the proposal that liquor licenses should be abolished.

It is a little bit early in the season for any section to start pinning ribbons on itself, but at this stage in a campaign notable for the plethora of major skirmishes it may be vouchsafed that Eastern football looks pretty good.

Louis M. Rogovin has arranged for the Junior Building Corp a temporary building loan of $100,000 to aid in the construction of a six-story apartment house on the s s of 49th St, 220 ft w of 12th Ave, Brooklyn. on a plot 100x100 ft.

Miss Lorraine Stansbury Ayers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ira Campbell Ayers of this place, became the bride of William Badeau Bragdon Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Badeau Bragdon of Cranford, yesterday in St. Paul's Episcopal Church here.

Three cowboys were slightly injured yesterday at the rodeo in Madison Square Garden, two while loitering in the arena waiting for their events. The mishaps occurred at the matinee performance, attended by 8,000 persons.

The Rev. Patrick J. Temple, director of the Mission of Our Lady of the Rosary, was honored last night by about 400 of his friends and parishioners at a dinner in the Hotel Astor, marking the twentyfifth anniversary of his ordination to the Roman Catholic priesthood.
E. W. Rettger, Professor of Mechanics at Cornell since 1922 and a faculty member since 1907, died today after a long illness. His age was 67.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Thomas A. Waywell of Flushing, Queens, of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Eileen Elizabeth Waywell, to Henri F. Jacques Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacques of Flushing and Montreal.

Marked by pleas for unity in the labor movement and by uproarious demonstrations against Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City and Henry Ford, the two-day convention of the New Jersey C. I. O., its first, ended tonight.

The motor vessel Wyatt Earp, base supply ship of the Ellsworth Antarctic Expedition, carrying members of the expedition and two planes to be used for exploration work in the Antarctic, arrived at Cape Town today.
The Brookhattans made four goals in the second half to defeat the Baltimore Germans in a league soccer game at Starlight Park yesterday, 5-3.
Frederick M. Pryor of Greenwich, brother of Republican National Committeeman Samutel F. Pryor Jr., died early today at Hot Springs, Va., members of his family were informed. His age was 38.

Scoring three goals each in the third and fourth periods, the Long Acre Farms poloists defeated the Glenelgs by 7-3 at the Burnt Mills Club's Schley Field today. Harry Frank Jr. led the winners withthree goals.

The 771 Trinity Avenue Corporation, through its attorneys, Gettinger Gettinger, bought from Durwood Hall, Inc., the twenty-family apartment building at 1,361 Intervale Avenue, the Bronx. The building is on a plot about 40 by 110 feet. George Weisbrod represented the seller.

The governors of the Los Angeles Stock Exchange approved yesterday the application of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company to list 114,780 additional shares of its $25-par-value 6 per cent first preferred and 24,616 additional shares of its $25-par 5 1/2 per cent preferred stock.

The Green Bay Packers were handed a stunning upset in their campaign for the Western division championship in the National Football League today when the Detroit Lions gained a spectacular 17-to-7 victory.

Our Wa??, bay gelding owned by Mrs. Harry Frank Jr., of Warrenville and ridden by Miss Patricia Bolling, added the hunter championship to three blues and a red in the final session of the eighteenth annual Orange Horse Show at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today.

As a start toward fulfillment of his acceptance speech promise to make his position clear on State issues, District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, announced last night his opposition to two of the nine proposed amendments to the State Constitution.

More than 3,500 gathered today at the Luther Monument in Druid Park Terrace for a rally incident to the eleventh biennal convention of the United Lutheran Church were told by the Rev. Dr. Franklin C. Fry of Akron, Ohio,
There was fairly general liquidation early last week in the lard futures market on the Board of Trade and all deliveries sold at the lowest prices of the season.

Mrs. Alice Rogers Hager, Washington newspaper woman, arrived at Floyd Bennett Field last night after a 19,000-mile tour of the commercial airlines of the country in the last nine days. She made her tour in the interests of National AirMail Week, which ended yesterday.

The financial markets are regaining poise after the recent violent disturbances. Last week opened with distinct signs of a set-back in securities following the robust upward surge at the end of the previous week.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler is sending his reservists home and speaks of a quiet Christmas. Truce, breathing space, armistice--call it what you like--Europe seem to have won time to take stock of the situation and prepare for coming events.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,973,564,350.
Charles H. Harrington of 33-15 161st Street, Flushing, Queens, a subway and water tunnel construction engineer, died on Saturday at Doctors Hospital.

Denouncing "outrageous demands" of the Polish and Hungarian Governments for annexation of Ruthenia, 1,000 members of the Carpatho-Russian organizations of New York met yesterday afternoon at Webster Hall and demanded the right of self-determination for some 1,000,000 Carpatho-Russians.

Earl Beauchamp of Madresfield Court, Malvern, England, and his son and daughters, the Hon. Richard E. Lygon, Lady Mary Lygon and Lady Dorothy Lygon will arrive today on the Normandie. They will attend the second Lygon family reunion, to be held in Washington, D. C., this week.

Princeton University's 674 freshmen named Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain of Great Britain as "the greatest living person" by a one-vote margin over Chancellor Adolf Hitler of Germany in a poll conducted by The Daily Princetonian, the results of which were announced today.

A brilliant sub-par 71 today for a total of 145 enabled Fred A. Kammer Jr. of Baltusrol, former Princeton athlete, to nose out Willie Turnesa of Briar Hills, the national amateur golf champion, by a single stroke for individual honors in the Crestmont Golf Club's second annual member-guest invitation tournament.

Miss Alice Paul, whose ken has shifted from the national to the international suffrage scene-from Washington to Geneva-was back tonight at the helm as in the days of the White House pickets she directed in the police skirmishes over the American woman's struggle for the ballot.
AN AMERICAN READER, edited by Burton Rascoe. (Putnam, $3.50.) An anthology of a century of American writing selected from the publications of the house of Putnam.

Colonel and Mrs. Avery John Cooper of Fort Totten, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ella Gibson Cooper, to Robert E. Lee Thomas, son of Major Frederick Thomas, U. S. A., retired, of Honolulu.

Julian Funt, in 41 5th Ave: Mrs. Estelle Fleishmann, in 45 5th Ave; Anna M . Cowlin, in 33 E 22d St; Sidney Wolfson, in 229 E 51st St: V. Harrison Berlitz, in 151 E 83d St; Harold Fowler, in 260 S 2d Ave, Mount Vernon; Wm. A. White Sons, brokers.

Colgate students and fans tonight visualized a passing battle between Sid Luckman of Columbia and Hal Lube of the Red Raiders when the teams meet in New York on Saturday as a result of what happened over the week-end.
Dr. John J. Crumlish, for more than fifty years a teacher of English and Latin at Mount St. Mary's College, was killed by an automobile tonight.

Impressive army manoeuvress, with tanks, armored cars, planes and thousands of infantry, artillery and cavalry troops participating, were the highlight of the Convention of Peoples' Delegates of Sinkiang, China's mid-Asian Province, now being concluded at Tihua, according to Chinese newspaper dispatches printed in Hankow.

Governor Lehman was expected to have available at noon today "all the facts" to support the request by William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, for the superseding of District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Kings County.

In olden times inventors, poets and artists alike starved in garrets or in other corners for which little or no rent had to be paid. Usually the poets still starve, if they depend solely on their poetry for a livelihood. The artists often do. The inventors no longer need to.

At the close of a two-day session here tonight, the New York State convention of the Steuben Society of America announced it would present its recommendations for endorsement of State and Congressional candidates in the coming general election to the organization's State council for final action.
Leslie J. Sorenson, Chicago traffic engineer, told delegates to the National Safety Council Congress today that the major problem for motorists no longer was where to drive but where to park.

Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for Governor, will be guest speaker at a dinner under the auspices of the Flushing branch of the Socialist party at 7 o'clock tomorrow night at the Bus Terminal Building, 136-56 Roosevelt Avenue, Flushing, Queens.

Use of group testing and the development of new techniques in questionnaires are features of a method of radio program rating now being developed by Miller, Franklin Co., engineers, in cooperation with two broadcasting chains and several advertising
For the first time in many months the term "sharp rise" appears in The Federal Reserve Bulletin as descriptive of recent industrial production.

The undefeated Brooklyn Eagles won their third straight American Football Association victory, by beating the Paterson Panthers, 10 to 7, at Ebbets Field yesterday. A 32-yard field goal by Stan Benton, former Iowa back, in the third quarter insured the victory.

Fresh from his triumphant, if bloodless, conquest of the Sudetenland, Chancellor Hitler, new master of continental Europe, announced in a speech before cheering hundreds of thousands at Saarbruecken today that following
The general index of French wholesale prices for the week ended on Oct. 1 was 646, against 648 and 645 one and two weeks before.

Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., Republican, of Massachusetts said today that he had asked President Roosevelt to call a special session of Congress to deal with the New England flood-hurricane emergency.

The final report on unemployment, in the census conducted by the Government under John D. Biggers, estimates that 2,740,000 more women workers have entered the country's labor market since 1930 than one would expect merely from the growth of population.
Charles Newcomb Brush, cotton broker and importer, died at a hospital yesterday after a short illness. His age was 78.
Unruly demonstrations in which forty-six civilians, sixty policemen and six officers were injured marked the return to Cairo today of Mustafa Nahas Pasha, Wafdist leader and former Premier.

Magistrate Anna M. Kross has accepted the nomination of the American Labor party for Justice of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District, to fill the vacancy created by the withdrawal of Leo J. Rosett.

CHARLES GOULD. butter and eggs, 202 St. Ann's Ave., and 487 E. 152d St.Voluntary proceedings under Chapter XI of the Chandler Act listing liabilities of $12.592 and assets of $2,620. The debtor proposes to pay 10 per cent in cash and 10 per cent in notes.
Harry Hopman, non-playing captain of the Australian Davis Cup team, eliminated J. Donald Budge of Oakland in a quarter-final round match of the Pacific Coast tennis tournament today, 6-2, 5-7, 6-1.

The second world crisis is over and the Yankees win in four straight. The expected happened. The proud prophets of today will probably be telling their grandchildren about the only ball team that ever captured three world series in a row. The Cubs came only to add new laurels to the conqueror's brow.
The Brooklyn Dodgers, National Football League team, tonight purchased Scrapper Farrell, 295-pound fullback, from the Pittsburgh Pirates.

Hysterical and half frozen after a terrifying night on the side of Mount Monadnock, in Dublin, N. H., Peter Brainard, 13 years old, of Milton was led to safety by his faithful Shepherd dog today while an air and ground search was in progress.
Production and shipments of lumber in the week ended on Oct. 1 amounted to 65 per cent of the weekly average for 1929, the National Lumber Manufacturers Association reported today.

The 107th Infantry, National Guard, the "Old Seventh", at its annual divine service in St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church yesterday heard a reminder from the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks, regimental chaplain, that the unit was "before all else, men trained for the preservation of peace."

Unanimous approval by both houses of Parliament of the Ministerial declarations following the recent crisis and the tenor of Premier Daladier's speech on European pacifications made an excellent impression in financial circles.

Now that King George and Queen Elizabeth have announced that .they will visit Canada early next Summer, this country can scarcely do less than invite them to visit the World's Fair in New York, perhaps the San Francisco Exposition, and certainly the White House at Washington.

Lieutenant Commissioner Richard Griffiths, who had been secretary to General Evangeline Booth, Commander in Chief of the Salvation Army, for the last forty years, dropped dead in Colston Hall at Bristol today, at the age o 62.

Gaiety Gaines, owned by C. F. Gaines of Sherburne, N. Y., today was crowned field dog champion in the National Pheasant Futurity Field Trials, richest of breeders' stakes. Gaiety Gaines led in the largest field of dogs in the history of the event to win the title after two days' judging by Thomas H. Carmody, Lambertville, N. J., and Harry Decker, Winamac, Ind.

Paul D. Cravath gave a musicale and tea at Still House, his home here, this afternoon for the layman's opera course of the Metropolitan Opera Company. Mrs. William Francis Gibbs, his daughter, who heads the committee of the layman's opera course, was hostess. Joseph Battista, pianist, gave the program.

Delegates at the closing session of the annual convention of the New Jersey State Federation of Teachers here today approved a resolution asking establishment of graduated income and corporation taxes in New Jersey for the purpose of

2d St. 306 E, n s. 25x106: 306 E 2d Corp (Morris Nathan, pres) to Jeanne D. Israel. 22 W 77th St; installments, 6 per cent, $2.250. Norfolk St, 138. e s, 25x100: David Geller to Metropolitan Life Ins Co; p m mtg, 10 yrs, 4 per cent, $3,020.

In Chicago the Bar Association has just made public its report on the candidates for judges of both parties. Little biographies of each are given. Sometimes both candidates are commended. Sometimes one is called "wellqualified" and the other "qualified."

When Henry Armstrong risks his welterweight championship of the world at Madison Square Garden on Nov. 2 it will be the first time that the Los Angeles Negro has defended a title. Within the past year Armstrong has played the challenger's role against the leaders of three divisions, the featherweight.
Edward G. Robinson, who has been with Warner Brothers for eight years, will remain with the studio under an agreement reached over the week-end and which will go into effect in January.

The important railroad junction of Bohumin [Oderberg] at the meeting place of Germany and the Czechoslovak province of Moravia was occupied by Polish troops at 6 o'clock this morning, three days ahead of schedule.
Elmore D. Hotchkiss, former freight traffic manager of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway Company, died today at his home here at the age of 88.
Excellent weather conditions prevailed in the Corn Belt last week, and the crop is reported as almost 100 per cent safe from frost damage.

Visitors to the hotel and restaurant at Camp Siegfried, the German-American Settlement League's Nazi camp, had to do without beer or wine with their German food today. The hotel's license was not renewed by the State liquor authority when it expired Monday.
Sir Cyril L. N. Newall, British Air Chief Marshal, and Air Vice Marshal Douglas, with their staff, arrived at Le Bourget airport today for several days of staff talks with the French air command.

Following is the text of Chancellor Hitler's speech today after the dedication of a new Saar theatre: GermanFolk ! If in the midst of these great days and their occurrences I have come into your district, then it was done in the conviction that nobody can evince greater appreciation of these last weeks and days than yourself.

The American European Securities Company has reported a net asset value of $4.33 a share for 354,500 common shares on Sept. 30, compared with $4.94 a share on June 30. Total assets were $16,455,173, against $18.359,964. Unrealized depreciation was $5,797,777, compared with $7,554,526 on June 30.

Frank Geleski, 35 years old, of 177 Jewel Street, Brooklyn, was drowned early this morning in Long Island Sound when he fell out of a rowboat in which he and a friend had been fishing for eels near here.
The Philharmonic - Symphony League committee of Englewood, N. J., will meet Wednesday afternoon at the home of Mrs. Daniel Pomeroy. Mrs. Malcolm S. Mackay will be chairman.

Trading in grain futures on the Board of Trade here last week was unusually light. Sales of all futures aggregated 114,064,000 bushels, or a daily average of about 19,000,000, compared with a mean of 36,000,000 bushels in the preceding week and about 42,000,000 a year ago.

The Fort Hamilton and Elroy A. C. football teams played a scoreless tie at Fort Hamilton yesterday before 1,500. In the last period Elroy advanced almost to the goal line, but the threat was smothered by the service men.

About twenty persons were driven from their apartments in the Hotel Sulgrave Annex, 646 Park Avenue, between Sixty-fifth and Sixty-seventh Streets, shortly after 10:15 o'clock last night by smoke from a small fire in a carpenter shop in the basement of the eight-story building.
The Hon. Montagu Ormond Forbes, eighth son of the nineteenth Lord Forbes, died here today at the age of 72.
Dietrick Lamade, president and publisher of The Williamsport Grit, died in the Wllliamsport Hospital early this morning of pneumonia, after a four days' illness. He was 79 years old.
Stocks advanced to the highest levels in a year, with trading the heaviest since the week ended on July 23; turnover, 9,674,470 shares.

Major John A. Warner, Superintendent of the State Police, believes establishment of a centralized missing persons bureau to function for the entire State would aid in solving crimes and in locating many persons who voluntarily drop from sight.
The German wholesale price index on Oct. 1 was 105.5, after having been 105.6 for two weeks.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 80.5, which compared with 80.4 the week before 80.8 two weeks before, 80.7 three weeks before and 80.6 four weeks before.
S. Wilbur Corman, advertising man and real estate developer, formerly general manager for N. W. Ayer Son of Philadelphia, died here today at his home,

The Financial News's index of 30 industrial shares, based on 100 as the July 1, 1935, level, was 82.6 on Oct. 6, compared with 79.9 last week, 82.8 last month, 102.3 last year, and 95.9 at the beginning of 1938.
The play-by-play description of the fourth and final game of the world series at the Yankee Stadium yesterday follows:

ADD a new name to the growing list of American authors who in one way or another are making deliberate use of their racial inheritance. The name is John Fante. Mr. Fante was born in Colorado twenty-odd years ago of ItalianAmerican parents. His first novel, "Wait Until Spring, Bandini,"* is published today.

The present so-called solution of European troubles is a dishonorable peace and therefore not to be depended upon, the Rev. Dr. J. Valdemar Moldenhawer, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue between Eleventh and Twelfth Streets, said in his sermon there yesterday.

The Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahue, Administrator of the Archdiocese of New York, sang pontifical mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday, the ceremony marking the observance of the twenty-eighth anniversary of the consecration of the church.

The "Peace of Munich," which finally shattered the Peace of Versailles and, in German eyes, replaced the moribund hegemony of the World War victors, was based on a realistic appraisal of Germany's new military status instead of on abstract principles and paper alliances.
The capture and sentencing to death of a man who might be called the dean of foreign spies in Soviet Russia was disclosed today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In his letter to THE TIMES Dr. William A. Neilson. president of Smith College, made a beautiful gesture by urging that the United States as moral debtor should offer Czechoslovakia substantial aid toward rehabilitation.
The Brooklyn Hispanos were held to a 3-3 tie by the Passon Phillies in an American Soccer League game at Celtic Park in Brooklyn yesterday after taking a 3-1 lead at halftime.
The New York Yankees have scored thirty-four victories, suffered eighteen setbacks and engaged in one tie in the ten world series in which they have participated.

The indications are for fair and cool weather today and for fair weather with slowly rising temperatures tomorrow, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock last night.

Good activity in better and medium-priced apparel was reported in wholesale and retail markets last week, and the delivery situation, although still very bad in some parts of the market, showed signs of improving. Good volume was noted. on sports. and untrimmed coats in the better ranges.

The magic in the trusty right arm of big Ed Danowski was more than a match for the pitching cleverness of Slingin' Sammy Baugh today as the Giants rode the airways in a rousing last-quarter comeback to topple the Washington Redskins, 10 to 7, before a record crowd of 37,500 in Griffith Stadium.

Those who had hoped that giving in to virtually all of Hitler's demands at Munich would lead to European appeasement will find little consolation in the speech of the Fuehrer at Saarbruecken. The moral that Hitler draws from the events of the past few weeks is that only by military strength and threats of war can Germany get what she wants.

The tenth annual sessions of the Metropolitan Presbyterian Missions Training Institute will be held this and tomorrow afternoons and evening at the Rutgers Presbyterian Church, Seventy-third Street, just west of Broadway.
With Gerald Dempsey leading the attack with four goals, the Westbury riders outscored veteran Earle W. Hopping's Sands Point combination, 9-7, in the high-goal match at Bostwick Field today.

Miss Ann Robertson Campbell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Lewis Campbell of 930 Park Avenue and Greenwich, Conn., has completed plans for her marriage to Donald Howes Gleason, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bemis Gleason of Newton, Mass., which will take place the afternoon of Nov. 5 in the chapel of St. Bartholemew's Church.

A tribute to the late Cardinal Hayes is paid by the Rev. George Paull T. Sargent, rector of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street, in a letter to the parishioners in the church bulletin. Dr. Sargent was abroad when the Cardinal died.

Charles Walzer, operator, represented by Hirsch Islon, sold to an investor through Henry Brinsley and the Morgan Management Corporation, co-brokers, the fourstory apartment building at 147 Ninth Street, Brooklyn,

Alex Ciecierski, 13 years old, of 87 Terrace Avenue, Jersey City, died at Hudson County General Hospital here tonight from injuries suffered yesterday in a seventy-five-foot fall at Laurel Hill quarry, where county penitentiary, prisoners work.

To celebrate the twentieth anniversary of the armistice the British Great War Veterans of America, Inc., will give their annual Armistice Ball on the night of Nov. 11 at the Hotel Astor. For many years this event has been one of the outstanding entertainments of the late Autumn in this city.

A saucy little upstart from Gloucester, Captain Ben Pine's challenger for the International Fishermen's Trophy, the schooner Gertrude L. Thebaud, today knocked somewhat askew the crown of the queen of the North Atlantic fishing fleet, Captain Angus Walters's Bluenose, the titleholder from Nova Scotia.

Though "the world does not fully realize it," more than one-third of the refugees from Nazi Germany are Christians who are being aided by Jewish organizations and individuals, Miss Katherine Devereux Blake,

Commissioner David C. Adie of the Department of Social Welfare announced today that a harvest valued at a half million dollars at retail prices had been reaped during the Summer by persons from some 12,000 welfare gardens.
Pianistic talents of the first rank were disclosed by Elizabeth Zug at her debut recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall.

Mr. and Mrs. Guy F. Wells of Mount Vernon, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Emily Dana Wells, to Leonard D. Slutz, a Cincinnati attorney, son of Mrs. Earl R. Slutz of Maplewood, N. J., and the late Mr. Slutz.

The first act of the new "Christian National Slovak Government" today was to suppress the Communist party and withdraw the right of Communist newspapers to collect subscriptions through the mails in the ordinary way.

As long as industry does not provide security, it is the duty of the government to tackle the problem, Governor Frank 'Murphy of Michigan told the National Conference of Catholic Charities here tonight.
" The Wise Fool," the season's opening production at the Public Theatre, adheres to the average unpretentious standards of Yiddish musical comedy.
Juilliard scholarships in orchestral instruments for study in the Institute of Musical Art have been awarded to nine students, it was announced yesterday.

The Chinese are expected to dynamite and burn industrial and other important buildings in Wuchang, Hankow and Hanyang--the Wuhan cities--in accordance with their "scorched earth" policy of destroying everything that might be profitable to the Japanese. Stores of explosives have been set aside for this destruction.

A duel between Marcelino Garrica, President of the House of Representatives, and Sergio Carbo, prominent journalist and leader of the Cuban Revolutionary party, was fought this morning in a grocery store in a suburb of Havana. Swords were used.

Plans for a $13,420,000 Harlem River Drive, to serve as a vehicular connection between the Triborough Bridge and the Harlem River Speedway, will be jointly submitted to the Board of Estimate today by Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan, and Robert Moses, head of the Park Department and the Triborough Bridge Authority.
Elizabeth Nourse, Cincinnati artist, died yesterday in Paris France, according to word received here today.

Notwithstanding the eleven-point average fall of stocks in the latter part of September, recovery was so emphatic, on news of the FourPower pact, that the Stock Exchange's compilation of values for all listed stocks at the month-end was almost exactly the same as at the end of August.
The cotton market here was fairly active last week, with a good increase in trade buying, active short covering and a fair volume of hedge selling.

Starting tomorrow morning at 4 o'clock more than 1,000,000 people living in 20,758 square miles of North Carolina will experience for one week the dubious thrills of mimic aerial war as the army conducts the largest air-raid defense exercises ever to be held in this country.
The money markets are preparing for a new 1,500,000,000-mark Reich loan, of which 950,000,000 is to be subscribed publicly, beginning tomorrow.
The local dance season was officially ushered in last night by Martha Graham and her group in a recital at Carnegie Hall under the auspices of The New Masses magazine.

One of the few remaining Sudeten areas in the United States is a twelvemile stretch of territory between Delaware and New Jersey. It lies entirely beneath the waters of Delaware Bay. This may explain why Governor Moore, heading the mobilized forces of his State, has not yet marched through it to seize Wilmington and the du Pont munition works.
Governor Kraschel said today he was ignoring the request of a union leader for National Guard intervention in the Swift Co. packing house strike at Sioux City.
The Countess of Ishburnham died at her home here today from a heart attack. Her husband, the late Earl of Ashburnham, died in 1923 on a visit to his ancestral home in England.
Random House has taken over from Covici, Friede "Insanity Fair" by Douglas Reed, together with the publishing rights to Mr. Reed's future books. The book is now in its third printing.
Under the fond title of "The Fabulous Invalid" Moss Hart and George S. Kaufman have assembled an enormous theatre parade, which was set in motion at the Broadhurst Saturday evening.
American banking houses recently have been participating in peso treasury bills offered fortnightly by the Central Bank of Argentina, according to the Argentine Information Bureau.
Benjamin N. Kaufman of New York has bought the stone residence of Roger Steffan on Delancey Cove Road, Mamaroneck, through Thomas B. Sutton, Inc, brokers.

In the climax of one of the most successful meetings in the seven-year history of the Albany Spaniel Field Trial Club, an enthusiastic gallery of more than 700 spectators saw the cocker all-age blue ribbon go to Hatch Up George, owned and handled by A. M. Lewis of New Canaan, Conn.

Designation of Dec. 15 as a day on which employers will be asked to offer jobs to self-dependent boys of proved character and competence was announced yesterday by the executive committee of Vocational Adoption.

ANYWAY, the Cubs saved their lives. Rather Painfully for the club owners, baseball once again proved that it is honest. If the Cubs had won a game from the Yankees, there might have been loud cries of "fake!" and a demand for a Federal inquiry.

The center of attention in the art world shifts this week to Pittsburgh, where, on Thursday, the 1938 Carnegie International Exhibition will open, to be current until Dec. 5. Eleven nations are to be represented-England, France, Germany, Italy, Spain, Poland, Belgium, Czechoslovakia, Holland, Hungary and the United States.

The memory of Corporal Joseph McGovern, a policeman who died of injuries received overseas in the World War, was honored yesterday at dedication ceremonies for Post 487, Veterans of Foreign Wars, named for him.
The Robinson farm estate of 377 Acres at Meridale, Delaware County, N. Y., has been purchased for occupancy by a client of Arthur C. Sheridan, broker.

Warning against "wildcat schemes" and "short cuts to Utopia," Welfare Commissioner William Hodson urged yesterday a national effort to eliminate relief for the able-bodied through "reconstruction" of the social and industrial order in a manner to make jobs at living wages available to all.

Customers served by companies in the United States distributing manufactured and natural gas numbered 16,901,800 on Aug. 31, an increase of 250,000 in a year, the American Gas Association reported yesterday.

The one-story brick and concrete building at 199-201 Magazine Street, Newark, N. J., formerly the plant of the 0. K. Potato Chip Company, has been sold through Louis Schlesinger, Inc., for the Allentown National Bank to the Radzewicz Organ Company, of Millburn.

Governor Lehman's up-State itinerary in his campaign for re-election was announced yesterday by the Lehman-Poletti Independent Citizens Committee, which has headquarters in the Chanin Building. Charles Poletti, nominee for Lieutenant Governor, will accompany the Governor, who will devote the final week of the campaign to speaking in New York City.
An increase in the birth rate and no advance in the death rate in the State during August as compared with the same month of last year are shown in the monthly report of Dr. J. V.

Miss Annie Jo White, founder of Washington and Lee University's annual fancy dress ball, died here tonight at the age of 85. Miss White gave the first fancy dress party in 1907 when she was university librarian.

A telephone booth in a drugstore at Twenty-third Street and Eighth Avenue served yesterday as the starting point of adventure, mostly unpleasant, for James Robinson, 32 years old, a taxicab driver, of 104 Eighth Avenue.
Hand crochet work by sightless workers of the New York Association for the Blind, the American Foundation for the Blind,

West Coast football was still in the national picture today; four major teams remained unbeaten and one more upset was added to the records of the season, three weeks old but jammed with unexpected endings.
On the foreign exchange market here this week the Equalization Fund was obliged to intervene to check the rise of the pound sterling, but its operations do not seem to have involved large amounts.

Charles Clare of Race Brook, Conn., won the twentieth annual Arcola invitation golf tournament today, beating Charles Whitehead of Plainfield, the New Jersey amateur champion, 4 and 2. It was Clare's second triumph in this event. His first victory was in 1933, and he needs but one more to retire the trophy.
Three persons were killed today when a cabin plane, attempting a forced landing within the city, struck a store and burst into flames.

Play in the Meadow Brook Club's annual Fall best-ball invitation golf tournament was momentarily halted shortly after noon today when a plane caught fire in mid-air and crashed into a bunker on the fifth hole, sending golfers and caddies scurrying for cover.
Luncheon, Pan-American Society, in honor of Laurence A.. Steinhardt, American Ambassador to Peru, India House, 12:30 P. M.
Organized society, like the human body, cannot recover from surgical shock with a shattered nerve system.

The Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service cared for 98,758 patients last year, the organization's annual report disclosed yesterday. The report showed that 265 staff nurses in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens made 545,900 visits, an increase of nearly 10,000 over 1936.

The Minnesota Gophers, who stole Michigan's football thunder in the Big Ten four years ago, may have to hand it back this week. Early rumbling from the camp of the Wolverines reached an ominous crescendo last week.
Problems of the natural gas industry are first on the list for the American Gas Association, which will open its twentieth annual convention tomorrow in the Municipal Auditorium and three beachfront

More than 200 young roller skaters of Queens took part yesterday in the annual carnival of the Queens Park Department at Chisholm Park, College Point, near the Summer City Hall. Winners in the various events will take part in a city-wide carnival next month.

Former United States Senator W. Warren Barbour, Republican candidate for election to the Senate, declared today that the tactics of the Democratic State organization from now until Election Day will be concentrated on misrepresentation of his voting record on relief measures while a member of the Senate and on regimentation of the WPA vote throughout the State.

The Department of Parks announced yesterday that harvesting of crops in children's gardens would begin at 1:30 P. M. on Wednesday at Crotona Park Garden in the Bronx, Betsy Head Park Garden and Fort Greene Park Garden in Brooklyn and Highland Park Garden in Queens.
Few of us realize that we play only a minor part in this game of life, the Rev. Ernest J. Monnenauer of Syracuse, said in a sermon yesterday at St. John's Lutheran Church, 81 Christopher Street.
Dr. George Edwin Rice of Bayport, L. I., a dentist in this city for more than fifty years, died Saturday night in the New York Hospital after a long illness. His age was 71.
New low prices for the season and since 1934 were established in the corn market last week.

The bonded indebtedness of the State of West Virginia and all subdivisions on July 2, was $131,406,760, a reduction of $20,639,850 in eight years, according to a report to be sent today to Governor Homer A. Holt by Ernest K. James, State Tax Commissioner.
Nazi Leader Albert Foerster told a meeting of the Danzig Nazi Leader Corps today that this virtually 100 per cent German free city would decide its own fate.
Mrs. Anna Matz Desgrey, wife of former Acting City Judge Gustave Desgrey ??r. of Yonkers, died yesterday of a heart ailment at her home here at the age of 65.

Mrs. Mary Gilbert Davis Rockwell of this city will be 90 years old tomorrow, and Mrs. Robert Metz of Chicago will give a luncheon in her honor at Fernbrook, Lenox. Mrs. Rockwell is the widow of Francis Walker Rockwell, lawyer, Representative in Congress and chairman of the Greylock Reservation Commission.

Like stocks in a bull market, scholastic football activities skyrocketed to a new high for 1938 during the past week-end, for many leading prep teams received their baptism under fire, while quite a few others kept rolling along victory highway to establish themselves as front-rank combinations.

An instrument that will add immeasurably to the safety of airplane flight, and may conceivably be modified and developed as an aid to anti-aircraft equipment and technique, was demonstrated over New York City yesterday for the first time.

Accused of stealing an automobile to make a trip to Florida, Jack Koerner, 17 years old, of 52-18 244th Street, and Robert Erdmann, 16, of 21 Poplar Street, both of Douglaston, Queens, were held by the police of the Bayside, Queens, precinct for the authorities of Nassau County yesterday.

Following improved sentiment on the fading of the European war fears has come a moderate rise in steel specifications and a small recovery in ingot production, pushing output to the best level for the year, the magazine Steel says this week.
