The Kansas City Blues of the American Association and the Newark Bears of the International League, both owned by the New York Yankees,

The Sands Point Club's first Scotch foursome invitation golf tournament was concluded today with the home combination of Stuart Scheftel and T. D. Boardman, winners of the qualifying medal, turning back T. F. Scholl of Huntington and Ray Torgerson of Queens Valley, 3 and 2, in the final round of the championship flight.

Private individuals and unincorporated business on the whole are "net creditors to a huge and increasing extent" and have emerged from the depression and recovery years with a total gain on the credit side of $35,000,000,000 or more, according to a study by the committee on debt adjustment of the Twentieth Century Fund made public yesterday.

So far Jim Curley, again Democratic candidate for Governor of Massachusetts, has been "ignored" by his rivals for the nomination, Governor Hurley and Lieutenant Governor Kelly. The three minor Republican candidates have all given their best wishes to the Republican nominee, Mr. Saltonstall. The party's happy family reunion was well managed.

After advancing last week to new high levels for the recent upward movement, cotton prices lost much of their gains in the last few minutes of trading on Saturday on announcement of the crop estimate by the Department of Agriculture.
Leroy Newton Mills of 40 Montrose 1oad, Scarsdale, N. Y., a lawyer and an authority on football kicking, was stricken with a heart attack while coaching on University Field this morning.

President Roosevelt brought his week's stay at Hyde Park House to a close today and packed his bags for Washington. At the White House beginning tomorrow morning he will face several days of crowded conferences on routine administration matters.
Skillman Homes, Long Island builders, have purchased from a Nassau County bank 800 lots in Franklin Square, L. I., and have started construction of a new group of small dwellings there.

Art Radvilas, Columbia's wingback, who was injured during the closing minutes of the game with Army last Saturday, will be available for the Blue and White's contest with Colgate this week. He was brought by ambulance Saturday night to the infirmary at John Jay

Senator Carter Glass of Virginia and Park Commissioner Robert Moses are the recipients of the Roosevelt Medals for 1938 for "distinguished service in the administration of public office," it was announced last night by James R. Garfield, president of the Roosevelt Memorial Association.

With heavily guarded recruits hired to take the place of striking drivers, the Municipal Bureau of Street Cleaning today made a second and more successful attempt to collect ashes and rubbish, which had been piled on sidewalks since the start of the walk-out three days ago.

A campaign to establish a pension system for all American merchant marine officers, on the basis of equal contributions by employers and employes, was announced yesterday by the United Licensed Officers, and independent union. B.

Charley Siegel's touchdown in the second quarter on a 15-yard run following a 10-yard pass from Johnny Murphy enabled the Bay Parkway Football Club to down the Mount Vernon Cardinals, 6-0, at Erasmus Field in Brooklyn yesterday.

Isamu Noguchi, 34 - year - old American-born Japanese, was announced yesterday as the winner of the $1,000 first prize in the national competition for the design of a large bronze panel for the main entrance of the new Associated Press Building in Rockefeller Center.

Declines in this country's imports from Great Britain, Belgium and Canada in the last eight months have exceeded the 40 per cent by which purchases from Germany have fallen, so it is "misleading" for "boycottt Germany" proponents to attribute that reduction to their efforts, according to a statement issued yesterday by the Board of Trade for German-American Commerce, Inc.

John Strachey, leading British writer on communism, will be subjected to an exhaustive examination at Ellis Island after he arrives today aboard the French liner Normandie for a nation-wide lecture tour in the United States, it became known last night.
Charles Heliker, 34 years old, of Long Branch, was fatally injured tonight when his midget automobile crashed and burst into flames during a preliminary race at the velodrome.

St. Mary's Gaels, their once famous gallop slowed down to a walk for three quarters, engineered a sharp passing attack in the final period today to defeat Loyola University's Lions, 7 to 0, before 50,000 fans.
Shorn of the cares of his beloved republic, Dr. Eduard Benes is finding peace and quiet in the rustic surroundings of his estate on the edge of his obscure Middle European community.
There seems no reason to doubt that Soviet Russia would have joined France, Czechoslovakia and Britain against Germany if war had resulted from the recent crisis.

Leaders of all political parties joined yesterday to work for a large registration in New York City this week. Instructions were issued to the party workers to check the registrants and spare no effort to get known party members to qualify themselves to vote in the election on Nov. 8.
There seems no reason to doubt that Soviet Russia would have joined France, Czechoslovakia and Britain against Germany if war had resulted from the recent crisis.

Leaders of all political parties joined yesterday to work for a large registration in New York City this week. Instructions were issued to the party workers to check the registrants and spare no effort to get known party members to qualify themselves to vote in the election on Nov. 8.

After running through a traffic light and knocking down a policeman, a truck in which three young men were joyriding swerved onto the sidewalk at St. Felix and Fulton Streets, Brooklyn, last night, killing a woman and seriously injuring her husband.
The race between War Admiral and Seabiscuit will be over a dry track, unless rain makes Pimlico muddy after 8:30 A. M. the day of the race, Maryland Jockey Club officials announced today.

The Protestant Big Sisters will give a benefit theatre party the evening of Nov. 9 at the Cort Theatre at the third performance of "Yankee Fable," the new play starring Ina Claire. Proceeds will be devoted to the work of the Big Sisters in aiding underprivileged girls.
Cleveland's rejuvenated Rams won their second National Football League game in a row today when they upset the league-leading Chicago Bears, 14-7.

Miss Sylvia Rudich, daughter of City Magistrate Mark Rudich and Mrs. Rudich, was married yesterday afternoon at the home of her parents, 736 Willoughby Avenue, Brooklyn, to Dr. I. Arthur Marshall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Marshall.
Mrs. Levan Corbiere of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Katrina Levan Corbiere, to Cyril Bradford Martin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kingsley Leverich Martin of Montclair.

Jacob Ruppert, owner of the world's champion Yankees baseball team, struck out today in the Supreme Court, at a cost of $637,291. The brewer, through his attorneys, informed the Court that in pre-prohibition days- he lent money to saloon-keepers for the purchase of equipment.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today for the first time authorized the issuance of equipment trust certificates for the full amount of the purchase price of railroad equipment. Commissioner Claude R. Porter denounced the new proceedure.

Mrs. May Montgomery Smith, national chairman of the Girl Homemakers of the Daughters of the American Revolution, died on Sunday in Bellevue Hospital of injuries sustained Saturday night when she was struck by a taxicab at Lexington Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

Sufficient encouraging domestic business and industrial news was at hand yesterday to supply the stock market with a major excuse to move higher, but only the utilities were able to break away in any great numbers from the general tendency to mill about within a fractional range.
Rogers Hornsby, who held many of the individual titles in major league baseball, signed as manager of the Baltimore Orioles of the International League tonight.

Miss Janet Hastings Woodbridge of New York, daughter of Major Harold Witter Churchill and Mrs. Churchill of Washington, D. C., was married Saturday to Henry Wares Bryce, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Wares Bryce of this place.

More than 400 dealers from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut yesterday had their first look at the 1939 Hudson motor cars at a meeting which included morning, luncheon and afternoon sessions at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

In a decision without an opinion, the United States District Court of Appeals yesterday denied a motion for a stay and a motion ,for immediate affirmance of Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson's decree of foreclosure against the Manhattan Railway Company, owner of the Sixth Avenue elevated line.

Notice The following now constitute the Board of 'Trustees of the Honor Emergency Fund of the Fire Department, City of New York: John J. McElligott, Fire Chief and Commissioner; chairman. William W. Cohen, Honorary Deputy Chief: vice chairman.

Throughout the week the polls are open for registration. It is expected that this will be heavy, for the Fall campaign promises to be an active one both in its State and national aspects. Yet there are always laggards and scatter-brains who put off this duty until it is too late. Regrets after next Saturday will be useless.
Jews throughout the city yesterday observed Sukkoth, the Feast of the Tabernacles, commemorating the habitation in the wilderness during the flight from Egypt.

Stockholders of the Superior Steel Corporation yesterday approved a plan whereby bond indebtedness can be increased to not more than $2,000,000 in the form of a new issue to be secured by a mortgage lien on all real estate, plants and improvements.

The chairman of the United Automobile Workers General Motors negotiating committee announced today that delegates from sixty General Motors plants had joined in a request for a 32-hour working week until idle employes have been rehired.

More than 400 fabricators of structural steel are expected to attend the sixtieth annual convention of the American Institute of Steel Construction opening today in French Lick, Ind., and continuing through Friday. Clyde G. Conley, president of the organization, will open the sessions.

Independent petitions nominating William O'Dwyer as candidate of the Progressive party for County Judge in Brooklyn were filed with the Board of Elections yesterday. Mr. O'Dwyer is already the candidate of the Democratic party.

Menzies C. Cleveland, an attorney with the Guaranty Trust Company, New York, died yesterday at his home here following a heart attack. His age was 78. Born in Jersey City, N. J., July 22, 1860, Mr. Cleveland, who made his home with his daughter, Mrs. G. Dudley Tilley of 21 Mansfield Avenue, had resided in Darien for a number of years.

Bobby Pacho and Salvy Saban, welterweight boxers, will meet for the third time when they clash in the star bout of eight rounds at the New York Coliseum tonight. The semi-final, slated for six rounds, c will be between Mike Gameri and Joey Zodda.

The improvement in wool textile production since April gained speed during August, but sales volume eased from the July level, according to a report yesterday by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.

Despite the fact that retail trade in men's wear continues to lag, previous slow buying by retailers and inability of mills to turn out sufficient quantities of piece goods brought about a serious delivery shortage on many items, manufacturers and retailers said yesterday.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses was described yesterday by William F. Carey, Sanitatior Commissioner, as a propagandist with no regard for the truth and a builder of monuments to himself. Mr. Carey and Mr. Moses engaged in a sharptongued exchange at an executive session of the Board of Estimate in City Hall.

Overriding strong objections to "putting the church in the insurance business," the biennial convention of the Uiited. Lutheran Church in America voted here today in favor of a contributory pension system providing equal pensions for all ministers, regardless of salary received before retirement.

Back at his desk in the White House, President Roosevelt went to grips today with the problem of how to keep governmental expenditures within the Federal income without cutting relief spending to the bone or raising additional funds by new taxes.

A statement diamond opposing the proposed State Con- aids in stitutional amendments, providing moved for free bus transportation and social welfare services for children attending parochial schools and other religious and private schools, was issued today by the Albany District of the Evangelical Lutheran Pastoral Conference.

Hogs continued to decline today, losing mostly 15 to 25 cents, with the top declining to $8.35. Strictly grain-fed steers and yearlings met with a broad demand, but the general market was steady to 25 cents lower. Fat lambs sold steady with best natives at $8.35, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.

During two or three recent days of mild temperature and sunny skies it was often remarked that Indian Summer had arrived. But the real Indian Summer comes later than this. It has been fixed by descriptive writers as "beginning about the middle of October," or as "expected near November."
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Various interpretations have been placed on the White House spokesman's recent statement laying our troubles to industry's "saber-rattling,"

Ending a quest of more than eighteen months for a successor to the late W. Forbes Morgan, the organization committee of the Distilled Spirits Institute last night was reported agreed upon Dr. Wesley A. Sturges, member of the faculty at Yale Law School and a director of the American Arbitration Association, as president.

A new mutual investment fund, the Knickerbocker Fund for the Diversification, Supervision and Safekeeping of Investments, has been organized with the new firm of Pettit, Bryan Kalback, Inc., as sponsors and distributors, according to an announcement yesterday.

The Treasury's weekly offering of approximately $100,000,000 of ninetyday bills today went at an average interest rate of 0.022 per cent, com pared with 0.032 per cent on last week's issue, Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight. One bid of 100 was submitted, as was the case on the previous offering.

Commodities advanced on a broad front last week. The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices rose to 80.1 on Oct. 8, compared with 79.7 (revised) in the previous week and 93.0 a year before.

A permanent injunction restraining Fotoshop, Inc., of 136 West Thirty-second Street from selling and advertising Eastman Kodak Company products at prices below those fixed in fair trade contracts was granted yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Lauer.

Wave after wave of attacking planes roared above the sand hills of Eastern North Carolina this morning and tonight as the largest and most realistic air defense exercises ever held in this country were started.

Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for Governor, centered his fire last night on the administration of unemployment insurance benefits by the present State administration, and called it a "gigantic failure." He accused the State administration of "bungling,"

Reviews were granted today on three questions of deep interest to the National Labor Relations Board, and thus to capital and labor, as the Supreme Court handed down about 300 formal orders, including a refusal to review the case of Thomas J. Mooney.

Evidence of "an early return to greater sanity on all sides" in the adjustment of differences between government and business was described as "the most hopeful star in our sky" by Saul Cohn, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, in an address last night before the meeting of the Housewares Buyers Club at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Members of the National Association of Retail Druggists preceded the formal opening of their fortieth annual convention here tonight with a series of executive committee meetings in which the extension of minimum price contracts under the State and Federal Fair Trade Acts were very much to the fore.

Macmillan has received from London the new verse translation by Lawrence Binyon of Dante's "Purgatorio," his translation of the "Inferno" having appeared in 1933. The "Purgatorio" will be published here within a few weeks. Mr. Binyon is now at work on a long poem of his own.
Sixty-ninth annual session, Grand Chapter, Order of Eastern Star, New York State, will open at the Hotel Astor at 10 A. M. and continue tomorrow and Thursday.

Two Nobel prize winners in the persons of Dr. August Krogh of Copenhagen and Dr. George R. Minot of Harvard, not to mention such medical and academic worthies as Dr. Russell M. Wilder of the Mayo Clinic and Dr. Abraham Flexner, are to deliver addresses at the dedication of the new Squibb Institute for Medical Research today.
Macedonian terrorists renewed their activities here yesterday after

Sitdown strikers who occupied the leather tanning plant of the McNeely' and Price Company for a week during July, 1937, were held directly responsible today for damage to company stock and were assessed $5,000 by a Jury in Common Pleas Court 6.

Norman Warren, Mrs. Eleanor Boyd Colt, In 829 Park Ave.; Julia G. Thomas, Carletto Franzonl, in 957 Park Ave.; Mrs. Margaret Deyo Dashiell, in 161 E. 79th St.; Harry A. Dubin, Joseph H. Simon, in 1.261 Madison Ave.; James H. Heroy, Mrs. Janet R. Perkins, in 122 E. 82d St.; Mabel H. Beekman, Helen V. K. Devens, May A. O'Ryan, in 12 E. 97th St.; Dr. Harold T.

Shipments of finished steel products by subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation for September amounted to 577,666 tons, compared to 558,634 tons in August, a gain of 19,032 tons, and to 1,047,962 tons in September last year, a decrease of 470,296 tons.

Another world series has moved into the pages of baseball history and New York yesterday returned hurriedly to its routine affairs, apparently experiencing no difficulty forgetting that another diamond campaign was over.

Hugh McKennan Landon of Indianapolis, Harvard College graduate in the class of 1892, a trust company official and a former president of the Associated Harvard Clubs, was elected president of the Harvard Alumni Association for the current academic year at a meeting

Welfare Commissioner Hodson may have alarmed some readers by his assertion on the first page of his annual report that "the great objective of our society should be elimination of relief for the able-bodied employable men and women of the country through a reconstruction of our social and industrial order."

A bill pending in Panama's National Assembly provides for the issue of $6,000,000 of 3 per cent bonds due in 1958, and authorizes application of the proceeds for the purchase of defaulted bonds in the republic's foreign debt.
A lodge at the Boy Scout Shiort Term Camp at New Dorp, S. I., will be dedicated at exercises tomorrow afternoon to the memory, of Dr. William C. Buntin, former Scout Commissioner and member
The Reichsbank's statement as of Oct. 8 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

The sworn petition and support ing facts on which William Be Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, seeks to have District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan superseded in an inquiry into official corruption in Brooklyn were turned over to Governor Lehman yesterday and await now the Governor's decision as to what shall be done in the Brooklyn situation.

The Holland America liner Statendam, sailing tonight for Rotterdam via Plymouth and Boulogne, will have among her passengers Mr. and- Mrs. R. P. Vos, R. W. Gifford, Mrs. Rachel de Clairmont, Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Richards, Gerald Stone and Dr. and Mrs. F. W. Schaefer.
Twenty persons were killed today when a Belgian airliner lost a wing in midair and plummeted to earth in flames near this Ruhr Valley community in Northwestern Germany.

Politics virtually excluded monetary questions in the talks carried on here over the week-end among the principal central bankers of Europe during the monthly meeting of the Bank for International Settlements, and the trend was pessimistic, even before Chancellor Hitler's speech at Saarbruecken on Sunday.

The ten-story Albender Building at 1,143-45 East Jersey Street, one of this city's largest office structures, has been sold to Harry and Isidore Roth of Morristown, former operators of several theatres in Union and Morris counties.
The Controller of the Currency, it was learned tonight, has decided to strengthen national bank examining machinery by establishing an office in Richmond, Va.

Under the auspices of the Park Association of New York, Inc., and the Queens Borough Chamber of Commerce, 140 members of the two organizations and of other civic groups yesterday made an all-day tour of Queens parks, housing projects and beach and parkway developments.
Eighteenth century music performed in an eighteenth-century atmosphere returned to Williamsburg tonight with the first concert in a series of programs for harpsichord and violins.

William Bullitt, United States Ambassador to France, arrived last night from Paris on the French liner Normandie to enjoy what, he termed "a planned vacation." He said that two months ago Secretary of State Cordell Hull had written advising him that he had six months' vacation due.

Reports from Washington that the Government's latest spending program will probably reach its peak in March or April will doubtless be welcomed in some quarters as assurance that the present improvement in business is likely to last for at least another six months.

Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin ruled yesterday that the deadline for seeking court review of real estate tax assessments had been extended from June 30 to Oct. 25 by the enactment of the new City Charter.

Efforts to avert the threatened strike of 2,000 towboat men on 300 towboats in the harbor were made yesterday by the Maritime Labor Board with the arrival in the city from Washington of James L. Ber-nard, conciliator, who conferred with both sides in the controversy with a view to bringing about resumption of negotiations.

The annual meeting and election of officers of the National Plant, Flower and Fruit Guild will take place the afternoon of Oct. 27 at the Hotel Pennsylvania. After the meeting Mrs. E. Walter Mitchell will give an illustrated talk on gardens of this city, including pictures of the Laura S. Stewart Memorial Roof Garden at Bellevue Hospital.
British forces killed eleven Arabs in the Beisan Valley and re-occupied the town of Bethlehem today in the first of a series of punitive actions to curb the Holy Land's growing terrorism.

Miss Elizabeth Crombie Sanborn, daughter of James F. Sanborn of this city and Martha's Vineyard, Mass., was married here yesterday in the Church of the Transfigura tion to Peter Franklin Mitchell, son of the, Rev. and Mrs. Henry Clay Mitchell of Wayne, Pa., and Marthat's Vineyard. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Harold F. Lemoine.
The appointment of John C. Kelly, prominent Catholic layman, as chairman of the Lehman-Poletti Independent Citizens Committee, was announced yesterday by Governor Lehman.
Official data on textile production, just published, help to explain why the average Soviet citizen is so inadequately dressed, although much better than three or four years ago.
Declaring that "it remains to be seen" whether a general war in Europe "has been escaped" by the events of the past few weeks, Francis B. Sayre, Assistant Secretary of State,

Berlin is losing the iron railings of its front gardens. During the week-end Storm Troopers acting on instructions of Field Marshal Hermann Goering carried out an old iron "collection" throughout this capital.

Princeton's varsity took things easy on University Field today while the reserves prepared for the Penn game by tearing into an Orange scrub outfit and scoring at will. The Tigers came through their Dartmouth defeat without an injury.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading citfollowing principal changes for the week ended Oct. 5:
Dionisio Trigo y Marcos, one of the island's leading Spanish merchants, died in Frankfort, Germany, this afternoon, according to word received by his family.
George E. Hughes, 53 years old, of 36 Lafayette Drive, Port Chester, a leading golf professional in Westchester County, was killed late this afternoon when his automobile left

Steel operations are scheduled at 51.4 per cent this week, the highest figure since 52.1 per cent for the week of Oct. 25, 1937, and a gain of 3.5 points, or 7.3 per cent, over last week, the Amerlean Iron and Steel Institute reports. One month ago the rate was 45.3 per cent.

C. J. Devine Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of a new issue of $525,000 of city of Niagara Falls (N. Y.) public welfare and public works bonds, on a bid of 100.159 for 1.40s. The bonds, maturing serially from Jan. 1, 1939 to 1948, were reoffered to yield 0.15 to 1.60 per cent, according to maturity.

Having come through the Case game in good condition, Lehigh started practice today for the Penn State invasion on Saturday. The only casualty was a dislocated shoulder suffered by Hulme Thomas, veteran guard, who is not likely to see service this week-end.

Football this year is putting on the best show ever. If the multiplicity of star attractions vying for the public's patronage each week is not evidence enough, just take a look at the decimation in the ranks of the major powers.

The Cubs returned from the world series wars today to face a threat of a sweeping shake-up. Manager Gabby Hartnett, disappointed by the team's showing against the Yankees, confirmed reports that he contemplated changes in an effort to build up the club's strength.
Fred Uhlmann, long a leading figure in the grain trade, died today in St. Luke's Hospital after an operation. He was 74 years old and resided in Glencoe a suburb.

The report of the Department of Agriculture on the probable yields of the principal grain crops this year showed that output will be around the 1928-32 level. The corn crop is almost 200,000,000 bushels below the heavy yield of last year,

Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, who was treated with extraordinary honor and hospitality last August on the occasion of his second visit to the Soviet Union, was the object of a violent attack in the newspaper Pravda today.

Another important milestone on the road of safety in flight was passed on Sunday when an absolute altimeter, showing actual height above the ground irrespective of barometric conditions, was demonstrated over New York.
Arturo Toscanini, noted Italian conductor, arrived last night from Europe on the French liner Normandie to conduct a series of concerts for theNational Broadcasting Company.

The citizens of North Dakota will vote next month on an initiative measure to substitute a $40 minimum for the $30 monthly maximum for needy persons 65 years old or more in the present Old-Age Pension Law.

Mrs. Elenore Van Houten Bolles, who kept so many German Spitz dogs last year at her estate in Harrison that neighbors obtained a Supreme Court injunction, was held today by a county court jury to be incompetent to manage her affairs.

A capital readjustment plan for the Pittston Company, a holding concern for coal and other properties of the former Van Sweringen railroad empire, was approved by stockholders at a special meeting in Dover, Del., today.

James V. Auditore, once known as the "millionaire stevedore," and a close friend of former Mayor James J. Walker, filed yesterday a voluntary petition of bankruptcy in Brooklyn Federal Court, listing total liabilities of $75,000 and no assets.
The wholesale price index of the National Fertilizer Association last week showed a slight drop due to a small decline in a wide range of commodities.

Dr. Robert L. Carson, one of this city's oldest practicing physicians, died here today after a long illness at the age of 74. Born in Canandaigua, N. Y., he was graduated from Williams College in 1886 and completed his medical course at Physicians and Surgeons College, New York City, and the Eye and Ear Infirmary at Philadelphia.

Miss Caroline Ogden Schwab and Gordon Page Williams, both of this city, were married here yesterday afternoon in St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street by the Rev. Dr. Maclaren Brydon of Richmond, Va., a cousin of the bridegroom, who was assisted by the rector of St. James, the Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan.

Joseph Buerckel, Chancellor Adolf Hitler's Commissioner for Austria, was understood to have returned to Vienna today intent upon sending to concentration camps the persons responsible for Nazi attacks upon Theodor Cardinal Innitzer.

Representative Allen T. Treadway had the largest luncheon party of the Berkshire Hills season today when he entertained 800 friends at Heaton Hall here. He was assisted by his son, Heaton I. Treadway, and William G. Havill, manager of the hall.

Twenty firemen were' overcome last night while fighting a stubborn smoky fire in the basement of an A. and P. grocery 'store at the northwest corner of Fortieth Street and Third Avenue. Eight firemen were taken to Bellevue Hospital for treatment.
This correspondent visited today the Czech town of Policka [west of the Silesian zone turned over to Germany before it was occupied at 2 o'clock in the afternoon by German troops.

Younger members of' society actively interested in plans for the December ball to be given on Dec. 1 at the Ritz-Carlton are holding frequent sessions to prepare for the event. Miss Jane Ewing Rovensky is chairman of the ball, net proceeds from which will be given to the Grosvenor Neighborhood House to assist it in meeting its annual budget of $15,000.

Coach Earl Blaik allowed the Dartmouth -arsity and ranking substitutes, Joe Cottone, Howard Nopper and Ed Wakelin, to rest today while he sent his second and third elevens through an hour's scrimmage.

Charles Todd Maines, one of the builders of Flint, died today at his home after a brief illness. His age was 80. Born in Williamson, N. Y., in 1858, Mr. Maines began his career by buying butter and eggs from farmers in that vicinity and selling them in Rochester.

Dressed as painters but equipped with acetylene torches and steel cutting tools, a gang of safe robbers worked leisurely and undisturbed over the week-end in the wholesale jewelry store of Gordon Brothers, 18 Providence Street, and took uncut diamonds and jewelry valued between $100,000 and $150,000.

Governors of the New York Stock Exchange will meet today, and those of the New York Curb Exchange on Thursday. The former are expected to receive, but to take no action, on a report from the special committee which has been preparing a report on the question of allied memberships.

Queen Wilhelmina today expressed personal approval of the call for "moral rearmament" launched by several prominent citizens. In a statement communicated by court officials, she urged general cooperation to fortify the moral forces that stand for peace and to develop the spirit that finds its expression in justice, confidence and charity.

Judge Charles C. Cavanah of the United States District Court for Idaho has fined the Boise Petroleum Corporation and C. S. Hassler, Inc., $250 each and Hassler and John T. Glass $500 each, and sentenced Hassler to six months in jail for violations of a permanent injunction issued by that court on April 15, 1937, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
The first application received by the new Civil Aeronautics Authority for a determination of "fair and reasonable rates" for carrying air mail came today from Pan American Airways, Inc.,

Without explanation, the Supreme Court today declined to review the conviction of Charles ("Lucky") Luciano, and five of his fellows, sent to prison as the result of the drive by Thomas E., Dewey against gangsters.

The totalitarian power-as it is field of candidates seeking election to- the House of Representatives was cleared further today when four independents notified the Secretary of State of withdrawal from the November balloting.

The Association of Buying Offices will hold its annual meeting on Oct. 19 at the offices of the National Retail Dry Goods Association. The annual dinner of the Association of Manufacturers' Representatives will be held on Nov. 2 at the Hotel Astor.
The Michigan Consolidated Gas Company has called for redemption on Dec. 9 two bond issues aggregating $31,000,000, it was announced yesterday by William G. Woolfolk, president.

Felix S. Towle, a retired manufacturer of steel tools and tin cans, died yesterday at his home, 40-31 Eighty-first Street, Jackson Heights, at the age of 71. He had formerly lived for many years in Far Rockaway.

The international copper cartel announced in London yesterday that, effective on Oct. 15, production will be increased to 105 per cert of agreed basic tonnages. It is expected that this will result in an increase of an additional 6,000 tons a month.

Van Campen Heilner, well-known sportsman and author of many books on hunting and fishing, has just returned from a week's hunting on Lake Willipegosis in Manitoba and reports that the duck shooting in that area is almost too good to be true.

After a week in Washington the Securities and Exchange Commission's stop-orderproceedingsagainst the Reiter-Foster Oil Corporation were transferred yesterday to the commission's office here at 120 Broadway.

Eastern lilies, smilax and lighted tapers decorated the Calvary Episcopal Church of Clifton for the marriage here this noon of Miss Jean Taylor Price to Robert Miner Gillespie, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Frederick Gillespie of Shippan Point, Stamford, Conn.

By apparently a 6-to-2 vote the Supreme Court today refused to review a decision of the California Supreme Court denying freedom to Thomas J. Mooney, serving a life sentence in San Quentin for alleged complicity in the San Francisco Preparedness Day bombing of 1916.

United States Consul Raymond H. Geist today obtained from German authorities assurance that the government order invalidating Jews' passports would not halt intending emigrants to the United States who had received American visas.

Commercial and industrial failures in the United States in the week ended Oct. 6 totaled 192, as compared with 146 in the same week a year ago and 203 a week ago, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

A total of 239,786 persons registered in the city yesterday, the opening day for the qualifying of voters for the November elections. Despite the issues confronting the electorate this election--the first four-year Governorship term in thehistory of the State,

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Oct. 10 unless specified: Manila to Southern Island, Oct. 9: Alden, Barker, Black Hawk, J. D. Edwards, Edsall, Parrott, Stewart, Whipple. Canal Zone to San Diego: Bagaduce, Trinity YT-129.

Charles E. Edison, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, said today he did not believe the United States should participate in any armament race, but added that "if trouble comes we must be prepared to meet it."
The Chinese will be. able to check the Japanese advance on the Canton Railway as the result of a victory claimed for Chinese troops east of Teian yesterday, the military spokesman believes.

G. D. Brooke, president of the New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad (the Nickel Plate), announced in a letter to the holders of the company's 6 per cent notes defaulted on Oct. 1 that the "current forecast" indicated that the company did not have cash to pay $2,400,000 of the notes not deposited under a plan to extend them for three years from their maturity date.

Howard C. Hopson, former utilities executive, was again today the center of a bitter legal-clash at a Secucities and Exchange Commission hearing. The proceedings were in an atmosphere of subdued hostility between counsel for the commission and lawyers for the Utilities Employes Securities Company.
An old-fashioned Halloween supper dance will be held at Le Coq Rouge on the evening of Oct. 27 to further the work of the National Bureau for Blind Artists.

Plans were filed during the month of September with the Department of Housing and Buildings for eight new buildings in Manhattan estimated to cost $786,050, it was announced yesterday by Commissioner Alfred Rheinstein.

A report reached the hide market here yesterday that Germany, which has bought only meagre quantities of hides in the last two months, has allotted a substantial amount of exchange for purchase of frigorifico hides in the Argentine, and already has made heavy purchases which have resulted in advances of 1/2 cent in prices at Buenos Aires.

Mike Turnesa of Fairview and Jack Creavy of Hickory won the Westchester Professional Golfers Association's weekly pro-amateur bestball tournament at the Siwanoy Country Club today with a card of 33, 32-65, finishing two strokes ahead of the next four teams.

GOVERNORS ISLAND So much of Paragraph 7. Special Orders 177, dated Aug. 1, as continues lst Lt. John W. Koletty. C.A.-Res., on active duty with the CCC until Feb. 19, 1939. is amended so as to continue Lt. Koletty on active duty until Oct. 24. 1938.

BEHOLD OUR LAND, by Russell Lord. (Houghton Mifflin, $3.) The story of the topographical differences of various regions of the United States, how they came into being and their significance. THE BEST PLAYS 1937-1938, edited by Burns Mantle. (Dodd, Mead, S3.) An anthology.

The State Department gave out the text of the arbitral award in the Chaco as made in Buenos Aires, Argentina, today, as follows: The undersigned plenipotentiary delegates, representing the Presidents of the Republics

Traveling representatives of American firms arriving here from Ecuador raise the question of reciprocity in the United States reciprocal trade treaty as a result of the restriction of import permits for American goods and the granting of permits for German goods.

Three-cornered debates in four corners of the State, with candidates for Governor discussing issues from the same platform in LincolnDouglas fashion, were proposed yesterday by Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate, as a challenge to Governor Lehman and to Thomas E. Dewey, the Republican candidate.

Science has discovered a new way to detect invisible, poisonous fumes by causing them to cast shadows. The first application was announced today by the General Electric Company. It is a detector for mercury vapor, a growing health risk in industry.

The foreign contingent had a field day in the Pacific Coast tennis tournament today, Mme. Rene Mathieu of France capturing the women's singles title and Harry Hopman and Leonard Schwartz winning the men's doubles championship.

ABRAHAMS-Rose, nee Nordeman, at her late residence, Daub Ave., Hewlett, L. I., wife of the late Adolph, beloved mother of George J. Service Tuesday, Oct. 11 11 A. M., Riverside Memorial Chapel, Far Rockaway.

The American Federation of Labor convention has raised the price of peace with the Committee for Industrial Organization by declaring it Would not make terms with the C. I. O. so long as John L. Lewis was its "dictator" and unless Communist officials in C. I. O. unions were repudiated and expelled.
The international stock market indices for Oct. 8, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:

The contracts for commercial space reported by brokers yesterday were for quarters in buildings in scattered sections of the metropolitan area, Including Manhattan, Brooklyn and White Plains, and in two cities in New Jersey.

The annual Forum on Current Events sponsored by The New York Herald Tribune, to be held Oct. 25, 26 and 27, will be opened by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and the closing address will be made by President Roosevelt, it was announced yesterday.
Accidents, deaths and injuries in traffic declined again last week and week-end as compared to the corresponding periods last year, the safety bureau of the Police Department announced yesterday.

The Pittsburgh Pirates today sold Frank Filchock, formerly of Indiana University, to Washington of the National Football League and Tom Burnette, formerly of North Carolina, to the Philadelphia Eagles.

Winston Churchill, former First Lord of the Admiralty, is scheduled to broadcast a "direct reply" on Sunday to the allegations made by Chancellor Adolf Hitler in his speech last Saturday at. Saarbruecken, Germany. Speaking from London, Mr. Churchill will be heard over the National Broadcasting Company's networks.

KIND-HEARTED citizens can now take their K hands from over their eyes. The Yanks have stopped beating those Cube. Maybe it should have been stopped before it was started. Everybody was warned of what was coming. The Cubs had about as much chance with that Yankee gang as Little Red Riding Hood's grandma had when the big bad wolf dropped in for luncheon.

After four years of painstaking investigation, during - which hundreds of witnesses have been interrogated throughout the country, police and prosecuting authorities are convinced now that they have obtrained sufficient evidence with which to "break" the $427,950 arrored car robbery in Brooklyn-the largest cash hold-up in the nation's history.

Expressing confidence in the business future, the American Gas Association, opening its twentieth annual convention here today, approved plans for a new three-year cooperative national advertising campaign for the industry.

Sir Neill Malcolm, League of Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, arrived today to investigate the refugee situation created by Czechoslovakia's enforced compliance with the Munich demands for surrender of territories.

Increases in employment and payrolls in New York State factories continued to mount in September, Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner, reported today. Payrolls advanced 6.4 per cent and employment 4 per cent from the middle of August to the middle of September.

Jonn H. Gill, at 5 Ritchie Place, for Mrs. F. W. Coburn; David T. Small, at 33 Cobb Ave, for Harold V. Atwell; Ralph Waring at 708 Mamaroneck Ave, for Beatrice E. Schieper; Albert J. Alllo, at 91 Stratford Ave, for W. J. Foster; White Plains (Westchester County) leases by Chauncey B. Griffen, broker.

Definitely deciding to use only members of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union for actors, Labor Stage has been forced to cancel its announced production of Sidney Kingsley's dramatization of "The Outward Room."

King Carol, continuing his conferences with political leaders at his villa in Sinaia, gave an audience today to Foreign Minister Nicolas Petrescu-Comnen. The King's attention at present is concentrated on the future direction of the country's foreign policy with special reference to Germany's desire for closer trade relations.

Members of the Abbott E. Kittredge Club for Girls and their friends will celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the club and the inauguration of its Winter season with a reception on Friday evening at the clubhouse, 440 East Fifty-seventh Street.
Columbia's varsity eleven, slightly bruised and sore from the hard buffeting received in its stirring victory against Army, enjoyed an ex- a tra day of rest yesterday.

A number of serial programs of the works of special composers will be given this Winter in this city. Last night Efrem Zimbalist, violinist, assisted by Vladimir Sokoloff, pianist, began a series of five concerts of violin and piano sonatas to be given on consecutive Monday nights in Town Hall.

The aftermath of the attempt at "purging" the Democratic forces in Congress of less than 100 per cent New Dealers today again claimed the attention of President Roosevelt and at least one other government official, Secretary Morgenthau.

No kosher kill in local markets yesterday on account of Jewish holiday, first day Succoth; Friday's kosher market opened higher on all classes except lamb, which was lower. Yesterday's hinds and ribs market was steady to strong; veal and calf hindsaddles higher; others steady. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow.

Emphasizing freedom of speech as a priceless possession, the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, as a result of a survey entitled "Broadcasting and the Public," urges that the control of radio in America must be democratic and censorship strictly avoided.

A plan for reorganizing the United Telephone and Electric Company under Section 77B of the National uder Section 77B of the National Bankruptcy Act was presented to Judge. P. Nields today in Federal Court.

Although State and city police had been combing the country for him since his indictment with fifty other persons and corporations last December in the $2,000,000 Slovak Manor, L. I., land fraud conspiracy, Henry Halmos, 57 years old, surrendered yesterday with the announcement:

Lord Hawke, outspoken veteran of cricket, captain of the Yorkshire team for twenty-seven years, former president of the Marylebone Cricket Club and the game's ruling authority, died today in Edinburgh at the age of 78.

Miss Margaret Jane Ewart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Bateman Ewart of this place, will be married to Howard Weaver McCall Jr. of New York and Chattanooga, Tenn., son of Mr. and Mrs. McCall of Chattanooga, on Oct. 21 in the Irving Presbyterian Church.

When the Navy football squad started preparations for the Yale game, to be played in New Haven his Saturday, Head Coach Harry Hardwick found his first job was ?o disabuse his charges of any idea ?hat easy opposition could be ex?ected from the Elis.

Ten Rutgers regulars who played a major part of the game against N. Y. U. were excused from practice by Coach Harman today. The remainder of the squad engaged in a spirited scrimmage, during which the running of Herm Grief and Jack Casey was outstanding.

Short interest on the New York Curb Exchange rose in September from 11,670- to 14,209 shares. Only three issues showed short lines of 1,000 shares or more, Fisk Rubber Company rising from 100 to 1,300 shares, American Republics Corporation from none to 1,177 shares and American Cyanamid B from 100 to 1,039 shares.
The American freighter Steel Exporter was the hundred thousandth ship to make transit of the Panama Canal since the waterway opened in 1914.

A net profit of $239,849 was re- and ins ported yesterday by the Silex Company for the first three quarters of 1938, after deductions for depreciation, Federal income taxes and surtax on undistributed earnings. The result is equivalent to $1.11 each on the 215,000 shares of capital stock outstanding.

Showing a decided liking for the course where he had captured the Metropolitan P. G. A. crown on Saturday, Al Brosch, Bethpage professional, continued to burn up the Oceanside layout as the Long Island Golf Association held a one-day amateur-pro tournament today.
Although beaten three touchdowns by Cornell on Saturday, Harward was encourged by the general improvement made in the week following the defeat by Brown.

While no sale was consummated yesterday, marked trade and customer interest was shown in the advertisement of Jay-Thorpe, Inc., offering a chinchilla fur garment at $35,000, according to Murray Cohen, head of the fur department of the Fifty-seventh Street establishment.

Grover A. Whalen, president of the World's Fair Corporation, yesterday presented a plaque to Gaetano Vecchiotti, Italian Consul General at New York, to commemorate the completion of foundation work for the Italian pavilion at the fair. The plaque will be transmitted to Premier Benito Mussolini.

17th St, 146 W, 24.3x92: Frederick J. Wells to Laura J. Wells, 455 E 51st St; 1 yr, 5%; $3,400. 117th St. 330 E, 25x100.11; Mary Pepe to Manufacturers Trust Co, install, int per bond, $3,117. 127th St, 241 W. 16.8x99.11; Belfield Green to Franklin Society for Home Building and Savings; ex lien with pr mtg, $9,000; due as bond. 6%: $2.100.

With the arrival of Arturo Toscanini in Manhattan, Warners plan to continue negotiations initiated some weeks ago under which the conductor will appear in "Memory of a Hero," based upon the life of Beethoven.

Mrs. Sophia Markowitz, a leader in Jewish circles, died today at her home here after a long illness. She was born fifty-four years ago in Russia. She was the widow of Benjamin Markowitz, a manufacturer.

Oscar W. Kalkhof, well known in athletic circles and a Spanish-American War veteran, died of a heart attack last night at the Yonkers Y. M. C. A., where he was manager of the bowling alleys. His age was 67.
Dr. Eugene A. Colligan, president of Hunter College, will be a guest of honor at the twenty-fourth annual dinner of the Bronx Chamber of Commerce to be held at the Hotel Concourse-Plaza tonight.
Two tongue-in-cheek students stacked a pile of milk bottle tops on a table today and started campaigning for a new pension scheme-"$50 every Friday for folks under 50."
The Transport Workers Union announced yesterday that it would not only resist any attempt to. reduce wages for transit employes but would insist upon an "appreciable" increase for 1939.

Timber Town Clansman, a Labrador dog owned by Winthrop Sands of the Time Town Kennels of Islip, and bred and handled by Mrs. Kathleen B. Starr of the same town, scored today at the retriever field trial meeting of the Women's Field Trial Club.

The eleventh National Antiques Exposition opened yesterday in the grand ballroom of Hotel Commodore, bringing some 150 dealers from eighteen States to show their rarities and hundreds of visitors to see them.

Coach Ossie Solem today ordered secret practice at Syracuse as intensive work opened for the traditional game here Saturday with Cornell. He moved the squad inside Archbold Stadium and barred all spectators.

The twenty-fifth annual "Silver Jubilee" convention of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America will start tomorrow in Chicago. More than 1,200 mortgage and commercial bankers, life insurance and title and trust officers, real estate men and government agency officials are expected to attend.

Charles Bigelow Denny of 85 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, a trustee of the South Brooklyn Savings Bank and a member of its finance committee, died early yesterday in the Long Island College Hospital after an illness of several months.

Mrs. Janet Isabel Dominick Lockwood, former president of the Woman's Auxiliary of the Church Temperance Society, died yesterday at her home, 40 East Sixty-second Street. She was born in this city eighty-seven years ago.
Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, lowering the tournament record by one stroke, won the Nancy Wilbur Cup at the St. Davids Golf Club today. Her 78, one over par, was the only score below 80.

A number of multi-family houses and private dwellings figured in the city realty trading reported by brokers yesterday. The six-story tenement at 817 East Fifth Street, on a plot 26 by 97 feet, was sold by the Metropolitan Savings Bank to a client of James Felt Co., Inc., brokers.

Automobile production last week expanded sharply and the adjusted index spurted to 51.4, its highest point since the week ended on April 16. This figure compared with 36.3 for the previous week and 159.3 for the week ended Oct. 2, 1937.

The Munich agreement for the transfer of Sudetenland to Germany averted a world catastrophe and opened new possibilities for the cause of peace and democracy, declared Alexander Kerensky, former. Russian Premier, on arrival here yesterday on the French liner Normandie.

The Commercial Credit Company yesterday announced the consumnation of plans to purchase the entire capital stock of Manufacturers Finance Company of Baltimore, Md., subject to assent within thirty days by 90 per cent of each class

The twenty-family flat at 52-54 Newkirk Street, Jersey City, N. J., on a plot 50 by 110 feet, assessed at $67,500 was sold by the A. L, Improvement Company to Isaao Adelman. The sale was subject to a $72,000 mortgage held by the New Jersey Title Guarantee and Trust Company. The buyer then resold the building to Miss Esther Cohen of Bayonne.

The Baltimore Ohio Railroad will suffer a net loss of $13,969,962 this year, compared with a net loss of $720,695 incurred in 1937, according to an estimate furnished the Interstate Commerce Commission. The estimate for 1938 follow.

Dr. and Mrs. J. Willard Travell of 12 East Sixty-fourth Street have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of Mrs. Travell's daughter, Miss Peggy Bates, to Stuart Henry van Saun, son of Mrs. Henry H. van Saun of Hackensack, N. J., and the late Mr. van Saun.

Russia henceforth wild play a lone hand. While France and Great Britain are coming to realize the full consequence of their Munich surrender--which Chancellor Adolf Hitler's Saarbruecken speech rubs home all too deeply-the Russians review the situation in the light of the past and present.

Approving a proposal for the formation of an association of importers and distillers to check price-cutting in the local liquor market, members of the National Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers at their annual meeting in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday left local importers free to proceed with the organization.

For the second year in succession the Long Island women's team of fifteen players won the Fall intersectional team event for the Myra D. Paterson Trophy by scoring 171/2 points against 15 for Westchester and 121/2 for.New Jersey over the Hackensack Golf Club course today.

In the face of almost constant guerrilla warfare waged by strikers and sympathizers, newly hired substitute workers in the Municipal Bureau of Street Cleaning found the going slow and often painful today as they tried in West Philadelphia and Germantown to cope with growing accumulations of garbage, rubbish and ashes.

Manufacturers and other business leaders, with the support of Governor'Cross and the Highway Safety Commission, have organized safe driving contests for employes of Connecticut companies. Safety for all users of the highways is the basic objective.
Former sio Ambassadors, British knights, a C Congressman and prominent business men have registered with the State Department as agents of foreign principals.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Oct. 5, aggregated $8,842,000,000, or 31 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 7 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

Several sales in the Eatontown section of New Jersey are reported by Ray H. Stillman, Eatontown broker. Among the properties was the Walter A. Smock farm of three acres with a six-room dwelling, which was purchased by George D. Lazarian of New York City.

As part of the effort to speed up Britain's fighting machine, War Secretary Leslie Hore-Belisha announced tonight a complete reorganization of the Territorial army of 200,000 men. This force corresponds to the National Guard of the United States and would become Britain's first line of defense on the home front in time of war.

Witnesses for railway labor placed before the President's Railway Wage Fact-Finding Board today statistics which -they declared to be conclusive proof that the proposed 15 per cent wage reduction is not warranted by the facts of the existing railroad situation.
The German high command announced tonight that the army had completed occupation of the Sudeten territory today according to schedule and was now installed along the new frontier.
Among the important proposed State Constitutional amendments to come before the voters next month is the one designed to provide a basis for further promotion of lowcost housing and slum clearance.

Congress has given President Roosevelt "our purse and our sword," Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan told a South Dakota Republican rally here tonight. "That," he said, "is close to totalitarian power-as it is known in Europe.
If the harrowing story of Oscar Wilde must be repeated more than forty years after it burst on the world, it is fortunate that an actor of Robert Morley's quality is chosen to play the chief part.
Blair Gullion, basketball and track coach at the University of Tennessee for two years, was signed today as head coach of basketball at Cornell, succeeding John H. (Bo) Rowland.

Charging that the plan of reorganization for the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation filed recently with the Federal court here by two bondholders' protective committees, is "unfair and unsound," James A. Beha, chairman of the protective committee for Postal's preferred stock, yesterday urged all Postal preferred shareholders to join with the committee to resist the plan as it is now drawn.

About 400 representatives of the large food and general merchandise chains of the country today heard Don Francisco, president of Lord Thomas and advertising counsel for the chain food stores, urge business in general and chain stores in particular to take their story to the public if they wish to defeat hostile legislation.

Following Saturday's reaction on an unexpectedly large government estimate on the crop, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied yesterday and advanced 8 to 12 points. The increase of nearly 400,000 bales in the indicated harvest to 12,212,000 failed to influence sentiment

Two independent automobile manufacturers, Graham and Nash, swung into production yesterday on their new cars. Nash Motors is now in full production following settlement of a labor difficulty, it was disclosed here.

Persons who hear the national anthem played over the radio in their homes should stand at attention only if the circumstances do not make that action forced and unnatural, it was said yesterday by Colonel James A. Moss, president general of the United States Flag Association.

John Strachey was officially notified on his way up the bay on the French liner Normandie yesterday that the State Department had canceled the visa he obtained before sailing from England to lecture in this country on socialism and communism.

George Kondolf, New York City director of the Federal theatre project, yesterday assured members of the cast of "Sing For Your Supper" that if they would be patient they would have a theatre, costumes and all the props that go with a stage production.

Morton St, 34-6, 50x91; Howard A. Newman, referee, to Citizens Savings Bank, foreclosure ($1). 137th St, 223 W. 18x99.11; Albertha Warren to Zena and Ferris Warren, 223 W 137th St. Orchard St. 99, 24.10x87.6; Isidor Itskowitz to Lillian Goldenberg, 99 Orchard St, quitclaim.
Ninetyfive banks and bond houses notified State Controller Morris S. Tremaine today of their willingness to accept allotments of a $100,000,000 shortterm note issue by the State.
Specifications for groups of small residential buildings to be constructed in various communities in Queens were filed with the Department of Housing and Building there yesterday.

170th St, E.: 6-story tenement, 45.8x100. irreg; Bankers Trust Co, trustee, against Joseph F. Thompson; due, $49,737; to plaintiff for $38,000. Pitman Ave, 2,110; 35.7x100; HOLC against Peter Paraskevopoulos; due, $4,539; to plaintiff for $500.

Figures for the first eight months of this year showed an increase of 27,206 motor vehicle registrations over the same period in 1937, Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, announced today.

Completion of alterations on the main floor of Sake at Thirty-fourth Street, which have resulted in an expansion of space for fashion accessories, was announced yesterday by H. L. Redman, general director of the store.

Rifted Clouds, a daughter of Insco who had run an impressive race back of Indomitable in her last appearance at Belmont Park, brought relief to the form players at Jamaica yesterday when she got home first in a driving finish in the Catalan Class D Handicap over the six-furlong route.

A general membership meeting last night of the National Maritime Union, attended by about 1,500 sailors, repudiated the findings of a trial committee which had recommended that Ferdinand Smith. Negro vice president, be dropped as an official because he had served on an intercoastal ship during the Pacific Coast maritime strike of 1934.
The election of three new members to the board of trustees of Town Hall was announced yesterday by George V. Denny Jr., president, following a meeting of the executive committee of the board.

Regular meetings between representatives of employer associations and unions for industrial stability was proposed here tonight by the Rev. John P. Boland, chairman of the New York State Labor Relations Board, in an address before the National Conference of Catholic Charities.
Germany was reported in informed circles today to have launched a campaign of pressure upon Czechoslovakia aimed at reducing the republic to the status of a vassal of the Nazi State.
The Hungarian Government is placed in a curious and difficult dilemma by the "free-for-all" developing out of the distribution of the pieces of Czechoslovakia.

William Goodenow, 30 years old 140 Berkeley Avenue, for eight years employed in the office of the Chevrolet export division of General Motors in Bloomfield, died of hydrophobia today in Essex County Isolation Hospital.
Nationwide sales of department stores in September showed a decrease of 9 per cent under the same month a year ago, according to the report issued today by the Federal Reserve Board.

Factory sales of passenger cars and trucks in September were estimated at 85,220 units by the Automobile Manufacturers Association yesterday. A total of 1,638,632 for the first nine months of the year was indicated. September
Sir Edward Beatty, chairman and president of the Canadian Pacific Railway, celebrated yesterday twenty years of service as head of the company, the largest privately owned transportation system.

Accompanied by Representatives O'Toole and Fitzpatrick, a delegation of HOLC mortgagors from Brooklyn and the Bronx asked Chairman Fahey of the Home Owners Loan Corporation today for a moratorium or reduction of interest rates.

Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh had to act as their own ground crew today just before they took off from Le Bourget airfield on their way to Berlin in their private plane to attend the Lilienthal scientific congress.

Miss Virginia Carver Whittier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Tupper Whittier of 30 Sidney Place, Brooklyn, has completed plans for her marriage to Dr. Thomas Angell Warthin of Ann Arbor, Mich., which will take place Saturday afternoon at the Whittier home.

Mediators in the labor dispute between publishers of Wilkes-Barre's four newspapers and the local unit of the American Newspaper Guild reached what was described tonight as a new "stalemate," but on their behalf "hope for the future" was voiced.

Although he took the opening race of a three-out-of-five series with Captain Angus Walters's big salt banker Bluenose, Canadian defender of the International Fishermen's Trophy, Captain Ben Pine of the Gloucester challenger, Gertrude L. Thebaud, tonight, on the eve of the second race, strove to improve the American craft.

The Marquis and Marquise de Talleyrand, who arrived on the Normandie, are at the St. Regis. Miss Cynthia Houston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. DeHart Houston of Concord, Mass., will be introduced to society here today at a tea to be given by her parents at the New York Junior League clubhouse.

Dawson St, 761 (10-2695): Helen Levowitz to Sylvia. Ziskin, 2.301. Kings Highway, Bklyn. Monticello Ave (17-5028), n e cor of Jefferson Ave, 100x125; Harold S. Matzinger to Eleanora. M. M. Sibley, 2,129 Edenwaldd Ave. 193d St ((11-3239), s w cor of Heath Ave, 100x25; John Eliot Jr. to Caroline Oertel, 980 Tremont Ave.
Governor Lehman says that in the long fight for progressive legislation in New York State "we have been unwilling to yield an

This morning's issue of Informazione Diplomatica, Foreign Office mouthpiece, contained somewhat sarcastic references to the delay by the British Government in putting into force the Anglo-Italian agreements of April 16. This created a very unfavorable impression in British circles here.

Public offering of a new issue of 25,000 shares of the common stock of the Kirkham Engineering and Manufacturing Corporation, manufacturers of aircraft parts, is expected to be made this week by Robinson, Miller Co., Inc., and Parrish Co.
The century-old Chaco dispute between Bolivia and Paraguay was terminated this afternoon by the arbitral award of the Presidents of Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Peru, the United States and Uruguaty.

The election of George Van Santvoord, headmaster of Hotchkiss School of Lakeville, Conn., as a fellow of the Yale Corporation, the trustee board of the university, was today announced by President Charles Seymour.

Statements of condition of out-oftown national banks which were made public yesterday in response to the call of the Controller of the Currency all showed advances in holdings of government securities in the third quarter of this year.

Pleas of not guilty were entered in General Sessions. yesterday by three former employes of the French Line who were indicted last Friday by the grand jury in the alleged theft of about $67,000 from the company through the use of canceled and "washed" internal revenue stamps on the manifests of passengers.
Mrs. Mary Jane McCormick, resident of Stamford for seventy-five years who celebrated her 100th birthday last July 5, died today after having been in failing health for the last few months.

Activity in the bond market settled down yesterday into a narrow trading range. Although a considerable volume of profit-taking developed in some sections, prices on the whole held firm, with modest gains in the majority at the close.
Frederick Freas Jordan, vice president of the Ralph H. Jones Company, advertising agents, 400 Madison Avenue, New York, died suddenly of a cerebral hemorrhage today at his home on Silver Spring Road.
Stocks fluctuated narrowly and closed steady and mixed; turnover, 1,663,960 shares. United States Government loans slightly higher, other bonds firm and mixed; transactions, $7,099,500.

Mr. and Mrs. George Edwin Steele of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Lees Steele, to the Rev. Robert Charles Batchelder, son of Mrs. Robert C. Batchelder and the late Mr. Batchelder of San Diego, Calif.
Mr. and Mrs. James J. O'Brien of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Veronica O'Brien, to Dr. James Sarsfield Lyons of Albany, N. Y.

The Treasury Department will announce on Oct. 24 the terms of a refinancing operation to take up about $300,000,000 of 11/2 per cent notes of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation which were to become due on Dec. 15, Secretary Morgenthau announced at his press conference this afternoon.

Work submitted in the just-concluded sculpture contest for a bronze panel to be placed over the entrance of the new Associated Press Building, Rockefeller Center, will be shown to the public today in the Mezzanine Galleries of International Building.
An old Midwestern catchline was "Stagg Fears Purdue," But Amos Alonzo did no such thing. Purdue was a ripe plum in those days to be plucked by Stagg's Chicago titans by whatever score they wished.

Complete adjustment of the Remington Rand strike settlement issues is scheduled to be reached by Oct. 17, William G. Thompson, chairman of Federal Union 18,344, the workers' organization, announced here today.

While group advertising of electrical appliances will be down considerably the second half of this year, because of suspension of several important campaigns for the Fall season, the Spring of next year will witness a resumption of these drives and the start of new ones, it was indicated here yesterday.

Billy Beauhuld, 140 pounds, Jersey City, gained the decision over Maxie Fisher, 1353/4, Newark, N. J., in the principal bout of eight rounds before 3,500 at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. Heavier punching and cleaner boxing enabled Beauhuld to receive the verdict, which, although not popular with the crowd, was fairly earned.

Business men appear to be more concerned over the government's impending investigation of monopoly than over any other future matters except the state of industry and the November election, which are kindred. Among the questions they ask-and their inquiries extend to the desks of newspaper men --are these:
Bert Arthur Linderman, industrial engineer and inventor, died Sunday night in the New York Hospital at the age of 67. He lived in Homestead, Fla.

That French union labor is at a crossroads over the settlement at Munich became increasingly evident last night when the Labor Federatioc's national committee met under the presidency of Leon Jouhaux.
Forty-one scholarships totaling $11,530 were awarded today to students at the Harvard University Medical School during the coming academic year. Those who received the scholarships were:

The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Sept. 30 shows the gold reserve ratio to notes in circulation at 120.64 per cent, compared with 123.55 per cent on Sept. 15. The reserve ratio of gold to notes and sight liabilities rose to 86.53 from 85.33 per cent.

Annabella, starring in the motion picture "Suez" with Tyrone Power, has announced a definite break with her husband, Jean Murat, French filmstar. She is returning to Hollywood Oct. 26 and will not oppose her husband's suit for a separation.

While record-breaking cargeos of gold were being unloaded here yesterday as an aftermath of the warscare crisis in the foreign-exchange market a few days ago, the pound sterling and other important European currencies suffered a renewed sinking spell as a result of the unfavorable impression made by Chancellor Hitler's speech in Saarbruecken on Sunday.
Concentrating on pass defense, the New York University football team worked three hours yesterday at Ohio Field in preparation for the meeting with North Carolina at the Yankee Stadium on Saturday.
The new account opened quietly on the stock market here today, And there were few outstanding developments. Giltedge issues fell away in dull dealings and foreign bonds were lower where changed.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent APpeals today, Richard F. Weeks of New York City was admitted to practice, and the following proceedings were had: CUSTOMS 4144-United States v. Pennsylvania Salt Mfg. Company. Argued. Judge Jackson did not sit during the argument.

The reorganization plan for the Denver Rio Grande Western railroad proposed by M. S. Jameson, examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission, "wholly disregarded" the primary objects of Section 77 of the Bankruptcy Act and applied the doctrine of Northern Pacific Railroad vs. Boyd under an "erroneous conception" of that case, the debtor railroad claimed in exceptions filed today with the commission.

A little known episode of the World War, that Leon Trotsky, interned by the British at Halifax in 1917, was freed and permitted to return to Russia at the instigation of President Wilson, is related by Isaac F. Marcosson, veteran writer and correspondent, in a book, "Turbulent Years," published today.
The Rev. Dr. August Pohlman, a Lutheran minister and former medical missionary in Africa, died in Woman's College Hospital here yesterday following an operation. He was 74 years old.

The Hotel Savoy Plaza had an income for the year ended July 31 of $2,500,000, with $508,000 available for the payment during the year of real estate taxes and. interest on the company's debt after operating expenses, according to Amott, Baker Co.

Justice fames J. Fitzgerald of New York, who presided in. the Municipal Court, Second District of the Bronx, lied here at the age of 77 in the ??ome of his sister, Miss Margaret Fitzgerald, late Saturday night.
The New York Football Giants will return to the Polo Grounds today to begin training for their encounter with the Philadelphia Eagles on Sunday.
The Washington Redskins, despite a defeat at the hands of the New York Giants, are continuing their great drive for new offensive records in the National Football League.

Rudolf Thomas, 43 years old, chief editor of the German-language newspaper Prager Tagblatt, and his wife were found near death today in what the police described as a suicide attempt. Both had taken overdoses of a drug.

A government forecast that the United States corn crop would total 2,459,316,000 bushels this year prompted officials to say today that the government loan rate to growers was virtually sure to be 61 cents a bushel.

Lamar Hardy, United States Attorney, said yesterday that the espionage laws must be strengthened to protect American military secrets and predicted that the trial, opening Friday, of three men and a woman accused of being members of a German spy ring would "give the American people a picture of whatS has been going on in this country for the last few years."

Apparently stricken with a heart attack while riding with his wife in the Independent subway, Isidor Kohn, 52 years old, head of the Isidor Kohn Company, furriers of 236 West Twenty-seventh Street, slumped forward dead on a southbound local yesterday morning during the rush hour.
Funeral services for Leroy N. Mills of Scarsdale, attorney and one of the country's foremost experts on football kicking, will be held at 3 P. M. Wednesday at the Burr Davis Funeral Chapel here.

Lewis Doughty, 30-year-old salesIman for the Public Service Corportion of Newark, was shot and wounded fatally here tonight while in the vestibule of a four-story apartment house at 4,656-4,660 Hudson Boulevard. The assailant escaped. Mr. Doughty died without identifying him.

Three and one-half years after his first attack on the government's dollar devaluation, John M. Perry of New York lost again today when the Supreme Court refused to review a decision of the Court of Claims that he had not suffered actual damage through abrogation of the gold clause on Liberty bonds.

Burleigh Grimes is out as manager of the Dodgers. Larry MacPhail, executive vice president of the club, made that official yesterlay when he called newspaper men into his Montague Street offices in Brooklyn and handed each a typed statement which praised Grimes for ais work and said that "our decision was reached with reluctance."
Wheat futures fluctuated today in a range of about 1 cent a bushel without establishing a definite trend. Trading was light and mostly of a local character.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today George H. Coppers, Roy E. Tomlinson and Richard H. Demuth of New York City were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had: 112-M. D. Carter, applt., v. the State of Texas. Appeal from the Court of Criminal Appeals, State of Texas. Per curlam: the appeal dismissed for want of a substantial Federal question.

A national promotion program in 1939 fdr Certified Performance gas ranges was announced today by W. E. Derwent of Rockford, Ill., chairman of-the domestic gas range division of the Association of Gas Appliance and Equipment Manufacturers, at the opening of the association's annual meeting at the Hotel Claridge here.

The Yugoslav Government tonight dissolved Parliament and called for new elections on Dec. 11 in what was interpreted by diplomatic circles as an attempt to prevent a possible catastrophe such as was experienced by Czechoslovakia.

The Supreme Court denied today the plea of employes of the Port of New York Authority for a rehearing of the Gerhardt case, in which a decision last Spring held that they were subject to Federal income tax because the Authority was not essential to the existence of New York and New Jersey.
The New York State Federation of Labor, through its nonpartisan committee, announced yesterday its stand on the nine proposals referred to the people by the recent Constitutional Convention.

225th St (17-4872). n s, 175 ft w of Laconia Ave. 50x109; Public National Bank and Trust Co to Orlando Franciosa, 349 E 113th St. Crotona Park E (11-2938), s s. 120 ft w of Wilkins Ave, 43x123: Clara Klyde to Gussie Fox, 1,221 Amsterdam Ave. Watson Ave, 2,138 (14-3808); Abraham Sherman to HOLC.

An abbreviated but interesting program of games has been arranged for schoolboy football teams in the metropolitan area today. All told, there are thirteen clashes on the holiday bill, with three listed for New York.City gridirons, one for Westchester and nine for New Jersey.

The report has been gathering force that Dr. Marvin A. Stevens is building himself a real football team at New York University this Fall. Lou Little gave nourishment to the rumor at Jack Dempsey's emporium of edibles on Monday and private operatives tell that in motoring uptown with the doctor following the Football Writers' luncheon Jimmy Crowley of Fordham expressed his concern over their annual November battle of the Bronx.

Mahmoud Hassan Bey expressed appreciation for President Roosevelt's efforts for peace during the Central European crisis in presenting his letters of credence as the new Minister of Egypt to the President at the White House yesterday.

Confirming reports of negotiations for the sale of station WINS, New York, to Milton H. Biow, president of the Biow Company, an advertising agency, E. N. Stoer, Hearst executive, announced yesterday that plans also were under way for the disposal of three other stations owned by Hearst Radio. They are KOMA, Oklahoma City; KYA, San Francisco, and WISN, Milwaukee.
With a present deficit of $98,000 the Philadelphia Orchestra Association mapped plans at a luncheon meeting today for a public campaign to raise a maintenance fund of $100,000.

10th St, 84-90 E, three 3 and one 5-story tenements; C. Blackburn Miller against Clara Fried; due. $19,977; taxes, etc, $1,192; to plaintiff for $59,500. By JACQUES COHEN 25th St. 412-14 W, two 4-story tenements, 50x93.9; Central Hanover Bank and Trust Co against Metropolis Holding Corp; due. $27,166; taxes, etc, $512; to plaintiff $22.000.

Tonight, for the first time on the American stage, Shakespeare's "Hamlet" in its entirety will be presented at the St. James Theatre. It will be the Maurice Evans production. with Mr. Evans as the Prince.

The French liner Normandie sails today for Europe. Her list includes Mrs. H. H. Childs, Dr. C. T. Wang, Kay Stammers, Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Richards, Colonel Norbert Champsaur and Mrs. Champsaur, Commandant Badard of the French Air Minitrvy, Pierre Hardy,

George W. Lederer, theatrical manager and producer, who died Saturday, was eulogized yesterday at funeral services conducted in the Park West Memorial Chapel, 115 West Seventy-ninth Street, by the Rev. Abraham L. Feinberg, rabbi of Mount Neboh Temple, 130 West Seventy-ninth Street.

Production supervisors of plants of the Armstrong Cork Company will study the policies, products and operations of the company in a training program which is to be started late this month by the company's personnel department. Some 261 supervisory employes will spend a week, in groups of not more than a dozen at a time, at the company's general offices and plants at Lancaster. Pa.
