District Attorney Edward J. Neary of Nassau County announced today that three psychiatric examinations of Harry C. Johnson, retired oil distributor of Hewlett, L. I., indicated that Mr. Johnson was temporarily insane on the morning of Oct. 1 when he killed his wife, Jennie, -63, by gas poisoning to prevent her from suffering any longer from a stomach cancer with which she had been afflicted for two years.

Commander Robert C. Lee, executive vice president of the MooreMcCormack Lines, Inc., urged the development of United States flag shipping service to South America as an "economic duty" in an address last night before the Women's Traffic Club of Greater New York.

Naturalness is the keynote of the current trend in feminine beauty, Mary Pickford, film actress, and Marcia Conner, fashion counselor to the New York World's Fair 1939, told 250 members and guests of the Advertising Women of New York, Inc., at a luncheon yesterday in the Advertising Club.

When the Board of Education meets tomorrow afternoon it will be faced with the question of installing movable furniture in two new high schools-the Christopher Columbus In the Bronx and Lafayette High School in Brooklyn.

Miss Florence Bernedette Crosby, daughter of Mrs. John Crosby of this city and the late Mr. Crosby, was married to William McCord Harris Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harris of Riverdale, yesterday afternoon at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

Estate, more than $20,000. To Warren S. Adams, husband, executor, 580 Park Ave., Jewelry and life estate in trust to yield $5,000 per year; Cecily S. Satterlee, daughter, executrix, Newport, N. H., personalty and residue. John D. Peabody, 18 E. 84th St.. executor.

The Supreme Court of the United States has shattered what seemed almost the last hope that Thomas J. Mooney could be released from San Quentin Prison by judicial process. True, in refusing to grant a writ of certiorari the court did permit an Mooney's attorney to renew his petition for a writ of habeas corpus.

Awards totaling $5,805 were made today to thirty-two students at the Harvard University Divinity School for study during the current academic year. Hopkins Shares, given annually to the six highest ranking seniors, went to John H. Bratt, Cecil E. Hinshaw, John A. Martin, Irving R. Murray, Roy M. Pearson and Harry B. Scholefield.

Father Luis Rodes, the Jesuit astronomer in charge of the Ebro Observatory, which was conducted under the protection of the Loyalist Government during the civil war until it was dismantled when it was in the 'thick of an enemy bombing area, has returned to Barcelona.

The violent the attacks in the Soviet press upon the Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh for alleged aspersions on the efficiency of the Soviet air fleet were met today by the American airman in his characteristic manner. He said:

A French program of champer music, the first of a series of six concerts of national schools that the Musical Art Quartet will give this Fall and Winter, opened the thirteenth season of that organization last night in Town Hall.

Seven members of the dissolved Left Communist party, the P. O. U. M. [Workers' Party of Unification], commonly called the Trotsky party, went on trial today before five judges of the Espionage Court here on charges of espionage and collaboration with the enemy.
With no world series to cramp its style, football really will come into its own this week-end when one of the greatest feasts of the whole year will be served up. Here's what's in store:

George Wharton Pepper of Philadelphia, as attorney for Charles Guth, former president of Loft, Inc., filed today with the State Supreme Court an appeal from the decision of Chancellor Josiah O. Wolcott ordering that 270,000 shares of stock of the Pepsi-Cola Company be turned over to Loft, Inc., by Mr. Guth and the Grace Company.

As a contribution toward a general healing of the labor rift, John L. Lewis offered today to resign from the Committee for Industrial Organization, provided that William Green resigned simultaneously as president of the American Federation of Labor.

Movements of vessels follow all dates are Oct. 11, unless specified: At Southern Island. Oct. 10: Alden, Black Hawk, Barker, Edsall, J. D. Edwards, Parrott, Stewart, Whipple. Boise, Norfolk, to Navy Yard, Philadelpnia. California, at San Pedro.

The charter boatmen are just about ready to call it a season, and even those who hung on late in the hopes of a big bluefish run are willing to admit that there's little left but hope and not much of that.

The cost of carrying out the plan of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad for modification of interest charges and maturities on its outstanding bonds will be about $1,063,140, not including counsel fees, George M. Shriver, senior vice president of the B. O., has informed Charles D. Mahaffie, a member of the Interstate Commerce Commission, it was learned today.
John L. MacDermott, one of the two Socialist members of the local Board of Education, died last night in Derby at the Hotel Clark, of which he was the owner. He was 55 years old.

Expansion of the work of the Magistrates Courts Social Service Bureau in the last ten months, with a corresponding increase in the staff and facilities, was reported yesterday to the membership at the first open meeting of the season, at the Hotel Commodore.

Charles P. Russell of Williamson, Wayne County, a farmer and fertilizer manufacturer, filed with the Secretary of State today a petition asking that his name be put on the Nov. 8 election ballot as an independent Townsend party candidate for Congress.

Gross assets. $351,325: net. $301,043. To Helen Bernstein, widow, temporary estate in trust of 50 per cent of residue, subject to invasion of principal: Louise B. Saxe, sister, 10 per cent of residue; Peggy L., Patricia E. and Pamela S. Bernstein. daughters, equal interests in trust of 40 per cent of residue.

Frank Gnup, Manhattan's 173-pound sophomore reserve center, clinched the quarterback post on the badly patched Jasper eleven yesterday as Coach Herb Kopf continued pointing for the encounter with Providence Saturday.
Columbus Day will be fairly generally observed throughout the United States today, with banks here and in the majority of the States closed.

Daily average crude oil production Steel ingot production las in the United States last week was 3,249,350 barrels, compared with 3,231,800 in the previous week, an increase of 17,550, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

Harriet B. Taylor, at 119 Meadow Rd; George D. Engel, at 125 Meadow Rd; J. Howard Denny, George A. Ferris residence on Park Drive South; Harrison (Westchester -County) rentals by Prince Ripley, Inc. brokers.

Albert Gwilliams, 63-year-old ticket puncher for the London, Midland Scottish Railway at St. Pancras Station, is the center of a trade union storm which, starting with an unofficial -porters' strike, has now spread to London's food services.

Acting on an urgent warning from Controller Joseph D. McGoldriclk yesterday against further large expenditures of capital funds at this time, Mayor La Guardia summoned members of the Board of Estimate to a conference on the city's financial status to be held in City Hall tomorrow morning.
The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today receipt of the following additional applications from New York City for registration as broker or dealer in the over-the-counter market:

Morningside Ave. 8, 75.3x101.5x irreg; Edward J. Mallory, 352 w 115th St, to Ethel Waters; quitclaim. Vandam St. 25, 20.1x100.1; Spring St Church. also known as Spring St Presbyterian Church. a corp. to 80-2 Carmine St Corp. 80 8th Ave; p m mtg, $8.250 ($10.50).
C. Heidt Son sold to the McNeill Cooperage Company, its cooperage plant in Jersey City, N. J., for a consideration shown as $24,000. The plant consists
Dartmouth's regulars were given another day of rest from contact work today and the second and third elevens repeated their performance of yesterday with a long scrimmage.

The Mexican Eagle Oil Company, Ltd., has levied an attachment on 12,500 tons, or about 90,000 barrels, of gasoline which originally was shipped from its former properties in Mexico and which now is in storage at Le Havre, France, according to private cable messages received here yesterday.

Fourteen persons were burned to death in forest fires which raged in Dance Township, about fifty miles northwest of here, yesterday and today. Police are also seeking a whole family cut off by the flames. Ten others, seriously burned, are receiving hospital treatment.

Testifying for the railway brotherhoods, W. Jett Lauck, a Washington economist, told the President's Railway Wage Fact-Finding Commis; sion today that the 15 per cent wage cut proposed by the railroads was inspired by bankers who, he declared, dominated the railroad industry.

An order of President Roosevelt made possible today the removal to Brooklyn of the body of George Watters Sr., a witness in a mail fraud case. Mr. Watters, an amateur song writer, of Brooklyn, died in the county jail hospital last night.
The Department of Commerce said today that gold imports into the United States in September set a record at $520,907,282. The previous record for a month was $452,000,000, in February, 1934.

The aid of the Federal Government in planning a 2,000-mile scenic trafficway along the Mississippi River was promised to representatives of the river States today by Secretary Ickes, according to a statement issued by the delegation following a conference with Mr. Ickes.

Installment buying was introduced to the National Hockey League today when the Detroit Red Wings acquired Charley Conacher, veteran rightwinger of the Toronto Maple Leafs, in a $16,000 transaction that will not be finally terminated for two more years and then only if Conacher retains his health.

A Kingsley Macomber's Khasnadar was installed favorite at 9 to 1 tonight for tomorrow's Cambridgeshire Stakes at a mile and a furlong. Barring overnight scratches, twenty-nine horses will race for the purse of approximately $11,250. The favorite is American-owned

Members of the National Association of Retail Druggits were urged today by Representative Wright Patman of Texas and by John W. Dargavel, secretary of the association, to throw the full weight of their support behind the proposed national tax on interstate chain-store systems.
The State Department is perfectly aware that the weakened world prestige of Great Britain after Munich engenders new o anxieties and responsibilities for this nation.

Fully aware that Peddie School's hardest football games of the season lie ahead, Head Coach Larry Kelley naturally is taking a conservative view concerning his unbeaten team's chances of winning all its five remaining games.

The Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company earned $850,586 after charges in the three months ended on Sept. 30, according to the quarterly statement to be made public today by John D. Biggers, president. The result was equivalent to 34 cents each on 2,508,380 shares of common stock outstanding.

A representative selection from the famous art collection of William Randolph Hearst is being prepared for public exhibition in a five-story building at 46 East Fifty-seventh Street which has been leased for the purpose. The exhibition is to be opened to the public on Nov. 15, according to M. Parish-Watson, who is managing the sale of the Hearst collection.
Joe Gordon, who took time out from his studies at the University of Oregon to become the star second baseman of the champion New York Yankees, will be back at his books here in January.

John Feldsine, 38 years old, of 102 West 183d Street, a dealer in securities, was arraigned yesterday in Special Sessions in Brooklyn on a charge of having jumped bail in that borough when faced in 1936 with a complaint that he had violated a securities law.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 10: COLONELS Miller, B. F., F.A., Fort Ethan Allen, Vt., detailed as a member of the General Staff Corps, and ordered to duty as Chief of Staff of the First Corps Area, Boston, Mass. Marley, J. P., F.A., Chicago, Ill., to 7th F.A., Fort Ethan Allen, Vt.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Oct. 8: CAPTAINS Farquhar, A. H., Washington, D. C., to duty as chief of staff and aide, commander Atlantic Squadron. Gearing, H. C.. Jr., San Francisco, Calif., to command Destroyer Squadron 4, Nov. 20.

A daughter, their second child, was born to Mr. and Mrs. L. J. Robbins of Short Hills, N. J., on Sunday at the Orange Memorial Hospital. Mrs. Robbins is the former Miss Ann Brokaw Roe, daughter of Mrs. William S. Roe of Summit, N. J., and the late Mr. Roe.

The attempt of the city to extend municipally operated rapid transit ervice completely across the city tap the rich Coney Island transortation business has been blocked mporarily by the refusal of the wners of Brooklyn's Culver line to dmit the city's right to take the property by exercising its contracal "recapture" right, it was arned yesterday.

Four to five miles above Fort Bragg today the future tactics of the type of warfare that all nations fear were tried and tested as pursuit planes and great bombers, their crews oxygen-equipped, cooperated with ground troops and civilians on the second day of the country's most extensive air-raid defense exercises.
The State Federation of Labor announced yesterday its endorsement of twenty-three candidates for State Senator, and of many Assembly and Congressional candidates.

Army's varsity scrimmaged tonight as Coach Bill Wood and his staff watched the offense and defense to be used against Harvard Saturday. Bob Stillman's B team, using Harvard plays, was matched against the regulars and the coaches carefully checked assignments.

The executive committee of the Wilkes-Barre Newspaper Guild tonight rejected "unconditionally" a five-point proposal submitted by publishers of this city's four newspapers as a basis for resuming publication.

Offensive drill was the order today as the Princeton varsity ran through ninety minutes of scrimmage against the scrubs on University Field and wound up with a white ball under the floodlights. The line spent half an hour perfecting its blocking, which bogged down last week against Dartmouth.
Howard C. Hopson, testifying today before the Securities and Exchange Commission, opposed wage-cutting in the public utility field as of doubtful value to utility companies themselves.

James D. Doyle. famous theatrical midget, was found dead in his bed here today from natural causes. Mr. Doyle, known as Major Doyle, was 70 years old. He had been appearing with a group of midgets here.
Herbert S. Houston, who was named in a list of the State Department yesterday as public relations counsel for the Consul Geineral of China in New York City, said here yesterday:

TEACHER IN INDIAN COMMUNITY AND BOARDING SCHOOLS. Indian Field Service (including Alaska). Department of the Interior; optional branches and annual entrance salaries: Science, $1,800. Agriculture. $1,800 and $2.000. Social sciences. $1.800.

Former United States Senator W. Warren Barbour, who is seeking to regain the seat he lost in the Roosevelt landslide two years ago, reported to the Secretary of State here today that his primary campaign for the Republican nomination cost $12,495.

Declaring that industry had already definitely lost to the government the right to regulate its industrial relations, Clyde G. Conley, president of the American Institute of Steel Construction, warned institute members today that the next move of "the politicians" would be to regulate the price structure and that the attempt would succeed unless industry placed its side of the case before the public.

Marking the official presentation of a new elephant to the Prospect Park Zoo in Brooklyn by the Abraham Straus department store to replace the ill-fated Hilda, who was pushed into the moat by Elephant Bill, a circus and other festivities will' be held in Prospect Park on Saturday at 2:30 P. M.
The New York Curb Exchange has stricken from unlisted trading Indianapolis Power and Light Company first mortgage gold bonds, Series A, 5 per cent, due on Jan. 1, 1957.

An appeal to 250 leading stores dealing in millinery to handle only merchandise bearing the Consumers' Protection label issued by the Millinery Stabilization Commission, Inc., was made yesterday by Nathaniel Spector, manager of the joint board, Millinery Workers Union.

Testimony to support an increase in ocean freight rates between Atlantic and Gulf ports and Puerto Rico will be submitted in New York, not here, counsel for the companies informed Examiner Russell of the United States

Five police cars and thirty policemen at 3 A. M. today took eleven American seamen from a boarding house at Sandefjord, near Oslo, and placed them on board the liner Bergensfjord for deportation to the United States.

Robert W. Allan, Acting State Administrator of the Works Progress Administration, warned WPA employes in New Jersey today against political activities. His warning was given as an investigation of alleged political coercion of WPA clients was started by Francis M. Dryden.

Municipal bond issues aggregating $48,831,500 were approved by the voters of 430 municipalities in thirty-nine States in September, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. This compared with $49,712,232 of bonds approved in August.

In commemoration of the 446th anniversary of the arrival of Christopher Columbus in the New World, 5,000 members of the Manhattan and Bronx councils, Knights of Columbus, will march in the annual Columbus Day parade, arranged by the New York Chapter, today at 2 P. M. from chapter headquarters, Eighth Avenue and Fifty-first Street, to Columnbus Circle.
Coach Carl Snavely sent his Cornell varsity through dummy scrimmage against various types of defenses today with five sophomores in the line-up.

On his own application-To take effect 12 noon, Oct. 16: LIEUTENANT--Arthur O'Neil, 63d Precinct, $2,000 per annum. Appointed Oct. 2, 1913. Transfers and Assignments LIEUTENANTS-To take effect 8 A. M., Oct. 12: William S. Brown, from 14th Division to Mounted Squadron 2, assignment to desk duty continued.

Governor Lehman is expected to make an early decision on the request made by William B. Here lands, Commissioner of Investigation, for a special prosecutor to supersede District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn in the Commissioner's investigation into official corruption in that borough. The Governor studied the evidence yesterday.
American visitors to Sweden numbered 14,579 during the first eight months of this year, the commercial attache at Stockholm has reported to the Department of Commerce.
Nine thousand tobacco strippers have ceased work this week in anticipation of the application of the WageHour Law and another 6,000 will have done so by the end of the week, it was revealed today
Evelyn John St. Loe Strachey of Eton and Oxford is a suave and amiable writer who used to call himself a Communist and now seems to prefer the name of Socialist.

Mr. and Mrs. F. DeHart Houston of Concord, Mass., gave a tea yesterday at the clubhouse of the New York Junior League, 221 East Seventy-first Street, to introduce to society here their daughter, Miss Cynthia Houston.

How 370,000 freight cars in tran- c sit, most of them protected mechanically from robbery only by a light metal seal, are escorted intact to their destination by the railroad police will be described by Frank G. Love, superintendent of property protection of the New York Central Railroad, before the New York, chapter of the Railway and Locomotive and Historical Society in the Engineering Society Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street, Friday evening.

Samuel N. Pierson, playing his home course, shot a 76 to win low gross honors in a one-day Metropolitan Golf Association tournament at the Woodway Country Club today. The runner-up, Frank Rampacek of Split Rock, had a 77. A field of thirty participated.

Many Macedonian leaders and many friends of Colonel Damian Veltcheff, the former dictator, were arrested today in connection with the assassination yesterday of Major Gen. Yordan Peyeff, Chief of the Bulgarian General Staff, and Major Stoytnoff of the Geographical Institute by a Macedonian.

A Japanese landing has been effected at Hachung on Bias Bay by a force estimated at 30,000, it is reliably reported in Canton. The presence of a Japanese fleet in Bias Bay was reported by captains of incoming coastal steamers. One observer counted twenty-five transports and warships last night.

A Chesapeake Bay retriever dog attained top honors in the chief event today at the final session of the second annual meeting of the Women's Field Trial Club, held through the covers of Kilsyth Farm, the estate of Gerald M. Livingston, and in the waters of Lloyds Harbor.

Willie Turnesa, national amateur golf champion, was the guest of honor at a dinner given by the Holy Cross Club of New York at the Hotel Commodore last night. About 150 persons attended. Turnesa, who was graduated from Holy Cross last June, received a trophy from the club.

Lord and Lady Moyne, accompanied by the Hon. Grania Guinness, arrived on the Normandie and are at the Waldorf-Astoria. Mr. and Mrs. Martin von Dehn will return today on the Bremen after passing the Summer in Europe.

Food specialties that have enhanced the fame of various cities and regions of the United States will be reproduced at the New York World's Fair of 1939 by Hometown Restaurant, Inc., whose contract for 53,000 square feet of space in the main exhibit area was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation.

Turpentine firm, 21 1/2c: sales, 30 barrels; receipts, 461 barrels; shipments, 35 barrels; stock. 50,583 barrels. Rosin steady; sales, 166: receipts, 3,063; shipments, 854: stock. 265,064. Quote: B, $3.90; D, $4; i, $4.25; F, $4.95; G. H, I, K. M, $5.05; N. $5.45; WG, $5.70; WW, X, $6.50.
Effective on Nov. 1, common and contract carriers transporting property will be required under a rule of the Public Service Commission to file with it a corporate bond or insurance policy.

Miss Jessiana Louise Holmes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Bertram Holmes of Douglaston, Queens, was married to William Dickson Johnston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Alan Johnston of 40 East Eighty-eighth Street, here yesterday afternoon in the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas.

Venezuela needs and welcomes foreign capital and foreign technicians to develop its natural resources, and the investor who will go there on bases of equality and fairness has nothing to fear, Dr. Diogenes Escalante, Venezuela's Minister to the United States,. said yesterday to a group of American bankers and investors at a luncheon in the Wall Street Club, 40 Wall Street.

The need for providing adequate housing for families on relief and in the lowest income groups was stressed at today's opening session of the sixth annual meeting of the National Association of Housing Officials.

Dr. Rufus E. Zimmerman, research vice president of the United States Steel Corporation, in a talk to the Robert Morris Associates at Hershey, Pa., yesterday, said that "it is doubtful that a popular vote would send into the discard any one of the processes or products introduced since 1900.

All killing classes of cattle sold fully steady in a very dependable trade today. Replacement cattle were active and strong under a good demand from the country. Hog prices continued to work lower but lambs strengthened, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.

The New York Central Railroad reduced its operating ratio in August to the lowest level for any month this year, it reported yesterday. Gross revenues, total income and net operating income were the highest for any month in the year. The net loss for the month was the smallest for the year.
Alfred P. Sloan Jr. said tonight that he was "encouraged for the first time in many years that American business and industry were headed for a long upward pull."
Mrs. Harry Houdini, widow of the magician, said today that after ten years of trying to establish contact with the spirit of her husband she felt that she had proved there was nothing to spiritism.
Stuart C. Hemingway Jr., right guard of the Yale football team, injured in last Saturday's game with Pennsylvania, still is in the University Hospital with a slight concussion.

The four-story apartment house at 513 East 145th Street, Bronx, was sold by the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, as trustee, to a client of the Hub Realty Company, Inc. Henry Waltemade, Inc., acted as co-broker.

The Twenty-third Street Association will hold its annual luncheon meeting on Oct. 19 at Cavanagh's Restaurant, 260 West Twenty-third Street. Officers and directors for the year will be elected. Justice Joseph W. Keller of the City Court will be the guest of honor.

THE aroused Annapolis alumni are determined not to let any writing gent suffer from lack of information on the Navy team. Half a dozen nautical chaps have sent word that a victory for Navy over Yale this week is a copper-bound cinch.

A plan to consolidate all or most German-American organizations in the United States into a single organization that would supplant the German-American Bund was indicated here today when it was learned that leaders of the New Jersey division of the bund had incorporated a new group known as the German-American Front.

Speculative operations in the wheat market were at a low ebb on the eve of the Columbus Day holiday. Prices held within a range of 1/2 to 3/4 cent a bushel on the Board of Trade here, with the close at net losses of 1/3 to 1/4 cent.

When real mutual understanding is built up between management and the working force, the rest of the industrial relations policy will take care of itself, Harold F. Browne of New York, director of the management research division of the National Industrial Conference Board, said here today to the American Gas Association.

The infant mortality rate in New York City for the first forty weeks of this year was 39.9 per 1,000 live births, a new low record for so long a period, it was reported yesterday to Dr. John L. Rice. City Health Commissioner, by Thomas J. Duffield, registrar of records.

ROTHCHILD, a French film with English titles, adapted by Jean Guitton and E. R. Escalmel from the novel by Paul Lafitte; directed by Marco De Gastayne and produced by Productions Escalmel; released by Regal Distributing Corporation. At the Belmont.

The fund for the relief of sufferers from the recent hurricane now being raised by the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross reached $125,060 yesterday, it was announced by General Robert C. Davis, executive director.

The first endeavor by any industry to fix minimum wages to accord with the Wages and Hours Act, which will go into effect on Oct. 24, began here today when Industry Committee No. 1 met to organize textiles. The full membership of twenty-one, seven representing the public, seven the employers and seven the employes, was present.

At midnight tonight, the deadline for filing independent petitions for the November elections in Westchester County, David S. Murden of Peekskill, who was to run for county executive on a Progressive party ticket, had not filed the petition which he and his followers last week said would be filed.

More energetic sales promotion activity to take advantage of opportunities for increased sales of awnings and tents was urged here today by Paul B. Halstead, secretary-treasurer of the Cotton Textile Institute. Inc., in an address before the National Tent and Awning Manufacturers Association.

An attempt to assassinate a British district commissioner and another battle against Arab outposts marked the bitter dispute today among Arabs, Jews and British authorities attempting to restore order.

Fellowships and scholarships totaling $55,963 have been awarded to 122 students in the Columbia University School of Law, it was announced yesterday by Dean Young B. Smith. The winners are residents of twenty-nine States.

The West Shore Railroad is in the "very inconsistent position" of defending reduction of vehicular rates to offset the diversion of traffic to the Lincoln Tunnel while at the same time advocating increases in local ferry passenger fares in the face of similar competition, six New Jersey communities today informed the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Lieut. Col. Nicholas Engel; wartime commander of the 107th Regiment and former Grand Marshal of the American Legion, died Monday in the Veteran Hospital at Bath, N. Y., after a long illness, it was learned here yesterday.

Albany's Democratic Mayor, John Boyd Thacher, lashed back tonight at Thomas E. Dewey, Republican Gubernatorial candidate, for asserting that the city's enforcement of registration and election laws was "a mockery."

Deeds filed in the county recorder's office disclosedd today that Marshall Field III. grandson and namesake of the Chicago merchant prince, is conveying real estate valued at $1,634,000 to three of his children.

Extension of the field and museum trips taken by the New York City school children in connection with their studies, and the incorportion of this extra-curricular activity in the regular program of the Board of Education were recommended by a group of ten educators in a report made public yesterday.

Baby Salvy Saban, 153 1/2 pounds, Greenwich Village, received the decison over Bobby Pacho, 149 3/4, Mexico, in the feature eight-round bout at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx last night before 7,000 persons. Aggressiveness and clever fighting at close quarters accounted for his victory.
CLOUDY TROPHY, by Leon Daudet. (Morrow, $2.50.) A biographical novel about Victor Hugo.

Freedom pleas of three "Scottsboro" case Negro convicts received a unanimous rebuff late today from the Alabama Board of Pardons. The board acted a few hours after it had refused to hear oral arguments in the case, which brought from former Senator J. Thomas Heflin a charge that a "veiled effort is being made to keep damaging evidence out of the public records of Alabama" against the Negroes.
Arthur Edward Grime, former president of the Newspaper Society and publisher of a group of Lancashire newspapers, died in St. Anne's, Lancashire, today at the age of 66.

Endorsement of the Townsend or some other old-age pension plan by some Republican voters of Maine and New Hampshire and the recent declaration by Massachusetts Republicans for Congressional study of the Townsend plan were asserted by Republican observers here today to be reflections of increasing pressure by older persons in those States for government assistance.

An income tax payer whose 18-year-old daughter was incapacitated for ten months of a tax year, owing to an attack of inflammatory rheumatism, and had to be supported by the tax payer, is entitled to a prorated credit of ten-twelfths of $400 on account of a dependent for that period, the Bureau of Internal Revenue ruled today.

Jim Bryant and Charles Scofield, backfield men. injured earlier in the season were back on the field today as Coach Mylin worked the Lafayette football squad hard for the Washington and Jefferson game.

The number of employes in cotton garment industry plants in this country fell to 83,946 in August, as compared with 84,518 in August, 1937, while at the same time the number of plants in operation rose from 517 to 569, the International Association of Garment Manufacturers reported in a bulletin issued yesterday.

Constant emphasis by the Federal Government upon the menace of "big crops" invites depressed prices the moment a large harvest is in sight, Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg declared in an address prepared for delivery here tonight at a Republican club rally.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt entered her fifty-fifth year today-smiling, vigorous and fighting for "positive" democracy. "We should work for things and not against things," she told the National Women's Press Club at a luncheon where she cut a twentyone-candle cake.

Miss Blanche E. Childs, 62 years old, filed a motion yesterday in Supreme Court to bring about her release from the New York County jail at 434 West Thirty-seventh Street, where she has been lodged since June 28 for failure to pay a judgment of $1,813 obtained against her by default in a civil action in City Court.

In Calvary Episcopal Church here this evening, Miss Lura Quackenbush Anderson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Augustus B. Anderson of Springfield, was married to Philip Charles Backer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Backer of Bound Brook.
George Hall Hoyt, president of Louis W. Hraba, Inc., leather goods concern, 29 East Nineteenth Street, died yesterday at his home, 103 East Seventy-fifth Street, after a brief illness.

" Work steadily and try as hard as did the Austrians. and Sudeten Germans and you will earn the same reward for your patience and sufferings," declared Albert Foerster, the Nazi leader here, addressing a group of Nazi officials. officials.

Dr. James J. McGuire of this city, secretary of the State Board of Medical Examiners, died this afternoon after a six weeks' illness. He had been a board member since 1915 and was elected secretary eight years ago.

The National Labor Relations Board was denounced by the American Federation of Labor today in a brief presented to the Supreme Court in advance of argument Friday in the case of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York against the board.
The Real Estate Board of New York yesterday announced the election of Clarke G. Dailey as president for the third term.

The monopoly study begun by the Temporary National Economic Committee is essentially a search for a formula for elimination of the evils of destructive competition, making unnecessary a planned economy under public authority, Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney

A number of properties in Brooklyn were reported yesterday as having been sold by the Kenwood Investing Corporation. Among them was the three-family brick house at 2,450 East Twenty-third Street, which was purchased by Peter Mastrion through James Perry, broker The seller took back a purchase-money mortgage for $4,500. The property is assessed at $10,500.

Dr. Eduard Benes, who resigned as President of Czechoslovakia last week, has been invited to be the Scottish Nationalist candidate for the honorary rectorship of Glasgow University, but he has not accepted.

The stock market patterned itself yesterday after the Monday session. Although the public utilities again paced those issues on the up side, the general list, and especially the pivotal shares, showed no urge to move outside a narrow rim.
A long defensive drill against forward passing kept the Lehigh squad busy today as the coaches prepared for the Penn State game herb Saturday.

Stocks continued to move within a narrow range and closed irregular for second consecutive day; turnover, 1,534,000 shares. United States Government issues closed irregular after registering new highs for year, other bonds generally lower; transac tions, $7,381,525.
Paid life insurance sales in September of the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company were $6,561,211, a gain of 3.8 per cent over September last year, the company announced yesterday.
Trade barriers between Germany and the Sudeten areas now occupied by German soldiers already have been reduced, the Department of Commerce announced today.

Germany intends shortly to begin negotiations with the United States for a barter trade agreement similar to the Anglo-German agreement, Dr. Walther Funk, German Minister of Economics, told reporters here today before he left for Sofia, Bulgaria, where he plans to spend three days.

The Rev. Alexander A. Cahill, since 1926 rector of St. Christopher's Roman Catholic Church in Grant City, Staten Island, died yesterday in the Benedictine Hospital, Kingston, N. Y., after an illness of more than a year. He was 57 years old. W.
Coach Jack Blott tried out a new zone defense with the Wesleyar football squad today in preparation for the Haverford game on Satur day. Kay was back in the line-up,
Willard C. McNutt, president of the American Utensil Company and a practicing attorney in Chicago for more than thirty years, died today in his home in Winnetka, a suburb, at the age of 57.

The Aetna Fire Group announce yesterday the appointment of Sidney S. Perry as special agent to succeed Thomas M. Hill, who has resigned, and Richard B. Elliott as staff adjuster for the Connecticut and Western Massachusetts territory.

The Atlantic, Gulf and West Indies Steamship Lines received $1,232,500 from insurance companies on claims made as a result of the burning of the steamer Morro Castle in 1934 and the sinking by collision of the Mohawk In 1935, it was disclosed in a statement issued yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Christopher Grant La Farge, eminent American architect and oldest member of a family which has contributed largely to American literature and the arts, died today in his home at Saunderstown, after an illness of two years. He was 76 years old.

A 17-year-old New Rochelle girl on her way to church was slain after a criminal attack late last night by a motorist who beat her on the head and hurled her body into a yard behind a vacant store here at 1,993 Palmer Avenue.

William F. Carey, Sanitation Commissioner, who referred to some members of Community Councils as "crackpots" in a dispute with Park Commissioner Robert Moses on Monday, was attacked by the organization yesterday on the ground that he had made false statements to the Board of Estimate.

The Rutgers football team engaged in a ninety-minute scrimmage against the freshmen on Neilson Field today in preparation for the game with Springfield College on Saturday. Running plays were stressed.

The National Congress elected Dr. Felix Paiva constitutional President of Paraguay today. He had been provisional President since Aug. 17, 1937, when he led a counter-revolution against Colonel Rafael Franco.

A program of songs and folk dances by sixty-five children of the day nursery attached to the mission marked the ninety-fourth annual meeting of the Five Points Methodist Mission at 69 Madison Street yesterday. The Rev. Dr.

Ten thousand dollars in jewelry and the wallet of S. Sloan Colt, president of the Bankers Trust Company of New York, containing about $200 and what were described as "exceptionally valuable" papers, were stolen last night from the Colt home in the heavily guarded Tuxedo Park colony.

John A. Logan, formerly executive vice president and treasurer, was elected president of the National Association of Food Chains at the fifth annual convention of the association here today. Mr. Logan serves as a full-time salaried president, the first in the history of the association.

The American Hechalutz Organization, which trains young Jewish men and women for life in Palestine, has proclaimed Saturday night, Oct. 22, and Sunday, Oct. 23, as the annual Flower Day for the benefit of the Palestine Pioneer Fund.

W. S. Shipley of York, Pa., was elected president of the Re frigeration Machinery Association of Washington today as the twoday convention of the organization's executive committee closed. J. I. Lyle of Syracuse, N. Y., was elected vice president and the following were appointed to the executive

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Having just heard by radio the news of the four-power agreement at Munich, I write to tell you how completely in agreement I am with your comments on the European situation, which were broadcast at the same time.

In the United State Supreme Court today, Wilder Goodwin of New York was admitted to practice and the following proceeds were had: 7-Rolla W. Coleman, W. A. Barron, et al., petrs.. v. Clarence W. Miller, as secretary of the Senate of the State of Kansas, et al.

The rental of a fifteen-room cooperative apartment in the building at 117 East Seventy-second Street by William Raymond was the feature of the leasing reports submitted yesterday. Bertha Stockwell, broker, arranged the lease for Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., the agents.

ABOUT three years ago Benjamin Stolberg and Warren Jay Vinton wrote a little book called "The Economic Consequences of the New Deal," in which, when they were not weeping over the fact that President Roosevelt and his advisers knew so little, they were roaring with laughter at the mistakes that had been made.
One hundred miles off shore is now the limit of operation for planes of the Army Air Corps except in

Expressing his concern over reports that the British Government is planning to stop Jewish immigration into Palestine, Senator Robert F. Wagner announced yesterday that he and a group of his associates in the Senate were arranging to see President-Roosevelt to discuss the situation.

Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, announced today that arrangements had been completed among the RFC, the Public Works Administration and the Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission covering the purchase by the RFC of $35,000,000 of 34 per cent thirty-year Commonwealth of Pennsylvania revenue bonds and a grant of $26,100,000 by the PWA.

Because the Appellate Division, Second Department, did not consider both charges against Charles H. Stowell, who was removed as police chief of Mamaroneck, the Court of Appeals sent the matter back to that tribunal today. ribunal today.

Following price cuts of $4 a ton made at the end of last week on about 50,000 tons of sheet steel ordered by the Ford Motor Company, which became known yesterday morning, a growing number of price reductions was made throughout the day, not only in Detroit, where the action originated, but in all principal consuming centers.

Apprentice Warren Yarberry and the Morgan brothers, all from Texas, had a very successful day at Jamaica yesterday, the lad riding four more winners to make a total of thirteen during the Metropolitan Jockey Club meeting.

The Whitney Museum opens to the public today the first of its scheduled exhibitions for the 1938-39 season. It is a regional exhibition, consisting of paintings by artists west of the Mississippi. Fifty painters from twelve States are represented by one canvas each,
Columbia's first-string eleven went through a fast offensive drill at Baker Field yesterday in the first workout this week In preparation for the Lions' New York debut with Colgate Saturday.

Miss Gertrude Naughton of this city, daughter of the late Michael J. Naughton and the late Mrs. Gertrude Naugton Cassin, was married to William Stoeffel Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stoeffel, also of New York, yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Philip Neri, the Bronx. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John C. Mulcahy.

With the military occupation of the Sudetenland complete, the Czechoslovak situation has now developed into a double-barreled campaign to collect the utmost spoils possible from the occupation and bring the "rump" of the former Czechoslovak State into fourthe German orbit economically and politically.

John B. Ritter, 54 years old, former superintending principal at Collingswood High School, was fined $100 and court costs today when he entered a plea bf non' vult to ten counts of embezzlement totaling $1,000 before Judge Clifford A. Baldwin here.

The shipyards of the world were engaged in the construction of 2,828,902 tons of commercial ships on Sept. 30, according to the quarterly report of Lloyd's Register of Shipping, which was published yesterday.

With the entire varsity backfield on the sidelines today because of physical reactions to the Pennsylvania game last Saturday, the Yale varsity and second elevens were sent through a long scrimmage in preparation for the Navy contest.
Monday was a bad day for the Lindbergh family at both ends of Europe. In the Moscow press Colonel Lindbergh

Informed sources said today that the United States would be asked to approve the appointment of Hjalmar Johan Procope as Finnish Minister to Washington, succeeding Eero Jarnefelt, who is to become Minister to Italy. Mr. Procope, 49 years old,

Back of the cottages at Edgemere on the salt meadows of Jamaica Bay lies a low tumulus that looks-and smells-suspiciously like the beginnings of the giant garbage mound at Flushing which it took a World's Fair to mow down.
Mrs. Elizabeth Penrose Averill of London, editor of British Vogue, today received a divorce from Lloyd B. Averill, World War flier and hotel man, on grounds of extreme cruelty and neglect to provide.

Mrs. Aimee Julian Thomas, wife of Harry F. Thomas, commercial vice president of the General Electric Supply Corporation, died yesterday morning in the J. H. Mathers Memorial Hospital, Port Jefferson, I. I. Born in Brooklyn, a daughter of James and Catherine F. Julian, she was married to Mr. Thomas in 1902.

If a couple of giddy Galitzianer had appeared a little earlier than 11 o'clock, "David and Esther," Louis Freiman and Ilia Trilling's "musical romance" of a blighted romance, which was presented at the downtown National Theatre last night, might have been a little less blighting entertainment.

Peter N. Peters of 528 Riverside dent Drive. filed suit yesterday in Supreme Court to ban the further operation of Claremont Inn at Riverside Drive and 124th Street on the ground that it was a public nuisance interfering with sleep and the peaceful enjoyment of their homes by residents of the surrounding area.

The bulk of the contracts for commercial space reported by brokers yesterday was for quarters in buildings on the West Side. Among those listed as having taken space was the Terminal Luggage Company which leased the store, basement and mezzanine at 366 Fifth Avenue, totaling 6,000 square feet, through the Charles Rosenthal Company.

Fordham is sparing no details preparing for its first major game against Purdue at the Polo Grounds Saturday. Coach Jimmy Crowley drove his charges through perhaps their longest and hardest drill on Fordham Field yesterday.

" My Son, My Son," over which there has been spirited bidding by several studios, was purchased today by Edward Small, who will release the picture through United Artists. It is reported that $50,000 was paid for the screen rights.

Premature speculative subdivisions of land not needed for new residential purposes seldom proves of benefit to the promoter or the purchaser, and "phantom communities," consisting of little more than idle acreage and weed-covered paths once intended for streets, stand as a warning here and there of the dangers in such schemes.
Steel ingot production last week increased more than seasonally, and the adjusted index advanced to 67.1 from 66.5. The figure was 94.3 for the week ended Oct. 2, 1937.

Army officers rehearsed on paper today the national set-up of a civilian-operated selective service act, and estimated that it would cost between $6,000,000 and $10,000,000 to mobilize 300,000 men in the first month of a war.

The sixty-ninth annual meeting of the Grand Chapter, Order of the Eastern Star of the State of New York, was opened yesterday with 3,000 delegates attending in the Hotel Astor. The order has 125,000 members in the State.
Mrs. Alice Adkins Johnson, wife of Douglas W. Johnson, Professor of Geology at Columbia, died last night in the Presbyterian Hospital after a long illness of cardiac complications.

The State Public Service Commission announced today approval of a $112,017,600 reorganization and refinancing program proposed by the Milwaukee Electric Railway and Light Company and affiliated concerns.

Miss Dorothy- Kaufmanni 20, of New York, a stenographer, told a jury in Federal court today that she was the one-woman faculty of the Civic Service Institute of St. Louis, which sold mail-order courses to persons hopeful of getting government jobs.

Senator Gerald P. Nye would be practically certain of re-election next month except for the $40-amonth minimum old-age pension plan which Governor William Langer at the eleventh hour decided to make his main issue in his independent candidacy after he lost to Senator Nye in the Republi. can primaries.

The Polish General Casimir Pulaski, if he were alive today," would be fighting for the democracies and against dictatorships, in the opinion of Stanley H. Howe, Mayor La Guardia's secretary, who addressed a Pulaski Day gathering in City Hall Park yesterday.

Prices of government bonds will stay up indefinitely, regardless of the standing of the government's credit, Alian M. Pope, investment banker, predicted today. The "stranglehold" that the Federal Government has on the money market makes certain its ability to hold up the prices of its bonds, he said.

The football Giants, preparing for Sunday's meeting with Philadelphia at the Polo Grounds, will work out there today, with Coach Steve Owen experimenting with several backfield combinations in an effort to arrive at the strongest quartet.

The final running of the national pheasant field trial championship was won today by Uncas Flying Devil, white and liver pointer owned by Harold E. Eyster of York, Pa. The runner-up was M. Fleischmann's Farmwood Yankee from New York, who two years ago beat the Pennsylvania entry in a test just as close as today's.
Colonel Sam Tate, manufacturer, banker, postmaster, churchman and philanthropist, died today in his home at Tate, near here. He was 78 years Engel old.

President Roosevelt declared tonight that the "real safeguard" of democracy is education. "Democracy cannot succeed unless those who express their choice are prepared to choose wisely," he said in an open letter, occasioned by the observance of American Education Week Nov. 6-12.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States in the week ended Oct. 6 was greater in two groups, fewer in two and unchanged in one, as compared with a year ago, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. Detailed comparisons are shown in the following table:

The 100-inch "eye" on the Carnegie Institution's Mount Wilson Observatory can see nearly half as far again as when it was installed in 1919. Then astronomers had to photograph the moon in quarter sections. Now they can do it all in one piece.
Reaffirmation of its policy on garment returns was announced yesterday by the vendors' relations committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

During the recent crisis the north Swedish mines worked night and day rushing supplies to ports. Fiftycar trains left every hour from Kiruna and Gellivara carrying ore. Miners earned 100 kroner a day.

One of the largest spots ever to be seen on the sun was reported today by Dr. J. Allen Hynek of Perkins Observatory of Ohio Wesleyan and Ohio State Universities. Dr. Hynek said it was roughly 130,000 miles long and 35,000 miles wide.

Under a continuation of the recent buying movement by domestic a and foreign interests, prices on the Cotton Exchange here advanced as much as 50 cents a bale for a time yesterday, going into new high ground with quotations $3 a bale above last month's low records.

Thirteen - year - old Miss Hazel Franklin of London, who, in her own words, weighs "4 stone 7" (63 pounds), made her first appearance on American ice last night as the Skating Club of New York officially opened its 1938-39 season at Iceland, atop Madison Square Garden.

A banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co. Inc., submitted yesterday the highest bid for $7,900,000 City of Utica, N. Y., water revenue bonds, which were offered for sale by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

A move for the creation of Bishops in the United Lutheran Church in America was defeated almost unanimously today at the biennal convention of the church. Delegates attacked the proposal as a trend away from democracy and a "surrender" of the whole history of the church.

School officials renewed their fight today with John Marsh for refusing to have his 9-year-old son vaccinated. Judge Fred S. Reese granted to District Attorney J. Boyd Landis permission to present a petition asking that the boy, Eugene, be brought before the court to answer his failure to attend school.

John P. Fletman, a former Brooklyn patrolman, and Jack and Harry Polotnick, brothers, were convicted yesterday by a jury in Federal Court of obstructing justice and of conspiracy to intimidate witnesses who were expected to testify against them and other alleged members of a large liquor ring.
The invention in Sweden of a device designed to protect workers against silicosis has been called to the attention of the Department of Commerce by the commercial attache at Stockholm.
William E. Housel, president of the Housel Oil Corporation, testified yesterday at the Securities and Exchange Commission's hearing here on the affairs of the ReiterFoster Oil Corporation.

Jacob J. Rosenblum, Assistant District Attorney, head of the Homicide Bureau, announced yesterday that he would make a motion on Friday before General Sessions Judge George L. Donnellan for the drawing of a blue-ribbon panel of 250 talesmen from which a jury could be chosen for the trial of Robert Irwin, accused of firstdegree murder in the Gedeon slayings. He has been in jail awaiting trail for seventeen months.

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor will visit Aiken this Winter, according to unconfirmed reports here. The reports are that the home of Edmund P. Rogers, brother of Herman L. Rogers, a close friend of the Duke, is being prepared for the informal visit of the couple.

In line with Martin Luther's cardinal doctrine of separation of church and State, the seventh triennial conference of the Evangelical Lutheran Synod, Atlantic District, adopted a resolution yesterday opposing passage of the proposed first amendment to the State Constitution opening the way toward allocation of public funds for transporting pupils to and from parochial schools in buses.

The Lincoln-Zephyr V-12 automobiles for 1939 were displayed yesterday at a preview to automobile editors and fashion writers of newspapers and magazines at the Ford Motor Company's showrooms, 1,710 Broadway.

Vandam St, 25, 20.1x100.1; 80-82 Carmine St Corp to Spring Street Church, 246 Spring St; p m, 10 years, 41 per cent; $8,250. Fort Charles Pi, 25-27, 56.4x100.10 Irreg: May J. MacKenna and Sibelle Cummings both at 27 Ft Charles PI, to Railroad Federal Savings Loan Assoc, 441 Lexington Ave: equal lien with three mtgs aggregating $5,427; install 6 per cent; $2,500.

Mrs. Landon Parker gave a dinner last night at Larue for her niece, Miss Caroline Sawyer, and Lieutenant Sam W. Agee Jr., U. S. A., whose marriage will take place at noon today in St. Bartholomew's Church.

Miss Janie Miller Averett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elliott Averett, and Sherman Vail Allen, whose engagement was announced on Sept. 30, have completed plans for their marriage, which will take place on Oct. 22 at Dixiedale Farm, the Averett home here, in the presence of relatives and a few friends.

The value of daily retail sales in August was 2.8 per cent greater than for August, 1937, according to statistics issued here today by the Bank of England. It was in August, 1933, that the advance in retail trade began. Last month's figures were about 28 per cent higher than those of five years ago.

Wesley Ferrell and Spurgeon Chandler, Yankee hurlers who went in for repairs upon their pitching arms with the close of the baseball season, were reported last night resting comfortably at St. Elizabeth's Hospital.
Characterizing the world as a "somewhat grim place," where gangster methods are used to settle international questions and where we are facing "our own Dark Ages," Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve,

Bonds followed an irregular course yesterday in slightly more active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Further profittaking was in evidence in some of the more speculative issues, sufficient to weaken the price structure as the main body of active bonds closed moderately lower on the day.

The election of Benjamin J. Buttenwieser as president of the Federation for the 'Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City was announced last night, together with the election of Percy S. Straus as chairman of the board of trustees and the naming of Henry Ittleson as associate chairman.
John Leonard Driscoll of this city celebrated the 101st anniversary of his birth today at his home, where his three daughters, the Misses Lizbeth, Caroline and Louise Driscoll reside with him.

The Metropolitan Opera Guild opened its season with a general meeting for members and friends yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Pierre. Mrs. August Belmont, chairman of the guild, presided, while Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association, was guest of honor.

The first Italian measure interfering with Jews' commercial activities was taken today when a circular was addressed by the Ministry of Corporations to all the prefects in the kingdom instructing them not to issue new licenses for opening shops or public establishments to Jews.
The radio English lessons given by the Department of Education's School of the Air have proved so popular with the pupils, ranging from actors to stenographers, that the course is being revised.

John Strachey was "excluded" from the United States by an Immigration Board of Inquiry yesterday at Ellis Island, and was held there without bail for the night. Cut off from visitors or telephone calls after governmental office hours, he settled down calmly to correct the proofs of his latest book, which is to come off the prsses here within a week or two.

Rockwell Kent, artist and writer, has filed with the New York Public Service Commission a complaint against the Delaware Hudson Railroad charging that the line discriminates against certain passengers in the matter of fare and that its Pullman cars are "antiquated and-non-air-conditioned," it became known yesterday.

President Federico Laredo Bru conferred the Carlos Manuel de Cespedes Order of Merit on several Cubans and foreigners in observance of the Oct. 10 holiday known as "Grito de Yara" [the "call of Yara," where a Cuban revolt against Spain broke out seventy years ago.]
The Cleveland Rams of the National Football League today released Johnny Giannoni, 215-pound end from St. Mary's College, California. Giannoni, a starter in the first
Tear gas was used by Trenton police tonight to disperse striking workers at the Joseph Stokes Rubber Com pany when pickets attempted to prevent two loaded trucks from leaving company grounds.

The appointment of James Moore of Buffalo as campaign manager for Thomas E. Dewey was announced at the Dewey headquarters, 11 East Forty-fourth Street, last night. Mr. Moore, a former Assistant United States Attorney in Buffalo,

Catholic charity leaders today advocated support of the national health program, vocational training and indulgence and correction for mistakes of the Federal welfare program and planned a larger and coordinated program for prison work.

The Pelham National Bank Building housing the Pelham branch of the postoffice, adjoining the New York -Central Railroad station at Pelham, Westchester County, was sold by Edward Loughman, receiver, to a client of John J. Reynolds, broker.

When the Legislature reconvenes Monday night for the specific purpose of considering unemployment relief financing, Director Arthur Mudd of the State Financial Assistance Commission will report that New Jersey's 1938 relief costs will total nearly $24,000,000, or about $10,000,000 more than the fund set up by the Legislature at its regular session last Spring.

Residents of the Fieldston section of the Bronx won their application for restrictive one-family home zoning yesterday when the City Planning Commission approved designation of the area as a "G" zone. The matter now goes to the Board of Estimate for final action.

The town of Brigue, Switzerland, has awarded its highest distinction, "honor citizenship" to its most distinguished son, Dr. Ernest Guglielminetti, the country doctor who invented the modern tarred road to save men from automobile dust.

As a preliminary to the opening of the espionage trial Friday, attorneys for Johanna Hofmann sought yesterday before Federal Judge John C. Knox to obtain a bill of particulars of the evidence against her and to suppress evidence she contends was obtained illegally.
Both major parties filed, shortly before last midnight, petitions nominating their State-wide tickets under separate names to insure themselves additional places on the ballot.

Despite international efforts, so far no concrete results have been achieved toward improving the position of German democratic and Jewish refugees from the Sudeten areas, who are threatened, under pressure from Berlin, with being handed over by Czechoslovakia to the German forces occupying the Sudeten areas.

The Joint Council of locals affiliated with the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. organization, met yesterday at the union's office, 153 West Sixty-fourth Street, and after approving the stand of the executive board rejecting the proposal of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company for a 10 per cent wage cut upon the expiration of the present contract ordered "mobilization" of all union forces for a determined resistance to any wage decreases.

Trade association executives were urged yesterday to discuss the basic problems of their industries in answering the questionnaire recently sent out to them, by Calvert Judkins, in charge of trade associations for the Department of Commerce, addressing members of the Trade and Commerce Bar Association at a luncheon at the Lawyers Club, 115 Broadway.

Short interest in stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange continued downward in September, according to a compilation made public yesterday. The total on Sept. 30 was 588,345 shares, compared with 729,480 on Aug. 31.

The Postal Bondholders Advisory Group sent yesterday a notice to independent holders of Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation 5 per cent bonds requesting that holders of these obligations refrain from depositing their securities under the plan of reorganization.
The Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission rejected finally late today the second revised plan to merge the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company and its underliers in one $100,000,000 corporation.
The stock market here was depressed today, most sections losing ground and nervousness again taking the shape of heavy bidding for dollars and gold.

Gulping down great helpings of ice cream, Shiver 2d, a small wirehaired terrier, took the honors yesterday afternoon at an eating contest for dogs at the Kips Bay Boys Club, 301 East Fifty-second Street.

Almost completely recovered from a three-month illness that reached a critical stage a month ago, Samuel Untermyer, noted lawyer, is able to get around the grounds of his country home, Greystone, in Yonkers, and today announced that a flower show with 90,000 chrysanthemums would be given on his estate for three days starting Oct. 26.

A test program which may become a nationwide "radio voice for distribution" at an aggregate cost of close to $1,000,000, was "piped" yesterday for private audition to 108 radio stations throughout the country by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Chester Howe, investigator for the Dies committee, now sitting in Detroit, asserted today that he would show that sitdown strikes originated in Michigan and were instigated by well-known Communist agitators, at a cost of hundreds of thousands of dollars to taxpayers.

A Sharp earth tremor jarred Sioux Falls early this morning but caused no damage. Residents reported a "rumble like thunder" from the heavy initial shock, which was followed by a series of lighter motions. Estimates of the duration of the shock ranged from ten to twenty seconds.
In a field of sixteen starters Johnny Nicholas of Shore View captured the low gross prize in the one-day tournament of the Long Island Golf Association on the Bayside links yesterday.

Seeking revenge for the 14--0 setback suffered last year, Boston College tonight ruled a slight favorite to turn the tables on Detroit University tomorrow in an intersectional game that is expected to draw 25,000 spectators to Fenway Park.
Edward Lund, engineer on the Howard Hughes round-the-world flight last Summer, last Saturday married Miss Eleanor Hoagland of 991 East Forty-third Street, Brooklyn.
The foreign-exchange market continued yesterday to decline and the engagement of gold abroad for shipment here once more became profitable on an arbitrage basis.

Mrs. J. J. Lese of Quaker Ridge bettered women's par by-one stroke when she carded 36, 42-78 to win low-gross honors in the last oneday tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association over the Washington Irving Country Club course today.

The twelve-story Wellwyn apartment house at 256-60 West Seventysecond Street, has been sold in a deal in which the seller took as part payment nine dwelling properties in San Antonio, Corpus Christi and McAllen. Texas.

Ivan M. Maisky, Soviet Ambassador to Great Britain, entered an angry protest today to a statement made yesterday by Earl Winterton, Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster and as such a member of the British Ministry.
The Commerce Department's report on total gold shipments during September, from foreign countries to the United States, goes far toward making a distinctive chapter of financial history.

The threatened strike of 2,000 men employed on 300 towboats in the harbor was averted, at least temporarily, yesterday, when representatives of the New York Towboat Exchange and Local 333 of the International Longshoremen's Association met at the office of the employers' organization,

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edmund L. Warner of Malvern, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mildred Elizabeth Warner, to Claude Swanson Nunn, son of Mrs. William Riley Nunn of Farmville, Va., and the late Mr. Nunn.

A truck blockade cut off supplies to some WPA projects here today, causing 6,000 of Akron's 21,000 WPA workers to be idle. The dispute arose over a competitive bidding system set up in Ohio by Dr. Carl Watson, State administrator.
Two college students, who had clung lost and bewildered to a damp underground ledge since Sunday night, were rescued from a cave today by two young Arbuckle mountaineers.

Dr. and Mrs. Percy Carey Spengeman of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Carol Spengeman, to Gordon Wanser Buckalew, son of Mr. and Mrs. Farmer Wanser Buckalew, also of Upper Montclair.

Governor Lehman told a group of his party workers yesterday that there was only one issue in the State campaign and that was "Do the people of the State of New York want to maintain in office a government that is clean, honest, humane, progressive and' efficient?"

Mrs. Ruth Gaynor Rennard of Hempstead, youngest daughter of the late William J. Gaynor, former Mayor of New York, and of the late Mrs. Gaynor, was married here this afternoon in the Community Church to Dudley Gautier Bird, also of Hempstead.

Coupons maturing Oct. 15, 1938, of American tranche of the Dawes loan, German external loan of 1924, stamped "USA Domicile Oct. 1, 1935," will be purchased in the same manner as those of the same tranche which matured April 15, 1938, according to an official statement issued yesterday by the German Consulate General.

President Roosevelt opened his press conference this afternoon by expressing his happiness over the termination of the Chaco dispute between Bolivia and Paraguay through the arbitral award made in Buenos Aires yesterday.
Budapest newspapers said today that several hundred Jews had been rounded up by the police in Eastern Hungary and sent to a concentration camp at Nagy Kanizsa.

To a proposal yesterday by John L. Lewis that he and William Green resign as C. I. 0. chairman and A. F. of L. president, respectively, to help toward labor peace, Mr. Green retorted at Houston that the A. F. of L. convention's election Friday would answer Lewis; he accused Lewis of deception. [Page 1.]

A $20,000 bequest from the estate of Mrs. Edith Greenough Wendell, Boston social leader, will "preserve the historic Jacob Wendell and Tibbetts houses" in Portsmouth, N. H., under terms of her will, filed in the Suffolk Probate Court.

So much of Paragraph 1, Special Orders 95 as reads 1st Lt. James L. Jimison, Vet Res.. is amended to read 1st Lt. Rober L. Jimison, Vet-Res. Capt. Franklin H. Berry, Inf-Res, 28-31 Main St., Toms River, N. J., is reliever from assignment to the 309th Infantr and is assigned to Headquarters 78th Division.

L. F. Loree, president of the Delaware Hudson Company until early this year, was the highest paid railroad executive in the East, a statement to the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed yesterday.
John Joseph Booth, president of the local Board of Education since 1921 and a well-known figure in the hat industry, died of pneumonia last night in his home here. His age was 72.

Advances made in the protection of lives and property at sea were outlined here today by Commander R. S. Field, director of the Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation of the Department of Commerce.

The Court of Appeals ruled against Time, Inc., today in passing on its motion for reargument of an appeal from a decision granting to Curtis B. Dall, former son-in-law of President Roosevelt, a new trial of his suit over an article in Time magazine of April 23, 1934.
Twelfth semi-annual model sail and motor boat regatta sponsored by the Department of Parks in cooperation with R . H. Macy Co., Conservatory Lake, Central Park, 9:30 A. M.
In a determined effort to make a real champion team out of the Chicago Cubs, Owner Philip K. Wrigley today revealed a six-point program for the rebuilding of his club.

Alfred Durr Cooper does not intend to resign his Conservative seat in the House of Commons or stand down at the next general election as a result of his resignation as First Lord of the Admiralty over his differences with Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's foreign policy, it was learned tonight.

Improvement of France's commercial trade balance with foreign nations and less encouraging business prospects in Italy were outstanding features of the week's business developments abroad as reported today by the Department of Commerce, the announcement being based on radio and cable advices from its agents in the field. The summary follows:

Mrs. Martha Litchford Corbett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Evans Litchford of Pineridge Farm, Raleigh, N. C., and widow of Henry M. Corbett of Toledo, Ohio, was married yesterday morning in the chantry of St. Thomas Church to Thomas Palmer Jerman of Chicago, formerly of this city.

The Ministry of Justice announced today that Baron Gottfried von Cramm, Germany's leading tennis player, would be released on parole on Sunday, with suspension for two years of the remainder of his one-year prison sentence.

Henry Ford, individualistic automobile manufacturer who has stanchly resisted unionization of his company, shook hands today with Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, which claims a membership of 400,000 in the industry.

Judge Robert E. Lamberton in Common Pleas Court ruled today that a large part of trusts aggregating $36,000,000 left by Dr. John T. Dorrance, head of the Campbell Soup Company, were subject to the one-mill Pennsylvania personal property tax. He held that the State was entitled to $27,256.
An agreement was reached today on a draft of a convention between the United States and Sweden for the avoidance of double taxation

The possibility of a visit by King George and Queen Elizabeth to the United States after their Canadian tour is not ruled out in court circles, where it is thought that a visit to Washington and to New York's World's Fair may be arranged.
The discovery of America was a tragedy of errors. In the first place, America had already been discovered, though the discoverers neither sought nor obtained much publicity. In the second place,

Vice-Admiral Kenji Maebara, retired commander of the Japanese fleet and former chief of the air force, announced tonight that his country wants to borrow up to $45,000,000 to establish an aviation corporation in Mukden, Manchukuo,

Word was received here yesterday from Detroit that shipments of the 1939 De Soto cars were on their way to 3,000 dealers in all parts of the country. Bodies in the new cars are four and a half inches wider across the front compartment than in the 1938 model.
The six-story dwelling at 1,008 Fifth Avenue, purchased last Spring by the National Association of Audubon Societies, will be opened as the new home of that organization on Oct. 24.
Government armies were reported to be driving quickly down the slopes of the Pandos Mountains tonight, pushing Insurgent battle lines back toward Gandesa in heavy fighting.

As part of the program for modernizing the Metropolitan Museum of Art, a new glass roof costing about $200,000 will be installed, according to plans filed yesterday for the Department of Parks by Aymar Embury 2d. architect.

Buyers registered in the market yesterday totaled 606, the highest daily total since July 19 when 692 were reported, and comparing with 313 recorded on Tuesday of last week, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

In order to regain the proportion of advertising they enjoyed in 1929, newspapers must improve their medium, the Newsprint Association of Canada has recommended in a special study "Business Trends of United States Newspapers" just released. Raising of advertising rates to cover the increased operating expenses was considered "a doubtful expedient."

Under the title "The American Theatre" John Anderson, New York dramatic critic, has written a history of the American stage from Colonial days to O'Neill, Odets and the Lunts. In addition to the material on the theatre, there will be a section written by Rene FiulopMiller devoted to the growth of moving pictures. Dial Press will publish the book on Nov. 14.
W. L. Brann's Aethelwold, winner of a maiden race in his previous start, mildly surprised today by winning a photo decision from W. M. Jeffords's Jolly Tar, an odds-on favorite in the Crumpton Purse.
An expression from Secretary of War Woodring today in favor of international outlawryy of the plane as an instrument 'of war" revived speculation about the possibility of a disarmament conference.

It is as difficult to imagine that Colonel Lindbergh made the public aspersons on the Soviet air force attribute to him by the Moscow press as it is to assume that the French and British Governments relied on an American observer to inform them of the comparative strength of German and Russian military aviation.
Within the last two weeks a member of the President's Cabinet intimated that complete State socialism might be necessary in his department of the government.
A squad of Montreal women golfers defeated five members of the British Curtis Cup team, 3-2, today in an exhibition match over the Royal Montreal course.

Harry Hopman of Australia won the men's singles championship at the Pacific Coast tennis tournament today in a battle with Jack Tidball of Los Angeles that lasted more than two hours. The score was 5--7, 6--2, 7--5, 8--6.

The Squibb Institute for Medical Research, founded by E. R. Squibb Sons to carry on pure research in the biological and medical sciences, was dedicated here today in the presence of 1,200 scientists from all parts of the country.

Consideration of the report on allied memberships by the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange has been scheduled for the next regular meeting on Oct. 26. The board received the report yesterday but took no action on it.

More than 400 women heard representative candidates of the Democratic, Republican and American Labor parties expound party principles and plead for votes last night at a Carnegie Hall meeting sponscored by six of the leading women's organizations of the city and State.

Application of the New York Stock Exchange to strike from listing and registration the no-par value common stock of the Advance-Rumeley Corporation was granted -today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, effective at the close of trading on Oct. 18.

Captain Ben Pine's challenger for the International Fishermen's Trophy, the Gloucester schooner Gertrude L. Thebaud, and Captain Angus Walters' Bluenose, the defender from Lunenburg, N. S., fought a losing battle today against time.

In his new play, "When We Are Married," which opened at the St. Martin's Theatre tonight, J. B. Priestley relaxes from his time theories into a "farcical comedy"--but keeps an experienced hand on his new mood and makes his Yorkshire characters of 1908 so true to life that critics are tempted to deny the farcical label.

Registration throughout the city continued yesterday to lag substantially behind last year's as 285,954 persons registered on the second day for the qualifying of voters for the November elections. In the two days 525,740 indicated their intention of voting.

A pastoral letter by Theodor Cardinal Innitzer that was read in all Vienna churches last Sunday was issued today in pamphlet form under the title "A Word to Catholic Parents." Its. publication, part of the Catholic campaign against the Nazi non-religious education law, has infuriated the Vienna Nazis.

Fred Lazarus Jr., vice president of F. R. Lazarus Co., and chairman of a special committee of store principals, presented a special report on organization and expense reduction at today's sessions of the board of directors' meeting of the Retail Research Association and the Associated - Merchandising Corporation here.

Peter Schmauss, 70 years old, an artist, was found dead yesterday suspended by a leather belt from a portiere rod in his five-room apart. ment at: 207 East Ninety-fourth Street. He left a note which began: "I wil not go on home relief or apply for old-age assistance."

The registration statement filed recently under the Securities Act of 1933 by the General Electric Employes Securities Corporation, covering $50, 000,000 of 4 per cent debenture voting bonds to mature serially from 1951 to 1959,
Reductions of prices for crude oil ranging from 15 to 20 cents a barrel were made yesterday by leading purchasing companies throughout Texas, Oklahoma, Kansas and New Mexico.

Dr. Wesley A. Sturges, Yale law, professor and an authority on credit transactions, debtor estates and commercial arbitration, was named. yesterday to succeed the late W. Forbes Morgan as executive head of the Distilled Spirits Institute. Dr. Sturges's appointment, by unanimous vote of the institute's board, meeting in the Hotel WaldorfAstoria, ended an eighteen months' search by the distillers for a sucesxsor to Mr. Morgan.

The following members having been tried before Francis X. Giaccone, Deputy Fire Commissioner, on Sept. 15, 1938, for violation of rules and regulations. 1937, the following decisions are rendered by the Fire Chief and Commissioner:

The address of senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Democrat of Wyoming, to the New York Board of Trade at the Hotel Astor yesterday follows: In the few months which have elapsed since the creation by Congress of the Temporary National Economic Committee,
A means of liquidating the estimated $4,000,000 debt owed brewers and wholesale liquor dealers by thousands of cafe and restaurant
