President Roosevelt declined today to pledge his support of all Democratic candidates in the November elections and indicated that Postmaster General Farley had done so only in his capacity as chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

A $161,000 mortgage at 4 per cent for five years on the fifteen-story apartment house at 345 W 86th St has been arranged for Gail Properties, Inc. owner, by Ivor B. Clark, Inc. broker. The North River Savings Bank is the mortgagee.

A Foreign Office spokesman said today that the Brazilian Ambassador to Berlin, Dr. Jose Joachim de Lima e Silva Monitz de Aragoa, had been transferred to the Foreign Ministry and would return from Berlin soon.

Voters of the State are to choose between Governor Lehman, an unwilling candidate, and District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, who wants to be Governor, Arthur V. McDermott, Republican candidate for Attorney General, said yesterday afternoon.

George Hiram Mann, a zealot who has fought a one-man campaign, in season and out for thirty years for "back pay for unpaid navy yard workers," was in police court yesterday, a victim of his cause. Magistrate Frank Oliver in West Side Court found him guilty of disorderly conduct, suspended sentence, and thanked him for "a laugh I needed today."

President Roosevelt announced today that present naval building plans would necessitate an increase of $150,000,000 in expenditures for war craft during the fiscal year beginning July l, and indicated that a similar increase in outlays for the military establishment might be expected.

Challenging views that retail mark-ups are too high, Lew Hahn, general manager of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said yesterday that a reduction in distribution costs parallel to. those of mass production will never be seen, because retail selling is and will remain an individual process. He spoke at the meeting of the Sales Executives Club at the Hotel Roosevelt.

John P. Ford, a retired inspector of grading and paving in the corporation division of the Brooklyn Borough President's office and in the service of the city for forty-six years, died in his home, 560 Dean Street, Brooklyn on Sunday. Mr.

No kosher kill in local markets yesterday on account of Jewish holiday, second day Succoth. General trading slow on all traefer classes. Hinds and ribs market steady to strong on choice and prime, others fully steady; demand for choice and prime good, others slow. Other classes mostly steady. Demand slow. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

The Academy of Allied Arts will hold its annual auditions for partial and complete scholarships in voice, piano, violin and 'cello on Saturday from 1 to 6 P. M. Dr. Duncan B. MacDonald Emrich, instructor in English and Comparative Literature at Columbia University, has been appointed to the faculty of the Juilliard Graduate School of Music, where he will hold classes in English literature.

Declaring that American imports will hold preference over all others in allotting exchange, the Bank of Brazil issued instructions today in what was purported to be an action putting into full execution a clause in the Brazil-American trade treaty.

Following a lay-off since last Winter and prepped by one race, Arnold Hanger's He Did yesterday captured the Interborough Handicap before 15,000 persons, the largest crowd of the Jamaica meeting. Evidently the 5-year-old son of Victorian was due for a keen effort, because the Hanger colorbearer went to the post at 9 to 2 and scored by half a length.
Tonight Gilbert Miller brings into the Guild Theatre "I Have Been Here Before," the play in which J. B. Priestley speculates on the possibility that people repeat their lives in future cycles.

Sydney Wooderson's half-mile mark of 1:49.2, made here Aug. 8, today was accepted as an English native record by the general committee of the British A. A. A. This ratification assures the time being submitted to the I. A. A. F. as a new world standard.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 11: COLONELS Denton. W., Med. Corps. excepted from provisions of act requiring duty with one or more combatant arms of army while on duty at Army Medical Center, Washington, D. C.

The Real Estate Board of New York yesterday announced the adedition of sixty-seven memberships to its roll, following approval by the board of governors. Eugene J. Busher, chairman of the admissions committee, said that at least one special meeting of that committee, in addition to its regular sessions, would have to be held prior to the October meeting of the governors, to pass on a large number of additional applications.

Anna, hairdresser, in 375 Park Ave; Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers. Samuel Cook, ladies' hats, loft in 31 W 46th St: Cyrille Carreau, Inc, broker. Advertisers Printing Service, store in 23 E 125th St; Porter Co, Real Estate, Inc, brokers.

Alexander Hamilton High's strong eleven scored its second straight triumph yesterday when it downed Thomas Jefferson High, 7--0, at Commercial Field, Brooklyn. A gathering of 10,000 packed the stands to watch the contest, which was roughly played throughout.

Joe Marsiglia was at his old right halfback post yesterday as Coach Benny Friedman put the City College football team through a long workout at Lewisohn Stadium in preparation for the invasion Saturday of the Clarkson Tech eleven, and at the conclusion of the drill the mentor indicated that the veteran would be in the starting line-up Saturday for the first time this season.

It has never been made clear what has become of the gold reserve of 420,000,000 Austrian schillings shown by Austrian National Bank statements to have been possessed by the bank when Austria was annexed last March.

A first mortgage of $325.000 has been secured for the Anru Realty Corporation, Gustave Halpern, president, on the recently completed six-story apartment on the southwest corner of Grand Concourse and 178th Street, the Bronx, by Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., brokers. The loan runs for ten years with interest at 4 1/2 per cent

Grand Duke Cyril Vladimirovitch died today at the American Hospital here, leaving his claim to the vacant throne of the Russian czars to his 21-year-old son, Vladimir, now an undergraduate at London University.
Cornell's air attack will be launched against Syracuse if work in practice is any criterion. Whit Baker, junior halfback, was tossing them with abandon tonight and was finding his targets.

The Weather Bureau ordered northeast storm warnings hoisted today from Pensacola, Fla., to Port Arthur, Texas, as a disturbance described as of moderate intensity was reported forming in the middle of the Gulf of Mexico.

There are two First Voters Leagues and in Supreme Court today Justice Lloyd Church will have to decide whether one or both are entitled to the use of the name. First Voters League, Inc., of 565 Fifth Avenue, is affiliated with the Republican organization and. incorporated in this State.

The Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company has applied to the Public Service Commission for authority to float a $5,000,000 bond issue to expand and improve present services, the Department of Commerce reported today.

The Japanese Foreign Office warned the principal powers yesterday to prevent Chinese troops from using foreign property in South China for defenses and to avoid troop or ship movements in South China that might cause clashes with Japanese.

All is in readiness for the opening tomorrow evening of the 1938 Carnegie International. After the Founder's Day exercises in the Carnegie Music Hall a preview of the exhibition will be held in the Carnegie Institute Galleries, and beginning Friday the public may visit the show, which continues until Dec. 4.
The Government of Ecuador formally requested -President Roosevelt today to intervene "in a friendly manner" in the boundary dispute between that country and Peru.

Decaring that there are "dozens of bright spots in the American picture," Floyd W. Parsons of New York, editorial director of Gas Age, said today that any substantial extension of sales volumes this Fall would have an "electrifying" effect on comparisons of profits.

Dr. Frantisek Chvaikovsky, the new Czechoslovak Foreign Minister, will arrive in Berlin tomorrow to visit Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop and discuss with him all questions pending between Germany and Czechoslovakia.

Mr. and Mrs. Albert Spalding gave a dinner tonight at Aston Magna, Great Barrington, in honor of their house guest, Miss Marion H. Beckett of Rye, N. Y. Others present were Miss M. Symphorosa Bristed, Stephanus Van Cortlandt Morris and Winthrop M. Crane 3d.

Crown Princess Juliana is still ill with influenza contracted five weeks ago at Amsterdam on the occasion of Queen Wilhelmina's jubilee. According to an official bulletin today she is progressing well but recovery has been delayed by a slight attack of jaundice.
Promoter Mike Jacobs agreed today to stage a heavyweight chainpionship fight at the Golden Gate International Exposition in the middle of San Francisco Bay next April-if his terms should be met.

The death toll from forest fires in the Rainy River area of Ontario rose to twenty today. As volunteers concentrated their forces in an effort to keep the blaze from spreading to Clearwater Lake, in the heart of the tourist and hunting area, four more persons were found dead, in addition to sixteen yesterday.

The Eastern Greene County Home Protection League, organized last night by farmers, began a fight here today against a $1,000,000 Federal project for buying up thousands of Southwestern Indiana hill farms and turning the land into forest and pasture.

Twenty-five years ago today, braving a forty-three-mile wind, five aviators completed the circuit of Manhattan Island in THE NEW YORK TIMES Aerial Derby, a sixty-mile course which the winner, William S. Luckey, covered in his 100-horsepower Curtiss biplane in what was hailed as the phenomenal time of 52 minutes 54 seconds.
An investing client of Seymour M. Tannenbaum, attorney, purchased from the Prudential Insurance Company of America the four-story apartment house at 1 Park Avenue, Tuckahoe, Westchester.

Tom Lipscomb, president of the Cleveland Rams, asked officials of the National Football League today to revoke the franchise of the Pittsburgh Pirates for canceling the Ram-Pirate game scheduled in Pittsburgh next Sunday.

Their own independent banking system is the next step for the cooperatives, Dr. James P. Warbasse, president of the Cooperative League of the United States, told delegates here today at the opening session of the Eleventh Biennial Congress of the league.
Every one knows that a war in Europe in the last few weeks was averted by making certain concessions at the Munich four-power conference to methods far from Christian, the Right Rev. Henry St.

A picture of huge airliners carrying a hundred passengers across the Atlantic in fifteen to eighteen hours within the next ten years was painted today by Igor Sikorsky, Russian-American aircraft constructor, in a paper read at the annual meeting of the Lilienthal Society for Aviation Research.

Electric-power production last week showed a larger increase than was anticipated on the basis of normal trends, and the adjusted index advanced to 93.3 from 93.2 (revised). The figure was 104.1 for the week ended Oct. 9, 1937.

The vision and courage of Christopher Columbus inspired a score of speakers, including Governor Herbert H. Lehman and District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, to plead yesterday for a continuance of the ideals that have marked America since the Genoese -navigator discovered the New World 446 years ago.

As Japanese troops began operations near British Hong Kong, London revealed yesterday it had reminded Tokyo that any damage to British interests in South 'China would jeopardize Anglo-Japanese relations.

While Housing officials of Federal, State and municipal agencies deliberated today on the problems of administering the present Federal Housing Program, a call for the program's expansion was made before the annual meeting of the National Association of Housing Officials by heads of housing bodies within the Committee for Industrial Organization.

Burial rackets are flourishing in many communities throughout the nation, particularly in Southern States, bringing tragic distress to many bereaved families and some undeserved disrepute to the respectable elements within the funeral industry, it was emphasized yesterday by the president of the National Funeral Directors Association.

New England industries are functioning on a normal basis despite the damage resulting from the recent hurricane and flood, R. W. Sulloway, chairman of the New England Council's Industrial Committee, reported today following a survey of manufacturing establishments, industries and manufacturers' associations in the six New England States.

Investments from the United States in foreign countries at the end of 1937 were $4,759,000,000 in excess of foreign investments in the United States, according to a report of the Department of Commerce of a study of international payments for 1937 which was made public today.

Expansion and liberalization of the old-age insurance provisions of the Social Security Act were urged today as the best alternative for "utopian schemes" for security by the retiring president of the National Conference of Catholic Charities, the Right Rev. Mgr. Thomas J. O'Dwyer of Los Angeles.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It seems to me that a few words should be added to one of the very sound remarks in Edmund K. Goldsborough's letter. He speaks of the political insanity of destroying surplus cotton and foodstuffs on one side of the fence, while people on the other side are forced to go hungry and half-clad.

Widespread buying of Spring lines of cotton and rayon piece goods has developed this week, and the largest number of wholesale buyers in several months have been in the market, converters said yesterday. The wholesalers have bought in small quantities, although taking a wide range of constructions.

The Medfield School Committee tonight announced the discharge of a teacher because, the committeemen said in a statement, the young woman "acknowledged" participating in a Boston demonstration against the four-power settlement at Munich of the CzechoslovakSudeten problem.

The appointment of -Roger W. Straus as New York City campaign manager for Thomas E. Dewey and G Speaker Oswald D. Heck as up- ic State campaign manager was announced yesterday at campaign headquarters at 11 East Fortyfourth Street.

The Federal Land Banks will call for payment on Nov. 1 about $14,000,000 of individual 4 1/2 per cent farm loan bonds dated Nov. 1, 1928, the Farm Credit Administration announced today. The bonds, callable in ten

A group of seven motions made by the protective committee for holders of the first mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds of the Rock Island, Arkansas Louisiana Railroad was overruled with one exception today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
One immediate effect of today's Japanese gains was a further decline in the value of the- Chinese dollar.
New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street. "The United States and Canada," Hans Simons, 11 A. M.; "Life and Health in New York City," Dr. John L. Rice, 8:20 P. M.

Nine days after Wilkes-Barre's four newspapers had suspended in a strike called by the Newspaper Guild, the way appeared open tonight for a resumption of negotiations and collective bargaining between the newspaper owners and Guild representatives.
Columbus Day brought no let-up in Coach Jimmy Crowley's efforts to get the Fordham football team ready for the clash with Purdue at the Polo Grounds Saturday.
THE DUKE'S CHILDREN, by Anthony Trollope. (Oxford University Press, 2 vols., $1.60.) An edition in the World's Classics Series of the last of Trollope's political novels.

The doughnut crown of the downtown branch of the Boys Club, Tenth Street and Avenue A, was won yesterday afternoon by Alex Fiore, a 9-year-old interloper from the club's uptown branch at 321 East 111th Street.
Leo Ernest Durocher, up to last Summer still the ranking shortstop in the National League and known far and wide as Lippy Leo, is the new manager of the Brooklyn Dodgers.

A Japanese force estimated at more than 30,000 men is continuing the landing of men and munitions for its march westward from Bias Bay, only twenty miles from Hong Kong, toward the vital CantonKowloon railway.
Buildings in Chinatown, Greenwhich Village and other sections of lower Manhattan figured in the sales of realty reported yesterday, in which banking institutions were principals.

The Railroad Credit Corporation has filed with a Federal District Court in Ohio objections to the plan of reorganization approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission for the Akron, Canton Youngstown Railroad, it was learned today.

Thomas Craven, art critic and writer, arriving here today for a lecture, took a verbal slap at the artistic features of the New York World's Fair. "They don't want art," he said. "All they want is symbolic claptrap.

The marriage of Miss Olive Ann Pearsall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. C. Pearsall of the Anchorage, West Islip, to George Robert Aitken; son of Mrs. Samuel R. Aitken of East Orange, N. J., and the late Mr. Aitken, took place here this morning in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.
Upsala College beat Panzer, 33-0, for the fourth consecutive time in their five-year series at Ashland Stadium today. It was Upsala's second victory of the season and Panzer's second defeat.

Because of the holiday yesterday, Coach Mal Stevens had the rare opportunity of having nearly all of his players on Ohio Field at one time, and as a result sent the N. Y. U. squad through an intensive fourhour workout. The eleven will hold

A 14-year-old boy who has never been outside the city limits and has never seen a cow won a gold medal yesterday for his ability as a farmer. The winner, Samuel Cohen of 547 Claremont Parkway, the Bronx, was one of 200 children who cultivated small vegetable plots in Crotona Park, the Bronx, in a Park Department contest.
Louis Kaufman has sold, through H. Frankfort Son, brokers, a brick residence on the corner of Broadway and Westover Lane, Lawrence, L. I., to Benjamin Wohlgemuth.

Many persons of prominence in society here, in Wilmington and New York, gathered at the dumb-bell course at Media in Rose Valley today for the inauguration of the Rose Tree Races conducted by the Rose Tree Fox Hunting Club, one of the oldest organizations of its kind in the country. This is the seventy-ninth

Iris Tash, 11 years old, of 338 Dahill Road, and John Dangaard, 12, of 845 McDonald Avenue, both Brooklyn, have been selected by the recreation division of the Park Department to represent the children of the borough at ceremonies on Saturday in the Music Grove of Prospect Park at 2:30 P. M., when the city will accept officially a young elephant donated by the Abraham Straus department store.

Joseph Bauer, 93 years old, a Civil War veteran and State G. A. R commander , died early this morning in a hospital here. For many years he led the Memorial Day parade, this year in an automobile and with one foot in a cast.

Disgusted and resentful against Governor Lehman and District Attorney Dewey, whom they blame for the indifferent success of the first tri-party feminine political rally last night at Carnegie Hall, a group of the participants arrived here this morning for the convention of the State League of Women Voters.

Coach Lou Oshins devoted a threehour scrimmage yesterday to a search for replacements for firststring Brooklyn College players who may not see service in Saturday's game with Rensselaer Poly because of injuries.

Miss Sally Clark, sister-in-law of John Roosevelt, youngest son of the President, will give up her singing career to become the bride of George X. McLanahan of New York on Dec. 3, instead of Jan. 6, the date previously planned, her mother, Mrs. F. Haven Clark, announced today.

An attempt to put the American Federation of Labor on record as considering Roosevelt Administration policies tainted with socialism was sidetracked at the Houston convention when a resolution sponsored by Matthew Woll and John P. Frey aroused a storm of protest from the delegates. [Page 1]
Reorder activity in the garment markets this week has fallen substantially under expectations, due principally to the Indian Summer weather in many sections of the East. Trade associations in the
Despite the sweltering heat from a mid-Summer sun today, Coach Earl Blaik drove his Dartmouth football forces through a scrimmage against the jayvees, who were using Brown plays.

Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for Governor, criticized yesterday Governor Lehman and Thomas E. Dewey, his opponents, for appearing at what Mr. Thomas called "the fascist celebration of Columbus Day" in the morning in Columbus Circle.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today that the United States Government was giving careful attention to all phases of the Palestine question and that he might be in a position to make a statement in the near future.
John Strachey spent his second day on Ellis Island as an excluded alien Communist yesterday, completely cut off by Columbus Day.
The Buick division of-the General Motors Corporation, increasing production for the second time since new-model work began, has called another 1,200 men back to work.

Collections by the Treasury under the Social Security and Railroad Retirement Acts through Sept. 30 totaled about twice the amount the government has spent under these acts, according to the Treasury's monthly recapitulation made public today.

Supreme Court Justice Bergan denied today the application of H. C. Hopson, Frederick S. Burroughs, J. I. Mange and others to quash subpoenas issued by the Public Service Commission in a proposed investigation.

Holders of Kingdom of Belgium external loan thirty-year 7 per cent bonds, due on June 1, 1955, will be notified today by J. P. Morgan Co. and the Guaranty Trust Company, sinking fund administrators, that $465,000 of these bonds have been drawn by lot for redemption at 107 1/2 on Dec. 1. Of the bonds drawn $356,000, according to advices from the Belgian Government, are held by it.

Word having got about that Shakespeare is a great writer, Maurice Evans has set out to prove it by producing and acting the full text of "Hamlet." He and his associates raise the curtain at 6:30; excepting for a half-hour or so for snacking they kept it raised until 11:15, making the night joint-laborer with the day. As acted at the St.

The five-story private dwelling at 44 East Eighty-second Street has been leased, furnished, from Jasper Morgan by Francis Currie. Situated on a plot 17 by 100 feet, the house contains three terraces and a garage. Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., arranged the rental.
Barringer High School's eleven ran the flanks almost at will to score a 26to-0 victory over Weequahic at the Newark Schools Stadium this afternoon.

Warners announced today that Eddie Albert and Marie Wilson will be starred in- a screen version of "The Poor Nut," legitimate comedy success of the early Nineteen Twenties written by J. C. and Elliott Nugent. The play, produced as a silent picture by Ben Lyon, deals with the struggles of a studious young collegian to become an athlete. Albert, who created the role of Bing Edwards in "Brother Rat."

Standing before the monument erected in Paris to the memory of his father, King Leopold of the Belgians today launched an appeal to the world to conquer peace and assure it by a heroic effort to get rid of the economic causes of war.

Six contestants received injuries yesterday at the matinee and evening performances of the rodeo in Madison Square Garden. The most unusual mishap occurred near the close of the evening performance. No one was injured.

Pennsylvania farmers have shot more than 2,500 deer this year "in self-defense," Seth Gordon, State Game Commissioner, said today. He explained that while hunting regulations were as strict as elsewhere, the commission permits shooting deer that destroy crops.

Considerably stronger offensively than last year, Lawrenceville School's football forces seem capable of compiling a splendid record this Fall, even though the coaching staff, headed by Larry Tlihonen, prefers to reserve decision for the present concerning the squad's strength.

Distillers must share with the Federal and State governments the responsibility of eliminating abuses in the distribution of liquor if the march of prohibition in towns and States is to be checked, Captain W. S. Alexander, Federal Alcohol Administrator, warned yesterday in an address before distillers at a luncheon held in the Terrace Club at the New York World's Fair, prior to the dedication of the industry's Hall of Distillers.

The stock market here was dull again today and prices in most sections dropped. Gilt-edge issues led the way with further declines, while foreign bonds also lost ground, particularly German and Czechoslovak issues, which were about a point lower.

There can be no such thing as a perpetual emergency or perpetual relief, Edward F. Corsi, Republican candidate for the short-term United States Senatorship, told the Rochester Chamber of Commerce at a luncheon here today.

The visit of Walther Funk. German Minister of Economics, and the granting of a credit of 150,000,000 marks to Turkey so soon after the Czechoslovak crisis have together provoked some conjecture about Turkish policy.

A Japanese guild under the supervision of the Japanese Department of Commerce and Industry plans to enter upon a high degree of control over production and distribution of electric motors because of the restricted supplies of iron and copper, particularly the latter, the Commerce Department reported today.

Further advances in residential building work during September were indicated in a report issued yesterday by the F. W. Dodge Corporation covering contracts awarded during the month for dwelling accommodations of all kinds in the thirty-seven States east of the Rocky Mountains.

Cuba celebrated Columbus Day with official ceremonies and the suspension of industrial and commercial activities throughout the island today. The diplomats of the American nations placed wreaths on the Columbus statue at the City Hall.

The following film programs, to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools:

William T. Simpson, RepublicanAmerican Labor Party candidate for the City Court bench in Brooklyn, who has been attacked by his Democratic opponent, Jacob H. Livingston, and the American Federation of Labor Non-Partisan Committee for his alleged anti-labor record, defended his record as a legislator last night.

While Governor Lehman continued to study evidence bearing on alleged official corruption in Brooklyn, William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, began yesterday his own scrutiny of the bank accounts of members of the staff of District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn, which were furnished to him in response to 1,402 subpoenas issued last week to financial institutions throughout the city.
Secretary Wallace stated today that a gigantic program to "dump" surplus farm products into the hands of poor Americans at cut prices was taking shape in the Agriculture Department.

Under a sweltering sun John Rahkonen, representing the Fianish A. C. of New York, today came from behind to win the National A. A. U. 20,000meter walking championship at Franklin Park. His time was 1 hour 51 minutes and 57 seconds.

A second chance was all Fella Gintoff, Boston College's veteran place-kicking and passing ace, needed to boot the Eagles to a hard-earned 9-6 victory over the Detroit Titans today before a shirt-sleeved crowd of 25,000 at Fenway Park.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Coil of this city have sent out invitations for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Madeleine J. Coll, to Lieutenant William J. Cain Jr., U. S. A., son of former Judge and Mrs. Cain of Bayonne.

With the full damage wrought by the recent hurricane along the North Atlantic seacoast and the Charleston tornado just becoming apparent, Norman H. Davis, national chairman of the American Red Cross, declared yesterday that the organization would. seek $1,500,000 instead of the $500,000 originally solicited from the public for the relief of 20,000 families in the stricken areas.
The missing home-made coat worn by 17-year-old Mary Imelda Coyle when she was attacked and beaten to death Monday night was found under a maple tree near her houseboat home here this morning.
Three members of an army patrol were injured yesterday on the HebronJerusalem road when their truck overturned when the driver speeded up to get away from an ambush by snipers.

An exhortation to the Roman Catholics of the United States to meet the challenge to Christian doctrine and morality which is now issuing from a world beset by unrest and conflict, was contained in a special letter from Pope Pius XI, read here today at ceremonies marking the beginning of the Golden Jubilee Year of the Catholic University of America.

The Informazione Diplomatica, after praising Chancellor Adolf Hitler's Saarbruecken speech, again appeals for a four-power pact as the only safeguard of Europe's peace. The most heated champions of a preventive war against the dictatorships, it declares, should have realized by now that the risks are too great.

As armed troops encamp in the little town of Bethlehem, so long associated with the shattered dream of "peace on earth," and large reinforcements of British troops arrive to put an end to the prolonged reign of terror in the Holy Land, disquieting reports are heard of a new plan said to be considered in London for the solution of the conflict in Palestine.

Pat Dengis, 38-year-old airplane tool designer from Baltimore, captured top honors in the fourteenth annual Port Chester national marathon today by the unprecedented margin of a mile and a half. Repeating his victory of a year ago, Dengis covered the course, a new one, incidentally, in 2:42:29.2.
Earl Winterton, Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster and a member of the Chamberlain Government, hit back today at Ivan M. Maisky, Soviet Ambassador to Great Britain. Mr.

Italy, whose forces are being withdrawn from Spain's civil war, announced tonight that 2,657 Italian officers and men had been killed in the conflict "from the beginning of operations in Spain until Oct. 10," and that an additional 278 legionnaires had died from service causes.

Testimony that Mayor Wilson more than two years ago gave his sanction to the. opening of one of the city's largest gambling- houses was given today by Jerome H. Louchheim, a contractor, before a jury in Quarter Sessions Court.

Dr. John A. Harriss, originator of the traffic signal light system in this city, formerly a special deputy police commisisoner in charge of traffic, and an authority on street traffic problems, died Tuesday night of a heart attack in his home, 103 Riverside Drive. He was 63 years old.

Vincent J. Ferris, president of the Allied Printing Trades Council of Greater New York and Kings County chairman of the A. F. of L. Non-Partisan Committee, issued a statement yesterday praising seven Democratic State Senators, candidates for re-election, as having a "100 per cent record" in support of legislation sponsored by the New York State Federation of Labor.
Tenant rosters of many East Side buildings will be enlarged as the result of rentals reported by brokers and agents yesterday. Park Avenue and Beekman Place appeared most frequently in the lists.

FOR years now the name Lindbergh has been in the prints so often and under a series of such extraordinary circumstances that a good many plain people are bored by the very sight of it-almost as bored, no doubt, as the owners themselves are tired of having it appear.

With a freshening southwesterly breeze promised by the weather soothsayers, the two fastest fishing schooners afloat tomorrow will continue their battle for the sailing championship of the North Atlantic.

America's Wage Earners' Protective Tariff Conference, of which Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, is president, and other leading members of the federation are officials, has begun a campaign in opposition to the reciprocal tariff treaties.

Dr. and Mrs. Morris Joseph of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Grace Joseph, to Willard Parker Brown Jr., son of Mrs. M. Poor Brown of this place and Willard P. Brown of Great Neck, L. I.

George M. Harrison, chairtman of the Railway Labor Executives Association, asserted before the President's Railway Wage Fact-Finding Commission today that if the railroads carried into effect their decision to cut wages 15 per cent, it would mean "economic suicide" so far as the railroads- were- concerned, and might be the beginning of a general wage-cutting campaign involving other great industries.

Reports last Saturday of a plot to overthrow the Siamese Government were called "sheer nonsense" today by Police Commissioner Luang Adulej. "There has been no plot and no arrests were made or are contemplated," he said.
Cardinal Verdier, Archbishop of Paris, announced today that at all masses in Paris Sunday a collection would be taken up for the relief of Czechoslovak refugees.
Activities in Real Estate

A new ray detecting device, more efficient sound locators and improved guns of various calibers are among the new anti-aircraft implements with which ground troops are attempting to meet the menace from the skies. Some of these are being tested here at the joint anti-aircraft air corns exercises.
Rallying to score three goals in the final period, the Sands Point four defeated Bostwick Field, 6 to 5, before a holiday gathering of 2,500 at Pete Bostwick's field today.
A slight decline in the index of machine tool orders for the last month was reported here today by the National Machine Tool Builders Association. The September
Gerry Leiper's Jr.'s Corky, an aged campaigner, won the Foxcatcher Plate two-mile steeplechase at the opening of the Rose Tree Fox Hunting Club Fall meeting today before 5,000 persons.
Today's events: "Martha," modernized English production by Federal Opera Company, Arthur Lief conducting, Federal Music Theatre, 8:45 P. M.; Alexander Harsanyi, violinist, Town Hall, 8:30 P. M.;

Major Philip G. Bruton. Corps of Engineers, is relieved from additional duty with the Organized Reserves, 2d Military Area, is detailed, in addition to his other duties, for duty with the Organized Reserves, 1st Military Area, and will report in writing to the executive officer, 1st Military Area, for instructions.

Declaring that he did not favor unreasonable use of independent nominating petitions merely to give a candidate an additional place on the voting machine, Governor Lehman last night notified Ben Howe, chairman of the City Fusion ,party, that he was declining the nomination of that party.

Brokers Tip, who won the 1933 Kentucky Derby for Colonel E. R. Bradley, today was the property of Dana D. Midkiff of Lexington. The son of Black Toney-Imp. Forteresse was sold at the Fallsales of the Lexington Sale Paddock for $1,400.

Bowman Biltmore Hotels Corporation (Hotel Commodore)-Nine months to Sept. 30: Gross income, $2,969,172, against $3,373,697 in the 1937 period. Gross operating profit was $786,906, against $985,840; net profit before interest,

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Scott Newhouse of Brooklyn and Central Valley, N. Y., have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Adele Lincoln Newhouse, to Richard Gordon Werner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Werner of Teaneck, N. J. The wedding will take place on Oct. 22.

UNITED STATES CABLE SPLICER-SEAMAN. $1,380 a year, New York, N. Y. Applications must be on file not later than Oct. 18. A vacancy in the position of cable splicer-seaman in the Signal Service at Large, U. S. A. M. P. "Joseph Henry," Army Base, Brooklyn, N. Y., and vacancies in positions requiring similar qualifications in the same locality, at approximately the same rate of pay, will be filled from this examination. Competitors will not be

THE cast of characters included Lou Little, Cliff Battles, Herb Kopf, Sam Cordovano, Dr. Mal Stevens, Dan Topping, Stout Steve Owen, Benny Friedman, Somnolent James Crowley and some merry villagers. Any man might expect some football chatter where that group had assembled and no man would be disappointed.

Reliable reports that the Soviet Union is hastening construction of a vast artificial no-man's-land along its western frontier as a first line of defense against Germany have reached diplomatic circles here.

Community centers to provide recreational facilities and leisure-time guidance for children after school hours and for adults in the evening will open today in 108 schools under the joint auspices of the WPA and the Board of Education. This is forty-seven more than there were last year.
Lammot du Pont sought in Federal court today to recover about $5,000,000 in Federal gift taxes and interest for 1934.

Harper has sold to Payot et Cie the French translation and publication right to "The Conquest of Civilization" by James Henry Breasted. The new and revised text, including the last writing done by the author before his death, will be used for the translation.

At the unity conference convention being held here by C. I. 0. and A. F. of L; delegates, the Alaska Labor party endorsed the idea of a third term for President Roosevelt, and asked that officeholders chosen in the Territory of Alaska be persons committed to the President's program.
Eddie McCormick, featherweight sophomore halfback, revealed himself as a passing threat as the Princeton squad went through a long practice session on University Field today. Aerial and defensive

Retail prices in September continued unchanged for the second consecutive month, according to the Fairchild retail price index, issued yesterday. This marked the first time in several years that there was no change for two consecutive months, it was declared. Quotations, however, showed a decline of 7.6 per cent from a year ago and were only 1.2 per cent above the 1932 low.
Anthony Perino, 55 years old, a longshoreman, of 468 Smith Street, Brooklyn, was shot four times in the back near his home yesterday at 10:30 A. M., dying shortly afterward in Holy Family Hospital.

There seem to be two current views of John L. Lewis's offer to resign from the chairmanship of the Committee for Industrial Organization if William Green will step down as president of the American Federation of Labor. One accepts Mr. Lewis as the victor in a contest of gestures. Another welcomes
The outsider in a field of three, the Rokeby Stable's Good Chance, scored an easy victory in the $3,500 added Governor Ogle Steeplechase today. The Chance Shotgelding,

The Christ Lutheran Church, 406 East Nineteenth Street, which on Sunday will begin a three weeks' celebration of its seventieth birthday, has received through its pastor, the Rev. Henry C. Offerman, a letter of greeting from President Roosevelt.

A warning against "control of radio broadcasting by the government" as a possible danger to the radio work of the church was sounded at the biennial convention of the United Lutheran Church in America, which closed its sessions today.

After Columbia tested its defensive armor against a slashing overhead and ground attack from a "Colgate" team that included Coaches Cliff Battles and Al Ciampa, yesterday at Baker Field, Lou Little stated frankly that he believes the undefeated Lions are "at the fork of the road.

Charles M. Byrne, former Democratic leader of the Eighth Assembly District in Brooklyn and for more than thirty years active in borough politics, died on Tuesday in his home, 720 East Nineteenth Street, Brooklyn, at the age of 80.

Byron (Whizzer) White, who is working harder than any other back in the National Football League to earn his record salary of $15,000 for one professional season with the Pirates, has moved to the fore among the circuit's groundgainers, according to yesterday's official statistics, covering the first five weeks of championship competition.
Lucienne Delforge, French pianist, a former pupil of Vincent D'Indy at the Paris Schola Cantorum, made her Town Hall debut last night.

Harold L. Ickes, Public Works Administrator, announced yesterday Presidential approval of an outright PWA grant of $585,000 to the town of Hyde Park, N. Y., toward the construction of two new school buildings, to cost $1,300,000.

Indian Summer weather made it impossible for Harvard to accomplish much in its forenoon session today. However, Coach Harlow figured that still another day was needed to get his squad back to condition after the Cornell battle, and tomorrow he plans to speed his team's final heavy drill for the Army game.
The Red Raiders are coming to town to play Columbia at Baker Field Saturday and Harold Lube is coming home.

The official map of the new German-Czech frontiers, which reached London tonight, shows that Germany in some districts has gained less than Chancellor Adolf Hitler asked in his Godesberg memorandum and in some a good deal more.

Two Czech-owned factories now within German territory, one manufacturing shoe laces and driving belts, the other porcelain, which were closed by their owners a short time ago, will be reopened in Sweden.

After blazing for more than fourteen hours, while 500 men worked in peril of their lives to prevent the spread of the flames to adjacent property valued at millions of dollars, a spectacular fire was still eating its way through an estimated 10,000,000 gallons of oil and gasoline at the plant' of the Cities Service Company early today.
For the benefit of the welfare department of the Ancient Order of Hibernians in New York, the New York County Board will hold its annual ball in the Hotel Astor tomorrow night. Those who are
The French Government decided today to bolater the army and navy against Germany's growing force with an additional expenditure of 2,307,000,000 francs.

Completing the third day of their fortieth annual convention, the National Association of Retail Druggists heard a defense today of Fair Trade measures by Senator John E. Miller, cosponsor of the Miller-Tydings Act, and by the association's fair trade advisory committee headed by John A. Goode. Both sought to refute

A return of private investment in existing industries is needed most to bring back prosperity, Dr. Harold G. Moulton, president of the Brookings Institution, Washington, D. C., said here today. He spoke on "The Capital

Clifford J. MacGregor, who headed the MacGregor Arctic expedition which returned recently, said today his wife, Mrs. Martha MacGregor, now living with her parents in Philadelphia, will file a suit soon for divorce, charging incompatibility.

Urging Catholics to break away from the "fetish" of party regularity, Justice Herbert A. O'Brien of the Children's Court, who is an independent Democrat, attacked yesterday the regular Democratic nominees, Governor Lehman, Senator Wagner and Charles Poletti.

Miss Grace Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Jones of West Hartford, and Benedict M. Holden Jr., son of Mrs. Holden of this city and the late Mr. Holden, noted attorney, were married today at St. Joseph's Cathedral.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it has entered an order closing without prejudice its case against the Devoe Raynolds Company, Inc., 1 West Fortyseventh Street, New York City, which was charged with unfair competition in the sale of paints.

Arthur V. McDermott, Republican candidate for Attorney General, charged yesterday that Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. had shown inefficiency in conducting his office during the last eight years. Had Mr. Bennett been
Mr. and Mrs. Henry Goddard Leach gave a dinner last night at their home, 170 East Sixty-fourth Street, for. J. Sigfrid Edstrom, president of the American Foundation of Sweden. Other guests

Brazil is considering reducing the $25 visa fee now charged American residents in Brazil who travel to other countries. J. C. Moniz, president of the Immigration Commission, will act tomorrow to reduce the fee to the level paid by other nationalities.

The National Labor Relations Board declared today in a brief filed with the Supreme Court, that the contracts between the Consolidated Edison Company 'of New York and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, an A. F. of L. affiliate. were "clearly illegal."

Magistrate Anna M. Kross, candidate of the American Labor party and the Progressive party for justice of the Supreme Court, announced yesterday that she would break with precedent and act as her own campaign manager. She is a veteran...

Elmer F. Andrews, Wages and Hours Administrator, ruled today that maintenance men, watchmen, clerks, stenographers and messengers employed in interstate commerce industries are subject to the new Wages and Hours Law, as they are engaged in occupations "necessary to the production" of goods moving in such commerce.

A formal request that John L. Lewis be required to appear before the Dies Committee, investigating un-American activities; was filed today with Chairman Dies by Hartley W. Barclay, editor of Mill and Factory.

Despondent over unemployment and worried about the fate of his 14-year-old son who has been in Germany for several months, Alphonse Lang, 47 years old, committed suicide last night by hanging himself in his apartment at 1,356 York Avenue.

Nine firemen were overcome by smoke and fumes early this morning in a fire that started in the factory of the M. Long Mattress Company on the ground floor of a six-story loft building at 153-55 West Seventy-second Street, between Columbus Avenue and Broadway.
The Norwegian American motorship Oslofjord is due today from Bergen and Oslo. Among her passengers are Wilhelm Morgenstierne, Norwegian Minister to the United States, and Mrs. Morgenstierne;

Unless the United States Circuit Court of Appeals indicates this morning a desire for a postponement, the Sixth Avenue elevated line will be sold at foreclosure, at the upset price of $12,500,000, at 2 o'clock this afternoon.

The Winnipeg grain market was affected today by the Columbus Day shutdown of Exchanges in the United States. Trade was virtually at a standstill after an early flourish because of the lack of inter-market operations.

Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor will give a dinner tonight in La Maisonette Russe of the St. Regis for Miss Le Brun Cruger Rhinelander and William G. McKnight Jr., who will be married tomorrow in St. James Church.

The latest issue of the film "The March of Time," called "Britain's Dilemma," which dramatizes the background and cause of the Czechoslovak crisis, has been banned by the British Board of Film Censors.

Miss Mary T. MacAlister, portrait painter and writer, died here at her home on Rittenhouse Square today. She was the daughter of the late James MacAlister, first president of Drexel Institute of Technology.
Ralph Hutchison of Bethlehem, Pa., and Joe Zarhardt of Plainfield, N. J., today advanced to the final of the annual Philadelphia district professional golfers' championship.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today set a hearing for Oct. 31 on applications for a report by it on a plan of reorganization of the Inland Power and Light Corporation and the Commonwealth Light and Power Company which contemplates the dissolution of the latter and the formation of a reorganized company, as successor to both companies.
Official approval was given by the French Cabinet today to the appointment of Andre Franeois-Poncet, Ambassador to Berlin, as Ambassador to Rome.

A vigil by Park Department employes last night at the bird sanctuary in Central Park, at 106th Street and the East Drive, following the disappearance from there Tuesday night of "Al Smith," a fifty-pound turkey, resulted in the capture of Sal Ortiz, 31 years old, of 58 West 113th Street.
The fortieth anniversary of the incorporation of this town and the dedication of the new local postoffice were celebrated in a series of ceremonies here this afternoon.
Mrs. Arthur H. Jones, wife of the late Mayor of this municipality, was appointed his successor today by unanimous action of the Kearny Town Council. Mrs. Jones, the first

Dr. Theodor Teimer, a former member of the Newark Board of Health, who was head of the metabolism department of Newark City Hospital, died today in his home here after an illness of one week. He was 66 years old.
In the Supreme Court of the United States today, Robert J. Fluskey, of New York City, was admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:
With the opening of the deer season in the Adirondacks area this Saturday a number of problems seem to be confronting the man trying this form of hunting for the first time. Novices want to know

It's sheer force of habit that carries you up to Baker Field when you want to see Herb Kopf. Along with nearly every one else who keeps in touch with football we, of course, knew that the distinguished W. and J. alumnus had transferred his allegiance to Manhattan, but habit is often unbreakable, as imbibers and smokers will tell you.

With the aid of a new radio instrument, an automatic directionfinder, a transport airplane carrying sixteen passengers found yesterday morning a hidden navy truck a dozen miles away as readily as a hound on a hot scent finds its game.

Catholics were urged last night by Mgr. J. Francis A. McIntyre, Chancellor of the Archdiocese of New York, to support Propositions 1, 6 and 8 of the new State Constitution in the coming election at the Columbus Day dinner of the New York Chapter of the Knights of Columbus at the Hotel Capitol.

A light and green Erasmus Hall High eleven covered itself with glory yesterday. The Buff and Blue lads, underdogs in the lest three games with their old rival, James Madison, gave a fine display of heads-up football to upset the veteran and much heavier Golden Tornado, 7-2, at Ebbets Field.

With more than 10,000 signatures to petitions nominating him as the candidate of the Andrew Jackson party, Representative John J. O'Connor declared yesterday that the majority of the signers were Democrats and that this support combined with the regular Republican vote would be sufficient to reelect him.

Nine hundred engineers, among them John Coolidge, son of the late Calvin Coolidge, visited the World's Fair yesterday in an inspection trip under the auspices of the Connecticut Society of Professional Engineers and the Connecticut Society of Civil Engineers, Inc.

It was strictly proper that only twenty-one candles should shine from Mrs. Franklin Roosevelt's birthday cake. Certainly among all the women of this active nation, none manages more successfully than she to retain the energy of a person less than half her age.
The First Division polo team, aided by a two-goal handicap, managed to beat the Fort Hamilton Officers 8 to 7, yesterday, on the latter's field in one of the feature contests of the holiday program.

Mayor La Guardia, who canceled his participation in the Columbus Day exercises of the Columbia Association yesterday because of ill health, was reported in bed with a cold by James M. Kieran, his press secretary.

Dismemberment of Czechoslovakia struck a snag yesterday when the Czechs rejected Hungarian territorial claims. The Hungarians threatened to walk out of the joint conference today unless their demands were met.

Dr. Homer P. Rainey of Washington, staff director of the American Youth Commission, told the sixth annual conference of the Commission on the Relation of School and College in Chalfonte-Haddon Hall here today that industry gradually was taking over vocational training and freeing the schools of the burden.
Billy Y. Dear Jr. of the Essex County Country Club annexed the qualifying medal in the twentieth annual invitation golf tournament at the Arcola Country Club today.

Temperatures ranging 20 degrees or more above the average for Columbus Day last year handicapped retail trade here yesterday, with the sales showing for the day estimated at 10 per cent or more under the 1937 figures.

Continuing its fine spirit of the past few days the Yale eleven today trounced the jayvee squad in a scrimmage that was designed to test a group of tricky running plays installed by Coach Raymond (Ducky) Pond for Saturday's clash with the Navy gridiron machine.

That mammoth peace vote in Great Britain a couple of years ago was not wholly an unmixed blessing, delegates to the State convention of the League of Women Voters were told today. In England last Summer, Mrs. Marion Dooley of Syracuse reported, public opinion had assigned it a role as one of the contributing causes of the recent world crisis.
Registration throughout the city picked up slightly yesterday as 308,866 persons registered on the third day for the qualifying of voters in the November elections.

September was the first month this year in which production and shipments of stock sash, doors and frames exceeded the volume of a year ago, according to a report yesterday by the National Door Manufacturers Association, Inc.
Members of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Banking and their friends to the number of about 5,000 yesterday had a "preview" of the New York World's Fair. The chapter's

The army authorities are not anxious for the army to assume responsibility for counter-espionage activities in peacetime, it became known here today. Progress of the German spy ring trial, which opens in New York City on Friday, will be followed with much interest by highranking army officers from Washington and other parts of the United States who are here for the joint anti-aircraft air corps exercises..

Lord Dawson of Penn, British physician, who has attended four kings, beginning with Edward VII, arrived yesterday from London on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen with Lady Dawson for a three-week visit. It is his second this year.

Production of Canadian newsprint in September reached 231,940 tons, the highest monthly figure of the year, the Newsprint Association of Canada reported today. Shipments last month, estimated at 230,346 tons, also reached a 1938 high. The output was 25.7
It is surprising how often the name of Stanford White, one of the leading architects of a generation ago, still crops up in the New York realty news of today.

At 2.236 cents a pound, the composite price of finished steel products is now at the lowest level since Dec. 23, 1936, according to The Iron Age. That publication's index declined as a result of the $4 slash in flat-rolled products this week. Dealers expect heavier operations to continue the upward movement in pig iron prices.

Governor E. W. Marland of Oklahoma asserted today that the United States should permit a limited amount of Mexican and Venezuelan oil to enter the United States to preserve what he asserted were the waning oil reserves of the country.
Further gains in the volume of awards for engineering construction over the 1937 figures have been made in the current week for the thirteenth consecutive time, The Engineering News-Record reports.

Miss Caroline Landon Sawyer, daughter of Mrs. Eugene M. Sawyer of 1,349 Lexington Avenue and the late Mr. Sawyer and granddaughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hutton Landon of New York, was married here yesterday noon to Lieutenant Sam W. Agee Jr., U. S. A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Agee of Silver City, N. M.

That the freight rate on lubricating oil from Texas ports to Puerto Rico, less than half the distance, is approximately 50 per cent more than the rate from Texas to Europe was brought out before Examiner Russell of the Maritime Commission today when Jose M. Gatell, representing the Maritime Oil Co., testified at the hearing.

Base metal stocks sold today at new high levels for the year on the Toronto Stock Exchange and the gold issues were the highest in more than a month. All index groups showed gains. Volume was the largest in a week with 838,000 shares changing hands.
Lester Patrick's "accent on youth" New York Rangers opened pre-season training today for the National Hockey League campaign.

David L. Hough of 140 East For-, tieth Street, a civil engineer and contractor who had a part in building some of the principal tunnels under Manhattan Island and the East River, died last evening in a sanitarium at Amityville, L. I., of pneumonia, after an illness of three days. He was 73 years old.

Representative Ramspeck of Georgia told the National League of District Postmasters today that extension of the merit system to cover all Federal employes would probably save taxpayers $1,000,000,000 annually.

Attorney General Cummings assigned today Special Assistants Welly K. Hopkins and Henry Schweinhaut to outline to a Federal grand jury at Newark, N. J., next week results of the Justice Department's investigation into the recent ejection of Norman Thomas from Jersey City.
The period between Columbus Day and Election Day is empty of redletter days with the exception of Theodore

The League of Nations' International Commission to verify the withdrawal of non-Spanish combatants in the Spanish civil war, set up at Premier Juan Negrin's request, will assemble Friday at Perpignan, France, the League Secretariat announced today.
For the first time since the week ended on June 8 bank clearings for the country have topped the corresponding period in 1937. Aided by

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo opened its first engagement in New York last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, more or less as successor to the DeBasil Ballet Russe, under the artistic direction of Leonide Massine. Though there is a

Since he took office last January Controller McGoldrick has consistently preached the simple doctrine that the city cannot spend more than it takes in. It cannot outrun its tax budget without borrowing. It cannot borrow more than the law allows or more than it can some day pay back. The possible

Earmarking of relief funds and moves toward decentralizing its administration gained a new and powerful friend in Washington this Week, according to reports that ran through the press gallery. He is Senator

Nazis warned tonight that "an end must be put to the methods" of Theodor Cardinal Innitzer. The warning was published in the newspaper Wiener Neueste Nachrichten under the name of its managing editor, Walter Petwaidie.

The Internatioal Ladies' Garment Workers' Union, third largest Committee for Industrial Organization affiliate, which has sought repeatedly to bring about peace between the American Federation of Labor and the C. I. O., yesterday called upon President Roosevelt to follow up his recent plea for peace, made to the A. F. of L. convention in session in' Houston, Texas, by another and more direct move.

Will Gallop, a chestnut gelding owned by Philip J. Bliss of Bronxville and one of the best jumpers of the outdoor season, today won the jumper championship of the colorful second annual horse show at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club.

Howard L. Hoffman Jr. was found dead in his room on the seventeenth floor of the Hotel Lexington yesterday morning of a bullet wound which police of the East Fifty-first Street station said was self-inflicted. He was 37 years old.

Cooperative advertising funds are curtailed to a greater degree.during periods of business adversity than are the appropriations for individual companies' advertising, the bureau of public relations of the American Institute of Steel Construction has found in a special report. The bureau has analyzed 177

Defying trade union leaders and breaking agreements for settlement of disputes with employers, railway strikers at the Paddington and Euston Stations tonight succeeded in enlisting the aid of 1,000 workers at the Camden Town freight yards.
The Manhattan College freshmen beat the St. Basil's Prep School eleven today, 31-0, scoring touchdowns in every period. The visitors tallied

Long-fed steers and yearlings were more plentiful in today's livestock market, but the outside demand was broad and prices were steady, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. Lambs also were fully steady in a fairly active trade but hogs continued to slide lower.

The trustees of the General Insurance Guaranty Fund of Savings Bank Life Insurance held an organization meeting yesterday in the office of Louis H. Pink Superintendent of Insurance, 80 Centre Street. Savings bank life

A delegation representing the New York Security Dealers Association and the New York Security Traders Association conferred today with officials of the Securities and Exchange Commission concerning the treatment to be accorded to the socalled smaller firms and the traders in the organization of over-thecounter brokers and dealers under the Maloney act.

The Mexican Government has agreed to buy immediately in the United States more than 3,000,000 bushels of wheat under the new American subsidy plan. It is believed to be the first such deal since the subsidies were announced in Washington.

The Richmond Radiator Company, Uniontown, Pa., manufacturer of enameled plumbing fixtures, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $600,000 of 5 per cent convertible debentures due in 1948 to be offered to common stockholders at 100.

The fourth annual Bath County field trials opened today with the open all-age cocker and English springer stakes. Rowcliffe Black Fury, 3-year-old owned by Walter Lempka of Poughkeepsie, N. Y., and handled by Luke Medlin, led a field of eight conkers.

A story of hopes that soared and dived earthward came out of Astoria yesterday. The .first breathtaking ascent occurred late Tuesday afternoon at Thirtieth Avenue and Thirty-first Street when two youngsters, Samuel Faraci of 113 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, and William Nickes of 48-04 Thirtieth Avenue, Queens, both 15 years old, found a $50 bill.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses, Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll of Brooklyn and- Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens joined yesterday in setting the stage for a showdown before the Board of Estimate today on Mayor La Guardia's plan to shelve the $28,000,000 Circumferential Highway until the city has more funds available to build it.

Cotton receipts 4,000 bales, including 2,000 American. Moderate business in spot, prices 4 to 9 points higher; quotations in pence: American, strictly good middling, 5.86, and middling, 5.56; strict middling, 5.31; dling, 5.56; strict middling, 5.31; middling, 5.11; strict low middling, 4.86; low middling, 4.46; strict good ordinary, 4.06; good ordinary, 3.71. Futures closed 3 points higher to 6 points lower.
Mrs. Bernard M. Shanley Jr. of South Orange, N. J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Regina Shanley, to Dr. Edward Caffron Klein Jr. of Newark, N. J.

Mary Rorke, "grand old lady of the British stage," died in London today at the age of 80. One of two sisters, Kate and Mary Rorke, who were famous on the London stage forty years ago, she was in almost continuous employment for sixty-six years and retired in 1933 after appearing in a film, "Testimony."

Frank R. McNinch, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, demanded today the resignation of Hampson Gary, general counsel of the FCC. Mr. Gary refused, and it is understood that the matter will be taken up by the commission as a whole at a meeting Friday.

The Dominican Commercial High School, 161st Street and Eightyninth Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, was dedicated yesterday by the Most Rev. Thomas E. Molloy, Bishop of the Brooklyn Diocese. A thousand persons were present.

French breeders scored a sweep in the ninety-ninth Cambridgeshire Stakes today when Jacques Meller's Helleniqua, a tiny mare rated no better than 130 to 1 in the totalisator, led two other French-bred candidates to the post.

The Texas Company met today the cut in prices of crude oil posted a yesterday by the Humble Oil and ii Refining Company. Its reductions equal those of Humble except on the Gulf coast of Texas, where the stop at 34 gravity and above.

An unofficial translation of the text of Ecuador's proposal to five American Presidents to mediate her dispute with Peru follows. The text in Spanish was' made public here today by Captain Colon Eloy Alfaro, the Ecuadorean Ambassador; it was signed by Manuel Maria Barrero, President of, Ecuador.

The reaction of merchants throughout the country to the private audition on Tuesday of the proposed national broadcast program featuring the New York Philharmonic Orchestra has been "highly favorable," although no contracts have yet been signed by retailers, it was learned here yesterday.

Miss Eleanor Kathryn Owens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Haydn Owens of New Haven, Conn., was married to Edward Everett Rockefeller Jr. of Valley Stream, L. I., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rockefeller of Schoharie, N. Y., yesterday afternoon in the Welsh Presbyterian Church in West 155th Street, between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue. The ceremony was

Senator O'Mahoney's address before the New York Board of Trade on the problems confronting the Temporary National Economic Committee was admirable in spirit and in many of its specific comments. Though the Senator was aware of a "profound suspicion" among some business men of "what they call politicians and demagogues,"

Processing taxes on wheat and cotton were assailed today by the Millers National Federation as "bread. and britches" taxes which the consumer is obliged to pay in increased cost of commodities. The association

Enveloped in swirls of fog and hampered by an almost dead calm, 200 tiny vessels took part in a series of miniature sea dramas yesterday morning and the winners beat their way to new glory, much in the manner of the clipper ships of old.

Having listened to addresses which indicated the chain stores had won the support of farm groups by their surplus products sales campaigns, the executive committee of the National Association of Food Chains met after the close of the fifth annual convention today to plan ways to win more friends for the industry.
In reporting to his stockholders yesterday, C. E. Groesbeck, chairman of Electric Bond and Share, rattled no saber at the SEC or any other branch of the government and did no namecalling.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes, in francs:
Commodore Nathaniel Matson Terry, physicist and former head of the Department of Physics and Chemistry at the United States Naval Academy at Annapolis, died last night. His age was 94.
Interesting from several angles is the proposal of the Budapest Government to submit the dispute over the Hungarian minority in Czechoslovakia to the decision of a four-power conference.

Governor Lehman's decision to supersede District Attorney Geoghan was perhaps the only one, under all the circumstances, that he could have made. The action doubtless shows that after investigating the evidence submitted to him by William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, there was sufficient doubt raised in the Governor's mind for him to feel that a thorough investigation was called for, by a disinterested agency.

The trial of nine members of the Left Communist party, P. O. U. M. Workers' party of Marxist Union], continued today with the interrogation of two of its executive committee, Jorge Arquer and Julian Gomez. The latter, known as a "Gorkin," was the right hand man of Andres Nin, P. O. U. M. leader, who vanished from a prison in Madrid.

The campus of City College yesterday was the scene of a Pyrrhic victory earned by members of the Class of 1942 over the Class of 1941 in the first freshman - sophomore flag rush at the college in three years.

The question of what steps should be taken to deal with the sufferings of the new mass of refugees dumped on the world by the German occupation of the Sudetenland received close attention in London today following news from Prague of the Czechs' determination to refuse to allow any Germans, whether opposed to Nazism or not, to live in the new Czechoslovakia.

The victory Germany did not win in the World War was given to her at Munich in an agreement that will go down as "one of the greatest betrayals" of history, Clark M. Eichelberger, national director of the League of Nations Association, told 300 members of the association at a luncheon yesterday at the Murray Hill Hotel.

With the huge curtain of flames and gray smoke finally beaten down in the devastated sector of the Cities Service Oil Company (of Pennsylvania) plant at Tremley Point, officials of the company were able to determine today that twenty-one tanks and contents,

The commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City rose $8,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $1,454,000,000, according to the condition statement of the banks issued yesterday.

The New York Railways Corporation lost yesterday its claim to a $75,000 refund on its 1933 real estate taxes because of the omission of a signature from a protest filed with the Board of Taxes and As'sessments against its 1932 assessed valuation.
The labor newspaper El Popular reported today that President Lazaro Cardenas had signed an order exempting all workers in mining cooperatives from paying the 12 per cent export tax on silver.

James J. Hines, Tammany leader of the Eleventh Assembly District, was challenged last night when he appeared at the registration place for the Seventeenth Election District of that Assembly district on Amsterdam Avenue between 106th and 107th Street to register for the election on Nov. 8.

Retail trade in the country as a whole will fare at least as poorly as in New York, reports reaching resident offices here yesterday indicated. Buying office men said warm weather was principally to blame for unsatisfactory results in nearly every section.

Producers yesterday advanced the price of copper in the domestic market from 10.75 cents a pound to 11 cents. This follows three increases of 1/8 cent a pound made in the last two weeks. Since the latter part of June, when the current movement started, the price of the metal has advanced from 9 cents a pound.
There are shepherds about Bethlehem yet, far-off descendants of those to whom the Angel of the Lord said: "For behold I bring you tidings of great joy which shall be to all the people."

The Administration's proposal to sell surplus agricultural products at "bargain prices" to the low-income third of the population won support today on capitol hill. Discussion turned immediately to the probable cost of such a program, and how the money would be raised.

Whoever coined the expression "out of the frying pan into the fire" doubtless had Columbia in mind. A week ago the Lions, having held a grand opening (from Columbia's point of view) by defeating Yale, 27-14, jumped out of Army's frying pan into what?
Research activities of the steel industry were praised by President Roosevelt in a message to the American Institute of Steel Construction, read at the annual convention banquet here tonight.

The whereabouts of the Austrian gold reserve appropriated by Germany as a result of the annexation is part of the general mystery that surrounds all Germany's finances, but this gold is 'generally assumed to have become part of a German war chest put aside in gold and estimated at approximately 1,000,000,000 marks.

Yesterday the Sloss-Sheffield Steel and Iron Company reported a net profit of $42,615 for the third quarter of 1938 after charges and taxes. This was equal to 70 cents a share on 60,473 preferred shares.

In a setting of ferns and gold and brown blossoms, Miss Margaret Schieffelin Pardee, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Irving H. Pardee of 133 East Eightieth Street, this city, and Lawrence, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Talcott Bates,

Another strong indication that the government is getting ready to introduce some form of national service against war emergency was given by Sir John Simon, Chancellor of the Exchequer, tonight in a speech at the cutlers' dinner at Sheffield.

Miss Lucile E. du Pont, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irenee du Pont of Granogue, Del., will be married to Robert B. Flint of Wilmington at 6 o'clock tomorrow night in the Cathedral Church of St. John, by the Rev. Hiram R. Bennett.

Moderate improvement in orders for rubber footwear in the last few weeks was reported by producers yesterday, but it was said that buying was well under that of a year 8th Ave, ago. Principal activity was in light goods, such as arctics and unlined rubbers, while boots, heavy arctics and other heavy goods have been quiet.
The United Automobile Workers of America announced this afternoon an agreement with the Chrysler Corporation whereby 8,000 additional men will be put to work in the company's plants next week.

Maurice Mermey, director of exhibits and concessions of the World's Fair, has leased an apartment at 65 Central Park West through Potter, Hamilton Co. Paul and Grace Hartman, dancers, have rented an apartment in the Hotel Plaza, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

Pennsylvania completed its hard work today for the Princeton game, devoting at least half of the time to defense. For fifty minutes Head Coach George Munger and Line Coach Rae Crowther followed the varsity while it endeavored to solve the Orange and Black offensive formations. Defense against a five and six man line and a fifteen-minute drill for the punters concluded the work.

Although she has sung in London and Central Europe, Kirsten Flagstad was heard for the first time in Paris only this evening when she appeared at the Opera as Isolde in a German performance of "Tristan
A storm cloud, black as soot and some 2,000 miles wide, was observed on the planet Jupiter last night by Lyle Abbott, astronomer in charge of the twelve-inch telescope of Griffith Observatory here.
Insuranshares Certificates, Inc., reported yesterday a liquidating value of $6.94 a share for the capital stock on Sept. 30, compared to $5.86 a share on Dec. 31 and $6.56 a share on Sept. 30, 1937.

Robert Eldredge, supervising engineer for the Public Works Administration on the Lincoln Tunnel, died Wednesday of a heart attack in his apartment at the Hotel Van Rensselaer, 17 East Eleventh Street. He was 64 years old.

Instead of lecturing to the American public as a visiting British author, John Strachey played cricket with other excluded aliens yesterday in the exercise yard on Ellis Island, where he passed his third day without bail.

First National Bank, Boston The First National Bank of Boston has reported, as of Sept. 28, total deposits of $631,928,716 and total assets of $733,401,003, compared, respectively, with $642,570,482 and $743,576,803 on June 30, last.

Art Gottlieb, regular Rutgers left halfback, reported to practice today with a sprained toe, and Coach Harvey Harman announced it was doubtful whether he would start against Springfield here Saturday.

Advertising must gain the complete confidence of the consuming public, if the value of the many technical improvements in all types of products is not to be diminished, Allan T. Preyer, vice president of the Vick Chemical Company and recently elected chairman of the board of the Association of National Advertisers, yesterday declared at the weekly luncheon meeting of the Advertising Club of New York.

Mrs. Gertrude Vander Poel Smith obtained a divorce today from Lloyd Hilton Smith of New York City on grounds of cruelty. Agreement on property affairs was reached and the decree restores her maiden name, Gertrude Schuyler Vander Poel.

Nearly 3,000 employes of the production and maintenance department of Armour Co. voted to make the United Packinghouse Workers, Local 347, an affilaite of the Committee for Industrial Organization, the sole bargaining agent for rail employes.

Thirty-two chess players opposed Dr. Emanuel Lasker, former world champion, in an exhibition of simultaneous play arranged for him at the German-Jewish Club, 210 West Ninety-first Street, yesterday. Twenty-seven were defeated, four drew their games and only one, Robert H. Zitzmann, was declared a winner against the veteran.

Miss Kathryn Gertrude Dillon, daughter of Mrs. John H. Dillon of New Haven, Conn., and the late Mr. Dillon, was married here yesterday afternoon in the rectory of St. Patrick's Cathedral to Frederick Laton McCartney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. McCartney of Denver.

The marriage of H. Russell Goode, 20-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Goode of 150 East Seventy-third Street, to Miss.Callie Ives Adams last June 24 in Elkton, Md., was disclosed yesterday. The romance began at the Orpheum Dance Palace, 1,553 Broadway, where Miss Adams was employed .
Stewart McDonald, administrator of the Federal Housing Administration, predicted today that more than 350,000 dwelling units would be built this year, against only 50,000 four years ago.
A new apartment house will rise Found, shortly on the East Side following the purchase of a site near Lexington Avenue by a group which already is preparing plans for the improvement.

The statement of the Bank of Canada for the week ended yesterday, issued today, shows an increase of $2,391,000 in notes in circulation. The ratio of net reserve to notes and deposit liabilities was 51.15 per cent, against 1 51.09 a week before.

Frank Allee, former United States Senator and for years active in the Republican party, died today at the home of his son, James F. Allee Jr., editor and publisher of The Dover State Sentinel. His age was 80.

Dr. Wesley A. Sturges, newly elected as executive director of the Distilled Spirits Institute, has a contract under which he will be paid at the rate of $30,000 annually for the first six months in his new post, according to reports in the liquor trade here yesterday.
Miss Genevieve Lane, a landscape, mural and portrait painter, died yesterday at the home of her sister, Mrs. Florence Smith, 517 West 151st Street.

Announcement was made at the Institute for Advanced Study here today of the immediate construction of the institute's first building, to cost approximately $500,000. The building will be erected on a 400acre tract recently acquired by the institute on the outskirts of Princeton.

Active steps were undertaken here today to sound out Latin-American sentiment on the question of mediation of the boundary dispute between Peru and Ecuador, the last remaining border controversy in the Western Hemisphere.
Mrs. Payne Whitney of New York, owner of Greentree Farm, was honored tonight as "The First Lady of the American Turf." Honor guest at the seventh annual dinner of the Thoroughbred Club of America,...
The American Merchant of the United States Lines is sailing today for London. Passengers are Miss Edith MacNeill, Mrs. Frances Newton, Charles T. Hawley, Mrs. Constance G. Rykert,...
John Witty, Portland, Ore., was elected president of the National Association of Retail Druggists at the fourth day of the convention here today.
