Easing down work of the Yale varsity eleven with a curtailed scrimmage against the scrubs, Coach Ducky Pond today closed preparations for the Navy game in the Bowl Saturday. Six shifts in the line-up that started against Pennsylvania were ordered and the new array is to open against the Middies:

A recommendation that an application by Gray Line Motor Tours, Inc., New York, to acquire control of Royal Blue Sightseeing Corporation by purchase of 1,000 shares of its capital stock for $100,000 be approved was made today to the Interstate Commerce Commission by Bernard P. Pitt, examiner.
The Ukrainians in Poland are continuing to protest the projected incorporation of Carpathian Ruthenia in Hungary. Undo,

A group of bankers headed by B. J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., of New York and E. H. Rollins Sons, Inc., of Philadelphia will offer today $10,000,000 of Pennsylvania Turnpike revenue 33/4 percent bonds representing part of an authorized issue of $35,000,000 to be sold by the Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission and purchased by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Carl Hubbell could have pitched in the world series if the Giants had won the National League race this season, Dr. Robert Brashear said today. "I think Hubbell's arm will be all right and that he will be an effective pitcher again next season." said Dr. Brashear,
The New York Curb Exchange has authorized the listing of 1,042 additional shares of Lion Oil Refining Company common stock, no-par value, on official notice of issuance.

New building operations in the Bronx during the first nine months of this year increased $6,068,189 over the figure for the same period of last year, it was announced yesterday by William E. Matthews, executive secretary of the Bronx Board of Trade.

Encouraged by the Indian Summer weather, a large field of eighty-three players turned out for the Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association's last one-day tournament on the west course of the Westchester Country Club today, with Mrs. Edgar H. Arnold of Greenwich scoring 43, 46-89 to take low gross honors.

Grand Duke Vladimir, 21 years old, was recognized by most White Russians tonight-as the new head of the House of Romanoff. His father, Grand Duke Cyril, who was the head of the house and pretender to the. vanished imperial Russian throne, died yesterday.

The Sixth Avenue elevated line, together with all easements and franchise rights incidental to its operation, was sold at foreclosure yesterday for $12,500,000, under a decree signed by Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson on Aug. 8, 1938.

A delegation of Americans representing Jewish organizations throughout the country submitted a memorandum today to Sir Ronald Lindsay, the British Ambassador, appealing to the British Government to "fulfill her international obligations in Palestine" so that Jewish immigration may continue.

Increased tension between the Catholic Church and the Nazi Government in Austrian Germany is reflected in a recent pastoral letter of the Austrian hierarchy objecting to severe restrictions on Catholic education there and listing other grievances.

THE European situation is bad enough, but European situation is bad enough, look what's going on around here: "Sir: In rebuttal to that Navy blast appearing in your column recently, I hope I will be permitted to answer the query of Lieutenant Jones (U. S. N., retired), to wit; 'Why did the Army enlisted team pull out of the President's Cup Competition?'

Continued Treasury disbursements in excess of receipts, chiefly for the purchase of gold imports, brought about a rise of $79,000,000 in member bank reserve balances in the week ended on Wednesday, covered by yesterday's reports.

Mr. and Mrs. Francis O. Ayres of Wicklow, this place, formerly of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Fancher Ayres, to Joseph Gordon Tompkins, son- of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph S. Tompkins of Newburgh, N. Y.

During the week ended Oct. 12 member bank reserve balances increased $79,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves rose from a decrease of $67,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and increases of $57,000,000 in gold stock,

The old queen of the North Atlantic, Captain Angus Walters's big salt banker Bluenose, today defeated Captain Ben Pine's challenger for the International Fishermen's Trophy, the schooner Gertrude L. Thebaud, by 12 minutes in a race around a purported forty-mile course.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday a net loss of $1,908,625 after taxes, depreciation and charges for the first eight months of 1938, contrasted with a net profit of $2,421,965, equal to $2.32 a share on 1,045,278 shares of capital stock for the 1937 period.

A more active demand for most classes of domestic corporate loans was the feature of trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Turnover reached $9,068,000, compared with $7,381,000 on Tuesday, with the increased activity centered in domestic corporate and foreign dollar obligations.

High administration circles regarded it as a certainty today that every effort would be made at the new session of Congress to extend the President's power to devalue the dollar, and the Treasury's authority to use the $2,000,000,000 exchange stabilization fund beyond June 30, the date on which they expire.

The city Department of Parks is working out numerous changes in design of its equipment as part of a program to combat vandalism that causes $250,000 damage to shrubbery, buildings and other park property in the city every year, it was disclosed last night by William H. Latham, park engineer.

Mayor La Guardia's official family increased by one yesterday when Edmund L. Palmieri, his law secretary, announced the birth of a daughter to Mrs. Palmieri in the Leroy Sanitarium, 40 East Sixtyfirst Street, early yesterday morning.

John F. Feltman, a former Brooklyn patrolman, and Jack and Harry Polotnick, brothers, all of whom were convicted last week of obstructing justice, received prison sentences of two years each-when they appeared yesterday before Federal Judge John C. Knox.

Harvard uses a panel of mirrors on its practice field in order to have the athletes notice their own mistakes ... The superstitious attribute the defeats by Brown and Cornell to the fact that a big lineman, so engrossed in his movements, tackled himself in the glass, shattered the mirror and thus brought on seven years' hard luck. . . . You don't have to believe that, though.
The German press, obedient servant of Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Propaganda Minister, has started a violent campaign against alleged excessive armaments of Great Britain.

A political sensation was caused today when negotiations were opened between former Dictator Peter Zivkovitch of the Yugoslav National party and former Premier Bogulyub, Yevtitch with the Croat Peasant party for an agreement in view of the forthcoming elections.

A plan to keep a reserve of 100 per cent behind demand deposits and a suggestion that savings and time deposits be separated completely from demand, or check deposits, were discussed here today at the Minnesota conference of the Society for Stability of Money and Banking.
The feature of yesterday's cotton market was an advance of $1 a bale in spot quotations in Liverpool and a change of about $2 a bale in relations between old and new October contracts there.

Unusual structural features are embodied in the plans for the tall apartment buildings which Dr. Charles V. Paterno will erect on the site formerly occupied by his fortress-like "castle" in upper Manhattan.

Constitutional Proposal 1 offers advantages to property owners chiefly because of the opportunities it affords toward obtaining, through legislation, an easing of the tax burden, Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, declared tonight at the Fall conference of the Westchester Real Estate Board.
Daily average sales of variety stores for September were about 5.5 per cent below September last year, the Deapartment of Commerce reported today. However,

More than a score of patrons continued to eat in Hector's Cafeteria, 1,506 Broadway, on the street floor of the old Hotel Claridge building, when firemen took a hose line through to the sub-basement kitchen to extinguish a flue fire at 11:30 o'clock last night.

Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente signed yesterday an order directing the release- of Miss Blanche E. Childs, 62 years old, from New York County Jail, where she has been a prisoner since June 28 for failure to pay a $1,813 judgment obtained against her by default in city court.

When they the Sofia citizenry sought to leave their houses this morning they found the streets occupied by troops who ordered the people indoors forthwith. The entire capital was under military rule from early in the morning until evening.
Dr. James William Cain, father of James M. Cain, novelist known for "The Postman Always Rings Twice," died today after a long illness. His age was 78.

Governor Lehman authorized yesterday a far-reaching investigation into official corruption in Brooklyn. He announced that District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan would be superseded and that Supreme Court Justice Francis D. McCurn of Syracuse,

The French Senate today voiced a demand that has been growing in the country for providing France with adequate aviation protection. A delegation of Senators representing the Aviation Commission of the Senate called at the Air Ministry and demanded urgent measures to remedy the deficiencies.
Mr. Strachey soon after his arrival gave the reporters a few elementary. definitions of communism, socialism, Communists and Socialists.

Steele Mitchell, president of Adams Express Company, reported yesterday that total assets were $43,219,276 on Sept. 30, against $44,470,521 on Dec. 31, 1937. Net asset value was equal to $13.48 a share on the common stock, compared to $11.61 on Dec. 31. By Oct. 8 the value had risen to $14.92 a common share.
Colgate had its final workout on the home field today for the Columbia battle, then entrained for New York. A send-off by the student body cheered the Maroon as it started the

For its second performance at the Metropolitan Opera House last night the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo added to its scheduled program a performance of the "Spectre de la Rose" with Igor Youskevitch and Mia Slavenska in the two roles.
The Commodity Exchange Commission announced today that a hearing of charges filed by Cargill, .Inc.,

Tudor Jenks Simpkins, a member of the Commodity Exchange, Inc., in New York and of the commodity brokerage firm of Simpkins Fitzpatrick, 81 Broad Street, New York, died yesterday in Lawrence Hospital here after an illness of eight months. Mr. Simpkins, who lived at 5 Church Street, was 33 years old.
Kayak II, an Argentine-bred stablemate of Seabiscuit, proved the class on a field of eight competing in the Aragon Purse, a feature race for 3-year-olds, today.

Joseph Buerckel, Nazi Commissioner for Austria, tonight announced three measures against the Austrian Catholic hierarchy as a result of what he said were "church attacks against the National Socialist party and Adolf Hitler.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and the Reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.

The Fordham football schedule for 1939 was announced yesterday by John F. Coffey, graduate manager of athletics. The list shows the Maroon meeting Waynesburg, Alabama, Tulane, Pittsburgh, Rice, Indiana, St. Mary's and New York University.

Renewed heavy selling, largely speculative, hit the pound sterling in the foreign exchange market yesterday forcing it down 21/8 points to $4.733/8 or more than 8 cents below its quotation of a week ago. Most other European exchanges were similarly weak.
A program providing for a major revamping of the Social Security Act will be laid before the next Congress by President Roosevelt.

Dr. E. George Payne, dean of the New York University School of Education, has been appointed to the University Board of Athletic Control, it was announced yesterday by Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase.

A total of $52,214 has been raised thus far by men and women workers in the campaign to obtain $250,000 for the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service, it was announced yesterday at the first report luncheon of the Women's Division, at the Empire State Club in the Empire State Building.

At the annual sophomore-freshmen ceremony last night Barnard College freshmen accepted a lighted torch, symbolizing their part in the carrying on of college tradition, from Phyllis Weigard, sophomore president.

Having sanctioned the immediate German occupation of more Sudeten territory than Chancellor Adolf Hitler demanded in his famous Godesberg ultimatum, the conference of Ambassadors sitting in Berlin to implement the "peace of Munich"

Coach Elton E. (Tad) Wieman has no magician's wand to rely upon at Princeton University but he already has done a job of transforming linemen into backs and vice versa with this season's football team.

BEHIND THE COUNTER, by Emily Van Brussel. (Appleton-Century, $1.50.) A handbook for sales clerks. BLACK IS My TRUE LOVE'S HAIR, by Elizabeth Madox Roberts. (Viking, $2.50.) A novel by the author of "The Time of Man."

Five persons were killed in a level crossing accident on the Canadian National Railways near Denfield today. The victims, all occupants of the one motor car were: Dr. George Racey and Miss Evelyn Mason of Parkhill, and Mr. and Mrs. Fred Wills and their adopted 5-year-old daughter of Thedford.

The one-story commercial building at 6 West Blackwell Street, Dover, N. J., was sold by the Garden State Realty Company to the Alice Arden Hosiery Company, which will hold it for investment. Leslie Blau, Inc., broker, negotiated the sale.

Amendments to the plan of reorganization of the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company have been filed with Howard B. Lewis, special master, by Percival E. Jackson of New York and David Bortin of this city, as counsel for the New York Protective Committee for Debenture Bondholders, it was disclosed today.

Bids for the Treasury's weekly offering of approximately $100,000,000 of ninety-one day bills were invited tonight by Secretary Morgenthau. The bills will be sold on the usual discount basis to the highest bidders, and will be issued in the customary denominations.

Although the number of new first mortgages on Manhattan properties recorded last month was the greatest since April, 1937, the dollar volume was the lowest for any month this year with the exception of February, according to the Real Estate Board of New York.

James H. Fay, regular Democratic nominee for Congress in the Sixteenth Manhattan District, opened his campaign last night with a radio address from his room at the French Hospital, where he has been since Primary Day.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Arthur Krock in his column today in THE NEW YORK TIMES went to the heart of our problem with Mexico. His article may be epitomized by the extracts: "Nor has Mexico's example (of expropriation of private property) as yet been imitated by any other important Latin-American country.

" Dance Night,". which has to. do with small-town boys and a reform school graduate who promises to mend his ways, has its premiere tonight at the Belasco. Kenyon Nicholson is the author and Robert Rockmore the formal sponsor.
President Roosevelt told the WPA today that its $764,000,000 of relief funds on hand would have to last until March 1, as Congress stipulated in authorizing the last relief appropriation.

Because of the violent readjustments of the depression and recovery years, the total farm and home mortgage debt of the United States has shrunk more than 18 per cent to about $25,000,000,000, according to a statement issued yesterday by the Committee on Debt Adjustment of the Twentieth Century Fund.

Bernard M. Baruch, chairman of the former War Industries Board, gave a warning today that the United States was unprepared to wage a defensive war and was thus in much the same position which United S forced Great Britain and France to accept the peace of Munich. Mr.

Representative Bruce Barton told a meeting at Temple Emanu-El last night that there were "several common misconceptions" about refugees from Central Europe and one of them was that persecution was directed only against the Jews.

MANHATTAN CURRY, PHILIP (Oct. 3). Estate, more than $10,000. To Mary F. Curry, widow, 1,225 Park Ave., life estate in residue; Mabel C. Reville, 7 Northway, Bronxville, N. Y., and Philip J. Curry, 1.225 Park Ave., children, executors, remainders in residue. Irene C. McCormack, daughter, 2 E. 93d St., executor.
The 1938 Carnegie International was opened this evening with the usual Founder's Day exercises held in honor of Andrew Carnegie. The program included announcement of the annual prize awards.

A question as to whether Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate t for Governor, is running against Governor Herbert H. Lehman or Charles Poletti, Democratic candidate for Lieutenant Governor, has been raised by voters in Representa- I tive Bruce Barton's Seventeenth Congressional District, according to Mr. Barton.

Only eleven of thirty-six departments in New York department stores registered advertising gains last month, according to a breakdown of figures by Media Records. The total for the month was 3,356,647 lines as against 3,586,449 lines for the corresponding period of 1937, a loss of 6.4 per cent.

New York University finished its practice in preparation for the North Carolina game at the Yankee Stadium tomorrow by going through a strenuous three-and-a-half-hour workout yesterday at Ohio Field. A dummy scrimmage, with emphasis on,offensive formations, occupied most of the time.

At no time today were wheat prices on the Board of Trade here as low as yesterday's closing level. Firmness in securities and buying by brokers who frequently act for cash interests absorbed commission-house and local selling.

At a special meeting of the bondholders protective committee for defaulted Straus issues, in the matter of 103 East Fifty-seventh Street Building (Ritz Towers Apartments), Roy M. Livingstone, Philadelphia attorney and vice president of the Ritz Carlton Hotel in that city, was elected chairman.

Blair's football new deal is making a big hit on the campus. With a couple of former Colgate aces, Clary Anderson and Jack Prendergast, at the helm for the first time, the academy's squad of huskies has handily blanked two rivals thus far and evidently is highly capable of continuing its string of conquests for some time.

Injuries suffered by City College players in Wednesday's scrimmage, the first contact work in practice for the Beavers since they left their pre-season camp at Tyler Hill, forced Coach Benny Friedman to revamp his backfield yesterday.

Clyde Castleman, Giant pitcher, and Miss Rebecca Paris, both of suburban Donelson, were married yesterday morning, it was announced tonight. The ceremony was held before the Rev. Guard Green in Donelson.

Wilhelm Morgenstierne, Norwegian Minister to the United States, who arrived yesterday on the Norwegian-America liner. Oslofjord on his way to Washington, said the partition of Czelhoslovakia had sharpened Norway's distrust of outside aid in a crisis and her sense of dependence on herself, alone.

Max Kaplan, controller of Alexander's, Bronx specialty store, will describe features in the low-cost operation of his establishment at a meeting of the Metropolitan Controllers Association at the Roger Smith Restaurant, 40 East Forty first Street, next Wednesday evening.

Freddie Bartholomew, juvenile screen star, made his Broadway debut as a vaudeville headliner yesterday at the Loew's State Theatre, where he will appear for one week. The supporting cast includes the Three Swifts, comedy trio; Allen and Croel, song and dance team;
Lumber production advanced contra-seasonally last week, and the adjusted index advanced to 75.1 from 72.4. The figure was 76.1 in the week ended Oct. 9, 1937.

Late this Fall International will publish another autobiographical volume by William Z. Foster. Unlike his previous book, "From Bryan to Stalin," which was largely an impersonal history of the left wing labor movement, the new volume is an intimate collection of sketches of experiences during more than half a century.

Stocks closed strong and active at highest levels in more than a year and with gains of 1 to 4 points; turnover, 2,360,520 shares. Corporation bonds generally higher, United States Government issues steady; transactions, $9,068,000.

As each successive effort at agricultural "planning" collapses, as each new scheme proves disappointing, creates more problems than it solves or more evils than it cures, the Administration never admits the failure of the scheme and proposes to abandon it. Instead,

Figures of the British Board of Trade for September follow: Total imports, [pound]75,000,000; exports of British products, [pound]39,800,000; reexports, [pound]4,030,000; total exports, [pound]43,830,000; excess of imports, [pound]31,170,000.

The general level of wholesale prices declined in the week ended on Oct. 8, th Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. This average, based on the 1926 level as 100, was 77.8, compared with 78.0 on Oct. 1 and 86.0 on Oct. 9, 1937.
The Mexican Government is buying from our Government 3,000,000 bushels of wheat at less than the market price. Our Government-i. e., our taxpayerswill take the loss.

The Federal Music Project tried its hand at opera again last night, making public an English version of Flotow's "Martha" at its Music Theatre. The advance notices had promised a "modern production," and one looked for something as hot off the griddle as the current swing treatment of the big tenor air from the opera.

Three officials of two bus corporations which had contracts with the government to transport WPA workers to the Orchard Beach project in the Bronx received prison sentences ranging - from eighteen months to two years when they appeared yesterday before Federal Judge Edward A. Conger, following their recent conviction on charges of defrauding the government of $25,000.
Surplus commodity purchasing programs for ice, cane syrup, topped beets and carrots were announced today by the Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation.

MANHATTAN ARNSTEIN, SIGMUND (March 13, 1936). Gross assets, $502,979; net, $437,480. To Congregation Orach Chaim. $500; Mary T. Bourke, $18,000 in trust; Herman Hyman, $10,000; Stella A. Hyman, daughter, $15, 000 contingent interests in several trusts and residuary estate: Nathan Arnstein,

Warm weather caused Coach Earr Blaik to give his Dartmouth football charges one of the lightest workouts of the season today. There was no contact work and the varsity watched some of the Brown plays demonstrated by the jayvees in slow motion.

Stock companies formed in September totaled 1,127, an increase of thirty-seven over the same month last year, the division of corporations of the Department of State announced today. For the nine months the total was 11,837 compared with 13,571.

Coach Jim Crowley sent his Fordham football squad through its last hard workout yesterday in preparation for the intersectional battle with Purdue at the Polo Grounds tomorrow. Calisthenics, work on the blocking and tackling dummies a defensive scrimmage against Purdue aerials and a brisk signal drill constituted the session.

Oliver French, president of the Rochester International League Baseball Club, said today the Red Wings had purchased Stanley (Frenchy) Bordagaray, outfielder with the Cardinals and Dodgers the last four years, from the Cardinals for an undisclosed sum.
The through trains to Boston and Portland are running again. Most of the blocked highways have been opened, bridges have been repaired and the fallen trees are being chopped up into firewood.

The role of the consumer is one of the major factors in heated discussions of the Patman bill to levy an excise tax on all chain store organizations in the country which now animate food trade circles, it was learned yesterday,
Charles W. Deeds has resigned as vice president and director of the United Aircraft Corporation to become president and a director of the new Chandler-Evans Corporation, manufacturer of carburetors.

Socialized medicine in Soviet Russia has made vast progress in the last nine years, it was said yesterday by Dr. Ralph A. Reynolds of San Francisco, who has just returned from his third visit to the Soviets since 1929.

The mystery of the murder of Mary Imelda Coyle after a criminal attack Monday night seemed farther from solution than ever tonight when it became known that the strands of brown -hair found clutched in the victim's hand were probably her own.
William Davidson, retired president of the International Steel Company of New York, died today at his home of complications from a fall he sustained in August. His age was 81.

Pending determination of appeals to the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court the hearing scheduled for today before the Public Service Commission on its proposed investigation of the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation was postponed.
The Census Bureau reported today that cottonseed crushed in the twomonth period, Aug. 1 to Sept. 30, totaled 799,189 tons, compared with 979,107 tons, in the corresponding period a year before.

The ocean freight rate to St. Croix, .Virgin Islands, on shipments from New York routed through San Juan and transferred here for re-shipment is less than the rate on the same commodities delivered at San Juan, according to testimony delivered before the Maritime Commission at today's hearing on ocean freight rates.

New York City's share of the $15,000,000 WPA clothing purchase will be divided equally among persons from the home and work relief rolls, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, announced yesterday. Distribution will begin Monday, but the total allotment for this city has not yet been determined.

Mrs. Elvina Cutts Bartlett, who celebrated her 100th birthday on June 4, died yesterday at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Carrington Hening of 21 Trinity Place, following a week's illness. Born in Pittston, Me., Mrs. Bartlett was a descendant of Lord William Cutts and Lady Ursula Cutts, who established their home on an island off Kittery, Me., in 1623. Her husband,

A loophole in the new Customs Administrative Act by which importers of products from Germany, Japan or any other nation could bring in merchandise not marked with the country of origin, is expected to provide the basis for a test case before the United States Customs Court here this Fall.

While material designed to tell the public the part distribution plays in the national economy will be included in the proposed national broadcast featuring the New York Philharmonic Orchestra, retail executives said yesterday that methods for preparing such material had not yet been worked out.

Andre Eglevsky, premier danseur of the American Ballet Company, will dance before the Bronx Ballet Club of Hunter College in the auditorium at the Bronx buildings this afternoon. He will illustrate by his dances the three eras of balletthose of Petipas, Fokine and Massine. Irving Deakin,

A mob today seized R. C. Williams, 19year-old Negro suspected of slaying a white man and beating his woman companion, refused to turn him over to the Sheriff, hanged him to a pine tree and riddled his body with bullets.

Robert C. Morris, for many years one of the leading members of the New York bar, died last night in Doctors Hospital after a short illness. Mr. Morris, who lived at the Union League Club, was 69 years old.

SO many road-company Hemingways have swarmed down the highways since some of the forty-nine Hemingway stories in this collection* first appeared that it is a pleasure and a revelation to see the original company again. Surely, no other author of this century has helped to make the reputation of such a lot of writers.

President Roosevelt expects to leave Washington on Saturday for another fortnight at his family home at Hyde Park, it was announced by the White House today. Departing from his custom of travel at night-time, the President plans to board his train about noon so as to make the trip by day.

Coach Jack Blott will take a Wesleyan squad of about twenty-five men to Haverford tomorrow to play the Quaker team on Saturday. The coaches will hold some of the first string material in reserve if, possible, not wishing to invite injuries with the important Amherst'and Trinity games coming so soon.

Tomorrow will mark the opening of the duck season in New York, and unless reports are incorrect, the wildfowlers in this area are in for one of the best seasons in years. In addition to ducks and geese, the season also will open on woodcock in the southern part of the State and in New Jersey.

Headquarters for the campaign of John Lord O'Brian, Buffalo attorney nominated for United States Senator from New York on the Republican ticket, will be opened today at the Hotel Roosevelt. Commeeting yesterday on his nomination Mr O'Brian said:

A voluntary organization of journalists, copywriters, artists, layout men, typographers and specialists in market research has been formed here with the title, Gray's Publicity, to use "the technique of modern publicity in the cause of peace and democracy."

The Masonite corporation in its report for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31, made public yesterday, showed a net. profit of $1,144,274 after depreciation, interest, Federal and State income taxes and other charges.
Registration throughout the city continued to pick up slightly yesterday as 356,753 persons qualified to vote in the November elections by registering on the fourth day.

110th St, 27-29 E, 46.10x100.11, 27 Holding Corp to Woman's Hospital in State of N. Y,. 141 W 109th St; p m mtg, 5 yrs, 31/2%; $40,500. 117th St, 47 W, 25x100.11; Jarus Realty Co, Inc, to Bankers Trust Co: trustee Henry D. Hotchkiss for benefit Alice C. Hotchkiss; due Oct. 1, 1943. 4%: 8,000.

The National Food and Grocery Conference Committee, meeting at the Palmer House late today, telegraphed Secretary of Agriculture Wallace, requesting a conference at the earliest possible moment on his program to distribute food to the underprivileged at subsidized low prices.

The Chinese this morning claim another outstanding success against the Japanese southwest of the key town of Yangsin. A communique says that a Japanese force of several thousands attempting to advance westward was defeated in the Yenkang highlands, suffering "2,000 killed" in a fourday battle. "One thousand bodies"

Premium Service Company. Inc. addltonal floor of 7,500 square feet at 7-9 W 18th St; S. Knitzer, retail hardware, in 707 Broadway; Benjamin W. Gammon, tools and dies, in 205 E 22d St; Manhattan Wire Goods Co, floor in 171-75 8th Ave; Central Silk Hosiery Co, in 349 5th Ave; Harle Publications, Inc. in 220 5th Ave; Spear Co, Inc, broker.
Following the example of Governor Lehman, Tammany Leader Christopher D. Sullivan filed with the Board of Elections yesterday his declination of the nomination of the City Fusion party.

In a move toward a "clean-up" ordered more than a year ago by President Roosevelt, the Federal Communications Commission today ousted Hampson Gary of Texas as its general counsel, supplanting him by William J. Dempsey, youthful protege of Thomas G. Corcoran.
E. C. Segar, artist and creator of the comic strip character, "Popeye the Sailor," died at his home here tonight after an illness of six months. His age was 44. He recently underwent an operation.

After spending almost the entire day yesterday on a discussion of financing the $28,000,000 Circumferential Parkway, the Board of Estimate finally voted for an immediate start on the project and voted to draw the necessary funds from other items in the city's capital outlay budget.
The following Coast Guard changes for the week orded Oct. 12 were announced today: COMMANDER Grenspun, J.. headquarters, to command the Campbell instead the Pontchartrain.

The League of New York Theatres received at its annual meeting yesterday the first complaints under the new ticket code. The first accused a ticket broker of allegedly "pushing" the sale of tickets for one revue to the detriment of a second revue.
Turpentine firm, 21 3/4c; sales, 10 barrels: receipts, 650 barrels; shipments, 1,416 barrels; stock, 49,817 barrels. Rosin firm; sales, 582; receipts, 3,02?' shipments, 3,635; stock, 264,452.

The Society of Amateur Chefs, composed of men whose hobby is preparing and serving their own favorite victuals, held its first organizational meeting yesterday afternoon in Parlor C at the Hotel New Yorker.
Considerable doubt still prevailed today concerning Cornell's right guard selection for the game at Syracuse Saturday. Senior Jack Hemingway has re-entered the fight with Kirk Hershey and may start.

Two distinct waves of buying swept over the stock market yesterday and pushed prices to the best levels of the year. The session on the Stock Exchange proved to be the largest and broadest, in both stocks and bonds, since last Thursday as trading aggregated 2,360,000 shares against 1,534,000 shares on Tuesday.

" Let Freedom Ring," a pioneer farming story prepared for the screen by Ben Hecht, will be Nelson Eddy's next vehicle, Metro announced today. Jack Conway will direct, and production is scheduled for November; no feminine player has been cast as yet.

ABRAHAM-Bernard, suddenly, beloved husband of Sophie (nee Sussman), dear brother of Henry, Saul, Anne Newman, Harry and Carl. Funeral services, 11 A. M., Friday, Oct. 14, at Midtown Chapel, 171 West 85th St.

Elected for his fourteenth successsive term as president of the American Federation of Labor, William Green appealed today to the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, the United Textile Workers of America,

After giving Detective Hyman Levine and two Treasury Department agents a demonstration of how to bleach $1 bills so as to convert them into $20 bills, according to the police, two men who said they were Samuel Cooper, 57 years old,

Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street, 11:30 A. M. "The American Scene," George Earle Raiguel. Fourth Northeastern Poultry Producers Council Exposition and Convention, Port Authority Building, Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street, opens with luncheon at noon.

Although the United States has no direct interest in the former German colonies, having taken none of them after the war, a nation-wide. survey conducted by the American Institute of Public Opinion, of which Dr. George Gallup is director, indicates that the American public is markedly unsympathetic: to German claims for her old territories.

A huge cash register, more than forty feet high, will ring up the daily and total attendance at the World's Fair in six-foot figures, Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation, announced yesterday.

Over 450 guests are expected to attend the eleventh annual alumnae week-end at Smith College, which will be held on the campus from tomorrow through Sunday. A special invitation has been etended to pre-college students interested in Smith, and about 100 are expected to take advantage of this school day which was formerly held in the Spring.
Herman Apple of 605 West 170th Street, senior trustee and former president of the Temple of the Covenant, died Wednesday in the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary after an operation. He was 73 years old.

The appointment of the first woman faculty member at the Case School of Applied Science in Cleveland was announced today by Dr. W. E. Wickenden, president. The appointee is Dr. Irene Levis, a former member of the faculty at the

The purpose of merchandise Is considered to be the most important guide to a decision as to where in a department store it should be sold, according an analysis of overlapping departments, based on a national survey in which 150 merchandising executives cooperated, made public yesterday by the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Running exactly as the betting indicated, Transmitter, former Joseph E. Widener color-bearer now carrying the colors of Mrs. J. H. McCoole, was first yesterday in the Sennings Park Purse, main event at Jamaica. All pre-race indications were that Torchlight would be the favorite, and Transmitter one of the lesser liked horses.
Jack Auerbach and Samuel Ginsberg were the brokers in the recently recorded sale of the apartment house at 910 Riverside Drive to Charles Walzer, operator, by the Shelby Realty Corporation.

Justice Francis D. McCurn, Democrat, who has just been endorsed by both major parties for a full term on the Supreme Court bench, was thrown into the spotlight of State politics today when Governor Lehman announced his appointment to preside over a special term of court to investigate conditions in Kings County.

Just one less than half of this year's entering class at Princeton have voted that Adolf Hitler is the "greatest living person." Prime Minister Chamberlain won the election by getting all the other votes.
A 2 1/2 per cent Dutch bond issued in 1624 and on which interest never has been defaulted is owned by the New York Stock Exchange.

Mr. and Victor Harris will give a dance on Nov. 23 at Sherry's for their debutante daughter, Miss Mary Grace Harris, for whom an afternoon reception will be given by her parents the following day, Thanksgiving Day, at their home, 405 Park Avenue..

Twenty-seven Manhattan football players will leave New York at 10:10' o'clock this morning for Providence, where they will meet Providence'College tomorrow. This will be the Jaspers' second visit to New England, the team having travelled to Worcester last Saturday to meet Holy Cross.

The American-bred bitch Queen's Fearnot Rouge, owned and handled by Buell Hollister of New York, won the open all-age stake for English springer spaniels, concluding event of the fourth annual Bath County field trials, today.

Inspired by the plea from Pope Pius XI for an educational system "to meet the challenge of these critical times," the Roman Catholic hierarchy of the United States made plans today for the inclusion in curricula of all its schools and colleges of study courses emphasizing the democratic ideals underlying a representative republic.
President Seymour today awarded to thirteen members of the class of 1941 at Yale the New York Yale Club prizes and charms at a meeting of the freshman faculty. The winners were:

Members of the American Association for Adult Education were urged yesterday in a letter sent out by Morse A. Cartwright, director, to aid the National Committee to Abolish Postal Discrimination Against Books, 285 Madison Avenue, in its campaign to induce the President to reduce postal rates for the mailing of books.

State income taxpayers who are paying in installments must have their final payment of the 1937 return in the mail before midnight tomorrow, Wesley M. Dawson, district supervisor of the Income Tax Division of the State Tax Department, warned yesterday.

When Syrian affairs come up for discussion between Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet and the Iraq Minister next Monday it is thought here that the status of the Mufti of Jerusalem, now in exile in the French mandate, will be one of the questions raised.

Dr. John R. Caulk, urologist and Professor of Clinical Genito-Urinary Surgery at Washington University School of Medicine since 1914, died today of complications after a long illness. He was 56 years old.

Mrs. Rebecca Henning McNab of Schenectady was installed last night as Grand Matron of the Order of the Eastern Star in the State at the closing session of the three-day annual meeting of the order at the Hotel Astor.

With the clouds of European war receding the upward spiral of business is again well under way, Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the boards of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York and the Niagara Hudson Power Company,

Twenty-four conferees endeavored for six hours yesterday afternoon to resolve satisfactorily the controversy centering about demands by tugboat employes for a new wage contract. The meeting finally was adjourned until 2:30 P. M. today with the problem of higher wages unsolved.

The proposed merger of the Mobile Ohio and the Gulf, Mobile Northern Railroad was advanced yesterday at a meeting here of the directors of the latter company. I. B. Tigrett, president of the G. M. N., said after the meeting that his directors would meet again on Oct. 26,
Movements of vessels follow (all dates are Oct. 13, unless specified): Manila to Southern Island: Bulmer, Paul Jones. At Hong Kong: Canopus, Pigeon, S-36, 37, 38, 39. 40, 41.

Manhattan Alterations Thompson St, 176; to 6-story tenement and store; One Mond Corp, 551 5th Ave, owner R. R. Rahman, architect; cost, $6.000. Stanton St, 62; to 5-story tenement and store; G. Neglla Sons; Inc, premises, owner; S. A. Hertz, architect; cost, 9th St, 25 W; to 4-story tenement, estate of Anna P. Fuller, premises, owner; W. J. Russell, architect; cost, 43,000.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Oct. 11: REAR ADMIRAL Johnson, A W., Commander Training Detachment United States fleet, on Oct. 10. to duty as Commander Atlantic Squadron.

Early trading only fair to slow on all classes in local markets yesterday. Lamb barely steady to lower, calf hindsaddles steady to slightly higher, pork barely steady to lower, other classes mostly steady. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

GOVERNORS ISLAND 1st Lt. Wallace P. Wolf. Inf.-Res., 15 Featherbed Lane, New York, N. Y., is ordered to active duty with the CCC for six months, effective Oct. 13, at Camden, N. Y., reporting upon arrival to the commanding officer, CCC Co. 3264c, Camp S-113, lor CCC duty. Date of rank, Sept. 29, 1938.
Representative John J. O'Connor received $14,875 and spent $6,540 in his primary campaign last month, according to a final statement filed yesterday with the Board of Elections.

Johnny Mundinger's Censor scored his third straight victory today when the Victorian gelding took the Newport Purse at Narragansett Park by a length from J. L. MacKnight's Slavonia as the twentyseven-day Fall meeting opened.

Japanese forces, advancing rapidly in their South China invasion, today occupied Tamshui, twenty miles from the Canton-Kowloon Railway, and were converging on Waichow before noon. Waichow is about seventy miles east of Canton.

Radio and telephone, sirens, whistles and church bells spread the "blackout alarm" tonight to about a fourth of the State of North Carolina and sixty-six.villages and towns in twenty-one counties were plunged into darkness for about forty-five minutes in the largest air raid defense test ever held in this country.

A. W. Robertson, chairman of the board of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, will welcome engineers from all over the country when they convene in Pittsburgh next week for the fourth annual convention of the National Society of Professional Engineers. Speakers prominent in the field of engineering and education will address the convention.

Although declining to comment on what the future may have in store for him and, in fact, stoutly professing he knew of no immediate plans that would keep him in baseball, Babe Ruth took time out from his golf yesterday to send his hearty best wishes to the Dodgers,

Mrs. Caroline O'Day, Democratic candidate for re-election as Representative at Large from New York, officially opened headquarters yesterday in the Hotel Biltmore. Her campaign, she said, will begin in Buffalo on Monday, when she will speak at a luncheon of Buffalo Democratic women, to be followed by atalk at a peace rally.

With registration still in progress in some divisions, the total enrollment in the Winter session of Columbia University is expected to exceed last year's figures of 18,852 by about 4 per- cent, Edward J. Grant, registrar, announced yesterday.

Vernon S. Campbell, 44 years old, a Negro, who has been a court room attendant for eleven years in the Municipal Court, has been appointed assistant clerk in the Ninth District Municipal Court, 624 Madison Avenue, at a salary of $3,000 a year, it was made known yesterday. Recently he has been an attendant at the Central Jury Court.

J. Sigfrid Edstrom, one of Sweden's leading industrialists, sailed a last night for France on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen after a three-week tour of this country. Mr. Edstrom, who is chairman of the Swedish-American Foundation, studied means of fostering continued amity between the Scandinavian countries and the United States.

Sleepy Jim Crowley of Fordham told the members of the Touchdown Club yesterday at its Fordham-Columbia luncheon at the Columbia Club that he still was keeping his fingers crossed, unwilling to assay his Ram eleven until after the test with Purdue tomorrow at the Polo Grounds.
Henry Jackson, pianist; will give a, recital tonight at 8:30 in Town Hall. The recital of Leona Flood, violinist, which was scheduled for this afternoon in Town Hall has been canceled.

The slump in gilt-edge issues, which has continued almost without interruption since the brief halt following the panic over the crisis in Central Europe, further depressed the stock markets here today.

The Brooklyn College football team climaxed its practice yesterday with a forty-five-minute signal drill in preparation for tomorrow's game with Rensselaer Poly Tech. The drill started with a passing session for the backs, in which Irv Roth,

Because, according to a ruling of the court, she was a trespasser upon railroad property when a train she had boarded to see a friend off started, the $30,000 injury suit brought by Mrs. Edward L. Kjeldson against the Pennsylvania-Reading Seashore Lines was dismissed today by Judge Wilfred H. Jayne in Atlantic County Circuit Court here, on motion of counsel for the railroad.
A press release from the Commerce Department, in discussing the distribution by countries of Unit-ed States electrical exports, classed New England as a foreign country. Said the release:

A banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will offer today a new issue of $7,900,000 city of Utica, N. Y., 2.75 per cent and 2.60 per cent water supply revenue bonds, due annually, in varying amounts, from Oct. 1, 1940 to 1973.

Possible influence on the shares of the Reiter-Foster Oil Corporation by persons concerned in their underwriting and distribution marked yesterday the Securities and Exchange Commission's stop-order proceedings against that company.

The first general meeting of the film division of the Theatre Arts Committee (TAC) will be held this evening at the Hotel Astor. Among the speakers scheduled are Sylvia Sidney, Richard Watts Jr., Harold Rome, Leif Erickson,

Hassan Sidky Dajany, a leading figure in Palestine Arab politics and a member of the Jerusalem Municipal Council, was found shot dead this morning on the railway line between Jerusalem and the Lydda function.

Japan's drive against the railroads around Canton, long expected by exporters here, materialized this week and yesterday foreign traders awaited word that alternate routes to the interior of China will be utilized by the Chinese.
Everywhere in Czechoslovakia there are signs of a retreat from the democratic system. It was announced today that all Freemason lodges in Czechoslovakia had decided on self-dissolution.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

The plan of the Railway Labor Unions for rehabilitating the railroads, as presented today in testimony of George M. Harrison of the Association of Railway Labor Executives before a Presidential fact-finding commission, is given herewith in stenographic transcript:

First introduction of women's hosiery manufactured from the new du Pont fiber, designated as 66 yarn, will probably be made at the World's Fair here next year, W. A. Hart, director of advertising of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., reported here yesterday.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., Oct. 16: PATROLMEN-Ambrose J. Cronin. 13th Precinct, assigned to duty as attendant. David H. Dick, from Traffic Precinct F to 108th Precinct. James A. Byers, from 18th Division, M. O. D. D. to Telegraph Bureau, assignment to duty in Bureau of Information discontinued.

A decision in favor of the defendants on all points was handed down yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente in the $10,600,000 rescission suit brought by the bankruptcy trustees of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway (the Frisco) against Edward N. Brown,

A "broad - scale rehabilitation program" designed to contribute to the solution of the financial problems of American railroads was laid before President Roosevelt's factfinding board today by the eighteen labor organizations which represent the railroad workers of the country.

Sales of General motors cars and trucks to dealers in the overseas markets during September totaled 27,608 units, a decline of 8.3 per cent from sales in September of last year, the corporation disclosed yesterday. In the first nine months of 1938 sales of 273,599 units represented a decline of 1.1 per cent from sales in the first nine months of 1937.
Harry W. Faath is in the municipal retail sales department of Tripp Co. The firm of Hession, Maher Griscom celebrated its second anniversary with a dinner last night in the Pennsylvania Hotel.
The War Department issued the following orders today dated Oct. 12: COLONEL North, E., Engrs., 3 days extension of leave. LIEUTENANT COLONELS
George Dobson, correspondent of The Times of London in St. Petersburg for twenty-five years at the end of the last century and at the outbreak of the Russian revolution, died in London today.

Mr. Priestley is still speculating about time in "I Have Been Here Before," which was politely spoken at the Guild Theatre last evening. Under the influence of J. W. Dunne's theories he wrote "Time and the Conways" last year; it was a success in London and a failure here. "I Have Been Here Before,"

Executive meetings of official boards opened the sixty-fifth annual convention of the State Woman's Christian Temperance Union here today. About 400 delegates and 100 observers are expected to be present tomorrow, when Mrs. D. Leigh Colvin of New York, president, opens the sessions, which will continue to Monday evening...
After a search for four and a half years Bronx detectives arrested three men last night in the shooting of a man in an attempted hold-up of a card game in the Bronx on May 6, 1934. The prisoners,

To get pointers for governing her West Indian colonies, where there has been more unrest in the past year than in the previous century, Britain is sending a royal commission headed by Lord Moyne to study in Puerto Rico and St. Croix, the Virgin Islands.
James P. Lardner definitely is not a prisoner in Franco territory and officially nothing is known about him, inquiries disclosed today.

Eight officials of Linden, including Mayor Myles J. McManus, three former officials and an Elizabeth real estate dealer were arraigned here today. before Common Pleas Judge Edward A. McGrath on indictments returned recently by the May term of the Union County grand jury in connection with a Supreme Court Commissioner's investigation of the financial affairs of Linden.

James Tilden Crane, a lawyer in Stamford for the last twenty-six years and clerk of the City Court since 1933, died late last night at his home here after an illness of more than a year. He was 62 years old.

Still aiming to have his team in prime condition for Army, Coach Dick Harlow again today confined the Harvard workout to defensive drills against the Cadets' running attack and passes. He also asked for more speed and precision in the Crimson's execution of its own attack.

Leaders of the Democratic organization, both State and local, took steps yesterday to meet the threatened revolt of Roman Catholic Democrats which, if it should increase, may cost Governor Lehman, candidate for re-election on the Democratic and American Labor party ticket, thousands of votes.
The following Marine Corps changes for the weel ended Oct. 12 were announced today: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Ames. E. O., Olongao, P. I., to Navy Yard, Cavite. P. I.
Police Chief Alfred Rarich of Rockaway returned with his wife and their daughter, Shirley, 16 years old, to their home here last night after having been absent for a week, on a vacation.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has given approval to a revised plan by the Republic Electric Power Corporation and six subsidiaries, involving reorganization and recapitalization, the companies having consented as part of the plan to an order in conformity with Section 11 (b) of the Public Utility

The death knell of standardized public school buildings, long denounced as "factories" by Board of Education officials, has been sounded, and a new era, in which "beautiful" schools are to be constructed, has opened for New York City, Ellsworth B. Buck, vice president of the board, announced yesterday.
Two boys, accused of cutting a double swastika into the forearm of a 9-year-old Jewish boy, were lectured on Americanism by Judge Thomas J. Holleran in a closed session of police court tonight.

Special Notice The monthly life insurance assessment will be reduced from $3 to $2, effective Jan. 1, 1939. To Fire Hazard Inspectors' School The following members shall be directed to report at the Fire Harard Inspectors' School, 32-02 Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, at 1:15 P. M. on the dates specified:

The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company announced yesterday it was taking over the manufacture of buttweld pipe and the distribution of lap and buttweld pipe from the Clayton Mark Company and would set up the equipment purchased from that company in its plant at Indiana Harbor, Ind.

A tract of 1,000 acres in the Kittatinny Mountains of New Jersey about fourteen miles from Port Jervis, N. Y., has been acquired by Life Camps, Inc., the fifty-twoyear-old organization sponsored by Life Magazine, it was announced yesterday by Dr.. Lloyd Burgess Sharp, director.

James O. Moore, general campaign manager for Thomas E. Dewey, and Oswald D. Heck, his up-State campaign manager, united yesterday in declaring that the influence of the "Old Guard" was at an end in the party councils.
Coach Hooks Mylin drilled the Lafayette varsity in Washington and Jefferson plays today as practice was speeded for the opening home contest on Saturday.

Trial of the government's suit to enjoin the Aluminum Company of America and its subsidiaries from alleged violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Law was resumed yesterday before Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey after a Summer adjournment.
Hungary walked out of the conference with the Czechoslovaks on her territorial demands yesterday and submitted the dispute to the four powers that drafted the Munich settlement.
Conservation of the power resources of New York State was the theme this afternoon for the most intensive debate in recent years in the ranks of the League of Women Voters.

Another slow and lower hog market today dropped the top to ?8, lowest since December, 1937, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Fat lambs also were lower in a slow trade. All slaughter classes of cattle sold generally steady in a dependable cleanup trade, but prime steers and yearlings were absent.

Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on Oct. 1 aggregated 280,852,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines. Compared with figures of the preceding week, this total represents an increase of 574,000 barrels, consisting of a rise of 684,000 barrels in stocks of domestic crude, but a decrease of 110,000 barrels in stocks of foreign crude.

A statement condemning the making of profits from war and calling for the sacrifice of such profits by groups that might benefit was issued yesterday by the National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church at the close of its three-day quarterly meeting at its headquarters, 281 Fourth Avenue. The council asked church agencies to take steps to win supnnrt for such a policy.

In connection with its survey of land subdivisions throughout the State, the New Jersey State Planning Board yesterday reported that the Delaware Bay region, taking in Salem and Cumberland Counties, has "suffered little as yet from urban land speculation,"

The offer of John L. Lewis, president of the- United Mine Workers and chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, to resign from the latter position in the interests of labor peace if William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor,

Three insurance companies on Sept. 1 bought $40,000,000 of fifteen-year 3 per cent sinking fund debentures, due in 1953, of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation, a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission revealed yesterday.

Sounding a keynote of cooperation with the Securities and Exchange Commission and pledging the wholehearted support of the Electric Bond and Share Company in working out the provisions of Section 11 of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, C. E. Groesbeck,

Eugene F. Moran, president of the Moran Towing and Transportation Company, was reelected president of the Whitehall Club yesterday at its annual meeting. The following also were elected: Vice presidents, Frederick T. Fisher of the Corn Products Company and Andrew Baxter Jr. of the Federal

Jack Haden and Jim Lee Howell, who were teammates on the Arkansas University eleven, have won starting berths on the Giants' team, it was announced yesterday by Coach Steve Owen following the extensive drill at the Polo Grounds.
Reasons why the business improvement which began in the early Summer should continue into 1939 were listed by A. W. Zelomek, economist of the International Statistical Bureau, Inc.,

While sufficient progress has not been achieved to know the final answer on copytesting, it should be used whenever there is a choice between relying on one's judgment or on public reaction, J. E. Wiley, vice president of Fuller Smith Ross, Inc.,

Joseph P. Kennedy, United States Ambassador, called today on Viscount Halifax, British Foreign Secretary, at the Foreign Office and on Malcolm MacDonald, Colonial Secretary, for a discussion of the Palestine situation.

Miss Laddie Irwin, 19-year-old Glen Ridge star, annexed the low-gross prize in the Women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day tournament today when she scored 43, 40-83 on the beautifully groomed Forsgate Country Club course. Her mother, Mrs. H. E. Irwin, won the low-net award for her score of 10422-82.
Domestic copper prices again were advanced 1/2 cent a pound yesterday to 11.25 cents, making the second advance in two days. Previously this month there had been three increases of 1/8 cent each.

Elmer Hackney, Kansas State's "one-man gang," was just that when he carried the ball six consecutive times on a 32-yard march that brought a touchdown and a 6-to-0 victory over Marquette tonight before 13,000.

" As Prime Minister Chamberlain stepped from the plane which brought him from Munich," says a London dispatch to THE TIMES, "he remarked to a friend that if there had not been 'this new means of traveling swiftly war would have occurred."
The leading foreign exchanges recovered slightly yesterday from their recent sharp declines, but the engagements of gold abroad for shipment here increased.

Deputy Joseph Rosse, described in recent Paris press comments as the "Henlein of Alsace," today addressed a letter to Camille Chautemps, who is the Cabinet member charged with the affairs of Alsace-Lorraine, hotly denying that either he or his party in Alsace were raising the question of autonomy at this time. In an editorial in his newspapers he asserted:

The volume of prospective business for the steel construction industry is showing an encouraging trend, according to a report by T. H. Hendrix, director of statistics of the American Institute of Steel Construction, delivered today at the institute's annual convention here.

The British Institute of Public Opinion, which found that 76 per cent of the rank and file of voters interviewed in Great Britain opposed return to Germany of the prewar German colonies, conducted its survey a year ago, it was pointed out yesterday.
The Brooklyn College football team will seek its first victory in its four year rivalry with Rensselaer Poly today on the Engineers' home grounds at Troy.

In the absence of any official reaction from the other governments concerned, the State Department marked time today in its consideration of Ecuador's proposal for mediation in the boundary dispute with Peru. Jose Richling, the Uruguayan Minister, called on Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles for a general discussion of the proposal.

Between 8,000 and 9,000 Jews in Palestine who are citizens of the United States laid plans today for a conference of all Jewish-American investors in the Holy Land to indicate to the British and United States Governments their objection to any restrictions against Jewish immigration in Palestine.

Eastern Gas and Fuel Associates sent yesterday to shareholders a notice referring to the decision of the directors in August to omit the dividend due on Oct. 1 on the company's 4 1/2 per cent prior preference U stock.

An explosion seriously damaged the stratosphere balloon Star of Poland early today and a projected ascension was postponed until next year. The builders had hoped the gigantic balloon would rise fifteen miles above sea level.

Miss Lucile Evelina du Pont, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irenee du Pont of Granogue, was married to Robert B. Flint of Wilmington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Scott H. Flint of West Cornwall, Conn., tonight in the Cathedral Church of St. John. The Rev. Hiram R. Bennett, dean of the cathedral, officiated.

Business recovery should gain speed and holiday volume should be very satisfactory, now that the European situation has been temporarily settled, Henry H. Heimann, Executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, declares in his monthly review released today to the association's 20,000 member concerns in banking, manufacturing and wholesaling fields.

A political party is and should be known by its principles and the manner in which it performs its promises. The Democratic party has not rested on promises but has redeemed those promises by performance.

The pending State elections will be commented on in some of the city's pulpits tomorrow. Many pastors will preach on the European situation. There will be special events in a number of parishes. Several Episcopal churches will hear sermons by Bishops or other ecclesiasts in high office. Some of the Protestant churches will observe the day as Missionary Sunday.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has called a hearing for Nov. 1 on an application of the New York Stock Exchange to strike from listing the 4 1/2 per cent first mortgage gold bonds due on June 1, 1943, of the Staten Island Railway Company.

Deposits in the mutual savings banks of this State rose $25,472,435 in the third quarter of this year to a total of $5,361,794,941 on Sept. 30, according to the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York.

Excessive division of land into building lots in New Jersey is likely to result in losses mounting into the millions, the New Jersey State Planning Board warned yesterday, pointing to a recent survey of platted lands in New York which revealed, the board said,

The map speaks more eloquently than words as to the desirability of the Brooklyn-Queens Circumferential Parkway, approved by the Board of Estimate on Thursday after a battle royal from which Mayor La Guardia, Park Commissioner Moses, Borough Presidents Ingersoll and Harvey and Controller McGoldrick all-seem to have emerged as victors.

Guy la Chambre, Air Minister, informed a Senate commission today that the government was preparing a complete overhaul of aviation affairs and that it was likely a new plan would be ready in a few weeks.

Supreme Court Justice Mitchell May in Brooklyn granted yesterday a permanent injunction restraining the Essar Gas Stations, Inc., 460 Kings Highway, Brooklyn, from selling motor fuel products of the Socony Company at a price less than that fixed by the manufacturer under a fair trade agreement.

The approximate. status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
Although making only two first downs to 10, the West Chester Teachers scored two touchdowns tonight for a 12-to-0 victory over La Salle College before a crowd of 8,000.

Urging Corn Belt farmers to fight enemies of "the best national program agriculture ever had," Secretary Wallace warned them today against alternative proposals which he said were aimed to destroy agricultural adjustment.

Coq Bruyere, owned by John Strawbridge of Philadelphia, probably will be the favorite today in the renewal of the Monmouth County Hunt Gold Cup race, feature of the thirteenth meeting of the Monmouth County Hunt Racing Association on the estate of Amory L. Haskell, near Red Bank, N. J.

Paced by its ace quarterback, Ed Rosenthal, who scored three touchdowns, the Horace Mann School eleven ushered in its campaign yesterday by overpowering Hastings High of Westchester, 34 to 0, on Horace Mann Field. The charges of Coach William (Ump) Tewhill tallied at least once in each period.
Although agreeing that sales experience this week was below that of a year ago, department store executives here yesterday varied sharply in their estimates of the extent of the decline.
Senator Robert F. Wagner filed a declination last night of the nomination by the City Fusion party for the office of Senator for the full term.
John Strachey, British author and lecturer, who has been barred from this country on the ground that he is a Communist, a charge he has denied, must remain at Ellis Island over the week-end.
Wheat futures on the Board of Trade here held today within a range of less than a cent bushel. While there was no material pressure on the market, there was likewise a lack of aggressive buying.

The number of plans for up-State construction work last month on factories, mercantile establishments and places of public assembly increased 48 per cent over the September average for the last fourteen years, the State Labor Department reported today.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES last Saturday a letter was published from a "Yankee Hater," who suggested boycotting the all-powerful New Yorkers as a means of benefiting our national pastime.

A rose point lace veil, first worh by her great-great-grandmother, Charlotte LeBrun of Paris, was a feature of the bridal costume of Miss LeBrun Cruger Rhinelander, who was married yesterday afternoon to William G. McKnight Jr.

As an old student of American customs and manners Kenyon Nicholson ought to be able to write a racy yarn about. Saturday night in a bucolic dance hall. Way back there in the old deal he wrote a gusty one called "The Barker,"

" Zoning" of thefts and training of railroad policemen have reduced looting of freight trains in recent years so that it now is 96 per cent less than in 1921, F. G. Love, superintendent of property protection of the New York Central Railroad, said last night in an address to members of the New York chapter of the Railway and Locomotive Historical Society in the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirtyninth Street.

A low record for strikes called and workers involved in any one month was set last August in this State, it was announced yesterday by Miss Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner. During the month only twenty- two strikes involving 1,454 workers were called.

United States Senator Robert F. Wagner late yesterday made a personal appeal to President Roosevelt to use his influence in an effort to obtain a reversal by the British Government of its reported determination to halt Jewish immigration into Palestine.
The Finance Ministry will introduce a bill in the National Assembly authorizing the appropriation of $1,000,000 for the purchase of arms and munitions.

Amid the crash of bombs and antiaircraft shells, Premier Juan Negrin broadcast tonight a message that was intended to go around the world in five languages, definitely rejecting all compromise proposals for ending Spain's civil war.

The marriage of Miss Alice Dunning, daughter of Mrs. Henry W. Lowe and of Clifford A. Dunning, to Henry Ashton Crosby 3d took place yesterday afternoon at the home of her mother and stepfather, Mr. Lowe, at 435 East Fifty-second Street. The Rev. Dr. Roelif H.

The gods of the winds frowned on the fishermen today, forcing postponement of the third race between Bluenose, Captain Angus Walters's Canadian sailing champion of the North Atlantic, and Captain Ben Pine's Gloucester schooner, Gertrude L. Thebaud, the challenger.
Lehman Brothers headed the banking group that yesterday purchased a new issue of $1,861,000 city, of Yonkers (N. Y.) school, equipment, general-assessment and debtequalization bonds.

Three new New York Stock Exchange partnerships have been proposed and will be considered by the committee on admissions on Oct. 27. The partnerships are Laird, Bissell Meeds and Arthur Wiesenberger Co. of this city and Keen Co. of Philadelphia.
Although restricted exclusively to the tax-exempt field, the volume of new bond financing this week was swelled to a total of $24,482,000 by the appearance of several sizable loans in that category.

A new system for flat burglaries was revealed before Judge Donnellan in General Sessions yesterday when a 17-year-old nursegirl-bride, her 19-year-old husband and another youth, a year older, pleaded guilty to larceny charges.
Department store sales in the week ended Oct. 8 were 8 per cent lower than a year ago and for the four weeks ended Oct. 8 they were 10 per cent under 1937, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The Jamestown colt, Johnstown, who recently redeemed himself in Maryland for his Futurity defeat, will be back in action on the local heath today, when he goes to the post in the $5,000-added Remsen Handicap, which may have a gross value of almost double that amount.

Lithgow Osborne, Conservation Commissioner, said today that he was having prepared for Governor Lehman's signature a proclamation closing Adirondack woods to hunters if fire hazards made it necessary.

The ten-family flat at 306 Montgomery Street, Jersey City, on a lot 25 by 100 feet, was sold by Mrs. Mary Tumulty, wife of Joseph P. Tumulty, former secretary to late President Woodrow Wilson and the other heirs of Patrick Byrne to the Permanent Builders, Inc., for a consideration shown as $5,000.

Alleging failure to comply with Section 137 of the Election Law, Henry G. Van Veen of the legal staff of Thomas E. Dewey's campaign committee filed tonight with the Secretary of State a protest against the City Fusion party's nominations of Governor Lehman and the Democratic ticket.

A jury to try two men and a woman for conspiracy to sell American military and naval secrets to Germany was completed yesterday before Federal Judge John C. Knox, after a fourth defendant, Guenther Gustav Rumrich, a former United States Army sergeant, changed his plea from not guilty to guilty, thus making himself available as a government witness.
Henry Jackson, a pianist from Princeton, Ill., who returned to this country recently after four years of study and concert appearances abroad, made his debut in a recital at Town Hall last night.
The Hungarian Government tonight ordered mobilization of five army classes totaling approximately 200,000 men after failure to obtain from Czechoslovakia satisfaction of Hungary's territorial claims.

The signs of a fundamental change in the Czechoslovak State increase daily. Following yesterday's announcement of a big revision of the diplomatic service, it is authoritatively stated today that the government has decided to change the whole electoral system.

A two-week campaign, the aim of which is to raise something more than $65,000 for the twenty-seven Lutheran welfare agencies in Greater New York, was started last night at a dinner attended by 150 laymen at St. Luke's Lutheran Church, 308 West Forty-sixth Street. The welfare agencies that will benefit are all members of the Lutheran Welfare Council.
The Manhattan College eleven, having a decided weight advantage, is favored to beat Providence College in the first football clash between the two colleges in ten years at LaSalle Field tomorrow.
The Cheshire Academy football team ended the Scarborough School's all-winning streak, which had extended through fifteen games since the start of the 1936 season, with a 2-0 triumph today.

Princeton and Pennsylvania will pick up the thread of an old rivalry at 2 o'clock in Palmer Stadium tomorrow. Over 40,000 fans are expected to watch the two teams tack the thirty-fourth game on a series that has seen little action since the turn of the century.

Clarence Halstead, former day manager of the New York office of The Associated Press, and a son of the Cincinnati editor, Murat Halstead, died Thursday in his home, at 20 Irving Place, after a short illness. He was 73 years old.

Differences of opinion as to the extent that national issues should be stressed in the State campaign were reported yesterday to have arisen between District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, and other candidates on the State-wide ticket.

The progressive legislative record of Representative James M. Mead, Democratic nominee for the unexpired two-year Senate term of the late Dr. Royal S. Copeland, was praised yesterday by Governor Lehman and others at an informal luncheon in the ballroom of the Hotel Pennsylvania. More than 200 attended.

For what is understood to be the first time in its musical history, Brussels tonight heard an American-born conductor. He was Benjamin Grosbayne, who, in the cheerful and acoustically phenomenal auditorium of the Palais des Beaux Arts, directed the season's opening concert of the Brussels Philharmonic Society.
Complete destruction of the Catholic Church is the aim of the present regime in Germany, the National Catholic Welfare Conference reported to the general meeting of Bishops here today.

Mrs. Laura Merryman Franklin, wife of Philip A. S. Franklin, chairman of the board of the United. States Lines and of the International Mercantile Marine Company, died today after a brief illness in the New York Hospital.

The cornerstone of the Harkness Chapel at Connecticut College, gift of Mrs. Edward S. Harkness of M New York, was laid this afternoon in the presence of a large gathering of students, faculty, trustees and alumnae. The event marked the beginning of the alumnae weekend activities which will continue through Sunday.
With a sales increase of more than 1,000 per cent in the first seven months of this year, the Utility Manufacturing Company, Inc., is again expanding its advertising campaign for Falcon cameras.

Cotton-mill activity last week held steady at the revised level for the previous week, although an increase was seasonal. The adjusted index has eased to 111.8 from 113.3 (revised) and compares with 116.3 for the week ended Oct. 9, 1937.

Fred Spreeman, former bookkeeper for William E. Housel, distributor for stock of the ReiterFoster Oil Corporation at one period, appeared yesterday at the Securities and Exchange Commission's hearing here into the affairs of the oil company.

Preliminary reports from eighty-seven Class One railroads, representing 79.9 per cent of total operating revenues, showed that in September those roads had estimated oprating revenues of $257,805,888, compared with $290,179,368 in September, 1937, a decrease of 11.2 per cent, the Association of American Railroads reported today.

Although there is a vast and steady migration of young people from small towns and farms to the big cities, only one-fifth of surplus rural youth will be needed in the cities in the future because of technological improvements in industry, Dr. Howard A. Dawson, director of rural service of the National Education Association, warned yesterday.

High stakes are involved for Britain and Germany, and indeed for all the great powers, in the discreet preliminary negotiations now going on between London and Berlin for the possible limitation of air armaments.
Money market remained at a standstill in the matter of business and quotations. The demand for funds was small at a schedule of rates which showed no variation.

Mgr. John L. Belford, pastor since 1905 of the Roman Catholic Church of the Nativity, Classon Avenue and Madison Street, Brooklyn, and for fifty years a priest, will be 77 today. But to him, he said yesterday, it will mean only another day in the week.

A plucky Lawrence High eleven, by virtue of several brilliant defensive stands, succeeded in holding Chaminade High of Mineola to a 0-0 tie in their game tonight at Horn Memorial Stadium. In the second period the visitors brought the ball to within one yard of a touchdown, but yielded it on downs.

Linking "New Dealism" with fascism, nazism and bolshevism as one of what he called "the four horsemen of autocracy," Representative J. Parnell Thomas, New Jersey Republican and member of the Dies Congressional committee investigating un-American activities,

Mrs. Frederick H. Brooke of Washington was re-elected president of the Girl Scout organization for her second term at the final session of the national convention here. Mrs. F. Louis Slade of New York City is the new vice chairman of the board of directors, succeeding Dr. Lillian M. Gilbreth of Montclair, and Miss Eleanor FrancesEdson, also of New York City, was elected treasurer to Succeed the late Mrs. Edgar Rickard.

Temple, battered by Pitt and Texas Christian University, came back tonight to swamp a favored Bucknell eleven, 26-0, before a crowd of 18,000. The defeat toppled Bucknell from the ranks of unbeaten teams.

Jonkheer H. M. van Haersma de With, the Netherland Minister to Washington, soon will be transferred to Berlin, according to an official statement published today. He will succeed Dr. C. Ridder van Rappard, who was killed in an automobile accident two months ago.

The Bowery Savings Bank has sold the two-story business building at 24 Grand Street, White Plains, Westchester, once the police headquarters of the city of White Plains, the former owner, to a client of Chauncey B.. Griffen, broker.
The Czechoslovak delegation to the League of Nations charged today that Hungary was attempting to provoke a revolution in Ruthenia through the activities of a terroristic organization.

Provision for construction of a "transition type" of housing as part of the Federal Housing Program to shelter families unable to change happily from rude dwellings to modern structures was suggested today at the final session of the Sixth Annual Meeting of the National Association of Housing Officials.

The Communist party withdrew its State ticket from the field yesterday and urged its members to vote for the candidates of the New Deal and the American Labor party. The Labor party previously had endorsed Governor Lehman and Charles Poletti.
