Twice-beaten Harvard will face hard-hitting Army as underdog tomorrow just as the Crimson has been doing since this forty-threeyear-old football rivalry was resumed in 1928. The game probably will draw a near-capacity crowd of 55,000 to the Stadium.

John McKenzie, Dock Commissioner, acting personally and as a Catholic, sent to Hans Dieckhoff, German Ambassador, a telegram yesterday declining to join in a German aviation ceremony today because of Nazi persecution of Catholics abroad.

Following the suspension yesterday of the pawnbroker's license of M. Goodstein Sons, Inc., of 279 Bridge Street, Brooklyn, Mayor La Guardia moved for the establishment of new rules and regulations governing pawnshops.

Every public utility in the United States could be brought under Federal regulation, and State control laws would be rendered futile, if the Supreme Court supported the National Labor Relations Board in the Consolidated Edison Company controversy, William L. Ransom, Edison counsel, declared before the court in opening arguments on the case today.

The directors of the Pacific Tin Corporation yesterday elected Medley G. B. Whelpley president to succeed Silas W. Howland, deceased. Mr. Whelpley is a partner in Guggenheim Brothers and is president of Anglo-Chilean Nitrate Corporation and of Santaro Nitrate Co. Ltd.

With two victories in their two previous meetings, the University of North Carolina is expected to furnish the first real test of the season for N. Y. U. in the game at the Yankee Stadium today. The start is set for 2 P. M.

Auburn's Tigers bounded back into the winning column tonight, whipping a fighting but outclassed Mississippi State team, 20-6. It was State's first setback and followed three previous runaway vicstories. More than 15,000 attended.
Mrs. Caroline O'Day, Delegate at Large to the Constitutional Convention has returned to the State $1,720 of her $2,500 salary, Controller Tremaine announced today. Mrs.

Borough President George U. Harvey announced yesterday all work on the $5,000,000 Queens General Court House, which is nearing completion, would be stopped because the services of his personal representative, who also is his brotherin-law, has been terminated by the Civil Service Commission.

With the world series completed and the plaudits for Joe McCarthy's invincibles subsiding, football takes undisputed possession of the sports stage today to provide the heaviest action of a campaign filled with major engagements from the start.

Sales increases ranging from 5 to 8 per cent for the Thom McAn shoe stores in the last quarter of 1938 and the first quarter of 1939 were predicted yesterday by Ward Melville, president of Melville Shoe Corporation, who said the concern is planning on such an increase.

President Roosevelt will tell the voters of his own State and, incidentally, those of the whole country, what he thinks about issues and candidates in a radio address from his Hyde Park home on Nov. 4.

Aluminium, Ltd., has notified the trustee for its 5 per cent sinkingfund debentures, due July 1, 1948, that it will redeem $3,000,000 principal amount of these securities on Jan. 1 next. They are callable now on sixty days' notice at 103 and interest.

RETHINKING RELIGION, by John Haynes Holmes. (Macmillan, $2.50.) A statement of the author's religious ideals as they stand today after thirty years of preaching in a free pulpit. Mr. Holmes finds in contemporary society three different, mutually exclusive. attitudes toward religion.
Receivers for the Wabash Railroad received authorization today from United States District Judge Charles B. Davis to withdraw for revision the plan of reorganization that they filed last Februarv.

The twenty-three-story building which has stood forlornly vacant and unfinished for about thirteen years at the northwest corner of West End Avenue and Seventysecond Street may soon be completed and occupied either as a hotel or apartment house.

The Osservatore Romano gives the Vatican version of the recent riots in Vienna against Theodor Cardinal Innitzer and says it believes the naked truth will carry more conviction than any number of comments.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Van Deusen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry N. Van Deusen of this place, and Aubrey William Christopher Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher, also of East Orange, took place here this evening in the Arlington Avenue Presbyterian Church.

A new board of directors for the Pepsi-Cola Company was elected yesterday under a court order handed down in the Guth-Loft case two weeks ago. Walter S. Mack Jr., president of the Phoenix Securities Corporation; James V. Carkner, president of Loft, Inc., and Herman Shulman, counsel for Loft, were elected to represent the Loft interests. John Burton, Robert Atkins and W. D. Hoodless were elected to represent the Guth interests.
Duquesne University recorded a hardwon 13--0 victory over West Virginia Wesleyan before 6,212 spectators tonight on fog-shrouded Forbes Field.
James Thomas Brownlie, veteran trade union leader, died aboard the liner Duchess of Richmond yesterday, it was reported when the vessel reached Greenock from Canada today. His age was 73.
Meeting for the fourth time on the gridiron, with Yale holding three straight victories, Navy and the Blue will attract 50,000 persons to the Bowl tomorrow.

Capitalizing on two fumbles early in the third period, Moravian College scored two touchdowns tonight to upset a hitherto undefeated Juniata eleven, 14-6, before 3,500 spectators in a Pennsylvania Conference game.

A "Christian Loyalty Parade," in which about 2,000 laymen of the Bronx Protestant churches will participate, will be held tomorrow afternoon. The parade will move west on Fordham Road from Webster Avenue at 3 P. M. The line of march will continue west on Fordham Road to Jerome Avenue.

Cornell remained a 2-to-1 favorite over Syracuse on the eve of their traditional gridiron battle tomorrow. About 25,000 are expected to see the two undefeated elevens clash in one of the nation's big games of the day.

Colin M. Eadie Realty Company, Inc. has moved its offices to the Masonic Building, 71 West Twenty-third Street. During the first six months of this year the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria produced gross earnings of about $3,500,000, according to a survey by Amott, Baker Co., Inc. This compared with $7,750.000 for the full year 1937.

First of the Playwrights' Company's ventures to arrive in this city is Robert E. Sherwood's "Abe Lincoln in Illinois" which opens tonight at the Plymouth Theatre after an auspicious tryout in Washington and Baltimore, where it was cheered by audiences and critics alike.

Funeral services for Dr. John A. Harriss, the originator of New York City's traffic signal light system and for many years an authority on traffic problems, were held yesterday morning at the Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Sixtieth Street and Park Avenue.

The field artillery exhibited here today one of its most modern weapons. The exhibition came during a lull in the joint anti-aircraft Air Corps exercises, which started Monday and are scheduled to end with a bombing test tomorrow.
South Carolina overpowered a lighter but scrappy Davidson College eleven, 25 to 0, today in a Southern Conference game before a crowd of 3,500.

Miss Laura S. McKenna, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. McKenna of New York, was married to Ivin S. Bear, also of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Grabill Bear of York, Pa., last night in the West End Presbyterian Church.

Ending an. abuse that existed for many years, the New York City school system has routed the petty "loan sharks" that preyed upon the teachers and supervisors, Dr. Alberto C. Bonaschi, chairman of the Retirement Board, disclosed yesterday in making public the board's twenty-first annual report.

The Munich conference ended with an agreement covering Czechoslovakia, since put into effect, but with a question mark covering all other problems, although Chancellor Hitler and Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain did supplement the larger agreement with a declaration of mutual amity and good-will.

Miss Lucile Anne Butler, daughter of Mrs. Lusson Butler of Haverford and James Russell Butler, was married this afternoon to Dr. Clifford Kinnard Murray, son of Mrs. William G. Murray of New York and of the late Mr. Murray.
Fire prevention was stressed yesterday by speakers at the annual presentation of medals to 246 school children who wrote the best essays on that subject in a recent competition.

Stocks closed irregularly lower and with trends mixed; utility and copper shares strongest; turnover 1,953,900 shares. United States Government bonds quiet and generally higher, others steady and mixed; transactions, $7,608,600.

Chancellor Hitler received the envoys of Hungary and Czechoslovakia yesterday and endeavored to settle the partition dispute between those nations. It was expected in Berlin that he would become the peace-maker of Central Europe without consulting other great powers;

Judge Michael G. Kasper of the Cook County Municipal Court died tonight in the Passavant Hospital after a heart attack. He was 51 years old. Judge Kasper was running for re-election, and it is believed that the strain of the campaign brought about the heart condition. heart condition.

The Dartmouth Indians, who have rolled up 119 points while keeping their goal-line uncrossed during three games, expect their stiffest competition of the season tomorrow from the best team Brown has turned out in six years.

William Henry Wright, theatrical press agent and manager, died Wednesday of a heart ailment in City Hospital. He was 72 years old. His last employment was on a WPA theatrical project. He had lived with his son, William Henry Wright Jr. at 64 West Eighty-second Street.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Oct. 8 totaled 702,964 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 5,026 cars, or 0.7 per cent, more than for the preceding week; 109,294 cars, of 13.5 per cent, less than for the corresponding week last year, and 117,231 cars, or 14.3 per cent, less than during the corresponding week two years ago.
Yale's 150-pound eleven defeated the Lafayette lightweights, 7--6. today in an Eastern Intercollegiate 150Pound League game.

In the second case of its kind, Justice Mitchell May in the Supreme Court of Kings County has held valid the provisions of the Feld-Crawford Resale Price Maintenance Law in its application to the sale of gasoline.

The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today an opinion dated Oct. 5 in which it gave its approval to various inter-company transactions incidental to and for the purpose of effecting the consolidation of properties and businesses of the Grand Rapids Gas Light Company, the Washtenaw Gas Company and the Muskegon Gas Company with the Michigan Consolidated Gas Company, which, until recently, was known as the Detroit City Gas Company.

The Newark Academy eleven continued its victory march by disposing of Morristown School today, 20 to 0. The victors advanced by ground and air and were aided considerably by the excellent kicking of Bob Perina. Pace led the scoring with two touchdowns.

Extensive relief work among "non-Aryan" German refugees has been accomplished by the Committee for Catholic Refugees from Germany and the American Committee for Christian German Refugees, it was explained yesterday by spokesmen for those organizations.

Mrs. Pauline Hirschl Mayer, active in philanthropic work here since 1904, died yesterday at her home at the age of 95. She was a granddaughter of Baron Moses Hirschl, who was knighted by the Austrian-Empire for his assistance in building hospitals, schools and libraries there.

Trading in round lots for their own account by members of the New York Stock Exchange in the wtek ended on Sept. 24 was 19.84 per cent of the total volume on the Exchange, compared with 19.92 per cent in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. The total volume was 5,591,500 shares sold, compared with 8,488,450.

Miss Sarah Huber Lewis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. L. Logan Lewis of Syracuse, N. Y., formerly of Plainfield, was married to Craig Hutchinson Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Morrow Smith of Plainfield, tonight in the First-Park Baptist Church here.

The Communist "strategists" who withdrew all but one of their State candidates in behalf of "the New DealProgressive-Labor candidates," which means most of the Democratic State ticket, either have no real conception of the deep devotion to American institutions which animates men like Governor Lehman or they hoped to advance their "revolution"
Irregularity of movement was the feature of trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, with operations on a more moderate scale than in recent sessions.
Many sections of the city, as well as several suburban communities, appeared in the lists of residential leases submitted by brokers and agents yesterday.

Poultry producers in thirteen States of the northeastern area joined in presenting recent developments in this industry at the fourth annual poultry exposition which opened yesterday in the Port Authority building, Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street.

Miss Alice Nordeck, daughter of Mrs. Harry A. Shepard and the late B. S. Nordeck of New Haven, Conn., was married tonight in Christ Church here to Marshall S. Walker Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall S. Walker of this place.

President Roosevelt hailed today the decision of the Electric Bond and Share Company to file with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan of integration as a concrete demonstration of the "cooperation" of industry with government of which he had frequently spoken in the past.

Net earnings of $6,400,000 after provision for income taxes will be reported today by the Union Oil Company of California in its financial statement for the nine months ended on Sept. 30. The result is equivalent to $1.37 a share on the 4,666,270 shares and compares with $8,850,000, or $1.90 a share, earned in the first nine months of 1937.

Many old country homes in New York are held in esteem amounting almost to reverence by persons who are familiar not only with their historic associations but also with the painstaking care which went into their construction.
Plans to. rebuild: immediately the Cities Service Refining Company's "tank farm," now. a field of firecharred girders, were announced today by Elliott McEldowney, the company's advertising manager.
Policemen operating radio patrol cars were ordered last night not to park their cars in a block in which an alarm of fire has been sounded.

In prep aration for the marketing of security issues aggregating $135,000,000 two large public utility companies have filed amendments to registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933, the amendments giving the names of the underwriters. In neither instance was the date for the offering named.

Attired in a gown of ivory satin with a Medici collar of old family lace, Miss Peggy Kipp, a member of the Junior League of New York, was married here this afternoon to Thomas Burns Drum, Philadelphia attorney, in St. John's Church by the rector, the Rev. Donald MacAdie.

" A Bill of Divorcement," the Clemence Dane play, the film version of which lifted Katharine Hepburn into prominence, is to be remade by RKO, with Anne Shirley as the star. The 1932 version featured John Barrymore and Billie Burke; an earlier edition was made in 1922 by Associated Exhibitors.

The pace of wholesale trading quickened noticeably during the week, with an increase in the number of buyers in the markets and the number and size of their orders indicating a shift in sentiment from extreme caution to hopeful moderation, Dun Bradstreet, Ino., reported yesterday in its weekly review.

Fordham stands at the crossroads today. The Rams, as much a mystery to their coach, Sleepy Jim Crowley, as to their multitude of supporters, will pit their green line and flashy backfield against feared Purdue at the Polo Grounds this afternoon and some 30,000 fans will be able to get an idea of the direction in which the Maroon will travel this season.
Now that the waterfowl season is in full swing, the discussion among the active wildfowlers seems to be turning more than ever in the direction of retrievers.

Fire did considerable damage last night in the warehouse of the National Gypsum Company at 152d Street and the East River, the Bronx, and the adjoining premises of James Newell, Inc., where several thousand bags of sawdust were stored.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Assemblyman Phelps Phelps in a letter to THE NEw YORK TIMES proposes an investigation to determine who the individuals are that now own transit securities and who would profit by the proposed unification plan under which $315,000,000 would be excluded from the debt limit by constitutional amendment.

Princeton's varsity soccer team suffered its first league defeat in two years, 3--2, at the hands of a strong Haverford eleven on Poe Field today. Captain Jack Evans and his twin brother Bill, who tallied twice, paced the Pennsvlvania attack.

The growing conflict between Federal and State Governments for power to regulate business will reach its peak in the next three to ten years, Harry Meixell, legislative manager of the Automobile Manufacturers Association, asserted yesterday at a luncheon sponsored by the Trade Association Executives in New York City at the National Republican Club, 54 East Fortieth. Street.

A suit against the Northern States Power Company of Minnesota, its officers, directors and affiliated interests, for accounting on transactions which are alleged to have caused loss of more than $5,000,000 to stockholders, was filed today in the county district court by five shareholders, for, and on behalf of, all other stock owners.

THE champagne glitter and the widely advertised depravity of Parisian night. life in the Eighteen Eighties and the Eighteen Nineties are summed up for. many in the very name of the painter Toulouse-Lautrec. That stunted, gifted and doomed artist is clearly enough a symbol of his epoch-so much so that there has been a tendency to lose sight of him as a man.

The writing of new life insurance last month was 18.5 per cent less than in September, 1937, while the total for the first nine months this year was 22.8 per cent, correspondingly, under 1937, the Association of Life Insurance Presidents reported yesterday to the United States Department of Commerce.
Herbert Griffith Loase, 19-year-old son of Frederick A. Loase, superintendent at the Greenwich Hospital, died last night in Deland, Fla., following an appendix operation.

Felix Lilienthal Co., resident office, has been named representative for William Y. Gilmore Sons, Oak Park, Ill., and Brien, Smith Royer, Inc., Greensburg, Pa. Irving C. Krewson Corporation, resident buyers, has added Chatlin's Department Store, Morristown, Pa., to its list of accounts.

Representative Ramspeck of Georgia, chairman of the House Committee on Civil Service Reform, is always doing his best for a principle which in practice is poison to so many politicians. He has been telling the National League of District Postmasters in session at Louisville of tax bills he is going to introduce in the next session of Congress to extend the merit system.
The Italian Ministry of Popular Culture is spending $1,500 monthly, a report to the State Department says, for the maintenance of an Italian information library in New York.

Mrs. Elizabeth J. Kenney, widow of Representative Edward A. Kenney, announced tonight her withdrawal as an independent candidate for Representative from the Ninth Congressional District of New Jersey. In a statement issued from her home here Mrs. Kenney urged support of the Democratic candidate,

The marriage of Miss Elsie Ellen Mabel Kingsbury, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Percy Charles Kingsbury of Elizabeth, to Louis Frederick Lubrecht of Bethlehem, son of Dr. and Mrs. James L. Lubrecht of Lock Haven, Pa., took place here this evening in Trinity Church.

Reports from Prague indicate that the political realignment of Czechoslovakia will be as drastic as the geographical changes. The republic of yesterday is fading out of the picture with astonishing rapidity.

Commercial leasing reported yesterday consisted largely of contracts for entire floors in midtown. In the building at 4 East Fiftythird Street, Anthony Bonagura and Otto Zoehrer, commercial artists, took a floor, and Ann Grady, for a beauty parlor, rented the parlor floor in 11 East Fifty-fourth Street, through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers.
Two hundred Macedonians and other members of the Opposition, including three Agrarian Deputies, arrested in a police round-up in Sofia yesterday, have been interned in a village in Eastern Bulgaria.
Dr. Harold Longsdorf, Mount Holly, N. J., surgeon, scored a double triumph today in the finals of the national amateur pheasant championship, handling both first and secand prize winners.

New York University's cross-country team opened its season yesterday, bowing to Princeton, 20 to.42, over the four-and-a-half-mile course at Van Cortlandt Park. Curtis Giddings of N. Y. U. was first to cross the finish line, covering the course in 27 minutes 11 seconds thirty yards ahead of Rumsey Skinner of Princeton.

Thousands of Polish-Americans will take part tomorrow afternoon in the Pulaski Annual Memorial Day Parade on Fifth Avenue from Washington Square to Fifty-fourth Street. It will mark the 159th anniversary of the death of Count Casimir Pulaski, Polish patriot, at Savannah while a Continental general. Military, religious, patriotic and civic groups will take part in the parade, which will start at 2 P. M.

Miss Elizabeth Love, daughter of Mrs. C. Wilson Love of Lakeland, Fla., and the late Dr. Love, was married yesterday afternoon to Eugene H. Catron of this city, son of Dr. and Mrs. Homer B. Catron of Denver, in the Church of the Transfiguration, by the Rev. B. A. E. MacLaughlin.
Registration throughout the city picked up for the third consecutive day yesterday as 388,920 persons qualified to vote in the November elections by registering on the fifth day.

Fritz Kuhn, leader of the GermanAmerican Bund and of the Nazi movement in the United States, addressed a notarized statement to Congress last night in which he assailed its Dies Committee on unAmerican Activities and reiterated that the bund had no political, financial or other ties with the German Government.

As the time for the great collective national effort to fill the community chests approaches, Mr. Roosevelt, saying that this year he will not make an appeal in behalf of a "mobilization for human needs," makes a most effective one.

Sphinx Head and Quill and Dagger, senior honorary societies at Cornell University, today announced the election of thirteen new members. Election is on the basis of participation in extra-curricular activities. New members are:

The City Council voted unanimously yesterday to memorialize President Roosevelt and Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, to use their influence toward upholding the Balfour Declaration and the continued immigration of Jews into Palestine.

Extremist Arab followers of the Mufti of Jerusalem, Haj Amin el Husseini, who are directing rebel activities in Palestine from exile in Lebanon and Syria, are rapidly achieving their aims by eliminating political opponents in Palestine who are inclined toward moderation.
Banks and trust companies were principals in a number of city realty deals reported yesterday. Properties in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn were involved.
James J. Conroy Sr., retired Delaware Hudson Railroad engineer, who achieved a "perfect" record during a career of forty-nine years, died here last night at the age of 73.

Michael F. Walsh, United States Attorney in Brooklyn, filed suit yesterday in Federal Court, seeking injunctions against three milk concerns charging violations of the Federal-State program regulating the handling of milk in the metropolitan area.

Plans for a $400,000 hospital and a $160,000 apartment house in the Bronx were among the building projects filed in the city yesterday. The list of filings in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn follows:

Mr. and Mrs. G. Beekman Hoppin have come to the Pierre from Four Winds, their country place in Syosset. Mr. and Mrs. Jonathan Bulkeley have returned from their Summer home in Ridgefield, Conn., and are at the Plaza.

The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that 2,058,238 of its common shares, or 23.65 per cent, were in brokers' names on Sept. 30, compared with 1,961,495, or 22.54 per cent, on June 30. Investors held 6,645,014 shares, or 76.35 per cent, compared with 6,741,757 shares, or 77.46 per cent, on June 30.

Dr. William I. Tomlinson, senior obstetrician at Hahnemann Hospital and a member of the Hahnemann Medical College faculty since his graduation from the college thirtyfive years ago, died today of a heart ailment in Broad Street Hospital after a ten-day illness. He was 57 years old.

Hog prices continued to sag today, with losses of 15 to 25 cents, carrying the top down to $7.70, lowest of the year, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Fat lambs also declined in some cases 10 cents, but cattle showed little change in a slow cleanup trade.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for award next week totals only $21,057,606, to be represented by one State and 103 munipalities, as compared with the revised total of $31,477,750 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $23,953,132.

Public utility securities acted impressively again yesterday in response to the overtures on the part of the utility industry and the Administration looking toward a settlement of the long standing controversy between private power interests and public power advocates.
The Reconstruction Finance Corporation has approved sale of the machinery and equipment of the Textile Dyeing and Printing Company of America to Consolidated Products Company, Inc.

Foreign Minister P. R. Munch told Parliament today that Denmark and other small States after the last League of Nations session felt themselves relieved of the obligation to impose sanctions under Article XVI and in the future would decide individually whether to follow the article.
The creation of an "army in overalls" to guard vital factories against air attacks was announced by the War Office today.

The "broad-scale rehabilitation program" for the railroads, submitted to the President's fact-finding board by the eighteen labor organizations which represent the railroad workers of the country, was. doubtless intended either to deflect attention from the wage-cut question or to show how the railroads could be put on their feet without a wage reduction.
Miss Roberta Thorburn Stockton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Stockton 3d of this city, was presented to society this afternoon at a large reception given by her parents at the Present Day Club.

Spencer Overton, Maryland State amateur champion, and William Goldthorpe, 16-year-old South Jersey amateur titleholder from Woodcrest, tied for the medal today with scores of 69 in the qualifying round of the Clarence Geist Memorial tournament at the Seaview Golf Club.

Miss Marguerite Wells of Minneapolis, president of the National League of Women Voters, stepped to the rostrum of the State convention in its closing session here this morning and within half an hour had virtually reshaped the immediate objectives of the group. Enthusiastic applause greeted her indirect appeal for a vitalized role for the league in the current precarious world situation.

Russian workmen in threadbare clothes rubbed shoulders with bearded generals in faded Czarist uniforms today at funeral services for Grand Duke Cyril Vladimirovitch, pretender to the throne of all the Russias, who died Wednesday.
Mr. and Mrs. David Tolmie of Tuxedo Park, N. Y., gave a luncheon yesterday in the Garden of the Ambassador for Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Lohmann of Denmark, who will leave soon for South America.

President Roosevelt disclosed today that he has ordered a searching investigation into the nation's defense requirements, including the adequacy of existing facilities and the possibilities of mass production of arms and equipment, and indicated that vastly increased expenditures in both army and navy were contemplated.

City College will present a reorganized lineup against Clarkson Tech this afternoon when the upStaters pay their first visit to Lewisohn Stadium to provide the Lavender football team with its third test of the season. The kick-off is set for 2:30 P. M.

In an order permitting the Middle West Corporation to acquire by March 31, 1939, in the open market an additional 20,000 shares of the $6 preferred stock of the Central Illinois Public Service Company, a subsidiary, the Securities and Exchange Commission imposed today

Introduction of racial or religious issues into the State campaign was denounced last night by Norman Thomas, Socialist nominee for Governor. Mr. Thomas spoke at an indoor meeting in the Golden Gate Hall, 1,574 Pitkin Avenue, Brooklyn, and at open-air rallies at Graham and Varet Streets and Sutter and Hopkinson Avenues.

Responsibility for the country's current economic condition was laid at the door of the Federal Government today by Fred H. Clausen, chairman of the Federal Finance Committee of the United States Chamber of Commerce. He charged that paternalism in government is "knocking the props out from under the pillars supporting it."

AMHERST vs. Rochester--Sometimes it seems that the best way to go at this is blindfold. Chess masters do pretty well that way with even more complicated problems. Sight unseen, one visionary vote for Amherst.

The executive council of the American Federation of Labor today issued an international charter to the Seafarers International Union of North, America, which will replace the disrupted International Seamen's Union.

Federal Judge Walter C. Lindley today set May 8, 1939, as the tentative date for the second trial of the huge oilconspiracy case in Madison, Wis. The number of defendants who will appear before him then will depend on the outcome of a mandamus action brought by the government and an appeal taken by seventeen defendants whose convictions were sustained by Judge Patrick Stone in Madison.
Two long runs kept Garfield High School in the race for the State championship tonight as a crowd of 7,000 watched East Rutherford outplay the favorites all the way, only to lose. 13-6.
The first of the local season's regular large group shows will open with a reception and preview this evening in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.
Aided by Wall Street's buoyancy yesterday, the stock markets here took on a slightly more cheerful tone today, and for the first time in eight days the drift toward the dollar was checked.
Regulations covering employment of learners, apprentices, handicapped persons and messengers under the Wages and Hours Act were issued today by Elmer F. Andrews, Administrator.
The State Department promised today that it would "take all necessary measures for the protection of American rights and interests in Palestine."
The State Banking Department announced today that it had approved application of the Shell Employees Credit Union for the establishment of a station at 420 Oakland Street, Brooklyn.

Westchester County property owners can sell top soil for use on the World's Fair grounds in Flushing without fear of violating residential zoning laws, Supreme Court Justice Lee Parsons Davis ruled today in refusing to grant a temporary injunction in a test case brought by the town of Harrison.

Another four-power meeting to consider the Czechoslovak problem was regarded as possible here today as a result of a declaration that Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Italian Foreign Minister, made first to Baron Frederic de Villani,
A collection of scores comprising the major portion of the surviving music library of the late Serge Diaghileff, impresario who founded the Diaghileff Russian Ballet, is now in New York.

William A. O'Brien, veteran prison worker and principal keeper at Clinton Prison here since 1931, died this morning at the age of 62. Born in Dannemora, he was the son of Michael and Mary Collins O'Brien, early settlers in the community. He was educated in district schools and Plattsburg State Normal School.

Senator Burton K. Wheeler of Montana, chairman of the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce, expressed the opinion before the Railway Wage Fact-Finding Board today that "indefensible waste" was causing a loss to the railroads of as much as $1,000,000 a day.

Count Ilya Tolstoy, grandson of the Russian author, married Mrs. Beatrice Ames Stewart, former wife of Donald Ogden Stewart, the writer, tonight at the Southern Hotel. After the ceremony the couple returned to New York.

A resolution urging President Roosevelt to "prevail upon the British Government to continue to keep open the doors of Palestine for Jewish immigration" was telegraphed to the White House yesterday following a meeting of representatives of national Jewish women's organizations at the headquarters of Hadassah, 1,860 Broadway.
Walter M. Jeffords's Regal Lily, unable to win a race this year while operating in the best company, found a field she could handle in the Annapolis Purse, today's feature race.

Trading in wool goods markets during the week was slow, except for calls for fabrics impossible to obtain for quick delivery, the New York Wool Top Exchange Service reported yesterday in its weekly summary.

More than 1,500 summonses a month are being issued for violations of no parking and limited parking restrictions in the thirty "express" streets of Manhattan, Deputy Chief Inspector James J. Sheehy of the Police Department said yesterday.

Belmiro Valdeverde, convicted as a leader of the Integralista uprising last May 11, was captured today. He was arrested immediately after the uprising, but escaped from jail a month ago. He did not leave the city.

The Greenwich Savings Bank, as plaintiff in foreclosure proceedings against the Thirty-Six Seventy-five Broadway Realty Corporation, bought for $200,000 the six-story St. Regis apartment house on the northwest corner of Broadway and 152d Street at auction in the Vesey Street rooms yesterday.

It was reliably learned tonight that urgent petitions have been made to Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and Premier Mussolini on behalf of the Dodecanese Islands which though entirely Greek are under Italian sovereignty.
King Carol today accepted the resignation of Rumania's Minister of War and quickly appointed a successor in what was said to be a move to speed up modernization of the nation's armed forces.

The annual mobilization for human needs was opened by President Roosevelt tonight in a radio address in which he asserted that the need for community action in aid of the needy and distressed was not lessened by the increased responsibilities assumed by the Federal Government for social- welfare.
It hurts to read that wanton mischief is responsible for something like a quarter million dollars in damage to the city's parks

Distinguished educators, commemorating the 300th anniversary of the founding of the first common school in New York State here today, pictured the school as the well spring of the American way of life and warned of the need for sound education to meet attacks on democracy.

Fedral Judge Paul Jones today granted to the Erie Railroad a sixty-day extension of the Oct. 18 deadline for filing of the company's reorganization plan. Details of the setup originally were scheduled to be filed on July 18.
Fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange here were unusually narrow yesterday, and, under a light volume of business, the list ended unchanged to 7 points lower than on Thursday.
Dr. Otto School, who served as Professor of Medicine at Temple University in 1917-19 and formerly as government health officer of the Philippines, died here today at the age of 62.

Denouncing as "malicious and false" rumors that he intended to resign. in the event of his re-election, Governor Herbert H. Lehman pledged himself last night to serve out his full term if re-elected at the general election on Nov. 8.

A strike of towboat employes which threatened to tie up at least twenty-five passenger and freight ships scheduled to leave or arrive in this port today was called last night after conferences of tugboat operators and an American Federation of Labor union failed to produce a satisfactory wage agreement.

Alvan Macauley, president of the Automobile Manufacturers Association, issued a statement yesterday saying that public acceptance of the 1939 model automobiles, thus far revealed, was enthusiastic. He added that there was an unmistakable start toward greater prosperity in America.

Roger Wolbarst's 5-yard run around right end for a touchdown, with twenty-five seconds to play, after his team had made an 88-yard march down the field, gave the Woodmere Academy eleven a 12-to-7 triumph over Columbia Grammar today.

The leaders of the strikers on the London, Midland Scottish Railway tonight declared open rebellion against their union, which had ordered an immediate return to work, and also announced they would carry their strike for a closed shop into the stations of-all railway companies.

The report that a German claim for the return of the colonies is imminent has revived discussion of the future of New Guinea. Acting Prime Minister Sir Earle Page, speaking to the House of Representatives, said today that the principles underlying

Acting under the recent amendment to the Bankruptcy Law which permits such action, the Haytian Corporation filed a petition yesterday in Federal Court asking permission to "make an arrangement" with holders of $2,971,846 in 8 per cent debentures.

James H. Sharp, vice president, was elected a director of the Grace National Bank. The Federal Savings and Loan Associations of Metropolitan New York will celebrate today the sixth birthday of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York.

Trading fair to good on all classes in local markets yesterday. Market mostly steady on all classes except kosher lamb, this class opening 50 cents to $1 higher. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

While Governor Lehman considered candidates for appointment as special prosecutor to supersede District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn yesterday, the District Attorney on his own initiative went ahead with plans for the prosecution of the Brooklyn fur racket cases which started the inquiry into official corruption in the borough.

Twentieth Century-Fox's "Suez" (at the Roxy) is a handsomely sepia-tinted and ponderously implausible description of how the Suez Canal came to be built by a dark-haired juvenile through the inspiration of a regimental
Dr. Francisco Castillo Najera, Mexican Ambassador to Washington, will confer with President Lazaro Cardenas again tomorrow before returning to the American capital by plane Monday.

In a written reply to questions on what action the police were taking in regard to published reports of vandalism to park property, Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine said yesterday that the matter was already under investigation.

A group of Ulster Irish appealed to Chancellor Adolf Hitler of Germany today to aid their campaign for union of Northern Ireland with Ireland [Eire, the former Irish Free State.] After an Armagh County mass meeting they sent this message:

New automobiles, valued at $225,000,000, will be bought by dealers in the United States within the next thirty days, D. E. Ahrens, general sales manager of the Cadillac Motor Division of General Motors, told about 400 dealers gathered for the introduction of the new Cadillac and LaSalle models at a luncheon meeting at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday.

A well-dressed young woman and two men were in the line-up at Police Headquarters yesterday as suspects in a series of burglaries in rooms of hotel guests in the midtown district in the last six months. The crimes had mystified the police and hotel attaches.
King Leopold of the Belgians surprised France by making an entirely unexpected speech this week at the dedication of a monument erected in Paris in memory of his father.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The improved tone noted in the wool market a week ago has been De translated into better prices. The market is definitely stronger and fine wools which were sold with some difficulty a few weeks ago at 65 cents are now difficult to purchase at 70 cents, clean basis.

The. Rev. Dr. William Barrow Pugh will be formally installed as Stated Clerk of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America on Thursday evening at 8 o'clock in the Second Presbyterian Church, Walnut and Twenty-first Street,

The Chinese apparently are putting up a stiffer effort in the vicinity of Tamshui, seventy-five miles southeast of Canton. They reported they were holding up the Japanese advance, inflicting heavy casualties, but were still falling back under pressure.

The activities last Monday night of 200 Larchmont and New Rochelle men are being studied closely by the police in an attempt to find the murderer of Mary Imelda Coyle, 17year-old New Rochelle girl who was attacked and beaten to death that night, Assistant District Attorney William F. Horan said today.

Belief that the new synthetic yarn with which E. I. duPont de Nemours Co. has been experimenting for the last several months is ready for commercial production was expressed in trade circles yesterday when it was announced at the du Pont general offices at Wilmington, Del., that the concern will build a $7,000,000 plant for production of "textile yarn" at one of three sites now under option in different States.

" Patagonian Year," the record of an engineer's experiences on the Argentine Pampas and in the scrawny towns of the coast, will be published by Knopf Oct. 24. The author is Bruno Nordang, who went to Patagonia shortly after the war to work as a land surveyor. His book will be published in Arthur G. Chater's translation from the Norwegian original.

Charles Creighton Carlin, Washington lawyer and former member of Congress from the Eighth Virginia District, died at his home here today. Mr. Carlin, who was 73, was owner of The Alexandria (Va.) Gazette. He was a delegate to the Democratic National Convention Mourners in 1932.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo last night presented Leonide Massine's "St. Francis" at the Metropolitan Opera House for the first time in America, and by so doing put us everlastingly in its debt. Certainly here is one of the great dance works of our day.

Announcement has been made by the Rev. and Mrs. Mihran T. Kalaidjian of this place of the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Ruth Radcliffe Kalaidjian, to Drought Delaney Davis, son of Mrs. George F. W. Davis of New York and the late Mr. Davis. The wedding will take place here on Oct. 28.

Any altruistic motive that may have prompted London's Lord Mayor to Journey to Prague to deliver relief funds collected in Britain to delegates from the German-occupied Sudetenland finds no response in the Boersen Zeitung.
Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,143,000 bales, against 1,140,000 a week ago, 1,157,000 two weeks ago, 1,167,000 three weeks ago and 726,000 a year ago;

Net sales of 957 full-line grocery wholesalers, whose volume represented 31 per cent of the sales of all full-line houses, increased 3.4 per cent in the second quarter of this year compared with the first quarter, William L. Austin, director of the Bureau of the Census of the Department of Commerce, reported yesterday in connection with the census survey of business for 1937-38.
The report of the Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday, showed a net income of $6,832,574 after operating expenses, taxes and charges.

Following is the address of Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, at the meeting of farmers, farm leaders and AAA committeemen today: Farmers who are assembled here today have come from several of the Corn Belt States, some of you from homes that are many miles away.

Agitation for the organization of cooperative burial societies and municipal mortuaries was described yesterday as an outgrowth of the depression at the closing session of the annual meeting of the National Funeral Directors Association.

Residents of Soviet Russia are approaching with concern a Winter which by present indications will be the most difficult in several years. Shortages in many of the most important goods for human consumption are now marked, and it is difficult to see how any appreciable improvement can be brought about in the immediate future.

A SINGULAR circumstance is visible today in apparently separate fields of art and politics. Briefly it is that a narrow and chauvinistic nationalism, with a hundred destructive and warlike potentialities in its wake, is the creed of the most of the governments of the world;

His team trailing by seven points with only five minutes of play remaining, Halfback Madden threw two perfect passes today, one to Chauncey Mackle for a touchdown, another to Henry Sinski for the conversion of the extra point.

The nineteenth annual meeting of the American Welding Society is to open in Detroit today and will continue through Friday, with more than 1,500 engineers, industrialists, metallurgists and educators in attendance. Forty-five technical
The Westchester County Realty Board yesterday announced the election of Herbert R. Houghton of New York and Mamaroneck as president for the coming year.

On college campuses from New England, where the Fall has died in the wreckage of the hurricane, to the cities of the East and West and the pleasant settings of the South, this academic year finds more students enrolled in higher education than in any year before.
Senator Wheeler, Democrat, of Montana, predicted today that a majority of the Senate would vote "independently" on all Administration measures in the next session.
THE last scheduled event of the American Contract Bridge League's current metropolitan tournament, which has been under way at the Park Central Hotel since Monday, will be played today.

Mr. and Mrs. William Wiese of Grand Island, Neb., have announced here the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Irene Lois Wiese, to Lester Charles Burdett Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Burdett of Palisade, N. J.

A marked dog from the moment he was sent away on his first pheasant this morning in the opening test on upland game, Chesacroft Baron continued to lead his field, and none could approach his record at the end of the day, when he was pronounced the winner of the open allage stake of the annual-field trial meeting of the Irish Water Spaniel Club of America.
The Canadian brother team, Torchy and Doug Peden of Victoria, B. C., won Montreal's six-day bike race tonight, outscoring four rival combinations they were tied in distance.

Frank M. McCurdy, president of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board, has been renominated for that office for the coming year. Other nominations to be voted on at the annual meeting of the board on Tuesday evening in Michel's Restaurant are Charles D. Behrens, for vice president;

The marriage of Miss Jean Trumbull Atwater, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Huntington Choate Atwater of this place, to Dr. W. Lynwood Heaver, son of Mrs. Maude Heaver of Oakland, Calif., took place tonight in the Church of St. James the Less here.

ALTHOUGH but two children had preceded him, the family had run out of names when the third, which proved to be a boy, was born. So the mother pulled a slip of paper from a hat. It bore the name "Edwin," and so Edwin he became. A friend from Arlington, in Massachusetts, was staying in the house, and so the middie name was found.

With the recent completion of the first unit of two-story houses in the $1,000,000 housing project known as Beech Spring Gardens in Summit, N. J., Willard E. Closs, head of the development- concern, is preparing to start work at once on the second unit of six houses.

THE new Australian half-penny copper piece has recently made its appearance in the United States. The obverse shows the head of King George VI facing left, and around the outer edge the inscription "Georgivs VI D:G:Br:Omn: Rex F:D:Ind:Imp."

Decorators, it is pointed out, have ascertained that two-thirds of the interior of a home is wall space. The importance of appropriate and pleasing treatment of walls deserves the serious consideration of every home owner.

The foreign exchange market hare was steadier today, with an improved trend in sterling. The United States dollar closed at 4.7311-16 against 4.73 5/8, and francs appreciated to 17823-32 In terms of the pound. The price of gold declined 1 1/2d to

The College of Our Lady of Good Counsel, a Roman- Catholic institution for women located in this city, announced today that it had established for the first time a major course in commerce. A model business office is to be an important part of the new course's equipment and arrangements are to be made to give students practical experience in local business offices.

The Spence Alumnae Society will benefit from a percentage of the proceeds of a dinner and supper party on Nov. 3 which will formally open, for the Autumn and Winter, the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. A diversified program of entertainment has been- arranged for the event.
Germany began yesterday an extensive advertising campaign in the Mexican press designed to increase Nazi trade and to sell Nazi principles and the Nazi version of history to the Mexican public.

WHAT with sandbags round the Foreign Office and gas masks in the outfit of every schoolchild returning for the Autumn session, the past month has hardly been one in which films and film personalities have taken a tremendous place in the lives of the ordinary English people.

Home construction in practically all of the development centers in Queens and adjacent sections of Long Island is being maintained with no apparent evidences of delining activity. Many builders of low cost and medium priced projects report that the buying interest thus far in the Fall season has equaled the desire for home ownership which characterized the Spring months.

Dick Chapman, Connecticut amateur champion; Spencer Overton, Maryland titleholder; J. Wood Platt, Philadelphia district leader, and Tom Wootton of Atlantic City advanced today to the semi-final bracket of the Geist Memorial Tournament at the Seaview Golf Club.

Opportunity knocked repeatedly for Nebraska but Indiana knocked too, and their interconference football game today ended scoreless. A crowd of 31,000 watched the tussle. The result left each team still gunning for its first victory of this season.

John Zahn, president of the Zahn Glass and Mirror Company of East Rutherford, died today at his home here at the age of 74. Mr. Zahn, who was born in New York, was formerly president of the Carlstadt National Bank and for many years was prominent in Bergen County banking circles.

FEB. 8, 1817, was a Saturday to be remembered in the Doak family. For this was the day when Father Doak, discouraged by hard times, high rents and war prices that continued though the War of 1812 was over, decided to move his family to Cincinnati.

If opposition to the AAA were united on a definite proposal for a substitute, explainable to the farmers in terms of cash income, it might profit greatly from the impatience and discontent arising from the debilitated condition of the market for the Midwest's great farm crops.

THERE is something so intriguing, so many human values, in that strange triangle of Dorothy and William Wordsworth and Samuel Taylor Coleridge that it must have seemed to many, as often it has seemed to this reviewer, to hold the material for a novel.

BERKELEY-MORRIS-Mr. and Mrs. Herman Morris announce the engagement of their daughter, Ruth, to Dr. William Edwin Berkeley. BERMAN-HEUBERG--Mrs. Adelle Heuberg, 1,776 Union St., Brooklyn, announces the betrothal of her daughter, Hilda Evelyn, to Mr. Alexander H. Berman, son of Mr. Nathan Berman of New York.

Germany's success in annexing the Sudeten areas of Czechbslovakia and her emergence as the uncontested ruler of Central and Eastern Europe are forcing wide shifts in the internal and foreign policies Of the Balkan nations. thing the weapons of political prestige and trade, Germany is rapidly increasing her influence over the entire Balkan peninsula.
Three thousand used books will be placed on sale tomorrow at 102 Park Avenue, Rutherford, N. J., by the Rutherford College Club and Woman's Club for the benefit of the clubs' scholarship fund.
For many of us in these later days the word Scandinavia has the same comforting sound that the syllables of Mesopotamia had for the old lady in the story.

Miss Mollie Todd Jenks, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Daker Jenks of this place, was married here this afternoon to Edward Victor Donaldson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Donaldson, also of Pelham Manor, in the Huguenot memorial Church by the Rev. Willazrd P. Soper.

The premitre of Richard Strauss's one act opera "Daphne," companion piece to "Der Friedenstag," was held at the State Opera here tonight before a brilliant audience of persons prominent in musical and government circles from all parts of the Reich.
BARS have recently been installed to prevent any one from falling as he kisses the famous stone at Blarney Castle, County Cork, Ireland.

Georgia remained among the unbeaten of football today by downing Mercer, 28-19, in a wild game splashed with offensive color but drab on the defensive side. Spec Landrum, jolted highly favored Georgia in the early minutes of play when he snatched a punt and ran 60 yards to a score. Pledger added the point.
With Ed Roth scoring both touchdowns, the Brooklyn College eleven defeated Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, 13-0, today.

Election of Harold L. Turk, Republican candidate for Kings County Judge, to bring about real law enforcement in Brooklyn, was urged yesterday by Edward W. Wright, immediately after his selection as Mr. Turk's campaign director.
PERSUADING children to eat food that is good for them is a task at any time and New York City's Board of Education undertook it on a major scale when inaugurating its system of school lunches.
A new six-story apartment house has just been completed by George Schor Sons, builders, on the site of the former home of James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany, at 17 Gramercy Park South.

So much of paragraph 7, Special Orders 129, dated Oct. 3, 1938, as pertains to 2d Lt. Alan C. Poole, F.A.-Res., is revoked. So much of paragraph 1, Special Orders 131, dated Oct. 10, 1938, as reads: "2d Lt. Frank L. Marinoli, F.A.-Res.," is amended to read 2d Lt. Frank L. Martinoli, F.A.-Res.

G. P. Ellis of Chicago, tax consultant of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, will speak at the luncheon meeting of the Manhattan Chapter of the association to be held on Thursday in the Hotel Commodore.

Funeral services for Charles Dersch, president of the General Slocum Survivors Association, were held yesterday afternoon at the Lutheran Zion Church, 339 East Eighty-fourth Street. Dr. William Popeke, pastor of the church, conducted the service.
Wagner College of Staten Island scored its first football victory in four years yesterday by defeating Panzer College of East Orange, N. J., 12 to 7, on the victors' field.
The marriage of Miss Mary Agnes Lennon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Lennon of Montclair, to John Robert Hoff of Newark took place this afternoon in the Church of the Immaculate Conception here.

Owing to the increasing demand for store space in Forest Hills, D. M. Sarkisian, as president of the Forest Hills Heights Corporation, is constructing a group of eight stores at the southeast corner of Queens Boulevard and Sixty-seventh Avenue, opposite the Virginia, first of a group of six-story apartment buildings also planned in the same community.

Opposition to Secretary Wallace's two-price plan, under which those on relief and other low-income groups. would buy foodstuffs at special prices, spread among grocery manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers last week.

ALL good American Savoyards, like Mohammedans at sunrise, bow low and kneel facing east. London is their Mecca, and D'Oyly Carte their prophet. I was no Savoyard, back in 1935, but just a Hollywood producer looking around for ideas to substitute for the big screen names which a limited budget prohibited.

Miss Susan Billings Meech of Groton, a genealogist, died today at the Lawrence Hospital at the age of 76. She was born in Groton the daughter of Noyes Billings Meech and Susan Spicer Meech. For the last thirteen years she had been a resident of St. Augustine, Fla.

" My first task after returning to Berlin will be to bring the Czech-German trade, negotiations that were interrupted months ago to a successful conclusion," Dr. Walter Funk, German Minister of Economics, declared last evening to newspaper

Columbia High of South Orange and Maplewood, undefeated since 1936, made a strong bid for the championship of the Oranges today as it defeated Orange High, 27 to 0. Hillman's passes figured prominently in setting up the scores by Cleary,. Sullivan, Roman and Hoyt.

Gold holdings, as reported in the Treasury's daily statement for Oct. 13, the latest available figures, aggregated $13,920,634,181, an increase of $51,295,010 in a day. Simultaneously the Treasury, in line with its policy of making gold available for purchase of incoming gold and other expenditures, transferred an additional $81,000,000 to the gold certificate fund of the Federal Reserve System, bringing the total of the fund to $8,285,765,847.

MRS. MILLER likes to quote things, all sorts of things, in a temper that is partly sentimental, partly gay and witty, partly ironic. Her very long novel is filled with an extraordinary collection of quoted sundries, many of them delightful: it has as many quotations as a McGuffey's reader, including a couple from that master anthologist himself.

Two boats, collided in a dense fog on Chesapeake Bay early today and one of them, a forty-foot bay freighter, was beached on Gibson Island, her captain reported to Commander William Kenner of the Fort McHenry Coast Guard base. A Coast Guard patrol boat was sent to Gibson Island to pump water out of the vessel.

The transfer of four sergeants and twenty-four policemen to the detective division, revealed in yesterday's police orders, was understood to be a move to increase the picketpocket squad with trained personnel before the World's Fair.

DETROIT. PREDICTIONS that automobile prices in 1939 would run close to those of 1937 are confirmed as dealers place the new tags on cars now on display throughout the country. Many improvements are incorporated in cars for the coming year over those of two years ago.

Boston University displayed power in downing Upsala College of East Orange, N. J., 25 to 0, today at Fenway Park. The visiting Vikings put up a strong defense in the first half, holding the heavier home team to one touchdown. The Terriers, at top strength for the first time this season, overpowered the Vikings in the second half.

To counterbalance the transatlantic failure of "On Borrowed Time," which was withdrawn after but six performances, Henry Sherek is bringing back from the suburbs "Idiot's Delight" for an unlimited season at His Majesty's at reduced prices.

Reporting continued interest in reconditioned houses, Russell Page, sales director of the "Easy-to-Own" Homes Organization, announced yesterday the sale of fifteen Queens and Brooklyn properties during the month of September by that organization.

Facing the contingency of a greatly increased migration of rural youth to New York to seek jobs during the World's Fair, the ruralurban conference on youth migration to cities in its closing session yesterday set up the machinery for a study of the problems that will arise out of this extra influx. It is hoped that the WPA will aid in the study.

New York City will be the surgical center of the United States this week, with the country's leading surgeons congregated here for the twenty-eighth clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons, which opens here tomorrow at the Waldorf Astoria for its annual five-day convention.

Net loss of 141 Class I railroads in August, as reported to the Interstate Commerce Commission, was $3,955,405, in contrast with a net income of $19,194,965 in the same period last year. The combined statement of these companies for August and the first seven months of the year follows:

Savings and loan associations are urged by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board to lead a campaign for all-year building, thus eliminating the Winter decline which is so costly to American economic and social life.

A mastodon skeleton discovered in Hudson Highlands has been presented to the Bear Mountain Trailside Museum by Dr. Reginald Gordon, former Professor of Physics at Columbia University, it was announced yesterday.

PATERSON, N. J. ALTHOUGH its 1,500-horsepower airplane engine is of recent development, the Wright Aeronautical Corporation of this city already is preparing for the day when 3,000-horsepower motors will be in production and when propellers will be twenty feet long.

On a high-wheeled bicycle three score years ago a youth with a great love of nature used to pedal leisurely along the footpaths of the Bronx River, at times dismounting for a swim in an inviting pool.

Japan's penetration into China is gradually depriving the latter nation of many major sources of foreign exchange, exporters pointed out here yesterday. While China is well supplied with money and able to pay here in cash for the supplies and equipment she buys, a considerable volume of annual revenue has been taken over by Japan through seizure of major shipping and trading centers of the nation.

Former Supreme Court Justice Charles Poletti, Democratic candidate for Lieutenant Governor, made a plea last night over radio Station WHN and a State-wide hookup for support of Amendment 4, which provides means of subsidizing housing for low-income groups.

The research work of the Arctic Institute of the Northern Sea Route Administration is being radically reorganized to the accompaniment of the continued elimination of "wreckers," it was announced today by Ivan Papanin, vice chief of the Sea Route Administration. Mr. Papanin won world fame last year as the head of the Soviet's North Pole expedition.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Lillian Nalle, daughter of Lieut. Col. William Nalle, Cavalry. U.S.A., and Mrs. Nalle of this city, to Lieuten ant Robert Nabors Tyson, Field Artillery, U.S.A., son of Mrs. Archibald Lowndes Tyson of Montgomery and Tuscaloosa, Ala., and the late Mr. Tyson.

John C. Rutherford, writer, lecturer and publisher, died this morning at Borgess Hospital following a brief illness. He was 73 years old. Mr. Rutherford had been a resident. of Kalamazoo for twenty years and in recent years had been owner of the Arts and Crafts Press of this city.

The marriage of Miss Lois Hamilton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emmett S. Hamilton of Queens Village, to Donald Leask Fuller of Stamford, Conn., took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents. The Rev. Dale De Witt performed the ceremony.

The extent to which construction activity in the New York area has risen this year compared with last year is vividly shown in a survey, made public yesterday by the F. W. Dodge Corporation, of construction contracts awarded in this vicinity during September and the first nine months of the year and similar periods of 1937.

In the closing days of the American Federation of Labor's annual convention every sign-despite the government's desire for mediation-pointed toward continuation of warfare by the federation against the Committee for Industrial Organization, on a broader front than before.
WITH Arabia, the polar regions and the interior of New Guinea, Tibet shares the distinction of having been ignored or missed by travel agencies.
Brig. Gen. George C. Marshall, Assistant Chief of Staff for War Plans, has been promoted to the post of Deputy Chief of Staff. He will be succeeded in his present post by Brig. Gen. George V. Strong.

The National Arts Club, in its efforts to encourage younger and unknown artists and to promote the mutual acquaintance of art lovers and art workers, is engaged in preliminary plans for an entertainment that is expected to be a colorful feature of the Winter season.

The marriage of Miss Maude Elizabeth Hardingham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Cecil Hardingham of North Plainfield, to George Alvin Cowee Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. George Alvin Cowee of Brookline, Mass., took place at noon today in the First Presbyterian Church, Plainfield.

This year will go down in golf annals marked by a revolt among the women who have handicaps of 6 or less and who therefore are eligible to play in the national championship. The uprising began with loud protests by all the contestants who had to start in the qualifying round at Westmoreland Sept. 19 so bundled up in sweaters,

HIGH on a ridge of the Blue Mountains in Eastern Pennsylvania a group of warmly clad people sit looking intently to the north. Before them a great saucer-like valley, decorated with a neat pattern of multi-colored farm land, stretches away to distant foothills. Below them the mountainside, darkly carpeted with trees, falls sharply away from a tumbled mass of gray rocks.

Miss Constantia Elizabeth Pleasants, daughter of Mrs.- Elizabeth W. Pleasants of Wynnewood and of Dr. Henry Pleasants of West Chester, was married this afternoon to Nathaniel Bowditch, son of Mrs. Henry Ingersoll Bowditch of Jamaica Plain, Mass., and the late Dr. Bowditch. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Gibson Bell in All Saints Church at Wynnewood.

WHEN a private library grows so as to include famous and unique books in English literature it has a slim chance of remaining private, in the sense of being unknown to the book trade at large.

Cincinnati Street Railway Company--Nine months to Sept. 30: Net income $52,228, after expenses and charges, equal to ii certs a common share, compared with a net of $168,787, or 36 cents a share, in the first nine months of 1937.
Miss Muriel Farnum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome E. Farnum of Providence, R. I., was married near here this afternoon to Philip Torchio Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Torchio of Bronxville, N. Y.

IF the first American production of "Hamlet" in its entirety won praise last Wednesday for a son of Britain, Ireland was not without honor too. With pawkiness befitting the moment, one of the most distinguished and cherubic progeny of County Ulster reaffirmed that he was a doyen of gravediggers in Elsinore.
Featurning two long touchdown jaunts and a strong opening running attack, Rhode Island State defeated Massachusetts State, 20 to 0, today.

Dartmouth undergraduates active in museum work will have a full year ahead of them as a result of the student expedition which returned from South Dakota and Wyoming this Summer with five crates of vertebrate fossils.

WHEN we turn to the international display of art at Pittsburgh we can, thank God, for the time being, forget about international politics. That doing so is, besides, an urgent requisite to the proper state of mind adds to one's sense of blessedness a sense of righteousness.

The most important single problem faced by the building industry at the present time, declared Stewart McDonald, FHA Administrator, is the development of neighorhoods so that they may resist he many deteriorating influences which have, in former years, either completely or partially destroyed the early home character of hunreds of communities.
Johnny Wysocki put on a one-man show today to. lead Villanova's undefeated Wildcats to their third straight victory, a 35-to-6 triumph over Centre College.

Earnings on capital invested in the steel industry have declined from an annual average return on investment of 8 per cent in 1910 to 1.5 per cent in 1938, the American Iron and Steel Institute reports.

Sammy Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va.; professional golf's leading money winner, carded a sub-par 65 today over the Sands Point Club's 6,404-yard course in an exhibition best-ball match. Snead, playing with Stuart Scheftel, amateur from the home club, turned back Captain Ernest F. Carter, also of Sands Point, and Jimmy Hines of Lakeville, metropolitan open titleholder, 2 and 1.
A drastic decline in exports complicates the Administration's efforts to solve agriculture's most pressing problem-the existence of price-depressing cotton surpluses, farm officials said today.

Weight, speed and power, wrapped in the colors of the University of Oklahoma, smothered a willing but wanting University of Kansas football team, 19 to 0, today in the season's first Big Six game for both.

Householders preparing to -store their. screens during the Winter are advised that to prevent warping they should either be stood up in racks or be laid flat. If stacked, it is important that the surface on which they are stacked be level and that each screen be placed squarely on the one below it.
Miss Betty Carpenter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward N. Carpenter of this place and Boston, was martried here this afternoon in the Church of the Holy Name to Lawrence F. Percival Jr., son of Mr.

The Kentucky-Tennessee Light and Power Company (Bowling Green, Ky.), a subsidiary of the Associated Gas and Electric System, has filed a declaration under the Holding Company Act covering issuance of a $750,000 4 1/4 per cent note to the First National Bank of Boston.

Minnesota's mighty men of the gridiron, their power house dynamited today by a scrappy Michigan wrecking crew, unveiled a puzzling passing attack to come from behind with six minutes to play and win, 7 to 6.

Playing heads-up football all the way, an aggressive Clarkson Tech eleven made its first meeting with City College a brilliant success at the Lewisohn Stadium yesterday, beating the Lavender before 4,000 fans by 19-6.
Proper foresight in the construction of shelves in the home is advised by a builder who points out that poor arrangement will eventually lead to home inconveniences.

N cooperation with Dr. Frank Graves, State Commissioner of Education, and Howard Pillsbury, Superintendent of Schools at Schenectady, a short-wave lecture series, opening on Nov. 1 over W2XAF and W2XAD, will aim to acquaint foreign listeners with the historical, social and economic background of the American school system.
Paul Governale scored all the points as undefeated, untied and unscored-on Evander Childs vanquished James Monroe, 14 to 0, before a crowd of 2,500 on Evander Field yesterday.

Columbia College has undertaken in intensive survey of each memer of the freshman class to prowide a basis for guiding the stuients in an intelligent plan of elecive work in their junior and senior rears, Dean Herbert E. Hawkes revealed in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.
DURHAM, N. H.-The University of New Hampshire's ocean zoological laboratory will have a new supervisor at Isles of Shoals next June.

Declaring that the time had come for the United States to strengthen its defenses against foreign aggression, Bernard M. Baruch said yesterday in an interview that he believed the American people would not object to paying the costs, no matter how great they might be.

Secretary Ickes, reputedly offended at being advertised as the attraction at a scheduled Los Angeles meeting where admission was to be charged, passed up a speaking engagement at Boulder Dam today and came to San Francisco five days ahead of time.

Since the beginning of the century about $220,000,000 have been granted by philanthropic foundations to some 300 colleges, the major portion to twenty or thirty. These grants have in turn stimulated the giving of a further $660,000,000.
Joseph Fischer, president of the Fischer Baking Company and a native of Newark, died here last night in St. Michael's Hospital after a week's illness. He was 59 years old.

Miss Mary Elizabeth Shick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick a. Shick of this city, and Walter J. Bragdon Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bragdon of Pittsburgh, were married here this evening in the Parker Memorial Church.

No other improvement, perhaps, contributes so much to making life in a farm home more convenient and healthful during the Winter than the installation of a complete water system with modern plumbing, states the Plumbing and, Heats ing Industries Bureau.

THE time of bird migration has come again and across the entire continent from the storm-lashed shores of Long Island to the foothills of the Rockies great wedge-shaped flocks of ducks and geese will soon be black against the sunset.

John M. Mendinhall, president of the Security Trust Company and a former Lieutenant Governor, died yesterday at the Homeopathic Hospital, where he had undergone an operation two weeks ago. He had been improving until yesterday when complications developed. His age was 71.

What is said to be the world's fourth diamond in size has now been examined by Treasury experts here. Found in the State of Minas Geraes it weighs 726.6 karats in the rough or six-tenths of a karat under the Jonker diamond from South Africa. It is 60.4 karats
A superior Amherst team that rolled up all its points in three periods trounced a slow-moving Rochester eleven, 41--6, today.

The University of Southern California Trojans ran into a battling band of Washington State Cougars today but finally subdued them, 19 to 6, to chalk up their second Pacific Coast Conference victory before a crowd of 45,000 fans.

THIS is the week that the major orchestras return to town. The Philharmonic Symphony, under John Barbirolli, begins its season on Thursday night, while the Philadelphia Orchestra pays its first visit of the new year on Tuesday.

THE exhibition of models submitted in the national competi tion for the design of a large bronze panel -to-be -placed above the entrance of the Associated Press Building, Rockefeller Center, is interesting on several counts.

RESIDENT ROOSEVELT has dropped the phrase "a little left of center" to describe the direction of his policy and the slant of his mind. He has revived the old-fashioned word "liberal," long rather obsolete in the political vocabulary.

Police, brandishing nightsticks, escorted gray uniformed members of the German-American Bund from a. meeting hall here tonight as a crowd which had gathered outside shouted threats and jeers. Despite police vigilance, tires on automobiles belonging- to several bund members were slashed,

The outstanding acquisition in nineteenth-century French art by the. Metropolitan Museum of Art since it received the bequest of Mrs. H. O. Havemeyer some years ago is a grisaille painting, "Odalisque"

OSCAR WILDE was prosecuted under the moral code on April 27, 1895. It was a trial from which no one emerged with honor. Although Wilde had written at least one play that still ranks with the finest work in English comedy, his career was destroyed and he died five years later.

The downward tendency of the principal foreign exchanges reasserted itself yesterday, after the brief rally on Friday. The pound sterling lost 3-16 cent and closed at $4.73 7-16, off 5 1-16 cents net in the week, while the French franc at 2.64 7/8 cents was unchanged in the

A general fight in which-several persons were cut and bruised halted a speech here tonight by Representative Clare E. Hoffman, Republican, of Michigan, at a political rally sponsored by the Republican State committee.

OIL has broken loose again in Mexico. It has burst the slender bonds of lease and treaty, gone roaring up through the quaking field of international relations, spattered its black energy across the wide Atlantic.

Three families were ordered from their homes and a score of basements were flooded when a 36-inch water main broke in the Bowery between Fourth and Fifth Streets at 3:05 A. M. yesterday. Three merchants affected by the flood estimated their damage at $100,000.
Mr. and Mrs. J. Stuart Tompkins of New York and Little Compton, R. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Church Tompkins, to Douglas Houston Kenyon.

Justice John Alexander of Schenectady, presiding here in court today set trial for Oct. 24 of six negligence actions in which plaintiffs seek to recover $110,750 from Francis Martin Jr. and his father, Supreme Court Justice Francis Martin Sr. of the Bronx.

Probably it was news to many people that, in the opinion of a national defense expert like B. M. Baruch (fresh from a conversation on the subject with the President, who is also an expert), the United States is unprepared to wage a defensive war. Undoubtedly the expression of this view was also a shock to those who have noted the leaping appropriations for this very purpose.

A large home containing seven rooms and three baths has just been completed in the Alden Esstates community on King Street, Port Chester, Westchester County, for John C. Chenery, vice president of the building firm of Mahlstedt Materials, Inc., of New Rochelle.

The marriage of Miss Marjorie Waite, daughter of Mrs. Knopf Waite of Orange, to Donald Dey Johnstone of New York took place this afternoon in the Episcopal Church of St. Andrew, South Orange. The rector, the Rev. F. Randall Williams, performed the ceremony.

The marriage of Miss Virginia Carver Whittier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Tupper Whittier, to Dr. Thomas Angell Warthin of Baltimore, son of Mrs. Aldred Scott Warthin of Ann Arbor, Mich., and the late Dr. Warthin, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, 30 Sidney Place, Brooklyn.

It has been reported by the executive committee, headed by Mrs. Diego Suarez, that half the house has already been sold for the performance of "First in the Hearts," a new musical comedy, with William Gaxton and Victor Moore in the leading roles, on the night of Nov. 3 at the Imperial Theatre for the benefit of the Maternity Center Association.

Given a tremendous psychological lift by their spectacular victory over the champion Washington Redskins last week, the New York Giants, back in the running for the Eastern Division crown in the National Football League, will meet the Philadelphia Eagles at the Polo Grounds today in the first Sunday game there this season.

L. W. Childress, president of the Laclede Gas Light Company, announced yesterday that the company intends to apply to the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to extend to April 1, 1942, its $10,000,000 of first-mortgage 5 per cent bonds which will mature on April 1, 1939.

An offer to provide the services of a landscape engineer free to any community interested in beautifying its Hudson River frontage has been made known by the Hudson River Conservation Society, Inc. of 542 Fifth Avenue.

Taking advantage of the presence here on Wednesday of a large number of women assembled for its semi-annual executive meeting, the National Committeee on the Cause and Cure of War has arranged a dinner in celebration of its fourteenth anniversary.
