It will be held at the Park Lane Hotel. Mrs. Henry Hill Pierce is chairman.
Iowa's Hawkeyes broke their co-lease with Chicago on the Big Ten cellar today by outpointing the Maroons, 27 to 14, before a crowd of 8,000 at Stagg Field.

The National Construction Conference, under the auspices of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, will be held in Washington at the chamber's headquarters Thursday and Friday, John W. O'Leary, chairman of the executive committee of that organization, announced yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Howard C. Turner of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance Turner, to William Arthur Dupee Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Arthur Dupee, also of Boston.

On Monday, Oct. 24, the Government of the United States, through the operation of the new national labor standards-or Wages and Hours Law, will formally initiate the second legislative attempt of the New Deal to "put a floor under wages and a ceiling over hours."
Red Cross headquarters state in a final report tonight that 57,034 houses were damaged or destroyed in the September hurricane and flood which struck Long Island and New England.

President Roosevelt, attending the theatre for the second time since he has been in the White House, laughed heartily at sallies poking fun at the government in "Knickerbocker Holidays," a musical comedy dealing with New Amsterdam, in which Walter Huston takes the role of Peter Stuyvesant, Governor of the seventeenth-century city which later became New York.
Scientists tonight brought a dying 16-monthold baby boy back to the path of life-only to say that he must travel it in total blindness.

A comparison of the prevailing dimensions of room doors of today and those of earlier periods, reveals the fact that in colonial times the doors were frequently three feet or more in width and less than six feet six inches high.
St. Lawrence University rode to a 21-12 victory over the Cortland Normal Red Dragons today.

Heads of the nation's largest banks, meeting in Chicago today and yesterday, agreed that bankers should do an aboutface in their attitude toward the public. They decided that bankers with large cash reserves in their vaults should tell the public why they are not lending to industry, instead of holding the cash without explanation and thereby antagonizing outside opinion.
Palestine, at grips with an Arab rebellion, regained communication with the outside world today after nineteen hours of isolation.

LUCK: Sir Harry Twyford, Lord Mayor of London, took off from London last week in a Belgian airliner. At Brussels he left the plane, which continued on its way to Essen and Berlin. Over the Ruhr Valley the Belgian plane lost a wing, fell in flames.
The ardent welcome extended Mack Harrell at his first New York recital yesterday afternoon was fully merited by the unusual musicianship made known in his singing.
Yale's own "community chest" campaign, the Budget Drive, has amassed $20,700 for this year's humanitarian purposes, bringing its sixteen-year total to more than $350,000.

The collection of eighteenth century furniture, Georgian silver and other art objects assembled by the late Ormond G. Smith, realized $33,433.50, it was announced yesterday by the Parke-Bernet Galleries, where it was sold Friday and yesterday.
A luncheon at the Hartford Golf Club tomorrow, with members from all parts of the State attending, will open a week devoted to the purposes of the Connecticut League of Women Voters. Ward E. Duffy,

FOR some time now, Billy Rose has denied as "grossly exaggerated" the persistent rumor that vaudeville is dead and he has invited mourners around to the Casa Manana, where he is willing to show proof.
Sparked by the flashy playing of Ray Craft, the Washington and Lee Generals upset a favored University of Kentucky football team, 8 to 0, today before 10,000 sweltering spectators.

Jerry Levin, brilliant young swimmer of Abraham Lincoln High School, again shattered the Public School Athletic League record for 220 yards free style yesterday in the second series of dual meets for the Brooklyn-Richmond senior high team championship in the 25-yard pool of Brooklyn Technical High School.

JUDITH ANDERSON, who has been absent from Broadway for a couple of years, likely will be wending her way back as Queen Elizabeth in the John Colton play "The Two Queens." This is the work Mr. Colton has based upon Schiller's "Mary Stuart," arid it has borne at least two other titles: "A Cry Among the Reeds" and "The Last Days of Mary Stuart."

ALTHOUGH folk art would seem to be the direct opposite of modern industrial art, both serve fundamentally the same purpose: the beautifying of articles of everyday use. So it is appropriate that the Swedish festival in Brooklyn.

PHILATELIC facts and rumors originating in troubled Europe seeped through to New York last week, and when these have been sifted and analyzed it will undoubtedly be found, in the opinion of veteran collectors, that the situation involving the partial dismemberment of Czechoslovakia has produced new stamps in line with speculations made in these columns recently.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., Oct. 18: LIEUTENANTS--Harry P. McCann, from 37th Precinct to 18th Division, assignment to desk duty discontinued. Charles G. Tiersch, from 12th Division to 67th Precinct, assignment to desk duty continued .

The blockfront of apartment houses at 1,812 Arthur Avenue, 637 and 641 East 175th Street and 1,815 Belmont Avenue, in the Bronx, has been sold by the Julia Realty Corporation to an investing client of Gerard M. Blumfield through the Morgenthau-Seixas Company, brokers.

WRITING after the German annexation of Austria, Willi Frischauer prophesied with a certain despairing matter-of-factness, that "the annexation of the technically German Sudetens could only be prevented by a war on which no country would dare embark."

Four monks have been arrested, it was disclosed today, for a demonstration apparently designed to protest an ejection order against their monastery. The monastery building is State property, and notice was served on the order last July to evacuate the third floor, which was required for secret police offices.

The scheduled appearance of Secretary of War Harry A. Woodring at the Hague rally to be held at the armory here Monday night in behalf of William H. J. Ely, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, is interpreted by Republican leaders as an indication that the rumored gap between the Roosevelt Administration and Mayor Hague has been bridged.

Governor Lehman continued yesterday his study of a list of possible candidates for appointment as specialpresecutor to supersede District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn in the inquiry he ordered into alleged official corruption in the borough. No selection has been made and none will be announced before tomorrow, if then.

Last Summer Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, interrupting his medical research, left his home on the Island of St. Gildas off the French coast for an aerial tour of Europe. Mrs. Lindbergh went with him. They flew to Moscow, where, warmly welcomed by the Russians, they saw the annual Aviation Day demonstration of Soviet flying.

Cadiz this morning witnessed the greatest parade in any one's memory if not in Cadiz's history when 10,000 Italian Legionnaires marched past the tribune where General Gonzalo Queipo de Llano, commander of the Southern Insurgent army, took the farewell salute on behalf of General Francisco Franco.

A convention of registered architects in New York State will be held under the auspices of the New York State Association of Architects at the Hotel Pennsylvania beginning Thursday, Oct. 27, and continuing through the week.

The Brooklyn-Queens Circumferential Parkway may be the means of staving off the impending flight of factories and allied industrial concerns from Brooklyn, according to a statement made yesterday by the Brooklyn Real Estate Board.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Mary Adair Edwards, daughter of Mrs. Gaston Holeombe Edwards of Orlando, Fla., and the late Dr. Edwards, to Dr. Edward William Phifer Jr., sonof Dr. and Mrs. Phifer of Morganton, N. C.

A legal point has been raised concerning a woman's right to sit on grand juries in three of New York's counties-Kings, Bronx and New York. It comes just as New York women have rounded out their first year of jury service, in which they have solemnly sworn to render a true verdict according to the evidence, and, according to all accounts, they have done the job well.

The marriage of Miss Barbara Houston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar R. Houston of this place, to John Lewis Grose, son of Mr. and Mrs. Waldo Grose of Great Neck, took place here this afternoon in All Saints Church.

It does seem a pity that New York should have to put up with the hoodlums whose depredations in our parks and playgrounds, according to Park Engineer William H. Latham, are costing us $250,000 a year. The money loss is comparatively small. It is the thought that some subhuman species is at work taking vengeance on ordinary humanity that is appalling.

When some of the more pressing planting problems such as the making of the lawn and the design of flower borders are out of the way, the owners of new homes find that the time has arrived when some decision must be made as to what hardy vines to put out.

Plans for the extension of the engineering laboratory facilities of Manhattan College were disclosed yesterday by Professor Clarence J. Velz, recently appointed head of the Department of Civil Engineering. The new laboratories, which will be situated in Manhattan Hall, will contain facilities for investigation in hydraulics, soil mechanics, structures and materials and sanistation.
The clerical worker, whose chances of employment in a highly crowded field stand in great need of improvement, has found new champions for her cause.

There is consternation in business and banking circles of Shanghai because of the Tokyo announcement that the millions of Bank of Japan yen in circulation in Central China would be replaced shortly by "war notes."

A series of teas is being held at the studio of Mme. Luella Melius, 152 West Fifty-seventh Street, for her singing pupils, among whom are several women of prominence in society here and in other cities.

The wheat market today showed a steady undertone. Prices on the Board of Trade here held within a range of 1/4 to 1/2 cent a bushel. There was no material pressure and late in the session sufficient professional buying developed in sympathy with an upturn in Winnipeg to lift prices moderately.

Mrs. Thomas J. Moran and Miss Charlotte A. Schaettler will be hostesses in charge of the annual benefit card party and bazaar of the Silver Cross Day Nursery to be held the afternoon of Nov. 17 at the Plaza.

A fire swept the three-story building housing the Fischer-Beer specialty store at 308-10 Washington Street here tonight, routing the occupants of three apartments on the top floor and the residents of near-by buildings.
The Colonial Trust Company has been appointed trustee for East Thirtieth Street Corporation firstmor age bonds and transfer agent of the voting trust certificates for the corporation's common stock.
On the thirtieth anniversary of the marriage of the bridegroom's parents and in the same setting Miss Katherine Isabelle Hannan, daughter of Mr. and

The first of the exhibitors' buildings of the New York World's Fair of 1939 was completed yesterday. Signalizing the completion of its ninety-foot dome which is 150 feet in diameter, the H. J. Heinz Company flew the flags of the great nations from its new building designed not only as an exposition, building but as a "milestone" marking the seventieth anniversary of the founding of the company.
Miss Clara Gertrude Koch, daughter of Mrs. Henry John Koch of the Bronx and the late Mr. Koch, was married to John Sherrard Welles of Plainfield, N. J., last night in the Fordham Lutheran Church.

The photographs in the rotogravure section of today's TIMES indicate that the inhabitants gave a joyous welcome to the German Army as it marched into the Sudetenland. But it is obvious that these photographs, whether depicting staged demonstrations or not, do not present the whole picture.

Swarthmore College defeated American University, 14-6, today in the local school's 1938 football inaugural. American tallied on a- 54-yard pass from Emerson Barlett to Hugo Schulze early-in the first period.

New York and other cities owe a good deal to Dr. John A. Harriss, who died last week at the too early age of 63. Dr. Harriss was a physician and business man, with a multitude of interests, but he gave many years of his best energies to the problem created by the automobile in city streets.

THE effort to re-create the subjective world of a child must be one of the most inviting of all literary tasks. We see it undertaken, season after season, by this or that novelist of acknowledged talent.

Andover defeated the Northeastern freshmen at football today, 16 to 6, two Blue and White touchdowns coming as a result of recovered fumbles. Bissett, Gould and Townson covered 74 yards in three plays to give Andover its first score and Bissett's 25-yard romp around left end accounted for the second.

A series of lecture-forums on international relations, with Nathaniel Peffer as conductor, will be held Tuesday nights at the County Center here under the auspices of the Westchester Workshop of the County's Recreation Commission, it was announced today by Charles B. Cranford, administrator of the workshop.

THOUGHTS of trees are much in the public mind these days, alike in the city, where fine familiar elms and maples of parks and residence streets lie uprooted and dying from the hurricane's wrath, and in the country for miles around, where woodlands are heaped with the wreckage of the blast and where harm has been done beyond hope of mending in a generation.

Uniforms in the diplomatic service will be banned, it was announced today. Foreign Minister Oswaldo Aranha's order was included in a decree announcing extensive changes in the consular and- diplomatic services of Brazil.

In streamlining the curriculum of the government Indian schools, the United States Indian Service has given studied consideration to music. What place should music have in the curriculum of the Indian school? To what extent may native music figure in the complete musical program? And by what practical means or methods can this material be presented most effectively?

Lanky Neal Martin, a whirling dervish of a halfback, led the scarlet-shirted University of Arkansas Razorbacks to a 42--6 victory today over the Texas Longhorns Thrice in the first half Martin swivel-hipped his way over the Texas goal line from within the 10 yard stripe. He watched proceedings from the bench in the last half.

The Modern Kitchen Bureau reports that the modern kitchen uses electrical equipment for efficiency. This equipment is arranged in the order in which it is used in the preparation of a meal. Such an orderly arrangement saves time, effort and nerve strain.

The Federal Trade Commission made public today a brief by James M. Hammond, one of its trial attorneys, which argued that the Ford Motor Company, acting concertedly and in cooperation with the Universal Credit Corporation, had been committing a "flagrant deception" on the public in advertising and using a so-called "6 per cent plan" for financing deferred-payment sales of its cars.
The Citadel's Bulldogs scored a touchdown and a safety in the second period today to defeat Furman, 9 to 6, in a Southern Conference football game. A crowd of 10,000 saw. the contest.

The "Moriz Rosenthal Golden Jubilee Committee," headed by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Governor Lehman and Dr. -Sylvester Gruszka, Consul General of Poland, has been organized to take charge of activities for the concert which Mr. Rosenthal will give in Carnegie Hall on Nov. 13 in celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of his American debut.

The Greenfield, Carroll and Cosmopolitan Clubs remained the only undefeated teams as play in the Women's New York Field Hockey Association interclub matches was concluded on the fields at Prospect Park yesterday.
Scoring in the first and fourth periods, George Washington University downed Colorado University, 13 to O, before 8,000 fans today to keep its goal line uncrossed and its undefeated record intact.

IN 1906, a little over a decade after Lillian Wald had come down to the lower East Side to inaugurate a neighborhood service which developed into the Henry Street Settlement, she was appointed a member of Mayor McClellan's Pushcart Commission.

Dr. Parke H. Schoch, former associate superintendent of Philadelphia public schools, died today at his home in St. David's at the age of 70. Before his retirement in September, 1937, because of illness, he had taught in this city for some forty-five years.

Announcement has been made here by Mr and Mrs. M. Lester Madden of Newton, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Grace E. Madden, to Stevenson E. Ward Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ward of Bronxville, N. Y.

Two Republicans, possessors of names famous in American history, are candidates for Governor this Fall in Massachusetts and Rhode Island. Leverett Saltonstall, descendant of Sir Richard Saltonstall, who settled Watertown in 1630, is opposing former Governor Curley, Democrat, in Massachusetts.

Leonard Harshner of near-by Montoursville was in the Lycoming County jail today for the week-end, the first installment of his sentence for violating the State Motor Code. He must spend two week-ends in the jail.

Action by the New York Security Dealers Association and the Security Traders Association of New York in complying with the provisions of the Maloney act for selfregulation of the over-the-counter security business will await the formation of a national association, Frank Dunne, president of the former group, stated in a letter sent last week to all members.

Union College is sponsoring a commemorative "first-day cover" in honor of Chester A. Arthur, former President of the United States, whose portrait will appear on the new 21-cent postage stamp scheduled to be issued on Nov. 22.

ONE-MAN shows of the week included the New York debut of Warren Chase Merritt, a water-colorist, who comes forward with endorsement from John Taylor Arms and a further explanatory foreword by Mrs. Merritt, otherwise Aline Kistler.

Wilbur Chase, for more than sixty years an official of the Middlesex Mutual Assurance Company of this city, and secretary at his retirement in 1932, died in the Middlesex Hospital today at the age of 88 years.
Skidmore College alumnae will return to the campus next week on Saturday and Sunday for the annual Fall reunion and meeting of the Alumnae Council.

Under the auspices of the Alice Hall Ali Committee of the Prosperity Shop, a luncheon with dancing and entertainment will be held today in the Green Room Cafe of the Madison for the benefit of the Northern Dispensary of the City of New York.
WHILE Autumn winds blow over European short-wave lanes, radio programs from the far south, sailing across the Equator, reflect the Spring sunshine now moving toward Argentina and Chile.

Dr. M. Leon Levine of the development syndicate at Bedford Avenue, between Avenues X and Y, in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn announces home sales to Max Bernstein, Mrs. Helene S. Kalnick, Mrs. Regina Kraminitz, Mrs. Anna Pescow, Mrs. Regina Rodin and Mrs. Ethel Schantz. Dr. Levine, who is associated with his brothers, Harry and Louis Levine, reports that the work has started on a new group of six houses on Bedford Avenue.

In the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church here yesterday afternoon Miss Anne Child, daughter of Mrs. Edmund William Pavenstedt of New York and Washington, D. C., and of the late Richard Washburn Child, one-time United States Ambassador to Italy, was married to Charles Barstow Wright Dick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Langhorne

Fourteen divisions of PolishAmericans from the metropolitan area, expected to number 75,000, will march today in the second annual Pulaski Memorial Day paTrade. The line of march will be from Washington Square up Fifth Avenue to Fifty-fourth Street, starting at 2 P. M.

Franklin and Marshall chalked up its third consecutive victory today, defeating Muhlenberg, 20 to 7, before 7,000 fans. The Lancaster collegians, with Abbie Asplin, 135-pound quarterback, and Captain Sammy Roeder, fullback, leading the attack, outplayed the Mules most of the way, registering fourteen first downs to Muhlenberg's eight.

MUCH heartened by the experience of accident reduction in the cities represented in its previous seminars of safety, the C. I. T. Safety Foundation will bring together tomorrow at Indianapolis editors, editorial and staff writers from all over the State of Indiana for a three-day seminar.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In THE TIMES of Oct. 12, Representative Wright Patman of Texas and the secretary of the Retail Druggists Association were reported as throwing their full weight behind the proposed national tax on interstate chain store systems.

Investigation into the death of Mrs. Maybelle Horlick Sidley, Racine, Wis., heiress to the malted milk fortune, will continue despite an adverse ruling by Justice C. P. McTague on the legality of an inquest.

To the Art Editor. HELIOGRAVURE" in French is photogravuree" in English. The French use "photogravure" where we use "photoengraving." Photogravures almost always require hand work with roulette, drypoint or graver.

Jim Gillette led Virginia to a 14to-6 victory over Virginia Tech today. V. P. I. marched from behind its goal to score on an electrifying pass attack in the last minute of play. A homecoming crowd of 7,000 saws the game.

With cries of "Clean up the Democratic mess at Harrisburg" and "rout the Republican reactionaries" resounding from platforms and radio loudspeakers all over the commonwealth, Pennsylvania is waiting for the next surprise in its campaign of name-calling and innuendo, a campaign in which the pulling of punches has nowhere been discernible.

Three new student groups have been formed at Smith College this Fall, at the suggestion of the students themselves, indicating a growing concern wih problems of health and adjustment and a widening interest in more general topics such as current events, education and religion.

The damage done by drought to this year's grain crop has been in a large measure offset by unusually good yields in the regions outside the drought areas, by good weather and by improved methods of agriculture, according to an article by N. Itskoff, Director of the All Union Institute of Grain Economy, in today's issue of Pravda.

United States Attorney John J. Quinn arranged today for special sessions of the Federal Grand Jury at Newark to hear Norman Thomas and other witnesses on charges that he was "kidnapped" by police when he attempted to speak in Jersey City April 30. Mr. Thomas will also attempt to prove civil rights are disregarded by Mayor Hague.

Word was received in Chicago today of the death in Atlanta yesterday of William Otis Swett Jr., an artist, who was a pupil of Whistler. His age was 79. He was the brother of Arthur Hollister Swett, president of the American Tag Company of Chicago.

Officers of the New York State Association of Young Republican Clubs conferred yesterday with District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, nominee for Governor, and decided to establish a first voters' bureau as part of their campaign for Mr. Dewey's election.

The appointment of J. D. Dawson as general Eastern freight agent here of the Seaboard Air Line Railway has been announced. Mr. Dawson succeeds B. F. Black, who retired for reasons of health after holding the position sixteen years and after a career of forty-two years with the comanpy.

Captain Giles c. Stedman, master of the United States liner Washington, will be relieved for two voyages of his ship to serve six weeks on the staff of Rear Admiral W. A. Anderson on the U. S. S. Northampton, flagship of the heavycruiser division of the Pacific Fleet, it was announced yesterday. He will leave Monday for Los Angeles to join the ship.

STEP by step the National Socialist regime of Germany continues to materialize its vast and totalitarian program, designed to give reality to both the Nationalist and Socialist aspect of its composite name.

Nothing has been more curious in all the fantastic history of the past few weeks than the meek acceptance by the British. Government and by thee greater part of the British press of what might have been regarded in other times as the direct interference by -the head of the..German .Government in the internal affairs of this country.

Miss Phyllis Jane Reid, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Williamson Reid of this city, was married to Ross B. Cameron of Freehold, N. J., son of Jesse B. Cameron of Allenhurst and the late Mrs. Cameron,
Syracuse University's "model" student government will swing into action for its second year following assembly elections Tuesday.

The colored-glass window, it is explained, owes its development to the fact that window makers were generally confined to small pieces of glass. These had to be joined together by strips of grooved lead, which, because of flexibility, could be made to fit around the small sections of glass.

Was the handsome, stout-hearted Prince who answered Snow White's prayers-who brought tears of tenderness to mother's eyes, made little boys wish they were princes, too, and little girls yearn for fairy-tale lives-was the Prince a Yale man?

Part-time work for 378 students will be provided at the University of Pittsburgh this year by the National Youth Administration, according to Robert J. Munce, instructor in sociology and director of the NYA project.

Edwin Hale Lincoln, 90, a Civil War veteran and once first vice commander of the national encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic, was killed in an automobile accident on South Street, near his home, tonight.

Bus Burrill intercepted a lateral, Horne to Mitchell, and ran 21 yards for a touchdown in the early minutes to provide the only score in Colby's 6-0 victory over New Hampshire today. The losers penetrated to within ten yards of Colby's goal line three times, but lost the ball on downs each time.

With a story book finish that will long be remembered here on Piety Hill, Syracuse came from behind today to conquer Cornell, 19-17, leaving a crowd of 25,000 persons at Archbold Stadium exhausted by the surprising turn of events.

Izzy Jannazzo of New York and Gustave Eder, German welter-weight champion, battled to a fifteen-round draw tonight in a fight at Hanseaten Hall. Eder was seeking revenge for a 1936 defeat by Jannazzo.
The Commodity Credit Corporation through Oct. 16, had made advances on 939,593 bales of cotton from this year's crop, according to information received by the New York Cotton Exchange.

Movements of vesseis follow, all dates are Oct. 15, unless specified: At Naval Opeating Base, Norfolk: Boise, Raiph Talbot. Pearl Harbor to San Diego: Neches, via San Pedro: S-21, 22, 24, 26. Nitro, San Diege to San Pedro.
THE COLONIAL PERIOD OF AMERICAN HISTORY. Volume 4. By Charles M. Andrews. 8vo. New Haven, Conn.: Yale University Press. $4. Volume 4, England's Commercial and Colonial Policy.

The Chicago Public Library and its forty-five branches is regaining the book circulation lost during the mid-years of the depression, according to Carl D. Roden, librarian. There were 931,384 volumes taken out last month as against 629,619 for September, 1937, a gain of 49 per cent.

The New York City schools will observe American Education Week from Nov. 7 to 10, during which period the parents and friends of the pupils will be invited to inspect the classrooms, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, announced.
Alfred University stretched its undefeated record to ten consecutive games tonight when it gained a 7-to-0 victory over the University of Buffalo.
Stanford came from behind to beat the University of Oregon, 27 to 16, today, giving the Northerners an unexpected setback in the Pacific Coast Conference football race.

Miss Helen Brown of the Towers Hotel, Brooklyn, daughter of Mrs. Philip Suss of Old Saybrook, Conn., and the late Harry Albert Brown of Brooklyn, was married to Arthur Morton Brown Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Brown of Hamden, Conn., yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Reformed Dutch Church of Flatbush.

Reporting seventy-six home sales in the third quarter of the year in the home community at Utopia Parkway and Horace Harding Boulevard, Flushing, L. 'I., Ben Swickle of the building syndicate said yesterday that ninety additional dwellings are nearing completion there.

The United States should insist that Great Britain make no disposition of Palestine without American thought and consultation, said Rabbi William F. Rosenblum in a sermon yesterday at Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-frst Street.

The Danish minority in Schleswig-Holstein, making capital of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's own words on the treatment of minorities, has addressed an open letter to him in an effort ?? improve the status of Danes living in Northern Germany.
Millard E. Gladfelter, Temple University registrar, predicted today that by 1942 American colleges would see a big drop in attendance figures.
DEADLIEST of the seven, or seventy, deadly sins of Hollywood is its unoriginality. There were two choice cases last week, the Warner "Secrets of an Actress" and the Hal Roach "There Goes My Heart."

If what is said about elephants' memories is true. Astra, a 5-yearold beast fresh from India, will never forget her naming yesterday in Prospect Park. where 10,000 persons, mostly children, gathered in the Music Grove to welcome the newcomer to Brooklyn's zoo.

Army made a desperate bid through the air in the dying moments of its game with Harvard today and the coup was successful enough to enable the cadets to outscore a surprisingly revivified Crimson eleven in a sensationally waged struggle, 20 to 17.

Hofstra and the New York Aggies battled to a 6-6 tie today, the Hofstra eleven coming through in the third period to tie the score. Bill Hillman gave the Aggies a 6-0 lead six minutes after the start. Intercepting Steve Backiel's pass, he ran 60 yards for the touchdown. Herb Thogode took a 22-yard aerial from Eddie Zendle and dashed 15 yards for the Hofstra marker.

General Manuel Avila Camacho, Secretary of National Defense, left by plane today to inspect northwestern military posts as troubles in the north, and particularly in the States of Sonora and Durango, have perturbed the government.
A 102-yard run for a touchdown by Steve Smoke saved Lehigh from a shut-out today as Penn State's Nittany Lions won an easy 59-to-6 victory.

About 1,000 watched Hotchke School tally twice in the first quarter to trounce Kent, 12 to 0, in football game today. The first score by Greene, came when Crowd blocked a kick on the 20-yard lick Taylor smashed over for the second touchdown after Hotchkiss by recovered a fumble on the Kent after the kick-off and had run passed to the 1-foot line.

The engagement of Miss Medera Francis Smith, daughter of Mrs. Frank Leslie Smith of Nashville, Tenn., and the late Mr. Smith, to Eric Franklin Lamb of this city and Boston, son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Lamb of Waban, Mass., has been announced by her mother.

An itinerary of almost 4,000 miles had been drawn up for the University of Pennsylvania's Mask and Wig Club musical show " All Around the Town," it was announced today by William M. Huggins, business manager of the club.

THE season of promenade concerts which is coming to an end has not been remarkable for novelties. Neither new compositions nor new performers have added interest to attractive programs dictated in the main by a sound but distinctly conservative policy. There were, however,

All communications between Hong Kong, British crown colony, and Canton were interrupted tonight as Japanese forces broadened their onslaught on the South China coast. Railway and highway bridges had been destroyed at several points by the aerial bombings that shielded

George Washington High's stal wart eleven remained undefeated and unscored upon as it ground out its third straight triumph at the expense of a stubborn DeWitt Clinton team, 20-0, at George Washington Stadium yesterday.
Lord Stanley, Secretary for Dominions in the British Cabinet and heir to the Earl of Derby, died at 3:30 A. M. today (10:30 P. M. E. S. T. Saturday). He was 44 years old.
The judges for the 1938 competition of the Pittsburgh Glass Institute have just been selected and they will announce the awards about the, middle of November.

EXHIBITIONS of manuscripts, letters and even more personal and intimate relics of great (and sometimes less great) composers have become nowadays an almost indispensable adjunct to every self-respecting European music festival.

More money was disbursed by savings, building and loan associations to home owners during August than during any previous month of this year, E. C. Baltz, Washington (D. C.) president of the United States Building and Loan League, announced yesterday.
Miss Irene Winifred O'Connor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Philip O'Connor of this city, was married yesterday morning to William John Harnisch, son of Mrs. William J. Harnisch of East
Detective Russell Hahn said tonight that Amos Hart Jr. of Frenchtown, N. J., had made a statement confessing that he shot and killed Mrs. Hazel Cronce Shrope, 22, also of Frenchtown, early today.

The report of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the principal operating subsidiaries in the Bell System for the twelve months ended on Aug. 31, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income of $156,741,291 after all operating expenses and taxes.

With the maintenance of Woodlawn, their new Alumnae House, as incentive, the Associate Alumnae of New Jersey College for Women started this week an intensive fundraising campaign under the direction of Mrs. Samuel G. Blackman of East Orange.

Led by Fullback Sammy Padjen, who scored three touchdowns, Dickinson subdued Delaware, 26--0, on Biddle Field today before 2,500 fans. Dickinson compiled sixteen first downs to ten in setting the pace for the visitors, who never seriously threatened the victors' goal line.
While the varsity was winning from Navy this afternoon, the Yale jayvee football team defeated the Navy jayvees, 7--0, on one thrilling play just as the first half ended.
A savage fourth-period attack, high-lighted by a last-minute 31yard touchdown pass, carried the resourceful Vanderbilt Commodores to a 13-to-7 victory over the University of Mississippi today.

PARK FALLS, Wis.--Deep in the heart of the Wisconsin cut-over wilds, where the Northern Lights play across Summer skies and the frosts come nipping almost the year round, Uncle Sam is creating a mighty wilderness playground.

Re fusal of the United States Supreme Court to review his case has disappointed Thomas J. Mooney far less than it has his lawyers, George T. Davis of San Francisco and John F. Finerty of New York, who had pressed the appeal over Mooney's protests. The prisoner,

Brazil today bluntly informed the Reich that she "did not desire the return of Dr. Karl Ritter to his post as Ambassador to Rio de Janeiro." The Reich promptly reciprocated with the flat demand that Jose Moniz de Aragao leave his Berlin post..
A Princeton team that had been regarded as having less than an even chance of beating Penn fought its rival to a standstill to score a 13-0 triumph as 35,000 looked on at Palmer Stadium today.
IN reviewing an earlier book on administrative law some eleven years ago it seemed worth while to recall to the
ZELLA JANSSEN, pulling her long nose, looking through you with her black eyes. owning and working a good farm, told Reen that she wanted Reen to have a baby.

President Roosevelt will speak in behalf of Governor Lehman's candidacy over the radio from Hyde Park on Nov. 4, from 9:30 to 10 P. M., the White House announced definitely today. There had been a tentative announcement of the President's intention, but the final details were arranged today in a telephone conversation between him and Governor Lehman today.

Gerald Ambrose O'Reilly, former vice president of the Irving Trust Company, died yesterday at his home, 90 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, after a long illness. He was born in Brandon, Wis., sixtysix years ago.
Development of a workable plan for student self-government was the subject of a conference this week at Cornell University between President Day and members of the Student Council.

In one of the finest races ever run for the trophy, John Strawbridge's gray gelding Coq Bruyere today won the Monmouth County Hunt Gold Cup at the thirteenth annual meeting of the Monmouth Racing Association on the estate of Amory L. Haskell.

The Czechoslovak Legation informed Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Foreign Minister, this afternoon that its government had decided to reopen negotiations with Hungary and was about to make fresh proposals on a new basis for the cession of Czech territory.

A new porous carbon which will be valuable in purifying water for household use, city supply and sewage disposal plants was described to delegates of the International Electrochemical Society at its closing session tonight.

ONCE more Vermont, stronghold of Republican individualism, has taken the individualist's stand. Her Governor. George D. Aiken, who in the past has uttered sharp words in criticism of his own Republican party. laconically announced that Vermont was ready to accept Federal help in flood-control work

Matthew Thornton, postoffice letter carrier, won a dark-horse victory today in the campaign for "Mayor of Beale Street." The Memphis World, Negro newspaper which sponsored the campaign, said Thornton polled about 12,000 of the 33,000-odd votes cast.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has signed a contract with the British Air Ministry calling for airplane spare parts in the amount of $3,900,000, the largest order for extra equipment that the company has ever received.

BRITAIN is not to be caught napping at the microphone in case of war, and so there was feverish activity at Broadcasting House while statesmen scurried about Europe during the recent international crisis which ended with the four-power agreement at Munich.

" You know that Napoleon when he formed his first consulate gathered only unimportant men around him." With these words Chancellor Hitler at one of the earliest meetings of the newly created Nazi party met objections against some of the collaborators whom he had chosen.

The Supreme Court considered today litigation that may affect deportation proceedings against Harry Bridges, West Coast labor leader. Before the Justices at their regular Saturday conference was a government petition seeking a review of a decision by the Fifth Circuit Court of

The Rutgers football team closed forty-five years of gridiron history on Nelson Field today when it defeated a surprisingly strong Springfield College eleven, 6 to 0. Next week the Scarlet moves across the Raritan River' to its new stadium to- play its first game on the new site against Hampden-Sydney of Virginia.

The New York Military Academy eleven was defeated today by Adelphi Academy of Brooklyn, 29 to 7. The Cadets scored early in the first period when Bill Nelson went over after taking the pass from Anido.

" Good Queen Eleanor," as she is known affectionately to many of her "subjects," celebrated her fifty-fourth birthday this week more as a great lady beloved of those who know her than as the wife of the President of the United States.

With the average home purchased during 1937 having a FHA loan, costing $5,065 and carrying a monthly payment of $32.43, the most popular mortgage contracts were for 80 per cent of the property value and called for amortization in twenty years, according to the current issue of the Architectural Forum.

The major portion of dresses in the $15.75 and $22.50 a dozen wholesale price brackets, formerly made from cotton wash goods, will be made from various spun rayons and spun-rayon mixtures, it was indicated last week in the purchases of Spring wash-goods lines.

The United States Rubber Company has made increases ranging from 2 per cent to 5 per cent in the price of tires, with the exception of the popular sizes, which remain unchanged. The price increases apply to the larger sizes, truck and bus tires and the company's line of rayon tires.

THE new-reign set of the British colony of St. Lucia in the West Indies reached New York last week. Unusually attractive in appearance, it gives philatelists several views not used on the island's stamps in the past.

PUSHING the task of ?? the Columbia. Broadcastin System's new $500,000 telesion transmitter atop ?? Chrysler Building toward its pletion date next January, Dr. ?? Goldmark, engineer in charge, ?? forward to seeing 1939 as the ?? experimental television will entthe American home.

While a chastened attitude was observable in steel quarters at the close of last week following price cuts of $4 a ton in several important rolled products, it was still impossible to determine what the future holds in store with respect to prices.
The committee for The Bachelors has sent out invitations for a Winter Ball to be given on Nov. 4 at the Plaza. The parties arranged by The Bachelors are for young married couples and post debutantes.

A revitalized University of Maine team registered its second victory of the season over a favored opponent in defeating Connecticut State, 13 to 0, efore 3, 500 fans today. The only Connecticut threats were blasted when Maine intercepted two forwards in the second period on the Maine 10 and 6 yard lines.

Dr. Edwin Sharp Burdell, former Dean of Humanities at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, will be installed as director of Cooper Union on Nov. 3, according to an announcement yesterday by Gano Dunn, president of the Union.

The Union College and Vermont elevens played before the largest opening game crowd on record here today and tied, 7 to 7. Union gained 370 yards to the Catamounts' 209 and made fourteen first downs to Vermont's ten. Sam Hammerstrom was the star of Union's attack.
The race meets at the Rolling Rock Club have attracted a large attendance from all parts of the United States, including many New Yorkers who were members of the various large house parties.

Before a background of shirt-sleeved spectators, unusual for this home of Winter sports, Dartmouth's football forces came through another game today, turning back a courageous and a fine Brown team by 34 to 13.

Approximately 500 candidates for the 208 Sejm [Diet] seats have been nominated by electoral committees composed of representatives of city councils, chambers of commerce, labor unions and similar organizations. Of these, 70 per cent are nominees of the Government party -the Camp of National Unity.
The French police today arrested three Rumanians and seized 150 pounds of heroin that they were accused of

President Roosevelt's announcement that in view of the international situation the United States proposes to embark on a vastly increased armament program, which is described as the biggest ever undertaken in its peacetime history, has produced a profound impression in German official quarters and a sensation in the German press.

Germnay's po-: litico-economic aspirations are again heading for the "Baghdad trail," that once hotly contested objective of prewar imperial expansionist ambitions. If the World War temporarily blasted that trail, its lost traces are now being recovered and exploited with a determination that presages a complete retracing of the trade map of the Balkans and the Near East.

A Rhode Island red hen won highest honors as "the hen of the year" yesterday at the fourth poultry exposition held under the auspices of the Northeastern Poultry Producers Council in the Port Authority Building, Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street. The show, which opened on Friday, will close on Tuesday night.
Wesleyan became the first team to defeat Haverford this season by winning today, 7-0, on the losers' gridiron.
" Farm relief" plans were threshed over in detail in the Middle West this week through the appearance of three national figures who engaged in a virtual three-cornered debate.

Since the black night when the Anglo-French two-hour ultimatum for acceptance of the Munich dictation was presented to former President Benes, Czechoslovakia has been in a: state of suspended animation. A country without defenses and with fluid frontiers cannot be reckoned as an independent State.

The Catholic Actors Guild will begin the celebration of its twentyfifth anniversary with a dance and entertainment tonight at the Plaza Hotel. George M. Cohan, whose father, Jerry Cohan, was the organization's first president, is the present leader of the Guild and will be present.
BAKER--Mr. and Mrs. Edward J., announce birth of a son, Oct. 11, 1938, at Polyclinic 1 Hospital. BARNETT-Mr. and Mrs. Ben, announce the birth of a son, Oct. 11, Brooklyn Women's Hospital.
Twenty sections will be represented in the eighth annual State conference of the National Council of Jewish Juniors to be held at the Park Central -Hotel Saturday and Sunday. Miss Beatrice Hahn of

The forthcoming Selima Stakes, to be renewed at the Laurel course in Maryland, is expected to see a continuation of the duel between Milky Way Farm's Dinner Date and Woolford Farm's Insoelda. These two met at Arlington Park in Chicago with Inscoelda the winner, but since that time Dinner Date has won again and again until it is likely that she will be installed the favorite.

Mrs. P. A. Shaw's Stage Beauty, the lone 3-year-oldandthe only filly in the field of nine, defeated some of the smartest sprinters in the East today to score a surprising victory in the $5,000 added Worcester Handicap at Narragansett Park.

To the Dram Editor: A few nights ago New Yorkers were privileged to attend "The Fabulous Invalid." It is a swiftmoving, smartly written show with something to suit all tastes, from Miss Dalton's hauntingly beautiful realization of the youthful Ethel Barrymore to a physically beautiful young woman's complete, realization of the strip tease.

The American Institute of Steel Construction was on record today in favor of a balanced Federal budget and relief of business from heavy taxation. The institute, winding up its four-day sixteenth annual convention yesterday, passed a resolution saying, "deficit financing and growing tax burdens are definitely curtailing investments and extensions."

Fifty students of the University of Vermont climbed the top of Mount Mansfield Sunday in annual observance of mountain day. C. L. Nussbaum, '40, of New York City, and C. O. Bailey, assistant director of the Fleming Museum, led two groups of hikers to the nose of the

The New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, of which Major Gen. James G. Harbord is chairman, made public yesterday the annual report covering the chapter's activities for the year ending last June 30.

The forthright answer of Governor Lehman to the industriously whispered charge that, if elected for a third term, he intended to resign after two years to run for the Senate, leaving Mr. Poletti in the Governor's chair, was inevitable in the character of the man. He does not make "deals."

The ground floor of the eighteenstory office building at 32 Broadway, opposite Morris Street and between Beaver Street and Exchange Place on the east side of the thoroughfare, has just been remodeled providing two ground floor stores and a new entrance lobby.

At a meeting of the Horticultural Society of New York on Wednesday at 2:30 P. M., at the society's headquarters, 598 Madison Avenue, there will be a talk on "Propagation of Primulas" by Mrs. Arthur Knapp, in conjunction with the regular monthly flower exhibition.

With all the objectives of its twenty-three-point program, laid out in 1933, either completed or on the way, the Bronx Board of Trade is inviting representative business and professional men and leaders in the real estate and building fields to offer suggestions for a new program of business and civic improvement, it was announced yesterday.

" Our Town's Health and Welfare" is the title of a series of lectures which the Junior League and the Welfare Council of the city will sponsor to mate more generally available information on the local welfare situation.

To aid those having contact with deaf or hard-of-hearing persons, free classes in lip reading and sign language have been organized for adults, Gustav A. Stumpf, project director of the. WPA adult education program of the New York City Board of Education, announced yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold Chase have come to the Savoy-Plaza from Scotland, where they visited their sonin-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. George Mercer-Nairne in Perthshire. They will return shortly to their home in Santa Barbara, Calif.

THESE lyrics written over a period of eight years and now arranged by Mr. Belitt to suggest a "discipline of integration" prove this young poet, to my mind, the most talented and interesting of the younger generation of American poets.

In a dozen decrees published today the French Government put into force a new series of regulations aiming to coordinate railroad and automobile transportation in France. In general the decrees are intended to reserve long-distance traffic to railroads and short hauls for trucking and bus services.

Secretary Perkins proposed today the creation of a commission of thirteen members to mediate the dispute between the C. I. O. and the A. F. of L. She suggested that each organization choose five of its "trusted and experienced representatives," who in turn would select three disinterested persons.

The American Chicle Company reported yesterday for the three months through September net income of $930,085 after depreciation, estimated Federal income taxes and other charges. This is equal to $2.13 each on 437,300 shares of capital stock outstanding.

Any doubt of Johnstown's ability to handle weight in a speed test was dispelled yesterday when 15,000 persons at Jamaica watched him make a runaway of the $8,850 Remsen Handicap, the six-furlong sprint which marked the conclusion of the Metropolitan Jockey meeting and the final day of racing on Long Island this year under Jockey Club jurisdiction.

Business leaders predicted yesterday that President Roosevelt's $1,000,000,000 rearmament plan would stimulate industrial spending of at least $5,000,000,000 more during the next fifteen months. The broad plans now being worked out in conferences between business executives and government officials, they said, were designed to become the dominating factor in the recovery picture.
The Council of Representatives of the Associate Alumnae of Vassar College, meeting at Alumnae House, were told of the completion of a $100,000 endowment for this house.
MANHATTAN CHARPIN, AUGUST (Oct. 3). Estate, more than $10.000. To Marie Charpin, widow, executrix. 319 E. 52d St., residue. Charles E. Lalanne, 151 E. 81st St., executor.
Two fine backs clashed today, but Baylor's Bill Patterson had the most help and shoved Weenie Bynum and his Centenary gentlemen into a 14 to 0 defeat before 5,000 fans.

Funeral services for Robert Clark Morris, lawyer and former chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, were held at noon yesterday in St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street. The Rev. Dr. George P. T. Sargent, rector of the. church,.. conducted the regular Episcopal service.

Financing and building material costs at the present time offer exellent opportunities for homeuilding, points out Clarence T. lice of Kansas City, chairman of thee home-building and home-ownng committee of the United States Building and Loan League.
Aided by a spectacular last-period splurge of three touchdowns. Pennsylvania Military College brought its losing streak to a close today by crushing Ursinus, 26-0.
By KATHERINE WOODS

DONKEYS in England seem well on the way to becoming as scarce as dancing bears. There used to be a donkey dairy in the Bayswater section of London, and old people and sickly children whose doctors prescribed donkey's milk used to get all they wanted at the equivalent of $1 a quart.
Oberlin College remained in the ranks of unbeaten teams by subduring Hamilton, 18 to 6, today before a crowd of 5,000.

Registration places throughout the city were crowded yesterday as thousands of persons staged a record-breaking last-day rush to qualify themselves for voting in the November elections before registration closed at 10:30 P. M.

" What is the mysterious, secretive, curiously over-publicized Colonel Lindbergh up to?" asks Lord Beaverbrook's Sunday Express today in an unsigned article that declares that many persons in Britain and on the Continent are "perturbed" about the American aviator's recent activities.

Everett Kischer, Iowa State's star back, led the assault today as the Cyclones defeated the Missouri Tigers, 16 to 13, in a Big Six football game. Eight thousand fans watched as the 155-pound Iowan kept his team at the top of the Conference standings.

Ellis S. Duvall, president of the Suffolk County Bankers Association, was founded dead of a bullet wound at 6 o'clock tonight in an upstairs room of his home on Griffing Avenue here. He was 53 years old.

One of the immediate repercussions of the recent European crisis has been the intensification in Ireland of the national campaign for ending partition. When Britain assented to the plan by which the Sudeten Germans of Czechoslovakia were joined to the Reich, Ireland's Northern Nationalists, particularly those in the counties of Tyrone and Fermanagh,

The main purpose of a sun par lor is to provide a cheerful place that may be used as a sitting room a porch, a place for flowers and frequently, as a sleeping porch. To meet these purposes a maximum of sun and light is needed, while ventilation should receive equal consideration.
Worcester Tech won its third straight game today, defeating the American International College eleven, 6 to 2.

Becalmed for the second straight day, two trim schooners fighting for the international fishermen's racing title pointed toward the Boston course tonight in some confusion, but with each captain hoping for a good wind.

Modern home design will be an important feature of the exhibits at the Bergen County Home Show, to be held for one week, beginning Oct. 27, in the armory of Teaneck, N. J. Harry C. Harper, New Jersey Civil Service Commissioner, is general chairman of the exhibition.

Miss Helene Brinkerhoff Acker, daughter of Mrs. Charles Livingston Acker of 65 East Fifty-fifth Street, New York, and the late Mr. Acker, was married to Jesse A. B. Smith Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Smith of
Three clear-cut developments indicating that a rapprochement between the private utility industry and the administration is now a definite possibility made themselves manifest last week.

Sales of wool rugs and carpets this year will be within 11 per cent of the $145,000,000 volume handled by the industry in 1937, W. D. Gardner, vice president of W. J. Sloane, told THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday on his return from a trip through the country. At present,

Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute's crosscountry team defeated Brooklyn College with a perfect score, 15 to 40, today on a four-and-six-tenthsmile course. Seven R. P. I. runners crossed the finish line tied for first in 27:10.

NO regular contribution to current criticism is more highly valued than Desmond MacCarthy's weekly article in The Sunday Times. In one of his recent articles he made incidentally some suggestive remarks on the general question of reviewing. In his opinion,

THIS book is an English expert's report on post-war attacks on the housing problem in Sweden, Holland, Germany, Austria, Italy and France; and it is introduced to the American public by Walter Gropius, Professor of Architecture in Harvard University.

SOLOISTS at the silver jubilee concerts of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, under Dr. Otto Klemperer, which open Nov. 3, will include Rose Bampton, Marian Anderson, Alice Ehlers, Olga Steeb, Yehudi Menuhin, Gregor Piatigorsky, Paul Hindemith, Nathan Milstein, Artur Schhabel, Charles Kullman, Artur Rubinstein, Bronislaw Gimpel, Philip Kahgan, Serge Prokofieff, Robert Casadesus, Joseph Achron and Alexander Borisoff.

APPLE--Herman. Mount Neboh Lodge, 257, F. and A. M., announces with deep regret the loss of its beloved brother. Funeral today, 11 o'clock. at Temple. 612 West 180th St. HERBERT FREY, Master. LEO STEIN, Secretary.

In consequence of their scholarship records, 199 students at the New York University College of Arts and Pure Science and College of Engineering were named to the honor roll, it was announced yesterday by Dean Irving H. Berg of the University College and Dean Thorndike Saville of the College of Engineering.

Miss Gloria Rendueles, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Manuel Rendueles of Brooklyn, was married to Donald Austin Farrey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Austin Farrey, also of that borough, yesterday morning in the Church of Our Lady of Refuge, Brooklyn, by the- Rev. James Kelly.

On Sept. 30, the day after the Munich agreement sacrificing Czechoslovakia's Sudenland to the cause of peace, Prime Minister Chamberlain and Chancellor Hitler agreed upon a declaration which contained the following paragraph: "We regard the agreement signed yesterday and the AngloGerman naval agreement as symbolic of the desire of our two peoples never to go to war with one another again."
CURIOSITIES odd enough to start an Eden Musee intrigue the traveler who voyages down South America's west coast. Stopping only at the regular

The Yale freshman eleven, trailing with two minutes remaining, staged a spectacular rally to defeat Exeter today, 26 to 20, when Hovey Seymour raced around end for 35 yards to register the winning touchdown. Seymour, whose all-round play featured the freshman attack, scored and earlier touchdown and a placement point.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.--With the opening of the duck hunting season yesterday, many hunters from the metropolitan areas are making this resort their headquarters for expeditions out into the salt marshes. The season on ducks, geese, snipe and coot in this vicinity continues until Nov. 28.

Louisiana State rolled up a 47-to-6 score over Loyola of New Orleans tonight in a football game witnessed by 10,000 fans. L. S. U. shoved over two touchdowns in the first period. four in the third and one more In the last.
Northwestern, braked down by forward pass interceptions, was held to a scoreless tie by a dogged Ohio State eleven before 38,000 spectators at Dyche Stadium today.
Ruggiero Ricci, 18-year-old American violinist, gave a recital in the Beethovensaal here tonight under the joint sponsorship of the American Ambassador, Hugh R. Wilson, and the Carl Schurz Society.
The American Red Cross reported today a peace-time record membership of 5,523,585 persons and increased activities in all of its services during the fiscal year which ended June 30.

Miss Julia Addis Durning, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Redmond Durning of 230 East Seventyfirst Street, was married yesterday afternoon in the Church of St. Agnes to Walter Charles Ranzini, son of Mr. and

Both the Commissioner of Sanitation, whose duty is to keep the city clean, and the Commissioner of Parks, whose duty is to make the city beautiful, are inclined to cast a covetous and often competitive eye on those wide open spaces that may be found within the 206,000. acres encompassed by the City of New York.

It costs about 25 cents to attract to New York each convention visitor, who spends approximately $100 after his arrival, it was disclosed yesterday by C. N. Nichols, executive director of the New York convention and visitors bureau of The Merchants Association.

The National Electrical Board has received an offer of aid from Germany for the construction of a government plant in competition with the Electric Bond and Share Company, the expropriation of whose properties has been authorized by Congress.

A strike of 2,000 towboat workers forced the city to press a fireboat and three municipally owned tugs into service yesterday for shipping garbage to Rikers Island, stopped the movement of forty-six carloads of cattle from Jersey City to the East River slaughter houses, tied up dredging operations in the harbor and impeded, but did not halt, the arrival and departure of ocean liners.

The marriage of Miss Mary Elizabeth Horner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Cecil Horner of New York and Stonington, to George Henry Miles Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. George Henry Miles of New York and Rumson, N. J., took place here this afternoon in Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church.

William Henry Eves, 105 years old, a retired maker of custom shoes and of lasts, died yesterday at his home, 607 West 184th Street, after a brief illness. He was born in Brighton, England, where his father was the oldest verger in England at his death at the age of 98. His grandfather was head groom to George IV and trainer of the King's race horses.

Miss Ruth Newell Maverick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Maverick of this city, was married to Hugh K. Haller, Buffalo, lawyer and son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Haller of Frederick, Md., here today.

James A. Mollison, Australian aviator, today filed notice at the Caxton Hall registry office of his intention to marry Mrs. Phyllis Hussey, former wife of Commander Thomas Hussey. The wedding is planned for next week.

Consumption of crude rubber last month by manufacturers in the United States is estimated at 37,823 long tons, against 38,170 tons in August and 43,945 in September, 1937, the Rubber Manufacturers Association reports.
DAYTON, Ohio. HOW the United States Air Corps stands prepared for possible war emergencies was disclosed last week by a source close to air-service procurement authorities at Wright Field.
Winning two races over the Lake Carnegie dinghy course, the Princeton Yacht Club swamped Penn, 26 1/4 to 16 1/4 today. Carl led the Tigers, chalking up ten points with his two second places.
Duke's powerhouse struck quickly at the first of the second half and defeated Georgia Tech, 6-0, today in an inter-Conference game witnessed by a crowd of 28,000.

University of Pennsylvania students who consistently fail to measure up to acceptable standards in spoken English will soon have an opportunity to hear themselves as others hear them, according to plans announced by Dr. Frank A. Laurie, chairman of the Department of English.

A committee of Hamilton College graduates is sending to alumni a letter asking their opinions on how the program of. the college can be improved and how alumni relations to the college can be bettered.

Fifty years ago this week the Manhattan Working Girls' Society was founded by a clergyman who took a long-range view of the social needs of a group of young women of German and Czechoslovak ancestry whose homes surrounded the Reformed Presbyterian Church at East Fifty-seventh Street and Madison Avenue.

Notification that the selection of a team to represent the United States in the 1940 Winter Olympics at St. Moritz, Switzerland, will be based largely on performances during the coming season was given yesterday to 391 amateur club and college hockey organizations throughout the country by John A. Thomas, secretary of the Olympic Hockey Committee.

The estate of William Gillette, into which the actor who died April 29, 1937, at the age of 81, poured an estimated million dollars, was sold at an executors' auction today to Louis Schlesinger, real estate broker of Newark, for $35,000.

Miss Winifred Ewing Stevenson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald E. Stevenson of the White House, New Canaan, was married to Anice Mogabgab of New York, formerly of Shanghai, China, here this afternoon in St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church.

WITH trenches dug in all the parks, the fleet mobilized and the whole population served with gas masks, there has been in England this week little care for the theatre. Day by day opinion has hardened and, in the manner of the English, opinion has become less excited and more determined.

Miss Jacqueline ElizabethWalker, daughter of Mrs. Walter Kemble Yarrow of Lombardie, Rosemont, was married this afternoon to Charles August Ernst Jr. of New York, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ernst of Ridley Park and Cecilton, Md. The Rev.

Special prayers for the Eighth National Eucharistic Congress, which will be held in New Orleans Tuesday to Thursday, will be offered at all services today in Roman Catholic churches of the Archdiocese of New York and the Diocese of Brooklyn.

Several sales of properties throughout the metropolitan area by the real estate department of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company were reported by that institution yesterday. In Manhattan the company sold through the office of Samuel Belchman, broker, the apartment house on a plot 102 by 60.6 feet at 889 St.

AFTER inadequate representation at Venetian modern music meets in late years, the American continent has now made a respectable showing at the Sixth International Festival of Contemporary Music, with first Italian hearings of two interesting works, one from the North (U. S. A.) and one from the South (Brazil).
Albright defeated Catawba of Salisbury, N. C., 14 to 0, today. It was the first setback for Coach Kirkland's Indians this season.

The mortgage program for New York State, as worked out by Superintendent Louis H. Pink of the Insurance Department, declares Clyde A. Mann, managing director of the Certified Building Registry, can do much to eliminate distrust of investors.
The mellow flavor of London bookstalls has been transplanted to the midwestern campus of Rockford College, where an eighteenth century volume may be picked up in Maddox House for "two and six."

Navy's football fleet floundered and had its winning streak smashed to fragments before 55,000 fans in the Yale Bowl today as the fighting forces of old Eli flashed a complete form reversal in the second half to triumph by 9--7.
Bates scored its first victory of the season today, defeating Arnold College, 26--2. Arnold's lone score came in the last period when Dyer downed Haberland behind the line for a safety.

Miss Mary McShane, a former school principal who was associated with Middletown public schools for thirty-eight years and one of the founders of Middletown Teachers Association, died here Thursday. Funeral services were held today in St. Joseph's Catholic Church, Middletown.
Colonel William D. Sohier, president of The Boston Journal from 1895 to 1900, an attorney and head of the Massachusetts Highway Commission for more than fifteen years, died today in his home here.

Alaska Eskimos, only 5 feet 4 inches tall and weighing 126 pounds, have registered bites reaching a strength of 345 pounds, indicating that they have jaws and teeth nearly twice as strong as those of Minnesota University football players, who average 6 feet in height and 178 pounds in weight.

MANY writers have traveled through distracted Europe collecting the opinions of the average man on international problems, but it remained for the author of this book to do so in the company of two acrobats from a circus.

At Cayce, in the southwestern tip of Kentucky, a week ago, Senator Barkley unveiled a stone marker to John Luther Jones, the Illinois Central engineer who was killed near Vaughn, Miss., April 30, 1900, when his crack cannonball train of twelve cars crashed into a standing freight.

Publication of a poem in praise of Marshal Vassilly Bluecher. Commander-inChief of the Far Eastern Red Army, aroused considerable interest today in foreign circles that have been mystified by the absence until today of any mention of him in the Soviet Russian press.

Columbia's Frank Merriwells, whose feats against Yale and Army inspired fond hopes of another Rose Bowl aggregation, were ambushed yesterday by Colgate's Red Raiders. Before a crowd of approximately 30,000 at Baker Field the Blue and White was completely outplayed by Andy Kerr's wily warriors from the Chenango Valley and when the final gun barked the score was: Colgate 12, Columbia 0.

Discussion by five leading educators of "The Ends and Means of College Education" was a feature of today's program of the celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of Goucher College. Dr. David A. Robertson, president of Goucher, presided.

The Columbia Alumni Club of Union County paid tribute this afternoon to James Kent, - former chancellor of New York State, by presenting a sun dial which was unveiled on the grounds of the Kent Place School for Girls. The memorial was unveiled by a grandson of the late chancellor, William Kent of Greenwich, Conn.
PROCEDURE: A New York housewife recently asked Mayor La Guardia the proper etiquette when "The Star Spangled Banner" comes over the...

Reports from many amateurs indicate that one of the garden tasks with which they have most trouble is the carrying of dahlia tubers in good condition through the Winter. Failure to do so often results in serious loss as well as inconvenience, for tubers or plants of new varieties may represent a substantial cash investment.

Boasting only two letter men from last season, a versatile St. Paul's School football team conquered the La Salle Military Academy eleven, 6-0, today. St. Paul's tallied on an interception by Herbert Wygant, who ran 60 yards to the goal. La Salle played without Jim Schwartzinger, its ace back.

After an ownership of six years, the Tilden Arms apartment house at 73-20 Austin Street, Forest Hills, L. I., has been sold by the Cord Meyer Development Company to the Rugby Estates, Joseph Goldfein, president.

Mike Belloise will attempt to win the world featherweight championship for the second time in his career when he tackles Joey Archibald of Pawtucket, R. I., in a fifteen-round bout at the St. Nicholas Palace tomorrow night. The popular Bronx battler, who was forced by illness to give up the 126-pound crown a year ago, is -the. choice at 8 to 5 to defeat Archibald and come into possession of the title once more.

Speculation as to whether the majority of distillers will use exclusive distributors in servicing the market here was general among liquor wholesalers and retailers-last week following the announcement by Gooderham Worts, Ltd., that it had designated the Standard Food Products Corporation as its exclusive distributor for the metropolitan district.

Scoring in every period, New Rochelle High School today defeated Charles E Gorton High of Yonkers in a W. I. A. A. game, 33 to 0. Nick D'Onofrio tallied two touchdowns and made three extra points with place-kicks.

Interest on the Cotton Exchange yesterday was centered in initial trading in contracts for the 1939 crop when October went on the board to replace the spot month. Opening trading was done at 7.80 cents a pound and that month ranged from 7.80 to 7.66 cents, or about one-quarter of a cent under July and more than half a cent under contracts for the December, 1938, delivery.

A ray of sun began shining through the dark clouds of the American Gold Cup situation last week. An American factory not hitherto identified with the Gold Cup Class was jockeyed into a position, through its president, of agreeing to develop motors of the 732-cubicinch or twelve-liter type.

John J. Pelley, former president of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad and now the president of the Association of American Railroads, virtually closed the door to an amicable settlement of the railway wage controversy today when he testified before the President's Railroad Labor Wage Fact Finding Board:
James H. Fay, Democratic Congressional candidate in Manhattan's Sixteenth District, left the French Hospital yesterday, where he had been confined since primary day, prepared to begin his campaign.

A course in newspaper writing, to be conducted this season by the New York Newspaper Women's Club, will be opened Wednesday evening by Stanley Walker of the editorial staff of The New York Herald Tribune.

STARTING Tuesday, two of the most popular gentlemen of the all-time cinema will make their joint bow at the Rialto Theatre, having risen from the dead expressly for that purpose. To prevent speculation on their identity, these fellows who have been outdrawing the glamour boys all over the country, do not belong on any list of screen Apollos, past or present. In fact, they do not even belong to the human race, strictly speaking.

Mr. and Mrs. W. Chester Mead of White Plains, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Aitken Mead, to Herbert C. Dienst Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert C. Dienst of Twin Brooks, Pleasantville, N. Y.

Agriculture Department officials said today that it might be necessary for the government itself to manufacture cotton goods if the textile industry declined a request that it cut costs to the bone on products made for sale at bargain prices to low-income families.

With today's dispersal of the Arbitral College of the Chaco and the announcement of plans for reopening their legations at Asuncion and La Paz, Bolivia and Paraguay began preparing today to resume normal relations, interrupted ten years ago.

Reporting indications that the coming session of Congress will be "more slefassertive" and show a strong inclination to help business and thus provide more jobs and larger payrolls, the Chamber of Commerce of the United States suggested today a five-point program to give "aid and comfort" to the. current upturn in business.

A formal protest against the State Department's interpretation placing importers, customs brokers, bankers, merchants and individuals engaged in bona fide commercial activities within the scope of the statute requiring propaganda agents of foreign principals to register with the State Department will be filed in Washington on Tuesday by the National Council of American Importers, Inc., it was announced here yesterday. The importers plan to insist on modification of the regulations.
The White House announced today the following schedule for the official receptions and dinners President and Mrs. Roosevelt will give during the season of 1938-1939:

The candidacy of Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, for Governor, received the support yesterday of John Dewey, educator and philosopher; Louis M. Hacker, historian John Haynes Holmes of the Community Church.

Trial of a suit for income and excess profits taxes for $3,820,743, brought by the government against the Schulte Retail Stores Corporation, will open tomorrow morning in. Federal court before Special Master Peter B. Olney Jr.

Georgetown's unbeaten football team routed Randolph Macon by 33--0 today at Griffith Stadium. A crowd of 2,000 saw the Hoyas win their third straight. The Yellow Jackets, victors in only one of their previous four games, were no match for the big Blue and Grey eleven.

Marshall smothered a hapless Oklahoma City University football team, 66 to 0, tonight before a crowd of 6,500. Three plays after the opening kick-off Hunter, Thundering Herd back, fumbled and Oklahoma recovered on Marshall's 32. The Goldbugs made 5 yards in four downs. It was their last threat.

Conferences here preliminary to the appointment of an industry committee or committees in the apparel field under the Wages and Hours Act were announced today by Elmer F. Andrews, administrator, for Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday.

An interesting alteration project has just been carried out at the Hotel Ambassador, Park Avenue and Fifty-first. Street, to provide sixteen additional rooms with baths on the top floor of the hostelry. The rooms will be opened officially tomorrow.

Debutantes of this season, headed by Miss Anne L. Wisner, daughter of Captain and Mrs. Roger Wisner, are aiding in the plans for the annual luncheon and card party for the benefit- of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery, which will be held Oct. 26 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.
Chinese Bronzes. Metropolitan Museum, from Oct. 19 to Nov. 27. Rare examples of antique bronzes from American private collections.

WHAT is expected to be South America's biggest travel season is now getting under way. The Maritime Commission recently put in operation a new fortnightly luxury-liner service to the East Coast, and in addition approved a cruise arrangement whereby tourists can sail down one coast, cross the continent by land or air, and return by the other coast.

The Penn players came romping into Palmer Stadium in uniforms that made them look like the Hestons and Heffelfingers of the canvas-back era-until the game started. Some of the more timorous Princeton supporters must have feared that they couldn't bear to watch what Was going to happen in Palmer Stadium. The Princeton side of the arena wasn't

A fleet little back from Fordham Prep, holding fast to the traditions of old Rose Hill despite his newer allegiance to the University of North Carolina, brought about the downfall of New York University in the Yankee Stadium yesterday as he passed the Tarheels to a 7-0 victory.

The Paint and Powder Club at Wesleyan University is planning activities for the academic year. Ralph Pendleton, faculty director of dramatics, has decided that the club shall undertake fewer things this year, but prepare more thoroughly on the three major plays to be assigned.

The names of sixty-one members of the Rutgers University Glee Club were announced today by Professor Howard D. McKinney, head of the Music Department and director of the club. Sixteen new members, eleven of them freshmen, are on the roster.

A new order today said traffic police may deflate the tires of "road hogs" and reckless drivers right at the spot where they are caught. Authorities explained the need of severe measures by the fact that despite more stringent control the annual average of 8,000 persons killed and 175,000 injured on Germany's highways remains almost stationary.

Paul Jones Thomson, vice president of the Item Company, which publishes The New Orleans Item and The Morning Tribune, died suddenly today a few hours after he was stricken Ill at work. His age was 54.

To stimulate interest in swans as landscape decorations, the Essex County Poultry Association staged a swan show in Swanwhite Park here this afternoon. The exhibit was said to be the first of its kind in the United States.
Final plans have been completed for the annual benefit dinner and dance of the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind, which will, be held on Thanksgiving Eve at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Assuming that New Yorkers who moved into new quarters on the first of October have now settled down, hung the curtains and put the last stick of furniture in its rightful place, the time has come to talk of decorative objects that give an apartment its finishing touches and make it look like home.

Grace Church on Brooklyn Heights was the scene of the marriage last night of Miss Virginia Burbank, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Russell Burbank of 19 Grace Court, to Charles Stokes Lowry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. Lowry of Montclair, N. J. The Rev. David T. Atwater performed the ceremony.

Production of gold in Quebec in August amounted to 71,475 ounces worth $2,501,625, against 71,535 ounces worth $2,503,725 in July, according to official statistics of that Provsince. Production for the eight
