While it is highly doubtful that any action will be taken on the plan for some time to come, a flexible price policy for newsprint, whereby the quotations would come down when newspaper revenue drops and rise when it advances, has been suggested to Canadian mills, it was learned here yesterday.

Gettysburg came from behind and defeated Drexel Tech in an Eastern Pennsylvania Conference game today, 21-12. With the score deadlocked at 12-12 and only eight minutes left, Harry O'Neill booted a 16-yard goal from placement to put the Bullets in the lead.

Lord Tweedsmuir, Governor General of Canada, told a special convocation of the University of Western Ontario today that it was "the happy fate of Canada" to be so far removed from the European political turbulence.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was "nominated" for Governor, with running-mates including Dorothy Thompson and Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College, at a dinner last night closing the annual National Business Women's Week programs at the Hotel Astor.
Turpentine, no trading; no sales; receipts, 359 barrels; shipments, 163 barrels; stock, 48,349 barrels. Rosin, no trading; no sales; receipts, 1,025; shipments, 215; stock, 223,109.

New Zealand today elected fifty-five Labor party members, a gain of two, to the-House of Representatives, but only two farming districts were held by Labor. The Nationalist party won twentyfive seats, a gain of five from Independents.
COHEN-JOSEPHIE-Mrs. Belle A. Josephie announces the marriage of her daughter, Paula Doris. to Dr. Ralph Cohen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Cohen, on Oct. 14, 1938.

The securities markets continued to display a confident tone last week and, at times, showed impressive strength. Trade and industrial indices. showed further gains, and the concrete evidence of better understanding between government and the utilities was interpreted as presaging- closer cooperation between government and business generally.

Los ANGELES. HUGE orders from Great Britain, Canada, Yugoslavia, Rumania, the Netherlands, Australia, Japan and-foremost of all-American commercial and service interests last week brought backlogs of four major aircraft corporations, all lying within a stone's throw of Los Angeles's City Hall, to an all-time peak of more than $70,000,000.

Four more Democratic candidates declined today nominations on the City Fusion party ticket. The declinations were postmarked before midnight last night, the deadline, and were received in the office of the Secretary of State today.

Miss Mary Josephine Salisbury, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar P. Salisbury of this place, was married here this afternoon in St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church to Andrew Tessmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Tessmann of Hampton, Va. The rector,

ONE of the debts of the New York art world to the Whitney Museum arises from that institution's series of regional shows, which have brought to this city in turn work by Philadelphia, Ohio and now Western artists.

In connection with the recently inaugurated drive to raise $250,000 for the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service an entertainment and rally will take place on the night of Nov. 20 at the Junior League clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street. Mrs.

A speedy Princeton 150-pound football team trounced the Cornell lightweights today by 27--0. Cornell was outclassed from the start, Princeton scoring once in the second period, twice in the third and once in the final.

Machine-like in its precision, the University of California's 1938 contribution to the football world steam-rollered over the University of California at Los Angeles today by a 20-to-7 score before 40,000 spectators.

While emergency crews are busy repairing the damage done by the recent hurricane to highways, bridges and communication lines in Westhampton Beach and other sections of Long Island, many owners of property there are making plans to rebuild their destroyed or damaged houses.

ALTHOUGH stories of World War refugees have been pushed into the background by later disasters, the dramatic account by Jascha Golowanjuk in "My Golden Road From Samarkand," telling how his family escaped the Bolshevist terrors, has captured sympathetic interest here in Sweden.

Clarence Francis, president of the General Foods Corporation, announced yesterday the appointment of Austin S. Igleheart as executive vice president. Mr Igleheart has been vice president in charge of sales and merchandising since 1935. Previously he was vice president in charge of manufacturing.

A twicewounded Lafayette Leopard unleashed all its fury today to taste victory for the first time this season by defeating a fighting Washington and Jefferson College eleven before a crowd of 7,000 by 27-0.

PERHAPS it is the migratory season-or some one just left the front gate open. But whatever the explanation, this city has been besieged by a virtual host of ace Hollywood directors during the past couple of weeks.
THERE'S been no end of prating about heads and hair, feathers and fuss this season. But we can't think about such frivolous things all the time.

The delicate line traced on a photographic film by eyes moving across an ordinary reading page will serve as new evidence of study habits in students at Mount Holyoke College, according to research plans in the Department of Education.

Curtailed receipts failed today to halt the downward trend of prices in the hog market and the quotable top declined another 10 cents a hundredweight. Receipts of 4.000 here were 1,000 fewer than expected and also that amount under receipts a week ago.

Mayor La Guardia will lay the cornerstone tomorrow at 3:30 P. M. of the seven-story $400,000 Washington Heights Health Center at 168th Street and Broadway, which is to be operated in conjunction with the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University.

The Long Island property being developed by the Hewlett-Seawane Corporation surrounds the Seawane Golf and Country Club and includes in its area of approximately 175 acres the Seawane Beach Club. About one-half of the acreage fronts on Hewlett Bay or some of its navigable waterways.
Two spectacular manoeuvres, one a sudden bid through the air and the other a breath-taking thrust on the ground, carried Notre Dame's football legions to a 14-to-6 victory over Illinois today.

Plans for the construction of a telescope with a 12-inch mirror for astronomical observations, an optical instrumentmaking shop and an observatory dome, are under way today in the student body at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute as the result of the ideas and persistent enthusiasm of two freshmen last year.

Miss Jenny Morris of London whose kindness to Canadian soldiers during the World War earned her the title of "The English Mother of the Princess Pats," arrived in New York yesterday morning after a cross-country visit to her "boys" in Canada.

Miss Frances Cantine of 333 East Fifty-seventh Street, New York, daughter of the late Mrs. Fanny Rudd Cantine and the late Martin Cantine, was married here today to Theodore de Joly de Sapla at Holleywood, once the home of the bride's great-grandfather, Governor Alexander Hamilton Holley of Connecticut.
DESPITE international complications, ships designed to increase the lure of foreign travel have figured with increasing prominence in the news lately.

Women engaged in real estate business will have a meeting of their own during the November convention in Milwaukee of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, announces the management committee.

KNIGHTS OF SONG-Monday evening at the Fifty-first Street Theatre. Glendon. Allvine's play about Gilbert and Sullivan and their times, with some of the music and lyrics by the firm of G. S. In the company are Nigel Bruce, Natalie Hall, John Moore, Reginald Bach, Monty Woolley, Molly Pearson, Winston O'Keefe and Robert Chisholm.

As yet there has been no great rush of business and industrial generals to lay down their swords before President Roosevelt in answer to the "White House spokesman's" invitation, issued last week, for an end to economic saber-rattling.

Assemblyman Albert Low Moffat, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee of the New York State Legislature, will be one of the speakers at the forum on the proposed amendments to the State Constitution to be held under the auspices of the Real Estate Owners -Association of the Twelfth and Nineteenth Wards at the-Julia Richman High School tomorrow evening at 8 o'clock.

The Truax Traer Coal Company, Chicago, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering 48,856 shares of no-parvalue common stock to be offered first to common stockholders at $4 a share.
The third quarter sales tax payments from individuals and business concerns will fall due on Thursday, City Treasurer Almerindo Portfolio announced yesterday. Failure to pay by that date,

The Pound Ridge Reservation, a 4,000-acre public camping ground established by the Westchester County Park Commission in 1925, was rededicated and named today Ward Pound Ridge Reservation in memory of William L. Ward of Port Chester, who died in 1933 after serving thirty-seven years as Republican leader of Westchester.

Advancing almost a point, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of businesss activity .has reached 85.1 for the week ended Oct. 8, which' compares with 84.2 - (revised) for the previous week, and 101.0 for the. corresponding week last year. Elec-. trio power production figures from the New England area became available and made necessary revisions for the previous two weeks.The combined index' for the week ended Sept. 24 is now 84.5.
Weather conditions remained unsettled over much of Florida today as a moderate tropical disturbance virtually stood still out in the Gulf of Mexico.

Captain Eddie Dunn, Miami's great halfback, led his mates to a 19-to-7 victory over Florida tonight in the first football encounter between the two universities. Florida took a 7-to-0 lead in the second period, capitalizing on a 55yard drive sparked by Pat Reen.

Miss Harriet Elizabeth Runcie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Thackeray Runcie of Maplewood, was married this evening in St. George's Episcopal Church here to William Wheatland Hartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Hartz of South Orange.
A joint theatre-supper party on Nov. 28 is now being arranged in the interests of the Edward MacDowell Association, which maintains the MacDowell Colony in Peterborough, N. H.

To an empire with a finger in every continent and strategic interests in almost every sea, troubles do not come singly. Its adversaries see to that. Perhaps the most illuminating clue to events of recent weeks in Europe and beyond is the simple fact that Britain's responsibilities are so vast and so scattered that she is unable

Various methods of preventing a crisis in the oil industry were suggested to the Railroad Commission at its State-wide proration hearing today by both major and independent operatorS. Their views were widely

Thaddeus M. Conniff, retired educator and dean of the Luzerne County bar, died today at his home in Plains following a heart attack. His age was 84. A native of Ireland, he was educated at St. Patrick's College, New York Normal School and Holy Cross College, where he received the degree of Master of Arts.

Miss Mary Louise Witmeyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Moore Witmeyer of this city, became the bride of John Henry Folk 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard N. Folk of Brielle, N. J., this afternoon in the North Side Presbyterian Church here. The Rev. Barnett S. Eby performed the wedding ceremony.

The thirtieth annual Founder's Day exercises of the College of New Rochelle here will be held on the campus next Saturday. In memory of the founder, the Rev. Mother Irene Gill, students, faculty and alumnae will take part in an all-day program, which will include an academic procession, a formal reception of students, a eulogy to the founder and an alumnae reunion.

RETAIL trade was still a "weather market" last week. High temperatures cut down on seasonal buying in many sections. One important exception was New England, where storm losses were followed by a spurt in sales. Stores report renewed interest in home furnishings, reflecting no doubt the rise in building, and executives are confident that more favorable weather will mean a quick jump in apparel trade.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The events abroad which brought the civilized world to the brink of catastrophe cannot be explained in terms of human action or decision. Civilization has rarely been confronted by so dire a crisis. Rather must we conclude that a combination of forces beyond the control of any group of nations has brought Europe to a hopeless pass from which escape seems to be impossible.

In her address here today, Miss Perkins said: "I suggest the application of a method frequently used in disputes between employers and their workers and also used in proceedings for mediation between conflicting economic interests in the business of conflicting family claims.

MORE than 1,500 feet below this spruce-covered summit a yellow ribbon of road creeps along the crests of the Blue Ridge, which basks in the sunny haze like a great purple snake as far as the eye can see to northeast and southwest.

Antonio R. Barcelo, Senator, advocate of independence and one of the most vivid political figures developed during the forty years of the American regime in Puerto Rico; died today at the age of 70. Flags were lowered at once to half staff.

Faye Hendryx, a soprano from Oklahoma now resident in Oyster Bay, L. I., gave a recital last night in Town Hall. She had been heard here once previously in a program at the Masters Institute last Spring. With Edwin McArthur at

Buoyancy in United Sates Government obligations, with nine of the Treasury bond issues reaching new high levels for the year, featured fairly active trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

Expansion of industrial activity and of consumer income in recent months soon should be reflected in a better demand for farm products, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics of the Department of Agriculture indicated today.

Israel A. Horowitz, American title Chess Federation titleholder in 1936, made a good start yesterday in an effort to regain the crown by winning the first game of a playoff series with Isaac I. Kashdan; champion of the Manhattan Chess Club, at the Hotel Alamac. Thirtythree moves were recorded before Kashdan resigned.

The marriage of Miss Priscilla Alden Badger, a descendant in the eleventh generation of John Alden and Priscilla Mullins Alden, to Edward Smillie Gilson, whose ancestor, Roger Conant, landed at Plymouth in 1623 and was the founder of Salem, Mass., took place this afternoon in the New Providence Presbyterian Church, which celebrated its 200th anniversary last year.

Balked twice in the first half, once on the 2-yard-line and again on the 1-yard line, Bowdoin began moving in the last two periods to defeat Williams, 14-0, on the gridiron today. The visitors threatened only once, when, with Batten doing most of the carrying and passing, they marched to Bowdoin's 8 against the second team.

An East Stroudsburg Teachers College eleven turned back the Trenton Teachers, 27 to 6, on the Hillwood Lakes Field today. The visitors scored once in every period, and missed only one conversion. Trenton scored in the first quarter.

The second annual session of Tuesday night classes in music, sculpting, the drama and tapestryweaving for Barnard College alumnae opened last week at Barnard College. Registration for them will continue for two weeks. Mrs. Robert Dirkes of the class of '22 is in charge of the fourteen evenings of the session.
In dedicating the newly reconstructed Mount Morris Park yesterday morning, Mayor La Guardia termed it typical of this country and said it shows that people can live in peace.

Waves set up by the stone cast into the sea of politics at Munich a fortnight ago washed last week upon many shores. Readjustments consequent upon the sacrifice of Czechoslovakia began. The message of the four-power agreement was heard in the Arab world, stirring further Palestine trouble. It was acted upon in the Far East.

THE famous old Southern Literary Messenger is being revived in its native city, Richmond, Va., under the editorship of August Dietz Jr. and F. Meredith Dietz. The first issue is scheduled to appear early in December with a January date line.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than it can publish. It endeavors, therefore,

The art collection formed by the late Erskine Hewitt, son of the Mayor Abram S. Hewitt and grandson of Peter Cooper, will be sold at auction at the Parke-Bernet Galleries on Tuesday evening, Wednesday and Thursday afternoons and evenings, and Friday and Saturday afternoons.

E. J. Husted's Rouquin, an outsider, won the Rose Tree Hunter Challenge Cup, a three and one-half mile post and rail event that featured the close of the Rose Tree Autumn meet today before 10,000 spectators. Abenaki finished a scant length behind, with Rockicy, the favorite, third.

The John Marshall College of Law will debate the Anglo-Irish team represented by William T. Williams and William A. Beers Sunday, Oct. 30, at 8:30 P. M., at the Hotel Plaza here. The subject will be "Resolved, That whatever assets America has she owes to Great Britain; her liabilities are her own." William Bannon, sophomore

The new Estonian Parliament opened its first session today with discussion of the specific dangers threatening the small Baltic countries in the event of a Russo-German conflict and the consolidation of national defense against any possible challenge to Estonian neutrality.

New courses in quality statistics at Massachusetts -Institute of Technology are opening up an educational field hitherto unexplored in any other university in this country, and the application of the principles expounded will result in unlimited savings to industry, according to institute officials.

The special feature of last night's performance by the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Metropolitan Opera House was the American miere of Leonide Massine's new ballet "The Seventh Symphony," set to the music of Beethoven.

Judge Arthur H. James, Republican candidate for Governor, today telegraphed a list of questions about PWA administrations. in Pennsylvania to Secretary Ickes and asked that theAdministrator answer them "as an expert witness."

Activity in the homefurnishings market was very brisk last week, with a good volume of orders, although deliveries were slow, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.

The Virginia Military Institute toppled the University of Richmond from the ranks of the country's undefeated and untied teams with a 13-6 victory today. The Spiders made a brilliant effort in the third period when Buzzer Jones raced 92 yards for a touchdown. The Cadets scored their first touchdown in less than four minutes of play in the first quarter.

Mary Ickes Watson, daughter of Dr. John B. Watson, well known psychologist, and niece of Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes, was married to Paul Hartley, New York insurance man, in the Methodist Episcopal Church here this afternoon.

Thomas Frederick Barton, superintendent of motive power of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway at Richmond, Va., died Friday night of a heart attack in Newport News, Va., according to word received here yesterday. His age was 65.

A hotel survey just completed by James A. McCarthy, executive secretary of the Hotel Association of New York City, discloses the fact that Manhattan borough has 326 hotels, whose assessed valuation represents $489,793,500.

An address on the possibilities of large-scale housing operations in the low-cost range will be given by John McC. Mowbray at the meeting of the land developers' section of the National Association of Real Estate Boards during the associations' annual convention in Milwaukee Nov. 9 to 12 inclusive. Mr.

The shift in interest and research that has taken place in psychology in America during the last two decades is indicated by the research interests of the members of the American Psychological Association in that period. These interests which are reported by the members are listed under their names in the yearbook of the association.

Miss Lena Madesin Phillips, president of the International Federation of Business and Professional Women, will be the speaker at the annual president's luncheon of the Westchester Woman's Club of Mount Vernon, to be held on Wednesday at 12:30 P. M.

Unexpected reversals of form resulted in leading teams in three of the English league's four divisions losing ground in today's round of football matches. Despite the poor performances positions were unchanged except in the third division's northern section where Oldham Athletic joined Barnsley in the top berth following Crewe Alexandra's 5-1 defeat at Stockport.
Announcement was made yesterday by T. D. Webb, vice chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, that 3,960 institutions are enrolled as members of that banking system.
The Hun School football team, undefeated in three years, put on a crushing attack today to defeat the Lehigh freshmen, 34--0.

NEW models went on display nationally last week of the Cadillac and LaSalle lines for 1939. The LaSalle will be offered in five-body types; coupe, five-passenger touring coupe, touring sedan, convertible sedan and convertible coupe.

To win the respect and confidence of their pupils, teachers should be "human and warm" in the classroom, Dr. Benjamin B. Greenberg, assistant superintendent of schools, declared yesterday at a conference on "Early Childhood Education" at the Aldine Club, 200 Fifth Avenue.

While returning this evening from celebrations marking the birth of Greater Vienna-by the absorption of many suburbs, increasing the city's area fivefold - crowds demonstrated against Jews in the city's Second District and against Czechs in the Eleventh and Twelfth Districts. Minor property damage was reported.

Municipal employes skilled in tossing two and a half pound horseshoes forty feet began yesterday their two day horseshoe pitching tournament in parks of the five boroughs. Police, Fire, Sanitation and other departments were represented in the qualifying trials requiring participants to pitch fifty shoes for a point score.

Although R. H. Helsel, with 50 in a row, again carried off the high gun honors at the weekly skeet shoot of the Bergen Beach Gun Club yesterday, the feature was the spirited battle for the handicap prize.

While a gay and noisy crowd watched the New York UniversityNorth Carolina game at the Yankee Stadium yesterday, Harris Moriarity, veteran football official of Birmingham, Ala., who was umpire of the game, collapsed at midfield during the final quarter and died of a heart attack within a few minutes.
The American Lutheran Church conference today unanimously adopted a pension plan, based on a 65 year age, for pastors, professors and others affiliated with church units.

Princeton's freshman football team openedd its season today by crushng a previously undefeated Mercers??urg eleven, 33-6, on University Field. Bud Rose, with one touchdown, ??nd Les Levy, with two. paced a ??trong Nassau running attack that ??ountedd in every period.

Extension of the bituminous coal industry's basic labor agreement to cover the non-union areas has resulted in fewer strikes and greater stabilization of the industry, according to the National Labor Relations Board's Division of Economic Research, in a report made public today. The study,

Miss Clarice Luciile D'Andrea of this place and Athanasius Albert Spica of Mount Vernon, N. Y., were married here this morning in St. Agnes Church by the Rev. John F. White of the College of New Rochelle.

Affiliated Fund-As of Sept. 30: Total assets of $14,017,582, compared with $8,982,682 on June 30 and $4,210,008 on Dec. 31, 1937. Asset value to the share on Sept. 30 was $3.82. By Oct. 13 total assets had increased to $15,746,407 and asset value to $4.30 a share.

PITTSFIELD, Mass.--In the Berkshire woodlands, which escaped the hurricane of Sept. 21, the bird-shooting season is scheduled to start on Thursday, to continue for one month. A hot, wet Summer and Autumn have produced an abundance of food for all kinds of wild life.

A few hours after the New York City Tunnel Authority had issued a statement yesterday declaring that not a single fatality had resulted from "the bends" during the two years in which the Queens-Midtown Tunnel has been under construction, one of the workers on the project was killed.

Twenty years of complacent disregard of the activities of spies in the United States will probably be ended by new legislation at the next session of Congress since President Roosevelt personally pointed out recently the need for strengthening our laws and precautionary efforts.

Four Radcliffe students in Eliot Hall, have started a little shop for providing snacks after evening hours of study. Every night from 10 to 10:30 these students sell sandwiches, Coca Cola, cigarettes, gum, and chocolate bars, and once each week they will serve hot dogs.

Miss Alice Beatrice Churchman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Churchman Jr. of Chestnut Hill, has completed plans for her marriage to Francis George du Pont, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eleuthere Paul du Pont of Squirrel Run Hill, Montchanin Del.
Development in the study of anesthetics both here and abroad will be reported at the seventeenth annual Congress of Anesthetists opening here tomorrow.

The United Automobile ' Workers of America revealed today that it was preparing to intensify its campaign to unionize employes in all plants of the Ford Motor Company, the only major automobile-manufacturing company which has not signed a contract with the Committee for Industrial Organization affiliate.

WHEN Arturo Toscanini returned to America last season to take over a new orchestra there was fear and trembling on the part of the officials of the ensemble that the maestro might disapprove arrangements that had been made for him.

Colonel Stephen A. Park, national president of the Reserve Officers Association, paid a formal call yesterday morning on Brig. Gen. Evan H. Humphrey, commanding the Second Corps Area, at his headquarters on Governors Island.
Funeral services were held here today for Joseph Bauer, Past State Commander of the Grand Army of the Republic. He had been grand marshal of Rochester's Memorial Day parades for half a century.

Captain Alexander Papana, a member of the Rumanian Royal Air force who has been in this country for two years participating in several air races and performing stunt flying, took off yesterday morning at 9:01 o'clock on the first leg of a flight to Bucharest.

The most cursory glance at a map is sufficient to reveal why the Mediterranean is of vital importance to three of the world's greatest powers and why it plays a leading part in international politics.

The pleasing diversity of tastes in our great country is illustrated by some observations as to our drinking habits, made public by Mida's Criterion. Straight corn likker holds its own west of the Mississippi, as far as California. Californians do not disdain hard drinks, but they do consume more than 20,000,000 gallons of wine a year, or about one quart a month for every man, woman and child.

THE mural paintings executed under the Federal Art Project, WPA, for George Washington High School in Manhattan, Girls Commercial High School in Brooklyn and Public School 41 have been granted final approval by the Art Commission of New York.

Seabiscuit ran into his old jinx of younger horses again today and was forced into second money in the twentyfifth running of the Laurel Stakes at a mile before 20,000 fans. The C. S. Howard horse, making his last start before his meeting with War

Who does not love the dancing daffodil that, by gardeners and poets alike, is considered the official usherer-in of Spring? The crowds that have gathered before displays of new varieties of this old favorite at Spring flower shows dur ing recent years give evidence of its enduring popularity.

The ability of untrained civilian observers to detect the approach of raiding planes even at high altitudes is probably the outstanding surprise of the week of joint AntiAircraft Air Corps exercises which ended here tonight.

The Dominican Chamber of Commerce in the United States reported to the State Department today that it was supported partly by Dominican Government funds in its efforts to promote better trade relations between the two countries.

City Judge Gus A. Voltz today fined four men $100 each and sentenced them to ninety days in jail on charges of "peddling and selling without State licenses" over distribution of literature alleged to urge fascism and to attack the Catholic church.

Military circles heard tonight that the War Department was thinking of asking Congress to authorize a strength of 4,000 or more planes for the Army Air Corps-nearly double the present goal of 2,320 first-line warcraft.

Thomas F. Heffernan, publisher of The Sunday Independent, one of the four Wilkes-Barre newspapers which suspended publication as a result of a strike by the Newspaper Guild, announced today that he was prepared to "enter a separate agreement" with the Guild.

The Munich agreement which averted the immediate threat of war over Czechoslovakia aroused speculation as to whether increased tension or better prospects for peace would be the ultimate result. At the moment the answer is apparently a spurt of armament activity all over Europe.

Democratic leaders were jubilant yesterday over Governor Lehman's formal acceptance speech in which he pledged himself to serve out his term if elected. The pledge, they said, would definitely scotch the rumor that the Governor intended to resign before his four-year term expired and would add substantially to the Democratic plurality on election day.

The Hobart Little Theatre opened its current dramatic season here tonight with the presentation of a variety show, including three one-act comedies and a group of numbers by the Hobart College Chapel Octet.

Thorney Wood, Columbia freshman quarterback, intercepte forwar pss by Layman Avery on the Rutgers Cubs' 40-year line in the thir period today and race 60 yards for a touchdown to lead his team to a 7-to-0 victory.

Miss Clarice Luciile D'Andrea of this place and Athanasius Albert Spica of Mount Vernon, N. Y., were married here this morning in St. Agnes Church by the Rev. John F. White of the College of New Rochelle.

Affiliated Fund-As of Sept. 30: Total assets of $14,017,582, compared with $8,982,682 on June 30 and $4,210,008 on Dec. 31, 1937. Asset value to the share on Sept. 30 was $3.82. By Oct. 13 total assets had increased to $15,746,407 and asset value to $4.30 a share.

Development in the study of anesthetics both here and abroad will be reported at the seventeenth annual Congress of Anesthetists opening here tomorrow.

The United Automobile ' Workers of America revealed today that it was preparing to intensify its campaign to unionize employes in all plants of the Ford Motor Company, the only major automobile-manufacturing company which has not signed a contract with the Committee for Industrial Organization affiliate.

WHEN Arturo Toscanini returned to America last season to take over a new orchestra there was fear and trembling on the part of the officials of the ensemble that the maestro might disapprove arrangements that had been made for him.

Colonel Stephen A. Park, national president of the Reserve Officers Association, paid a formal call yesterday morning on Brig. Gen. Evan H. Humphrey, commanding the Second Corps Area, at his headquarters on Governors Island.
Funeral services were held here today for Joseph Bauer, Past State Commander of the Grand Army of the Republic. He had been grand marshal of Rochester's Memorial Day parades for half a century.

Taking advantage of Washington misplays, Oregon State College defeated the Huskies, 13 to 6, in a Pacific Coast Conference football game today. Twenty thousand fans were dumfounded to see Coach Jimmy Phelan's fumbling footballers make it three losses and a tie in four starts, after having been hailed as potential champions.

Sept. 12--At Nuremberg Adolf Hitler declares that the right of self-determination must be given to the Sudeten Germans. Sept. 13--An outbreak of rioting leads the Czechoslovak Government to impose martial law in several Sudeten areas; the Henleinists serve an ultimatum on the government giving it six hours in which to cancel its decree. Sept. 14--Prague ignores Henleinist ultimatum and sends more troops into the Sudeten areas.
John Roberts, Chicago packer and philanthropist, died today of a heart attack at his home in Barrington,.Ill. He was 72 years old.

Tulane University's football team not only stole Rice thunder in passing but counted on the ground as well in a 26-to-17 victory today. The exciting contest showed Tulane possessed a backfield, led by Warren Brunner, with a versatile attack. Rice's 226-pound Ernie Lain also rose to the heights and, almost single-handed, nearly gained victory with his unerring passes and runs before 24,000 fans.
Srake and Creigh n, traditional Missouri Valley Conference foes, fought to a 7-to-7 stalemate tonight under the lights at the Bulldog stadium.

The cancellation of John Strachey's visa earlier in the week was a step of such rare occurrence as to arouse considerable interest here in the general machinery for the granting of visas. The State Department felt called upon to issue a detailed statement setting forth the reasons for the action of Douglas Jenkins, the American Consul General in London.

To an unusual degree, the views of Wall Street and of organized labor were disclosed last week to be in considerable agreement-in an important phase of the national economy; namely, the rehabilitation of the railroads.

To take care of Miami's growing air traffic a $2,500,000 adedition is to be made to the city's present municipal plant. The project will get under way, it is announced, as soon as PWA and WPA appropriations are available.

The Dominican Chamber of Commerce in the United States reported to the State Department today that it was supported partly by Dominican Government funds in its efforts to promote better trade relations between the two countries.

Thomas F. Heffernan, publisher of The Sunday Independent, one of the four Wilkes-Barre newspapers which suspended publication as a result of a strike by the Newspaper Guild, announced today that he was prepared to "enter a separate agreement" with the Guild.

In the belief that a good carpenter or efficient mechanic should also be an intelligent citizen, the New York City vocational schools are now placing greater emphasis upon the teaching of citizenship, industrial relations and the social studies. Courses in civics and Americanism are required of all students in the trade and technical schools.
The Music Department at Bowdoin College, now entering its second year under Professor Frederic Tillotson, has drawn nearly one-third of the students into some musical activity.

An informal organization called the "promotion league" within the Police Department has been the subject of investigation, it was disclosed yesterday, because of "high pressure" methods of raising funds with which to influence legislation making retirement from the deapartment mandatory at the age of 60.

AN interesting bit of information concerning airplane engines came to light last week when Pratt Whitney Aircraft, a division of United Aircraft Corporation, released some performance figures on the engines that powered the first two planes over the finish line of the Thompson Trophy Race at Cleveland last month. .

Monday Athena Club of Freeport-Flower show. 2:30 P. M. Bergenfield (N. J.) Woman's Club-Senior-junior party, Murray Hill Arms. College Club of the Oranges (N. J.)--Meeting, Trinity Congregational Church. East Orange, 3 P. M.

Capitalizing on forward passes, Pawling overpowered Riverdale today, 28-0. Julius Hoyt intercepted a Riverdale pass and ran 75 yards for a touchdown to provide the game's feature. Talcott was outstanding in the backfield.

ON twenty-three records contained in three volumes (Albums 423-5) Victor gives general release to the Glyndebourne Festival Opera Company's complete "Don Giovanni," another set that in England came under the restrictions of a subscription society. In the days when complete

Five dwellings for all-year occupancy are being erected by Charles Weisbart, president of Bell Homes, developers of a tract at Lake Nelson in Middelsx County, N. J. The site is readily accessible to Plainfield, Bound Brook, Perth Amboy and New Brunswick and the community now contains forty homes. The new houses are of the bungalow type, containing four and five rooms and are being built under the FHA specifications.

A second-half aerial attack led by Quarterback Charlie Weidinger carried Maryland's thrice-defeated Terrapins to a hardearned victory today over Western Maryland in the twentyeighth game of their gridiron series. The score was 14-8.
A series of Autumn outings has been arranged under the auspices of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association to raise funds for the organization's work in maintaining a cleaner New York.

The thrilling spectacle of a great four-motored seaplane rushing into the air at the rate of ninety miles an hour less than two seconds after it had been standing still on the deck of a ship was witnessed yesterday by fifty persons who visited the motorship Friesenland as guests of Hans Dieckhoff, the German Ambassador.

AMERICAN radio engineers do not look forward to the day when the expression "moon struck" will be superseded by "radio struck," because of an aurora across the sky, as depicted by Dr. V. A. Bailey of the University of Sydney in the issue of Nature delivered to America this week in the mail from England.

OUTSTANDING among the specialties now in favor with photographers is documentary photography. In the camera clubs of the nation the mention of the phrase has long been the signal for another long and profound controversy on the question of art and record material.

Miss Theodora Hoe Mead, younger daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Mead of this place, was married to Joseph Leonard Regan of Philipse Manor tonight at the Mead home. The Rev. David O. Kendall, rector of the Dobbs Ferry Presbyterian Church, assisted by the Rev. Charles

Carnegie Tech, champion short-ender, upset Holy Cross today, 7 to 6, the first victory for the Plaid in a four-year rivalry. Ray Carnelly's 42-yard touchdown run and placement conversion in the second period were the first points Tech scored against Holy Cross in four meetings.

Although the upward movement in building contract awards started back in May, only in the last six weeks have manufacturers of plumbing and heating equipment and building supplies experienced any impetus from the rise, they reported here yesterday.
The aggregate income of New York State farmers in the JanuaryAugust period of 1938 was $20,032,000 less than in the corresponding period of 1937, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

Mrs. Edison Mosiman is chairman of a committee arranging a news seminar on the Far Eastern situation opening at the Contemporary of Newark, N. J., 605 Broad Street, on Wednesday. The speakers will be Mrs. Clarence Webber, Mrs. Irving R. Smith and Mrs. Solomon Foster.

Two large Connecticut properties were reported sold yesterday by Previews, Inc. At Cornwall, the 271acre estate with an old farmhouse, formerly owned by the late Leonard J. Nickerson, was purchased by a client of W. B. Bronson, co-broker in the deal with Kenneth Ives Co.

Frank Dixon, Negro- star from James Monroe High School, finished first in the sixteenth annual Manhattan College invitation interscholastic cross-country meet yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park. With a sparkling performance, he was clocked in 11:41.3 for the two-andone-half-mile test, best time made by a schoolboy this season.

Second annual Pulaski Memorial Day Parade begins at Fifth Avenue and Washington Square and proceeds to Fifty-ninth Street, passing reviewing stand in front of New York Public Library, 2 P. M. Ball in the 165th Regiment Armory, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street, 7 P. M.
Miss Joan King Chapin, daughter of Mrs. Roy D. Chapin of Grosse Pointe, and the late Mr. Chapin, was married this afternoon to William E. Hutton 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Hutton of Cincinnati.

With 43,000 miners still out of work in Pennsylvania's anthracite region and distressed communities calling for aid, the likelihood of enactment of corrective legislation by the present special session of the General Assembly nevertheless diminished this week as a House sub-committee held additional hearings.
The London, Midland Scottish Railway's closed-shop strike collapsed today after the company promised the strikers that there would be no victimization if they returned to duty tonight.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today granted petitions for a reopening of the proceedings for the reorganization of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company, filed on Sept. 24 and Oct. 4, respectively, by the railroad as principal debtor and by the Housatonic Bondholders' Protective Committee, an intervenor.

The candidacy of Magistrate Anna M. Kross for Justice of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District received the support yesterday of several organizations in Manhattan and the Bronx, including the Women Jurors Association.

The new Dyker Hall apartment building at 675 Eighty-sixth Street in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, is already 90 per cent rented, according to Theodore Swenson, agent for the Renault Construction Corporation, owners.

We arrived late today at this little scattering of log-and-frame farmhouses strung along the southwest branch of the Miramichi. As we drove from New York the foliage seemed to grow more brilliant and less luxurious every hour, and there are many hours of driving to cover 750 miles of roads.
Middlebury blanked Tufts, 10 to 0, today and scored the first victory over its foe in thirteen 'years. The triumph was Middlebury's third straight and marked the third consecutive defeat for Tufts.

Commenting on rental conditions in Westchester County, Raymond R. Beatty, head of Raymond R. Beatty Management, Inc., agents for the new Scarsdale Manor Apartments and other Westchester houses, said yesterday that rentals are likely to continue at the brisk pace shown in September and that many families outside of Westchester will be attrated to that section.

Austin S; Igleheart, since 1935 vice president in charge of sales and merchandising of GeneralFoods Corporation, has been appointed executive vice president of the concern, it was announced yesterday by Clarence Francis, president. Mr. Igleheart had been vice president in charge of manufacturing and traffic from 1928 to 1935.

OCTOBER is to new radio sets what June is to the rose. Ever since those hectic days in the Autumn of the early. Twenties, when, in the old Madison Square Garden, wireless enthusiasts were so rambunctious that the doors had to be closed for safety of those jammed inside, the public has been invited in October to see what has blossomed electrically in radio.
Captain Ed Channing of Elizabeth City won the National Open Moth boat title for the second straight year today as the International Regatta held its second-day races under threatening skies.

A 92-yard drive for a touchdown in the last period today gave the University of Scranton a 19-to-14 victory over Morris-Harvey. John Clmakasky scored the touchdown on a 9-yard dash off tackle to erase a 14-12 Morris-Harvey lead.

The most dangerous running attack exhibited by Fordham in the six years of Jim Crowley's tenure as head coach piled up the staggering total of 419 yards against Purdue yesterday, but the Ram was prodigal in wasting scoring opportunities and had to remain with a 6-6 tie in its first major test of the season at the Polo Grounds.
A prize of $100 has been established at Franklin and Marshall College by Paul C. Wagner, an alumnus, in memory of his father, the late Judge George W. Wagner of Reading. The prize will be awarded

Mary Imelda Coyle, murdered after a criminal attack near her houseboats home here last Monday night, was buried today in Holy Sepulchre Cemetery after a solemn requiem mass at the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Name, Petersville Road.

Czechoslovakia's partners in the Little Entente, Rumania and Yugoslavia, came to Prague's rescue today, ordering their Ministers in Budapest, Berlin, Rome, Paris and London to make representations against the Hungarian claims for the cession of Slovakian and Ruthenian areas with a non-Hungarian majority as contradicting the principle of self-determination.

Four years after its inception at Hunter College, the pre-social work specialization has a total registration almost twenty times as great as in 1934 and an enrollment of entering freshmen which has been tripled, according to a statement made by Assistant Professor Agnes M. H. Byrnes, chairman of the committee in charge of the specialization.
The Coast Guard Academy eleven defeated Norwich University, 13-0, today in the first home game of 1938 for the Cadets. The Coast Guard dominated the proceedings from start to finish.
The Greenport High School footb?? machine staged a second-half dri to beat Stony Brook School, 13today. Frank Messoline, alert right he back, was the dominant figure the home forces' attack.

The Office of the Controller of Currency announced today that the liquidation of eighteen receiverships of national banks was completed last month, including that of the National Bank of Whitehall, N. Y. The latter bank was placed in receivership Jan. 26, 1932. Its creditors have received, including offsets, $1,105,690, or 90.06 per cent of

A recent survey by the Investors Syndicate of Minneapolis on 1937 housing activities in 310 cities situated in forty-one States and the District of Columbia showed that residential building in New York City for that year furnished shelter for 26 per cent of the persons newly housed in the seven-year period from 1931 to 1937 inclusive.

The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that in the future it will make available for public inspection documents and other papers required of corporations applying for listing to support their applications. The committee said the material would be made available immediately following the adoption of applications submitted hereafter.

Candidates on the Republican State ticket other than for Covernor will start tomorrow on a three weeks' motor trip up-State to fill speaking engagements in more than fifty cities and villages, with side trips, luncheons and dinners in as majority of the counties.

Plans for a "water ballet," said to be the first of its kind ever executed, were announced yesterday by the Consolidated Edison Company as one of the features of its building under construction at the World's Fair.
The series of harpsichord concerts in the ballroom of the Governor's palace was brought to a close here tonight. The concerts had been received enthusiastically each night during the week.

A smart Michigan State eleven scored on a break early in the first quarter and rolled up the count on intercepted passes today to down West Virginia-University, 26--0, in the first meeting of the teams.

Scoring twice by the aerial route and adding another touchdown on a thrilling 73-yard run by Billy Bothman, Valley Stream Central High School's football team remained undefeated today by smothering Mepham, 20--7, at Firemen's Field before. 2,500 fans.

The loop roadway approach to the New Jersey and of the Lincoln Tunnel was opened at noon yesterday. Representatives of the Port of New York Authority and the Town of Weehawken joined in the informal observance of the opening.

Members of Chapter One, an auxiliary of the Berkshire Industrial Farm, have taken- over the performance the evening of Nov. 1 of Maxwell Anderson's musical comedy, "Knickerbocker Holiday," at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre.

FOUR additions to the repertory will mark the second week of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Metropolitan Opera House, and it would be difficult to find four pieces offering wider divergences. The first of them, to be seen tomorrow evening, will be a revival of "Coppelia," but a revival with a

Rising in all their might, the orange-shirted Volunteers of Tennessee shattered the Southeastern Conference championship hopes of a heralded Alabama Crimson Tide today with a stunning and soundly administered 13-to-O victory.

Frank A. Moore, who played his first game of golf in 1898, today turned in the low net score of 92-22-70 to win the Apple Tree Tourney celebrating the fiftieth anniversary of golf in America and of the St. Andrews Golf Club here. The runner-up was W. W. Peake, who carded 91-20-71.

TWO camera-coach cruises intended to satisfy the wanderlust of city photographers have been scheduled for Oct. 23 and 30. The first cruise in to Garrison, N. Y., and the second through Rockland County, N. Y.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Knox, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Albert Knox of Ridgefield Park, to Proctor Mayo Lovell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maitland Clair Lovell of Springfield, Vt., took place here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents.

Commerce Commissioner River Chaves testified yesterday before Examiner Russell of the Maritime Commission that wage increases totaling $370,000 had been awarded longshoremen in Puerto Rico by the arbitration board, whereas the freight rate increases effective Sept. 21, but suspended by the commission, totaled $750,000.

The Lenox Hill Hospital will be the beneficiary of a card party arranged for the afternoon of Oct. 25 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria by members of the Ladies' Aid Society of the hospital, of which Mrs. Carl Eggers is president.

Miss Elizabeth Jane Parks, daughter of Mrs. Grace L. Parks of New York and Harold A. Parks of New Haven, Conn., was married to Alan Mills MacQuarrie here this afternoon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Bogardus.

THE New York Grand Opera Company will open its season Oct. 24, at the Manhattan Center, with "La Traviata." Three other operas will be presented in the initial week, "Madama Butterfly," "Rigoletto" and "II Trovatore." Cosma Vullo will appear as the soprano lead in "La Traviata."

" Pressing Present Problems of Independent Colleges" and "The,Relation of the Colleges to the Operation of the Social Security Act" will be the most important matters under discussion at the regional conference of the Association of American Colleges, which will be held Friday and Saturday with the University of Richmond as host. About eighty colleges in Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina. Maryland and the District of Columbia have indicated that delegates will be present.

C. C. N. Y. harriers today defeated the Lafayette cross-country team, 2431, although Archie Sparks led the field over the 5 1/4-mile course in 29 minutes 16 seconds, finishing far ahead of Captain George Bonnett of New York.
An alert Trinity pass defense brought the Hartford eleven from behind and gave them a 6-to-6 tie with Hobart before a large homecoming crowd today. Hobart scored after

Ruth Etting's husband, Myrl Alderman, 30 years old, to whom she was married secretly at Tijuana two months ago, was shot in the abdomen tonight at the singer's Hollywood Hills home, and the police arrested Martin Snyder, her former husband.

Mr. and Mrs. E. Fontaine Broun of this city have announced the engagement and forthcoming marriage of their daughter, Miss Virginia Peyton Broun, to Robert W. Lawson Jr., also of Charleston, son of Mrs. Lewis D. Johnston of South Boston, Va., and the late Robert W. Lawson.

AS a concession to the realists who have contended for some years that all the major adventures in life do not of necessity end in a clinch, the screen is leaning toward less romantic fadeouts, and the tendency of the moment is to film a conclusion that relieves Him of the customary business of looking into Her eyes.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were in fairly large volume despite the legal holiday on Wednesday. Land Bank bonds and several large issues of public utility loans featured the week's announcements. Except for a few small amounts of municipal securities called for payment this month, the new redemptions posted were for payment in later months, particularly in November and December.

The landing of Japanese troops on the shores of Bias Bay, north of Hong Kong, and their advance toward Canton is more than a military move to interrupt the trickle of supplies to China from Hong Kong via Hankow. It is the result of a struggle inside Japan and the repercussion of the Munich agreement in the Far East.
Nothing Wisconsin could do was good enough today to stop the march of unbeaten Pittsburgh, which defeated the Badgers 26 to 6 and extended its victories to four this season.
More jobs and better homes are the objectives of the "Ready-forWinter" campaign just launched by building supply dealers with the cooperation of the FHA.

Despite the recent hurricane which took its toll at Fishers Island in common with other sections, the annual field trial meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association will be conducted as arranged over the usual courses, beginning next Friday and running through Sunday.
The Union Settlement at 237 East 104th Street will be the beneficiary of the performance of "Abe Lincoln in Illinois," by Robert Sherwood, on the night of Nov. 14 at the Plymouth Theatre.
Professor Milton S. Baxter, botanist, curator of the herbarium of the University of Rochester and a pioneer in the development of the telephone industry abroad, died here tonight at the age of 83.

The Nassau Sovereign, a new monthly periodical dealing with the more serious aspects of Princeton University's campus life, will be started here this week by a group of sophomore students. The first issue will appear Friday, according to Malcolm S. Forbes, '41, of Englewood, N. J., editor of the publication.

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration reported today sugar delivered to American markets during the first nine months of 1938 under the domestic marketing and import quotas totaled 4,824,766 short tons, raw value.

Miss Susan de R. Gilbert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Thorne Gilbert of Greenaway, Clayville, N. Y., formerly of New York, was married to Alexander Howard Ross Cann, an actor of New York and Hollywood, in the West Milford Presbyterian Church this afternoon.

The marriage of Miss Jules Manning Boykin of Brooklyn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Davie Boykin of Berkeley, Calif.; to A. Lockley McEntee, son of Mrs. Arthur John McEntee of Brooklyn and the late Mr. McEntee, took place last night in St. Paul's Church, Flatbush.

Columbia University will hold a special convocation Tuesday at 4 P. M. in the Low Memorial Library to mark the 400th year since the Bible was made accessibile to the laity. Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, will preside, and the Rev. Raymond C. Knox, chaplain, will read the invocation.

President Roosevelt's dramatic action in - appealing to Chancellor Hitler and other European leaders for a peaceful settlement of the Sudeten issue has been followed by the sharpest upturn in the President's popularity ever measured in a survey by the Institute of Public Opinion, according to an announcement yesterday by the institute's director, Dr. George Gallup.

With the production-control program for agriculture yielding unsatisfactory results, officials of the Department of Agriculture in recent weeks have been suggesting first one scheme and then another in an almost frantic effort to make the program effective.
Rebecca Browning Rankin, who first observed the processes of municipal government in the town of Piqua, Ohio, is to be the city's official biographer for the New York World's Fair. When Piqua,

Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, who last year decided to retire from racing and sell his stable, yesterday announced plans to bring his colors back to the turf next Spring, according to The Associated Press.

Many Westchester residents will entertain at dinner parties in New York before the preview performance of "Knickerbocker Holiday," the, Maxwell Anderson musical comedy with Walter Huston, which will be held for the benefit of the Westchester County Children's Association Tuesday night at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre.

Led by the public utility and the copper shares, the stock market advanced strongly yesterday. Lowpriced shares were chiefly in demand and many of the erstwhile leaders of the market were relegated to a minor place in the trading scene as traders sought to take advantage of the new prospects of peace in the utility field.

AMOST exciting book could be written about blacklegs who have bilked biblio philes and not the least interesting sketch will describe an Englishman named Leonard Smithers. He was a tall thin, rather distinguished looking solicitor with a monocle, a ladies' man and a bon viveur, to whom books meant more than did the practice of his profession.

Mr. and Mrs. I. Leston Nickerson of Swarthmore, formerly of Larchmont, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Berna Nickerson, to Alfred Norman Frecker Jr., son of Mrs. William Brigham Brown of New York.

NEW ORLEANS. WITH more than 300 collectors attending from all parts of the country, the fifty-third annual convention of the American Philatelic Socity was held at the Roosevelt Hotel here, opening on Monday and concluding on Friday. The group's president, Carter Glass Jr., Lynchburg, Va., newspaper publisher, was in the chair.

George L. Bliss, president of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York, will report today to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board that his institution enters its seventh year of operation with increased resources.
The increase in political refugees coming to this country from Europe has necessitated the establishment of a new clubhouse in this city for sheltering them, Mrs. Stephen S. Wise declared yesterday.
The 1938 high-goal polo season came to an end on Long Island today with the Bostwick Field riders turning back the Westbury quartet, 12 to 5, on the former's ground.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 80.3, which compared with 80.5 the week before, 80.4 two weeks before, 80.8 three weeks before and 80.7 four weeks before.
Four Germans were under arrest at Fort de Lesseps here today for photographing coast defenses at Fort Randolph. The prisoners include woman, Ingebord Gutmann.

A head-on automobile collision, attributed to the heaviest fog this vicinity has seen in years, caused the death of one man and injuries to five others at 6:30 o'clock this morning. Four of the injured are in a serious condition.

Mrs. E. Parmalee Prentice had her largest musical of the season yesterday afternoon at Mount Hope Farm, Williamstown. The Russian Cathedral male quartet sang seven groups of songs with Archer Gibson of New York as organist. Tea was served to 150 guests.

J. Wood Platt, 40-year-old amateur golf champion of the Philadelphia district, won the Geist Memorial Trophy at the Seaview Golf Glub today after battling with Dick Chapman, Connecticut State champion, for twenty holes.

More than 200 Masons of the New York area observed their second annual Royal Arch Sunday at evening services yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine under the auspices of the State Grand Chapter, Royal Arch Masons.

A thick fog and absence of a breeze today held up the third race between two schooners for the sailing championship of the North Atlantic, and once more the doughty contestants made ready for battle off this old fishing port.
Dr. Henry Alexander Sussman, attending physician at the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital, died early yesterday at his home, 105 Lincoln Road, Brooklyn, after an illness of two months. He was 47 years old.

A company of 102 singers will be included in the personnel of the Metropolitan Opera Association during the coming season, which will begin on Nov. 21, it was revealed yesterday when the prospectus for 1938-39 was made public.

Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, denied today that he had canceled any speaking engagements and emphasized that he would be in Los Angeles as scheduled Wednesday night to discuss democracy and dictatorship.

The featherweight championship of the world will be at stake tonight when Mike Belloise, former holder of the crown, collides with Joey Archibald of Pawtucket, R. I., in a fifteen-round bout at St. Nicholas Palace.

ABE LINCOLN IN ILLINOIS, a play in two acts and twelve scenes, by Robert E. Sherwood. Staged by Elmer Rice; settings by Jo Mielziner; presented by the Playwrights' Company (comprising Maxwell Anderson, S. N. Behrman, Sidney Howard. Mr. Rice and Mr. Sherwood), as its first Broadway offering. At the Plymouth Theatre.
Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's Doubleday, Doran Bookshops, Gimbel's, Macy's, Scribner's and Wanamaker's:

A church that had its humble beginnings in a small loft above a blacksmith shop on East Fourteenth Street, where the pastor had to use an anvil as a pulpit from which to preach his first sermon, began yesterday morning the celebration of its seventieth anniversary with a service of reminiscence.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain is returning to London on Tuesday for what his Chancellor of the Exchequer, Sir John Simon, described the other day as "a vigorous, complete, remorseless and urgent survey" of Britain's changed position in the world as a result of the recent crisis and the Munich agreement.

Miss Bertha N. Holt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Morton Holt of Newton Highlands, Mass., was married here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration to Albert T. K. Warner, son of Mrs. Charles Kumerdank of New Bedford, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. B. A. E. McLaughlin.

Increasing mechanization in the production of cotton is responsible to a large degree, for decreased labor requirements of 16 per cent an acre and 10 per cent a bale, between 1907 and 1936, according to a summary issued today by the Works Progress Administration.
The Bourse here failed last week to react, to the degree that might have been expected, to the improvement in the country's finances that was indicated in the last statement of the Bank of France.
A long-range passing attack gave Niagara University a 6-to-O victory over St. Bonaventure today in the last three minutes of play before 12,000 fans.

The undefeated Jersey City Giants captured undisputed possession of first place in the American Football Association standings by handing the Brooklyn Eagles their first setback of the campaign, 7 to 0, at Ebbets Field yesterday.

As the retail distribution set-up in foods and groceries becomes more and more complicated, national advertisers in the field in choosing advertising agencies are placing major emphasis on the merchandising knowledge and abilities of agency personnel, according to comment among food executives.

The Republican campaign to elect memberg of that party to the Senate and House and as Governors of States will be intensified this week, the Republican National Committee announced today, and party oratory will resound in "every State north of the Potomac and west of the Ohio with pleas that the way to establish economic recover is to elect Republicans."

Representative Clare E. Hoffman of Michigan charged here today that many of the C. I. O. men accused of breaking up his meeting last night in Crystal City, Mo., carried guns. Several persons, including women, were injured in the melee and Mr. Hoffman himself was caught in the aftermath of the riot when some one lunged at him and tore his shirt and collar.

Mrs. Mary Pearl Thompson Stevens, an old-time resident of Mount Vernon, died yesterday in the Morrisania Hospital, the Bronx, of a heart attack. Her age was 74. She was the widow of John W. Stevens, who for a number of years was president of the Board of Aldermen of Mount Vernon and City Water Commissioner.
The entrance of fascist Rexists into Belgium's communal elections failed to disturb the political balance in the country's 2,671 communal councils, early returns from today's election indicated.

For the purpose of preparing the ground for Congressional acceptance next January of the still-unpublished Joint Preparatory Committee report revising Philippine-American relations under the Independence Act, Vice President Sergio Osmefia, accompanied by a small government mission, sailed for the United States today.

More than 700 manufacturers and retailers of home furnishings will attend a dinner conference on trade relations at the Hotel Astor, Oct. 24, according to an announcement here yesterday by a conference committee formed last week to sponsor the event.
Diplomatic relations between Germany and Brazil will be subjected to a complete overhauling, it was learned from informed quarters today.
The Atlantic Model Yacht Club of Amityville, L. I., won the country's first inter-league model yacht regatta today, defeating Marblehead, Mass., 123 points to 107, in the twoday competition.
The Consumer-Retailer Relations Council will hold its first annual dinner at the Hotel Pennsylvania on Oct. 27, according to announcement yesterday by Harold W. Brightman, chairman of the council.
Announcement of the entry of Cuba in the international military jumping contests at the National Horse Show was made yesterday by Whitney Stone, secretary of the exhibition.

Strolling players from Broadway performed at the World's Fair grounds yesterday at a carnival for the Stage Relief Fund. It was the first full-fledged, pay-as-you-enter event at the future Flushing Meadow Park.

Moaernist theologians who do not accept certain conceptions of Christ presented in the Bible were called "wolves in sheep's clothing" in a serm n yesterday by the Rev. Dr. John H. McComb at the Broadway Presbyterian Church, at 114th Street.

Percy S. Straus, chairman of the board of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City, announced last night that Walter Rothschild would head the joint campaign for funds of the Manhattan group and the Brooklyn Federatioa of Jewish Charities. Mr. Rothschild served in a similar capacity last year.
The Green Bay Packers smashed and passed their way to a 35-to-7 victory over the Brooklyn Dodgers in a National Football League game played in midsummer heat today before a crowd of 13,000.
Members of the Eastern Shore Baseball League voted at their annual meeting today to increase the number of next year's games from 112 to 128.

Following is the text of the radio address of Winston Churchill, Britain's former First Lord of the Admiralty, in reply to Chancellor Hitler, as broadcast from London to the United States last evening and transcribed in New York by the National Broadcasting Company:

The British people want peace, but those who think they would not defend themselves against aggression are mistaken, the Very Rev. Walter Noble Matthews, dean of St. Paul's Cathedral, London, said yesterday in his sermon at Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street.

The 2,000 towboat strikers rejected overwhelmingly late last night a proposed basis for settlement of the dispute offered by the New York Towboat Exchange, but after determining to go on with the strike backed a counter-proposal on which agreement will be sought today.

Reports of a reduction on certain lines of steel of $4 a ton mark the further decline of prices of this basic commodity from the high levels of last Spring. Quotations at that time were the highest in fourteen years.

Lithgow Osborne, State Conservation Commissioner, advised that twentynine forest fires were reported curing the day, said tonight "there seems to be no other course than to close the woods" to hunters "during the present crisis."

Since the Czeehoslovak crisis was definitely settled, business in Germany has been relatively quiet and has not been expectant, the belief being that Chancellor Hitler, after changing his course because of the British Fleet's threat, will not embark upon any enterprise which might lead to war with the great powers.
In a hotly contested American Soccer League game at Celtic Park in Brooklyn yesterday Brookhattan defeated the St. Mary's Celtics, 4 to 3. The Celtics led at half-time, 2 to 1.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 51 per cent of capacity, up 3 points from the preceding week and the highest rate of the year.
Alsace believes it has a case for revision of its situation-but the case does not concern autonomy in the generally accepted sense of that word and much less secession from France.

In theory, at least, Universal's "Youth Takes a Fling" is a slight romantic comedy. In practice, it is the frequently terrifying record of a manhunt which must make every bachelor at the Rivoli quake in his shoes and deserve to be roundly abused by haughty feminists.

Widespread arrests of Jews on charges of anti-Fascist activities were officially announced tonight. The arrests were made in several cities and the number of persons seized was reported as "considerable."

Mr. and Mrs. Harry Lord Powers of Red Bank, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathleen Powers, to Charles Rieley Neighbour of Indianapolis and Beverly Hills, Calif., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Neighbour.

Announcement has been made of the engagement and approaching marriage of Miss Ursula Irene Wertheim, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Georg Wertheim. of.. Berlin, Germany, to Douglas Quackenbush Froeb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Augustus C. Froeb of Brooklyn and Westhampton Beach, L. I.

It was reported today that several prominent taxpayers of this village and New Rochelle were planning to appeal to J. Edgar Hoover, head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, to send several of his detectives here to try to solve the murder of 17-year-old Mary Imelda Coyle.
Although there are still numerous incidents of sniping, arson and sabotage by Arab rebels in all parts of Palestine, the main center of their activities has now shifted to the Old City of Jerusalem.

The Rev. Moses Richardson Lovell, who will be installed Thursday night at Central Congregational Church, Hancock Street near Franklin Avenue, Brooklyn, as successor to the late Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman, in his sermon there yesterday morning discussed the gambling spirit in man, saying it had a place in the divine scheme along with other forms of merriment and mirth.
Members of the Brooklyn Alumni Sodality received holy communion in a body yesterday at the 8 o'clock mass in the chapel of Our Lady Seat of Wisdom, 1,150 Carroll street. Brooklyn.

William Goetz, 57 years old, of 2,790 Sexton Place, the Bronx, who retired from the Police Department four years ago after almost thirty years of service, died of a heart attack at his home yesterday afternoon.
A new type of airplane indicator which anticipates wing stalls, one of the leading causes of crashes, and warns the pilot, was announced today by the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics.

Since its report on "How to Recognize Quality Rayons" was made available on Aug. 8, the consumers advisory committee of the Women's National Institute, 247 Park Avenue, has received requests for more than 25,000 copies.

The Board of Trade's index of British wholesale prices for September, based on the average for 1930 as 100, was 98.4, against 99.5 for the preceding month and 111.2 for September, 1937. The fall in the year was 11 1/2 per cent, with prices of foods and industrial products sharing almost equally in the decline.

Waste and inefficiency in the Department of Sanitation under Commissioner William F. Carey are charged in a statement submitted to Mayor La Guardia and the Board of Estimate yesterday by Edward T. Russell, chairman of the sanitation and water committee of the Community Councils of the City of New York, Inc.

The low bid received by the Department of Hospitals for general construction work on the new administration building for Bellevue Hospital was $1,779,000 submitted by the D. M. W. Contracting Company, according to Brown's Letters, Inc.
Stocks advanced to new high levels for the year; low-priced issues strongest; utility, copper and aviation groups in the forefront; turnover, 8,981,190 shares.
Many small tenement houses in various parts of Manhattan were reported yesterday as having changed ownership.
The Giants beat the Philadelphia Eagles on the scoreboard as well as on the field yesterday, a minor Item they neglected to attend to in their previous meeting three weeks ago.
The United States light cruiser Boise will sail from Norfolk, Va., tomorrow for Monrovia, Liberia, the Navy Department announced today.

The Dutch markets, after a brief feeling of relief, do not consider the danger of war fully eliminated. Unless the European political situation is definitely settled and the colonial problem solved, it is feared that the aggressive attitude of the totalitarian countries will burst forth and make the Munich accord only a postponement of a clash.
When demonstrating a hand grenade to his pupils in the Cieszyn High School the teacher, Jan Hajkowski, heard a fuse hiss when he pulled the ring on the supposedly harmless projectile.
The State Unemployment Insurance Appeal Board ruled today that drydock workers are entitled to unemployment insurance benefits on the same basis as other workers in commarce and industry.
Last night's program of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Metropolitan Opera House contained the first performance this season of "L'Apres-midi d'un Faune," with Serge Lifar in the central role.
The Annalist reported yesterday that its index of wholesale commodity prices had moved downward last week and stood on Saturday at 79.7, against 80.3 a week before and 91.9 a year ago.

The Daily Herald said today that a state visit of King George to the United States at the end of his Canadian tour next Spring would be announced in his speech from the throne at the opening of Parliament Nov. 8.

For the third time in four years, the team representing the Deepdale Club, playing over its own layout, captured the Chrysler Cup in the annual team golf match against Meadow Brook and Piping Rock today.

The Vienna edition of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's Voelkischer Beobachter raised the question today of "millions of marks" worth of Catholic Church property in Austria that "it does not seem easy to socialize and in some way make useful to the community."

The Mexican Ambassador to Washington, Dr. Francisco Castillo Najera, will leave by airplane for Washington tomorrow with the best offer he could obtain from President Lazaro Cardenas to settle the dispute over payment for land taken from United States citizens.
Thousands of Polish-American citizens paraded up Fifth Avenue yesterday in honor of the Revolutionary War hero Brig. Gen. Casimir Pulaski.
A twelve-year lease on the entire third floor of the Barclay Hotel has been signed by the Cornell Club of New York, Charles H. Blair, president of the club, announced yesterday.

The index of thirty industrial shares, compiled by The Financial News and based on July 1, 1935, as 100, was 81 on Oct. 13, compared with 82.6 last week, 80.5 last month, 100.9 a year ago, 95.9 at the beginning of the year, a high record of 124.9 on Nov. 18, 1936, and the low of 83.7 on Sept. 28 last.

Formation of a citizens' committee of men and women to have charge of a campaign for $205,000 for the 1939 work of the Young Women's Christian Asociation of the City of New York was announced yesterday by John C. Traphagen, president of the Bank of New York, who is a member of the association's board of trustees.

Carroll Miller Jr., a nephew of Senator Joseph F. Guffey, took as his bride Miss Nancy Lee Milligan, daughter of a Pittsburgh real estate dealer, in Calvary Episcopal Church late yesterday. Senator Guffey was present.

Frederick A. MacCluer, head of the men's wear importing firm of his name at 9 East Thirty-eighth Street, died yesterday at his home, 210 East Sixty-eighth Street, of pneumonia. Born in London seven ty-six years ago, he came here in 1903.

The Thirty-fifth Spanish division paid its farewell today to the Fifteenth, Eleventh and Thirteenth International Brigades, which had fought With the division through battles from Brunete to the Ebro.
Dowager Lady Sinha, widow of the first Lord Sinha, who was the first Indian to become a member of the United Kingdom peerage, died today at the age of 69.

Unable to pay $2 fines and $2 costs, fourteen motor cyclists from the Bronx were lodged in the county jail here tonight after they had been found guilty of careless riding by Justice of the Peace Thomas Piston of Browns Mills.
The political disorders characterizing the recent European war crisis were discussed in several pulpits here yesterday.
Police held Martin Snyder, 43-year-old divorced husband of Ruth Etting, radio singer, on suspicion of wounding Miss Etting's second husband, Myrl Alderman, 30, in her home here last night.

Our civilization is foundering in a raging sea of uncontrolled, selfish authority and violent hatred, the Rev. Leon Merle Flanders, pastor of the Tremont Presbyterian Church, Grand Concourse and 178th Street, the Bronx, said in his morning sermon yesterday.
Wrestlers from the United States won five out of seven matches from a German team before a crowd of 6,000 today.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward Richard Hoffman of 782 West End Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth B. Hoffman, to Professor Mario C. Giannini, son of Edward E. Glannini of New Rochelle, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Rose Giannini.

The course of the financial markets last week cannot be described as anything but most unsatisfactory. Numerous reasons can be adduced for this, but in the first place, perhaps, renewed pronounced weakness in sterling must be recognized as overshadowing all else.

Christian people today must choose between bootless agitation for complete disarmament and ceaseless work toward the creation of conditions that will make disarmament possible in time, the Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker, rector of Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, said in his sermon yesterday.
Everett Elkins, ace of the Marshall College team which has piled up 213 points in four games, heads the East's individual scoring stars in the first Associated Press roundup of the year.

Great Britain's imports of gold in September amounted to [Pound]35,953,144, against [Pound]15,439,327 In September last year, and they made the total for the first nine months of this year [Pound]198,748,431, compared with [Pound]258,133,165 a year before.
