President Roosevelt came back to his Hudson River home here today for another week's stay, which will be marked by occasional conferences and further study of the national defense, budget and political problems confronting the Administration.
Masayoshi Shibata, a member of the Japanese Archery Club, captured the men's title in the New York City championship archery tournament at Alley Pond Park in Douglaston, Queens, yesterday.
Exports of avocados from Havana to the United States in September totaled 1,200,000 pounds less than in August and 1,400,000 pounds less than in September last year, the Commerce Department reports.

Low prices and large-scale production are upheld as sound business policy in a pamphlet to be issued today by the Public Affairs Committee, 8 West Fortieth Street. The pamphlet is based on "Industrial Price Policies and Economic Progress" by Edwin G. Nourse and Horace B. Drury, a study recently completed by the Brookings Institution.

Jack Doyle, known as a singing prizefighter, was arrested by immigration officers today as he stepped from a transcontinental plane and booked at the county jail for "Illegal entry," on a telegraphic warrant from New York. Albert Del Guercio, immigration service counsel, said the warrant indicated Doyle was accused of falsifying information when obtaining a visa to enter the United States.

The champion Washington Redskins came from behind with a third-period touchdown to down the Lions today, 7 to 5, and take undisputed hold of first place in the Eastern Division of the National Football League.

A large apartment house in Forest Hills, a blockfront taxpayer in Jackson Heights and an estate at Hewlett were included in the long list of Long Island real estate transactions reported by brokers yesterday.

The world premiere of Richard Strauss's second one-act opera, "Daphne," which was given at the State Opera House here yesterday under the direction of Karl Boehm, brought the composer a respectable success d'estime, but by no means such an enthusiastic ovation as was given to "Friedenstag," as played in both Munich and Dresden.

The one-star flag, emblem of Puerto Rico's independence, in behalf of which he had devoted forty years of political activity, draped the bronze coffin in which Antonio R. Barcelo, president of the Liberal Party, was buried at sunset here today.

Contributions amounting to $583,303, with $130,650 in pledges, have been made to the Fiftieth Anniver-. sary Fund of Barnard College, which is seeking $4,250,000 to strengthen and equip the college, Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve said yesterday in announcing the plans of the fund organization, of which Mrs. Hooker Talcott is chairman of the general committee, Lucius Beers, acting chairman, and Dave Hennen Morris, former United States Ambassador to Belgium, head of the men's committee.

Flashing a strong ground offensive throughout, the Fort Hamilton eleven crushed Fort Hancock of New Jersey, 24 to 6, in their Army Service Football League contest yesterday at Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn.
David Sackson, violinist, and Julius Chajes, pianist, who brought their three programs of sonatas to a close late yesterday afternoon, introduced to a Town Hall audience Werner Josten's Sonata in A.
AMERICAN AUTHORS, 1600-1900, edited by Stanley J. Kunitz and Howard Haycraft. (Wilson, $5.) A biographical dictionary of American literature.
The Japanese forces from Bias Bay have advanced rapidly westward from Tamshui north of Hong Kong, the Chinese steadily falling back.

Thousands of visitors at Roosevelt Field today viewed the new "aviation fresco" at Hangar F. The work was finished on Saturday by Miss Aline Rhonie of New York City and former wife of Reginald Langhorne Brooks, the nephew of Lady Astor.

So the World's Fair is going to have the longest bar in these diggings or in the world. It is a doubtful honor, but has been thought to appeal to out-oftowners. There are always two or three places in New York that claim to have the longest bar in it.
Mike Murra, Wichita Country Club professional, edged out Johnny Revolta of Evanston, Ill., with a subpar 66 today to win $500 first prize in the $1,600 Wichita open golf tournament.
Scotland is due for a severe shock when they learn over there that the grand and bonny game of golf is not Scotch at all, but Dutch.
In twenty years American anti-aircraft gunnery has become some twelve times as effective as it was at the end of the World War, many army anti-aircraft experts here believe.
Miss Gwyn Grant and Roland Ruutz-Rees, who are to wed on Nov. 5 in the Round Hill Community Church, are being widely entertained.

Last week's trend in the securities' market was irregular and, at times, inclined to weakness. On Monday selling was induced by the flotation of the new Reich loan, and prices tended to sag until news of the increased Kloeckner dividend induced a sharp recovery in the steels.

The vehement German press campaign against the armament programs of Britain, France and America is simply the latest revelation of the strange nature of the Nazi mind. If that mind is infuriated when it confronts disagreement, it seems to be still more infuriated when it finds some of its views accepted.
Mrs. Anna Karpf of Woodbury, N. Y., has made known the engagement of her daughter, Miss Sylvia Karpf, to Dr. Abraham H. Friedman, son of Dr. Samuel Friedman of this city and the late Mrs. Friedman.

An armed conflict has developed in the State of Sonora between the State government, ?? by General Roman Yocupicio, and forces directed by the local leaders of unions of the Mexican Confederation of Labor, according to dispatches reaching the newspaper Universal today from Hermosillo, capital of the northwest border State.

The C. I. O., as represented in the State by the New York State Industrial Union Council, came out yesterday for the defeat of five of the nine proposed constitutional amendments to be submitted to the people on election day

Corn futures on the Board of Trade here sold last week at the lowest prices since May, 1934. Pressure of both the old and new crop grain and lack of an aggressive export demand were responsible for the decline.

The salaries of members of the faculty of the Sheffield Scientific School of Yale University will be raised as a result of a bequest of Miss Marie Oakes Hotchkiss of Madison, the inventory of whose estate, announced today, totaled $253,448.
The Bears ran up a 34-to-14 lead over their Chicago rivals, the Cardinals, today, then had to stave off a furious passing offensive to gain a 34-to-28 National Football League victory.

Captain William Bruce Oakley will command the American Republic's liner Uruguay when she sails Saturday in the fortnightly service of the "Good Neighbor Fleet" to Rio de Janeiro, Santos, Montevideo and Buenos Aires, it was announced yesterday by the United States Maritime Commission.

The Rev. Clinton Pope Morris, pastor of the Belmont Park Baptist Church, died tonight at the age of 54. A minister for more than twenty-five years, and a former missionary in China, the. Rev. Mr. Morris had been in Chicago ten years.
Scoring in every period, the Paterson Panthers gained a 25-to-6 American Professional Football Association victory over the Clifton Wessingtons today before 6,500 at Hinchliffe Stadium.

More than 5,500 persons, arriving by automobile and by special train, joined today in the first State-wide pilgrimage to the Shrine of the North American Martyrs, burial place of church heroes slain by Indians nearly 300 years ago.

Harry Shaw, former Waterloo and Cedar Falls daily newspaper publisher, died today at his home in Sarasota, Fla., at the age of 52. Mr. Shaw was a publisher of The Waterloo Daily Tribune, which was merged with The Waterloo Daily Courier in 1930, and later was publisher of The Cedar Falls Daily News prior to its suspension a year ago.

Great Britain's foreign trade in September reflects in some degree the impact of the European crisis. Imports were 13.6 per cent lower than correspondingly last year, about two-thirds of this decline being in the way of unmanufactured articles. Exports declined 12.8 per cent, manufactured goods accounting for most of the recession.

WOE, woe, unutterable woe! But there was some fun, too, on Saturday. Not for the hosts of Ithaca or the cohorts of Columbia. Not for the nautical gents from Annapolis. Not for the proud platoon of Penn.

Undefeated, untied and unscored on, Mount St. Michael turned back Xavier, 13 to 0, for its third football victory of the season before a crowd of 3,000 on its home field in the Bronx yesterday. Bob Bryan had a hand in all the winning school's points.
St. Mary's Gaels put on a wild fourth-period scoring splurge today to smother the University of Portland eleven, 32 to 7.

The sweepstakes of the egg show at the fourth exposition of the Northeastern Poultry Producers Council being held at Commerce Hall of the Port Authority Building was won by a dozen rich brown eggs exhibited by the Nicholas Poultry Farm of Kingston, N. H., it was announced yesterday.
Delegates to the West Virginia Printing Trades Conference rejected today a suggestion that Secretary Perkins be asked, to become the fifth member of a board to compose C. I. O.-A. F. L. differences.

The States have often been compared to so many legislative laboratories in which laws and other social experiments may be tried out on a relatively small scale before the whole country needs to suffer under them.

Earle Bailie, chairman of the board of the Tri-Continental Corportion and affiliated investment companies, reveals in the quarterly report which will be made today to stockholders in these companies that J. W. Seligman Co. will not engage in the origination, underwriting or distribution of securities so long as any members of that firm are officers of the newly formed Union Securities Corporation.

Organization of the American Jewish Federation to Combat Communism and Fascism, a non-profit membership corporation with headquarters at 170 Broadway, was announced yesterday by Milton Solomon, former Kings County commander of the American Legion and past national patriotic instructor of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States.

Winners of twenty-three undergraduate scholarships, awarded on the basis of competitive examinations held at the opening of Cornell University this September, were named by President Edmund Ezra Day today.
A furnished apartment of fifteen rooms and six baths in 1,030 Fifth Avenue has been leased to Jacob H. Schaffer, lawyer, through Douglas L. Elliman Co.

The nation's four major airlines cooperated during the transportation emergency created by the recent New 'England hurricane to perform what has now been officially recorded as a task unparalleled in the history of commercial aviation.

The Crosley Radio Corporation's application to continue operating the only superpower commercial broadcasting station in the country was rejected today by three of the seven members of the Federal Communications Commission.

The National Committee to Uphold Constitutional Government announces a campaign to enlist one million Americans to fight the "'isms." The accompanying explanation shows that the "isms" referred to are socialism, fascism and communism.
All deliveries of lard futures sold at a new low for the season last week. The market failed to show any rallying power and closing sales yesterday were at the bottom.
The engagement of Miss Erica Bos, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Coenraad V. Bos of New York, to Cerbert Grunfeld has been announced.

The outstanding feature of the foreign-exchange market this week was the rise of the United States dollar, the movements of which here were like those in London. The French equalization fund limited its actions to defending the franc rate against sterling.

Randolph Scott, who left Paramount in August after seven years with the studio, has signed a sixyear agreement with Columbia providing for two pictures a year. It is probable That his first film will be Joseph Dineen's "Murder in Massachusetts," now known as "Let Me Live." Rouben Mamoulian has been tentatively set as director.

With the flags of the United States and Great Britain massed before the altar and an abundance of ripe Autumn fruits and vegetables heaped about the nave, the seventeenth annual British Harvest Festival was celebrated yesterday afternoon in Trinity Chureh.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. John F. White of this city and East Rockaway, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jeanne Frances White, to Laurence C. Ehrhardt, son of Mr. and Mrs. George L. Ehrhardt of Flushing, Queens.
Executive officers of labor's Nonpartisan League, a league spokesman said tonight, have received authority to endorse the Republican candidate for the United States Senate, W. Warren Barbour.

Registration, which appeared apathetic at the beginning of the week, ended with an encouraging rush. More than a third of the voters qualified on the final day, bringing the total registration in this city to 2,437,270.

Miss Barbara Elizabeth Lockwood, daughter of Judge and Mrs. Charles D. Lockwood of this city, has chosen the afternoon of Nov. 5 for her marriage to Garrett Bunker of New York, son of Captain Charles White Orville Bunker of the United States Naval Hospital in Brooklyn and Mrs. Bunker.

The fifth annual exhibition of the New York State Wholesale Beer Distributors Association will open at the Hotel Commodore on Tuesday and will continue through Thursday. Products of brewers and of allied industries will be displayed.
Several changes affecting its sales organization in New York were announced today by the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation.

The Governorship campaign gets well under way this week with both Governor Lehman and Thomas E. Dewey, his Republican opponent, beginning up-State speaking tours. Governor Lehman is to speak in Binghamton Thursday, while Mr. Dewey will start Wednesday in Rochester and will continue Thursday in Utica.

At a vesper service late yesterday afternoon, by the light of kerosene lamps reminiscent of fifty years ago, the congregation of Goodsell Memorial Methodist Church, McKinley and Sheridan Avenues, Brooklyn, was warned to forget the past in order "to escape the perils that lurk in anniversary celebrations." The speaker was the Rev.

A group of doctors, nurses and other persons connected with Lenox Hill Hospital will receive a scroll from the Honor Legion of the Police Department in recognition of their services to two policemen wounded last Aug. 14 in a pistol fight with a maniac in Central Park, it was announced yesterday.

The engagement of Miss Rose Igstaedter, daughter of Mrs. Oscar Igstaedter of this city and Long Beach, L. I., and the late Mr. Igstaedter, to Martin M. Hertzog, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dave Hertzog of New York, has been announced by her mother.

The funeral of Lieutenant Commissioner Richard Griffith of the Salvation Army, who died suddenly in Bristol, England, on Oct. 9, will be held on Wednesday at 10 A. M. In the Army's Centennial Memorial Temple at 120 West Fourteenth Street.

The headquarters of Mrs. Anna Moskowitz Kross, American Labor and Progressive party candidate for the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District, announced yesterday that Mrs. Kross's candidacy had been endorsed by Mrs. William H. Good of Brooklyn, Democratic National Committeewoman from New York State.
More than 100 police were instructed by Chief William J. Quinn to report for duty Monday at a liquor warehouse which is scheduled to open, despite C. I. O. threats that the move will be resisted.
Mgr. the Right Rev. Eugene P. Carroll, pastor of Our Lady of Grace Catholic Church, Hoboken, died today in the church rectory, 411 Willow Avenue, after an illness of three weeks. He was 79 years old.
Annual meeting, Association of Record Librarians of North America, Hotel Roosevelt, 10 A. M. Address of welcome by Mayor La Guardia.

At least once in every campaign a campaign letter soliciting support for a candidate reaches the home or headquarters of his opponent, a humorous reply is sent and both literary efforts are made public.

Proposed Federal taxation of the income from State and municipal bonds would add tremendously to the burdens of local government, State and municipal officers predicted last week in replies to a questionnaire sent to them by the Conference on State Defense.
J. M. Hickerson, large English-type house at 33 Greenacres Ave. Scarsdale, from Maxwell Smith; Robert E. Farley Organization, broker.
Prime Minister W. L. Mackenzie King of Canada suggested today that Bermuda was an ideal place for imperial and other conferences.
Americanization Day was observed today by the Children's Village, an institution for problem children in Dobbs Ferry. A parade was reviewed by Lieut. Gen. Robert Lee

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,973,390,350. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills.
All hail to the Big Three and to the team that scorns the score and the odds and rolls up its sleever when the clock is ticking off the last few minutes and all seems lost beyond redemption.
The Federal Government's efforts to adorn its public buildings with the finest native art obtainable will be intensified and made permanent, the Treasury Department announced today.
Mrs. Paula Ollendorff, proponent of Jewish liberalism and active in Jewish social work, died Saturday in Jerusalem, Palestine, at the age of 78, according to word received here yesterday.

Five persons were killed today when two airplanes collided 300 feet in the air over a Detroit suburb and fell in flames on a golf-driving range. The victims were: William Stanislaw, 35 years old, a pilot; Walter Paselk, 40, a pilot; Frank Baby, 24; Robert E. Lee, 26, and Robert E. Lee Jr., 3 1/2, all of Detroit. H
More than 150 policemen were called out this evening to quell a riot that broke out when anti-fascists tried to carry an American flag into a North Side hall.
The Scots-Americans defeated the Baltimore S. C., 4-1, in their American Soccer League fixture at Scots Field today.

The attempt to raise a religious issue against former Supreme Court Justice Charles Poletti, Democratic nominee for Lieutenant-Governor, was denounced yesterday by Dr. Charles Fama in a talk at the Boro Park Italian Baptist Church, 67 Eleventh Avenue, Brooklyn.
The French wholesale price index on Oct. 8 was 652, against 646 and 648 one and two weeks previously.

A permanent first mortgage loan of $106,000 for ten years at 41/2 per cent interest has been arranged by Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc, with the Bowery Savings Bank for David Markbreiter on the new 6-story apartment house at 47 Arden St.

Governmental operations here and abroad continue to dominate the wheat market. While quotations, in general, have been showing a steady to firm undertone little progress has been made on the upside and at the close yesterday, prices were about the same as on Sept. 1.
The St. Joseph's College of Philadelphia struck twice today to defeat Canisius College of Buffalo, 13 to 0, before a crowd of 8,000. It was the fourth straight victory for the Hawks.

A banking group composed of Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.; the Peoples National Bank of Rock Hill, S. C.; Hamilton Co. of Chester, S. C., and Kinloch, Huger Co. of Charleston, S. C., will offer today a new issue of $300,000 Charleston County, S. C., 21/2 and 23/4 per cent public improvement bonds, maturing $30,000 annually from Oct. 15, 1943 to 1952.

Official announcement of the 1938 list of hospitals approved by the American College of Surgeons; will be made today at the opening session of the annual hospital standardization conference, held annually in conjunction with the annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons.
Baron Gottfried von Cramm, German tennis player, was released on parole today from Lehrterstrasse Prison, where he had almost five months more to serve on a morals charge.

A thousand railway workers, representing spokesmen and members of twenty-one railway labor organizations, met at the Manhattan Opera House, Thirty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue, yesterday afternoon and unanimously adopted resolutions expressing their determination to resist the wage cut proposed by the railroads for Dec. 1 by declaring a general strike on the nation's railroads.

Child Labor Regulation No. 1, relating to the certificate of age for children employes which employers must obtain under the Fair Labor Standards Act if they wish to avoid unwitting violation of the act, was issued today by Miss Katharine Lenroot, chief of the Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor.

Near-by deliveries of cotton made further net advances last week, but the distant positions showed net losses. On the New York Cotton Exchange the December and January deliveries were up 6 and 7 points, respectively, while the July position registered a net loss of 6 points.

The three-story apartment building at 121 Nineteenth Street, West New York, N. J., accommodating nine families, was sold by Elizabeth Junger to the Vigor Realty Company, which will modernize and hold the property as an investment.

Shipments of hosiery in August were higher than for any previous August in the history of the hosiery industry and showed a gain of 9.3 per cent over that month of 1937, according to the statistical bulletin issued for publication today by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers. August shipments increased 37.2 percent over July as compared to "normal" increase between two months of 27.4 per cent.

The Jews should not be overmodest in this world crisis, when they are at bay as never before. They should do more than ask Great Britain to remove any restrictions which may prevent their immigration in Palestine. They should do that which will bring world peace.

Catholics were chided for their attitude toward Sunday attendance at mas by the Rev. Cornelius J. Drew, head of the New York Apostolate, the mission band of the New York Archdiocese, in a sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.
An appeal to American public opinion "not to say farewell too early to Czechoslovakia" was uttered here yesterday by Vladimir E. S. Hurban, Czechoslovak Minister to the United States.

Wellington H. Tinker of Montclair, N. J., has been appointed regional director for New England and the Middle Atlantic States in the campaign to raise funds for Chinese victims of the Sino-Japanese war under the auspices of the Church Committee for China Relief.

The cornerstone of the new Protestant Episcopal Church of the Epiphany on the northwest corner of York Avenue and Seventy-fourth Street was laid yesterday afternoon by Bishop William T. Manning at a service attended by more than 300 persons.

The two-month strike of the Yellow Cab Company's 950 drivers was ended this afternoon when the strikers voted to accept a compromise agreement drawn yesterday by representatives of the company and the union.

Yrjo Nikkanen, Finnish athlete, bettered his own unofficial world record for the javelin throw today with a toss of 78.70 meters (258 feet 2 1/2 inches) in a track and field meet at Kotka. His previous mark was 77.97 meters (255 feet 9 3/4 inches).

The proposed closer union between Presbyterian and Protestant Episcopal churches probably will receive new impetus here this week at the opening session of the Presbyterian Synod of New York, when the keynote address will be delivered by Dean Philemon F. Sturgess of the Cathedral of St. Paul in Boston.

A debutante committee, of which Miss Rosette A. King is chairman, is aiding with arrangements for a chrysanthemum luncheon and fashion show to be held tomorrow and Wednesday at the Versailles Restaurant.

Canadian radio sales to dealers in August amounted to 25,927 units valued at $1,909,176, compared to 13,558 units valued at $917,448 in July and 25,195 units, valued at $2,277,781 in August last year, the. Commerce Department reports.

A handsome chow chow, Champion Tally Ho Black Image Of Storm, climbed to the top for the second time in his career yesterday when he was judged best in show at the third annual event of the Staten Island Kennel Club.

The annual convention of the New York State Hairdressers and Cosmetologists Association, which usually draws at least 20,000 hairdressers and sets off a bombshell or two in the matter of novel and striking coiffures, will begin today at the Hotel Pennsylvania and continue through Wednesday.

The new Mary Louis Academy for Girls, named to perpetuate the memory of Mother Mary Louis, for many years connected with educational work in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, was dedicated yesterday by the Most Rev. Thomas

The regular apparel season this Fall will be at least three or four weeks longer than it was a year ago, Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak,Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., declared yesterday.
The key to Central Europe is Vienna, not Prague. As a little Vienna, Prague was decidedly east and north of center. It was not the natural and traditional nucleus of a system, as Vienna was.

Under the auspices of a junior committee of which Miss Winifred Harper Bonnell is chairman and a debutante committee headed by Miss Patricia Peale of the National Cathedral Association in New York, a benefit lecture has been arranged for the evening of Dec. 14 in the grand ballroom of the Plaza.
Mayor La Guardia has endorsed the candidacies of Edmund L. Palmieri and William T. Simpson for the City Court in Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday by the Palmieri-Simpson campaign headquarters.

The three three-story buildings at 1,304, 1,306 and 1,316 Avenue U, Brooklyn, each containing one store and two apartments, have been sold by the 117-20 Liberty Avenue Corporation to an investing client of Sidney Levine, broker.

The security markets here, although they closed yesterday in a slightly more cheerful mood, thanks to Wall Street's renewed strength, have had a gloomy week. Sterling securities, like the currency itself, have suddenly fallen from favor abroad, and Continental European liquidation for the purpose of switching into dollar securities has been very evident.

A few minutes after a fire company and a fireboat had put out a small fire in the piling at the base of the Manhattan Bridge a spectator from a near-by dock on the East River became so excited in praising the firemen's exploit to other watchers that he fell into the river.
The heavy pressure on the pound sterling in foreign exchange has elicited no surprise here. Great Britain's economic and financial position is deemed a cause for concern.

The Rev. Robert Bowman Stewart, for almost three years assistant pastor of the Coliegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, at the entrance to Rockefeller Center, has accepted a call to the pastorate of the First Presbyterian Church, Wheaton, Ill.
Supply contracts valued at $7,182,330 were awarded during the week ended Oct. 8 by fourteen Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Labor Department announced today.

The directors of North American Aviation, Inc., have voted a dividend of 40 cents a share of the capital stock, payable on Dec. 1 to stockholders of record of Nov. 15. The initial dividend was 121/2 cents, paid in December, 1937.

In the foreign-exchange market here the belga will continue to be linked to gold. The guilder and Swiss franc, for the time being, will not follow sterling in its distress but will, so far as possible, pursue an independent policy with one eye fixed on the price of gold.

Patients suffering from leprosy in the San Lazaro Hospital in Manila organized a track and field team today and leaders announced that the team planned to invade the famous Culion Island leper colony for a meet in December.
Legislation now before the Ecuadovean National Assembly provides for establishment of a cooperative composed of weavers, finishers and exporters of toauilla straw, or "Panamaa"

173d St. (11-2524), n w cor Morris Ave, 85x18; Nettie Goldstein to Morris Heights Realty Corp, 67 W 44th St. Jackson Ave (10-2652), n e cor Home St, 100x40; Dora Wolf to Jacob Cohen, 332 N Stricker St, Baltimore, Md.; mtg $45.200.

Leases of space for two new stock brokerage branches, one in the Hotel Commodore and the other on the Upper East Side, were among the business rentals reported yesterday. Many contracts for space by clothing firms and garment manufacturers also were announced.
Startling upheavals, more numerous perhaps than usual, caused a sharp reduction in the ranks of the undefeated during the past weekend as scholastic football warfare continued in full stride.
The new Swedish Methodist Church at 150 East Sixty-second Street, formerly at Lexington Avenue and Fifty-second Street, was opened to the congregation yesterday.

Miss Elizabeth Cass Smith and Alfred Pamton Sanford 2d will be married here on Nov. 5 in the Crescent Avenue, Presbyterian Church. The prospective bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry DeWitt Smith of Plainfield.

Great crowds of Catholic clergy, religious and laity kept pouring all day today into this ancient citadel of Catholicism in America in anticipation of the eighth National Eucharistic Congress, which will open here Tuesday morning and will continue through Thursday.
A union, not only military but moral, among all the forces opposed to aggression was urged today by Edouard Herriot, President of the Chamber of Deputies, speaking at Lyons on the recent crisis.

It is indeed cheering to be able to record that the downward curve of motor-vehicle deaths, which first began to brighten a thoroughly gloomy picture in the closing months of last year and the early months of this, continues its trend.
William C. Stokes, veteran policeman who guarded the assassin of President McKinley from an angry mob, died today In his home at the age of 77.
" Knights of Song," or the trials and triumphs of Gilbert and Sullivan set to their own music, opens tonight at the Fifty-first Street Theatre, which, as a movie theatre, was known as the Hollywood.

The board of directors of the New York Furniture Exchange has approved an immediate expenditure of $25,000 to remodel the corridors of the 16-story building at 206 Lexington Avenue in modern style Louis Bernstein, president, announced yesterday.

More than 1,000 Protestant men of all ages, representing about fifty Bronx churches of various denominations, marched in a "Christian Loyalty Parade" along Fordham Road yesterday to St. James Episcopal Church, Jerome Avenue and 190th Street, where a special service was held.

I. A. Horowitz and I. I. Kashdan contested the second game of their match of ten in the play-off for the championship of the American Chess Federation at the rooms of the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday.

When Alex Price shook us awake this morning it was still dark, and we had finished breakfast and were ready for the trek into the woods before it grew, light in the East. "Here's Johnny Murphy now," Alex announced, "and all ready to go."
Colonel Percy E. Van Nostrand, commandant of the first wing base of the United States Army Air Corps at March Field, died last night of a heart ailment at the age of 51.

American Writing Paper CompanyQuarter ended Sept. 30: Net loss, $46,031 before $630 interest on Federal Reserve Bank loan commitment and interest on general mortgage bonds and before estimated flood losses of $8,500.

Miss Anne Rice, daughter of Mrs. Louis Rice of 241 Old Army Road, Scarsdale, N. Y., was married here to Ralph G. Peterson of Cos Cob, Greenwich, son of Mrs. William Monthele of Brooklyn, this afternoon in the Greenville Reformed Church by the Rev. Russell Auman of the Evangelical Lutheran Church of the Redeemer.
It was announced in authoritative quarters today that Germany and Italy were in complete agreement over Hungary's demands for her nationality group in Czechoslovakia.

The Governors Island Yellows made it three victories in a row over the First Division four in their Colyer Trophy competition yesterday at Morris Memorial Field. The score was 8-5. The game closed the polo season at Governors Island.

A Brooklyn water main burst in spectacular fashion early yesterday morning, driving 350 persons from their homes in a dozen apartment buildings, as the pavement of Atlantic Avenue at Sherlock Place split open and water poured into cellars.

The currency which went so rapidly into circulation during the recent European crisis is returning now, last week's fall of [Pound]9,403,000 in the Bank of England's circulation being more than one-third of the rise which occurred on the preceding fortnight.

NOWADAYS it is neither polite nor practical to be uncertain. Among those books dealing with arguable matters, the ones that sell most widely are those giving a full $2.50, $3 or $5 worth of promise and comfort. Eric T. Bell's "Man and His Lifebelts"* gives literally none.

Lieut. Col. the Hon. Arthur Cecil Murray, who has had a distinguished career in the British Army and in Parliament, arrived yesterday from Scotland on the Anchor liner Cameronia accompanied by Mrs. Murray. He is a friend of President Roosevelt and will spend a week at Hyde Park as his guest.
Warm weather, general in most sections of the country, hampered trade in wholesale and retail markets somewhat last week, causing a sharp drop in volume on most apparel for Fall and Winter wear.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Marvin Nelson wil give a tea dance in the Louis Sherry Room at Sherry's on Dec. 27 to introduce their daughter, Miss Daphne B. Nelson. Miss Nelson attended the Brearley School and Miss Porter's School in Farmington, Conn.

With a declaration against "all dictatorships whether from the right, left or middle," and against "all the first steps leading to such dictatorships such as the suppression of civil liberties, whether of freedom of speech, press or assembly," the United States section of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom today broke off its affiliation with the American League for Peace and Democracy.

Laurence A. Ball, one of the engineers of the Delaware River Bridge between Philadelphia and Camden and recently active in World's Fair projects, died yesterday morning at Mount Sinai Hospital, which he entered Tuesday.
Mrs. Charles Bruen Perkins of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth Perkins, to Lee H. B. Malone of Cleveland, son of Mrs. Doris Malone.
The horseshoe pitching tournament for employes of New York City departments, which began on Saturday in parks of the five boroughs, was finished in Central Park yesterday.
The annual card party sponsored by members of the Alumnae Auxiliary Association of the Catholic Summer School of America will be held this year on the afternoon of Nov. 5 at the Waldorf-Astoria.
The Danish freighter Sejro, with a cargo of oiled scrap iron, was burning at Pier 7, Jersey City, early this morning with a ruddy glow below deck that threw a red glare across the water.

The annual campaign of the United Hospital Fund of New York for funds to carry on the work of its ninety-two voluntary hospitals and related services and the Visiting Nurse Association of Brooklyn will begin next Monday, it was announced yesterday by David H. McAlpin Pyle, president of the fund.

The last-day rush of voters to register for the general election on Nov. 8, which resulted in a registration only 45,965 less than that for the city election last year, was interpreted yesterday as probably favorable to District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, with one important qualification.
Tiffany St. 933 (10-2711); Benjamin Harris to City Bank Farmers Trust Co; 5 yrs, 4 per cent; $18,000. Arthur Ave, 1.812 (11-2945): also 175th St. 637 E; also 175th St, 641 E: also Belmont Ave, 1,815;

The religion that fills men with something supremely beautiful is the builder of a great personality, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church, said yesterday morning in his sermon there.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company in five years has added seven plants to its properties, according to the registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering $50,000,000 of ten-year 3 1/2 per cent debentures which are to be offered to the public this month.

Development of a microscope in which electrons take their own photographs was disclosed today at the California Institute of Technology by scientists who said they hoped it would permit exploration of a realm of objects hitherto thought too small to be seen.
Onefourth of the account numbers issued by the Social Security Board went to women workers, it was revealed by an analysis of old-age insurance records made public today.

A new world record for 1,000 yards was established today. as Sam Tekulsky of the Roosevelt Rifle Club of New York shot 99 successive bullseyes to capture the metropolitan all-caliber rifle championship at that distance at Camp Smith.
William H. Cole of New York died in a hospital here yesterday of a heart attack after a brief illness. He was here to arrange for the opening of a new warehouse.

Billy Cox, 14-year-old NorfolK, Va., skipper, gave a field of old timers a lesson in Moth boating today as he won the world title and the Antonia Trophy in a race featuring the three-day international regatta.

In "America Now," which Scribner will publish on Oct. 24, Harold E. Stearns has edited, with an introduction, an inquiry into civilization in the United States today by thirty-six men and women who are prominent in their fields.

Before one of the largest galleries to witness final formalities in the retriever meeting, prizes were awarded today for two stakes in the annual field trials of the Irish Water Spaniel Club of America.

The election of Francis A. Stanley, '25, and Samuel Rosenblum, '07, as captain and manager, respectively, of the New York University Letter Club was announced yesterday by Ben Ross, secretary of the Alumni Federation.

The warmest weather in nearly a month continued Summer's return engagement in the city yesterday. Beaches, highways and other open spaces were crowded as thousands took to the outdoors to enjoy the bright golden sunshine of a summery Fall day. It was' perfect weather for the several parades in the city.

The Seeing Eye, organization for assisting 'the blind, will open a drive for enrollment of 1,500 members in New York tomorrow morning with a meeting of the entire New York committee at the home of Mrs. Artemas L. Gates, 36 East Seventy-fourth Street.

36th St. 15-17 W, 48x98.9; Irving J. Joseph, ref. to Greenwich Savings Bank (foreclosure) ($326). 31st St, 343-45 E, 50x98.9; George A. Molleson to George A. Molleson Co, 142 Chambers St; mtg. $41,550 ($18.50).

69th St, 330 E, 16.8x67.4: Bertha Kessler to Julius Czapp, 328 E 69th St, 5 yrs, 51/2 per cent: $6,000. 82d St, 64 W, 19x102.2: Rexhold Realty Corp (James H. Cruikshank, pres), to Leo J. Goodwin and another; trustee Thomas J. Goodwin; p m mtg due Nov. 1, 1941. 5 per' cent; $8,500.
All in all, the annual spread of weather has been pretty unsatisfactory, including alternate hot, rainy and moldy spells this Summer and a hurricane to usher in the Fall.

Mrs. Berta Seiders Billing, manager of the free employment bureau of the New York Chapter, American Red Cross, 315 Lexington Avenue, died on Sunday at her home, 68-05 Burns Street, Forest Hills, Queens, of pneumonia after an illness of one month. Her age was 64.

Chief of Police C. T. White said a crowd of unidentified men burned a tenroom, two-story Negro school near here during a demonstration tonight following reported confession by a Negro that he was responsible for a double slaying Saturday night.

Agog with excitement at being in the national metropolis, the "typical" American family, Mr. and Mrs. Glen Craig and their two young children, Emmy and Billy, arrived in New York yesterday from Muncie, Ind.

Turpentine firm, 213/4c bid; no sales; receipts, 209 barrels; shipments, 441 barrels; stock, 49,985 barrels. Rosin firm; sales, 222; receipts, 2,000; shipments, 1,454; stock, 267,346. Quote: B, $3.80; D, $4; E. $4.25; F, $4.85; G. H. I, $4.95; K, $4.971/2; M, $5; N, $5.35; WG, $5.65; WW, X, $6.25.
Because of the many bruises and pulled muscles sustained in the North Carolina tussle last Saturday, Coach Mal Stevens allowed his New York University football squad an extra day of rest yesterday.

Andres Pastoriza, Minister from the Dominican Republic, said tonight that national committees had been formed in fourteen American republics to cooperate in plans for pushing to completion the construction of a Columbus Memorial Lighthouse near Ciudad Trujillo.

The Strecker case, which may have a strong bearing upon deportation proceedings against Harry Bridges, Pacific Coast labor leader, will be argued before the Supreme Court, in accordance with an order issued by the justices today.

The Supreme Court was sustained today by the Court of Errors and Appeals in refusing to revoke the 145-year-old charter of the Society for Establishing Useful Manufactures, founded by Alexander Hamilton.

President Roosevelt inn message today to Dr. Manuel Maria Borrero, President of Ecuador, declared the readiness of the United States Government to participate with other American governments that have been approached by Ecuador in an effort to mediate the long-standing boundary dispute between Ecuador and Peru, provided Peru was also agreeable to the proposal.
The United States, controlling 60 per cent of the word's crude oil supply, can look forward to a future of expanding world trade
Surgeons removed "a loose body" from the right arm of Hal Schumacher, pitcher of the Giants, on Friday, hospital attaches disclosed today.

A recent lecture by a philosophy teacher who asserted that Menshevism was based on principles laid down by Aristotle nearly 2,500 years ago, and termed Plato, Aristotle's teacher, the founder of fascism, has aroused a storm of protest in the student body of the Moscow Electrical Institute.

No pupil in the city's high schools hereafter will be permitted in rapidadvancement classes until the principal first makes sure "he can take it," Associate Superintendent Frederic Ernst decreed yesterday.

Charles G. Mortimer Jr., vice president in charge of sales of General Foods Corporation, has been appointed advertising manager, it was announced yesterday. by Austin S. Igleheart, newly appointed executive vice president.
The Smithsonian Institution announced today the invention of a new instrument which will measure the heat of a star billions of miles away.

Trading in the foreign exchange market was quieter yesterday and the principal monetary units improved. Most prices, however, closed under the best of the day. The pound sterling gained 1 5-16 cents to $4.74 3/4, although its high of the day was $4.75 1/8.

As youngsters' hearts all over the world beat anxiously for the millennium in the schoolroom it comes quietly and calmly to P. S. 500. This pupils' paradise has just illustrated the final phase in a history of land transportation through the operation of model railroads by model students, a method found to be startlingly successful.

The first test of the Robinson-Patman act's brokerage clause ended without a decision today when the Supreme Court rejected the petition of the Biddle Purchasing Company of New York to review a Second Circuit Court decision upholding the Federal Trade Commission's interpretation of the clause.

The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company has signed contracts for construction of its hot and cold strip mill improvement at Indiana Harbor, Ill., which will cost several million dollars, it was announced yesterday.

A proposed amendment to the State Constitution limiting labor to a fiveday week and an eight-hour day brought disapproval of the New York State Mayors' Conference today on the ground its adoption "might seriously impede public work."

A self-contained economic domain stretching from the North Sea to the Black Sea, able to supply Germany with almost everything she needs and held together by an economic axis running along the Danube, such is the vision Economics Minister Walther Funk brought home from his visits to the Balkan capitals.
The international stock market indices for Oct. 15, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:

The Legislature adopted tonight a resolution asking Harry L. Hopkins, head of the Federal Works Progress Administration, to investigate alleged abuses in the administration of the WPA in New Jersey and to but into effect corrective measures.

Before resting its case in the trial for treason of nine Left Wing Communist followers of Andres Nin, the prosecution today introduced what seems its most damaging evidence against the P. O. U. M. [Workers' Party for Marxist Unification.].

The New York State division of the American Federation of Labor, through the American Federation of Labor Non-Partisan Committee, announced yesterday its support for the grade-crossing amendment to the State Constitution. At the same time the body assailed the State C. I. O. organization for its disapproval of the proposal.

The four-story brownstone dwelling containing sixteen rooms at 704 Hudson Street, Hoboken, N. J., has been sold by the Hudson Trust Company to the 704 Hudson Street Corporation, which will renovate it and hold it for investment. J. I. Kislak, Inc., were the brokers in the deal.

A force of 100,000 well-equipped Chinese troops, entrenched in strong positions forty-five miles east of Canton, was reported to have stopped the Japanese South China expedition tonight in bitter fighting.
Hundreds of beauty culturists crowded into a lecture room at Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday to see the latest methods of creating the "simply must" upswept hair-do.

The Union Securities Corporation, new underwriting affiliate of the Tri-Continental Corporation and Seelected Industries, Inc., will make its bow as an underwriter tomorrow with a $500,000 participation in the $80,000,000 of new 3 1/2 per cent first-mortgage bonds of the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois which are to be offered by a syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

The legislative board of the State Association of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen today urged support of Attorney General Bennett Jr., who seeks re-election in November. The board said Governor Lehman had been "extremely fair" to labor, but took no further action on his candidacy.

Eddie Zivic, 140, Pittsburgh, won a decision over Tony Canzoneri, 142, New York, former featherweight : and lightweight champion, in a tenround bout tonight. It was the first fight in a comeback for the former champion.

A1 Reid and Joey Fontana, featherweights, will meet in the feature bout of eight rounds at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, tonight. The semi-final, also an eight-rounder, will bring together Leonard Del Genio and Bobby Wilson.

Hal Lube, left halfback, and Bob Johnson, quarterback, rested today as Colgate began to prepare for the intersectional game with Iowa at Iowa City next Saturday. At left half, Coach Andy Kerr used both Johnny Long and Wallie Davids, while Trey Coley, sophomore, was in the quarterback berth.
Secretary Wallace, in his speech at Springfield, effectively demonstrated what was wrong in such proposed substitutes for the present farm program as restriction of imports and pricefixing.

Some 2,000 members of the American Bakers Association, meeting here for their annual convention, heard their president, L. J. Shumaker, suggest that the industry cease wishing and star-gazing and get down to earth and hard work.

The story of a hand-to-horn battle with a wounded buck was told today by Joseph Bixby of Denver, State hail insurance commissioner. Mr. Bixby had only one shell in his gun when he saw a large buck. He fired and the animal dashed over a hill.

Attorneys for the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization presented clashing views in the Supreme Court today on the validity of a National Labor Relations Board order directing the abrogation of collective bargaining contracts by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York.

The Rev. Dr. George H. Talbott of Passaic, retiring moderator of the Presbyterian Synod of New Jersey, said tonight at its 116th annual meeting that "the besetting sin of the world today is that it would rather seek out some new social or governmental gadget than turn its footsteps toward eternal and everlasting righteousness, and we in America have joined that world goose-step."

The eight-room dwelling on a plot 100 by 132.5 feet at 71 Whitehall Boulevard, Garden City, L. I., was sold by the Y. W. C. A. retirement fund to Randall F. Brahe who will occupy it. The property was reported held at $18,500. William L. Enequist, Inc., was the broker in the deal.

More than 200 volunteer workers headed by Robert Lehman and Jerome Levine will seek support in the financial district for the 1938 campaign of the New York and Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities, it was announced yesterday by Paul Felix Warburg, chairman of the Business Men's Council of the Federations.
Steel operations are scheduled at 49.4 per cent of capacity this week, as compared to 51.4 per cent last week, a decline of 2 points, or 3.9 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute reports.

Everett Elkins, halfback of Marshall College in Huntington, W. Va., is top scorer of the nation's football players, according to The Associated Press. In four games Elkins has tallied 11 touchdowns for 66 point.
Oral arguments were presented today before the United States Circuit Court of Appeals by attorneys for 5,000 stockholders of the old Central Republic Bank and Trust Company.

Adoption of Proposition 1 of the new State Constitution was urged by speakers last night at a constitutional forum under the auspices of the Real Estate Owners Association of the Twelfth and Nineteenth Wards. The forum was held at the Julia Richman High School, 317 East Sixty-seventh Street.

The American College of Surgeons issued yesterday a list of 2,664 approved hospitals in the United States out of a total of 3,596 surveyed. Those listed for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut follow, with asterisks denoting hospitals provisionally approved:

Stocks sagged and closed generally lower, after early strength in aviation, utility and copper shares; turnover, 2,523,960 shares, largest trading since Sept. 14. Rail bonds lower, United States Government and other issues irregular; transactions, $6,652,625.

The first printing of 75,000 copies of Anne Morrow Lindbergh's "Listen! the Wind" was entirely subscribed for by the book trade on publication last Thursday, according to the publishers, Harcourt, Brace. Twenty-five thousand more copies already have been printed and an order was placed yesterday for 30,000 additional copies.

John J. Burns, formerly general counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission, was elected yesterday a director of the United Corporation, it was announced by George Howard, president of the utility holding company.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel H. Sternberg of 135 Central Park West have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gene Sternberg, to Dr. Thomas Paine Saltiel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leopold Saltiel of Chicago.

In the "first proceeding of importance" under the 1937 amendment to Section 26 of the Interstate Commerce Act, which broadened the Interstate Commerce Commission's jurisdiction to cover railroad safety, the ICC today denied an application by the Illinois Central Railroad to substitute the latest type of automatic block signals for the present automatic train-stop and cab-signal devices on its double-track main line between Champaign and Branch Junction, Ill.

Trial Decisions The following members of the Department having been tried before the Hon. Francis X. Giaccone. Deputy Fire Commissioner, on date specified, the following decisions are rendered by the Fire Chief and Commissioner:

A minimum hourly wage of 35 cents and a minimum weekly wage of $14 for forty hours' work are recommended for women and minor workers in the candy industry in this State by the Confectionery Wage Board, whose report was made public yesterday by Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner.

Commercial and industrial failures in the United States in the week ended Oct. 13 totaled 226, as compared with 191 in the same week a year ago and 192 a week ago, Dun . Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

Spanish war orphans will be aided by an entertainment to be presented tonight in the Palm Room of One Fifth Avenue, under the sponsorship of Mrs. Carl Lehman, as a benefit for the Foster Parents' Plan for Children in Spain.

The east side of the Midtown section accounted for the bulk of the contracts for residential space reported by brokers yesterday. Included in the leases were several for space in buildings on Park and Fifth Avenues.

A special bureau of investigation, operated by detectives of virtually all police departments in Westchester County and managed by the District Attorney's office, was opened today in the Larchmont Village Hall in a new attempt to solve the murder of Mary Imelda Coyle, 17-year-old New Rochelle girl who was attacked and beaten to death one week ago tonight while on her way to church.

With a regularity that is approaching clocklike precision, the foreign exchange market is being subjected to the usual rumors concerning devaluation. While the rumors usually include the pound, franc and even the dollar, the persistent reports in banking circles yesterday concentrated on sterling.

Retail orders in the hands of Buick dealers are the highest in ten years, W. F. Hufstader, general sales manager, announced yesterday. He said a cross-section of the dealer organization revealed that in all instances dealers had more orders for cars than a year ago and that in many instances they had booked more business than in the first half of the 1938 model year.

A routine experiment went awry here this morning in the Frick Chemistry Laboratory, and the explosion shattered the professor's right eardrum and peppered him and four students with fragments of a galvanized iron tub.

The status of banks under the Fair Labor Standard Act of 1938 is doubtful and probably will not be determined before next Monday, the effective date of the wage and hour requirements, Robert M. Hanes, vice president of the American Bankers Association and chairman

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Color Schemes: Blue and Purple," Grace Cornell, 11 A. M.: Oriental Art: the Far East (general tour), noon; motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.; "Interior Design: English Furniture," Grace Cornell, 3 P. M.

The contract for the new building of the United National Bank of Long Island to be erected on the west side of Lefferts Boulevard, north of Liberty Avenue, Richmond Hill, L. I., at a cost of $70,000 has been awarded to Theodore Rubsamen Co., according to Brown's Letters, Inc. Koch Wagner are the architects.

Jimmy Crowley was doing a nice job of broken-field tooling through the Bronx traffic yesterday when a taxicab cut. out from the curb in a U turn and piled things up. "Best block of the day," said Mr. Crowley, with a grin.
The results of the communal election held yesterday throughout Belgium were sufficiently known tonight to confirm a victory for the traditional parties against all the advanced and extremist groups.

Germany has promised support to Hungary in her demands for immediate cession of Czechoslovak territory containing 51 per cent Magyar. population provided she grants increased national and cultural rights to some 600,000 German settlers in Hungary, it was learned in foreign diplomatic quarters tonight.

Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, was in Mexico City today on what he described as "a visit of observation," the findings of which would be reported to the executive council of the A. F. of L.

Although credited with two victories in three starts, Andover's football forces have not flashed any amazing power. The coaching staff has detected consistent improvement, however, and hopes to field a formidable unit for the traditional Exeter game here on Nov. 12.

Seiji Noma, author, publisher of the newspaper Hochi and of .Japanese magazines, died today of a heart attack. He was 59 years old. Starting as a poor boy, working his way through college by teaching, Seiji Noma developed
The House Committee on Un-American Activities was told today that Commaunists seeking control of the Minnesota Farmer-Labor party, were highly active in that party's recent nominating convention.

The Archbishop of Canterbury today guardedly criticized the Munich peace settlement in a speech to his diocesan conference. The Archbishop, the Most Rev. Cosmo Gordon Lang, who was former Prime Minister Baldwin's stanchest supporter in the 1936 crisis over the abdication of King Edward VIII, said:

The cardinal factor in Central and Southern Europe today and the surest guide for the future is the vast stimulus given to native nazisms by the sweeping victory of their German prototype and protector.

A suit challenging the eligibility of Joaquin M. Elizalde, resident commissioner of the Philippines, to hold office, was filed today in the United States Court for the District of Columbia by Porfirio U. Sevilla of New York. Mr. Sevilla asked that Mr. Elizalde be enjoined from performing the duties of Resident Commissioner.

Thousands of Philadelphians lost their votes at the May 17 primary, according to a report made today by a committee appointed by Governor Earle to investigate complaints against the work of the Philadelphia Registration Commission, composed of three Democrats and two Republicans.

Efrem Zimbalist, with Vladimir Sokoloff at the piano, continued last night at the Town Hall his cycle of five programs devoted to the sonatas of the three B's. As at the opening concert last week, the second program in the series dealt with Bach and Beethoven:
In any event it can be established that Colonel Lindbergh did partake of food during his visit to England before

Reiterating the opposition of the Quebec Provincial Government to the St. Lawrence waterway scheme, Premier Duplessis said today that it would be constitutionally impossible for the Dominion to develop power under the plan without the consent of Ontario and Quebec.

Expansion of the Federal program for slum clearance and rehousing, which he said had played a big part in turning business upward, was predicted by Senator Wagner, author of the National Housing Act, in an address last night.

Duties collected on imported wines and liquors in August amounted to $1,739,551 compared with $2,002,188 in July, and $2,719,174 in August, 1937, James. H. Moyle, customs commissioner, announced today.

James Burke, president of the Edison Pioneers, announced yesterday that a wreath would be laid today on the grave of Thomas Alva Edison at Orange, N. J., and at the foot of the Edison Tower at Menlo Park. N. J.,

The Costume Designers Union, a branch of the United Scenic Artists, opened negotiations yesterday with the League of New York Theatres, the producers' organization, with a view to obtaining a closed-shop contract.

Department of Agriculture officials today set the disposal of 1,000,000 bales of cotton as the maximum goal of an experiment in a two-price sales program for surplus agricultural commodities conceived by Secretary Wallace.
The Rev. Dr. Paul C. Warren, associate pastor of West End Presbyterian Church in New York City, was elected Moderator of the New York State Presbyterian Synod as the annual gathering opened tonight.

Dr. Hugh Cabot was called today as the first witness before a Federal grand jury investigating charges that the American Medical Association and the District of Columbia Medical Society broke the antitrust law.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a recent letter to THE TIMES, Assemblyman Phelps Phelps inquired what assurance there would be that the 5-cent subway fare would not be increased after unification, pointing out that it is costing the city 10 cents for each 5-cent passenger using the Independent subway.

Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for Governor, cancelled his speaking engagements last night to remain at the bedside of his wife, who underwent an appendicitis operation yesterday in the New Haven Hospital, New Haven, Conn., it was announced at Socialist campaign headquarters.

Secretary Wallace charged the Republicans tonight with promoting "a campaign of jealousy of the sharecroppers' little corn patch." In a speech at a Democratic rally here the Cabinet official said the corn acreage harvested in the twelve cotton States in 1932 "was larger than the acreage being harvested in the same States this Fall."

Dr. Francis Charles Ligouri, physician and surgeon here for the last thirty-two years, died on Saturday in his home, at the age of 65. Coming from his native Italy when a boy, he attended public schools in New York, Bellevue Medical College and the medical school of the University ot Vermont, graduating from the last named in 1899.

The "hen of the year" of the fourth annual poultry exposition of the Northeastern Poultry Producers Council made her radio debut at 1:15 P. M. yesterday. She clucked a pleased obbligato while speeches were made in her honor.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, appealed to the United States last night to take the lead in the cause of world peace by calling an international conference for disarmament and, the creation of an international police force.

With 300 delegates from all parts of this country and fourteen foreign nations in attendance, the seventeenth annual Congress of Anesthetists opened here yesterday with discussions of new techniques for further extending relief of pain to the 25,000,000 persons who annually undergo surgical and dental operations.

Four Germans, one a young woman, were held in Cristobal jail in default of $15,000 bail each here today by Magistrate E. I. P. Tatleman after their arrest yesterday by military authorities at Fort Randolph for alleged attempted espionage.

Assembly Speaker Oswald D. Heck, up-State campaign chairman for Republican Gubernatorial Nominee Thomas E. Dewey, deplored tonight "halo-wearing" of Democratic candidates, who, he said, proclaim "purity of their own cause and depravity of their opponents' cause."

Three and a half months of the spending program cost the Treasury $908,980,284 more than it took in. Paced by WPA expenditures, Treasury spending amounted to $2,564,735,321, compared with $2,231,566,562 in the similar period last year.

Officers and board members of the Association of the Junior Leagues of America, from all parts of this country, Canada and Mexico, convened yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria for a five-day series of meetings.

Stockings that "must not be transparent" and brown leather shoes with low heels and plain toecaps will be prescribed for the Women's Auxiliary Territorial Service, an organization of women who during the crisis joined their husbands or brothers in Britain's volunteer service.

After another day of futile efforts to end the strike of 2,000 towboat Workers in the port of New York hope of a settlement appeared again last night when it was announced that a joint committee of the strikers and the New York Towboat Exchange would meet again this morning at the office of the exchange, 17 Battery Place.

After a day of charges and countercharges topped off by a new tangle, Martin Snyder, 42, was arraigned today for the shooting of Myrl Alderman, 30-year-old pianist, at the home of Ruth Etting, radio singer, Saturday night.

Nicholas Fodera, 27 years old, of 349 East Twelfth Street, was sentenced to serve five days in the workhouse yesterday when he pleaded guilty before Magistrate Troy in the Brooklyn Felony Court, to a charge of disorderly conduct.

Laurens Morgan Hamilton, great-great-great-grandson of Alexander Hamilton, was elected president of the New York Chapter, Sons of the American Revolution, at the organization's annual meeting last night at the Hotel Plaza.
Joey Archibald boxed his way to the featherweight championship of the world last night at the expense of Mike Belloise of the Bronx, whom he outpointed in a 15-round bout at the St. Nicholas Palace.

Following is the prepared text of the address tonight by Herbert Hoover on "Undermining Representative Government": The election of the Congress of the United States is always a serious action by the people.

Oblivious to the political activity of State Republican leaders in nearby Poughkeepsie, President Roosevelt put aside the cares of office today and drove about the backcountry dirt roads of his estate, inspecting his crop of Christmas trees.

ARON--Ray (nee Levy), daughter of the late Isidore and Hannah, beloved mother of Jennie. Minnie, Betty and Helma. Services Wednesday, Oct. 19, at 2 P. M. Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

Former Premier Nicolas lorga, one' of the greatest Rumanian authorities on national questions, whose influence is still felt in government circles, writing in the Temps explains that no country can now rely on France's support.
If the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo's revival of "Coppelia" does not take you back to your youth, it is certainly because it was a very recent youth, indeed, or a very sheltered one.

Mr. Churchill was guilty of one inaccuracy in an otherwise impeccable address. Speaking of the gains which 1 fascism has achieved in far-flung parts of the world, he said: "Even in South America the Nazi regime, thriving under the Monroe Doctrine, begins to undermine the fabric of Brazilian society."

Lou Little was a very glum in dividual at the weekly luncheon of the Football Writers Association at Jack Dempsey's yesterday. "Colgate gained on us and we couldn't gain on them," declared the Columbia maestro. "That's the story in a nutshell.

A reorganization plan for the Western Pacific Railroad which reduces the hides capitalization from around $144,700,000 to $93,726,517 and bars the present stockholders and unsecured creditors from participation in the reorganized company, was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Problems in connection with retailing of gasoline in the metropolitan area will be discussed at a luncheon-meeting of the Gasoline Chamber of Commerce tomorrow in the Hotel Whitman, Jamaica, Queens. Most major distributors recently signed Feld-Crawford pricemaintenance contracts covering their products in the five boroughs, but nevertheless there has been some minor cutting of prices.

Manny Strewl, intermediary in the kidnapping in 1933 of John J. O'Connell Jr., nephew of Edward and Daniel O'Connell, brothers and Democratic leaders of Albany County, won a reduction yesterday of thirty-six years in the time he must serve in Federal prison for the part he played in that crime.

The wholesale price index of the National Fertilizer Association continued downward last week, chiefly because of lower prices for petroleum, steel sheets and livestock. The index, based on the 1926-1928 average, was 72.7 for the week ended Oct. 15. compared with 73.2 last week, 73.8 a month ago and 83.9 a year ago.
Harry A. Mackey, attorney and former Mayor of Philadelphia, died here today after an illness of two months. He was 69 years old.

Mrs. John Hubbard of Paris, sister of Harris Fahnestock, was honored at a luncheon today by Mrs. Fahnestock at Eastover, Lenox. Others present included Mrs. Frederick S. Delafield, Mrs. Churchill Satterlee, Mrs. Samuel Frothingham, Mrs. Charles Robinson Smith and the Misses Gertrude Robinson Smith, Mary Parsons and Nancy T. Patten. Mrs. Hubbard is to sail Wednesday for Paris.

Stephen F. Chadwick, National Commander of the American Legion, stated at a press conference today that the Legion would "exert its full influence" toward obtaining an increased American Air Force, a larger army and navy "second to none."

The fishing schooner dual for the sailing championship of the North Atlantic has been postponed again. The third race for the International Fishermen's Trophy has been set for Wednesday, when favorable winds are expected.
Coach Earl Blalk saw the motion pictures of the Brown game today, and the result was a long, strenuour session for the Dartmouth football team on pass defense.

Sermons on a variety of topics, many bearing on contemporary international problems, were preached by rabbis yesterday morning at services ending the eight-day observance of Sukkoth, the Feast of Tabernacles.

Clyde Bathurst, sculptor and art authority, died at a hospital here today at the age of 55. Educated in Pennsylvania schools, Mr. Bathurst won early honors there after accepting a scholarship from the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts.

In making a musical comedy out of the lives of Gilbert and Sullivan, Glendon Allvine enjoys the services of a good composer and a good librettist. Although that is a great asset in "Knights of Song," which was staged at the Fifty-first Street last evening, it is not the greatest.
Elmer F. Andrews, wage-hour administrator, ruled today that only the Philippine Islands, among United States Territories, dependencies or possessions, were exempt from the Fair Labor Standards Act.
The Sandar Corporation's application for a status as a non-holding company under the Public Utility Holding Company Act was granted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Dr. James H. Kimball, chief meteorologist at the United States Weather Bureau in this city, announced yesterday the promotion of Burton Salisbury, night observer at the bureau, to the post as first assistant meteorologist at the Weather Bureau in Des Moines, Iowa.

A serious shortage of reasonably priced quarters suitable for young women who will want to live in New York during the World's Fair was predicted yesterday at the first Fall meeting of the New York City board of the Young Women's Christian Association, at the association's New York headquarters, 135 East Fifty-second Street.

Jacob Keler has leased from Elizabeth Hoyt, for occupancy, the four-story private dwelling at 108 West Seventy-third Street, through the Hudaky Company, Inc., broker. The house contains eighteen rooms and seven baths.

Henry L. Fraissinet, president of the Button Machinery Corporation of Hoboken, died today at his home here after a month's illness. His age was 82. Born in France, Mr. Fraissinet came to this country sixty-five years ago. He lived in Clifton, Ariz.,

With three weeks to go before the November election, confidence of Ohio Republicans that they will elect both a Governor and a Senator and make substantial gains in the House is running higher than at any time since the New Deal swept them into the political discard.

William Rhodes Davis, American independent oil operator who was reported to have negotiated the sale of expropriated Mexican oil to Germany, Italy and Sweden, was found guilty of conspiracy to defraud a Danish oil company, in the Kings Bench Division of the High Court today.

Marcel Olivier, the commissioner general of the French section of the New York World's Fair, has leased space on the fourth floor of La Maison Francaise in Rockfeller Center for the executive offices of the French World's Fair Commission, it was announced yesterday.

Standing beneath the scaffolding of the incomplete Washington Heights Health and Teaching Center, Mayor La Guardia told 500 persons yesterday that the city had perfected plans for a housing development that would cost either. $10,000,000 or $22,000,000 and accommodate 1,500 families.

The monthly survey of bankers' dollar acceptance outstanding in all of the Federal Reserve Districts as of Sept. 30, 1938, showed an aggregate of $261,430,941, an increase in the period of $3,111,329, but a decrease of $344,419,113, compared with a year previously.

Preparing to meet undefeated Georgetown at the Yankee Stadium next Saturday, Coach Herb Kopf sent the Manhattan football team through a ninety-minute offensive and defensive dummy scrimmage yesterday.

The Holy Cross football squad today opened. preparations for Saturday's intersectional game against Georgia with a lively scrimmage between the second and third teams. The first string assembled for a lengthy offensive drill in a dummy scrimmage.

The American Labor party yesterday followed the lead of Governor Lehman and Charles Poletti and rejected the support of the Communist party, which last week withdrew its nominees and announced its intention of supporting the Statewide candidates of the American Labor party.
An afternoon party for the benefit of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals will inaugurate the formal opening of the cocktail lounge at the Versailles on Thursday afternoon.

Mrs. William Brown Meloney, editor of This Week magazine, will close the first session of The New York Herald Tribune's three-day 1938 forum on current problems, which will open next Tuesday morning at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, it was announced last night.

The twenty-eighth annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons, the outstanding event of the year in surgery on the North American Continent, opened here yesterday its multifarious activities of conferences, general sessions, clinical demonstrations and discussions on hospital standardization, aiming to improve the general standards of surgery and of hospital care in the United States and Canada.

A highspeed process for electroplating copper in one-fourth the time required by methods now in use was demonstrated here today at the National Metals Show by chemists of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc.

A committee of the Wilkes-Barre Newspaper Guild arranged today with Thomas F. Heffernan, publisher of The Sunday Independent, to begin immediate negotiations for a wage-hour contract. which would enable The Independent to resume publication next Sunday.

Two men and a woman were found shot to death today in a locked house in the northwestern section of the city. Stuart K. Smith, a State investigator, said all three were killed by shotgun blasts and apparently had been dead since Saturday night.
" Sky guns" threw thousands of rounds of 3-inch and .30 caliber projectiles high into the heavens today in a spectacular demonstration of the firing power of anti-aircraft weapons.

Albert M. Greenfield, real estate broker, stated tonight that he had obtained warrants for the arrest on criminal charges of Moses L. Annenberg, publisher of The Philadelphia Inquirer; Eli Z. Dimitman, city editor of The Inquirer, and Daniel G. Murphy an attorney.

Weitzel Anderson Turner of Richmond, Va., a milkman, today received the gold Pasteur Medal of the Milk Industry Foundation for the "outstanding heroic deed of the year in connection with his work." The award was made at the convention of the International Association of Milk Dealers and affiliated groups.

Farmers throughout the Middle West are beginning to turn over to the Federal Government sealed corn put up as sole collateral for Federal loans made on the 1937 crop. Seals are being broken on this old corn that indirectly is competing with new corn beginning to move into market channels.

With, Big Bill Tranavitch, backfield star, lost for at least two weeks and possibly for the remainder of the season, the Rutgers football team started preparations today for the game with HampdenSydney next Saturday.
Boone Gross, formerly merchandising manager of Hiram Walker, Inc., and F. R. LaBerge, formerly of the San Francisco district, have been appointed assistant general sales managers.

The outlines of an alleged German plot to obtain plans for the defense of the Eastern Coast and the Pantma Canal, along with other mill cary and naval secrets of the Unitad States, began to take shape yesterday before Federal Judge John C. Knox and a jury of housewives and business men as the governnent opened its case against three accused pawns of the Reich on trial cor espionage.

For improvement with a one-story business building, the vacant plot comprising the east side of Morgan Avenue between Skillman and Jackson Avenues, Brooklyn, has been purchased by the V. Z. Realty Corporation from the FCA Corporation.

Style settlements last week fell to 1,898, a decline of about 11 per cent from the preceding week and almost 40 per cent below the corresponding week of 1937, the joint board, Dress and Waistmakers Union, reported yesterday.

After being informed yesterday that George U. Harvey, Borough President of Queens, had ordered all work stopped on the $5,000,000 Queens General Court House in Jamaica because his brother-in-law, James A. Lunn, had been dropped from the payroll, Paul J. Kern, president of the Civil Service Commission, suggested that some public-spirited residents of Queens might assemble a fund to pay Mr. Lunn's salary.

Henry Schectman, 22 years old, of 2,214 Sixty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, recently convicted by a jury of first-degree robbery, was sentenced yesterday by Kings County Judge Peter J. Brancato to twenty to forty years in Sing Sing prison.

The Board of Review of the Immigration Service today reserved decision on the appeal of John St. Loe Strachey, English writer and lecturer, from a ruling by a special board of inquiry at Ellis Island last week, holding he was not admissible to the United States.

The marriage of Miss Henrietta C. Westendorf, daughter of Mrs. William Henry Westendorf of this city and the late Mr. Westendorf, to Edward W. Spooner, son of Mrs. M. W. Spooner of Newark, N. J., took place here this afternoon in the rectory of the Church of Our Lady Help of Christians.

Michael Reiburn, former New York. State Senator and Assemblyman, was arrested yesterday in Foley Square by a detective of Attorney General Bennett's staff on a Jersey City warrant charging grand larceny.

The stock market staged yesterday one of the most boisterous openings of the year, but as the session proceeded gave up the fight to hold the gains in the face of strong profit-taking which brought final prices 1 to 3 points under close on Saturday.

The controversy over the proposed 15 per cent cut in railroad wages moved nearer to President Roosevelt today when representatives of both sides made their final arguments before the Fact-Finding Board.

The Social Security Board reported a decline today of 2 per cent from August to September in the number of persons receiving general relief from public funds in 115 cities, and a drop of 3 per cent in the amount of obligations incurred for this type of relief. The report was based on telegraphic reports from the cities.

Dr. John Barrett, credited by many with doing more than any other person of his generation to promote closer relations among the American republics, died in a hospital here today of bronchial pneumonia at the age of 71.

Al Brosch, who captured the Metropolitan P. G. A. crown at Oceanside two weeks ago and who has won many one-day tournaments in this section recently, set the pace again today. He took three prizes in the Long Island P. G. A. event on the difficult black course at Bethpage State Park.
Too much government from Paris continues to be the chief complaint of the Alsatian regionalists, who have taken up the claim for decentralization that the autonomists had made their own.
