Sir Henry Fowler, designer of the famed "Royal Scot" locomotives of The London, Midland Scottish Railroad, died last night at Spondon Hall, Derbyshire, at the age of 68. He had served as president of many engineering societies.

Decision to make a study of all aspects of the "two-price" plan of Secretary Wallace was reached at a meeting here yesterday of local and out-of-town retail executives held at the offices of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
Mrs. Wanamaker Munn will give a supper dance on Nov. 23 in the Starlight Roof of the WaldorfAstoria to introduce to society her daughter, Miss Fernanda Wanamaker Munn.
Senator Wagner of New York had no personal expenses in his primary campaign, and received no contributions, according to his report to the Senate Committee on Campaign Expenditures.

Miss Margaret Johnston of Chapel Hill was married here this afternoon to Robert Morris Gardiner of Rochester, N. Y., and Philadelphia in the Chapel of the Cross by the rector, the Rev. Alfred Lawrence.

Philanthropic organizations will be beneficiaries of the performance of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo tonight at the Metropolitan Opera House. The lower tier of boxes has been taken over by a committee under the joint chairmanship of Mrs. Flagler Matthews and Mrs. Richard W. Hollaman in the interests of the East Side Settlement House and its auxiliary, the Winifred Wheeler Day Nursery.

A banking group headed by the Harris Trust and Savings Bank of Chicago won the award yesterday of a new issue of $1,346,000 of city of Davenport, Iowa, independent school district bonds, on a bid of 100.276 for 2s.

Edward J. Madden, Kearny lawyer and formerly assistant prosecutor of Hudson County, today filed a petition to run as an independent candidate for the unexpired term of the late Mayor Arthur H. Jones of Kearny. who died Oct. 4. Mr.
The Adirondack Forest Preserve was officially closed today to hunters by a proclamation of Governor Lehman, because of the fire hazard in fourteen counties.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. reported yesterday earnings of $2.31 each on 11,042,003 shares of common stock in the nine months ended on Sept. 30, compared with $5.33 a share earned in the same period of 1937.
Transactions involving city realty reported yesterday included the sale of a large apartment house on Central park West and of properties on the East Side and in the Bronx.

The gloomy forecast of Saturday's Texas Christian-Texas A. and M. result was Scout Howard Grubbs's: "Those Aggies will mow us down. We may make one or two first downs but if we score a point it will be one of the major upsets of 1938." .. Ho Hum.... Final count. Texas Christian 34, Texas A. and M. 6.

THERE is unfortunately only one sure way to get a reputation for critical wisdom: to endorse novelties as they appear. If you are interested in belles-lettres, applaud almost every crank poet, freak novelist and eccentric essayist who happens to come your way. If you are a student of music or the fine arts, speak in respectful tones of all but the dizziest cacophonists and paint-pot flingers.

The blotter entry at the West Forty-seventh Street station house read: "10 A. M.--Patrolman William B. Kip, midtown squad present with one goat found on Sixth Avenue near Fifty-third Street. Owner unknown. Placed in cell 3 and at 11:15 A. M. delivered to A. S. P. C. A. Agent Thomas Hannaberry."
An official bulletin issued tonight embodies a report from the physicians in attendance on President Kemal Ataturk, who is lying ill at Dolma Baghche Palace.
Mr. and Mrs. Bryce Stewart Hume of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Stewart Hume, to John Edmund Norris Hume Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hume of Schenectady, N. Y.

In one of the first opinions of the present term the Supreme Court today ruled for "one model Ford V-8 de luxe coach" and against the government, which had said its defeat would mean an easy way for bootleggers to obtain "one of the instrumentalities of their trade," and, would add to the difficulty of enforcing the internal revenue laws.

Meetings of importance to the future of the Van Sweringen railroad system are to be held in Cleveland today by the directors of the Chesapeake Corporation and the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad, which the holding agency controls.

The highest price ever paid for a seat on the New York Stock Exchange became the center of a legal fight today when the widows of the two Beal brothers, former residents of Danbury, carried their dispute over their husbands' assets to the Superior Court.

IT is fairly well known that few college football coaches take a stand near the campus gate in September and beat off good football players with a stick. No, sir; that isn't quite the way they operate. In fact, if you see them at the gate, the chances are that they are straining their eyes looking down the road and wondering what's keeping that big tackle who promised to enroll in the freshman class.
Paraguay continued her return to a normal constitutional regime today when both Houses of Congress began their first business session since the Chaco war. The press was relaxed at noon. Dr.

Dr. J. Mott Heath, one of the coroners of Suffolk County, who conducted the inquest in the death of Ellis S. Duvall of Riverhead, president of the Suffolk County National Bank, of this village, decided today that death was due to a bullet wound, self-inflicted.
Mrs. James Reeves gave a luncheon yesterday at Sherry's for Miss Antoinette Corroon, who will be married on Saturday in the Church of the Cure of Ars, in Merrick, L. I., to Donald Vincent Reed.

Today's events: Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conducting, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.; Lotte Lehman, soprano, Town Hall, 8:30 P. M. The Philharmonic - Symphony League will open its season tomorrow afternoon with a luncheon in the Hotel Plaza Ball Room.

Penn State announced an eightgame football schedule for 1939 today, with Army replacing Lafayette in the only change from this year's foes. It will be the first meeting of the Nittany Lions and the cadets in thirty-nine years. Penn State beat Army, 6 to 0, in 1899, and the teams played a scoreless tie in 1900.
Winston Churchill's broadcast attack on dietators received contemptuous editorial treatment in the Boersen Zeitung.

Aroused by the Colgate defeat, Columbla's football team sped through a thorough rehearsal of plays yesterday at Baker Field. The Lions, confident that their lapse in speed and timing against the Red Raiders was only temporary, buckled down to perfect the precision of their pausing and running attack for the Penn game Saturday in Philadelphia.

Charles N. Manfred, retired magazine publisher, died on Saturday night at the Presbyterian Hospital after an illness of one week. He was 67 years old and lived at 365 West Forty-fifth Street. He also maintained a Winter home at Coral Gables, Fla., and a Summer residence at Dallas, Texas.

Selected by welfare agencies of the metropolitan area, 593 candidates for enrollment in the Civilian Conservation Corps have been notified to report at the U. S. Army Building, 39 Whitehall Street, Manhattan, this morning at 9 o'clock for physical examination by army Medical Corps officers.

Small retailers in the Loop District are about holding their own with the large department stores, suffering declines that are no better and no worse than those of the individual departments in the bigger establishments.
Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, handed to United States Ambassador William Phillips today Rome's reply to Washington's note regarding American Jews.

The first cautious venture by the staid British Broadcasting Corporation into Sunday broadcasting of dance music brought a quick decision by the Lord's Day Observance Society today to "protest with every nerve and fibre of our religious conviction."

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary is due today from Southampton via Cherbourg. Her passengers include Sir George Paish. Meyer W. Weisgal, Dr. Max Habicht, Fritz Kreisler, Sergei Rachmaninoff, Richard Collet, Mrs. Lilian T. Mowrer, Mrs. James H. Sharp, Viscount and Viscountess Harcourt, Lord and Lady de Ramsay, Sir Alfred Booth and Lady Booth.

Governor Lehman last night named John Harlan Amen, one of the Federal Government's leading "racket busters," to supersede District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan in the inquiry into official corruption in Brooklyn.

No kosher kill in local markets yesterday because of Jewish holiday, eighth day of Succoth. Trading on traefer meats was slow, pork cuts mostly lower and other classes about steady. Steer hindquarter cuts were very slow. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:

The rate on the Treasury's weekly bill offering dropped from an average of 0.022 per cent last week to 0.018 per cent for the bills sold today, according to an announcement by Secretary Morgenthau. For the third successive week there was at least one bid of 100.
Mr. and Mrs. John G. Medley of 304 East Fourth Street, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Emma Medley, to Laurence Alfred Brewer of New York.

Warners completed the cast of "Always Leave Them Laughing" today and prepared to start the picture within the week. Gale Page was assigned the feminine lead opposite Dick Powell and added in support were Ann Sheridan, Maxie Rosenbloom, Allen Jenkins and Jerry Colonna. Ray Enright will direct.

High temperatures last week in many areas of the country were reflected yesterday in the smaller volume of mail orders received in the wholesale markets here. The number of arriving buyers also was below that of last Monday. The mail orders for ready-to-wear were of a scattering nature.

Again traffic accidents, fatalities and the number injured on the city streets dropped last week and weekend compared with the corresponding periods a year ago, it was announced yesterday by the safety bureau of the Police Department.

Expressing his faith that the spirit of the Sermon on the Mount would bring about the happy solution of every social, political and economic problem of the world today, President Roosevelt declared in a letter to the eighth National Eucharistio Congress opening here tomorrow that "no greater blessing could come to our land today than a revival of the spirit of religion."

It is learned unofficially but definitely that Yosuke Matsuoka is resigning the presidency of the South Manchuria Railway soon. He is believed to be the most likely candidate for the Foreign Ministership.

Pensioned On his own application. To take effect 12 noon, Oct. 16: PATROLMAN--James J. Powers. 18th Division, 11th Detective District, $1,500 per annum. Appointed April 22, 1910. Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., Oct. 18: ACTING CAPTAIN--Charles E. Fields. from Telegraph Bureau to 12th Division, assigned to desk duty. Designation as acting captain revoked.

139th St (10-2590), s s, 453 e of Southern Blvd. 175x100; the Port Morris Land and Improvement Co to 808 E 139th St Realty Corp, 808 E 139th St; mtge, $24,000. 230th St (13-2407), s e cor Arlington Ave, 127x65; Edward C. Hooker to Adolph Hoehn, 89 Devoe St, Yonkers; mtge, $12,000.

2d Lt. Andrew J. Choos, Inf.-Res., 2,322 Tremann Ave., Bronx, N. Y., First Division, is ordered to active duty with the CCC for a period for six months, effective Oct. 18, at CCC Co. 3216, Camp S-116, Mannsville, N. Y. Date of rank, Oct. 15. 1937. He will revert to an inactive status April 17. 1939.

The Order of the Silver Star was presented last night by Colonel Hugh McGee, former Chief of Staff of the Seventy-seventh Division, to three former officers and one former noncommissioned officer of the 305th Infantry at a dinner given by the 305th Infantry Association to the four war heroes at the Seventyseventh Division Clubhouse.

Kenneth F. Simpson, Republican National Committeeman for New York, and also the New York County chairman, resigned yesterday as a member of the executive committee of the State committee. George Frankenthaler, a lawyer, was elected at a meeting yesterday afternoon to succeed him.

Colonel Allan B. Wallace, one of the bestknown citizens of Summit and at one time a member of the firm of J. C. Smith Wallace, grain merchants of Newark, died this afternoon of a heart attack at his home here. His age was 75.

Pilots, owners and officials of two speed boat racing classes evolved a number of significant new regatta rules last night at the Hotel Lexington'in the first of the annual October series of four days of gatherings of the American Power Boat Association.

A complete default in the handling of the housing problem was laid at the door of Governor Lehman and the Democratia State administration last night by Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for Governor.

Trial of Robert Gammon, 27 years old, a wireless operator at the Navy Radio Compass Station at Amagansett, L. I., on a charge of first degree murder, began today before County Judge L. Barron Hill here.
Declaring lynch law "must never prevail here," Judge E. L. Walker ordered the Lincoln Parish grand jury today to investigate the lynching of a Negro by a white mob last Thursday.

By refusing to consider an appeal, the Supreme Court today upheld jail sentences and fines for thirtynine men who defied a court order to evacuate the plant of the Fansteel Metallurgical Corporation in North Chicago in February during a strike led by C. I. O. organizers.
Automobile production expanded sharply again last week and the adjusted index jumped to 65.9. The figure was 51.4 for the preceding week. and 157.1 for the week ended Oct. 16. 1937.
Money market was quiet and quotations unchanged for all types of loans.

Miss Isabel Imlay Butterworth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G. Forrest Butterworth Jr. of Hilltop Place, Rye, N. Y., has completed plans for her marriage to Cabot Ward Low, son of Mrs. Peter F. Crossman of New York, which will take place the afternoon of Nov. 5.
David Amariglio, Paris representative of the Friends of the Abraham Lincoln Battalion, made the following statement today:
All previous Weather Bureau records for the date were broken yesterday when--on the seventh day of New York's Fair "heat wave"--the temperature reached 87 degree.

By a vote of 12 to 3, the Court of Errors and Appeals, New Jersey's highest law tribunal, sustained today Vice Chancellor Henry T. Rays's finding that the resolution adopted by the lower house of the 1938 Legislature creating a committee to investigate the Hudson County balloting in the 1937 general election was invalid because it attempted to usurp judicial functions.

Only two minutes after the pheasant hunting season opened at noon today, William A. Schriner, about 40, of Rochester, was fatally shot on a farm near here. Schriner was hunting with Herman Stevens, 43, of Coldwater.

Ananda Mahidol, boy King of Siam, today started on a long journey to Bangkok to visit the land he has not seen since he became its King three and a half years ago. Ananda, who. became 13 years old last Sept. 20, was accompanied by his mother, Princess Mahidol, and his 10-year-old brother, Pompipal.
Irving Shaw, 33 years old, of 200 West Ninety-fifth Street, Manhattan; Jack Engelsberg, 38, of 1,203 Chaning Road, Far Rockaway, and Siegfried Wechsler, 35, of 1,382 Eggert Place, Far Rockaway,

Losing no opportunity, to strengthen his reserves, Coach Bill Wood had Army's varsity-squad men who did not play Saturday against Harvard scrimmage today against B squad teams, using Notre Dame plays.

A somewhat easier tone prevailed in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Exceptions to the trend, however, were noted, particularly among the pivotal power and light issues, but weakness in the secondary railroad issues, the local tractions and numerous convertible obligations more than offset stability in the public utility list.

Clarence Klinck, vice president of the Manufacturers Trust Company at 707 Fifth Avenue, died suddenly yesterday at his home, 457 Rugby Road, of a heart attack, in his sixty-second year. He was also a trustee of the Kings County Savings Bank, of which his brother, Jacob C. Klinck, is president.
" A Woman's a Fool -- To Be Clever," the Dorothy Bennett-Link Hannah comedy about actors and dramatists in Bermuda, is unveiled tonight by John J. Wildberg at the National.

Miss May Morris, younger daughter of William Morris, the poet, died yesterday at Kelmscott Manor, Lechdale, after a short illness, at the age of 75. She edited and wrote introductions to her father's collected works in twenty-four volumes. She also had an important position with an embroidery manufacturing firm.
Mighty Pittsburgh, unbeaten since mid-season in 1936 and perennial Paladin of the East in intersectional warfare, is the nation's first football team.

Secretary Ickes, who holds at least a dozen posts besides his titular one, is one of the busiest of men. He if anybody has earned a vacation and deserves not to be pestered. Yet in his travels in the realms of gold Rumor is always barking at him.

New plays to be used against the Michigan eleven in the Bowl Saturday were turned over to the Yale regulars today and they spent the afternoon mastering them. The players who saw action Saturday against Navy came through in fine physical condition.

The stock market here was listless today and prices were inclined to droop. The gilt-edge issues behaved irregularly and finished with net declines. Foreign bonds were unsettled, although Central European issues held up fairly well.
The purge that is still continuing in the Red Army, though apparently on a smaller scale, is being accompanied by promotions of thousands of junior officers to responsible posts.

Six Catholic priests have been arrested in Vienna, accused of complicity in demonstrations against the Nazi regime. Archbishop Waits was barred from visits to schools because he had supported monks who opposed occupation of a Salzburg monastery.

C. R. V. Coutts, manager and actuary of the Provident Mutual Life Assurance Association, dropped dead here today in the office of the company, at the age of 62. He was well known in his field, and had returned recently from a professional conference in New York.

Two brothers, one a physician, the other a dentist, reported last night the isolation of a streptococcus they believe is the principal cause of tooth decay and the discovery that it is nurtured by an element in food made from cereals which could be eliminated by a change in the processing.

In an effort to prevent a runaway market, the International Copper Cartel announced yesterday in London that all restrictions on production were removed as of Oct. 15 "for whatever period is considered advisable."

The Security Publishing Corporation announces that the first issue of its new magazine, The Policyholder's Monthly, which is to discuss insurance problems from the standpoint of the policyholder, will be available on Thursday.

Strictly choice and prime fed steers and yearlings sold steady today, mostly on shippers and order buyer account, but the bulk of the trade was 25 cents lower, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. Lambs sold generally weak to 25 cents lower, and hogs, although active, were again weak to 10 cents lower.
Good news for certain certificate holders has come again, as it has on several other occasions in the past, just at the time when the investors were about to give up hope.

The Equity Corporation reported yesterday a net asset value of $5,454.78 for each $1,000 of assumed debentures, of $57.21 a share of $8 convertible preferred stock, and of 37 cents a common share, all as of Sept. 30, compared with $5,298.05, $55.20 and 26 cents, respectively, on June 30, and with $4,833.61 for each $1,000 of debentures and $48.81 a preferred share on Dec. 31, 1937.

In Federal housing legislation and in most people's minds subsidized housing and slum clearance are closely connected. In practice, as Chairman Alfred Rheinstein of the New York City Housing Authority made plain in his address delivered before the National Association of Housing Officials, there are difficulties in making the two objectives trot in harness.
Good news for certain certificate holders has come again, as it has on several other occasions in the past, just at the time when the investors were about to give up hope.

The Equity Corporation reported yesterday a net asset value of $5,454.78 for each $1,000 of assumed debentures, of $57.21 a share of $8 convertible preferred stock, and of 37 cents a common share, all as of Sept. 30, compared with $5,298.05, $55.20 and 26 cents, respectively, on June 30, and with $4,833.61 for each $1,000 of debentures and $48.81 a preferred share on Dec. 31, 1937.

In Federal housing legislation and in most people's minds subsidized housing and slum clearance are closely connected. In practice, as Chairman Alfred Rheinstein of the New York City Housing Authority made plain in his address delivered before the National Association of Housing Officials, there are difficulties in making the two objectives trot in harness.
Preparations for the game with Navy next Saturday were initiated by Princeton today with an extensive passing drill for the firststring players and more than an hour of scrimmage for the seconds.
An Englishwoman's conspicuous courage in braving street sniping in the Old City to help destitute children and old people has won the admiration of British soldiers and terrorists alike.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Oct. 12, which included only five business days in most of the reporting centers, aggregated $6,854,000,000, or 22 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week, and 3 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year, which also included only five business days in most of the reporting centers.

Syracuse's squad drew a light day of work today as a reward for its victory last week over Cornell. Most of the varsity men only exercised, as Coach Ossie Solem ordered rest to make up the big loss in weight last Saturday. Many of the regulars dropped ten to twelve poundse in the heat of the Cornell game.
Sports Promoter Jack Harris said today he had offered Donald. Budge, world's No. 1 amateur tennis player, $75,000 to turn professional, but that Budge was asking "at least $100,000."
An important loan exhibition of Chinese bronzes, all from American collections, will open with a private view this afternoon in Gallery D 6 at the Metropolitan Museum.

Georgetown University's undefeated football team launched its preparation for the first major test, that against Manhattan College, with Coach Jack Hagerty sending his varsity squad through a two-hour scrimmage against the freshmen.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Oct. 14: Johnson, Lt. Comdr. F. L., Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. about Dec. 20 to the Lang and In command when commissioned. Phleger, Lt. Comdr. C. C.. the West Virginia, to the Maryland as Engineer Officer, about Dec. 9.

Three men were injured and several persons knocked from their feet at 10:15 o'clock last night in the Times Square Subway station when a paper package containing thirty vials of mixed chemicals exploded in the hand of a chemical engineer who was carrying it.

Miss Ruth Caroline Fewsmith, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Livingston Fewsmith of this city and Spring Lake, will be introduced to society on Dec. 27 at a reception to be given here by Mrs. Fewsmith and Mrs. Frederick W. Parker at the home of Mrs. Parker.

An invitation to King George and Queen Elizabeth to include this city in their itinerary during their state visit to Canada and the United States next Spring has been extended by Mayor Henry S. Wheeler. Next year will be Newport's tercentenary.

Karl Johann Kautsky, German Socialist and theorist, died here early this morning, the day after his eighty-fourth birthday. Mr. Kautsky was destitute and in poor health when, with his wife, he arrived from Vienna soon after Austria was united with Germany last March. Four years ago Mr. Kautsky, who was born in Prague, became a naturalized citizen of Czechoslovakia.

LAST NIGHT'S RESULTS First Game (Doubles)-Jose Munagorri and Jose Mugica defeated Angel Iturrino ahd Domingo Ulacia, 20 to 15. Second Game (Doubles)-Alejandro Guisasola and Jose Echeverria, Spain, defeated Kiki Enrique and Epifanio Saenz, Cuba, 20 to 13.

The Green Bay Packers have assumed the lead in the race for scoring honors in the National Football League, according to statistics announced yesterday. The team, with 120 tallies, enjoys a wide margin over the second-place Washington Redskins.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 12: increases for the week of $28,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans;

There must be a friendly relationship between the employer and the employee if industry is to prosper, gyrus S. Ching, director of industrial and public relations of United States Rubber Products, Inc., told a joint meeting of hardware men here tonight.

Reports from the MaehrischOstrau area indicate that the Czech minority is receiving the harshest treatment from the Poles. A general order has been issued to Czechs to leave the occupied district before Nov. 1.

The Dean of Canterbury, Dr. Hewlett Johnson, canceled a projected visit to the United States tonight on advice from sources there that it was ir advisable for a Briton to talk to Americans about Spain at the present time.

Another dawn found us through breakfast and on our way into the tall timber. Despite a shower during the night, the woods are still very noisy, and we had little hope of getting near enough to a deer or bear for a shot.

AMERICAN FAR EASTERN POLICY AND THE SINO-JAPANESE WAR, edited by Miriam S. Farley. (American Council, Institute of Pacific Relations, 50 cents.) A report of seven discussion conferences held under the auspices of the council.

Philip S. Werner, through Grace M.Branham, at 40 Cedar Lane, Yonkers; Victor D. Ziminsky, through Fish Marvin, at 34 Moore Rd., Scarsdale: Frederick S. Firi, through William F. Moles, at 158 Ellsworth Ave., Yonkers; Raymond R. Beatty Organization, agent.

William O'Neil, president of the General Tire and Rubber Company, who returned-yesterday from Europe, where he had been on business for two months, gave the opinion that the United States will need more crude rubber next year than British and Dutch producers are allowing to us this year.
An unqualified New Deal endorsement of William H. J. Ely, Democratio candidate for the United States Senate, was given tonight by Secretary of War Harry H. Woodring.

The Morgan brothers from Texas, T. P. and W. F., saw their horses run one, two in the New Rochelle Handicap as Empire City began its Fall meeting yesterday with a capacity attendance in the clubhouse. It was one of the biggest Fall turnouts in years at the Yonkers course, ascribed in part to the bright, warm weather, but caused also no doubt by the keen field in the main event.
For the first time since the war started, Barcelona this. morning saw a priest, in full vestments, bearing a cross through the streets at the head of a funeral procession.

Architects filed the plans yesterday for a total of forty-six small dwellings in the Flatbush, Sheepshead Bay and Bay Ridge sections of Brooklyn. Manhattan projects were confined to alterations, while Bronx work included six threestory tenements and a private dwelling. In Queens the specifications submitted called for three private residences.

Less than a fortnight after the ratification of the peace of Munich by the Parliaments of France andBritain every nation in the world is building armaments or planning to build armaments on an unprecedented scale.

An attack on Thomas E. Dewey as the "front for the forces of reaction," made last night by Israel Amter, Communist candidate for Representative at large, featured the opening rally of the Communist campaign, held at Mecca Temple.

Trading in wheat futures today was at a low ebb, with the volume of business the smallest in some time. Prices held to a range of less than 1 cent a bushel, with closing quotations the Board of Trade here at net losses of 5/8 to 3/4 cent.

Miss Rose May McCabe heads the committee in charge of the plans for the annual Thanksgiving Eve dance of the alumnae of the College of Our Lady of Good Counsel, which will be held Nov. 23 at Hampshire House.

An unusually bold political murder took place today. A leading Chinese official of the "Reformed" Government, fostered by Japan, was killed in Hongkew, a part of the International Settlement occupied by Japanese.
While business in the United States during August showed a considerable improvement, there was a moderate but less decisive gain in Canada, according to a survey made by the Bank of Nova Scotia.

President Roosevelt said today that he would request adequate funds to extend the Federal civil service system. He sent a message to the Civil Service Assembly of the United States and Canada calling the sys tem the best approach to effeetive Federal administration, ever though it has not been perfect.

Accusing President Roosevelt and the New Deal of "corrupting" liberalism and, "undermining" representative government, former President Herbert Hoover, in an address here tonight, called for the election of "independent-minded" men to Congress "to emancipate the legislative arm of the government from the personal domination of Mr. Roosevelt."

Four pickets hired by the Window Trimmers Union, Local 144, an affiliate of the Committee for Industrial Organization, to picket, the Busch jewelry stores, and the business manager of the local were foun", guilty yesterday by a jury in Supreme Court of criminal contempt of court for violating an injunction issued June 28.
Governor Lehman will go to Hyde Park today to confer with President Roosevelt with regard to the State campaign. It will be the first meeting of the two in- many months.

Eduard Benes, former President of' Czechoslovakia, has accepted an invitation to become a visiting professor at the University of Chicago. It is expected that he will lecture on democratic institutions.
Unusually limited fluctuations again featured trading yesterday on the Cotton Exchange and, despite rapid harvesting of the new crop, the marketing movement failed to depress prices.

Many persons prominent in society will give dinner and supper parties tonight at the formal opening of the Trianon Room of the Ambassador. The occasion will be a benefit for Five Points House, an organization which cares for more than 300 children of destitute families at Pomona, in Rockland County, and in boarding homes in the suburbs of New York.
The site of the cell of the famous "Hermit of Westminster," credited with an important role in the history of the early Tudor kings, was believed discovered today in Westminster Abbey.

Commonwealth Edison Company first mortgage gold bonds, 4 1/2 per cent, series C due in 1956 and series D due in 1957, which were suspended from dealings on Sept. 2, when called for redemption, have been stricken from listing and registration on the Stock Exchange.

The Italian Government today notified the French Foreign Office of its approval of the appointment of Andre Francois Poncet as Ambassador accredited to the King of Italy and Emperor of Ethiopia. M. Frangois-Poncet will leave for Rome early in November.

A farewell benefit dinner in honor of the Duchess of Atholl, member of the British-Parliament and wife of the premier Earl of Scotland, who is sailing for England tomorrow after a brief visit in America, was held at the Hotel Pierre last night.
Mrs. Elizabeth Jarvis Wyeth Gilbert, wife of Cass Gilbert Jr., architect, of Greenwich, Conn., died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital, after a brief illness, in her fortyfirst year.

Harry Eliot Robinson of 63 Cambridge Place, Brooklyn, since 1910 a partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of E. C. Benedict Co., died on Sunday at his country.home in Setauket, L. I., after a brief illness, at the age of 68. He was executor of Commodore Benedict's estate.

The Germanpocket battleship Ieutschland left this morning for Cadiz, Spain, after a short visit. The British battle-cruiser Hood left this morning for visits to Barcelona and Valencia, Spain, and Palma, Majorca.

When Benny Friedman issued the call for candidates at 0. C. N. Y. early last month, exactly twentysix gridiron -minded young men heard and responded. Benny must have found such privacy somewhat disconcerting, for when he was at Michigan any time less than 300 came out for the freshman squad the coaches felt slighted and perhans a little worried.

Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, announced yesterday that sales billed in the first nine months of this year amounted to $192,501,173, compared with $260,773,533 during the correspending 1937 period, a decrease of 26 per cent.

Some idea of the atmosphere prevailing in official circles as well as in party camps and unofficial quarters since the European crisis was offered today in the fact that the French Government was obliged to issue flat denials of four news items of the day.

Governor Lehman's boast of a balanced budget was based on "a nice job of window dressing," Frederic H. Bontecou, Republican candidate for Lieutenant Governor, told 400 persons at a rally tonight in the high school here.

Prices of wheat futures drifted lower today wi h speculative interest at a minimum. The purchase of about 500,000 bushels of futures attributed to removing hedges against sales to the Federal Surplus Commodity Corporation featured trading.
John Thompson 'and Andrew Anderson Thompson, coal operators and the last surviving children of the late J. V, Thompson, owner of large coal properties, died today within a few hours of each other.

Mayor La Guardia will make several radio speeches in support of the candidacy of Magistrate Anna Moskowitz Kross for the Supreme Court,- it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Kross's headquarters. Tne dates will be announced as soon as arrangements for radio time are completed.

The Wisconsin Electric Power Company of the North American System prepared today for the flotation of $55,000,000 of 3% per cent first-mortgage bonds due on Oct. 1, 1968, by filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to its registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering issuance of the bonds.

Announcement was made here last night of the death on Saturday at his home in Los Angeles of Montgomery Blair Wailes, chairman of the board and former president of the Edward Thompson Company, law-book publishers, of 141 Willoughby Street, Brooklyn.

A major Police Department scandal flared wide open in Brooklyn last night when Police Commissioner Valentine, with other high officials and a score of laboratory technicians, descended unexpectedly on the Bergen Street station, where six arrest books containing all the data on 7,200 prisoners had been slit from their bindings and stolen.

Poland stepped prominently into the picture of Czechoslovak dismemberment yesterday. It was revealed that Foreign Minister Beck would see King Carol of Rumania today and try to enlist his support of Warsaw's plan to give Ruthenia to Hungary and thus form a common Polish-Hungarian frontier.

To bolster Spanish Insurgent ranks,weakened by the withdrawal of thousands of Italian legionaires, the Burgos government has lowered its standard for recruits, Insurgent dispatches reaching the frontier said tonight.

The World's Fair and the new Queens subway line continue to foster a vast amount of realty activity and construction work in the Forest Hills area. With at least ten apartment buildings recently completed or under construction there, plans were announced yesterday- for new groups of multi-family houses and along with them two or three new rows of stores. The center of this added

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Cleveland Lyon of this village of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Phyllis Lyon, to Maurice L. Cotton Jr. of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cotton of Altus, Okla.

A burst of strength yesterday in the Stock Market, inspired by the General Motors Corporation's announcement late in the trading session that it plans to re-employ 35,000 men and restore salary reductions of lower paid employes, sent share prices up 1 to 3 points on the day, and pushed the motor issues into new high ground for 1938. While the rally had been

The Missing Persons Bureau at police headquarters became a nursery for more than two hours yesterday afternoon when a woman seeking the whereabouts of her husband disappeared herself and left four pretty little girls ranging in age from 2 months to 5 years virtually in the laps of the police.

The average New Yorker, if there were such a person, would spend about three days a year in a hospital. The chances are about three to one that he will spend them in a public hospital, supported mainly out of tax funds.

The proposal of Secretary Wallace for a two-price system under which agricultural surpluses would be marketed in this country to people of low income at prices below the regular market has been put forward merely as a suggestion and is open to discussion, according to a letter sent members of the National Food and Grocery Conference Committee by the Department of Agriculture.

The heavy tax burden, "the nation's No. 1 problem," is pushing business overhead so high that the consumer may revolt at the high prices to such an extent that new and cheaper forms of distribution may, crop up to take the place of those now in use. This was the warning

John E. Hughes's Orchids Next, heavily campaigned daughter, of Time Maker, jolted -the talent. in winning her third purse of the year in the Bolivar Purse, today's feature race; Opposed by eleven other juvenile fillies, some eligible for the Selima Stakes on Saturday, Orchids Next drove to a length verdict over W. F. Hitt's Sun Girl.

Mrs. Mathilda Leister Heather, co-proprietor- with her husband of the Clearview Hotel at Center Moriches, L. I., which was destroyed by the recent hurricane, died yesterday at the New York Post-Graduate Hospital after a month's illness.
Four Harvard University freshmen today were convicted of disturbing an American Legion parade and were fined $5 each by District Judge Arthur P. Stone.

Rumors that the Bulldog was on his last legs have been, it appears, grossly exaggerated. A visit to New Haven today found the old fellow in fine fettle and rarin' to tear out at the Wolverine here Saturday.

William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has been chosen to receive the 1938 award of the National Association of Accredited Publicity Directors, it was announced yesterday. The award will be presented at the annual dinner of the association at the Lotos Club on Nov. 21.

The Bible must be regarded in "a new view," stressing spiritual qualities, if it is to be reinstated as the core of English-speaking culture, the Very Rev. Walter Robert Matthews, dean of St. Paul's Cathedral, London, declared yesterday at a special convocation in the Low Memorial Library of Columbia University, marking the 400th anniversary of the English Bible.

The bulk of the Manhattan realty activity announced by brokers yesterday centered in properties on the West Side. Several industrial properties in midtown, and apartment buildings in Harlem and Washington Heights were involved.

Captain Daddario, using a special harness for his dislocated shoulder, was in the Wesleyan line-up for practice today. It was his first appearance since the Connecticut State game, when he was injured.

Representative and Mrs. E. Harold Cluett of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Bywater Cluett, to the Rev. Nelson M. Burroughs, rector of St. John's Episcopal Church here.

Fifty versions of the essential wardrobe featuring the coney coat were presented yesterday at a style show held by the National Coney Institute at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. More than 150 resident buyers, retail executives and fashion authorities attended the show, designed as the opening gun in a campaign to make retailers and consumers "coney conscious."

Mr. and Mrs. H. Lester Cuddihy will give a dinner dance on Dec. 23 at Sherry's to introduce their daughter, Miss Mary Jane Cuddihy. The debutante will be presented to older friends of the family at an afternoon reception to be given by her parents on Thanksgiving Day at their home, 24 East Seventythird Street.

By Nov. 1 Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers Union, must purge his staff of the "Lovestone" Communists and of others who have incurred the enmity of the union's executive board, it was reported today.

Patrolman' Arthur Pedersen at practice on the police pistol range in the basement-of the Fourteenth Regiment Armory, Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street, Brooklyn, accidentally shot and killed Patrolman Martin A. Hanke, the pistol instructor, shortly before noon, yesterda.

The announcement that the General Motors Corporation would add about 35,000 additional workers during the next two weeks means that if 85 per cent of this number is employed for an entire year at a fortyhour week, payroll costs will rise $47,500,000 on an annual basis.

Harvard's football players were in far better physical condition today than they were a week ago, but Coach Dick Harlow will continue last week's policy of withholding his regulars from contact work right through to the game with Dartmouth here Saturday.

John Totaro, dealing under the trade name of the Venango Oil Company at 150 Broadway here, paid a $50 fine this morning after he pleaded guilty to a charge of violating the section of the recently enacted Motor Fuel Act which forbids the sale of gasoline under the posted price. The fine was imposed
Three more auditors for the State Insurance Fund, including the alleged "ringleader" who was accused of extorting "tens of thousands of dollars" from employers, were arrested yesterday.

Striking while the iron is hot, Germany today extended to Poland a commercial credit of 120,000,000 zlotys (roughly 60,000,000 marks) for intensified Polish industrialization with German equipment and machinery:

Sister Gabriel of All Saints, who had been associated with the Home of the Little Sisters of the Pobr in this city since 1895, and was one of the group that organized the Bronx branch in 1903, died yesterday in the home at 660 East 183d Street after an illness of ten days.

The government, which is conducting an "anti-monopoly" investigation, announced through the Department of Justice tonight that it would intervene in an important patent case to be argued before the Supreme Court tomorrow.

The warfare in Palestine will overshadow all other present and future problems when Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain meets his Cabinet tomorrow for the first time since the Munich agreement was signed.

A campaign, which is expected to start a competitive battle between electric ranges and the new "CP" gas ranges and which will be followed locally in other sections of the country, has been launched in newspapers by the Electric Institute of Washington, D. C.
The Rev. Mother Louise Tedrini, superior of Our Mother of Sorrows Institute at Blue Island, a suburb, and founder in this country of the Mantellate Sisters, died yesterday.

Organization of the Paramount Fire Insurance Company was announced today. Owen M. Murray of Dallas, Texas is expected to be president. W. Eugene Harrington, former president of the National Association of Insurance Agents, will be a director.

The last railroad grade-crossing on the Sunrise Highway was eliminated this morning when trains on the Long Beach division of the Long Island Railroad were routed over the new overhead trackbed which spans the highway in this village.

Cuba's candidates for international jumping honors at the national horse show in Madison Square Garden Nov. 5 to 12 debarked yesterday from the S. S. Orizaba of the New York Cuba Line and prepared to start their training for the numerous competitions in which they have been entered.
The Bureau of Internal Revenue ruled today upon the question of who employs radio artists for purposes of the Social Security Act, drawing distinctions between three types of such employment.
Expanding businesses s in need of additional space to care for their increased activities accounted for a number of the commercial rentals announced yesterday.

Determined to place Columbia's football team back in the winning column, Coach Lou Little drove the varsity through a whirlwind review of its passing attack in a dummy scrimmage against a "Pennsylvania" team of reserves yesterday at Baker Field. At the same time on a
When pressed and pinned down to a yes-or-no answer, Steve Owen, the portly and genial coach of the football Giants, will break down and confess that he thinks highly of his current crop of athletes.

City officials took the first step yesterday toward selling the grimy old Criminal Courts Building and the Tombs in the blocks just north of the Civic Center in FoleySquare. A sign announcing the forthcoming sale of - tee land and buildings was placed on the buildings yesterday. The court building site

In his fireside radio address of June 24 the President made these remarks, palpably directed to the boss of Hudson County, New Jersey: And I am concerned about the attitude of a candidate or his sponsors with respect to the rights of American citizens to assemble peaceably and to express publicly their views and opinions on important social and economic issues.

Administration hopes for an early blanket endorsement of the New Deal by Governor Lehman went unanswered today when the Democratic Gubernatorial candidate emerged from a two-hour conference with President Roosevelt and said in effect that he would cross that political bridge when he came to it.

Steel ingot output increased last week, countering a downward seasonal trend, and the adjusted index rose to 73.5, its highest point since the end of last October. This compared with 67.1 for the preceding week, and 90.1 for the week ended Oct. 16, 1937.

State newspaper editors sought today legislative protection of the sources of stories published in their papers. Prepared under the direction of a committee of the State Society of Newspaper Editors, the "News Confidence" Bill will be introduced in the Legislature this Winter.

A big effort is being made to stir up anti-Jewish feeling in these regions. German propaganda is popularly held responsible for much of this activity aiming to graft the sprout of anti-Semitism on to the tree of Alsatian regionalism, but it is also being aided and abetted by such purely French political groups as Jacques Doriot's Parti Populaire and kindred organizations.
The Rev. Dr. Lee E. Rife, for twentyfive years pastor of the Norris Square United Presbyterian Church, died of heart disease last night in his home here. He was 60 years old. Born at Clifton, Ohio,
George H. Norton of Berwyn, president of George H. Norton Co., Inc., a Chicago investment house, died last night in the Berwyn Hospital after a long illness. He was 67 years old.
Ecclesiastical circles expect Cardinal Innitzer to go to the Vatican soon to report on Catholic Church difficulties in Austria.

Investigation of a government payroll racket reportedly involving Puerto Rican Senate officials today progressed so far that Assistant Attorney General Enrique Campos del Toro took a plane for Washington to seek Federal aid following a conference with United States District Attorney A. Cecil Snvder.
The appointment of Raymond Harris, George H. Jamison and J. Donald Whelehan as Deputy State Superintendents of Insurance has been announced by Louis H. Pink.

The belief that the ideas of self-containment, with attendant embargoes and exchange restrictions on the part of Russia, Germany and Italy, are not insurmountable obstacles to the efforts of Great Britain, France and the United States to remove barriers to world trade was expressed by Paul van Zeeland, former Belgian Premier, lecturing at Cambridge University today.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary will sail this afternoon for Cherbourg and Southampton. Her passenger list includes the Duchess of Atholl, Sir Harold Harmsworth, British newspaper proprietor; the Hon. Geoffrey

The Securities and Exchange Commission [announced today that Howard H. Tracy of Elmira, N. Y., had withdrawn his registration as an overthe-counter broker or dealer and that the proceedings instituted on June 14 to determine whether his registration should be revoked or suspended have been dismissed.

A $30,000 first mortgage loan at 5 per cent for five years on the recently completed 1-story business building at 77-81 Central Ave. White Plains, Westchester, has been arranged for the Parkway West Corn, Irving J. Bland, president. Nehring Bros, Inc, were the brokers.
Thomas Mann's "Buddenbrooks," the novel of the German burgher family which first brought its author international fame, will be issued in a new one-volume edition by Knopf on Oct. 24. Published
ONE of the choruses in the classic "Ruddigore" goes like this: A moderate livelihood we're gaining, In fact we rule, A National School, The duties are dull, but I'm not complaining.

A series of illustrated music talks by Olin Downes, sponsored by the music committee of the New York Junior League, will be given this season at the league clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street. The series will begin on Oct. 26, with Giovanni Martinelli of the Metropolitan Opera as guest artist.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York adopted a report at its stated meeting last night urging the electorate to defeat the proposed judiciary article, Amendment 5, as adopted by this year's Constitutional Convention for action by the voters on Nov. 8. The report was submitted by Paul Windels, chairman of the committee on constitutional conventions.

Policies of retailers who buy overcautiously on boys' wear lines were attacked as "vicious and weak" last night by Arthur Price, vice president of the National Grape Products Corporation and former general manager of the Hearn Department Stores, Inc., in an address before a meeting of the Boys Apparel Buyers Association at the Hotel St. Moritz.

Steve Bahun, 46 years old, who -was serving twenty-five to thirty years for murder in the New Jersey State prison here, committed suicide this morning by diving from his fourthtier cell block to the concrete floor thirty feet below, according to prison authorities. Principal Keeper

In a ceremony at the United States Embassy today the honorary title of Citizen of Saint-Die was conferred on General John J. Pershing by a delegation representing that town in the Vosges Mountains, where American troops were stationed in 1918.

Miss Carol Whitney Van Etten, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Rutan Van Etten of this city, was married to Dr. Albert P. D'Errico of Dallas, Texas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph D'Errico of Cleveland, yesterday afternoon in the Central Presbyterian Church.
The Italian loan of $1,050,000 in 5 per cent bonds incorporated in Ecuador's national debt in 1937 has been reduced to $840,000, according to a report by the Minister of Finance.

The "boom, days" of the predepression era were recalled at the Board of Education yesterday when examinations for teaching licenses in nearly 150 subjects-a record number-were announced for this Fall by Dr. Louis Marks, chairman of the board of examiners.

Mrs. Opal S. Hill, internationally known golfer, announced today in a telegram to The Kansas City Star that she has decided to become a "business-woman" professional. She said she had accepted a position on the promotion staff of a sporting goods company.

The whole blockfront on the east side of Washington Street between Gansevoort and Little West Twelfth Streets was bought in at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms by The Guaranty Trust Company of New York, as plaintiff, on a bid of $200,000.

The International Master Ladies Hairdressers Association and the Coiffure Guild of New York, which are strenuously fostering the upswing hair style, adopted yesterday a joint resolution criticizing Greta Garbo for- wearing her hair not only down but straight.

Hunters were barred today from four counties in the Catskill Mountain region by Governor Lehman because of the continued critical forest fire hazard. In an amendment to his proclamation closing fourteen counties in the Adirondack forest preserve to hunters the Governor included Delaware, Greene, Sullivan and Ulster Counties.

Prices of the rank and file of slaughter cattle declined 25 cents today, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Prime weighty steers, however, remained steady, with the top at $13.50. Hogs again were weak to a shade lower but were more active. Lambs strengthened in a fairly active trade.

Laurence J. Harwood Jr., a government witness who testified last Monday that he had sold his interest in the Fulton-Harwood.Brass Works at a "gift price," admitted yesterday before Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey, who is presiding at trial of a suit to enjoin the Aluminum Company of America from violating the Anti-Trust Law, that the witness had received $25,000 in cash for his share in the company, plus $1,000,000 in stock.

The New Jersey Court of Errors and Appeals took under advisement today an appeal by trustees of the estate of George H. Hartford of Orange, N. J., founder of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, from a decision of the State Supreme Court holding that the transfer of stock to his children in 1915- was subject to inheritance tax.

Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark's Mahdi, 4-year-old son of Dis Done who had been chasing topnotchers all season, dropped down a peg or two at Empire City yesterday and easily captured a five and three-quarterfurlong sprint. Under a hustling

A series of Autumn outings in the interests of the work of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association will begin today with a visit to Planting Fields, the country estate of Mr.. and Mrs. William Robertson Coe at Oyster Bay, L. I. Subscribers to the outing will have the privilege of admission to the Piping Rock Club in Locust Valley, where tea will be served. The outing will be repeated
John Randolph Hearst, son of the publisher, has leased an apartment in 30 Sutton Place through Hickernell-Romeyn, Inc., brokers.

For the first time in Latin America, it is believed, a major political party is headed by a woman in Puerto Rico. She is Senora Maria Prez de Almiroty, the island's only woman Senator and vice president of the Liberal party.
The announcement of a federation of American Jews to fight fascism and Nazism was commented upon in the Italian press today in tones ranging from the serious to the facetious.

G. Harvey Porter has resigned as managing director of the Oil Burner Institute, effective Oct. 31, he announced yesterday. Mr. Porter, who is executive vice president of The Industrial Corporation, Baltimore, industrial financing and management organization, held the post for the last three years. No successor has been named.

At a meeting of the board yesterday directors of the American I. G. Chemical Corporation declared a dividend of $2 a share to holders of the common A stock and 20 cents a share to common B stockholders. Both are payable Nov. 7 to stock of record Oct. 31.

The "typical American family," the Glenn Craigs of Muncie, Ind., were scheduled to be the center of attraction yesterday at the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt, but when the introductions were over only a few minutes were left to probe into the life of this average family.

The stock market here staged a late rally today under the lead of the gilt-edge issues after a dull and quiet morning. The gilt-edge group more than recovered its early losses and foreign bonds were firm on the whole, Czechoslovak issues being an exception.
A nine-game football schedule for 1939 was announced by the University of Pittsburgh today in a step toward the eight-game programs it plans to have in the future.
The State Department of Audit and Control opened today an advertising campaign designed to locate the owners of more than $3,000,000 in unclaimed bank deposits throughout the State.

New Jersey in this campaign offers the best illustration of that political marriage of convenience which the New Deal, despite its loftiest utterances to the contrary, is as willing to make as Tammany ever was.

The condition of President Kemal Ataturk, who is gravely ill with cirrhosis of the liver at Dolma Baghche Palace here, took a turn for the worse today. An encouraging bulletin issued in the morning said he had had a better night and there was no change in his condition, but a bulletin at night reported a sharp jump in his temperature to 1004 from 97.2 in the morning.

In Brooklyn, where the legal atmosphere has just been surcharged by the appointment of a special prosecutor to supersede the District Attorney, a young policeman-lawyer from Manhattan came to grips yesterday with Magistrate Sylvester Sabbatino when he appeared officially in pinball gambling cases, with a variety of issues.

If a wind can we whistled up, Captain Ben Pine's challenger, the schooner Gertrude L. Thebaud, and Captain Angus Walters's Bluenose, the big Canadian defender of the International Fishermen's Trophy, will resume their contest for the sailing championship of the North Atlantic off this port at 9:05 A. M. tomorrow.

In a broadcast message addressed to the National Eucharistic Congress at New Orleans, Pope Plus XI voiced today his fear and anxiety concerning the situation of the world, expressing his particular distress at the contempt in which some held the precepts of the Gospel and the way in which they outraged the Eternal Majesty of God.

" Goodness, How Sad," by Robert Morley, a play about actors and actresses by an actor-dramatist, opened at the Vaudeville Theatre tonight. The scene is set in a provincial town's theatrical lodgings peopled by struggling young repertory actors, a sentimental film star revisiting his old haunts and a tender-hearted trainer of seals.

The Court of Appeals decided. unanimously today that John Cashmore was legally elected vice chairman of the City Council of New York City on Jan. 3, and that he is entitled to serve a full two-year term.
Carroll Thayer, building contractor and former burgess, died in his home here today after a year's illness. He was 76 years old.

Vigorous objections were lodged today with the Interstate Commerce Commission by the Southern Railway, the Louisville Nashville Railroad and Southern trade and civic groups to a report by Milo H. Brinkley, an examiner for the commission, proposing that the Southern and Louisville Nashville be deprived of their present control of the Chicago, Indianapolis Louisville Railway, known as the Monon.

John Sullivan, alleged to be the operator of a watchmen's service "racket" in Wallabout Market. Brooklyn, for twenty-seven years, and which was said to be sufficiently lucrative to move the Federal Government to prosecute him for income tax evasion, was arrested in the market last night on charges of violating the State insurance and private detective laws.

The National Hockey League race will start earlier than ever this year. The regular campaign opens on Nov. 3, but New York fans will not have the opportunity of watching one of their teams in action until ten days later, when the Americans open their home stand in Madison Square Garden against the Boston Bruins.
Two noted musicians returned from Europe yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary to make concert tours during the coming season.

During the so-called Dark Ages of the past, the lamps of civilization were kept alight in a few scattered schools and monasteries, which became the last refuge of scholars and thinkers in a world given over to warring tribes.

Among the projects for which plans were filed yesterday were two more units of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's housing development in the Bronx, sixty small dwellings in Queens and twenty-four in Brooklyn, while in Manhattan specifications for a number of alteration jobs were submitted.
Japanese troops entered Sheklung, only thirty-five miles east of Canton today, after stiff Chinese resistance, it was reliably reported. Japanese commanders are confident they soon'will enter Canton.

The National Biscuit Company reported yesterday a net profit of $3,662,311 for the quarter ended on Sept. 30, after deductions for taxes and charges. After dividend requirements on the preferred stock the profit was equivalent to 51 cents a share on 6,289,448 common shares. In the three months

Donald Budge, the world's leading amateur tennis player, admitted today $25,000 was all that was keeping him out of the professionalranks. Budge said he had been offered $75,000 for a one-year tour, but wants at least $100,000. The offer was made by Jack Harris, Chicago sports Promoter.

Air-mail compensation for Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., over Route 2, from Newark to Los Angeles, one of the most important air routes in the country, should be increased to 30 cents a mile for a base mileage of 600,000 miles a month, C. Edward Leasure and R. J. Bartoo, examiners, recommended to the Interstate Commerce Commission today.

The Ambassadors of two major powers motored up from Obersalzberg today to present their letters of recall to Chancellor Adolf Hitler. The better known of the two envoys, Andre Franqois-Poncet, is leaving his Berlin post to become France's envoy to Rome.

In keeping with the recent. regulations adopted by the State Department of Education, school sports are now to become a reglar part of the New York City high school curriculum, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, disclosed yesterday.

Shipments of gold estimated at more than $34,000,000 reached here yesterday from Europe. About $24,500,000 came in on the Queen Mary and about $10,000,000 on the American Farmer. All the gold on the American Farmer, which came from England, and about $15,250,000 from France on the Queen Mary was consigned to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York as official shipments from foreign stabilization funds.

No kosher kill in local markets yesterday because of Jewish holiday, ninth day of Succoth. Trading on transfer meats was slow; pork loin prices barely steady to $1 lower; Boston butts, spare ribs and pork trimmings lower. other pork cuts and other classes about steady. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Although a fairly large number of wholesale buyers were in the dry goods market yesterday, there was little more than scattered trading in most staple goods and selling agents were convinced that purchasing of Spring lines will be fully as slow as the Fall buying has been.
The up-State campaign in the Governorship race gets under way today as both Governor Lehman and Thomas E. Dewey, the Republican nominee, leave Grand Central on the Empire State Express at 8:50 A. M.

Edward Wentworth Haskins, vice president and secretary of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company of America, died of a stroke today in his home here at the age of 72. He had been ill since an earlier stroke eighteen months ago.

Miss Evelyn Norma Purcell of this city, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Marcus Purcell, was married yesterday morning to Judge' Samuel Jordan Graham of Washington, D. C., onetime Assistant Attorney General of the United States, in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church.

The Emile Branchard memo?? exhibition at the Marie Harrima Gallery, 61 East Fifty-sevent' Street, seems thoroughly represent active. The canvases are not datein the catalogue, but we know tha Mr. Branchard, who died hasFebruary, did not take up painti? until 1912-"by chance" then, an? "for his own pleasure."

Police Chief Timothy Leahy of Cambridge today granted a request for a permit to drive an automobile into the Harvard Stadium for the Princeton football game on Oct. 29 so that an aged Connecticut grandmother with an artificial leg might see her grandson perform on the stadium turf.

Edoardo Sacerdote, teacher, composer and conductor, died today of pneumonia. His age was 55. Mr. Sacerdote came here three years ago from Chicago, where he taught singing for twenty years and conducted for the Chicago Opera Company. He was Nellie

James Frederick Chance, historian, died today at the age of 82. Although he became a partner in his family's glassmaking firm of Chance Brothers, he soon retired to devote himself to writing on historical subjects.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,271,600 barrels, compared with 3,249,350 in the previous week, an increase of 22,250, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was less by 95,
The Duchess of Atholl, who will sail today on the Queen Mary, was the guest of honor at a dinner given for her last evening by Dr. and Mrs. Nicholas Murray Butler at their home, 60 Morningside Drive.
The twelve-story and office building at 15-17 West Forty-fourth Street has been sold by the Excelsior Savings Bank to the Paragon Funding Corporation, of which William S. Sussman is president.
Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, praised, today, New Jersey's State te scholarship plan and emphasized L the "educational philosophy" of the institution in his annual report.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, arriving yesterday with 1,602 passengers, docked at the foot of West Fiftieth Street in thirty-four minutes without the aid of tugs. The only craft that took part in the docking was the small rowboat which usually runs the lines from the ships to the piers.

Indications tonight were that Young Bussey, 20-year-old star halfback dismissed from Louisiana State's football squad, intended to remain at the university and continue his study of petroleum engineering.

Two members of the State Law Department's "Racket Bureau" will handle election complaints' in this- Democratic county this year instead of the thirty special deputy, assistants" usually designated by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr.

The Nassau County grand jury declined today to indict Harry C. Johnson, 65-year-old retired gasoline distributor of Hewlett, L. I., who, on Oct. 1, killed his wife, to whom he had been married thirty-nine years, to end her suffering from a stomach cancer.

An overcrowded meeting of the Kings County Medical Society broke up shortly after 1 o'clock this morning in an uproar over medical insurance, with the president of the society, Dr. John B. D'Albora, shouting from the platform that he would like to meet some of his floor critics "face to face."

Committee members planning for the theatre benefit to be given Nov. 9 under the auspices of the Protestant Big Sisters will meet tomorrow afternoon at the home of the vice president, Mrs. John G. Kilbreth, at 156 East Seventy-ninth Street. The performance of "Yankee

George H. Bucher, president of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, announced yesterday that, for the first time since the Westinghouse wage-andsalary plan was begun more than two years ago, the company's earnings had been insufficient to. provide employes extra compensation for the current month in addition to their regular wages or salaries.
The New Jersey Supreme Court held constitutional today a law enacted by the Legislature in 1934 prohibiting dentists from advertising prices and the character of their services.

Delegates of the six countries competing in the Pan-American boxing championships, which start tomorrow-the United States, Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Peru and Uruguaymet last night and decided to run the tournament in twelve series of ten bouts each. The tournament is to be completedly Nov. 11.

The lives of fifty-five to eighty of every 100 sufferers from meningitis caused by a streptococcus are now saved by the addition of the drug sulfanilamide to the standard surgical treatment of this disease, which as late as three years ago killed nearly all its victims, it was reported here yesterday before the annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Miss Bertha Herrick of Albany, daughter of the late Supreme Court Justice D.-Cady Herrick, nominee for Governor of New York in 1904, died tonight in Albany Hospital from injuries suffered in an automobile accident that occurred just outside the city.

Was Plato the first Fascist? Professor Shatkin of the Moscow Electrical Institute makes the electrifying announcement that Plato was not only the Father and Founder of Fascism but, what is even worse in Russia, a Menshevist, and, in all probability, a Trotskyite Bukharinist.

An additional reduction of $2 a ton on automobile steel sheets was confirmed yesterday, making the total cut $6 a ton under the published price. Hot-rolled sheets are now selling at $1.95 per hundred/pounds at Detroit, and cold-rolled sheets at $3, or reductions of $13 a ton since mid-June.

The sale of $25,000 of Missouri Pacific Railroad first and refunding 5 per cent bonds by the American Alliance Insurance Corporation has been reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission by the committee of savings banks and insurance companies which invested in these securities.

The two-family dwelling at 375 Union Street, Jersey City, N. J., was sold by David J., Thomas J. and Marjorie Roberts to Patrick A. Pandolfo, who will occupy one of the apartments. J. I. Kislak, Inc., brokers, negotiated the sale.

The State Supreme Court held today that neither Federal nor State constitutional rights were violated when a permit to speak at an open-air meeting in Jersey City was denied to Norman Thomas, Socialist party leader.

Sir Edmund Wyldbore-Smith, director of the Suez Canal and many other companies, former diplomat and director of the International Commission to Purchase Supplies for the Allies from 1914 to 1919, died today in his home in Stoke D'Abernon, Surrey. He was 61 years old.

China's official and private traffic is now, reported to be moving over the Chungking-Kunming highway be tween Szechuen and Indo-China, the length of the road being about 585 miles, according to the weekly, summary of reports of develops ments affecting business, received by radio and cable by the Depart. ment of Commerce.

A further sharp widening of the discount of contracts for the current months under near months featured trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. Mill price-fixing held near-by positions relatively steady, while spot interests continued to transfer hedges forward. Final quotations ranged from points higher to 11 points lower on the day.

Fourteen college basketball double-headers, two more than last year, have been arranged for Madison Square Garden for the forthcoming court campaign, it was announced yesterday by Director Ned Irish. Since 162,000 persons witnessed the games last season, Irish is certain that a new attendance record will be set.

A pre-theatre dinner party was given last night in the Caprice Room of the Weylin at its opening for the Autumn and Winter. The entertainment was arranged by committee members under whose auspices the preview performance of "Knickerbocker Holiday" was given later in the evening at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre as a benefit for the Westchester County Children's Association.
Roy L. Williams, newspaper cartoonist, died last night in his apartment at the Cornell Club. He was 64 years old.
The Court of Appeals today reaffirmed its decisions upholding the validity of the Civil Practice Act which limits deficiency judgments on bonds securing mortgages.

In devoting her Town Hall recital last night to songs of Hugo Wolf, Lotte Lehmann has put us gratefully into her debt. Previous performances have long since indicated her sympathy with Wolf's music, but a complete program revealed to the full the richness and scope of that sympathy:

The Rev. Edward Lodge Curran, president of the International Catholic Truth Society, gave his unqualified endorsement yesterday; to the candidacy of Charles Poletti for Lieutenant Governor on the Democratic ticket.

The "brains" and guiding spirit of the Arab "holy rebels" in Palestine, Haj Amin el Husseini, Mufti of Jerusalem, is standing pat on six "minimum" demands which he declares must be fulfilled by Great Britain before he will order his followers to stop fighting.

Ferdinand L. Smithe, head of the F. L. Smithe Machinery Company, 633 West Forty-fourth Street, died yesterday at his residence, 211 Central Park West, in his sixty-ninth year. His firm is one of the largest

Tonight's events: James Friskin, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30 o'clock; lecture-recital, Motet Singers and Marcia Davenport, Town Hall, 5:30; Budapest String Quartet, Y. M. H. A., Ninety-second Street and Lexington Avenue, 9; lecture-recital, Bernard Gabriel, Sherman Square Studios, 8:15; Perole String Quartet, New York University, 8:30.

Movement for the extension of a $1,500 annual salary limit for ministers of smaller Presbyterian churches to other States, as well as New York, is under way, New York State Synod delegates were told at their fifty-sixth annual convention in the First Church here today by the Rev. Howard V. Yergin of New York City, synodical executive.

Secret agents who boasted of connections in high official places in the Third Reich stalked yesterday through Guenther Gustav Rumrich's account of his own bungling espionage efforts as the United States Army deserter and unsuccessful dishwasher continued his testimony against three erstwhile co-defendants charged with pilfering American defense secrets and selling them to Germany.

A number of apartment houses in the Bronx were reported yesterday by brokers as having been sold. Among them was the multi-family dwelling at 1,144 Nelson Avenue, containing forty-five apartments, which was sold by the Townsend

W. Randolph Burgess, recently elected vice chairman of the National City Bank after serving nineteen years as an executive of the Federal Reserve Bank, will be chief guest and principal speaker at the second dinner meeting of the recently organized New York Financial Writers Association.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., head one of the largest groups ever organized to distribute an Issue of corporate bonds in the public offering today of a new issue of $80,000,000 of Publio Service Company of Northern Illinois first mortgage 3% per cent bonds, due in 1968.

Speed boat pilots, owners and officials of two classes met at the Hotel Lexington last night and laid plans for a greater regatta season in 1939. Tonight the Gold Cup division will assemble its contest board for tomorrow's annual election of officers of the American Power Boat Association.

Charles J. Margiotti, former State Attorney General, presented tonight to a House investigating committee what he termed "documentary evidence" purporting to show that an Albert M. Greenfield Company lent $50,000 to both Governor Earle and Senator Guffey.

Cochenour Williams Gold Mines, Ltd., Toronto, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 1,000,000 shares of $1 par value common stock to be offered at 50 cents a share.
Even though he holds a Georgetown degree, Herb Kopf, Jasper head coach,- has no qualms about the prospect of his Manhattan team defeating the Hoyas on Saturday in the game at the Yankee Stadium.

A new anti-aircraft gun of the same general type as that used so successfully by the Germans in Spain was demonstrated here today as the army's "sky gunners," assembled from all anti-aircraft stations east of the Rockies, fired their final target practice.

Brown's varsity eleven resumed practice today after resting yesterday, confining itself to a short signal drill and a turn at looking over the Rhode Island State College offense as demonstrated by reserves. The varsity closed its work a half hour ahead of the remainder of the squad.
Al Reid, 127 1/2 pounds, Bronx, and Joey Fontana, 130 1/2, Bensonhurst, fought eight hard rounds to a draw in the main bout at the. Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night before a capacity crowd.

Pennant or no pennant, piloting the Pirates appeared a steady job today as Manager Harold Joseph (Pie) Traynor signed for his fifth full season, at an increase in salary. The quiet, likable Traynor has lasted longer than any of his predecessors since Fred Clarke finished a sixteen-year reign in 1915.

Herbert Orrin (Fritz) Crisler is heading back East this week to the Yale Bowl. Accompanying him -on the trip is the strongest Michigan team since 1933, when the Wolverines won. the. Western .Conference championship for the fourth successive time.

The Republican caravan came into Oneida and Madison Counties, in the heart of the State's rich farm lands, today. Its members, Frederic Bontecou, candidate for Lieutenant Governor; Arthur V. McDermott, candidate for Controller; Edward

Walter H. Johnson Jr., vice president of the Marine Midland Trust Company of New York, has purchased an old farmhouse and five acres in the Yale Farms property near Greenwich, Conn., consisting of about 1,400 acres bequeathed by the late John W. Sterling to Yale University.

A memorial to Adolph S. Ochs, publisher of The Chattanooga Times and THE NEW YORK TIMES, will be erected on the point of Lookout Mountain within nine months, Z. C. Patten announced today on behalf of a group of Chattanooga citizens.

Cornell's football forces, in good spirits again after being chastened by the Syracuse defeat, spent much of today's practice session on defense against Penn State plays, then worked on their own offense, closing the session with sprints.

" Knickerbocker Holiday," the musical comedy by Maxwell Anderson-it marks Mr. A's first attempt in that field-and Kurt Weill, opens tonight at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre as the Playwrights Company's second offering of the season. Walter Huston
With a seriousness and a drive that were impressive, Dartmouth settled down to heavy work today for the game on Saturday at Cambridge.
Captain Alex Papana of the Rumanian Air Force abandoned his flight to Bucharest today following an accident to his plane, the third of a series of misfortunes. The aviator, and his

There were brilliant performances last night in Carnegie Hall by the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conductor. Mr. Ormandy develops. His performances were not even, interpretively speaking, and in places they were superficial.
Maxie Berger, 139 1/4, hard-hitting Bronx fighter, earned the decision over Lou Lombardi, 141, Jersey City, in the feature eight-round bout at the New York Coliseum last night before 10,000 persons.

The Rev. T. H. Gibson of the Orange Glade Baptist Church reported today that a group of men representing themselves as Ku Klux Klansmen invaded his church last night and protested against a Negro chorus participating in a revival service.

Following his attendance on the Lilienthal Society's Aeronautic Congress last week, Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh is making an extensive tour of German aircraft factories under the guidance of Major Arthur Vanaman, Assistant Air Attache at the United States Embassy.
