Unqualified support for united States Senator Robert F. Wagner, Democratic candidate for re-election, was expressed yesterday by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

More than 1,000 beer wholesalers from all parts of the United States yesterday attended the opening sessions of the first annual convention of the National Beer Wholesalers Association at the Hotel Commodore. Most of the day was given

The Republic Steel Corporation Is beginning immediately the construction of a new light oil recovery plant at Youngstown, Ohio, to recover light oils from coke oven gas, with a capacity to treat 4,300 tons of coal coked per day.

Speaking at a Tri-State Republican rally today, John D. M. Hamilton, chairman of the National Committee, attacked the New Deal farm program as a "miserable failure," and ridiculed Secretary Wallace's proposed new plan for "dumping" surpluses at reduced prices for needy persons in the domestic market, as an unworkable panacea "that should end all New Deal ideas."
James G. Blaine, president of the Marine Midland Trust Company, fu has been elected president of the Bankers Club of America for the th coming twelve months. He will

The injury jinx which has been trailing the Brooklyn College football team all season struck again yesterday, when Coach Lou Oshins revealed that Stan White, fleet freshman back, would be lost for the rest of the season because of a ruptured kidney suffered in Saturday's game with Rensselaer Poly.

The Associated Theatre Ticket Agencies, Inc., representing twenty-two brokers, yesterday accused the League of New York Theatres, the producers' organization, of harboring within its own ranks the chief violators of the new code barring speculation in the sale of theatre tickets.

The hearings before the Railroad Fact-Finding Board have been concluded. The board must now, before Oct. 27, send a report to the President presenting the facts it has ascertained and making its own recommendations.

Death Announced Retired Fireman John J. Loftus. formerly a member of H. L. Co. 38, residing at 34 King Ave., Yonkers, N. Y., died Oct. 16. Funeral will take place from his late residence at 9:30 A. M., Wednesday, Oct. 19. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. The Deputy Chief of the 7th Division shall detail one Captain, one Lieutenant and twelve Firemen as funeral escort.

The body of Joe Miller, 34, house painter hunted as the shotgun slayer of a woman and two men, was found in a ditch today, officers said, with a suicide note in his wallet. "I loved her and she did me-I could not stand it any longer."

The World's Fair should bring more than $1,000,000,000 in "new money" into New York City during 1939, Grover A. Whalen, president of the World's Fair Corporation, told 122 guests yesterday at a "Brooklyn. Day". luncheon at Namm's Department Store in Brooklyn.

The State Chamber of Commerce, which was founded in 1768, will hold its 170th annual dinner at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria on Tuesday evening, Nov. 22, it was announced yesterday by Richard W. Lawrence, president, who will act as toastmaster.

Anthony Eden, former Foreign Secretary, speaking at the 122d annual meeting of the International Peace Society at Guildhall today, said Great Britain could not repair the gaps in her defenses or recover her authority in the world without an all-party government and united national effort.

A versatile varsity attack ran roughshod over the Princeton scrubs in a sixty-minute scrimmage session today on University Field in preparation for the game with Navy Saturday in Baltimore. Practice was long and spirited and ended under the floodlights.
More powerful than last year but riddled by injuries at. present, Exeter's football eleven comes to the halfway mark of the current campaign facing several remaining games which loom as hard battles.
Colgate continued preparing today for the Iowa game at Iowa City on Saturday, with two teams drilling on defense against the passing attack that the Middle Western team is expected to use.

Three hundred and fifty union wholesale liquor salesmen voted tonight to strike against fifteen leading New Jersey jobbers chiefly on the ground the jobbers allegedly cut the salesmen's commission under the 4 1/2 per cent stipulated in contracts signed last year.

Twenty-four State retail associations and seven national organizations are now affiliated with the American Retail Federation, representing a total membership of 175,000 retailers, Dr. David R. Craig, president of the federation, reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the board of trustees at the Hotel Roosevelt.

The General Motors Corporation will re-employ 35,000 more workers within the next two weeks and will rescind last February's 10 to 30 per cent pay cuts for salaried employes and executives, it was announced yesterday by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the board.

More than 150 social workers have formed a special committee to reelect Governor Lehman and elect his running mate, Charles Poletti, it was announced yesterday. The Social Workers Committee will function under the direction of the women's division of the LehmanPoletti Independent Citizens Cam-, paign Committee.

Paul List, German-born resident of this city, whose illegal entry into this country to see his wife and threeyear-old daughter started Federal deportation proceedings, heard from the government today that he was to be sent back to Germany, an order he considers equivalent to a death sentence or long imprisonment.

Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruotion Finance Corporation, said today that he was convinced a definite turn for the better had been taken by business, adding that all of those with whom he had been in contact were "moderately hopeful" of the future trend.
Money Will be lying around in quantities at the New York World's Fair, but not money waiting to be picked up. Five thousand dollars
Stocks rallied and closed higher; motor shares rose 1 to a points on announcement of General Motors Corporation rehiring 35,000 workers; turnover, 2,408,208 shares.

The War Department today announced awards of $8,889,013.29 in ordnance contracts to private manufacturers This amount, together with $5,444,393.87 yet to be awarded, is expected to complete, the total ordnance contracts to private industry forthe current fiscal year, making a grand total of $24,631,444.61.

Consumer acceptance of the chain store system as a logical development in retail distribution has almoat halted the move toward discriminatory taxation of chains, John P. Nichols, managing director of the Institute of Distribution, Inc., declared last night at a dinner

Determined to prevent any letdown after the victory over Cornell, Coach Ossie Solem today sent the Syracuse football squad through one of the season's longest workouts in preparation for the Michigan State game.

While New York admirers sang the praises of Leonard Eshmont, brilliant sophomore ball-carrier, Coach Jimmy Crowley, a football realist, set to work yesterday to improve the Fordham defense. He sent his men through a two-hourand-a-half workout.

New pneumonia cases in the week ended last Saturday rose to 213, the highest number for any week since June 18, it was reported yesterday to Dr. John L. Rice, City Health Commissioner, by Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Records. The rise over the previous week was seventy.

With the cooperation of the composing and proof-rooms, the comedy that appeared at the National last evening is to be set as "A Woman's A Fool-(To Be Clever)." That is the impish fashion in which it is inscribed in the program.

The City Council of Cambridge voted unanimously tonight .to "secede" from Harvard University in a resolution asking the State to en act legislation severing all relations between the city and the university.

France today paid tribute to the memory of Georges Clemenceau by deciding to name one of her new 35,000-ton battleships still under construction after the statesman. Its sister ship will be named the Gascogne.

The severe strain of an operation, sometimes resulting in the death of the patient, can be eliminated in large part by respiratory control that makes a major surgical operation "a rest period," Dr. Robert

A stay of proceedings against the American, George Bennett of the United Fruit Company,- and two Colombia defendants has been requested by the government attorney investigating charges of bribery, subornation and betrayal of trust in connection of Colombian legislators.

Directors of the Chesapeake Corporation took today what was viewed as the first step toward dissolution of the middle holding company of the former Van Sweringen interests when the directors approved action "looking toward" the sale of the 60,490
Secretary of State Cordell Hull expressed his sorrow at the death of John Barrett, former diplomat, in a statement today as follows:

Virtual martial law was proclaimed throughout Palestine last night as the Arab siege in Jerusalem continued. -Today British troops will enter the Old City in an effort to drive out rebel bands and at the same time will move on scattered towns that are strongholds of armed Arabs. [Page 1.]
We arrived here about 9 A. M. after a 400-mile drive from Doaktown, N. B., and although the woodcock covers look promising, the weather is too temperate for much successful shooting.

Intimating that there must be a big improvement in tackling and blocking if the Lehigh eleven expects to hold its own with Delaware Saturday, Coach Glen Harmeson again stressed these fundamentals in the workout today.
Another plot to assassinate high officials of Brazil on a wholesale scale was nipped today by the police, according to a statement issued by Minister of Justice Francisco Campos.

A drastic shake-up in the New York University backfield was threatened yesterday as Coach Mal Stevens declared himself dissatisfied with the offense of the Violet r against North Carolina last Saturday. N. Y. U. worked three and one-half hours at Ohio Field in the e first day's preparation for the game t with Lafayette at Easton, Pa., on Saturday.

The B. F. Goodrich Company, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and the General Tire and Rubber Company have increased the prices of special, bus and truck tires 2 to 5 per cent. The United States Rubber Company announced last week a similar increase. No change in price was made in the popular sizes.
Connie Mack, veteran pilot of the Athletics, came out today in favor of night baseball, convinced, he said, that it "has its place in the scheme of the major leagues just as much as day baseball."

The new one-story taxpayer at 60-02 and 60-06 Woodside Avenue, Woodside, L. I., was sold by A. B. and B. B. Block to Herring Rosenfeld and Sigmund Solomon. Sale was for cash above a first mortgage of $35.000 at 412 per cent, maturing in 1947.
The rodeo will go tomorrow from Madison Square Garden to Bellevue Hospital, to rope and ride before the crippled children and other patients confined there. Parading 200

Registration of out-of-town buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday reached the thousand mark for the first time in five weeks. The total was also well ahead of the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings published in THE TIMES.

Tear bombs were hurled and clubs were wielded by deputy sheriffs and policemen tonight as they quelled a C. I. O. riot at the Swift Co. packing plant here. There was sharp fighting as nearly a thousand strike sympathizers, in direct violation of an injunction, advanced on the plant with the announced intention of dragging out 150 workmen who were inside.

Remarking that there was no competition between hospitals and public health nursing services, Leo Arnstein, president of Mount Sinai Hospital and chairman of the finance committee of the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service, explained yesterday why the Henry Street group was not participating in the United Hospital Fund.

J. J. Mascuch, president of Breeze Corporations, Inc., says in a letter to stockholders that it was intended to call a special meeting of stockholders to present the situation with respect to the filing of a suit against the company, but: that upon advice of counsel it was deeined inaldvisable to do so until the alleged charges are determined by the Court of Chancery of New. Jersey.

Premier Ed- pri ouard Daladier and his Ministers, seeking to settle France's heavy financial, economic and diplomatic problems, are reported to have investigated the possibility of finding some solution to the French war debt to the United States.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to the registration statement covering its proposed issue of $50,000,000 of 3% per cent debentures due in 1948, in which it named the underwriters and their respective participations.
Edward Purcell Mellon of New York has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Mary Churchill Mellon, to Henry A. Wise Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wise of Kintopeke, Va.

The latest plan for reorganizing the Erie Railroad was announced yesterday at the First National Bank in the form of a unique proposal which, if consummated, would preserve intact the Chesapeake Ohio Railway's $45,000,000 investment in the bankrupt line.
A protest has been received at the White House from the Palestine Defense Society in Baghdad. an Arab organization, against American

Charges that the Young Communist League dominated and practically created the Second American Youth Congress in Detroit were made before the special House committee investigating un-American activities today by William Gernaey of Detroit, who told of four years' activity as a member of the league and of the Communist party as an undercover investigator.

The action of the New York State convention of the Steuben Society of America in endorsing Thomas E. Dewey for Governor has been ratiflied by the organization's New York State council, it was disclosed yesterday.

That national bugaboo, America's relief predicament and its ultimate solution, was the theme tonight of the two speakers at the opening general session of the New York State Conference on Social Work, in the First Baptist Church here.
Five Points House was the beneficiary of the many dinner and supper parties given last night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador to mark the formal opening of the room for the season. A feature

Alter his Legate, George Cardinal Mun- in delein of Chicago, had opened the ch eighth national Eucharistic Con- the gress with a solemn pontifical of mass, attended by nearly 60,000 worshipers in an "outdoor cathedral" at the City Park Stadium here, the thousands in attendance heard Pope Pius XI broadcast to fri them today a message of hope for better things for the church through the "reflowering of eucharistic love."

War Admiral, displaying a liking-for the fast Pimlico strip, on which he will race Seabiscuit Nov. 1 in their longawaited $25,000 match, uncorked an impressive mile-and-a-quarter workout in 2:09 today.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States in the week ended Oct. 13 was greater in four groups and unchanged in one, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. Detailed comparisons are shown in the following table:
A survey of the British electorate shows that 57 per cent of all voters approve of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and his foreign policy in the past few weeks, while 43 Per cent are opposed.

The first arrest under a new State law that makes it a felony for a securities broker or dealer to do business while insolvent, even though no loss is incurred by his customers, was made yesterday in the office of Attorney General Bennett. Richard I. Koota of 735

Public officials and banking executives from many parts of Long Island were among the several hundred persons who attended funeral services here today for Ellis S. Duvall, president of the Suffolk County National Bank, who died of a self-inflicted bullet wound in his home last Saturday.
Eugene J. Zukor, a general partner in Strauss, Phillips Co., became a special partner yesterday. The interest of the estate of the late John F. Forsyth in Billings, Olcott Co. will cease on Oct. 31.

The report of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after all operating expenses and taxes, of $12,242,220.

The City Investing Company instituted suit yesterday in Supreme Court to foreclose a $1,050,000 mortgage on the building at 40 Broad Street which it holds. In its complaint, it alleged that the General Realty and Utilities Corporation.
The Reichsbank's statement as of Oct. 17 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Governor Lehman's appointment of John Harlan Amen to supersede District Attorney Geoghan in the inquiry into official corruption in Brooklyn will be accepted in every circle, including the ranks of previously convicted racketeers, as one of the strongest that could have been made. The naming of

An injunction permanently restraining from further business in this State Robert E. Lancaster Co., Inc., of 110 East Forty-second Street, an over-the-counter securities concern whose customers are said to have lost $50,000 through objectionable practices, was issued yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente.

The Anne Bush MacLear Memorial Library was started last night with the presentation of the first volume to Hunter College at memorial services, held in the college auditorium at Sixty-eighth Street for Dr. Anne Bush MacLear, Professor of History at Hunter from 1911 until her death last April.

The bond market settled into a narrow range in listless trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Gains and losses were about evenly distributed in the domestic corporate list, resulting in minor changes in the respective group price averages.

John Moore de Bienville Grant, ninth Baron de Longueuil and holder of the only French title taken from an estate in Canada, is dead in Pau, France, according to word received here today. He was 79 yers old.
The Public Service Commission awaited today acceptance of conditions on which it has consented to the sale of the Utica Consolidated Water Company's property to the city of Utica for $7,900,000.

One of three groups representing the apparel industry voted unanimously today in favor of having one committee make recommendations for the industry concerning wage and hour conditions under the Fair Labor Standards Act which goes into effect Monday.

" Zaza" today created a minor crisis at Paramount, where editing and scoring of the picture was halted by the Hays office when the purity seal was denied the film. Although the script was approved by the Production Code Authority before shooting started, several changes were made during filming to which exception has been taken.

TO THE EDITOR oF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES'S report of the injuries to playgrounds by vandals goes a long way toward upholding this writer's contention that there is too much done gratis for the people of this city. In my mind's

The Treasury Procurement Division today telegraphed invitations to bid, by wire or letter, on a total of 140,000 yards of textiles for shipment to WPA consignee at Phoenix, Ariz., by Nov. 4, subject to the specifications and.. conditions stated for each item as follows:

Alick G. Richardson Jr. gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza. In the party were the Governor of New Jersey and Mrs. A. Harry Moore, Dr. and Mrs. Milton A. Bridges, Mrs. Alick G. Richardson, Mr. and Mrs. Simon J. Griffinger, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Fitzgerald, Mrs. John M. Fitzgerald and George Gordon Battle.
Courtlandt H. Trowbridge, for many years a resident of this city, died In Washington, Conn., yesterday. He was born here in his parents' residence, one-time home of Noah Webster, 68 years ago.

Miss Mary C. Helm, principal of the Sarah M. Wherry School for girls in Jagraon, India, and a missionary of the Punjab Mission of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, died in Deaconess Hospital, Boston, on Saturday of a throat ailment, according to a report yesterday by the Board of Foreign Missions. She was 60 years old.

Original plates of the engravings and woodcuts which illustrated original editions of the works of Charles Dickens were presented yesterday evening to subscribers to the new edition of Dickens's works issued- by the Nonesuch Press of London. The distribution was made
The pilot of a blazing Eastern Air Lines plane clung to the controls of his ship tonight despite flames licking around his hands and safely landed eleven persons aboard.

Prospects of a satisfactory adjustment of the controversy with Mexico over expropriation of lands other than oil lands owned by citizens of the United States were held out today after Francisco Castillo Najera, the Mexican Ambassador, returned by

Fourteen American volunteers, captured by the Franco forces in Spain and recently released from prison camp, arrived here yesterday aboard the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary. They were welcomed by 200 persons and a band.

Bids for the construction of twelve new design single screw steel cargo ships, the deadweight tonnage of the ships to be about 12,000 tons each, with a speed of sixteen and one-half knots, were announced today by the Maritime Commission.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today ordered ballots sent to holders of bonds of the Savannah Atlanta Railway participating in the plan of organization approved on Feb. 5 by the Federal District Court for the Southern District of Georgia.

Tappy, the Dalmatian or coach dog attached to Engine Company 65 in West Forty-third Street, will be out of the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital within the next few days, Mrs. George Bethune Adams, resident director, said yesterday.

Alex Brown Sons of Baltimore, the First Boston Corporation and B. J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., have bought $5,500,000 of State of Maryland bridge revenue bonds covering proposed bridges over the Susquehanna and Potomac Rivers, it was announced yesterday.
The High Schools Games Committee of the Public Schools Athletic League at its monthly meeting yesterday in the Hotel Astor adopted the New York State rules govern!ing high school competition.

Governor Lehman's record of six years as Chief Executive of the State, together with his stand on all important State problems, is outlined in a campaign booklet to be issued today by the Citizens Independent Committee for the Election of Herbert H. Lehman and Charles Poletti. The slogan on the cover and repeated through the booklet is "I stand on my record."

Lifting of the international copper cartel's restrictions on production of copper had a sobering effect yesterday on the copper market. Abroad sales of the metal were made at 11.15 cents a pound, o. i. f., European base ports, compared with 11.425 to 11.60 cents on Monday. The volume of business done declined.
Robert Edward Crozier Long, financial correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMEs and a contributor to The Economist of London, died here early this morning of pneumonia after a nervous breakdown. Actually
The Rev. John J. O'Brien, a curate attached to St. Cecile's Catholic Church in Brooklyn, died on Monday in St. Catherine's Hospital at the age of 44. Father O'Brien was born in Brooklyn and was...

Thrusting what "felt like a pistol" into the back of his victim, a hold-up man forced a messenger to walk down sixteen flights of stairs in the building at 520 Eighth Avenue at 3:15 o'clock yesterday afternoon -and then robbed him of a $2,180 payroll, according to the police of the West Thirtieth Street station.

Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, suggested yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler adoption of a new procedure which the former said would expedite evaluation of investors' claims against the defunct New York Title and Mortgage Company and hasten its liquidation.
Richard Stephen McCreery, San Francisco capitalist and sportsman, died today at his Hillsborough estate on the San Francisco Peninsula at the age of 71. Death was due to a heart attack.
Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe yesterday directed the Standard Commercial Tobacco Company, Inc., to file a concrete plan of reorganization under Section 77b bankruptcy proceedings on or before Nov. 2,

Under the power delegated to it by the Legislature to preserve peace and order the Jersey City government adopted an ordinance forbidding parades or public assembly in public streets, highways, parks, buildings, without permit from the Director of Public Safety.

The new automobile year was launched for Nash dealers in the New York territory yesterday when those from this area previewed the 1939 cars and heard W. A. Blees, general sales manager of Nash Motors, Detroit, predict a good business and outline sales and advertising plans at the Park Central Hotel.
British troops entered and effectively occupied the Old City of Jerusalem at an early hour today, making approximately the twenty-eighth capture of the city since King David's historic exploit.

William Hopkins Yeager, 44 years old, assistant to the treasurer of Drew University at Madison. was held without bail for the grand jury when arraigned this afternoon before Justice of the Peace E. Marco Stirone on a charge of embezzling $8,743 of university funds.

Major Kellogg K. V. Casey, marksman and director of military sales for E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., died last midnight in the Homeopathic Hospital here. He entered the hospital several weeks ago with a foot infection, which necessitated amputation of the right leg. He was 61 years old.
First Game (Doubles)-Manuel Lasa and Domingo Ulacia defeated Jose Munagorri and Ramon Maiz, 20 to 17.
Viewed from virtually every angle, the football picture at Groton School is radically different from that of last season. Gone are most of the stars

The first performance this season of the Polovetsian dances from Borodin's "Prince Igor" was given by the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, with Frederic Franklin, Jeanneue Lauret and Lubov Roudenko in the chief solo roles.
National Guardsmen began to arrive here tonight, ordered by Governor Nelson G. Kraschel to reopen the strike-bound Swift Co. packing plant, where violence flared last night.
All "inhabitants of the Reich" can be "conscripted to meet public emergencies or to anticipate them," according to a decree issued by Field Marshal Hermann Goering today.

After having been sought by the police since the early part of 1936 on an indictment charging him with having defrauded Chief Justice Louis Wendel of the City Court and Mrs. Wendel of $14,500, William N. Adelson, known also as Ade, according to the police, was arrested yesterday in Los Angeles.

John L. Burdett of Bloomfield, a New York cotton broker, died today after a brief illness at Homeopathic Hospital here at the age of 59. Mr. Burdett was formerly with the New York cotton brokerage house of Gwathmey Co., but for ten years had conducted his own business.

Eleven Austrian Jews who arrived in Mexico on tourist cards after escaping from Nazi concentration camps and obtaining tourists' visas at the Mexican Consulate in Cologne were waiting to learn whether they will be deported.

The Charity Organization Society spent $763,986 during the year that ended Sept. 30 in helping families in distress and in its community services, Walter S. Gifford, president, reported at a meeting of the governing council yesterday at 195 Broadway.

Various proposals under consideration in connection with the reorganization plan of the New York Stock Exchange were discussed today with officials of the Exchange by William 0. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and Ganson Purcell, director of the commission's Trading and Exchange Division.

Mr. and Mrs. James Madison Macdonald of 2 East Eighty-sixth Street and Old Lyme, Conn., formerly of Robe, Japan, and Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Frederick Allen Bibby of Sandanona, Brattleboro, Vt., and 14 East Sixtieth Street, this city, will give a tea dance on Nov. 23 in the Embassy Suite of the Ambassador to introduce to society their daughters, Miss Helen Macdonald and Miss Audrey Bibby.

Professor John E. Ostrander, "Johnny O" to thousands of students who passed through his classes during the thirty-seven years he taught mathematics at Massachusetts State College, died here early this morning after an illness of three months. He was 73 years old.

Alfred M. Landon, former Governor of Kansas, assailed the agricultural and relief policies of the Roosevelt Administration as "utter failures" in a speech today at a Southern Illinois Republican rally.
Either Jim Campbell, veteran signal caller, who returned to practice today, or Charlie Griffith, Cranford, N. J., sophomore, will direct the Lehigh team at Delaware University Saturday.

Ray Foster, Indian-blooded sophomore, stood out in a brisk halfhour scrimmage that concluded the practice session of the Rutgers football squad today. Foster repeatedly reeled off nice gains, working behind the first-string line against the second team.
Canadian construction activity in the first nine months of 1938 was about 20 per cent below the corresponding period in 1937, the Department of Commerce reported today.

CRONIN, JOHN M. (March 4, 1938). Gross assets, $52,472; net, $48,220. To Nora Cronin, sister, and Cornelius Cronin, brother, equally. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $26,256. Earle Rust, attorneys, 15 William St.

The second dinner meeting of the New York Financial Writers Association was held last night in the Belmont Plaza Hotel. The chief guest, W. Randolph Burgess, vice chairman of the National City Rank spoke "off the record."

Fifty-five appointments to professorships have been made by the trustees of Columbia University, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president, announced yesterday. There are two new full professors, two associate professors, twenty-seven assistant professors, twelve assistant clinical professors and twelve visiting professors.

John W. O'Leary, chairman of the executive committee of the United States Chamber of Commerce, said today that recovery in the construction industry to "reasonable employment levels" hinged on revival of private capital investment.
Seven Army cross-country runners broke the tape simultaneously to defeat Fordham by a perfect score of 15 to 40 on the Howze Field course today. The seven cadets locked arms jogging across the line.

The strike of 2,000 towboat men on 300 boats in the port of New York, begun at midnight last Friday, was settled yesterday by a compromise under which the men agreed to return to work at midnight last night on the understarding that negotiations with the employers for a satisfactory adjustment of their wage demands would be carried to a speedy conclusion. Any agreement reached will be retroactive as of yesterday.

Dr. Wesley A. Sturges, Yale law professor and newly elected executive director of the Distilled Spirits Institute, will assume full-time duties with the organization on Monday, it was announced yesterday following a meeting of directors in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Coach Mal Stevens's words of warning that better blocking and greater speed would have to be shown by the varsity backs if they expected to start against Lafayette at Easton Pa., on Saturday, evidently were taken to heart as the New York University football squad went through a spirited scrimmage for more than an hour yesterday afternoon at Ohio Field.
Bank loans of $20,000,000 extended to the Southern Pacific Company which would have matured on Nov. 1 have been extended for one year, Hale Holden, chairman of the railroad, said yesterday.

The best breeze of the series went by the board today when Bluenose, Captain Angus Walters's Canadian defender of the International Fishermen's Trophy, broke down while approaching the starting line for her third contest with the American challenger, Captain Ben Pine's schooner Gertrude L. Thebaud.
Francis Child, Newark attorney, an Advisory Master in Chancery and member of an old New Jersey family, died today in his home here after a long illness. He was 58 years old.

Major Christopher Draper, wartime flying ace turned actor, who is an admirer of Chancellor Hitler, was located by reporters tonight rehearsing at the Playhouse here, where he refused to confirm or deny that he was the man mentioned by Guenther Gus-' tav Rumrich in the spy trial in New York.

Stopping immigration "from whatever source" until the present unemployment crisis abates, was urged in a resolution adopted yesterday at the fifty-third annual convention of the Military Order of the Loyal Legion of the United States at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Miss Margaret Vahlsing, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Vahlsing of Forest Hills, Queens, has completed plans for her marriage to Henry Frelinghuysen Schenk, son of Mrs. Henry S. Schenk of Flemington, N. J., and the late Mr. Schenk, which will take place Oct. 28- in the Catholic Church of Our Lady of Mercy in Forest Hills.

The exclusion of John Strachey was upheld today by the Board of Review of the Immigration Service, on the ground that the British writer did not have a valid visa to his passport when he presented himself for entry at New York on Oct. 10.

Electric power production last week increased more than anticipated on the basis of normal trends, and the adjusted index advanced almost two points to 95.2. The figure was 93.3 for the previous week, and 104.4 for the week ended Oct. 16, 1937.
Before the scramble for Czechoslovak territory has ended, Germany and Poland apparently are already looking ahead to new fields.

The danger of explosions in the operating room, resulting from a union of static electricity in the atmosphere and anesthetic mixtures, has been eliminated largely as the result of a new device which determines the exact amount of static electricity present, it was reported yesterday by Dr. Horatio B. Williams, Professor of Physiology at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University. Dr.

Miss Peggy Bates will have Miss Barbara Belmont of this city for her only attendant at her marriage to Stuart Henry van Saun, which will take place next Wednesday in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

With more than 99 per cent of the coffee growers in Puerto Rico pledged to abide by the minimum price fixed by Lopez Dominguez, Commissioner of Agriculture, for coffee consumed within Puerto Rico, the price was announced today as 20 cents a pound.

Stocks closed heavy, with widest losses of the month; turnover, 2,433,890 shares.. Second-grade railway bonds irregularly higher, United States Government and other issues firm and mixed; transactions, $7,630,000.

Mr. Poletti's letter to Father Curran and Father Curran's generous reply will doubtless gain many votes for the Democratic State ticket next month. This, however, is a fact of relatively minor importance.

Wallace F. H. Lyons of Greenwich, Conn., a retired New York textile merchant, died Tuesday night in the Greenwich Hospital after a long illness, at the age of 67. After many years with Carlin Co. he became associated with Joshua L. Baily Co., remaining with that firm until his retirement in 1937.

Elmer F. Andrews, wage-hour administrator, issued definitions today of professionals, executives, outside salesmen and persons engaged in a retail capacity, all of whom will be exempt from the Fair Labor Standards Act which becomes effective Monday.
Movements of vessels follow, all date are Oct. 19, unless specified: Alden, at Manila. Barker, at Manila. Cormorant, at Yorktown, Oct. 18. J. D. Edwards, at Manila.
The ancient and dishonorable goldbrick game has been revived here for the benefit of customers who do not mind buying "cut-rate Spanish gold."

The Chrysler Corporation has recalled 34,000 men to work since Aug. 1, is still taking on men, and recently has increased its production schedules 20 per cent, according to an announcement yesterday by K. T. Keller, president.

Mary Pickford presented to the archives of the United States today a copy of one of her earliest films, "The New York Hat," for preservation as an illustration of the technique of the movies in their beginnings. Under the law the archivist is authorized to restore films given by private donors as well as by government agencies, providing they fall within categories which are deemed worthy of preservation.

Three successive "New Deals" in New Zealand have proved the futility of government pump priming and government spending and ruined both the industry of the country and the morale of its people, Mrs. Leila M. Bloomfield of New York, economist and writer, told a joint meeting of the American Hardware Manufacturers Association and the National Wholesale Hardware Association in the Marlborough-Blenheim here today.

Max Schling, dean of New York City's florists, celebrated yesterday the fiftieth anniversary of his career in horticulture, which began in Austria, where he was born. Many congratulatory messages were received from leaders in the flower and seed industry at his office and flower shop at 765 Fifth Avenue, in the Savoy-Plaza.

The Massachusetts Investors Trust reported yesterday a net asset value of $20.69 a share on 5,673,505 shares of stock on Sept. 30, compared with $20.13 on June 30 and with $15.56 on March 31. On Oct. 15 the value had advanced further to $22.33 a share.

Although home building will probably by the end of this year surpass the total for 1937, advertising linage by national manufacturers of plumbing and heating and other items going into home construction will fall short of last year's total, agency men agreed yesterday.

Tuesday's announcement by President Sloan of the General Motors, that in the next two weeks his company will re-employ 35,000 workers, was a reassuring incident. The announcement reflected conditions in an industry which has been hard hit in the recent business reaction.
The net operating incomes of the first five railroads to report for September show a drop of 18.4 per cent from September, 1937. In August they showed a decline of 11.3 per cent from August, 1937.

Capitalizing on the fine all-around physical condition of his squad, Coach Dick Harlow drove Harvard for more than two hours today, and plans a similar workout tomorrow, in the hope of having the Crimson at top form for Dartmouth Saturday.

Dr. James Phinney Baxter 3d, president of Williams College, and Mrs. Baxter were honored at a luncheon given at the Pittsfield Country Club today by Mrs. Sheridan R. Cate, acting president. of the Wednesday Morning Club, which Dr. Baxter had addressed earlier in the day on "The United States and Balance of Power."

Many buildings in Greenwich Village and in the Chelsea district were listed in the reports of new apartment tenancies submitted yesterday by brokers. Several figures of prominence also appeared among the lessees.

The possibility of a settlement soon of the French war debt to the United States, occasionally referred to in White House circles as "a hardy perennial," was revived here today with the arrival of William C. Bullitt, United States Ambassador to France.

A good. dealt of. yesterday's chitchat along the- Rialto seemed to dwell on booking problems--local and out of town. For instance, trusted scouts advise from Boston that John Golden and Fred Stone are thinking of launching what must be a sentimental journey to both of them--namely, a coast-tocoast tour of "Lightnin'," with Mr. Stone starred.

Deferring to the protests of patriotic organizations, the Treasury Department completed today the removal of two aluminum reproductions of the Great Seal of the United States from the floor at the principal entrances of the Newark Federal Building. The seals will be replaced with tile inlays.
Louis Johnson, assistant secretary of war, warned in an address here today that a shortage of skilled labor threatened to impede mobilization of 'America for national defense in an emergency.
Manufacturers of paper and operators of textile plants joined today in opposition to continued effectiveness of a year-old surcharge of 10 cents a ton on shipments of bituminous coal.

Elimination of certain services and administrative positions has been an important factor in enabling Alexander's, Bronx specialty store, to cut its ratio of expense cost to net sales 11.99 per cent below that of the average specialty store in its volume class, Max M.
Finance Minister Joseph Kalfus yesterday outlined for the press the effects of the Munich decisions on Czechoslovakia's financial position.

With Bub Johnson, regular quarterback, definitely out of the line-up because of injuries, Coach Andy Kerr today tried Trey Coley, sophomore; Bill Bartlett, junior, and Mike Caseria, sophomore, at the signal-calling berth as he prepared Colgate's Red Raiders for the Iowa game in the Midwest on Saturday,

Tonight's events: Greenwich Orchestra, Joseph Littau conducting, Martha Thompson, Thomas Richner, Edward Sporar, piano soloists, Federal Music Theatre, 8:45 o'clock; Kate Kieth Field, soprano, Town Hall, 8:30; Queens Chamber Music Society, Carnegie Chamber Hall, evening; Society of Professional Musicians, chamber music and lieder, Steinway Hall, 9:30.
The twenty-fourth annual pencil campaign of the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind was started yesterday by Helen Hayes, the actress, at the guild headquarters, 200 West Seventy-second Street.

The Long Island Railroad has embarked on a high-speed program for transporting passengers to the World's Fair next year for a dime. "The World of Tomorrow in 10 minutes for 10 cents" will be the slogan.

The Supreme Court heard today for the second time arguments in the suit of General Talking Pictures against subsidiaries of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company on the question whether a patent owner could restrict the use of an article after its purchase.

Mayor La Guardia and his Fusion colleagues on the Board of Estimate took the unprecedented step yesterday of sending a nine-point questionnaire to all candidates for the State Legislature, asking them to state their position on various aspects of city home rule.
Evidence is accumulating that, despite months of warning, the defense of Malta's civilian population during the recent crisis left much to be desired.

Carl Snavely has been giving his Cornell gridiron squad more work on the defense of passes this week than they have ever had before, fearing an aerial attack from Penn State here Saturday. University officials expect a slim crowd of 7,500.

It appeared today as if Coach Hooks Mylin would start a veteran Lafayette line against New York University but he is still experimenting with a backfield combination which may include several sophomore starters.

Electric power production by the power and light industry in the United States last week totaled 2,182,751,000 kilowatt-hours, compared with 2,154,449,000 in the preceding week, an increase of 28,302,000 kilowatt-hours. Output for last week was only 4.1 per cent under the production for the comparable week a year ago.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In Mr. Fanning's letter published in your issue of Oct. 13 a very good picture of our economic troubles is given and a solution hinted at, but the real cause and cure are omitted, as in most discussions of the subject.

General trading slow on all classes except lamb, which was In fair demand in local markets yesterday. Veal, calf, pork loins, kosher beef and traefer chucks were lower; hinds and ribs barely steady: lamb fully steady to slightly higher; others mostly steady.

Monroe Newberger of 33 East Seventeenth Street, president of B. Blumenthal Co., Inc., importers and manufacturers of buttons and dress ornaments, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after an illness of six months His age was 44.

Dressed in blue overalls and looking trim, youthful and vivacious, Mme. Chiang Kai-shek today demonstrated for correspondents and cameramen the routine that she has been following daily for several weeks while training the initial group of girl members of the new youth corps.

Cancer of the stomach, the most deadly form of cancer, could be largely reduced by the adoption of two simple rules, the annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons was told yesterday by W. H. Ogilvie of London, England, one of the world's leading cancer authorities.

The touring United States amateur boxing team opened its South American invasion with a victory tonight as Bobby Carroll, Trenton (N. J.) flyweight, easily outpointed Guillermo Porteiro of Uruguay in the first bout of the Pan-American championships.

Confusion in the dry goods market over the introduction this season for the first time of a two-pound 25 per cent part wool blanket, which competes with the regular 2 3/4 to 3 pound numbers, was intensified yesterday when New York department stores began a mild price war on the new number.

2d Lt. John Ballerino, QM-Res., 2,344 Harprison St., Schenectady, N. Y., Arm and Service Assignment Group, is ordered to active duty with the CCC for six months, effective Oct. 18, at CCC Co. 1291, Camp S-126, Fillmore, N. Y. (Railhead: Freedom, N. Y.). Date of rank: Oct. 3, 1938.

The question uppermost in every one's mind inside Generalissimo Francisco Franco's zone today, just as it is outside Spain, is what will happen now that the withdrawal of Italian soldiers is well under way.

The candidacy of Charles Poletti for Lieutenant Governor on the Democratic ticket, which was endorsed on Tuesday by the Rev. Edward Lodge Curran, prominent Catholic priest, received further support yesterday by the endorsement of Martin Conboy, a leading Catholic layman and formerUnited States Attorney.

Publication today of the catalogue of part one of the William Randolph Hearst collection discloses for the first time the extent of the historical and literary autographs and manuscripts collected by Mr. Hearst for more than forty years, which he will sell at auction on Nov. 16 and 17 at the Parke-Bernet Gal series, 742 Fifth Avenue.

An appeal to this country to recognize that the Union of South Africa as an important consumer of American goods deserves a larger share of orders from America than It has been getting was made last night by Emil F. Horn, consul in this city for the Union.

A new issue of $55,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent first mortgage bonds of the Ohio Power Company, due in 1968, is being offered publicly today by a syndicate headed by Dillon, Read Co. at a price of 101 1/2 and accrued interest.

The National League for American Citizenship helped 36,000 persons last year in New York City alone with naturalization, according to a report yesterday by Nathaniel Phillips, president of the organization.

The Shippers Conference of Greater New York went on record yesterday in opposition to a city traffic bureau proposed by Mayor La Guardia's committee on ports and terminals. Robert A. Cooke, chairman of the conference, read a report pointing out that the bureau would operate under the Dock Department at a cost to the city of $50,000 a year.

The four little girls left by their mother at the Missing Persons Bureau at headquarters Tuesday were at the home of their grandmother yesterday, and the mother, Mrs. Helen Von Reine of 463 Seventyeighth Street, Brooklyn, was in Kings County Hospital for observation.

Moving to forestall any attempt to stop work on the $5,000,000 Queens General Court House, Mayor La Guardia directed Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick yesterday to transfer all accounts on .the project from the Queens Borough President's office to the Department of Public Works.

Books ranging from Galileo's "Dialogo Matematico Sopra-Ordinario" of 1632 to a French translation of "Pilgrim's Progress" from the library of Joe E., Brown, comedian, were auctioned last night for the benefit. of the National Bureau for Blind Artists at the Hotel Astor.

Promoters Andy Niederreiter and Lew Raymond announced tonight a week's postponement in the title bout between John Henry Lewis, light-heavyweight champion, and Al Gainer, New Haven Negro, which was scheduled for Friday night.

An Oregon team, as big as the great outdoors, arrived in New York today for Saturday's struggle with Fordham, craned its collective neck at the Empire State Building, the Polo Grounds and other assorted sights of the big city, and then was whisked to the bucolic calm of the Westchester Country Club, where the squad will be quartered until game time.

The Newspaper Advertising Executives Association tonight announced winners from a group of more than 300 exhibits on newspaper advertising promotion and newspaper sales promotion, presented by more than sixty newspapers.

WITH pro football booming along and drawing bigger crowds each season, it was a shock to have one of the league championship games postponed because the owner admitted that he couldn't put a proper team in the field. That was Owner Art Rooney of the Pittsburgh Pirates, reported to be the highest paid squad in the league.

Modification of plans for the proposed broadcast of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under the sponsorship of retailers may result in switching the program from Sunday afternoons to Thursday nights, it was learned here yesterday.
A State-wide investigation of labor law evasions through pseudo-partnerships or subcontracts was started today by the State Labor Department on the heels of an inquiry in the Rochester area.
Equipment of the Caledonia Woolen Mills of Clifton Heights, a suburb, were auctioned off today by the Pennsylvania Auction Company. The company manufactured woolen fabrics for men's wear generally.

One woman school teacher was killed and another was seriously injured yesterday when the automobile in which they were riding was in collision with a Third Avenue trolley car at Southern Boulevard near 183d Street, the Bronx.

The two-year-old differences between the management of the Remington Rand Company, office equipment manufacturer, and members of an A. F. L. union here, were near settlement today, according to Harold Beer, the union's shop committee chairman, who said demands of workers who struck in 1936 has been met by the company nearly 100 per cent.
Money market was featureless. Business continued quiet and rates for all classes of loans remained unchanged.

The Chilean Government has decided to turn down offers made by shipbuilding firms in The Netherlands and Finland for construction of two 8,000-ton cruisers equipped with Krupp guns for the Chilean Navy.

Back in the days when the Abenakis-roamed this area they had a name for the area southward of the broad reaches of this bay. They called it Ahmelahcogneturcook, which, translators say, means a place where fish and game are plentiful.
The police of Guayaquil complain that they have difficulty in catching thieves because they take refuge in the city jail. The keeper of the jail is not under the Police Department.

Efforts to change radically America's oldest and most important speed-boat race were made last night at the Hotel Lexington at a meeting of the Gold Cup Contest Board. But the sum total of five hours of wrangling was surprisingly barren of new legislation.

All government business in wartorn republican Spain ceased for two hours this afternoon while officials who included President Manuel Azana, Premier Juan Negrin and the entire Cabinet as well as many high staff officers and other notables listened to Pablo Casals play a concert broadcast to the United States.

In a decision handed down today a Havre tribunal refused to raise an attachment placed on shipments of petroleum from expropriated oil fields in Mexico, on the grounds that the ownership of the oil was still in doubt.

Army routed Johns Hopkins at soccer this afternoon, 3 to 0. The cadets had the upper hand all the way and only fine work at goal by Alperstein kept the Army total down. It was Army's third straight victory of the season.

The Rev. Dr. Paul Austin Wolfe, 40 years old, pastor for six and a half years of the First Presbyterian Church, Evanston, Ill., was installed last night by the Presbytery of New York as pastor of the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street.

With Governor Lehman, Democratic candidate for re-election; scheduled to open his up-State campaign with a speech in Kalurah Temple, Binghamton, tonight, John C. Kelly, chairman of the LehmanPoletti Independent Citizens Committee, announced yesterday that the Governor's campaign organization had been completed.
Basque refugees say Spanish Insurgent authorities have used divining rods successfully to locate buried treasure.

Lucy Giordano sold to Joseph Barbieri the two-family dwelling and store at 6,812 Third Avenue, Brooklyn, on a plot 20 by 100 feet, through the Colonial Realty Company, Inc. The stock and fixtures of the store also were taken by Mr. Barbieri.

Jimmy Hines of Lakeville, metropolitan open champion and one of the favorites, came through easily in the first and second rounds of the Long Island P. G. A. championship tournament which got under way at the Bayside golf links yesterday.

Out of the early history of Manhattan, Maxwell Anderson has written the book and lyrics for a cultivated musical comedy, "Knickerbocker Holiday," which was staged at the Ethel Barrymore last evening, and Kurt Weill has written the music.

A jury in Federal Court, after deliberating five minutes yesterday, convicted Raymond Sheldon and his wife Annette of 198 Washington Park, Brooklyn, of using the mails fraudulently in a scheme to obtain Federal housing loans.
The Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30 a net income of $22,281,403 after all operating expenses, taxes and charges.

Milton J. Greenebaum of Felix Lilienthal Co. was re-elected president of the Association of Buying Offices at the annual meeting of the organization held yesterday in the offices of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Harvard officially kept silent tonight concerning an attempt of the Cambridge City Council to dissolve a 300-year partnership between the university and the municipality, but the suggestions and speculations of the sons of Harvard and the towniess" were loud and multiple.

The Berengaria, the last of the three great German ships handed over under the reparations agreement, is to be sold for breaking up. She has been laid up here since March when defects in the electrical installation, which resulted in three fires, caused her to be withdrawn from transatlantic service.

The bond market on ,the New York Stock Exchange made a feeble effort to overcome heavy selling yesterday but the show of resistance was not sufficient to put prices higher except in the railroad section.

Four security issues have been approved by the committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange. The authorizations do not necessarily indicate that the securities will be admitted immediately to dealings.
Thirty-four horses, including William Woodward's American-owned Olympus, were kept eligible for next Wednesday's running of the Cesarewitch at Newmarket when the final forfeits were paid today.

The Rev. Charles Palamtier, Universalist minister and former police justice of Newark, N. Y., died today in that village. He was 77 years old. After-his graduation from St. Lawrence University in 1885 he occupied Universalist pulpits in Webster, Friendship, Oxford and Perry before going to Newark.

Governor Lehman came back to the capital today for his usual conference with Democratic candidates for the Legislature and to- clean his desk of pressing matters before starting tomorrow on a ten-day tour of upState New York. He said he was in "fine shape" for his campaign.

Hundreds of penniless Jews are living in ditches between the German and Czechoslovak army lines. The Nazis are depriving Jews of all possessions and expelling them from occupied Sudeten territories and Czechoslovak authorities refuse to allow them to enter the republic.

The marriage on Tuesday afternoon of the Earl of Carrick and Mrs. Margaret Power Drum of Center Island, L. I., was revealed here yesterday several; hours before the couple sailed on the Queen Mary for England.
BORDER JUSTICE, by Amos Moore (Ives Washburn, $2.) A Western novel. THE DEATH SYNDICATE, by Judson P. Philips. (Ives Washburn, $2.) A mystery novel.

Ralph Furey brought his freshman team out on the varsity preserves at Baker Field yesterday and for almost an hour the Columbia Lions roared and their coaches growled in one of the most intensive scrimmages of the season.

A decline of about $9,000,000 in income tax collections in the first quarter of this fiscal year, compared with the first three months of last year, and a drop of $55,506,053 in all internal revenue from the earlier period were shown in a report made public today by the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

Two National Football League records are within the grasp of Ed Danowski, ace passer of the Giants, if he continues his present pace. According to the official league statistics released yesterday, the former Fordham back has completed forty-five out of seventy-six passes for a total of 523 yards.
When the steamship Brazil, the first ship of the "Good Neighbor" fleet, arrives here tomorrow, Brazilians will give her an appropriate welcome.

Wall Street again dictated the trend in the stock market today when the tone was more cheerful following yesterday's smart upswing in the New York prices, although business continued on a moderate scale here.

A copy of the first, or Kilmarnock, edition of the "Poems" of Robert Burns brought $2,300 yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., at the auction of the library of the late James Wilcon Falconer of Minneapolis.
The recent upswing in stocks extended even to Wall Street art last night when a painting of the famous thoroughfare as it appeared in 1820 brought $13,500 at auction at the parke-Bernet Galleries.

Stephen W. Hamilton, Deputy Collector of Customs in charge of the Marine Division, was the guest of honor last night at a dinner held in Busto's Restaurant, 11 Stone Street, to celebrate his completion of fifty years in the customs service.

St. Christopher and Britannia combined to rule the waves of New York Harbor Tuesday morning. At least they guided the signaling hand of Commodore Robert Irving as he warped the giant 82,000-ton Queen Mary into her North River berth without a single puffing tug to help him.

Bernard W. Quinn, manager of the furniture department of W. J. Sloane, Fifth Avenue and Fortyseventh Street, and World War veteran, died on Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a three-week illness. Mr. Quinn, who lived in Bogota, N. J., was 44 years old.

Prince Arsene Karageorgevitch, father of Prince Regent Paul of Yugoslavia and younger brother of the late King Peter I of Serbia, died this morning in his Paris home, where he had lived since the beginning of the century. He was 79 years old.

The statement of the Corn Products Refining Company for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $7,113,111 after charges and taxes. The net is equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.30 each on the 2,530,000 common shares outstanding and compares with $5,003,040, or $1.46 a share, in the corresponding period of 1937.

The Wesleyan eleven worked on a new defense against the Amherst wingback formation in practice today. The varsity lined up against the freshman team, which used the Amherst plays, More carrying the ball and Croop throwing the passes for the cubs.

Thirty-five thousand children garbed in all the hues of the rainbow formed a mosaic of colors against. a background of 30,000 of their elders this morning at. a solemn pontifical mass for youth, held in the outdoor Cathedral of the National Eucharistic Congress in the City Park Stadium.

A small bronze sculpture, "Kneeling Figure," that of a girl, the work of Robert Laurent of Brooklyn, today earned the main prize of the fortyninth annual exhibition of Amerlean paintings and-sculpture at the Chicago Art Institute.
John Curtin, leader of the Labor Opposition, issued today a statement on Labor's new defense policy, framed to meet the new European situation.
A declaration that President Roosevelt "might" have to run again when the question of a 1940 choice came up was made by Secretary Ickes at a press conference today.

Establishment of two-year postgraduate courses for New York City's academic and vocational high school students who are unable to find employment or go to college was recommended yesterday by the Board of Education's advisory board on industrial education.

The diary left by Lieut. Comdr. George Washington De Long on Henrietta Island, in the Arctic Circle fifty-seven years ago, before the American explorer and most of his party perished, was brought to Moscow today by L. F. Mukhanoff, head of the Soviet scientific party that discovered it last June.

Four able and honorable men nave been nominated in this State for two places in the Senate of the United States. Mr. Wagner and Mr. Mead, for the Democrats, Mr. O'Brian and Mr. Corsi, for the Republicans, have all shown competence in public office.
Sixty armed motor boats are en route along the South China coast tonight, supposedly to add an assault by river to Japanese overland drives against Canton.
Longmans, Green is rushing through the press a book on British policy in Palestine. Written by William B. Ziff and entitled "The Rape of Palestine," it will be issued on Nov. 9.
Dave Hissong, flame-seared but whole, rested in seclusion today while the thirteen persons whom he brought to safety in a crippled and blazing airplane sang his praises.

Ralph Knox, former president of a Detroit local of the United Automobile Workers, told the special House committee investigating un-American activities today that in 1934 a Ben Wood, or Wolf, an attorney for the old National Labor Board, urged him to become a member of the Communist party.

Members of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms were advised yesterday to consider themselves bound by the Wages and Hours Law until such time as administirators or courts decide that they are not.
The Bangs Cup Regatta, Columbia's annual Fall crew race that marks the close of outdoor training, was taken by the varsity yesterday over a one-mile course on the Harlem River.

The Taylor-Young Airplane Company announced today that a controlling block of its stock had been placed in a voting trust, allying the concern with the Fairchild Aviation Corporation of New York City.

Green St, 12; 12 Greene St Corp to Plymouth Cordage Co, North Plymouth, Mass ($26). Hudson St, 166-172, n e cor Laight St; Barbara N. Gage, executrix of Isabella M. Cammann, to Helena Van Kortlandt Cammann, 115 E 92d St. executrix of. Edward C. Cammann, 3/48th interest (50c).

With her heavy weather sails still reefed after a recent crossing of the Atlantic, the 45-foot Norwegian life-saving ketch Colin Archer slipped into the Battery basin at Pier A yesterday morning for a two-month visit in the port.

President Kemal Ataturk, gravely ill of cirrhosis of the liver, recovered consciousness this afternoon and took food, and an evening bulletin told of "a slight but definite abatement of the nervous disorders."

The story of a Federal Army officer who fell in love with the South even while fighting against it during the Civil War, and returned later to marry and live there, was brought to mind yesterday by the news of the sale of a notable Virginia estate.

Mrs. Katherine R. Fell, the former Miss Katherine Reeves Royce, has announced her engagement to Edward Lyddon Lycett of Haverford, her stepfather. The marriage, which will be Mrs. Fell's second and Mr. Lycett's third, will take place in December.

Vigorous exercise of the good old Yankee prerogative of free speech enlivened more than one session today of the annual State Conference on Social Work, current in the hotels and public buildings of this city.
School District No. 1 of Jeferson Parish, La., will be in the market on Nov. 16 with an issue of $1,600,000 of bonds for which bidders are to name an interest rate not exceeding 5 per cent.

Turpentine firm, 23c; sales 96 barrels; receipts, 794 barrels; shipments, 235 barrels; stock, 50,574 barrels. Rosin firm; sales,. 85: receipts, 1,500; shipments, 230; stock. 268,868. Quote: B, $3.80; D. $4; E, $4.30: F, $4.90; G, H, I K, $5.05; M, $5.07 1/2-10; N, $5.35; WG, $5.65; WW,. X, $6.40.

The thirteen-story and penthouse building containing ninety-five apartments at 25 Fifth Avenue, northeast corner of Ninth Street, has been purchased by a syndicate, it was announced yesterday. The buyer, Cortland Properties, Inc., paid cash over a first mortgage of $825,000 for the property, which is opposite the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

Under pressure for nearly' two hours, the Yale squad today underwent a stubborn defensive drill against the air plays of the Wolverines. The regulars finished the practice with a powerful ground attack against the Grays, employing the new formations taught by Head Coach Ducky Pond and Strategist Earle Neale.

JAMES THURBER wasn't merely being funny when he wrote the following in a recent New Yorker: "The effect of Thurber's letters on his generation was about the same as the effect of anybody's letters on any generation; that is to say, nil. It is only when a man's letters are published after his death that they have any effect, and this effect is usually only on literary critics.

President Lazaro Cardenas today decreed authorization for the importation of 500 tons of rice. The decree stipulates: "The price in the interior of the country shall not exceed the price set for rice by the Food Regulation Committee."
Eugene De Lancey Hays, former member of the New York Stock Exchange, died yesterday in his home in Los Angeles, where he had resided for seven years. He was 77 years old.

Political talks scheduled for broadcast today are: Nicholas Bucci, assistant corporation counsel, in behalf of Edmund L. Palmieri, candidtae for Justice of City Court in Brooklyn, WBIL, 6:30 P. M. (1,100 Kc.)
Payment of the third installment of the city's 2 per cent sales tax for 1.938 must be made by 5 o'clock this afternoon if the taxpayer wishes to avoid an interest penalty.

A hearing has been called for Nov. 1 by the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with four a registration statements filed under the Securities Act of 1933 by W, Wallace Alexander, Inc., of Philadelphia, one of the oldest of the investment trusts, which was originated in 1907.
Moon Mullin, Sid Martin and Jim Dubuisson all had a try at Army's tailback position today as Coach Wood rested Woodrow Wilson during a scrimmage.

The National Council of Catholic Men urged President Roosevelt in a letter today to exercise his influence to avert the closing of the doors of Palestine to Jewish refugees and the abandonment of the Jewish national home policy by Great Britain.
One of the pleasantest experiences that life in the United States can offer today is to be fired from a factory job or a government

Most steers and yearlings declined further today but prime offerings held unchanged, topping at $13.50. the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Hogs and lambs sold strong to higher, influenced by smaller receipts and cooler weather.
The recently organized Atlantic Squadron of the navy is to be a permanent organization, although not in its present form, it was learned today.

Formation of a Republican committee to back Representative John J. O'Connor for re-election was announced yesterday. Mr. O'Connor, object of the Roosevelt "purge," lost the - Democratic nomination, but won the Republican one, in the recent primary.

Walter G. C. Otto, Democratic candidate for county executive, called tonight for a change from a Republican to a Democratic administration of Westchester County to stop the "piling up" of bonded indebtedness.
Lord and Lady Esher have come from London and are at the Delmonico. Mrs. John Claflin of Morristown, N. J., will be at the Ritz Tower for the Winter.

The Rev. Sir Francis Ffolkes, rector of Hillington and chaplain-inordinary to the King, died today at the age of 74. During the World War Sir Francis was a padre with the British forces in the Near East and was mentioned in dispatches.

Adriana Caselotti, who supplied Snow White's voice in the animated cartoon film, "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs," and Harry Stockwell, who supplied the voice of the Prince, filed yesterday separate suits in Supreme Court against Disney Productions, Ltd., and the R. C. A. Manufacturing Company for $200,000 and $100,000 respectively.

The Citizens Union has made public its recommendations on local candidates for judicial and county offices and for seats in the State Senate from the twenty-three districts that lie wholly or in part within the city.

Joseph P. Smith, manager of the bureau of methods and equipment of the New York Emloying Printers Association, Inc., declared last night at a meeting of the association at the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn that New York printers were the "leaders and exponents of printing" and that this city was no longer a "step-child" in the printing industry of the country.

Building projects submitted yesterday by architects include plans for numerous apartment houses and dwellings in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens. Activity in Manhattan was limited to plans for altering existing structures.

Any emoluments that clerics, active or retired, or their dependents receive from the Reich will be withheld under a decree that Church Minister Hanns Kerrl issued today, unless they "prove themselves worthy of the State's solicitude."
Chancellor Adolf Hitler's reported price for a guaranty of French-German peace appeared too high to France today.

Following a workout at the Polo Grounds yesterday the Giants watched movies of last Sunday's contest with the Eagles and also those of the last meeting with the Brooklyn eleven. Coach Steve Owen pointed out the flaws in the Giants' play and warned the men against 'repetition.

Army engineers said today that they would continue preparations for construction of six flood-control dams in the Connecticut and Merrimack Valleys of New England. They explained they would use $4,750,000 of army reserve funds, and added that they were already negotiating with property owners for land.

Edward R. Stettinius Jr., chairman of the board of directors of the United States Steel Corporation, will head the roll-call of the New York chapter of the Red Cross, General James G. Harbord, chairman of the chapter, announced yesterday.

The government's weekly report of crop conditions was issued yesterday as follows: The generally fair, warm weather throughout the cotton belt was favorable for picking and ginning. Rapid progress of this work was made and it has been largely completed in the more southern portions of the belt, with only small amounts remaining.

Fordham worked long and hard on its forward-passing attack yesterday. Coach Jimmy Crowley had both his first and second elevens throwing aerials in a dummy scrimmage against the freshmen that featured a fast three-hour drill.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Oct. 17:
Georgetown University announced today a 1939 football schedule on which Syracuse and George Washington are newcomers. The Hoyas last met Syracuse in 1927 and George Washington in 1923.
Robert Gammon, 27 years old, formerly radio operator of the Amagansett Naval Radio Compass Station, was convicted of murder in the second degree here early today by a Suffolk County Court jury.

The formation of an association that is not a political party and that places itself outside politics as a "union for pubic salvation" has been announced by a group of leading figures in French scientific, educational, artistic and public life.

The present reserve account system of financing the old-age insurance provisions of the Social Security Act, which has been criticized, among other reasons, because the Treasury spends the funds paid in by workers and employers rather than "saving" them, was defended today by a Treasury official who reflects the official views of his department.

Continuing his recital of brash espionage plots that never quite came off, Guenther Gustav Rumrich told in Federal court yesterday how he pulled the wool over the eyes of his foreign employers by palming off an innocuous set of airplane landing signals as a secret code for communication between land batteries and the fleet.
Exhibitions of work by two European modernists, one French, the other German, opened here this week. A group of oils, gouaches

As a token of the esteem Germany holds for Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, Chancellor Adolf Hitler has bestowed upon him the Service Cross of the Order of the German Eagle with Starthe second highest German decoration, outranked only by the Grand Cross of the same order.
The city of Utica acquired title today to the Consolidated Water Company of Utica, the transfer being made in the Federal Reserve Bank in New York on payment of $7,910,693.

A funeral service will be held at 1 P. M. today at the Campbell Funeral Church, Broadway and Sixty-sixth Street, for Ferdinand L. Smithe, president and founder of the F. L. Smithe Machine Company, Inc., 633 West Forty-fourth Street.

The sudden emergence of a major police scandal in Brooklyn, following the discovery that the records of 7,200 arrests have been slashed from the books, confirms the urgent necessity of the sweeping investigation of official corruption in that borough which Governor Lehman has ordered Special Prosecutor Amen to make. No consideration should be allowed to delay or circumscribe the inquiry.

Joseph V. O'Leary, American Labor party candidate for the office of Attorney General, was made the subject yesterday of a lien filed in Federal court by James J. Hoey, Collector of Internal Rvenue, ering income and miscellaneous taxes for the years 1929-30 and 32.
The National Labor Board ordered the Republic Steel Corporation today to offer reinstatement to about 5,000 employes who went on strike in six Ohio plants in May, 1937.

BRADY, MARY E. (July 7). Estate less than $10,000. To Alice F. Koch, sister, Little Silver, N. J.; George M. Hamilton, nephew, 29 Washington St., Rumson, N. J., and George H. Hallanan, brother, executor. 12 West River Road. Rumson, N. J., interests in specific real property.
Following is the text of Thomas E. Dewey's speech at a Republican rally here tonight:

The Thomas Hitchcock entry dominated the twenty-seventh running of the Chevy Chase Steeplechase Handicap, today's $5,000 added feature race. Ridden by Rigan McKinney, leading amateur jockey, Annibal defeated Rioter, his stable-mate, by a length and a half.

The American Republics Line will entertain 250 shipping men and their wives with a dinner tonight on the reconditioned liner Uruguay, which will sail from New York on Saturday on her first voyage in the new service to South American ports.

City College's practice scrimmage with Columbia on Tuesday proved a costly workout, it was discovered yesterday when the Lavender squad returned to the Lewisohn Stadium and resumed drills for Saturday's game with Brooklyn College at the Kingsmen's new field.
Compared with relative strength in near deliveries, a further decline occurred yesterday in distant positions on the Cotton Exchange. The list ended unchanged to 5 points lower than on Tuesday.

Manuel Rionda, president of the Manati Sugar Company, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday that after payment of interest on its bonds due on Nov. 1 the company would have about $500,000 in cash in its treasury.
Completely recovered from smallpox, Dr. Edward Hamilton Pershing, 73year-old cousin of General John J. Pershing, left the isolation hospital this morning and is now staying at the Bristol Hotel.

The Title Guarantee and Trust Company, New York, reported as of Sept. 28, total deposits of $18,068,723 and total assets of $40,117,155, compared with $17,234,323 and $39,455,014 respectively, on June 30, last.

Henry Stuart Fleming, known as a mechanical, civil and metallurgical engineer in many sections of North and South America, died of a stroke today in his home here after an illness of two weeks. He had been president for the last ten years of the Louisiana Southern Railway. His age was 75.
Modification or abandonment of the attempt to seek a-temporary thirty-two hour week in the entire motor industry was forecast today in union circles.
Mrs. John L. Boatwright gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for the Hon. Mrs. Charles C. F. Dundas, wife of the Governor General of the Bahamas.

More than 1,000 Salvation Army officers and friends attended an impressive funeral service yesterday morning for Lieut. Comm. Richard Griffith in the Army's Centennial Memorial Temple at 120 West Fourteenth Street.

By strict law observance and true temperance education, dry propagandists can be disarmed and the threat of prohibition "forever eliminated," George W. Eads of Anheuser-Busch, Inc., told members of the National Beer Wholesalers Association of America at their first annual convention in the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

Democracies and dictatorships should cooperate for the common good rather than emphasize "self-apparent differences," United States Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy declared at the annual Trafalgar-Day dinner of the Navy League tonight.
After six lean years the opinion at Brooklyn College is that its football team will defeat City College for the first time on Saturday at the Kingsmen's field.

Donald R. Richberg joined the fight against a Congressional movement to eliminate chain stores by heavy taxation in a radio speech tonight in which he said that the elimination of chain stores would amount in effect to a wage cut for American wage-earners.
In the Supreme Court of the United States today Floyd H. Crews of New York City was admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:
Early ratification of the Anglo-Italian treaty became a possibility today in the light of new information that Viscount Halifax, Foreign Secretary, laid before his Cabinet colleagues.

A supplementary summary of transactions in equity securities by officers, directors and principal stockholders for August issued today by. the Securities and Exchange Commission recorded the sale of 1,000 shares of Chrysler Corporation common by O. R. Skelton;

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, and Mrs. Butler gave a dinner last night at their home, 60 Morningside Drive, for the Very Rev Walter R. Matthews, Dean of St. Paul's Cathedral, London, and Mrs. Matthews.

James H. Fay, Democratic nominee for Representative in the Sixteenth Congressional District, last night again challenged Representative John J. O'Connor, defeated in the. Democratic primary but winner of the Republican nomination, to say whether he was supporting Governor Lehman or Thomas E. Dewey for Governor.

The Charles L. Eidlitz Company has sold the four-story industrial building on the northeast corner of Eleventh Street and Forty-fourth Road, Long Island City, assessed for $60,000, to the Artwall Realty Company. The structure, on a plot 100 by 90 feet, will be remodeled by the new owner.
