The city Department of Parks will conduct a whistling contest, not only for soloists on "classical, semi-classical and popular songs," but also for bird imitators.

The cost to the Chesapeake Ohio Railway of retaining a majority control in the Erie Railroad would be $45,000,000 under the terms of the reorganization plan announced by a group headed by Wilfred Kurth, chairman of the Home Insurance Company, it was pointed out yesterday in Wall Street.

The price war in the steel industry that has been going on for two months, with particular bitterness in the last ten days, came to a sudden close yesterday when all producers rescinded the cuts of $6 to $4 a ton below official prices for business for the fourth quarter of this year.

T. M. Dorsett and Pagliacci, two of the shortest-priced choices of the meeting, scored at Empire City yesterday to increase the percentage of winning favorites, which has been higher at the Yonkers course than in previous weeks. Joe W.

A new investigation in connection with the kidnapping of John J. O'Connell Jr. in 1933 developed today with the announcement that Clarence L. Chamberlain, Broome County Republican Chairman, had been subpoenaed before an Albany County grand jury.
Alexander W. Weddell, United States Ambassador to Argentina, was appointed today United States delegate at-the Chaco peace conference in Buenos Aires.

The speaker was No. 6 himself, more familiarly known as Tony Sarausky, late of Fordham and still later of the Giants, but at the moment an important cog in the Dodger machine, which has a rather important date with the Giants at the Polo Grounds on Sunday. No. 6, it appears, has an axe to grind.

Because of the purely intrastate nature of thei business, most of the independent telephone companies of the United States are exempt from the Federal Wages and Hours Bill in his opinion, Howard P. Macfarlane, attorney, Tampa, Fla., told members of the United States Independent Telephone Association at its fortysecond annual convention here today.

The principal foreign exchanges made further gains against the dollar yesterday. The pound sterling rose to $4.78 1/2 and closed at $4.78, up 1 1/4 cents, while the French franc gained 7/8 point net to 2.67% cents.

The German fortification line stretching along the French-German border from Switzerland to The Netherlands, on which 500,000 men are still at work, has received an official name from Chancellor Adolf Hitler himself.
Negotiations were reported to be under way today between Samuel Goldwyn and Robert Sherwood for the purchase of the film rights to "Abe Lincoln in Illinois" for $200,000.

While Governor Lehman prepared to issue in Albany today his executive order formally beginning a thoroughgoing clean-up of official corruption in Brooklyn, the local investigating authorities undertook yesterday the herculean detective problem of piecing together 7,200 vanished police records as they continued their search for the thief who stole them from the locked record room in the Bergen Street station.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Socity of New York will open its ninety-seventh season tonight at Carnegie Hall. John Barbirolli will direct the overture to "Der Freischuetz" by Weber, "The Swan of Tuonela" and "The Return of Lemminkainen" by Sibelius, Stravinsky's "Fire-Bird" suite, adagio and fugue for strings by Mozart and the Fifth symphony of Beethoven.

A large and friendly audience last night at Town Hall heard James Friskin play three Scarlatti sonatas, a Mozart Adagio, a Fantasia of C. P. E. Bach, Franck's Prelude, Aria and Finale, some Chopin, Albeniz and Debussy, and a final hefty group of Brahms.

Faced with a lack of funds to continue its department for preventing and curbing financial frauds, which it has operated for sixteen years, the Better Business Bureau of New York City announced last night that it would begin an emergency fund-raising campaign to enable it to carry on the work.
Educated toes of the nation's football players are paying big dividends this year in drama and victories.

The liner Europa of the North German Lloyd Company is due to arrive today from the Channel ports. Among her passengers are Charles Creed, Walter Hingelmann, German consul at Mobile, Ala.; the Countess of Listowel, Jean Dansereau, Canadian pianist, and Mrs. Dansereau;

Reports of public opinion on more than 900 important issues, correct forecasts of fifty-six out of sixtytwo election tests, and continuous measurement of the trends of publie sentiment from week to week are among the achievements of the American Institute of Public Opinion, of which Dr. George Gallup is the director, as it celebrates its third anniversary today.

Three ex-convicts were held yesterday in the theft of 500,000 onecent cigarette tax stamps that were stolen from a steel room in the City Collector's office on the ground floor of the Municipal Building on Aug. 24. None of the stamps in the $5,000 batch was recovered.

Dispatches from Hyde Park in this newspaper yesterday describe Governor Lehman as "surprised and somewhat puzzled" that reporters, after he left the President, should have centered their fire of interrogation on the extent and detail of his support of the New Deal.
Hal Kempie, orchestra leader, died today of a heart attack he suffered early this morning while playing with his swing band at a downtown night club.

The program for the sixty-fourth annual convention of the American Bankers Association, which is to be held in Houston, Texas, on Nov. 14 to 17, was announced here yesterday by Orval W. Adams, executive vice president of the Utah State National Bank of Salt Lake City, who is president of the association.
The democratic German paper Prager Mittag today announced it was ceasing publication rather than submit to being obliged "to damn what it formerly praised and praise what it formerly condemned."

Miss Nancy Bogue, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Perry D. Bogue of this city, will be married to William Townsend, son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Townsend, also of Greenwich, on Nov. 11 at the home of her parents.
The Air Transport Association of America reported today that September was the best month in the history of the air carrier industry in point of revenue passenger miles flown.
Miss Ruth Dicke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen A. Dicke of this place, has chosen Nov. 5 for her marriage to Harold W. Howard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Howard of Pompton Lakes.

Determined to make undefeated Georgetown its first major victim of the season, the Manhattan football team moved through a brisk two-hour drill yesterday in preparation for Saturday's game at the Yankee Stadium.
Dates have been set for the holiday dances conducted by Miss Adeline King Robinson for juniors in society.
Lieut. Col. James S. Stewart, O. R. C., who had charge of the American Red Cross canteens in Paris in the World War, died suddenly last night of a. heart attack at his home here, at the age of 66.

Thomas E. Dewey, head of the Republican State ticket, declared himself here tonight to be a middle-of-the-road candidate for Governor and disavowed support from "the reactionary on the right or the radical on the left."

Syracuse's squad spent more than an hour of its practice today in both dummy and contact scrimmage against a freshman eleven using Michigan State plays which the Orange must face Saturday at East Lansing, Mich.
With the exception of Minnesota, the nation's leading elevens take to the gridiron this Saturday, when the ranks of the unbeaten may be further thinned.

The sixty-two-family apartment house at 3,165 Decatur Avenue, the Bronx, which was reported held at $250,000, has been sold by Harry Klein, president of Sherwood Estates, Inc., to a client of William Shafer, attorney. Philip I. Globerman was the broker.

Corn closed today with gains for the first time since Oct. 7. There was no-material pressure on the market and buying attributed to removing hedges against export sales resulted in an advance of about 1 cent a bushel from yesterday's finish.

A demand for store locations in the midtown section of Manhattan was indicated yesterday by reports of new leasing contracts. A ten-year lease with a percentage arrangement on gross sales was signed by Alfred Timen for the store at 605 Madison Avenue for a drug store and luncheonette.
To Report to Chief Medical Officer The following ununiformed firemen shall be directed to report to the Chief Medical Officer, at these Headquarters, at 11 A. M., on dates specified;

Finland's foreign trade relations were placed on a more stable basis today when Parliament accepted the government's bill for the first permanent tariff. Previously import duties were fixed for only one year.

A campaign for human liberty that will destroy the menace of dictatorships was urged by Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, feminist leader, in a speech last night at the fourteenth annual dinner of the National Committee on the Cause and Cure of War, held at the Park Lane.
The Republican caravan which has been touring the State in behalf of the Republican ticket since Monday reached Rochester tonight in time to take part in the Dewey rally at Convention Hall.
Between 10,000 and 15,000 new automobiles will be sold in Greater Cleveland before the end of this year, it was indicated today by a tremendous increase in new car orders.

A ruling by Nathan Straus, Administrator of the United States Housing Authority, fixing a general limit of $1.50 a square foot as the price for land for new public housing projects has left housing officials here confused as to the prospects for further slum clearance in New York under the Federal program, it was learned yesterday.

Mrs. F. J. Holleran of Greenwich won the qualifying medal in the two-day match play tournament of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield County Golf Association over the Whippoorwill course today with a score of 41 for the nine-hole test.

The sixtieth annual appeal of the United Hospital Fund for the maintenance of its ninety-two voluntary member hospitals will open officially with a dinner in the Hotel Astor on Monday night, C. M. Chester, chairman of the appeal, announced yesterday.
An attack on the American Labor party was conspicuous in an address made here tonight before the Columbia County Republican organization by the Republican State Chairman,William S. Murray.
A special meeting of the stockholders of the Sunray Oil Corporation has been called for Nov. 14 to vote on an amendment to the certificate of incorporation, it was announced yesterday.
The following film programs, to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been especially recommended for young people by the Schools Motion Picture Committee:
The thirty-second annual convention of the Association of Life Insurance Presidents will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria here on Dec. 1
The State Department reported today the registration of twenty-one more agents of foreign principals as required by an act of the last Congress.
New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street. "The United States and Canada," Hans Simons, 11 A. M.; "New York City: Welfare Service," Commissioner William Hodson, 8;20 P. M.

For the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. cross-country run on Monday, Nov. 14, at Van Cortlandt Park, a new five-mile course has been laid out, it was announced yesterday by Asa Bushnell, executive director of the Central Office for Eastern Intercollegiate Athletics.

Injuries may slow the Princeton eleven considerably when it meets Navy at Baltimore on Saturday, according to developments on University Field today. Coach Tad Wieman eased up on the first team, but kept the rest of his squad working hard against the Middies' plays.

The newspaper Gazzetta del Popolo today announced that kosher killings of animals for Jewish consumption had been prohibited in Italy. It said an order to that effect had been communicated by the government to local prefects in a "circular telegram."
The appointment of Dr. Alexander Loudon, the Netherland Minister in Berne, to Washington to succeed Jonkheer H. M. van Haersma de With, who is going to Berlin, is expected soon.

Thirty-one alleged members of a Dutchess County liquor ring, including two Federal revenue agents, a former justice of the peace said to have acted as its front, and members of the Sheriff's office, one of whom, a man from Hyde Park, was also county jailer, were named defendants in an indictment on file yesterday in Federal court.

Republican optimism increased yesterday as a result of the Rochester speech of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, candidate for Governor, the preceding evening. Telegrams and telephone calls to State Chairman William S. Murray, at the party headquarters, expressed gratification of hundreds of Republicans over Mr. Dewey's criticism of the New Deal as waste of the taxpayers' money.

After 119 years of continuous operation directed by members of the same family, Benedict Brothers, jewelers of 168 Fulton Street, will shut its doors and take down the clock over the entrance on Dec. 31. The decision to liquidate was announced yesterday, following a recent stockholders' meeting.

Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, will be the principal speaker at the twentyfifth annual Bankers Forum dinner to be held in the Hotel Astor on Dec. 1, it was announced yesterday by John A. Elbe, president of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Banking.
While John Strachey was being denied admittance to the United States, Blas Roca, general secretary of the Communist party in Cuba, entered this country unchallenged,.it became known yesterday.

The current week's total of engineering construction lettings, $65,224,000, shows a gain of 59 per cent over the same period of last year and is the fourteenth in succession to show improvement over 1937. The volume for the. same week of last year was $41,146,000.

A Vatican news service said that Pope Pius denounced the Nazis in Germany and Austria in a discourse today before several delegates to the Christian Arehaeological Congress. The Pope was said to have used "very strong language" in reference to events in Germany and Austria.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings, the reserve note circulation and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date, while total bills discounted for the system were at the lowest.
Henry Barstow Platt, who served during the World War as director of the Bureau of Personnel of the Atlantic Division of the Red Cross, died yesterday at his home, 535 Park Avenue, at the age of 78.

The League for Industrial Rights, an association of employers, was pictured yesterday as a "unionbusting, anti-labor group" and as a possible subject for investigation by Robert M. La Follette, chairman of the Senate Civil Liberties Investigating Committee.

Princess Olga Chagodalf of the Russian house of Chagodalf, was married to Jose R. Capablanca, commercial attache-at-large in Europe for the Cuban Government, here today. Eugenio Castillo, Cuban Consul in Baltimore, was best man.

The Rev. Dr. Moses Richardson Lovell, who succeeded the late Dr. S. Parkes Cadman as pastor of the Central. Congregational Church, Hancock Street and Franklin Avenue, Brooklyn, was formally installed there last night. In the afternoon he spoke at an ecclesiastical council of 300 representatives and clergymen of his denomination from the metropolitan area.

Samuel H. West, village blacksmith for sixty years and oldest member of the official board of the Setauket Methodist Episcopal Church, died yesterday at the home of his daughter, Mrs. James A. Van Brunt, at the age of 85. Mr.

Using gangsters as symbols and making his first direct reference to the Hines case in the campaign, Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate I for Governor, asked tonight for an end of the "Democratic political monopoly" in the State.

Armed police early today raided the offices of the "Danish Socialist party," one of several small mutually warring Nazi factions in Copenhagen. Twelve youths, including a "Fuehrer," Vilfred Petersen, 33, were taken to Police Headquarters and charged with blackmail.

American Trusteed Funds, Inc., New York City, an investment trust, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 557,114 Lexington Trust Fund Shares certificates to be offered first to holders of Lexington Foundation certificates in exchange for Trusteed Industry shares at current issue price and then at the market.

The general level of wholesale prices declined in the week ended on Oct. 15, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, which is based on the 1926 average as 100, was 77.7, compared with 77.8 on Oct. 8 and 85.2 on Oct. 16 a year ago.

Preliminary steps toward establishing the first minimum wage under the Fair Labor Standards Act, which goes into effect Monday, were taken today by Elmer F. Andrews, Administrator, when he asked leaders of the textile industry to report on the probable effects of the law.

The Priceman Building Corp has obtained from an insurance company a first mortgage loan of $205,000 for ten years at 5 per cent on the six-story apartment house at 82 to 104 Ave P. Brooklyn. The Empire Title Guarantee Co and Punia Marx arranged the loan.
Head Coach Ducky Pond today made three changes in the Yale line-up used in the fast scrimmaging of yesterday and Tuesday. The three shifts were in the line.
The General Brokers Association, an organization of several hundred insurance brokers in this city, will hold its thirteenth annual dinner next Wednesday in the Hotel Astor.

Two plans under which retailers of alcoholic beverages in this State may liquidate back debts said to aggregate $4,000,000, were laid before distillers, brewers, their wholesalers and retailers, yesterday by Henry E. Bruckman, chairman of the State Liquor Authority at a closed meeting at the Authority's headquarters here.
The Commercial Credit Company reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $2,086,393 for the third quarter of 1938, after all deductions, equal after preferred dividends, to $1.06 a common share.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick has invited bankers to submit bids at noon on Monday for $6,000,000 of New York City 41/2 per cent assessment bonds held by the city's pension funds. The issue, dated Jan.

On police surgeon's certificate--To take effect 12 midnight Oct. 19. DEPUTY CHIEF INSPECTOR--Edward A. Bracken, 19th Division, office of chief inspector, at $3,150 per annum. Appointed Sept. 22, 1905.
Authorization to list 253,450 common shares of the Panhandle Producing and Refining Company was withdrawn yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.

It begins to look like a Republican year: the movies are saying nice things about the Junior League again. Over Rockefeller way, at the Music Hall, "The Mad Miss Manton" is establishing the civic sense of the gay Park Avenue set. Oh,
The Southern California Edison Company, Ltd., reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30 a net income of $11,165,254 after all operating expenses, taxes and charges.

Opening of the 1938-39 raw fur season will see materially higher prices than a year ago for muskrat, skunk and mink, according to the survey issued yesterday by the United Fur Brokers, Inc. The brokerage organization reported prospects for a good season appear

Ernest Dimnet, French author and lecturer, declared yesterday that freedom of the press in the United States was one of the remaining bright rays in a darkening world. On his arrival on the French liner Champlain for his annual lecture tour, Abbe Dimnet discussed the recent European crisis and said that the people of Europe never really understood what was happening around -them until the American newspapers arrived, days after it was all over.

Colgate's Red Raiders went through a short workout today and then entrained for Iowa City, where on Saturday they meet Iowa's Hawkeyes in an intersectional contest. The Maroon had the customary kicking and passing drill and then Coach Andy Kerr sent his charges through a dummy signal session to polish the Maroon offensive repertoire.

" Journey of Tapiola," Robert Nathan's forthcoming novel, will be published in England by Constable, who has acquired the rights from Knopf. This story of the Yorkshire terrier's adventures will be published Oct. 31.

Facilities of the new Rutgers Stadium were used for the first time today when Coach Harvey Harman sent his Scarlet charges through their practice paces at the new site to familiarize them with the surroundings.

Increases of wages amounting to more than $300,000 annually were announced today to the 5,500 employes of the Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc., here by Donald W. Douglas, president. They are 21/2 cents an hour, retroactive to Oct. 1.

A reception in honor of Professor Harry D. Gideonse, newly appointed head of the department of economics end social sciences at Barnard College, and Mrs. Gideonse will be given this afternoon by Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve at 4 o'clock in the deanery, on the campus. Trustees of the college,

P. S. Chase, president of the Chase Brass and Copper Company, Inc., was yesterday elected president of the Copper and Brass Research Association, at its seventeenth annual meeting, held at the Hotel Biltmore. John A. Coe, president of the American Brass Company; C. D. Dallas,

Twenty persons, including five women, were arrested as a result of a riot early yesterday morning at the plant of the Aerovox Corporation, 70 Washington Street, Brooklyn, where more than 400 strikers, non-strikers and policemen engaged for half an hour in an egg-throwing, fist-swinging melee growing out of a nine-week strike.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The character of the-Republican nominations has injected a new spirit of courage and optimism into the campaign. They will tend to raise the plane of the discussion to a higher level and to clarify and make manifest the importance of this election to the people of the State.

Fred W. Frahm, superintendent of the Detroit Police Department, told the House committee investigating unAmerican activities today that he believed 75 per cent of the strikes in Detroit in the last two years had been inspired by Communists.

Two amateur gunmen entered the jewelry shop of R. W. Johnston, Inc., in the lobby of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday, where few seasoned crooks would dare to go, and robbed three men of about $6,000 worth of jewelry.

F. O. Pierce Company, Brooklyn, manufacturer of paints and varnishes, which applied for reorganization under Section 77b of the National Bankruptcy Act in March, 1937, has been successfully reorganized through the purchase of capital stock by Harry R. Hillman,

With the establishment of a flying physician at Alice Springs capital of Central Australia, aerial medical services based on Wyndham, Port Hedland, Kalgoorlie, Broken Hill, Cloncurry and Alice Springs will cover every sparsely settled area in the Commonwealth.

Paul B. Kellogg, president of the National Conference of Social Work, saw to it tonight that no lapse took place in the nonpassivity record of the State Conference on Social Work, which is in session here.

In the first change of ownership in more than half a century the five-story flat at 778 Ninth Avenue, southeast corner of Fifty-second Street, and the adjoining two fourstory houses at 366 and 368 West Fifty-second Street were sold by Leonard Denner to the 778 Ninth Avenue Corporation.

Captain Edward A. Levy, JAG-Res., 77 Pennington Ave., Passaic, N. J., is relieved from assignment to Headquarters 78th Division, and is assigned to C.A.S.U. 1235. He is further assigned therein to the position of Judge Advocate General, headquarters, third Military Area.

Henry Cluci of Fresh Meadow and Tony Longo of Inwood each downed a champion yesterday to gain the final round of the Long Island P. G. A. tournament over the course of the Bayside links. Ciuci defeated Jifmmy Hines of Lakeville, metropolitan open titleholder, as well as defender in this tourney, by 2 and 1, while Longo stopped Al Brosch of Bethpage, metropolitan P. G. A. ruler, by 3 and 1.

Meeting, Woman's Forum, Hotel Roosevelt, 11 A. M. Speakers: William S. Bennet, Mrs. John S. Sheppard, Helen Varick Boswell. Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street, 11:30 A. M. "Current Events," George Earle Raiguel.

The New York University football team will engage in nine games next year, it was announced by Albert B. Nixon, graduate manager of athletics, who released the schedule yesterday. The season will open with Colgate on Sept. 30 at Hamilton, N. Y., and will close on Thanksgiving Day, Nov. 30, with the traditional contest against Fordham at the Yankee Stadium.

An Italian crew has arrived at Casablanca to take back to Italy one of two Savoia-Marchetti airplanes that on July 30, 1936, were forced down in French Morocco while en route to Spain a few days after the outbreak of the civil war.
While the momentum of the Japanese advance in South China has carried the invaders within twenty miles of Canton, a mass retreat of the Chinese forces in the Yangtze Valley seems impending.
The Dartmouth squad coasted today after a strenuous week of practice, and a long signal session finished practice on Memorial Field for the Harvard game.

The Ladies Auxiliary of Manhattan College will hold its annual Fall tea on the campus of the college next Tuesday afternoon, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. James E. Dougherty, president of the auxiliary.
The 15 per cent tax on gold exported from Cuba was suspended today by Presidential decree in an attempt to encourage the development of mining properties believed to contain large gold deposits.

One important element has been overlooked in the forecasts of what is going to happen in Southeastern Europe as the result of the German conquest of Austria and the Sudetenland. Certain obvious consequences are stressed:

The construction industry, conference heard Thomas S. Holden, vice president of the F. W. Dodge Corporation, assert today that growth in the utility industry was to be expected largely as the result of supplying more power at decreased cost.

The American International Corporation reported yesterday that its net assets amounted to $19,258,016 on Sept. 30, or $1,930.82 for each $1,000 of debentures and $9.28 for each share of common stock outstanding. This compared with $17,453,422, or $1,745.34 and $7.45 respectively on Dec. 31, 1937. On Oct.
The United States Army team led Chilean and Mexican rivals in the first day events of the Inter-American Horse Show today.

Harry Stein, veteran quarterback of the City College football team, will be at his accustomed post tomorrow when the Lavender meets lar Brooklyn College at the Kingsmen's stadium in the seventh renewal of their gridiron rivalry.

Sir Earl Page, Acting Prime Minister, has informed the House of Representatives that proposals for a national attack on problems of defense development will be considered at a meeting of the Australian Loan Council here tomorrow. The appointment of an advisory committee of representatives of the government and industry has been suggested to the States to aid the Council.

A renewed heavy decline in the volume of commercial loans and- a somewhat large gain in brokers' loans were disclosed for the week ended on Wednesday by reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City in their statement of condition issued yesterday.

Robert J. Stokes, president and general manager of the Joseph Stokes Rubber Company here, died last night of a heart attack at his home on the Lawrenceville-Princeton Road. He was 54 years old. Mr. Stokes was the son of the late W. J. B. Stokes, long a prominent rubber manufacturer and former president of the Thermold Rubber Company. The younger Mr.
Boris Romanoff, the new ballet director of the Metropolitan Opera Association, arrived yesterday on the French liner Champlain to take over the work of developing the opera's ballet.

In a ruling denouncing what he termed a "faked labor dispute" created for the sole purpose of evading a previous court injunction, Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo gave jail sentences of five to thirty days and fines of $100 to $250 yesterday to four pickets and the business manager of the Window Trimmers Union, Local 144, affiliated with the C. I. O.

Columbia's training for the Penn game reached the climax yesterday at Baker Field as -the varsity repulsed a slashing "Penn" attack as shown by the freshman team in a ninety-minute scrimmage. The squad will leave this morning at 10 o'clock for Philadelphia and will hold a light signal drill on Franklin Field this afternoon.

The American Woolen Company announced yesterday advances of 5 cents a yard on several men's wear fabrics, including gabardines, series and fancies, and it was reported that several other concerns also were making advances.

On election night in 1916 the New York newspapers, finding that the Eastern States were giving majorities to Charles E. Hughes, issued extra editions announcing his election. Further West many newspapers did not issue such editions because they were watching the returns from Ohio.
Those of us who are sometimes fatigued by the humor of the exorbitant children who run The Harvard Lampoon are finding a deep satisfaction in the genuine comic spirit of the Cambridge City Council.

Walter H. Liebman, Democratic opponent of Representative Bruce Barton in the Seventeenth Congressional District, in a speech last night to the Roland Society at the Hotel Peter Stuyvesant described the New Deal as the embodiment of "true conservatism."

In the Supreme Court of the United States today the following cases were argued: 1-General Talking Pictures Corporation, petr., v. Western Electric Company, Inc. et al. 29-The Polk Company, Bruce's Juices, Inc. et al., applts., v. Manuel M. Glover, as County Solicitor of Polk County, Fla..
Lumber output rose less than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index declined to 74.7 from 75.1. The figure was 76.9 for the week ended Oct. 16, 1937.

Gross revenues of the Southern Railway in the first two weeks of the current month were about $50,000 greater than the corresponding total last year, Ernest E. Norris, president, made known yesterday. September gross was estimated at about $8,250,000, an increase of $77,000 from September, 1937.

The Houdry Process Corporation announced yesterday that the engineering and construction firm of E. B. Badger Sons Company of Boston would act as licensing agent for its processes for increasing the amount of high octane gasoline recoverable from crude oil.
Mayor Leo E. J. Carney, seventeen members of the New Bedford City Council and two others were named in indictments returned today by the Bristol County grand jury.

The statement of the Glenn L. Martin Company for the third quarter of this year, released for publication today, shows a net income of $768,393 after all expenses, taxes and charges. The net is equal to 82 cents each on 936,583 shares outstanding. On the same basis,

Testifying at the first hearing to be held under the new Wage and Hour Act, officials of the Western Union Telegraph Company declared yesterday that unless its application for exemption under the provisions of the act is granted it will have to discharge 3,125 of its messenger boys.

The marriage of Miss Janie Elizabeth Igoe, daughter of Mrs. Joseph A. Igoe of 322 East Seventeenth Street, Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Igoe, to Dr. Henry George Wehmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Cort Wehmann, also of Brooklyn, took place yesterday morning in the Catholic Church of the Holy Innocents in Brooklyn.

Buyers placed orders for a wide variety of wool goods this week as the market turned active, according to the weekly summary prepared yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service. Mills set higher prices on some lines of goods, notably tropical worsteds, and prepared to extend the advances to Spring goods, which have Just been opened.

Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, said tonight that the business outlook for the near future "holds promise of further improvement." He addressed the annual banquet of the American Association for Metals, in convention here.

James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, gave Pennsylvania New Dealers a "party loyalty" talk tonight in which he declared that the Republicans' only hope at the Nov. 8 election was "that some form of Democratic disunion" would give them a look-in.

Sir Samuel Hoare, Home Minister, produced today a brand new explanation of why Britain is rearming so furiously just after her Prime Minister has signed a declaration of peace and friendship with the dictator of Germany.

European politics are changing so rapidly that the map-makers are forced to issue interim editions. The Edward Stanford Company has just issued a new edition of their map of Central Europe showing the areas recently transferred from Czechoslovakia to Germany.

The American-born former Countess of Carrick was married today to the fourth Baron Chesham. The Earl of Carrick married Miss Margaret Power Drum of Helena, Mont., in Franklin, N. J., yesterday. Baron Chesham was divorced last year.

Columbia's cross-country schedule, listing five runs, was announced yesterday by Reynolds Benson, Athletics manager. Six dual contests will be determined in two of the runs, the Lions racing Army, Navy and Princeton tomorrow at Van Cortlandt Park, and Yale, Dartmouth and Cornell over the same course the following Saturday.

The World's Fair here next year will be utilized as a springboard for the introduction of many new products, it was indicated yesterday. Some of the new items are now ready, but will not be introduced until the fair opens.

Fred O. Cosgrove and Ernest G. Giamais have been elected vice presidents of the Knott Corporation, hotel operator. Frederick Posses, who has just been admitted to the bar, has been appointed general counsel to Herman Brickman, impartial chairman of the laundry industry. Previously he was Mr. Brickman's technical adviser.

The board of officers of the defunct International Seamen's Union, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor until the latter body canceled its charter last week, has been reorganized as a labor body independent of both the C. I. O. and A. F. of L.

Thirty-eight WPA workers, all firm believers in the principle that a laborer may wield a pick or a shovel, but never both on the same job, walked off a ditch-digging project yesterday when their superiors ordered them to use picks and shovels interchangeably.

Livestock trading improved today, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Lambs were mostly 25c higher and hogs also were up. Part of the improvement was evidently due to cooler weather. Fed steer and yearling demand was stronger, but prices were not measureably higher.

George J. Schaefer, until recently general manager of distribution for United Artists in the United States and Canada, in scheduled to become today president of the RadioKeith-Orpheum Corporation following the expected resignation of Leo Spitz, which is to be considered at a meeting of the board of directors late this afternoon.

After a member of the Cambridge City Council had been kicked today by a Harvard student during a scuffle, Harvard College authorities banned undergraduate demonstrations burlesquing the City Council's plan for divorcing Harvard University from the city of Cambridge.

With all of the 2,000 towboat workers in the harbor, who went on strike last Friday, back at work yesterday, under the settlement promoted by Mayor La Guardia, negotiations for a final agreement between the New York Towboat Exchange, the employers' organization, and Local 333A of the International Longshoremen's Association were begun at the office of the exchange, 17 Battery Place.

The address on the navy and merchant marine delivered in London last night by Joseph P. Kennedy, the United States Ambassador, at the annual Trafalgar Day dinner of the Navy League was known in advance at the State Department.

The W. Sergeant Bouvier Memorial Cup of Columbia College, which is given annually to a member of the freshman crew who "has best exhibited the qualities of college loyalty, self-discipline and improvement in watermanship," was awarded to Arthur Stuart Clarke of Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday by Dean Herbert E. Hawkes.

The re-election of John A. Remon of Washington, D. C., as president and commodore of the American Power Boat Association, ruling body of the sport, brought to a close yesterday at the Hotel Lexington four days of speed-boat meetings. Reports of the year's activities were read, and now the boating interests will begin preparations for the national annual show in New York in January.

General Mario Berti, Commander in Chief of the Italian forces in Spain, and about 10,000 survivors of the original Legionnaires who went to Spain more than eighteen months ago received a magnificent reception on reaching Italian soil here today.
Heavy selling, said to have been speculative in character, yesterday sent the pound sterling and other important currencies sharply lower in the foreign-exchange market.

The Census Bureau reported today that the cotton spinning industry operated during September at 72.8 per cent of capacity on an eightyhour-week basis, compared with 76.2 per cent during August, this year, and 82.3 per cent during September last year.

Governor A. Harry Moore, Mayor Frank Hague, Mayor Bernard F. McFeely, seventy priests and eight monsignori were among 2,000 persons who attended the funeral for Mgr. Eugene P. Carroll, pastor of Our Lady of Grace Church here, today. Mgr. Carroll died on Sunday.
Sir John Home, twelfth Baronet of Blackadder, a director in the National Bank of Egypt and many other Egyptian companies, died yesterday at the age of 66.

Michael Rosenker, violinist, will appear in recital at the Town Hall tonight. A large musical and tea for the Metropolitan Opera Guild will be given by Mrs. Carl H. Pforzheimer at her home in Purchase, N. Y., this afternoon.

To the British Poet Laureate, John Masefield, has been awarded the Hamburg University Shakespeare Prize amounting to [pound]800, with a diploma awarded annually to the most eminent Englishman in the field of science and art.

A part of the original Peter Stuyvesant farm on the East Side that came down to the seller by inheritance passed to new control yesterday when the Margaret Folsom Corporation sold the property at 171 East Second Street to Sophie Einschlag. Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc.. were the brokers.

Following is the text of the prepared speech of Thomas E. Dewey here tonight: Ladies and Gentlemen of Oneida County: Tonight we meet in a campaign to revitalize the government of the State of New York. Last night in Convention Hall in Rochester I told a vast crowd that once more the drums of victory are beating along the Mohawk.

Michigan's sit-down strikes are figuring prominently in the Gubernatorial campaign as former Governor Frank D. Fitzgerald, Republican, criticizes Governor Frank Murphy, Democrat, for his handling of the labor situation.

A Hallowe'en dinner dance will be given at the Nassau Country Club here on Oct. 29. Members of the committee are Mrs. Warren Brewster. Mrs. Leon Abbett, Mrs. Jeremiah Clark, Mrs. Robert Burdick, Mrs. C. M. De Land Jr.,
Political talks scheduled for broadcasting over local stations today are: Mrs. Emily Newell Blair, former vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee, WABC, 6:45 to 7 P. M.

Cat owners desiring to dispose of unwanted cats were asked yesterday by the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, 50 Madison Avenue, not to turn them out on the streets. Warning that stray cats face severe hardships,

George Washington Kramer, who during a fifty-five year career as an architect designed more than 2,200 churches and many public buildings, died here today in his home at the age of 91. Born in Ashland, Ohio, Mr. Kramer left school at the age of 16 to study architecture in-the employ of a contractor.

Miss Harriet Van Vechten Van Wyck, daughter of Mrs. James R. Van Wyck of this place and the late Mr. Van Wyck, was married here this evening to Minott A. Osborn of New York, son of the late Colonel and Mrs. Norris J. Osborn of New Haven, Conn.

The appointment of Arthur H. Radasch, New York chemical engineer, as head of the. Department of Chemical Engneering at Cooper Union with the rank of professor was announced yesterday. He succeeds Dr. Albert B. Neawman, who resigned to head the Chemical Engineering Department of City College.

Israel W. Stout, retired contractor, died today at the home of his son, Chauncey F. Stout of 511 East Front Street, publisher of The Plainfield Courier News. Born in Virginia ninety-three years ago, Mr. Stout passed most of his life in New Jersey.

Coach Jimmy Crowley read an angry lecture to his Fordham football squad yesterday as they made ready for the intersectional battle with the University of Oregon at the Polo Grounds tomorrow. Jimmy's wrath was stirred when he watched moving pictures of the Fordham-Purdue game, which disclosed slipshod tackling by the Rams in the Boilermakers' secondhalf touchdown march.

Lack of a breeze brought an abrupt halt today to the race between the American schooner Gertrude L. Thebaud, challenger for the International Fishermen's Trophy, and the Canadian salt banker defender, Bluenose, but tonight a storm of charges and counter charges whistled through GloucesIter.

Mrs. Marion Reid Dudley of this city and Camden, Me., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Carol Reid Dudley, to Peter Patrullo Prichett, son of Mrs. William Cresson Prichett of Newark and the late Mr. Prichett of Philadelphia.

Gathering in a distinctly optimistic atmosphere, members of the Tanners Council of America met for their twenty-second annual meeting here today and admitted that the biggest obstacle to a reasonable degree of prosperity in the industry was the reluctance of the consumer to pay higher prices for shoes. Statistically,

Trial Decisions The following members having been tried before Francis X. Giaccone, Deputy Fire Commissioner, on Oct. 10, 1938, for violation of Rules and Regulations, 1937. the following decisions are rendered by the Fire Chief and Commiseioner:
The text of Governor Herbert H. Lehman's order for investigation of Kings County law enforcement agencies to Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. follows:

Charged with resisting an order to surrender their monastery, sixteen Franciscan monks today were sent to jail by a Salzburg court. A portion of the monastery was requisitioned for Gestapo [State Police] purposes, effective Oct. 12. The. monks refused to comply on Oct. 13.

All political activities of the Communist party were suspended throughout the Czech areas of the republic tonight and Communist newspapers were suppressed. This action was taken despite the fact that no revolution had been attempted here by the Communists. It followed the return of Foreign Minister Frantisek Chvalkovsky from his visit to Chancellor Adolf Hitler.

Seventy employes of the Ruberold Company who have been with the company continuously for twentyfive years or more received gold emblems yesterday as part of the concern's observance of its fiftysecond anniversary. Thirteen former employes, now on retirement pensions, also received emblems.

Sales of 1,257 jewelry stores throughout the country, which had a total volume of $47,727,000 in 1937, were off 14.5 per cent in the first half of 1938, as compared with the same period of 1937, according to a survey of the Bureau of the Census of the Department of Commerce.

C. L. McCuen, general manager of the Oldsmobile Division of General Motors Corporation, announced today that production schedules of the Olds Factories here had been revised upward for the third time since 1939 models were first shown to distributors, and that 51,000 of the new cars would be produced by Jan. 1.

According to the government mouthpiece, the Nacion, Minister of Finance Francisco Garces Gana is now giving the finishing touches to the text of a message to be sent to Congress with the idea of drawing foreign capital into Chile.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company filed yesterday plans for two eight-story tenement houses in its development on the old Catholic Protectory grounds in the Bronx. Each structure will cost $600,000, according to the plans by Richmond Shreve, the architect.

The Union Pacific Railroad will be in the market later this year for rails to be laid next Spring, according to W. M. Jeffers, president. He said the program for this year would be completed next month, by which time 300 miles will have been laid.

A major upheaval in the economic position of Japan through loss of its huge market in the United States for raw silk was predicted by hosiery producers here yesterday when Celanese Corporation of America, manufacturer of acetateprocess yarns and fabrics, announced plans for erecting near Pearlsburg, Va., a $10,000,000 plant for production of an entirely new synthetic yarn that can be used in all textile fields.

Both the Giants and the Dodgers, guards, pointing for their interborough game at the Polo Grounds on Sunday, put in intensive sessions yesterday. The Giants, at the Polo Grounds, did more than two and a half hours of thorough work. Their opponents at Freeport, L. I., practiced more than three hours.

The Ebro bridgehead was quiet when your correspondent visited the sector today. The trip was convincing as to the government's defensive success there, for the writer saw how little terrain the Insurgents had regained after a series of costly attacks.

Miss Jane Parks, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elton Parks of 510 Park Avenue, this city, and Katonah, .N. Y., and DeWitt Peterkin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Peterkin of Garden City, L. I., were married here yesterday afternoon in St. James's Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street.

With an attack on government and on the law schools, which, he charged, have failed to keep pace with the progress of the medical profession, Mayor La Guardia laid the cornerstone yesterday of the new $1,500,000 building of the New York Medical College, Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals at 105th Street and Fifth Avenue.

The New York concerns of John Tuman Sons, Inc., and L. E. Stirn, Inc., located at 1,400 Broadway, today agreed with stipulations with the Federal Trade Commission requiring more accurate labeling of a velvet-like fabric composed in whole or in part of rayon.

Federal Judge Edward A. Conger yesterday signed a writ of habeas corpus calling for the production next Tuesday in court of John Strachey, the English writer and lecturer, who is being held on Ellis Island, having been excluded from the United States on the ground that he is a Communist.

Inspired by their devotion to the Holy Eucharist, a great stream of devout Catholics, 100,000 strong, paraded through the streets of this traditional stronghold of the faith this afternoon and evening to bring to a triumphant close the eighth National Eucharistic Congress.

Resentful over the action of the majority members of the Board of Estimate in sending questionnaires to 289 candidates for the State Senate and Assembly asking them to record their views on legislation affecting the city, Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx said yesterday that he would query the Mayor and his colleagues "on who they are going to support for Governor."

At the conclusion of the workout at Lehigh today Coach Harmeson stated that six sophomores are likely to start against Delaware Saturday. Included are Stan Grossman and Jerry Hubney, tackles; Bill Hauserman, guard; Walter Prelle, center; Bob Walker, quarterback and Emery Loomis, halfback.

Dubonnet, owned by J. Hornung, became favorite tonight for next Wednesday's Cesarewitch when the cards were called over at the Victoria Club. Dubonnet's new odds were 10-to-1, compared with 13-to-1 previously when he was second choice.

The Sedgburn Realty Corporation has sold to an investing client of Thomas K. Saltzman, attorney; the five - and- a - half - story apartment house at 1,955 Sedgwick Avenue, assessed at $125,000. The house contains 140 rooms and is on a plot 163 by 74 by 127 by 86 feet.

An exhibition consisting of work produced by artists in the four main creative divisions of the Federal Art Project, WPA, opens today at the Federal Art Gallery, 225 West Fifty-seventh Street. Known as the "Four Unit Exhibition," it includes paintings in oil, water-colors, prints, sculpture and murals.

The twenty-first anniversary of the entry of the first American troops into the trenches on the Western Front in France during the World War will be celebrated today at Fort Hamilton, Governors Island, Fort Wadsworth and other army posts where First Division troops are now stationed.

Unanimous endorsement of James H. Fay, Democratic candidate for Congress in the Sixteenth District of Manhattan, against Representative John J. O'Connor, who lost the primary fight for renomination on the Democratic ticket but won the Republican designation, was voted by the Central Trades and Labor Council, representing 600,000 A. F. of L. members in this city, at a meeting in Beethoven Hall, 210 East Fifth Street, last night.

Mutual courtesy should be an aim of salesmen and buyers, Vactor Chambers, ready-to-wear merchandise manager of the Associated Merchandising Corporation, said last night in a talk before the Garment Salesmen's Guild at the Hotel Piccadilly.

Wtih the end of the account approaching, business in the stock markets here was quiet today and movements were small, although generally favoring holders. Gilt-edged issues held overnight gains. A feature of the stronger foreign bonds was a fresh rise in Czech issues. German units,

The Rev. Thomas David Richards, retired Presbyterian clergyman, died today. He was graduated from Wooster University and Princeton Seminary and had served at Nealsville Presbyterian Church, in Washington City Presbytery, for thirty years.

Lurting Ave (15-4304) e s, 120 ft s of Esplanade, 50x100 ft: May B. Hall to Ellen Murray, 2,110 Lurting Ave. Ludlow Ave (14-3727) n s, 75 ft e of St. Lawrence Ave, 25x100 ft, also St. Lawrence Ave, e s, 100 ft n of Ludlow Ave, 25x100 ft; Susette Abraham to Henry Dilg, 2,165 Eastern Blvd.

Fordham's varsity basketball schedule for the coming season was announced yesterday by John F. Coffey, graduate manager of athletics. The Rams, once again under the tutelage of Ed Kelleher after a four-year interim, will meet seventeen opponents.

Walter S. Gifford, 53-year-old president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, was recovering last night from an operation for acute appendicitis at the New York Hospital. His condition was reported as "very good."

Arthur M. Fischel of this town, founder of the Irvington B'nai B'rith Lodge and prominent in Jewish activities in this area, collapsed in a Newark restaurant last night while entertaining Dr. Isadore Rosenthal of Lancaster, Pa., past president of the Grand Lodge, and died later in Beth Israel Hospital, Newark.

Officials of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad have begun negotiations with large holders of an issue of an $45,350,000 of Chicago Alton Railroad refunding 3 per cent bonds due in 1949 for a reduction in interest on the obligations.

The controversy between the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Corporation and the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line Company over control of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company broke out anew yesterday, when it was disclosed that the directors of Panhandle Eastern had voted to rescind, as of Nov. 30, the transferable warrant now held by the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line

The British Cabinet is confronted with the problem of consenting to appreciable concessions to the United States on a few important products or risking the defeat of efforts of the past year to conclude a reciprocal trade agreement between the United States on the one hand and the United Kingdom and British colonial possessions, apart from the dominions, on the other.
Turpentine firm, 23 1/2c: sales 14 barrels: receipts 247 barrels: shipments, 357 barrels; stock, 50,464 barrels. Rosin firm: sales. 151: receipts. 1,371; shipments. 715; stock, 269,524.
Automotive News in its midweek survey of activity in the motor manufacturing industry today placed the current week's production at 62,727 units, compared with last week's 45,506, and 88,315 a year

JOHN STRACHEY'S new book is published today. And, of course, the fact that Mr. Strachey is by now about the most celebrated guest Ellis Island has entertained in decades has given the event an importance the book could scarcely have expected in any other time.

Conrad (Connie) Immerman, manager of the La Conga night club at 57 West Fifty-seventh Street, Manhattan, pleaded not guilty when arraigned before County Judge Cortland A. Johnson here today on an indictment charging him with maintaining a gambling room at the richly appointed Surfside Club, Atlantic Beach, which District Attorney Edward J. Neary raided on Sept. 1.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Nina M. Summ of this city of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Edith Louise Summ, to Thomas Woodrow Eck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Eck of Allentown, Pa. Miss Summ attended Pratt Institute.

With a continuation of the non-contact work of the week, the Navy team had its last lengthy practice today for the game with Princeton Fin Baltimore Saturday. Pass defense and handling of kicks were the chief elements in the work of the day.

Seventy-three persons, many of them leaders of the Democratic party in New Mexico, were indicted here today by a Federal grand jury which has been investigating graft and corruption in the Works Progress Administration in this State. The indictments charged diversion of WPA funds, property and services to private uses; political discrimination against WPA employes, illegal political activities, and conspiracy to violate the WPA laws.

The Census Bureau reported today apparel wool stocks as of Sept. 24 totaled 147,279,000 pounds; carpet wool stocks, 26,782,000; top stocks, 26,208,000, and noils, 8,748,000. The estimates were made on a scoured basis, the bureau announced, and were believed to include over 96 per

The will of Pearl White, heroine of "The Perils of Pauline" of silent film fame, which was drawn on June 22, was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday. It provided for about $75,000 in charitable bequests and left about $5,000 for her employes.

The Rev. Archibald Main, Regius Professor of Ecclesiastical History at Glasgow University, has been nominated for Moderator of the Church of Scotland to succeed the Rev. James Black of Edinburgh. Professor Main, 61 years old, is a native of Partick, Glasgow.

From the Treasury's daily statement of Oct. 20 it appears that the gold in the Government's hands has for the first time passed $14,000,000,000. Last July much attention was paid to the passing of $13,000,000,000; the $12,000,000,000 mark was first reached in May, 1937. That is to say,

Frank Malcolm Farmer, vice president and chief engineer of the Electrical Testing Laboratories, New York, has been re-elected chairman of the Engineering Foundation, research organization of national engineering societies, according to an announcement yesterday.

Recent changes in the capital gains tax as it affects real estate deals, and decisions under the Federal Social Security Act defining the status of salesmen, were discussed yesterday by George P. Ellis, tax consultant to the National Association of Real Estate Boards, at a meeting of the Manhattan chapter of the association in the Hotel Commodore.
Although the volume of bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday was the largest for any week this year, the total was slightly below the corresponding period a year ago.
Creation of the Grain Exchange Institute to offer academic education in grain and its marketing was announced today by the Association of Grain Commission Merchants of the Chicago Board of Trade.

Daniel Lewis Esquirol of 30 Woodruff Avenue, Brooklyn, formerly for many years connected with the lithographic firm of Haywood Stresser, died yesterday in Midwood Sanatorium at the age of 69. He was born in Brooklyn and was an uncle of State Senator Joseph A. Esquirol and of the Rev. John H. Esquirol of the Cathedral of the Incarnation, Garden City.

Treasury purchases of gold, which aggregated $139,000,000 in the week and lifted the monetary gold stocks to a new record of $14,008,000,000 as of Wednesday, were partly responsible for the steep rise of $293,000,000 in member bank reserve balances. Only $220,000,000 of this gain was carried to excess reserves, rising deposits having increased reserve requirements.

Lawrence Tibbett, the Metropolitan baritone, returned to New York yesterday after completing a 32,000mile trip to Australia and New Zealand, where he made a fivemonth, record-breaking tour of fifty-five appearances.

A detailed analysis of the defects in spun rayon fabrics on which retailers have commented was presented to the spun rayon symposium of the American Society for Testing Materials at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday by Alexis Sommaripa, manager of the fabric development bureau of the rayon division of the du Pont Company.

Considerably superior to last year's eleven in all-around ability, the St. Mark's School football squad appears to have a good chance of continuing along Victory Lane to become the second unbeaten combination during Roland P. Sawyer's reign here as head coach.

During the week ended Oct. 19 member bank reserve balances increased $293,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases of $42,000,000 in Treasury cash, $94,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and $33,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts and

East and West Sides shared alike in the new apartment rentals announced yesterday by brokers and agents. In the Hotel Savoy-Plaza, Frederick Lonsdale, playwright, has leased quarters, while in the house at 131 Riverside Drive, the Apartment Locating Bureau rented a nine-room suite to Mrs. M. De Aya of Brazil.
John J. Watts's Merry Gesture, trained by Miss Mary Hirsch and carrying only ninety-six pounds, ran away with the fifth race, best event on a featureless card at Laurel today.

Mrs. Elizabeth Singer Proctor, daughter of the late W. H. Singer, one-time partner of Andrew Carnegie, left a net estate of $1,383,113 when she died May 21, 1937, at her E home at 630 Park Avenue, the transfer-tax appraisal showed yesterday.

Charging the Democratic party with the "exploitation of poverty for political purposes" in its handling of relief, Edward F. Corsi, Republican candidate for the short term in the United States Senate, declared today that the new liberal Republican party under Thomas E. Dewey was four square on the proposition that it was the duty of government to help those in need.

George Henry Tryon, vice president of Marsh McLennan, insurance brokerage firm, 70 Pine Street, New York, died today in his home here after a short illness. He was 72 years old. Born in Buffalo, Mr. Tryon started in the insurance business there with the Armstrong Agency.

There ought to be a rule to prevent head football coaches from masquerading as undergraduate players. It leads to embarrassing situations. For instance: Today it was our job to interview the new Pennsylvania coach. What's his name? Oh. you know. Munger.

Dr. Marvin A. Stevens has stopped looking around corners to see which opponent is on the list following the next game. A year ago he saw that Colgate was to be met after the Lafayette fray. So he pointed his N. Y. U. squad at the Red Raiders, overlooked the Maroon and then tripped over the Easton lads for an unexpected defeat.

The Interstate Commerce Commission instituted today on its own motion an investigation of railroad rates and charges in Idaho to determine if a refusal of the State's Public Utilities Commission to permit intrastate adjustment of rates to conform with recent passenger and freight rate increases ordered by the I. C. C. is injurious to interstate commerce.

The substitution of honey for sugar, rye bread and corn meal foods for wheat foods, and diluted grape juice and water for milk in the diet of children has been found in certain cases to act as effective aids to defective hearing, the clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons was told yesterday by Dr. James A. Babbitt of Philadelphia in a general review on medical and surgical aids to hearing.
Clem son routed South Carolina, 34 to 12, in their thirty-sixth annual football game today, but the breaks rather than the Tigers' vaunted power made the score so topheavy.

Mrs. Joel Ellis Fisher gave a dinner last evening in the Rainbow Boom, Rockefeller Center, for Baroness Robert de Foucaucourt of Paris and Mrs. John D. Little of Atlanta, Ga. Other guests were Mrs. Henry Darlington, the Rev. and Mrs. Gilbert Darlington,

A subcommittee of the law committee of the Association of American Railroads met yesterday in the Grand Central Terminal to consider proposals for amendments to Section 77 of the Bankruptcy Law, which applies to railroads, with a view to speeding railroad reorganizations.
The State Department stressed today that the fact that agents of foreign principals were required to register did not bring into question their loyalty to American principles.

More than 150 practitioners in the Sixteenth Congressional District formed yesterday Physicians, Surgeons and Dentists Committee to work for the re-election of Representative John J. O'Connor as "protection against the threat of regimentation of the medical profession."
The government's monetary gold stocks passed $14,000,000,000 on Tuesday, establishing a new high record, the Treasury announced today. On that day the Treasurys gold holdings reached $14,008,236,361.

Speaking amid the sumptuous surroundings of the newly reconditioned American Republics liner Uruguay, which sails tomorrow on its first voyage to South America, former Governor Alfred E. Smith recalled last night the days when he was a boy on the East Side and saw the clipper ships sail into New York Harbor from South American ports.

More than 1,000 travel agents from all parts of the country, as well as the wives of many of them, will attend the seventh annual convention of the American Steamship and Tourist Agents Association today at the Hotel McAlpin.

" Case History," a play about the medical profession and "a delicate problem" with which it has always been confronted, arrives tonight at the Lyceum under the sponsorship of a group of physicians who go by the corporate title of M.D. Productions, Inc. Unless the program errs, however, Jamess Troup, the firm's general manager, is the formal producer.
It looks as though you hunters had better start praying for rain, for until we get enough to wet down the forests your hunting is going to be prohibited.

Governor Lehman opened his up-State campaign for re-election tonight in this normally Republican city, a traditional starting point for Democratic campaigns, and gave a militant recital of the accomplishments of his Administration with a jibe at "spokesmen" of the Republicans, who, he said were attempting "to shed the cloak of reaction in an attempt to gain votes."

Mrs. Margaret S. Pedrick, the mother of Captain William J. Pedrick, president of the Fifth Avenue Association, died yesterday at her home, 814 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, after a long illness. She was in her eightieth year.
The election of Robert M. Catherine as executive vice president of the Dollar Savings Bank of the City of New York was announced yesterday by Howell T. Manson, president of the bank.

A political party should be tested by three standards: Its administrative record; the soundness of the legislation which it enacts; and the manner in which it has redeemed its promises to the people. By all of these standards the Democratic party in this State has met the test of service.
James M. Gifford, since 1883 a practicing attorney in New York, died yesterday in the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital after an operation. He was 82 years old and lived at 319 West 103d Street.

Howard P. Clements, retired passenger traffic manager of the Pullman Company, died last night in the Passavant Hospital after a short illness. His age was 77. Mr. Clements was born in Washington, D. C.,

Closer relations between Brazil and the United States were foreseen today as the liner Brazil received a rousing welcome here on her arrival inaugurating the "Good Neighbor Fleet" service to the east coast of South America under the direction of the United States Maritime Commission.

The Department of Commerce today announced issuance of the October number of its "Comparative Law" series, in which the leading article is devoted to an outline of Japanese taxes on business by Joseph H. Barkmeier.

The dollar volume of retail financing of new passenger automobiles in September showed a decrease of 21.5 per cent from August and 61 per cent from September, 1937, according to preliminary figures issued today by the Department of Commerce.

The merging of all Japanese political groups into a single National party, headed by Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye, which has been frequently discussed in the past few years, moved much closer to accomplishment yesterday. The Premier conferred with his Home, Justice and Welfare Ministers on this plan.
A special Canadian luncheon will be a feature of the National Foreign Trade Council's annual convention at the Hotel Commodore here, Oct. 31 to Nov. 2, it was announced yesterday. The luncheon,

A modified version of the proposed radio broadcast under retailer sponsorship is being submitted to merchants for their reactions, it was stated yesterday by officials of the Columbia Broadcasting System. This is the second time the suggested program has been submitted, this time with changes designed for an evening broadcast instead of on Sunday afternoon as originally suggested.

Planning a new "billion-dollar enterprise," the radio industry, through the board of directors of the Radio Manufacturers Association, announced at a meeting here yesterday that factories would be geared to build television receivers for home use in April.

A program for conducting a series of children's theatre conferences, which will include the first nationai amateur puppetry conference to be held in the United States, was completed yesterday by the directors of the Association of the Junior Leagues of America, now holding their October meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Bermuda's veteran legislator, Dr. Thomas H. Outerbridge, will cerebrate his ninety-first birthday today. He has served in the colony's Parliament since 1882, first in the Assembly until 1926 and since then in the Legislative Council--probably record legislalative service in the British Empire.

Considerable strengthening and expansion of the naval base in Hawaii and establishment of- naval air bases in Alaska and Puerto Rico are expected to be the principal recommendations of the naval board recently appointed to study the navy's base facilities.

Although Eastern gridirons furnished Saturday's biggest consignment of grief for the form pickers, the football returns to date in this section have been more in accordance with preconceived notions than have those of any other geographical division.

An agreement by the three committees for holders of bonds of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway, in bankruptcy proceedings, for a new plan of reorganization was announced yesterday. The plan makes provisions neither for the unsecured creditors nor for stockholders of the Frisco.

Charles C. Conant, formerly president of the Journal Publishing Company and the Service Corporation, both of Troy, N. Y., died here today at the home of his daughter, Mrs. A. H. Gillespie, after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

Fears of fascist progress in South America are exaggerated, in the opinion of exporters who yesterday attended a round-table discussion of foreign markets at the regular monthly meeting of the Overseas Automotive Club in the Hotel Lincoln.

In a dramatic speech before the Kings County Grand Jurors Association, Martin W. Littleton, former District Attorney of Nassau County and a lifelong Republican, made a vigorous defense of Governor Herbert H. Lehman's crime investigation record, and praised William F. X. Geoghan, the Brooklyn District Attorney who is under fire, as "an honorable gentleman."

Commenting yesterday on a statement by Nathan Straus, Administrator of the United States Housing Authority, promising cooperation with the New York City Housing Authority in land purchases where the cost exceeds the .general limit of $1.50 a square foot which has been set by the USHA for slumclearance and low-rent housing
L. C. Steele of Fredonia, N. Y., was elected today a vice president and director of the Cudahy Packing Company. He succeeds C. G. Marhoff. who resigned because of illness.
Capitalizing upon the world's interest in war, Paramount today announced plans for "Invasion," based upon an idea by Captain William F. Cox of the Chemical Warfare Division of the army.

The Securities and Exchange Commission asked the Federal court today to compel three officials of Recources Corporation International, owner of Mexican timberlands, to testify and produce records relative to an application for registration of 35,000 shares of stock held by Harper S. Hoover, chairman of the board.

The Rev. Vincent William Palazzo, assistant pastor of St. Margaret's Catholic Church here, died in the rectory yesterday of a heart attack. He was 59 years old. Father Palazzo was born in Sarno, Italy, and was ordained on March 19, 1904, in the cathedral at Naples.

The feud between Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, and William F, Carey, Sanitation Commissioner, over dumping operations flared up again yesterday at the Board of Estimate meeting in City Hall, when the board was requested to decide whether to permit the dumping to continue, or whether to drop it to protect Mr. Moses' new boat basins near the World's Fair grounds on Flushing Bay.

Growth of consumer cooperatives in this country will depend largely upon the action taken by business men themselves, Wilford L. White, chief of the Maiketing Research Division of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce,

Borough President James J. Lyons, Supreme Court Justice Albert Cohn and County Judge Harry Stackell of the Bronx were speakers at exercises last night of Adolph S. Ochs Memorial, Post 1207, of the American Legion, marking the presentation of the post colors by Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger, daughter of Mr. Ochs.

A hearing will be held on Monday at the law offices of Javits Javits, 165 Broadway, regarding the corporate organization and control of the General Investment Corporation. J. K. Javits, counsel for shareholders who have instituted proceedings against former officers of General Investment, will question Frederick S. Burroughs, the former president, as the first witness. Mr.

The Chase National Bank, New York, filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission a brief defending a proposal by an examiner of the commission that a note of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad held by the bank be replaced upon reorganization of the railroad by a new note maturing in ten years.
Miss Anne Stewart will be presented to society on Dec. 21 at the Essex County Country Club at a supper dance to be given by her Parents, Mr. and Mrs. Warren Trusdell Stewart of this place.

The apartment house containing fourteen suites and three stores at 1,159 Carroll Street, corner of Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn, was sold by I. M. Kalt to an investing client of Pillion Voss, brokers. The structure is on a plot 27.9 by 100 feet and was reported held at $59,000.

Placing emphasis on ball handling, Army went through a long passing drill in the rain today, with Coach Bill Wood alternating tailbacks and ends to give all ball handlers as much work as possible. The cadets continued to work on the plays to be used against Notre Dame next week, and the B squad carried the ball several times to test the varsity defense. Boston University,

The American Federation of Labor lost two petitions filed with the National Labor Relations Board in a decision rendered today denying it the right to represent two groups of employes of toy factories in New York.

A prominent leader in the German steel industry, Dr. Arthur Schmolz, is visiting Chilean markets in the course of an intense trade survey. It was admitted today that German industries are interested in extending their contacts with the South American countries and they believe that this is likely in the near future.

Realty interests generally, and small property owners and storekeepers in the northeast section of the Bronx particularly, received with interest yesterday the announcement that the City Planning Commission had decided to limit the new residential zone in their neighborhood to the boundaries of the vast garden apartment community which the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company is building there.
The overture to Weber's "Freisphutz" opened the ninety-seventh season of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, John Barbirolli conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall.

Of growing. importance to school authorities and public officials is the problem of what to do with the. vast numbers of unemployed youth between 18 and 24 who in other countries are the backbone of the fascist armies, James Marshall, president of the Board of Education, indicated yesterday.

A syndicate of investors purchased 386 lots on Powell, Norcores, Revere and Cambridge Avenues, Bethpage, L. I. The lots were owned by the defunct Central Park National Bank. J. Edward Breuer negotiated the sale.

The statement of the Bank of Canada for the week ended yesterday, which was issued today, showed that the ratio of net reserve to notes and deposit liabilities was 50.67 per cent, against 51.15 per cent a week before. The statement with changes noted from the previous week (in thousands of dollars), follows:

It might have been a tryout for a Broadway show that was staged at the usually staid Municipal Building yesterday, but it was only a group of fifty bare-legged women, garbed in dancing shorts, bloomers and other abbreviated attire, trying to pass the physical tests necessary to become policewomen.

Thirty thousand dollars in tax money accruing to the French Government from the Davis Cup finals between France and the United States that less than ten years ago held capacity crowds breathless at the Stade Rolland Garros is missing.

A suit for alleged damages of $100,000 filed in June, 1936, by Arthur R. Rule, president of the Wychwood Corporation of Westfield, N. J., charging that Frank A. Vanderlip Jr., head of the Scarborough Properties Corporation, violated a copyright in his use of illustrations in an advertising booklet, has been settled by stipulation, Mr. Rule announced yesterday.

The Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs will take up tomorrow the case of a Norwegian shipmaster, Freidar Jacobsen. He was recently appointed a non-intervention control officer in Spain, but has been arrested in Germany and placed in the concentration camp as Osnabrueck.

A moderate advance which included virtually every group, but favored especially the low-priced shares, characterized the stock market yesterday. Although trading on the. Stock Exchange was at a reduced volume, closing prices were generally up from 1 to 2 points.

New York Luggage Co, additional store space in 943-45 Eighth Ave; Leonard J. Beck, Inc, broker. Don Cohen, automobiles, in 1,650 Broadway; Parfums Varre, Inc, in 240 Madison Ave; Mayne Broderick. in 31-33 James St; Herbert McLean Purdy Management Corp, broker. Governor General of India in Council. for India Trade Commission, in International Building, Rockefeller Center; Cushman Wakefield, Inc, brokers.

The Right Rev. Orest Chornock, pastor of the Carpatho-Russian Greek Church of Bridgeport, Conn., returned yesterday on the French liner Champlain after a visit to Constantinople, where he was consecrated by the Patriarchy as a Bishop. The ceremony took place on Sept. 18.

Contributions of $127,500 to the forthcoming campaign of the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities were announced last night at a testimonial dinner for George Z. Medalie, given by more than 300 members of the lawyers' division of the two federations. The event,

Four Germans, including a girl of 19, were held for trial in United States District Court here today on charges of attempted espionage by Magistrate E. I. P. Tatelman. They were arrested last Sunday when discovered photographing coast defenses at Fort Randolph, near the mouth of the Panama Canal.

John S. Bizel, city judge or acting city judge here for eighteen years before his retirement five years ago, died of a heart attack last night while listening to the radio in his home. Ill for several years, his right leg was amputated in 1934 and his left in 1937. He was 70 years old.

Good friends of the Wagner Labor Act ought to find in the latest decision of the board which administers it further evidence of the wisdom and desirability of certain fundamental chances in the law. Here is a decision,

The big yard of Bellevue Hospital became temporarily yesterday a section of the Wild West when 200 cowboys and cowgirls in gay costumes rode on prancing and bucking steeds through a breath-taking program of stunts at a private rodeo show before 3,000 shut-in patients.

The national average of the construction cost index maintained by the American Appraisal Company remained unchanged in September at 181, the same as for June, July and August, according to Lyle H. Olson, vice president.

Insisting there is "no unbridgable gulf between the German and American trade systems," the Board of Trade for German-American Commerce, through a new committee on reciprocal trade agreements, yesterday telegraphed Secretary Hull of the Department of State urging the

New surgical techniques and local anesthetics developed in the last year make it possible now to eliminate almost wholly all pain to the mother both during and after childbirth, it was reported yesterday by two authorities to the seventeenth annual congress of anesthetists.

The Cuban Government today granted legal status to "Joven Cuba" and the National Fascist party in line with the new policy for the participation of all groups in the coming elections. Joven Cuba had been an outlawed organization for several years.

The ??itler salute, which was recently adopted by a large portion of Estonia's German-speaking minority, has caused resentment in wide circles here and has even resulted in a diplomatic incident throwing light on the strict attention official

With only limited selling by growers, and with the floating supply of contracts for Winter delivery reduced through recent spothouse operations, prices on the Cotton Exchange responded quickly to a buying wave that developed in the last hour yesterday.
THE COCK'S TAIL MURDER, by Hugh Austin. (Crime Club, $2.) A mystery novel. COOPERATIVES IN AMERICA, by Ellis Cowling. (Coward-McCann, $2.) A survey, with an introduction by J. P. Warbasse.
