The $250,000 movie quiz contest now being conducted in motion-picture theatres throughout the country is a lottery in violation of Missouri laws, Attorney General Roy McKittrick's office ruled today.

Strict production control in agriculture and petroleum refining were suggested by President Roosevelt as a remedy for the price-depressing surpluses from which both industries are suffering, according to visitors who canvassed the twin problems of the Southwest in conference with the President today.

Harold L. Rutledge, 39 years old, of Lake, Packanack, N. J., cashier for Hemphill, Noyes Co., dealers in investment securities at 15 Broad Street, was indicted by the New York County grand jury yesterday in thefts from the concern estimated at $109,000.

The United States liner American Farmer, sailing today for London, will have among her passengers Charles Rodda; Roberto Arias, the Rev. John J. O'Neill, C. D. Clark, Mrs. D. D. Collinson, Mrs. Eleanor R. Reilly, Miss Brenda Graves, Miss Mildred Monke, Charles H. Schurr, the Rev. and Mrs. C. D. Schwan, Mr. and Mrs. William W. Stickle and Mrs. Rosemary Clifford.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Ray G. Burton of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary E. Burton, to Frank O. Romney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest O. Romney of Rest Pen, Andrew's, Jamaica, British West Indies.

Norman R. Baker of White Plains, an executive in the real estate department of the Texas Oil Company, died here last night in the Lawrence Hospital at the age of 45. An operation had been performed Saturday.

Geoffrey Crowther, a former Commonwealth scholar at Yale, has been appointed editor of The Ecpnomist, the most influential weekly of its kind in Great Britain. Mr. Crowther, a Yorkshireman, 31 years old, succeeds Sir Walter Layton, who resigned on account of the pressure of other business.

Johanna Hofmann's "confession" that she was an intermediary between officers of the German Military Intelligence Service and their local agents was read yesterday to the jury in Federal Court, where for the last four days Guenther Gustav Rumrich, a United States Army deserter, has been relating from the witness stand his own reckless efforts to become a successful spy.

Nathan Straus, Administrator of the United States Housing Authority, disputed asserting that a ruling limiting the today a statement made yesterday by Alfred Rheinstein, head of the New York City Housing Authority, purchase price of land for housing projects to $1.50 a square foot had made uncertain the future of housing projects in New York.

The Wesleyan regulars were given a light workout today in preparation for the Amherst game on Andrus Field Saturday. Murphy, Kay and Moore were in the backfield for the Hussong and Kay throwing the passes, and Green and Cagney on the receiving end.

Mrs. George Learnard of Round Hill won the' women's Westchester and Fairfield two-day match play tournament by defeating Mrs. Russell Holman of Innis Arden, 3 and 1, in the final round over the Whippoorwill Golf Club course today.

On the complaint of Attorney General Bennett, four dealers in oil royalties were restrained temporarily yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente from further dealings in securities in. this State. The defendants, who were.

Preparations for the Penn State game were comparatively light today for the Cornell gridiron squad. Coach Carl Snavely spent most of the session on pass defense and reviewing the offense in a dummy scrimmage.

In a ceremony unprecedented in the history of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America the Rev. Dr. William Barrow Pugh, former pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Chester, was installed tonight as stated clerk of the denomination's General Assembly.

Dr. John M. Wainright, who practiced medicine here for thirty-two years, died in his sleep early this morning. He was 58 years old. Dr. Wainright as born in Brielle, N. J. He received his professional training at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, and was graduated in 1904.

Internal developments in France are waiting upon two events, the Senatorial elections Sunday and the Radical Socialist party congress sin Marseille next week. But in the meantime Premier Edouard Daladier is making every effort to prepare the way for his financial and governmental program if these two events result favorably.

Although official registration figures will not be available until the registration period ends next Saturday night, the Nassau County Board of Elections reported today that the enrollment for the first two days of personal registration was "almost double"

With substantial reductions in the prices of almost all foods this. week, the consumer is now reaping the benefits of one of the nation's knottiest economic problems, that of heavy food surpluses and their distribution. Retail prices in New York stores on everything but eggs and fruit are now from 7 to 24 per cent below what they were a year ago, latest figures show.

Coach Dick Harlow worked for speed and precision until dark tonight, for tomorrow Harvard will have only a light session as its final preparation for Dartmouth. The coaches feel that much has been accomplished during the week, and that the eleven will show more all-round strength than against Army.
Box-office receipts for the speaking appearance here tonight of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt were reported to police as having been stolen by two men masquerading as guards.

Counsel for the Republic Steel Corporation petitioned the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals here today to "review and set aside" the order of the National Labor Relations Board, made public yesterday, directing the company to reinstate about 5,000 men who engaged in the "little steel" strike of May and June, 1937.

5th Ave, 25, n e cor 9th St; Benjamin Samflow to Cortland Properties, Inc, 9 E 40th St; mtg $825,000 ($1). 4th St, 368-70 E; Isidore W. Gottlieb, executor of Aaron Gottlieb, to Manhattan Holding Corp, 401 Broadway; mtg $29,900 ($7.50) 25th St, 412-14 W; Samuel S. Burman, referee, to Central Hanover Bank Trust Co: foreclosure ($22).
A group of 120 interest-paying issues of realty bonds at present market prices return a current average yield of 8 1/2 per cent, according to Burr Co., Inc.

Something new is coming into the lives of Hollywood's actors and actresses-time cards and time clocks. The new Screen Actors' Guild contract, which goes into effect Nov. 1, limits hours of work for players to forty-eight a week, with provisions for overtime.

The Corporation of London and twelve great city guilds, or livery companies, have decided to make a gift of a piece of silver plate to the municipality of New York on the occasion of the World's Fair. The suggestion was made by Lord Bradbury, prime warden of the Goldsmith's company, which ranks fifth in precedence.

Swing will rub shoulders with chamber music in a concert to be presented at Washington Irving High School next Friday evening. The first half of the program will include works of Boyce, Bach and Brahms, played by the New York Sinfonietta, conducted by Max Goberman;

Aggressive buying of wheat futures today on the Board of Trade here and in Winnipeg, which brokers attributed to short covering for a New York speculator, lifted the market out of the narrow range in which it had held of late.

The two three-story industrial buildings known as 24 and 32 Spring Street, Newark, fronting 121 feet on Spring and running 130 feet deep through to McCarter Highway, have been sold by the Danbury-Bethel Fur Company to the Spring Realty Company, Peter Steiger, president.

Tenders were invited tonight by Secretary Morgenthau for approximately $100,000,000 of ninety-one-day Treasury bills to be sold on the usual discount basis to the highest bidders. The bills will be issued in the customary denominations, dated Oct. 26 and maturing on Jan. 25.

After holding about unchanged for four weeks, business in the Pittsburgh district last week reached a new high level for the year, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.
Joseph D. C. Young, last surviving son of Brigham Young, died last night following an illness of several years. His age was 83. Four daughters of the early-day Mormon leader are still living.
Mr. and Mrs. Philip Chapin Jones of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sheridan Earle Jones, to Newhall Douglas of New York.

Troops continued their searching operations in the Old City of Jerusalem all day today. It was officially reported that six Arabs had been killed, eleven wounded and three caught trying to escape over the city walls.

Police Lieutenant Cuthbert J. Behan, 44 years old, of the Prospect Park station, Brooklyn, was suspended and locked up at the Brooklyn Police Headquarters at 4:05 A. M., charged with grand larceny and the mutilation of public records, by order of Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine, who with Commissioner

George U. Harvey, Borough President of Queens, accused Mayor La Guardia yesterday of seeking the personal glory of opening the new $5,000,000 Queens General Court House and said that was the reason for transferring the construction out of the Borough President's jurisdiction.
Lester Patrick's Rangers scored a 2-1 overtime victory over Red Dutton's Americans tonight in the first contest of a pre-season series of exhibition hockey games between the two New York teams.

Joe DiMaggio confided to the home folks today, "I'm through being the hold-out kid." Back in San Francisco at picturesque Fishermen's Wharf, Joe talked with the humble fishermen who were his companions before he deserted the nets for baseball and who are among his greatest boosters.

A dinner for the purpose of awarding the August V. Lambert Memorial -Trophy to the leading Eastern collegiate football team will be given at the World's Fair Grounds late in November, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation. The date of the event has been tentatively set for Nov. 29.

Mrs. Roger W. Straus was named yesterday chairman of the women's division of the campaign committee of Edward Corsi, Republican nominee for United States Senator. Mrs. Straus is vice president of the Public Education Association, a trustee of Mount Sinai Hospital and a member of the Council of the American Arbitration Association, the Board of the American Joint Distribution Committee and the Board of the Women's Roosevelt Memorial Association.
CAMMANN, DONALD F. (July 14, 1936). Gross assets, $10,264; net, $6,342. To Annie Gilbert Cammann, widow, $6,342. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $7,725. Eugene A. Donohue, attorney, 521 5th Ave.

Willis Ave, 310. 5-story tenement, 25x100: Otto L. Witte against A. E. D. Realty Corp; due, $1,545; taxes. etc, $350; subject to mortgage of $7,500; to Andrews Avenue Realty Co, Inc, Fred Oppenheim, pres, 1,860 Andrews Ave, for $9,560. University Ave, 1,201, 6-story tenement, 118.11 x 157 x irreg; Railroad Federal Savings Loan Assn against University Heights Associates, Inc; due, $139,286; taxes, etc. $1,686; to plaintiff for $1,000.
The quiet, almost fatherly Tad Wieman stood under gray skies today as the Princeton football squad 'he coaches moved through its last hard practice before Saturday's Navy game and shook his head.

Speakers at a dinner-conference of manufacturers and retailers of home furnishings, to be held at the Hotel Astor next Monday, will include Louis J. Breuner of Oakland, Calif., president of the National Retail Furniture Association; Louis Bernstein,

Lithuania, threatened by a deal between Germany and Poland, yesterday took steps to improve relations with both by moving to halt measures aimed at them and her German and Polish minorities. [Page 1.] Hungary was cautioned by Berlin that fixing of new borders with Czechoslovakia must be based on nationality.

Sales by banks of tenement houses in scattered sections of Manhattan and the resale of a residence on the West Side after a brief ownership featured realty deals yesterday. Mae V. Sullivan, who purchased the four-story dwelling at 31 West Seventy-fifth Street about two weeks ago, resold it to a client of E. C. Whittington, broker.

Union College has arranged to have Mayor La Guardia of New York City and State Senator Pitcher of Watertown discuss "Metropolitan vs. Up State Views on the State Constitution and Government" in a public meeting on the campus Tuesday night.
Colonel G. Creighton Webb has returned to his home here for the Winter. Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Oliphant of Strafford, Pa., are at the RitzCarlton.

Trading fair on lamb and pork, other classes slow in local markets yesterday. Veal hlndsaddles were steady to $1 lower. Kosher lamb foresaddles were higher, other classes mostly steady. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:

James W. Carkner, president of Loft, Inc., has prepared a letter to stockholders outlining the company's lack of complete knowledge with respect to the financial condition of the Pepsi-Cola Company, together with details of the arrangements with lawyers relating to the litigation in which the ownership of about 91 per cent of Pepsi-Cola shares outstanding was awarded to Loft, Inc. This award,

A nose finish, with a 7-to-1 chance beating the even-money favorite on the post, was the big thrill of the featured Winsted Handicap at Empire City yesterday, the result bringing a great roar of approval from the backers of the Woolford Farm. The winner, Rifted Clouds,

Manhattan, concentrating on the development of a defense strong enough to stop unbeaten Georgetown's powerful attack, went through a hard, two-hour dummy scrimmage yesterday as it concluded heavy preparations for the Hoyas' visit to the Yankee Stadium tomorrow.

Three upState county chairmen were subpoenaed today for questioning by an Albany County grand jury investigating the escape of three convicted O'Connell kidnappers from the Onondaga County penitentiary, near Syracuse, in November.

Big business enterprise offers the best weapon for the maintenance and protection of democracy in "the world struggle between despotism and freedom," James H. R. Cromwell of Somerville declared tonight at the eighth annual dinner of the Advertising Club of Newark. Discussing the recent world crisis, Mr. Cromwell said:

The world premiere of a sumptuous "choreographic legend" called "Bogatyri" took place at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, as the fourth new work of theseason to be created by Leonide Massine for the Ballet Russe de Monte- Carlo. It is logical to suppose that this is designed to be successor to "Coq d'Or,"-which was a great hit last season and is no longer the property of the present company.

Only fifteen out of 135 candidates for the Assembly, running this year in the sixty-two Assembly districts within the city and listed in a Citizens Union report yesterday, are commended by that organization; A group of thirty-sevan are placed on a "qualified and preferred" list
Sales of securities in odd lots on the New York-Stock Exchange in the week ended on Oct. 15 exceeded purchases by 128,257 shares, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Retail credit collections showed a decline of 0.61 per cent in September, according to the twenty-store index of the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. The average collection percentage for the month was 43.03, compared with 43.64 in September, 1937.

Rheumatic heart disease has become the "forgotten health problem" of this country, causing 40,000 deaths annually and weakening a large proportion of the population, Dr. O. F. Hedley, past assistant surgeon of the United States Public Health Service, warned yesterday.

Only fifteen out of 135 candidates for the Assembly, running this year in the sixty-two Assembly districts within the city and listed in a Citizens Union report yesterday, are commended by that organization; A group of thirty-sevan are placed on a "qualified and preferred" list
Sales of securities in odd lots on the New York-Stock Exchange in the week ended on Oct. 15 exceeded purchases by 128,257 shares, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Retail credit collections showed a decline of 0.61 per cent in September, according to the twenty-store index of the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. The average collection percentage for the month was 43.03, compared with 43.64 in September, 1937.

Rheumatic heart disease has become the "forgotten health problem" of this country, causing 40,000 deaths annually and weakening a large proportion of the population, Dr. O. F. Hedley, past assistant surgeon of the United States Public Health Service, warned yesterday.
Fred 0. Cosgrove and Ernest G. Giamais have been elected vice presidents of the Knott Corporation. The annual meeting of the Hupp Motor Car Company has again been adjourned, this time to Nov. 18.
The War Ministry, acting with the Czechoslovak Red Cross, today ordered immediate relief sent to three groups of Jewish refugees living in the fields near Breclav.

Seventeen candidates of four political parties spoke today at the annual pre-election meeting of the Westchester County League of Women Voters and explained why they thought they should be elected to Westchester offices next month. The meeting was held in the Little Theatre of the county center and was attended by 200 persons.

What he termed as a "small and scattered" minority which, he said, is trying to bring the wage and hour law into disrepute was denounced today by Elmer F. Andrews, Administrator of the Wage and Hour Division, as his small staff labored into the night on definitions that need to be completed before the act goes into effect on Monday.
Sir John Purser Griffith, an Irish Free State Senator from 1922 to 1926 and a distinguished civil engineer, died here today at the age of 90.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $23,369,020, to be represented by four States and 100 municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $21,893,606 for last week.

The Duck season will open at the Polo Grounds today, and Fordham hopes to bag more than the legal limit when it fires its new highpowered rifles at the Oregon Webfoots. This will be a game that should test to the limit the untried hunters from the Bronx, and Sleepy Jim Crowley fervently trusts that the Ducks do not chase his nimrods up a tree.
The State Banking Department reported today that the affairs of the Yorkville Credit Union, New York, had been liquidated by the Superintendent of Banks, and the corporation had been dissolved.
Today's major events: Trio of New York, assisted by Lillian Fuchs, viola, Town Hall, 3 P. M. Earl Oliver, baritone, Town Hall, 8:30 P. M.

The first concrete evidence of the intention of two of the country's largest public utility holding companies to comply voluntarily with the integration provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 appeared yesterday

James R. Brackett, now assistant supervisor of information of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has been selected as assistant to Leon Henderson, executive secretary of the present investigating committee into monopolies being conducted by the government, it was announced tonight.

President Roosevelt declared today that the response of interstate industry to the provisions of the Wage-Hour Law gave him hope that local business in strictly intrastate traffic would raise its standards to square with the national program.
Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended on Oct. 15 totaled 726,612 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Bond prices developed a somewhat firmer undertone yesterday in more active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The increased activity was centered principally in the more speculative issues, the demand resulting in a substantial improvement over a fairly broad list of issues.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES'S editorial of Oct. 18, discussing the merits of the policy of the United States Housing Authority in respect to land costs for low-rental projects, is very interesting.
Harvard's varsity soccer team put on a real drive in the last two periods of its New England Intercollegiate League game with Dartmouth today and won, 3-0.
Princeton's 150-pound team defeated the Villanova lightweights in an Intercollegiate League football game today, 14-7.

The Treasury's deficit for the fiscal year which began on July 1 amounted to $1,012,389,658 on Oct. 19, with receipts listed as $1,711,599,368 and expenditures as $2,723,989,026, the Treasury reported today. A year before, the deficit was $487,202,215.

In an indictment returned here today by the Federal grand jury, sixteen sand, gravel and stone contracting companies and thirty-two individuals were charged with conspiracy to defraud the United States Government of about $250,000 in connection with WPA contracts.
The Brooklyn College football team will be seeking its first victory in the seven-year-old series with City College this afternoon when the rivals meet on the Kingsmen's field.

Joseph Cignetti, who sent his son, Peter, from his hospital bedside to Philadelphia to join his Boston College team-mates for the game against Temple, died today of injuries suffered in an automobile accident on Columbus Day.

Miss Elizabeth Goodard Binney Newberry, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barnes Newberry of Narragansett, was married today to Charles Hollister Judd Jr. of Philadelphia, son of Dr. Charles Hollister Judd of Detroit and the late Mrs. Gertrude Bucknell Day.

The marriage of Miss Lorraine Cooper, daughter of Mrs. William Henry Blauvelt Cooper of 361 Carlton Avenue, Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Cooper, to Warren Allen King, son of Mrs. Warren Charles Strugnell of Bloomfield, N. J., and the late George Garrett Hallock King, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Central Presbyterian Church.

Settlement for $2,975 of two suits brought against A. Lawrence Lowell, president emeritus of Harvard University, as a result of an automobile accident more than a year ago, were announced today in Superior Court. Mrs. Margaret J.

Secretary Ickes broadened his last year's ?? on the "sixty families" today to "the two hundred corporations," which he said were "dominated by a few hundred men" and "control" half the nation's corporate wealth.
The long-distance press wires will get a big play this afternoon on the season's heaviest day of intersectional football competition for the East.

La Casita Mexicana, Mexican novelties, store in concourse of RCA Building, Rockefeller Center. Beacon Operating Corp. food supplies; Francis P. Britton, hops, in 120 Liberty St; Daher El-Roury, exporter: Grigat Fahlteich, publishers, additional space in 135 Liberty St; Gruntal Co, member New York Stock Exchange. additional space in 30 Broad St: L N. White Co, food supplies, additional space in 24 Stone St; Cushman Wakefield, Inc, brokers.

The Appellate Division upheld unanimously yesterday the right of Surrogate James A. Foley to pass on litigation involving the estate of Irving I. Bloomingdale, vice president of Bloomingdale Brothers, despite the claim of the widow, Mrs. Geanne Hughes Bloomingdale Butler,

In St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Forest Hills, Queens, last night Miss Doris Lang Clark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elton Waterbury Clark of that community, was married to William Booth Trainer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Trainer of Sewickley Heights, Pa. The Rev. R. Thomas Blomquist, rector of the church, performed the ceremony.

The finance committee of the New York Curb Exchange, directors of the New York Curb Exchange Realty Associates, Inc., and the New York Curb Exchange Securities Clearing Corporation announced yesterday that they would adopt the schedule as to maximum hours of work provided in Section 7 of the Fair Labor Standards Law.

Nathan Straus, administrator of the United States Housing Authority, in an address broadcast last night by Station WHN, endorsed the proposed housing amendment to the State Constitution as "evidence that the States are beginning to assume their share of responsibility for the nation-wide housing and slum clearance program."

Foreign Minister Frantisek Chvalkovsky today received the Soviet Minister, Sergei Alexandrovsky, who was personally responsible for working out many elaborate details of Czech-Russian cooperation in the event of an invasion of this country, and informed him that Czechoslovakia had no further interest in the maintenance of her mutual assistance pact with Russia.

A week ago Secretary Wallace implied. that control of production in the oil fields was based on exactly the same principles as control of crop production. There is a similar implication in the latest reports that the President favors the restriction of output both in the petroleum fields and on the farm.
The new UFA film at the Eightysixth Street Garden Theatre is called "Die Macht der Berge" (The Power of the Mountains), but a better name would have been "The Power of a Good Woman's Common Sense."

Harvard's cross-country team won the varsity race against Dartmouth and New Hampshire today, scoring 28 points, to New Hampshire's 40 and Dartmouth's 57. Dartmouth took the freshman run with 27 points, the Crimson scoring 41 and New Hampshire 55.
Following the capture of the rich Tayeh iron mines on Thursday, Japanese forces yesterday drove out the Chinese defenders of the town of Tayeh, forty miles southeast of Hankow.

A cornerstone containing flowers and plants representing the fortyeight States, the Territories and the District of Columbia was dedicated yesterday afternoon at Horticultural Hall of the New York World's Fair. The ceremony was attended by more than 600 persons.

Lady Armstrong, widow of Sir Harry Gloster Armstrong, former British Consul General in New York, presided for the first time at a meeting of the officers and executive committee of the Ladies of Catholic Charity held last Monday at the headquarters, 415 Lexington Avenue.

A special meeting of stockholders of the Ward Baking Corporation has been called for Nov. 18 in Baltimore to approve a merger of the company into the Ward Baking Company, its subsidiary, to escape Federal taxes on intercompany dividends and to simplify the corporate structure.

Miss Enid Lockwood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Harkness Lockwood of 115 Willow Street, Brooklyn, was married here yesterday afternoon to Jay George Mills, son of Mrs. Ernest L. Mills, also of Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Mills.
A meeting of the Australian Loan Council today marks an attempt to initiate cooperation in defense measures among the Commonwealth States by pooling loan funds in the national interest.

Tomorrow will be observed as a special day by several different groups. In the Protestant Episcopal Church throughout the United States it will be annual Sailors Day. In port cities services will be held for seamen.

A. F. Dixon, a director of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company and vice president of the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line Company, issued yesterday a statement in connection with the action taken Wednesday by a majority of the
According to his friends and pupils here, Professor Eugen Sweinach, distinguished pioneer in the study of sex hormones, has established a laboratory in Zurich, Switzerland.
A banking group headed by Smith, Barney Co. purchased yesterday $1,894,000 of Cleveland, Ohio, various purpose bonds which had been held by the city in its sinking funds.
Manager Gabby Hartnett of the Chicago Cubs, on his way to a pheasant hunt, today spiked a recent rumor that his field captain, Billy Herman, might go to the Cardinals as manager.
Navy, upset, 9-7, last week by Yale, takes the field tomorrow hoping' to upset Princeton and even the score with the Ivy League.

In so far as any one around Gloucester knew tonight, competition for the sailing championship of the North Atlantic, which has been bogged down by fog, calm weather, protests and disputes, will be resumed off here Sunday morning.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John J. Daly of Elmhurst, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Louise Daly, to Fernand A. Bernardin, son of Mrs. Eugenie Bernardin of Lawrence, Mass.

The council of the International Chamber of Commerce, meeting here and representing business interests of twentythree countries, rejected today "the fallacy that artificially cheap money is necessary for business activity."

Wheat prices were on the upgrade today for the third straight day. There was aggressive buying, attributed to Eastern speculators, and also a broadening in the general commissionhouse demand, largely in small lots.
The New York Stock Exchange excess announced yesterday the formation of the firm of Pedley, Martin Co., with offices at 42 Broadway and in Los Angeles.

Patrolman Patrick O'Keefe, 28 years old, of 41 Convent Avenue, the Bronx, attached to the Fortysixth Precinct, the Bronx, was injured critically early today when his automobile, which he was driving along Cross-County Parkway here, skidded, went off the road, struck a boulder and overturned.

Special agents of the Crinimal Investigation Division of the WPA carried ahead today the investigation into State WPA activities which resulted yesterday in wholesale indictments by a Federal grand jury.

Miss Alice Beatrice Maison Churchman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Churchman Jr. of Chestnut Hill, was married this afternoon to Francis George du Pont, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Paul du Pont of Squirrel Run Hill, Montchanin, Del.

This week's session of the British Cabinet, the first since the Government heard Mr. Chamberlain's report on the meeting at Munich, did not revert to the Central European situation at all. Consideration of the burning problem of national defense was held over until next week.

For the first time, representatives of all branches of capital and labor engaged in the country's building industry gathered here today for a frank discussion of labor relations as they affect the progress of building throughout the country.

The New York Stock Exchange relaxed yesterday its rule whereby a member or general partner, operating under the so-called "daylight margin" rules and maintaining two or more accounts with the same broker,

Miss Gwendolyn Eldredge Wilder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Wilder of Madison, was married to Walter Dongan Wood Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wood of Summit, N. J., tonight in Grace Episcopal Church by the Rev. Victor W. Mori, the rector.

A proposal to make visual the periodic circulation reports of newspapers by means of maps showing market coverage, which was one of the highlights of the two-day convention here of the Audit Bureau of Circulations, was shelved at today's closing session with a recommendation that the plan be referred to the ABC Board for further study.

The fear that Japan would not send a representative to the mandates commission sessions opening Monday to answer questions on administration of her Pacific islands mandate has been expressed by Consul U. Usami.

Charles F. Noyes Co, Inc, has arranged the renewal of the first mortgage of $265.000 on the 11-story apartment house at 955-9 Lexington Ave, with interest at 42 per cent. Byrne Bowman, Inc, procured for a client of Robert Moers, attorney, a first mortgage of $65,000 on the 5-story house at 440 Jackson Ave, the Bronx.

Mrs. Edith Livingston Smith of West Palm Beach, Fla., a pioneer in social service in the Massachusetts General Hospital, died Thursday of a heart ailment on the S. S. Shawnee en route from Florida to New York, according to word received here. yesterday.

More than fifty guests, including trustees, members of the faculty and administrative officers of Barnard College, attended the reception for Professor Harry D. Gideonse, new head of the Department of Economics and Social Sciences, and Mrs. Gideonse, given by Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve yesterday afternoon in the deanery on the campus.

Governor Lehman accepted as an honored title today Thomas E. Dewey's reference to him last night as a "bookkeeping Governor." In a fighting reply this afternoon to his Republican opponent's Utica reference and in a detailed discussion of the State's finances at a rally here tonight he called on the voters to judge which was better qualified to administer the affairs of New York State.

It seems that the situation on Barnegat Bay is somewhat similar to that up on Merrymeeting-there are plenty of black ducks, but they leave before 7 A. M. and return after 4 P. M. They're wise birds, and until we have a storm of sufficient proportions to send them in from the ocean and the middle of the bay, the shooting will be mediocre.

Word was received here today of the death last night in San Pedro, Calif., of George Otis Draper, former mill man and world traveler. His age was 71. A native of near-by Hopedale, he was the son of the late William F. Draper, one-time Ambassador to Italy.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions for Arrangement LOUIS BERKOWITZ, doing business as Supreme Junior Coat Co., 265 W. 37th St.Petition under Chapter XI of the Chandler Act to effect a composition of 60 per cent. An order of adjudication was entered last August on an involuntary petition against the debtor and he asks that it be vacated.
The particular novelty of last night's program by the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Metropolitan Opera House was the American premiere of Serge Lifar's ballet, "Icare." As its "choreauthor,"

One WPA worker was discharged yesterday and another suspended as an aftermath of the walkout on Thursday of thirty-eight relief laborers who objected to being required to use both pick and shovel on a ditch-digging project at 151st Street and Exterior Avenue, the Bronx.

Appearance of two major public utility loans swelled the total of new bond offerings this week to $143,222,350, the largest for any similar period since the week ended June 3, last, when $205,394,000 in bonds, including the $100,000,000 United States Steel Corporation 31/4 per cent debentures, were placed on the market.

Chairman Sheppard said today that a list of Federal officials who have contributed to Senatorial campaign funds will be put before the Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee for action at its meeting next week.
Net bales of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. for the third quarter of 1938 amounted to $63,540,013, comp red to $53,297,770 in the preceding quarter and to $70,938,942 in the third quarter of 1937.
This day is one of bitterness for Chu Tachi, 26-year-old self-styled pretender to the ancient Ming throne of China.
The Navy won a well-played game of soccer from Yale today by 3 to 2. Dick Parker, Navy, and Tim Erickson, Yale, scored all the points for their respective sides.

Daniel J. Curtin, confidential attendant to the justices of the Supreme Court in the Bronx, died yesterday at his home, 2,980 Perry Avenue, the Bronx, after an illness of a month. He was 71 years old.
The October ball, one of the most important events of the social season in this city, was attended tonight at the Warwick by more than 500.

Movements or vessels follow, all dates are Oct. 21, unless specified: At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk: Kewaydin, Oct. 20; Acushnet. At San Pedro: Houston, Oct. 20; Arctic, Wright. Southern Island to Manila: Bulmer, Edsall, Paul Jones, Parrott, Stewart.
On Sept. 7 a Federal grand jury in Albuquerque began an investigation of alleged political activity of the State WPA. One of the witnesses called before it was the State Administrator, Fred Healy.
Four Eastern Arkansas lumber mills announced today they were closing because of restrictions in the wage-hour law which goes in effect Monday.

Announcement that Germany is extending a credit of some $24,000,000 to Poland, following upon a $60,000,000 advance to Turkey and one of $40,000,000 reported under negotiation with Greece, shows that she is losing no time in capitalizing her victory at Munich.

William C. Chanler, Corporation Counsel, announced his support of the Lehman-Poletti ticket yesterday, breaking the silence maintained by city officials since the opening of the State political campaign.

Madison Square Garden will be host this morning to 15,000 orphaned, crippled and otherwise underprivileged children at a special performance of the World's Championship Rodeo, beginning at 10 o'clock.

A runaway truck killed a woman and injured three other pedestrians at the busy Brooklyn intersection of Fulton, Bridge and Hoyt Streets at 11:15 o'clock yesterday morning when it plunged through traffic and mounted a sidewalk crowded with shoppers.

George Leete Anderson, one of the world's foremost developers of hibiscus, died today of coronary thrombosis. He was 67 years old. A son of the late George Henry and Carolina Peck Anderson, he was reared in New Haven, Conn., and developed a hobby into a successful business.

Although their trial had been postponed thirty times in General Sessions since their indictment three years and three months ago for the theft of about $730 of pimento imported from Spain, Harry Dean, 53 years old, of 3,021 Briggs Avenue, the Bronx, and James C.
Arthur Schuschnigg, father of the former Chancellor of Austria, Kurt Schuschnigg, was found dead in bed in his home here this morning. It is believed that he died from a heart attack in his sleep.
Coach Carl Snavely made one lastminute change in his Cornell lineup today as the Big Red and the Pennsylvania State College squad held final light workouts for their grid clash here tomorrow.

A conference "to study plans for making eventual union" of the Protestant Episcopal Church and the Presbtyerian Church will be held Friday morning and afternoon in the General Episcopal Theological Seminary, 175 Ninth Avenue.

Sales of ordinary life insurance in September, amounting to $428,482,000, remained at about the level reached in August, when an upturn brought sales to within 16 per cent of August, 1937, according to the Life Insurance Sales Research Bureau. Sales in the first nine months of 1938 totaled $4,400,516,000.

Members of the Tanners Council of America heard a prophecy of better times by Henry H. Stafford of the Babson Statistical Organization at the final sessions of their twenty-second annual meeting here today.

Edgar Kenny of Garden City, L. I., a securities dealer doing business as Edgar Kenny Co. at 60 Beaver Street, was arrested yesterday by Detective Frank Wilson in the office of Attorney General Bennett on a charge of grand larceny.

Announcement yesterday-by officials of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and the Cities Service Company that the former concern had agreed to purchase Cities Service's utility properties in Michigan marks the first definite step by two major holding companies to comply voluntarily with section 11 of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

Bernard S. Michell, who trained Reigh Count, winner of the 1928 Kentucky Derby, and many other horses, died of a heart ailment here last night in a hospital. His age was 56. His home was in Miami, Fla.

Mrs. Carrie L. Lehman, wife of Philip Lehman, senior partner of Lehman Brothers, investment bankers, who died on Nov. 10, 1937, left an estate of $4,817,914, which was worth $3,676,835 on Sept. 30, last, according to an accounting filed in Surrogate's Court by Robert Lehman, son; Henry R. Ickelheimer, son-in-law, and Monroe C. Gutman, executors of her estate.
A. C. Spencer-Hess, British M. P. who lived for many years in the United States, has sold his estate in Kensington Gardens, Great Neck, to A. V. B. Geoghegan of the advertising firm of Young Rubicam.

President Roosevelt advised Mayor Thomas J. Spellacy today that the United States Government would continue to follow closely the Jewish situation in Palestine, but that because of the terms of the convention with Great Britain, the United States was unable to prevent modifications in the Palestine mandate by the Council of the League of Nations.

The WPA and the city government will spend $21,321,400 in the next twelve months on a program intended to make New York a cleaner, healthier and more attractive place for its own citizens and for millions of World's Fair visitors, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, announced yesterday.
Scoring twice in both the first and final periods, St. Louis University defeated Grinnell College, 27 to 7, in a Missouri Valley conference football game tonight.
The New York Stock Exchange has authorized the listing of 45,000 shares of Wisconsin Electric Power Company 6 per cent preferred stock of $100 par value.

In the hope of finding new sources of revenue for the New York City school system, a two-year survey of the financial situation within the city and State will be undertaken by a committee of educators, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday.

John Lord O'Brian, Republican nominee for the New York Senatorial long term, reported today to the Senate Campaign Expeditures Committee that he had received no contributions and made no expenditures in his primary campaign.

The race mare, Esposa, who has been campaigned the season long, will try once more today when she takes up top weight of 124 pouns fort he mile and an eithth of the Yorktown Handicap, richest race of the Empire City meeting.
Dartmouth, undefeated in its last nineteen games, today completed preparations for the Harvard battle with mixed feelings.
Forum of the Association of Teachers of Social Studies, City College, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-third Street, 10:30 A. M. Speakers: Edward Corsi, S. Howard Evans.

Congressional tax experts are studying several proposals for increasing income taxes to finance an expanded armament program. Staff members of the Joint Committee on Internal Revenue will make recommendations for tax legislation at the next session of Congress.
Aircraft Components, Inc., Vernon, Calif., C. A. Herberts, president, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 38,000 shares of $5 par value capital stock.
Department-store sales during the week ended Oct. 15 were 18 per cent lower than a year ago and for the four weeks ended Oct. 15 were 12 per cent lower, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Trading by members in round lots for their own account on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Oct. 1 was 21.75 per cent of the total volume, compared with 19.84 per cent in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "While the market may be somewhat less active than last week, there has been a fair movement in wool, and prices have been well maintained, both East and West.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum. on Oct. 8 were 279,007,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of. Mines.

Professor Skatkin, who said in a lecture at the Moscow Power Institute that Aristotle had laid down the fundamental principles of menshevism and that Plato was the father of fascism, has been summarily removed.
The most serious accident of the Madison Square Garden rodeo occurred last night in the horseback basket ball game between cowboys of Texas and Oklahoma when John Fleming of Center, Texas,

David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, said today his executive board would meet here early in November to decide whether to attend the forthcoming C.I.O. convention in Pittsburgh.

The National Association of Science Writers has won the second annual Clement Cleveland Medal "for outstanding work during the year in the campaign to control cancer," according to an announcement made yesterday by Dr. John C. A. Gerster, chairman of the New York City Cancer Committee of the American Society for the Control of Cancer Inc.

All of the disgrace and humiliation that the Police Department could heap on a high officer accused as a traitor were piled yesterday upon Lieutenant Cuthbert J. Behan, who slept last night in the Brooklyn city prison, stripped of his shield and facing criminal charges for the theft of the 7,200 police records from the Bergen Street station.

Miss Mary E. Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Orville B. Moore, was married to George W. Cocks Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cocks of Upper Montclair, at the Moore home here tonight. The Rev. Chester E. Hodgson, pastor of Park Methodist Episcopal Church, officiated.

Jack Carson, vaudeville and nightclub recruit who appeared as the interne in the Astaire-Rogers "Carefree," was cast today in the second male lead in RKO's "The Castles," based upon the life of Mr. and Mrs. Vernon Castle. Alan Hale was added to "Pacific Liner."

Japanese troops occupied Canton yesterday withoutt fighting, the Chinese defenders having hastily retreated. The $8,000,000 bridge over the Pearl River and many public buildings were blown up. Fires were reported in many parts of the city and the firemen were said to have fled.
An audience of 3,000 persons heard Lawrence Tibbett tonight at the County Center in the first concert of the current Mrs. Julian 01ney series here.
Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for Governor, returned to New York yesterday after a twoday up-State swing, heartened by cheering reports from the Republican chairmen of the counties in
The Board of Trade issued a statement today minimizing the extent of the hitch in Anglo-American trade pact negotiations.

Mrs. Walter Oliver Ford entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Mrs. Leonard B. McKitterick and Miss Elizabeth Glendinning, who celebrated their birthdays. Other guests were Mrs.
typhoon sweeping in from the sea today killed at least 226 persons, injured more than 590 and left 35,000 homeless. About 230 persons were missing.

Three up-State Republican leaders appeared today before an Albany County grand jury investigating the escape of three convicted O'Connell kidnappers. The witnesses were Mayor Rolland B. Marvin of Syracuse, who also is chairman of the Onondaga County Republican committee;

Lester Patrick, manager of the New York Rangers, finally has filled a longneeded want in the amateur link of his famous Three-R hockey chain by appointing Frank Boucher as coach of the New York Rovers of the Eastern Amateur League.

An undefeated Georgetown eleven that has rolled up 117 points in three games thus far will face Manhattan's football warriors at Yankee Stadium today in a contest starting at 2:30 P. M. A crowd of 20,000 is expected.

M. L. Annenberg, publisher of The Philadelphia Inquirer, and two codefendants were held in $1,000 bail each for the grand jury today by Magistrate Muhly on a charge of criminal libel brought by Albert M. Greenfield, real estate operator active in Democratic politics.

Friedar Jacobsen, a Norwegian shipmaster and non-intervention control officer who disappeared while traveling to London via Germany, causing a diplomatic incident, has been sentenced to one month's imprisonment at Osnabrueck, according to a preliminary report isued today by the Norwegian Consulate at Hamburg, Germany.

After having exhausted every avenue of appeal from convictions two and a half years ago on charges of making false reports to the State Banking Department, Henry C. and George W. Steneck, president and vice president, respectively, of the defunct Steneck Trust Company of Hoboken, N. J., surrendered at the State prison here today.
Two teams with an intense desire to do the same thing-get back in the winning column-come together at Franklin Field tomorrow afternoon with the renewal of the ColumbiaPennsylvania football battles.

A fighting Poly Prep eleven bowed to the heavier Newark Academy outfit, 26 to 6, on Poly Field yesterday. The Dyker Heights team, badly hit by injuries, took the field without its first-string backfield and could do little against the powerful New Jersey invaders, who counted twice in the first period and once in each of the third and fourth.
President Kemal Ataturk is making such good progress with his recovery that his Ministers, who held a Cabinet meeting near his sickroom in Dolma Bagtche Palace yesterday, are now returning to Angora.

J. Sidney Bernstein, Democratic candidate for Supreme Court justice in the First Judicial District, and Magistrate Anna Moskovitz Kross, American Labor and Progressive party candidate for the same office, failed to win the approval of the New York County Lawyers Association, its board of directors announced yesterday.

The burglar who stole $1,000 worth of jewelry from a house at Hawthorne and Westchester Avenues here has one piece of loot that no one has dared touch in twenty years because the owners believe it carries an Egyptian curse.

The problem of how to extend old-age benefits under the Social Security Act to about 5,000,000 persons occupied members of the Advisory Council on Social Security as they met with Treasury officials today in an effort to draft proposals to be laid before the next Congress.

Each of the following reserve officers, unassigned, is assigned to the organization indicated: 61st Cavalry Division-Col. William J. Donovan, Cav.-Res., 1 Beekman Place, New York, N. Y.; Major Lawrence Beattie, Cav.-Res., 60 Clarkson Ave., Brooklyn, N. Y.

BROWN vs. Rhode Island--The acid tests are coming up now, making it a matter of chemical analysis. Turning to chemistry; an acid is a chemical compound whose water solutions contain hydrogen ions. Either that or a textbook borrowed for the occasion is dreadfully wrong. Putting the first ion in the fire, a brief vote for Brown.

Mgr. Charles J. Canivan, pastor of St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church, Oyster Bay, L. I., has been made president of the board of directors of the Tablet Publishing Company, 1 Hanson Place, Brooklyn, publishers of the official newspaper of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn.

Amsterdam was blacked out tonight between 10 and 11 o'clock, while air raid precautions were rehearsed for the first time. Protective measures for the civil population are being organized with increasing activity.
Conversations looking toward a more formal move to restore peace in labor's ranks were disclosed today by Secretary Perkins to have been going forward during the past few days.

John P. Durkin, Street Commissioner here for twenty-eight years, died today at his home, 37 New Lawn Avenue, after a month's illness. His age was 59. Mr. Durkin was president of the Wilson Wire Works of Kearny.

Norman Thomas, national chairman of the Socialist party and its candidate for Governor, made public yesterday a letter to President Roosevelt, in which he urged that steps be taken to protect Jewish, Socialist and other anti-Nazi refugees from Sudetenland.
3d Ave. 4,177-9, 51x92.11xirreg; Edward King Realty Co against Aaron Bartelstone; due, $42,481; taxes, etc, $1,082; to plaintiff for $27,500.
Following is the text of Governor Lehman's address before a campaign rally here tonight: Tonight I shall tell you of the record of my administration in planning and managing State finances.
Johns Hopkins University scored a 7-to-O victory over Washington College tonight in the first collegiate football game ever played at Salisbury.

Mr. and Mrs. John Willard McCoy of this city and Ratcliffe Manor, Talbot County, Md., have announced the engagement of Mr. McCoy's daughter, Miss Anne Douglas McCoy, to Henry P. Cannon 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry L. Cannon of Bridgeville.
Rudolph Sikora, "the perfect husband," was acquitted by a Criminal Court jury tonight of a charge that he murdered Edward Solomon, who stole the love of his wife.

Leases of two garages and other structures on the West Side formed the bulk of realty trading in.Manhattan yesterday. A five-year lease of a building on the East Side also figured in the day's activity.

Members of the Savings Banks Association of New York State and their guests, to the number of about 400, sailed last night on the motorship Kungsholm of the Swedish American Line for a six-day "convention cruise" to Nassau, Bahamas.

New York University will try to atone for last year's 13-0 defeat by Lafayette when the Violets meet the Maroons at Fisher Field tomorrow. Lafayette won last year's game mainly through the medium of the kicking of Tom Kearns and two forward passes that were converted into touchdowns.

Political talks scheduled for broadcast over local stations today are: Mrs. Andree De Montlouis of the French Division of the Nonpartisan Committee, in behalf of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, Republican gubernatprial candidate, WINS, 6:55 to 7 P. M. (1,180 Kc.)
Dr. Harry Gilbert, a physician of 11 West Sixty-ninth Street, was held in $50,000 bail yesterday as a material witness in the $427,950 armored car robbery in Brooklyn four years ago.

A rally to bring back football at Long Island University resulted yesterday in a petition signed by 800 students at the school, where the enrollment is about 1,100. The petition will be presented to Dean Tristram Walker Metcalfe Monday.
The Boston Maine Railroad applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to borrow $1,500,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
Kenneth T. Keller, president of the Chrysler Corporation, announced today that salaries reduced on March 16 would be restored on -Oct. 31 for -employes receiving less than $300 a month.

Incorporated Investors reports new assets of $51,215,410 as of Sept. 3 equal to $17.53 a share on the capital stock, compared to $14.01 a share on March 31. As of Oct. 17 asset value had further risen to $18.98 a share. At Sept. 30 the company had 16.9 per cent of net assets in cash or government securities.

MANHATTAN BROWN, KATIE A. (July 12). Estate, not more than $5,000. To New York Catholic Foundling Asylum, St. Joseph's Home for the Aged, Cancer Hospital at Hawthorne, N. Y., and Seton Hospital, one-eighth residue each; five relatives share in other half of residue. Francis J. McLoughlin, 404 4th St.. Brooklyn. executor.
George Washington University rolled over Davis and Elkins on the gridiron tonight, beating the West Virginians by 27 to 0.
Tony Longo, 33-year-old pro of the Inwood Country Club, yesterday crashed into the ranks of champions to achieve an ambition harbored for his eleven years as a professional golfer.
A department of business economics has been instituted at Hunter College under authorization of the Board of Higher Education to divide the department of history and social sciences into three parts.

Retail furniture sales slipped off somewhat under the influence of rainy weather and war scares during September, but made a better-than-average showing, nevertheless, reports of representative units to the National Retail Furniture Association showed today.

William V. Dwyer, who in the prohibition era amassed a fortune as the head of one of the largest rings of liquor smugglers ever discovered in this section of the country and who served a term of two years in a Federal prison for his bootlegging activities, is in trouble with the government once more.
Hudson St, 494-6: Lerna Realty Co to Boris Realty Corp, 47 Washington Square S; correction deed. Same property; Boris Realty Corp to Crowell Realty Corp, 47 Washington Square S.

Governor Frank Murphy of Michigan was accused of "treasonable" tactics and obstruction of civil authority during the General Motors sit-down strikes of January, 1937, in testimony given today before the House Committee Investigating Un-American Activities.

Chrystle St, 111, 25x100; Chrystie Management Corp to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, p m, demand, int as per bond; $25,199. Same property, same to same, bldg loan, pr mtg $25,199, demand; int as per bond; $5,800.

A larger budget is necessary to carry through the expansion program of the Bureau of Advertising of the A. N. P. A., members of the committee in charge of the bureau agreed this week at a meeting in Chicago. The campaign has gotten off to an excellent start, it was reported, but additional funds, particularly for research and promotion, are necessary.

Four pickets at the Aerovox Corporation plant, 70 Washington Street, Brooklyn, were fined $25 each yesterday by Magistrate Jacob Eilperin -in Bay Ridge Court for disorderly conduct during a fistfight with non-striking workers on Oct. 12.

Among the new apartment tenancies reported yesterday was arranged with Allen Wardwell of the law firm of Davis, Polk, Wardwell, Gardiner Reed, who took a triplex suite of twelve rooms and four baths in 136 East Seventy-ninth Street, through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers.

Eight furry animals, about ten inches long, with five-fingered, hand-like paws, panda-like bodies and owls' eyes, arrived from Singapore today in the care of Clifford M. Pressnall of Chicago. The animals are en route to the San Diego zoo.

A fighting Temple eleven that refused to be beaten came surging back in a thrilling fourth-period rally tonight to tie undefeated Boston College, 26-26, before a crowd of 15,000 that yelled itself hoarse.

Judge Cornelius F. Collins in General Sessions yesterday expressed indignation at vice conditions in Harlem, after a Negro woman had been found guilty before him of manslaughter in the first degree in the stabbing of Frederick J. Supanic, 29 years old, a city fireman, there in the early morning of July 18 last.

IN that shrill pastoral of Manhattan's needled fields called "I Can Get It for You Wholesale," Jerome Weidman first presented felonious Harry Bogen, the Heel of Destiny. Bogen's relentlessly contemptible career is continued this morning in Mr. Weidman's second panel of an inhuman comedy, "What's in It for Me?"*

The new municipal recreational center, directly above the entrance to the Lincoln Tunnel, which was built here by the. Port Authority at a cost of $40,000 on a two-acre plot exchanged for land condemned for tunnel purposes, was dedicated this afternoon.

Miss Margaret Jane Ewart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Bateman Ewart of Ardsley-onHudson, was married this afternoon to Howard Weaver McCall Jr. of New York and Chattanooga, Tenn., son of Mr. and Mrs. McCall of Chattanooga, in the Irvington Presbyterian Church.

Roger H. Butterworth, pioneer real estate operator here and a former president of the local board of health, died yesterday at the Marcus L. Ward Homestead, Maplewood. at the age of 73. Born in this city, Mr. Butterworth entered the real estate business as a young man.

Philip Hill and associates have obtained government sanction for repatriation from the United States of 2,200,000 5s ordinary shares of F. W. Woolworth Co., Ltd. The group proposes to offer the shares for sale in London on Nov. 1. The deal will involve about [Pound]6,000,000.
Airplane "bombings" of Burgos, Spanish Insurgent capital, with silk stockings and other articles of clothing was described today in advices from across the border.

140th St (10-2570), n e cor of Jackson Ave, 100x125; Celia Kaufman to Bernard Kaufman, 682 St Marys St; mtg $25,000. Castle Hill Ave (15-3990), e s, 213 ft s of Parker Ave, 25x81; also Castle Hill Ave, e s, 238 ft s of Parker Ave, 25x92; Rose Thiel to Angelina Puccl, 1,425 Vyse Ave; mtg $13,250.

The stock markets here closed the account today on a rising note, although business still was on a small scale. Gilt-edge issues showed little alteration. Foreign bonds were equally firm, with Czech and Japanese issues up.

The tragic death from heart failure of Harris Moriarty while umpiring in the N. Y. U.-North Carolina game last Saturday brings into focus a situation too long neglected in collegiate football, namely the age and physical condition of the officials.

Mayor La Guardia analyzed the merits of the nine proposed amendments to the State Constitution to be voted upon Nov. 8 in a radio talk last evening, and counseled the voters of the State to vote against amendments 1, 2, 5 and 7.
New York's 1940 automobile license plates will cost the State at least $23,000 less to manufacture than the plantes for 1939 now in production.

Cheshire Academy today defeated the Yale freshmen, 6-0, Halfback Ed Marx of New Britain galloping 40 yards on an off-tackle reverse through a broken field in the second quarter for the only score of the contest.

Information has reached British shipping circles that French plans for construction of a larger and faster liner than the Cunard-White Star liner Queen Elizabeth are further advanced than hitherto supposed, according to Hector C. Bywater, The Daily Telegraph's naval expert.

Closing of all automobile sales rooms on Sundays will soon be customary throughout the country it is predicted by the National Automobile Dealers Association, which has just completed a survey covering 1,000 dealers.

Alberto Santo, 37 years old, operator of the Cross Bay Speedway, an automobile racing track in Ozone Park, Queens, was exonerated of a charge of manslaughter yesterday when he wars arraigned before Magistrate Nicholas H. Pinto in Felony Court, Ridgewood, Queens.

The farewell between Chancellor Hitler and Andre Francois-Poncet at Berchtesgaden Tuesday has given currency to reports that the retiring French Ambassador is returning to Paris with a significant message of goodwill from Herr Hitler to France.

The hope was expressed by Secretary of State Cordell Hull at his press conference today that he would be able to head the United States delegation to the Pan American Conference in Lima, Peru, in December.
" Preliminary and limited" excavation shows that the poet Edmund Spenser was buried not in a vault but in a grave, according to the Right Rev. Paul de Labilliere, Dean of Westminster Abbey.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construction of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Three new passenger ships for transpacific service are being designed by the United States Maritime Commission as its next step in the development of a complete American merchant marine, M. L. Wilcox, director of operations and traffic of the commission, said last night at the dinner of the American Steamship and Tourist Agents Association, held in the Hotel McAlpin.
Following is the reply of John Lord O'Brian, Republican candidate for Senator, to questions put in an editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES, this being embodied in a speech made by him here today:

Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said today that the increase in industrial loans reported by the Federal Reserve Banks might be, in part, owing to the standardization of Federal regulations for examining banks.

The cornerstone of the Lorimer Memorial Chapel on the new Colby College campus was laid this afternoon by Graeme Lorimer of Philadelphia, son of the donor, the late George Horace Lorimer, Colby alumnus and long editor of The Saturday Evening Post.

After a twenty-four-hour silence, the Rumanian newspapers are being allowed to discuss the surprise visit of Foreign Minister Josef Beck of Poland. The comment that has passed the censorship says that Colonel Beck achieved nothing that he had Sought.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Breaking for the first time the law of exile, which bars male members of the house of Bourbon-Orleans from France, 30-year-old Prince Henry, Count of Paris and pretender to the extinct French throne, today made a dramatic secret airplane dash to plead on the soil of his ancestors for restoration of the monarchy as the only means of saving his country from decay or party dictatorship.
Paul Runyan of White Plains, N. Y., qualified for the semi-finals of the golf masters tournament today by defeating Agapito Moreno, 3 and 2, in a second-round match.

John F. Hamlin, manager of the 'residential department of Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., has been elected to the firm's board of directors. Mary E. McLaughinhas been named assistant secretary and Alfred L. Campbell controller and assistant treasurer.

Mrs. Dorothy Hale, widow of Gardner Hale, noted fresco and mural painter, and a close friend of Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, was instantly killed early yesterday in a fall from the window of her small apartment on the sixteenth floor of Hampshire House at 150 Central Park South.

The Irving Trust Company, trustee in bankruptcy for the Radio-KeithOrpheum Corporation, announced yesterday that Leo Spitz had tendered his resignation as president of the Keith-Albee-Orpheum Corporation,

In an attempt to make the new theatre ticket code foolproof, the board of governors of the League of New York Theatres and its recognized ticket brokers held a joint parley yesterday in the league's offices, 234 West Forty-fourth Street.

Trading somewhat improved in local markets yesterday because of cooler weather. Lamb and pork were steady to slightly higher; veal and calf lower; other classes about steady. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture. follow:

The annual class day exercises of the Evening Division of the New York University College of Engineering will be attended tonight by sixty-six students who this month have completed their requirements for bachelor degrees.

On Monday F. R. Tripler Co. will open a new clothing and furnishings department for young men. Clothing at $42 and $48, evening wear at $45 and polo coats at $50 will be among the new price ranges, which are somewhat lower than those hitherto featured by the store.
Realty interests generally appear to frown upon.the proposed State constitutional amendment designed to give State aid, to supplement Federal and local funds, for slum clearance and low-rent housing.
Sam Blair, Chicago newspaper man, died today of a heart attack at his home here at the age of 47. He was educated at Bucknell Unfversity and at the Universities of Texas and of Kansas.

Colonel Beau, white and black setter owned by Dr. C. E. Wagg of Lambertville, won first honors in the open derby stake today at the start of the thirty-seventh annual meeting of the English Setter Club of America.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced again yesterday to end the session at the highest quotations of the week and with net gains of 5 to 11 points for the day.

AHLSTROM, MATHILDA (May 9, 1938). Gross assets, $14,790; net, $14,175. To husband, Gustave E. Ahlstrom. Chief assets, jointly owned property, $14,790. Adolph Hansen, attorney, 150 Nassau St., Manhattan.

Postmaster General James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratio State Committee, has invited the Democratic chairmen of eleven Southern Tier counties to a breakfast conference at the Hotel Biltmore Monday,

Virginio Gayda, writing in the Giornale d'Italia, seizes the opportunity offered by the speech made yesterday by Sir Samuel Hoare, British Home Secretary, to voice displeasure with the intensification of the rearmament programs of the United States, Great Britain and France.

Declaring that "the goal is now in sight," Bishop William T. Manning announced yesterday that he had requested the 400 clergymen in the Episcopal Diocese of New York, of which he is the head, to call on all their parishioners, on Sunday, Oct. 30, to make some contribution toward the opening of the interior of the nave of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine before the start of the World's Fair.

Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson adjourned yesterday until next Friday afternoon a hearing on confirmation of the recent foreclosure sale of the Sixth Avenue elevated line to a protective committee representing holders of the 4 per cent first mortgage bonds of the Manhattan Railway Company.

" Son of Old Man Hat," the autobiography of a Navajo Indian from childhood to maturity, will be published by Harcourt, Brace on Oct. 27. The book is "recorded by" Walter Dyk, who holds a doctor's degree in anthropology from Yale University and who is now at Harvard Pavchological Clinic.

The Italian liner Conte di Savoia, sailing today for Mediterranean ports, will have as passengers Mrs. Charles de Rham, Sidney Chaplin, Mrs. Reginald C. Vanderbilt, Mrs. A. B. Thaw, Lady Mary Lygon, Miss Dorothy Flagg, Miss Helen Gifford and Mrs. Augusto Rosso.
Two sophomore substitutes, Harvey Johnson and Frank Chambers, galloped to glory tonight in a pair of spectacular 80-yard drives which gave Mississippi State a 12-to-7 triumph over Duquesne.

It may not be an accident that the two Broadway plays which have met this season with the highest praise from the critics are "Hamlet" and "Abe Lincoln in Illinois." Shakespeare's creation and America's native son were both puzzled liberals.

George Smith, 38-year-old WPA worker, is going to trade places with his wife, Dorothy, 33. He will take up his wife's duties in the home, doing the dishes, sweeping the house and taking care of their four small children, while Mrs. Smith does the breadwinning via the WPA.

The Norman Stewart Hall Memorial Scholarship in Yale University was awarded today to Joseph William Stack Jr. of Lansing, Mich., a junior in Yale College. A member of the varsity football team this year, he was captain of his freshman team. He has been largely self-supporting during his college course.

Completely outplayed in the first quarter, St. Paul's School of Nassau County came from behind with touchdowns in each of the next two periods to conquer its traditional rival, Brooklyn Prep, 14-9, yesterday at Prep's Field.

Mr. and Mrs. Maitland Armstrong of Newport have arrived at the Gotham. Mrs. Charles Henry Coster will be at 277 Park Avenue for the Winter. Mrs. John S. Phipps of Palm Beach is at the Pierre. Mr. and Mrs. Carl B. Ely of Greenwich are at Hampshire House for the season. Mrs. Roy D. Chapin Jr. of Detroit is visiting them.
The Swarthmore College soccer team lost its first game in three starts today to a powerful Princeton eleven, 2-0.

In the old-fashioned court house at Lowville, county seat of Lewis County, John Lord O'Brian, Republican candidate for United States Senator, stood at the judge's bench this afternoon and, in the manner of a judge delivering a charge to a jury, made his reply to the questions to candidates for the Senate asked by THE NEw YORK TIMES on its editorial page yesterday.

Relief investigators under Mayor La Guardia coerced tenement dwellers in the Sixteenth Congressional District into voting against him by threatening that relief would be stopped if he were renominated, Representative-John J. O'Connor, the "purged" Democrat who is seeking re-election as the Republican nominee, charged last night in a speech before the Metropolitan Republican Women's Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street.

John C. Bancroft, president of the International Match Realization Company, Ltd., has sent to holders of its voting-trust certificates a letter explaining the foreign affairs of the company, especially those in Turkey.

Thomas E. Dewey has a chance to do better in the Southern Tier counties than any other Republican Governorship candidate in recent years. Whether he will poll that greater plurality is likely to be determined by the character of his campaign from now on.

Three stakes were completed today during the first day's running in the fifteenth annual meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association. Conditions' were excellent and a large gallery of enthusiasts followed the dogs morning and afternoon through the trying covers that have made Fishers Island the last word as a proving ground.
The Nassau County grand jury started today an investigation into charges of bribery and corruption made against several officials of the city of Long Beach t Lorenzo Carlino, Republican leader there.

A surgical technique whereby artificial arms are attached to the muscles of the stump in a manner enabling a person to manipulate hand and fingers was reported yesterday before the closing sessions of

An increase of $78,434,000 in the value of construction planned thus far in 1938, despite 12,095 fewer building permits, was reported by State Industrial Commissioner Frieda S. Miller today as "characteristic of a building revival."

The nineteenth annual pilgrimage of the Boy Scouts of America to the grave of Theodore Roosevelt at Youngs Memorial Cemetery, Oyster Bay, L. I., will be held at 2 P. M. today, it was announced yesterday at the National Council office here.
Most of the foreign exchanges rallied yesterday, but there was as little in the day's foreign news to explain this recovery as there had been on the previous day to explain the sharp fall.

The trial of Raymond Swinscoe, 39 years old, of 955 Rossville Avenue, Rossville, S. I., ended abruptly before Judge Downs in Richmond County Court yesterday when Swinscoe pleaded guilty to a charge of murder in the second degree in the death of his daughter, Delores, 4, at the Swinscoe home on June 3. The prisoner is a former WPA chauffeur.
Three persons were arraigned today before County Judge Cortland A. Johnson here on an indictment charging them with being common gamblers and with maintaining a place for gambling.
Three hundred prominent educators came here today to witness the inauguration of Dr. K. C. Leebrick as fourth president of Kent State University and discuss the place of education in democracy.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,120,000 bales, against 1,143,000 a week ago, 1,140,000 two weeks ago, 1,157,000 three weeks ago and 773,000 a year ago; of which American 547,000 bales, against 565,000 a week ago, 581,000 two weeks ago, 599,000 three weeks ago and 322.000 a year ago.

About 2,500 enlisted men in the Second Corps Area participated yesterday in celebrations commemorating the entry of the first American troops into the trenches on the Western Front in the World War. The ceremonies in the metropolitan area were held at Fort Hamilton, Governors Island and Fort Wadsworth, where some of the First Division troops are now stationed.

Guenther Gustav Rumrich, an army deserter who pleaded guilty to a charge of espionage, testified yesterday at the trial of three erstwhile co-defendants that he entered into a plot to sell military secrets to Germany with the dual motive of eking out a meagre income as a translator and of rehabilitating himself with army officials by exposing the machinations of his fellow conspirators.

Calling for careful scrutiny of the Neutrality Act because of present world conditions, Dr. James P. Baxter 3d, president of Williams College, declared at Founders' Day exercises at Lafayette College today that the act of 1937 was less likely to keep this country out of war than our earlier system.

The Group Theatre, it seems, has changed its mind again regarding the opening date of "Rocket to the Moon" at the Belasco. First set for Nov. 24, then advanced to Nov. 17, the opening is now scheduled for the original date.

Arnold H. Goss,66-year-old retired president of the Kelvinator Corporation, was found dead tonight, his throat slashed by a razor which lay near by, in a wood near the Oaklands Dairy Farm, which he owned. Dr. Edwin C. Ganzhorn, Coroner, returned a verdict of suicide. Mr.

The inquiry of the United States Maritime Commission into freight rates to Puerto Rico continued yesterday at the hearing room at 45 Broadway before John A. Russell, examiner for the government. Dr. Ernest Gruening, regional territorial director of the Department

Harold Dublirer, counsel for the Window Trimmers Union, Local 144, a C. I. O. affiliate, announced last night that he had posted bond for the four pickets and a union business agent sentenced by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo on Thursday, and that he had obtained their release from civil jail.

For the second week in succession Miss Laddie Irwin, young Glen Ridge star, annexed low gross honors in the weekly one-day tournament of the New Jersey Women's Golf Association by scoring 42, 42-84 over the Shackamaxon Country Club course today.

Dr. and Mrs. James Rowland Angell today gave a tea and reception to introduce to society Mrs. Angell's daughter, Miss Caroline Woodman, a sophomore at Smith College. At the tea table were Mrs. Edward Grant Buckland, Mrs. Harvey Cushing, Mrs. Carl A. Lohmann, Mrs. George H. Nettleton, Mrs. William Lyon Phelps, Mrs. Edward Bliss Reed, Mrs. Henry H. Townsend and Mrs. Charles Seymour.

The report of the United Corporation for the three months to Sept. 30, issued for publication today, shows a net income of $1,891,644 after all operating expenses and charges, compared with a net of $2,185,351 in the third quarter of last year.

President Getulio Vargas will open the Philatelic Exposition here tomorrow. Twenty-nine countries will be represented. There will be 230 exhibitors, including President Roosevelt and Prince Dom Pedro d'Orleans, pretender to the extinct Brazilian imperial throne.
H. R. Bain, a member of the local syndicate that recently bought Senator O'Connor's controlling interest of about 30,000 shares in Laura Secord Candy Shops, Ltd., announced today that the company,

The New York University freshman football team opened its fourgame schedule by bowing to the Lafayette cubs, 19 to 6, at Ohio Field yesterday. It was the second victory in as many Starts for the Leopards.

After two days of private showing, at which attendance figures of last year were doubled, a display of 1939 automobiles of the Chrysler Corporation was opened to the public yesterday at the International Automobile Salon in the Chrysler Building.
Retail trade here improved with the arrival of cooler weather this week. Ready-to-wear and fur departments began to show a greater degree of activity.
Patrick F. Joyce, former State Senator, manufacturer and sportsman, died today, following a long illness. His age was 71. His entire life was spent in his native Pittston and suburban Harding.
Walter (Popeye) Woods of New York scored a technical knockout over Al Diamond of Newark, N. J., in 2:55 of the second round of the main event of a fight card tonight. Woods weighed 163, Diamond 169.
Tire shipments in September amounted to 3,943,486 units, compared with 4,045,540 in August and 3,511,552 in September last year, according to the Rubber Manufacturers Association.

Throttling the opposition's offensive and capitalizing on two scoring opportunities, Blair Academy's band of football huskies continued their all-conquering pace today with a 14-to-0 victory over the Horace Mann School eleven of New York City.

Governor Lehman was on notice from Mayor La Guardia tonight that he would not have the Mayor's support in the State Democratic campaign unless and until he proclaimed his endorsement of President Roosevelt and the policies of his Administration.
Central ParK South, 208:0-story apartment and store, 25x100.5; East River Savings Bank against Emma, J. O'Connor; due $83,170; taxes, etc., $25,584; to plaintiff for $1,000.

A hearing has been set for Oct. 27 by the Securities and Exchange Commission on an application by the Staten Island Edison Company for exemption from filing a declaration in connection with the issue and sale at par of a $3,000,000 note bearing 3 1/4 per cent interest and the issuance of $3,000,000 of first mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds to mature in not less than twenty years.
