Cotton-mill activity, with allowance for the holiday, increased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index rose to 109.9 from 108.9, the revised level for the previous week. The figure was 105.9 for the week ended Oct. 16, 1937.

Formation of a citizens' commisLee for John Lord O'Brian, Republican nominee for United States Senator, with William M. Chadbourne as chairman and Mark W. Maclay as treasurer, was announced yesterday at the O'Brian headquarters in the Hotel Roosevelt. Other members of the committee are:

The New Zealand Reserve Bank raised its selling rate for foreign exchange one-half per cent today in an effort to check she flight of capital from the country since the Socialist government was returned for a second term.

Behind shrieking police sirens and stretched out in the ambulance he designed, Dr. Harry M. Archer, dean of New York's fire "buffs" and for thirty years honorary surgeon of the Fire Department, was brought back to the city yesterday afternoon after he had suffered painful injuries in an automobile accident in New Jersey.

To take effect 8 A. M., Oct. 22: Lieutenant Gustave R. Mauch, from Emergency Service Division to 122d Precinct, assignment to desk duty continued. (Res. Pct. 120.) PATROLMEN-Patrick T. O'Connor from Pot. 44 to Trf. Pct. D; John J. Ross from Pet. 72 to Trf. Pet. F; Harold J. Hartmayer from E. S. S. 2 to E. S. S. 7; Thomas E. J. McHugh from E. S. S. 10 to E. S. S. 3.

The War Deapartment released the following orders today, dated Oct. 20: Holbrook, Maj. Gen. L. R., three months' and eleven days' leave, about Oct. 20. Gardner, Brig. Gen. F. Q. C., ordered to sail from New York for the Hawaiian Dept., about Nov. 15 instead from Charleston. S. C.. Dec. 30.
Colo Colo, beautifully ridden by Major Eduardo Yanez of the Chilean Army, won the individual military championship of the International Horse Show today.
Michael Rosenker, Russian violinist, who made his initial appearance here two seasons ago, gave his second recital last night in Town Hall.
The Douglas Aircraft Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday consolidated net profits of $1,821,964 for the nine months ended on Aug. 31.

Representatives of seven sections of the petroleum unions have sent a memorandum to the chief of the Petroleum Administration, Vicente Cortes Herrera, asserting that labor chiefs now running the camps for the government have wasted money on automobiles and refrigerators.
Our picture yesterday of the First Lady's new coiffure had a caption describing it as "a modified upswing."

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Oct. 19: LIEUTENANTS Crandell, D. A., the Dallas, to the Tattnall. as executive officer; orders to Naval Academy revoked. Danhoff, J. B., the Litchfield, to continue treatment Naval Hospital, Pearl Harbor, T. H.

Despite promises by the Moslem Supreme Council to Keith Roach, District Commissioner of Jerusalem, that the Arabs within the Old City would henceforth be on their best behavior, one British soldier was killed by Arab snipers this morning.
Replacement buying at wholesale slackened during the week, as retail turnover fell, according to the weekly summary issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Henry Angley Lewis-Dale, 62, who just before his retirement from the Air Ministry was responsible for surveying the transatlantic air route, was found dead from gas with his wife at the home of a relative at Crewe, where there had been a family reunion.

Attorneys for Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, in the injunction suit against the union won a legal battle yesterday for the admission of evidence intended to show that the League for Industrial Rights was an anti-labor group aiding the plaintiffs in alleged efforts to "break up" the union.
Nearly every house in the park is the scene of a week-end house party for the annual Tuxedo Autumn Ball to be held tomorrow night at the club. The ball will be the largest held here in twenty years.

An official of the Western Union Telegraph Company, testifying in support of the company's plea that its messenger boys be exempted from the 25-cents-an-hour minimum wage prescribed in the new Wage and Hour Act, told a Federal examiner yesterday that 1,401 Western Union messengers were earning less than 10 cents an hour.

Firmly established as favorite over Yale in tomorrow's game, the University of Michigan eleven arrived today and spent the afternoon and night at the Cheshire Academy, its headquarters. The eleven did not visit the Yale Bowl for practice.

The Japanese press and public interpret the capture of Canton as marking the initial stage of the disintegration of Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek's government and the ultimate collapse of Chinese resistance against Japan.

An investor has purchased from the Manufacturers Trust Company the six-story elevator apartment house for sixty-five families at 2,842 Grand Concourse, southeast corner of 198th Street, the Bronx. Assessed at $240,000, the property fronts 121 feet on the Concourse and 110 feet on the street.

Foreign Minister Rickard Sandler of Sweden and Foreign Minister Rudolf Holsti of Finland have arranged a meeting to settle the question of the fortification of the Aaland Islands, lying between Sweden arid Finland.
Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh today expressed the hope that German airships soon would cross the Atlantic again in regular flights to America.

Josef Hofmann, pianist, will make his only orchestral appearance this season as soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under John Barbirolli, at a benefit concert for the orchestra penion fund, to be given Dec. 19 at Carnegie Hall,

Dr. Louis S. Bardoly does not do things by halves. He is a Cleveland surgeon who has written a medical play entitled "Case History," which was acted at the Lyceum last evening. When he dramatizes sickness in one household he steps it up to the proportions of a plague.

Building plans filed yesterday included specifications for two more apartment houses in the development of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in the Bronx. Architects also filed for numerous dwellings in Queens.

The Board of Trade for GermanAmerican Commerce, an organization with headquarters in this city, has urged upon Secretary Hull the prompt opening of negotiations for a reciprocal trade treaty between the United States and Germany. Eighteen such treaties have already been concluded by our Government.
COURAGE, by Tim Pridgen. (Little, Brown, $3.50.) The story of modern cock-fighting. DOCTOR BRADLEY REMEMBERS, by Francis Brett Young. (Reynal

Pope Pius in a speech yesterday to 300 professors of Christian archaeology gathered in Rome compared Chancellor Hitler with Julian the Apostate and recalled Nero and the Apostle Judas in denouncing in strong terms recent Nazi tactics.

International monetary problems in general and particularly the deprecation of the British pound in its relationship to the dollar, were dis cussed today at a conference between Secretary Morgenthau and a group of economic advisers.
Colonel Frank Knox of The Chicago Daily News said today in a speech here: "To work and vote for the success of the Republican candidates this year is the only way to put America back to work."

A folder entitled "The Unfinished Drama of Health," outlining progress in medicine since the first organized hospital campaign was begun sixty years ago, will be issued today by the United Hospital Campaign Committee. The committee will start a drive on Monday for $2,523,179.78 for ninety-two member hospitals and the Visiting Nurse Association of Brooklyn.
The annual State conference on social work closed this afternoon on the same note of grave concern for the future morale of relief clients, on which it opened Monday night. Dr.

Sidney Levine, broker, sold to an investor for the Lafayette National Bank the two four-story apartment houses at 92-94 Brooklyn Avenue, Brooklyn, for cash above a first mortgage of $17,000 running for five years, which was taken back by the bank.

This city has lived through an unusually tense twenty-seven hours marked by nine bombing raids. In a mass attack on a crowded residential district near the port, women and children were among the victims.

Play in the Metropolitan League Class C squash tennis tournament started yesterday with the Harvard Club, defending titleholder, conquering the Columbia University Club, 4 to 1, on the Harvard courts.

Fifteen minutes after they had been ejected from a Bronx bar and grill yesterday for disorderly drunkenness two WPA workers returned and in a twenty-minute brawl which ensued a Department of Sanitation employee was fatally stabbed and three other men were wounded.
Placements of unemployed workers in positions reached the highest point of the year in September, Secretary Perkins reported today.

An urgent S O S for more men and women to become teachers in New York City's vocational schools was sent out yesterday by the Board of Examiners. All the good points of a teaching job were stressed: tenure, vacations, $4,500 yearly pay and pension rights.

The Rev. Dr. Edmund Melville Wylie, former minister of the Park Avenue Presbyterian Church and associate minister of the Brick Presbyterian Church, both in New York City, was installed tonight as minister of the Scarborough Presbyterian Church. He succeeds the Rev.
Substitute Johnny Healey of the Yale 150-pound varsity eleven crashed off tackle 23 yards for the only score in the game with the Pennsylvania 150-pounders today and the Elis won, 6-0.
Henry Bentley, one of the leading organizers and first president of the Cincinnati Charter Committee, died here today at the age of 58.
Wallace Wade, head coach of Duke University, said today that he had given Syracuse University permission to play Wilmeth Sidat-Singh, cr_ck Negro back, against Duke Nov 12 at Syracuse.

John J. Murphy, 44 years old, manager of the Whist Club at 9 East Sixty-second Street, was arrested yesterday afternoon, charged with grand larceny. He was accused on the complaint of H. H. McClure, secretary of the club, with appropriating $8,423 of the organization's funds.

Jerry Essig, white and black setter owned by Dr. Sherman Ames of Easton, Pa., won a leg on the F. Dwight Foster Trophy today by defeating thirty-six rivals in the English Setter Club of America shooting dog stake.

With the number being increased at the rate of 12,500 a week, more than 1,200,000 persons are now living in homes financed under the Federal Housing Administration program, Administrator Stewart McDonald announced yesterday.

The annual roller skating meet of the city Department of Parks will be held next Saturday afternoon on the Circle Lawn rink at 106th Street and Central Park West. There will be events for both children and adults, and for boys and girls.
The annual Tuxedo Autumn Ball, held here tonight at the Tuxedo Club, was attended by more than 500 members of this colony and their house guests.

COMPLETELY ignoring the conventions of present-day fiction, Angela Thirkell has written a gay and sparkling social comedy which will cause the average modern reader to rub his, or more probably her, eyes in amazement.

The Citizens Union issued yesterday two corrections to its statement of recommendations on legislative candidates in the Bronx. In its earlier statement, the union omitted mention of Nathan Ginsberg, Republican candidate for State Senator, and erroneously listed Meyer Levenstein, Assembly candidate, as a Socialist, when he is a member of the American Labor party.

PUBLIC interest in broadcasting the City Council meetings as evidenced by response from listeners last season has led WNYC, the municipal station, to install its microphone to pick up the sessions in toto.

The Consumers Cooperative Institute of the Westchester Federation of Consumers Clubs will be held here next Saturday at the First Presbyterian Church "to find out how cooperative clubs can best serve Westchester communities" and to study "the value of cooperatives in suburban life."

Judge Florence E. Allen of the Ohio Supreme Court will talk on "The Place of Churchwomen in National Life" at a meeting on Wednesday of the Women's Cooperating Commission of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America.

George R. Van Namee, manager of Senator Robert F. Wagner's reelection campaign, forecast yesterday on the basis of reports from up-State that the Senator would win this year by a wider margin than he did in 1932.

AFTER Indian Summer, with its golden leaves and crimson, come the real football days. Cold winds will soon whirl around the gridiron-carpeted bowls. Girls had better make ready with woolly togs to keep them warm.

A plan of reorganization for the West Ohio Gas Company, a subsidiary of the Midland Utilities Company, by which the outstanding common stock owned by Midland would be eliminated and by which new bonds would be issued to the present
THE past few decades have witnessed the rapid re-emergence of the arts of the Eastern Roman Empire from the fogs of prejudice and the silence of indifference.

It is amusing, but perhaps not surprising, that the garden beginner is timorous when it comes to Fall planting. Planting in the Spring has been in so many ways forced upon his attention that he just naturally takes it for granted that Spring is the only time to plant anything and everything except.bulbs, which, since they must be planted in the Fall, he makes plans to put in then..
IN 1665 four of the five nations of the Iroquois Confederacy concluded an alliance with the French; the Mohawks alone pledged friendship to the English. That friendship,

With ten seconds to play, Fullback Bob White drove off tackle from the one-foot line on fourth down to score the touchdown that gave West Virginia University a 20-to-13 victory over the previously unbeaten Creighton University eleven today.

Bible breakfast, William Sloane House Y. M. C. A., 356 West Thirtyfourth Street, 9 A. M. Address by Dr. Norman Vincent Peale. Communion breakfast, Catholic Action group of Giuditta Guild, Hotel Biltmore, 10:30 A. M. Speakers: Mgr. J. Francis A. McIntyre, the Rev. Francis X. Talbot, the Rey. Joseph Dougherty.

President Roosevelt let it be known through Senator Robert F. Wagner today that he was "greatly concerned" for the maintenance of Palestine as a Jewish national home and that this government would do all in its power to dissuade Britain against restriction of Jewish immigration there.
Mrs. Maude Zeamer Keat, teacher of English for more than twenty years at Orange High School until her retirement last month, died of a heart attack last night at her home here.

Lehigh ran wild in the final period of the game with the University of Delaware on Frazer Field today, making four touchdowns to triumph by 32-0. The Blue Hens gave the Engineers a tough battle for three quarters, but tired in the final minutes.

Elderly couples eligible for old-age pensions received $700 in the past year while younger heads of families, unemployable because of illness or other causes, received $43. This is only one of the many anomalies of the Colorado pension situation.

WORKING steadily at a job that will not be finished until 1949, excavators in Wiltshire, England, are uncovering at Avebury village a huge temple where Neolithic people worshiped at least 3,000 years ago.

The marriage of Miss Juliette E. Marshall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Marshall of this place, to Robert D. High, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. High, also of Westfield, took place here today In the First Methodist Church. The Rev.
A WHOLE generation of tremblers, musicians and professional lyricists. grew up around the lacework of ideas that occupies M. de Pourtales's warm and intelligent novel. His hero, Paul de Villars,

WITHOUT benefit of chromium gadgets, bizarre murals or fake palm trees, the Trianon Room at the Ambassador still retains all the courtly charm of an Old World ballroom in which fastidious folk may dance to the music of one of the finest ensembles in town.

Secretary Swanson warned today against any slackening of pace in building the navy to a strength considered necessary for the country's security. In a message occasioned by the approach of Navy Day, he said:

WHEN a stevedore, unloading cargo from the banana boats in New York Harbor, gives a shout of alarm, his co-workers know in a flash what has happened. The gang rushes to his assistance and there, coiled neatly in a bunch of bananas and glaring at his disturbers with a beady and belligerent eye, will in all probability be a boa constrictor or some other species of tropical reptile.

Despite the thousands of troops that have arrived here within the past fortnight, there is little, if any, change in Palestine's chaotic condition. Sniping, looting, sabotage, arson, kidnapping and murder in broad daylight in front of police barracks in such cities as Jaffa and Haifa continue unabated.
The Japanese announced today that General Yu Han-mou, the Military Governor of Kwangtung, had surrendered and had handed his sword to Lieut. Gen. Motoo Furusho, commander of the South China invasion.

IN his ballet "St. Francis," devised in collaboration with Paul Hindemith, Leonide Massine has achieved one of the most memorable and beautiful dance works of our time. Unorthodox in subject matter, elevated in tone, and revolutionary in its choreographic procedure, it is one of those creations which, like Bronislava Nijinska's "Les Noces," grow out of boldness of conception without regard for precedent or consequences.

In another move to strengthen its position by obtaining increased business for its members, the Pittsburgh Stock Exchange has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission applications for the unlisted trading privileges in thirtyfour stocks which are registered and listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

With the embarkation of Italian troops from Cadiz and -the withdrawal of the International Brigade from the Ebro front this week, the first active steps have been taken toward applying the British plan for removing international issues from the Spanish Civil War.

Henry Heitfeld, former United States Senator from Idaho, State legislator, business man and Mayor of Lewiston, Idaho, died here late yesterday at the age of 79. He was elected to the Senate in 1897 and served one term.

The marriage of Miss Antoinette Corroon, daughter of Mr.,and Mrs. Richard A. Corroon of Massapequa, to Donald Vincent Reed, son of Frank L. Reed of Park Hill, Yonkers, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Reed, took place here this morning in the Church of the Cure of Ars. Mgr. Edmund J. Reilly performed the ceremony.

The police have decided to permit the public to celebrate the fall of Canton with lantern parades and other demonstrations banned since the capture of Nanking. The date of the celebration has not been decided, but it will probably be the greatest yet.

Motion-picture companies are debating whether to apply this week to the Federal court here for bills of particulars outlining the allegations of the Department of Justice in the anti-trust suit against the industry and citing specific instances at point, it was learned yesterday.

Sterling's reCover was checked on the market here today as the result of a Con-tinental demand for dollars, the rate closing at 4.75 3/4. Francs were firmer under the control of the Paris Equalization Fund, and closed at 178 23-32.

Martin Saxe, ranking member of the Committee on State and Local Finances of the recent Constitutional Convention, addressing members of the Lawyers Club last week at 115 Broadway, explained the effeet of Amendment 1 on large pension systems, such as those of the Police and Fire Departments in this city.

WHAT happened to Mark Twain's story of the Jumping Frog, when it hopped into the French language and then back again into English, is well known. And those who have seen their plays put in another tongue should approach with sympathy, for the original author, any adaptation they may make.

The boundaries of the Boy Scout districts of New York City have been revised to coincide with the municipal health areas, according to Charles M. Heistand, director of field and educational service of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York.

Rice Institute today opened its conference play with a. 13-6 victory over the University of Texas, scoring the winning touchdown in the last two and a half minutes of play. A long pass from midfield by Billy Cline, sub back, to Ollie Cordill gave Rice the ball on the Texas 23 in the last quarter.
Taking the water easily yesterday morning on the high tide, Mrs. Barklie Henry's new yawl Odyssey, designed by Sparkman Stephens and built by Henry B. Nevins, was launched at City Island.
Altrusa Club--Dinner, Woman's National Republican Club. Athena Club of Freeport--Civics and current events departments meeting, 2:30 P. M., Columbus Avenue School. Speaker, Mayor Robert E. Patterson.
Outweighed five pounds per man, the Kent State University eleven today defeated the University of Buffalo squad, 54-0.

Former President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia, who is on his way to the United States to lecture at the University of Chicago, arrived in London by air today accompanied by his wife and private secretary.

TEN years ago when Secretary Kellogg was on his way back from beflagged Paris, where the Peace Pact had just been signed by governments renouncing war as the instrument of their policy, a cynical cartoonist of Moscow depicted peace as a dove resting for a perilous moment upon bracketed bayonet points. Today that cynicism seems to most people here as elsewhere to have been justified.

The Advisory Committee of the Transportation Conference of 1938, comprising operators, users and investors, made public today the agenda for a second meeting to be held here on Nov. 21 and 22. The committee was appointed at an organization meeting-a month ago.
Lebanon Valley scored two touchdowns on forward passes today to topple St. Joseph's of Philadelphia from the ranks of undefeated college teams. The final score was 13 to 7.
A powerful Niagara University football team outclassed St. Lawrence University today to win, 32 to 7.

With several hundred bankruptcy cases filed since the Chandler act, revising the national bankruptcy law, went-into effect a month ago, credit men yesterday expressed the opinion that the law is working out excellently and that it will achieve all of the benefits' claimed for it.

ST. LOUIS. THE Mississippi River Park way, stretching from the river's source in Minnesota through five States to its mouth in the Gulf of Mexico, has taken a long step toward realization as the result of a recent conference here.
If she isn't the busiest nonagenarian in this country, Mrs. Emma A. Fox of Detroit at least keeps her nearest competitor breathing hard to maintain his margin of activity.

First showing of a Temple University Newsreel, pictorial record of campus activities, is scheduled for the coming week. The newsreel, the result of an editorial suggestion made last semester in the Temple University News, undergraduate newspaper, is thought to be the first project of its kind in the East.

Miss Clayton Sayre Sullivan, daughter of Mrs. Walter Bernard Sullivan of this city and New York, and of the late Mr. Sullivan, former publisher of The Charlotte Observer, was married here this afternoon In St. Peter's Catholic Church to Gregory Sylvester Mangin, a former member of the Davis Tennis Cup team. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Maurice McDonnell.

A snappy round of Nazi salutes greeted the Duke of Kent, younger brother of King George VI, when he arrived at Donington Park race course today to wave the starting flag of the International Grand Prix automobile race.
Crown Princess Juliana, feeling much better after her recent indisposition, today wheeled Baby Princess Beatrix in the gardens at Loo Palace near Apeldoorn.

NORTH CREEK. RADIO is the latest device to join the fight against forest refires in New York State. Though barely out of the experimental stage as an aid in fighting forest fires, the radio has tended already to cut down the tremendous annual toll of timber, wild life and recreational resources taken last year by 1,614 forest fires.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Anson Krickl of 14 East Ninetieth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diana Krickl, to John H. Brennen Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Brennen of Pelham, N. Y. The announcement was made at a buffet supper party given last night at the Larchmont Yacht Club by the prospective bride's parents.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Upon arrival in New York from Paris on Oct. 10 I made a statement, published, in part, in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 11, that the Munich agreement averted another European war and opened new possibilities for peace.

The Albany Academy eleven invaded Tarrytown today and emerged victorious over Irving School 13-7. Jack Hill scored for the visitors on a 40-yard sprint in the first period. Two minutes later Irving tallied when Russ Davies threw a 20-yard pass to Everett Carter in the end zone.

Gettysburg's Bullets took undisputed possession of first place in the conference championship today when they defeated the Franklin and Marshall Diplomats, 16 to 8. The viistors scored fourteen first downs to twelve for the Bullets.

Playing for the first time in its new stadium, the Rutgers football team crushed Hampden-Sydney of Virginia, 32 to 0, for its fourth victory of the season today. A crowd of 10,000 was on hand to see the Scarlet turn in its most convincing victory to date, as it rolled up 26 points in the first half alone.

The Argentine Government's second official estimate of the areas in this country sown to cereals shows an increase of 7.4 per cent in the wheat acreage compared with a year ago. Flaxseed sowings are up 5.3 per cent from last year.

The modern radiator has undergone radical changes in design, points out the Plumbing and Heating Industries Bureau. Manufacturers have given a smart, streamlined design to the type of radiator which stands out in the room.

More than 10,000 retail druggists of this city, as well as drug manufacturers and scientists, have been invited to attend the drug industry's dedication of its $1,000,000 Hall of Pharmacy at the New York World's Fair of 1939 on the afternoon of Sunday, Nov. 13, it was announced yesterday by Dr. William J. Schieffelin, chairman of the dedication committee.
The eight-story buildings at 528 and 532 West 111th Street, each of which contains forty suites, are fully rented, according to the Borchard Management Corporation, agents.
The Calumet Farms' Bull Lea, odds-on favorite and carrying top weight, won the $5,000-added Autumn Handicap by five lengths in near-record time at Narragansett Park today.

Political talks scheduled for broadcast over local stations today are: Harold Riegelman and L. A. Tanzer, attorneys, in a debate on Amendment No. 1 of the new State Constitution, WMCA, 8 to 8:30 P. M.

Army and Navy split the laurels in the second annual quadrangular cross-country meet yesterday over Van Cortlandt Park's testing fivemile course. Columbia and Princeton filled the other two places in the event. The cadets carried away team honors with 26 points and Navy's Barney Oldfield won the individual prize.
June as the universally favored month for marriages was largely disproved yesterday by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. Citing a survey of sixteen

George Meany, chairman of the American Federation of Labor State Nonpartisan Committee, took issue yesterday with Mayor La Guardia and the American Labor party for their opposition to Amendment 1 to the State Constitution.
Hunters with machine guns had an invitation today to contract for the killing of 1,000 elk said to be damaging property at C. H. Rathbone's Circle H Ranch, near Augusta, on the Sun River.

Congress probably will be asked at its next session to increase the authorized total of army planes by 1,000 or more, it became known yesterday. Authorization for the creation of an adequate reserve of planes for the army air corps may also be sought, and efforts to place the aviation industry on a mass-production basis will be hastened.

Drexel Tech defeated Juniata College today, 18-13. Walter Ehmling starred for the victors with two touchdowns. Powell Hughes accounted for the third Dragon marker. Ehmling ran 43 yards to the 1-yard line, then plunged through center for his second touchdown.

The United States Hydrographic Office, in its weekly bulletin, urgently requests mariners of every nationality to give complete information on hurricane conditions during the season of these storms, which lasts until Nov. 30.
AMONG the baker's dozen of solo shows and eight group Exhibitions which fell to the lot of this reviewer last week were works by old-timers and newcomers--oils, sculpture, water-colors

Clarkson Tech and Ithaca College battled to a 7-to-7 tie on the gridiron today in the first home game for the Engineers this season. The Ithacans took the lead early the first quarter on sustained power plays. The Clarkson eleven,

A survey of substitute markets to replace those merchandise sources involved in the Czechoslovak crisis will be continued until the end of the year, it was stated yesterday by P. J. Reilly, managing director of the Associated Merchandising Corporation.

A plea for the Jewish people not to isolate themselves but to join Christian groups in the struggle against dictatorships and the preservation of liberty and justice was made yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Hyman I. Schachtel of the West End Synagogue, 160 West Eightysecond Street.
Candidates for County President will speak Friday on better government before the Westchester Federation of Women at the Contemporary Club of White Plains.
Graduates of the Class of '32 of the Pennsylvania State College have offered $4,500 to the board of trustees to begin a series of mural paintings in Old Main, the college administration building.

Political aides here were not surprised by Administration proposals in the last ten days for extensive broadening of the old-age benefits of the Social Security Act, which now provides for payments to persons over 65, beginning in 1942.
FOR years, it was generally supposed that the last remaining pillar of resistance to the persuasions of the cinema was (and would continue to be) George Bernard Shaw.

Dartmouth's line strength enabled the Green Indians from Hanover to subdue a gallant Harvard eleven today in a rousing football struggle that rightfully took its place among the thrillers unfolded in the Harvard Stadium this season.

To the Art Editor: PERHAPS Mr. Eilshemius misunderstands me, since one can not set forth a very complete philosophy of art in a single letter. Certainly I shall not deny the part that the intellect plays in the production of a work of art.

Eight students of the State Normal School at Fredonia are on tour of Chautauqua County this month, speaking to parent-teacher, church and service club groups on the proposed amendments to the New York State Constitution.

The average New York family in the lower-income brackets operates on a deficit of $115.75 a year and at the same time pays at least $192.19 in hidden taxes on normal family expenditures, according to a report made public here today by the National Consumers Tax Commission.
Warren Lee Pierson, president of the United States Export-Import Bank, outlined today a four-point program to improve United States exports to South American countries.
SOME of the best of the mansions and cottages of early American and colonial days are shown in photographs at an exhibition of domestic architecture at the Metropolitan Museum.

In sharp contrast to the boom in both prices and sales which occurred when the NRA was inaugurated, the application of the Fair Labor Standards Act tomorrow will begin without having caused more than a ripple in a few industries, it was indicated by a study of various markets last week.

An exhibition of drawings and paintings by adult and child patients in the observation wards of the Psychiatric Division of Bellevue Hospital will be opened with preview tomorrow night at the Harlem Community Art Center, 290 Lenox Avenue.
Approximately 200 nurses will attend a joint meeting of the Industrial Nurses' Clubs of New England, New Jersey, Philadelphia and New York on Saturday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON. WHEN President Roosevelt named Major General Henry H. Arnold the new head of the Army Air Corps, one of the most important of all the commands involving the defense of the United States, he killed the position with a veteran airman whose career is an outstanding one in the history of American aviation.

THE second book of a new poet is a crucial phenomenon--for poet, publisher and reader. Those who took special delight in Robert Francis's "Stand With Me Here," two years ago, need have no misgivings about opening "yalhalla."

The "purging of the purgers," launched last January when the Communist party leadership ordered an end to mass expulsions of members, is proceeding much more gently than did the original purge, the injustices of which the "re-purge" was designed to redress.
Duke's powerhouse struck quickly in the waning minutes of the opening period today to whip Wake Forest's scintillating sophomores, 7 to 0, in a Southern Conference game before 10,000 spectators.

INASMUCH as the Summer season of survey flights over the North Atlantic between Europe and the United States was brought to a close last week with the final flight of Deutsche Lufthansa's Nordstern, it is possible now to check results against announcements and prepare some sort of box score.

Miss Helena Lawrence Tiffany, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan N. Tiffany of East Hampton, L. I., and William Harry Lillywhite, son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. H. Lillywhite of Southampton, were married this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents on the Montauk Highway.

Frankie Taylor, sophomore halfback, scored two touchdowns on 91 and 66 yard gallops, passed to Bill Pye for the third and kicked two conversions from placement to spark Vermont to a 20-to-0 victory over New Hampshire today before 2,500 spectators.

WE have had in recent years a number of fine stories of the Southern mountains, some of them built with more narrative skill, but none of them told with more sincerity or a sharper flavor of that primitive life than is "Posey and the Peddler."

More than 200 Barnard College undergraduates attended the Harvest Hop, the first all-college dance of the year, in Barnard Hall on the campus last night. This traditional Autumn dance, sponsored by the Athletic Association, marked the opening of sports week at the college and was directed by Helen Dollinger.
Robert E. Sherwood has just produced an impressive play dealing with Abraham Lincoln up to his election as President.
Mr. and Mrs. Alfred F. Lichtenstein's home here was the setting today for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Louise Boyd Lichtenstein, to John Denny Dale.

Some department store and other retail executives who have been studying the two-price plan of Secretary Wallace began toward the close of last week to weigh the possibilities of expanding the market through retail promotions for some of the surpluses coming within the scope of the plan.
Science has found a job for static, bane of radio listeners. It has been put to work tracing the origin and path of destructive hurricanes.
The Albright Lions outplayed the Moravian invaders, 32 to 0, on the gridiron today, handing the Blue and Gray the worst setback in the series in the past five Years.

To the Screen Editor: THE Schools Motion Picture Committee is entering upon its fourth season of recommending previewed and approved weekend programs for children and young people and we would like, through THE NEW YORK TIMES, to tell of our plans and explain some changes in policy to the parents who use our lists.

MANHATTAN BLANCHARD, LUCY N. (Oct. 5). Estate, $10,000. To Alice B. and Maria W. Blanchard, sisters, executrices, 151 E. 81st St., equal shares. CARR, WILLIAM A. (Oct. 5). Estate, more than $10,000. To Adeline S. Carr, widow, executrix, 440 W. 34th St., residue.

The American Republics liner Uruguay sailed yesterday on her first voyage to South America with eighty-five passengers and a full cargo. Captain William Bruce Oakley, former chief officer of the Leviathan and captain of the Uruguay when she was the California, was on the bridge.

Specific answers to six questions asked of candidates for election to the United States Senate in an editrial in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Thursday were made last night by Edward Corsi, Republican nominee for the short Senatorial term. Mr. Corsi spoke at a meeting of representatives of Young Republican Clubs at an oratorical contest sponscored by the Young Republican national organization.
Oberlin struck through the air twice today and dropped Swarthmore from the ranks of the unbeaten as the mid-Westerners triumphed, 14-0, before a crowd of 3,000 at Swarthmore Field.

Once again, as had been the case on many recent Saturdays, the stock market ended the week yesterday with a burst of bullish activity. In trading that ran well over 1,000,000 shares all sections of the market advanced.

After having been called ten days ago to Manila to perform a series of goiter operations, Dr. H. W. Miller, noted American surgeon and superintendent of the Seventh Day Adventist Sanitarium here, was back in Hankow today.

WE have had many novels about the Russian Revolution both by Soviet writers and Russian emigres, and now and then one by an American, but it has remained for an Englishman to write a novel of the great upheaval worthy of the name.

THIS is the first volume of an authorized autobiography made up of material supplied to an American woman by a great pianist who, by a strange trick of fate, became the Prime Minister of his native land during its rebirth as a result of the World War.

Two United States gunboats at Hankow and another at Canton refused to obey a Japanese warning to move because of danger from intense airplane bombings. The warnings, sent to all powers yesterday, set last midnight as the beginning of merciless air attacks in these districts. [Page 1.]
The Chrysler Corporation was reported today to have agreed to abandon several auto-financing practices to which the Justice Department objected last May.

The doyen of all the universities in the Three Americas, the University of San Marcos at Lima, Peru, is enlarging its plant as an aid to a recently widened curriculum. It was founded in 1553, the same year that saw the opening of the University of Mexico, but eighty-three years before Harvard saw the light of day in 1636.

The long-discussed project for the nationalization of foreign banks and insurance companies was brought to the fore again yesterday when President Getulio Vargas requested Finance Minister Arthur de Souza Costa to take action with regard to carrying out the constitutional provision for such a move.
George Washington High School's undefeated football team came from behind in the last period to nip Stuyvesant, 13 to 12, before a crowd of 3,000 at Washington Stadium yesterday.

An adjustable gas mask to fit all types and sizes of faces and a new system of anti-aircraft fire control which permits firing against planes flying above the clouds or out of sight from the ground are two recent national defense developments, it was learned yesterday.

As a step in increasing its tax ratables and getting its municipally owned properties, taken because of tax arrears, back in private hands, the borough officials of Bergenfield, Bergen County, have started a concerted effort to sell these holdings.

Residential buying in many sections of New Jersey is being maintained at a higher average than is usually customary at this period of the year, according to brokers, and the new development centers with their well-equipped houses are attracting considerable attention from prospective owners.

WITH the curtain rising to the scream of a fire siren, "The Theatre of the Air" is presented as one of the season's new shows on the California stage that feeds WABC's ninety-three-station hook-up for an hour on Wednesday nights at 9:30 o'clock.

To make a valuable collection of antiquities assembled through years available for enjoyment and study by students of all departments, Vassar College has created a new Classical Museum. A large room on the second floor of Avery Hall has been transformed by modern devices of light and color into a fitting setting for these treasures from the ancient world.

LONDON. ONE of the most interesting of recent enterprises in the English theatre was inaugurated this week at the Phoenix, where Mr. Bronson Albery and M. Michel Saint-Denis began a series of plays which are to be performed by a permanent company, supplemented as occasion may require by additional actors and actresses of the first rank.

Southern California had to come from behind to defeat Stanford, 13 to 2, today, but when the Trojan Horse started galloping after the intermission there was nothing the Indians could do about it. The result enabled the Trojans to remain tied with California for the Pacific Coast Conference lead with three straight victories for each.

Two spectacular plays netted touchdowns that aided Western Maryland to a 19-0 victory over Upsala at Ashland Stadium today. It was the Green Terrors' third victory of the season and the third consecutive defeat for the Vikings.
Already reduced crops have been destroyed in Guanacaste by heavy rains, which are flooding rivers and endangering lives in that region and in the vicinity of Puerto Cortes.

Frank Cozzi, 31-year-old welder;his wife Nancy, 27, and their three daughters, whose ages range from 3 to 9, were found dead in their four-room flat at 228 Monticello Avenue early this morning, asphyxiated from lack of oxygen. Five windows in the flat were closed. In the kitchen a gas water heater burned and two electric heaters were turned on.
FEW collectors have had the ability or stamina to develop the art of extra-illustration to as fine a point as did the late David McNeely Stauffer. Himself an artist of some note, he secured or drew

Tulane, gaining power each Saturday, turned loose its endless array of backfield stars before 15,000 spectators today to swamp Mercer, 51 to 0. Mercer could not cope with the Greenie forward wall, led by Captain Ray Miller, stellar tackle. Tulane uncovered a new star in Bob Kellogg, a fast halfback, who was one of the nation's top scorers last year at the northeast center of Louisiana State University.

An invitation to the oil companies to come directly to him for a settlement of their expropriation difficulties under Mexican law instead of working through diplomatic channels was voiced here today by President Lazaro Cardenas.

" Botany for Gardeners" is the title of a course which begins Tuesday at 11 A. M. at the laboratory building of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. The course will consist of eight lectures and discussions conducted by Dr. Henry K. Svenson on successive Tuesdays and is designed especially for those interested in amateur gardening.

PARIS. ALTHOUGH I am over my head in work on the screen adaptation of Zola's "La Bete Humaine," I am so anxious to convey my thoughts on "Grand Illusion" to the American people that I am hurriedly writing a few words about the picture, which, now more than ever, remains close to me.

A preliminary list of patrons has been completed for the benefit concert to be given by Mme. Kirsten Flagstad the evening of Nov. 15 at Carnegie Hall under the auspices of the New York Kindergarten Association.
Pitt's football juggernaut, unbeaten in twenty-games, swept over Southern Methodist, 34 to 7, today in a scramble at times so bewildering the 37,500 spectators were left gasp ing.

Alert and eager, a group of boys and girls will take their places this week behind counters to open the first florist shop ever to be operated by the vocational branch of the New York City school system.

Coming in at a daringly low altitude, thirty-six Japanese planes bombed Hankow and Wuchang, across the Yangtze River, for the first time in several weeks yesterday morning. Hankow's suburban Kiangan station and Wuchang's north station were targets. The damage was not extensive.
Iowa State's high-stepping Cyclones made it three in a row in the Big Six Conference today by vanquishing a stubborn University of Kansas football team, 21 to 7, before a homecoming crowd of 18,000.
Rapid recovery of investment values since the Munich pact averted the immediate menace of European war, still did not remove uncertainty which has of recent years existed in the investor's mind.

CATCHING the whiff of roasting chestnuts in the streets may be the New Yorkers' nearest approach to nutting in October's golden weather, but the new nut crop, even in the city, still belongs to the good things that come along in the Fall.

Livestock men attending the American Royal Livestock and Horse Show here this week reported their industry in satisfactory financial condition, due to the favorable feeding ratio, but many were worried over the outlook for fat cattle prices six months hence unless industrial operations grow in volume.

The Republican National Committee accused the Democratic National Committee today of "openly" flouting a ruling by the Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee on political contributions by Federal employes.

It was almost Summer weather as Captains MacLeod of Dartmouth and Green of Harvard ran out on Soldiers Field for the toss. Referee Red Friesell, a Princetonian himself, tossed the coin and Bob MacLeod guessed wrong. Harvard elected to receive.

Serge Lifar, one of the dancers of the Monte Carlo Ballet Russe at the Metropolitan Opera House, who resigned last Thursday night in the belief that he had been slighted by the artistic director, Leonide Massine, sailed yesterday on the French liner Champlain, declaring that he would take legal proceedings in Paris against Sol Hurok, the impresario.

The first degree murder trial of Robert Irwin, due to begin Thursday, was postponed yesterday until Nov. 3 by General Sessions Judge James G. Wallace because of the illness of an important State witness.

Miss Eleanor Morgan Taylor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Herbert Taylor of Newark, and Arthur Conrad Mentall, son of Mrs. Albert F. Mentall of Cleveland and the late Mr. Mentall, were married this evening in Roseville Methodist Episcopal Church here.
Great Union ran his most impressive race yesterday before Empire City's largest crowd and brought to Mrs. Elizabeth Graham Lewis perhaps her most important sore since she has been in racing.

A fresco that is one of the largest ever undertaken by the Federal Art Project has been completed in the Mount Vernon Public Library and is attracting wide attention during the celebration this week of the opening of a $300,000 addition to the institution.

Wearing a month's growth of beard, James (Jeff) Burkitt, 50year-old crusader against the Hague Democratic organization here, came out of the Hudson County Penitentiary at Secaucus this morning after completing a six-month sentence which resulted from his arrest in a free speech fight.
North Carolina's Tar Heels staged an air circus for 6,000 football fans today as they routed the Davidson Wildcats, 34 to 0, in the thirty-third renewal of their football rivalry.

RUBBER prices in the United States next year will soar unless the International Rubber Conference, controlled by British and Dutch producers, raises America's quota substantially above 45 per cent, preferably to 55 per cent, William O'Neil, president of the General Tire and Rubber Company, predicted last week.

Just as slide fasteners have taken a huge volume of business from button manufacturers, the rapid growth of snap closures for men's, women's and children's apparel threatens what is left, according to comment in the trade last week.

Prudential Investors, Inc.--As of Sept. 30: Net assets of $9,803,119, based on market value of investments at close of this period, equaled $215.99 each on 45,386 shares of $6 preferred stock outstanding.

The cotton textile manufacturing industry of the South will conform "to the utmost of its ability" to the provisions of the Federal WageHour Law, which becomes effective Monday, W. M. McLaurine of Charlotte, secretary of the American Cotton Manufacturers Association, said in a statement tonight.
The New Deal was attacked by Senator Capper of Kansas tonight for its farm program, for its centralization of authority in Washington and for its tax burden as well as on other fronts.

VENICE. OF the fifteen novelties launched at Venice three were by composers who wrote them expressly for the festival: Bohuslav Martinu tCzechoslovakia), Jacques Ibert (France) and Josip Slavenski (Yugoslavia).

Several residents of Lansing, Mich., told the Housa Committee investigating unAmerican activities today that a "labor holiday" staged by the United Auto Workers in the State capital June 7, 1937, resulted in forcible closing of business establishments, complete blockade of traffic, including the mails, and various types of violence and threats of violence.
Training of the "small business woman" will be emphasized in the curriculum of the Simmons College School of Busiless and Secretarial Studies this year.

WHILE he was lecturing at Olivet College and the Olivet Foundation in Detroit, Ford Madox Ford was so impressed by the number and quality of imaginative manuscripts submitted by young writers from all over the Middle West that he has for some time been considering a method to bring those manuscripts and others by new writers before the public.

Miss Ella Beach, an authority on trees and flowers, died here today at her country residence, "The Beeches," after a long illness. Born in Brooklyn, Miss Beach was the daughter of the late Chloe Buckingham Beach and Moses S. Beach, onetime editor of The New York Sun.

The British are endeavoring to assess the extent of damage to their trading and financial interests as the result of the debacle at Canton. Less than ninety miles southeast of Canton at the mouth of the Canton River is the British Crown Colony of Hong Kong.

THE general postoffice has released the first remittance of 1,000,000 received of 29,300,000 stamps of a new ordinary postage series being printed in New York in nine different values. The first five, 200,000

In a breath-taking struggle that developed into an individual battle between Johnny Pingel and Wilmeth Sidat-Singh, Michigan State's Spartans downed Syracuse, 19 to 12, today to topple the Orange from the ranks of the nation's undefeated college football elevens.

With both Governor Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic candidate for re-election, and District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, his Republican opponent, starting their up-State drives last week, the issues of the New York State campaign have begun to take definite shape.

The Federal Home Loan Bank Board, in announcing yesterday the results of a recent survey on housing and home mortgage finance conditions, points out that for a long time now residential constructiop has been one of the dark spots in the general economic situation.

Miss Carolyn Elizabeth Bronnenberg of this city, daughter of C. Ernest Bronnenberg of Anderson, Ind., and the late Mrs. Bronnenberg, was married to Ildon Rife Blackburn of East Orange and Red Bank, N. J., here yesterday morning in the chapel of the First Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Wilbert F. Smith.

WORKMEN on a lofty perch atop the dome of the Empire State Building, aided by perfect autumnal weather during the past two weeks, have been installing a radically new television aerial expected to greatly improve the telecasts routed from the studios at Radio City and from mobile televans.

Political observers in New Jersey seem to think that William H. J. Ely, Democratic candidate for United States Senator, will defeat former Senator W. Warren Barbour, Republican, in the general election on Nov. 8.

THE first coin of Sarawak made its appearance in 1870. This is a bronze cent piece showing the head profile of the "white rajah" facing left on the obverse with the inscription "C. Brooke Rajah" around the rim. The rim is beaded and the edge plain.

The scene of the most important development in the theatre today has been shifted from the stage to the box office in an attempt to win new audiences. London never has known so big a move to reduce theatre prices as the one now in progress.

FOR nine years Winston Churchill has shared with David Lloyd George the honors of an emeritus. With a seat in the House of Commons and the prestige of a Privy Councilor, he could hardly be described as a forgotten man. On occasions such as the debate on the Munich agreement he rises to the height of a powerful spokesman for a section of British public opinion.
A home-coming crowd of 8,000 saw the University of Mississippi Rebels stage their most powerful offensive thrusts of the season today to' batter a highly rated Centenary team to a 47-14 defeat.

In Chemung County, at the western end of the Sixth Judicial District, and in Steuben County, in the neighboring Seventh Judicial District, one of the things the Republicans are finding the hardest to combat is the high personal regard in which Governor Lehman is held.

The bright lights of the city and jobs in factories have lured workers away from the farm in everincreasing numbers. A Census Bureau survey Issued today showed that 53 per cent of all the nation's gainful workers were on the farm in 1870.

New government plans for a big arms drive have been revealed in three important statements. First, the Air Ministry announced that the huge armament firm of Vickers-Armstrong is to create with the aid of its whole organization a widespread subcontracting system for the manufacture of aircraft.

Prices paid for Manhattan real estate, in "open-market" transactions recently have been running closer to assessed values than was the case earlier this year, according to the monthly sales analysis of the Real Estate Board of New York.

The War Deapartment released the following orders today, dated Oct. 21: LIEUTENANT COLONEL Kroner, H. A., Inf., 10 days' leave, Oct. 30, on account of sickness. MAJORS Smith, F. M., Adjutant General's Dept., 4 days' leave, Nov. 1.

The regular meeting of the Board of Education will be held Wednesday at 4 P. M. at 500 Park Avenue. The election of an associate superintendent of schools is scheduled. New elementary, junior and senior High school teacher appointments are to be made.

In an effort to give the cloistered college student a more practical view of the world of politics and industry, the new union meeting plan of Princeton University's American Whig-Cliosophic debating societies will expand this year, it was announced today by Sydney WooddCahusac, '40, of Brooklyn, president of the societies.

By extending the study of French from the classroom to the theatre the French Department of the University of Rochester believes it has found a successful method for stimulating interest throughout the university and community which could not have been aroused otherwise.

A DRIFT of yellow leaves lies at the street curb. Elsewhere it might soon be filling the air with the bonfire smoke of Autumn, but here in mechanized New York it has a less poetic finish. A snow pusher, a snow-loading machine and a rubbish truck, all bearing the insignia "D. S. N. Y.," gang up on the yellow drift, and the truck takes it for a ride to the nearest incinerator.

With the campus of Georgian Court College as the scene of its fourth biennial convention, the New Jersey chapter of the International Federation of Catholic Alumnae will meet here Oct. 29-30. More than 100 delegates representing Roman Catholic colleges and high schools in the State are expected to attend.

On cruthces and in wheelchairs and plaster casts, 15,000 underprivileged boys and girls from more than 200 schools, hospitals and orphan homes in the city and vicinity had their rodeo day at Madison Square Garden yesterday as guests of a retired business man of New York who could remember his longing, as a youth, to herd cattle in Texas. He annually takes crippled chirdren to the rodeo.

The Department of Agriculture estimated today that the world's wheat production for 1938-39 would be 4,365,000,000 bushels, the largest on record. This is an increase of about 20,000,000 bushels over the department's estimate made a month ago and about 525,000,000 bushels greater than this year's harvest.

THE builders who are transforming blueprints into reality at the New York World's Fair grounds now have six months to go. Their job must be completed before the fair's opening day, April 30, 1939. Several of those six months can be counted on to bring Winter storms when little work can be done.

Children's bands and orchestras will be organized in each borough except Manhattan by the city Department of Parks, it was announced yesterday. Boys and girls not more than 18 years old who play a band or orchestral instrument are eligible to compete for places in the ensembles.

Greenwich real estate brokers report an upward trend in real estate sales, as well as in rentals, since Oct. 1, and there are many vidences of renewed building activity in various sections of the town.
The Adjutant General released the following orders today: Colvin, Maj. Eugene T., 224th C. A., assigned to Headquarters, 1st Batt. Mallay, Capt. Jules E., assigned to 244th C. A. as adjutant.

Several important industrial leases have just been closed in various parts of Newark, N. J., by the David Houston Corporation. In the building at 318 Jefferson Street, Jacob Poh, manufacturer of leather novelties, rented space aggregating 20,000 square feet for a long term.

Sam Hammerstrom and Merl Brockmeyer were the stars of a Union College attack which resulted in a 26-13 victory over Rensselaer Tech today. Thomas carried most of the way to the Rensselaer 14 in the second, to aid Brockmeyer in tallying first for the Garnet. Brockmeyer got away in the third for a 70-yard run netting another score.

The savings to motorists, and particularly to truck owners, will more than counterbalance the cost of the $58,000,000 PWA-financed Queens Midtown Tunnel, it was said yesterday by T. D. Pratt, president of the Motor Truck Association of America, Inc., 60 Hudson Street, in emphasizing the importance of additional means of communication between Manhattan and Long Island.

The decline in railroad revenues and the continued deficits that most carriers are reporting lead to the forecast that "unless some unexpected change for the better soon sets in, it is virtually certain that we must have either wholesale reorganization, or some sort of government rescue party," according to a report prepared by the Twentieth Century Fund.
A breadth of interest which few organizations could match is revealed in a study of 337 resolutions passed by the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs since 1919. Mrs. J. Lester Lewine,

Dr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Ganey of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Williams Ganey, to Lieutenant Joseph McKnitt Alexander, U. S. N., son of Joseph D. Alexander of Huntersville, N. C., and the late Mrs. Alexander.

IN this colonial town where 161 years ago George Washington led his tattered troops against British regulars and Hessian hirelings, here where is located one of this country's foremost institutions of learning, two of Germany's most distinguished, but banished, citizens have come to live.

THE first Sunday afternoon concert of the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra this season takes place today at Carnegie Hall. On Thursday and Friday Guiomar Novaes will be piano soloist with the orchestra, playing Beethoven's Concerto No. 4, in G major.

Kinsmen, you shall behold Our stage, in mimic action, mould A man's character. ALTHOUGH those verses come from the introduction to John Drinkwater's "Abraham Lincoln" of twenty years ago, they can also serve Robert Sherwood's "Abe Lincoln in Illinois," which is just a week old.

The concert given last night in Radio City by Toscanini and the NBC Symphony Orchestra began with a performance of Rossini's "Cenerentola" overture--as fine as a performance of that thoroughly commonplace music could be--and proceeded with one of the most subtle and moving interpretations that Toscanini has ever given in this city. The composition so presented by him was Richard Strauss's "Don Quixote."

Lawrenceville School's powerful football team remained undefeated, untied and unscored upon by defeating George School today, 27-0. The Laurentian attack, which chalked up 21 points in the first half, was featured by Willoughby's 55-yard run for a touchdown on a pass interception in the first quarter.

Wheat showed a firm undertone in early trading today on the Board of Trade but failure of export business to develop and week-end evening-up by operators who had bought at lower prices brought about a reaction of about 1 cent a bushel from the high point.

Dr. Allen Stockdale of the National Manufacturers Association will speak to a meeting of industrial nurses from New England, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, Saturday at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Miss Marion G. Dowling,
LINCOLN STEFFENS was writing to his sister, Laura, in March, 1917: "The day of letters is over, like the day of kings; we write only telegrams or lettergrams, or phone."

Bucknell University students who are interested in public speaking as distinct from debating will have an opportunity this year for such experience through a newly organized Student Speakers Bureau. The bureau will be under the management of the Bucknell Debating Council and will be headed by Robert Burke of Cincinnati, a member nf the men's debating team.

Sparked by a 69-yard touchdown run by Roland Cardignan early in the third period, Central High School of Manchester, N. H., swept to a 19-0 victory over Curtis High yesterday before 4,000 at Thompson's Stadium, Stapleton, Staten Island.

Special classes in music for the blind are being given at the Lighthouse, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street, famous headquarters of New York Association for the Blind, through the aid of teachers supplied by the WPA adulteducation program of the New York City Board of Education, Gustav A. Stumpf, project supervisor, announced yesterday.

Edward F. Corsi, Republican candidate for the short-term United States Senatorial position, "stole the show" last night at the eighteenth annual dinner of the Paul P. Rao Association, Democratic club in Yorkville, held at the Hotel Commodore.
John A. Jorgensen of this city, formerly of Washington, D. C., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Geraldine Jorgensen, to James F. Neale Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Neale of Washington.

The collection of English and American furniture and Oriental rugs that was auctioned Friday and yesterday at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries brought $15,678. The total for the final session was $10,210.50.

Colgate's Red Raiders, football aerial artists from New York State'S Chenango Valley, struck twice with their favorite weapon today to humiliate Iowa, 14 to 0. in an intersectional game played before 10,000 shivering fans.
After trailing for three periods, the New Hampshire freshmen football team broke loose in the last period and scored a touchdown to defeat Phillips Exeter, 6 to 0, today.

THERE are signs that President Roosevelt seeks a political heir. There are slight stirring that if both Democratic and Republican parties fail to discover a candidate able to capture the imagination of the country, Mr. Roosevelt might hold the Presidency by default.

Unbeaten Baylor twice reared up on its one-foot line today to muzzle Texas A. M. and escape with a 6-6 tie. Crippled and helpless before Aggie charges until the enemy moved into the 10-yard stripe, the Baylor line dug in while rain pelted their faces and 15,000 fans screamed. Not even the Aggies' Dick Todd, one of the nation's craftiest brokenfield runners, could work his magic around the goal line.
Following is the text of regutations issued today by Adminstrator Elmer F. Andrews on information which employers should keep in conform?y with the Wages and Hours Act:

ADLER--Mr. and Mrs. Harry (nee Bertha Helen Wertheimer), are happy to announce the birth of Ann Jean, at Beth Israel Hospital on Oct. 20. BERLINER-Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Lee (Rosa Levin) of Woodmere, L. I.. announce the arrival of Janet's sister, Sally, Oct. 21, at St. Joseph's Hospital, Far Rockaway.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow:

The old-fashioned Hallowe'en supper dance to be held at Le Coq Rouge on Thursday night has received a large advance subscription. The party, featuring the traditional games and festivities of Hallowe'en, will be for the benefit of the work conducted by the National Bureau for Blind Artists, of which Mrs. James Roosevelt is honorary chairman.
Reuters (British news agency) reported today in a dispatch from Hankow that Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and Mme. Chiang still were in Hankow.

Texas Christian, led by Davey O'Brien, great little quarterback who tossed passes all over the field, smothered Marquette's football team today, 21 to 0. before 14,000 fans. Marquette was helpless as it tried to stop O'Brien's accurate tosses in the opening period. The T. C. U.

Sewanee was routed by Alabama today, 32 to 0, but the Tigers firsthalf fight won them the plaudits of a partisan Alabama crowd of 5,000. It was late in the third period before Alabama could generate enough power to put across a second score, but the touchdowns came rapidly in the closing minutes.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-This resort is expecting a gala Halloween week-end. All over the island preparations are being made for parties. Biggest of the celebrations will be the Halloween masquerade ball on Hamid's Million Dollar Pier on Friday evening.

PARIS. A NOVEL use has been found for the box cars in which the American soldiers "toured" France twenty years ago. These cars, which provided the atmosphere and the vocabulary for the American Legion affiliate, "La Societe des 40 Hommes et 8 Chevaux," have been improved, renovated and embellished.

If the voters of New York State adopt the Constitutional Convention's proposal to ban proportional representation, future generations of New Yorkers will recover with the majority system, "the only instrument for the making of effective decisions," Dr. F. A. Hermens, member of the political science faculty of Notre Dame University, declares in a monograph, "The Trojan Horse of Democracy," made public today.

Slight but steady gains marked industrial activity this month, the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents pointed out yesterday in its regular monthly survey of current business.

Mary (nee McCabe), beloved wife of the late Peter, devoted mother of Joseph, Marie. Evelyn, Peter J. and John Agnew; sister of Mrs. Sarah Callahan. Funeral from her residence, 44 Bennett Ave., Monday, Oct. 24, at 9:30 A. M.: thence to St. Elizabeth's Church, 187th St. and Wadsworth Ave. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

A YOUTHFUL writer's first novel inevitably evokes anticipatory speculation. Will the author deal convincingly with his factors of character, plot and atmosphere? Will he truly and entertainingly reflect an aspect of life?

An attempt to provide keener competition for scotch whiskies in the domestic market lies behind the announcement last week by Schenley Distillers Corporation that they are marketing a four-year-old straight whisky, according to those in the industry.
The Rochester University team conquered the Hamilton College eleven today on Steuben Field. 17-0.

The Evander Childs High eleven was toppled from the unbeaten ranks yesterday as it bowed to the De Witt Clinton High team,. 19 to 12, in the feature contest of a scholastic double-header at the Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, before a crowd of 9,000.

Experts in educational, recreational and welfare fields have been invited to assist the Girls' Service League in devising a remedy for the growing unemployment of young women between the ages of 16 and 21 years.

LONDON. ENGLAND'S two Senior Universities, hitherto basking in scholarly isolation along the green banks of the Isis and the Cam, have Just been joined in unwilling union by a streamlined train which zips along at the unacademic speed of seventy-five miles an hour.
